C¶

C and A Act¶

n.

[Letter from Fowlds to J. Leggett] [There] is growing unrest amongst the Labour people who in recent years ... pinned their faith to the ... C & A Act and have now come to the conclusion that it has not greatly improved their economic condition. (Feb 3, 1908,Letter) [NOTES: 1908 Feb 3 in 1980 Rogers The Fowlds Papers - Politics 8 1908, 3rd Feb -]

I want to belong to something that has grit and can fight boldly for its rights, not a Lab-Lib., Lib-Lab., half-and-half concern that allows itself to be tied up bound hand and foot by the employers' C. and A. Act. (Oct 20, 1911,Maoriland Worker,33/17/1)

c'mon¶

exclam. come on

But the dog will say, 'C'mon, let's go. (May 24, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

...they are no more culturally us than jogging or "C'mon, Kiwi. c'mon" (remember the name of that Auckland lass? (Apr 19, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

C-Force¶

n. the CIVIL EMERGENCY CORPS formed in April 1951 during the Wharf lockout (after J-FORCE (Japan occupation), K-FORCE (volunteers for the Korean War).

C-lister¶

n. one on list 'C' for housing allocation [list in terms of need]

No A-list applicants were housed in Mangere last month - the average waiting time for Mangere B-listers is 86 days, and for C-listers 364. (Dec 5, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C2)

C-oner¶

n. a medical grading

(Apr 29, 1925,NZ Tit-Bits,6) [NOTES: [see quot jigga jig]]

C.C.¶

abbr. Christchurch

Walker There is to be a ball in C.C. tomorrow night and an Agricultural Show on Wednesday. (Oct 19, 1862,Journal and Letters (Walker))

WALKER ... we took advantage of a lift into C.C. The cart was driven by a cooley, [20] we could not understand him and he could not understand (Oct 19, 1862,Journal and Letters (Walker))

C.F.A.¶

abbr. cast-for-age, esp. of ewes [ORIGIN: acronym]

McLINTOCK The ewes, which are bred on the farm, pass into the breeding flock, where they remain for four or five years. They then leave the farm in the autumn and appear in the ewe fairs to be bought by fat-lamb breeders as cast for age (or `C.F.A.') ewes. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/235)

The products from this type of farm are wool, some store lambs, a few fat wether lambs, some culled hoggets, store cattle, varying numbers of store or fat wethers, and a draft of `cast-for-age' (c.f.a.) ewes. (1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,59)

C.O.¶

abbr. conscientious objector, conchie [(C.O. was the usual word among conscientious objectors; conchie among the public.)]

HOLLAND 'The C.O.'s' [a poem] (1919,Armageddon or Calvary) [NOTES: 1917 July 26 in 1919 Holland`Armageddon or Calvary]

C2¶

abbr.

Sa-eeda Ahmed, Akers, arrak,/ Bints, Bomonti. backsheech, barrak;/ Centipedes and Cleopatra,/ Dust and desert, djinns and Fatima;/ Eggs-cook, ana miskeen,'/ Fever, flies, and felaheen;/ Gehenam, Galabeyah, gods,/ Harems, hooshters, heat and hods;/Igri wallah, imshi Y'allah.'/ Jackos, jackals, `gala gala';/ Khamseen, kan kan, tala hena,/ Lice and locusts, love and Lena;/ Mirage, Mahomet, mosquistoe,/ Niggers, T.A.B. and C2;/ Olives oranges, askarie./ (Jul 10, 1919,Quick March,33)

CAB¶

abbr. Charitable Aid Board

SIMPSON ... there was a great deal of shame [during the Depression] in the minds of working men ... who had to go with an order from the Charitable Aid Board for groceries up to the local Self Help. If I remember rightly, my parents used to spell out C.A.B. so that I wouldn't know what it meant ... I knew that we were going with a C.A.B. chit to get groceries ... (1974,Sugarbag Years,55) [NOTES: [c1931]]

cab¶

n. a cabernet wine [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

Mourvedre was initially used to add colour and a spine to non-descript blends; later, when Cabs and Chardonnay became fashionable, it was downgraded. (Feb 26, 1997,Norwester,14)

cab sav¶

n. (informal) cabernet sauvignon wine

Distinguished maker of fine tawny tales, teaching us how words are best baked together... a mighty Cab Sav. (Sep 11, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

If wine had been part of the culture when the early colonials arrived a bottle of Cab Sav would have been evident too! (Sep 1995,Cuisine,52/60)

Owen Marshall We have finished the wine, and I buy a bottle of Australian cab sav. (2005,Watch of Gryphons,153)

Now, insinuate your modern rugby player at that table, and he would have laced his cab sav with Perrier, stayed "focused", and talked "agents" and "endorsements" and "career moves" with the best of them. (Nov 12, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

John McCrystal's clever "One Stop Shopping" offers the latter - four video cassettes, a box of condoms, a courgette, a balaclava.. a bottle of cab sav, a spade, a road map, many other miscellaneous items. (Jul 3, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49)

You wrestle the cork out of the Cab Sav your brother gave you last Christmas. (Dec 28, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),39)

cabbage¶

n. low-grade cannabis leaf

YSKA The first significant thefts of chemical solvents were reported as growers started processing low-grade bulky "cabbage" cannabis leaf into cannabis oil. (1990,NZ Green,159)

n. usu. with epithet Maori, native, wild; the European cabbage growing wild.

CRUISE Their [sc. Maori] general food is the koomera ...; the indigenous taro ...; the common potato; the cabbage plant; ... [?not cabbage-tree] (1823,Journal,185,1957 ed.)

POWER Cabbages (introduced by Captain Cook) grow wild over the country. (1853,Recollections (various authors/titles),341)

TAYLOR [Introduced by Captain Cook] the turnip, a species of turnip cabbage, soon became wild and spread everywhere, and is still a valuable addition to the stock of esculents, both the leaves and root are eaten, and it cannot be said to have greatly deteriorated; ... (1868,Past and Present of NZ,291)

CRUISE The excellent plants left by Captain Cook, viz. cabbages, turnips , parsnips, carrots, etc., etc. are still numerous but very much degenerated; and a great part of the country is overrun with cow-itch, which the natives gave Marion the credit for having left among them.] (1957,Journal,215) [NOTES: [1957 Bagnall in 1823 Cruise Journal (1957) 215]

cabbage boat¶

n.

I think it is important,' he said,that people get a perspective of me as not someone that comes from a background of pink gins, quiche and Parnell but someone who had to come up the river in a cabbage boat. (Sep 26, 1987,Evening Post,2)

cabbage course¶

n. an easy NCEA option

...potential exam flunkers being whipped out of mainstream courses with no warning to their teachers, then shunted into "achievement recovery" to tick boxes for "cabbage course" credits...Ibid. 40 Cambridge High teachers also express concern about practices.. such as deflecting students from NCEA's challenging core subjects into "cabbage courses" where they are less likely to register a failure. (Jun 2004,North & South,38)

cabbage hat¶

n. cabbage-tree hat

FERGUSON The cabbage hat and the blouse were then/ Insignias of the flow'r of men. (1912,Castle Gay,48) [NOTES: (The Diggers: check ?1897 edn]]

These were made in Australia whence both the name and the article were imported. Both had dropped out of use in New Zealand long before the 'nineties, but I have heard old hands speak of them. (Morris 1852 Cabbage Tree hat: made out of the leaves of the cabbage tree) (1933,Press, The) [NOTES: Acland;(a1890)]

cabbage out¶

v. chill out

When Cullen was home "cabbaging out", he was "just another guy" in the village. (Jul 17, 2003,Dominion Post,A1)

cabbage palm¶

n. (formerly Areca sapida) areca spp, nikau

FORSTER In our rambles through the woods at this place we found a true cabbage-palm (areca oleracea), of the same sort which we had seen at Norfolk Island. (1777,Voyage Round the World,2/451)

DIEFFENBACH High tree-ferns [fn Cyathea medullaris and dealbata.], with the cabbage-palm [fn Areca sapida.], strike the eye as the most beautiful forms of New Zealand vegetation. Ibid.I/223 [?=nikau] They are intermingled with fern-trees, especially Cyathea medullaris and Cyathea dealbata; while the cabbage-palm (Areca sapida) grows in the deepest recesses. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/27)

ANGAS The houses or huts were many of them thatched with the leaves of the nikau, or cabbage-palm (areca sapida); ... Ibid. I/321 The taro, ... the heart of the nikau, or cabbage-palm (areca sapida) ... are amongst the vegetable productions which they [sc. natives] use for the purposes of food. (1847,Savage Life,1/263)

[We] had our first bush walk [in New Plymouth] over matted roots and stumps amidst tree fern, cabbage palm, supple jack, not to name a long list of timber trees. [probably NIKAU] (Mar 25, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/79) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond)]

WHITWORTH (1870,Martin's Bay Settlement,5) [NOTES: see chron notes ? c-treE]

n. cabbage tree

FORSTER [?not nikau] ... an infinite variety of high trees & shrubbery [in Dusky Bay], among which the New-Zeeland Dragon-tree (Dracaena antarctica) [ed. fn Cordyline australis] is very remarkable; (NB Our Sailors called them the Cabbage-palm, but it is different; though the middle most leaves may be eaten & taste almost like sweet fresh Almonds). (May 13, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/277)

FORSTER These trees, however, were not the true cabbage-palms, nor did they belong at all to the class of palms, ... They were properly speaking a new species of dragon-trees, with broad leaves (dracaena australis) of which the central shoot when quite tender, tastes something like an almond's kernel, with a little of the flavour of cabbage. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/176) [NOTES: [?here not =nikau contrast 1777 cit. in 2. below: recheck thoroughly]]

DIEFFENBACH ... cabbage palm. (1843,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/27)

HURSTHOUSE (And) [c-p] Cordyline australis (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles))

LINDSAY (And) Cordyline australis (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany)

WHITWORTH The hills rise very rapidly from the coast, being thickly wooded with hini-hini and other scrub, flax, grass-tree, cabbage-palm, ... (1870,Martin's Bay Settlement,5)

KNOX American pines have been introduced and are doing well; they make a pleasing contrast to the New Zealand wattle-tree and cabbage-palm and the ferns which abound everywhere. (1888,Boy Travellers,220)

Cab.bage (k&abreve.b.bA.j), n. [Add.] ... Cabbage tree, or Cabbage palm. (Bot.) ... In New Zealand, the liliaceous tree Cordyline indivisa, and other species of Cordyline. See the Note under TI. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2019)

MORRIS Cabbage Palm ... same as Cabbage tree (I) (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,75)

BOYD (And) [c-p] Cordyline australis (1900,Our Stolen Summer)

TREGEAR The other fibres ... used in making garments were those of the Cabbage Palm (ti: Cordyline sp.) ... (1904,Maori Race, The,224)

SCANLAN Tree fern and cabbage palm and clumps of toi-toi grew ... around the swimming-pool in the river. (1934,Winds of Heaven,58)

HYDE And the cabbage-palms and tree-ferns people grew in their backyards - like beasts in a zoo - looked cowed and sick. (1938,Godwits Fly, The,32,1970 ed.)

(And) Cordyline australis -->1917 Duncan and Davies Catalogue (And)Cordyline australis (1916,NZ Association of Nurserymen, Trade Register)

The Europeans began to include these palm hearts in their otherwise barren diets and gave the sources the general name "cabbage palm", alluding to James Cook' insistence on the i nclusion of cabbage in his crew's rations to stave off scurvy. (Jun 2, 2001,Dominion,14)

cabbage palm tree¶

n.

PARKINSON They also saw several young cabbage palm-trees, and a new species of Pardanus, or palm-nut. (Nov 20, 1769,Journal,107)

FORSTER It was very remarkable, that at a considerable height they found 3 or four Cabbage-Palm-trees [[ed. fn] Cordyline australis Hook f.], one of which they cut down & used for their refreshment. The leaves of this tree, which Mr Sparrman preserved, were lost in the dangerous & hasty descent; ... Ibid. II/270 We met with a great many Cabbage-palmtrees, [Cordyline australis ] as they were commonly called by our Sailors, but upon Examination we found them to be a kind of Dragon tree (Dracaena Linn): for we met with the fruit and flowers of them. (Apr 24, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/265)

POLACK ... the guardian ... pointed to a small bunch of human hair made fast to a ti, or cabbage palm-tree, denoting the strictness of the tapu. Ibid. 1/130 ... he informed me that both fire and water was tapued by the tohunga, or priest, who was busy at preparing an incantation near the Wai-tapu [a2-acute], situated among a grove of cabbage palm-trees without the fence. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/67)

cabbage plant¶

n. [Prob. check that this is not a Scholefield mistranscription for palm: JCR uses cabbage palm at 79]

... in many places the undergrowth consisted of young tree [84]ferns and cabbage plants. many of the ferns attain a great height but the palms more rarely, probably for their being cut down at a certain age for the sake of the heart of the young stem which is very good to eat either raw or cooked, being something between the heart of a cabbage and a cocoanut. (Apr 3, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/83) [NOTES: (H.R. Richmond)]

cabbage train¶

n. the overnight Picton-Christchurch goods train carrying vegetables for the Christchurch market [ca1986 p.c. Jane Godfrey We always called it the Cabbage train; aka the Cabbage]

Frank Andrew, of Kelburn, telephoned to tell me how the Picton-Christchurch express got lumped with the name `The Cabbage'. He discovered the express goods train was so nicknamed because it regularly delivered vegetables from Marlborough to the hungry people in Christchurch. (Oct 31, 1972,Dominion,7)

Cabbage Train¶

n.

MILES Even the 1970s Friday Sunday Christchurch-Dunedin Express and the Blenheim Cabbage Train with the faded glories of its 1930's armchairs and cream interior were far nearer the great age of rail than the Northerner or Southerner of today. (1998,Fay Richwhite's Railway,4)

The South Island had its equivalents, including the quaintly named Cabbage Train from Blenheim to Christchurch and the Perishable from Christchurch to Greymouth. (Oct 30, 2004,Dominion Post,A1)

cabbage tree¶

n. a striking palm-like tree with tall bare trunks topped with clusters of fibrous sword-shaped leaves

HOCHSTETTER [list of trees from Taylor Natural Hist 1848] (And) (1867,New Zealand (various authors/titles),167)

CLARK (And) (1891,Southern Cross Fairy Tale)

HUDSON (And) (1898,NZ Moths & Butterflies)

Cab.bage (k&abreve.b.bA.j), n. [Add.] ... Cabbage tree, or Cabbage palm. (Bot.) ... In New Zealand, the liliaceous tree Cordyline indivisa, and other species of Cordyline. See the Note under TI. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2019)

WHITE (And) (1902,My NZ Garden)

LAING & BLACKWELL (And) (1906,Plants of NZ)

COCKAYNE (And) (1907,AJHR,C-8) [NOTES: Report on Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island]

COCKAYNE (And) (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story)

(And) (1911,Emu, The,11/)

(And) (1916,Dunedin Field Club Plant Catalogues)

COCKAYNE (And) (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

GUTHRIE-SMITH (And) (1921,Tutira)

COCKAYNE (And) (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The)

(1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,173)

cabbage tree [s] Cordyline australis (Forst. f.) Hook.f. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,10)

cabbage tree n 1. a. a tall palm-like ornamental New Zealand tree. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,152) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 98; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 66]]

Small bundle of the vascular part of the cabbage tree stem or root (kauru). (1897,TrNZI,29/175)

n. -

We likewise found one Cabbage tree which we cut down for the sake of the cabbage. [fn] [fn 4] The cabbage tree or ti, various species of Cordyline. (Oct 29, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/186,1955 ed.)

[We met] once only a Cabbage tree, the Cabbage of which made us one delicious meal. [fn] The Cabbage tree' of N-Z (Kouaka of the Maori who ate its leaf-heads) is <i>Cordyline australis</i> (Forst. f)) Hook. f. [But Hooker identified Banks'one delicious meal' as the Nikau palm, Beaglehole tends to favour nikau) (Mar 1770,Banks Journal,2/9,1962 ed.)

PARKINSON [??nikau] We saw the tree that produces the cabbage, which ate well boiled. We also found some trees that yielded a fine transparent gum: ... (Oct 22, 1769,Journal,97)

RHODES The six sailors and the [settler on Sunday Island] had entirely subsisted on an aquatic bird they called a mutton bird, and cabbage tree. (1836,Whaling Journal,35,1954 ed.)

n. Cordyline Banskii

1 n. (Rural) One of the species Cordyline especially Cordyline australis, a nectar-bearing native tree, known as ti, valued by early apiarists, and early shepherds for boundary-keeping purposes.

The iconic cabbage tree, Cordyline australis, has starchy tap roots that soften when slow-cooked in a hangi or earth oven. (Jun 24, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),15)

He is informed that it [sc. Cordyline Australis is vulgarly termed a "cabbage- tree." (Oct 11, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,7)

Have you ever tried sliding down a hill on a cabbage tree? (Jun 3, 1924,Otago Witness,71)

The name "cabbage" tree seems to have been applied to the ti because the leaf buds provided for the early settlers a substance that could be cooked and eaten in the place of green vegetables. (1945,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),III(1) : 13)

Cabbage trees around Wellington are likely to have the same disease that is killing thousands of trees in the north of the country. (Dec 6, 1991,Evening Post,3)

Her husband was up in the cabbage tree with his flounder spear. (1974,Islands,3(1) Autumn 7/129)

How many people know where Cabbage Tree Swamp is? (Mar 5, 1904,NZ Observer,3)

Tobogganing down a greasy hillside on cabbage tree tops. (Nov 18, 1924,Otago Witness,54)

POLACK The heart of the delicious palms, called E' Rito, is highly esteemed. The korou, which the branches of another of these umbelliferous trees afford is equally prized, together with the saccharine roots of the ti, cabbage-tree. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/287)

WAKEFIELD ... the indigenous flax-plant and ... the Cabbage-tree or Ti-palm. [fn] Dracaena Australis. Ibid. 461-462 An unmixed growth [462] of stunted manuka is a bad sign, a quantity of ti-shrubs, commonly called the cabbage-tree, a very good one. (1848,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),45)

HARPER ... there are shrubs and plants ... besides various kinds of Veronica, white and purple, tall palm trees, locally termed Cabbage trees, masses of New Zealand flax, ... [fn] Ti-Ti palm. (Dec 25, 1856,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,2,1914 ed.)

W.H.S.ROBERTS Writing of the Waimea Plain in 1856: - The ground was well grassed, but the speargrass was too plentiful. The pasturage was very good. There was a good deal of scrub in the bends of the Mataura known aswire plant' (Olearia virgata). There were also manuka and koromiko. Maori-heads, a kind of grass tree about three feet high, abounded in the swamps, and in some we saw toitoi grass and raupo. We did not pass any cabbage trees to-day ... we proceeded slowly through tomatakuru scrub, speargrass, Spaniard, snowgrass, and other native grasses ... we camped in a bend with good feed at the Elbow and a swamp on one side. Maori cabbage abounded ...' (1856,Diary) [NOTES: 1856 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 18]

BUTLER ... there remains a large extent of river-bed, in the process of gradually being covered with cabbage-trees, flax, tussock, Irishman, and other plants and evergreens; ... Ibid. ix/132 The cabbage-tree or ti palm is not a true palm, though it looks like one. It has not the least resemblance to a cabbage. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,vii/95) [NOTES: 1860 in 1863 Butler First Year vii/95]

BARKER Nothing seems [25] so wonderful to me as the utter treelessness of the vast Canterbury plains; occasionally you pass a few Ti-ti palms (ordinarily called cabbage-trees), or a large prickly bush which goes by the name of `wild Irishman,' but for miles and miles you see nothing but ... undulating downs of yellow tussocks, the tall native grass. (1865,Station Life in NZ,24)

HUNT [=NIKAU, or is the or disjunctive] When sick the only medicine they would take was water ..., and nikau, or cabbage tree: ... (1866,Chatham Islands,37)

Besides which the following roots and plants were often eaten, viz., the roots (cooked) of the Panahi (Calystegia sepium); of the Maikaika (Arthropodium cirrhatum); ... the roots of the little sugary Ti-koraha (Cordyline stricta), of the large Ti, or Cabbage Tree' (<i>C. australis</i>), and of the large Fern, Para, (<i>Marattia salicina</i>). <i>Ibid.</i> 1/III/32 [leaves eaten] The young inner blanched leaves and heart of the Ti, orCabbage-tree' (Cordyline australis), and of the Nikau, or New Zealand Palm, (Areca sapida), were eaten both raw and cooked.. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/31) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

Cabbage tree Cordyline australis, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/50) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

WAKEFIELD (And) Cordyline australis (1845,Adventure in NZ,1903 ed.)

HARPER Tall palm trees locally termed cabbage trees. (Dec 25, 1856,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,2,1914 ed.)

TINNE ... cabbage tree (what Lady Barker calls the ti-tree palm). (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,61)

MORRIS Cabbage Tree ... (1) Name given to various palm trees of which the heart of the young leaves is eaten like the head of a cabbage. In Australia the name is applied to the fan palm, Livistona inermis, R. Br., and more commonly to Livistona australis, Martius. In New Zealand the name is given to varius species of Cordyline, especially to Cordyline indiovisa. (1898,Austral English,75)

WHITE Parallel with the happy family on the trellis I planted a row of twenty Cordylines, or Palm Lilies, commonly [50] called New Zealand Cabbage Trees, for the uninteresting reason that someone once boiled some and ate them as a vegetable. (1905,My NZ Garden,49)

CHEESEMAN C[ordyline] australis, Hook.f. ... Ti; Ti-kauka; Ti-rakau; Palm-lily. ... Universally known to New Zealand residents by the inappropriate name of `cabbage-tree'. Maori ti raakau (1906,Manual NZ Flora,706)

LAING & BLACKWELL Cordyline australis. [title] Ti-kouka. The Cabbage-Tree or Palm Lily. (1907,Plants of NZ,93,1940 p. 95 ed.)

BAUGHAN Cabbage-tree, an ugly name for a beautiful thing: the Palm-Lily, the Maori Ti. This is the most distinctive of all New Zealand trees. In growth it somewhat resembles a true Palm. (1908,Shingle-Short,160)

COCKAYNE (And) cabbage tree: ti-palm (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Waipoua Kauri Forest]

COWAN In the rear of the church surrounded by lines of whanake or cabbage-trees (these whanake, now grown to enormous trees, still adorn the old village-site), was the kainga Te Reinga, ... Ibid. II/399 The Kapenga tableland ..., a gully-seamed broken plateau, is covered with a thick growth of manuka and monoao shrubs, tutu and fern, with many ti or cabbage trees ... (1922,NZ Wars, The,1/353)

cabbage tree n. an Australian feathery-leaved palm.-cabbage-tree hat n. a broad-brimmed hat made in Australia from the leaves of the cabbage tree. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3)

The name cabbage-tree' was given by Captain Cook's people. ... Journal, 10th October, 1774 :These cabbage-trees or palms were not thicker than a man's leg, and from ten to twenty feet high. They are of the same genus with the cocoa-nut tree ; like it they have very large pinnated leaves, and are the same sort as the second sort found in the northern parts of New South Wales [vide Hawkesworth Voyages Vol 3]. The cabbage is, properly speaking, the bud of the tree ; each tree producing but one cabbage which is at the crown, where the leaves spring out, and is enclosed in the stem ... -->[Cook, Voyage to Pacific Ocean 1777 Vol II pp 148-9] ... The remarks that the leaves are pinnate, that each tree produces but one cabbage, and that the cutting of it destroys the tree, lead one to suspect that the tree referred to is not a Cordyline. The entry in the Journal was made at Norfolk Island, not New Zealand, but there is no indication in Cook as to what tree is referred to. ... A more definite clue in Banks (Journal of the Rt Hon Sir Joseph Banks during Captain Cook's First Voyage ... 1768-77, London, 1896 p227), where he writes of New zealand [sic] plants ... A footnote identifies the [cabbage-tree'] as Areca Sapida Soland. ... [Nikau] ...very closely related to the Norfolk Island A. Baueri which is a larger plant' [Hooker]. [Banks] says nothing of the eating of the young shoots of the Cordyline. It would appear, then, that primarily the term cabbage-tree',cabbage-palm' was applied to Areca Baueri, but has become transferred exclusively to Cordyline ... [examples and references to Cordyline and Areca in Colenso and others] ... (1926,TrNZI,660 ff)

660ff One would suppose that Kirk had forgotten the origin of the name when he says, Settlers and bushmen generally apply the unmeaning [sic] name of "cabbage-tree"' (Kirk, Forest Flora of NZ p295). Cheeseman, too, says,Universally known to New Zealand residents by the inappropriate name of "cabbage-tree"' (Cheeseman, Manual NZ Flora p707). Thomas explains the name and errs in doing so : It receives its name from the arrangement of its leaves in tufts or heads at the ends of the branches' (Clark A Southern Cross Fairy-tale p53). Butler remarksThe cabbage-tree or ti-palm is not a true palm, though it looks like one. It has not the least resemblance to a cabbage.' The settlers and bushmen followed Cook in using the young heart as a vegetable, and in their naming of the tree ; and when the reason for the name is known its inapproriateness disappears. To one section of the public it will always be the cabbage-tree ; to the other section, let it be lily-palm. Ti-tree' and ti-palm' should certainly be banned, because of the hopeless confusion with tea-tree. The Canterbury form ti (-tree, -palm) is obs. Originally from Maori name for the tree,ti', it was confused with tea-tree (`Manuka', Leptospermum sp) see Acland. (1926,TrNZI)

Cabbage tree. Cordyline australis. There are various species of this Cordyline which in old days grew single or in groups on many parts of the plains, and up to 1500ft on the hills. The earliest settlers often called it ti-tree or ti-palm, from its Maori name. It was a most inconvenient name, causing confusion with tea tree (Manuka), one of the commonest Canterbury scrub bushes. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]; Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p.117) (Sep 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

HUNT It has the world's largest lily in the Cabbage Tree (Cordyline australis) ... (1951,Confessions,136)

LEVY ... such species as lancewood, karamu, toro, ramarama, koromiko, kanono, kohuhu, kawakawa, hangehange, rangiora, five finger, patete, toru, tree daisies, broadleaf, kamahi, mahoe, tarata, karo, lacebark, wineberry, fuchsia, kowhai, with tree ferns, weki, and mamuku. Toetoe, phormium, cabbage tree, with swamp coprosma and hupiro may figure as a (1951,Grasslands of NZ,87,1970 ed.)

Cabbage ~ Different trees in Australia and New Zealand are called by this name, which means that the heart of the young leaves was formerly eaten like cabbage. The Maori name is ti. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),56)

SHADBOLT I grew to awareness rejecting as alien our scrubby backblocks farm, the thick bush of tall kauri, rimu and kahikatea ..., the mangroved tidal creek, ... the cabbage trees in the playground ... Ibid. 15... a grove of cabbage trees ... screened off the milking-shed and hay-barn. (1959,New Zealanders, The,10,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (The Woman's Story)]

McLINTOCK Cabbage tree .. .. ti, tikapu, tikauka, tirahau, kouka whanake .. .. Cordyline (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

BAXTER ... I and my son/ Went past the hundred-headed cabbage tree/ (1979,Collected Poems,264,1963 ed.)

cabbage tree n. several species of palm tree, the heart of the young leaves resembling a cabbage. Maori name, ti. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),5)

FULLER The bushy crowns (kouka) of Cordyline australis, the Maori ti tree, were relished ... also by early European settlers, who found the kouka tasted like cabbage and named the tree accordingly. (1978,Maori Food and Cookery,34)

The most common cabbage tree is Cordyline australis -- the multi-headed and often multi-trunked one that grows to about six metres and is seen all around our country. (Nov 19, 1999,Daily News,A9)

The first whisky was made by Mr. Carey and Mr. Roebuck. It was made out of cabbage tree, which was obtained about the place where the Grand Hotel now stands. They had seen the Maoris chewing the cabbage, and on tasting it they found that it contained sugar. (Jan 2, 1890,Otago Daily Times,9)

The same goes for cabbage trees, those ungainly stalks with clumps of flax on the top. (Aug 15, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C3)

Don't you rattle your / dry swords at me / cabbage tree (Mar 27, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),39)

The cabbage tree was a terrible farness from them. (Apr 16, 1904,NZ Free Lance,13)

The same goes for cabbage trees, those ungainly stalks with clumps of flax on the top. (Aug 15, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C3)

Dracaenas and their other relationscordylines (cabbage trees) can be used togreat effect. (Oct 1992,Metro,28)

There are [sic] a number of native trees in blossom at the same time as pukapuka, including puriri, tea-tree, 'bush lawyer,' clematis, cabbage-tree, mingi and ohoho. Of these, bush-lawyer, cabbage-tree and ohoho bloom only at the same time as pukapuka and all three yield more nectar than pukapuka does. (Jul 1911,NZ Farmer,765)

ACLAND On some of the plains stations 'crow's nests' were built - platforms on poles or up cabbage trees. (1946,Early Canterbury Runs,19)

LOUGHNAN crowsnest: a platform used before the plains lands were fenced, built in the top of a cabbage tree from which a shepherd could survey his sheep. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,23)

2 n. Meryta Sinclairii

MARRINER (And) Meryta Sinclairii (1908,Kea, The: a NZ Problem)

HETLEY (And) Meryta Sinclairii (1888,Native Flowers of NZ)

HETL.EY & RAOUL (And) Meryta Sinclairii (1889,Fleurs Sauvages)

cabbage-garden hat¶

n. = cabbage-tree hat [cf. AC Cabbage Garden (patch). The Colony or State of Victoria 1889 AND 1882]

Cabbage garden. ... A name applied to the colony of Victoria by Sir John Robertson, the Premier of New South Wales, in contempt for its size. (1898,Austral English,75)

A lady went to the Wanganui theatre last week wearing a big cabbage-garden hat. (Aug 19, 1905,NZ Truth,9/1/7)

cabbage-leaf¶

n. a 10-pound note (from colour) [ca1963 July 23 Maori bettor in the Te Aro Hotel, Wellington, waved a [pounds]10 note and said: `Anybody have me on for a cabbage-leaf'.]

BOB ADAMS Cabbage-leaf was used for a 10-pound note c1930s. (1979,Personal Communication) [NOTES: (WELLINGTON)]

cabbage-leaf hat¶

n.

POWER The bush costume of the [Artillery] officers in New Zealand [c.1846] consists of a blue serge shirt, coarse trowsers, hobnail boots, and a cabbage-leaf hat or cap; as like the dress of the street orderlies as anything can be. It is a pity that those who identify a soldier with his red coat, gold lace, feathers and trappings, cannot see the reverse of the picture. (1849,Sketches in NZ,38)

cabbage-tree hat¶

n. a light-weight hat with a wide, upturned brim, made out of the leaves of the cabbage tree (orig. Aust.; ref. may be to hats imported from Aust.; or to those made locally from Cordyline (or nikau) leaves); ]cabbage hat; cady.

BIDWILL & WOODHOUSE The universal dress in those says [c1848] for country settlers and travellers was moleskin trousers, blue serge shirt, and that much prized head-covering, when it could be obtained, a New South Wales cabbage tree hat with a long black ribbon. [Note] A broad brimmed hat plaited from the leaves of the Australian Cabbage Tree. (1927,Bidwill of Pihautea,53) [NOTES: Pagination from 1927 edition]

BIDWILL & WOODHOUSE Their only outfit was a pair of moleskin trousers, blue serge shirt, and "cabbage-tree hat". (1927,Bidwill of Pihautea,3)

ACLAND He used to wear a pair of wide white moleskin trousers, a blue woollen smock (it used to be called in Victoria a "blue short") and a cabbage tree hat. The blue shirt and cabbage tree hat were the last I ever saw - the only ones I ever saw in New Zealand. (1930,Early Canterbury Runs,122) [NOTES: Pagination from 1946 edition]

MILLER The universal dress in those days for country settlers in moleskin trousers, blue serge suit, and the much prized head-covering, when it could be obtained, a New South Wales cabbage tree hat with a long black ribbon. (1958,Early Victorian NZ,137)

... up comes ... one solitary policeman dressed in a blue shirt and a cabbage-tree hat. (1864,Saturday Review,X/134)

They had in their possession two cabbage-tree hats and a cloth cap. (Nov 2, 1867,Otago Witness,8) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)[see also Mantell's Sketchbook in the 1840s]]

The fibrous leaves of the Kiekie (Freycinetia Banksii), is an excellent article for [51] men's hats, - far better than the largely imported common `Cabbage-tree' hat, but little inferior to a coarse Leghorn or Manilla one ... (1869,TrNZI,1/3/50) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

MEREDITH We went out into the bush after tawharas this week. This is the fruit of the kia kia, a parasite which climbs and adheres to the dead trees. The Maoris make excellent hats resembling the celebrated `cabbage-tree' hats, from the fibre of the leaves. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,135) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 135]

ELWELL ... cabbage-tree hats ... (1878,Boy Colonists,118)

Cab.bage (k&abreve.b.bA.j), n. [Add.] ... Cabbage tree, or Cabbage palm. (Bot.) ... - Cabbage tree hat, a broad-brimmed hat plaited with the fibrous leaves of Cordyline, much worn by the early colonists; - called also simply cabbage tree. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2019)

I therefore dressed myself in the garb of an up-country `Shagroon' [in pursuit of McKenzie c1855-1856] and searched the vessel; but with no result. ... [110] I took off my cabbage-tree hat, loosened my neckerchief and shirt-band, and shifted the candle out of his reach. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,109)

BAUCKE Upon which a hurrying woman in a man's soiled cabbage-tree hat, drying soapsud arms on a flour-sack apron, came round the [303] corner ... (1905,Where the White Man Treads,297)

BIDWILL & WQODHOUSE (1927,Bidwill of Pihautea,53) [NOTES: 1927 Bidwell and Woodhouse Bidwell of Pihautea 53 in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 137]

Cabbage-tree hat. These were made in Australia, whence both the name and the article were imported. Both had dropped out of use in New Zealand long before the 'nineties, but I heard old hands speak of them. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

cabbagetree ... n. large low-crowned hat made from plaited leaves of the cabbage tree. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),5)

The young officer's costume was as primitive as his river boat - a cabbage-tree hat, a Crimean shirt, and a kilt mat of woven flax beltedround his waist. (Nov 1937,NZ Railways Magazine,17)

PARK I remember the Australians, happy and reckless, in their sunbleached cabbage-tree hats. (1957,One-a-pecker, Two-a-pecker,101)

ADAMS My costume consisted of a pair of white duck trousers, checked shirt, stout boots, large cabbage-tree hat and a sort of blue flannel frock confined at the waist by a leather belt. (1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,57)

n.

cabbage-tree hut¶

n.

PYKE We immediately turned to and built a cabbage-tree hut to live in, and then with the new set of tools determined to tackle the dep ground in the flat. (1887,History of the Early Gold Discoveries in Otago,98,1962 ed.)

cabbage-tree juice¶

n.

BEATTIE I once listened to an account of an early resident of Waikouaiti who made whisky out of cabbage-tree juice and sold it to the Maoris ... (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,98)

cabbage-tree kit¶

n.

She walked over to the ngawha. A tukohu - cabbage tree kit - was hanging in its place ... close to the steaming pool. (1989,Awekotuku Tahuri,33)

cabbage-tree moth¶

n. Venusia verriculata

POWELL CABBAGE-TREE MOTH (Venusia verriculata). ... The moth always rests lengthwise on the dead leaves of the cabbage-tree ... (1947,Native Animals of NZ,55)

SHOT-HOLE MOTH, DIAMOND-BACK MOTH, CABBAGE MOTH. (Plutella cruciferarum). (1902,Brett's Colonists Guide,591)

cabbage-tree palm¶

n.

HAY There is the cabbage-tree palm, with bare shank and top-knot; the nikau palm, with weird and wondrous frondage; the lancewood, ...; the fern-tree, ... (1882,Brighter Britain,2/187)

cabbage-tree rum¶

1 n. (Rural) rum made from ti or cabbage tree.

HALL-JONES Ti is the cabbage tree and the spirit was rather a cabbage tree rum than the type later associated with the Hokonuis. (1944,Kelly of Inverkelly,162)

NATUSCH Those rotating to a stand-still were revived with Cooper McShane's cabbage-tree toddy and the dance went on to the small hours. [cabbage-tree toddy] (1953,On The Edge of the Bush: Women in Early Southland,51)

HALL-JONES The manufacture of cabbage-tree rum by McShane the Cooper .. earned the place an unsavoury reputation. (1945,Historical Southland,45)

cabbage-tree sheep¶

n. a hermit(sheep).

On the Canterbury Plains in the early days, when all the runs were unfenced for many years, we used to find cabbage-tree or hermit sheep. These were merino sheep living alone, and having a cabbage-tree or a flax-bush for a mate or companion; and they could not be made to leave, always keeping within a certain radius of that special tree, which they considered their especial friend ... They could never be made to associate with flock sheep. (1891,TrNZI,23/215) [NOTES: [?c1860s] (White)]

cabbaging¶

n.

McGILL cabbaging smoking dope leaves, inferior product. [Alison Gray] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,25)

cabin¶

adj. (See cf. cuddy)

CHAPMAN Whilst we condemn ... this assumption of superiority on the part of cabin over intermediate passengers, the feeling which prompts the passenger in moderate circumstances to shrink from subjecting himself ... thereto, cannot be disapproved of. (1843,NZ Portfolio,101)

FITTON A stock of sheep and pigs are always carried on board an emigrant ship, for the use of the cabin table. (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),265)

cabin biscuit¶

n. a hard, thick biscuit of about 2-3 inches in diameter or up to 2 inches square; a domestic form of ship's biscuit; often called cabin bread (?f. a spec. trade name and gen. name) (See cf. also captain's biscuit)

BUCKLEY In 1866 the [Victoria Flour Mills and Steam Biscuit Factory] advertised - Best Cabin Biscuits [pounds]18 per ton Navy biscuits [pounds]16 per ton (1983,Of Toffs and Toilers,150)

cabin bread¶

n. a large hard flour and water cracker biscuit. [from early sailing days]; the commercial variety of ship's biscuit =cabin biscuit [a1940 Griffin and Sons (?or Aulsebook and Co.), biscuit-makers, produced a hard, thick, round biscuit, 2-3 inches in diameter, called (at least to WW2) cabin bread; now (1985) usually found in shops under the name cabin biscuit (q.v.).]

SATCHELL Having nibbled some cabin-bread and made himself a panikin of tea ... Ibid. 188 The establishment [gum-digger's tent] contained nothing save cabin-bread. (1902,Land of the Lost,25,1971 ed.)

The grey man gnawed at the biscuits and cheese. `It's all right, tasting the old cabin bread again. I don't bother to make bread for myself. Too much trouble keeping yeast in here and the cabin bread goes mouldy.' (Jul 31, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),70) [NOTES: (Jack Lasenby)]

cabin crewie¶

n.

Air NZ opts for snacks over meals, single class without a business section, 5cm less leg room all around and about 200 fewer cabin crewies to boot. (Jun 1, 2002,Evening Post,19)

cable logging¶

n.

Cable logging, as this method of recovering felled trees is known, has a number of advantages over ground-based logging, in which a heavy four-wheeler drags trees one at a time to the dump site. (Jul 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 64/100)

cable-twist¶

n. a sweet

(Jan 15, 1903,Dominion,7/1-5) [NOTES: see Cupid's Whispers ]

cableway¶

n.

The Department of Conservation has spent $190,000 on the new bridges, replacing a swing bridge and cableway which were damaged last July following heavy rain. (May 2003,Footnotes,No. 19/3)

cabman's exercise¶

n.

MONEY In spite of our situation sleepiness came over us now and then, and we had to jump up every ten minutes and go through what used to be called `cabman's exercise.' (1871,Knocking About in NZ,76)

caboose¶

n.

PYKE [Pratt, a blatantly American character who features Bret Harte style americanisms, speaks] It's a darned wrong thing to allow in your caboose mister [here, a goldfields shanty]. (1874,George Washington Pratt,13)

FERGUSON It's a queer old caboose where he trades in [here, an up-country store]. (1883,Castle Gay,68)

BAUCKE [On a whaling station] a rough caboose' for the men, and aslop store' which could be locked up securely, and contained all moveable articles, ... (1905,Where the White Man Treads,75)

2 n. [(I remember the term being used for a small hut on skids or wheels - DEH)]

GRACE Do you want the whole caboose pulled across the paddock? (1914,Tale of Timbertown,173) [NOTES: [The context refers to a small gaol: Grace also uses caboodle in the collocation the whole caboodle (ibid. 75 Now I can verify the whole caboodle at my leisure.)]]

cabotage¶

n. OED: 1. Coasting; coast-pilotage; the coast carrying trade by sea.

Mr Grout blamed the 1994 abolition of cabotage, which used to stop foreign ships carrying domestic cargo. (May 13, 2003,Dominion Post,C2)

The [Seafarers] union is hoping politicians will get on board its campaign to bring back "cabotage" - a practice that restricts shipping between New Zealand ports to local companies. (Feb 15, 2001,Evening Post,3)

cack¶

n. excrement (still current in NZ, like poop, poss. regarded as a nursery term) [(also verb to kak [sic] below)]

..I nearly kaked my daks. (2001,Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success,29)

I knew it as I took the boulder..and got out the window, putting my bare foot on the garden to get down, feeling the duck cack like plasticine between my toes. (Oct 20, 1991,Dominion Sunday Times,21)

Thus, to go beyond the several examples already given in the book, cack and dunnekin survive in New Zealand as well as Pitcairnese (though in New Zealand, as in Australia, the shorter dunny is much commoner than dunnekin now), but presumably these are independent survivals. (1968,Anglia,86/359) [NOTES: G.W.Turner review Pitcairnese Language in Anglia]

cack-hander¶

n. a cack-handed person

A dead loss cack-hander you are. (Oct 20, 1991,Dominion Sunday Times,21)

cackle¶

n. short for hencackle q.v.

Went up and down that Baker Peak, asBarrer says a "cackle", with indecenthaste. (1936,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,V/53)

cackle-berry¶

n. egg

Of course, the ubiquitous cackle-berrymanifested itself in many forms. (Jan 27, 1996,Dominion,21)

Gee He was an easy laugher too. He laughed every time Lionel said cow juice instead of milk and cackle-berries instead of eggs. (2009,Access Road,68)

A couple of husky troopers doubled back and demanded to know why the cackle berries were cold and uncooked. (Aug 13, 2001,NZEF Times,IV/216 : 5)

cacoscopy¶

n.

There seems to be a law that requires movie cameras to be waved about all over the place. No shot lasts more than half a second. Slow motion, jerky slow motion, tortuous graphics. It's visual cacophony, and could well be called cacoscopy, though I can't find that word in the dictionary. Yet. (Jun 10, 2004,Dominion Post,B8)

cactus¶

n. (w. def. art.) the backblocks; anywhere remote

FULLARTON Where do we go from here? Into the cactus every time. orig. WW2 for the remote desert (cf the blue), but also for any remote place: also used in the Pacific theatre as the code name ofGuadalcanal (fide K.L. Warren, RNZAF 1942), a rough and remote place then: the term perhaps originated in US (cf Am Thes Slang 1942) for the desert',the range' - (1944,Troop Target,202)

SYDER & HODGETTS An isolated location, well away from towns. .in 4;`He's taken up some land in the high country. I don't know just where - away out in the cactus, anyway.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],548) [NOTES: (1962-63)1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust and NZ English [TS] 548]

BACON sticks-out in the sticks',out in the backblocks', out in the bush',out in the booay', out in the cactus', all have the same basic meaning offifty miles from nowhere'. (1963,In the Sticks,184)

TURNER Up the boo-ay means altogether wrong'. This seems to me a commoner meaning for <i>boo-ay</i> thanbackblocks', `remote rural districts', mentioned by Keith Sinclair, in the Pelican History of New Zealand, with suggested derivation from the settlement at Puhoi. Since the backblocks are already called the woop woops (the form given by Partridge who says it is mainly restricted to New South Wales: I know the word but think of it as wook wooks), the sticks, the tea tree and the cactus, some semantic differentiation is not impossible. It must be pointed out that my meaning for up the boo-ay is already supplied by up the chute, however. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,122)

cactus stove¶

n. a rough `bush' stove (poss. from cactus, military code-name for Guadalcanal) (See cf. Benghazi burner)

[Cactus Stoves'] have nothing to do with cactus, and they are as much like a stove as a mountain range is a heating appliance ... Just how they came to be calledcactus stoves' is more than I can say and I don't propose to hazard a guess. (Dec 1944,Coral Dust)

caddie¶

n. (See cady)

caddle¶

v. to ransack; turn upside down; rummage (as in a drawer) [ca1920 Mrs Joan Cochrane (from English dialect : ? family use)]

cadet¶

v. (Rural) to work as an apprentice farmer. (See cadet n)

GUTHRIE-SMITH At Peel Forest, South Canterbury, where in the early 'eighties I was cadeting ... (1921,Tutira,391)

ANDERSON 2 At sixteen I was cadeting up the Rakaia River ... (1962,Life's Roundabout, A,2)

PLUMMER At one stage he was cadeting on a big property, Huiarua, in behind Tolaga Bay. (1994,From Drover to Director,23)

TAIT Mr JT came out from England at the age of 16, in 1882, and after cadeting and shepherding for three and a half years in Hawkes Bay ... (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,54)

v. to be, or work as, a cadet

Frank was cadeting. (1890,Zealandia,1/487)

Cadet (1) A young man working on a station to learn sheep farming. He often used to pay 100 [pounds] a year for the privilege in [the] old days. He often worked `on even terms' but is now usually paid a low wage. (2) To be, or to work as, a cadet. (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement, p.69; [1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

JAMESON We [are] in want of a college for colonial cadets. (1842,New Zealand, S. Aust. and NSW,337)

n. (Rural) an apprentice or trainee farmer, employed either under private arrangement or under a cadet scheme.

Stock manager .. This person must also have the ability to communicate well with staff and pass on skills and knowledge to cadets. (Mar 16, 2002,Dominion,47)

STEVENS He followed the traditional pattern for the educated young and spent some years gaining farming experience as a cadet on Mount Peel before taking up land at Otaio. (1970,Pyne Gould Guinness: the jubilee history,36)

n. a young person being trained in an occupation (for example a farm).

There will be some changes in the format of the North Canterbury farm cadet scheme this year. Mr W.T. (Trevor) Simpson, field officer for the North Canterbury Farm Training Council cadet scheme, said that the scheme was continuing to grow ...This year Mr Simpson said it was expected that there would be about 120 cadets training ... (Jan 16, 1981,Press, The,6/6)

Simon Grant Caves, 16, farm cadet of Palmerston North ... [was] killed ...on December 5. (May 5, 1985,Press, The,8) [NOTES: check year]

n. a farm cadet

(Jan 16, 1981,Press, The,6/6)

He became a sort of half-cadet, half-general hand on the historic estate. (Aug 27, 1904,NZ Observer,4)

[Wanted, a cadet for a sheep farm.] (Apr 23, 1910,NZ Truth,1)

LANCASTER This man was a town cadet. (1904,Sons o' Men,96)

Occasionally a younger son or a stray baronet were to be met with in the back-blocks; one had run a store at Pahia, another had been a cadet on the Woolaston's station. (Sep 30, 1924,Otago Witness,54)

Some really good cricketers could always be raked up in these station teams, with so many cadets from Home being employed learning farming. (Mar 23, 1934,Feilding Star,7)

n. a school cadet

Even at school, when time came to do cadets [military training], he never even suggested I shouldn't do it. (Feb 28, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

n. a young gentleman sent, sometimes paying, to gain colonial station experience; on the job.

n.

The [New Zealand] Company should take charge, during his minority, of the landed property intended for a cadet. (1842,New Zealand, S. Aust. and NSW,339)

PHILLIPS Herbert Matthias came over to take Mrs. Leech home - Jem his cadet - (Oct 30, 1847,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,71)

cadet ... 5. (in New Zealand, formerly) a person learning sheep farming on a sheep station. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,153) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 99; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 66]]

BUTLER I had two cadets with me, and must explain that a cadet means a young fellow who has lately come out, and who wants to see a little of up-country life. He is neither paid nor pays. He receives his food and lodging gratis but works (or is supposed to work) in order to learn. (Jun 1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,6/74)

BUTLER A cadet is a young fellow who receives his food and lodging gratis and works (or is supposed to work) in order to learn. (1860,Letter) [NOTES: 1860 Butler letter in 1919 Jones Samuel Butler I/82]

BARKER The household consists ... of a cadet, as they are called - he is a clergyman's son learning sheep-farming under our auspices - and a boy who milks the cows ... (1866,Station Life in NZ,68,1870 ed.)

MONEY This military designation of cadet was applied to any young fellow who was attached to a sheep or cattle station in the same capacity as myself. He was neither flesh, nor fowl, nor good red herring,' neither master nor man. In consideration of hiseducation,' he was permitted to reside and take his meals with the master, but was sent to work with the men - the essential difference between the latter and himself being that they were paid for their labour, ... (1871,Knocking About in NZ,6)

>G.M.WILSON There was a young fellow better looking than the shepherd ... He was a cadet, as they call the young fellows learning sheep farming here, but I am afraid he would not learn much at such a rough place. (Feb 3, 1873,Diary,166) [NOTES: 1873 Feb 3 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 166]

G.M.WILSON There was a young fellow better looking than the shepherd ... He was a cadet, as they call the young fellows learning sheep farming here, but I am afraid he would not learn much at such a rough place. (Feb 3, 1873,Diary,166) [NOTES: 1873 Feb 3 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 166]

NESFIELD My fellow-cadet and I were out of the scrimmage. We were up on the station. (1881,Chequered Career,49)

SWANTON Let me warn all against the pernicious system of paying premiums as cadets', and against being swindled by so-calledlabour offices'. (1892,Notes on NZ,70)

Cadets are vast errors, nearly as bad as lady helps which is the ne plus ultra of vexation. (Nov 29, 1894,Chudleigh Diary,388,1950 ed.)

MORRIS Cadet ... term used in New Zealand, answering to the Australian Colonial Experience, or Jackaroo (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,76)

Ca-det. (k&adot.-d&ebreve.t.), n. [Add.] 3. A young gentleman learning sheep farming at a station; any young man attached to a sheep station. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2019)

VOGEL A cadet is a young man, generally from England, who is paying a run-holder so much a year for the honour and privilege of working for him. (1898,Maori Maid,147) [NOTES: (OEDS?)]

From a Dunedin paper:- Wanted, a cadet for a sheep farm. - Apply by letter to X.Y.Z.,Times' office.' Why, tarboys must be putting on `dorg' nowadays. (Apr 23, 1910,NZ Truth,252/1/3)

In answer to your advertisement in this morning's Herald I beg to apply for the situation of Cadet' on youryouthful' ewe farm. (Dec 13, 1923,Letter) [NOTES: 1923 Dec 13 Letter in 1969 Moore From Forest to Farm 67]

MANDER He had been apprenticed as a cadet on the sheep run of one of his father's clients. (1925,Allen Adair,3,1971 ed.)

STAPLEDON The lucky young man may get placed as Jackaroo' on an Australian station, or asCadet' on a New Zealand station. (1928,Tour in Australia and NZ,29)

Cadet (1) A young man working on a station to learn sheep farming. He often used to pay 100 [pounds] a year for the privilege in [the] old days. He often worked `on even terms' but is now usually paid a low wage. (2) To be, or to work as, a cadet. (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement, p.69; [1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

SCANLAN As a new cadet, working under Kelly ... no difficulties had arisen. (1933,Tides of Youth,15)

MULGAN They climbed into a four-wheeled buggy drawn by two horses, which a bright-faced cadet (who had failed his army examinations and had been shipped oversea) had driven down the day before. (1934,Spur of Morning,310)

ACLAND Heath had been a cadet with Savill at ... Craigieburn .. (1946,Early Canterbury Runs,222)

cadet. ... 3. A young man learning sheep or cattle farming on a station in Australia or New Zealand. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),57)

TOMLINSON There was also [on Roundel run] a cadet from Wellington, Arthur Coningham, who was to grow from this country background into Sir Arthur Coningham, of the Royal Air Force. (1968,Remembered Trails,50)

MOORE I managed to get a job as a cadet' or apprentice shepherd on one of the large back country sheepstations' as they were called. (1969,From Forest to Farm,16)

HARPER Two more cadets came in 1921 ... (1975,Eight Daughters,78)

n.

ANDERSON On Wednesday 28 August 1907 we reached Wellington. We were met on the windy wharf by Mrs Howard Kenway, wife of one of the Kenway brothers, also by Mr Arthur Jackman, the stock manager through whose agency I had secured the cadet job. (1964,Doctor in the Mountains,27,1974 ed.)

1 n. (Rural) a young man sent from Great Britain, financed by family, to learn farming on a large sheep station.

MONEY This military designation of cadet was applied to any young fellow who was attached to a sheep or cattle station in the same capacity as myself. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,6)

BUTLER .. it was here at a small and newly found station that I was received as a cadet, and soon regularly employed. (1872,Erewhon,11)

STUDHOLME Another day, when working at John Douglas's dip at Waihao Downs, a cadet named T K Evans, who was crutching, went right out of sight of top boots, chokebore pants and all. (1940,Te Waimate,118)

CRAWFORD When Tripp and Acland had served as cadets and took up their own runs, they themselves took on cadets ... (1949,Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury,102)

WILLIAMS For the shearing's been long, and is going on yet At the station on which I am now a cadet. (1889,Colonial Couplets,9)

2 n.

... cadets on the surveying staff. (1842,NZ Journal,72/305)

WAKEFIELD He was accompanied by a large suite of young gentlemen engaged by the company for three years as `Surveying Cadets.' (1845,Adventure in NZ,2/162)

[surveying cadet] Jollie (one of the Wellington cadets and brother of the Nelson Jollie) came down ... and has joined our staff. (Aug 23, 1849,Torlesse Papers,97,1958 ed.)

HOCKEN Desirous that no delay should occur with the surveys, Colonel Wakefield ... had despatched the Carbon ... having on board Messrs. Richard Nicholson and Albert Allom, who were surveying cadets, and seven men selected for their knowledge of bush work. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,59)

JOLLIE Two of the Cadets were requested [c1842] by one of the Asst. Surveyors to take a chain ... The cadets were gentlemen and they were quite right to refuse to do labourers' work. (1878,Reminiscences,2)

3 n.

HUNT [a railways cadet] The work of a cadet included clerical work, portering, shunting trucks, etc. (1951,Confessions,55)

Back then, cadets were allocated to departments, and Margaret-Rose is to go to the Maori Department. (Oct 23, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

Cadet Corps¶

n. [?How does the 1868 cit. fit here? Preserve as an early dating. (HWO)]

The Cadets met at the target on Saturday last and fired for the Colonial prizes ... Consequently John Tait will ... go to Wellington on behalf of the Blenheim Cadet Corps. (Jan 11, 1868,Marlborough Express,3)

... I get quite enough of lessons in school [Nelson College] so I will go on to our gallant cadet corps. ... the [uniform] jumper or loose jacket is more grand, the cuffs of the sleaves [sic] have a red twirligig of braid on them ... [ed. fn. The cadet corps was formed in 1875. the first captain was Joseph Mackay, who was resident master at the [Nelson] College (1865-81) ...] (Aug 16, 1875,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/400,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (?Bill Atkinson, Nelson, 15 years)]

There is a force of thirty-six cadet corps - viz., six in the North Island and thirty in the Middle Island, with a total strength of 1,885 of all ranks. (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,50)

GORST The whole school [Wanganui College] is formed into a cadet corps, and was paraded for our inspection. (1908,New Zealand Revisited,100)

SLATTER I sometimes wonder if the Cadet Corps is worthwhile in this day and age. (1968,Pagan Game, The,86)

Snider Carbines - All the public-school cadet corps.. were armed with these; butas a shooting-weapon they were utterly useless, on account of their antiquityand kicking powers. (1902,AJHR,E-ID/1)

The cadet corps is still an institution in connection with the school [sc. Greytown]. (Jan 29, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

McLean As officer commanding the school cadet corps, 'Blobs", wearing the famous lemon-squeezer hat (sometimes back to front) was a force not to be reckoned with. (1990,Otago Boys' High School,13)

BAXTER The school had a militant and activecadet corps. (1967,Man on the Horse, The,137)

The regulations respecting Public School cadets provide that in order to qualify for capitation a cadet corps must, inter alia, have attended during the school year two battalion parades. (Sep 4, 1908,Dominion,3)

As he said, "The Cadet Corps did notreally die, but like a good Old Soldierjust faded away" at the end of 1969. (1981,St Patrick's College, Silverstream 1931-1980,67)

[Father Keogh] also designed the olive-green full-dress uniforms of the Cadet Corps which were reluctantly relinquished when compulsory training came into being some years later. (1935,St Patrick's College 1883-1935,49)

An ancient photograph came to my rescue, a picture of the St Patrick's College Cadets at Trentham; the date April 1st, 1908. (1935,St Patrick's College 1883-1935,26)

We both belonged, compulsorily, to that fearful body of men, the Linwood High School Cadet Corps. (Mar 26, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

The speaker next referred to the fact that the Cadet Corps was now defunct, and suggested its revival. (Feb 16, 1885,Illustrated NZ News,7)

cadetship¶

n. a scholarship which includes a bond to work for the company, etc. giving it; orig. colonial cadetship, the position or status of a cadet (1853). (See cadet)

JAMESON ... colonial cadetships. (1841,New Zealand, S. Aust. and NSW,337)

ROCHFORD The other two ... had just finished their `cadetship,' that is, they had been learning sheep-farming under a settler, and were waiting for a remittance from their friends in England to begin on their own account. (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,20)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Our three months' cadetship on Captain ... Russell's Tunanui station had taught us that indiscriminate burning of fern was unwise. (1926,Tutira,156)

cadetting¶

n. the practice of working as a cadet

VOGEL Otherwise cadetting ... is a swindle. (1898,Maori Maid,147)

[He] doubted that the wisdom gained in a year's cadetting on Jamison's station would over-pay for the raw newness of life lived on the level of strenuous fact. (1987,Happy Endings,103) [NOTES: 1902 Lancaster Our Lady of the Plains in 1987 Happy Endings 103]

SMIITH Some men do instruct cadets for whom premiums are paid. Otherwise cadetting is in plain English a swindle. (1939,History of NZ Fiction,65)

COTTLE [Hdg] Recovery - Cadetting - Baronet's Son Again to the Fore. (1891,Frank Melton's Luck,91)

cadger's fish¶

n. megrim

GRAHAM NEW ZEALAND MEGRIM or WITCH (MAHUE) Caulopsetta scaphus (Bloch and Schneider). In Napier it is known as Lantern-fish, but for what reason I am unable to say, unless it is from the peculiar transparency when it/is held up to a strong light. Another name given to this useless fish by local fishermen, in Port Chalmers at least, was that of Cadger's-fish. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,186)

NATUSCH All [Flatfish] are excellent food fish - again with the exception of the megrim, once dubbed `cadgers'-fish' because of its suitability for palming off on those who hover round landing fishing-craft in the hope of perks, especially flatfish! (1967,Animals of NZ, The,217)

WILSON Name give by early South Island fishermen to the Megrim, or Witch, flatfish. This `fake' flounder was frequently caught and kept to hand out to cadgers who frequented the docks in search of a few fish from the commercial fishermen just returned from sea. ... Also called Fake Flounder. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,44)

Cads in Disguise¶

phr. the CID (Criminal Investigation Division)

... C.I.D., better known as the Cads in Disguise. (1905,NZ Truth,11/8/4)

cady¶

n. a type of felt or straw hat (See cf. cabbage-tree hat)

MORRIS Cady, n. a bush name for the slouch-hat or wide-awake. In the Australian bush the brim is generally turned down at the back and sometimes all round. (1898,Austral English,76)

[Bloke's Patter] ... while a `kadi' is a hat ... (Mar 31, 1906,NZ Truth,41/6/4)

Fred Leslie kinked his knees so as to come down to camera height, and dear boy Bradshaw artistically polished the nap of his cady as Bob Solomon gracefully smoothed his moustache, while other layers of the odds posed prettily. (Mar 13, 1909,NZ Truth,195/2/6)

caddie n. sl. a slouch hat, or wide-awake. [dial. cady] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3)

PARTRIDGE Cady. occas. cadey or kadi ... 3. Hence also, a straw hat: NZders': f. ca1920. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,120)

HYDE [reference c1919-1923] School regulation costume [c1919-1923]: navy serge gym. costume ... black band with college colours about your hat, which is in winter a straw cady, making a thick red furrow on your forehead; in summer - much better - a panama. (1938,Godwits Fly, The,92,1970 ed.)

BAKER Other terms which probably hailed from the country are ... cady or kadi, a straw hat. (1941,NZ Slang,55)

caddie, cady n. slouch hat: New Zealand, a straw hat. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),613)

caddie, cady ... n. straw hat in N.Z. Ibid.11 kadi n. (Obs.) Straw hat. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),5)

The correct headgear for the boy of the period was either a tight-fitting college cap ... or, at holiday time, a `cady' (straw hat) or a cast-off panama of your dad's. (Aug 20, 1977,Dominion,11) [NOTES: [Lawlor, Wellington Diary]]

CAFCA¶

abbr. Campaign Against Foreign Control of Aotearoa

Bill Rosenberg of the Campaign Against Foreign Control of Aotearoa (Cafca) has analysed OIC records and listed all rural land sales to foreigners between January 1991 and the end of last year. (Mar 2, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

CAFCA was formed in the mid-1970s and has about 500 paid-up members... CAFCA's bottom likne is that "land should not be sold to foreigners." (Aug 10, 2002,Dominion Post,A10)

cafe de curb¶

n. a roadside cafe or pie cart

The illustrated "Cafe de Curb" is located on the Western Hutt Road, about 500 m northwest of the Wellington Fault. (Aug 1989,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,85/50) [NOTES: Quote is for photo showing the 'Faultline Cafe", a caravan cafe or pie cart.]

cafeteria Catholic¶

phr. a non-practising Catholic who picks and chooses which doctrines and practices he or she accepts

While members of CUF are gravely concerned by the subjectivism of "cafeteria Catholics", as people of Faith they are cheerful, positive and clear-sighted. (Feb 22, 2004,NZ Catholic,10)

Now that the enrolment criteria for Catholic schools have been revised to cater for "cafeteria Catholics", a recent survey in Queensland seems relevant to our situation. (Dec 14, 2003,NZ Catholic,24)

"Cafeteria Catholics" - non baptised, non practising Catholics who had a family link to the church through grandparents or other relatives - could now apply for preferential enrolments. Ibid. C8 For the first time in 28 years, non-baptised, non-practising 'cafeteria Catholics" will be included in the high percentage of the faithful who must make up a Catholic roll. (Dec 7, 2003,Sunday Star Times,A5)

caffeinista¶

n. A coffee-shop addict

Expert caffeinistas., it is said, can pick up snatches of conversation and note who is coffeeing with who - and, just as important - who they leave with - while paying earnest attention to their coffee companions. (Nov 28, 1998,Dominion,19)

Smart young Kiwis like "caffeinista" and super-marketer Chris Weaver are reversing the brain drain and coming home. (Jun 5, 2001,Dominion Infotech Weekly,No. 492 : 1)

cag-mag¶

n.

Mere cheapness is mostly a waste of good cash/ On `cag-mag' which cannot endure, You can't cure a cold with empirical trash,/ (May 10, 1921,Quick March,13) [NOTES: [Woods Pep. Cure advt]]

cage¶

n. a crude transporter bridge over some back-country rivers, consisting usu. of a wire cage, suspended from wires, which can be drawn from one side of the river to the other, and back. [1950 N.C.C. Small : used by trampers and hunters 1954 R. Mason `Still in use.']

Half a mile above the junction the Hokitika River is crossed by means of a wire rope and cage ... (1908,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.6 (NS) 21) [NOTES: (Morgan, West Coast)]

GUTHRIE Later they were swinging across the great Teramakau river in a cage which was simply a box with sides not quite waist-high, and suspended from wire ropes bove; it would require some nerve to be shot across the ... torrent in this fashion. (1930,NZ Memories,170)

PASCOE The treacherous Hokitika River is bridged by a wire and cage, and where the boulder beaches merge into gorges well-benched foot-tracks make delightful walking. (1960,Over the Whitcombe Pass,14)

SHARPE One of the most unlucky country children ... fell out of a `cage' slung on a cable across a river, landing face down on shingle. (1962,Country Occasions,80)

TURNER Apart from personal equipment there are installations belonging to the club, especially huts, sometimes a cage, a box on an endless rope for crossing a river, called in Australia a flying fox (from the name of a native bat). (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,161)

McCASKILL After organising the first deer campaign in northern Nelson, he returned to South Westland in charge of track-making and the erection of cages for river crossings. (1969,Molesworth,141)

NOLAN Cage: the elevator (`lift') used for the transport of men and material up and down a mine shaft. Also, a suspended cable and pulley device for crossing rivers. (1983,Gold Fossicker's Handbook,111)

The Smith boys would let the cage run to the middle of the river ready to pull to the opposite side. At this point, they would say the cage was too heavy with the dog on board and he would have to swim. (Dec 2001,NZ Memories,No. 27/40)

cage fighting¶

n. all-in fighting in an octagonal cage

The fuss was over Cage Kumite, the first official cage fighting (CF) compeititon in New Zealand, a "sport" popularised in 1993 in the US by the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC). (Dec 16, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

cage-laid¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of eggs] laid by batttery or caged hens.

"We don't battery farm!" he insists. "We produce cage-laid eggs." (May 16, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,3)

About 92 per cent of the 720 million eggs bought in New Zealand each year are battery-laid - oops, cage-laid .. Mr Diprose is reluctant to debate the rights and wrongs of battery-laid - or cage-laid - eggs ... (May 16, 2002,Dominion,3)

cagged¶

adj.

DAVIN You are a duck. I'd do it myself but I'm completely cagged. If only Edward could talk as well as he can dance. (1970,Not Here, Not Now,25)

cairned¶

adj. shaped like a cairn

About 20 minutes down..a short track leads to a large, cairned rock at a small side-stream that indicates the turn-off to the old benched track. (1990,Tramping in South Island Forest Parks,213)

cake kitchen¶

n.

Cake kitchens recorded the worst performance in food hygiene in a Department of Health five-yearly food premises survey. (Sep 29, 1981,Dominion,2)

cake shop¶

n.

Whatever happened.. to the great Kiwi tradition of the lunch bar and the neighbourhood cake shop? (Jul 17, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

Cake Tin¶

n. the Westpac Stadium, Wellington. [humorous]

All the ingredients for a major national disappointment were assembled in Wellington's flash new "Cake Tin" and ready to pop in the oven. (Aug 26, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),70)

"We're not going to the Cake Tin," Mr Clarke said, referring to plans to shify test matches in Wellington from the Basin to the WestpacTrust Stadium. (Dec 28, 2000,Evening Post,1)

Inside the Cake Tin police were moving among sections of the crowd. (Mar 2002,Wel-com (Wellington),8)

The caketin is very appropriately nicknamed, because the home team - in all sports - invariably gives a half-baked performance there and fails to rise to the occasion. (Jan 25, 2003,Dominion Post,A16)

"They've got to make sure that whatever comes out of the Cake Tin is sure to rise." (Jun 26, 2002,Dominion,1)

He played it tight and taut in the winter wonderland of Jade, roamed freely in the Cake Tin cakewalk, was a standout in a losing cause at Sydney's Bledisloe and last weekend finished it all with a flourish,... (Aug 18, 2002,Sunday Star Times,B2)

[Advt] Do the Cake Tin Yodel... If you want to be thrilled to your feet this summer, try the Cake Tin Yodel along with the Topp Twins.. at Wellington's Big Summer Celebration of Kiwi Culture. (Oct 19, 2002,Dominion Post,C20)

About 3000 punters rolled up for the first Shell Cup home match of the cricket season in which Wellington met Northern Districts, but it's a fair bet they were just as curious to check out the Cake Tin, as the stadium has been nicknamed, and be part of a historic day. (Jan 5, 2000,Evening Post,17)

Along with the hideous Majestic Centre, the garish Courtenay Central and the monstrous Te Papa, Museum of New Zealand, the "Cake-Tin" adds to the visual eye-sores that define Wellington. (May 5, 2004,Capital Times,?19)

The usually laid-back Queenslander yesterday provided a none-too-subtle variation on Australia's execution of New Zealand last week, this time pummeling his hosts into submission with a blockbusting 156 at the Cake Tin. (Dec 8, 2005,NZ Herald,C18)

Mates-v-mates factor in Cake-Tin affair (May 4, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,12)

[Hdg] Full Cake Tin for Aussie test would make up for French farce. (Jun 17, 2001,Sunday Star Times,B6)

... [John Ansell] thought he had left all that behind as he pursued other interests - publishing a book of poems, giving speeches on the English language and naming Wellington's stadium "The Cake Tin". (Jul 3, 2005,Sunday Star Times,A6)

We don't climb the biggest mountain in the world, we "knock the bugger off". And we don't play epic rugby matches where players bleed for their jersey in stadia, we play rugger in Cake Tins. (May 12, 2004,Capital Times,14)

It may not be to everyone's liking but apparently it is fine to refer to Wellington's Westpac Stadium as the "cake tin" - on television at least... Many people, including Wellingtonians, called the stadium the cake tin just as people call buildings "Big Ben" or "The Beehive". (May 29, 2003,Dominion,A5)

Uniting under a flag, come hell or high water, no matter the quality or character of our own "players". regardless of their worthiness, is both the cause of lobbed beer cans at the Cake Tin and lobbed cluster bombs in Arabia. (Apr 25, 2004,Sunday Times (NZ),B12)

Some call it the Cake Tin, some the Colosseum, call it what you like - but Canterbury rugby coach Robbie Deans predicts a tough time for any visiting team at Wellington's WespacTrust Stadium. (Aug 12, 2000,Evening Post,1)

Wellington's fantastic new WestpacTrust Stadium should be known as "the Cauldron". The current "Cake Tin" alias is totally inappropriate, as opposing sides will tell us "it's anything but a cakewalk to play there, in a far-from-sugar-filled atmosphere where they often experience their own decay. (Aug 25, 2000,Evening Post,4)

[Hdg] Debate over name just a storm in a cake tin. Tetchy WestpacTrust Stadium officials want to put en end to the great cake tin debate...Stadium communications manager Iain Morrison said he had heard them all before - the cake tin, Watertank Stadium, the colosseum and the donut (it has a hole in it and cost a lot of dough. (Aug 29, 2000,Dominion,28)

Wins [in the Stadium] are bound to be a piece of cake, if not a cakewalk, so why not let the spectators bask or bake in the cake tin? (Sep 3, 2000,Sunday Star Times,B2)

There was a jink and a swerve and a burst of speed and a flapping of arms as five tacklers launched themselves and failed as the sevens whiz set off on a run that was the icing on the cake for the 25,000 who packed into this place they call the Cake Tin... In the end it was Wellington which came out of the Cake Tin half-baked. (Oct 8, 2000,Sunday Star Times,B4)

Calling the Westpac Stadium the Cake Tin at a Wellington dinner party is a sure way to get a rise out of someone. (Jul 14, 2004,Capital Times,14)

I have undertaken to write out a thousand times, "I must not use the name caketin because to do so is to undermine the dignity of all those sensitive souls whose personal sense of selfworth is invested in the stadium". (Aug 14, 2001,Evening Post,8)

On the Friday before the All Blacks played France at the Cake Tin, four South Island farmers ambled into the court room in their jerseys and fawn trousers, and stood along one wall, their ruddy faces glowing with astonishment. (Jul 14, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

cakeage¶

n. a restaurant charge for BYO celebratory cake, equivalent to corkage for BYO wine.

The manageress didn't seem to understand that we were unhappy about having to pay for two invisible people, $44 corkage and $8 "cakeage". (Oct 17, 2005,NZ Herald,A16)

'Cakeage' fee is only fair Special occasion or not, taking a birthday cake to a restaurant is using that restaurant as a BYO-food venue (Sept 17-18). (Sep 29, 2005,Dominion Post,B6)

calabash¶

n.

YATE ... green calabash [among NZ vegetables] Ibid. 108 a calabash-full of water ... [as a gourd to hold liquids etc] (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),107) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

DIEFFENBACH long rows of baskets filled with articles of food, such as green calabashes, kumeras, pumpkins, water-melons, and dried fish. Ibid. II/49 The calabashes (hue) were, according to their traditions, the next addition to their stock of eatables. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/314)

WILLIAMS Kiaka, n. calabash. (1871,Dictionary of the NZ Language,53) [NOTES: [so 1892, 1957]]

Lagenaria vulgaris (1897,TrNZI,29/)

LYSNAR The calabash, the kumara, the taro, and the yam, were carried in the fleet. (1924,New Zealand (various authors/titles),20)

v.

When the bodies placed in the hangis were cooked they were calabashed, and formally handed over to the Ngatitoa as payment for the children of Te Rauparaha who had been treacherously killed by the Muaupoko. (1894,TrNZI,26/579)

2 n.

FORSTER ... they have nothing in which to keep liquids except a minute kind of calabash or gourd, which grows only in the northern island, and was extremely scarce among the people of Queen Charlotte's Sound. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/220)

BIDWILL The food was in a calabash, and pushed by the woman's fingers to the edge, so that it should fall into his mouth. (1841,Rambles in NZ,49,1952 ed.)

DIEFFENBACH Hue, or ue - a gourd, calabash (1843,Travels in NZ,2/363)

MOSER Things ... were got ready at last, and served up in baskets made of flax, known as kits, calabashes, pots and kettles; and a roar of `kai-kai! haeremai', created a sudden sensation amongst the outsiders. (1863,Mahoe Leaves,34)

THATCHER They've [Maori women] got their eye to cooking --/ Calibashes, [???check this and preceding out] (1864,Songs of the War,4)

DOMETT A ditty to the startled Child/ About a fountain' anda calabash;' (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/262)

TREGEAR At one [hakari] feast there has ben seen 2,000 one-bushel baskets of kumara, ... calabashes of oil, etc. etc. (1904,Maori Race, The,113)

SHAND The Calabash, so useful to the other branches of the race, did not grow on the [Chatham] island; ... (1911,Moriori People of the Chatham Islands, The,10)

COWAN ... the people were unable to swallow this food when the water-supply in calabashes (kiaka) was exhausted. (1922,NZ Wars, The,1/377)

HENDERSON [The chiefs] had their share brought to them in calabashes called taha, .. (1948,Taina,112)

At school Jumbo Gilfillan thought his new calc was nicked. ... It turned up in the silly honky's own bag. (1986,New Outlook,21/49) [NOTES: Macrae (The Kingsland Kid)]

Calcutta splutter¶

n. diarrhoea

Did you get Dehli [sic] Belly or Calcutta Splutter? We had very little sickness in our time. (Sep 21, 2003,Sunday Star Times,B12)

Calcutta sweep(stake)¶

n. a method of gambling on horse races or golf matches [also ellipt. Calcutta]

BELTON [Calcutta Sweep - Te Aroha] The method of conducting aCalcutta' differs entirely from the more common form of sweep. In a `Calcutta' subscripters are ... 1 pound each ... and are not governed by the number of horses in the race upon which the sweep is based. Slips of paper with the horses written on then placed in a hat and in another hat - names of subscribers. Promoter ... takes role of auctioneer ... each horse drawn offered at auction and sold to highest bidder ... full amount bid has only to be paid if the buyer is not the drawer of that particular horse. If the drawer should buy the horse in, then he pays only half the amount bid, and the money goes into the pool. If the buyer does not draw the horse, the amount bid is divided, half to the drawer and half to the pool. (1939,Outside the Law,169)

NEWTON [Reference 1928] Another memory of that meeting [at Springfield, c1928] is the Calcutta Sweep'. This was a common practice in those days and now that it seems to be a thing of the past it might be worth describing. The evening before the event concerned the crowd would get together and every dog on the programme would be put up forauction'.
