The proceeds of the sale' would be pooled, divided into first, second and third money, and after the actual event was finished this went to the men who hadpurchased' the placed dogs. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,45)

[The] system, known casually as the Calcutta sweep, is practised in most clubs round the country and makes amateur golfers wealthy men through golf as an amateur sport. Basically, the idea works on the system of paired golfers who compete for prize-money put up by their fellow club-members ... The pairs are deemed horses and are bought at local club auctions by other club members. And it is at those auctions that anything happens ... The competition is usually run on a match-play basis with the winning couple collecting half of what they have won while the `owner' who bought them gets the other half ... I know of one team that went for $3 all up and won a calcutta. (Jun 23, 1974,Sunday Times (NZ),20)

He was appearing for a number of peoplewho pleaded guilty to being found in acommon gaming house, the SouthFeatherston Hall, while a Calcutta Sweepwas in progress. (May 28, 1952,NZ Truth,18)

Throughout New Zealand, wherever populations ensure a sufficient congregation of racing enthusiasts, thousands of pounds are invested on the eve of important races in Calcutta sweepstakes... The auctioneer told the crowd that the last Calcutta sweep at this club.. was worth aGBP100 to start. (Nov 24, 1937,NZ Truth,22)

Cale/Calley¶

n. (See Cally)

calf beating¶

1 n. (Rural) the attacking of young deer calves by hinds.

The victims of calf beating, as it is called, were always attacked by hinds other than their own mothers. Calf beating does not appear to be a general pattern of behaviour in all hinds, because in some herds no deaths from this phenomenon occur. Consequently, the calf beating is thought to have been due to the high stocking rate and the lack of cover provision. (Oct 1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,53)

calf bedding¶

1 n. (Rural) material, usually wood chip, used to provide warmth to newborn calves taken from their mothers to be hand-reared or bobbied.

Premium dry wood shavings available now for calf bedding. (Jun 13, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,16)

Calf bedding - blend of sawdust and woodchip. (Jun 13, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,18)

calf club¶

1 n. (Rural) a rural school or district club in which children raise and exhibit their own calves.

The calf club movement which is well established in Northland is proving itself in results. (Nov 23, 1939,NZ Farmer,4)

The various rules and regulations that govern calf club groups, have largely been hammered out on the anvil of experience by former enthusiasts. (Aug 1, 1949,NZ Dairy Exporter,75)

Jessee Leatherby (10) of Normanby and calf Gypsy stand around in the rain before taking the ring during the annual Taranaki Boys' and Girls' Calf Club Championships at Stratford A & P Showgrounds on Saturday. (Nov 4, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,19)

The calf club has already been tried successfully in a few centres ... (Aug 1, 1927,NZ Farmer,930)

A school teacher, Mr J F Crocker of Pipiroa School, on the Hauraki Plains, was the first to introduce calf clubs in New Zealand, according to an article in 'The Dairy Farmer' dated July 20, 1921. (Nov 1986,NZ Dairy Exporter,Supplement 31)

calf club day¶

1 n. (Rural) an exhibition day in rural schools where children exhibit calves that they have reared.

When their calf club days are over, they should spend 'five years away from Dad ...' (Apr 10, 1980,NZ Farmer,26)

GORDON Calf club day is one of the really big occasions in a rural school's calendar. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,139)

.. it is part of the fabric of the community, as important an event as calf club day .. But he also talks about the calf he will soon start to ready for that calf club day here in October ... (Aug 24, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,17)

calf day¶

1 n. (Rural) (See calf club day)

New Zealand has a strong emphasis on agriculture. Already I've discovered calf days, which are unheard of in Ireland ... (Oct 18, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,17)

HILL The principal [of the school] also has to organise Calf Day - the uniquely rural occasion when the children's pet is exercised, shampooed, brushed, perfumed, has its hoofs vaselined and polished and its muzzle wiped, and is then carried tenderly to school in the back seat of the car in case it gets dirty before judging. (1985,Moaville Magic,22)

Jenny Jackson, who currently organises the plant stall, says the Lamb and Calf Day has been held on the first Saturday in November since World War II and plants have always been a feature. (Oct 4, 2003,Dominion Post,E11)

calf disbudding¶

n. the dehorning of calves

Calf Disbudding We provide An expert service A professional service A fuss free service All equipment required All labour required (Sep 27, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,6)

Calf Disbudding Book now for your calves' dehorning! (Sep 27, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,6)

calf pool¶

1 n. (Rural) an enterprise organised locally where the returns from the sale of bobby calves are pooled and shared among the farmers involved.

successful results of last year's Southland Calf Pool operations have more than justified the contention that one co-operative organisation handling this business is much more satisfactory ... (Aug 1, 1936,NZ Dairy Exporter,48)

The Banks Peninsula calf pool paid 34/10 a head to farmers last season. (Aug 2, 1951,NZ Farmer,25)

It is indeed a far cry back to the days of the inception of the bobby calf pools when the dairy farmer was getting next to nothing for his surplus calves. [bobby calf pool] (Jul 10, 1959,NZ Dairy Exporter,11)

calf scheme¶

1 n. (Rural) a national programme where dairy farmers donate a calf and graze it themselves for at least four months before sale with proceeds to charity.

The calf scheme has been running for 15 years and has grown rapidly. IHC fundraising manager Greg Millar says the success of the calf scheme can be attributed to the generosity of the farming community. (Sep 5, 2002,Dominion Post,Farm Supplement 24)

This year's [Golden Gumboot] award went to Christchurch convenor Phil Griffiths, particularly for his calf scheme work during the snow and harsh weather of last winter. The calf scheme will contribute 15% to 20% of this - ... (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,42)

calf-paddock¶

n.

I haven't got a proper calf-paddock. I keep them in the calf-shed depending on the weather, and let them out in mobs of 15 into any handy paddock. (Aug 30, 1986,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Landline [Taranaki]]

calf-shed¶

n.

I haven't got a proper calf-paddock. I keep them in the calf-shed depending on the weather, and let them out in mobs of 15 into any handy paddock. (Aug 30, 1986,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 2YA Landline [Taranaki]]

calf-sick¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of paddocks close to feeding sheds and used year after year] harbouring coccidiosis organisms, causing scouring and unthrifty calves.

NELSON calf-sick paddock - one where calves have been kept without spelling, allowing disease-causing organisms to proliferate. (1999,Eugene Nelson Glossary,3)

calfarama¶

1 n. (Rural) equipment and system for mass-feeding of calves.

equipment for feeding calves - calfarama. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

calfetaria¶

1 n. (Rural) equipment and system for mass-feeding of calves.

The herd of tomorrow - a group of calves self-feeding at a 'calfetaria' on the farm of Mrs Charles Warren at Tamahere in the Waikato. (Sep 11, 1961,NZ Dairy Exporter,63)

Calves were kept in a pen until they'd had about three feeds from a calfetaria. (Nov 1975,NZ Dairy Exporter,11)

All dairy replacements are AI sired and for the last four years have been calfetaria reared. (May 13, 1982,NZ Farmer,27)

1 motorbike calfetaria, on wheels. (Nov 18, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,23)

A calfetaria is a handy way to feed stock, but it must be thoroughly cleaned after use. (Jul 3, 2001,Central Districts Farmer,13)

The calfetaria is a special unit fitting any standard size milk can. (Jun 1958,NZ Journal of Agriculture,592)

GORDON She uses a 'calfetaria' system, another way of saying bovine milk bar. It's a row of teats, fixed to a board, with each connected to a bucket of milk by a plastic straw. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,88)

calfeteria¶

n.

I'll feed the calves from a mobile calf-teria [Taranaki] ... I won't feed them so much meal this year - milk is cheaper. (Aug 30, 1986,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 2YA Landline]

...calfateria... (Apr 28, 2004,Wairarapa News,28)

One may more readily propose what to put in than what to take out, such as one coinage which turned up some years ago and which I thought was a nonce word.. calfeteria, a bowl with several teats from which a number of calves may feed at the same time. (1987,Te Reo,30/132)

,,,45 teat calfateria... (May 5, 2004,Wairarapa News,30)

calfmeal¶

n.

You're bringing cows and calves in / With no time to go to town, / But you need some new shed rubbers / A bag of calfmeal or two. (1999,Hubbard's 'Clipboard',44 : 2)

About this time dad noticed his calf-meal disappearing rapidly. (Sep 26, 1931,Exporter & Home Journal,46)

Cali¶

n. Californian thistle [ORIGIN: abbreviation, 1944 Callies used in the Canterbury Botanist for Californian thistles (R. Mason)]

1 n. (Rural) Californian thistle.

HILGENDORF CALIFORNIAN THISTLE (Cirsium arvense) is also called Canadian thistle, and sometimes field thistle or creeping thistle. It is probably [was some years ago,] the most discussed weed in New Zealand. ... Of the fourteen districts into which the country was divided, `Cali' was considered one of the three worst weeds in no fewer than twelve. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,186,1967 ed.)

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR Calies aren't killed by cutting. ... the seed blows across ... (1981,Sunrise,61)

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR Calies aren't killed by cutting. ... the seed blows across ... (1981,Sunrise,61)

Digging 'Cali' thistles, a legacy of hay-carting, out of one's fingers. (Apr 28, 1966,NZ Farmer,37)

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR Calies aren't killed by cutting .. the seed blows across. (1981,Sunrise on Hikurangi,72)

HILGENDORF Of the fourteen districts into which the country was divided, 'Cali' was considered one of the three worst weeds in no fewer than twelve. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,187)

calicivirus¶

n.

And Max Bradford announced that a judicial calicivirus would be released into the Employment Contracts Act. (May 10, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

It's the greatest exodus the Maniototo has seen since calcivirus dealt to the rabbits. (Jan 31, 1999,Sunday Star Times,C3)

BAKER Before the telly died, haggard-looking people, politicians mostly, described how an illegally imported rabbit calicivirus had mutated... The mutated calicivirus had already seen the country tightly quarantined. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,4)

Overall, rabbit calcivirus had proved beneficial... It had significantly reduced rabbit numbers in dry areas, thougb it was not effective in wetter areas. (Jan 25, 2001,Dominion,2)

The last time I appeared [sc. on Hudson and Halls] I wound up having to eat, and appear to enjoy, a rabbit simultaneously prepared two ways: braised in Pinot Noir, and sauteed with honey and grain mustard. My verdict: calcivirus would have been kinder in either case. (Sep 1999,Cuisine,No. 76 : 106)

With the return of live and dead kiwi to Northland following their participation in the rabbit calicivirus research, the Department of Conservation is now deliberating on whether or when the virus will be let loose in New Zealand. (Jun 15, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

There's the vexed question of rabbit calicivirus and the alarming news from the Conservation Department that native robins and tomtits have died as a result of a 1080 poison carrot drop in Pureora Forest. (Nov 30, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),52)

calico¶

n.

2 n.

Run up the calico. - Pitch the tent. (Jan 27, 1934,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Gloss]

calico-jimmy¶

n.

By plausibly pandering to the prejudices of a parvenu plutocracy, and craftily catering to contemptible foiblies of society coteries cunningly cloaking the calico-jimmy crimes of commercial cliques, and condoning the corruption of pirate politicians, the [Sydney Morning] `Herald' had come to be the ideal paper of a boodling bourgeoisie, .. (Jul 14, 1906,NZ Truth,56/e4/4)

califont¶

adj. a gas apparatus for heating water; a geyser [ca1915 Mary O'Connor, Wellington ca1952 R. Mason In universal use in NZ for a certain type of gas hot water heater, for the English `geyser'? - a name never used in NZ. 1982 February. Jean Watson used it for an above-the-sink gas water-heater]

Tests were made on a bathroom califont of the ordinary type shown in fig. 2. ... [caption] Gas-califont of the ordinary type. (1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,3/259) [NOTES: (Marsden and Fenton)]

DRYLAND He would have nothing to do with the gas califont in the bathroom, preferring cold baths to being blown up. (1973,Multiple Texture, A,31)

an old-fashioned gas-burning water-heater. [? from trade name] (1979,Heinemann NZ Dictionary,149)

LELAND Califont. You may rent a flat that has a SMALL GAS WATERHEATER over the tub or shower. You switch this on and it roars into life, startling the hell out of you and providing the frightening sight and sound of a violent conflagration that quickly heats the water. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,20)

califont n. N.Z. an old-fashioned name for a gas water-heater; geyser. [C19: < L calidus hot + fons fountain] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,156) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 67]]

BINNEY [spg Calefont] Instructions on Government Department paper were affixed to throughout the rooms. ... Pilot Light in Bathroom Calefont NOT to be Left Unattended. (1985,Long Lives the King,49)

(Cornish) In the bathroom ... resided my enemy - the califont, a silver contraption that you lit and from which hot water flowed into the bath. (1988,Through the Looking Glass,94)

The Gas Association recognises it may be possible to resite an appliance but it strongly recommends that these califont installations be replaced. (Dec 9, 1998,Dominion,12)

I've looked at a califont and wondered how she managed to carry it home. (May 28, 1927,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,00) [NOTES: Check page]

California pump/Californian pump¶

n.

I would also advise parties of six to ... provide themselves with a California pump, sluice, picks, shovels ... (Aug 14, 1861,Letter) [NOTES: 1861 Aug 14 letter from Tuapeka in 1867 Hochstetter NZ 110fn]

Almost every claim was a wet one, and Californian pumps had to be kept constantly going to prevent the water rising to too high a level. (Sep 27, 1861,NZ Goldfields,28,1976 ed.) [NOTES: 1861 Sep 27 Tuapeka in NZ Goldfields 1861 (1976) 28]

BATHGATE We could hear ... the creaking of their [sc miners'] Californian pumps. (1874,Colonial Experiences,129) [NOTES: [goldminers']]

Pumping gear became more elaborate with the introduction, in the deeper paddocks, of the ingenious Californian pump. This comprised a long narrow box, open at each end but otherwise completely enclosed. Through it ran an endless canvas belt with wooden cleats fitting neatly into the inside of the box. The belt passed over rollers at the upper and lower ends of the box; the lower end was immersed in the flooded paddock and as the belt turned clockwise over its rollers the water was drawn up through the box and delivered to a tail-race. The motive power was commonly an overshot water-wheel. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,190,1962 ed.)

California weed¶

n. Anacharis canadensis (Elodea canadensis) [1927 August Christchurch Press R. Mason]

Californian black cricket¶

n.

The ground being full of cracks, has harboured millions of Californian black crickets which have gnawed the grass into the very roots. (May 7, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,24)

Californian bluebell¶

n. Phacelia campanularia

Anne's Californian bluebell, Phacelia campanularia belongs not to the Boraginaceae but the Hydrophyllaceae group. It is a native of southern California, introduced in 1882. (Dec 2, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45)

Californian bungalow¶

n.

The house.. was a Californian bungalow,New Zealand version, built in the late1920s... Our house had a corner-bowwindow, with a window-seat, a small sideporch and a back verandah. There was acoloured-glass window picturing a sailingship and - the other mark of theCalifornian bungalow - a feature area ofwood shingles beneath the bow window. (Aug 8, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),61)

The Californian bungalow, the English arts and crafts and English Queen Anne styles dominated the housing scene in New Zealand from 1910-1940. (Sep 10, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),97)

SINCLAIR & HARREX After about 1910 probably the commonest type of new house was the bungalow, which was influenced by the earlier Californian bungalow. (1978,Looking Back,118)

Californian poppy¶

n. eschscholtzia, johnny-go-to bed

HILGENDORF poppy, Californian [=] eschscholtzia [s] Ibid. 86 CALIFORNIAN POPPY (Eschsholzia [Eschscholtzia] californica), often called eschscholtzia, and sometimes Johnny-go-to-bed, on account perhaps of its nightcap-like calyces, is found in profusion on the shingly river-beds of the South Island. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,26,1967 ed.)

Californian poppy [=] eschscholtzia [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,10)

ADAM On the shingle river beds and dry soils of Canterbury and inland Otago acres of vivid Californian poppy are a blaze of golden orange ... Botanical name: Eschscholtzia californica. (1980,Wild Flowers,26)

The Californian bluebell, P. campanularia, like the Californian poppy, Eschscholzia, enjoys sandy or poor soil and full sun. (Dec 2, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45)

Like a number of rivers in Canterbury, the Waireka was more often than not dry - no water, just boulders, broom and Californian Poppies. (Feb 2004,NZ Memories,No. 46/44)

Californian quail¶

n. an introduced black-crested quail, the state bird of California, now the most numerous variety in New Zealand. [aka California quail; OED2 California quail 1831]

The Californian quails are just aboutnesting. (Oct 16, 1912,Otago Witness,16)

The Californian quail is a very handsome bird, of large size and brilliant plumage, and is likely to be easily acclimatized. (Oct 4, 1864,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

The Californian quail promise to become as plentiful as the pheasants, and are rapidly increasing. The Australian brown quail, turned out at Motueka, will, we hope, thrive equally well ... (Nov 12, 1870,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

Imported game, comprising cock pheasants, Californian quail, Australian swamp quail, and hares, may be killed within the Wellington Acclimatisation District from 1st May to 31st July, both days inclusive. (Apr 7, 1909,Evening Post,6)

The Acclimatisation Society have received the first shipment of Californian quail from Thomas Russell, and several thousand are expected to follow. (Oct 9, 1887,Grey River Argus,2)

The dryness and drainage of the dunes is food for ground-nesting birds.. including the little brown quail, which whistles a rising call, unlike the California quail's chi-ca-go. (May 10, 1992,Dominion Sunday Times,23)

After some discussion the following resolutions were carried .. (3) That the game to be shot be cock pheasants and Californian quail ... (Mar 6, 1894,Taranaki Herald,2)

A letter was read from the Acclimatisation Society of Nelson, requesting the assistance of the Auckland Society in procuring Californian quail. (Mar 8, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,4)

The quail would be at the very end of our northward journey in a copse of poplar and boxthorn where the wind had scoured sand away from a dune base and exposed the water table. (Jul 12, 2003,Dominion Post,F9)

ARD FAIRBURN [Sargeson] is no more distinctively `New Zealand' than I am ... or wedgie shoes - orCalifornian quail. (1947,Letters,160) [NOTES: 1981 ed.]

A Flock of Californian Quail. [caption] (Oct 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,37)

... various kinds have been introduced by ... the Acclimatization Society. Especially may be named the black swan ...; Californian quail, and Victorian quail ... (1868,Province of Otago in NZ, The,31)

  1. Lophortyx californica brunnescens Ridgway, 1884 Californian [California] Quail Introduced from U.S.A. first in 1865 ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,40) [NOTES: 1980 ed.]

California Quail Lophortyx californica brunnescens RIDGWAY, 1884 ...OTHER NAMES: Californian quail, callie. ... Since it was introduced successfully into New Zealand betwen 1862 and 1880 the California quail has been a popular game bird. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,159)

Our handsome little quail (Coturnix Novae Zelandiae) was formerly ... abundant ... Its place is adequately supplied by ... the Californian Quail ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/14) [NOTES: Buller Ornithology]

The Pheasant, the Partridge, and Californian Quail, are amongst the best of the game birds ... established amongst us. (1870,TrNZI,2/49) [NOTES: Potts Birds]

The two species of quail introduced, the swamp-quail (Synoecus australis) and the Californian quail (Callipepla californica) have been hardly more successful than the pheasants. (1907,TrNZI,39/249)

He was charged with having, on may 23, shot Californian quail without being in possession of a license so to do. (Jun 22, 1918,NZ Truth,5)

It appears that pheasants, Californian quail and Australian quail may be taken.. from the 1st May, 1887, to the 31st July in the same year. (Apr 9, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,17)

I passed seven covey of quail - four Californian quail, and the others, I am confident, New Zealand quail, which are described as extinct by a label.. in the Dominion Museum. (Feb 2, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

Cock pheasants and Californian quail maybe killed in the StratfordAcclimatisation district from May 1st toJuly 31st. (Apr 7, 1919,Stratford Evening Post,5)

I have just been alarmed by quail, Californian quail, perhaps 50 of them, waiting until the dogs and I were almost upon them before they erupted from a gorse thicket with a roar of wings. (Aug 29, 2001,Evening Post,12)

The chaffinch, the Californian quail, and the Australian swamp quail, or stubble-quail, are mentioned. (Jan 5, 1949,Auckland Weekly News,15)

HENDERSON We hear the long lines of California quail as they travel out and home at about the same time as we do. (1967,Return to Open Country,74)

ANDERSON When at and near Kaingaroa I was struck by the quantity of Californian quail I saw. (1882,Chatham Islands, The,17)

Californian stinkweed¶

n. Navarettia squarrosa , [formerly named Gilla squarrosa ]; digger's weed, yeast plant (See digger's weed)

HILGENDORF STINK WEED ([Navarettia] squarrosa ), [formerly named Gilla squarrosa ] and called Californian stink weed, digger's weed and yeast plant, occurs chiefly [in river beds] on dry pastures and cultivated fields in Marlborough and Otago, where it sometimes becomes dominant over all other herbage. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,139,1967 ed.)

SARGESON I abruptly dropped my share of the load, turned and walked back through the demented dogs and out beyond blackberry and stinkweed until I could look down onto the pasture and across the railway line and beyond. (1977,Never Enough!,143)

Californian Stinkweed, Digger's Weed (Navarettia (Gilia) squarrosa) . . . It is sometimes erroneously called "Bathurst burr." (1895,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,III/121)

GUTHRIE-SMITH During the following season ... germinated masses of the evil-smelling plant [Gillia squarrosa ], Californian stinkweed as it is called, on account of its malodorous savour. (1926,Tutira,286)

Californian stinkweed [s] Navarretia squarrosa (Esch.) Hook. & Arn. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,10)

TAYLOR CALIFORNIAN STINKWEED (Navarretia squarrosa ) ... Introduced from California, this plant grows mainly in the lower rainfall areas of the South Island. (1980,Weeds of Crops,24)

Californian Stinkweed, Diggers' Weed (Navarettia (Gilia) squarrosa) . Ibid. 2 It is sometimes erroneously called "Bathurst burr." (1895,Leaflets for Farmers,No.22/1)

Californian thistle¶

n. (Rural) an introduced plant, Cirsium arvense, an invasive paddock weed recognised in 1878, often called Cali and Canada thistle.

Mr. Cockayne.. has been studying thehabits of the Californian thistle with aview to the eradication of the pest... Hestates that the weed is not a native ofCalifornia (where it is unknown), but ofEurope (May 22, 1912,Otago Witness,30)

The Californian thistle, which is atroublesome pest all over New Zealand, isbeing experimented on in Otago. (Feb 3, 1912,Dominion,8)

THE Californian thistle's days may be numbered, thanks to a biocontrol project managed by the Clutha Agricultural Development Board. (Aug 18, 2005,Dominion Post,C7)

Two years ago this land was covered with Californian thistle, but is now producing, from left to right, potatoes, mangels, disease-free pedigree beans, and 2a acres of swedes, which yielded three tons of first-class club-root resistant seed. (Jun 19, 1935,Evening Post,19)

A tiny, green weed-eating predator released in Otago and Southland last week is expected to have a major impact on Californian thistles, which are a $32 million a year problem. (Nov 27, 2007,Southland Times,A15)

There are two varieties of the thistle which are very stubborn to eradicate.. They have been called respectively the American and the Californian thistle, a distinction which has been unfairly given to the Union and to the particular state whose name is used. Both plants arenatives of Britain (Feb 20, 1890,Otago Witness,7)

Californian thistle increases. I was surprised to find this weed is spreading on the Otago Peninsula, and also on some of the best lands inthe Taieri Plains. (1899,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,VII/5)

Californian thistle increases. I was surprised to find how this weed is spreading on the Otago Peninsula and also on some of the best land on the Taieri Plain. (1899,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,5) [NOTES: 1899 Dept Ag Rep 5 referring back to Farmers' Leaflet 18, for description (Griffiths Collection)]

The best means of dealing with Californian thistle where the ground is suitable is continuous cultivation of the plot affected, either by ploughing or grubbing. Ibid. 346 Amongst the many noxious weeds that harass New Zealand agriculture Californian thistle (Cnicus arvensis) is generally ranked as the most widespread and most injurious... Californian thistle is a native of Europe, and is there known as field, creeping, or corn thistle. In New Zealand the name Canadian thistle is also often applied to the plant. Notwithstanding its name of Californian, that State is one of the few in the Union where it is altogether absent. [footnote] (Jan 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,79)

HILGENDORF & CALDER CALIFORNIAN THISTLE (Cirsium arvense) is also called Canadian thistle, and sometimes field thistle or creeping thistle. It is probably [was some years ago,] the most discussed weed in New Zealand. ... Of the fourteen districts into which the country was divided, `Cali' was considered one of the three worst weeds in no fewer than twelve. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,186)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Corn thistle (Cnicus arvensis), in New Zealand rechristened Californian or Canadian thistle, was first detected by me on Putorino, ... (1926,Tutira,254)

ANTHONY ... and here was this Crown land going wild and seeding the whole country with ragwort and Californian thistle. (1927,Me and Gus,85,1977 Gus Tomlins ed Sturm ed.)

BALLANTYNE Last time he wrote he said it's been awful with Californian thistle up there this year. (1948,Cunninghams, The,17,1976 ed.)

LEVY Weeds that are neglected by all classes of stock ... Scotch thistle, Californian thistle, winged thistle, variegated thistle, and the like are all weeds which, when properly established, are unpalatable to stock. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,302,1970 ed.)

TAYLOR CALIFORNIAN THISTLE (Cirisium arvense) ... is known as creeping thistle in England. It is native to Europe but known as Canadian thistle in many countries. Californian thistle is an important weed of crops and grasslands throughout New Zealand. It is most abundant in coastal Southland and some elevated regions, e.g. about Raetihi. (1980,Weeds of Crops,24)

WALLACE Canadian' orCalifornian' thistle. ... said to have been introduced about 1886 in Californian barley. (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,310)

Noxious Weeds. ... Californian or Canadian thistle ... Bathurst Burr ... (1902,Settlements of NZ Coy,203)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Corn thistle (Cnicus arvensis), in New Zealand rechristened Californian or Canadian thistle, was first detected by me on Putorino, ... (1926,Tutira,254)

HILGENDORF & CALDER CALIFORNIAN THISTLE (Cirsium arvense) is also called Canadian thistle, and sometimes field thistle or creeping thistle. It is probably [was some years ago,] the most discussed weed in New Zealand. ... Of the fourteen districts into which the country was divided, `Cali' was considered one of the three worst weeds in on fewer than twelve. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,186)

DAVIN ... what was down in grass ... was eaten up by ragwort and Canadian thistle. (1959,No Remittance,100) [NOTES: [?Southland]]

HILGENDORF CALIFORNIAN THISTLE (Cirsium arvense) is also called Canadian thistle, and sometimes field thistle or creeping thistle. It is probably [was some years ago,] the most discussed weed in New Zealand. ... Of the fourteen districts into which the country was divided, `Cali' was considered one of the three worst weeds in on fewer than twelve. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,186,1967 ed.)

HILGENDORF CALIFORNIAN THISTLE (Cirsium arvense) is also called Canadian thistle, and sometimes field thistle or creeping thistle. It is probably [was some years ago,] the most discussed weed in New Zealand. ... Of the fourteen districts into which the country was divided, `Cali' was considered one of the three worst weeds in on fewer than twelve. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,186,1967 ed.)

creeping thistle [=] Californian thistle [s] Ibid. 78 thistle, creeping [=] Californian thistle [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,17)

ELL Californian thistle is also known as the creeping thistle, for the way it spreads. (1983,Wildflowers and Weeds,13)

HILGENDORF CALIFORNIAN THISTLE (Cirsium arvense) is also called Canadian thistle, and sometimes field thistle or creeping thistle. It is probably [was some years ago,] the most discussed weed in New Zealand. ... Of the fourteen districts into which the country was divided, `Cali' was considered one of the three worst weeds in on fewer than twelve. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,186,1967 ed.)

Caduus arvensis, English corn thistle (the so-called Californian thistle of the settlers). (1895,TrNZI,27/407)

Californian Thistle, or Canada Thistle (Australia and New Zealand); Corn Thistle or Green Thistle (England); Canada Thistle (United States of America); Canada or Cursed Thistle (Canada) Cnicus arvensis. (1894,Leaflets for Farmers,No.4/1)

Californian Thistle, or Canada Thistle (Australia and New Zealand); Corn Thistle or Green Thistle (England); Canada Thistle (United States of America); Canada or Cursed Thistle (Canada) Cnicus arvensis. (1894,Leaflets for Farmers,No.4/1)

I spend an hour grubbing thistles... Only the scotch ones. The others, californian and so on, I spray. (May 12, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

In the meantime the horses and oxen of the milling lessees are being fed on oats infested with Californian thistle seed. The settler writes as follows:- 'I spent the whole of last summer fighting Californians. (1913,NZ Journal of Agriculture,7/250)

The Californian thistle.. is provingexceedingly valuable to farmers inHawke's Bay this season. (Jan 21, 1915,Stratford Evening Post,4)

The seed [cocksfoot] is of excellent quality .. it is entirely free from Californian thistle ... (Feb 18, 1888,Eight Daughters,7)

BRABAZON 3 patches of Californian thistle seen. (Apr 30, 1907,Brabazon Diaries)

The other day I happened to see a mower at work cutting down a heavy growth of Californians, the machine being followed by the plough. (May 1909,NZ Farmer,396)

Like most other farmers in Southland I have come to regard the Californian thistle as like the poor, always with us. (Aug 1912,NZ Farmer,948)

CONNELL & HADFIELD With the exception of certain weeds, such as Californian thistle, sorrel and blackberry, the farmer has more to fear from the weed seeds in the ground than from the growing weeds. (1961,Agriculture,242)

Californian thistle is the only perennial thistle in New Zealand. (Apr 9, 2001,Fencepost.com,Expert Farmer)

Growing thickly, all around, absolutely untouched, were Californian thistles, one of the worst pests in the whole country. (Jan 26, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,47)

Noise mad motor-cyclists... are a pestiferous nuisance and the sooner they are eradicated along with Californian thistles, fireblight.. and other minor evils, the sooner will the citizenry be rid of a fruitful source of bad temper and righteous indignation. (May 16, 1928,NZ Free Lance,6)

The most satisfactory way of dealing with the Californian thistle is to prevent any green leaf reaching the surface for a whole season. (Feb 2, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,73)

Could you prescribe a cure for Californian thistle? (Feb 25, 1943,NZ Farmers' Weekly,34)

STEWART When we rode through the beastly Californian thistles that everywhere infested the farm the prickles stuck themselves into our bare feet and legs; and Californian thistles always fester. (1991,Springtime in Taranaki,87)

BALLANTYNE "He said it's been awful with the Californian thistle up there this year." (1948,Cunninghams, The,17)

BALLANTYNE "He said it's been awful with the Californian thistle up there this year." (1948,Cunninghams, The,17) [NOTES: Pagination from 1976 edition]

2 n. californian thistle

2 n. californian thistle, a New Zealand name for creeping thistle, originally from Europe

2 n. Canadian thistle, creeping thistle, field thistle

Californian thistle [s] Cirsium arvense (L.) Scop. Ibid. 78 thistle, Californian [s] Cirsium arvense (L.) Scop. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,10)

STEWART When we rode through the beastly Californian thistles that everywhere infested the farm the prickles stuck themselves into our bare feet and legs; and Californian thistles always fester. (1991,Springtime in Taranaki,87)

call¶

v. to give the broadcast commentary; to describe a race between horses etc.; to broadcast a commentary on a race; cf race-caller, -ing.

[sc. to commentate on radio etc] Quinn's case is interesting. After a long stint in radio he became the NZBC's first `sole charge' television rugby commentator, calling his first test match at home in 1973 and away in 1974. (Aug 23, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),35)

[sc. Radio/TV commentary] Don't expect Television New Zealand to call foul on basketball's motor-mouth commentator, Marshall Seifert. Seifert's one-eyed call of the national men's basketball final last weekend left many Canterbury fans seething. (Aug 24, 1986,Sunday News,23)

: introduction to Canadian/Tongan Rugby Union game [sc. a race, a sporting fixture] Calling today's game is Keith Quinn ... (May 24, 1987,TV1)

Bill McCarthy, the acting head of sport for TVNZ told me that good commentators are hard to find. Some of the best and most hyped-up commentators in this country are Americans who call the American-originated sports. (Jul 22, 1987,Contact (Wgtn),16)

Yesterday, co-commentator and close friend John McBeth had to call the game for Television New Zealand at 10 minutes' notice. (Jun 21, 1998,Sunday Star Times,A2)

It will be interesting to see who dominates but I put my money on Hosking, who talks so fast he sounds like he's calling it at Trentham, which is just the ticket for election night when the votes come in. (Jul 8, 2002,Dominion Post,B11)

1 n. (Rural) a list of competitors in dog trialling.

GORDON .. the rural broadcaster of the parish where the champs are being held, would be presented with the call at that stage of the trial. The call is a list of the top seven competitors and their dogs in each of the four events. (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,16)

call bird¶

1 n. (Rural) a caged or tethered kea used to call others for capture.

MACFARLANE The bird we had as a 'call bird' at a hunt got loose one morning. (1931,Farming: Facts, Faults & Fancies,23)

MCKENZIE If they are within easy approach and not killers but nibblers, simply mimic the 'call-kea' and they will come right up close enough to be shot. (1951,Wakatipu Pioneers,99)

MCLEOD We had two call birds and one of us would camp in one place with one bird ... (1951,NZ High Country,41)

STACEY Arthur later sold the captives [keas] as call birds for two pounds 10 shillings each ... [call-bird; call-kea] (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,72)

NEWTON My belief that all I had to do was climb some sunny knob, tether my call bird and wait for the birds to come to me, was soon shattered. (1947,Wayleggo,44)

LOUGHNAN A good well-balanced load of musterer's swags and food had been surmounted by a parrot's cage containing the station's call-bird. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,36)

call in¶

v.

SLATTER There was [postal] work [in the 1960s], hard satisfying work. Unloading parcel bags, huge cumbersome containers nicknamed pre-fabs, from a three-door Z. There was slots, there was lumps, there was packing fragies in bottles, there was the tying down of the north line for a clearance, the scissors, lead seals and squeezers. The sorters on call-back flicking circulars with precision. The volcanoes of letters on the facing-up table, the checker chanting the reds onto the lorry, the checker calling the overseas in, London 45 ... The queue of men working at the parcel depot or the postal siding ... Tieing down the cargon. ... The sorters' school at the posties' pub known colloquially as Box 44 or the B.B.C., the Back Bar of the Cecil. The cheerful abuse of cobbers. (1985,Pagan Game, The,85)

The judge called in [x] fourth. What a race - the H.R.Chalmers 2400. (Mar 14, 1987,TV1) [NOTES: TV1 racing commentator]

call one's lug¶

phr. [(the point of the expression is, I think, is call, which may mean shout in ; call into' perhaps confused with the quasi-transitive form ofcall (a person's) bluff'. The expression as a whole, however, may mean something like bite (a person's) ear off ; chew the lug off' -talk pointedly' sarcastically too much and too loud; nag viciously').] (See cf. bite)

If you'll only listen in',/ You will hear himcall' some fellows lug:/ `Why don't you join up and dig in.'/ (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,70)

call the game in¶

phr. to cease doing something; to admit that one has had enough (phr. from cards or sport on analogy of analogy of call something off' andthrow one's hand, the sponge in'; or call in one's bets, or credit ora mortgage' =`foreclose' etc).

PARTRIDGE Call the game in. To cease doing something; to admit one has had enough: NZ coll: f. ca1912. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,121)

BAKER To call the game in, to cease any activity, has been current since early in the twentieth century. (1941,NZ Slang,53)

call-back¶

n. be on call-back (sc. at ? rushtimes)

SLATTER There was [postal] work [in the 1960s], hard satisfying work. Unloading parcel bags, huge cumbersome containers nicknamed pre-fabs, from a three-door Z. There was slots, there was lumps, there was packing fragies in bottlos, there was the tying down of the north line for a clearance, the scissors, lead seals and squeezers. The sorters on call-back flicking circulars with precision. The volcanoes of letters on the facing-up table, the checker chanting the reds onto the lorry, the checker calling the overseas in, London 45 ... The queue of men working at the parcel depot or the postal siding ... Tieing down the cargon. ... The sorters' school at the posties' pub known colloquially as Box 44 or the B.B.C., the Back Bar of the Cecil. The cheerful abuse of cobbers. (1968,Pagan Game, The,85)

call-leaf¶

n.

Berries of the karamu... were used as bait ... while the pepe, or call-leaf, was also employed to lure birds to this snare-mounted perch. (1910,TrNZI,42/480)

call-out¶

n.

KEINZLY `There's always strike talk. There always will be on big jobs like these. When you've got so many conditions covering so many different sections of the workers; when you've got height money, wet money, dirt money, gum-boot money; when you've got call-outs and twenty different opinions on what constitutes wet time; when men are rained off ...' (1960,Tangahano,79)

calla lily¶

n. = arum lily (introduced)

lily, calla [=] arum lily [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,44)

caller¶

n. a race commentator (See also race-caller)

Now, as the caller of most races in the north, and part-owner of the highly successful McGinty, he is perhaps the best-known commentator in the country. (Jun 16, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

callie¶

n. California quail

California Quail Lophortyx californica brunnescens RIDGWAY, 1884 ...OTHER NAMES: Californian quail, callie. ... Since it was introduced successfully into New Zealand betwen 1862 and 1880 the California quail has been a popular game bird. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,159)

Callithumpian¶

n. [Jeff Sheerin, Statistics dept, Census returns: some put down Callithumpian under Religion: classed as RELIGION, JOCULAR. Seems a new Dvt in NZ: OED, EDD definition rather different.1989 Apr 15]

callover¶

n.

Picture 1.. shows the 46 members of the Dunedin Stock Exchange in August 1900 at a "callover"... In the callover era, telephones were discouraged because they were thought unfair. (Apr 19, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),60)

cally¶

n. Californian thistle

n. a call bird

SUTTON-SMITH The birds were shot with guns and shanghais, or trapped with bird lime and other traps. To catch them with bird lime, the lime was put on willow sticks which were lain over the cage of the call bird, or `cally.' When the bird alighted on the stick, he stuck fast. (1981,History of Children's Play,119)

Cally, the¶

n. the Caledonian sportsground in Dunedin [a familiar local shortening of the Caledonian Sports Ground, Dunedin [check correct full name from G. Griffiths]] (See also Cale,Calley)

ALLEN ... The Cally (1936,Poor Scholar,18)

WHITWORTH [Father] took me ... to the Caledonian Grounds on New Year's Day. `Where are ye going to on New Year's day? Oot to the Calley, oot to the Calley.' (1950,Otago Interval,51)

LEE `Where are you going on New Year's Day?/ Oot to the Cale. (Caledonian Grounds),/ To hear John Hogg and hear his pipers play,/ Oot at the Cale.' (1934,Children of the Poor,14,1949 ed.)

caltha¶

n. Caltha novae-zelandiae.

FEATON CALTHA NOVAE ZELANDIAE (Hook.F.) The New Zealand Caltha. ... The `NATIVE CALTHA'. ... (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,10)

;LAING & BLACKWELL (And) (1906,Plants of NZ)

COCKAYNE (And) (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island]

n. Caltha obtusa

MARK & ADAMS Caltha obtusa Cheesem WHITE CALTHA. A low-growing herb ... (1973,NZ Alpine Plants,44)

n. Caltha novae-zelandiae

MARKS & ADAMS Caltha novae-zelandiae Hook. f. YELLOW CALTHA (1973,NZ Alpine Plants,44,1979 ed.)

WILSON Caltha novae-zelandiae ... YELLOW CALTHA ... New Zealand marsh marigold ... Small, hairless rosettes ... Flowers pale yellow ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,274)

calve¶

v. to help with or oversee the birth of calves [Jim writes: cf lamb down in DNZE. Not in NSOD or Collins in this sense.]

He was calving so plans were changed. (Oct 1997,Growing Today,15)

calve down¶

v. (Rural) [dairy cows] to produce calves.

The grazing must also be of consistent high quality to ensure the herd will calve down in at least as good as, and preferably better, body condition that they would normally have when wintered at home. (May 18, 2001,Fencepost.com,Expert Farmer)

calving jack¶

n.

...calving jack... (Apr 28, 2004,Wairarapa News,28)

calving paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) the location where station cows are kept at calving.

Calving paddocks can be one to three hours' ride from station quarters. (Jun 1, 1994,NZ Farmer,29)

calving pulley¶

n.

...calving pulley... (Apr 28, 2004,Wairarapa News,28)

calving rope¶

n.

SUTHERLAND Uncle Angus tied a calving rope to the [unborn calf's] foot, and forced the calf's head back again. ... With Alma [the calving cow] heaving Uncle Angus worked the head and the front feet out. He fixed the loose end of the calving rope to the other foot. (1978,Elver, The,47)

Camel Brigade¶

n.

POWLES The Camel Brigade were the greatest sufferers, for the one thing a camel hates is slippery mud; "and when he comes to greasy ground he splits himself in two. Ibid. 202 A heavy counter-attack fell upon the junction between the New Zealanders and the Camels. (1922,New Zealanders in Sinai & Palestine,198) [NOTES: Camels were also called cacolets - the real camels, that is.]

POWLES On the left of the NZ Brigade., the Camels, the infantry and the 2nd Light Horse.. had been desperately attacking all day. (1928,History of the Canterbury Regiment,212)

Camel Company¶

n.

POWLES This work [sc. of constantly patrolling] was undertaken by the Imperial Camel Corps Brigade, which had been formed from New Zealand, Australian, and Yeomanry reinforcements... New Zealand contributed two companies, the first of which - the 15th Camel Company - was formed in July [1915]. (1922,New Zealanders in Sinai & Palestine,47)

camel hump¶

n. a judder bar

He had been seen by a traffic officer driving across the centre of the road over a `camel hump'. (Nov 2, 1972,Marlborough Express,2)

camel scrub¶

n. a type of scrub growing in the North African desert.

BRUNO The chameleon was to be found in the camel-scrub. (1944,Desert Daze,43)

cameliers¶

n. Members of the WWI Camel Corps

HOGUE Like a column of spectres the Cameliers glided noiselessly down the wadi bed. (1919,Cameliers, The,68)

ROBERTSON The Australian and New Zealand "Cameliers" well upheld their traditions in the battle of Megiddo. Ibid. 10. The Australian and New Zealand Cameliers said goodbye to their camels, which had carried them in comfort over desert and wilderness. Ibid. 116 Interest was lent to these ticking parades by Cameliers laying bets as to whose animal would provide the record number of ticks for the day. (1938,With the Cameliers in Palestine,8)

camels¶

n. Turkish or Egyptian cigarettes (from their odour)

PARTRIDGE 2. Turkish, or Egyptian, cigarettes: NZ soldiers': in G.W. Ex their odour. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,122)

n.

MARSHALL Creamy was even better with the aluminium ones [sc. knuckle bones]. Cutting cabbages, camels, swatting flies, clicks, little jingles, through the arch, goliath, horses in the stable; Creamy mastered them all. (1982,Master of Big Jingles,55)

camels' bile¶

n. cheap `hard liquor' or plonk (esp. if overproof); cf crocodile's tears, purple death, rooster's blood.

[check citation] He should be able to hold his liquor ... even Purple Death, [Crocodiles' Tears and Camels' Bile]. (1946,Johnny Enzed in Italy,53)

camos¶

n. camouflage patterned clothing [rarely camo]

I've considered growing a beard, dashing up the road to the army surplus store to get some camos and wandering about the neighbourhood wielding my slug gun. (Apr 3, 2010,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

Boys also get into the swing of the season with vests, retro-inspired striped and check shorts, as well as the must-have military shirt and camos. (2010,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.gloss.co.nz/Fashion/trends-now/Kidswear-trends.html]

camowhaiwhai¶

n.

With one suite of paintings, though, his barbs arrive right on target. In the paintings that he calls his "Camowhaiwhai", McLeod merges traditional kowhaiwhai designs with military camouflage and renders the result as a paint-by-numbers exercise. (Jul 31, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),39)

camp¶

v.

Camp.-As transitive verb, e.g. to c. the sheep. -----A shearer's expression meaning to go slow (so as to let a pen mate in for a bad cobbler). (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13) [NOTES: (Acland]

ACLAND Camp (1) As transitive verb, e.g., to camp the sheep. (2) A shearer's expression meaning to go slow - so as to let a pen mate in for a cobbler. (q.v.) (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,360)

n. In NZ as elsewhere the usual word for (1) `The temporary quarters formed by tents ...' (OED2 4. a) (esp. as applied to mining, Public Works, forestry camps, or temporary settlements); and (2) An encamping; a camping out.' (OED2 5.). Freq. in NZ use

F. MATHEW After a walk of about four hours we returned thoroughly fagged, and were glad to rest for a while at the native camp. (Feb 27, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Feb 27 F.Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 65]

v. (Rural) [shearing] to slow down to allow one's penmate to gain the catch, i.e. the last sheep in the catching pen.

LOUGHNAN camp: a shearer camps when he slows down to allow his penmate to gain the catch. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,15)

v. (Rural) to accommodate sheep overnight.

WESTMACOTT We camped the sheep at the edge of the bush and arrived home a little after dark. (Jul 25, 1914,Letter,189) [NOTES: in Westmacott (1977) The After-Breakfast Cigar]

v. to rest, to assemble, usu. at a preferred place (See also encamp)

PHARAZYN Inspected Ewes and Hogs, the former all camped on the left hand hill. (1846,Journal,40 (et pass))

[? they =sheep; ? =drovers] I was with the sheep till 8 p.m. when they camped and I turned into the tent till 1 when my watch began. (Mar 13, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,80,1950 ed.)

PHILLIPS Hastily collecting a small but heroic band of attendants ... she [Lady Barker] sallied forth and mustered the Hills in person - reporting fewer casualities [sic in TS] among the `jambucks' [sic in TS] who were camped there than she had dared to hope - (Aug 9, 1867,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,112)

MOWATT On 24 December 1909 a mob of 5,600 shorn hoggets were taken from Molesworth to the sheep yards ... where they camped for the night. (Dec 24, 1909,Diary) [NOTES: 1909 Dec 24 Mowatt Diary in 1969 McCaskill Molesworth 104]

BLAKISTON Merino ewes always camp just below the highest top on what they regard as their own piece of country, ... (1952,My Yesteryears,31) [NOTES: [f. c1869]]

camp ... 2. v.i ... NZ & Austral. (of livestock) assemble for rest or at night. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,102) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

v. to assemble sheep for the night or an extended rest.

We followed [the cattle] ... and drove them over the Timooka and camped them on a triangle formerly the junction of the Timooka and Opihi ... (Apr 21, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,33,1950 ed.)

We took [the cattle] on 8 miles and camped them in a bite bounded on three sides by 40ft. of perpendicular cliff. (May 15, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,87,1950 ed.)

BUTLER You can camp under the dray at night. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,118)

PHILLIPS Camped sheep on Washpen Hill. (Nov 27, 1868,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,169)

MACDONALD [?v.t.] And footrot appears through the dry-foot loving sheep being camped ... too long on damp ground. (1915,NZ Sheepfarming,120)

AYSON ... as there were wild dogs about I had to follow the lambs about all day, bringing them home at night to camp them near the homestead and sometimes in the yards. That is what they call in Australia `tailing', as the dingoes were very bad in the early days. (1937,Pioneering in Otago,40)

On inland northerly and westerly situations ... these breaks develop successively in definite steps or benches. ... This problem is very real in holding-paddocks and on hillsides that are frequently used as access routes. ... Near the crests of hills sheep aggravate the position by camping on these terracettes ... (1946,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,27/159)

ACLAND Camp (1) As transitive verb, e.g., to camp the sheep. (2) A shearer's expression meaning to go slow - so as to let a pen mate in for a cobbler. (q.v.) (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,360)

1 v. (Rural) [sheep] to congregate, moving to dry and high ground in the evening, known as the ''evening rise.''

CONNELL & HADFIELD On steep hill country which is not topdressed the stock tend to move along a few tracks following the contours and to camp in a few specially attractive places like broad ridges and around lone trees. (1961,Agriculture,317)

Sheep which camp together are also said to 'break camp' when they move off to feed at dawn. (Sep 16, 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

NEWTON He was relieved to find the sheep still camping undisturbed. (1949,High Country,71) [NOTES: ?High Country Days]

GASCOIGNE I mean that the sheep camp on those ridges and every night they are carting the good from the slopes upstairs with them and leaving it on the camps. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,130)

LOUGHNAN camp: sheep will settle down for the night in groups and always on the same spot. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,15)

2 v. to establish a permanent resting-place

MEREDITH The wild dogs had been among the sheep, and were evidently camped in the ranges at the back of the outstation, as we could hear them howling quite close at night. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,65) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 65]

2 n. a place where people on holiday or itinerants camp; now often a motor camp

3 n.

In the event of such a camp.. being established in connection with the Forestry Department, what arrangements would be made in respect to medical attendance? (1913,AJHR,C-12/69)

3 n. a sheltered place where sheep or cattle regularly congregate; a resting or assembly place (of sheep or cattle), see also sheep camp.

Reached Ontopope in good time but we could not get a good camp and the consequence was the cattle broke camp at the back in my watch ... (May 17, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,87,1950 ed.)

BEATTIE In connection with stock the following terms were used: - Let the sheep draw down to the Taieri';stags,' crawlers,'stragglers,' a horse with couples in his mouth,'the bull baked on the road,' cut and tailed,'lagoon washing,' spaying cattle,'killed a pleuro,' herding lambs,'buisting weaners,' `a camp for the cattle,' ... (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,85) [NOTES: [1858-1869] Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 85]

FERGUSON The ewes in camp all safe and fast/ And all the lambs composed at last./ (1883,Castle Gay,193)

... the sheep have favourite places for sleeping ... These spots are called `camps' ... (1907,TrNZI,39/291)

FERGUSON (1891,Bush Life in Australia & NZ,170) [NOTES: (Aust ?)]

Where sheep `camp' there is invariably abundance of Marrubium vulgare, and perhaps Urtica urens. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,358)

BURDON After deep snow has fallen, the sheep are found stuck in their `camps' in greatly varying numbers, according to the kind of country and the time of the year. (1938,High Country,156)

LYON One of these men on a beef hunt, could head straight for the [wild-cattle's] camp and get there by the shortest route over steep ridges and gullies. (1952,Faring South,101)

camp n. temporary resting place, place for mustering cattle; camp v. often in composition with `out' to camp-out, sleep in the open air, whence n. camper-out, camping-out. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),613)

(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,158)

camp ... 7. Austral. a place where sheep or cattle gather to rest. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,102)

LEVY Bare-ground camps may be the inevitable outcome of a high carrying capacity, without full control of all feed in the early summer when the camp weeds come to flower, and seed. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,300,1970 ed.)

camp bed¶

n. [?Include with an entry in freq. use - ??with camp-stretcher; light bed made by stretching wire-netting across a frame, the whole supported by folding legs; sometimes, a light bed which folds in half, ca1900 at least] (See cf. bush stretcher,camp stretcher)

NEAVE We had [in 1858] an old tent pitched inside and had about half a bale of pieces as a field bed. ... after wading through the Ahuriri we had to take off our pants before making a camp bed of shingle and snowgrass. (1980,Land of Munros, The,65) [NOTES: 1917 James Strachan Experiences (Hocken L.) in 1980 Neave The Land of Munros 65]

camp bread¶

n. as camp-oven bread [ca1900 Jane Morison]

camp down¶

v.

BUTLER I was afraid to go out, and camping down, waited for daylight. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,96)

camp kid¶

n.

Most of these children went to Khandallah School and were known as the 'camp kids'. Homebush Road had no name that I recall during the depression, so the camp kids called it the 'old clay road'. (Aug 2004,NZ Memories,31)

Camp Leader¶

n. a creation of the Topp Twins

Their songs have entered the nation's consciousness and the characters they have created - Ken and Ken, Prue and Dilly, Camp Mother and Camp leader - are part of the lexicon of Kiwiana. (Jun 3, 2001,Sunday Star Times,D9)

camp on¶

v. to stay as guests for a long time with; to overstay one's welcome with (a person, a household); to make a convenience of a person's house (as though it were a camping-ground; ?or like stock). [ca1930 at least e.g. They arrived on the Saturday and camped on us for three whole weeks. We almost had to tell them to go.]

camp oven¶

1 n. (Rural) [mustering, bush work and exploration] a three-legged cast iron pot, with a flat lid, used in an open fire.

He sat down and had a refreshing drink oftea and a slice of camp-oven bread. (Jul 31, 1912,Otago Witness,17)

Ex "Samarang"... Camp Ovens, KitchenRanges and Boilers. (Dec 11, 1852,Lyttelton Times,11)

It was a great day when Grandfather brought home a camp over, and when later still a colonial oven was installed, Grandmother felt that life had little more to offer. (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,211) [NOTES: Writing of 1940]

CHAMIER I prefer the camp oven, with a little baking soda and acid, just enough to make the bread rise without discolouring it. (1891,Philosopher Dick,225)

WEEKES ... camp oven and gypsy kettles. (1842,Journal,4/3)

WEEKES (Feb 25, 1842,Journal) [NOTES: 1842 Feb 25 Weekes Journal in 1940 Rutherford and Skinner 1 VII/118]

BRADEY I bought a camp oven. (May 30, 1844,Papers)

WEEKES Our cooking, as with most early settlers, was now an open-air affair with camp-oven and gypsy kettles. (1846,My Island) [NOTES: c1846 Weekes My Island in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 118]

It is of little use bothering with household furniture, except a couple of pots, a small camp oven, a time piece, ... (Apr 16, 1849,Letters from Otago,32,1978 ed.)

LUSH Learned how to make bread with flour, buttermilk and carbonate of soda, baked in a camp oven - tasted some ...and thought it as nice as `Sally Lunn'. (Oct 25, 1850,Auckland Journals,30,1971 ed.)

A wooden house, with a shingle roof ... pannikins and pots a few, two packing-cases and a log, A cupboard - all bereft of prog - A tripod pot for boiling - a big camp-oven. (Feb 15, 1851,Lyttelton Times,8)

Item, a tripod pot for boiling -/ A big camp oven, used for spoiling/ Good water and good meal; ... (Aug 22, 1851,Lyttelton Times,8)

We bought a large camp oven 68lbs at 3 1/2 per lb. Ibid. I/136 Harry and I went down to the Beach House and opened our tool cask ...[sic] we bought a large camp oven ..., 3 English-American axes 7/- each and billhooks 5/-. (Oct 22, 1853,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/35) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

ON SALE ... camp ovens ... (Mar 29, 1857,Lyttelton Times,8)

My beautiful new camp-oven cracked right in two. (1860,Taranaki Punch,5/2)

BUTLER We carried down a kettle, a camp oven, some flour, tea, sugar, and salt beef; ... also two cats. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,7/111) [NOTES: 1860 in 1863 Butler First Year vii/111]

Z.W.WELLS Bought tin [25] dish for camp oven 3/-. (Dec 5, 1861,Diary,24,(TS 1970) ed.)

LUSH ... I was suggesting using their camp-ovens till they could afford to buy a boiler - (Apr 11, 1866,Waikato Journals,82,1982 ed.)

PRENTICE Our domestic economy was at first unique, the cooking gear comprised ... a frying pan and a circular iron pot called a camp-oven ... pot lids serving as plates and dishes with tin pannikins to drink from. (1870,Tale of NZ,32)

MEREDITH As for culinary arrangements [in camp], there is the indispensable `billy' for tea, and for boiling water generally; a kerosene-tin for carrying and storing water, etc.; and a camp-oven, which is the general cooker. It is an iron pot about fifteen inches diameter, six inches deep, with straightly sloping sides, the top being about an inch or so wider than the bottom. The lid is slightly concave on the lower side, and has a looped handle on top at the centre. The whole is either slung over the fire by means of a big, looped handle, the ends of which are loosely affixed to loops on the outer sides of the oven or stood over coals. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,29,1935 ed.) [NOTES: 1872 Oct in c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 29]

THATCHER Camp ovens, sperm candles, and bill-hooks and sickles; (1875,NZ Songster,No. 5/49) [NOTES: c1875? Thatcher Life of a Auctioneer in NZ Songster No.5/49]

STEWART [1888 Kati Kati] Our colonial oven showed signs of old age ... and what was I to do? ... Tinker Simmonds ... showed me how to use a `camp-oven' - a 15-inch round iron pot on legs, and with a handle, so that it could either stand or hang. (1908,My Simple Life in NZ,105)

MALTHUS A dixie of tea (one of those big old oval ones made of cast iron, like a camp oven) arrived for our platoon. (1965,ANZAC,85) [NOTES: 1915 May 31-June 9 in 1965 Malthus ANZAC 85]

MANDER Just then his eye rested on a heavy iron camp oven set on the hearth. ... `Mrs. Roland ... are you lifting that oven about?' (1920,Story of a NZ River, The,52,1920 ed.)

Camp oven. An iron pot with three short legs and a flat top, so that it can be used to boil, bake, or fry in. It is a convenient utensil but heavy to carry and awkward to pack on a horse. (C.) (Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

SOLJAK New Zealanders have coined or adapted many expressions to meet local requirements, as illustrated by the following: ... camp oven: three-legged iron pot used for all forms of cooking by early settlers (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),117)

NEWTON Camp oven: A broad, rather shallow iron `pot.' It has three short legs and a handle like that of a bucket. Very good for cooking mutton. (1949,High Country Days,193,1950 ed.)

CRESSWELL ... Mrs Godley and young Arthur stretched their legs in the Port and had an open-air dinner of camp-oven mutton, potatoes and cabbage. (1951,Canterbury Tales,21)

CRUMP I insisted on having the camp-oven left empty for me one night. (1960,Good Keen Man, A,46)

MASTERS Among materials and gear carried in along the rugged scrub lined track, were rolls of malthoid and wirenetting, cement and iron, dressed timber for cupboards, door and table, axes, a crosscut saw, a big cast-iron camp-oven, window and various other things. (1960,Back-Country Tales,29)

JOSEPH We baked our own bread in a camp-oven, and lived mainly on that and fish and billy-tea. (1962,Pound of Saffron, A,12)

HELMER He spooned used beef dripping into the camp oven and swung it over the flames. (1964,Stag Party,81)

BURTON A refinement of open roasting was the Dutch or camp oven, a 38-centimetre round iron pot with legs and a handle so that it could either stand or hang. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,23)

camp oven n. Austral. & NZ a metal pot or box with a heavy lid, used for baking over an open fire. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,158) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 102; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 68]]

HOGAN We buried Old Frank by the Kowhai,/ Our champion camp oven cook. (1962,Billy-Can Ballads,6)

HUNT One day I took in a camp oven and a twenty-five of flour on my back. (1981,Speaking a Silence,103)

Our women used to bake bread beautifully in a camp oven - oh, it was good. (Jun 4, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

Tell your mother to bring pots and pans and a camp oven for baking bread. (Dec 4, 1890,Otago Witness,31) [NOTES: From Nov. 1849 issue of Otago Journal, published in Edinburgh]

It took a bit of a search to find camp ovens for sale, but I finally landed this one at Doyles for $29.95... Camp ovens are made of cast-iron so need to be protected from rust... My next project is to improve on the camp oven baking that I've tried so far... My sister's family are also old hands at camp oven cooking on summer holidays,though their oven has gathered dust for a few years now. (Jan 20, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

Although a camp oven can also be used as a pot, it special character comes from using it as a small oven, with the top heat provided by embers lifted onto the lid... [Dorothy Leonard] writes that cooking in a camp oven nestled into hot embers with more piled on top is "like cooking in an old coal range without a gauge. Your hand tells you the temperature." (Mar 17, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),40)

We had nothing but camp ovens to cook in. (Sep 17, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

The cooking apparatus used to be very primitive.., the camp-oven and the three-legged pot comprising the outfit. (Oct 8, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7)

WEEKES Our cooking was now an open-air affair .. with a camp-oven and gypsy kettles. (1846,BLANK ENTRY,118) [NOTES: in Rutherford & Skinner (1940) New Plymouth Settlement]

Camp oven, an iron pot with three short legs and a flat top, so that it can be used to boil, bake or fry in. (Sep 23, 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),13)

WILSON Road to Porongahau 41 Sixty years ago some country homes were still using colonial ovens, which had superseded the camp ovens, except in bush camps. (1962,Road to Porangahau, The,41)

I used a camp oven for two years. (May 25, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,24)

He made a billy of tea and cooked a flapjack in the camp oven. (Feb 12, 1924,Otago Witness,73)

EDWARDS I've a big rewena bread for lunch, madein the camp oven, brown and crusty. (1992,Mihipeka,29)

Nowadays, musters are completed in days using helicopters and 4WDs. Hob-nailed boots, billy tea and camp ovens have been replaced by GPS locators, energy drinks and Vibram rubber soles. (Feb 20, 2010,Your Weekend,8)

The focus is on food of the 1830s, which Barbara describes as camping food. It was cooked over a fire, using cast-iron camp ovens or flat girdles, a style of cooking already familiar to the Scottish settlers. (Apr 19, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

OWEN & PERKINS The camp oven disappeared, the windows were blown out, and the table was blown over. (1986,Southern Cross (Wgton),19)

They faced no easy task when one remembers the bush, etc., and that tents, camp oven, candles or kerosene lamp., and a shortage of stores was the order of the day. (1957,Mangamaire School,29)

OWEN & PERKINS On the ground in front of the fire would be the great camp ovens; these were twenty-four inches wide and eight or nine inches deep, standing on short legs. Coals of fire were shovelled under the camp oven or poured on top to give the necessary heat. And that's where the cook did his baking. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,153)

There'd be an open fireplace and a camp oven. They were round, cast iron, with a lid, on three legs., You made a bed of charcoal, and put the oven on it, then put hot coals on the lid, too. You could do a leg of mutton, bread, puddings, anything. (Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,22)

camp over¶

v.

camping over or camping over the station: The expression used when a shearer chooses to stay on the farm waiting for wet sheep to dry (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/22) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

v.

I am told that some person at present camping over on the ground has ordered timber for the floor of his tent as he is going to stay permanently. (Sep 28, 1939,Te Aroha Times,5)

camp pie¶

n.

CAMP PIE Chop cold beef ... add pepper and salt; make gravy of the bones; put ... the whole in a piedish, and add mashed potato. Beat up an egg with flour, pour it on the top, and bake ... (1902,Brett's Colonists Guide,833)

camp site¶

n.

BUICK This camp site also is involved in another interesting problem. (1937,Moa-Hunters of NZ,132)

2 n.

Variegated thistle established on a stock camp site under a tree. (Aug 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,141) [NOTES: (OEDS)]

camp stew¶

n.

The guest also sang in a manner which demonstrated that camp stew and early rising is good for the voice as well as for bodily fitness. (Jun 5, 1917,Otautau Standard,3)

The once derided camp stew, soldier boots, uniforms, food, and everything else liable to criticism is known as "Massey's." (Oct 2, 1918,Poverty Bay Herald,9)

camp stretcher¶

n.

And long after I got on to my camp stretcher in the corner, Mr Larsen and Uncle stayed up playing cribbage ... (1987,Listener Short Stories,2/37) [NOTES: 1956 Middleton in 1978 Listener Short Stories Vol 2 37]

KIDMAN Billy brings the camp stretcher in, dangling it under one big arm as if it is a box of matches. ... But it turns out that Billy has forgotten how to put it up and gets the struts jammed the wrong way round ... (1983,Paddy's Puzzle,115)

camp tucker¶

1 n. (Rural) of mustering and hunting, food foraged from the environment, to be eaten in that environment.

HOLDEN Only Tony made good, shooting a hind and yearling for 'camp tucker' within easy walking distance from the camp. (1996,Great Hunting Yarns,183)

camp weed¶

1 n. (Rural) a weed that germinates and grows at stock camps, carried there by dung or the feet of stock.

LEVY Bare-ground camps may be the inevitable outcome of a high carrying capacity, without full control of all feed in the early summer when the camp weeds come to flower and seed. Chemical weedkillers, including any chemical differential grasskillers, are a useful adjunct in the control of camp weeds and it is very obvious that, without the control of smother weeds such as wing thistle ... (1970,Grasslands of NZ,300)

camp-keeper¶

n. one of a group appointed to look after a camp.

LINDSAY-BUCKNALL One of our party was to be appointed cook and `campkeeper' week about. (1878,Search for Fortune, A,30)

camp-oven bread¶

n. bread made in a camp oven (See camp oven)

MASTERS She had just cooked a big camp-oven loaf of bread. As she lifted the lid off the camp-oven, something prompted her to look round. [1860's ?] (1959,Tales of the Mails,116)

CHARLES Camp Oven bread [title] Bread in those early days was baked in a camp oven - usually a large, cast-iron pot with a tin lid and short legs; it was placed in the embers and covered with hot ashes. (1981,Black Billy Tea,25)

HUNT (Bill Henderson) We made camp oven bread, too - beautiful. (1985,I'm Ninety-five,28)

OWEN & PERKINS (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country) I've never eaten bread the equal of camp-oven bread. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,153)

BATISTICH Tea from a tin mug, camp-oven bread, hunks of it, hot, running with butter. (1987,Sing Vila in the Mountain,34)

We ate our campoven bread and fat chops, and dream 'd of great flocks to be drafted off every year to boiling-down works. (Aug 7, 1890,Otago Witness,36)

HENDERSON The two men rejoiced at well-cooked meal and fresh new campoven bread. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,135)

Tea from a tin mug, camp-oven bread, hunks of it, hot, running with butter. (1987,Sing Vila in the Mountain,34)

HENDERSON Bill recommended pipi bait fpor sea-run trout and in the mountains would carry a bucket of porridge, dipping into it for a handful to refresh himself for up to a week, plus eels and campoven bread. (1998,From Top to Bottom : Reinga to Bluff,128)

Campbell black-browed albatross¶

n. (Environment)

Campbell black-browed albatross Thalassarche impavida This is a New Zealand variant of the world's commonest albatross (estimated at 500,000 pairs) which breeds only on Campbell Id. It regularly roams further north (to Fiji) than other albatrosses in our region. (2007,NZ Geographic Poster,No 84 Mar-Apr)

Campbell Island pipit¶

n.

Together, these intruders wiped out all the native birds from the main island, such as the Campbell Island pipit, snipe and teal, along with smaller sea birds, including the storm petrel, diving petrel and various prions. (Jul 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 58/88)

Campbell Island shag¶

n. (Environment)

BULLER PHALACROCORAX NYCTHEMERUS. (CAMPBELL-ISLAND SHAG.) (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/167)

Hypoleucus campbelli Filhol. Campbell Island Shag. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/75) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

FALLA et al. CAMPBELL ISLAND SHAG Phalacrocorax campbelli campbelli (1966,Birds of New Zealand,71)

84.c. Leucocarbo campbelli campbelli (Filhol, 1878) Campbell Island Shag (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,33,1980 ed.)

Campbell Island Shag Leucocarbo campbelli (FILHOL, 1878) ... Fewer than 10 000 birds at Campbell Island and adjacent stacks, rocks and islets. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,122)

Campbell Island snipe¶

n. . [tutukiwi] (See tutukiwi)

Campbell Island's snipe flew home from its precarious refuge on tiny Jacquemart Island recently and onto prime-time television news. (May 2005,NZ Geographic,no 73 / page 8)

There are also plans to re-establish a population of the Campbell Island snipe, a diminutive wading bird which was found on a small rock stack off the coast of Campbell island in 1977... (Jan 2001,NZ Geographic,9)

.. [A]nd the Campbell Island snipe/tutukiwi was rediscovered on the island in February having made its own way back from a small offshore rock stack. (Jul 2005,Conservation Action,p 47)

Campbell Island teal¶

n. (Environment) Anas aucklandica nesiotis

Campbell Island teal are a small flightless brown duck and look just like models for the original rubber duck! (Jul 2005,Conservation Action,p 47)

111.c. Anas aucklandica nesiotis (Fleming, 1935) Campbell Island Teal Dent Island, off Campbell Island, in small numbers. (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,38,1980 ed.)

We pass three Campbell Island teal that stand in the shallows of the stream behind the beach. (Sep 30, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),47)

[J.H. Sorensen] later remembered a possible sighting in 1943 of a very rare bird, the Campbell Island teal... This small, brown, more or less flightless duck (Anas aucklandicus nesiotis) now lives only on Dent Island in the Campbell Island group. (Aug 2000,NZWords,No. 4:8)

[Caption] One of the beneficiaries is the flightless Campbell Island teal... (Sep 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 59/58)

The rare Campbell Island teal, a flightless relative of the endangered brown teal, can now be reintroduced. (May 27, 2003,Dominion Post,A5)

Fifty endangered Campbell Island teal will be taken back there next week after an absence of nearly 200 years. (Sep 4, 2004,Dominion Post,A3)

As well as being one of the only refuges for Campbell Island teal, Wellington Zoo is also the only zoo in Australasia that has sucessfully bred sun bears. ... (Jan 28, 2006,Listener (New Zealand Listener),51)

Campbell Islander¶

n. a one-time inhabitant of Campbell Island

In 1969, former inhabitants [sc. of Campbell Island] or Campbell Islanders, were invited to attend a solemn New Zealand rite: Notice to all Campbell Islanders: Rugby game on Saturday next 14 December. (Aug 2000,NZWords,No. 4 : 8)

Notice to all Campbell Islanders: Rugby game on Saturday next 14 December. (Feb 1969,Islander, The,3)

campground¶

n. a holiday camping ground

Campgrounds, aluminium and canvas towns away from town, are part of our birthright. (Jan 14, 2001,Sunday Star Times,D1)

camping¶

1 n.

KENNAWAY But for the sheep there were only a few quiet campings at sunset, and a few dewy mornings to come. (1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,153)

camping: This often occurs when two shearers are catching from one pen. One slows down to force his pen mate to catch the cobbler. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/22) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

LEVY The East Coast country in question is not alone in being denuded of vegetation on the knolls and ridges by the camping of stock. Almost all hill country is subject to damage by intensification of stock camping on the hilltops, and as carrying capacity is built up the problem of the camp becomes more acute. (1951,NZ English Newsletter,32,1970 ed.)

2 n. in NZ and Aust. a holiday spent out of doors in a tent or in a motor camp, or camping-ground; esp. in phrase go camping.

camping ground¶

n. a camp (of sheep) (See cf. break camp,sheep camp)

KENNAWAY `Reached sheep about two o'clock, - rounded them up and began driving at once. Reached our proposed camping-ground about sundown. (1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,111) [NOTES: 1860 Apr 4 notebook in 1874 Kennaway Crusts 111]

BARKER Here and there we saw strings of sheep going down from their high camping-grounds to feed on the sunny slopes and in the warm valleys. (1867,Station Life in NZ,135,1870 ed.)

LADY BARKER (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,4 [freq. passim])

ELWELL They came on some very old camping-grounds where numbers [of sheep] had clearly at one time encamped. (1878,Boy Colonists,182)

GUTHRIE-SMITH [Sheep-paths] are, in fact, roads from a city, for to sheep their camping-ground is as his town to man, at once a refuge and a resting-place. (1926,Tutira,181)

DUFF But always she [an old ewe] is the first in and the first out, the first back up the hill again, and I suspect, though I have not taken the trouble to find out, the first on to the camping ground when the sun sets, and the first off it when day returns. (Feb 21, 1951,Shepherd's Calendar,22,1961 ed.)

They've turned the sheep on the long fern hill .../ Stringing far out to their camping ground in the ti-tree on the ridge./ (1918,New Zealand At the Front,77) [NOTES: (`Diggerland')]

n. a place to camp at; now usu. an area set aside for camping or camping sites.

I have heard a good deal of open grumbling ... and a few small meetings have been held on the wharf, and in the immigrants' camping ground, to consider their position (1861,NZ Goldfields,31,1976 ed.)

LINDSAY-BUCKNALL Having landed our stores and worldly goods, we proceeded next to select a `camping ground.' (1878,Search for Fortune, A,30)

DOMETT In search of some good camping-ground/ They paddled up Mahanas [a2-acute] Lake,/ (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,2/55)

No change took place until we reached the Parerau camping-ground, where there is a patch of bush, and a pretty little stream ... (1897,TrNZI,29/341)

[The wekas] visit every camping ground, investigating the empty tins and sampling the cheese with their sharp beaks almost as tamely as barn door fowls. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,195)

From the above-described camping-ground at the end of the road, the top of the mountain may be reached after ... hard climbing. (1905,TrNZI,37/335)

The resort is on land valued at $280,000 which was formerly occupied by a camping ground and baches paying peppercorn rentals. (Sep 5, 1986,National Business Review,3)

...with all the debate over Wellington's homeless, no one has pointed out that the capital does not provide a camping ground within the city or suburbs. (May 7, 2004,Dominion Post,B6)

Walkways are replacing tracks, holiday homes are suffocating baches, turnstiles are turning up everywhere and camping grounds are disappearing altogether. (Nov 29, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

Charlotte Grimshaw The camping ground was full of caravans and tents, and there were torches on the beach - people fishing or going for a late-night swim. (2007,Six Pack 2, The,66)
