Just before the recent cold snap, South Taranaki camping grounds were in hot demand. (Feb 1, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

COWLEY They found the camping ground quiteeasily. (1991,Bow Down Shadrach,83)

The object of the ground is to provide accommodation for the moving public and it should be left as a camping ground. (Sep 28, 1939,Te Aroha Times,5)

The old camping ground used in the distant past by nomadic tribes of natives.. on the north-western side of Milford Lagoon.. is fast disappearing. (Jan 9, 1940,Otago Daily Times,11)

Camping grounds were where the average Joe could go. (Mar 27, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),60)

1 n. (Rural) a specific place where sheep gather, usually on a rise, in the evening. (See sheep camp)

BARKER On the skyline of the hills could be preceived towards evening, mobs of sheep feeding with their heads up-wind and travelling to the high camping-grounds which they always select in preference to a valley. (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,4)

BARKER Water, and sheltered feed, and undisturbed camping grounds, - all these good things were provided for them, and in return they were expected to yield a large percentage of lambs and a good 'clip.' (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,223)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Amongst the newly dropped lambs, concentrated from dusk to dawn on camping-grounds, great havoc was wrought, the marauders [wild pigs] with returning light retiring to their distant lairs. (1921,Tutira,371)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Tutira 180 From every camp they [sheep-paths] radiate like roads from a city. They are in fact, roads from a city, for a sheep their camping-ground is as town to man, at once a refuge and a resting-place. (1921,Tutira,180)

camping out¶

n.

McHUTCHESON "Camping out! Camping out!"... There is a world of luxury in the thought of "Camping out." (1892,Camp-Life in Fiordland,1)

They say... That "camping out" is very popular just now, but in most cases the phrase is simply a euphemism for seaside life in a furnished cottage. (Feb 13, 1904,NZ Observer,7)

camping-shed¶

n. a shelter in the back-country for trampers, bushmen, explorers, etc.; (tramping) hut.

CRAWFORD Camping-shed on the Waihohona River. [title of an illustration which shows a rough raupo shelter] (1880,Travels in NZ,133)

campion rose¶

n.

rose, campion [s] Lychnis coronaria (L.) Desf. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,65)

camptastic¶

adj.

"The music of the night is unashamedly camptastic gay anthems," Brown continues, "So Kylie, Geri, Gwen Stefani, Mariah, Madonna, Whitney, Tina Cousins and other such divas will feature heavily, and in a departure from many similar events there will be no drag shows, just blatant camp music, cheap drinks and loads of fun." (Jun 29, 2005,Express (Gay & Lesbian Express),7)

campto¶

n. Ochlerotatus camptorhynchus, the southern salt marsh mosquito

Campto's preferred habitat is ephemeral ponds around the high tide line in salt marshes or in low-lying coastal farmland and estuaries... Campto lays individual eggs a few inches above the surface of the water where inundation by a high spring tide or heavy rain triggers hatching. (Jul 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 68/8)

can¶

n. tin:the main early NZ usage for n, v. vbl n, ppl aj for the sealed tinned receptacle for preserving food, though can was perhaps the usual word on the goldfields among diggers until c1880s often enclosed quotation marks as a US or colonial term: twentieth century idiom would prefer tin @v (e.g. tinned fruit, milk) until about WW2, after which can has become more frequent, esp. in the 60s and 70s with ref. to canned beer - tins of beer. (cf Aust. ); cannery `commercial factory' has been in use from at least 1890. cf tinning etc

can off¶

v. have a fall [1984 16 M E65 Pakuranga Coll. 16 CAN OFF [have a fall]]

LELAND `Then he went round the corner and canned off his bike which went on to win the race without him'. Then he went round the corner and fell (violently) off his motorcycle which ... FALL (VIOLENTLY) OFF. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,20)

can out¶

v. to have a fall or spill, capsize [1984 16-17 F E3 Pakuranga Coll. 16 CAN OUT [have a fall] [F5M3] -->1984 14 F E135Wgton Girls C. 16 CAN OUT] (See cf. can off)

LELAND Can out: to OVERTURN one's yacht, canoe, or other WATERBORNE CRAFT under circumstances that imply that this was not your intention. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,20)

can it: shut up can out: capsize (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use)

He fell to the ground. He canned out something chronic. (Jul 11, 2001,Dominion,9)

can stand¶

n. occas. for milk stand (which Anthony also uses).

ANTHONY As I milked each cow in the shed I used to pour the milk into two kerosene tins ... and when they were full I would tote them out to the can-stand. (1924,Follow the Call,10,1975 ed.)

can't say fairer than that¶

phr.

They smirked in the big snow. We sent them a rain-dancing Wizard. Can't say fairer than that. (Jul 30, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

Canada bluegrass¶

n. (See grass)

Canada goose/Canadian goose¶

n. an introduced North American wild goose, Branta canadensis, with an invasive habit, particularly around areas of the South Island high country.

Fish and Game officers in Canterbury say many farmers are too easygoing about small incursions of Canada geese... (Feb 5, 2004,Dominion Post,C7)

Canada geese have become a pest in the high country of the South Island, and they have an uncanny eye for the best of grazing, seeking out our red clover, and the lushest grasses, leaving a continuous trail of droppings, fouling pasture and depriving stock of grazing. (Nov 15, 1999,Evening Post,17)

The Labour Day canada goose cull was on. (Nov 15, 1999,Evening Post,16)

Canada Geese are good eating. Bond says they're vastly superior to duck, being more of a cross between venison and swan. (Jan 19, 2000,Capital Times,8)

Canada geese are long-lived birds. A bird shot by a companion of mine on Molesworth Station a few years ago proved to have been banded more than 30 years previously. (Jun 19, 2004,Dominion Post,E12)

.. Federated Farmers said the canada goose is a pest, and they defile crops, pasture, waterways and wildlife habitats .. A single canada goose produces more excrement than a sheep, with most of that ending up in our waterways. (Oct 13, 2009,Manawatu Standard,A13)

Hares were plentiful, and as we sat and watched the play of light and cloud on the snowline, a flight of canada geese swept into the valley. (May 8, 2000,Evening Post,15)

While summer was traditionally the best time of the year to hunt Canada geese, a survey of local game harvests last year had shown that more geese were taken during the winter season. (Jul 25, 2001,Dominion,15)

For example, the Canada goose, an introduced game species, enjoys some protection but can cause significant damage to crops if it gets too numerous. (Aug 1, 2006,Dominion Post,A8)

He was not long into his journey when he found himself mistaken for Mother Goose, as he was trailed for 20 kilometres by two Canada geese. (Oct 12, 2000,Dominion,12)

It is interesting to see flocks of Canadian geese and New Zealand geese being reared in the upper mountain valleys. (Apr 1, 1924,Otago Witness,71)

NEWTON The Lochinvar flats were a breeding ground for Canadian geese, and in early summer there were flappers by the thousand. (1966,Boss's Story, The,131)

Relph The Canada goose is the only exotic bird to have become a pest: it causes damage to pastures and winter feed in wetter areas. (2007,From Tussocks to Tourists,69)

Canadian fence¶

n. aka chock-and-log fence

The Canadian' (or chock-and-log) fence was also made of tree trunks, four logs being placed one on top of the other ... At either end short transverse pieces were placed between each log. The short crosswise chocks had a concave section chopped out top and bottom so that the fence logs would remain firm and not roll. <i>(Oct 1965,NZ Geographer,148</i>) [NOTES: (HargreavesFarm Fences')]

Canadian thistle¶

1 n. (Rural) a creeping thistle, Cirsium arvense, also known as Californian thistle in NZ.

Thee is but one thing raised on a farm like it, and that is the Canadian thistle, which swarms new plants every time you break its roots, whose blossoms are prolific, and every flour [sic] the father of a million seeds. (Aug 17, 1860,Colonist, The,3)

WALLACE Canadian' orCalifornia' thistle. ... said to have been introduced about 1886 in Californian barley. (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,310)

This plant is termed the Californian or Canada thistle in Australia and New Zealand; the corn thistle or green thistle in England; and Canada thistle in Canada and United States (Cnicus arvensis). (1902,Brett's Colonists Guide,241)

Noxious Weeds. ... Californian or Canadian thistle ... Bathurst Burr ... (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,203)

COCKAYNE Probably all the worst weeds of the earth have already arrived, and we cannot expect newcomers that would rival the couch-grass (Agropyron repens), the sorrel (Rumex acetosella), or the so-called Californian thistle' (<i>Cnicus arvensis</i>). At the same time, any farmer who sees a new plant on his farm should look at it askance, obtain what information he can get respecting it, and eradicate it at once if he has any reason to suspect it of having the weed-assuming characteristics. [fn] This plant is a native of the British Islands, Europe generally, north Africa, and northern to western Asia. It is only naturalised in the United States, where, however, it is called theCanada thistle.' In England it is known as the corn thistle' andcreeping thistle,' and is a weed of either cultivated or waste ground. (1902,NZ Plants,136)

DAVIN Goldfinches swung on the tall Canadian thistles. (1970,Not Here, Not Now,125)

We are sorry to learn from a Lichfield correspondent that the Californian alias Canada thistle .. is to be seen on most of the stations in that part of the Thames Valley. (1896,NZ Farmer,141)

A farmer who was fined for not keeping down Canadian thistles writes to the 'Otago Daily Times' expressing his surprise at seeing the weed growing in the Dunedin gardens and in other parts of the city. (1909,NZ Farmer,358)

A number of new clauses were added, among them being one giving councils power to spend money in eradicating the Californian thistle or other noxious weeds. (Jul 6, 1886,Timaru Herald,3)

Periodically methods of how to rid the land of Canadians are reported ... (1909,NZ Farmer,396)

The whole country would be one mass of thistles, instead of appearing as the Canadians do, in patches, and spreading from roots. (Jul 1911,NZ Farmer,698)

WALLACE One of the more recent importations is that of the 'Canadian' or 'Californian' thistle. (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,310)

If you have Canada thistles, cut them in summer at the time the stalk is hollow; if it rains and fills the stock, the root will rot. (Jul 20, 1872,Otago Witness,9)

2 n. Californian thistle

Canadian thistle [=] Californian thistle [s] Ibid. 78 thistle, Canadian [=] Californian thistle [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,11)

canary¶

n. a Chinese stowaway

It would be interesting to know how many `canaries' (Chow stowaways) are landed in the diminutive wayside ports of this colony. (Mar 9, 1907,NZ Truth,90/1/4)

n.

Made Bird Of Old Tickets. Sales of `canaries' - used tickets - by drivers and conductors of buses have been giving the Auckland Transport Board a headache. (Jun 24, 1958,NZ Truth)

n. to give free or cheap rides on city transport

If drivers were `selling canaries' - giving free or cheap rides - they faced dismissal and the union would not support them. (May 24, 1978,Dominion,1)

n. one who `sings' to authorities

MacKENZIE Prisoners who did converse [with officers] were accused of sucking up' to officers, and were held in contempt by their fellows. They were known asbrown noses', toppers' orcanaries'. Ibid. 95 canary squealer; a songbird (1980,While We Have Prisons,16)

n. yellowhead, bush canary, native/New Zealand canary, storm bird, (u)popokatea (etc.)usu. ochrocephala(South Island) and M. albicilla (NI), the NZ bush canary; (See mohua)

MOHOUA OCHROCEPHALA, Gml. Mohoua. Canary. ... as soon as one ascends the bushy gullies of the hills, the Canary is sure to pay a reconnoitering visit; ... (1870,TrNZI,2/57) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

HUTTON 10. ORTHONYX OCHROCEPHALA. Gml. Canary. Yellow-head. Popokatea. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,8)

BULLER ORTHONYX [CLITONYX] OCHROCEPHALA. (The YELLOW-HEAD.) ... Native names. same [Popotea, Poupoutea, Popokotea, and Upokotea] as those applied to the preceding species [White-head]: `Canary' of the colonists. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,103,1888 2nd edn I/56 ed.)

BATHGATE A small flight of canaries (Orthonyx ochrocephala). (1874,Colonial Experiences,233)

  1. Orthonyx ochrocephala, Gml. Canary, Popokatea. - Perhaps amongst the native avifauna this genus is one of the most puzzling to understand. (Nov 1884,NZ Journal of Science,283) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

Ca-na.ry (k&adot.-n&amacr..r&ybreve.), n. [Add.] 2. (Zoo.l.) (b) The yellowhead. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2019)

MORRIS Canary ... (1) A bird-name used in New Zealand for Clitonyx ochrocephala, called also the Yellow-head. Dwellers in in the back-blocks of Australia apply the name to the .us Orange-fronted Ephthianura (E. aurifrons, Gould), and sometimes to the White-throated Gerygone ( Gerygone albigularis). (1898,Austral English,77)

BULLER 'Clitonyx Ochrocephala. Yellow-head. Canary' of the colonists.' (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/56)

HARPER The canaries (Orthonyx ochrocephala) and the little mountain wrens (Xenicus filviventris) [sic] are useful as foretellers of the weather, ... (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,39)

HILL I do not know to what to attribute the scarcity of small birds, ...such as crows, saddlebacks, thrushes, tuis, canaries, wrens, riflebeaks, fantails and many others. (1987,Richard Henry of Resolution Island,88) [NOTES: 1897 Apr 5 E.H. Wilmot Exploration and Topographical Survey in Fiord Country in 1987 Hill Richard Henry of Resolution Island 88]

HILL I do not know to what to attribute the scarcity of small birds, ...such as crows, saddlebacks, thrushes, tuis, canaries, wrens, riflebeaks, fantails and many others. (1987,Richard Henry of Resolution Island,88) [NOTES: 1897 Apr 5 E.H. Wilmot Exploration and Topographical Survey in Fiord Country in 1987 Hill Richard Henry of Resolution Island 88]

PASCOE The Canary. [The Yellowhead. Mohoua ochrocephala] The diggers used to call them the storm bird, as they made appearance in flocks just before rain accompanied by another bird. The two indicated a change of weather better than any barometer. (1957,Mr Explorer Douglas,269) [NOTES: c1899 Douglas Birds of South Westland in 1957 Mr Explorer Douglas 269]

Amongs[t?] the creepers there are the bush-wren, the rock-wren, the rifleman and the yellow-headed native canary. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,195)

So with the New Zealand birds: the Mocker, the Tui, the warbler, the Tomtit, the Robin, the Brown Creeper, the Canary, the White-eye ...are all known to feed the Cuckoo bantlings ... (1904,TrNZI,36/116)

Where thick native bush remains untouched our canaries - the yellow-head and the white-head - will be with us. (1908,TrNZI,40/491)

FERGUSON Canaries wild .../ All round are chanting joyously ... (1912,Castle Gay,61)

JACKSON In one [of Buller's aviary cages], there were parrakeets, yellow heads, New Zealand canary, fantails, robins and tom tits, and a pio pio (New Zealand thrush) one of our best songsters - ... (1935,Annals of a NZ Family,129)

2 n.

mohua, a gregarious bird (Mohoua ochrocephala), South Island form of the bush-canary, the North Island form (Mohoua albicilla) being upokotea. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/154) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

BEST There are many song bird species in the park, including the whitehead or bush canary, ... and the robin which hads a surprisingly powerful song for its size. (1983,Land of the Mist,70)

2 n. Certhiparus novae zelandiae,brown creeper

CERTHIPARUS NOVAE ZELANDIAE, Gml. Brown creeper; Brown Canary. Although this Creeper may be seen in almost every bush, from the coast to the distant Alpine Ranges, we have only once found its nest. (1870,TrNZI,2/59) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

2 n. (See whitehead)

2 n.

I have paid special attention to the nests of three birds- the Native Canary (Orthonyx ochrocephala), the Robin (Myiomoira albifrons), and the Tomtit (Myiomoira macropcephala). Sir Walter Buller says ... that the Blue Crow (Glaucopis cinerea) lays a single egg, and ... leaves the care of the chick to the to the Popokatea, or Canary (Orthonyx albicilla). (1904,TrNZI,36/119)

The native canary, once common ... round Dunedin, has now absolutely disappeared from these parts. (1908,TrNZI,40/490)

The saddlebacks were first observed following flights of yellowheads, or native canaries (Clitonyx ocrocephala). (1911,TrNZI,43/166)

2 n.

ORTHONYX. - New Zealand Canary, two species (Popokatea). (1886,TrNZI,18/102) [NOTES: Reischek]

2 n.

Yellow-head Canary (Orthonyx ochrocephala). (1895,TrNZI,28/361)

2 n.

HUTTON & DRUMMOND The Bush Canary. Mohua ocrocephala [check spg] ... The New Zealand Canary has a sharp, strident call, and its movements are quick and active. (1904,Animals of NZ, The,2/91)

WILLIAMS Mohua ... Mohua ochrocephala, bush canary. [1957 adds yellow-head] (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,240)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Although the New Zealand Crow, the New Zealand Thrush were still to find [in Nelson province], Bush Canary at any rate were plentiful. Ibid. 65 MOHUA OCHROCEPHALA has been well named the Bush Canary. Its commonest call is a trill or rapid shivering rattle not unlike the pea whistle note of the popular cage bird.Ibid. 67 The rain forests beloved of the Bush Canary. (1936,NZ Naturalist,57)

bush canary n : a small New Zealand bird (Mohua ochrocephala) having a yellow head and breast (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,301)

FALLA et al. YELLOWHEAD Mohoua ochrocephala Other names: Mohua, Bush Canary. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,210)

HENDERSON Among other pleasing companions of the wild he, anyhow, managed to find were bush canaries, numerous there in 1925, ... (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,105)

Yellowhead Mohoua ochrocephala (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAMES: Mohoua, mohoua houa, bush canary. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,277)

bush canary NZ = YELLOWHEAD. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,96) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

I.. saw two bush canaries running excitedly up and down a dead branch of a broadleaf that hung well out over the creek. (Sep 14, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17)

canary grass¶

n. (See grass)

canary stain¶

1 n. (Rural) a yellow colouring in fleecewool [thought to be caused by dampness.]

BARTON This permanent type of yellowness comes broadly under the heading of canary stain. (1972,Sheepfarming Annual 1972,111)

MAF Canary stain: Bright yellow unscourable discoloration of wool which occurs under conditions of high temperature and high humidity following a thorough wetting of the fleece. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53)

SQUIRE Term usually applied to wool with some form of permanent stain such as canary or bacterial stains ... (1991,A to Z Glossary of Wool Terms,17)

(1946,Bulletin of the Wgtn Botanical Soc.,14/8)

candle lantern¶

n. (See cf. bush lantern)

BOSWELL Meanwhile my father and the boys, in the light of a couple of candle lanterns - in the early days [c1890s] simply candles stuck into the necks of inverted bottles which had their bottoms cut off - would be scraping the day's swag. (1956,Dim Horizons,55,1955 ed.)

cane-juice¶

[Hdg] Might Canes make it four in a row. The Hurricanes are continuing to punch above their weight in rugby's Super 12... (Mar 31, 2003,Dominion Post,A1)

canner ewe¶

1 n. (Rural) a poorly-conditioned ewe, to be culled for canning or potting.

The canner muttons and ewes were not so much in demand. (Jan 22, 1964,Weekly News,40)

DU FAUR .. the combined return from the the ewes plus lambs at foot is as good, and often better, than the value of the fat lambs and the canner ewes three months later. (1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,87)

cannery¶

n.

MOORE ... fish in prodigal abundance and fruit ... have given rise to `canneries' and jam factories. (1890,New Zealand For the Emigrant,179)

cannibal¶

n.

(Griffiths Collection) (1814,Marsden's Lieutenants,89)

... for I had now become tired of spending my time to no purpose, and amongst wild savages, where I felt myself like one cast away. ... and now to be a lost man in the midst of strange people, and cannibals tho' in justice to the New Zealanders, I have seen more friendship amonst them than I have subsequently amongst the white people who formed the crew of the boat I was in. (1835,Boultbee Journal,76,1986 ed.)

MILLER At the age of nineteen, Jerningham Wakefield, son of the theorist, heard that his Uncle William was going to lead an expedition to the Cannibal Isles. [Also title to Ch.2:THE CANNIBAL ISLES p.13 ff.] (1958,Early Victorian NZ,20)

E.G. WAKEFIELD Not to mention my own stake at Port Nicholson ... I consider that we are under a strong obligation to abstain from doing anything that might hurtfully affect the men who had the pluck to go to the Cannibal Lands when all seemed ... risk. But I am satisfied ... that the more and greater settlements there are in New Zealand ... the better for the Wellingtonians. (1840,Letter) [NOTES: 1840 E.G. WAKEFIELD Letter Jan 8 in 1901 FAWCETT Sir William Molesworth 173]

canning¶

n.

At present the canning industry is confined to mullet, of which there is a large amount exported, and an equal quantity used for home consumption. Ibid. 10 The Western Packing and Canning Company during 1899 slaughtered 43,000 sheep, averaging 54lb. each; 1,000 cattle, averaging 550lb.; with an output of 9,000 cases of tinned meats, and 640 casks of tallow. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,5)

cannon¶

n. a pickpocket

You would be playing into the hands of the "cannons" and "rollers" - the pickpockets who fleece the drunks in bars. (Dec 16, 1953,NZ Observer,5)

cannon cracker¶

n. a firework

BAXTER What you say might be correct. But Tom ... has no business to go round lighting matches alongside a box of cannon crackers! (1982,Collected Plays,170) [NOTES: [1967] 1982 Baxter Collected Plays (The Bureaucrat) 170]

cannonball man¶

n.

WHITWORTH Well he might, for Johnson, who was our cannon-ball man, did look a beauty without paint. [fn] The strong man in a circus, who throws weights, &c. (1879,Spangles and Sawdust,4)

cannons¶

n.

SUTTON-SMITH It is important to distinguish these `Action-Terms' of marbles from the innumerable merely descriptive marble terms which have no effect on the course of the action - terms such as Ringer, In, Smug, Dead Stick, Skun, Skinned, Sported off, Scat, Cannons, Dubs, Kills, Funs, Keeps, Pink. (1953,Unorganized Games,2/770)

SUTTON-SMITH Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. (1972,Folkgames of Children,175)

canoe¶

n. a Maori dugout canoe (? early connected with Indian, the early word for Maori).

PARKINSON ... discovered many of the natives (who seemed to be of very dark hue) and several of their canoes hauled upon the beach. (Oct 9, 1769,Journal,87)

MONKHOUSE Presently, two or three of the natives were observed running along the beach. Six or seven Canoes had been observed coming in. (Oct 6, 1769,Journal) [NOTES: 1769 October 6 Monkhouse Journal in Cook Journals (1955) I/564]

... in each of the Canoes were two or three Cheifs [sic] and the habits of these were superior to any we had yet seen, the Cloth they were made on was of the best sort and cover'd on the out side with Dog skins put on in such a manner as to look agreeable to the Eye. Few of these people were tattow'd or mark'd in the face like those we have seen farther to the south, but several had their Backsides tattou'd much in the same manner as the Inhabitants of the Islands within the Tropics. (Nov 27, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/213,1955 ed.)

WILLIAM BAYLY As we were coming out of the Sound in the morning the Indians made off in their Canoos to take a farewell of us as well as they could by signs. (Jun 7, 1773,Journal) [NOTES: 1773 June 7 William Bayly's Journal in 1908 McNab Historical Records II/209]

FORSTER They were scarcely returned on board, when a canoe* appeared off a point ... [fn] We shall always make use of this word to signify an Indian embarkation, unless we mean to describe or specify it more particularly. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/131)

As soon as the bay opened, the natives came out in their canoes, and came alongside of the ship with the greatest confidence, ... (Nov 19, 1793,Letter) [NOTES: 1793 Nov 19 Letter from Norfolk Island in 1908 McNab Historical Records I/184]

SAVAGE Immediately upon coming to an anchor we were surrounded by a great number of canoes ... (1807,New Zealand (various authors/titles),3) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

H. WILLIAMS When prepared to proceed, we obsd. all the canoes under sail, and could not understand whither they were bound; ... (Mar 25, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,46,1961 ed.)

H. WILLIAMS As we came towards Wakatani we obs'd some canoes and natives. (Apr 8, 1828,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,120,1961 ed.)

Captain Harled the Canous up to Hous [on the beach] Natives went to the bush again. [ed note glossary 155] CANEW. - Canoes, or dug-outs', fashioned out of a single tree-trunk, ... were the only sea-going craft in the possession of the Natives at that time. In the Log they are calledboats', apparently in order to avoid a spelling difficulty. (Apr 14, 1837,Piraki Log,52,(ed. Anson 1911) ed.)

Returned up the Avon in canoe having shot a bittern and grey teal which J.Deans stuffed. (May 21, 1849,Torlesse Papers,79,1958 ed.)

SMITH ... putting our packs in the canoe, we walked down the bank till opposite the pa, where they put us across ... (Jan 4, 1858,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1858 Jan 4 Smith Notes of a Journey in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 352]

HAAST ... the river fell, and by tying bundles of flax sticks together on each side of the canoe in which the provisions had been brought up, we ventured down the stream with the flood. (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,29)

HUNT Here we stopped, and the canoes were drawn up in front of the pa, amidst much tangi-ing, and shouts of `Haeremai, haeremai, haeremai!' - the usual amount of shaking hands and rubbing noses being over, a long korero, or talk, ensued. (1866,Chatham Islands,17)

HAAST My two Maori companions had here ample opportunity to show their skill in guiding the canoe through all the obstacles in our way, ... which they accomplished most successfully. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,92)

BATHGATE Sure ... and they tell me there is something they call a canoe down there that takes you across [to the island in the Otago river]. Ibid. 74 Gilbert ... got the shepherd to show him the canoe ... It was really a canoe of native manufacture, and was simply a log of Totara, which had been hollowed out by some patient Maori, assisted by ... a stone adze, in the days before the advent of the Pakeha' with his deadly civilisation and exterminatingWaipouru' (alcoholic liquor - literally, `stinking water'). (1881,Waitaruna,72)

... although there are numerous rapids on its course, it [Waitara] is navigable for canoes for about ninety miles. ... The Patea is navigable for canoes for fifty miles. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,41)

n.

TINNE [He] would receive two canoe-loads of provisions, if he came to a bone-scraping in his official capacity ... (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,70)

BAINES The largest attempt at canoe-building I ever saw [83] was an unfinished one ... (1874,Edward Crewe,82)

LYSNAR Few savage races were greater adepts in the art of canoe-building than the Maoris. (1924,New Zealand (various authors/titles),65)

COWAN Among the olden Maoris Nga-whatu were isles of tapu and dread, and there were curious observances among canoe-voyagers across these perilous waters. (1926,Travel in NZ,(Vol II South Island) 8)

n. a Te Whiti procession

RICHARDS (1952,Chatham Islands,125) [NOTES: [check and get cit if needed]]

RICHARDS (1952,Chatham Islands,125) [NOTES: [check and get cit if needed]]

3 v. to travel by canoe

BAINES When night came we camped, building a very rough hut ... and this ... made us as comfortable ... as travellers canoeing it could desire. (1874,Edward Crewe,95)

DOBSON When working with the Maoris, we were so much in and out of the water, canoeing and travelling along the beaches, ... (1930,Reminiscences,156)

4 n.

FORSTER Here [at Dusky Bay] we found a double canoe hauled upon the shore ... The canoe ... consisted of two troughs or boats joined together with sticks, tied across the gunwales with strings of the New Zeeland flax-plant. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/132)

5 n. used in the figurative Maori sense of waka

In the end, however, the Treaty of Waitangi placed us all in the same canoe. (Apr 7, 2004,Dominion Post,B7)

canoe pois¶

n.

HYDE The Maori girls sing them, weaving lithe arms and bodies in the canoe pois, the graceful dance of the womenfolk. (1936,Passport to Hell,141)

Cantab¶

adj. from Canterbury

If people from the northern parts of NZ were disappointed with excessive Cantab influence in style and selection - they ain't seen nothin' yet!!! (Dec 28, 2003,Sunday Star Times,B9)

Cantabrian¶

n.

HASCOMBE Riccarton Bush ... called `Deans Bush' by any Cantabrian worthy of the name. (1969,Down and Almost Under,57)

ELDRED-GRIGG `He's a fine little Cantabrian,' she said. (1987,Oracles and Miracles,226)

Television of Cantabrians, by Cantabrians and for Cantabrians. (Jan 2000,North & South,68)

Why do Canterbury women wear their collars turned up?... Baby girl Cantabrians come out like this, I'm told, but only if their parents hail from Fendalton, Merivale or the rural areas. (Feb 1999,North & South,21)

As people who live in Auckland are called Aucklanders and people who live in Christchurch, or Canterbury, are called Cantabrians, should we call people who live in Wellington Capitalists? (Mar 2, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

Do you believe in the one-eyed Cantabrian? ... When I came up here, I realised it was quite different being a Cantabrian. (Nov 20, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

The new AB coaches will be objective Cantabrians. (As the beer slogan would say - yeah right!!). (Dec 28, 2003,Sunday Star Times,B9)

Perhaps Cochrane failed to notice the team had a Canterbury coach, a Canterbury captain, a Cantabrian throwing the ball in and the targets were Cantabrians. (Aug 20, 2000,Sunday Star Times,B2)

adj. of Canterbury

I can't help noticing that, on manyoccasions, the term "Cantabrian" is usedas the adjective for Canterbury. This isnot correct. The term "Cantabrian" is thaadjective for Cambridge... Presumably,the adjective for Canterbury is"Cantaburian" or "Canterburian". (Jul 24, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

SIR, Your news item of May 11, Unashamedly Cantabrian' quotes the chairman of a Christchurch City Council committee saying some development project wasunashamedly parochial and unashamedly Cantabrian.' -->this adjective for pertaining to Canterbury' rouses my curiosity. The word Canterbury itself is quite capable of being used as an adjective - Canterbury bells, Canterbury gallop (hencecanter') John Brooke-White? [The following in bold type.] The Post's' chief reader Ian Spicer saysCantabrian' to describe a resident of, or phenomenon related to Canterbury - and more particularly Christchurch - has been around for a long time. Usage appears to be peculiar to Christchurch newspapers and some individuals, perhaps as a means of reinforcing some quaint notions held by them about the city's Englishness. Arguments about the word have waxed at least as long with Canterburians being preferred by some as being etymologically more valid. However, Canterburians looks awkward and is a mouthful to pronounce: for those reasons, Cantabrian appears to have scored the victory. (May 21, 1983,Evening Post,6)

Cantabs¶

n. a Canterbury representative team

The Cantabs had their chances in the first spell and, with Scott Robertson hitting his straps in the No 7 jersey, and the tighties doing their stuff, there was enough possession for at least a try or two. (May 6, 2001,Sunday Star Times,B2)

Canterberian¶

n. (See Cantabrian (1983))

Canterbury Association¶

n. the organisation involved in settling Canterbury

When the Canterbury Association ship the Randolph arrived at the Port of Lyttelton on 16th December 18950, John Stanley and his young wife Mary were aon board as immigrants. [44] The Canterbury Association provided free lodgings for one week in the immigration barracks constructed for new arrivals at Lyttelton with provisions. (Apr 2004,NZ Memories,No. 47/43)

Canterbury Block¶

n. (See block)

Canterbury broom¶

n. Notospartium torulosum

Notospartium torulosum' the Canterbury broom: Notospartium from Greek, notos, the south wind, and spartium, broom - literally, the southern broom, torulosum from Latin, torula, diminutive of torus, a protuberance or bulge, describing the characteristic `waisted' seed-pods (Oct 9, 1982,Press, The,15)

The range of Canterbury broom (Notospartium torulosum) is now very discontinuous, ... (1987,Triennial Report Botany Division,60)

Canterbury duster¶

1 n. (Rural) a sheep with a fleece full of fine sandy dirt.

WILLIAMS The sheep in 1982 had come from the dry side of the Wairarapa and were not unlike the Canterbury dusters he'd been raised on. (1993,Gone West for Shearing,78)

.. and 130 for sheep, including pasture, paddock or ground lice, maggot magnets, bag of dags, Canterbury duster, Waiouru blonde, cotty, decoy, glue pot and scrubdasher. (Nov 22, 2002,Dominion Post,C6)

Canterbury flatworm¶

n. the endemic NZ flatworm, Artioposthia triangulata, accidentally introduced into England.

And just what is this terror by night? None other than our native Canterbury flatworm!... The Canterbury flatworm, Artioposthia triangulata, is a relatively shy little bush-dwelling creature at home and has only revealed these alarming habits since some entered Britain - it is thought with a shipment of plants from Banks Peninsula - around 1963. (Jan 14, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

The clipping is headed, "Worm Blitz Fears from Kiwi Invader" and describes the Canterbury flatworm, Artioposthia triangulata, as "an alien threatening England's green and pleasant land." Oh dear! (Mar 4, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),55)

Canterbury knobbed weevil¶

n. Hadramphus tuberculatus (See Canterbury knobbled weevil)

Canterbury Museum entomologist Peter Johns has found so many Canterbury knobbed [sic] weevils, Hadramphus tuberculatus, which previously had not been seen since 1922, that it has escaped a category one "critically endangered" Department of Conservation rating. (2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/story.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10127298accessed 09/02/06]

Canterbury knobbled weevil¶

n. Hadramphus tuberculatus [Also called: Banks Peninsula speargrass weevil, spaniard weevil, Lyperobius tuberculatus] (See Canterbury knobbed weevil)

Hadramphus tuberculatus (the Canterbury knobbled weevil) has been largely forgotten - a category X (presumed extinct) species ... whether the knobbled weevil is one of the mysterious pollinators of Aciphylla has yet to be established. (Mar 2005,NZ Geographic,72/23)

University of Canterbury masters student Laura Young made the discovery of a lifetime recently - she found a weevil thought to be extinct since 1922 living in Burkes Pass, South Canterbury. Laura was studying Aciphylla (speargrass/spaniards) in the Burkes Pass Scenic Reserve last month as part of her Masters degree in ecology when she stumbled across the Canterbury knobbled weevil. (Feb 2, 2005,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.comsdev.canterbury.ac.nz/news/2005/050202b.shtmlAccessed 14/03/06]

Order: ColeopteraFamily: CurculionidaeTaxonomic Name: Hadramphus tuberculatus (Pascoe, 1877)Common Names: Canterbury knobbled weevil (Scott & Emberson 1999), BanksPeninsula speargrass weevil (Foord 1990), spaniard weevil(Kuschel & Worthy 1996)Synonyms: Lyperobius tuberculatus (Pascoe 1877) (Mar 14, 2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/Conservation/001~Plants-and-Animals/001~Native-Animals/Invertebrates/Conservation-Requirements-of-NZs-Nationally-Threatened-Invertebrates/011~Beetles-Curculionids-I.pdfAccessed 14/03/06No date of publication found on document.]

Canterbury lamb¶

n.

Does he mean to say that intrinsically as food ... English mutton is worth about three times as much as prime Canterbury frozen? (Jul 1898,NZ Farmer,232/1)

We are basking in prosperity, now that we can turn off a large quantity of `Prime Canterbury' from the plains. (1903,Cyclopedia of NZ,3/80)

STAPLETON A brief reference to the New Zealand `Canterbury lamb' ... may not be out of place. (1928,Tour in Australia and NZ,58)

`Canterbury' lamb and mutton is now a trade term and because of consistent high quality usually has had a premium over other New Zealand supplies although reports of recent years show a tendency for selected North Island products to bring a price equal to that of Canterbury products. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,636)

PASCOE Every time we buy Canterbury lamb from the butcher we are reminded that the meat we are going to eat has come from a New Zealand sheep-farm. (1959,NZ Sheep Station,3)

TURNER The term Canterbury lamb must not be overlooked, though it has now become a victim of standardization, being replaced by the term down grade ... (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,146)

Canterbury lamb (now rare) term used for certain grades of NZ lamb or mutton. [name of province] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

Cheekily, he lists "farmer" as his occupation these days, and mentions he's now one sheep short in the paddock, having bagged a prime piece of Canterbury lamb for the boys to take with them to Auckland after Christmas. (Dec 24, 2000,Sunday Star Times,B3)

SCRYMGEOUR "Prime Canterbury" was mostly the result of Southdown or Border mated to half-bred Merinos... Even with this and other complaints, sheep throve, and put `Canterbury lamb' on the map, despite the fact ... that more lamb, so papered, illuminated, and appreciated by the British public, was often bred in the North Island. Later on New Zealand instituted a rather wonderful system of grading, from about 1882, when frozen lamb weighed 50lbs. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,146)

1 n. (Rural) [originally] a Merino-cross fat lamb bred for export from Canterbury; [later] a trade term denoting high quality.

STAPLEDON A brief reference to the New Zealand 'Canterbury lamb' .. may not be out of place. (1928,Tour in Australia and NZ,58)

BELSHAW 'Canterbury' lamb and mutton is now a trade term and because of consistent high quality usually has had a premium over other New Zealand supplies. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,636)

HAWKINS .. he [Marmaduke Dixon, a squatter] sent to England its first twenty-five carcasses of Canterbury lamb, five of these going to the Duke of Edinburgh and the remainder to the editors of London newspapers. (1957,Beyond the Waimakariri,128)

Canterbury mudfish¶

n.

PHILLIPPS Galaxias burowsii Phillipps. CANTERBURY MUDFISH. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,14,1971 ed.)

Galaxias burowsii : [European Name] Canterbury mud-fish [Maori Name ?] (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,73)

PHILLIPPS CANTERBURY MUD-FISH Paragalaxias burrowsii Phillipps ... This is one of the most degenerate species of Galaxias and has been placed in a separate genus. (1940,Fishes,39)

GRAHAM Canterbury Mudfish or Mud Galaxias Saxilaga (Lixagasa) burrowsius (Phillipps) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,400) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 400]

Although many of the creatures are exotic, they are now concentrating on New Zealand natives, including the extinct Canterbury mudfish, which looks like thriving. (Oct 4, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5) [NOTES: 1986 July 28 NZ Woman's Weeekly quoted in 1986 Oct 4 Listener 5]

Canterbury sling¶

n.

Mr Kenny said that one of the agreements, the so-called Canterbury sling.' was a district agreement, giving a group of workers an extra $40 a week.It was agreed to 20 years ago on a district basis and it cannot be broken by one company,' he said. (Oct 30, 1982,Press, The,1)

Canterbury smelt¶

n.

GRAHAM Canterbury Smelt Retropinna spp. nov. (unnamed) Stokell (1955,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,399)

Canterburys¶

n. Short for "Canterbury Regiment"

WAITE Some of the Canterburys were at El Ferdan. (1919,New Zealanders at Gallipoli,53)

WAITE The Wellingtons were on the left, the Aucklands in the centre, and the Canterburys on the right. (1919,New Zealanders at Gallipoli,125)

PUGSLEY His party was joined by more Canterburys. (1984,Gallipoli: the New Zealand Story,178)

The Canterburys have continued fightingwith dash and great gallantry. (Oct 16, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/4 : 81)

Canterbury got quite a haul of prisoners. (Nov 15, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,i/6 : 128)

canvas¶

adj.

HAAST ... we found everywhere [near Teramakau] tents and canvas stores, often comfortably fitted up, and the people hard at work. ... [87] At the mouth of ... the Waimea river ... we found a settlement ... consisting of about thirty shanties and canvas houses, mostly stores and public-houses. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,85)

canvas town¶

n. a goldfields tent settlement; thence a place name.

Mr. Cairns ...pointed out the nature of the case [about shortage of accommodation], and urged that a space of ground should be allotted to the new comers, somewhat after the fashion of the `Canvas Town' of 1852 and 1853. (Sep 23, 1861,NZ Goldfields,18,1976 ed.)

A wet day at Canvas Town is only surpassed in misery by a wet night at the same place, as most of the tents leak very uncomfortably, while in no few the `floor' would make an agreeable pleasure ground for the most amphibious ducks. (Jun 11, 1864,Nelson Examiner,3)

BARKER The gold-fields on this coast were only discovered eight months ago, and already several canvas towns have sprung up; there are thirty thousand diggers at work ... (1865,Station Life in NZ,16,1870 ed.)

FARJEON Nothing further was known of him, than that he had sprung up suddenly in Canvas Town, and that, when that motley delectability was swept away, he had migrated... (1866,Grif: a Story of Colonial Life,78)

... I went up to Dunedin and how it has grown since I was here last. Then it was a canvas town. I do not know any building to equal some of the new stone ones here ... (Apr 18, 1868,Chudleigh Diary,220,1950 ed.)

REEVES Round Dunedin [in 1860s] rose a canvas town' for miles, and a new career ofgo-a-headism' began for the colony. (1892,Homeward Bound,3)

PFAFF On our return we found a canvas town instead of the bush that we had left. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,42)

Within three years there was a populate [at Thames] estimated at 20,000. ... Canvastown, the hundreds of bell-tents, had been replaced by wooden buildings, by houses ... (1948,Our Own Country,23)

HUNT Most of the inhabitants of `Canvastown' might well have been described as the scum of the earth - wild men attracted by the lure of gold. (1951,Confessions,13)

PEARSON She knew it rained hard [on the West Coast], that there was saw-milking, that there had been a violent history of gold-rushes and canvas-towns. (1963,Coal Flat,46)

HENDERSON ... picturing the start of the track and lacebark or ribbonwood in flower bringing thoughts of white glimpses of miners' sudden canvastowns. (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,131)

GRACE Across the scarred, disfigured valley, over the mullock heaps... bearded men.. collect in Canvas Town's one ramshackle street. (1914,Tale of a Timber Town,152)

Te Aroha was a canvas town. (Aug 6, 1904,NZ Observer,4)

Hokitika then was known as Canvas Town. (Oct 21, 1924,Otago Witness,54)

CANZ¶

abbr. Corrections Association of New Zealand

Starting tomorrow the union, the Corrections Association of New Zealand (CANZ), will consult its 2200 members over the notice... CANZ national organiser Brian Davies said when the armed forces and police were last used in 1996, prison officers were split into two main unions... This was not the case this time, with more than 90% of prison officers being CANZ members. (Jul 22, 2001,Sunday Star Times,A5)

cap¶

n. grafitti

Graffiti Speak... Cap, fat or skinny: Interchangeable spray can nozzle fitted to can to vary width of spray. Hard to get in New Zealand. Writers adapt oven cleaner nozzles or use needles to alter nozzle holes. Empty food cans are filled with ink and topped with foam rubber to create giant markers. (Nov 30, 1940,Evening Post,19)

v. to confer a degree (See also capping)

[Advt] Economy'/ GEORGE COURT .../ Is still teaching Economy/ to a Discerning Public/ THE STUDENTS/ Admit that OUR Value/CAPS ALL' (1912,Auckland University Carnival Book,10) [NOTES: 1912 Auckland University Capping Carnival Programme 10]

cap ... 19. Chiefly Scot. & N.Z. to award a degree to. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,162) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 104; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 162]]

n. stratum of soil

'H' The hard quartz is broken out after the weathered `cap' [of the reef or outcrop] has been split away. (1898,Grain of Gold, The,10)

2 n. the loose `top' of a wool-pack (sewn on when the pack is filled with wool).

NEWTON ... the `cap' of the pack. (1949,High Country Days)

RICHARDS While one press was being filled and pressed, the already pressed bale would have the cap clipped (not sewn), and then it would be branded and wheeled away and another empty bale inserted (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,113)

cap rail¶

n. the top rail of a post-and-rail stockyard fence, the top rail on cattle yards used for walking on

W.H.S. ROBERTS At Macfarlane's the men saddled fresh horses and rode in some cattle which we had a great bother to yard, as everything was new ... The yard was divided into three - one large and two small - but as there was no crush pen, or drafting race, we had to head rope those requiring branding, and after hauling them up to a corner post, leg-roped and threw them on [44] their side, placing a long lever on their neck and under the lowest rail so that they would not move much ... When released the poor beast is not in an amiable temper ... So anyone in the yard has to climb the rails quickly ..., and the idea that it may catch you before your legs are safely over the cap rail certainly accelerates one's movements. (Dec 18, 1856,Diary) [NOTES: 1856 Dec 18 W.H.S. Roberts diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 43-44]

BARKER .. the gentlemen sallied forth once more to the stock-yard, and with great difficulty got off two of the cap or top rails ... (1867,Station Life in NZ,163,1870 ed.)

Cap rail.-Top rail of a yard fence. (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13)

ACLAND Cap rail: Top rail of a yard fence. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,360)

McLEOD The yard consists of a netting enclosure and a smaller pen beyond, built of posts or stakes, with a cap [25] rail to hold the lambs upon. (1951,High Country,24)

Cap rail. Top rail on cattle yards used for walking on. Top rail on wooden fence. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,27)

Cape¶

adj. (from Cape of Good Hope) as a distinguishing epithet in plant and animal names, see blechnum, crassula, daisy, fern, fuchsia, honey flower, ivy, petrel, pondweed, tulip, see also Cape gooseberry, Cape hen, Cape weed.

n. ellipt. for Cape gooseberry

DAVIES I hope max doesn't find that patch of Capes up there. (1975,Outback,123)

Cape barley¶

n.

I was cutting cape barley with machine and then drafting sheep. (Mar 19, 1890,Chudleigh Diary,371,1950 ed.)

Cape Barley: ... Its extreme hardiness renders it peculiarly adapted for autumn sowing. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,120)

(1899,Department of Agriculture Report,16) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

A breadth of oats or Cape barley is usually sown to come in at early spring, .. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,98)

GUTHRIE-SMITH ... lastly, record of early connection with South Africa, with the Cape of Good Hope, is preserved by such plant-names as Capeweed' (<i>Crepis taraxacifolia</i>),Cape gooseberry' (Physalis peruviana), and `Cape barley', not improbably from its hardihood, the old Scottish bere (Hordeum sp.). (1926,Tutira,306)

Cape broom¶

n.

BARKER ... even the large beds for vegetables in the garden have a hedge of Cape broom on the exposed side; fortunately, the broom grows very quickly in spite of the wind, and attains to a luxuriant beauty rarely seen in England. (1866,Station Life in NZ,63,1870 ed.)

They were the larvae of the yellow underwing moth, ... feeding on the introduced Cape broom. (1889,TrNZI,21/208)

Cape daisy¶

n.

It was mentioned that a weed called "Cape Daisy" was becoming dangerous in the country. (Dec 12, 1916,Wanganui Herald,5)

I asked about that other rapidly spreading vegetative horror, Cape Daisy, which is invading lawns and roadside berms throughout the North island - and probably the South. (Jan 13, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),47)

Cape Expeditioner¶

n. a member of the wartime coastwatching "Cape" Expedition to the Subantarctic Islands

One of the terms.. is one restricted to the New Zealand subantarctic: Cape Expeditioner. During World War II, the New Zealand government sent small numbers of men to Campbell Island and the Auckland Islands as coast-watchers. In order to minimise chances of this action being detected by the enemy, the code name 'Cape Expedition' was given to the project. (Aug 2000,NZWords,No. 4 : 7)

Cape fern¶

n. Blechnum capense

Cape fern [=] kiokio [s] ... Cape blechnum {=} kiokio[s} (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,11)

Cape fever¶

n.

The Captain laid up with rheumatism and six hands on the sick list, chiefly with `Cape fever'. (Oct 10, 1850,Journal of Edward Ward,64,1951 ed.)

Cape gooseberry¶

n. a widespread introduced South American plant with an edible berry yellow when ripe, enclosed in a hood-like calyx; its berry; the usual name for the plant (Physalis peruviana) and berry in NZ from 1841; winter cherry is not recorded here (Cape, poss. from or reinforced by, the `cape' covering the berry which is orig. a South American native).

We came across many bushes of buli-buli,which is a plant something like the capegooseberry, but its fruit is twice itssize. (Sep 14, 1927,NZ Tablet,37)

Cape gooseberries (Physalis peruviana) are thought to be a native of Peru and Chile, but take their popular name from the Cape of Good Hope. From South Africa they came to New Zealand and Australia, where they grow almost wild in many old gardens and fruit over a long season, starting in spring. (Nov 4, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

On his first visit he commented that Cape Gooseberries were abundant - a sign of earlier European occupation. (Oct 3, 1999,Sunday Star Times,A11)

BRIGHT A plant introduced by the missionaries termed the `Cape Gooseberry', growing low, thrives exceedingly well. (1841,Handbook for Emigrants,51)

LUSH There were several ... pits where grow peach trees and vines and the Cape Gooseberry - why called `Cape' I know not as it is indigenous to this country. [fn] V.L. was mistaken; Physalis peruviana is not indigenous to N.Z. It grows easily in many parts of the world, including no doubt the Cape of Good Hope. (Oct 18, 1866,Waikato Journals,98,1982 ed.)

They.. sell such delicacies as Tea Tree tea, Horopito rub, Cape Gooseberry jam, and Bushman's tonic (manuka, rimu, miro berries, and a couple of other things steeped in vodka). (Jun 2004,North & South,32)

It certainly makes for more interesting walks, when.. you can recognise such delights as ceps, snowberries, or cape gooseberries. (Mar 13, 1993,Dominion,11)

In 1850.. potatoes, onions, peaches and Cape gooseberries were a drug. (Sep 24, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,27)

Try fresh Cape gooseberries dipped in chocolate and served as a petit four for an exquisite chocolate fruit sensation. (Jun 16, 2002,Sunday Star Times,D1)

Cape hen¶

n. a small kind of albatross

BUTLER The great feature of the southern seas is the multitude of birds ... Huge albatrosses, molimorks (a smaller albatross), Cape hens, Cape pigeons, parsons, boobies, whale birds, mutton birds and many more, wheel continually about the ship's stern, ... (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,1/12)

HUTTON 122. DIOMEDEA FULIGINOSA. Gml. Cape Hen. This well-known species (theCape hen' of sailors), ... is comparatively common in the New-Zealand seas.' (1871,Birds of New Zealand,44)

KENNAWAY ... new birds steered by the mast-head ... - seagulls of the Antipodes (blue-grey), and cape hens, and greater sea-birds, ... (1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,150)

White-chinned Petrel Procellaria aequinoctialis LINNAEUS, 1758. ... OTHER NAMES: Shoemaker, Cape hen. .... DISTRIBUTION Breeds at the Auckland Islands ... the Falkland Islands ... (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,92)

Cape honey flower¶

n.

TAYLOR CAPE HONEY FLOWER (Melianthus major) ... A South Africa ornamental plant ... often wrongly called castor oil plant. (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,33)

Cape honey flower [s] Melianthus major L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,11)

Cape ivy¶

n.

Cape ivy [=] German ivy [s] ... Cape ivy [s] Senecio angulatus L. Ibid. 40 ivy, Cape [=] German ivy [s] ... ivy, Cape [s] Senecio angulatus L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,11)

TAYLOR CAPE IVY ( Senecio-angulatus ) South Africa perennial tending to sprawl ... Less Common Than German ivy. ... (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,33)

WILSON Further exotic climbers in Halfmoon Bay: CAPE IVY (*Senecio mikanoides), really a climbinggroundsel. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,44)

Cape petrel¶

n. Cape pigeon [AKA: blue petrel, Cape Pigeon]

BULLER DAPTION CAPENSIS. (CAPE PETREL {PINTADO PETREL}.) ... So familiar is the so-called `Cape Pigeon' to all who have made a voyage in the southern seas ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,299,1888 2nd edn 2/215 ed.)

Cape Pigeon Daption capense (LINNAEUS, 1758) ... OTHER NAMES: Cape Petrel, pintado petrel. ?(ii) =PINTADA (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,70)

FORSTER The principal sorts [in S. Indian Ocean] were the Cape petrel, or pintada (procellaria capensis), and the blue petrel, so called from having a blueish-grey colour, and a band of blackish feathers across the whole wing. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/91)

Cape Pigeon Daption capense (LINNAEUS, 1758) ... OTHER NAMES: Cape Petrel, pintado petrel. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,70)

BULLER DAPTION CAPENSIS. (CAPE PETREL {PINTADO PETREL}.) ... So familiar is the so-called `Cape Pigeon' to all who have made a voyage in the southern seas ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,299,1888 2nd edn 2/215 ed.)

Cape pigeon¶

n.

Numbers of that beautiful bird, the Cape pigeon, hovered and wheeled their circling flight around us. (Jul 29, 1848,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,86)

Now and then, too, a Cape pigeon (beautiful bird!) would get his wings entangled amongst the threads of his unwound reels of cotton, and his anxiety was intense to get the poor animal safe on deck. (Nov 12, 1867,North Otago Times,4)

He had to supplement the food put on board for them by catching Cape pigeons and albatrosses - a diet which the ferrets took to kindly; in fact, nothing seemed to come amiss to them; and success in bringing these animals alive to the colony evidently depends on their getting good housing and ample food. (Nov 11, 1882,Nelson Evening Mail,2)

ADAMS Among these may be noticed the albatross, the molimawk, the Cape pigeon, and several varieties of tern and petrel. The Cape pigeon, which is a beautifully marked black and white bird about the size of a wood pigeon, will follow the vessel to the end of the voyage. (1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,8)

BULLER DAPTION CAPENSIS. (CAPE PETREL {PINTADO PETREL}.) ... So familiar is the so-called `Cape Pigeon' to all who have made a voyage in the southern seas ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,299) [NOTES: 1888 2nd edn 2/215]

REISCHEK Cape pigeons were here [at Campbell Island] in plenty, and great numbers of Magellan shags were fishing round about. (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,280,1933 ed.)

RICHARDS Daption capense ... Cape pigeon. (1952,Chatham Islands,86)

FALLA et al. CAPE PIGEON Daption capensis (1966,Birds of New Zealand,36)

30 b. [Daption capense capense (Linnaeus, 1758) Cape Pigeon ... ranging widely in southern oceans north to northern New Zealand. (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,21,1980 ed.)

Cape Pigeon Daption capense (LINNAEUS, 1758) ... OTHER NAMES: Cape Petrel, pintado petrel. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,70)

On Sunday my brother shot a Cape Pigeon. (Jun 10, 1924,Otago Witness,71)

All hands, through her long passage, were all but starved, and only sustained life by eating sharks' flesh, varied by an occasional Cape pigeon. (May 19, 1873,West Coast Times,2)

n. (historical) the nickname of a group of early Waikato settlers.

LUSH Later William Berg of Capetown sponsored a small group of South Africans, to be known to their fellow settlers as `the Cape pigeons'. (1864,Waikato Journals) [NOTES: [1864] 1982 Drummond Lush Waikato Journals 15]

I never mentioned James Stephenson, nor did I know he was a "Cape Pigeon", although I worked with him at one time. (Mar 16, 1906,Wanganui Herald,2)

Cape primrose¶

n.

Blame the excitement and a gift voucher burning a hole in the pocket that resulted in two seriously sagging streptocarpus plants plus matching posh pot coming home to intensive care... Popularly known as Cape Primroses, thanks to their long, primula-like leaves and South African origin, these rescuees were labelled "Cape Violetta."... (Jan 4, 2003,Dominion Post,E14)

Cape Smoke¶

n. hard (?illicit) liquor, esp. overproof (?f. S. African soldiers)

ANZAC Shebangs [in Cairo] where they sell you whisky that takes the lining of your throat down with it, ... a soothing liquid that licks forty-rod',chained lighting', or `Cape Smoke' to the back of creation; the kind of lush that gives you a sixty-horse dose of the jim-jams while you wait. (1916,On the Anzac Trail,77)

Cape tulip¶

n. an extremely poisonous introduced South African plant with a brightly coloured flower.

The only bits of green proved to be tips of the Cape Tulip just forcing their way through the parched ground and waiting for any foolish animal to partake of a deadly meal. (Jun 2002,NZ Memories,No. 36/5)

WHITE Among exotic things worth having are the Proteas, or Cape Tulips - handsome shrubs, with large tulip-shaped flowers. [incorrect???] (1905,My NZ Garden,97)

HILGENDORF ONE-LEAVED CAPE TULIP (Homeria collina). A single leaf arising from a corm. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,60,1967 ed.)

11 Cape tulip [s] Homeria breyniana (L.) Lewis Ibid. 80 tulip, Cape [s] Homeria breyniana (L.) Lewis (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds)

TAYLOR CAPE TULIP (Homeria collona) South Africa perennial ... with grass-like leaves, ... and pretty flowers with six reddish orange petals ... extremely poisonous to stock ... (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,33) [NOTES: collana or collina?]

Cape weed¶

n. (Rural) one of two daisy-like weeds Arctotheca calendula and Hypochoeris radicata.

GUTHRIE-SMITH Throughout this block, especially on the edges of the dead groves, capeweed or cat's-ear (Hypochaeris radicata) germinated in millions of millions of millions ... (1921,Tutira,285)

MORRIS Cape Weed .. In New Zealand, name given to the European cats-ear. (1898,Austral English,78)

NGAWHIKA Realising the vehicle could move ten metres at a time, we drove straight up a bank and into a clump of capeweed and cutty grass. [cape weed, cape daisy] (1996,Tell Them I've Gone Pighunting,109)

n. the English catsear, esp. in Cant.;a) a weed of sandy soils and dry open pasture; b) (formerly) in Cant., cat's ear; often =Cape daisy [(check also Cape tulip) and cf W3] [x-ref only now at weed].

Cape.weed. (k&amacr.p.w&emacr.d.), n. (Bot.) A composite plant (Cryptostemma calendulaceum) allied to the marigold. It is a native of South Africa (the Cape). Introduced into Australia, it has spread over every pasture, and in the springtime its blossoms make yellow all the landscape. The Capeweed of Europe is a lichen (Rocella tinctoria) from the Cape Verde Islands. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2019)

MORRIS Cape Weed In Europe, Roccella tinctoria, a lichen from the Cape de Verde Islands, from which a dye is produced. In New Zealand, name given to the European cats-ear, Hypaechoris radicata. In Australia it is as in quotation below. [1878 Cryptostemma calendulaceum] (1898,Austral English,78)

The only introduced plant I noticed [on Mt Holdsworth] was the `cape-weed' (Hypochaeris), which was in profusion at about 4,000 ft. (1905,TrNZI,37/336)

HILGENDORF CATS-EAR (Hypochaeris radicata), called Cape weed in the South Island and often confused with the hawkbits, is an excessively common weed in all soils and situations, ... This is one of the best known weeds in New Zealand. Unfortunately, it is often called Cape weed,' specially in the south, where the true Cape weed is not known, and oftendandelion' by those who do not distinguish between two superficially similar weeds. On the tussock country of the South Island it is found to be largely eaten by sheep, ... (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,203,1967 ed.)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Throughout this block, especially on the edges of the dead groves, `capeweed' or cat's-ear (Hypochaeris radicata) germinated in millions. ... (1926,Tutira,285)

Capeweed, cape weed. The English catsear (Hypochaeris radicata) is always so called in Canterbury. (Dr F.W. Hilgendorf; [1898 Morris Austral-English]) [re-arranged slightly to follow the clearer 1951 entry] (Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

BLAKISTON Keen to make two blades of grass grow where one had grown before, he had small patches of ground ploughed on the tops of hills and spurs where the black soil was only a few inches deep. When the sour clay beneath was turned up, it would grow nothing but Cape weed and Yorkshire fog. (1952,My Yesteryears,45) [NOTES: [f. c1869]]

Cape weed [=] catsear: hawksbeard [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,11)

n.

Cryptostemma calendulacea, Br. The Cape weed, which is plentiful in Auckland, is with us confined to the vicinity of Wanganui, where it is spreading rapidly. (1878,TrNZI,10/367)

HILGENDORF CAPE WEED ( Cryptostemma calendulaceum[1967 Calendula]) or Cape daisy is abundant in pastures and waste places in the North Island and is also recorded from Greymouth. It is a soft herb, rarely a foot high. ... This weed comes from Cape Colony and so is properly called `Cape Weed'. The same name is given to cats-ear, a much more common weed. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,184,1967 ed.)

cape-weed A South African plant, introduced into Australia and New Zealand as a fodder-plant, which has proven rather a nuisance. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),60)

Cape weed [s] Cryptostemma calendula (L.) Druce (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,11)

ADAMS Capeweed is found on dry sandy soils and poor open pasture near the sea. ... Botanical name: Cryptostemma calendula, South Africa. Family: Compositae. (1980,Wildflowers and Weeds,40)

TAYLOR CAPE WEED (Arctotheca calendula) ... This South Africa plant is well-established [on] the west coast of the North Island. ... [It] grows densely in many regions of Australia, where it is a bad weed of wheat ... It has often been called Cape daisy, but this name rightly belongs to a garden flower. (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,35)

cape weed NZ & Austral. yellow-flowered pasture-land weed. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,105) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

caper¶

n. NZ coll. since 1944 (phs earlier) in various senses of business'sort of thing', trick',dodge' etc., esp. inthat's the caper, that's the trick',that's satisfactory'.

LEE It's getting worse for this caper every year. (1944,Shining with the Shiner,75) [NOTES: [OED2]]

GASKELL It's one hell of a caper in a way. (1947,Big Game,12)

Marxism was the caper (Jun 12, 1959,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5/2) [NOTES: [OED2]]

caper spurge¶

n.

spurge, caper [s] Euphorbia lathyrus L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,74)

caperberry¶

n.

Caperberries : You may have noticed them draped over your martini glass in the hottest bars. Quite simply, caperberries are the new olive. Moreover, because they come attached to their stalks, they make an effective seduction tool. One can nibble the delicious, plump green fruit straight from the shaft in a manner that'll get you thrown out of under-aged premises. (Mar 17, 2002,Sunday Star Times,D2)

capex¶

n. portmanteau word for capital expenditure

What percenbtage of capex do you expect to spend this financial year?... A share of about 25 per cent of our capex this financial year will be spent on the new IT system. (Apr 22, 2002,NZ Infotech Weekly,No. 534 : 9)

abbr. capital expenditure

Now the government has taken on the burden of the single biggest capex cost hanging over Tranz Rail. (Jun 8, 2003,Sunday Star Times,D1)

Capital Mixing Bowl¶

phr.

The new WestpacTrust Stadium in Wellington, otherwise known as the "Capital Mixing Bowl", has some strange rules regarding food... Pull the plug on the Mixing Bowl. (Jan 23, 2000,Sunday Star Times,B2)

capital stock¶

1 n. (Rural) a farm animal retained over more than one season by the same owner.

Most farmers have seen the signs and have quit stock already including some capital stock ... (Sep 25, 1997,NZ Farmer,11)

Auction: complete line of capital stock in-calf heifers. (May 31, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,27)

Due to the property being sold this is a capital stock herd of top quality pure bred Angus females. (Apr 13, 2002,Dominion,33)

CAPM¶

abbr. capital asset pricing model

So the economic model called the Capital Asset Pricing model (CAPM pronounced "cap-em") apparently gives different answers to different public agencies - even after using the same consultants. (Sep 6, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

capping¶

n. The NZ university graduation ceremonies (held usu. in May), and the attendant activities, the University ceremony (and the various student activities associated with it) of formal presentation of a degree ? ca1900; capping day, capping week, capping magazine.

Sir Robert Stout ... announced at the last capping at Wellington that ... if the students persisted in their senseless conduct there would be no more capping ceremonies in public. (Aug 28, 1905,Westminster Gazette,2/3) [NOTES: [OED2]]

List what the Senate has said -/ `Capping for ever is dead'/ Gone is our function of solemn state, / (Jun 5, 1914,Auckland University Carnival Book,12) [NOTES: 1914 June 5 Auckland University College Students' Carnival Programme 12]

MULGAN `Capping' was the one day in the year when the college came before the public ... (1934,Spur of Morning,60)

LELAND Capping. In May of each year, the seven University level institutions hold their GRADUATIONS after a week of traditional hi-jinks. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,21)

capping n. 1. Scot. & N.Z. the act of conferring an academic degree. 2. (as modifier) Capping Day. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,164) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 104; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 70]]

Capping From Otago [headline] Ibid. 3 Capping Auckland Style [headline] (Jun 3, 1986,Campus News,2)

HULL Capping Songs are a matter of yearly duty, but these lyrical pieces are spontaneous. ... The greater part of these poems are Capping Songs - irresponsible expressions of College opinion, and humorous criticisms of ephemeral events in College life; ... (1907,College Songs,7) [NOTES: Auckland University College 1907. -]

The decision of the Board of Governors of Canterbury College to revive the function known as the capping ceremony this year led the students to mark the event with old-time gaieties... The students propose inaugurating the capping carnival with a Diploma Ball. (May 30, 1919,Press, The,6)

The annual "capping" of graduates who have kept their classes at the University of Otago took place in Garrison Hall last evening. (Aug 28, 1890,Otago Witness,25)

Capping parade was stopped because some students had sympathy to the strikers. (2000,Salient,12 : 17)

The University students' capping band also formed a guard of honour. (May 18, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,44)

2 n.

THOMPSON Only on one occasion in my high schooldays did my rage manifest itself. And that was very early in my first year, over the business of `capping'. Whatever capping meant (or means) elsewhere, in Greymouth it meant the ceremony by which new boys were initiated into the ways of high school by means of being belted on the rump with the rolled-up caps of older boys, peak outwards. For most Runanga boys this meant being thumped raw all the way to Greymouth on the train, and then being pushed through a tunnel of about 150 boys on the school ground and belted once again. (1980,All My Lives,30)

Capping Ball¶

n. a graduation ball

SLATTER ... the riding of bicycles around the dance floor at the Capping Ball, ... the raiding of the women's hostels for trophies (1968,Pagan Game, The,81)

n.

Speaking at the capping Banquet.. Dr.Barnett said he thought that the seniorstudents at the University.. should set ahigher standard to the first-year men. (Jul 3, 1912,Otago Witness,37)

capping ceremony¶

n. a graduation ceremony

They have given us a bad name and hanged us: and taken our Capping Ceremony from us. (Jun 6, 1913,Auckland University Carnival Book,20)

At the "Capping" ceremony last week,everything went as merry as a marriagebell... The "capping" occasion was SirJames Hector's first appearance before anOtago audience in his chancellor's togs. (Sep 4, 1890,Otago Witness,24)

The decision of the Board of Governors of Canterbury College to revive the function known as the capping ceremony this year led the students to mark the event with old-time gaieties... The students propose inaugurating the capping carnival with a Diploma Ball. (May 30, 1919,Press, The,6)

﻿At the "capping" ceremony in connectionwith the Auckland University College, theGovernor is reported to have said:-"Knowledge produced by cramming.. was notwhat was wanted." (Jun 14, 1899,NZ Times,7)

capping concert¶

n.

CAPPING COMMITTEE, 1934 ...CAPPING CONCERT, May 16th ... CAPPING BOOK, May 15th ... (1934,Otago University Capping Book,[inside cover])

Capping concert. At graduation time each year, the students of a number of New Zealand's Universities put on a musical stage show. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,21)

Student capping time in Dunedin for half a century or more centred largely on the capping concert - the equivalent of the "Extravaganza" revues of northern students. (May 24, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

Capping Day¶

n. graduation day

[Caption] What can be done to stimulate the public interest in politics? The Hon. W. Downie Stewart suggests that politicians should be caught young. How about introducing the Capping Day spirit and a few Varsity students? (May 2, 1928,NZ Free Lance,5)

We're students gathered here for fun on this our Capping Day;/ (Jun 6, 1912,Auckland University Carnival Book,9)

On Capping Day students of Victoria College had a procession ... (Jul 10, 1919,Quick March,49)

SLATTER ... he never wagged lectures to go on a pub crawl, ... he never made an exhibition of himself on Capping Day. (1968,Pagan Game, The,15)

KINROSS Round about the third race there was great excitement in the contingent from Victoria College, for there, ridden by Ben Deeley, was ... Capping Day; and it was largely unbacked. (1936,Please to Remember,88)
