CAPRONZ¶

abbr. (Rural) the Cashmere Producers' Organisation of New Zealand. [ORIGIN: acronym]

J of Ag June 13 There are fewer Cashmere producers (CAPRONZ 500, MOPANZ 3,000) and the fibre yield ... (Jun 13, 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture)

Kevin Were, the president of CAPRONZ, acknowledged that the lack of it [cashmere] was exacerbated by the reluctance of farmers to shear their animals because of the fear of losing them. (Aug 1987,NZ Journal of Agriculture,26)

At a CAPRONZ seminar at Flock House, Mr Were announced increases in cashmere prices... (Dec 7, 1988,NZ Farmer,5)

The emphasis of CAPRONZ's membership will largely be on fibre production. (Jun 13, 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture,17)

Captain Cook¶

n. a punch; hook.

NEWBOLD CAPTAIN COOK (n) Punch or hook. (1982,Big Huey, The,246)

n. (in allusive ref. to wild pigs allegedly descended from domestic pigs released by Captain Cook, according to a longstanding tradition or legend viz. [.ho;1840 Apr 25 Sarah Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 128 We passed numerous traces of wild pigs [in Northland], which are said to be very numerous, the descendants of those left by Captain Cook.)

These animals are a legacy bequeathed by Captain Cook, who ... let loose the few progenitors to the hundreds of thousands of pigs who roam the country ...] (Oct 4, 1861,NZ Goldfields,37) [NOTES: 1861 Oct 4 Dunedin in NZ Goldfields 1861 (1976) 37]

BATHGATE He stayed only ... to examine its long tusks ... which told that the boar was a patriarch of its kind. `He is evidently what the doctor calls "one of Captain Cook's original lot"', muttered Gilbert ... (1881,Waitaruna,282)

DAVIDSON ... as the dogs do most of the [pig-hunting] work, the knives ... are used principally [25] to inspire Captain Cook's proteges [e2-acute] with a due sense of respect ... (1889,Stories of NZ Life,24)

SCRYMGEOUR There, with much natural cover, were a number of wild pigs, descendants of the once liberated `Captain Cook' progeny. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,147)

n. = Captain Cooker (See cf. bush pig)

n.

BROOKES ... pig-hunting (of what is termed the Captain Cook breed) will be one of the past sports of New Zealand. [check citation] (1892,Frontier Life,122)

COWAN The old boar was so furious a brute that most of us, being ill-equipped for an argument with a Captain Cook tusker, shinned up a tree ... (1916,Bush Explorers,19)

MAXWELL ... wild pigs of the `Captain Cook' type ; many of them grisly monsters. (1937,Days With the Old Force,16)

BRUCE Here too is fresh evidence of the Captain Cook habitat (pig rootings). (1977,Life in the Hinterland of the South Island,75)

HENDERSON ... a shorthaired collie ... superb at bailing up wild cattle or Captain Cook pigs, plump from hinau berries ... (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,134)

n. Captain Cook, the proper title and surname of James Cook (1728-1779), the navigator and explorer, used allusively, then often as a noun in direct and attrib. use : see Captain Cook's ropes; and Captain Cook's cabbage, cress, scurvy grass at cabbage etc.

1 n. (Rural) a wild pig. (See also Captain Cooker)

Many a rare old tusker finds a home in the mountain gorges. The immense tusks at Brooksdale attest the size of the wild boars or Captain Cooks, as the patriarchs are generally named. (1879,NZ Country Journal,3/55) [NOTES: (W. Quin) [Morris]]

BATHGATE Wild boars are usually known by their name `Captain Cooks.' (1880,New Zealand (various authors/titles),7)

SWANTON The old boars among them are called `Captain Cooks', after the esteemed founder of their order. (1892,Notes on NZ,116)

MORRIS Captain Cook turned two pigs loose; but it is stated on authority that these pigs left no descendants. One was ridden to death by Maori boys, and the other was killed for sacrilege: he rooted in a tapu burial place. Nevertheless, the settlers still call any wild-pig, especially if lean and bony, a `Captain Cook'. (1898,Austral English,xviii)

In later years the `Captain-Cooks', as they were called, afforded splendid diet for the Maoris and early European visitors. (1907,TrNZI,39/228)

SCANLAN Yet in all this wilderness thereis no prowling beast or snake. Perhaps a chance `Captain Cook', one of the pigs, now wild, descended from those few liberated by Captain Cook when he first visited New Zealand. (1933,Tides of Youth,60)

Only Captain Cook in an ungetatable `bail' warrants the full-stop bullet, and only a fool doesn't put it in then; otherwise the knife's the caper. (Dec 1951,Here & Now,14)

Since the pig was introduced by Captain Cook ... [fn] Hence modern New Zealand slang a Captain Cook or Captain Cooker, for a wild pig. (Current since the late 19th century.) Also, slang, Pig-islands, Newzealand, Pig-islander, a Newzealander. (1945,Journal of the Polynesian Society,54/225fn)

WAKEFIELD The lean-ness and roughness of the wild pig gives it quite a different appearance from the domesticated variety; and hence a gaunt, ill-shaped, or sorry-looking pig is everywhere called in derision a `Captain Cook.' (1889,New Zealand After 50 Years,85)

The day before I meet them for my hunt, John and Andrea caught, gutted and carried a 62-kilogram Captain Cook boar out of the bush on their shoulders. (2009,Good,No. 7 (Jun-Jul): 75)

Amongst the sporting evenets of John Mckellar's time were the wild pig hunts he organised for townspeople, bush hands etc and many great days were held on the hills, where the 'Captain Cooks' were exceedingly numerous. (1910,Tapanui Station,15)

JONES The wild boars were generally called 'Captain Cooks.' (1933,Autobiography of an Early Settler,114)

Captain Cook's cabbage¶

n. Brassica oleracea, Maori cabbage.

HUNT ... we found ourselves in Evans' Bay; and here, to our great surprise, we discovered wild oats and turnips growing luxuriantly. By whom the seed was first sown God only knows; but as the Maori designates the turnip Captain Cook's cabbage, I presume that great circumnavigator had something to do with it. (1866,Chatham Islands,9)

(1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4) [NOTES: (And)]

Captain Cook's cress¶

n. Lepidium oleraceum [(Marlborough Sounds)] (See Cook's scurvy grass)

(Nature session) Dr Cohen [says] ... Captain Cook's cress or as some people call it Captain Cook's Scurvy Grass. It is edible. (Oct 31, 1951,2ZB)

Captain Cook's ropes¶

n. = bush lawyer.

PYKE Two species of wild vines. One of these is known to the settlers as supplejack' and the other has received the fantastic name ofCaptain Cook's ropes.' Rubus australis (1868,Province of Otago in NZ, The,35)

Captain Cooker¶

n. an informal name (often shortened to cooker) for a NZ wild pig (esp. a boar) of the lean, blue-gray, razor-backed variety allegedly descended from domestic pigs released by Captain Cook released among Maoris; also used of domestic pigs of this appearance whether orig., or bred from, wild pigs or not; esp. Maori pigs, and humorously; (See also Captain Cook; kunekune)

1 n. (Rural) a wild pig, Sus scrofa, also known as bush pig, grunter, Irish merino, poaka, and porker, among other names. The name comes from the pigs released into the wild by Captain James Cook, reputed to be domesticated white Berkshires.

He had all the savage characteristics ofthe real "Captain Cooker." (Nov 1, 1928,Evening Post,6)

In the 1770s, Captain Cook and his crew released pigs in New Zealand. Today, wild black pigs similar to those early porcine settlers are called Captain Cookers. (Aug 2008,North & South,66)

WATERSON Hedley suggested they take Mack, Wart's penning up dog, to see if they could round up a 'Captain Cooker' in the handy scrub country. (1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,70)

SCRYMGEOUR Running lightly to the fatter "Captain Cookers" Jim slipped out his sheath knife. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,148)

Neither red nor fallow deer have spread into the area in significant numbers, so wild pigs -Captain Cookers - have for years provided the main blood sport. (2006,National Geographic Magazine,77 / 85 , Jan - Feb)

CRAIG ... a real `Captain Cooker' came along. (1893,Hist. Rec. Jubilee Reunion of Old Colonists,7)

MORRIS Captain Cook, or Cooker, n. New Zealand colonists' slang. First applied to the wild pigs of New Zealand, supposed to be descended from those first introduced by Captain Cook; afterwards used as term of reproach for any pig which, like the wild variety, obstinately refused to fatten. see .us Introduction, p. xv. (1898,Austral English,79)

... the wild pig, or `Captain Cooker', ... (1899,TrNZI,31/471) [NOTES: (Walsh)]

[The dog] got `bailed up' a regular Captain Cooker, long, lean and muscular. (1902,Zealandia's Guerdon,42)

A Marlborough sport ... advanced into a gully where his two dogs had bailed up a Captain Cooker. (May 5, 1906,NZ Truth,46/1/8)

(Jul 17, 1915,Hutt Valley Independent,3)

... in those low ridges and bush-clad hills roamed herds of red deer and thousands of `Captain Cookers'. (Sep 10, 1921,Quick March,23)

ANTHONY I aimed my gun carefully, and shot that inquisitive looking Captain Cooker fair between the eyes. (1975,Follow the Call,121) [NOTES: a1927 Anthony Dave Baird in Follow the Call (1975) 121]

Captain cooker. Slang for wild pig. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

HYDE ... - from tiger to New Zealand moose, from a wicked-looking Captain Cooker to a forlorn little black bear, ... (1934,Journalese,108)

... Captain Cooker' is well known, better known thanFuller's Earth' as a synonym for New Zealand (from the theatrical family). (Apr 4, 1938,Press, The) [NOTES: 1938 Apr 4 McNab NZ Slang Press]

HYDE They climbed until they got to the turrets of the big rocks, and heard wild pig crashing in the undergrowth. `Old Captain Cooker, eh?' said Starkie softly. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,128)

Since the pig was introduced by Captain Cook ... [fn] Hence modern Newzealand slang a Captain Cook or Captain Cooker, for a wild pig. (Current since the late 19th century.) Also, slang, Pig-islands, Newzealand, Pig-islander, a Newzealander. (1945,Journal of the Polynesian Society,54/225fn)

HALL-JONES While the wild pig is generally known as a `Captain Cooker,' the great navigator never released these animals in the South Island. Captain Furneaux liberated some at Queen Charlotte Sound. (1945,Historical Southland,36)

SOLJAK New Zealanders have coined or adapted many expressions to meet local requirements, as illustrated by the following: ... Captain Cooker: wild pig; pigs were first introduced by Captain Cook (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),117)

... Captain Cooker in the Main Street. (1949,Marlborough Express) [NOTES: 1949 [? date] Marlborough Express, Havelock Notes [p?]]

HUNT `Captain Cookers', with sharp snouts and formidable tusks, waged constant war with a group of dogs ... that rushed towards ... food thrown out on to the open spaces [of the pa]. Running from place to place, the half-grown porkers led a precarious life ... (1951,Confessions,34)

The pigs [introduced by Cook] seem ... to have taken hold and to rank among the progenitors of the ... wild swine which have been traditionally known as `Captain Cookers'. (Apr 1952,NZ Geographer,4) [NOTES: (Murphy)]

DEWAR At the season when bokakas dropped their berries the wild pigs made a migration from tree to tree, and a `Captain Cooker' was not despised [in Southland c1900]. [fn] Bokaka : Pokaka. (1953,Chaslands,82)

~ Wild pig in New Zealand supposed to be decended from those introduced by Captain Cook. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),61)

DAVIN `Man, it's a Captain Cooker.' (1959,No Remittance,138)

McLINTOCK Examples of slang and colloquial expressions of local origin are ...Captain Cooker for a wild pig,. . . (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/680) [NOTES: (Wall NZ Speech)]

Captain Cookers ... n. (N.Z. Sl.) N.Z. wild boars, supposed to be descendants of pigs released by Capt. Cook, 1770. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),5)

Although the wild pig in this country has traditionally ben known as a `Captain Cooker', the succesful introduction of pigs into northern New Zealand may be attributed to Lieutenant-Governor King of Norfolk Island. (1971,New Zealand's Heritage,1/253)

BARTLETT In this great forest there were flocks of native pigeons ... and wild pigs, the long-legged descendants of Captain Cookers. (1974,Emigrants, The,57)

HENDERSON Some of these free Captain Cooker hams and bacon were delicious. (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,61)

[Breeds of pig] Also feral pig (Captain Cooker) and kuni kuni (Maori pig). (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,45)

BURTON Although Cook was the first to liberate pigs in New Zealand, the modern `Captain Cookers' found in the north are more likely to be descendants of pigs sent to New Zealand by Lieutenant-Governor King of Norfolk Island. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,13)

Captain Cooker n. N.Z. a wild pig. [< Captain James Cook (1728-79), E. navigator, who first released pigs in the N.Z. bush] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,164) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 106; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 70]]

McSweeney is battling to control crop damage caused by feral pigs and Canada geese on his 2400ha high-country sheep run at Arthurs Pass. "Captain Cookers did this," he says as he strides through a devastated field of turnips he was growing for winter stock feed. (Mar 8, 2001,Press, The,B4)

HENDERSON A shorthaired collie.. superb at bailing up wild cattle or Captain Cook pigs, plump from hinau berries. (1983,Dominion Sunday Times,134)

However, warm husky red wine, with its nuances of animal and earth, is not yet a strength of New Zealand's wine artists, and, as these are the soul companions for roast leg of captain cooker, you need to look further afield. (Aug 6, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

Many of them [sc. pigs] were of a fair breed and in good condition, while others were of that nondescript or mongrel character that is generally known as "Captain Cook's". (May 24, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,8)

CRESSWELL The "Captain Cookers" were so plentiful that from two to three hundred were usually killed, every year. (1956,Early NZ Families,108)

TIFFEN The 'Captain Cookers' were so plentiful that from two to three hundred were usually killed every year. (1845,Journal,108) [NOTES: in Cresswell (1949) Early New Zealand Families 1949]

We had heard their dogs baiting the pigs at intervals throughout the day, and learn afterwards that they have secured three or four "Captain Cookers" almost, however, losing one of their dogs in the scrimmage. (Aug 15, 1900,Hawera Star,4)

He cut the tail from the dead pig then gently led the blind Captain Cooker back to the truck, where he was quickly disposed of. (Nov 13, 1975,NZ Farmer,100)

MCGREGOR There have been occasions when Captain Cookers, caught when young, have struck up strong friendships with dogs. (1980,Dog's Life, A,123)

CARR The snorting and bellowing coming from that direction sounded more like a Hereford bull than a true Captain Cooker ... (1986,Diary of a Pig Hunter,81)

HYDE Wild pigs, known as Captain Cookers, barged and rooted. (1937,Wednesday's Children,135) [NOTES: 1989 edition]

They were called "Captain Cookers" and had been brought from New Zealand. (Mar 30, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,96)

I just dived like a flash uv greasedlightnin'.. an' stuck 'im like I uster aCaptain Cooker. (Jul 25, 1917,Chronicles NZEF,II/23 : 244)

MCGREGOR There were wild cattle, sheep and pigs, the latter real Captain Cookers, long snouted, huge tusks, long-legged and rangy. (1978,Mangaohane: The Story of a Sheep Station,39)

Captain Crimp¶

n.

SINCLAIR Among the Wellington settlers, Hobson was called `Captain Crimp' because, having insulted them by placing his capital in the north, he then sent a ship to entice some of the Wellington labourers to help in building Auckland. (1959,History of New Zealand,104)

captain's biscuit¶

n. = cabin biscuit q.v. [a mishearing by Lush?]

LUSH Returned to breakfast at 8: fried captain's biscuit and very good it is - the biscuit is soaked in water overnight and then fried in a little butter the next morning. (Dec 25, 1853,Auckland Journals,147,1971 ed.)

capture paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a paddock enclosed by deer fences where newly-captured deer are placed.

ANDERSON One of the simplest was for the catching firm [deer catchers] or the farmer on whose property the deer happened to be, to build a capture paddock, perhaps in a suitable mountain valley. The helicopter then 'rounded up' the deer and drove as many as possible of them into the capture paddock. (1978,Gold on Four Feet,15)

car¶

n. a carriage

... started with the Bishop and Mrs Harper in the Carr. (Jan 30, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,75,1950 ed.)

n. a motorcycle side-car

n. a motorcycle side-car

ANTHONY Gus hasn't got a lady friend just for the time, and sooner than go by himself, he wants me to ride in his car [other texts `cart'] with him to the next dance ... when Gus arrived with his buzzer at my gate, I just slipped on an overcoat over the rig-out, and stepped into the side-car. (1924,Me and Gus,11) [NOTES: c1924 Anthony Me and Gus (1977 Gus Tomlins ed. Sturm) 11]

CAR¶

abbr. Canterbury Adult Rural education scheme

The Car scheme was aimed at individuals rather than groups. In 1930, Shelley persuaded the Carnegie Corporation of New York to provide him with enough money, over a period of years, to set up a travelling library. A small van was purchased and, with a pun, was labelled Car, for Canterbury Adult Rural education scheme. (Sep 27, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49)

car-attached¶

adj. (of a goods train) with passenger carriages attached

Nor was it enjoyed by passengers on the 'car-attached' goods train No.590 which picked up passengers from the Wellington-Auckland express at Marton each evening. (Dec 2002,NZ Memories,No. 39/54)

car-case¶

n. as a building material

HARVEY Dad had built rather a neat fowl-house out of car-cases and malthoid away up on the hill, after chipping out a large flat piece from the clay. (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,2)

CONEY The car-case bach still stands down in the Piha Valley. (1990,Out of the Frying Pan,46)

car-shed¶

n. garage

KING ... [sic] this was because he was going to build a car-shed. The shed only just fitted between the footpath and the back wall of our house, ... [reference c1920] (1982,Seen But Not Heard,111)

caraceer¶

n. (See karaka)

caracol¶

n.

Butch is in the caracol, what comes of drinkin' alcohol. (Dec 21, 1942,NZEF Times,II/78 : 18)

carageen¶

n.

MARTIN A South Island firm is also ... preparing sea-meal for culinary purposes from several species of NEW ZEALAND CARRAGREEN (Gigartina). Ibid. 26 The immense masses of NEW ZEALAND DULSE or CARRAGREEN (Gigartina) exposed in some areas are now being harvested for the peparation of sea-meal. (1929,Flora NZ,6)

carapid¶

n. a fish

[species name] echiodon cryomargarites .. [scientific name] Echiodon cryomargarites .. [other name(s)] messmate fish, carapid (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

cararoon¶

n.

CARAROONS ... egg whites ... salt ... sugar ... cornflakes ... cocoanut ... almond essence ... Drop a teaspoon on to a greased paper laid on a greased tray ... (1934,Marigold Book of Recipes, The,26)

Caravan¶

n. cigarette [a pun on Craven A, and the droppings left by passing camel caravans.]

YSKA Another brand of cigarette called Caravan more aptly suggested the mystery ingredient: it was camel dung. (1990,NZ Green,44)

Caravan A instead of just caravan. (Jan 9, 1942,2NZEF Times,32/6) [NOTES: (Johnny Enzed)]

A brand of alleged cigarettes issued free to the troops. In the same classification as V's. Correct name `Caravans' - others deleted by censor. (1946,Johnny Enzed in Italy)

SLATTER `Clueless, that's what he is. Gonna cost me dough. Cinque mille and a carton of Caravan A thrown in.' (1970,On the Ball,136)

Unless I bought some Caravan A instead of just Caravan he would view it with even more concern. (Feb 9, 1942,NZEF Times,I/33 : 6)

carbash¶

n. a fight

carbie/carby¶

n. a carburettor

SUTHERLAND `If you was to stir your old wreck along a bit faster she wouldn't get flyblown - you never hear of Harrington getting maggots in the carbie, do you now?' (1956,Green Kiwi,126,1960 ed.)

The new [Heinemann's] dictionary carries: ... mall, ... M.O.W. and o.n.o. ... dropper (for fencing) ... and garage sale. It does not contain diff and carby (which have now moved from slang into general use among at least half the population), leg-in, woolly (as a noun), farmlet, fat (or sharp) sand, nor, amazingly, home-brew. (Mar 28, 1979,Otago Daily Times,21) [NOTES: (G. Griffiths)]

Carbine¶

n. Transf. to a horse put out to grass.

HISLOP Being a tender-hearted sort of chap ... he asked me if I would mind putting a bullet in [the sheep-worrier's] head ... [and burying it] near the road boundary - `about opposite the old horse will do,' he said, as he pointed to his old Carbine taking it easy in his old age. (1943,Pure Gold,124)

SCRYMGEOUR Charlie Eager shouted with approval [at the win in the cross country horse race], Hell, Stewie old horse, had I known you were such a carbine, would have had a placard on your backDalgety's for Woolpacks'.' (1960,Memories of Maoriland,180)

carbonette¶

n. a briquette of compressed coal dust, used in fires [a trademark].

BAXTER Tonight the carbonettes/ Are glowing in the fire at Kathy's house. (1979,Collected Poems,593) [NOTES: 1972 Sep 4 in 1979 Baxter Collected Poems 593]

FRAME That evening we sat in our armchairs ... by the carbonette fire. (1979,Living in the Maniatoto,51)

LELAND Carbonettes (North Island): hard packed BRIQUETS of COKE. Long and hot burning. The biggest bit of culture shock I've experienced in New Zealand was moving from the North Island, where these are sold in every neighborhood store (dairy) and gas (petrol) station, to the South Island and trying to buy some. No one knew what I was talking about. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,22)

[Such] can be virtually restricted to the Antipodes - carbonette, five-eighth, or huntaway (dog) - or even to New Zealand - dairy (the shop), trundler or section (which is N.Z.) in the sense a plot of land for building' but <i>Austral.</i> and <i>N.Z</i>. in the sensea fare stage on a bus, train etc.' (Aug 20, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),100)

carbonette n. N.Z. a ball of compressed coal dust used as fuel. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,166) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 71]]

... in the north we refer to little lumps of coal dust as carbonettes. (Jan 1989,Pacific Way,11) [NOTES: (Sharp New Zildish)]

CarboNZero¶

n. initiative to lower carbon emissions in NZ

A few months back, all staff at the Auckland studios were handed a pack that included a coffee mug, native plant seedling, pocket ashtray and information on the CarboNZero initiative. ... The CarboNZero project is a promise to balance the company's CO2 emissions with investment in forest regeneration projects that will absorb greenhouse gases. (Dec 12, 2005,Dominion Post,C2)

card rug¶

n.

WILSON But all round the perimeter [of the two-up ring] sat solemn cross-legged men with their crown and anchor boards and their card rugs set out before them ... (1956,Sweet White Wine,138)

card-not-present¶

adj.

[He] is part of a plague hitting online retailers and card owners alike - using stolen credit-card numbers in online "card-not-present" transactions. (Jun 1, 2004,Dominion Post,A13)

cardamine¶

n. heterophylla.

FEATON (And.) (1889,Art Album NZ Flora)

cardie/cardy¶

n. a cardigan [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

Not cardie patterns and Mince 101, she adds hurriedly, but something along those lines. (Feb 9, 2006,Dominion Post,D1)

But the old cardy image is reinforced when RNZ sets up a new weeknight arts and entertainment show and calls it What's Going On? (Dec 6, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

n. [ca1935 (Havelock) Put on your cardy, or else you'll get cold.' 1954 R. MasonOccasionally heard, but usually in speaking to small children.]

We brought out the cardie and raincoat when we were told. (Dec 17, 1992,Evening Post,8)

In actuality, it is the day when.. staid secretaries who all year have worn cardies and taken Earl Grey expose their preference for Geneva gin on the rocks and lacy black scraps next to the skin. (Dec 19, 1992,Evening Post,4)

In the glare of the neon strips is the soft glow of a great deal of grey hair and a disproportionate number of Sunday-best cardies. (Aug 25, 1999,Evening Post,22)

You can't do that with a cardy and a floral chiffon frock. (Jan 2000,North & South,63)

LELAND Cardigan or cardie: A SWEATER that is cut like a jacket in that it buttons up the front. These grow more common as you go south into the colder weather. Sweater sets that include cardigans are popular with some of the ladies. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,22)

HULME This godzone baby talk. Hottie, lolly, cardie, nappy, crappy, the lot of it, she snarls to herself. But what to say that the kid'd recognise? (1983,Bone People, The,31)

Where else are they so big on hypocorisms? ... They're those dinky little words we make up, like these: kiddies (children), cardies (cardigans), boatie (person who sails boats), yachtie (person who sails yachts), drinkies (drinks), bikies (people who get together to ride motorbikes), wrinklies (old people), rellies (relations), wellies (Wellingtons, as in gumboots), wallies (variation on wankers), littlies (children). (Sep 1988,North & South,41)

Those strangely infantile condensations - prezzies' andrellies' (for presents and relatives) were bandied about on the radio quite a bit recently. It looks as if they are going to join veges, ciggy, brekky, cardy - and all the rest as OK idiom. But there is one antipodean expression that charms people internationally ... That is the word `naughty', for sexual intercourse. (Jan 10, 1989,Evening Post,6)

SLIGO Mum was wearing a brown cardie ... (1987,Final Things,13)

That he was wearing a cardy was the tragedy. (Apr 22, 2000,Evening Post,11)

Even the handknitted cardie, which, as Bronwyn Labrum, Te Papa curator of history and textiles, points out is "a really New Zealand thing", came from sport. The cardigan, she says, was a golfing garment before Coco Chanel popularised it. (Dec 18, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

She stomps off, a rottweiler in a cardie. (Oct 30, 2002,Dominion Post,B5)

Alas, this doesn't mean that the fraudsters will soon be filmed guiltily emerging from their homes in their grubby cardies with police escorts. (Apr 8, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

Gone are the days of public servants in brown cardies, corduroys and grey shoes; the senior public service has always contained some fine minds. (Oct 4, 2000,Dominion,4)

FARRELL She took her cardy and wrapped it roundthe thing then stood carefully, wobblinga little. (1992,Skinny Louie Book,15)

It's [sc. the body's] just like an old cardy - when you finish with it, you throw it away. (Oct 12, 1991,Dominion,13)

cardigan capital¶

n. Wellington, seen as a capital city with an image of public servant drabness

From cardigan capital to popular tourist town [hg] .. The transformation from cardigan capital to tourism town isn't complete but it's well on track.. This was a government town, a cardigan capital. (Jul 5, 2006,Dominion Post,B5)

Cossar, T This Tourism Action Plan is an outline of what is needed to help complete Wellington's metamorphosis from 'cardigan capital' to ultimate urban destination. (Feb 2004,Wellington Tourism Action Plan 2004-2209,2)

cardinal fish¶

n.

[species name] cardinal fish .. [scientific name] Epigonus sp. .. [other name(s)] unspecified - see also Epigonus telescopus, E. robustus and E. lenimen (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

Cardinal Huff¶

n. a drinking game

Other well-known [drinking] games are Hokonui Swindle, Bottles, Fluffy Ducks, Bunnies are Hovering, Cardinal Huff, All Blacks, Matches, and The Amazing Grimaldi Brothers. All these games involve either a complicated intellectual exercise, tongue twisters, mathematical calculations or aerobatics in a confined space; High Candelabras for example, involves intoxicated individuals attempting to traverse the four walls of a room without touching the floor. (Mar 13, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,16)

cardy capital¶

n. [aka cardi capital, cardie capital]

It makes it clear that Wellington is now longer the cardy capital of the world - - or that if it is, the cardigans will be something ironic put together by a post-modern designer as a fashion statement rather than a woolly artefact of the Gliding On years. (Dec 9, 2006,Dominion Post,4)

THE CARDIE CAPITAL (Jun 25, 2005,Dominion Post,1)

CARE¶

abbr.

Anti-apartheid groups split last night over the controversial visit of the South African golf team. The Citizens Association of Racial Equality (Care) entered a pact not to disrupt the tourney featuring the South Africans in Auckland. But Halt All Racist Tours (Hart) pledged to go ahead with plans to disrupt the event. (Sep 23, 1971,Otago Daily Times,3) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

CARE n. acronym for: ... 2. N.Z. Citizens' Association for Racial Equality. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,167) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 72]]

CHAPPLE Then in 1964 one organization, CARE, the Citizens' Association for Racial Equality, which had as its twin aims the promotion of racial equality and opposition to apartheid. (1981,Tour, The,6)

[The meeting, organised by the Citizens'Association for racial equality, heardfour speakers, two of them Maoris,declare that the Springboks should not bewelcomed in New Zealand because of theapartheid policies of their country.] (Jun 30, 1965,NZ Herald,2)

The Campaign for the Advancement ofRacial Equality (CARE) has decided tosupport a move to coordinate theactivities of all the groups opposed tothe 1970 Rugby tour of South Africa, (Jan 14, 1969,NZ Herald,1)

THOMPSON C.A.R.E. objections to the tour were summarised in one of its leaflets. (1975,Retreat from Apartheid,54)

The meeting, chose the titles Citizens' Association for Racial Equality, whose initials spelled the felicitous acronym CARE.. which.. became a household word throughout New Zealand in the years which fol lowed. (1989,25 Years of Care,3)

career girl¶

1 n. (Rural) a ewe that refuses to accept and feed her lamb.

A ewe that will not mother her lamb - career girl. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

Dry humour runs thick through this collection .. career girl - a ewe that refuses to mother her lamb ... (Nov 22, 2002,Dominion,C6)

cargon¶

n. the cargon-system is a system of handling air-cargo, used by the Straits Air Freight Express Ltd and conceived by Mr T.M.A. O'Connell, General Manager: the aeroplane is built without a conventional floor, and rails are built into the fuselage and the cargon (or pallet), like a huge, wheeled tray, pre-packed with goods, is easily wheeled in or out of the aircraft (R. Mason). -

(Aug 13, 1956,Press, The)

SLATTER [Postal workers'] There was [postal] work [in the 1960s], hard satisfying work. Unloading parcel bags, huge cumbersome containers nicknamed pre-fabs, from a three-door Z. There was slots, there was lumps, there was packing fragies in bottlos, there was the tying down of the north line for a clearance, the scissors, lead seals and squeezers. The sorters on call-back flicking circulars with precision. The volcanoes of letters on the facing-up table, the checker chanting the reds onto the lorry, the checker calling the overseas in, London 45 ... The queue of men working at the parcel depot or the postal siding ... Tieing down the cargon. ... The sorters' school at the posties' pub known colloquially as Box 44 or the B.B.C., the Back Bar of the Cecil. The cheerful abuse of cobbers. (1968,Pagan Game, The,85)

The "cargon", a New Zealand inventionused by Straits Air Freight Company tospeed the loading and unloading of itsair freighters at Paraparaumu, may beadopted for use at most of the world'sairports in a few years' time... A bigcontainer, the "cargon" can be loaded inWellington and taken to Paraparaumu readyto put straight into the air freighters. (Sep 5, 1952,Evening Post,4)

carillon¶

n. a bell-tower and set of bells

Last Anzac Day in Wellington the bells of the refurbished National War Memorial Carillon sounded for the fallen... Carillons (generally pronounced here as if spelt "carillion") consist of at least 23 stationary bells, which sound when struck by clappers controlled by wires attached to a clavier (keyboard). (Jun 11, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),104)

The carillon (pronounced badly by antipodeans as carill-i-on, (Hurd says) is the bell-tower in front of the old museum on Buckle Street. (Apr 25, 2001,Capital Times,3)

cark¶

v. (also cark it, cark out) die or falter

I also saw a sleeping vagrant on La Brea, carked out with too little of the American dream, his tatty back pack bearing a small copy of old glory. (Oct 7, 2001,Sunday Star Times,C4)

LELAND Cark out, to GO TO SLEEP, often as a result of alcohol intake or exhaustion, or to DIE. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,22)

McGILL cark collapse and die, of person or machine, in phr. cark it to die, cark out to collapse into a drunken stupor; possibly derived from slaughtered carcass of an animal; eg `When the scrum collapsed on Rippin, I thought he was goin' to cark.' N (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,25)

...the most-hated feature is how it [sc. Windows 9x] carks in various mysterious fashions thanks to some important system file being overwritten or deleted without notice. (Sep 2000,NZ PC World,20)

Denis carking it in intensive care on Tuesday night's Coro Street drama left me utterly cold because this dramatic hospital scene is now so frequent on television that most viewers, if push came to shove, would be able to perform the CPR procedure from having watched it a million times over (Jul 11, 2002,Dominion Post,B9)

'How 'bout we celebrate me making it to halfway, eh Dad. Lucky thirteen and I haven't carked it yet.' (2001,Huia 4: Contemp. Maori Fiction,75)

It wasn' until the following year when there were a few photos in the album that I said, "Why do you reckon I carked out on that first trip?" (Jan 19, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

CHAPPLE 'If we kark outin the bush just gut us and leave us there,' said Noel. (2002,Te Araroa: the New Zealand Trail,194)

But instead, in 1977, Tarzan Presley carks it, his black pompadour turned floppy, his girth a balloon. (Jun 5, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),65)

carkoi¶

n. (informal) a hikoi travelling in cars

Hundreds of Rotorua people are forming a "carkoi" to travel to Auckland's hikoi on Monday to support calls for Maori seats for the Super City.Auckland iwi have planned the hikoi to demand proper representation in the planned Auckland Super City.Waiariki MP Te Ururoa Flavell, from Rotorua, said he was rapt to hear so many local people were supporting the cause."The people here are professionals when it comes to carkoi and I'm stoked to see that hundreds of them are prepared to take part. (May 23, 2009,Daily Post (Rotorua)) [NOTES: Internet edition]

carless day¶

n. (historical)

Carless day wheelies [headline] (Oct 3, 1979,Dominion,3)

JONES All this car-less day nonsense is ludicrous. If the government is really serious about saving 10 per cent of petrol consumption they should simply shoot every tenth motorist. (Jul 30, 1979,Letter,106) [NOTES: 1979 July 30 in 1982 Jones Letters 106]

LELAND carless days: On the 30th July 1979, New Zealand introduced a drastic fuel conservation measure ... This was the banning of the operation of all privately and petrol powered motor vehicles weighing 4,400 lbs or less (except for motor-cycles) for one day per week. That day to be chosen by the owner of the vehicle in question. ... You will see a green sticker with a white X upon it next to the red carless day sticker on the windscreens of exempt vehicles. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,22)

My carless day was Thursday. With oil prices dropping through the sump I can probably scrape the sticker off my windscreen now. Remember carless days, exemption stickers, weekend petrol sales bans, plans for petrol rationing, the Iranians cutting their oil production to a quarter, the somber pleas of the Government to `go easy on energy', the threat of petrol prices going through the garage roof? (Apr 13, 1986,NZ Times,8)

This contributed to a significant drop in the road toll, as did 'carless days' and the halting of weekend petrol sales in 1979. (Jun 2003,AA Directions,51)

Carlyon pony¶

1 n. (Rural) a breed of pony that is cream, with a black tail and manes [introduced in Hawke's Bay by Major Carlyon.]

TAIT The Carlyon pony introduced a new breed of pony - cream with a black tail and manes. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,7)

NEWTON Cream with a black mane, the breed was evolved through Major Carlyon crossing imported Exmoor sires with local horses. They became widely known as the Carlyon ponies and are held in high repute. Later in my travels I saw a Carlyon stallion at Ahinewairua Station in the Inland Patea: it was a beautiful pony. These Carlyon horses are cream with a black mane and tail ... he has a batch of yearlings by the Carlyon horse out of draught mares ... [Carlyon horse] (1969,Big Country of the North Island,132)

Carmine rata¶

n. [Metrosideros carminea, a climbing rata]

Myrtaceae Metrosideros carmineacarmine rata (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri]

Carmine rata is the showiest of the climbing rata and has a distinct juvenile and adult form. (Oct 23, 2004,Dominion Post,E13)

Mary Robertson Metrosideros carminea or Carmine Rata is a close relative of the Pohutukawa. (Dec 10, 2009,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.maryrobertson.co.nz/climbing-rata.html]

carnal¶

n. short for carnal knowledge

ARNEFELT `No one would dare send them to prison. They're just up for carnal.' (1971,Catching Up,90)

carnal knowledge¶

n. (in law, often in phrase unlawful carnal knowledge) sex with an under-age female

ARMFELT `Do you think he actually had carnal knowledge of her?' ...I doubt it. ... It help her reputation with the other kids.'' [see also carner] 240 `... up before the court for Unlawful Carnal Knowledge ...' (1971,Catching Up,145)

MORRIESON The girl's under age ... thats a twelve-mouth rap for carnal knowledge. I hope he's got plenty of gold. (1974,Predicament,1981)

carner¶

n.

ARMFELT And Trevor was no longerTrevour', but Carner'. He was said to have tumbled to this title with Annette in his sleeping bag. <i>Ibid.</i> 199 She read about somebody being fined for carnal knowledge of a girl under the age of sixteen ... She didn't know <i>exactly</i> what it was, but she knew that acarner' was a person who did it. [the writer is a non-NZder; shaky on idiom] (1971,Catching Up,144)

carnie/carny¶

n. (informal) underage (under 16) girl as a sexual object (from the older term `unlawful carnal knowledge' sc. of a girl younger than 16 years).

He used to call her `Carny', a popular term for anyone who had carnal knowlege and was underage. A boy who knew this, also knew he was committing a criminal offence if intercourse took place. (Nov 27, 1962,NZ Truth,13)

Blackie knew her by the name carny', a term used to describe a girl who was under the age of sixteen. ... The people with whom she associated commonly called hercarny', the girl said. She understood the term to mean a girl under sixteen and also to have something to do with carnal knowledge. (Mar 26, 1963,NZ Truth,11)

SHADBOLT All these little teenybopper girls used to hang around trying to look tough, but none of the guys would touch them because they were all carnies. (1971,Bullshit and Jellybeans,34)

carnie: womaniser[?]; sexy (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

McGILL carnie sexually desirable and probably available female under the lawful age of 16 for sexual intercourse, short for carnal knowledge'; akajailbait', because of jail sentence for male convicted of carnal knowledge. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,25)

LELAND carny kid: JAIL BAIT (see: age of consent). (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,22)

carousel¶

n. a type of milking platform

I have just watched the afternoon milking of 350 cows. It took about an hour in a rotary shed that has more in common with the Sydney Opera House than with John Scott's old herringbone shed... One at a time, the cows boarded a huge, slow merry-go-round capable of holding 66 animals and stood side by side like slides in a carousel, heads facing the centre. Ibid. 39 A few metres away, Danny Woodcock, the sharemilker, removed cups from the cows as the carousel completed its circuit. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/38)

carp¶

n.

FULLER In the thermal areas of the North Island it is not long ago that one could watch people diving for carp, ... and cooking them in the ngawha (hot springs). (1978,Maori Food and Cookery,13)

2 n. tarakihi

SHERRIN EHOUHOUNAMU (Chilodactylus spectabilis). ... [19] Dr. Hector says it is common near the East Cape, and is called by the Natives ehouhounamu or nanua. The family to which this fish belongs - the Cirrhitidae - contains the hiwi-hiwi, the tarakihi, the moki, the trumpeter, and the porae, most of which are well-known fish, and stand, as it were, sponsors of its belonging to a good parentage. The same fish is found in Tasmania, where it is call the `carp,' ... Ibid. 98 TARAKIHI (Chilodactylus macropterus). ... The tarakihi is found in the Tasmanian waters, where it is known as the black perch. ... In Sydney it is called the carp, or morwong, where its length varies from 12in. to 18in. (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,18)

Carpenter's Gothic¶

n. (cf. builder's, businessman's Gothic etc.) a degenerate architectural style. [nonce use?]

LOUGHNAN Gradually everything [owing to the use of wood for all building] degenerates [in NZ] into the style known as `Carpenter's Gothic.' (1922,New Zealand At Home,210)

carpet¶

n. a one-pound note

Following are other local money-names: - 1pound note - flimsy, rag or carpet... (Jan 14, 1899,Sydney Bulletin,(Red Page)) [NOTES: (Letter from -->Loafer, Tauranga) [Bill Pearson]]

The pound note of pre-decimal days was variously [sic] known as a quid, nicker, smacker, flimsy, rag, and carpet. The latter term was apparently peculiar to New Zealand and Australia. (Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,16)

carpet fern¶

1 n. (Rural) Paesia scaberula, hard fern or ring fern.

HINDMARSH The sweet fern (also known as hard fern, ring fern and carpet fern) was burned and grass sown on about 250 acres of the hardiest country. (1997,Come Be a Pioneer,136)

(And) Hymenophyllum demissum carpet fern. (1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue)

Paesia scaberula (hard fern, ring fern, scented fern, carpet fern) is considered one of the most troublesome weeds of the wetter hill farms of New Zealand. (1943,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,23/113B)

Although I crush carpet fern in my pastures by feeding out hay to cows during the winter, the fern still comes away in the spring. Total elimination of carpet fern (better known as hard or ring fern) under high rainfall conditions even under topdressing and stocking is not easy. (Mar 1967,NZ Journal of Agriculture,13)

.. the control of carpet fern has allowed them to do stock much better. (Sep 25, 1997,NZ Farmer,13)

carpet grass¶

n. (Rural) a smooth lawn-like turf found in high basins [ favoured by musterers wanting a rest.]

CURTIS I was halfway up the hill when I slipped on a patch of smooth carpet grass and spilt all the water. (1996,Beneath the Mountain Mist,27)

THOMSON A kind of carpet grass was also in abundance. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,99)

MCLEOD Walk up the open ridges, taking a spur each, and hunt the sheep back towards the higher basins where the soft green 'carpet grass' surrounded little icy tarns lying black among the many-coloured boulders. (1960,Tall Tussock,47)

1 n. (Rural) [high country] a comfort-loving, soft working dog.

MCLEOD Glossary of High Country terms: Carpet grass: Used to describe ease or laziness, eg 'carpet grass bastard' or soft or lazy dog. (1960,Tall Tussock,124)

MCLEOD ..we call a dog which doesn't like running on shingle a "carpet grass so-and-so." (1951,NZ High Country,43)

carpet shark¶

n. [both one the ground sharks and a general term applied to whale sharks]

haloscyllium isabella aterre. The carpet- shark ... is common in the harbour and along the coast. (1913,TrNZI,45/235) [NOTES: (Thomson, Otago)]

3. Cephaloscyllium laticeps Dumeril. Carpet Shark. (1929,TrNZI,60/139) [NOTES: (Young)]

Cephaloscyllium sabella: Carpet-shark. (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,71)

Cephaloscyllium sabella (Broussonet). Carpet shark (ground shark). (1938,TrRSNZ,68/400) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

GRAHAM Carpet Shark Cephaloscyllium isabella (Bonnaterre) (Syn. Scyllium lima Richardson) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,397) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 397]

GRAHAM CARPET SHARK (PEKAPEKA) Cephaloscyllium isabella (Bonnaterre) ... It is known in Australia as the Draughtsboard Shark. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,66)

WILLIAMS Pekapeka, ...Cephaloscyllium isabellum, carpet shark. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,275)

McLINTOCK Carpet shark Pekapeka, Cephaloscyllium isabellum (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

DOOGUE & MORELAND SWELL SHARK ... Othe names: Cephaloscyllium isabellum ; carpet shark; draughtsboard shark (Australia); pekapeka (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,188)

[species name] carpet shark .. [scientific name] Cephaloscyllium isabella .. [other name(s)] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] shark, carpet 182-94 (14) CAT SHARK [?chk separate entry CATSHARK] (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] shark, cat 195 SHARKS, CAT 181-96 (14a) SHARK, CIGAR (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

One such "egg-purse" of a carpet shark.. contained a lively sharklet swimming round inside with yolk-sac attached. (Oct 5, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,60)

The carpet-shark, Cephaloscyllium sabella, was first listed from new Zealand by Hutton ... under the name Scyllium laticeps. Ibid. 265 Fig. 8. - Carpet-shark, Cephaloscyllium sabella. (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/264) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

SPEIGHT ... the rather flat headed, broadly mottled Carpet Shark or Cat Shark .. ( Cephaloscyllium isabella ) does not seem to grow much more than three feet in length. (1927,Natural History of Canterbury,192) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 192]

PHILLIPPS Cephaloscyllium sabella (Broussenet). CARPET-SHARK. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,8,1971 ed.)

DOOGUE & MORELAND Other names: Cephaloscyllium isabellum; carpet shark; draughtsboard shark (Australia); pekapeka (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,188)

WILSON SWELL SHARK see Shark, Carpet Ibid. 225 SWELL SHARK see Carpet shark (1981,Fisherman's Bible,198)

AYLING CARPET SHARK Cephaloscyllium isabella (Swell shark, catshark, ground shark) (1982,Collins Guide,55,1982 ed.)

PAUL Carpet shark Cephaloscyllium isabella Alternative names include swell shark (from its ability to inflate with water or air) and catshark (its eyes are like a cat's). The latter is more appropriate than carpet shark as a common name; the true tropical to subtropical carpet sharks are unrelated. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,28)

carpet, the¶

1 n. (Rural) downcountry land with a thicker sole of grass than high country land [easier for dogs to work on.]

They, too [dogs with soft paws] went down to 'The Carpet.' (Nov 5, 1953,NZ Farmer,45)

carpetlayer¶

n. [the common NZ term, see Yellow Pages although not there as a heading]

Carpetmaster¶

1 n. (Rural) a New Zealand breed of sheep, bred especially for the production of carpet wool.

BLACK & DYSON The fleece weight of the Cheviot and Down breeds does not match that of the Drysdales, Tukidales, Carpetmasters, and coarse Perendales. (1978,Carpetmakers: Specialty Carpet Wool breeds of NZ,12)

WARMAN It [the Drysdale] grew into something that has been called a 'carpet on the hoof' and its success has inspired the development of two similar breeds - the intriguingly named Tukidales and Carpetmasters. (1991,What Sheep is that?,28)

BLACK & DYSON The Carpetmaster descended from a Perendale flock and a ram of both Romney and Border Leicester ancestry bought by Professor K.B Cumberland and his son Garth Cumberland of Clevedon, near Auckland. (1978,Carpetmakers: Specialty Carpet Wool breeds of NZ,8)

WRONZ Tukidales and Carpetmasters, other strains developed since Drysdales, have similar genes and wool characteristics. (1994,NZ Sheep and Their Wool,19)

carpets¶

n. slippers

Also, Annie sported a glad coat of fuzzy-wuzzy' pattern, and her daintytootsies' were adorned with those useful and comfortable hoof-coverings known as `carpets' (Jul 20, 1912,NZ Truth,369/7/3)

carriage road¶

n.

HAAST With every step, the effects of the enormous glaciation become more manifest, all mountains and hills have not only the roche moutonnee[e1-acute] form, but glacier shelves at different altitudes and lying one above the other, are cut deeply into the hillsides. Some of these are so regular that the settlers have called them carriage roads, devil's highways, or by some similar epithets. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,121)

carrier¶

n. a rabbiter's dog; retriever (See carry v)

Carrier: Rabbiters always speak of a dog that will retrieve as a dog that will carry or as a carrier. (Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

carrier shell¶

n.

I was given a remarkable shell found 40 fathoms deep off Cuvier I. [[ed note] between Coromandel Pen. and Gt. Barrier I. It is called the Carrier Shell Xenophora corrugata. It protects its own shell by sticking small flat shells on its back like slates.] (Nov 26, 1909,Chudleigh Diary,449,1950 ed.)

POWELL CARRIER SHELL (Xenophora neozelandica). A rare deep water species of the northern part of the North Island. ... In order to evade detection the carrier cements to the back of it's shell bits and pieces of rock or shell from the surrounding debris of the sea-bottom. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,26)

carrier-away¶

n.

1 n. (Rural) a person who carries fleeces from the wool-table to the bins in a woolshed.

ACLAND carrier-away: a man or boy who carries the fleeces from the wool table to their bins after the wool-classer has classed them. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,367)

carrier-in¶

n. sc at cocksfooting

CARR Carriers-in are always hard to get, as the general harvest is on at the same time. (1913,Country Work,13)

carrot¶

n. Anisotome pilifera

[Alan Mark] described the giant alpine bristly carrot, Anisotome pilifera, as:'Almost restricted to rocky sites especially ledges and bluffs'. (Nov 2002,Forest & Bird,306/2)

...Aciphylla belong to the carrot family, along with other alpine plants including the smaller - and softer - Anisotome, or bristly carrots. (Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/41)

n. Daucus brachiatus, native carrot, wild carrot

(1869,TrNZI)

n.

THOMSON (And) [native c.] (1906,Introductory Classbook of Botany)

THOMSON (And) (1909,NZ Naturalist's Calendar)

native carrot [=] New Zealand carrot [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,52)

MARTIN Eight genera have but a single species, the NATIVE CARROT (Daucus brachiatus) and the MOUNTAIN MYRRH (Oreomyrrhis andicola) being two with no very attractive features. (1929,Flora NZ,288,1961 ed.)

carrot, native [=] New Zealand carrot [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,12)

n.

Above on the rocky bluffs [at Nugget Point, South Otago] the hardy native carrot anisotomi [sic] lyalli, the local daisy celmisia lindsayii and the tiny blue grass (Jun 1988,Pacific Way,48)

n.

carrot, New Zealand [s] Daucus glochidiatus (Lab.) F., M., L. Ibid. 52 New Zealand carrot [s] Daucus glochidiatus (Lab.) F., M., L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,12)

2 n. native carrot, storksbill, carrot-weed (Central Otago)

HILGENDORF STORKSBILL (Erodium cicutarium) is sometimes called native carrot in Central Otago. It is abundant in cultivated fields and waste places, but it reaches its maximum development in thin pastures on light or sandy land. It is a perennial, with deep tap-root, trailing stems up to 2 ft. in length and leaves 6 to 18 inches in length, ... (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,114,1967 ed.)

3 n. white carrot

(And) ? Geranium dissectum (1855,Te Ika a Maui)

4 n. wild carrot (loosely), hemlock

HILGENDORF HEMLOCK (Conium maculatum) is loosely called wild carrot or wild parsley in certain districts. It is a biennial found in waste places and rich grasslands in scattered localities in both islands. ... Hemlock has been famous from ancient times for the poison extracted from its roots and unripe seeds. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,130,1967 ed.)

carrot country¶

n. the Ohakune district in the central NI.

Later on when the sun was hotter and the walking tougher a Tuwharetoa elder from `carrot country' (Ohakune, his words), offered me bites of his melting lemonade iceblock ... poa astonii cling resolutely to small cracks ... (Feb 4, 1984,Evening Post,2)

carry¶

v. (be carrying) of stock, to be pregnant (with)

"Scanning only took off in the mid 1990s," he said. "It enables farmers to identify which ewes aren't carrying and which are carrying one, two or three lambs." (Nov 23, 2002,Dominion Post,C1)

v.

The drummer,' starting from the man who carried a drum, became the man who carried a swag and (then or there after) the loaded man (as a commercial traveller loaded with samples). Tocarry the load' is another synonym; and the essential point throughout the symbolry was evidently the load. (Nov 7, 1911,Maoriland Worker,18/14/2)

BAKER The phrase to carry one's swag is used to describe a condition of penury. (1941,NZ Slang,41)

v. (Rural) [soil] to support vegetation.

There are large areas outside of this which will carry good grass. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,2)

ANDERSON The type of bush the King Country carried was practically the same carried on the wonderful papa country of the northern part of the Rangitikei County. (1962,Life's Roundabout, A,42)

1 v. (Rural) [land] to support and feed stock.

DEANS The pasture will now carry as much stock per acre as the bank in front of your house. (1849,BLANK ENTRY,56) [NOTES: in Deans (1964) Pioneers on Port Cooper Plains]

On what is known in Auckland as virgin bush no sheep are depastured, but it will carry cattle during the winter months ... (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,285)

2 v. the sense `maintain, support' (OEDS2 38d. orig. US) is commonly used in NZ in its farming sense of land, pasture etc., maintaining stock (OED2 40 a. 1884 of crops, cattle and people), cf carrying capacity of a farm, a paddock, a crop of grass.

SCOTT We had not grass to carry them for many days. (1897,How I Stole 10,000 Sheep,24)

SCOTT We had not grass to carry them for many days. (1897,How I Stole 10,000 Sheep,24)

Carry. Country is said to carry so much stock, meaning that it will grow enough feed to support them. (C.) (Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

3 v.

Rabbiters always speak of a dog that will retrieve as a dog that will carry or as a carrier. (Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

carry over¶

1 v. (Rural) to retain stock from one season to another.

TAIT The wether lambs are carried over until the following seasons to be sold as fats. (1958,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol II,463)

For a few years before 1960 Mr Johnstone used to buy rough summer grazing to carry his cattle over the dry summer and autumn. (Jan 1965,NZ Journal of Agriculture)

.. particularly in situations where the number of essential culls has been unseasonably high, the temptation to carry over a few of the younger, appealing empties can be strong. (Apr 27, 2001,Fencepost.com,Expert Farmer)

Culling rather than carrying over good quality empty cows is a traditional view ... (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,76)

carry the kit¶

phr. to carry or run messages

FOSTON The lad hesitated. He was tired of carrying the kit and said so. (1911,Bell Bird's Lair,12)

carry-tray¶

1 n. (Rural) a deck or tray built on to the back of a farm bike, often used for transporting dogs.

SWAN 'Get up,' he called as soon as they emerged and both leapt up onto the little carry-tray behind the bike seat. (1995,Chasin' Bacon,21)

carryall¶

n. an earth-mover

WATT quoting report for April 26, 1955 (Griffiths Collection) by means of a bulldozer and carryall. (1971,Centenary of Invercargill,102) [NOTES: 1955 Apr 26 in 1971 Watt Centenary of Invercargill 102]

carrying capacity¶

n. (Rural) the potential of a piece of land to support stock. [aka stock carrying capacity]

If this is realized, then the carrying-capacity will be one head to 1.3 acres - a very creditable performance. (Oct 20, 1926,NZ Journal of Agriculture,242)

When John bought the run six years ago the hill had been split into 14 blocks .. Today there are 34 hill blocks and the carrying capacity has been lifted to 15,500 stock units ... (Sep 1985,NZ Journal of Agriculture,32)

As the area under discussion comprises about 6,000,000 acres, this gives a carrying-capacity of one-third of a sheep per acre. (1916,TrNZI,48/156)

The ravages of these diseases are a serious factor in limiting the stock-carrying capacity of New Zealand land. (Nov 7, 1929,Evening Post,17)

Steady development in connection with strains of pasture grasses and clovers has proceeded, and, through certification, the time is fast approaching when it will be possible, by the proper utilisation of approved strains of pasture plants, to increase the per-acre stock-carrying capacity of the Dominion's grassed lands. (Oct 17, 1931,Evening Post,5)

Some back-door influence has evidently been at work, and misrepresentations as to the stock-carrying capacity of the commonage have been made, else the Government would never contemplate such a step. (Oct 16, 1873,Tuapeka Times,7)

The hill country seemed to be improving in its stock-carrying capacity,and both agriculturists and pastoralists, as well as friut [sic] growers, were in fine heart for the future. (Apr 2, 1914,Poverty Bay Herald,7)

WILLIAMS And the carrying capacity of all the native grass ... (1889,Colonial Couplets,2)

Nearly the whole is broken forest country, fitted more for sheep than cattle, and having an average carrying-capacity, when cleared, of about one sheep to the acre. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,10)

Many farmers stocked up to fullest carrying capacity. (Mar 1907,NZ Farmer,218)

In the Vincent County alone the diminution of the sheep carrying capacity of the land is shown by the fact that whereas in 1879 the flocks totalled nearly 500,000, the present number grazed ... (Jul 15, 1911,NZ Journal of Agriculture,1)

ACLAND Hoare .. by ploughing, had raised the carrying-capacity [of the station] to over 30,000 sheep in 1890. (1930,Early Canterbury Runs,151)

The survey showed that Northland's farmlands have a potential stock-carrying capacity of about 200 per cent greater than at present. (Nov 5, 1953,NZ Farmer,4)

MAF The loss of grazing, when compared to the current livestock carrying capacity, is regarded as lost revenue. [stock-carrying capacity; carrying capacity] (1989,Report,57) [NOTES: Source: Economic Evaluation of Agroforestry in Otago]

carrying over¶

1 n. (Rural) the retaining of stock on one property from one season to another.

So on the surface this carrying over looks a very good proposition, but sadly it completely overlooks one very important factor - that is the fertility status of the carryover. (Apr 27, 2001,Fencepost.com,Expert Farmer)

carryover¶

n. (Rural) the conservation of pasture feed.

WHITE ET AL The carryover of standing feed into the winter as a feed-bank is an important practice. [carry-over; carry over] (1999,NZ Pasture and Crop Science,149)

1 n. (Rural) an animal retained by a farmer between seasons or over winter; a cow that is not dried off, a lamb that is not sent to freezing works but kept and sold as a two-tooth.

Good carryover shorn wether hoggets have been eagerly sought from 76/- to 88/-. (Aug 2, 1951,NZ Farmer,41)

.. any carryover lambs are worth more as mutton as two-tooths. (Oct 1, 1926,NZ Farmer,1436)

During May most of the cows are dried off and the carryovers are grazed in a handy paddock near the shed. (Mar 1967,NZ Journal of Agriculture,35)

Forty-five of his beasts are carryovers going through their second winter. (Aug 27, 1970,NZ Farmer,21)

They also had another 15 carryover cows which were grazed off the farm. (Jan 1977,NZ Dairy Exporter,2)

So on the surface this carrying over looks a very good proposition, but sadly it completely overlooks one very important factor - that is the fertility status of the carryover. (Apr 27, 2001,Fencepost.com,Expert Farmer)

The Vetcare grazing package offers carryover grazing ... (Feb 21, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,21)

It would appear that the number of carryover cows is the first deciding factor. (May 1981,NZ Dairy Exporter,33)

One hundred carryover cows were milked. (May 31, 2002,Dominion,17)

cart¶

n. trotting sulky

Shand reckons its safer out on the racetrack than driving on the roads and while he's broken legs, collarbones and ribs in falls from the cart, he says he's been phneomenally lucky with his health. (Dec 8, 2002,Sunday Star Times,B16)

n. a bed

Smith lives on it too? He doesn't have his food. He pays for his room and his cart. [Smith is a boarder who pays 10/- a week.] (Mar 1909,NZ Truth,195/6/1)

Smith lives on it too? He doesn't have his food. He pays for his room and his cart. [Smith is a boarder who pays 10/- a week.] (Mar 13, 1909,NZ Truth,195/6/1)

n. ? card

When I draw'd me wind, and wus walkin' aht/ In me slommicky 'orspital blue,/ I sights a tart, who gets me cart'/ Wiv aglad' wot bites me through./ ... We wus photograrfed, jest me an' 'er,/ 'Ere 'ave a cook at the proof.'/ Bill `cooked' and saw RED. (Jul 10, 1919,Quick March,17) [NOTES: (by Harcus Plimmer)]

cart tart¶

There was the stereotype - trolley dolly, cart tart, lolly tosser, air mattress, space waitress... She says the trolley dolly stigma has faded. (Jun 30, 2002,Sunday Star Times,D3)

Scary because the experiences of these women, the trolley-dollies or cart-tarts as they were called, weren't that long ago. (Mar 3, 2003,Dominion Post,B9)

A cart-shed and stable should be provided where the company does its own carting. (Jun 15, 1910,NZ Journal of Agriculture,43)

cartie¶
