SCRYMGEOUR Jock set off for the spring-cart, and Jenny' the draught mare. Half-way, Jock was hampered, ... Angus ... assured that William Steuart could hold the fort until thecartie' duly arrived. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,5)

cartwheel¶

n.

The crown was called a bull, a cartwheel, a caser, five bob, and most familiar of all a dollar, the latter dating from the time when the rate of exchange was four US dollars to the pound. (Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,15)

2 n. b. disc. of sponge cake dipped in jelly and sprinkled with coconut

Cartwright Report¶

n. a report by Judge Cartwright on treatment of cervical cancer at National Women's Hospital.

The hard-hitting Cartwright Report on the treatment of cevical cancer at National Women's Hospital has been widely praised. (Nov 26, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

carunculated shag¶

n. (Environment)

King Shag Leucocarbo carunculatus (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAMES: Carunculated shag, Marlborough Sounds shag, rough-faced shag, Cook Strait cormorant. ... The only shag with pink feet in the Cook Strait and Marlborough Sounds area. Prominent caruncles at base of bill. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,118)

carve out of the bush¶

phr. (Rural) [early settlement] to develop a farm and livelihood from standing bush.

Just a word to the large number that are just beginning to hew homes out of the bush. (Aug 1909,NZ Farmer,354)

SUTHERLAND Roundelay had mellowed with the years, losing in the process one of the characteristics which had appealed so strongly - that of a farm being 'carved out of the bush.' (1966,Sixty Million Muster,59)

YEREX Many of the earliest dairy farms were carved out of the bush by men who raised a deposit working on the roads ... [hew out of the bush] (1989,Empire of the Dairy Farmers,32)

WOODHOUSE The first block was cut up into small sections called State Farms, which were balloted for in 1896, and settlers soon arrived to carve out homes in the bush. (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,73)

carved house¶

n. a Maori meeting house: the concept is post-European: distinguish from earlier carved house, which often seemed to be a chiefly dwelling or used for a special purpose

The carved house, which ... has just been purchased for the Auckland Museum, was the property of Te Pokiha Taranui ... (1895,TrNZI,27/674)

I think it can be said definitely that our people everywhere are awakening to the need for (a) Proper maraes with superior houses as centres thereof and (b) Recovering and maintaining the arts and crafts. Here is a list of projected carved houses:- ... There is some talk of a carved house at Nelson, one at Dunedin, while the Whanganui-a-Tara Association is keen on one here. (Sep 20, 1930,Na To Hoa Aroha,2/56,1987 ed.) [NOTES: (Ngata)]

The whare-runanga, carved house, with war canoe house in the background [caption to scene from Waitangi museum] (Aug 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,187)

CAS¶

abbr. Community Arts Service [ORIGIN: acronym]

AUTHOR: Then, early in 1960, the CAS in Otago - INTERVIEWER: CAS? Explain. AUTHOR: The Community Arts Service of the Regional Councils for [197] Adult Education. They hardly exist now, except for a little music, but they performed an invaluable service for isolated communities before television. They had opera, theatre, ballet or music three or four times a year; ... a CAS visit was a real communal work-out. (1981,Solo,196) [NOTES: 1969 Mason Television Script in 1981 Solo 196-197]

Cascades Forest gecko¶

n. a variable species of gecko limited to harsh alpine habitats in the north of Fiordland and South Westland. [Hoplodactylus "Cascades" aka Cascade gecko]

Known as the cascade gecko-a reference to the waterfall-rich landscape in which it was found-it is just one of many New Zealand geckos that have yet to be formally described and named. (2004,Internet - see Notes,Issue 88) [NOTES: http://www.nzgeographic.co.nz/articles.php?ID=223]

Black-eyed geckos have been recorded at 2200 metres above sea level, and Cascade geckos were discovered in the Sinbad Gully in fiordland clinging to rock ledges at 1600 metres above sea level, suffering from frost damage to their bodies. (Sep 2010,NZ Geographic,52)

In 2004 and 2005, DOC undertook alpine gecko surveys in many parts of Fiordland. TheCascades gecko (a member of the forest gecko, Hoplodactylus granulatus,species complex) was discovered during these surveys and is now known fromseveral sites. . . (Mar 2007,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: DOC Research & Development Series 304http://www.conservation.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/drds304entire.pdf]

The forest gecko in South Westland/Weheka Area is a genetically distinct member of the Halocarpus granulatus complex - the 'Cascade forest gecko' - presently known only from the Cascade Plateau and Gorge River. (2002,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.linz.govt.nz/docs/crownproperty/high-country-leases/leaselist/cascade-con-res.pdf Document copied to this site 2002]

case¶

n. the spermaceti of a sperm whale; ?thence later the head; contrast junk, the soft part of a sperm-whale's head.

RHODES At 6pm got one case baled and the junk cut up. Hung the other head astern ... (1837,Whaling Journal,59,1954 ed.)

POLACK ... the case or occipital part [of the sperm whale is] opened and the spermaceti, which is entirely pure is then baled out. This head matter bears the highest price in the market. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/420)

GRADY Case - Upper portion of the head of a sperm whale which contains oil and spermaceti. (1982,Perano Whalers,226)

v. to take nursing cases; to earn a living by taking cases as distinct from working in a hospital

For six weeks Adair and Patty cased in Melbourne [fide R. Mason `of two Karitane nurses, pre-1950'] (1950,Auckland Weekly News)

case manager¶

n.

Get rid of all obstinate people currently in 'case manager' roles. (Apr 3, 2000,Salient,20)

casein¶

n.

Lactic casein is made only in spring, when the factory is struggling to handle the flood of milk. It is produced by adding bacteria to milk which convert lactose to lactic acid, so lowering the pH and precipitating the casein. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/46)

n.

Rennet casein is much more important, and the whey produced - up to 90,000 litres an hour - is passed through an ultrafiltration process to separate the proteins (made up of large molecules) from the lactose (small molecules) and water. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/46)

caser¶

n.

Following are other local money-names ... 5s. piece - caser, K or bull ... (Jan 14, 1899,Sydney Bulletin,(Red Page)) [NOTES: (Letter from Loafer, Tauranga) [Bill Pearson]]

n.(slang). a dollar; half-a-caser, half a dollar. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),613)

caser n. (Sl.) a dollar; half-a-caser, half a dollar. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),5)

The crown was called a bull, a cartwheel, a caser, five bob, and most familiar of all a dollar, the latter dating from the time when the rate of exchange was four US dollars to the pound. (Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,15)

cash fielder¶

n.

Honest bookmakers.. are in some respect preferable to the machine, but the greatest mischief lies in the numbers of "small fry", generally known as "cash fielders", who take the shop-boys' shillings and half-crowns. (Jul 30, 1904,NZ Observer,3)

cash up¶

v. to front up with money

... Mark probably told you I have been swishing some luckies for him [distributing lysergiside] The witness told Williams he just wanted to make a decent earn ...Williams had replied: ... That would be no problem. I could let you have them if you cashed up. (Feb 16, 1982,Dominion,10/2)

cash-peter¶

n. a cashbox

PARTRIDGE `There was a cash-peter left behing - that means a cash-box,' Sessions Papers, April 1863 (p. 786); by 1920. cf PETER n 2 and 4 (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,109,1961 ed.)

cashed- up¶

adj. having money

CRUMP I couldn't even go on the bash when we were cashed-up because me mate wasn't the sort of bloke a man likes to lead astray. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,191)

Cashel Street cocky¶

1 n. (Rural) a hobby farmer, or one who owns land but knows little about farming. (See Queen Street farmer)

hobby farmer: a Cashel Street cocky. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

cashflow machine¶

n. an ATM

BAKER ...I never did believe anything worth having came out of a Cashflow machine. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,171)

cashgora¶

n. a fine goat's hair with properties of cashmere and angora [CASH(mere) + (an)GORA].

But the buzz word in goat farming is `cashgora'. This stuff, hailed as the first new natural fibre to hit the world for 35 years, is an intermediate grade of fibre culled from crossbred goats. Judging what's what is a matter of microns - the measurement used to rate the fineness of the fibre diameter. ... Cashmere is the finest ... at no more than 19.5 microns. Cashgora goes up to 25 microns. Mohair measures anywhere from 23 to 40 microns. (Oct 1985,More Magazine,71)

The high profile of the industry has forced investors to become familiar with the three types of goat breeds - cashmere (feral), angora and the hybrid cashgora - as well as reach conclusions about the differing merits of them. (Aug 1, 1986,National Business Review,41)

It is held that the name [contravenes EEC regulations because it] implies that cashgora is a blend of cashmere and angora (a fibre type produced by angora rabbits). However, cashgora goat fibre was identified in France in the early 1800s and has been offered for sale in Australia since the late 1970s. ... As a generic term, cashgora received international recognition at Avignon (France) in June last year when the International Wool Textile Organisation approved the name. It now appears in the organisation's `Blue Book' which lists all internationally-recognised generic fibre names ... (May 10, 1989,Marlborough Express,17)

McCALLUM Suddenly goats were in great demand... So valuable are they for their fibre 'cashgora'. That is in world-wide demand. (1986,Meeting of Gentlemen on Matters Agricultural, A,199)

n. (Rural) fibre consisting of the fine downy wool from the Cashmere goat and mohair.

.. Ian Bain is aiming to achieve cashgora fleece yields of 50 per cent and better in future. (1987,NZ Journal of Agriculture,27,Jan/Feb ed.)

All Cashgora in the latest industry pool has been sold and producers do not face a repeat of payment delays which surfaced at the end of last year. (Feb 7, 1990,NZ Farmer,12)

They [goats] also provide a handy source of income for their Cashgora fleeces. (Feb 21, 1990,NZ Farmer,13)

FISK Cashgora is finding its own market ... (1996,Practical Smallfarming,95)

1 n. (Rural) a cashmere/angora crossbreed of goat

Crossbreeding between these two types of goat produces crossbred fibre, most of which is cashgora. (Mar 4, 1986,Proceedings 1985 Hill & High Country Seminar) [NOTES: 1985 Hill & High Country Seminar]

While Mahia farms the ferals through to cashgora and cashmere, Waimarama proffers the purebreds and a further 1500 feral does. ibid. 10 Cashgora is a totally new industry. (Nov 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture,4)

cashie¶

n.

Most "cashies" are on a company's books and do cash jobs at the weekend for friends, family and neighbours. (May 25, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,1)

n.

The language used consistently downplays any sense of crime : "cashies", "mate's rates", "a bit of excitement."... Ibid. 19 Pete, a Tauranga builder, says that he doesn't know of anyone in his field keen on doing cashies. (Sep 18, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

I doubt whether such announcements will have any significant effect on the amount of tax not declared on "cashies", but what will probably happen is that Inland Revenue auditors will take the announcement as justification to use an even more aggressive approach in attacking high-risk industries. (May 29, 2002,Dominion,24)

The empire was propped up by tax-free cartrading - known in the trade as'cashies'. (Dec 17, 1995,Sunday Star Times,A4)

adj.

The object of "cashie" cars was to turn aquick profit of 100% with no paperworkand no tax cut. (Dec 17, 1995,Sunday Star Times,A4)

casing¶

n.

n. the casing industry now uses a lot of synthetics; sausage skin(s), looked at esp. from manufacturers' or bulk point of view: a casing manufacturer; a butcher might say: I'm running out of casings, have to order some more. Guts are sold as sausage casings; the consumer of sausages would more usually speak of sausage skins

n. casings are zones of material altered by vein action and lying between the unaltered country rock and the vein.

... a great deal of the soil that was thrown away ... contained ... gold. Captain Hutton asked whether the earth was meant, or the casing of the veins. Dr. Purchas said it was the casing he was referring to. (1869,TrNZI,1/75)

[Reference Maerewhenua goldfield 1869] Several quartz-leaders are being followed up, and look very likely'. Gold has ... been washed out of thecasing' but no gold has been yet found in the quartz itself. (1914,History of North Otago,178,1978 ed.)

cask¶

n.

cask ... NZ & Austral. plastic-lined cardboard container for wine (cask wines now form about 50% of the wine sales in NZ). (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,110) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 74]]

What has caused this mushroom-like growth of Chateau Cardboard? As a simple matter of economics it is cheaper to put wine into a cask than a bottle. Plastic and cardboard are not as expensive as glass ... (Jan 18, 1987,NZ Times,9)

n.

Often closer to rose in colour, more often than not, smelly, dilute and lolly waterish, without doubt Kiwi casks are much better now. (Jul 13, 2002,Dominion,F7)

cask shell¶

n.

POWELL CASK SHELL (Tonna haurakiensis). This is very large and thin, sculptured with strong spiral corrugations. It grows up to nine inches in height and has a very large aperture. Occasionally these shells wash ashore on North Auckland beaches, ... (1947,Native Animals of NZ,28)

cask wine¶

n.

[Villa Maria winemakers] had to sell at Cook's prices or they didn't sell at all. Cask wine made up 65 to 70 percent of their total product. (Jun 1986,Metro,110)

Christchurch company Cottesbrook began selling cask wine to the British supermarket chain Tescos last year. (Jul 3, 2004,Dominion Post,A10)

Caspian tern¶

n. (Environment) a large red-billed tern, Sterna caspia, with black cap and forked tail (also called taranui); found on the New Zealand coast and widely elsewhere.

[NZ dotterel] and other shore birds (variable oystercatchers, white-fronted and Caspian terns) lay their eggs in a shallow, unlined scrape in the sand. (Nov 1999,AA Directions,50)

GUTHRIE-SMITH The birds breeding on [Bird Island, Nelson] were Caspian Tern (Hydroprogne caspia), Sea Swallows (Sterna frontalis) and Blackbilled Gulls (Larus bulleri), these in amity and friendship closely packed together; lastly ... half a dozen wicked pair of Blackbacked Gulls (Larus dominianus). Ibid. 118 The nesting habits of the Caspian Tern (Hydroprogne caspia) have elsewhere been described. (1936,NZ Naturalist)

POWELL CASPIAN TERN (Hydroprogne caspia), Tara-nui of the Maoris, is a larger and more solidly built bird than the white fronted Terns. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,80)

FALLA et al. CASPIAN TERN Hydroprogne caspia Maori name: Taranui. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,158)

199. Hydroprogne caspia (Pallas, 1770) Caspian Tern Cosmopolitan species ... New Zealand ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,54,1980 ed.)

JOHNSTON ... they'd left the Cove in his boat to troll for kahawai amidst the white cloud of swirling and darting Caspian terns that has appeared the [53] previous afternoon. (1981,Fish Factory,52)

Caspian Tern Hydroprogne caspia (PALLAS, 1770) OTHER NAME: Taranui. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,226)

NATUSCH The large Caspian tern (Hydroprogne caspia, ... ) is a large tern that includes New Zealand ... in its world-wide breeding range (1967,Animals of NZ, The,267)

HUTTON 112. STERNA CASPIA. Pall. Caspian Tern. us;S. strennua . GOULD. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,42)

BULLER STERNA CASPIA. (CASPIAN TERN.) ... Native name.- Tara-nui. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,279,1888 2nd edn 2/73 ed.)

CASPIAN TERN (Sterna caspia, Pall.). (1891,TrNZI,23/221)

The big Caspian tern is a bird of much dignity, and somewhat shier than his lesser relative the common tern, or sea-swallow, who is a jeering noisy fellow, a `larrikin' of birds (1901,TrNZI,33/218)

WILLIAMS Kahawai, n. Hydroprogne caspia, Caspian tern; a bird. [Probably the noun was the original use in this sense; thence the intrans verb, thence the transitive, though the recorded dating does not (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,97)

In size the Caspian tern approaches the well-known black-backed gull, so common around our coasts. (Oct 22, 1927,Evening Post,17)

From the description of these larger birds supplied by this correspondent, they were the Caspian tern, a species found generally around the New Zealand coast, though not in very large numbers. (Feb 17, 1940,Evening Post,11)

Crowe The Caspian tern is thought to have arrived in New Zealand about 1860 - since European settlement. (2001,Which New Zealand Bird?,76)

The common tern and the Caspian tern make no nest beyond scooping out a slight hollow in the ground. (Feb 24, 1888,Otago Witness,36)

n.

We rested several times, and ate some cassada, a pithy substance found in a tree resembling a fern tree: ... (1835,Boultbee Journal,94,1986 ed.) [NOTES: [Ed fn 94: JB's vocabulary identifies this fern tree as `mammok', mamaku ..]]

cassowary¶

n. weka (?poss. pukeko).

The cassowary has also been seen in different parts of the island, ... (Jun 28, 1840,GBPP,(No.311) 106) [NOTES: 1840 June 28 Thomas Bunbury's Report in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 106. Also in 1848 E.J. Wakefield Handbook for NZ 294]

Stewart's Island (South Island) ... is the haunt of the cassowary. (1848,Otago Journal,1/8)

cast¶

v.

SCOTT As their fleeces grew heavy ... they began to cast with monotonous regularity. (1953,Breakfast at Six,145)

n.

HENDERSON When sent out to head off one or more sheep, [the dog] generally runs in a curve which, in the language of the shepherds, is described as a "cast". (1967,Return to Open Country,37)

adj. (Rural) [of wool] sloughed off a live sheep or rosella [in contrast to dead wool that has been sloughed off a dead sheep.]

LOUGHNAN cast: wool sloughed off a live sheep. It is said to have cast the wool. When sloughed from a dead sheep, wool is not classed as cast but as dead wool. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,16)

v. (Rural) [dog trials and sheep-handling] to send a heading dog away to head sheep.

KOEBEL He must acquire the art of 'casting' a sheep dog. (1911,In Maoriland Bush,77)

LOUGHNAN It is sometimes necessary to cast out a dog on one line, stop him, and then recast on another. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,66)

Cast - sending a heading dog to head sheep. (Aug 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,11)

v. (Rural) [sheep dogs] to move in a wide arc to head sheep, so as not to first disturb them.

LILICO Would go out a mile, cast in any direction, would work in yards over the sheep's back or underneath them if he could not get through the other way, and bark like a rouseabout. (1919,Breeding and Training of Sheep Dogs,7)

NEWTON The Sweep breed, great dogs to cast, were noted for their running out ... (1973,Big Country of the South Island,157)

NEWTON It is instinctive for a heading dog to cast when running out. ie to make a wide detour so as not to get around his sheep without disturbing them. (1947,Wayleggo,153)

She cast out very wide and then she spotted the sheep on the huntaway course. (Apr 6, 1966,Weekly News,45)

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheep] turned on to their backs and unable to rise [resulting in possible attack by seagulls and other birds, fly-strike and starvation.]

Sheep that were 'cast' were soon attacked by the blow fly. (1877,TrNZI,310)

STEVENS This results in the ewes carrying massive fleeces and unless close-shepherded, the death rate from 'cast' ewes can be serious. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,78)

STEVENS The heavy autumn fleece may be more prone to fly strike in some districts, and 'cast' sheep may be more common during the winter. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,81)

MCGREGOR When the boss said 'cast sheep', Rum would stand on his hind legs to give himself more height and peer round the countryside to see where it was. (1980,Dog's Life, A,14)

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR In the meantime my main job was to ride round the paddocks for cast sheep and keep an eye on growing lambs. (1981,Sunrise on Hikurangi,96)

PEAT .. this dog will help drag a cast sheep to its feet .. been sloughed off a dead sheep.). (1992,Falcon and the Lark, The,68)

cast out¶

v. (of a trained dog) make a cast.

HARTLEY In order to develop the habit of casting out fast the young dog should not only see his sheep, but should exhibit an inclination to run out before being encouraged to do so. (1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,24)

cast-for-age¶

adj.

Cast. ... (3) Cast for age, etc., means culled for [age], etc. This term is used for stud rather than flock sheep. (C.) (Sep 30, 1833,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

NEWTON Cast: Cast sheep - sheep which have been culled out of the flock, mainly refers to age, i.e. cast for age. (1949,High Country Days,193,1950 ed.)

The products from this type of farm are wool, some store lambs, a few fat wether lambs, some culled hoggets, store cattle, varying numbers of store or fat wethers, and a draft of `cast-for-age' (c.f.a.) ewes. (1974,NZ Agriculture,59)

WHEELER Most surplus lambs go to the works at weaning, and cast-for-age sheep sell well at the end of their useful life here. (1982,Historic Sheep Stations of NZ,25)

cast-for-age NZ & Austral. (of a sheep) disposed of because it is too old. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,111) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

1 n. (Rural) a farm animal culled for age.

The products of this type of farm are wool, some store lambs, and a few fat wethers and store cattle, and last, but not least, an annual draft of cast-for-age ewes. (Jul 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,51)

LOUGHNAN cast-for-age: an animal culled out because of its age. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,16)

Cast for age etc means 'culled' for etc. (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

SHRIMPTON Each year the following are sold: 100 fat lambs .. 550 cast ewes (annual draft) ... (1948,Mataura Valley, The,13)

DU FAUR The old ewes from the hill country, commonly referred to as "cast for age" ewes are bought as either four, five or six year olds ... (1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,139)

This [decline in quality] is also quite apparent in the CFA ewes. [cast] (Apr 12, 2001,NZ Farmer,48)

caste¶

n. applied to one of mixed Maori-European breed.

LANGDALE-HUNT ... they left a son and daughter who were, of course, full Maoris. This was very rare on the Chathams as most, but not all were castes of Europeans mostly, who had either emigrated to New Zealand (1985,Last Entail Male,130)

caster¶

adj. well, fine, `sweet'

I was caster [?spg check -or] for Gene Tunney, so I took a slapsie maxie to the course. (May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19)

NEWBOLD CASTER (adj) Good, OK, fine. caster ... well off (1982,Big Huey, The,246)

casting pole¶

1 n. (Rural) a position on a heading dog trial course where a competitor stands.

In some heading events may be a casting pole - where you stand for the runout and, once the head is over, walk into the ring or quad. (1991,Constitution of NZ Dog Trial Assoc,4B)

castle¶

n. applied to a Maori fortified place; a pa.

ELDER Korro Korro's hippah or castle (1819,Marsden's Lieutenants,153) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

Castlecliffian¶

adj. Geol. classification

It should perhaps be pointed out here that the fault passing through Onerahi chaos breccia to the south of the Orewa River, which is marked as a firm line, is intended to be a concealed fault, and that in the legend the Castlecliffian and Nukumaruan stages of the Wanganui Series should be embraced by the Pleistocene, not the Pliocene, bracket. (Dec 1967,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,24/19)

Pronounced uplift along the axis of the basin did not begin until about mid Castlecliffian time although some rise of the greywacke under-mass had occurred before then to the west of the basin axis. (Nov 1978,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,46/6)

Castlecliffian and younger samples are so like the modern pollen rain that dating is not possible with the present state of knowledge. (May 1975,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,39/51)

The five oldest terraces are assigned a Castlecliffian age, the younger terraces are of Haweran Age. (Aug 1990,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,89/77)

castor-oil fish¶

n.

WILSON POISONING ... Eating the flesh of the Oilfish (or Escolar) can cause excess purging - hence its nickname of Castor-oil fish. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,180)

casualty calf¶

1 n. (Rural) a dead newborn calf.

Wanted: casualty calves NP to Opunake ... (Jul 22, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,22)

Casualty calf and lamb collection service. (Jul 20, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,25)

Casualty calves wanted, Inglewood/Waitara areas. (Aug 10, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,28)

cat¶

n. a long sledge [ORIGIN: abbreviation] (See catamaran)

ASPDEN Trees were felled with cross cut saws and axes.. then.. placed on a long sledge called a "cat" which was made to convey them to the waterway. (1981,New Life, A,41) [NOTES: from 1865]

Owen & Perkins In many places the logs were brought out on what was called a 'cat', which was short for catamarans. A catamaran was a big heavy sledge made of bush timber - yes, everything [was] made of bush timber. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,160)

cat and mouse¶

phr.

WALL A rare example of real ... wit in the criminal class is Kathleen Mavourneen' orkath' for an indeterminate sentence. ... Another fancy term for this tantalising sentence, `Cat and Mouse', is also clever and witty but less poetical. (1958,Queen's English, The,127)

Cat boat¶

n. Catalina flying boat

We still find some time for our girlfriends and wives,/ Whacko' when three sixty hourly arrives,/ The Cat boats will <i>not</i> fly tonight! <i>(1982,WAAF Book,54</i>) [NOTES: 1943-1944CAT BOATS' in 1982 Mackenzie WAAF Book 54]

cat cruncher¶

1 n. (Rural) a working dog with a habit of hunting cats and other small animals.

SWAN Any dog, of any description, may be a cat cruncher, a general turner .. a dog may be a scrapper. (1995,Chasin' Bacon,82)

cat shop¶

n. brothel

TEXIDOR They'd never hit such a town if it was a town but they said if it would be sly grog or a cat shop (1987,In Fifteen Minutes,200) [NOTES: a1964 Texidor in 1987 In Fifteen Minutes 200]

cat swamp¶

1 n. (Rural) a low-lying pasture containing small sink holes.

Advantage should be taken of enforced leisure in this respect to put in a drain here and there to dry up wet patches in paddocks and what are sometimes called 'cat swamps.' (Jul 1887,NZ Farmer,193)

.. we have described at different times various methods that have been adopted for draining spots in a field that are sometimes called 'pot holes' or 'cat swamps.' [cat-swamp] (Nov 1888,Egmont Star,24)

cat's ear¶

n. (mistakenly for) hawksbeard

HILGENDORF HAWKSBEARD (Crepis capillaris or C. virens) is also called hawkweed, hawkbit, and hawkbite, as well as being confused with cat's ear and dandelion. It is common in gardens, pastures, and waste places throughout the islands. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,201,1967 ed.)

cat's eye¶

n. a shellfish (Turbo spp.) which closes the entry to its shell with a horny valve (`operculum') resembling a cat's eye in shape and colour; (See also ataata)

POWELL CAT'S EYE (Lunella smaragda). Best known of all our shells of intertidal rocks. ... The circular greenish operculum, the cat's eye, is its most conspicuous feature. The Maori name is Ataata. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,26)

FRAME ... look at all of the coloured shells, look a little pink one like a fan, and a cat's eye (1984,Some Other Country,102) [NOTES: 1951 Frame `Swans' in 1984 Some Other Country 102]

McLINTOCK Cat's eye: ataata Lunella smaragda (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

FULLER The catseye (Lunella smarada) is a small helical shellfish common on rocky beaches. (1978,Maori Food and Cookery,49)

SANSOM No knob [on the supplejack stick] ... so green ... fitted on a suitable shell, usually a whelk or a cat's eye shell, the lunella (`Bu-bu' to us) for a hand-grip ... (1982,In the Grip of an Island,144)

SANSOM They had no gun but they cooked limpets and bu-bus (the catseye shell) and a few pauas to keep them going. Ibid. 184 [Horse Shoe Bay] is a good beach on which to find the big strong shells, the ostrich-foot, a big whelk, and the southern volute, or dog shell, the lunella or catseye shell, and the rare modelia, also with a catseye to close its door. (1970,Stewart Islanders,134)

HENDERSON This supports a sprinkling of desertsnails, white shells about the size of"catseyes." (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,272)

n. a marble coloured like a cat's eye.

Granny's needs [for Christmas presents] were simple and few - a Dutch doll for Marjorie, and a dozen assorted marbles of the genus `Cat's eye' for five-year-old John. (1930,NZ Short Stories,237) [NOTES: 1930 Winifred Tennant in NZ Short Stories 237]

SUTTON-SMITH Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies ... (1972,Folkgames of Children,174)

2 n. the operculum itself

MORRIS Cat's-eye, ... Not the true Cat's-eye, but the name given in Australia to the opercula of Turbo smaragdus, Martyn, a marine mollusc. The operculum is the horny or shelly lid which closes the aperture of most spiral shell fish. (1898,Austral English,83)

Cats-eyes: The heavy lid closing the opening of certain Australian and New Zealand shellfish. (1949,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn))

NATUSCH Familiar examples [of opercular] are the `cat's eye' of Lumella smaragda ... (1967,Animals of NZ, The,72)

cat's meat¶

n. something easy, light, trifling, etc. (often constr. it (is etc.) the cat's meat: it's easy, nothing; it's a pushover).

McCALLUM I sure got an ear bashing for being late, but I knew it was only cat's meat to what I would get when I got home. (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,84)

cat's reed mace¶

n. reed mace and cat's tail were common Brit. names for Typha latifolia, here applied in a mixed way to Typha angustifolia ; raupo

Another curious article of vegetable food was the pungapunga, the yellow pollen of the raupo flowers - the common bulrush, or cat's-reed mace (Typha angustifolia). (1881,TrNZI,13/28)

cat's tail¶

n. reed mace and cat's tail were common Brit. names for Typha latifolia, here applied in a mixed way to Typha angustifolia ; raupo.

Cat's tail. Typha angustifolia, Linn. (1869,TrNZI,1/3/49) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

cat-face¶

n.

CAT-FACE. A partly-healed scar on the face of a tree. (1952,NZ Forest Glossary)

catamaran¶

n. a logging sledge with usu. two runners on to which the front end of log was raised and placed for towing (`snigging') out of the bush (contrast jinker, a contraption with two front wheels to raise the log: in NZ, as in Nth America, now usu. called a logging arch)

In the winter-time [the log] is jacked on to a large catamaran. (1902,NZ Illustrated Magazine,5/375)

REED ... a kind of sledge, known as a catamaran, or, in bushmen's language, the `cat'. It consisted of two hard wood runners, about thirty feet in length, with two mortised and cross-bolsters about ten feet apart, on which the logs were placed, and well chocked. In order to prevent the runners from catching on the skids they were rounded off with an upwards snipe, and this was done at both ends, thus avoiding the necessity of the turning the cat around for the return trip. (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,180)

I. DAVEY Cat is another Northland Kauri bushman's term for a `catamaran', a forked trunk used to sledge out timber with bullocks, horses and even a modern tractor. I've used one myself! (Jul 29, 1966,Letter) [NOTES: (Whangarei)]

MOORE To transport the timber on these [skidded, i.e. corduroy] roads a `catamaran' would be constructed. This consisted of two heavy hard-wearing pieces of timber, rata for preference, with up-turned ends and 20-30 feet in length. They formed runners, spaced apart by two heavy crosspieces bolted to them. On these the logs lay. (1969,From Forest to Farm,40)

OWEN & PERKINS It was astonishing the tremendous loads they could pull out of the bush along the ground - snigging', that was called. In many places the logs were brought out on what was called acat', which was short for catamaran. A catamaran was a big heavy sledge made of bush timber ... The bushmen would build a special road for them - a corduroy road, or `skidded' road, as we used to call it. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,160) [NOTES: (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country)]

KENDRICK SMITHYMAN [Notice on exhibit] CATAMARAN One of the more popular methods of getting logs out of the bush it was usually associated with the skidded road, a small section of which is shown here, and hauled by a team of bullocks consisting of 12 to 16 animals. This particular Cat' is made of white ti-tree runners. The skidded road is also of white ti-tree orKanuka'. Constructed by Mr Reg Poyner, Matakohe (1988,Personal Communication) [NOTES: ? Museum, Northland]

OWEN & PERKINS In many places the logs were brought out on what was called a 'cat', which was short for catamarans. A catamaran was a big heavy sledge made of bush timber - yes, everything [was] made of bush timber. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,160)

2 n. applied to various farm sledges, often with a set of wheels to raise either the front or the back (of esp. a long load) off the ground; often =konaki.

R. MASON In the Rangitikei district applied to a sledge with two wheels to raise the front runners off the ground. (1953,Personal Communication) [NOTES: a1920 p.c. R. Mason (1953)]

THOMAS Harry built a catamaran; a vehicle which is perhaps best described as a cross between a sledge and a trolley. It has one central runner in front and two wheels towards the rear. (1970,Way Up North,93)

catch¶

v. catch up with, see

n. (Rural) the action of a huntaway moving from one side of a mob to another.

Catch - a huntaway moving from one side of a mob to the other to change the direction of the sheep. On a zig-zag course, sheep that have been on a slew to the right may need a strong catch on the right to move them directly to the left slew. (Aug 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,11)

The wider the gap, the easier it is for the huntaway to balance off the leader and the less it has to travel across to take a 'catch'. (Sep 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,15)

n. (Rural) a person in a tailing or docking team who catches and holds lambs for tailing, emasculating earmarking etc.

MCKENNY It may be well to remark that the man who holds the lambs for the operation is called a 'catch.' The 'catch' then takes a lamb, passes his hands between its forelegs, seizes its hindlegs below the hock and places it sitting on the docking-board..the 'catch' should hold the lamb in such a way that its head rests against his breast. The 'catch' should be careful so to release the lamb that he falls on all fours. (1927,Sheep-Farming, Fencing etc.,28)

v. to take a sheep from the catching-pen

Oamarama Remit No. 1 ....`That any shearer catching a sheep or bringing one on the board after the signal to cease work shall be fined [pound]1. (1912,NZ Shearers (Report Third Annual Conference),16)

He had put up a rather willing fight with the man who had been.. "catching" from the same pen that day. (1913,NZ Observer,Xmas Annual : 4)

n.

MEEK CATCH: When a shearer takes a sheep from the catching pen, that's his catch. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

BOWEN The Catch The first part of shearing is to catch your sheep and get it onto the board in the correct starting position. (1955,Wool Away!,19)

n. a sheep incompletely shorn or still being shorn when the signal for the end of a run goes; see citations.

Catch. Just before stopping time in a wool shed, a shearer tries to finish the sheep he is on and catch another which he can finish at ease after knock-off. This is called getting a catch e.g. How many more can you do this run?'Two and a catch.' (C.) (Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

NEWTON No man, even if he were actually in the pen could bring another sheep out on the board after the bell had gone [for smoko etc]. For the last 10 minutes of each run, the men would endeavour to select sheep which would enable them to just beat the gong and get an extra sheep. This was known as getting the catch.' With the old New Zealand hours of 5.30 to 5.30, the day was broken into 6runs', and getting a `catch' each time meant another half a dozen sheep to the day's tally. (1949,High Country Days,53)

BOWEN A catch' of course is the sheep a shearer has on the board when the gong goes for time up, he then being allowed to shear or finish it. <i>Ibid.</i> 155 CATCH. The last sheep of a mob. Very often this sheep produces one extra for the tally of the shearer who shears well enough to catch it first. In a tough mob, shearers will acclaim thecatch' as `the one we've been looking for all day.' (1955,Wool Away!,48)

RICHARDS He thought [94] he would be able to put one around me and get the catch, thus putting his tally two up on the rest of us. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,93)

catch ... NZ & Austral. sheep incompletely shorn at stopping-time but counted in tally. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,112) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

catch ... NZ & Austral. sheep incompletely shorn at stopping-time but counted in tally. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,112) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

OGONOWSKA-COATES Catch. A sheep that a shearer pulls out from the catching pen. In the few minutes before knock-off, each shearer tries to finish the sheep actually being shorn and catch another one, which, if started before the bell, can be finished at leisure and is an easy addition to one's tally. Aiming to get a sheep before the bell is termed `going for the catch'. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,95)

catch, the: See bell sheep; e.g. `I'd better pull my finger out if I am to get the catch'. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/22) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

1 n. (Rural) a last sheep in a catching pen to be shorn before a run is completed or any sheep taken from a catching-pen to be shorn.

Just before stopping time in a wool shed, a shearer tries to finish the sheep he is on and catch another which he can finish at ease after knock-off. This is called getting a catch. (Sep 23, 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),13)

MEEK With a vet'ran pair o' blades, he slipped in for his catch ... (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,22)

MEEK catch - when a shearer takes his sheep from the catching-pen, that's his catch. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

LOUGHNAN catch: a sheep snatched from his pen by a shearer just before the bell. So, if there is one, he will take his cobbler as he can now shear it at a leisurely pace. He may, in order to time his catch, have previously chosen a rosella or perhaps someone had barrowed one for him. In thus timing his work, he is said to go for a catch. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,16)

SINCLAIR In we'd go for the next catch together and shear apparently in unison. (1973,Boot in the Stirrup,68)

MACNICOL & TROTTER In this competition it was a great thing to get ahead of the others, so they would have a 'catch' sheep, this was the second last sheep before the breaks for meals ... (1987,I, Duncan from Skippers,68)

catch at¶

v. to receive (opportunely), ?chance to get.

LEE He caught at an odd drop [of whiskey]. (1937,Civilian into Soldier,199)

catch history¶

n. the historic fisheries catch of an individual fisher (or such catches collectively)

In 1991, a submission to the task force by the then ministry of agriculture and fisheries warned that the use of catch history as the basis of quota allocation was flawed... "Third, catch history encourages the premature development of fisheries, and the use of harvesting methods which maximise volume rather than value." (Nov 11, 2002,Dominion Post,B6)

catch the ten¶

n. a card game circa 1860s in Otago

BEATTIE I could play cards, however. Catch the Ten was then called Scotch whist. People did not want games then, but news. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,125)

catch-grass¶

n. (See grass)

catch-pen¶

n. catching-pen

HARPER .. a small catch-pen (1934,Windy Island,240)

catcher¶

n. (attached to a lawnmower)

n. one who catches sheep for shearers, tailers etc

STUDHOLME One man tailing could keep three catchers going at top speed. (1940,Te Waimate,99)

n. (Rural) a chain slaughterman who catches, upends and holds the sheep for the sticker.

LOUGHNAN catcher: chain slaughterman who catches, upends and holds the sheep for the sticker. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,17)

n. (Rural) a shepherd who catches and encourages sheep over a sheepbridge or through a hazard.

KERR To calm the nervy, a decoy would be tied up on the Bog Roy side, and a shepherd called 'the catcher' would run up, slip a lead over her and pull her across, or step over her, lick her bum and go maa-maa. other shepherds on the shingle riverbanks below poked their 'crooks' through the slats, but over water the catcher was on his own. Ian was tops at it. But Ian was off chasing a racehorse one hot muster, and Dunc was catcher. (2000,High Times in the High Country,117)

1 n. (Rural) a person who catches and holds sheep upright to allow footrotting, dagging, mouthing or other examination to take place.

STUDHOLME This made the work much simpler and quicker; one man tailing could keep catchers going at top speed. (1940,Te Waimate,114)

RICHARDS Docking in those days was vastly different to which it is today. It was a bloody business for both catchers and lambs. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,90)

MILLS ET AL An experienced catcher need use only one hand and knee to bring the sheep into a sitting position, leaning against his legs. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,81)

catcher boy¶

n.

HUNT A Maori showed us where [the old flaxmill] was, and when we asked him if there were any signs he replied: Te glory hole and te garden'. We found the oldglory hole' of the mill where once the catcher boy sat, covered with green pulp and flax gum as it dropped from the stripper rollers overhead. (1951,Confessions,42)

catching dog¶

n. a dog which catches animals for its owner; a pig dog

STUDHOLME [Grass-thieving] quickly came to an end, one old Scot [shepherd] looking his country with a catching dog and a sharp knife [to kill foreign trespassing sheep]. (1940,Te Waimate,116)

CARR Now this is where I made a big mistake. Mine were holding dogs and, when asking Tony whether his dogs would help I was thinking along the lines of holding something like an ear, a leg, or a snout. Tony, however, had only bailing dogs with him; his catching dog, Rock, was tied up at the cowshed and in saying, "Oh sure", he was meaning his dogs would dive down and keep the mob bailed up. (1986,Diary of a Pig Hunter,19)

catching-pen¶

n. (Rural) a woolshed pen in which sheep are kept prior to being dragged on to the board for shearing, or a pen in sheepyards for catching sheep for dipping, docking, inspection, etc.

HALL I went back to the pens and shuffled the sheep around so that no time would be wasted filling a catching pen. (1987,Shepherd's Year, A,9)

In this there was accommodation for six shearers, every two of whom drew from one of the three catching pens... (Mar 1895,NZ Farmer,96)

The catching pen of the temporary docking yards should not not be too large. (Aug 5, 1936,Weekly News,82)

STRONACH At the back of the shed worked the 'penners-up,'whose job was to keep the small catching pens full for the shearers. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,31)

The building is conventional in floor layout, with the woolroom and catching pens elevated to give full headroom to tally-pens and night-pens underneath. (May 8, 1969,NZ Farmer,2)

The old long or running boards oblige shedhands to race up and down dodging shearers and catching pen doors. (Jun 1, 1994,NZ Farmer,25)

PERRY There are two catching pens, and two sweating pens and a back race 5 ft wide. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,17)

n.

[The solo butcher relied very] much on the support of the other butchers, in particular the mate with who [sic] he was sharing the catching pen. (Dec 3, 1982,Dominion,9/2)

I worked at the dip yards making a catching pen so that men can catch and slide each sheep in head first. (Jul 18, 1903,Chudleigh Diary,418,1950 ed.)

PERRY The material required in making a small catching pen are two coils of netting, stakes, and about six or seven hurdles. The pen is generally placed alongside a fence, ... (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,79)

n. a small pen adjacent to the shearing board from which the shearer selects sheep; pen adjacent to a shearing stand in which a shearer catches sheep for shearing; a small pen built next to the board, or shearers' stand, in a wool shed, in which one or two shearers catch their sheep; a pen in which sheep are held ready for shearing.

[Otago Shearers] No shearer shall enter acatching-pen after the bell rings. (1906,Awards etc.,VII/625)

PAUL The next point will be to make a sheep-yard. I should say make it of short, stiff hurdles with a post and rail catching pen. (1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,88)

MEREDITH When the word is given to start, the shearers go into the catching-pen' and feel over the sheep, select one, carry it out on to the shearing-floor, and commence shearing. Naturally, the easiest-shorn sheep --bare-bellies' and `bare points' -- are selected first. It is amusing to watch the tactics of some of the shearers to dodge the Kapara (Cobbler) the last sheep in the pen, which, presumably, is the worst shearing sheep of the lot. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,143) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 143]

CRADDOCK The wool-shed' where all shearing is done has a row of pens (catching-pens', they are called) in it reaching from one end to the other, each pen holding some 25 to 30 sheep. Opposite each of these are two shearers, who draw their sheep one by one out of their pens until the pen is exhausted. (1904,Sport in NZ,172) [NOTES: [H. Buckland]]

  1. No shearer shall enter the catching pen after the bell rings. (1912,Sheepowner's Handbook, The,26)

CARR Another job suitable for a new hand is Sheep O!' The work consists of filling up thecatching pens' when empty. The shearer who takes the last sheep (called the cobbler') calls outSheep O!' when the boy ... immediately fills up the back pen. (1913,Country Work,17)

PERRY Doors leading from the shearing board to catching pens are doub[l]e swing doors. ...There are two catching pens, and two sweating pens, and a back race 5ft. wide. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,17)

GUHRIE-SMITH A considerable proportion of our flock appeared on the shearing-board with bellies, sometimes with sides too, bare of wool, - `Pare perries' - bare bellies - joyfully the shearers hailed them in the catching-pens. (1926,Tutira,157)

GUTHRIE-SMITH A considerable proportion of our flock appeared on the shearing-board with bellies, sometimes with sides too, bare of wool, - `Pare perries' - bare bellies - joyfully the shearers hailed them in the catching-pens. (1926,Tutira,157)

SMITH Two shearers usually have one pen to catch their sheep from. They are called catching pens. When the shearer has shorn the sheep, he lets it go into another pen, which is known as a counting-out pen, because it is in these pens that the overseer counts the number of sheep each shearer has shorn. (1927,Sheep & Wool Industry,70)

Catching pen: Pens built small, and next the board in a woolshed, from each of which one or two shearers catch their sheep. (C.) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

STUDHOLME In addition to filling up the catching pens, [the sheep-o] weighed the bales and recorded them, with their descriptions in the wool book. Ibid. 129 When an old hand and a young one were sharing a catching pen, the former [130] would let the learner in for the cobbler', or hard shearing sheep, at the end of every pen, and when the pen had been re-filled, quickly catch and shear all therosellas,' or easily shorn sheep, before the unfortunate novice had finished his cobbler. (1940,Te Waimate,112)

McLEOD The classer stands beside the gong ... and when the clang of the old disc blade rings through the shed, the catching pen doors are flung open and each shearer dives into the pen and comes out dragging a sheep. (1951,High Country,28)

MEEK CATCHING-PEN: An enclosure holding the woolly sheep, from which the shearer catches his sheep to shear it. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

SCRYMGEOUR The bell rang, the whole procedure stopped, shearers trooped out, half shorn sheep were pushed back into the catching pens. Jimmy Greave the classer hurriedly whispered to William Steuart to desist, but loppies, rousies, and even young Jim, who was assisting to pen up, followed out from the side door to where the shoots from the stands gave the nearest exit, to the level space of the outside turf, that made eventually the [boxing] ring. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,50)

15 Catching pen: The pen in which sheep are held ready for shearing. In competition the shearer is not permitted assistance in catching his sheep. (Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener)) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing)]

CATCHING PEN: The pen in which sheep are held ready for the shearer. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20)

CHARLES At the very bottom [of the shearing shed scale] are the rouseabouts - the boys and old men who sweep the floors, fill the individual shearers' `catching' pens, ... (1981,Black Billy Tea,28)

Catching pen: Pen adjacent to a shearing stand in which a shearer catches sheep for shearing. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53)

catching-pen NZ & Austral. pen where sheep are held immediately prior to shearing. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,112) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

RICHARDS The catching pens in the woolshed were screened off by sacks, and used for dressing rooms. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,31)

OGONOWSKA-COATES Catching pen. Small pen alongside the board in the woolshed. The catching pen is usually shared by two shearers. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,95)

catching pen: A small pen adjoining the board. The shearer catches his sheep from his pen and calls `sheep-oh' when he has emptied it. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/22) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

The shearers were leaning on their catching pen doors, ... (Mar 1988,More Magazine,30)

The men rushed into the catching pens. (Dec 2, 1897,Otago Witness,58)

Catchment Board¶

n.

The Catchment Board possesses extensive powers for rating for works carried out in its district. (Dec 22, 1944,Ellesmere Guardian,3)

The Catchment Board possesses extensive powers for rating for works carried out in its district. (Dec 22, 1944,Ellesmere Guardian,3)

HENDERSON They're a lot of cranky halfwits on that flaming Catchment Board. (1969,Open Country Calling,177)

Inland Revenue's departure removed another 80-100 jobs, and the exit of the catchment board office wiped another important batch of job openings. (Nov 13, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

HOLLAND When constituted,.. the Catchment Board was specifically charged with flood control and drainage work, and with soil conservat ion. (1982,History of the Manawatu River,19)

McCONNELL Erosion was a natural function which could not be eliminated; rather the aim should be to arrest it, and the wide powers of Catchment Boards, if used wisely, would be of tremendous benefit to the country. (1989,Challenge & Change,4) [NOTES: Quote from 1943, check page number]

As I see it, the Catchment Board is simply another claw to the already over-grown octopus, represented by local bodies. (Jul 10, 1945,Timaru Herald)

McCONNELL From Government-led beginnings, to its Government-engineered demise, the South Canterbury Catchment Board played a substantial part in the development of the region. (1989,Challenge & Change,1)

McCASKILL The [Soil] Council thought it opportune to involve Catchment Boards in the supervision and administration of small irrigation schemes. (1973,Hold This Land,231)

1 n. (Rural) a conservation body, with local rural representation.

BARNES I was determined that we had to do something, so the Catchment Board agreed that if we retired certain areas of our higher altitude country they would assist financially to put in protection banks. (1987,Country Calendar (TVNZ),22)

MCLEOD Very useful but rather dangerous, and in these days of Catchment Boards, the practice [of lighting a snow-grass] is not encouraged any more. (1951,NZ High Country,35)

CUMBERLAND Catchment Boards are being set up by the Council under the provisions of the Act ... (1944,Soil Erosion in New Zealand,2)

SHARPE .. the catchment boards have done something to reduce flood damage. (1962,Country Occasions,112)

WHEELER The catchment board and the station have together put in a twenty-mile retirement fence at 3,500 feet to prevent stock from using potentially dangerous snow country. (1971,Historic Sheep Stations SI II,30)

DOMINY a run plan based on the report was drawn up by the Catchment Board, calling for compensation for loss of grazing land to be retired from use ... (2001,Calling the Station Home,108)

catfish¶

n. Genyagnus monopterygius spotted stargazer

POLACK Many other fish are equally numerous, answering to our hakes, tench, bream, snapper, haddock, elephant-fish, pollock, salmon, gurnards, pipe-fish, parrot-fish, leather-jackets, cole-fish, John Dorys, sword-fish, cod; various kinds of skate and cat-fish, sting-ray and dog-fish. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/322)

POLACK Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-ray (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202fn)

Cathedral City¶

Some call her the Cathedral City, the most English City, the City of the Plains. (Aug 1, 1928,NZ Free Lance,18)

[Hilda Spong's] love for the Cathedral City remains undiminished. (May 4, 1912,NZ Free Lance,26)

WALKER Christchurch, the Cathedral City of New Zealand. (1902,Zealandia's Guerdon,16)

[sic: referring to Christchurch] (Jun 24, 1905,NZ Truth,1/7)

HISLOP That was by no means the best of the many sales I made in the Cathedral City, ... (1934,Pure Gold,90)

HISLOP That was by no means the best of the many sales I made in the Cathedral City, ... (1934,Pure Gold,90)

McGILL Coasters never miss a chance to poke the borax [159] at the Cathedral City. (1985,G'day Country,158)

TURNER Even in this [passage from Slatter Gun in My Hand], there are two expressions with which I am not personally directly familiar, cat's bar, presumably ladies bar' and <i>ran like a hairy goat </i>ran badly', an Australianism, recorded by Baker. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,120)

catnapper¶

n. someone who kidnaps cats

[Hdg] Catnappers on prowl in north Wellington suburbs. Animal welfare advocates fear a cat-thieving ring is at work in Wellington's northern suburbs. (Mar 24, 2001,Evening Post,1)

cats' bar¶

n. a women's bar; often constr. with the. [cat prob. mere a derog. male term for a woman (esp. one who drank publicly), rather than a prostitute'.] Formerly, orig. a bar other than a public bar, where women could be served liquor; aLadies and Escorts' bar; often pejorative, connoting a bar where prostitutes could be picked up. [ca1930 at least (Jack Columbus)]

SLATTER There will be wisps of talk to be heard, the jargoning of the working man at rest, as anywhere in the country. - I was shikkered to beat the band. He's a randy old coot always hangin around the cat's bar. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,23)

McLENAGHAN `What bar's that?' 'The cat bar,' said Eton Junior. I'd rather walk into a lion's den than a cat's bar,' ... It was explained that this bar ... was used by women. They were not allowed into the other bars. (1976,Travelling Man,118)

McGILL cat's bar ladies' bar or lounge hotel where women permitted, as opposed to all-male traditional public bar; eg Gordon Slatter's A Gun in My Hand: `He's a randy old coot always hanging around the cat's bar.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,26)

They could not help being brought into close personal contact with what some of them coarsely termed "the cats' bar" or "the mares' nest". (Jul 1, 1953,NZ Observer,6)

catshag¶

v. usu. in collocation stop catshagging around = quit messing about! quit duckshovelling!; or as a vbl n, e.g. a bit of catshagging', to work aimlessly or inefficiently (an extension of shag (about, around) to muck about; with some suggestion of the noisy shambles of cats' lovemaking). [ca 1945 =stop messing around' (undergrads) ca1940 pc. Les Cleveland]

catshark¶

n. . [aka deepwater catshark; aka cat shark; catshark is a family of ground shark order containing numerous species, some specific to NZ waters and terminology]

[species name] apristurus sp. .. [scientific name] Apristurus sp. .. [other name(s)] catshark (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Deepwater catsharks Apristurus spp There are several species of brown catsharks ... around New Zealand. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,28)

Thirty rank and file, five Catskins (Mounted Police) ... (1840,NZ Journal,24/302) [NOTES: (Letter from Francis Molesworth)]

catting¶
