cattle¶

1 v. (Rural) to apply cattle to land to trample and eat rough growth.

Paddock by paddock, each one in succession is cattled, until it is bare and brown. That man has recognised the worth of cattling closely, of subdivision, and of shifting stock .. During the war he had been manager for several estates, on which he carried out a cattling policy. (Dec 1, 1928,NZ Farmer,1599)

2 v. to stock with cattle

You will ruin your pastures unless you cattle more. (1949,Report of Royal Comm. Sheep-Farming Industry,98)

cattle baron¶

1 n. (Rural) a cattle stockman, who is something of an expert with a long history of handling cattle.

FOSTER & WRIGHT Ken Lewis is something of a legend in these parts - the charismatic cattle baron of the north, respected among cattlemen in the same way that Bill Chisholm, former manager of Molesworth Station, filled that role in the south. (1983,Stockman Country,35)

cattle crate¶

1 n. (Rural) a hurdled yard for transporting cattle on a truck or trailer.

Clearing sale .. Large Holland car trailer with cattle crate. (May 4, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,29)

cattle crush¶

1 n. (Rural) a portable head bail, used when marking, docking or treating cattle.

GORDON This [nervousness] was eventually overcome while explaining and demonstrating the intricacies of a portable cattle crush ... (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,17)

For sale: cattle crush, 5 Holstein Friesian rising 1 yr bulls, cream cans. (Apr 6, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,28)

Clearing sale sundries: road baler feeder, cattle crush, electric fence standards ... (Apr 2002,Taranaki Daily News,13)

cattle dip¶

n.

cattle dip n. a tank containing an insecticide through which cattle are passed to free them from ticks, etc.; the solution used. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3)

cattle dog¶

n. a dog trained to work cattle.

... the shepherds say he would make a cannie sheepdog. He is very sharpe, his fighting qualities will make him a good cattle dog and I have named him Thug. (Oct 26, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,202,1950 ed.)

ELWELL48 Fricker ... [was] delighted to show the `new chum' how to work a cattle dog. (1878,Boy Colonists)

HAY But clever, well-trained cattle-dogs are a treasure beyond price in the bush; and this we know, taking great pains with our colleys. (1882,Brighter Britain,1/204)

(1920,NZ Journal of Agriculture)

McLINTOCK Cattle Dogs: Most of the cattle in New Zealand are worked by sheep dogs. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/493)

CARR And there was Tiger, a big black dog - part cattle dog, part boxer and part kelpie - but wholly pig dog. He earned his tucker this particular day as we were soon to find out. (1986,Diary of a Pig Hunter,30)

cattle-dog NZ & Austral. dog trained to herd cattle. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,113) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

cattle-dog NZ & Austral. dog trained to herd cattle. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,113) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

A fifth [veterinarian], with his needle unwisely visible as he approached a hackle-raised, blazing-eyed, bare-fanged cattle dog, heard the owner say, 'That dog doesn't take to strangers". (1985,Moaville Magic,38)

2 n. a State school abusive term for a Catholic

McCARTHY It was only natural that we Cattledogs' [from Marist Brothers School, Tasman Street, c1916] were frequently ambushed by thoseProddyhoppers' [from Mount Cook State School]. (1973,Listen...!,21)

McGILL cattle dog Protestant term of abuse for a Catholic. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,26)

cattle drench¶

n.

HILL The average Moaville weekly shopping list places raffles in the top ten items, somewhere between the weetbix and the cattle drench. (1985,Moaville Magic,12)

cattle grid¶

n.

SHERWOOD The minibus is parked about two hundred yards down the gorge from the Mount Ephraim cattle grid. ' (1985,Botanist at Bay,59)

Then a second person took a tumble from a farm bike on the cattle grid, got an arm stuck in the grid and broke a wrist and had to be taken to hospital. ((14/0/1986),Contact (Wgtn),4)

Then a second person took a tumble from a farm bike on the cattle grid, got an arm stuck in the grid and broke a wrist and had to be taken to hospital. (Nov 14, 1986,Contact (Wgtn),4)

cattle king¶

1 n. (Rural) [used elsewhere but sign. in NZ] owner of a large number of cattle.

NEWTON Among the higlights were my meeting with old Jim Hurley, the cattle king ... (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,214)

NEWTON From this modest start he gradually extended his activities until by the middle of this century he [David Oxnam] was farming some 200,000 acres and was widely known as the Cattle King of Northern Westland. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,119)

NOLAN He [Paddy Nolan] was a man of sober habits and unassuming manner, who was held in high regard by cattle men on the Coast and often referred to as the 'Cattle King' of South Westland. (1998,Droving Days, The,33)

NOLAN His still early rising, and conscientious work habits, may have been formed in part by the influence of his Uncle Paddy, referred to as the 'Cattle King.' (1998,Droving Days, The,42)

cattle lick¶

n. = salt lick

FINLAYSON `Oh, that was a cattlelick salesman. ... He said it was full of minerals and things. Well, I always reckon a bit of rock-salt's all right but with these patent mixtures you don't know what you're getting.' (1948,Tidal Creek,134,1979 ed.)

cattle man¶

n. a man who works with cattle; cowboy (in US sense); (the modern sense of cattleman would perhaps be felt as cattle-owner' (ranch owner); infreq. -man knowledgeable about cattle' - cf sheep man in this sense).

[a herd] ... surrounded by a number of `cattlemen' ... The term cowboy is not known here. (1907,Trip to Maoriland, A,26)

1 n. (Rural) a cattle breeder or enthusiast.

BARTON .. other industries have achieved much greater progress than the cattle man .. The cattle man wakes up every morning .. gets into the Toyoto landcruiser to go to inspect the cattle. (1971,Sheepfarming Annual 1971,226)

cattle muster¶

1 n. (Rural) a gathering together of cattle [usually specified as such, as a ''muster'' or ''going mustering'' denotes sheep.]

ASPINALL Occasionally friends would assist with a cattle muster ... (1993,Farming Under Aspiring,181)

cattle run¶

n.

McDONNELL It is very hilly near the Coast, but as you proceed inland and gain the summit of the lofty ridges, you may travel for miles in any direction over a perfectly level, or at most but a very gently undulating Country - the very model, in fact, of a sheep or cattle run; but nothing can be done with it so long as the Natives remain so deeply sunk in barbarism. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,35,1979 ed.)

A Captain Lethart, of Sydney, also here [at Akaroa] since the 10th of November last, has established a cattle run, with about thirty head of horned cattle, and had two stockmen in charge of them. From the appearance of this herd, I am inclined to believe the pasturage much better than at the Bay of Islands Parliamentary Papers, Correspondence, N.Z. 11 May No 311, p105 (1841,GBPP,(No.311) 106) [NOTES: 1840 June 28 Thomas Bunbury's Report in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 106Major Bunbury's report quoted in 1841 Petre Account of NZ pp84, 86, 87 in 1848 Wakefield Handbook for NZ 294]

POWER The only plan will be to lease sheep and cattle runs, at a cheap rate for a long term of years, on much the same system as in New South Wales with the squatters; with this difference, that the rate ought to be even cheaper in this country, as there are scarcely any native grasses, and the whole face of the country is fern and swamp, which is improved each year by the introduction of stock, - ... (1849,Sketches in NZ,113)

POWER The only plan will be to lease sheep and cattle runs, at a cheap rate for a long term of years, on much the same system as in New South Wales with the squatters; with this difference, that the rate ought to be even cheaper in this country, as there are scarcely any native grasses, and the whole face of the country is fern and swamp, which is improved each year by the introduction of stock, - ... (1849,Sketches in NZ,113)

WELD ... the track of downs and vallies between [the Hurunui] ... and the Waiau-ua, now in the occupation of Mr.Caverhill as a heifer station, is the finest and richest cattle run I have seen in either island ... (Jan 1851,Letter) [NOTES: 1851 Jan Weld Letter in 1851 Feb 21 NZGG 30]

[The Maori] desire to have large tracts of land for pig and cattle runs, over which the herds may range without danger of trespass on the white man's cultivation, ... (1860,Maori King Movement,21)

MEREDITH [? Aust.] I told them that it is quite an easy thing for a horseman to throw a beast, and described how I had done so several times on the cattle-run at home. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,93,1935 ed.)

On a cattle-run the tasks of mustering and drafting the stock and branding the youngsters are very heavy work, needing the display of considerable powers of rough- riding among the horsemen; while on a sheep-run the lambing and shearing seasons tax every power of the station-hands. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,157)

DEVANNY Sawmills, flaxmills, sheep-stations and cattle-runs encircled it in all directions. (1926,Butcher Shop, The,9)

BEATTIE ... Wilkin and Thomson owned The Forks, which was a cattle run ... (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,160)

1 n. (Rural) [used elsewhere, but sign. in NZ] a large property stocked by cattle.

The coarse land at the base of the sand hills is excellent for cattle runs. (Aug 6, 1864,Weekly News,6)

W WILLIAMS Held morning school with our small party and then went to call upon a respectable settler in the neighbourhood (Mr Pharazyn) who rents a cattle run from the natives. (Feb 9, 1848,Journal,475) [NOTES: in Porter (1974) Turanga Journals]

Some miles further to the west, lies the Ruanui Station, which Messrs Studholme use as cattle run. (May 5, 1888,Egmont Star,9)

cattle scow¶

n.

To men animated with such noble sentiments and guided with such singleness of purpose nothing can be impossible, and in furtherance of these views a syndicate has been formed for the purchase of Byers' cattle scow, lately lengthened by Bailey, our most eminent shipbuilder ... (Mar 28, 1885,Observer (Auckland),3)

cattle sickness¶

n. bush sickness

The first three local names of the disease Tauranga disease',Bush sickness' and Cattle sickness', are misleading. Tauranga is not a typically affected district, the trouble does not invariably occur inBush' or forest country, and sheep are more susceptible than cattle to the ailment. (1929,TrNZI,60/47) [NOTES: (Aston)]

This theory [of its being due to iron deficiency] was exploded when it was found that certain brands of limonite were ineffective in remeding cattle sickness' orbush sickness' as it was called. (Jul 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,67)

cattle station¶

1 n. (Rural) a large property running beef cattle.

W WILLIAMS Called at the cattle station of Mr Alum ... (Feb 22, 1847,Journal,421) [NOTES: in Porter (1974) Turanga Journals]

... cattle-station (1845,NZ Journal,153/282)

WAKEFIELD On each side of the entrance of Otago harbour, there are cattle-stations, &c. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,309)

[so OED2] A Canterbury colonist ... would undertake the entire management of a cattle Station or Farm. (Mar 1, 1851,Lyttelton Times,8)

A CANTERBURY COLONIST, to whom emolument is no consideration, wishes to meet with a Gentleman whom he would assist in working his farm, or he would undertake the entire management of a cattle Station or farm. (Mar 8, 1851,Lyttelton Times,2)

MACKIE Cattle and sheep station are the most profitable and you find government officers, lawyers ... all have their stations in the Wairau. (May 24, 1853,Traveller under Concern,111,1973 ed.)

EARP The present number of sheep and cattle stations [in the Wairarapa] is thirteen ... (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),115)

ROCHFORT Neither do cattle-stations pay well. (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,27)

FITTON ... the intending stock-owner can hardly do better ... while seeking for a profitable investment of his capital in either a sheep run, a cattle station, or in ... dairy-farming. (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),215)

HARPER ... we came to a cattle station, and there revelled in a homely meal, ... (Nov 4, 1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,33,1914 ed.)

MONEY He was one of the owners of Tarndale, the largest cattle-station in the country, and the next day I passed the homestead, and saw a party of his hands preparing for a mustering expedition. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,85)

HALL-JONES He acquired the stock at McKoy's cattle station, Sandy Point ... (1945,Historical Southland,86)

To let, 1971 acres of good Land, well adapted for a Sheep or Cattle Station ... (Sep 25, 1857,Daily Southern Cross,1)

Rankin has gone up to the cattle station for a month. (1843,BLANK ENTRY,80) [NOTES: in DEANS Pioneers on Port Cooper Plains (1964)]

FULLER .. a cattle station may be started with a less cattle than a sheep station requires ... (1859,Five Years' Residence in New Zealand,169)

MONEY .. a few miles further on arrived at a hut on a cattle station ... (1871,Knocking About in NZ,85)

cattle-banger¶

n. a dairy farmer; a dairy farmhand.

BAKER Cowspank, to be a dairy farmer or a farmhand, whence cowspanker (we also use cattle-[42] banger, cow-banger). (1941,NZ Slang,41)

cattle-camp¶

n. (See also camp)

cat'tle-camp n. a place where cattle are herded. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3)

cattle-camp n. a place where cattle are collected. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),613)

CATTLE camp n. a place where cattle are collected. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),5)

cattle-catcher¶

n. a cattle-stop: see cit. cattle-pit (1883).

cattle-country¶

n.

... large herds of dairy stock, with flocks of long-wool and cross-bred sheep. The west coast of the island is essentially a cattle-country. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,115)

cattle-driver¶

n. (See cf. driver,drover)

A mob of cattle-beasts ... and `cattle-drivers' from Cambers. (Apr 1862,Puketoi Station Diary)

HAAST Numbers of tents were put up ... for the accommodation of gold-diggers, cattle-drivers, and storekeepers. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,82)

cattle-driving¶

n.

HAY I have had some experience of this cattle-driving work; and of all the aggravating jobs I know, it certainly is the very worst. (1882,Brighter Britain,1/209)

cattle-flat¶

n.

BAXTER A hundred yards away the river ran brown ... under gorse-pods, cutting the earth away from under the edge of the cattle-flats. (1985,Horse,11) [NOTES: c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Ghost in Trousers) 11]

cattle-holder¶

n. (See cf. sheep-holder)

WELD A cattle-holder will of course look to rich succulent pasture ... (1851,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,6)

cattle-hunting¶

n.

HAY He [the stockman] has to go out with the dogs almost every day to hunt up some mob or other. ... Cattle-hunting, as we term this employment, has a certain charm ... The stockman has to travel through pathless woods all the time ... to search for his cattle. (1882,Brighter Britain,1/203)

cattle-pit¶

n. cattlestop

PASH Cattle, sheep and horses etc., are prevented from straying on the [railway] line by what is termed a cattle-pit' orcatcher'. This is a pit sunk between the rails and fences about two feet six inches deep and ten inches wide, covered by bars of wood and placed parallel with the lines and about five inches apart. (1883,Report on NZ,5)

cattle-proof¶

adj. of a fence, resistant to the passage of cattle (See cf. deer-proof,rabbit-proof)

[OED2] Can you advise me as to the best hedge to grow ... to make a good cattle-proof fence? (Feb 1915,NZ Journal of Agriculture,190)

Cattle proof: A fence that will hold in cattle is called cattle proof in New Zeland. Cattle tight, the Australian equivalent, is not used here. (C.) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

cattle-puncher¶

n. a stockfood supplement presented as a "lick"

`A dashed cattle-puncher, I tell you. He nailed forty of my calves, and banged 'em along with his own mob 'fore I could get on his trail.' (1987,Happy Endings,103) [NOTES: 1902 Lancaster Our Lady of the Plains in 1987 Happy Endings 103]

RICHARDS There was no skilled labour as generally understood on the Chathams. We were our own sheep shearers, cattle punchers, horse breakers, carpenters, blacksmiths, ... builders. (1952,Chatham Islands,137)

cattle-punching¶

n. working with or herding cattle, cf bullock-punching, cow-banging, cow-spanking, and US cow-punching.

KOEBEL During no time of ... that first eventful day of `cattle punching' ... did the Gunner put in an appearance. (1907,Return of Joe,282)

cattle-sick¶

adj.

We were in a "cattle-sick" area, andArabella was developing signs of thedisease. (Jul 23, 1927,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,43)

1 adj. (Rural) [of land and soil] overgrazed by cattle.

TAIT .. considered to be cattle-sick land. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,122)

cattle-stop¶

n.

Wellington City Council officers have told him to remove the gate and replace it with a cattle stop if he has livestock worries. (Aug 31, 1999,Independent Herald (Wellington),8)

It's not much more than an hour later that they're juddering over the cattlestop and up the rutted dirt drive. (Dec 31, 2000,Sunday Star Times,D4)

SCOTT Presently we came to a cattle-stop. (1953,Breakfast at Six,12)

FRAME A man stood in front of the gate of the village, by the cattle-stop. (1988,Carpathians, The,194)

The passage of wheels across a cattle-stop's galvanised pipes or recycled railway lines is accompanied by a sound effect that announces one's arrival to all sensors within a radius of 200 metres. (Nov 2, 1991,Dominion,10)

First-time cattle-stop crossers often clutch convulsively at their steering wheel, as their entrance is greeted by what sounds like a burst of heavy machine-gun fire beneath their bows. (Nov 2, 1991,Dominion,10)

n. (Rural) a metal grated pit over which traffic can travel, but which stock will baulk at.

MCLEOD Three cattle stops were scattered along the seven or eight miles to Cass and on the outward journey he rode over every one without mishap, but coming back, at the one which had replaced the gate that John broke opposite Grasmere, the horse fell through. (1974,Kingdom in the Hills,159)

One heifer broke its leg in the cattle-stops and had to be destroyed. (Jun 13, 1946,NZ Farmer,45)

This cattle stop is on a stock route and while being driven along the road, the cow got its leg caught near our farm. (Sep 27, 1951,NZ Farmer,24)

BARDSLEY I remember that Joan and Judy built a cattle stop. (2000,Land Girls, The,101)

KERR HJ wanted a cattlestop to replace the gate on the station's only entrance-exit. I expressed misgivings about the safety of cattlestops on sheep places, but if he wanted a cattlestop, a cattlestop he'd have. [cattle stop; cattle-stop] (2000,High Times in the High Country,31)

cattle-tick¶

n. any of several ticks (esp. of the genus Boophilus ) attacking cattle in Amer, Aust, and NZ.

[OED] Where cattle ticks are plentiful spraying or dipping should be out. (Sep 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,196/1)

cattle-yard¶

n.

Not many people have suitable cattle yards. (Apr 29, 2004,Independent Herald (Wellington),8)

cattleperson¶

1 n. (Rural) a person who works with cattle.

Stanfield Bushy Park Ltd requires a stud cattleperson to assist in the development of and manage a new Hereford Stud at Bushey. This is an exciting new opportunity for an ambitious dedicated and experienced stud cattleperson. (Dec 5, 2001,Press, The,66)

cattling¶

1 n. (Rural) the applying of cattle to pasture usually in order to eradicate weeds.

That man has recognised the worth of cattling closely, of subdivision, and of shifting stock .. During the war he had been general manager for several estates, on which he carried out the cattling policy. (Dec 1, 1928,NZ Farmer,1599)

catwalk¶

1 n. (Rural) a walkway built on to the outside of a drafting race or stockyards to give stockmen easy access to animals or from which auctioneers and buyers can view stock for sale.

That history, with images of cockies leaning over the railings, auctioneers on catwalks between yards, dust and dung, will be left behind in the new sales complex. (Aug 12, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,4)

STEVENS A lusty ringing of the handbell and Hanham would take his place on the catwalk on the first pen to be sold. (1970,Pyne Gould Guinness: the jubilee history,130)

GORDON Thankfully for the vendors, my nervous murmurings were only heard on the catwalk at Paddy's Markets, a monthly sale at Oxford in North Canterbury where everything from tractors to the kitchen sink is up for sale ... (1996,Trouble with Stock Agents, The,iv)

catwalkery¶

n.

Calling designers to task about outrageous catwalkery is unfair, she feels. (May 27, 1999,Dominion,15)

caucus¶

n.

I am not aware that Ministers of the Crown have been in the habit of bringing before Parliament what took place at a meeting of their supporters. It is supposed that these things are done secretly; and if it is parliamentary to refer to such a thing as a caucus meeting, I can only assume we are getting sort of Americanized in some of our proceedings and this serves as the first step in making us acquainted with what are called caucuses and rings. (1876,NZ Parliamentary Debates,20/73)

Could those gentlemen who attended the caucus find no more definite and clear form of words in which they could manifest their independence than such a flimsy resolution as this? (1876,NZ Parliamentary Debates,20/84)

SAUNDERS The debate was adjourned from the 26th to the 28th of June [sc. 1861], when the Government avoided defeat by adopting an amendment.. which had been.. unanimously adopted at an Opposition caucus. (1896,History of New Zealand,I/446)

PALMER The role of caucus is one of the minor mysteries of New Zealand government. An opposition caucus mainly debates strategy and tactics in parliament and related questions. (1979,Unbridled Power,25)

LELAND caucus: ... Each party holds caucus meetings consisting of all the representations of that party in Parliament. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,23)

caucus ... 4. N.Z. a formal meeting of all M.P.s of one party. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,176) [NOTES: [cf. 1986 NZPOD 113; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 76]]

caucus meeting¶

n.

[?modern Caucus] Wellington, July 21st. The Mimbers are wastin' the counthry's time houldin Kaukass meetins. (Jul 22, 1876,Saturday Advertiser,11)

[`Paddy Murphy' reporting House of Representatives from Wellington] At a Kawkass meetin' held a few nights since, wid miself in the chair, it was unanimously resolved that the country be cut up into three powerful inchular kingdoms, to consist of the North, the Middle, and the South Islands ... (Aug 5, 1876,Saturday Advertiser,9)

8 July - Last week ... one of the most successful caucus meetings of the Party I have ever seen and Sir Joseph handled it with consummate skill ... [Letter from Fowlds to T.W. Orr] (1980,Fowlds Papers, The,6) [NOTES: 1907 July 8 in 1980 Rogers The Fowlds Papers - Politics 6 1907,]

SEDDON However, a caucus meeting of the party which the Speaker attended cleared the atmosphere and the recalcitrants were rebuked and warned against the Machiavellian influences of certain members of the opposition. (1968,Seddons, The,198)

caudie¶

n. (See kauri)

cauf¶

n.

SANSOM A big smokehouse at Halfmoon Bay in the seventies was his first commercial venture. He was the first local man to send fish out of Bluff to Australia. They were packed in big cases called caufs and carried on deck. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,40)

cautious as a cartload of cats¶

phr. very cautious; cf as cunning as a cartload of monkeys

(Aug 1934,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,5)

9th Dec - We had a caucus of the party a few days ago which cleared the atmosphere considerably. [Letter from Fowlds to T.W. Orr] (1980,Fowlds Papers, The,18) [NOTES: 1909 Dec 9 in 1980 Rogers The Fowlds Papers - Politics 18 1909,]

LEE Historic caucus (1936) 1981 ibid ? 29 March Caucus on superannuation. Caucus committee brought down a magnificent report. (Aug 25, 1936,Diary) [NOTES: (1936) 1981 Lee Diaries 9 25 August]

SMITH Prior to each election the parties hold what is called a Caucus. ... it seems reasonable to suggest that this word was originally spelt Kakas', the sound made at a meeting of Kakas or native parrots. At thiscaucus' the parties `prepare their platform.' (1947,From N to Z,38)

cavalha¶

n. (See cavalli)

Cavaliers¶

n. rebel NZ rugby union team 1986

With the All Blacks assembling to prepare for the second test, captain David Kirk says he hopes the word `Cavalier' will slip from New Zealanders' vocabulary. The All Blacks, including nine rebel players chosen to bolster a losing first test side, gathered mid afternoon, ... (Aug 21, 1986,Dominion,22)

KNIGHT And so too is the Cavaliers' tour of South Africa which sprung from the blue early in the 1986 season ... (1986,Geriatrics, The,14)

They were the Cavaliers of New Zealand rugby. In history, the Cavaliers of King Charles's day were courtly gentlemen, romantic figures, loyal to a lost cause. (Jun 28, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

QUINN Cavaliers : this word had little or no significance in the sport of rugby until 1986, when the name 'Cavaliers' was adopted by a rebel team of New Zealand players, which toured South Africa in 1986. (1991,Encyclopedia of World Rugby,00) [NOTES: Check page]

cavalla/cavalle/cavallo¶

n. (See cavalli)

cavalli¶

n. (See also trevally (1872))

.. 2 or 3 of them sold us some fish - Cavalles as they are call'd which occasioned my giving the Islands the same name - (Nov 27, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/213)

... there are not wanting Several Sorts [of fish] that are well known; such as Mullet, Cavallas, Guard-Fish, Horse-Mackeral. (1773,Cook's Journals,2/787,1961 ed.) [NOTES: 1773 Wales Journal in Cook Journal (1961) II/787]

FORSTER The best and most savoury fish was a species of cod, which, from its external colour, our sailors called a coal-fish : besides this we caught several species of excellent flat cavalhas (sciaenae), some scorpens, mullets, horse-mackrel, and many other sorts ... which were entirely unknown in Europe (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/126)

ROSS The more delicious [fish at Kawa Kawa] were the John Doree (Zeus Australis) and the red mullet; the largest, a kind of mackarel called yellow tail, and sometimes cavallo, though coarse, was found to be very good eating. (1847,Voyage of Discovery to North Pacific Ocean,2/117) [NOTES: 1841 in 1847 Ross Voyage of Discovery II]

SHERRIN TREVALLI (Caranx Georgianus). ... Dr. Hector says: `The trevalli is the arara of the Maoris, or trevalli or cavalli of the fishermen.' (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,99)

PARROTT The School Trevally was known to the Maoris as the Araara' and to Europeans as theTrevally' or `Cavalli'. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,78)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] cavalle 1396 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

Cave Creek¶

n.

It's enough politically to point to overweaning and bungling attempts to boost them [sc. statistics]:.. sudden funding injections into tribal roading under the guise of Cave Creek safety-proofing. (Sep 2, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

Meanwhile, he notes Cave Creek hasentered the vocabulary as a metaphor forshoddy. He heard a builder buying cheapercement and another builder commentingthat he was "doing a Cave Creek". (Apr 20, 1996,Evening Post,9)

It is not just those deaths at Cave Creek that are disturbing, but that shortly afterwards a whole raft of structures were closed down following inspection. (Jun 15, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),00) [NOTES: check page]

Previously, bureaucrats enjoyed a protected status and were often allowed - Cave Creek being a case in point - to escape the consequences of their actions. (May 6, 2001,Sunday Star Times,A7)

Before that, we witnessed an Auditor-General convicted of fraud, and the Cave Creek tragedy, which was officially put down to "systemic failure" in the Conservation Department. (Aug 25, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

cave in¶

v. to defecate

McGILL cave in to defecate; Tom Scott sources to Fielding freezing works. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,26)

cave spider¶

n. Spelungula cavernicola (See spelungula; Nelson cave spider)

The rare cave spider Spelungula cavernicola resides here, as do wetas and glow-worms. (1990,Tramping in South Island Forest Parks,116)

Cave Valley flour ball¶

n.

The Derwent potato, for which North Otagowas at one time famous, has almostdisappeared. At time a tuber of thevariety is to be obtained, but it is apoor apology for the mealy, fullflavoured sort that was so abundantduring the year[s] 1864 to 1885. The lateMr. Hassal, of Cave Valley, brought themearly into prominence, and they weredistributed over Otago as the Cave Valleyflour balls. (May 15, 1916,Rangitikei Advocate,8)

[Advt] "Balls of flour" table potatoesfrom Otago, finest you've ever boiled -like huge "flour balls". (Jul 16, 1916,Hawera Star,3)

cave weta¶

n. (Environment)

They saw gradungula, New Zealand's biggest spider - unique to the limestone belts of the area - which spans five inches, eats cave wetas, and whose egg sacs hung as big as golf balls in the caves ahead. (Jul 21, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),37)

Ducking in fright, I turned on my torch and saw row upon row of cave weta clustered together. (Feb 28, 2004,Dominion Post)

Cave wetas are found in the tussock country up to an altitude of 5000ft. (May 14, 1895,Hawera & Normanby Star,8)

Here they [Stenopelmatidae] are generally known by their Maori name of weta. ... Most of them are solitary, but the cave-wetas live together in considerable numbers. (1897,TrNZI,29/208) [NOTES: (Hutton)[weta sounds at night described 1897 TrNZI 29/209]]

ANDERSEN There are four kinds [of wetas]: the bush-weta, the cave-weta, smaller in body with very long legs and feelers - the rock-weta found under rocks on mountain sides, ground-weta, as small as a cricket and found buried under the soil. ... The male has a huge horny mandibled head, the female a long stout ovipositor which has been stigmatised as a sting and earned for the insect the undeserved names, scorpion, and herself and her mate wood-devil and taipo. (1942,Maori Place Names,452)

POWELL CAVE WETA (Pachyrhamma acanthocers). A large insect, remarkable for the extreme length of its antennae and hind legs. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,47)

McLINTOCK Cave weta, [family Rhaphidophoridae] with small body and very long legs and antennae Ibid. 3/705-12 Cave weta .. .. taipo .... Deinacrida (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/636)

BALE He handed us each a candle and as we entered the tunnel warned us not to disturb the cave wetas. (1971,Maratoto Gold,22)

DENNIS [part cit cave weta missing] having been taught from childhood that it is ugly and horrid; (1981,Paparoas Guide,192)

SANSOM A dry cave and a good night's camping it has only one snag, cave wetas. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,118)

She moved the packs behind a rocky outcrop jutting into the cave's centre; ... and not at the back, where the ghostly cave wetas waved anaemic limbs. (Dec 28, 1986,Sunday Star (Auckland),B1)

He stops mid-tunnel to spotlight a huddle of cave weta. (Jul 2006,Air New Zealand inflight magazine,34)

cavel¶

n.

PEARSON cavel: The casting of lots by which miners are assigned their places on the coal-face and the mates they will work with. 1963 Ibid 206 In the last cavel Jock had been paired with Ben Nicholson. (1963,Coal Flat,420)

The extinct cavel - the drawing of lots for places in the mire is anything but extinct. The cavel takes place every three months on the West Coast and, apart from the chance of a change, the cavel day' is looked forward to by all at the mine as it involves a short, two-hour shift. Not only is this old north-country term alive, it still often retains its old north-country pronunciationkay-vel'. (May 2, 1981,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43) [NOTES: I.A. Gordon: West Coast Strongman Mine]

cavel n. N.Z. a drawing of lots among miners for an easy and profitable place at the coalface. [C19: < E dialect cavel to cast lots, apportion] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,177) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 76]]

Caversham sandstone¶

n.

It is hardly necessary to say that for almost all readers, it is much more important to know whether a certain area is underlain by say Abbotsford Mudstone or Caversham Sandstone, than it is to know the stage or series in the New Zealand time-stratigraphic system of nomenclature. (Jul 1967,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,23/8)

BATHGATE At the foot of the precipice a small hut built of Caversham sandstone, known as the Maori house, was used by the Maoris from the Kaik ... the Bank of New South Wales occupied a building of Caversham stone ... (1925,Random Recollections,14)

cavil¶

n. (See also cavel)

[Denniston Coal-Miners]. All coal to becavilled for every three months... Allmen who are competent to be included inthe cavil. (1900,Awards etc.,I.186) [NOTES: 1897 award.]

v. (See cf. cavel noun)

[Denniston Coal-Miners]. All coal to becavilled for every three months... Allmen who are competent to be included inthe cavil. (1900,Awards etc.,I. 186) [NOTES: 1897 award.]

n. (See milking cow)

caving method¶

caw¶

v.

v. to turn; to wind (a handle etc).

cawcaw¶

n. (See kaka)

CB King¶

Two [Sergeants] were universally known as C.B. Kings', and were the worstbites' in their respective battalions. (Sep 5, 1917,NZEF Chronicles,28)

abbr. Council-Controlled (Trading) Organisation (one owned by a local authority) [formerly called LATE (Local Authority Trading Enterprise)]

CCC¶

Apologists for this medium are wont to [13] suggest that there is some educative value involved and the Courts Consultative Committee (CCC) reports that the televising of court proceedings can (among other things) provide "an educative role for the public." (May 20, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

CCDHB¶

The implications for Porirua would be significant if Capital and Coast District Health Board's proposal is adopted... CCDBH recently released their favoured option for the future of the region's health services. (Jul 18, 2001,Norwester,2)

CCH¶

abbr. Capital and Coast Health

Representatives of the Service and Food Workers' Union and Capital and Coast Health are returning to mediation... A CCH spokesman said about 75 orderlies were represented by the union, the overwhelming majority of its orderly staff. (May 28, 2001,Evening Post,2)

CCMau¶

abbr. Crown Company Monitoring Advisory Unit [ORIGIN: acronym]

One of the truly damning aspects of Stent's report was its revelation of the role played by the Crown Companuy Monitoring Advisory Unit (CCMAU), which had recommended that Christchurch Hospital be not told that its budget targets were unrealistic, as "it will undermine their resolve to achieve the targets set." (Aug 26, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

"It's an issue of Ministers giving approval for a genuine consultancy and then the proposal going significantly further than that without Ministers eve being advised by either the board or the Crown Company Monitoring Unit [CCMau]."... Her comments followed a top-level briefing yesterday from CCMau, which is examining hundreds of documents about the bid... CCMau officials were later ordered to draft the terms of reference for the enquiry. (May 19, 2000,Evening Post,3)

Worse is the non-reform of the Crown Company Monitoring agency. This goes by the cultish-sounding acronym of CCMau, and seems indeed to be a cult of some kind. (Feb 10, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

Parliament's finance and expenditure committee said in its report they were "not satisfied" with the performance of officials from Treasury's Crown Company Monitoring Advisory Unit (CCMAU), which monitors and advises on the performances of State-owned companies. It had invited the Auditor-General to examine CCMAU in light of its comments. (Jul 25, 2001,Evening Post,6)

Well, if she cannot read accounts and raise queries, surely Treasury and CCMAU can do it for her. (May 26, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

Some [acronyms], such as Cypfa, merge in effortlessly with events in Bosnia, while others, notably CCMAU, evoke Swahili. (Aug 7, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

Although chillier by far is the reception Treasury's version of Opus Dei receives from the Beehive these days. I refer to CCMAU - the Crown Company Monitoring and Advisory Unit - the suicide bombers of the public sector. They are not so much a unit as a cadre - doctrinaire, humourless, fanatic. (Aug 19, 2001,Sunday Star Times,A7)

[Hdg] cc: Mao. Fresh from the beating it gave Christine Rankin in the Employment Court, the government has now turned its attention to the Treasury, specifically the Crown Company Monitoring Advisory Unit, known colloquially as CCMAU (from the bureaucratic lexicon that also recently brought you Crown Owned Company, or CrOC or COC, depending on your taste in acronyms). Ibid. 16 It probably doesn't help public comprehension much that this organisation is acronymised to CCMAU, pronounced See See Mau, which is the kind of name you'd expect a Filipino dictator to have, rather than a public sector audit department. (Aug 25, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

cedar¶

n. kohekohe.

CRAIK Crozet ... asserts in his account of Marion's voyage [fn. Nouveau Voyage a la Mer du Sud, p.81.] that they found what he calls the cedar of New Zealand to weigh no heavier than the best Riga fir. (1830,New Zealanders, The,175)

KIRK In the North Island the native kohe-kohe (Dysoxylum spectabile), which yields a tough reddish-coloured wood ... is also called cedar by the settlers. (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,14)

(1877,TrNZI,9/)

[Native name] Kohekohe .. [Settler' name] Cedar .. [Family] Meliaceae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

The higher portion of the hills ... were clothed with the various species ... of birch (beech), to which along the shores of the [Marlborough] sounds were added pukatea and kohekohe, the latter locally called cedar. (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,509)

KIRK (1889,Forest Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

Kohekohe (cedar) .. Dysoxylum spectabile .. Wood light, soft, and easily worked, heart blood-red in colour; ... (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,11)

The higher portion of the hills and steep spurs are clothed with the various species and variety of birch (beech), to which along the shores of the [Marlborough] sounds were added pukatea and kohekohe, the latter locally called cedar. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,17)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Of the primeval growth that once covered [Stephen Island, Marlborough], little or nothing remains - only here and there an inconsiderable grove of cedar - kohekohe - a species difficult to burn ... (1936,NZ Naturalist,97)

n.

POLACK (1849,Manners & Customs of the NZers) [NOTES: (And)]

n. kawaka.

Cedar (Libocedrus Doniana), a handsome conical tree, with reddish wood, fit only for inside work. (1869,TrNZI,1/3/31) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

(1880,TrNZI,12/)

HECTOR Libocedrus doniana, Endl. Kawaka, Cypress, Cedar. This handsome tree attains a height of 60-100 feet, and a diameter of 3-5 feet. Wood reddish, fine-grained and heavy. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,122)

[Native name] Kawaka .. [Settlers' name] Cedar .. [Family] Coniferae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,120) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 120]

Kawaka (cedar) .. Libocedrus Doniana .. Timber dark red colour, straight and even in grain, ... (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,10)

The timber on the western side consists of red- and white-pine, matai (or black-pine), totara, kawhaka (or cedar), rata, and occasional silver-pine, besides black- and red-birch (Fagus fusca). (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,19)

Ce.dar (s&emacr..d&etilde.r), n. [Add.] ... In New Zealand the kaikawaka is called cedar. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2019)

McLINTOCK Cedar: kawaka, kaikawaka Libocedrus plumosa pahautea Libocedrus bidwillii (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

n. pahautea

KIRK CEDAR - PAHAUTEA.- (Libocedrus bidwillii.) (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,13)

HECTOR Libocedrus bidwillii, Hook. Pahautea, Cedar. A handsome conical tree 60-80 feet high, 2-3 feet in diameter. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,123)

English Name Native name Botanical Name Cedar Kawaka Libocedrus Bidwillii (1889,Catalogue, Canterbury Court Exhibition,35)

LAING & BLACKWELL The tree [Libocedrus Bidwillii] is often known to bushmen as the Kaikawaka, [68] though Colenso states that its correct name is Pahautea. ... It and the previous species [L. plumosa, Kawaka] are sometimes also called the New Zealand Cedar, but must not be confused with Dysoxylum spectabile, to which this name is often applied. (1907,Plants of NZ,66,1940, P. 68 ed.)

COCKAYNE Libocedrus Bidwilli (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Waipoua Kauri Forest]

HARPER ... it is really not necessary to carry canvas [on the West Coast] unless ... one is fastidious as to shelter. It is always possible to build a good whare'[e-acute] ormai-mai' with bark stripped from the rata (Metrosideros robusta), totara ..., or cedar (Libocedrus Bidwillii) trees ... (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,35)

MORRIS Cedar, ... In New Zealand, the name of Cedar is applied to Libocedrus Bidwillii, Hook., N.O. Conferae; Maori name, Pahautea [1883 Hector Handbook]. (1898,Austral English,84)

Cedar, or pahautea, pokaka, and hinau are not unfrequent, while most of the beeches are plentiful, especially in the southern parts of the district. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,119)

Cedar, or pahautea, pokaka, and hinau are not unfrequent, while most of the beeches are plentiful, especially in the southern parts of the district. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,119)

Still foreign to my Tararua-trained eyes were the handsome, symmetrical cedars (Libocedrus Bidwillii) of the [Ruahine] forest, ... (Sep 1958,Tararua,13)

MARTIN [Kawaka] is the commoner species [of Libocedrus] in the North Island as the PAHAUTEA or MOUNTAIN CEDAR is in the South Island, ... . (1929,Flora NZ,171,1961 ed.)

At times the bush turned from beech to silver pine and the long lanky boles of the mountain cedar with its sparse foliage and naked trunk stood out above the canopy ... (1978,Manawatu Tramping Club Jubilee,117) [NOTES: [=?] [Ruapehu]]

DAWSON Mountain five-finger (Pseudopanax colensoi) also has a wide range, but is absent north of 36[degrees]S and from Stewart Island. I have observed it growing as an epiphyte on kaikawaka or mountain cedar (Libocedrus Bidwillii ) on Mt. Taranaki ... (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,82)

The tips of kaikawaka, or mountain cedar, which thrust above the main canopy, display a distinctive "flag form, the foliage appearing to stream out on the trees' downwind side. (Jan 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 67/36)

.. TVNZ has increasingly insulted viewers by celebritising its news personnel .. (Dec 16, 2004,Dominion Post,B9)

The Inland Revenue Department admits it has sacked staff for "celebrity surfing" - prying into famous people's files. (Aug 1, 2003,Dominion Post,A3)

celery pine¶

n. an indigenous pine [Phyllocladus trichomanoides, aka tanekaha, celery leafed pine, celery-leafed pine, celery leaved pine, celery-leaved pine, parsley leafed pine etc. 1984: exhibit by Botany Dept, VUW f. CELERY(-LEAVED), CELERY(-TOP(PED)) PINE CELERY(-)PINE [AND 1820]]

Not so many know the curious philocladus,the tanekaha, or celery-pine, so odd indetails of growth, so shapely in whole,brilliantly clothed in yellow and red,with a bark that brings in a high pricefor the tanning of ladies' gloves. (Oct 12, 1935,Christchurch Star-Sun,14)

Celery pine [?Palpinus] ... is covered with large well-defined leaves like the common celery plant, from which the name is derived. (1876,TrNZI,104) [NOTES: (Blair)]

Phyllocladus alpinus celery pine (1869,TrNZI,1/)

Phyllocladus trichomanoides. This species of the so-called celery-leaved pine is reported ... as growing in the Maitai Valley, Nelson. (1895,TrNZI,27/408)

From 1000 feet upwards ... in addition to the common kinds [of Pine],the Toa-toa or Celery Pine (Phyllocladus alpinus) becomes abundant. (1869,TrNZI,1/iii/4) [NOTES: (Hector)]

Brooker et al Phyllocladus trichomanoides D. Don Common name: Celery pine Maori name:Tanekaha (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,32)

Martin The name CELERY PINE in common usage is almost restricted to Phyllocladus alpinus, the others being called tanekaha and toatoa, ... This celery pine or MOUNTAIN TOATOA is an abundant plant in subalpine beech forests ... (1961,Flora NZ,171,1929 ed.)

HOOKER The `Celery-leaved Pines' [Gen. Phyllocladus] are natives of New Zealand, Tasmania, and the mountains of Borneo; ... (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 234)

Toa toa (Phyllocladus alpinus). Celery leaved Pine. A small tree, common on the central mountains, ... Ibid. 49 Celery-leaved Pine. Phylloclades alpinus, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI,1/iii/32) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

HECTOR Phyllocladus trichomanoides, Don. Tanekaha, Celery-leaved Pine. A slender handsome tree, 60 feet high; trunk rarely exceeds 3 feet in diameter: (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,125)

LAING & BLACKWELL Phyllocladus trichomanoides (The Celery Pine). [1907 Celery- leaved Pine: 76] The native name of this tree - Tanekaha - is said to signify virile, or strong in growth. (1940,Plants of NZ,79)

Phyllocladus trichomanoides celery-leaved pine (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: (And) Cockayne Botanical Survey Waipoua Kauri Forest]

Phyllocladus alpinus celery-leaved pine Phyllocladus trichomanoides celery-leaved pine (1916,Dunedin Field Club Plant Catalogues) [NOTES: (And)]

celery topped pine¶

n. aka celery-topped pine; tanekaha; (In New Zealand)- P. trichomanoides, Don.; Maori name, Tanekaha (q.v.); P. glauca, and P. alpinus; Maori name, Toatoa, and often also called Tanekaha. ... [celery topped pine [1919 Jul 29] Ver. (WB).= Vernacular names used by settlers supplied by W. Best, Otaki (And) P. trichomanoides celery top pine (In Australia)- Phyllocladus rhomboidalis, Rich.]

... the silvery parsley pine. [fn] Or celery-top pine of settlers - tanekaha, Phyllocladus . (1895,NZ Reader,82) [NOTES: 1895 The NZ Reader 82 quoting 1882 T.H. Potts `Out in the Open' [Central Otago]]

Phyllocladus alpinus celery-topped pine (1896,Dunedin Field Club Plant Catalogues,Indigenous Plants) [NOTES: (And)]

MORRIS Celery-topped Pine. See Pine. The tree is so called from the appearance of the upper part of the branchlets, which resemble in shape the leaf of the garden celery. (1898,Austral English,84)

KIRK Phyllocladus alpinus celery-topped pine ... The tanekaha is one of the remarkablecelery-topped pines,' and was discovered by Banks and Solander during Cook's first voyage.' (1889,Forest Flora,9)

Phyllocladus alpinus celery-topped pine (1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue) [NOTES: (And)]

celery-top(ped) pine NZ & Austral. evergreen tree with leaves resembling celery. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,115) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

cell¶

n. section of land for GPS reference

Mapped out using GPS, it incorporates laneways of around 4ha which are split into about 48 cells, approximately .08ha in size. (Jul 2005,Country-Wide,28)

cell count¶

1 n. (Rural) an assessment that indicates potential for mastitis.

Somatic cell counts are not high ... he removes about 30 cows a year when he culls on high cell counts. (Jul 26, 2002,Dominion Post,C7)

The cell count average is low, all cows will be dry by sale day. (May 19, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,18)

Top BW/PWs with 100% reliability and good cell counts. (Apr 6, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,28)

How many farmers complain of three-quarter cows, black pox damage, heifers that hold milk, high empty rates or high somatic cell counts? (Oct 31, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,16)

cell paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a land area sub-divided into small intensively grazed units.

Fenced into approximately 40 paddocks with new 10 cell paddocks for intensive cattle finishing. (Dec 7, 2001,Manawatu Property Press,25)

cell system¶

1 n. (Rural) a method of stock grazing where small mobs of sheep are moved every 24-48 hours.

Stock is grazed on a cell system in mobs of about 20 and shifted every one or two days. The cell system requires an average grass cover of 2500 kg/dm/ha on May 1. (Jul 13, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,17)

cellarhand¶

n. [Google search Jan 2006, most use in Austral., some in NZ and S Africa. * Nov 2006: NZ 58, Austral. 431, UK 114 hits.]

Cellarhand required for busy winery for the forthcoming vintage. (Jan 15, 2006,Hawke's Bay Today,C18)

cellie/celly¶

n. cellphone

"I'm unemployed, but the celly reflects success, wealth, even sex appeal - everything I don't have but want women to think I do," he said. (Jan 4, 2001,Dominion,3)

His look said, "Okay, that was close, and I'm not so good on the one-handed turns, but mate, I'm on my cellie." (Dec 16, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

I'd never mention a word like 'drugs' on the cellie. (Mar 10, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

If anyone puts my life at risk I may just used a quick spirt of the water bottle through an open window to learn them either that or put the celly to use and *555 the buggers. (Nov 9, 2000,City Voice,11)

celmisia¶

n. the generic commonly used, also with distinguishing epithets; mountain daisy

In the morning the hillside would be black up to the line where the overnight dew had extinguished the flames when they reached the celmisia and sparser vegetation on the upper slopes. (Sep 2000,North & South,138)

A number of species of Clemisia (mountain daisy) and hebe have their southern limits at about this latitude... (1990,Tramping in South Island Forest Parks,178)

W.H.S. ROBERTS Speaking of the Moonlight Ranges (Taringatura) he [Mr Roberts] says: - `The snowgrass was very rank and in flower, a greenish white, like rye grass. The speargrass was a great nuisance. There was a large celmesia, or cotton plant, growing very abundantly, the leaves long and narrow with a soft down on the under part of the leaf and a white flower like a large moon daisy.' (1856,Diary,18) [NOTES: 1856 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 18]

A hare has left droppings, orange urine stains and melted out footprints as it dodged around the spiny speargrass and wandered about dry celmisia heads poking through the snow. (Jun 12, 2004,Dominion Post,E16)

Near the summit ..., a Celmisia ... was collected ... (1869,TrNZI,1/141) [NOTES: (T. Kirk)]

[CELMESIA] [We left] ... a wooden cross, wreathed with beautiful celmesias [sic] and alpine lilies, to mark the spot where he was last seen. (1889,Zealandia,1/27) [NOTES: (Ross)]

COWAN Most abundant are the giant alpine buttercup (Ranunculus Lyalli), popularly called `mountain lily', and the celmisia or mountain daisy, called by the Maoris ti-kumu. (1926,Travel in NZ,(Vol II South Island) 70)

McLINTOCK Celmisia: puhaeretaiko, puheretaiko, tikumu Celmisia spectabilis (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

SEDDON Daisy-like celmisias grew in drifts and between rocks near the series of little lakes at the top of the pass, and fields of mountain lilies which older people called ranunculas opened their white petals and nodded to the passer-by, ... (1968,Seddons, The,57)

DAWSON Mountain daisies or celmisias are probably the most frequently encountered of our alpine herbs. (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,179)

About 4 o'clock in the afternoon we reached the Celmesia flat, where we were to stay the night. (Dec 23, 1890,Otago Witness,37)

MORELAND All this alpine meadow was beautiful with flowers: giant celmisias with satiny-white petals like enormous daisies, mingled with snow-white gentians, and the wonder of the Alps - the mountain lily. (1911,Through South Westland,6)

2 n. Celmisia sessiliflora. M

COCKAYNE (And) Celmisia glandulosa var. latifolia. bog celmisia (1908,AJHR) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Tongariro National Park]

TURNER (1909,AJHR,C-11) [NOTES: (And) Botanical Examination Higher Waimarino]

COCKAYNE (And) (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

2 n. Celmisia longifolia.
