celmisia rupestris¶

n. a white daisy

Keep an eye out, on these high south-easterly-facing tops, for Clemisia rupestris, a white daisy only known from this general location. (1990,Tramping in South Island Forest Parks,100) [NOTES: sp. sic in source?]

cement¶

n.

HOCHSTETTER Where a ferruginous cement binds the boulders and gravel together, this conglomerate is compact. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),105)

cenotaph¶

n. a war memorial in the form usu. of a column set on a raised area approached by steps, with an enclosed recess representing the empty tomb of the fallen.

GUTHRIE ... Only a stone's throw from the grey sea of morning stood the cenotaph ... Other places ... had individual and beautiful memorials for the men who had fallen. (1935,Little Country, The,408,1937 ed.)

HYDE Bede Collins (no longer, unless by courtesy, Sister Collins) was attending Anzac Day service in Auckland. There was a church service before the parade and laying of wreaths at the foot of the Cenotaph, which would follow in the Domain grounds, ... (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,236)

[esp. war memorial (also Aust)] (1979,Heinemann NZ Dictionary,170)

centella¶

n. Centella uniflora, a native perennial

centella [s] Centella uniflora (Col.) Nannf. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,12)

Umbelliferae Centella uniflora centella (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: (Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri)]

TAYLOR CENTELLA (Centella uniflora) ... is a native perennial which prefers acid soils. It grows in many districts on ditch banks, in thin pasture and in lawns, ... (1981,Weeds of Lawns,29)

centennial¶

n. [R. Mason notes: N.Z. had a centennial in 1940, not a centenary. Australia had a centenary. No one could decide how to pronounce the seconde', [ ] or [i:], and `centennial' was deliberately chosen by the N.Z. Government to attempt to avoid the difficulty.']

McCORMICK Some readers will have seen ... the Centennial Exhibition of New Zealand Art. Ibid.194 [OED2] Government patronage of artists has more recently marked the celebration of New zealand's Centennial. (1940,Letters & Art in NZ,viii)

SOLJAK Celebration of the Dominion Centennial in 1940 impressed on New Zealanders the fact that their country had attained its place in history history ... (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),102)

SLATTER Here he collapsed ... his head whirling and glowing like a fireworks display at the Centennial ... (1968,Pagan Game, The,172)

The Netherton School and District celebrates its centennial on March 2-3, 1990. (Mar 14, 1989,Dominion,8)

centipede¶

n. Cormocephalus rubriceps

McLINTOCK Centipede: hara, hura, weri,wheke Cormocephalus rubriceps (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

Central¶

n. a short form of Central Otago (or Otago Central).

New Zealand's coldest temperatures as well as some of its hottest, have been recorded in Central. (Jul 2000,NZ Wilderness,47)

THOMPSON From the wild Otago Central to Otago's biggest town./ (1909,Ballads about Business,89)

SMYTH Know th' Central ... (1909,Bonzer Jones,94)

BEATTIE The Central was an area of far horizons then; ... (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,116)

HISLOP Fresh fish is a luxury in the Central in the summer ... Ibid. When the result ... got about it caused a great laugh all through the Central, ... (1943,Pure Gold,28)

If we were thinking of taking up farming in Central his advice was, `Clear out the rabbits and get a good wife.' (1948,Our Own Country,132)

DAVIN He'd arrived too late for ... the big strikes round Central Otago but he'd ... gone back to Central later with the dredgers. (1959,No Remittance,42)

BEATTIE Some of the Central runs had been applied for at the Dunedin Land Office late in 1857 and others during 1858. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,118)

Owen Marshall And both his Canterbury and her Central were rain shadow regions bleached to wheat colours in summer by drought and sun. (2007,Drybread,54)

The authors have defined Central as an area rather larger than that traditionally thought of; they've followed the boundary of schist geology, and thus cover some of the western lakes region and parts of northern Southland. (Jul 2000,NZ Wilderness,47)

Did you know for example, Central is home to the rare chafer beetle, the insect thought to have the most restricted distribution in the world? (Jul 2000,NZ Wilderness,47)

Central Districts¶

n. usu. a national cricket region, but ? also gen. [get def. from DH dict.]

TOP CENTRAL Districts jockey David Walsh completed a feat ... (Apr 6, 1983,Dominion,1)

central government¶

n. at least in 20C. as used in NZ (as elsewhere) for the Government of the whole country as distinct from Local Government by Local Bodies (Authorities); up to c1876 usually means the central government by the General Assembly, distinct from Provincial Government by Provincial Councils; (See cf. Centralism)

CRESSWELL These now had control of the central government, and when the Provinces hampered their aims they swept them away. ... For these Provincials had aims other than acquisition and the destruction of all that stood in the way of the most rapid settlement for the sake of what could be gained. (1939,Present Without Leave,9)

Some members of the Roman Catholic faith are against State aid ... on the grounds that to receive help from the central government ... (1963,Dominion,6)

Central nation¶

n. China (a play on Middle Kingdom)

They had also acquired a taste for tea, so this was the first thing asked for. Fortunately, I had a pound or two of the soothing product of the Central nation, so I handed it over to the savage ... (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher,65) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

Central Otago gecko¶

n. a boldly blotched gecko, common in the schist rock outcrops of Central Otago. [Hoplodactylus "Central Otago" aka schist gecko]

The Central Otago gecko is abundant throughout mostof its range, and is especially common aroundAlexandra, where it even occurs in some residentialareas where suitable rock outcrops remain. (2009,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/otagogeckosa.pdf]

Survey needsDetermine the local distribution and relative abundance of Central Otagogeckos at key sites within their range.Undertake searches for Central Otago geckos at the periphery of their range todetermine the limits of their range and whether it abuts or overlaps with othertaxa in the Hoplodactylus maculatus species complex. (Jul 2002,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://csl.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/OCLizards.pdf]

'Otago large' gecko and 'Central Otago' gecko are the only two speciesknown to co-occur within the coastal Otago area but the former species isgenerally (but not definitively) identified by the larger adult size (Jewell2006). (Nov 2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.google.co.nz/search?hl=en&q=%22Central+Otago+gecko%22&meta=cr%3DcountryNZ&aq=f&oq=]

Central Otago ground weta¶

n.

One of these is the Central Otago ground weta, which lives in sealed burrows dug into sandy soil. (2006,Internet - see Notes)

Central Plateau¶

n.

It's a beautiful afternoon up here on the Central Plateau. (Dec 14, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

It was Poulton's love of the Central Plateau that drew the couple to the region while visiting him in the 1970s. (Mar 15, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

The worst-affected area was the central plateau, where heavy snow cut power, toppled trees and closed all roads on a line north of Marton and south of Turangi. (Aug 16, 2001,Dominion,1)

Centraliser¶

n. ?=Centralist

I was in Auckland attending the session of the Genl. Assembly. I went as representative of Omata, a district possessing now, 5 houses and a stockade. To add to the pleasures of the war we had a desperate political conflict. The two parties which divide us are the Ultra provincial and the General Govt. parties called opprobriously the Centralisers. The difference ... is no doubt the old difference under a new face, England or America? (Dec 9, 1860,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/666) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond)]

Centralism¶

n. the name for the point of view, or the movement, which supported the absolute authority of the central General General Assembly over the several Provincial Councils: with Vogel's abolition of provincial Governments in 187?, the word became unnecessary and dropped out of use contrast Provincialism

Sewell's policy in finance is a Middle Island policy. He is inclined to Centralism in every thing but finance but is not strong enough to face the [Provincial] Superintendents. (Apr 26, 1856,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/214,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

FITZGERALD Half the recent session was occupied in a struggle between Centralism and Provincialism (1856,Letter to the Electors of Lyttelton,5)

H. SEWELL I can see through all this, a distinct policy which would settle in a great measure the question of Centralism and Provincialism. (1856,Journal,2/207)

As regards Centralism and provincialism, do not let us run into extremes either way. Provincialism up to a certain point is indispensable for the progress of the Colony. ... Pruned and reduced to right dimensions our provincial governments may be made admirable institutions. (Apr 7, 1858,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/379,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (H. Sewell)]

After all, the names Centralist' andProvincialist' do not in most cases give a truer impression than party nick-names generally convey. Centralism', properly so called, is repugnant to all the political instincts of Englishmen.Provincialism' is as repugnant their educated sympat who are called or erroneously call themselves Centralists are truer friends of local self-government than many of the defenders of `Provincialism', .. (Sep 11, 1858,Lyttelton Times,EDITORIAL) [NOTES: 1858 Sep 11 Lyttelton Times (Editorial) in 1971 Speeches and Documents 105]

Centralism' andprovincialism' were the watchwords used by the contending parties to represent the same thing [that is, the desire of a few to secure power]. (Sep 26, 1862,NZ Advertiser)

On the question of Provincialism v. Centralism, he expresses our own views. As to whether Provincial Governments should be abolished or not, he thinks ... (Jan 4, 1868,Marlborough Express,6)

McLINTOCK In 1873 Ballance entered politics ... The main issue was provincialism versus centralism. As supporter of Stafford's ... `Centralist' policy, Ballance retired ... (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/144)

Centralist¶

n. (historical) in 19th century NZ, one who favoured a strong central government; a supporter of Centralism (contrast Provincialist).

BATHGATE On both sides are to be found Provincialists and Centralists. (1874,Colonial Experiences)

After all, the names Centralist' andProvincialist' do not in most cases give a truer impression than party nick-names generally convey. ... Many of those who are called or erroneously call themselves Centralists are truer friends of local self-government than many of the defenders of `Provincialism', ... (Sep 11, 1858,Lyttelton Times,editorial) [NOTES: 1858 Lyttelton Times 11 Sept (Editorial) in 1971 Speeches and Documents 105]

THOMSON Two parties were now [mid 1850s] developed in the colony; one was called Centralists, the other Provincialists. The former aimed at the incorporation of the provincial governments, with a view to their ultimate absorption, and maintained the right of the General Assembly to intermeddle in all provincial affairs. The latter, on the other hand, insisted that the Imperial Parliament had established two independent governments in New Zealand, each for its own sphere, the provinces having exclusive jurisdiction in all provincial matters, and only under the control of the General Assembly on matters of general concern. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,2/223)

HURSTHOUSE In civil matters we are not Whigs and Tories in New Zealand, but Centralists' andProvincialists', that is those who would govern New Zealand by one Parliament, and those who should govern her by many. The six Provincial Councils given to the Colony by the Constitution were given to `Provincialism'. (1865,England's NZ War,49[fn])

WILLIAMS Of Dr Featherston, the Chief Land Commissioner, ... Superintendent of the Province, ... in general politics he is a Provincialist, whilst in Provincial politics he is a Centralist; ... (1868,Manawatu Purchase,5)

SINCLAIR There were in the House of Representatives in the fifties, less clearly thereafter, two loose groups which were called the Centralist' and theProvincialist' parties. No one has succeeded in giving a convincing explanation of the nature of this division, nor made clear to what extent these labels were meaningful. (1959,History of New Zealand,106)

Michael King Atkinson was a centralist in opposition to the provincialists, and it was largely on this issue that he had joined forces with Vogel. (2003,Penguin History of New Zealand,210)

2 n.

Mr. John Cargill begs to call the attention of recently elected Members of Parliament to his Stock of Centralist Opinions. (1868,Punch or the Wellington Charivari,34)

McLINTOCK In 1873 Ballance entered politics ... The main issue was provincialism versus centralism. As supporter of Stafford's ... `Centralist' policy, Ballance retired ... (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/144)

Harry Atkinson and Charles Bowen, representing Stafford's centralist faction in the government, the opposition was made up of an angry rump of provincialists, mainly from Auckland and led by Grey. (Apr 1987,NZ Journal of History,48)

BRAITHWAITE CENTRALIST PARTY That political faction which, in the 1860s, stood for one central governing body, as apposed to Provincial Councils. (1967,Evil Day,379)

centrally-raced¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of a farm property] served by a system of interconnected lane and paddocks.

This 92 ha property has a near new 24 aside H/B cowshed, it is centrally-raced and well fenced. (Oct 27, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,38)

centre¶

n. population centre [C.C. Ransom heard `the 14 largest centres'.] (See four main centres)

centre hoot¶

exclam. (to or by two-up players) put your money into the ring (See hoot n)

The ringies' they were bending low/ And yelled forcentre hoot!' (May 16, 1917,NZEF Chronicles,137)

centre pivot irrigation¶

1 n. (Rural) a pasture irrigation system that propels water from a central area.

We offer 2nd year conversion with centre pivot irrigation. (Apr 13, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,25)

centreboard/centreboard woolshed¶

1 n. (Rural) a design of woolshed where the board runs across the width of the shed with port-holes beside each catching-pen door.

TAIT .. a new centreboard woolshed was built on the property in 1957. (1961,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol III,144)

TAIT The Rangitoto centreboard woolshed built in 1928 is still modern ... (1961,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol III,144)

Variations include centre-board, side-port, across-the-board , U board, raised board and return race. (Apr 24, 1980,NZ Farmer,36)

Many of these old sheds are sufficiently elevated and sound to be converted to an extremely efficient centreboard with a modest outlay. (Jun 1, 1994,NZ Farmer,25)

centurion¶

n. a member of a Wellington rugby union club formed from senior or experienced players (orig. from past provincial representatives) to foster and encourage the game at all levels; ?a rugby player invited to play for centurion club; or to make up a special team; ? distinguish from barbarian [but check this term]; [G.J.Griffiths notes: a player (particularly in Rugby) who has played 100 1st class games (in this example, limited to one team); used at least since the 1960s when centurions had become more common but before, too.]

Rugby centurion [heading] Salute Mike Hanham, who became Mid-Canterbury's second only rugby centurion when he led his team against North Otago at Oamaru this week. Only other player to represent Mid-Canterbury 100 times was full-back Allan Smith, of Rakaia. Since he branched out on his representative career in 1962, Hanham has made 111 first-class appearances; including one game for the South Island last year ... (Sep 18, 1971,Evening Star,6) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection) 1971 Sep 18 Evening Star 7'o'clock 6]

... the `centurion' still wears a sword and armour, though the New Zealand centurion is more usually a much-capped rugby hero; ... (Mar 28, 1979,Otago Daily Times,21) [NOTES: (G. Griffiths)]

THE Wellington Centurions rugby team to play Marlborough at Blenheim's Lansdowne Park on Sunday, July 18, is a mixture of old and new. (Jul 7, 1982,Dominion,20)

[Advt] FESTIVAL RUGBY ... AUCKLAND BARBARIANS XV V WELLINGTON CENTURIONS. (Mar 23, 1984,Dominion,19)

JONES [Wellington only] Terry left school at the end of the fifth form, although he would have been a dead certainty for the Centurions next season. There were All Blacks who had been Centurions. (1985,Gilmore's Dairy,44)

century¶

n. a hundred sheep

century: To get a century' is to shear a hundred sheep in a day. Often calledgetting the ton'. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/22) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

n. one hundred pounds currency

BURGESS I then told him ... they might get a few century for their trouble. (1866,Confessions,95,1983 ed.)

Burgess had asked Sullivan to go to the Arahaura, along with Kelly, to put up Mr. Parr, where they would get two or three `centuries' - meaning two or three hundred pounds. (1866,Maungatapu Murders,71)

CEP¶

abbr. Closer Economic Partnership

[New Zealand and Mexico] have agreed to study the potential benefits of a closer economic partnership (CEP) agreement... "We expect that a CEP would bring significant economic benefits for New Zealand, given that Mexico is already our largest Latin American export market..." (Oct 28, 2002,Dominion Post,A2)

Trading agreements such as our Closer Economic Partnership with Singapore and our Closer Economic Relationship with Australia, can make it easier for our exporters to break into crucial overseas markets. In relation to your criticism of the consultation process and the lack of parliamentary scrutiny that preceded the conclusion of the Singapore CEP, the coalition government went to great lengths to ensure that there was ample opportunity for consultation and debate... The "basic problems" with the Singapore CEP referred to in the editorial have so far proved to be groundless. (May 26, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

Donald's criticisms of the Hong Kong Closer Economic Partnership (CEP) consultation process are even less tenable. (Jul 21, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9)

CER¶

abbr. Closer Economic Relations, NZ/Australia trading agreement signed in 1983

CER abbr. Closer Economic Relations (NZ/Austral. trade agreements, 1983). (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,116) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 78]]

[Hdg] Customs and C.E.R abuses - department replies The Customs Department has been accused of over-zealously implementing the Act in relation to alleged abuses of the Closer Economic Relations Agreement. (Feb 13, 1987,Press, The,16)

Prime Minister Bob Hawke's visit late last month to discuss further developments in CER was distinguished (Dec 12, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

Cera¶

n. [The Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (CERA) is the agency established by the Government to lead and coordinate the ongoing recovery effort following the devastating earthquakes of September 2010 and February 2011.]

Jane Bowron Will Cera, armed with its immense and sweeping powers, make sure that the developers don't drip-feed the land to get top dollar? If ever there was a time for an overlord to act like on, it's about now - and every time I hear the Cera word, I am afflicted with the brain-worm of the Dylan line: "Cer Cera (Sarah), so easy to look at, so hard to define". (Jun 20, 2011,Dominion Post,B5)

certificate of fitness¶

n. a certificate of the roadworthiness of a heavy transport vehicle

certificate of fitness NZ certificate of the roadworthiness of a heavy transport vehicle (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,117)

certificate of title¶

n.

Some New Zealand land law terms are uncommon or unknown in England. (Conversely the term title deeds is not much used here either by lawyers or laymen. Instead we talk of the title or certificate of title, in the concrete sense of a document which is a copy of the registry entry in the Land Transfer Office. (Jan 1999,NZWords,1)

certificated scum¶

phr. [Check for primary ref.: ?Rollo Arnold.]

SINCLAIR Conditions on some of the chartered ships were appalling; at the immigration depots the poorer families swarmed with lice; many of the newcomers, who poured in at the rate of 15,000 a year from 1875 to 1879, were described by older colonists as `certificated scum'. (1959,History of New Zealand,153)

Cervelt¶

n. a fibre made from the superfine under-down of the New Zealand red deer pelt.

.. the world's finest cashmere is 15.5, whereas Cervelt is only 13 microns. (Dec 20, 2004,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.marketnewzealand.com/mnz]

Named Cervelt, the new fibre is a product of the superfine under-down of the New Zealand red deer pelt. Cervelt is only 13 microns ... (Dec 20, 2004,Dominion Post,C3)

cervena¶

n.

We started with 4500 names before comingdown to Cervena [pronounced sir-venn-ah,derived from the Latin family name fordeer, Cervidae, plus ven for venison and'a' for premium, in total meaningnothing, like Kodak or Lego]. (Jun 1993,North & South,60)

I was impressed with his understanding of flavours and particularly intrigued with his method of cooking Cervena, New Zraland farm-raised venison. (Mar 27, 2004,Dominion Post,E5)

Three years ago a group of leading producers of farmed venison made a bold move. Believing that the word "venison" conjured up something wild, gamy and tough, which weekend hunters might bring down from the hills and give away to friends, they decided to rename their meat... However, cervena was to be more than just a name. It was also to be a trademark that would guarantee quality. In addition, heeding the lesson learnt from kiwifruit growers after they renamed their product, the name cervena would also be registered as an appellation. (Jun 8, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

1 n. (Rural) [appellation coined in 1993 blending cervidae, L for deer, and venison] farm-produced venison.

Richmond is part of the cervana appellation. (Oct 26, 2001,Dominion,18)

Cervena is making an impact on cooks at home and abroad. The producers decided on "cervena", an invented name, but with linguistic links to the Latin word for deer... This [registering it as an appellation] meant that it could only be used for meat grown in New Zealand. (Jun 8, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

Converting the deer industry's pioneering Cervena label from a Game Industry Board marketing strategy to a stand alone brand is supported by board chairman Clive Jermy ... (Oct 28, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,15)

He sees the strength of the Cervena appellation as its consistency of price. (Nov 8, 2002,NZ Deer Farmer)

cestrum¶

n. a weed, Cestrum sp.

cestrum, green [s] Cestrum parqui L'Her. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,12)

n.

cestrum, orange [s] Cestrum aurantiacum Lindl. Ibid. 55 orange cestrum [s] Cestrum aurantiacum Lindl. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,12)

chaff house¶

1 n. (Rural) a whare or room near the stables kept to store grains.

ANDERSON The chaff-house led off one end. (1966,Over the River,37)

For Sale 190 acres. New 5 roomed house with every convenience, wood shed, chaff room ... (Jul 21, 1923,Hawera Star,3)

MCDONALD .. two [workers] were reaping peas, one mowing oats, one was at the chaff-house, and one was on odd jobs. (1962,White Stone Country,162)

NEWTON The walls of the chaff house in the old stables are lined with pictures and newspaper cuttings dating back to 1887. [chaff-room] (1975,Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,108)

chaff mill¶

n.

His great interest was farm machinery and he made regular use of new equipment for farming - motors, chaff mills, headers and the like. (May 1996,NZ Historic Places,58/18)

chaff-cutter¶

n. in phrase to make a noise like a chaff-cutter (of esp. a machine): to make a terrible noise, racket.

2 n. a noisy car or motorcycle; a bomb.

chaff-shed¶

1 n. (Rural) a farm building adjacent to a stable in which grains are stored.

HAMMOND There's a rat in the chaff-shed. (1966,This Man's Father had my Father's Farm,75)

chaffage¶

1 n. (Rural) plant roughage necessary for healthy growth of calves. (See baleage)

WESTWOOD Chaffage or baleage is a good substitute if pasture is not available. (2000,Rearing Healthy Calves,5)

Calves are ad lib fed colostrum for three weeks and then cut back to three litres of wholemilk with ad lib chaffage and muesli. (Aug 10, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,13)

chaffie¶

1 n. (Rural) a threshing mill team hand. (See straw walloper)

ANGUS Two others, the 'straw wallopers' or 'chaffees' built the straw from the elevator into a good stack. (1981,Aspiring Settlers,49)

The duties of the important personage known as 'chaffey' are now done in most cases automatically. (Apr 28, 1888,Egmont Star,15)

The very disagreeable job of 'chaffy' to become a duty of the past. (Apr 1908,NZ Farmer,346)

ANDERSON One of the worst jobs on the mill was that of chaffie. (1976,Water Joey,23)

MARTIN The jobs at the bottom of the hierarchy were those of the 'chaffie' and 'water-joey' or waterman. The chaffie's job was the most unpleasant. [chaffy; chaffey] (1990,Forgotten Worker, The,132)

chaffie/chaffy¶

n. a threshing-mill hand.

'A good deal was said in Court on Tuesday during the hearing of a case about threshing-machines, and no little amusement was caused by a list given by one witness of the 'technical' names of titles of some of the workmen employed about them. 'Chaffy' and 'baggy' raised a smile merely, but 'straw walloper' tickled everybody except the witness, who glanced around with an air of pity on the laughing faces of those who were ignorant of the designation of the man who attends to the straw elevator. Some machines, it appears, boast of two 'straw wallopers', others are content with one'. (Sep 6, 1884,Otago Witness,18) [NOTES: Otago Witness is quoting Timaru Herald of 3 September 1884, p. 2]

DUFF Today I was No. 4 of the crew of a header harvester, which however was not heading but threshing from the stack. Fifty years ago I would have been No. 12, `Chaffy', the dirtiest and most despised member of the gang, dragging my loads away on a bag sheet, and with no hot shower ahead of me when we finished. (May 17, 1951,Shepherd's Calendar,30,1961 ed.)

KERSE The usual gang for stack threshing [c1900] was 12 men. The boss kept steam up and attended to the mill adjustments and lubrication, three men worked in the bag hole, the bag-rammer, the bag-sower, and the bag-carrier; two men were on top of the mill, a band cutter and a man to turn the sheaves to the band cutter: two men were on the stack forking to the turner', and then there was the chaffy, two men on the straw stack, a builder and a strawwalloper' and last of all, the water joey. Threshing out of the stock required an even larger gang, usually about three more men. ... [When the threshing mill was working] the chaffy' driving one horse inchaffstick' brought round threshed straw to the bag hole end to make a bed and cover for the heap of [full wheat] bags. (1984,Knapdale Run, The,148)

OGILVIE [reference 1880] About a dozen men were needed to operate such a [threshing] mill. The engine driver who was the boss, the feeder' who fed in the sheaves, three men at the bags, three who forked the sheaves to thefeeder', a cook, a water joey', and achaffie'. (1971,Moonshine County,151)

The mills here are now equipped withpipes and fans to blow a strong currentof air through them to carry away thechaff, thus dispensing with the servicesof a "chaffy". (Apr 11, 1917,Otago Witness,23)

chai latte set¶

n.

But surely in this age of the metrosexual male, chardonnay socialists and the chai latte set we can do better in collectively celebrating excellence and outstanding achievement. (Jan 11, 2004,Sunday Star Times,B10)

chain¶

n. a) the overhead chain on which carcasses move for processing in a freezing works; b) the specialist workers who work at various points along such a chain; drag the chain, to be slow (usual constr. the); the work-line on which each of a specialised group of men works consecutively from killing to completing the dressing of carcases; the killing-chain (also go down the chain, give a cut up the chain, beef chain, mutton chain etc).

LIND Establishing a seventh chain.. was not a simple matter. (1985,Cut Above, A,212)

PERRIAM One catch pen and sticking area.. would feed stock onto the chain. (1989,Where it all Began,87)

COLIN GORDON The chain: `machine' which moves carcases through [the works]. exclamation to slow workers ahead of one on the chain If chaps are cramping you yell Get up the chain!; to which an adequate reply is Get up you too! (May 17, 1951,Personal Communication) [NOTES: Feilding Freezing Works terms]

SLATTER I'd like to see them ... racing the chain, that remorseless heartless chain. And when the last is scrubbed and the chain is switched off, going down for a shower ... I'd like to see them on the chain. Even the learners' chain. In that narrow cell of concrete with the lambs swinging in quick time up the ramp from the sticking-pen ... Lambs hooked on to the chain and progressing slowly along while the row of men standing alongside slash and tear and nick with knives while others punch briskets or pull the skins from the swinging carcases. More men rip out the guts and throw the heart and liver on to the small-goods table ... and the skins and innards and hooves and ears all go by chutes to the departments below. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,67)

SLATTER He had been overseas and he had been up and down the island picking up jobs ... Crayfishing and scrubcutting. Contract fencing. Poisoning rabbits. Even collecting agar. On the chain at Whakatu [166] when they put through 13,000 lambs a day. Share-milking for a while. (1968,Pagan Game, The,165)

... the inspection for cysts could be handled away from the chain, perhaps on the cooling floor, and this would eliminate slowing down the chain itself. (Nov 1, 1972,Press, The,1/10)

LELAND The chain. In the freezing works where meat animals are butchered for New Zealand's most lucrative export trade, there is a kind of dis- [24] assembly line where each person chops out the same portion of each carcass as it reaches him on an endless belt. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,23)

chain ... 9. Austral. & N.Z. a. the rail along which carcasses are moved in a slaughterhouse. b. the team of workers who slaughter, skin, and otherwise process carcasses in a slaughterhouse. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,182) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 79]]

HULME He laughs bitterly. `I'm a typical hori after all, made to work on the chain, or be a factory hand, not try for high places. (1983,Bone People, The,240)

Suppose a friend says to me, `You know that drongo who was on the chain with me at the works last summer? Just a little joker he was, remember? A real serious ankle-biter. ... A non-New Zealander will probably require a translation, ... My friend is communicating to me the information that a slow-witted, incompetent person of diminutive stature, who was reared in the Wairarapa district and worked for a time in the killing gang of an abattoir... (Jan 1989,Pacific Way,10) [NOTES: (Sharp New Zildish)]

Ihimaera He thought back to times when he had been lead man on the chain at the Whakatu Freezing Works. (2000,Uncle's Story, The,96)

n. a Paul Jones

TURNER [S]ome years ago the term Paul Jones at a dance was replaced by chain south of an isogloss somewhere in the middle of the North Island. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,179)

3 n. as attrib. chain slaughterman, chain system

At least eight of the present employees at Waitaki NZR Stoke, were solo butchers at the time the chain system was introduced in 1956. Stoke is not unique among New Zealand meat processing plants in still employing staff who were solo butchers. (Mar 12, 1982,Dominion,9/1)

His one ... companion was a freezing-works chain slaughter-man (with appropriate gestures he explained his job as a brisket-puncher) ... (1975,NZ Short Stories III,4) [NOTES: 19? Sargeson `A Final Cure' in 1975 NZ Short Stories III 4]

The `chain' system is used for slaughtering lambs, sheep, bobby calves, and pigs (the number of lambs slaughtered reaches 3000 to 3500 a day on each chain, and some works have 6 separate chains). (1974,NZ Agriculture,189)

In 1932, wages were cut, and the freezing workers struck throughout the country. The butchers didn't believe that they could be replaced, but when the works reopened it was found that the companies had installed the American chain system, with each worker responsible for only one aspect of the process. The butchers were replaced by the unemployed, who initially made a terrible mess of the carcasses. But in time they became competent process workers, as opposed to the tradesmen who had preceded them. (Jul 1986,Metro,76)

chain dropper¶

1 n. (Rural) a galvanised-iron batten used in chain fences. (See Hunter Fence,chain dropper fence)

RIDDOLLS One type of dropper coming into widespread use is the chain dropper. These consist of lengths of chain, made of 12 gauge galvanised-iron wire, spaced about 3 ft. apart along the fence and fastened to the fence wires by patent fasteners. Barbed wire is used for the top and bottom wires, the barbs keeping the chain droppers in place along the fence wires. The use of the new angle steel fence posts with the chain droppers gives a fence with all the advantages mentioned above, and at the same time one that is much cheaper than a conventional fence. (1958,Farm Engineering,427)

chain dropper fence¶

1 n. (Rural) a fence made entirely of metal fenceposts, droppers and chains. (See chain dropper)

RIDDOLL The advantages of chain dropper fences compared with conventional fences are cheapness, lightness, tightness, resistance against shock, durability, and suitability for dropping from aircraft. (1958,Farm Engineering,427)

chain fern¶

n. Tmesipteris tannensis

MOORE & IRWIN TMESIPTERIS TANNENSIS, `chain fern'. In lowland rain forest plants hang from tree-fern trunks ... (1878,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,214)

chain gang¶

n. [freezing workers]

When they're not shearing they're probably on the chain gang at the freezing-works. (1945,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),3(6) : 24)

chain lightning/chained lightning¶

n. crude, often illicit, liquor

... where as if they did likewise with good, wholesome beer - not half chain-lightning brands - not half the harm would result, ... (Nov 7, 1908,NZ Truth,8)

ANZAC Shebangs [in Cairo] where they sell you whisky that takes the lining of your throat down with it, ... a soothing liquid that licks forty-rod',chained lightning', or `Cape Smoke' to the back of creation; the kind of lush that gives you a sixty-horse dose of the jim-jams while you wait. (1916,On the Anzac Trail,77)

EADDY Most of the masters being well under the influence', and nearly all supplied with a parting gift ofchain-lightning' whiskey. (1933,Hull Down,95)

LEE `There's enough wine [in the abandoned French winery at Mailly Maillet] to float a ship. There's about two or three barrels of chain lightning. You can't have the chain lightning.' He waved towards the wine. (1976,Soldier,60)

chain migration¶

n. migrating in stages from country to country

This "chain migration" - immigrants using New Zealand as a stepping stone to Australia - is of significant policy interest to Australian authorities given that New Zealanders now comprise Australia's largest settler group. (Nov 1999,North & South,39)

chain strainer¶

n. a metal fence batten composed of chained loops to accomodate wire

Chain strainer have been around for well over 100 years but it is only now that someone's come up with an idea which makes them dramatically easier to use (Nov 17, 2004,Wairarapa News,18)

chain system¶

n.

PERRIAM Under the chain system a recruit soon learned the knack of carrying out the specialised but limited job required of him. (1989,Where it all Began,87)

DARE All the work was done on the chain system, each man doing the same job all the time, the carcass going slowly down the line until it was finished ... (1956,Rouseabout Jane,188)

chain-crazed¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of a dog] frenzied from being tied up for too long.

Philip Ward. chain-crazed dogs are casualties of being left on the chain too long. (1998,Personal Communication)

GORDON chain-crazed: a state of excitement in a dog chained up too long. (1983,Other Side of Farming, The,3)

chain-crazed: a kind of violent reaction to being let off a chain after a long interval. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

chain-dragging¶

adj. slow

There is still long and gruelling rehabilitation for the severely injured; and a chain-dragging ACC meant many counselling and physiotherapy sessions have been paid for by victims' families. (Dec 2004,North & South,44)

chain-rack¶

n. twitch (@v and @n). [R. Gilberd (milling Okaihau, Northland) The old method of tightening the chain securing logs to trucks is called twitching' ortaking a twitch.' First the chain is fastened leaving it quite slack. A lever is passed through the bight and used to twist the slack up on itself. When chain is tight enough the end of the lever is tied to the chain. A chain-rack' is now used - a giant Hayes wire-strainer. It is sometimes, but improperly, called atwitch.' Twitch' is probably an amalgamation oftwist' and `pitch.']

chain-shy¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheepdogs] averse to being tied up.

MILLS ET AL Incidentally, if from the time he was a pup you had held a few tempting scraps in front of Boy as you walked towards his kennel that should convincingly overcome this chain-shy habit. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,38)

chainbird¶

n.

The chainbird, however, or more specifically its cry, is mentioned more frequently. The sound has two elements: the bird cry and a subsequent whirring noise, which has been likened to 'a jet-stream', 'a blind rolling itself up', or even 'a shell passing overhead'. (Aug 2000,NZWords,No. 4: 6)

chainbreaker¶

n. a tool to fix bicycle chains

In the essential category [of extra equipment] are helmet, sunnies (to ward off flying insects as well as UV),.. a chainbreaker to fix bent links.. and a banana or two. (Feb 1997,North & South,98)

chained-up¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheepdogs] fastened to kennels or fences with chains.

BARKER All the chained-up dogs were pulling at the staples of their fastenings ... (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,188)

chainer¶

n. =chainman.

COLIN GORDON Chainers: workers on the chain. (May 17, 1951,Personal Communication) [NOTES: ca1951 May 17 Feilding Freezing Works terms p.c. Colin Gordon]

n. the last pair of bullocks who bore the weight of the drag through the the chains rather than through the pole.

REED The rear pair of bullocks, next the logs, and known as chainers, were generally chosen for their conformation ... (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,183) [NOTES: (c1900)]

The last pair in the team were called the chainers and usually were very heavy-necked cattle. (1951,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: [ca1914] 1951 H.S. McCarroll The Days of the Kauri Bushmen [Radio Talk 3: TS]]

OWEN & PERKINS At the back of the [sc. bullock] team were the 'chainers'... The chainers had a heavier job to do than the others and theirs was the dangerous job, because if a log happened to go out of control going down a slope, they would be the first to catch it. (1986,Southern Cross (Wgton),160)

chainie¶

n. chainman.

On the floor itself you had the number one beefies, the number one chainies and they were, in the main, Maori. (Sep 2000,North & South,48)

chainman¶

n. one who works on the chain [ca1946 Ngauranga, Wellington]

When a man saw his wife and another man sitting naked in his bed drinking wine `I just exploded, and the gun went off', Peter Douglas Gillies said in the Dunedin High Court yesterday. Gillies, 30, chainman, was giving evidence in his trial for the murder of Thomas Craig Taggart at Alexandra on October 30 last year. Asked why he had exploded, he said he thought it was because of the wine. (Feb 10, 1982,Dominion,4)

He was a "Homie", and had got work as a"chainman" with a survey party near us. (Aug 27, 1927,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,48)

Chalice¶

n. an iconic giant Christchurch sculpture in Cathedral Square

Certainly, he [sc. Peter Beaven] described the Chalice, a giant sculpture in Cathedral Square as resembling a vent for an underground lavatory. (Dec 6, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

chalk¶

n. (in rugby) the try line

Rokocoko is desperately looking for a way to get back over the chalk. (Aug 14, 2004,Dominion Post,D8)

They couldn't get across the chalk. (May 9, 2004,TV1)

n. a grade of kauri gum; also chalky gum.

... it is no doubt also responsible for the dark coloured varnishes produced from the chip grades. [fn] The terms dust, seeds, chips, nubs, &c., are the names given to certain of the lower kauri gum grades according to the relative sizes of the pieces. From dust' the size of the fragments increases in the order given, as does also the purity of the grade. Chalk, orchalky gum,' is a particular grade recovered from swampy country and is characterized by its white or chalky appearance and large water content. (1936,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,17/371)

SUTHERLAND Some of the classifications under which gum was exported give an indication of the appearance of some of the grades: bright, rescraped bush, bright chips, black flour dust, chalk, bright seeds and black sugar are some of the names. (1956,Green Kiwi,70,1960 ed.)

chalkie¶

n. a marble

HYDE Once Curly Adams' bag of marbles, glimmers and chalkies, came up [from the street-sewer] on the shovel, and the drain-men gave them to Eliza. (1938,Godwits Fly, The,26,1970 ed.)

HISLOP I suppose at that time [c1860s goldrush] I would be more interested in grabbing my `dumps' out of the ring at school, when some quick eye had noticed that a young pointer had tried to get away with placing a stinkie or a chalkie into play with the rest of his marbles. (1943,Pure Gold,22)

n. a schoolteacher

chalkie/chalky¶

n. a Stock Exchange employee who records the sale of each share traded on the chalk board of the Stock Exchange. [transf. from Stock Exchange chalkie to restaurant chalkie [Also used as pseudonym for financial columnist]]

It was time to make a farewell toast of appreciation to the post trading clerks (chalkies) who recorded the market bids and sales. Ibid. 50 The chalkies brought sparkle and speed to the trading floor. (Sep 30, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49)

As the sale [of shares on the Stock Exchange floor] proceeds, a `chalky' records the quote for each share traded. ,ho;1987 Oct 19 TV1 News 6.30 p.m. [reference fall in share prices] The changes kept the chalkies [sc the girls who write up the share changes on the board] busy. (Jun 1986,Consumer,144)

Karen McNulty is a post board operator. ... Post board operator still doesn't rank high as a preferred occupation though the colloquial term `chalkie' is now better known than it was BC (before crash). Chalkies were on television a lot last October - ... flitting from blackboard to blackboard, armed with chalk and duster, squiggling the hieroglyphs that rule the world via the stock exchange. (Nov 12, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

[Hdg] Callovers, chalkies and chips... Note also the miniskirt of the "chalkie". There is a myth that the height of the fashionable skirt correlates with the price of shares. (Apr 19, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),60)

Chalkies are endowed with magical powers of decoding; very handy they'd have been around the Tower of Babel...[She] is the first chalkie at the board in the world each day - well, along with those in Christchurch and Auckland. (Nov 12, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

Eventually a chalkie arrived and removedwhat was obviously last night'shighlight. (Oct 21, 1995,Dominion,23)

chalkiness¶

1 n. (Rural) a property of Down wool and other hairy wools, in which wool reflects light.

MAF Chalkiness: Property by which Down and very hairy wools reflect light. Sometimes called whiteness. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53)

Chalkiness: The matt, chalky non-lustrous appearance of Down and Cheviot wools. (2001,Woolpro Glossary of Wool Terms,7)

chalkmark¶

n. the try-line (or touchline), marked out with powdered chalk.

... the northerners twice crossed their opponents chalkmark (Sep 2, 1905,NZ Truth,11/2/2)

challenge feeder¶

n.

McARA Challenge feeder: An inclined cast-iron disc about two feet in diameter mounted in the chute leading from the stamp hopper to the stamp mortar-box; it rotated slowly in short jerks, actuated by a striking mechanism attached to the camshaft, thus spilling the ore lying on it into the mortar-box at regular intervals and providing a remarkably constant feed. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),315)

Challenger Plateau¶

n.

This year's project is a seafloor habitat and biodiversity comparison between the Chatham Rise and Challenger Plateau. (Sep 2006,Climate Update, The (NIWA),Coasts and Oceans)

chamber¶

n. a room in a freezing works where carcasses can be frozen rapidly; chamberhand a person who works in a freezing chamber

[Canterbury Freezers] No freezers shallbe asked to work outside at a lower rateof pay while work is going on in thechambers. (1901,Awards etc.,III/438)

chamber ... NZ & Austral. room in freezing works where carcasses are frozen. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,118) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 79]]

2 n.

McARA Chamber: The space close to the shaft on each level for loading and unloading the cages. It was generally about twelve feet high near the shaft and about the same width and up to 150 ft long to take a rake of about eighteen trucks. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),315)

(Jul 26, 1913,NZ Bulletin,10)

Under Sir Joseph Ward the building became the social centre of Wellington but in 1935 was nicknamed `chamber of horrors' after it became a [school dental nursing] dental centre. (Dec 20, 1989,Dominion,2)

LIND In the past, chamberhands had serviced the old cutting department. (1985,Cut Above, A,327)

PERRIAM The chamber hands were next to make an award. (1989,Where it all Began,130)

chamberhand n. worker in freezing works. (1985,Collins Compact Dictionary,79) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD]]

The gang of chamberhands who usually dawdle along behind me are already crossing the loci [sic] tracks up in front. (1950,Landfall,4(2) : 125)

chamberman¶

n.

Brace and chambermen not to be employed in any other occupation. (Sep 29, 1911,Maoriland Worker,30/6/2)

McARA Chamberman: The man in charge of the cages underground who attended to all underground loading. All the men were subject to his direction when travelling in the cages. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),315)

"I got two chammy." (Dec 29, 1965,Weekly News,36)

Chancery-Lane nymphs¶

phr. ?female or male toughs

A few days ago at Auckland, a poor Maori woman ... was savagely maltreated by two chancery-lane nymphs.' ... thenymphs' were subsequently bought up at the Police Court and fined [pounds]10. (Feb 23, 1871,Evening Post,2)

chandelier¶

NEWBOLD Chandelier (n) Ear. (1982,Big Huey, The,246)

change-house¶

n. a place where miners could clean themselves and change clothes after an underground shift.

It was pointed out by witnesses that without change-houses near the mine mouth, men were compelled to walk home, sometimes a distance of two miles, in their wet clothes, ... (Aug 25, 1911,Maoriland Worker,25/10/4)

McARA Changehouse: The building in which the miners changed from their street clothes into their underground clothes and vice-versa. It had hot showers and equipment for washing and drying work-clothes. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),315)

change-over man¶

n. freezing worker

HENDERSON CHANGE-OVER MEN (Two required) (1975,Log of a Superfluous Son, The,42)

changer¶

n. a marble so called because they could be changed or ?exchanged as the game demanded [[check Janet Frame].]

FRAME `Treasure' I played ringie and holie. I played funs and keeps. I had pee-wees and bully taws and changers that weren't made of glass mind you. And I won nearly every game because the kids were so dazzled by the look of my stinkers. ... They came for miles to play marbles with me ... (1951,Lagoon, The,116,1961 ed.)

SUTTON-SMITH Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as taw' orshooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; dubs',dates', stakes',dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. (1972,Folkgames of Children,174)

changi¶

n. a forked stick to hold sheep's tails up [see discussion at shanghai]. [ca1974 p.c. Les Lang (Agricultural Reporter Radio NZ)]

changing shed¶

n. = dressing shed

MARSHALL Dusty suggested we spend time drilling a hole in the girls' changing sheds. (1989,Divided World,188)

O'Sullivan And a few weeks after that, in the wooden changing shed with the southerly slicing between the boards, he heard the coach telling his father, 'I think we've got a natural this time, Rob.' (2006,Pictures by Goya,208)

changing station¶

1 n. (Rural) a place on a circuit, similar to a staging post, where horses are rested or changed and travellers refreshed.

HENDERSON The next stop is Warakiki, a changing station, where we enjoy a hot meal and are given a change of horses. (1969,Open Country Calling,171)

Channel Nine¶

n. the ninth floor of the Beehive

Helen Clark's staff - dubbed Channel Nine by Dover Samuels - are well known for their relaxed and chatty attitude towards gallery hacks... Now one rueful spin-man says it looks like Channel Nine is about to be pulled from the air, just when they were thinking about bidding for spectrum to go digital. (Jul 26, 2000,Independent Business Weekly,11)

Even the Prime Minister's ninth-floor Beehive office is being accused of leaking ordure - "Channel Nine," according to Dover Samuels, "the sewage channel". (Aug 5, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

character office¶

n.

These [options] could include character offices on the upper floors, with a showroom or cafe on the ground floor... The 1905 building would suit a variety of uses, from character office space, or reinstatement as an entertainment facility, to possibly apartments... (Apr 4, 2002,Dominion,20)

charcoal stain¶

n. bush stain, log stain

Charcoal stain: Discoloration of wool with charcoal from bush burns. More commonly referred to as log stain. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53)

Chardonnay capital¶

n. Gisborne

The country's first varietal wine, Montana Gisborne Chardonnay, was produced here in 1973. Gisborne still prides itself as "The Chardonnay Capital of New Zealand". (2007,Internet - see Notes,2) [NOTES: www.montana.co.nz/wine/wine_regions.html]

The Gisborne wine region (in the North Island province of Eastland) is the New Zealand Chardonnay Capital. (2008,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.fourcorners.co.nz/new-zealand/gisborne-wine/]

So when and if you make your way over the Whareratas on your journey to the Chardonnay capital of N.Z. glance to your left before reaching the present "lookout" and its magnificent view and picture that sparkling trough of cool clear water just above the horizon .. it's still there! (1996,Trouble with Stock Agents, The,93)

The difference between Hawke's Bay and Gisborne, the so-called Chardonnay Capital of New Zealand, is simply soil and climate. (Jun 17, 2009,Southland Times,3)

chardonnay set¶

n.

Many Wellingtonians were outraged by the proposal, and some labelled the move a breach of human rights developed by the "chardonnay set". (Dec 4, 2003,Sunday Star Times,1)

chardonnay socialist¶

n. [Believed to be been used first publicly by Mike Moore on the Holmes Show on 26 November, 1993, during the Moore-Clark "affair" and subsequently picked up by various TV and radio commentators but not so obviously by the papers at the time except for a subsequent rather nasty editorial in the Dom. The (later?)English equivalent appears to be "champagne socialist". Bruce Moore (ANU) says 30/4/1999 in an e-mail that "it's been around for at least 6 years, though we haven't been collecting citations coz it's American."]

For daring to fight back publicly againstthe sisters and their largely leftistbackers - comdemning them as "chardonnaysocialists" - Mr Moore has beenpilloried. (Nov 30, 1993,Dominion,8)

The majority of the sitting Governmentmember was more than doubled, and VernWalsh, the "chardonnay socialist", tocoin a recent Mooreism, was defeated. (Dec 9, 1993,Evening Post,6)

He cannot resist describing her as a "Chardonnay Socialist". (Apr 24, 1999,Dominion,18)

He calls Neill a chardonnay socialist. "That really stung," says Neill. "I don't drink chardonnay." (Nov 25, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

She is frequently branded as a coremember of what Labour dissidents call the"chardonnay socialist, neurotic left". (Mar 24, 1996,Sunday Star Times,C1) [NOTES: now "champagne socialists" in UK]

Simpson may be a foodie, but he is also atrade union leader (who wants it knownthat he is no chardonnay socialist -"sauvignon blanc if you don't mind"). (Apr 6, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),44)

So how did Kan - Wellington born and bred - manage to avoid becoming a sad chardonnay socialist? He travels a lot. To places like Palmerston North. (Jan 31, 2001,Capital Times,7)

Makes one wonder whether the chardonnay socialists really care about the workers. (Sep 20, 1999,Evening Post,4)

Was Hunt perhaps the original chardonnay socialist?.. Given the oenological state of the times, he must have been more of a McWilliams Bakano socialist, but out to Labour's left in the early days, nonetheless. (Mar 25, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

Sir Geoffrey Palmer does not appear to remember his party was trounced at the last election and most New Zealanders rejected its nanny-state policies. Chardonnay socialists and wowsers of his ilk are always ready to tell others what to do. (May 4, 2009,Dominion Post,B4) [NOTES: Letter to the editor re the Law Commission review of the alcohol licensing laws.]

Helen Clark may be setting him up as the real Chardonnay socialist. (Dec 15, 1993,TV3,Richard Prebble in The Ralston Group)

This provides every reason you need to be a Chardonnay Socialist - its lovely nose is part blue-collar sweat of the land, part exotic fruit and part Old World sophistication. (Jun 11, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),61)

"Chardonnay socialists," grins Lianne,referring to Mike Moore's scathingdismissal of the liberal-left LabourMPs.. who plotted against him to installHelen Clark. (May 1995,North & South,67)

n.

.. his evident frustation with the kind of Wellington chardonnistas whose vision of paradise is wholegrain, smokefree and sensibly shod ... (Apr 10, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C10)

chardy¶

n. (informal) chardonnay [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

Stoneybatter's my new favourite, a lovely chardonnay from a Waiheke vineyard. I've always been a chardy drinker. (Dec 14, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),9)

charette¶

n. type of consultation process [-] (See correctly charrette q.v)

Mr Clews said the idea of a charette gave the best chance of comprehensive, environmentally sound planning. ... The charette is being held on private farm land at the Haupouri Station woolshed. (Sep 17, 2005,Dominion Post,A6)

charge¶

v. insert contraband into one's rectum to hide and transport it

To charge something is to insert contraband into one's rectum to hide and transport it, as opposed to cheeking, where contraband is not actually inserted, yet is held between the cheeks of one's bottom. (Oct 2000,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

charge like a bull¶

phr. said of one demanding an excessive price

McGILL excessive prices; pun on charge; eg `Sure, nice gear, but she charges like a bull for it.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,26)

charger¶

n. a nitrous oxide cylinder

The contents of one cylinder make the user high for a few minutes... These cylinders are known as "chargers" and are available for about $10 for a box of 10 or 12 from many dairies and supermarkets... [27] But there are strong rumours circulating among users that it's only a matter of time before the sale and use of nos chargers are controlled. (Feb 1, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

chariot¶

n. a vehicle, esp a motorcar [ca1929 (Auckland) R. Mason (1952) heard for acar'; and occasionally since']

By 4 p.m. Chariots of all kinds were bowling homewards. (1929,Tararua Tramper,2(2)?4) [NOTES: check year]

[`Chariot' used for a lorry] (1939,Tararua Tramper,12(3)/4) [NOTES: CHECK YEAR]

He owned an ancient and extremely battered car which he called the `Episcopal chariot' ... (Oct 3, 1952,Evening Post) [NOTES: [of Rt Rev G.V. Gerard, referring to the evacuation of Greece in 1941]]

Charitable Aid Board¶

n.

SIMPSON ... there was a great deal of shame [during the Depression] in the minds of working men ... who had to go with an order from the Charitable Aid Board for groceries up to the local Self Help. If I remember rightly, my parents used to spell out C.A.B. so that I wouldn't know what it meant ... I knew that we were going with a C.A.B. chit to get groceries ... (1974,Sugarbag Years,55)

charity¶

n. uneconomic fish catch

JOHNSON Sometimes different grades of the same [commercial fish] species had other names - small snapper and tarakihi were recorded as 'charity'. (They were marginally economical to process so the buyer was being 'charitable' in buying them). (2004,Hooked,309)

Charity Ball¶

n. a pre-1980s debutante presentation ball

... the sorry few who do not understand the way of the cue and the chalk; those who think the word "ball" should always be prefixed with the word "charity". (Jul 11, 2004,Sunday Star Times,B10)

Charity Charley¶

phr. an orphan living in a charity orphanage.

PEACOCKE [a child speaks] That big red big place at the top of the hill ... [the orphanage] where the Charity Charley's live. (1926,His Kid Brother,36)

Charleston gentian¶

n. (Environment) a rare native plant Gentianella scopulorim , grown naturally in the Charleston area near Westport [ORIGIN: toponym]

The threatened Charleston gentian occurs on several coastal rocky headlands near that town. (2007,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.westmarine.org.nz/report5_5.html]

The future of the rare Charleston gentian, Gentianella scopulorum , found only in the Charleston area near Westport, is more secure after members of the local community planted 50 more plants during Conservation Week. (Jun 2007,Conservation Action,22)

Buller/Kawatiri Area staff are continuing to monitor the translocated Charleston gentian at Chareleston and Tauranga Bay. (2007,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.doc.govt.nz/templates/MultipageDocumentPage.aspx?id=41835]

Charlie¶

n. ??

A four-year-old silver Holden Commodore, tailing the car in front too closely, drifting from one side of its lane to the other. "Do you reckon it's a Charlie?" asks de Heer. "Looks just like one. I'd hate to tip out a Charlie." (Oct 1997,North & South,51)

n. a bar-room gambling game.

Police have seen up to 50 people betting on a single game of Charlie' in Wellington hotel bars, and are mounting a campaign to halt the gambling. The sudden popularity was inexplicable, but involved large numbers of punters of all ages. Eighty percent of public bars hosted the game from time to time, he thought.Charlie' is played with three cards. The conductor turns over the middle card and the players bet on whether the other cards will be of a higher or lower value, depending on the value of the middle card. (Aug 1, 1984,Evening Post,44)

Charlie across the water¶

n. a children's game (See bullrush)

McGILL Bullrush involved as many of the school as possible, all at one end of the paddock, one person in the middle. At the cry of 'bullrush' we all ran and he had to catch one of us. It was also called Charlie across the water and kingaseeny (1989,Kiwi Baby Boomers,41)

Charlie Browns¶

n.

LELAND Charlie Browns: Lace up BROWN SHOES with crepe soles FOR KIDS. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,24)

Charlie Wheeler¶

n. girl, sheila [rhyming slang]

Yeah, what a day it was. And to have to cop an ear bashing from me Charlie Wheeler on top of it all. Charlie Wheeler (sheila) ... girlfriend (May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19)

charlock¶

n. ?? wild turnip [?Keep in as dialectal and var.]

HILGENDORF WILD TURNIP (Sinapsis arvensis) [1967, no species given] is also commonly called charlock and yellow weed, and even wild mustard. It is exceedingly common on rich agricultural lands, at any rate in Canterbury and Otago, where masses of it often rival gorse in brilliancy. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,90,1967 ed.)

HILGENDORF & CALDER WILD TURNIP ... (b) Sinapsis arvensis (CHARLOCK) with three faint lines on the sides of the pods; ... (1967,Weeds of New Zealand,98,[nf 1926] ed.)

charlock, [s] Sinapis arvensis L. Ibid. 41 jointed charlock [=] wild radish [s] (1967,Standard Common Names for Weeds,13)

charrette¶

n. a creative consultation process

The French word, "Charrette" means "cart" and is often used to describe the final, intense work effort expended by art and architecture students to meet a project deadline. This use of the term is said to originate from the Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris during the 19th century, where proctors circulated a cart, or "charrette", to collect final drawings while students frantically put finishing touches on their work. (Oct 1, 2004,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.charetteinst.org/ in Portland USA]

A consultant team was appointed by Council this month. They have been asked to independently develop and run a design "charrette". Charrette is a French word used by architects and urban designers to describe a process that is creative, which operates with community input, but under pressure and with a high degree of focus... If support continues, then the team will proceed to the second stage - the holding of a design "charrette" probably some time in November. (Sep 29, 2004,Northern Courier,4)

chart¶

n. a (racing) doubles chart

SARGESON chart: doubles-chart. See double. (1964,Collected Stories,298)

Charter¶

n. the 1999 document which sets out the direction of TVNZ.

The new Charter era for TVNZ is almost upon us... Others might argue that it will take supernatural powers to make the new Charter work... But there are also dangers in the new set-up - mainly that TYVNZ swaps the orthodoxy of ratings for a new orthodoxy of the Charter, where every mainstream New Zealand programme must account for minority tates and carry the baggage of social engineering. (Feb 1, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

chartered club¶

n. a club licensed to serve liquor by charter

chartered club n. N.Z. old-fashioned. a club which provides alcohol to members (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,187) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 80]]

chase¶

v. to court (also as vbl n chasing) [1953 15 M A24 Thames DHS 27 CHASE -->1984 16 F E38 Pakuranga Coll. 27 CHASING -->1984 14 F E143Wgton Girls C. 27 CHASING AFTER]

chase pork¶

phr. (Rural) to hunt wild pigs.

NGAWHIKA We cruised on through the year, taking any opportunity we could to chase pork. (1996,Tell Them I've Gone Pighunting,74)

chase the bugle¶

phr. to endure enforced continuous drill; to be Confined to Barracks; an extension of CB (confined to barracks).

MILLER We ... were awarded two days C.B., Confined to Barracks', commonly termedChasing the Bugle'. `Trumpeter what are you sounding now? Is it the call I'm seeking?' (May 15, 1917,Camps, Tramps and Trenches,75)

At one stage a much older soldier than myself didn't drink unless he got a "skinful" and would be picked up Awol. His spare time was not his own for a period during which time he "chased the bugle" - continuous drill. (Sep 8, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A10)

chase the tally¶

phr. (Rural) to shear at high speed.

BOWEN My advice to shearers is that they should not chase the tally too much, for a shearer can only go as fast as the sheep will let him. (1955,Wool Away!,3)

chaser¶

n. (Rural) a dog with the bad habit of barking loudly and running towards approaching vehicles and after retreating ones.

Chaser - of cars. A Kamikaze strain that persists in hurling itself at approaching vehicles whilst howling at the top of its bark. (Aug 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,11)

n. a whaling vessel

[Caption] The chasers are tied up at the jetty. Ibid. 11 Winter maintenance on the fleet of chasers was last carried out in 1931. (Feb 2000,NZ Historic Places,76/22)

JOHNSTON In the excitement of the chase the gunsmen seemed to fire at random for shot after shot missed. Irons were pulled in and guns reloaded with feverish haste.) (1968,Turn of the Tide, The,38)

NEWTON Originally a `chaser' in the Perano whaling fleet she was purchased by the Moletas when the Peranos discontinued their whaling operations. ... These boats have a maximum speed of well over 30 knots ... (1973,Big Country,39,1977 ed.)

n. a girl who chases after men, or comes on strongly to men.

HYDE He had known Jackie's girl would be good, but hoped somehow that she would be older and harder, a bit more of a chaser. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,47)

n. a beer (drunk with, and following, spirits) (cf ?gen. Eng. `beerchaser').

DAVIN We ordered you a chaser ... Barry won't come at it. Says he's not going to start the Mission with a skinful of piece. (1949,Roads from Home,44)

1 n. (Rural) a ram used to serve any ewes that may have been missed in the initial tupping.

All the ewes that are going to mate in the first 10 days will be in Mob A, will be identified and will go on to hard tucker early on with a chaser to catch any stragglers. (Mar 9, 1967,NZ Farmer,35)

LOUGHNAN chaser: a ram, usually old or inferior, left with the ewes to catch any that might have missed being tupped. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,18)

chasing mutton¶

1 n. (Rural) mustering.

LOUGHNAN chasing mutton: mustering; see also tussock jumping. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,18)

Chastechurch¶

n. Christchurch

Forget trying to console yourself with delusions of having climatic conditions better than Irkland or Chastechurch. (Nov 13, 1996,Capital Times,4)

chat¶

v. to give advice or reproof to

He don't like to see others toiling,/ And he proves he's a tiger-skin',/ When he drinks with a bloke and chats him/Why don't you join up and dig in.' (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,69)

SYDER & HODGETTS To tell another that he is at fault. .in 4;He knows that we should've had gloves issued for this job. I'll chat him about that when he comes back.'Charlie's leaving; the boss chatted him over something, and Charlie didn't like it.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],166)

Chateau Cardboard¶

n. cask wine

BAKER ...Te Rina and the kids and Uncle Wire would be enjoying the legs, wings and breasts, washed down with Chateau Cardboard. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,16)

Ye gods, Chateau Cardborde without the cardboard. (Aug 29, 1999,Sunday Star Times,D5)

Invite some intelligent, urbane people around for dinner, fill them up with Spaghetti a la Puttanesca (Prostitute's Pasta - wonderful recipe!) and a glass or five of Chateau Cardboard and wait for the gems of erudition that will form your next column. (Nov 18, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),40)

But he [a winemaker] had to keep selling because some return was better than none, ... and when it came to bulk wine the cheapest Chateau Cardboard is the best in the eyes of the average consumer and Villa Maria's had nothing to distinguish it from any others. (Jun 1986,Metro,110)

What has caused this mushroom-like growth of Chateau Cardboard? As a simple matter of economics it is cheaper to put wine into a cask than a bottle. Plastic and cardboard are not as expensive as glass ... (Jan 18, 1987,NZ Times,9)

Chateau cardboard expected to decline [headline] A top Australian winemaker believes that the day of bag-in-the-box wines will soon be on the decline in New Zealand. (Nov 1, 1989,Dominion,6)

If the budget allows only chateau cardboard, you can flash it up a littleby decanting into carafes. (Feb 1993,Cuisine,00)

House wine is Australian chateau cardboard but not bad with it. (Nov 6, 2001,Evening Post,2)

The Spanish love their wine. Now they say it may help prevent the common cold. But a New Zealand expert urges caution before people consider getting tanked up on Chateau Cardboard. (May 18, 2001,Evening Post,6)

Grace 'Well maybe we have us just a mini celebration while we work,' Wai said. 'Get us a few cans, a chateau cardboard, just enough to see the New Year in. How's that?' (2001,Dogside Story,232)

The everyday wine of a typical Frenchfamily is of equal or less quality thansome of our domestic "Chateau Cardboard". (Jul 1994,Cuisine,4)

Chateau Collapso¶

n. cheap wine [see vino collapso on Google]

Politicians have exponentially more functions to attend than your average worker at the best of times, so by the Christmas season, when every electorate committee. lobby group, PR firm and local bowling club expects to clap a party hat on an MP an earbash him or her over a trough of Chateau Collapso, the novelty has well and truly worn off. (Dec 15, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

Chateau de Cask¶

n. cask wine

On with the party! ... Apparently normally with it & highly organised Jenny got a bit under the weather - but who wouldn't surrounded by such a bunch of socially diverse politicos all hitting the Chateau de Cask on a Sunday avo? (Mar 9, 1987,Salient,2)

Chateau Fizzy¶

n. sparkling wine

Take a mob of malcontent dyspeptic uncles, frowzy aunts and mumbling grannies, drop a crate of Chateau Fizzy in their midst and watch the graph of pleasure soar. (Dec 25, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

Chateau Tongariro¶

n. the originally government-owned hotel on Mount Ruapehu

BAKER They were riding past the Chateau Tongariro, a place of evil repute. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,126)

Chateau, The¶

n. The Chateau Tongariro hotel

The Chateau was built in 1929 in a neo-Georgian style to attract overseas tourists. It was all very grand and posh, and it was all about dinner jackets and evening frocks after a hard day on the slopes. (Oct 10, 2004,Sunday Star Times: Escape,12)

The slightly surreal, olde world of The Grand Chateau - more commonly cxalled The Chateau - is being resurrected from the ashes of multiple volcanic eruptions, several miserable ski seasons, mismanagement and penury. (Oct 8, 2001,Evening Post,19)

CURNOW Does he ski ... One handsome young single baronet at the Chateau ... (1972,Four Plays,103) [NOTES: [1962] 1972 Allen Curnow Four Plays (`The Overseas Expert') 103]

Chatham albatross¶

n. (Environment)

The second most critically endangered species, the Chathams albatross, breeds in New Zealand waters. (Sep 14, 2003,Sunday Star Times,A14)

Chatham albatross Thalassarche eremita Pyramid Rock in the Chathams is the only location where this species breeds, and some 5000 pairs nest there. It is thought to feed east of the Chathams and winter in Peruvian waters. (2007,NZ Geographic Poster,No 84 Mar-Apr)

The chatham albatross is down to 4000-5000 breeding pairs at Pyramid Rock, a 10ha slab of rock in the ocean. (Nov 26, 2001,Evening Post,5)

Chatham Island¶

adj. (occas. as Chatham solely) as a distinguishing epithet in the names of plants and animals, see akeake, aster, bellbird, cranesbill, fernbird, flax, forget-me-not, gentian, geranium, grass, fescue; kowhai, lancewood, lily, mahoe, matipo, mingimingi, mollymawk, oystercatcher, parakeet, petrel, pigeon, ribbonwood, robin, shag, snipe, sow-thistle, thistle, tit, tree-daisy, tree-heath, warbler.

GRUNDY It was too bad if [the stock] had drawn their dying breaths ... in a lambing paddock. Apart from a few very conscientious ones, the Chatham farmers ignored their dead stock ... (1968,Who'd Marry a Doctor?,39)

COCKAYNE [Bogs] are frequently occupied by a close growth of the Chatham Island aster (Olearia semidentata), ... (1910,NZ Plants,122)

Chatham Island bellbird¶

2 n. Anthornis melanura melanocephala.

BULLER ANTHORNIS MELANOCEPHALA. (CHATHAM-ISLAND BELL-BIRD.) (1873,Birds of New Zealand,96,1888 2nd edn I/92 ed.)

279 13. Anthornis melanocephala, Gray. Chatham island Bell-bird. - ... in others [sc nests] may be found long pieces of piri-piri (Acaena) entwined with other materials; ... (Nov 1884,NZ Journal of Science) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts),]

Chatham Island black robin¶

n. (Environment)

The Chatham Island black robin, once the world's most endangered bird, has been welcomed back onto Pitt Island after an absence of over half a century. (Nov 2002,Footnotes,No. 18/1)

HOLMES CHATHAM ISLAND BLACK ROBIN, Petroica traversi - Little Mangere Island is the native home of this little member of the flycatcher family ... (1984,Chatham Islands,96)

Chatham Island blue penguin¶

n. (Environment)

10.e. Eudyptula minor chathamensis Kinsky and Falla, 1976 Chatham Island Blue Penguin (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,17,1980 ed.)

Blue Penguin Eudyptula minor (FORSTER, 1781) ENDEMIC Northern Blue Penguin E.m. iredalei MATHEWS, 1911. Cook Strait Blue Penguin E.m. variabilis KINSKY & FALLA, 1976. White-flippered Penguin E.m. albosignata FINSCH, 1874. Southern Blue Penguin E.m. minor (FORSTER, 1781). Chatham Island Blue Penguin E.m. chathamensis KINSKY & FALLA, 1976. OTHER NAMES: Little blue penguin, little penguin, fairy penguin, korara. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,46)

Chatham Island button daisy¶

n. (Environment) a rare daisy, Leptinella featherstonii

.. a second mainland site of the rare Chatham Island button daisy (Leptinella featherstonii). (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 7)

Chatham Island Christmas tree¶

n. (Environment) a rare plant, Brachyglottis huntii , also known as rautini, which is restricted to the Chatham Islands.

Hundreds of people voted in the New Zealand Plant Conservation Network's annual quest for the country's favourite native plant. Number one was rautini, the rare Chatham Island Christmas tree. (Nov 24, 2006,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.landcareresearch.co.nz/news/release.asp?Ne_ID=219]

Rautini, sometimes referred to as the Chatham Island Christmas tree, grows up to 8 m tall. (2007,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: http://conservation.govt.nz/conservation/native-plants/chatham-island-christmas-tree/]

Chatham Island fantail¶

2 n. (Environment)

256.c. Rhipidura fuliginosa penitus Bangs, 1911 Chatham Island Fantail (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,1980)

Fantail Rhipidura fuliginosa (SPARRMAN, 1787) North Island Fantail R.f. placabilis BANGS, 1921. South Island Fantail R.f. fulginosa (SPARRMAN, 1787). Chatham Island Fantail R.f. penitus BANGS, 1911. OTHER NAMES: Piwakawaka, pied fantail, black fantail. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,280)

Chatham Island flax¶

n.

RICHARDS Linum monogonum ... The Chatham Island flax is the same as that in New Zealand except the white blossom is here flaked with blue ... Chatham Island Flax. NAU, RAHUIA. (1952,Chatham Islands,32)

n.

An Invercargill correspondent.. has sent blooms of the Chatham Island geranium, which were grown in a Dunedin garden. (Jan 19, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)
