Chatham Island oystercatcher¶

n. (Environment)

The endangered Chatham Island oystercatcher is finding it easier to reproduce thanks to intensive predator control and the replacement of marram grass with native species. (May 2004,Footnotes,No. 21/6)

FALLA et al. CHATHAM ISLAND OYSTERCATCHER Haemotopus chathamensis (1966,Birds of New Zealand,120)

  1. Haemotopus chathamensis Hartert, 1927 Chatham Island Oystercatcher ... (now rare). (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,44,1980 ed.)

HOLMES CHATHAM ISLAND OYSTERCATCHER, Haemotopus chathamensis ... is not found in abundance. (1984,Chatham Islands,99)

Chatham Island parakeet¶

n.

RICHARDS Cyanoramphus ... Forbesi. The Chatham Island parrakeet is very like the yellow-fronted parrakeet of New Zealand ... (1952,Chatham Islands,77)

Chatham Island petrel¶

n. [also known as Chatham petrel]

Chatham Island Petrel Pterodroma axillaris (SALVIN, 1893) ... OTHER NAME: Ranguru ... Fewer than 20 specimens of this rare petrel have been banded. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,81)

[45.1 Pterodroma axillaris] (Salvin, 1893) Chatham Island Petrel (Ranguru) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,24,1980 ed.)

FALLA et al. CHATHAM ISLAND PETREL Pterodroma axillaris Maori name: Ranguru. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,52)

HOLMES It has no land mammals and ... has retained its original population of Shore Plover, Chatham Islands Petrel and insular sub-species of Antarctic Snipe. Ibid. 99 CHATHAM ISLAND PETREL, Pterodroma axillaris - breed on South-east Island ... (1984,Chatham Islands,60)

The most critically endangered species on the island is the Chatham petrel, Pterodroma axillaris. Ibid. 88 The greatest enemy of the Chatham petrel is not a predator but a competitor, the broad-billed prion (Pachyptila vittata). (Jun 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 52/86)

Pitt Island school children welcomed the 49 Chatham Island petrel chicks which arrived from South East Island on 1 May (May 2003,Footnotes,No. 19/5)

The most critically endangered species on the island is the Chatham petrel, Pterodroma axillaris. Rangatira is the only place in the world where it still breeds... Chatham petrels, which nest only on tiny Rangatira Island, are one of our rarest seabirds, numbering around 100 breeding pairs. (Aug 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 52/86)

Forty-seven Chatham petrel chicks were transferred from Rangatira (South East Island) to the safety of the predator fenced Sweetwater covenant in South Chatham ... (Jun 2008,Footnotes,10)

Chatham Island pigeon¶

n. (Environment) [also Chatham Islands pigeon] (See parea)

The collection brought by Mr Forbes from the Chatham Islands consists chiefly of fossil bones of birds, but there are also three skulls of whales and some plants and bird skins, including two specimens of the Chatham Island pigeon, described last year by Mr. Rothschild in the proceedings of the Zoological Society. (Jul 12, 1892,Star, The,3)

Hemiphaga chathamensis Roths. Chatham Islands Pigeon. I have no recent news of this species. A natural history survey of the Chatham Islands is an urgent necessity. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/82) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

RICHARDS Hemi-phaga ... chathamensis ... Chatham Island Pigeon. KUKU. (1952,Checkmate To Your King,77)

211.b. Hemiphaga novaeseelandiae chathamensis (Rothschild, 1891) Chatham Island Pigeon (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,57,1980 ed.)

RICHARDS CHATHAM ISLAND PIGEON, Hemiphaga novaeseelandiae chathamensis - is confined to the broadleafed forest remnants on the southern half of Chatham Island. (1984,Chatham Islands,97)

New Zealand Pigeon Hemiphaga novaeseelandiae GMELIN, 1789) ... [239] Chatham Island Pigeon H.n. chathamensis (ROTHSCHILD, 1891) OTHER NAMES: Kereru, kuku, kukupa. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,238)

One of New Zealand's most endangered birds, the Chatham Islands pigeon, or parea, may be making a quiet recovery. (Oct 27, 1992,Evening Post,19)

Chatham Island rail¶

n. [also Chatham Islands rail] (See also little Chatham Islands rail,Dieffenbach's rail)

A skeleton of the extinct Chatham Island rail (Diaphorapertyx [sic] hawkinsi) has been placed in the New Zealand room at the Christchurch Museum, together with the skeletons of the extinct crow, coot, and swan from the same islands. (Aug 16, 1905,Otago Witness,4)

But the distribution of this Chatham Island rail - if it should yet turn out to be a species identical with the Mauritian - is still more extraordinary, for we have a sea as wide as all but half the circumference of the globle [sic] lying between the two regions. (Apr 1, 1892,Hawke's Bay Herald,2)

Nesolimnas dieffenbachii Gray. Chatham Islands Rail. This is said to have been exterminated more than sixty-five years ago. Undoubtedly the greatest enemy of these three rails, two of which represent endemic general, was the collector. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/76) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

WILLIAMS Matirakahu, n. Cabalus modestus, the Chatham Island rail (extinct). (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,194)

  1. Rallus modestus Hutton, 1872 Chatham Island rail ... extinct since about 1900. (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,42,1980 ed.)

Chatham Island red-crowned parakeet¶

n.

22.c. Cyanoramphus novaezelandiae chathamensis Oliver, 1930 Chatham Island Red-crowned Parakeet (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,59,1980 ed.)

Chatham Island robin¶

n. (See also black robin)

Dr. Cockayne has received a letter from Mr G. Allport, Secretary to the Marine Department, stating that the Colonial Secretary has given permission to take ten of each of the following birds from the islands to be placed on Kapiti Island : .. the Chatham Islands robin, and the Auckland Island ducks. (Nov 2, 1907,Taranaki Herald,5)

Nesomiro traversi Buller. Chatham Islands Robin. Buller (1895) stated, on the authority of Hawkins, that this bird was extinct. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/88)

BULLER MIRO TRAVERSI. (CHATHAM-ISLAND ROBIN.) ... This species was discovered by Mr. Henry Travers during an exploratory visit to the Chatham Islands in 1871. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,123,1888 2nd edn 1/38 ed.)

Miro traversi, Buller. I exhibit ... a pair of so-called Chatham Island Robin, [sic] obtained at the Snares ... (1891,TrNZI,23/37) [NOTES: (Buller)]

FALLA et al. CHATHAM ISLAND ROBIN Petroica traversi (1966,Birds of New Zealand,204)

Black Robin Petroica traversi (BULLER, 1872) The black robin is one of the rarest birds in the world. ... OTHER NAME: Chatham Island robin. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,281)

Chatham Island shag¶

n. (Environment)

He has shipped some live Chatham Island shags to England by the s.s. Aorangi, and had previously landed in England alive five kiwis out of 13. (Nov 6, 1890,Otago Witness,29)

BULLER PHALACROCORAX FEATHERSTONI. (CHATHAM-ISLAND SHAG.) (1873,Birds of New Zealand,338,1888 2nd edn 2/166 ed.)

Stictocarbo featherstoni Buller, Chatham Islands Shag. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/75) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

RICHARDS P[halacrocorax] Featherstoni ... Chatham Island Shag. (1952,Chatham Islands,89)

FALLA et al. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,69)

83.c. Leucocarbo carunculatus onslowi Forbes 1893 Chatham Island Shag (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,32,1980 ed.)

HOLMES CHATHAM ISLAND SHAG, Phalacrocorax onslowi - restricted entirely to Chatham Island. (1984,Chatham Islands,100)

Chatham Island Shag Leucocarbo onslowi Forbes, 1893 ... The Chatham Island shag shares its breding islands with both the Pitt Island shag and the great cormorant. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,121)

Chatham Island snipe¶

n.

FALLA et al. CHATHAM ISLAND SNIPE Coenocorypha pusilla (1966,Birds of New Zealand,139)

HOLMES CHATHAM ISLAND SNIPE, Coenocorypha pusilla - survives on South-east Island and the Star Keys. (1984,Chatham Islands,99)

RICHARDS Gallinago ... pusilla ... Chatham Island Snipe. (1952,Chatham Islands,80)

172.b. Coenocorypha aucklandica pusilla (Buller, 1869) Chatham Island Snipe (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,49,1980 ed.)

.. 20 Chatham Island snipe from Rangatira went into the predator-fenced Ellen Elizabeth Preece covenant in Pitt Island ... (Jun 2008,Footnotes,10)

Chatham Island swan¶

n.

[Caption] Philip Millener with bones from an extinct Chatham Island swan Cycrnus sumneriensis. (Mar 18, 1993,Contact (Wgtn),1)

Chatham Island taiko¶

n. Pterodroma magentae ; OTHER NAMES: Magenta petrel; tchaik of the Moriori. (See taiko,tchiak)

Eight Chatham Island Taiko chicks fledged this season, five of them from artificial burrows installed to protect against flooding and pig damage. (Jun 23, 2005,Footnotes,11)

Taiko (the Maori adaption of the Moriori name for the magenta petrel) was unknown to ornithologists until 1867, when it made a brief appearance. Scientists on board the Italian research vessel Magenta, sailing in the South Pacific, became hosts to an unusual sea bird. (2003,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.heritage-expeditions.com/The%20Sub%20Antarctic%20Islands/Important%20Background%20Information/Chatham%20Islandsaccessed 12/01 2006. Site dated 2003.]

[She] was tempted by a friend to help track the Chatham Island taiko, a sea bird thnought to be extinct before being rediscovered in 1978. (May 2004,Footnotes,No. 21/15)

A new generation of Chatham Island taiko is emerging among the 11 chicks that hatched this season - four more than last year's record crop of seven. (May 2003,Footnotes,No. 19/5)

40. Pterodroma magentae (Giglioli and Salvadori, 1868) Chatham Island Taiko [Formerly breeding commonly at Chathams, now very rare...] (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,23,1980 ed.)

HOLMES CHATHAM ISLAND TAIKO Pterodroma magentae (Magenta Petrel) - remains one of the rarest birds in the world too. (1984,Chatham Islands,97)

Chatham Island Taiko Pterodroma magentae (GIGLIOLI & SALVADORI, 1868) ... However, this extremely rare bird is hardly ever seen. ... OTHER NAMES: Magenta petrel, tchaik of the Moriori. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,78)

It's all part of a mammoth effort to save one of the world's most endangered seabirds - the Chatham Islands taiko... On the night of New Year's Day, 1978, the first two birds were caught by the lights, captured and confirmed as the Chatham Islands taiko. (Jan 17, 2004,Dominion Post,E12)

NZ Post is doing its bit for the preservation of the little known Chatham Island's taiko. The world's rarest seabird is getting its own commemorative coin. (Jan 14, 2004,Capital Times,6)

Among a listed 50 threatened species or sub-species, Ms Lee noted as most threatened, "critically endangered", the New Zealand fairy tern - of which only 30 are believed to survive, breeding only in Northland - and the Chatham Islands taiko, of which fewer than 150 might be left. (Jan 6, 2001,Dominion,9)

Chatham Island thistle¶

n. Embergeria grandifolia

Another plant from the same locality is Souchus grandifolius, or Chatham Island thistle. (Mar 1, 1918,Evening Post,2)

RICHARDS Sonchus ... grandifolius ... Chatham Island Thistle. (1952,Chatham Islands,49)

Chatham Island tit¶

n. [Chatham Island tit]

MIRO TRAVERSI, Buller. - Chatham Island Tit. (1875,TrNZI,7/205) [NOTES: (Buller Ornitology)]

257.c. Petroica macrocephala chathamensis Fleming, 1950 Chatham Island Tit (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,68,1980 ed.)

Tit Petroica macrocephala (GMELIN, 1789) .... Chatham Island Tit P.m. chathamensis FLEMING, 1950. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,284)

The story of the black robin's rescue from a deteriorating habitat on Little Mangere and of its establishment on Mangere Island in 1976 is famous. The cross-fostering techniques using Chatham Island warblers on Mangere and Chatham Island tits on South East Island are experiments that have excited the conservation world. (Apr 12, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49)

Chatham Island tree-daisy¶

n. -

I expected to find both of the Chatham Island tree daisies, Olearia chathamica and O. semidentata, growing in homestead gardens. (Aug 1991,NZ Gardener,29)

Chatham Island truck¶

n. (See cf. jogger)

HOLMES Only four vehicles were in use on the island up until this time but by 1952 over 100 were in use. [59] Before the coming of motorised transport, the mode of transportation was the `Chatham Island Truck' (Konake), a wooden flat-decked horse or bullock-drawn vehicle, with iron or wooden wheels at the back and sledge runners on the front. (1984,Chatham Islands,58) [NOTES: 1984 Holmes Chatham Islands 58-59 1948]

Chatham Island tui¶

n. (Environment) [ORIGIN: Maori]

266.b. Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae chathamensis Hartet, 1928 Chatham Island Tui (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,70,1980 ed.)

(1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,291)

Chatham Island warbler¶

n.

  1. Gerygone albofrontata, Gray. Chatahm Island warbler. - Larger than the preceding species [G. flaviventris, grey warbler], distinguished also by its song; .. (1884,NZ Journal of Science,285) [NOTES: (T.H.Potts)]

BULLER GERYGONE ALBOFRONTATA. (CHATHAM-ISLAND WARBLER.) (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/49)

Hapolorhynchus albofrontatus Gray. Chatham Island Warbler. Buller (1905) wrote that this beautiful and very distinct form was `on e the borderland of extinction if not already gone.' (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/90) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

Pseudogerygone ... albafrontata ... it is a good deal larger than the New Zealand grey warbler. ... [71] Chatham Is. Warbler. RIRO-RIRO. (1952,Chatham Islands,70)

FALLA et al. CHATHAM ISLAND WARBLER Gerygone albofrontata Local name: Woodpecker. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,212)

  1. Gerygone albofrontata Gray, 1844 Chatham Island Warbler (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,67,1980 ed.)

Chatham Island Warbler Gerygone albofrontata GRAY, 1844 ... The Chatham Island warbler has not adapted to human settlement and lives only in native bush. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,279)

Chatham Island Warbler Gerygone albofrontata GRAY, 1844 ... The Chatham Island warbler has not adapted to human settlement and lives only in native bush. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,279)

The story of the black robin's rescue from a deteriorating habitat on Little Mangere and of its establishment on Mangere Island in 1976 is famous. The cross-fostering techniques using Chatham Island warblers on Mangere and Chatham Island tits on South East Island are experiments that have excited the conservation world. (Apr 12, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49)

The shining cuckoo is known to the islanders as "summer-bird," and is well-known, and the long-tailed cuckoo is very infrequently seen. The shining species parasitises the nest of the Chatham Island warbler. (May 22, 1926,Evening Post,13)

Although the Chatham Island warbler is the commonest endemic land bird on the group, it is not evenly distributed and is not nearly so abundant in the changed conditions in settled country as is its New Zeaeland [sic] representative. (Apr 22, 1939,Evening Post,17)

Chatham Island wren¶

n.

A little later the Chatham Island wren made her appearance - for a wren quite a fine and comparatively large bird. (Jul 12, 1924,Otago Witness,7)

Chatham Island yellow-crowned parakeet¶

n.

222.b. Cyanoramphus auriceps forbesi Rothschild, 1893 Chatham Island Yellow-crowned parakeet (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,59,1980 ed.)

Yellow-crowned Parakeet Cyanoramphus auriceps (KUHL, 1820) ... Chatham Island Yellow-crowned Parakeet C.a.forbesi ROTHSCHILD, 1893. OTHER NAMES: Kakariki, Forbes' parakeet. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,251)

Chatham Island(s) fernbird¶

n.

BULLER SPHENOEACUS RUFESCENS. (CHATHAM-ISLAND FERN-BIRD.) ... This well-marked species is confined to the Chatham Islands, where it was first discovered, in 1868 ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,131,[1888 2nd edn 1/62] ed.)

Bowdleria rufescens Buller, Chatham Islands Fern-bird. Buller (1895), writing on the authority of his collector, Hawkins, stated that this species had been exterminated by wild cats and by the firing of low vegetation. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/92)

RICHARDS Spheneacus ... rufescens ... Chatham Island Fern Bird. MATATA. (1952,Chatham Islands,72)

(Buller) Sphenaeacus rufescens, Buller. (The Chatham Island Fernbird.) (1893,TrNZI,25/58)

250.e. Bowdleria punctata rufescens (Buller, 1869) Chatham Island fernbird (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,66,1980 ed.)

Fernbird Bowdleria punctata (QUOY & GAIMARD, 1830) ... North Island Fernbird B.p. vealeae KEMP, 1912. South Island Fernbird B.p. punctata (QUOY & GAIMARD, 1830) ... Codfish Island Fernbird B.p. wilsoni STEAD, 1936. Stewart Island fernbird B.p. stewartiana OLIVER, 1930. Snares fernbird B.p. caudata (BULLER, 1894). EXTINCT Chatham Island Fernbird B.p. rufescens (BULLER, 1869). OTHER NAMES: Swamp thrush, grass bird, matata. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,274)

Chatham Island(s) lily¶

n. The strikingly large Chatham Island native forget-me-not when cultivated in gardens; also called giant forget-me-not, and formerly Macquarie cabbage. Myosotidium nobile (hortensia) [also Chatham lily]

VON MUELLER Myosotidium nobile (hortensia) Chatham-Islands lily (1864,Vegetation of the Chatham Islands)

Myosotidium nobile (hortensia) Chatham Island lily (1882,TrNZI,14 :)

(And) Myosotidium nobile (hortensia) (1885,NZ Country Journal,Vol I 1877-XXII 1898)

MATTHEWS ... (And) (1890,Descriptive & Priced List)

THOMSON ... (And) (1906,Introductory Classbook of Botany)

CHEESEMAN (And) Myosotidium nobile (hortensia) Chatham Islands lily (1906,NZ Flora)

LAING & BLACKWELL The plant [ Myosotidium hortensia (previously M. nobile)] is much cultivated in gardens in New Zealand, and is then known as the Chatham Island Lily. (1907,Plants of NZ,348,1940, p. 370 ed.)

COCKAYNE The most famous of all the Chatham Island plants is the giant forget-me-not ( Myosotidium nobile ) ..., frequently called by the absurd name of Chatham Island lily, or, what is worse, Macquarie cabbage! (1910,NZ Plants,123)

NAIRN & SON (1912,Catalogue (Nairn & Son)) [NOTES: (And)]

(And) Myosotidium nobile (hortensia) (1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue)

COCKAYNE (And) Myosotidium nobile (hortensia) (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The)

LAING & BLACKWELL Myosotidium hortensia (The Chatham Island Lily). ... Leaves thick and shining, bright green. Flowers in dense head, 2 in.-5 in. across. ... azure blue, with purple eye. ... Chathams Islands only. (1940,Plants of NZ,368)

COCKAYNE (1919,NZ Plants) [NOTES: (And)]

MATTHEWS (1943,NZ Gardening Dictionary, The,124,3rd ed. ed.)

Chatham islands(?) lily, kopakopa, kopukapuka Myosotidium hortensia (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

The Chatham lily ; ... it has pink and blue flowers in the the spring. It used to cover the islands. Now it is rare. (Jun 1984,Landfall,150/177) [NOTES: (Kidman `Going to the Chathams')]

RUCHARDS Myosotidium ... nobile ... The Chatham Island Lily or Giant Forget-me-not, as it is now more suitably called, is a huge plant ... Giant Forget-me-not. KO-PUKA-PUKA. (1952,Chatham Islands,41)

Chatham Islands in the early days called it their lily, and the Chatham Island lily it will be to the end of the chapter. (Feb 16, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

Now the Chatham Island lily is thought to be entirely gone. (Feb 5, 1947,NZ Observer,6)

Chatham Island/s forget-me-not¶

n. (Environment) an indigenous flowering plant Myosotidium hortensia , found principally in the Chatham Islands.

TAYLOR The forget-me-not, Kopa-kopa Myosotis, with its fine bunches of flowers and large glossy leaves, is a native of these [Chatham] isles. (1868,Past and Present of NZ,225)

COCKAYNE Fig. 1- The Chatham Island Forget-me-not (Myosotidium nobile), growing near sea in north of Chatham Island. (Myosotidium nobile) with leaves as large as those of a rhubarb. (1910,NZ Plants,2)

HUNT It has in the Mahoe (Melicytus ramiflorus) a violet which is a tree .. and a forget-me-not. (1951,Confessions,136)

MOORE & IRWIN MYOSOTIDIUM HORTENSIA, Chatham Island forget-me-not. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,168)

Joyce Holmes hasn't forgotten to grow the beautiful Chatham Island forget-me-not (Myosotidium hortensia) in her garden. (Aug 1991,NZ Gardener,29)

Chatham Islands Forget-me-not (Myosotidium hortensia) - Details of the culture of this plant were given in these columns some weeks ago. (Nov 11, 1993,Evening Post,14)

To contrast the sharp lines of the flaxes and grasses, nothing can match the lush, glossy curvaceousness of Myosotidium hortensia, the Chatham Islands Forget-me-not. (Sep 15, 2001,Dominion Weekend Magazine,C10)

Unfortunately, our soil can turn very quickly from wet to concrete-dry, which is why my Chatham Island forget-me-nots (Myosotidium hortensia) grow well in one place but not another. (Oct 20, 2002,Sunday Star Times,F7)

But I cover my Chatham Island forget-me-nots with frost cloth in winter and I also cover our young rewarewa tree. (Aug 8, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),47)

But a change to farming cattle instead of sheep in the south-east appears to be benefiting the Chatham Island forget-me-not (Myosotidium hortensia) which has improved since the last survey. (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 7)

The most impressive of them [Chatham Islands plants] such as .. and the Chatham Islands' forget-me-not have probably never occurred on the mainland. (Dec 2006,Growing Today,31)

Chatham Islander¶

n. (specifically) a Moriori

SKINNER ... the greater hue of the Chatham Islanders may be in great measure attributed to their greater exposure and still greater uncleanliness. (1923,Morioris of the Chatham Islands, The,35) [NOTES: 1841 E.Dieffenbach Account of the Chatham Islands in 1841 Royal Geog. Soc. Journal II/195 in 1923 Skinner Morioris of the Chatham Islands 35]

TREGEAR The Moriori lived in small unfortified villages, the houses of which were thatched with long grass and rushes. ... The Chatham Islanders were clever in making their sea-craft from the most unpromising materials. (1904,Maori Race, The,577)

n. a person born or resident in the Chatham Islands

Hood, Shand, Naera and three Maories and a white girl servant for some Chatham Islander. (Jun 23, 1879,Chudleigh Diary,281,1950 ed.)

Went to the Chief Postmaster ... and stated that the Chatham Islanders ... had gone too far to withdraw from the Canterbury Steamship Coy. ... (Mar 12, 1906,Chudleigh Diary,432,1950 ed.)

SANSOM Chatham Islanders had settled at Port Adventure and also people from Enderby's Auckland Island settlement ... (1982,In the Grip of an Island,140)

LANGDALE-HUNT He did not know the Chatham Islanders who always liked to get their mail even if it was only bills ... (1985,Last Entail Male,74)

Waitangi, May 22. - Chatham Islanders today warned the Government of `Dire consequences' for the economy if the tough recommendations of a departmental review team on subsidies were implemented. (May 23, 1986,Evening Post,2)

He has spoken with many of the present-day Chatham Islanders and to Moriori descendants in New Zealand. (Nov 13, 1989,Evening Post,110)

The Chatham Islanders are a race of their own. Some can claim descent from the Moriori, some from the Maori, some from the original German missionaries, and even from Spanish whalers, but, today, they have become a new race with a pleasing accent to their speech, not altogether Maori, but typically local. (1952,Te Ao Hou,2: 36) [NOTES: Spring 1952 number]

Chatham Islands skink¶

n. The only lizard to live in the Chatham Islands where it is numerous; appearance can be striped, speckled, or uniform colour. [Oligosoma nigriplantare nigriplantare aka Chathams skink.]

The lizards observed were divided into two categories (bronze and green) onthe basis of their dorsal colouration (Fig. 2) as it has been suggested that differences incolouration and patterning in Chatham Island skinks may indicate that there is morethan one species on Rangatira Island (M. Bell pers. comm.). (Apr 1997,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://researcharchive.lincoln.ac.nz/dspace/bitstream/10182/713/1/wmr_12.pdf]

The Chatham Islands skink, formerly recognised as the subspeciesOligosoma nigriplantare nigriplantare can now formally be described as a separatespecies on the basis of our molecular data (mitochondrial DNA: ND2 and ND4,1323bp). (2006,Internet - see Notes,30) [NOTES: http://www.allanwilsoncentre.ac.nz/documents/annualReports/Annual%20Report%202006.pdf Allan Wilson Centre for Molecular Ecology and Evolution - Annual Report 2006]

Liggins, Chapple, Daugherty We examine the origin and post-colonization evolution of the Chatham Islands skink, Oligosoma nigriplantare nigriplantare, the sole reptile species occurring on the archipelago. We sampled O. n. nigriplantare from across nine islands within the Chatham Islands group, and representative samples from across the range of its closest relative, the New Zealand mainland common skink (Oligosoma nigriplantare polychroma). (May 2008,Internet - see Notes,3290) [NOTES: http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/119879332/abstract?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0Origin and post-colonization evolution of the Chatham Islands skink (Oligosoma nigriplantare nigriplantare)LIBBY LIGGINS, DAVID G. CHAPPLE, CHARLES H. DAUGHERTY and PETER A. RITCHIE]

Chatham lancewood¶

n. Pseudopanax chathamicum.

Chatham Plateau¶

n.

RV Tangaroa spearheaded the first of the Government's Ocean Survey 20/20 .. projects last month with the first of three voyages to the Chatham Rise and the Chatham Plateau. (Sep 2006,Climate Update, The (NIWA),Coasts and Oceans)

Chatham Rise¶

n.

RV Tangaroa spearheaded the first of the Government's Ocean Survey 20/20 .. projects last month with the first of three voyages to the Chatham Rise and the Chatham Plateau .. This year's project is a seafloor habitat and biodiversity comparison between the Chatham Rise and Challenger Plateau. (Sep 2006,Climate Update, The (NIWA),Coasts and Oceans)

chattels security¶

n. a mortgage of other form of charge over personal property (Chattels Transfer Act 1924). [Jim Cameron writes: More formally known as instrument by way of security. The corresponding English term is (conditional)bill of sale, which I think is little if at all used in NZ.]

chatting minister¶

n. ['conversation' sic in citation??]

The new year got off to a great start vocabulary-wise when the minister of conversation (or the "chatting minister" for those keener on informal titles), Chris Carter, introduced us to the joys of "Pepper Potting ". (Jan 22, 2006,Sunday Star Times,A11)

chatty¶

n. [as a name not recorded in NZ outside Partridge and Baker: ?confined to WW1 soldiers: the connection with kutu not convincing.]

PARTRIDGE Chati. A louse; New Zealanders': 20C. Ex chat; prob. by Maori influence: see koota. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,142)

BAKER Among ... terms originated in the first Great War (are) ... chatty or chati, a louse (the versions koota and kooti from the Maori kutu, a louse, had been in use much earlier). (1941,NZ Slang,50)

PARTRIDGE Chatty, n - 5. A louse: New Zealand: since ca1915. B1941. See chat, n, 7, and esp. chati (p. 142) (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1012)

chaw¶

n. often pl.; a lolly, a chew. [1951 14 M 10 Wellington H.S. 22A CHAWS -->1951 14 M 14 St Bede's, Chch 22A CHAWS [M4] -->1953 14 M A17 Thames DHS 22A CHAW -->1960 17C M B6 St Bede's, Chch 22A CHAWS -->1960 17C F B8 Wanganui Girls C.I 22A CHAWS]

BALLANTYNE He could buy things like chaws and pies out of his own earnings. Ibid.. 145 Barry held out a bag of chaws. (1948,Cunninghams, The,97,1976 ed.)

SLATTER (1968,Pagan Game, The,67) [NOTES: See bung @n.]

ChCh¶

n. Christchurch [ORIGIN: abbreviation, ca1920; a spoken form is occas. used: 'chuh chuh' - citations below have renderings of other pronunciations]

"I was still not prepared for the mobs of reporters and television crews that were waiting for my arrival in Cheech", she said. (Jan 28, 2001,Sunday Star Times,A2)

D'ARCY CRESSWELL What is the glyph for Chch? Something, surely, indicative of a stuck-up backwardness. (Jun 3, 1934,Letters,89,1971 ed.)

FAIRBURN I suppose the ignorantzia of Chch is full of little jealousies, same as in Auckland. (Sep 11, 1935,Letters,97,1981 ed.)

FIARBURN I haven't really any phobia as far as Chch goes. (May 1947,Letters) [NOTES: 1947 May 14 Fairburn (to Brasch) in 1981 Letters (ed Edmond) 159]

WINKS New Zealanders show due respect for the names of their cities. Words like Paraparaumu ... do get horribly mangled, and dignified Christchurch sounds like a steam engine - CHCH - but one never hears of Auck, Gizzy, or Ham. (1954,These New Zealanders,52,1954 ed.)

RIVES In the evening I surrounded Ch.ch. by walking around it. (Mar 7, 1975,Jottings on the Spot,10)

HULME The big one that has come to some unholy truce with good ol' CHCH pollution ... (1986,Te Kaihau,21)

I like to think of myself in my Chich Chich cubbyhole. (Oct 26, 2001,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Al Morrison talking to Kim Hill from Christchurch]

HENDERSON Then, with an effort, you grope around and open the cardboard box you were given in Che-Chee (Christchurch) containing tucker... Wish the Albatross book wasn't back in Chee-Chee. Ibid. 52 You feel excited, rub gloves together, scrape a foot backwards and forwards experimentally in the crisp, dry-looking snow covering the ice and never a thought for Chee-Chee in the morning. (1962,One Foot at the Pole,48)

CHE¶

abbr. [ORIGIN: acronym, pronounced 'chee', plural 'cheese']

The new chief executive officer (CEO) of a Crown Health Enterprise (CHE) enthused over the staff he was to lead... CHEs whose CEOs are insensitive to the culture clash will end up with severe industrial disputes. (Oct 2, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),64)

[Hdg] Let them eat CHEs cake... One medical staffer.. wondered why she was getting cake when some other CHEs beneficiaries will be getting up to $750 a day. (Dec 4, 1992,Dominion,8)

There she [sc. Jenny Shipley] sat, flanked by her new Nat pack of English, Sowry,, Smith and Ryall, saying "cheese" (or in English's case, "CHEs") for the massed cameras, looing for all the world like Brown Owl let loose in the Cub den. (Feb 13, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),2)

Sick of CHES? Nothing quite conveys the rise and fall of the health reforms like those nostalgia-drenched acronyms CHE and RHA, now consigned to history's dustbins. (Mar 27, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

There she sat, flanked by her new Nat Pack of English, Sowry, Smith and Ryall, saying "cheese"(or in English's case, "CHEs") for the massed cameras, looking for all the world like Brown Owl let loose in the Cub den. (Feb 13, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),2)

SICK OF CHES? Nothing quite conveys the rise and fall of the health reforms like those already nostalgia-drenched acronyms CHE and RHA, now confined to history's dustbin. (Mar 27, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

Deficit funding, he says, should be phased out in favour of sustainable, efficient pricing and that top-up money instead given to the RHAs to distribute to the most efficient CHEs. (Dec 21, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

After all, if you want to make [the public] cry, say CHEs! (Mar 12, 1993,Evening Post,4)

It is widely agreed among health professionals, CHE managers and members of boards of directors of CHEs that the present system of funding and administering the health system is fraught with serious problems... (May 14, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

[Hdg] 'Politics' behind creation of competing CHEs... We think it can be made line-ball, but that depends on each CHE Board. (Dec 7, 1992,Evening Post,17)

With due respect to the current TV dairy products commercial, I wonder if we would witness the same reaction if hospital staff employed at the work face were asked to "Say CHE." (Dec 10, 1992,Evening Post,6)

che wop¶

phr. [teenage slang]

[Hdg] The bomb sites : Where teens hang out... Ingrid Goodwin took a ride through Wellington's teen territory and asked what they really wanted - what's the bomb and what's not all that. Che wop... Che wop b'o / Che bro - All purpose term for "hello" or "I agree" (Sep 23, 1998,Capital Times,5)

CHEAC¶

('chee-ak) abbr. Crown Health Enterprise Advisory Committee [ORIGIN: acronym]

He believed the Crown Health Enterprise Advisory Committee had told the Government that converting the Wellington Area Health Board into one CHE was the best option... I believe the CHEACs were told that in some areas they could not have only one CHE. (Dec 7, 1992,Evening Post,17)

cheap as chips¶

phr. very cheap

"This record is only $14.95". "Cheap as chips, and shouldn't be treated as such". (Apr 30, 2004,Radio NZ / National Radio)

cheap as cho¶

phr.

BEATTIE Mr Ferens was a Methodist, and so was my father, and they were `as cheep as cho', as the old saying went, so I took an interest in the sale and noticed that the biggest price of the day was ... for a two-year-old Hereford beast. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,151) [NOTES: The context is disputing WHS Roberts's claim about the first sale in Hampden; but this does not seem to have any bearing on the usage: nf EDD cheep, cho(w). =?]

cheap keep¶

1 n. (Rural) a period between weaning and preparation for tupping.

STEVENS Flushing simply means supplying the ewes with better feed than they have subsisted on during the period of 'cheap keep.' (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,34)

STEVENS This period between weaning and preparation for tupping is generally referred to by shepherds as 'cheap keep', which means just what it implies - that the ewes should receive just enough to keep them in store condition. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,32)

STEVENS The commencement of the flushing period is the beginning of the new flock year, and brings with it the need for a tightening of control following the slack 'cheap keep' period. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,35)

cheats¶

n.

SUTTON-SMITH Here are some [marble] terms from Taranaki around 1880-1890: firsts, lay-up, stakes, tips, sticking-taw, nothings, anythings, fade-it, knuckledown stiff, dubs, finking [sic, ?funking], sips, spanning, placing; and from Dunedin School in 1949: knee high, manyies, tracks, screws, nuts, sleets, kills, forces, dig, dubs, cheats. (1981,History of Children's Play,269)

check¶

n. [?Check further NZ usage??]

HENDERSON CHECK: Short reins leading from main reins to horse's bridle-bit. (1961,Friends in Chains,185) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 185]

CRUMP In a little while I worked out that checks are the leads off the reins that go from the outside of one lead horse to the inside of the other lead horse's bit, so that both of them steer at the same time. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,39)

v. to deposit property, especially luggage, for transport.

HILLIARD She... joined the throng on the platform, joined a long and irritable queue to get her two checked suitcases. (1960,Maori Girl,70)

KING There was too the disappointment that she, the daughter of a railway family, misunderstood the French arrangements for checked bags. (2000,Wrestling with the Angel,155)

check-pen¶

n. a special pen for checking sheep in a sheepyards

A further lot of sheep [can be] placed in the check-pen. (Sep 20, 1922,NZ Journal of Agriculture,152) [NOTES: [OED2]]

In larger sets of yards one or more of these drafting pens communicate, via a gate, with the check pen(s): These vary in number corresponding with the number of drafting pens. Since their purpose is to hold sheep while they are being checked over for mistakes in drafting and for treatment, these pens must be small. (Jul 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,7)

HUTCHINSON ... the manager [was] at race and check-pen (1947,At Omatua's Fireside,29)

BOWEN This drafting race divides sheep into the separate lots required, and these are then handled by the drafting pens, check pens, and holding yards, which should correspond in size to the receiving yards. (1955,Wool Away!,120)

1 n. (Rural) a small yard in a set of sheep-yards where sheep are held and examined for mistakes in drafting, or for inspection or treatment.

GUTHRIE-SMITH In the check-pens minor errors in drafting were rectified. (1921,Tutira,158)

LOUGHNAN check-pen: pen in which the drafting is checked for any mistakes. [check pen] (1981,Loughnan Glossary,18)

In larger sets of yards one or more if these drafting pens communicate via a gate, with the check pen(s)..their purpose is to hold the sheep while they are being checked over for mistakes in drafting and treatment. (Jul 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,7)

BOWEN This drafting race divides sheep into the separate lots required, and these are then handled by the drafting pens, check pens and holding yards, which should correspond in size to the receiving yards. (1955,Wool Away!,120)

RIDDOLLS Check pens may also be used for such jobs as raddling and dagging. In large yards the sheep will pass from the check pens into the holding yards. (1958,Farm Engineering,333)

check-shirt bird¶

n. (?female) shining cuckoo.

HARPER On the way down [the Cook River from Tony's Rock] we saw a cuckoo, and his usual companion the check-shirt' bird. ... The former is the Maori koe-koea (<i>Eudynamys taitensis</i>), and like his English namesake, he makes use of other birds' nests. Thecheck-shirt' follows him in his migrations, and is often seen with him in the lower hills. (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,147)

PASCOE The Check Shirt or Spirit Bird ... The name check shirt is local and was given on account of its breast being marked with black and white like Scotch tweed shirts. (1957,Mr Explorer Douglas,273) [NOTES: c1899 Douglas Birds South Westland in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 273-274]

checkpoint¶

n. a roadside place where Ministry of Transport officers stops cars and check drivers for alcohol consumption Also checkpointing,the stopping of cars for alcohol testing of drivers

WELLINGTON hotels have noticed significant changes in patrons' drinking habits since the Ministry of Transport's drink-driving blitz started two weekends ago. One city hotel says orange juice and other non-alcoholic drinks have been nicknamed `checkpoint specials' by patrons. (Dec 13, 1983,Dominion,3)

Hon Ann Hercus Burglars have been found by checkpointing. (Dec 5, 1986,TV1) [NOTES: News]

cheek¶

v. hide contraband by holding it between the cheeks of one's bottom

To charge something is to insert contraband into one's rectum to hide and transport it, as opposed to cheeking, where contraband is not actually inserted, yet is held between the cheeks of one's bottom. (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

cheek of Ned Kelly¶

phr.

HILLIARD Pretty cheeky, they are,' he told the winchman.Got the cheek of Ned Kelly, some of them.' (1963,Piece of Land, A,99)

cheeking¶

n. cutting the skin off an animal's cheeks [ca1946 Ngauranga]

COLIN GORDON Cheeking: Cutting skin off right and left cheeks and leaving it hanging. (May 17, 1951,Personal Communication) [NOTES: ca1951 May 17 Feilding Freezing Works terms p.c. Colin Gordon]

cheeks¶

n. freezing-worker

HENDERSON CHEEKS (Rotates with shoulder men) (1975,Log of a Superfluous Son, The,42)

cheeky darkie¶

phr. pejorative term first used by Paul Holmes of UN Head, Kofi Annan

...he saw the censoring as another attack on Ms Ah Hoi whom others saw as a "cheeky darkie". (Apr 22, 2004,Dominion Post,A7)

The word "cheeky" quite obviously refers to the plump part of a person's face, and the word "darkie" in our dictionary alludes to people of profound intellectual depth... Cheeky, of course, is what his rounded face is; little is what his height is; and bugger, as we know, is a word coined by an advertising agency meaning "a serendipitous accident". It doesn't mean at all what is used to mean - and that's official. (May 2, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C8)

One Sky Kiwi reader observed cynically that "just joking" is the standard media defence against accusations of racism - "cheeky darkie" anyone? (May 28, 2006,Sunday Star Times,C9)

Still, there are plenty of cultural references to be going on with, from Erebus to Holmes ("cheeky darkie" never gets told) and Al Pacino in Scarface (Oct 16, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),70)

The Paul Holmes 'cheeky darkie' crisis, newsroom rumblings and a new charter have given Craig Boyce an eventful start to his job as TVNZ chairman. (Oct 22, 2003,Dominion Post,C9)

It should be no surprise to find the two-tone painting is by Ralph Hotere. The surprise is the inspiration behind it - White Drip is a response to Paul Holmes' "cheeky darkie" comments. (May 26, 2004,Capital Times,5)

Third only to the Iraq war and Lord of the Rings as the major news item of 2003 - for New Zealanders, anyway - was Paul Holmes's "cheeky darkie" remark, followed closely by the America's Cup mast debacle. (Dec 27, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

No matter the outcome of Paul Holmes' plummeting ratings, his inflammatory comments will ensure his name will live forever, at least in film. Bollywood producer Jitendra Pal is in pre-production of a film set in New Zealand tauntingly titled The Cheekie Darkie. Jitendra's website explains the film as "When Hollywood dreamer Karen elopes with cute Indian scamster Varun to Bollywood, the Kiwi mob is left with no option but to turn up in Mumbai in hot pursuit." (Jul 17, 2005,Sunday Star Times,Escape 7)

"I was trying to shock, trying to provoke," he admitted after his repeated "cheeky darkie" comments on radio. (Oct 19, 2003,NZ Catholic,7)

And with Holmes-like diplomacy, there were so many words for off-whit, I guess for women of trampiness - champagne, ivory and cheeky darkie. Hooker red. (Sep 28, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C2)

On his Newstalk ZB show on Wednesday, Holmes called United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan a "cheeky darkie" and said the world shouldn't be told what to do by a Ghanaian. (Sep 27, 2003,Dominion Post,E2)

"That Kofi Annan, I've got to say to you, has been a very cheeky darkie overnight. He's been a very cheeky darkie. It's all very well giving a darkie that secretary-general job but we'll only take so much [laughs] I'm sorry, we will only take so much. (Sep 24, 2003,NZ Herald)

[Hdg] Holmes: a 'cheeky darkie' responds. Former race relations conciliator Gregory Fortuin writes of his reaction to the row over broadcaster Paul Holmes' comments about Kofi Annan. (Oct 2, 2003,Dominion,B5)

King's star guest.. dropped in to vouch that, as her TV One colleague, Holmes had at all times been a great interview whenever she'd had him on her show;.. and to spontaneously tell King that she thought he was a cheeky darkie, thus making it okay for the brilliant female journalist to follow suit in using the controversial racist epithet. (Oct 2, 2003,Dominion,B9)

...Apple's comic timing when interrupting Corsello's introdiuction of Parlor with a "cheeky darkie" quip got the biggest laugh of the night. (Oct 15, 2003,Capital Times,12)

The title page shows a full page cartoon of a girl in a bikini with dark brown skin, the heading at the top left of the page reads "Cheeky Darkie?" (Oct 15, 2003,Capital Times,3)

... it seems the whole "cheeky darkie" episode has uncovered a double standard at the national broadcaster. (Oct 4, 2003,Dominion Post,B4)

That was before "Cheeky darkie", which surely rates at least four cheekies on Mrs Holmes's cheekometer. (Apr 17, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),78)

A top Maori leader has called the prime minister "a very cheeky Clarkie", accusing the government of deliberately confusing the public about Maori ownership of the beaches. (Oct 5, 2003,Sunday Star Times,A2)

The happiest people in the world, apparently, are the Nigerians. See. Nothing wrong with being a "cheeky darkie" - and they've sure had a better week of it than Paul Homes. (Oct 5, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C8)

A succession of cheeky darkies - sorry, developers-set out to make monkeys of our planners and councillors. (Jan 19, 2005,Capital Times,Vol 30 No 15 PP2)

cheeky whitey¶

phr. response to cheeky darkie

If it makes Pakeha understand that we are not an island,.. then Holmes won't have done too bad for a cheeky little whitey. (Oct 11, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9)

cheer-germ¶

n. [Term popularised by Aunt Molly of 2YA Children's Hour in the 1930s.]

cheeri¶

exclam.

PARTRIDGE 203 cheeri! Cheerio!: NZ: since ca. 1930. (Slatter.) (1984,Dictionary of Slang)

McGILL cheeri! cheerio, c.1930. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,26)

cheerio¶

n. a small party sausage; a cocktail sausage

IHIMAERA & LONG (ed.) By four o'clock everything was prepared - cheerios in a pot on the stove,.. chippies, lollies, bottles of fiz. (1982,Into the World of Light,72)

They're called cheerios because they were often the last goodbye before the stomach pump. We used to call them sayonara saveloys. Life, I have decided, is too short to eat crook cheerios or drink sweet beer. (Dec 20, 2003,Weekend Herald,A23) [NOTES: Gordon McLauchlan]

My father named these little beauts. He was manager of J C Hutton, whose brand was Swan Bacon and he always used that word to say goodbye. The little sauasages became great favourites - tasty novelties, giving much pleasure... Marty Read-Turner (Eastbourne, Wellington). (Nov 10, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

Whatever happened to the great little New Zealand cheerio? Alas, my butcher now also labels these as cocktail sausages. "That's what we call them nowawadays," he says. (Oct 20, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10)

It's not all cheerio lunches at theschool library day or reading to thewomenfolk in the marquee during thepossum-skinning contest at the AMP* show. (Jan 1996,North & South,120) [NOTES: Curious distortion of A & P]

Some butchers use the same saveloy filling to make miniatures known as cheerios. (Jan 15, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

DUCKWORTH `It must be a party.' ... Peanuts and chippies and cheerios and cheese. (1963,Barbarous Tongue, A,170)

LELAND cheerios: ... In New Zealand Cheerios are COCKTAIL FRANKFURTERS. The rude and lewd also call these `little boys' [sc. penises]. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,24)

JONES Gilmore had two ... pots of cheerios on the boil ... (1985,Gilmore's Dairy,95)

RICHARDSON Sixth birthday. ... Cheerios on sticks and sauce to dip them in and they fall in and we laugh. (1986,Choices,58)

McGILL cheerio cocktail sausage. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,26)

I'll get tomatoes and ham and cheerios... The cheerios went on, and the making of sandwiches, coffee and cocktails began. (Feb 11, 1953,NZ Observer,14)

The manicured gents of Britain's financial establishment have polished off all the cheerios and asparagus rolls by the time Bill gets there, but they have left plenty of Dag's Run Rough Red. (Sep 26, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

McGEE Care for a pinch of pav deah?... Perhaps a small tumescent cheerio? (1981,Foreskin's Lament,70)

I felt there should have been cheerios and tomato sauce, meat pies, tinned spaghetti pizzas, pavlovas, lamingtons, sausage rolls, fat club sandwiches, beer and thick cups of steaming tea. (Mar 1991,More Magazine,66)

cheese blister¶

n. variant of cheese buster in earlier recipes [the risen cooked result often has the appearance of a blister] (See cheese buster,buster)

BASHAM CHEESE BLISTERS ... Roll out thinly, and cut into oblong pieces ... Bake ... (1939,Aunt Daisy's Cookery Book,109)

cheese buster¶

n. equivalent to present-day cheese straws (See also buster)

CHEESE BUSTERS ... flour ... salt ... butter ... grated cheese. ... Roll out very thin, cut into squares and place on cold oven shelf. Bake ... (1928,Everybody's Cookery Book of Tested Recipes,45)

CHEESE BUSTERS ... butter ... flour ... grated cheese ... cayenne pepper ... salt ...B.P. ... stiff paste with ... water. Roll out thin ... (1934,Marigold Book of Recipes, The,26)

Cheese Busters. Eight ozs flour, 2ozs butter, 4ozs grated cheese, pinch cayenne, mustard, salt and pepper. Rub butter into flour and mix with cold water. Roll very thin, cut and bake on cold slide. (1936,Cookery Book of NZ Women's Institutes,154,[not in 1955 edn] ed.)

CHEESE BUSTERS ... Roll out, cut into strips about three inches long and brush over with egg. Bake ... (1936,Merry Meal Maker Cookery Book,31) [NOTES: [these are referred to elsewhere as CHEESE STRAWS]]

cheese factory¶

n. (See cf. butter factory)

It was in 1911 also that Pahia Co-op cheese factory got under way. (Jan 1960,NZ Dairy Exporter,13)

INGLIS A cheese factory has been started here [Gisborne] lately [c1885], and the cheese I tasted was exquisite in flavour. (1887,Our NZ Cousins,91)

It is true that cheese factories are becoming numerous in Otago and Southland, with a few butter-factories. (1892,NZ Official Handbook)

I intend to go in for a cheese factory. (Apr 1, 1899,Chudleigh Diary,398,1950 ed.)

Eighty-seven butter- and cheese-factories were returned to 1st November, 1900, as at work in the Wellington Provincial District. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,14)

Before the Native Minister removed the A.C.'s there was every chance of starting a butter and cheese factory at Pungarehu. (Mar 28, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

When I visited the Opunake Cheese Factory there were 1200 gallons of milk in process of being made into cheese. (Jan 1, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7)

Mangamaire was a dairying district and there was a busy cheese factory where farmers brought their milk daily. (1957,Mangamaire School,5)

cheese fundo¶

n. [The recipe sounds more like a souffle; fundo = fondue ?]

CHEESE FUNDO ... milk ... bread crumbs ... cheese ... eggs. Beat yolks, add milk, mix in cheese and bread crumbs; ... fold in whites, put in pie-dish ... bake ... serve hot. (1938,Souvenir Book of Cookery Recipes,13)

cheese plant¶

n. marsh mallow

HILGENDORF MARSH MALLOW (Althoea officinalis), is also known as cheese plant. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,122) [NOTES: [nf 1967]]

cheese roll¶

n.

Growing up in Dunedin, I was addicted to what's known throughout the lower South island as cheese rolls. What they are in fact is a tiny snack-sized version of a toasted cheese sandwich. (Sep 6, 2001,Evening Post,2)

cheese-crate¶

1 n. (Rural) a wooden container, similar to a butter-box, used to transport cheese, particularly for export.

Cheese-crates are also of white-pine, but single-dresed timber .. Cheese should fit the crates so as to leave very little spare room... No marks should be put on battens of cheese-crates, except, perhaps, West of England marks. (Jun 15, 1910,NZ Journal of Agriculture,52)

.. in some districts the co-operative principle has been extended, and includes co-operative box manufacturing factories for the making of butter boxes and cheese crates. (Jul 1925,NZ Dairy Exporter,30)

Cheese is graded by a different method from butter, mainly because laying out cheese crates in the same manner as butter boxes would involve too much labour and space. [cheese crate] (Jul 1947,NZ Journal of Agriculture,45)

cheese-puncher¶

n. (Rural) a labourer in a cheese factory.

TINSLEY 6 To an old cheesepuncher who lived out his life in solitude. (1985,Cheese Punchers' Ball, The,6)

TINSLEY The cheesepuncher lived in a tiny community where everyone talked shop. (1985,Cheese Punchers' Ball, The,12)

TINSLEY To earn an extra bob or two, before Christmas, many cheese-punchers used to go haymaking. (1985,Cheese Punchers' Ball, The,157)

cheese-scraping¶

n. a var. of cheese-paring, miserly economising (? nonce)

WHITWORTH As mother detested `misery' or any form of cheese-scraping, we had a splendid table. (1950,Otago Interval,32)

cheesery¶

n. a cheese factory

The winery also [plans to develop and operate a cheesery, which is still undergoing the resource consent process. (Jan 29, 2001,Evening Post,18)

cheesewood¶

n. kaikomako

MARTIN The kaikomako, also known as CHEESEWOOD and BRIDAL TREE, commences life as a bushy shrub ... (1929,Flora NZ,1961 ed.)

Chelsea¶

n. sugar

McGILL chelsea sugar; from the name of the sugar works (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,26)

chemical ploughing¶

1 n. (Rural) the poisoning of unwanted pasture plant species and oversowing with seed of desired species.

The other [pasture improvement method] was to use the 'chemical ploughing' technique, in which unwanted grass species are killed out by chemical spraying and new ones established by oversowing. The chemical ploughing trial was described by Mr Robinson of Massey College. (Nov 21, 1963,NZ Farmer,5)

The term 'chemical ploughing' is a misnomer, but is commonly used because there is no other suitable abbreviation for the process, which may be defined as "establishment of pasture or crops after destruction of the previous sward with chemicals instead of by cultivation." (Sep 1961,NZ Journal of Agriculture,239)

In the absence of a reliable technique for employing chemical ploughing in dry climates, renovation of run-out pastures could well be achieved. (Dec 1964,NZ Journal of Agriculture,477)

chemical topping¶

1 n. (Rural) the spraying of certain pasture grass and weeds in order to allow desirable species to develop.

Chemical topping of the hilltops, using a light application of Roundup, knocks back tbe grass and encourages clover growth. (Oct 3, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,18)

Cammock employs chemical topping to create specific high quality clover-dominant pastures for weaner calves and finishing lambs. Another farmer to try chemical topping is Pahiatua's Bill Wallace, who has been experimenting with the method for the last three years to suppress grasses and weeds on selected areas with shady faces and Californian thistle. (2002,Wool Grower,Winter 20)

chemigation¶

1 n. (Rural) the provision of fertilisers and pesticides through a drip irrigation system.

It [drip irrigation] is not only a method to supply water but also can be used to supply soluble materials such as fertilisers, fumigants, insecticides, fungicides or herbicides, called 'chemigation.' (Aug 1985,Growing Today,23)

chenille fern¶

n. (See fern)

cheque¶

n.

Every acre ... of grass represents a cow, whose yield of milk helps to swell the monthly cheque from the factory. (1911,TrNZI,43/440)

cheque kiting¶

n.

Cheque kiting was a process in which two bank accounts were set up, and very large cheques were written between the two accounts. (Aug 11, 1998,Dominion,1)

cheque proud¶

adj. anxious to get rid of or spend one's wages (See cf. collar-proud)

Cheque proud.-A station hand becomes c.p. when he wants a bust. He will be no good to himself or anyone else until he has spent his wages. (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Gloss]

adj. mean or tight with money; not anxious to pay out

PRESTON Next morning Jack solemnly paraded from one end of the shed to the other, eying [?] every shorn sheep critically and saying not a word. ... `Look out fellers, the young bugger's cheque proud!' [get more context] (1978,Woolgatherers)

chequebook Maori¶

phr.

[Mr Tamihere] has also accused protesters of being "new chequebook Maori". (Dec 20, 2003,Dominion Post,A2)

cherney¶

n. the wreckfish, Polyprion cernuum

DIEFFENBACH 2. Polyprion cernuum. - Wreck-fish, Cherney, or Jew-fish. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/206) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna (Richardson's Fish) in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ II/206]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] cherny [TS] 1290 (1986,Fishes: A Bibliography)

cherry¶

v.

Other twentieth century New Zealand expressions ... include ... to cherry, a term used at Wellington College to describe the initiation of new boys with the aid of knotted ropes, straps and sticks (a now obs practice, I understand). a sharp blow (cherrap) (1941,NZ Slang,56)

n. transf. to native trees thought to resemble the cherry in appearance; prob.the Miro, which has cherry-like berries.

There was one tree, which they call the cherry-tree, nineteen feet round, ... (1843,Letters from New Plymouth,22,1968 ed.) [NOTES: (1842 Mar 2) 1843 (1968) Letters from New Plymouth 22]

n. lacebark

FEATON PLAGIANTHUS LYALLII (Hook., F.) ... THE HOHERE'. - This very handsome tree is found in the mountainous districts of the Middle Island. ... Owing to the flowering habit of the tree, and its fruit being a depressed sphere, hanging on a long ... stalk, it is commonly known by the settlers as theWild Cherry'. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,54)

cherry birch¶

n. [1972 p.c. W.H.B.Orsman Cherry birch used as alternate for and sometimes as distinct from red birch in Marlborough c1900: both are noteworthy for being no good for firewood : they never dry out properly. Cherry birch is lighter, pinkish wood; red birch is darker, browner wood.] (See cf. red birch)

cherry boy¶

n.

SNOOK A number of prostitutes came to our ship while at Sydney. As Cherry Boy' (that is sailor talk for young men who have not had sexual relations with a woman) I was sent to this woman who was supposed to likeCherry Boys'. (1988,Snookered,51)

cherry-pie¶

n. Ageratum conyzoides.

(1888,TrNZI,20/)

COCKAYNE A certain number of tropical plants have reached the Kermadecs ... Amongst these are - ... Ageratum conyzoides. . (which bears the name of cherry-pie, or wild heliotrope), ... (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story,125) [NOTES: also 1919]

Ches and Dale¶

phr. two characters from advertisements for Chesdale cheese

...in the absence of any real subcultures in New Zealand, consumerism represents both a common denominator and the mark of a (once) high standard of living. Ches and Dale are really mascots of egalitarianism ... and they really know their cheese. (Aug 13, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

Big literary cheeses: Introduced in a televsiion commercial 35 years ago, Ches and Dale, "the boys from down on the farm who really knew their cheese", now make their debut as the stars of a series of children's picture books. (Feb 11, 2001,Sunday Star Times,F2)

But the ad was as instantly a part of our culture as Ches and Dale. (Sep 1, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

I like cheese... Like most New Zealanders I grew up with Ches and Dale. (Apr 20, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),7)

chest-tapping¶

n. a medical procedure used on new-born babies

The disciplinary body for phsyiotherapists is anticipating that members will have to find tens of thousands of dollars because of complaints about the chest-tapping of babies at National Women's Hospital... Thirteen sick, premature babies who received chest-tapping treatment between 1992 and 1994 suffered a rare form of brain damage... The tapping, with a soft latex mask, was used to help remove chest secretions. (Jan 17, 2001,Dominion,8)

chevron skink¶

n. (Environment) a rare skink species from the Barrier Islands, distinguished by its large body with distinct chevron patterns on the back and bold black/white markings beneath the eye.

The chevron skink, or Oligosoma homalonotum , is one of New Zealand's rarest lizards, and its longest, measuring up to 30 cm from the nose to the tip of the tail. (Sep 2008,NZ Geographic,18)

Under the stewardship of the Department of Conservation it has 34 species of breeding native birds, many of which are endangered or rare, two species of native bat and at least 14 reptile species, including the tuatara and the very rare chevron skink. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,55/16)

...it is also home to two species of native bat, 14 reptiles (including tuatara and the rare chevron skink), giant weta,.. and myriad shrubs and trees. (Nov 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 54/96)

Chevron skink: This species is thought to survive only on Great Barrier Island. Most sightings of chevron skinks have been in close proximity to streams or damp places. (2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.conservation.govt.nz/upload/documents/about-doc/concessions-and-permits/conservation-revealed/skinks-geckos-lowres.pdf]

Among the 14 or so species of reptile on Little Barrier are Duvaucel's gecko (at up to 25 cm, including the tail, one of the largest geckos in the world) the very rare chevron skink (found only on Little and Great Barrier islands), and the Pacific gecko, seen here licking nectar from a pohutukawa blossom. (2002,NZ Geographic,55/13)

Neilson has already told me how rare it is to see chevron skinks in the wild... So few chevron skinks have been reported that there is no way of estimating the size of their populations... [74] Chevron skinks at Auckland Zoo have been observed to jump up onto the mesh covering of their cage and hang upside down by their feet, which also suggests they would be at home in the forest canopy. (Jul 2000,NZ Geographic,No. 47/73)

Jenny Jones The other large skinks in New Zealand are Falla's skink, the Otago skink and the chevron skink. (2002,Lizards,31)

One of New Zealand's rarest lizards, the chevron skink is on the nationally endangered list. (Jan 10, 2007,NZ Herald,A7)

chew¶

n. usu. pl, =lolly, sweet. cf chaw.

G.T. Dannevirke use pl =sweets; a slang term for normallollies' (1932,Diary)

SUTTON-SMITH He would spend it on biscuits and chews. (1950,Our Street,48)

HARVEY There was a lot of noise in that place [the station]. People running up and down with luggage and yakking flat out and buying books and chews; ... (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,122)

SUTTON-SMITH It appears that the children then were more often urgently hungry than is the case today, when there is an ever-ready supply of school milk and `chews' available. (1981,History of Children's Play,115)

SUTTON-SMITH It appears that the children then were more often urgently hungry than is the case today, when there is an ever-ready supply of school milk and `chews' available. (1981,History of Children's Play,115)

McGILL chews sweets or lollies, originally chewing gum handed out by Americans here during WWII. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,26) [NOTES: McGill's note appears incorrect; the usage predates WWII, and the Americans would have handed out bubblegum rather than chewing gum (TD/GK)]

v. to talk, to gossip

`Chewing about homely women and chasing the gay birds.' Ex chew the fat. (1929,Riven)

PARTRIDGE chew, v. To talk: NZ: since ca. 1920. Jean Devanney (1984,Dictionary of Slang,206)

v. not to cut (the wool) cleanly [?a normal transf. use; omit: not a techn term].

BOWEN There are two grave errors in tension adjustment. One is to start the handpiece with too light a tension, so the when the first blow goes in the gear bogs and chews, and small balls of wool collect under the cutter. (1955,Wool Away!,77)

chew a kumara¶

phr. (Rural) (of a topdressing plane) to crash

MCGILL Chew a kumara: topdressing plane crash. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,26)

chew hops¶

phr. linger over a glass of beer [[See and check beer-chewer] 1948 Wellington hotels, especially of one who `drags the chain' in a round]

PICARD He's a man for pushing ahead for a crust and not hanging round chewing hops ... (1906,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A)

chew one's ear/chew one's lug¶

phr. to accost (a person) for a loan; to borrow money (from); to put the bite (on); (See bite v)

If you ask a pal for money/ When you cannot strap a beer',/ Then youchew his lug', how funny,/ And what's more you `bite his ear.' (Mar 31, 1906,NZ Truth,41/6/4)

He `made his marble good', he alleged, by paying up a score he owed, having for that purpose chewed the ear of an acquaintance he had providentially met in the street. (May 15, 1909,NZ Truth,204/7/2)

And the Sergeant-Major's genial,/ And he doesn't `chew your lug',/ (1918,New Zealand At the Front,109)

chew wool¶

phr. of a sheep, to be very hungry.

HARPER The sheep we seen yesterday are still chewing each other's wool. (1934,Windy Island,266)

chewer of swipes¶

phr.

[Hdg] THE BEER-CHEWERS CALL. It is, however, the `beer-eater', the chewer of swipes whom we have in our mind's eye just now. (Jul 21, 1906,NZ Truth,57/6/6)

chewing-gum budget¶

n.

Overnight the so-called 'chewing-gum Budget' has transformed tax cuts from a symbol of the 'failed policies of the past' into an election winner. (Aug 10, 2005,Independent (Wellington),9)

Can Michael Cullen rehabilitate his cred after last year's "chewing gum budget"? (Jan 22, 2006,Sunday Star Times,A10)

[heading] Not even a pack of chuddy? ..Finance Minister Michael Cullen has given a strong hint he may ditch the small and widely derided "chewing gum" tax cut promised for 2006. ..This is a clear signal that they are likely taking the chewing gum out of the chewing gum budget. (Feb 14, 2006,Dominion Post,A1)

chewing-gum tax¶

n. [Google search Mar 2006: Spec. use in Canada, UK, Austral to refer to a tax for removing gum from sidewalks.]

'Chewing gum' tax cuts still expected to become law, says Dunne. ..[B4]Rather than scrapping the chewing gum tax, Dr Cullen should be looking to make it bigger and introduce it sooner. (Feb 17, 2006,Dominion Post,A6)

And the perception that he had more money than he knew what to do with underpinned the electoral backlash over his chewing gum tax threshold movements in the 2000 Budget. A term first coined by NZ First Leader Winston Peters... (Jan 22, 2005,Dominion Post,B5)

Chewings¶

n. Chewings fescue - a type of grass

MACDONALD It is therefore necessary to sow only a small quantity of Chewing's, or preferably ... have what might be called a `Chewing's' paddock. (1920,Australian & NZ Sheep Farming,112)

Chewings fescue¶

n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of red fescue, named after farmer Charles (George) Chewings.

Chewing's fescue: A few plants, but not doing well. (Jan 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,21)

MACDONALD It is therefore necessary to sow only a small quantity of Chewing's ... (1920,Australian & NZ Sheep Farming,112)

The history of chewings fescue seed goes back to 1880, when a farmer in the Rimu district of Southland sowed a 2-acre paddock in grass ... (Sep 1957,NZ Journal of Agriculture,293)

chews¶

n. a kaka's food residues

McLINTOCK [The] Characteristic signs of the species' [Kaka's] presence , especially when it was more abundant, were well-tended tracks, dusting bowls, and chews'. All of these are exceedingly rare and local nowadays. Thechews' result from a peculiar method of feeding in which leaves such as those of mountain flax of tall tussock grasses are frayed and sucked and the fibrous residue is left hanging on the plant in a loose ball. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/202)

chi-hike¶

v. (See chiack)

chiack¶

v. to barrack; rib, poke fun at; cheek; tease; the shouting of chi-hike' as a salute; hence, a noisy demonstration. In Aust. and (less commonly) in NZ, jeering, banter, cheek 1859 Hence <i>chi-hike</i> vt to salute with the crychi-hike'; also absol and intr to make a noisy demonstration. In Aust and (less commonly) in NZ to jeer at, tease, make fun of. So chi-acking, chyaching vbl n and ppa.] (Occas. constr. with at.)

GRACE "Go on chiaking.. poke borak - it doesn't hurt me." Ibid. 116 You won't chiack or poke borak at his grey and honoured head. (1914,Tale of a Timber Town,88)

The man.. is obviously orating through his sombrero, "skiting through his lid" (as they say in Wooloomooloo), or "chyakkin' through his roof" as Chaucer has it. (Mar 8, 1913,NZ Observer,16)

Every man who dared `chyack' her/ Found how well her arms were hung./ (Sep 8, 1889,Sydney Bulletin) [NOTES: 1889 Sep 8 Sydney Bulletin in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 120]

LANCASTER [Stationhand speaks] You're always chiackin' a fellow. (1904,Sons o' Men,42)

He had had his little troubles, but was never ordered out. Did not `chiack' Curran about his hat, and Curran did not tell him that he was always interfering with things that had nothing to do with his business. (Nov 7, 1908,NZ Truth,177/4/7)

chyak, chiak v.t. sl. sometimes, to barrack. [corrupt. fr. cheek] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3)

FULLARTON . he was `chyiked' unmercifully. (1944,Troop Target,36)

chiack, chyack ... v. jeer at [From Cockney slang]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

chiack or chyack Austral. inf. ~ vb. 1. (tr.) to tease or banter. ~ n. 2. good-humoured banter. Also called chiacking. [C19: chi-hike, a shout of greeting] chyack vb., n. variant spelling of chiack. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,191) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 123]]

McGILL chiack mock, tease, disparage, usually by sporting spectators, used by commentator in 1987 World Rugby Cup; originally English costermonger greeting chiike' (orchy-ack, chiack' andchihike'); here c.1890. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,26)

PARK Excited, forgetting everything, she sat down at the table, looking with eager appetite at the mutton-birds, rich and greasy, lying upon the plates of steaming potatoes, and then shyly at the boys who elbowed and chiacked their way to the table. (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,67)

n.

BOWEN ... shearers (all you good cobbers' that have shorn sheep) know the romance, glory,shi-ack' and fascination of this grand job. Ibid. 157 SHI-ACK. The usual shed banter, from which none are excused. All in the shed from the boss to the `rousie' can be the target of good-natured teasing. This does much to make a hard job a lot easier, and all should enter into this woolshed spirit. (1955,Wool Away!,2)

chiacking¶

n. cheeking, teasing [also spelt shi-(y)acking] (See chiack v)

LANCASTER [Stationhand speaks] Stop off yer chiackin', you fellers, can't yer? (1904,Sons o' Men,30)

DEVANNY Phillips' `shi-acking' ... (1927,Old Savage,171)

[re: a neighbour's quarrel] I will not say that this [neighbours' quarrel] has been an entirely one-sided affair as there has been chyacking from both camps over many months. (Nov 1, 1975,Press, The,17/5)

O'Sullivan Craig stood beside him in the to and fro of good-humoured insult, the old slick intimacy of shi-yacking and having on. (2006,Pictures by Goya,218)

Chicago window centre¶

n.

SALMOND `Chicago' Window Centre. a composite window made up of centre panel and two narrow side panels - usually double hung sashes - named for a typical office window in Chicago in the 1890s. (1986,Old New Zealand Houses,231)

chicken stealing¶

n. courting; usu. applied when one of the partners is older than the other [1953 15-17 M A31 Thames DHS 27 CHICKEN STEALING [courting] [M6]]

chicken tractor¶

n.

A chicken tractor is a moveable chicken pen with no base that allows hens to fertilize and scratch over the soil while at the same time eating household scraps and producing organic eggs. I built the chicken tractor last winter out of recycled timber and wire, and added nest boxes made from old wooden nail boxes. (May 4, 2006,Timaru Herald,8)

chicken-walking¶

n.

Caving in the central plateau, you move forward by crawling, chicken-walking and pushing your way along. (Feb 1989,North & South,44)

chickenfoot machine¶

n.

BOWEN Now put on one more notch of tension - i.e. a fraction of a turn on a chickenfoot' machine, or the notch on the tension screw of other handpieces. <i>Ibid.</i> 84 Most of thechicken-foot' machine firms supply a gauge for adjusting the centre post. (1955,Wool Away!,77)

chickweed¶

n. chickweed /'tkwid/ n. any of numerous small plants, esp. Stellaria media, a garden weed with slender stems and tiny white flowers; Stellaria spp. native, New Zealand chickweed, usu. native, New Zealand chickweed, native spp. of Stellaria, kohukohu

For salads over winter, there's lamb's lettuce (corn salad), and Kim also eats young chickweed - soft, juicy and delicately flavoured. (Nov 30, 2004,Dominion Post,E13)

DIEFFENBACH From having formerly been the principal abode of the Rotu-rua natives, ... [Mokoia] was always well cultivated, and grasses, noth native and European, plantain, chickweed, and others, which in such cases generally spring up, vary agreeably the usually brown tint of the lower native vegetation. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/393)

(And) Stellaria gracilenta (1885,NZ Country Journal)

WILLIAMS kohukohu, n. 1 chickweed; stellaria sp. (1892,Dictionary of the NZ Language,64)

RICHARDS STELLARIA ... parviflora ... New Zealand chickweed. (1952,Chatham Islands,28)

WILSON Stellaria parviflora Native chickweed ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,270)

BAKER Hoheria was helping Kevin fry turkey and potato leftovers with freshly gathered chickweed. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,182)

2 n.

mouse-ear chickweed [s] Cerastium holosteoides Fries (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,50)

2 n.

mouse-ear chickweed [s] Cerastium holosteoides Fries (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,50)

TAYLOR MOUSE-EAR CHICKWEEDS (Cerastium spp.) ... This introduced cosmopolitan weed is frequent in clover which is sown under cereals,in lucerne in winter and spring, and in thin pastures in the drier districts, especially on light land. (1981,Weeds of Lawns,72)

2 n. Stellaria decipiens, var. angustata.

COCKAYNE (1919,NZ Plants)

2 n.

mouse-ear chickweed, annual [s] Cerastium glomeratum Thuill. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,50)

2 n.

mouse-ear chickweed, little [s] Cerastium semidecandrum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,50)

chief¶

n.

DONNE The word `Chief' is in general use in New Zealand to indicate the head man of a tribe or section of a tribe. The Maori term for chief is Ariki, and these are of various degrees of importance. (1927,Maori Past and Present,97)

chief cook and bottle-washer¶

phr. cook and bottle washer, in collocations (head, chief) cook and bottle-washer; a general hand, a person of all (menial) work [check bottle-washer ca1940 Havelock: ca1950s Wellington CHIEF COOK AND BOTTLE-WASHER, of somebody who has perforce do the rouseabout jobs]

SYDER & HODGETTS as it turned out ... `I was going to the races but as it turned out, I'll be home, chief cook and bottle-washer. My wife had to go away to her sick father? (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],14)

ROSIER-JONES I'm Sally,' she says ...I work here in the [pub] kitchen. Chief cook and bottle-washer.' (1985,Cast Two Shadows,129)

... in the same month [March 1861] we read that the manager was acting as cook and b.w. (presumably this stands for `bottle-washer'). (Mar 1861,Puketoi Station Diary) [NOTES: 1861 March Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 113]

PHILLIPPS Head Bottle-washer. (Aug 5, 1867,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,111)

chiefess¶

n. a chiefly Maori woman

TINNE The first visit we had was from Maria, a `chiefess', who owns most of the estate on which we live. (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,66)

chieflet¶

n. a petty Maori chief

RICHARDS ... her marriage twenty years previously with Wi Te Tahuhu, a chieflet of the East Coast Maoris ... who held no land in the Chathams. (1952,Chatham Islands,128)

Chiefs¶

Hansen has been impressed with the form of the Chiefs alongside his much-loved Crusaders team. (May 7, 2004,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,3)

chieftain¶

n. a Maori chief

SAVAGE (1807,New Zealand (various authors/titles),12) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

chieftainess¶

n. a chiefly Maori woman

CAMPBELL But Tangata Maori being essentially a hard, practical, matter-or-fact animal, shaped his conduct to attain the greatest possible gain at smallest possible cost, and thus it came about that young chieftainesses were a cheap bait with which to lure and secure the Pakeha. (1881,Poenamo,Bk3/4/161)

The great-nephew of the chieftainess, Mr Joe Karaka, her namesake, Mrs Tuaiwa (Eva) Rickard and relatives followed Mrs Rongo into the tomb to tangi over the remains. (Sep 25, 1972,Marlborough Express,6)

... they were able to explain to the Maoris exactly what they were being asked to sign. In fact they took very great pains to ensure that the chieftains really understood the treaty. (Jan 22, 1990,Dominion,6)

n.

POLACK Haupatu, Chieftess of Waipoa. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,2/8)

child allowance¶

n. the family benefit, a weekly payment made by State since 19?? to mothers or a parent of non-working children under 16 (or in some cases 18) years of age.

SLATTER People in pubs spending the child allowance on booze. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,225)

ASHTON-WARNER I like the Child Allowance. And there'd be none of that without a government. (1964,Bell Call,57)

Child of the Stars¶

n. Clematis paniculata puawhananga

You can see it, clematis paniculata, Child of the Stars, puawhananga, sprawling over the trees ... with its mass of white starry flowers. (Sep 23, 1983,Evening Post Weekender,4)

child support¶

n.

Figures.. show two New Zealanders are paying child support for 11 children, four are contributing toward the upkeep of 10 youngsters, 13 are helping to support nine, and 40 are paying for eight... Citing privacy, Inland Revenue would not provide personal information about those paying child support - money paid by parents living away from their children - or how much they were paying. (Mar 27, 2004,Dominion Post,A13)

Child Welfare¶

n. a short title of the former Child Welfare Division of the Social Welfare Department

ASHTON-WARNER And all this brandishing of paper we get from the Education Board these days. And from the Child Welfare and the court. (1964,Bell Call,56)

GROVER The magistrate ... said that Con would be put under the care of the Child Welfare and if he was in trouble again he would finish up in Borstal. (1967,Another Man's Role)

THOMPSON Later when my mother's periods of disturbance became worse ... the children are farmed out under Child Welfare, and I live at various times in Dunedin, Milton, Blaketown and Hokitika, as well as being taken off for short periods of bliss in health camps. (1980,All My Lives,12)

Children of the Mist¶

n. the Tuhoe iwi

Tuhoe - Children of the Mist is filled with beautiful and powerful objects - weapons, cloaks, carvings, and other significanrt taonga (treasures), along with striking images of the mist-filled valleys and awesome forests of our homeland in and around the Urewera Ranges in Waiariki (the Bay of Planty). (Oct 2002,Ephemera) [NOTES: Advertising leaflet for Te Papa Exhibition]

ANGAS [Quoting Hursthouse] Here and there [in the wild mountain region of south-west Nelson], in some secluded nook, a few miserable natives, the remnants of early fugitives from the massacres on the eastern side, true children of the mist' andwild men of the woods,' have raised their little huts to snare the kiwi' and theweka,' unmolested and unseen. (1866,Polynesia,120)

The first people of the Urewera, the Tuhoe, are known as `the Children of the Mist', because they are believed to be descendants from the marriage of Hine-pukohu-rangi, the celestial Mist Maiden, with the mountain. (1983,Land of the Mist,19) [NOTES: [get Elsdon Bests title]]

IHIMAERA And the Tuhoe, Children of the Mist, are to our west. (1986,Matriarch, The,5)
