Chilean rhubarb¶

n. the introduced plant, Gunnera tinctoria

The spectacular garden escapee known as Chilean rhubarb or giant rhubarb (Gunner tinctoria or chilensis) is rapidly becoming a major weed problem on South Taranaki's coastal cliff faces. (May 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 63/5)

chilled lamb¶

n. lamb chilled for shipping

Unfortunately for exporters, the last ships with chilled lamb were leaving any day now, and as it took four weeks to send cargoes to Britain, any animals slaughtered now " would be too late to meet this window of opportunity". (Nov 13, 2003,Dominion Post,C6)

chiller¶

n. a cool room with temperature above freezing point used as a cool-storage area for carcasses.

It is thought the beef chain will stop in about two days when the chillers are full. (Mar 8, 1974,Dominion,1)

Meat-boners and chiller hands were among those immediately affected. (Mar 9, 1974,Dominion,1)

Chiller. Cool room with temperature above freezing point. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,33)

chiller n. N.Z. a refrigerated storage area for meat. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,192) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 83]]

...the trays of fillets had all been taken away by Dottie or Michelle to the chiller, until all that was left was the scrap bin. (Dec 28, 2003,Sunday Star Times,D12)

chilly bin¶

n. an insulated, portable food container; a cooler (US); an esky (Aus.)

He says that after graduating from the chilly bin lid in the bath, he moved onto bigger and better things. (Jul 3, 2002,Capital Times,18)

Over the years the chilly bin and six-pack has become a picnic. (Feb 4, 1999,Dominion,11)

I'm comfortably propped in a 5m runabout motoring slowly across Lake Rotorua. Near me is a chillibin full of provisions. (Jul 5, 1999,Evening Post,15)

Everybody is grabbing big orange containers, the size of chillibins, packed with roast beef, roast potatoes, salads, desserts, tea and coffee. (Sep 27, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),86)

If they can be sufficiently appeased, then Cullen will announce loose details of the government's planned law changes on Wednesday - mere days before New Zealand packs the kids and chilly bin into the stationwagon and heads off for the beach... The will still head to the same beaches they have always gone to, unpack the chillie [sic]bin and slap on the sun cream. (Dec 14, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C3)

While most of us are endowed with a chilly-bin to protect the perishables, remember that wet newspaper works well for keeping vegetables fresh. (Jan 7, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49)

Like last time he's packed a nice chilly bin - sorry, eski - and he knows the best bit of the boat to install yourself in for the hour-long journey out to the island. (Dec 8, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),47)

Most of us will have to settle for that great Australasian stand-by, the chilly bin or esky, perhaps bolstered by some sort of carry-bag. (Nov 1999,AA Directions,41)

So a little while later, feeling a bit guilty about my absence of hospitality I walk over to the stranger with a peace offering of a can of beer fresh from a chilly bin full of ice. (Mar 2003,North & South,92)

Remember to spread a layer of ice on the bottom of your chilly bin and pack ice pads or packs around your food. (Feb 2, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,4)

McDERMOTT A chilly-bin is a polystyrene picnic hamper which will keep ice, cold drinks ... cold up to ten hours, dependably. (1976,How to Get Lost & Found in NZ,18)

LELAND Chilly bin. A literal description of the inside of the ideal PICNIC HAMPER, made of foamed polystyrene. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,24)

`Chilly bins, in Australia called eskies [Eski: z]' (Feb 13, 1982,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 1982 Feb 13 Saturday Cricket commentator Glenn Turner]

[Advertisement Rambler Chilly Bin Double Insulated Made of Plastic. (Dec 28, 1982,Evening Post,17)

chilly bin n. N.Z. inf. a portable insulated container with provision for packing food and drink in ice. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,192) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 124; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 83]]

THE Hawke's Bay Cricket Association has relaxed its ban on people taking chilly bins in to McLean Park ... (Mar 9, 1983,NZ Times,1)

The booze ban at Eden Park was carried too far. Two middle-aged ladies took their chilly-bin with lunch etc and two cans of beer to wash the food down. Hard luck. (Mar 23, 1986,NZ Truth,2)

McGILL chillybin polystyrene picnic hamper for keeping food and particularly drink cool. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,27)

"Bout time - you fellas are stink," mocks a Mum sitting, Lady Muck-like on a chilly bin. (Aug 21, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),31)

I emptied my chilly bin into the sea, / Though it seemed an awfu' shame / And tossed the rest o' my smokes in too, / Said, "Bugger!" and rowed for hame. (Feb 21, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),57)

A mate of mine reckons it's nearly time to put some CRC on his fishing reel and scrub last year's dried squid-bait off the lid of the chillybin. (Nov 8, 2000,Independent Business Weekly,21)

Someone had even moved my chilly bin closer to the van to allow space for a 4WD. (May 2008,NZ Geographic,24)

But the high speed and quality of the duel in the Chilly Bin made this a very special kind of rugby test. (Jul 10, 2008,Rugby News,39)

chimaera¶

n. ghost shark

PARKINSON All the coves of this bay teem with fish of various kinds, such as cuttle-fish, large breams, ... cole-fish, the beautiful fish called chimera, and shags. [In the Stout Collection copy, Victoria University Library, an early 19th C. or late 18th C. hand has added: `*Baracootas, a fish remarkably smooth about 7 or 8 foot long [dagger] ... [double dagger] Chimeras, a fish of Silver Colour] (Jan 15, 1770,Journal,114)

PHIL;LIPS Chimaera novae-zelandiae Fowler. CHIMAERA. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,11,1971 ed.)

[species name] ghost shark .. [scientific name] Hydrolagus novaezelandiae .. [other name(s)] dark ghost shark, pearl fillets, N.Z. ghost shark, chimaera (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

2 n. Chimaera phantasma

chimaera, giant .. [scientific name] Chimaera phantasma .. [other name(s)] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

2 n. Harriotta raleighana

longnosed chimaera .. [scientific name] Harriotta raleighana .. [other name(s)] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Long-nosed chimaeras Family Rhinochimaeridae Similar to ghost sharks, but with snout greatly extended towards a point. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,39)

chimaera purple .. [scientific name] Chimaera sp. .. [other name(s)] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

2 n. Rhinochimaera pacifica

chimney¶

n.

*Chimney.-A deep perpendicular cleft in a rock facing, up which a musterer finds it convenient to climb to a higher beat. Rather an alpine than a mustering term, I think. (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Gloss]

56 Pete had a dekko up a chimney. But there was a lay-back ... In the end they saw some hogsbacks up above the col so they tossed it in and glissaded down ... (Apr 19, 1971,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

1 n. (Rural) a narrow, high pass or chute through which sheep can be brought during mustering.

ACLAND chimney: a deep perpendicular cleft in a rock facing, up which a musterer finds it convenient to climb to a higher beat. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,368)

chimney: a narrow gut that musterers have to pass sheep through. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

chimney is on fire¶

phr.

GRADY A soft groan comes from his [the sperm whale's] open jaws. The sea is crimson with his blood, As he spouts, a crimson mist blows upwards, In old whaling vernacular `the chimney is on fire'. (1982,Perano Whalers,181)

chin music¶

phr. a fast bowl, a bouncer

With Shane Bond's future cloudy at best, Butler is suddenly the only bowler capable of dishing up the chin music. (Jul 23, 2004,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,11)

chin-warmer¶

n. a (large) beard

McCALLUM ... a pakeha joker comes to the gate with a chin-warmer that would make Father Christmas look clean-shaven (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,85)

China-stone¶

n. (See also Chinaman stone)

1) He says that "China-stones" which are found in the area also support this theory. ... The "China-stones" contain remains of plants, animals and people, like those found Pompei after the Vesuvius eruption, says Dr Pajak. (Aug 1988,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,81/52)

Chinaman¶

n. usu. the Chinaman, a chute or hopper device for loading trucks, etc. with spoil; ?also the process itself.

FOSTON [In working down a big cutting] - a small drive put into the hill. Into this rails were laid for trucks to run on. A hole was then made overhead, into which soil and debris was allowed to slide. The trucks when full were drawn by horses, which, after starting, were quickly unhooked. Once going, the truck gathers momentum and automatically tips itself. It is then returned again and again by the horses and again and again tipped in a like manner, until the work is completed. This device is called the Chinaman', because it was a Chinaman who is credited with being first to introduce it into New Zealand. 1921 <i>Ibid </i>107 ... by means ofthe Chinaman' they were able to load trucks underneath. (1921,At The Front,65)

TROUP [Caption] The navvies have built a wooden"Chinaman," or earth-hopper, holding thespoil loosened above, until the trucksare backed in to be filled. (1973,Steel Roads of NZ,146)

n. (Rural) an unshorn lock on a sheep's rump.

Chinaman: An unshorn lock on the sheep's rump, like the pigtail of Orientals. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20)

MCGILL chinaman: unshorn lock on the sheep's rump, which Straight Furrow magazine, 21 February 1968, explained was 'like the pigtail of Orientals.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,27)

n. the diamonds suit in a pack of cards

BEAGLEHOLE The old [Maori] ladies have a series of type witticisms [at Euchre] ...: they call diamonds `Chinaman'. (1946,Some Modern Maoris,190)

n. an unshorn lock on a sheep's rump, reminiscent of an oriental pigtail.

BOWEN CHINAMAN. A lock of wool missed by the shearer and left unshorn on the sheep's rump. The shearer does not see it until the sheep has stood up and got out of the porthole. (1956,Wool Away!,155)

Chinaman: An unshorn lock on the sheep's rump reminiscent of the pigtail worn by Orientals in earlier years. (Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing)]

CHINAMAN: An unshorn lock on the sheep's rump, like the pigtail of the Orientals. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20) [NOTES: [Shearer's language]]

An unshorn lock on the sheep's rump, like the pigtail of Orientals. (Feb 24, 1977,Dominion,11)

McGILL chinaman unshorn lock on the sheep's rump, which Straight Furrow magazine, 21 February 1968, explained was `like the pigtail of Orientals.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,27)

flag: Lock of wool left unshorn on a sheep's rump, and sometimes called a `chinaman'. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/24) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

n. = banded parrotfish

The banded parrot-fish - kelp-fish or Chinaman in the Stewart Island waters - is the most plentiful fish in the inlet after the blue cod. (Mar 9, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

n.

R. GIBBERD Sometimes a drill-hole develops a `chinaman', a ridge running down one side of the hole which prevents the drill from turning freely, and if not cut out, will eventually cause the drill to jam. (1950,Personal Communication) [NOTES: (Northland)]

n. cement-stone; (usu. pl) a large stone found in gold-bearing gravels etc.; large blocks of cement

The cement stones or `Chinamen' of the miners, occur in the basin, but are never abundant. (1908,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No 5 (N.S.) 33) [NOTES: (Park, Cromwell)]

... these sands have, owing to the deposition of secondary silica, become consolidated into hard flinty concretionary boulders, often of large size. These boulders locally called `chinamen', are quite analogous to the sarsen stones of English geology. (1918,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.19 (NS) 54) [NOTES: (Marshall, Tuapeka)]

These masses are similar to the quartzose blocks which lie on the surface of the schists of Central Otago, formed by the cementation of quartz sands, and are locally known to the miners as chinamen' ... [428] ... siliceous masses i.e.chinamen', associated with these basic rocks. (1928,TrNZI,58/413) [NOTES: (Spright)]

Quartz pebbles and cemented silts or quartzite boulders derived from the quartz conglomerate formation, and locally called `chinamen', also occur in the gravel bands. (1933,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,14/263) [NOTES: (Macpherson)]

HISLOP In sluicing big stones are pitch-forked out of the gutter before they block the intake, but should a Chinaman' - (as the miners call the extra large sand stones) - come within the force of the nozzle it is blown aside unless it is of exceptional size. Some of theseChinamen' are very queer in shape and colour, and are taken away as ornamental stones for the garden. (1943,Pure Gold,104)

McKAY In the face of this can be seen a stratum of the cement-stone,"Chinaman" or "white Maori," asboulders of it are called indifferently by the miners in different parts. (1894,Report on the Older Auriferous Drifts of C.Otago,56)

n. a Chinese pheasant

SENIOR He had seen two cock pheasants - Chinamen - fighting furiously [near Cust]. (1880,Travel & Trout,276)

n. a game

SUTTON-SMITH And then there was Chinaman':It was just a sort of follow-my-leader, but the trot was in imitation of the itinerant Chinese fruit vendors, of whom there were so many in the Auckland of those days. An interesting thing is that an old West Coaster told me he had seen children playing it on the Greenstone and at Red Jacks, both old Chinese diggings' (1900; Parnell, Auckland). (1981,History of Children's Play,129)

n. a pool game

ANDERSON When we arrived [at the Homer Tunnel Camp social hall] they were playing a pool game which they called Chinaman. (1975,Milford Road,113)

n. a fish, a flathead

Katheostoma giganteum Haast. Flathead (Chinaman). (1938,TrRSNZ,68/413) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

GRAHAM FLATHEAD Katheostoma giganteum Haast ... Other names for the Flathead are Chinaman and Frenchman, but where these names originated and for what reason I do not know with certainty. One theory is that when Chinamen hawked fish about Dunedin they kept Flatheads for their own consumption, as they preferred them to all other fish. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,286)

WILSON [The Flathead, Kathetostoma sp.] Sometimes called Frenchman or Chinaman (presumably because these fishermen sold them in the early Otago days). The Latin translation of the name means roughly `large, perpendicular mouth.' Also known as Spotted Stargazer.... FRENCHMAN Another name for Flathead. Also known as Chinaman. The latter name apparently derives from the fact that Chinese fish merchants in Dunedin in the early days always kept these fish for their own consumption. Nowadays these fish are more accurately termed Spotted Stargazer (1981,Fisherman's Bible,100)

NATUSCH Family URANISCOPIDAE. The flathead, Katheostoma giganteum ... is usually found on its own. ... Some fishermen call it chinaman. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,224)

2 n. the name for a loading chute in second Field Squadron during WW2

Chinaman chute¶

n.

McARA Chinaman chutes: These were used for feeding the surface filling into two-and-a-half-ton trucks. They generally consisted of a few planks laid across the drift timbers under which the trucks were placed while the material was `rilled down' from the sloping face above and checked by dropping a plank into position. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),315)

Chinaman stone¶

n. [-] (See China-stone)

SKINNER ... the presence of many large `Chinaman' stones caused [the dredge's] failure as a suction machine. (1947,Waitahuna Memories,70) [NOTES: [ca1893] 1947 Skinner Waitahuna Memories 70]

The scarp has formed a large edge' at the hill side [near Tapanui]. The land slide containsChina-man stones' (not China-stones as reported). (May 26, 1989,Sunday News) [NOTES: 1989 May 26 Sunday News: letter cited in 1989 Aug NZ Skeptic 6]

Chinaman's digging¶

phr. a lot of work for a small return of gold [see also the gen. Chinese digging: in the cit. at chinaman]

REES `But this is just chinaman's digging', he said. (1933,NZ Holiday,109)

Chinaman's luck¶

phr. very good luck esp. at gold-digging or gambling (Chinese are reputed to be lucky gamblers); [also Chow's luck (no cit.)] (See also Chinese luck)

BARR Chinaman's luck, thought our hero, as `John' entered ... (1908,British Rugby Team in Maoriland,111)

Chinese ballast¶

n. rice

Ah, good old Chinese Ballast! You know, our old dad always called rice that! Hated the stuff. (1989,Chosen Place,60)

Chinese boxthorn¶

n. (See boxthorn)

Chinese cabbage¶

n. bok choy

Cabbage and leeks have tightened but Chinese cabbage varieties offer a good alternative to steamed dishes... (Jun 24, 2004,Dominion Post,D5)

Bok choy, also known as Chinese white cabbage, has a mild cabbage flavour and is best eaten now during the cooler months. (Sep 16, 2001,Sunday Star Times,D6)

Chinese elevator¶

1 n. (Rural) [mainly Central Otago] a shovel.

SCURR shovel.- banjo, Chinese elevator. (2000,Rabbiters' Glossary,1)

Chinese fairy grass¶

n. (See grass)

Chinese gooseberry¶

n. The plant and fruit of the Actinidia chinensis, since 1960s commercially and popularly known as kiwifruit; an old name for kiwifruit.

A fruit with great possibilities as a market crop for the small orchardist, the Chinese gooseberry, has come into prominence of late years. (Apr 3, 1937,King Country Chronicle,8)

Other fruits [grown at Kerikeri], of which there are fairly extensive plantings, are Chinese gooseberries and tree tomatoes. Ibid. 40 Chinese gooseberries flourish. (1948,Our Own Country,10)

We had a small Chinese gooseberry plant. (Jan 10, 1946,NZ Farmers' Weekly,57)

BURTON During the war, when imports of fruitwere cut, the winter-bearing Chinesegooseberry came into prominence. (1985,Delectable Fruits Cookery,89)

[The natural world] gave us the Chinese gooseberry, which with a bit of local ingenuity, was transformed into the kiwifruit (shortened overseas to just "kiwi"). (Jan 2000,NZ Geographic,No. 45/20)

I've heard some say.. boxes of rotten Zespri (Chinese gooseberries to my generation), tomatoes, eggs and yoghurt [should be] provided for the kids of all ages to throw. (Sep 13, 1996,Independent (Auckland),24)

I am a stranger in a strange land, where people park too near to street corners so that drivers must pull far out into oncoming traffic to see when the way is clear, where lunatics run red lights and this lawlessness goes unpunished, where a person dressed as a Chinese gooseberry dances outside a new supermarket to entice custom. (Jan 6, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),3)

Few people imagined the Chinese gooseberry would become a runaway global success story, prized in Tokyo and served in ritzy restaurants throughout Europe when 30 years ago a handful of brave entrepreneurs planted the first commercial-colume vines around the Bay of Plenty. The export marketing breakthrough came with the clever renaming and branding, first kiwfruit, then Zespri. (Sep 21, 2003,Sunday Star Times,D14)

The Chinese gooseberry ... has been introduced into Auckland. (Oct 1, 1925,Weekly News,62) [NOTES: [OED2]]

DUCKWORTH Lie down. Oh, look, I forgot - your Chinese gooseberries. (1963,Barbarous Tongue, A,148)

TURNER Among cultivated plants, silver beet, tree tomato and Chinese gooseberry seem to be commoner in New Zealand than in other English-speaking countries ... (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,172)

LELAND Chinese gooseberry. Brown and hairy on the outside, bright green on the inside and about the size and shape of an egg. You may know this as KIWIFRUIT (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,24)

BURTON The story, probably apocryphal, goes that an American wholesaler cabled back to a prospective New Zealand exporter some time in the 1960s saying Americans were not buying Chinese gooseberries' because they assumed the fruit had been grown by the Communist Chinese.Sell them as kiwifruit', came the telegrammed reply. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,138)

chinese gooseberry n. another name for kiwi fruit. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,193) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 124; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 83]]

A century on from the arrival in New Zealand of Chinese gooseberry seeds, kiwifruit growers will this year celebrate the growth of a cottage industry into a global business. New Zealand founded the world's first commercial kiwifruit industry, with Hayward green kiwifruit, sold as "Chinese gooseberries" at Covent Garden markets in London 44 years ago. (Apr 29, 2004,Dominion Post,C11)

In 1959 the name was changed from Chinese gooseberry to kiwifruit to identify the fruit with this country rather than its botanical homeland. (Jun 9, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

Chinese gooseberries are rampantclimbers. (May 20, 1948,Southern Cross (Wgton),8)

You must plant a pair of Chinesegooseberries, for they are unisexual,that is, the male and female flowers areborne on different plants. (May 20, 1949,Southern Cross (Wgton),8)

1 n. (Rural) commercially-grown plant and fruit Actinidia chinensis [later called kiwifruit and Zespri.]

The Chinese gooseberry (Actinidia chinensis) is related to a family of climbing shrubs often cultivated for their handsome foliage, and at times for the edible fruit produced on some species. (Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,105)

Although it is not extensively cultivated at the present time, it may be grown successfully in certain portions of this Dominion, not only for ornamental purposes, but with profit to the grower, as the fruits - commonly known as Chinese gooseberries - find a ready sale with an increasing demand at 6d to 9d per pound. (Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,106)

Introduction of the Chinese Gooseberry into New Zealand: Over twenty years ago a gentleman living at Wanganui raised plants from seed that he imported from Central China. .. The accompanying illustrations, taken in a commercial Chinese gooseberry plantation at Wanganui, give a very good indication of the prolific crop that may be anticipated.. (Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,108)

Chinese lady¶

n.

McGILL Chinese lady multi-seat longdrop-style South Island dunny, indicating the regard in which Chinese goldminers were not held last century. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,20)

Chinese luck¶

phr.

W. HENRY THOMAS They said he [sc. a new chum digger] did not know a bar of gold from a bar of soap. But he had Chinese luck!... The embryo prospector.. actually struck it rich. (1960,Inky Way, The,6)

Chinese smoking¶

n.

HARVEY And he [sc. a boy] sat back with an old look on his face and let smoke trickle from his mouth and up through his nostrils. `Chinese smoking,' he said proudly and started to cough. (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,72)

Chinglish¶

adj.

These thoughts will occur to anyone who strolls down Glasgow Wharf, Wellington, and notes the yellow crew of the British' ship Crown of Galicia, chartered by the New Zealand Shipping Company for trade in the Dominion waters. Some time agoTruth' spoke with derision concerning the manner in which the [pounds]100 poll-tax was being dodged by wholesale desertions from vessels like this and it is gratifying to find that protests under this head have borne good fruit, for during the presence of the Chinglish trader in Wellington harbor[sic] no member of the yellow crew is permitted ashore, and two watchmen patrol the wharf from 6 p.m. till 6 a.m. with the same object. (Jan 11, 1908,NZ Truth,134/4/4)

Chink¶

n. a Chinese [(used freq. in Truth--> 1905-1914 as an abusive term for the `yellow peril').]

'It's not stealing.' Tama lifted his feet onto the dashboard. 'And if we don't take it, the Chinks will.' (2007,Best New Zealand Fiction, Vol 4, The,144) [NOTES: 'Red Christmas', Paula Morris, 2007]

TVNZ said "Poms" was a term used affectionately by Kiwis and Australians, and it rejected the complainants' view that the word was comparable to terms such as "Chinks", "Wogs", or "Horis". It agreed expressions such as "Pommy bastards" and "whingeing Poms" were terms of abuse. Authority chairman Sam Maling noted the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's ruling that the words "Pom" and "Pommy" were unlikely to offend of insult. (Mar 24, 1999,Dominion,1)

... Chinks and Japs. (1905,NZ Truth,11/5/2)

MANSFIELD He thought he heard one of the Chinks after him and he slipped into a timber-yard. (1913,Stories,132,(1984 Alpers) ed.)

FRASER & GIBBONS CHINK, A: In the War usual term for a man of the Chinese Labour Corps: also any Chinaman. Chink is an old pre-War name for a Chinaman, long current in the East-End of London and the Chinese quarters of Liverpool, Cardiff, etc., and in America. (1925,Soldier and Sailor Words,54)

BAKER NZ Slang regards it as a common children's term. cf the old song `Chink(ie), chink(ie) chinaman, velly, velly bad'. (1941,NZ Slang)

BEATTIE Later they put on Peter, a modern Chink,' to help him but Ah See chased him off sayingHim no Chinese - him no pigtail.' He would have none of him. (1956,Pioneer Recollections,39) [NOTES: 1947-1948 Beattie Pioneer Recollections (1956) 39]

chink, chinie ... n. (Sl.) a Chinese. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6) [NOTES: check chinie or chinkie?]

Chinkie¶

n. a Chinese (See cf. Chinko)

BARRY We .. had a good passage to Hong-Kong. When we arrived, the first Chinese war with Britain had broken out, and there was every appearance of plenty of fun to be shortly had with the Chinkies. Ibid. 284 One of the Chinkies threw a stone at me. (1879,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,51)

FERGUSON And Chinkies, Malay, Fiji cannibal/ All had a dab at thee, yet didst thou 'scape them all. Ibid. 213 And those who cannot shake theirs, fegs!/ Are deemed no more than `Chinkies',/ Or left like clocking hens, on eggs,/ (1883,Castle Gay,201)

Certainly it says a good deal for the much abused `Chinkie'. (1888,New Zealander Abroad, The,68) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

WOODHOUSE For the country as far as I've seen it's as chock full of holes as a sieve,/ With the Chinkies a-mullocking through it, and yet those coves manage to live. (1950,Farm & Station Verse,36) [NOTES: 1890s McKee Wright in 1950 A.E. Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 36]

Chink.ie (ch&ibreve.nk.&ybreve.), n. A Chinaman. [Colloq.] Lawson. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2019)

One Christchurch daily includes Chinkies in its passenger list if they travel first class. (Jun 24, 1905,NZ Truth,5)

They have a penchant for cheap vegetables down Milton way, and the Chinkies' gardens are so frequently raided that the pigtailed fraternity have now laid in a stock of shot guns. (Jul 21, 1906,NZ Truth,1)

chink, chinkie ... n. (Sl.) a Chinese. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

WOODHOUSE For the country as far as I've seen it's as chock full of holes as a sieve,/ With the Chinkies a-mullocking through it, and yet those coves manage to live.]. (1950,Farm & Station Verse,36) [NOTES: 1890s McKee Wright in 1950 A.E. Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 36]

chinkie¶

n. a marble

SUTTON-SMITH Marbles had a language of its own. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, ... Scotties, Scottish alleys... (1972,Folkgames of Children,174)

Chinko¶

n. (offensive) a Chinese (cf. Chink(ie)).

SMALL Now the bamboos' they were flashing,/ And poor Pat at them was dashing;/ But he very soon discovered that theChinkos' had the best,/ (1866,NZ & Australian Songster,22,1970 ed.) [NOTES: (`Paddy's Fight with the Chinamen')]

chip¶

n. short for wood chip

MANTELL The chip pile! ... Anyone living in Nelson was intensely aware of the chip pile. Sawmills to the west chewed up southern beech, radiata pine, into small flat chips around an inch square. (1980,Murder and Chips,5)

n. piece of (kauri) gum

In order of decreasing size, the pieces of gum were known as nuggets, nubs, peas, chips, and dust. (Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,41)

v. (Rural) [of weeds, grasses and scrub] to dig out or grub.

First the tussocks are burned off, the roots are chipped with a sharp spade, thrown into heaps and burnt gain ... (Sep 9, 1905,BLANK ENTRY,162) [NOTES: in BARRY (1966) In Lee of the Hokonuis]

STACEY We had chipped all the rushes off a paddock that we had previously drained. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,46)

n. Geol. bit of mud

Chip (mud) samples have been retained fro about 150 holes considered representative of the entire programme. ... Core and chip samples often provide a useful supplement to outcrop data or to compare with sequences in other regions. (Jan 1983,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,59/32)

v. to dig out

First the tussocks are burned off, the roots are [162] chipped with a sharp spade, thrown into heaps and burnt again, leaving an untrammelled course for the plough. (Sep 9, 1905,Mataura Ensign) [NOTES: 1905 Sep 9 Ensign (Mataura) in 1966 Barry In the Lee of the Hokonuis 161-162]

BARRY At this stage communication with English speaking people was almost impossible and Mr. Kubala senior, worked at ditching, chipping tussock etc. ... (1966,In the Lee of the Hokonuis,100)

chip ... 9. N.Z. a container for soft fruit, made of thin sheets of wood; punnet. ... 17. Austral. to dig or weed (a crop) with a hoe. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,193) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 124; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 83]]

n. usu. pl., small pieces of dried faeces in crutchings

Chip. Small pieces[sic] of dried faeces in crutchings. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53)

n. usu. pl, boiled sweets in the form of chips.

CHIPS. - Centennial, Opera, Florence, Boston, and other `chips' are merely refined sugar, boiled to the crack, and flavoured to taste. (1902,Brett's Colonists Guide,807)

n. usu. pl., kindling wood

n. a small piece of kauri gum

The chief factor influencing sales and prices of kauri-gum in recent years has been the rquest for the poorer qualities, called chips' anddust'. (Aug 1916,Chambers Edinburgh Journal,542/1)

... it is no doubt also responsible for the dark coloured varnishes produced from the chip grades. [fn] The terms dust, seeds, chips, nubs, &c., are the names given to certain of the lower kauri gum grades according to the relative sizes of the pieces. From dust' the size of the fragments increases in the order given, as does also the purity of the grade. Chalk, orchalky gum,' is a particular grade recovered from swampy country and is characterized by its white or chalky appearance and large water content. (1936,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,17/371)

REED The great bulk [of gum] retrieved by [washing] is small stuff, and is known as chips. (1948,Gumdigger, The,56)

SUTHERLAND Some of the classifications under which gum was exported give an indication of the appearance of some of the grades: bright, rescraped bush, bright chips, black flour dust, chalk, bright seeds and black sugar are some of the names. (1956,Green Kiwi,70,1960 ed.)

McLINTOCK An increasing demand for poorer grades of gum [after 1900], used in making linoleum, made it profitable to search for smaller gum: nuts',chips', seeds', anddust'. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/307)

THOMAS [Large pieces of gum] were exceptional and much smaller pieces ranging right down to nuts and chips were far more common. (1970,Way Up North,31)

REED Lumps of gum weighing half a hundredweight or more have on rare occasions been found, but in general, on the ranges and flats the size varied from an occasional nugget weighing a few pounds down to `nuts' the size of an acorn or smaller. In the peat swamps, however, while large pieces were not uncommon, much of the gum would be smaller still, known as chips. (1972,Gumdiggers, The,24)

In order of decreasing size, the pieces of gum were known as nuggets, nubs, peas, chips, and dust. (Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,41)

n. short for chip basket,a small container, formerly of thin strips of wood, for holding berries and other soft fruit. In NZ earlier called punnet, or strawberry-box; now, occas. and esp. plastic, a pottle

BIRKENHEAD CITY COUNCIL When you picked [strawberries] you had a little wooden carrier with three chips in it. One was for the jam berries and the other two were for berries that you were picking and you packed as you went...They were a ply. Very thin... It was a very light wood and very, very thin like a veneer. (1988,Back Then..,I : 19) [NOTES: This refers to about 1930]

LELAND Chip. A North Island term for a SMALL BOX of berries, the equivalent of (see:) punnet, also a North Island term. The South Island term (Christchurch south), is (see:) pottle. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,25)

chip ... 9. N.Z. a container for soft fruit, made of thin sheets of wood; punnet. .. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,193) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 124; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 83]]

I hated it there. My first time I hid in the dunny for about an hour. But she usually gave me a good feed - savs or snarlers, and sometimes a whole chip of strawberries. And fizzy drink instead of cordial. (1988,University Entrance Board Bursaries Exam,6)

chip (small container; pottle' orpunnet' elsewhere) (1988,Unorganized Games,3)

A few chips of strawberries.. were sold at the Auckland city markets on Friday. (Jun 15, 1932,Oamaru Mail,4)

n. spec. in shearing, a reprimand or warning about faulty workmanship (See chip v)

During shearing at one station in the early days, the boss came along and gave him a chip for shearing roughly, and asked him how it was that he shore all right in the morning but got rough after dinner. `... Professional shearers ... shear to the chip and if they don't get a chip then shearings fall off ...' (Oct 15, 1910,Maoriland Worker,2/4/3)

chip: This is a reprimand handed out to a shearer by a station owner/manager. It can also mean to shear a little roughly; e.g. He's been chipping at that sheep for hours'. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/22) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

RICHARDS Les always held to the opinion that if you did not get chipped' at least once a day, you were shearing entirely for the boss. Achip' meant you were on the borderline and shearing a few for yourself as well. ... He [the critical foreman] failed to show any sense of humour when Les ... replied: `I shore a few for myself that run'. [123] The shearing is below my standard of workmanship. ... You can take this as a general chip - or else. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,122)

1 n. (Rural) a small piece of dried dung in crutchings or dag wool.

MAF Chip: small pieces of dried faeces in crutchings. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53)

SQUIRE Chip - refers to dag chip - a contaminant, not desirable in manufacture. (1991,A to Z Glossary of Wool Terms,13)

WOOLPRO Chip : small pieces of dried dung (dag) often found in some crutching and oddment lines, and as a residue in dagwool. (2001,Woolpro Glossary of Wool Terms,7)

chip (at)¶

v. to find fault with; provoke, nag [also chip (away) at (someone)]

Chip. Shearer's slang. To chip a shearer is to find fault with work, or to caution him. (C.) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (c1890-1910) Acland Glossary]

NEWTON ... if any shearer gets a bit rough in his work the runholder simply tells the gang leader and his is the unpleasant job of chipping the shearer in question. (1966,Boss's Story, The,22)

'... It's up to the farmers to chip [trainee shearers] about lapse in quality.' (Dec 7, 1980,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 12.50p.m. 2YA National Programme's Farming Session]

RICHARDS Les always held to the opinion that if you did not get `chipped' at least once a day, you were shearing entirely for the boss. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,122)

OGONOWSKA-COATES Chip. To be critical of a shearer's work. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,95)

McGILL chip at/chip away at undermine someone with unpleasant criticism; originally shearing term for finding fault with work of a shearer; eg `If you keep on chipping away at him about his maths, he's going to fail everything. You know the boy's not very confident.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,27)

Why the policeman had been called to the pub was the fact that Milligan was `chipping' at the proprietor and wouldn't desist. (Aug 11, 1906,NZ Truth,69/5/5)

NEWTON ... on one occasion he chipped Jack Murchison because the chaff wasn't too good. (1973,Big Country,196,1977 ed.)

Chip away at us here: beigebrigade@xtra.co.nz Or if its easier please ring and leave a message for the Beige Brigade on + 64 27 294 9732 or call Tracy on the Beige Phone - she's on 0800 BRIGADE (0800 274423) (Jan 16, 2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.beigebrigade.co.nz/]

NEWTON If you started chipping men after a few hours' dipping, you'd soon be without any men at all. (1966,Boss's Story, The,20)

chip chocolate¶

phr. (Rural) to sort dags

sorting dags - to chip chocolate. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

chip heater¶

n. a domestic heater (often wet-back) fuelled by wood chips

HYDE Starkie did their cooking, lit the chip-heater, tidied up, minded the flat, wearing Olive's apron. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,218)

FERNANDEZ There were fowls to feed ..., the coke buckets to fill for the Aga, kindling to chop for the chip heater and sitting room fire ... (1973,Tussock Fever,99)

chip heater n. Austral. & N.Z. a domestic water heater that burns chips of wood. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,193) [NOTES: [cf. 1986 NZPOD 124; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 83]]

The school has the best bark garden in the district. The schoolteacher's house has one of the best-fed chip heaters in the country. (Jun 28, 1987,Dominion,8)

[Advt] The Chip Bath Heater. Your Warmbaths from waste fuel. (Sep 23, 1916,Rangitikei Advocate,1)

chip in¶

v. to hoe seed in, or turn it in with a harrow.

PHARAZYN ... sowed 4 rods more barley chipped it in after dusk. (Oct 24, 1846,Journal,61)

PHARAZYN ... sowed 4 rods more barley chipped it in after dusk. (Oct 24, 1846,Journal,61)

HURSTHOUSE For its first grain crop the seed can be `chipped-in' for 10s.per acre more. (1849,Account of Settlement of New Plymouth, An,98)

MAY It is advisable to chip in [wheat] seed. (1869,Farmer's Wife, The,21)

MACDONALD The first settlers at the Hutt and in the Porirua and Karori districts [c1840s], `chipped' in their little patches of wheat among the stumps. (1910,Reminiscences,36)

chip-and-gather¶

n.

...the fullback's second [try] was laid on by Spencer's brilliant chip-and-gather to launch the attack. (May 11, 2003,Sunday Star Times,B3)

chip-mill¶

n. a mill producing wood pulp

chip-mill n. NZ mill producing wood pulp (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,124)

chipper¶

1 n. (Rural) a sheep that is difficult to shear with its wool-yolk not sufficiently risen.

a sticky sheep (shearing) - a chipper. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

chippie¶

n. usu. pl., a thin slice of potato fried until crisp and eaten cold; a potato crisp; from (potato) chip US = (potato) crisp, possibly the early form used in NZ: (See chip)

It all started with garlic bread. "Initially we sold chippies, but then we started broadening the options to include garlic bread," says Taita College principal Murray Trenberth. (Jun 12, 2002,Capital Times,20)

One day I'd love to have my own car - without any chippies or spilt milk on the carpet. (Sep 2002,AA Directions,20)

KEINZLY Children ... tore off to the front seats of the pictures; and bought before going in waxed bags of potato chips, chewing-gum, orangeade and ice-cream - and the same again at half time.]. -- (1960,Tangahano,64)

DUCKWORTH `It must be a party.' ... Peanuts and chippies and cheerios and cheese. (1963,Barbarous Tongue, A,170)

LELAND CHIPPIES: Those crunchy thin slices of fried potato (POTATO CHIPS). One of my first language laughs in New Zealand was a sign in the Palmerston North Opera House which said: NO CHIPPIES ALLOWED: I hadn't realized that soliciting was such a serious problem although every city has its (legal) solicitors. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,25)

chippie n. 1. potato crisp; 2. inf. carpenter (1985,Collins Compact Dictionary,83) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD]]

There's a doctor's house, ... a TAB, and here's a dairy. Have I enough money for some chippies. (1985,Women's Work,215) [NOTES: Coalhouse (The Mask)]

MARSHALL While they were still at the chippies and peanut stage Lew Tranter opened the discussion. (1985,Secret Diary of a Telephonist,20)

McCAULEY They can't be too far from civilisation; cigarette packets and ice-cream wrappers and chippie packets mark out a trail. (1986,Then Again,30)

TAYLOR One cake of chocolate, a can of Coke, two bags of chippies, an apple. (1986,Shooting Through,4)

WATSON Anyway, they all went up and down and up and down in the lift while we were drinking in Peoples and then came in and asked for money for coke and chippies and the barman said `Are these your boys, Mrs Carter?' (1986,Address to a King,59)

McGILL chippie a potato chip. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,27)

This story spans quite a few years, so you may need a large packet of lollies, chippies, or whatever, to help you through ... (1988,Short Stories from NZ,82)

But the guests appeared more interested in the chippies and balloons, and a clown and a juggler, than in Miss Clark's speech. (Oct 25, 2001,Dominion,21)

The boys have fruit and sandwiches for lunch and, as an occasional treat, chippies or biscuits. (Nov 8, 2003,Dominion Post,E1)

The boys have fruit and sandwiches for lunch and, as an occasional treat, chippies or biscuits. (Nov 8, 2003,Dominion Post,E1)

The only ideal stoner activities missing were pigging out on chocolate and chippies, and going to the beach and doing angels in the sand. (Nov 2, 2000,City Voice,15)

It is a comfort, as they rub crumbled chippies in your hair, to know that they got As in Romance languages. (Jan 2, 1892,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

n. [carpenter or builder]

Jane Bowron Sure it's quake porn but people are naturally curious and I'm a bottom liner, as in: see how bad it is, absorb it, and then start getting on with the business, but I fully understand those who don't want a bar of looking at any of it. (Apr 25, 2011,Dominion Post,B5)

n. a chip heater, a wood-burning wetback stove

McGILL chippee[sic]wood-burning wetback stove, short for a chip heater. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,20)

Consisting of 3 bedrooms, heat pump, log burner and a chippie on a wetback, open plan kitchen and dining area with a sunny deck. (Nov 6, 2010,Wairarapa Times-Age,Property)

n. (Sport) an easy basketball shot

As basketball in this country is growing so is the terminology to describe the sport. ... The power forwards are the muscle of the team. They work the paint (keyhole area usually painted a solid colour), collect all the garbage (missed shots or loose balls around the hoop, sorry basket) and chuck in the chippies (short easy shots). (Mar 18, 1984,NZ Times,18)

n. a kind of marble

SUTTON-SMITH Marbles had a language of its own. ... There were terms for marbles such as taw' orshooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; dubs',dates', stakes',dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies ... and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. (1972,Folkgames of Children,174)

SUTTON-SMITH Elsewhere the [marble] tradition has continued unbroken (with `chippies' throughout the war), and strong seasons still flourish. (1981,History of Children's Play,261)

chips¶

n. money (See do/do in)

I owed him some chips. (Nov 23, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,96)

chipsealing¶

n. applying a type of road seal

chisel¶

n. applied to various Maori stone or bone implements resembling or used as chisels: such as a shaped pigeon bone used for tattooing

ELDER (1819,Marsden's Lieutenants,171) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

TREGEAR Long narrow axes were used as chisels (whao) or gouges, and, being lashed long-wise to a handle, were struck with a piece of wood as a mallet. (1904,Maori Race, The,320)

chisel mouth¶

n.

NEWTON CHISEL MOUTH: A fresh full-mouthed sheep whose teeth have not yet been worn down level; sheep grow two teeth each year; they grow only eight, and at four years arse chisel mouths. With age the teeth wear down until each tooth is level. (1949,High Country Days,193,1950 ed.)

chisel plough¶

v. (Rural) to use a chisel plough to enhance drainage.

The second and third areas treated were bulldozed, terraced, and then chisel-ploughed in the spring of 1960. In the autumn of 1961 both areas were again double chisel ploughed and the seeds mixture was sown with a fiddle behind the chisel plough. (Oct 15, 1962,NZ Journal of Agriculture,305)

1 n. (Rural) a stiff-tined plough used specifically in areas with under-runners to enhance drainage.

LOUGHNAN chisel-plough: agricultural implement, usually very heavy, with rows of stiff tines. Sometimes, but incorrectly, termed a subsoiler. [chisel-plough] (1981,Loughnan Glossary,18)

In the autumn of 1961 both areas were again double chisel ploughed and the seeds mixture was sown with a fiddle behind the chisel plough. (Oct 15, 1962,NZ Journal of Agriculture,305)

NEWTON .. with the chisel plough the main implement big areas can be covered in a minimum of time ... (1973,Big Country of the South Island,165)

chisel-mouthed¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of old sheep] having good teeth for one's age.

Dealers and stock agents use various terms such as chisel-mouthed to make failing mouthed sheep sound younger; but these terms are not in common use by sheepfarmers or shepherds. (Sep 9, 1993,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

Dealers and stock-agents use various terms, such as chisel-mouthed, to make failing mouthed sheep sound younger. (Sep 9, 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

chit¶

v. to chip, tease, to give a dig about; to barrack, to remind in a cautionary way; also as noun (give one a chit)

HISLOP After a lot of happy chat I made a sale about which Bill has at times chitted me for what he called my keenness. Ibid. 122 I was always chitting Jimmy about the good track times I used to put up myself - (tell another) -, so when on holiday with him ... the back-chat was good and merry between us, ... (1943,Pure Gold,57)

HISLOP It was only lately that he gave me a chit about the machine that flew away. (1943,Pure Gold,81)

chiv¶

1 n. (Rural) a twig or leaves caught in fleecewool of sheep.

.. large discounts are associated with fleece wool with medium shive and light thistle ... [shive] (2001,Wool Grower,Winter 27)

Crossbred descriptions were mainly light conditioned, good average topmaking wools, though a proportion lacked full length and were affected by 'chiv' and light discoloration, thus restricting the supply of specialty types. Much of the offering was affected by vegetable fault, especially in respect to 'chiv' and moit. Good average topmaking pre-lamb shorn crossbreds predominated in the offering, which, because of seasonal faults of slight discoloration and 'chiv' included rather less good to super wools and specialty types than are usually on hand at this time. (Nov 6, 1963,Straight Furrow,5)

chivoo¶

n. (See shivoo)

chivvy¶

v.

HENDERSON They hate being chivvied about and taken from their familiar pastures. (1965,Open Country,233)

Doris ... and I chivvied the chicken around until we caught her. (Feb 27, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,27)

MANSFIELD Really, they kept her alive in places where she'd been that chivvied she'd been afraid to go to bed at night ... (1920,Stories,250,1984 ed.)

He had come to "chivy" me out, so I stood not upon the order of my "chivy," but "chivied" at once. (Jan 15, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

n. a children's chasing and catching game

THOMSON Others wanted [to play] Prisoners' Base' orChivvy', Brewer',Egg-in-the hat', Duck-stone',Red Rover', or Kingy-seeny'. The boys did not know where this last game came from. They did not know its proper spelling or pronunciation.Kingy-seeny' it was to them and they did not whether that had a meaning or not. This rough and tumble game was the most popular of all. (1905,Bush Boys of NZ,84)

chivvying¶

n. behaviour exhibited by stags in the roar towards a hind of the harem.

LENTLE & SAXTON chivvying: behaviour exhibited by stags on the road towards a hind of the harem. Stag chases the hind to see if she will stand to be mounted. (1991,Red Deer in New Zealand,183)

Chloe of Wainuiomata¶

phr.

This segment did make you have to watch [sic], even if the show's relentlessly dippy treatment of Cohen gave you that slightly uneasy, Chloe-of-Wainuiomata feeling. (Aug 23, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),71)

chloroformed¶

adj. drunk

LORD He'll get chloroformed' incelebrating' something great you understand. (1921,Ballads of Bung 'Stunology',1976)

chock and log¶

n.

Chock (ch&obreve.k), n. [Add.] Chock and log, a kind of fence. Rough split beams, from 2 to 3 feet long (called chocks) are laid at right angles to the line of the fence. On these are laid the logs, which are from 10 to 15 feet long, the ends of the logs often being fitted into slots cut in the chocks. The fence is built up to the required height in alternate layers of chock and log. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2019)

chock-and-log fence¶

n.

The Canadian' (or chock-and-log) fence was also made of tree trunks, four logs being placed one on top of the other ... At either end short transverse pieces were placed between each log. The short crosswise chocks had a concave section chopped out top and bottom so that the fence logs would remain firm and not roll. <i>(Oct 1965,NZ Geographic,148</i>) [NOTES: (HargreavesFarm Fences')]

chocka¶

adj. drunk - 'full' of alcohol

No one realises that even when he's not chocka he wears his wife's undies on his head when she's out doing the shopping. (Feb 2005,Capital Times,Vol 30/No 19/p17)

chocka/chokka¶

adj. (informal) full

Both [wines] are built like Arnie (Schwarzenneger) - hugely powerful, intensely coloured and chocka with black fruits and spice. (Oct 18, 2003,Dominion Post,E7)

But it's also the weekend of the Bledisloe Cup and Sydney is chocker with rugby fans. (Dec 2, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),53)

Hutt Valley High School principal Graeme Marshall.. says his school is "chokka". (Jun 30, 1998,Dominion,11)

...both his hands were just chocker with wads of notes. (Feb 13, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),31)

His large colonial Palmerston North home is chocker with New Zealand contemporary and folk art... (Apr 13, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),52)

BAKER It was chokka, eels of all sizes. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,97)

Tens of thousands of dollars worth of crayfish on the deck and a fresh-hauled pot chokka with crays. (Sep 13, 1996,Independent (Auckland),20)

The rooms, traditionally chocker during the week with businesspeople, and empty at the weekends when the businesspeople go home, are increasingly being filled at weekends. (Jan 30, 2002,Evening Post,20)

It was obvious from the start that James was chocka block full of talent. (Feb 20, 2000,Sunday Star Times,D3)

LELAND chocka: ... Chocka means FULL to bursting. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,25)

VIRTUE It was chocka with other things Parnell had shifted out there. (1991,Always the Islands of Memory,142)

The room is also chocka with society's style arbiters. (May 13, 2001,Sunday Star Times,D1)

Half an hour before the first fight and the ASB Stadium is already chocka. (May 5, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

At first, they're outsiders, but Jo soon realises that the town is chocka with outsiders - the Cambodians running a restaurant, the elderly European neighbours who fled the Holocaust, the violin repairer with a large chip on his shoulder. (Jan 12, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),60)

Minister's offices are, it seems, no longer chocka with senior staff from the requisite Ministry. (Oct 4, 2000,Dominion,4)

Traffic was chokka. Cars were queued up stationary along the motorway for about three or four kilometres. (Aug 11, 1992,Evening Post,3)

Behind him, the nightclub (dayclub?) he has just stumbled out of is still thumping away, chokka full of punters who have had better pills than he did. (Jul 7, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),65)

This is the scenario facing All Black coach John Mitchell as he sorts through an aspect of the New Zealand game that is chokka with talent and possibilities. (Apr 13, 2003,Sunday Star Times,B3)

..."on a Saturday you couldn't walk on the pavements there, it was that chocka"... (Jan 2003,NZ Geographic,63)

"The huge hall in heaven marked 'New Zealand babies' is just about chocka, there's no room ..." (Aug 7, 2007,Dominion Post,A3)

chocker/chockers¶

adj. full to overflowing (f. chock-a-block-->) as well as the gen. Eng. `fed up'. -->1980 [in ODE (chockers marked as Austral.)] (See chocka/chokka)

Surging growth in the Chinese economy is driving a world-wide shortage in shipping freight capacity... Cosco's New Zealand manager Stuart Ferguson says: "From New Zealand to Asia everybody's chocker at the moment." (Apr 18, 2004,Sunday Star Times,D3)

chocker adj. 1. Austral. & N.Z. inf. full up; packed. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,194) [NOTES: [cf. 1986 NZPOD CHOCK-A-BLOCK, 125; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 83]]

STEWART They can't lean across the front seat. It's usually chockers anyhow. (1985,Gumboots and Goalposts,39)

dags - chocolate. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

When I get a bit pettish with them theymerely give me a gentle slap and hand mea chocolate fish.. to keep me quiet. (Jun 22, 1955,NZ Truth,4)

KEINZLY He bought Cinta a bag of jelly beans, a chocolate fish and a chocolate frog and he played a record for his mother. (1960,Tangahano,147)

chocolate loam¶

n.

The light soils of this area [Te Kuiti district], generally known to farmers as `chocolate loam', have been recognised by Taylor as being derived from similar volcanic ash to that which covers Wairoa. (1931,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,13/67) [NOTES: (Wright)]

chocolate war cake¶

n.

CHOCOLATE WAR CAKE ... sugar ... butter cocoa ... 1 egg ... salt ... baking soda ... sour milk ... flour ... vanilla ... boiling water ... Fill and ice with ... cocoa ... in boiling water ... butter ... icing sugar. (1932,St Andrew's Cookery Book,148)

chocolate wheel¶

n.

LELAND chocolate wheel: At school fairs and other charity gatherings, the chocolate wheel is a traditional fundraiser. This is a WHEEL OF FORTUNE with a box of chocolates for the person who has purchased the ticket marked with the winning number. Occasionally other prizes are offered (e.g. chickens) but chocolates are the staple. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,25)

CHOGM¶

abbr. Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting

He probably hasn't given us a single thought since Sir Robert Muldoon used to say rude things about tree-dwellers to annoy him [sc. Sir Robert Mugabe] at ancient Chogms. (Mar 16, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

This year's Chogm takes place this weekend in Valletta, Malta, chaired by Maltese Prime Minister Lawrence Gonzi. (Nov 24, 2005,NZ Herald,A18)

The city is abuzz with official and unofficial activities, a forerunner to the Commonwealth Heads of Government (CHOGM) meeting to be held in Auckland later this year. (May 6, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

This weekend's Chogm is a critical event in the career of New Zealand's Don McKinnon. (Dec 6, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)
