n. [usu. pl. chews [?choc(olate) + hog].]

choice¶

adj. very good [From N.Z. English to U.S. English Dictionary at http://nz.com/NZ/Culture/NZDic.html]

HARGREAVES Now I'd rather be on a 38-footer doing sharks. They're choice fun, especially when you get a real live whitey or bronze-whaler on your first hook and you've got to wrestle them about on the deck. (1998,On the Next Tide,73)

`Hey, this sounds really "choice".' (1989,Chosen Place,38)

Kiri gets up eagerly and hugs her sister. 'Marama, that's just choice! Told you we'd find her one day.' (2007,Huia 7: Contemp. Maori Fiction,136)

choke¶

v. cancel or stop something

McGILL choke it cancel or stop something; eg `Shall I choke the telly? There's nothing worth watching tonight.' [Shepard] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,27)

2 v. of a sailing ship

BAILEY & ROTH Well, we cannot fetch the Gannet - keep her just a point away,/ If you `choke' her now - in ballast - with the sea she will not stay; (1900,Shanties,132,1967 ed.)

choke a darkie¶

phr. to defecate [ca1964 Wellington University students]

McGILL choke a darkie to defecate. ANZ. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,27)

chokebore pants¶

n. trousers narrowing towards the bottom of the leg

STUDHOLME Cadet [of the 1870s] ... in top boots, chokebore pants and all. (1940,Te Waimate,102)

chokee/chokey¶

n. (See choky)

choker¶

n. a choke-hold

Wellington Central duty Inspector ... said: `I have been assured he was not held in a choker because we do not use them any more.' (Dec 31, 1989,Dominion,1)

choker chaser¶

n. [See cit.]

Every two minutes or so the giant chopper surges out of the forest with a three-tonne log looming over the cleared skid site ... releasing the great tree butts with a thump ... Two men - the choker chasers - grab the swinging hook, trusting totally in the pilot not to dash their brains out ..., and attach a new cable. (Dec 14, 1986,Sunday Times (NZ),5)

choko¶

n. the vine and green fruit of the tropical American vine Sechium edule

A canary creeper unravels itself among achoko vine just about to transmogrify the ancient garden shed. (Nov 7, 1993,Sunday Times (NZ),14)

BLACKWELL Stewed Chokos (As a Fruit)... Peel thechokos, quarter and cut into thinslices. Boil the water, sugar and lemonrind, pour carefully into serving dishwhen cold, chill, serve with cream orcustard. (1992,NZ Woman's Weekly: The First 60 Years,13)

The atmosphere of Auckland's North Shorein 1962 is deftly sketched - suburbanitesproud of.. their ice-cream-sundae paintedbungalows, their datura and choko-ladengardens. (Nov 12, 1993,Evening Post,5)

TANNOCK Choko.- This is a perennial climber, a member of the gourd family with a green squash-like fruit. (1934,Practical Gardening in NZ,195)

The choko, as the fruit of Sechium edule is called, has become very popular in recent years in the warmer parts of the Dominion. (1949,Brett's Gardening Guide,78)

The choko is a perennial trailing plant belonging to the order Cucurbitaceae or cucumber family and is indigenous to Central America; botanically it is known as Sechium edute [sic]. (Oct 1949,NZ Journal of Agriculture,79/373)

Choko (Mexican marrow): This member of the melon family grows like a climbing cucumber. (1943,Whitcombe's Complete NZ Gardener,226)

BALDWIN Choko Sechium edule... The plant is also known as chayote, or Mexican marrow. (1984,Home Vegetable Garden, The,75)

McDONNELL Choko... The fruit looks like a cucumber and tastes rather like a marrow. (1991,Grow Your Own Fruit & Vegetables,77)

[Hdg] Become a chokoholic... Auntie May had chokos for Africa and loved the share them. If you visitede her during the choko season you would enjoy choko canapes with a glass of sherry, choko soup for lunch and chokos in a white sauce for dinner. Large bags of chokos were given to you on departure. (May 17, 1998,Sunday Star Times,E7)

I'd never thought to eat a choko raw until I started reading the recipes sent in by readers. Then I found out that in contemporary Chinese cuisine, where the choko is known as hop jeung qwa, meaning "the folded hands of the praying Buddha", they are sliced thinly and used in a salad with blanched snow peas and mixed with a yoghurt and sesame-seed dressing. (Jun 22, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

A mature plant of choko, or chayote, will carry two of three hundred fruits and need a strong fence or trellis to ramble over. (Dec 1985,NZ Gardener,23)

Peel the chokos, halve them, and remove the central cores, slice or cube the chokos if desired, and cook them in boiling salted water or a steamer until they are tender (20-30 minutes). (1955,Journal of Agriculture Cookery Book,125)

Choko is a name peculiar to New Zealand and Australia, whilst chayote is the preferred name in most countries for the vegetable Sechium edule, although christophene has its adherents. (Oct 1996,NZ Gardener,58)

The choko (Sechium edule ) is grown by manu home gardeners in the North island, especially by those who are fond of marrows and squashes. (Oct 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,363) [NOTES: [OED2]]

choko n. pl. -kos. Austral. & N.Z. the cucumber-like fruit of a tropical American vine. [C18: < Brazilian-Indian] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,195) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 125]]

Choko is our name for a squash-type vegetable known in other countries as chayote, pepinello, custard marrow or vegetable pear. (Jun 28, 1988,NZ Herald,5)

Since then, I have always fed the caterpillars on choko. (May 1989,NZ Gardener,7)

Chokos, 6d to 1s per dozen. (Jun 1, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,46)

(May 2, 1917,Otago Daily Times,00) [NOTES: Citation & page number missing]

Peel the choko and cut into four. (Sep 19, 1918,Wairarapa Daily Times,3)

choko plant/choko vine¶

n.

The choko plant is common in many home gardens around Auckland. (Oct 1949,NZ Journal of Agriculture,79/373)

His eyes lifted to take in the expanse of the choko vine that weighed down, and was strangling, the oak tree. (1976,Tall & Short Stories,44) [NOTES: 2nd edition]

MATTHEWS One choko vine will provide all the fruit needed for one family. (1986,NZ Garden Book,203)

chokoholic¶

n.

[Hdg] Become a chokoholic... Auntie May had chokos for Africa and loved the share them. If you visited her during the choko season you would enjoy choko canapes with a glass of sherry, choko soup for lunch and chokos in a white sauce for dinner. Large bags of chokos were given to you on departure. (May 17, 1998,Sunday Star Times,E7)

choky¶

n. a lock-up; gaol.

If the Whaler does not keep within bounds, he is soon an inmate of the chokee', id estlock up.' (1844,NZ Journal,105/343) [NOTES: (Shephard)]

.. a few hours rest in `choky' to teach him better manners for the future. (1852,McLean Papers,10/146) [NOTES: (Ritchie)]

.. taking care of the chokey while the old man is out. (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher,15) [NOTES: -->1867 Rambles of a Philosopher 15 (Griffiths Collection) .]

THATCHER Come along now,' says Plummer,and let us away,/ No longer in Chokee will we be confined,/And long ere the warders turn out for their breakfast/ We'll have left the Stockade and Mount Eden behind./Softly, softly, let us away.' (1869,Wit and Humour: Local Songs...,4) [NOTES: (The Captured Prisoners)]

DUNCAN We [sc. sailors] found ourselves in `chokey' before we had fairly begun to enjoy our spree. (1888,Wakatipians,39)

BODELL I considered this very bad Conduct on the Part of the Sergt ... to put me in Chokey to save himself. (1890,Soldier's View of Empire, A,137,1982 ed.)

OWEN [a half-caste speaks] Oh, te case, werry goot. Three month's choky (1909,Philip Loveluck,84)

NEWBOLD Prison, detention block. British army slang, mid-19th century. From Urdu chauki, a shed or police post. (1982,Big Huey, The,246)

chook¶

n. a (parliamentary) reporter or journalist

We have never argued that our treaty rights should be calculated by "coastal length" - that's a northern fiction which the journalistic chooks have been feeding on. (Apr 3, 1993,Dominion,10)

Clarks travelling party also included the usual chooks from the press gallery chookhouse. (Sep 7, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

n. a domestic fowl, esp. a hen; a call to fowls: chook! chook! (See also chookie)

Eyes bulging from their heads, the bargain-hunters were feverishly going through stacks of books like chooks turning over straw in search of the grains of wheat they are sure are in there somewhere. (Aug 15, 1999,Sunday Star Times,C4)

Very often a pipe would contain an eel.We could sell these to Mrs Rose forthreepence. Perhaps she fed them to thechooks. (Aug 8, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

If they are able to free range, even for short periods, your chooks will also love to scratch for worms, slaters and snails if they can find them. (Nov 2, 2001,Nelson Mail,B18)

FERNANDEZ The fowls' mash might be a sloppy mess one day ... after he had mixed the pollard into the aromatic chook pot of peelings Bessie had cooked for him. (1973,Tussock Fever,99)

... the rooster had cornered 17 chooks. (Sep 2, 1905,NZ Truth,11/7/4)

She warned the family ... to feed the pigs. `And the chooks,' she raised her voice as the horses moved. (Aug 11, 1919,Quick March,26)

SCANLAN `Chook! chook! chook!' the children called, and the hungry hens, the rooster and the two ducks came crowding around for their evening meal. (1948,Dusty Road,58,1949 ed.)

FRAME ... a big blue pinny to shake at me as if it were wheat for a little chook. (1951,Lagoon, The,66,1961 ed.)

CRUMP Cleaned up the pigs, got sick of e.g.gs and chooks. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,125)

HARVEY Mum reckoned he had a natural way with chooks and things, and she often said, `Look at your father out there with those stupid fowls of his.' (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,2)

HASCOMBE The jobs that are always taken for granted, such as ... feeding the `chooks', raising chicks ... must be child's play ... (1969,Down and Almost Under,67)

McDERMOTT ... (`seasoned' chickens means they are stuffed). The colloquial word for chicken is chooks. (1976,How to Get Lost & Found in NZ,20)

JOHNSTON Get them tourists at Christmas time when they descend on our village with their bulging wallets just begging to be relieved of their cash. Quick raffles in the boozer here. Chooks raised and fattened by the maestro of the poultry business. (1981,Fish Factory,74)

SUTTON-SMITH We would imitate a rooster in the evening and set all the chucks [hens] in the valley going. (1895; Takaka) (1981,History of Children's Play,89)

chook n. Austral. & N.Z. inf. a hen or chicken. Also called: chookie. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,195) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 125; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 84]]

GILDERDALE chook Chicken. Throughout I.M. Peacocke's The Misdoings of Micky and Mac (1919). (1982,Sea Change,240)

JACKSON `After tea you children can take Nicholas out to feed the chooks,' she rattled on ... (1988,Rainshadow,59)

McGIL;L chook domestic fowl. - woman. - silly person. All NZA. - Kiwi army signal corps, from alleged habit of running around with their head cut off; hence phr. run around like a headless chook like a chook with its head cut off compounding the panic. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,27)

McGILL choom British person; `chum' pronounces in Northern English accent. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,27)

ANDERSON Apart from the odd pheasant, and of course the duck season, they jog along quite happily with an occasional chook or two. (1999,Long Hot Summer,120)

The chooks have now come home to roost. And I wonder if these are the same people complaining bitterly about the quality of programmes and the excesses of advertising on TV. (Feb 27, 2006,NZ Herald,A10) [NOTES: Metaphor.]

What will become of our much-loved airline? Will it soar like an eagle or be stuffed like a chook? (Nov 12, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

VANCE When Betty and I first came here [sc. Ashburton], everyone milked a house cow and most people kept a few chooks. (1976,Bush, Bullocks & Boulders,240)

2 n. someone silly, disliked, in authority etc (often silly chook)

2 n. as a term of friendship

chook feed¶

n.

What's the bet that, even amortised over a lifetime, the cost is so great as to make even a Rolls-Royce rehab programme look like chook feed? (Mar 27, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

HARTLEY Quite the opposite of Dad's, which got hidden in the corners of the barn by sacks of superphosphate and chook feed and left coated with dirt. (1987,Swagger on Our Doorstep,46)

chook lotto¶

n. an unlicensed raffle for poultry, usually of minor scale and often in bars

[Hdg] 'Chook lotto' for title... Ford's series leader Marcos Ambrose and Holden's Mark Scaife have joined New Zealand driver Murphy in complaining about the "chook lotto" qualifying concept introduced at Eastern Creek... Skaife's Holden racing team have also dismissed the system as "chook lotto" and "names out of a hat". (Nov 29, 2003,Dominion Post,D1)

chook raffle¶

n. (See also chook lotto)

Now, she should know how to spin the wheel for the chook raffle. (Feb 22, 2003,Dominion Post,A14)

If fund-raising were limited to the cake-stall and the chook raffle, politicians who represented the poorest and least-privileged could foot it with those who represent the richest and most powerful. (Jun 29, 1992,Dominion,6)

chook run¶

n. fowl run

A day or two before Christmas, Mum would take Dad out to the chook run in the back yard and point out a couple of black orpingtons that hadn't been filling their egg quotas... (Dec 2002,NZ Memories,No. 39/51)

chook shed¶

n.

Houses, barns and chook sheds clustered at it's foot... (Jul 2, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

chook wheel¶

n. [Internet search Jan. 2006: also used in Austral.]

Bill Tauwhare was running a chook wheel to raise funds for the school ... (2001,Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success,54)

chook's bum¶

n. the mouth

McGILL chook's bum the mouth. ANZ. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,27)

chookbucket¶

n. bucket for scraps for the hens

In the kitchen, his mother throws away potato peelings and vegetable stalks into something that is his favourite word in the world - a chookbucket. (Jul 1, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

chooked¶

adj. drunk

"Saw him dangling off an apartment balcony the other night., Chooked, of course." (Oct 16, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

Pouring himself a cup - milk, no sugar - he amused himself with memories of getting chooked to the gills at the Alhambra. (Jan 8, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

We proceeded to get chooked. (Jul 31, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

chookhouse¶

n. the women's section of journalists

Time for Clark to do her usual prime ministerial stroll down to the cheap seats.. and make chit-chat with the chooks from the press gallery chookhouse... (Jan 10, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

n.

Out the back, there is his second favourite word in the world - a chookhouse. (Jul 1, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

We had chookhouses and if you lifted them up there were ratholes underneath. (Nov 1999,North & South,29)

The fridge came laden with supplies - including fresh eggs from the chook house and juicy little tomatoes from the greehouse - for a hearty breakfast. (Apr 12, 2005,Dominion Post,A10)

There were fresh eggs each afternoon in the chookhouse, there were quince trees and plum trees and apricot trees, and reports that you could buy a pig's head from Pak 'N Save for as cheap as $1.5. (Dec 4, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

Like a fox in a chookhouse, Labour knows instinctively what to do with a plump, clucking SOE, and is doing it unsentimentally. (Feb 26, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

1 n. (Rural) a hen house.

There were fresh eggs each afternoon in the chookhouse, there were quince trees and plum trees and apricot trees, and reports that you could buy a pig's head from Pak 'n Save for as cheap as $1.5. (Feb 4, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

Add to that list a chook house and you have an impressive array of out buildings. [chook-house] (Mar 22, 2002,Hawke's Bay Today,Property Guide 2)

She splashed round the back to the chook house. (1989,Awekotuku Tahuri,23)

House truckers are always good value and the Tamakis found some. One had a portable chook-house coop, a child with a classic mullet and a mobile home with "Only We Can Free Oursleves from Mental Slavery" written on it. Pure Kiwiana. (May 18, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),77)

RICHARDS Some of the boys decided they wanted some fresh eggs and raided the farmer's chook-house. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,95)

Winners of the variable order section of last year's Taranaki Sharemilker of the Year competition, Stu and Debbie Bland, packed up their household, two kids, four cats and Ralf the dog, threw in the chookhouse and the farm machinery and moved to Otago for the 2000/01 season. (Mar 15, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,17)

.. this isn't how well or otherwise my chook house is built, this is about getting you out there doing it ... (Apr 2001,Growing Today,66)

chookie¶

n. Chookie is a children's or familiar usage (also a call to fowls: chook, chook, chook);

[Hdg] Chilled "Chookies"; Prospect of new export industry. (Jul 11, 1928,NZ Free Lance,9)

HENDERSON She loved her fowls - 'my chookies', as she always called them. (1965,Open Country,236)

CHAMIER You will let me carve the chucky? (1895,South Sea Siren,195)

LANCASTER ... chuckies ... (1904,Sons o' Men,266)

SCANLAN Here's your grannie, darling; she'll take you down the garden to see the chookies (1934,Winds of Heaven,79)

2 n. in NZ use, as a term of endearment or reference, usu. of a girl or young woman (in contrast to AND citations which mainly refer to mature women); a male's girl-friend (rarely as a familiar or domestic term of endearment addressed to an older woman or wife).

McGILL chookie girlfriend or young woman. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,27)

chooklit¶

n. chicklit for the more mature

And not to be outdone by the barrage of chicklit by sassy and sexy young women writers, middle-aged women writers are now fighting back with what I, being in the demographic, feel at liberty to call chooklit. (Jun 12, 2004,Dominion Post,E11)

choom¶

n. an English soldier.

Our chaps are rather fond of the `Aw choom' dialect. (May 10, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,153)

(1918,Kia-ora Coo-ee,14/3) [NOTES: [?check ?also NZ]]

PARTRIDGE Choom. properly, but less gen., chum. A term of address much used by the Australian and New Zealand soldiers to an unknown English (not Welsh, Scottish or Irish) soldier: 1915-18. Ex chum, n, 1. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,150)

2 n. an English immigrant

BAKER Choom, also a New Zealand use for an Englishman is merely the lengthening (as in English Midland dialects) of the vowel in chum. (1941,NZ Slang,43)

SLATTER `They're all right really. The Pommies, I mean. The Homey's, [220] the Chooms, the Pongos.' (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,219)

McLINTOCK An English immigrant is choom. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/680) [NOTES: (Wall NZ Speech)]

choom n. an Englishman [N.Z. parody of English Midland accent]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

chop¶

n. a share

HOGAN `You'd better get in for your chop,/ .../ You'd better make tracks for the store at once/ Or you won't get a thing to eat. (1962,Billy-Can Ballads,31)

HARVEY A man should have been in for his chop long before this,' said Dad with a funny gleam in his eye. ...I'm going down first thing in th' morning to join up.' (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,110)

CRUMP Don't worry mate ... Be in for your chop! Make the most of it while you've got the chance. (1960,Good Keen Man, A,101)

CROSS First it was free milk at schools. Fill up on it, girl', he would tell her.Get your chop, because we workers are getting our money back now.' (1961,After Anzac Day,11)

SLATTER That Cheryl Thomas ... Now there's a piece if I ever saw one. They tell me Colin Harrington is in for his chop there. Ibid. 163 Never dipped out, that boy. In for his chop, Old Tank - Just had her twenty-first and she's only eighteen - (1968,Pagan Game, The,102)

McGILL chop share or cut; phr. in for one's chop selfishly interested in getting one's share and perhaps more; from the best cut of sheep or beef carcass; eg Any hint of extra profits and Nat's in for his chop, no worries.' C. 1920, Australia c.1940. - <i>not much chop </i>of little value; from Anglo-Indianfirst chop', first rate, from Hindi chhap', a print, seal or brand; egAll the fuss about this new supermarket. Prices are no different. I don't think it's much chop myself.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,27)

n. a fool or silly person [?f. chump/chop].

n. a log-chopping contest; a competitive log-chopping event, esp. at sports meetings (standing chop, underhand chop, jigger chop, etc)

(Dec 13, 1913,Hutt Valley Independent,3)

PARTRIDGE Chop. 2. Wood-chopping contest: Australian and New Zealand coll: late 19-20C. B1942. (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1014)

chop ... 12. Austral. & N.Z. a competition of skill and speed in chopping logs. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,195) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 126; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 84]]

There are axes too - Eddie is a competitive axeman and attends around 20 chops each season. Not just to compete, but to keep in touch with the many axemen who use axes he has ground or, these days, that have been crafted in his workship. ... Sometimes he'll return from a chop with as many as 40 in the boot of his car for re-grinding. (Aug 31, 1984,Dominion,13)

BACON Mac Harris was saying they want a Chops Steward. You could do that, couldn't you?'Chops? Wouldn't that be a woman's job? I don't know the first thing about catering.' ... Now, John, you've got to take this seriously. The Chops are the most important part of the Sports. ... (1963,In the Sticks,131)

v. to fell, clear

TOMLINSON In the winter of 1913, Ned Russ and I chopped some bush for Jack Brough and fifty acres for Arnold Mead at [pound]1 per acre. We made good wages because we chopped only up to two feet in diameter. (1968,Remembered Trails,61)

v. to grind or gnash the upper and lower tusks, i.e. his chops.

NEWTON ... the [mad] boar was content to stand and chop in the creek. (1947,Wayleggo,112)

NEWTON [v.i. of a boar] However, by then the boar was exhausted and was content to stand in the creek and chop. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,78)

2 v.

STRONACH The dogs began to get distemper ...; their eyes dulled and began to run; their jaws began to `chop', or open and shut convulsively; and finally their legs weakened and their loins became affected. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,42)

chop off¶

n.

Patrons are advised to get a seat on the grandstand and obtain a good view of the competition, which will be run in two heats and a final chop off. (Jan 27, 1934,Feilding Star,4)

chopped forest¶

phr. chopped parsley [chefs']

Chopped parsley has always been chopped forest. (Aug 18, 2002,Sunday Star Times,D5)

chopper¶

n. one who cuts off trotters

COLIN GORDON Chopper: cuts off trotters; at Feilding with a rubber hammer and thick-edge knife, at other works by sawing (May 17, 1951,Personal Communication) [NOTES: Feilding Freezing Works terms]

n. an axeman who takes part in a chopping contest

WILLIAMS True, there is only one axeman's carnival per year scheduled for Carlton, the choppers being booked up well ahead, weekend after weekend. (1979,Skin Deep,63)

n. a Malaysian ????

LELAND choppers: (A) `Sink your choppers into that chook and you'll think you died and went to heaven'. TEETH ... (B) Slang term for Malaysians, used on some University campuses. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,25)

n. a meat animal not esp. suitable for sale in fresh butcher's cut; a pig

chopper n -s 3 : a meat animal not esp. suitable for sale in fresh butcher's cuts - used of an overweight or aged hog in Australia and New Zealand... (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,398)

Other types of pig are sold at weekly sales; they include weaners a few weeks old and aged sows and boars (classified as `choppers'). These choppers are used for sausages, brawn, and other pork smallgoods. chopper 3: a meat animal not esp. suitable for sale in fresh butcher's cuts - used of an overweight or aged hog in Australia and New Zealand ... (1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,188)

[Advt] Baconers & Choppers. We buy pigson a "No Grade Basis". (Jun 21, 1945,It Was So Late,1)

[Advt] Waitara Freezing Workds. Buyers ofPorkers, Baconers and Choppers. (Jun 29, 1945,Taranaki Daily News,8)

1 n. (Rural) [stock sales] a pig for slaughter, older than the porker or baconer stage.

Choppers were in good supply and included a line of 55 from a Hawke's Bay vendor which averaged $160. Best-cutting choppers made up to $200. (Dec 14, 1988,NZ Farmer,42)

Pigs were entered in rather larger numbers than last week. Choppers and baconers sold well. Choppers sold up to aGBP3 10/- slips 13/- to 16/-. (May 1909,NZ Farmer,409)

Choppers sold to aGBP15 last week. (Sep 13, 1951,NZ Farmer,46)

Choppers aGBP5 10/- to aGBP6, slips aGBP3 2/- to aGBP4 15/-. (Dec 20, 1951,NZ Farmer,45)

chopper boy¶

1 n. (Rural) a helicopter hunter.

FORRESTER The chopper boys were aptly nicknamed the 'Red Airforce.' (1983,Chopper Boys, The,35)

FORRESTER The chopper men in the chapters which follow are not the villains of the deer saga ... (1983,Chopper Boys, The,26)

FORRESTER This is the story of the chopper boys, the adventurers who risk their lives hunting deer from helicopters in New Zealand's remote mountains and fiords. (1983,Chopper Boys, The,170)

FARMER But then the chopper lads cottoned on to the fact that there were deer closer than the Ureweras ... [chopper lad, chopper man] (1994,Best Job Ever, The,263)

chopper cowboy¶

n. [Internet search Jan 2006: Also in use in N Amer. and Austral.]

Hundreds of deer, including wapiti, were taken out out by helicopter in what became known as the deer wars. ..professionally trained pilots flying large military helicopters were no match for the "chopper cowboys", with all their unequalled experience of Fiordland's steep terrain. (2006,National Geographic Magazine,#77, Jan - Feb 2006, p28)

chopper hunter¶

1 n. (Rural) a deer hunter who captures live deer from a helicopter.

.. the chopper hunters took to the air either after they had returned, or before they took off. The chopper hunters eventually won the day ... (1983,Chopper Boys, The,103)

chopping¶

n. = wood-chopping

An ingenious device for signalling the results in chopping competitions was used in the axemen's events at the carnival of the Rotorua Athletic and Axemen's Club. (Jun 11, 1932,Oamaru Mail,6)

chops¶

n. [see ODE]

Though Wilson certainly has the chops to get it, the edgy aggression written into the part is not quite there yet. (Apr 2, 2001,Dominion,11)

"I don't have any chops and I don't know any Metallica riffs." (Nov 28, 2001,Capital Times,9)

When a two-time Oscar winner breaks down in the middle of an interview, one has to wonder whether the tears are genuine or the person is showing off his considerable acting chops. (Jan 3, 2002,Evening Post,10)

[Hdg] Big band flexes its chops and wins (May 19, 2004,Dominion Post,B9)

He wasn't very flash when he first did Rocky... But the guy built actor chops very quickly. (Mar 24, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

Girl's got chops, man! She can play piano for real. (Sep 28, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),22)

In New Zealand, it is the haka, offering up a tour de Maori culture as the kid learns his chops. (Feb 1, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),78)

chou¶

n. ellipt. for chou moellier

Another excellent crop inspected was one of chou moellier, commonly called Chow' in New Zealand. <i>(Feb 1, 1952,Tasmanian Journal of Agriculture,23(1)/7</i>) [NOTES: (E.H. BenhamTasmanian Farmers' Tour of New Zealand')]

NEWTON Winter feeding is now a big item and the normal practice is to grow about 100 acres of turnips and chou ... (1973,Big Country,207)

Chow (chou), n. {see CHOWCHOW in the Dictionary.] A Chinaman. [Colloq.] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2020)

chou moellier¶

n. a kind of kale grown as a root-crop for stock feed.

Chou moellier (Marrow Cabbage): Ruakura. This comparatively new plant is proving valuable as a fodder crop. (Oct 15, 1910,NZ Journal of Agriculture,354) [NOTES: (OEDS)]

The photograph below illustrates a very promising crop of chou moellier at Ruakura Farm of Instruction. (Jan 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,25)

The photograph below illustrates a very promising crop of chou moellier at Ruakura Farm of Instruction. (Jan 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,25)

(Jan 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,19/1)

... a like area of chou moellier, ... is often used for winter feed. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,70,1970 ed.)

chou moellier NZ & Austral. kind of kale used as cattle feed. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 84]]

Chow¶

adj. (offensive) Chinese

Chow husbands of Samoan wives is a subject in which Harry Holland is particularly interested. (Aug 11, 1926,NZ Observer,7)

The yellow peril doesn't worry the average man.... He continues to patronise the Chow fruiterers and the Chow vegetable grower and the Chow laundry. (May 17, 1913,NZ Bulletin,15)

BEARDSLEY Up there were the last of the Chinesediggers... They were only Chows toeveryone, everyone but old Pop Geary...Pop would visit the Chow diggers upCroesus. (1984,Blackball 08,73)

n. a person of Chinese origin

I won't offend you. I'll get it at theChow's. (May 25, 1912,NZ Free Lance,12)

I've been called a chow, a chink, a yellow-bellied chow and all those kinds of names and taunts, and I still don't really know if they called me that simply because I was Chinese - just like calling a fat kid fatty or a guy with glasses specs - or whether they said those things because they hated me. (Oct 9, 2004,Dominion Post,A13)

I was thinking about those poor Chows thousands of miles from home and no one except themselves, just a dozen or so of them, to understand what they're saying. (Jan 7, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

The sleuths.. picked up.. a rendering pot (which looked very much like the one produced in a recent case against a Chow). (May 7, 1910,NZ Truth,7)

MEREDITH History does not report what induced the solitary Chinaman to take up his abode amongst the hardy Scots of Dunedin. Possibly this `Chow' wanted to study economy in its higher branches, as the following incident would indicate. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,22,1935 ed.) [NOTES: 1872 Oct in c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 22]

The greatest mistake the average New Zealander makes when referring to the Jap is in assessing him as on a higher social civilised plane than his cousin the Chow. (Jun 25, 1905,NZ Truth,1/1/1)

PICARD ... he might as well go and murder a Chow he's looked down on so much.Ibid., 21 Wellington about stinks of Chow. (1906,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,7)

(Jun 14, 1913,NZ Bulletin,6)

[Humorous pun on the musical Chu Chin Chow'] ... ousted from the Theatre by theChows' - will the President of the White Australasia League please note - (1921,Auckland Capping Book,21)

COAD `The old Chow who sold it took us in nicely.' (1931,Such Is Life,51)

BENNETT A Chinese (generally known as John') is a <i>Chow</i> (a derivative ofchow-chow' [the yellow pickle']. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,89)

n. (Slang) a chinaman, called also chow-chow. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),613)

chow n. (Sl.) a chinese, called also chow-chow. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

FINLAYSON chow: contemptuous term for a Chinese. (1973,Brown Man's Burden,140)

chow ... 3. Austral. & N.Z. obs. a derogatory term for Chinese. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,196) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD]]

McGILL chow offensive term for Chinese form mid-C19. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,28)

All over New Zealand the unfortunate white woman has been pushed out of the laundry business by the smellful, evil, industrial law-breaking Chow. (Jan 1, 1910,NZ Truth,4)

BEARDSLEY Up there were the last of the Chinesediggers... They were only Chows toeveryone, everyone but old Pop Geary...Pop would visit the Chow diggers upCroesus. (1984,Blackball 08,73)

n. cf. Chinaman, extended to a conveyor belt

chow¶

v.

DAVIS After I come home at night the jargon runs round and round my head. On wool, when three men work elbow to elbow on seven-hundred-pound dumps and one slip means a hook through your mate's hand - straight roll in, boys; cut her back a bit; easy now; chow her; up and over; stowed. (1964,Watersiders)

n. (See chou)

chow chows¶

n. flax bulbules

Their kids were chewing chow chows... bits of flax with bulbs attached (Aug 10, 2004,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: A Maori woman speaking]

chow shift¶

n.

THOMPSON ] In the seeming open sewer that extends beyond the claim,/ Slinging stows out with his sluice-fork - ... / And the stones are ever coming,/ While the dirt-pipes keep a-drumming,/ You can hear the tail-race humming,/ ... Night shift, day shift - ah, you'll now shift,/ For your chum will take thechow' shift,'/ ... Ibid. 70 Night shift, day shift - ah, you'll now shift,/ For your chum will take thechow' shift,'/ (1909,Ballads about Business) [NOTES: 1909 Thompson Ballads about Business (`The Sluicers') in Centennial Treasury of Otago Verse 59]

Chow-Chow¶

n. an early derog. name for a Chinese, the forerunner of Chow q.v.

THATCHER Chow Chow his hands with glee did rub. /'Cause he'd washed out a halfpennyweight to the tub. (1864,Invercargill Minstrel,72)

Chowick¶

n. Offensive term for Howick, referring to the numbers of Chinese

ARMSTRONG Racism and bigotry, however, are not limited to the eastern suburbs of Howick and Pakuranga (known to locals as 'Chowick' and 'Japaranga'). (1997,True Colours,72)

But Howick hasn't been renamed Chowick for nothing. (Nov 1991,Metro,116)

You get racist jokes, like the suburb of Avonhead being called Asianhead, like Howick and Chowick in Auckland. (Jul 1996,North & South,49)

A reader unsuccessfully complained to the Press Council about the term "Chowick", used by critics of the growing Asian population in the Auckland suburb of Howick. "Chowick" was employed in an editorial urging New Zealand First not to use the race card to inflame the immigration debate. (Jun 22, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

2 n. a resident of Howick, an Asian

Some are only a little bit racist, others are barely able to control themselves when talking about Asians, blacks, Chowicks, Samoans, towelheads, Pakeha ... you name it. (Oct 5, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C2)

Christchurch fever¶

n.

ELDRED-GRIGG Every year the `Christchurch Fever', rising from heated marshes east of the city, struck the very young, the very old and the poor. (1980,Southern Gentry,98)

Christchurch/by Christchurch¶

exclam. euphemism for (by) Christ! (also oh Christchurch, by Christchurch hooya!) [1953 16 M A31 Thames DHS 5 CHRISTCHURCH [annoyance]]

BAKER Need to find some outlet for pent up feelings resulted in ... by Christchurch! [The supposedly Maorified By Christchurch, hooya? of earlier editions of Partridge (and copied by McGill Kiwi Slang) came from a telescoped misreading of two of Baker's entries.] (1941,NZ Slang,50)

SMITH [Christchurch] derived its name from a remark passed by the first settler who ... was so overcome by the magnificent sight that all he could exclaim was `Oh, Christchurch!' (1947,From N to Z,25)

CASEY `Christchurch, look at your bed. You can't see a doctor like that.' (1963,As Short a Spring,129)

TURNER Some expressions that have been claimed for New Zealand are at the rate of knots very fast', <i>hook your mutton</i>clear out', have the wood on? `have an advantage over' and the oaths Blimey Charlie and (By) Christchurch (obviously a neat save suggested by the place name). (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,177)

PARTRIDGE Christchurch, by. A euph. oath,current since ca. 1945 (?earlier) in NZ and UK. From Christchurch, Canterbury Province, NZ; and Dorset. (1984,Dictionary of Slang,215)

ELDRED-GRIGG `Oh Christchurch!' is what some people used to say when they wanted to swear. (1987,Oracles and Miracles,6)

McGILL Christchurch!/by Christchurch!/by Christchurch, hooya? euphemistic extension of exclamation by Christ!', thehooya' short for who are you?' a juvenile addition; Partridge suggests aMaorified' shape of `by crikey, who are you?' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,28)

Christchurchian¶

n.

SMITH If you are a visitor, the first sight ... is the river Avon which is the pride and joy of every Christchurchian. (1947,From N to Z,27)

Christianese¶

n. Christian terminology

Excuse me speaking in Christianese, but it's one of the languages I am fluent in. (Jul 21, 2004,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Artist Allie Eagle speaking to Linda Clark, Nine to Noon]

Christmas box¶

n. In NZ use much wider and friendlier than OED2 sense of usu. money tips and gratuities given to postmen, etc, and hence, vulgarly and in dial. use it is often equivalent to "Christmas present"'; or P8:low coll. (and dial.)'. It can now mean any Christmas present whether given to family, or to workpeople as a Christmas tip.

SKEY So shall I, when dustmen sue,/ Drop the Christmas box for you./ (1889,Pirate Chief and the Mummy's Complaint..., The,144)

HENRY SMITH [Title: The Three Boxes] ... my friend, the father of three children. He came home one Christmas Eve from the city with the Christmas boxes. (1897,Steps to the Temple of Happiness,96)

McCALLUM Well, I got a Christmas box myself. The missus presents me with a pipe. (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,18)

Christmas flower¶

n. Christmas tree, pohutukawa

KIRK (And) Metrosideros tomentosa Christmas flower (1899,Students' Flora)

Christmas hold¶

n.

In a commentary from Johannesburg a few weeks ago he [sc. Keith Quinn] used the term "the Christmas hold" and explained that that's what you call it when a player grabs the wrong sort of ball. (Aug 16, 1997,Dominion,17)

Christmas lily¶

n. a strongly perfumed lily flowering around Christmas time. [Jim writes: Often used in church decoration for Xmas services.]

Christmas tree¶

n. the pohutukawa tree

With any luck, this person might end up in South Africa where, as he dreamt of GE glowing Christmas trees, he might discover that New Zealand's own Christmas tree - the pohutukawa - was considered a serious weed problem there. (Nov 8, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

LUSH Charlie and Martin accompanied to the beach for Pohutukawas (our Xmas tree - our substitute for holly). (Dec 24, 1864,Waikato Journals,43)

HOCHSTETTER Some few scattered Pohutukaua [check spg] trees (Metrosideros tomentosa) ... About Christmas these trees are full of charming purple [- so OED2: check]blossoms; the settler decorates his church and dwelling with its lovely branches, and calls the tree `Christmas-tree'! (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),240)

Metrosideros tomentosa (1884,Maoriland) [NOTES: 1884 [?1888 check] Maoriland: an Illustrated Handbook USSCo (And)]

FEATON Pohutukawa [Maori name] .. Christmas tree [Settlers' name] .. Metrosideros tomentosa .. Tree (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,178)

KIRK (And) Metrosideros tomentosa (1889,Forest Flora)

Pohutukawa (Christmas-tree) .. Metrosideros tomentosa .. Wood deep red colour, dense and durable; ... (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,13)

BOYD (1900,Our Stolen Summer) [NOTES: (And)]

SATCHELL The boys on the [Northland] station were getting the big shed ready for a dance ... another young man ... was engaged in looping up garlands of `waiwaikoko' or owl's-foot moss, together with branches of Christmas tree, aflame with blood-red flowers. (1905,Toll of the Bush,236)

WHITE They are called the Christmas-tree because they flower about that time. (1905,My NZ Garden,87)

CHEESEMAN M[etrosideros] tomentosa, A.Rich. ... Pohutukawa; Christmas-tree. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,166)

COCKAYNE (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And) Also 1919]

(And) Metrosideros tomentosa, New Zealand Christmas-tree (1916,Official Trade Register of Nurserymen)

(1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue) [NOTES: (And)]

MULGAN He ... looked up past the still leaves of the Christmas tree to the darkening blue of the sky. (1934,Spur of Morning,197)

LAING & BLACKWELL Metrosideros excelsa (The Christmas Tree) ... Maori name Pohutukawa. [Contrast 1907, 288: By the settlers, the tree [now Metrosideros excelsa ] is often known as the Christmas Tree, because it flowers about the end of the year.] (1940,Plants of NZ,299)

Christmas tree : tree with red flowers, pohutukawa. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,1Q73)

~ A name for the New Zealand pohutukawa, a large coastal tree of the myrtle family, whose scarlet flowers appear in midsummer. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),73)

christmas tree n, usu cap C 1 b NewZeal : POHUTUKAWA (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,400)

Christmas tree n. in Australia the Christmas bush; in N.Z. the pohutukawa [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

SARGESON ... and a great Christmas tree in flower reached out far enough to colour the tide. (1977,Never Enough!,11)

Christmas tree ... 3. N.Z. another name for the pohutukawa. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,197) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 127; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 84]]

n. (Marine) a form of mussel-farming rope

Rope for Sale - 5 coils of 12mm black and 2 coils of xmas tree. (Oct 7, 1981,Marlborough Sounds Mar. Farm. Ass. Newsletter,5)

They [spats] were washed off - 100 mm lengths of 'Christmas tree' (QE1 trim, Quality Equipment Limited) spat settlement rope ... (Mar 2006,Aquaculture,252/1)

Menzel 'Christmas tree' rope, a black polypropylene rope incorporating sacking offcuts to increase it surface area, is the preferred spat-catching medium [in New Zealand mussel farming]. (1991,Estuarine and Marine Bivalve Mollusk Culture,330)

Christopher Columbus¶

exclam. a mild euphemistic oath [1953 15 M A26 Thames DHS 5 CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS]

chrome dome¶

n. a bald man

chrome dome: baldie (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: 1981 Feb Avondale College (Auckland) Slang Words in Use (Goldie Brown Collection)]

chryssie¶

n. (informal) chrysanthemum [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

People who saw, as Bethell did, both defiance and beauty in their "chryssies". (Jul 1, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),44)

chrystie¶

n. (usu pl.) a chrysanthemum

Colourful chrysties - chrysanthemums that is. (Apr 9, 1987,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: (Jack Forsythe, fruit market commentator)]

chu that splor¶

phr. [[?Chiv : Burton's transcription error.]]

BURGESS When he shortly returned he said, I had to chu that splor' - meaning thereby that he stabbed Mathieu. <i>Ibid.</i> 133 ... Sullivan took the handkerchief and threw it into the sea saying,that belongs to Phil, but there is blood on it that came from the splor we strangled. ...' (1866,Confessions,125,1983 ed.)

chub¶

n. a short, thick cooked sausage totally enclosed at both ends by the skin.

Wardells advertising insert TOTAL PET FOOD - 2.25 kg CHUB (Feb 22, 1982,Evening Post)

n. a chap, joker.

... and the barman, he's the hatchman,/ (Not a bad sort of chub.) (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,82)

2 n. a stubby loaf of bread

chuck a spaz¶

phr. throw a tantrum [also pack a spaz below]

He has been planning how his district will deal with the possibility of non-functioning utilities and general chaos if computerdom does chuck a spaz at having to deal with the unaccustomed digits of the year 2000. (Apr 24, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

And you thought frilled lizards looked ugly when they pack a spaz. (Sep 22, 2001,Evening Post,18)

chuck off at¶

v. deride, mock

Hosking's terminal uncoolness gave Hawkesby, and all those anchoresses who sailed before her, a chance to chuck off at him so they could develop a running gag with the urbane female fatale poking fun at the neurotic male. (Nov 2, 2004,Dominion Post,A17)

chuck-in¶

n. a bargain; a bonus; an advantageous happening.

McHUTCHESON ... the watch was a `chuck in' at [dollars]40 ... (1888,New Zealander Abroad, The,84) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

Fancy landing thousands of the starving humans from Bull's country, where the wheels of industry were stopped for some weeks in an ineffectual attempt to obtain a living wage of FIVE SHILLINGS a day. What a chuck-in for the local squatters! (May 11, 1912,NZ Truth,359/4/4)

HULME I hear a cleaning woman at the station say, `Imagine what it does to me, coming in every morning and seeing all this chunder lying around.' (1986,Te Kaihau)

chuckaway¶

n. throwaway newspaper

`Uhu', Owen said. His head was in the local chuckaway, from which he read an advertisement. (Jun 1955,Numbers,3/8)

chucker-in¶

1 n. (Rural) [sheep dipping] a worker responsible for throwing sheep into the dipping pool.

In the small final pen, two hands were stationed. These .. were called the 'dry-chuckers-in.' The berth of dry-chucker-in was one of some dignity, because upon these officers devolved the responsibility of keeping tally of the number of sheep washed. (1888,Textile Educator I,262)

But the berth of the wet-chucker-in is certainly no sinecure .. the wet sheep are heavy, frightened, and stubborn ... (1888,Textile Educator I,263)

chucker-out¶

n.

ELKINGTON The "chucker-out," a sturdy little Swede, was kept very busy. (1906,Adrift in NZ,237)

chuckie¶

n. (See chookie,chooky)

chuckie-chuck¶

n. [Note that Gaultheria spp. are endemic in NZ, except for G. depressa of Tasmania. Gaultheria names in Biggs not suggestive; possibly a SI error or confused application of say kotukutuku. Check Williams. Used only by Potts (Canterbury), and Mrs Praed (Aust.). NZ Contemp. Dict is a crib from Morris. The calyx of Gaultheria spp. eaten as a fruit, (prob. G. antipoda Forst. f).]

Two other Gaultheriae are very distinct; one, of prostrate habit, bears a round white flower, which is eaten, under the name of `Chuckiechuck.' [check this cit.] (1871,TrNZI,3/194) [NOTES: (Potts)]

When out of breath, hot and thirsty, how one longed for a handful of chuckie-chucks. In their season how good we used to think these fruits of the gaultheria, or rather its thickened calyx. A few handfuls were excellent in quenching one's thirst, and so plentifully did the plant abound that quantities could soon be gathered. ... [The] notable [pioneer housekeepers] sometimes encouraged children to collect sufficient chuckie-chucks to make preserve.[sic] The result was a jam of a sweet mawkish flavour that gave some idea of a whiff caught in passing a hair-dresser's shop. (1891,Country Journal,15/198) [NOTES: 1891 T.H. Potts `Out in the Open', NZ Country Journal Vol XV/198 (Morris)]

Chucky-chucky, n. native berry [Abo]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),613)

chucks¶

n. a knucklebone game

SUTTON-SMITH Knucklebones (K-34) was played in both Europe and Polynesia, independently at first. In the nineteenth century distinct European [177] and Maori versions were known. More recently, the two types have merged, and today the Maori children, who are mainly responsible for perpetuating the game in New Zealand, include in their games movements borrowed from the European tradition. ... In most of the provinces the game was known as Knucklebones, and it is widely reported as having been played by New Zealand children of European origin until about 1900. Occasionally it was known as Chucks, Chuckstones, Chuckystones, Fingerstones, Hucklebones, Jacks, Jackstones, Knuckles, or Knucklestones. Children still played it here and there throughout the country in 1949, but they knew little about it until plastic knuckles were imported in 1954 in large quantities and revived the game. (1972,Folkgames of Children,176)

chuckstones¶

n. a form of knucklebones

SUTTON-SMITH Knucklebones (K-34) was played in both Europe and Polynesia, independently at first. In the nineteenth century distinct European [177] and Maori versions were known. More recently, the two types have merged, and today the Maori children, who are mainly responsible for perpetuating the game in New Zealand, include in their games movements borrowed from the European tradition. ... In most of the provinces the game was known as Knucklebones, and it is widely reported as having been played by New Zealand children of European origin until about 1900. Occasionally it was known as Chucks, Chuckstones, Chuckystones, Fingerstones, Hucklebones, Jacks, Jackstones, Knuckles, or Knucklestones. Children still played it here and there throughout the country in 1949, but they knew little about it until plastic knuckles were imported in 1954 in large quantities and revived the game. (1972,Folkgames of Children,176)

chucky-chucky¶

n. (See chuckie-chuck)

chud¶

n. a short form of chuddy [1953 17 M A38 Thames DHS 22A CHUD -->1960 17C M B8 Wanganui Girls C.I 22A CHUD -->1984 14 F E120Wgton Girls C. 22A CHUD]

chuddy gum/chutty gum¶

n. chewing gum, chuddy

Today they'll [sc. 13-year-old girls] will perform the Kamasutra with any boy who'll share his chuddy gum. (Mar 16, 2000,Dominion,10)

Another young body among so many. Another piece of sexual chuddy gum. Notes (Jan 24, 1999,Sunday Star Times,D2)

chutty-gum: chewing gum (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

chuddy/chutty¶

n. chewing gum [1953 13-17 M A2 Thames DHS 22A CHUDDY [M17] -->1960 17C M B7 Hamilton H.S. 22A CHUDDY -->1960 18C F B12 Horowhenua C. 22A CHUDDY]

"Still to come - the history of chutty." (Feb 11, 1992,TV3,Nightline)

SUTTON-SMITH Brin saw a boy put a big lump of "chutty" on the top of the seat in front. (1950,Our Street,19) [NOTES: 1975 edition]

LAWLOR Jan. 15. Wally gave me some chuddy. It's corker for playing games with ... You will not find the word 'chuddy' in the Oxford Dictionary. In my boyhood days it was the equivalent of today's chewing gum, but different in shape or for mastication.. The generation of 'chuddy' per medium of teeth, tongue and saliva was a minor work of art. (1962,More Wellington Days,53) [NOTES: Quote from 1904 diary]

In fact, the artists don't chew chuddy. They have developed a method of "chewing" the gum buy [sic] warming it in a microwave and "washing" it to get the colour they want. (Aug 7, 2002,Capital Times,11)

HILLIARD `Better have some chuddy,' said Tom. (1960,Maori Girl,152)

HILLIARD They were all chewing chuddy, smoking, tramping butts into the litter on the floor. (1963,Piece of Land, A,32)

TURNER Some words, like lollies for sweets or candy are shared with those adults who talk to children; others like chutty (or chuddy) `chewing gum' are a child's equivalent for different adult words; ... (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,179)

SUTTON-SMITH Chuddy - now called `chewing gum' - was then [c1910] in the zenith of its popularity. (1981,History of Children's Play,228)

chuddy n. N.Z. inf. chewing gum. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,198) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 127; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 85]]

McGILL chuddy or chutty chewing gum. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,28)

BAKER In constant use by our youngsters [is] ... chutty. (1941,NZ Slang,51)

A boy put a big lump of `chutty' on the top of the seat in front. (1950,Our Street,35)

FRAME `O.K., chief' was best said while you were chewing chutty or chewing gum, drawing the chutty out of your mouth ... and stretching it as you watched the adult alarm at this apparent irresponsibility ... (1982,To the Is-Land,90)

[heading] Not even a pack of chuddy? ..Finance Minister Michael Cullen has given a strong hint he may ditch the small and widely derided "chewing gum" tax cut promised for 2006. ..This is a clear signal that they are likely taking the chewing gum out of the chewing gum budget. (Feb 14, 2006,Dominion Post,A1)

chuffer¶

n. (See Benghazi boiler,thermette)

HUGHES A bombardier then explained that a handful of propellant from a 105mm cartridge dropped into the orifice of a portable hot water boiler (commonly known as a chuffer) is guaranteed to produce brew water in less than thirty seconds. Ibid. 85 These clever cylindrical devices have a hollow core where the twigs or other fuel burns. Around the heating core is a vessel that contains the water. The hollow core forms a chimney with quite a strong draught and of course nearly all the heat acts on the walls of the vessel and it boils water very efficiently in just a few minutes. (1999,Shooting from the Lip,84)

chuffers¶

n. behind, chuff, (the cheeks of) the arse

MORRIESON >We're not going to prove anything ... sitting up here on our chuffers. (1974,Predicament,89,1981 ed.)

chug¶

v. (informal) down (an alcoholic or other drink), especially quickly or without pausing. [(also as noun the downing of a drink quickly or without pausing; a drinking bout.)] (See chug-a-lug)

McGILL chug to drink alcohol; chugalug act of drinking, usually a beer, in one gulp, or a drinking bout; eg `Fancy a few chugs after work, Nobby?' ANZ. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,28)

Ihimaera The Aussie had jumped on the table, chugged as many jugs as he could, burped and pulled down his trou. (2000,Uncle's Story, The,143)

chug-a-lug¶

n. a noisy swig of liquor

SLIGO All dancing around, passing the whisky bottle after a good swig ... and trying a few passes and a few more chug-a-lugs. (1987,Final Things,100)

chugger¶

n. [short for Charity Mugger]

Every time I'm in the city I'm approached by Charity Muggers (Chuggers), earnest people who want me to save whales/bears/my mortal soul. (Feb 11, 2006,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10) [NOTES: note international use but not in OED, nor AND, nor Webster's online dict.]

chukky¶

n. a piece of stone in coal (cf. chuck n.); a pebble used in a game of knucklebones (See also chucks,chuckstones)

West Coast miners call these [bits of stone in coal] chukkies, another north-country term. A chukky in the north was (and is) a pebble, and the children's game of knuckle-bones was there called chukkies or chukky-stones, played not with sheep's bones but with pebbles. It was - like skipping-ropes - a purely female sport and no six-year-old male chauvinist would touch a chukky - unless he wanted to use it as a projectile. (May 2, 1981,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

chum¶

n. (See also chummy; new chum,old chum)

COOK Who is the big, smiling chum gettin' out the luggage? ... came out to learn sheep farming, eh? (1925,Far Flung,14)

MASTERS The chum thought the story sounded feasible, so he wrote home [a1900] and told his people about it. (1959,Tales of the Mails,69)

2 n. an English soldier

MacDONALD A `chum' whom we picked up on the way in. (1945,Way from Home,124)

chum in¶

v.

MONEY ... camps affably with savages, `chums in' with diggers, ... (1871,Knocking About in NZ,viii) [NOTES: 1871 Marcus Clarke in Money Knocking About in NZ viii]

chummy¶

n. a new chum

Well they know me on the Murray/ When the tally boards are full/ With the `chummies', hurry-scurry/ To their eyes in sweat and wool; (Sep 8, 1889,Sydney Bulletin) [NOTES: 1889 Sept 8 Sydney Bulletin in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 121]

Chunder¶

n. a nickname for an Egyptian.

... so questioned Chunder' (a walid, who, for a few piastres per week, acted asbatman' to myself and a couple of mates. (Jun 15, 1918,Kia-ora Coo-ee,4/15,1981 ed.)

chunder¶

n. vomit; an act of vomiting

[Cartoon] I see by your diploma in beer swilling and pie throwing that you passed the chunder-mile with honours! (Jan 24, 2002,Capital Times,8 ed.)

GEBBIE & McGREGOR Not too many years ago the New Zealand diner's wine-tastes stopped at a bottle of Waihirere Sauterne followed by a chunder on the carpet. (1979,Incredible 8-Ounce Dream,15)

[cartoon: after-match function] By cripes that trip was a beauty eh - thirteen tries, forty jugs, twenty whiskeys and six chunders (Sep 27, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

Four bottles [of beer] is said to test the digestive system to the limit and is almost impossible to keep down and so usually leads to what is called a `power chunder' or projectile vomiting. (Mar 13, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,16)

Hans Huik said most people on the boat "had a chunder", while the ferry was tossed around "like a rubber duckie in a busy bath". (Sep 1, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14) [NOTES: Originally in Manawatu Evening SAtanbdard 23/7/01]

Imagine what it does to me, coming in every morning and seeing all this chunder lying round (Apr 1979,Islands,7(3) No. 25 : 237)

n. vomit

The three-hour ferry ride has a rough reputation ("You're going on the chunder boat?" gasped a friend who hadn't been on it)... (Jul 11, 2004,Sunday Star Times: Escape,10)

Over the ditch in the northern Victorian town of Greater Shepperton, the local council has just introduced a chunder tax. (Jul 9, 2002,Independent Herald (Wellington),17)

A rather stuffy announcement.. signals some anxiety about a chunder mile spewing down Kelburn parade to the organiser's front door. (May 22, 2002,Capital Times,3)

v. to vomit, spew, esp. after excessive drinking

ELDRED-GRIGG 'What a hoot!' yelled the others. 'Al's chundered again!' (1995,Mum,148)

For Christ's sake!' says the medal ...not there, eh? Don't chunder there, boy.' (1971,NZ Short Stories III,194) [NOTES: 1971 O'Sullivan `Mavvy Phoenix' in 1975 NZ Short Stories III 194]

McLEOD Then this friend of Nigel's ...chundered all over the supper table. (1976,Girl Like I, A,171)

BALLANTYNE Rhodes grimaced. `I chundered somewhere along the way.' (1978,Talkback Man,115)

LELAND Chunder: a term which is used freely by people who engage in occasional massive over-indulgence in alcoholic beverages: regurgitate. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,26)

chunder: to vomit, esp. after drinking beer (1980,Lynfield College, Auckland) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

chunder: vomit (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

COX `Some fuckwit chundered in our bed - lucky I didn't have to sleep in it!' She laughed, pleased by something. (1984,Einstein)

chunder v.i. NZ & Austral. colloq. vomit. Also n. [orig. uncert.] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,127) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 85]]

Philippa Swan 'Erica, I've been wondering, do you remember when you chundered in someone's letterbox after the DD Smash concert?' (2006,Six Pack, The,49)

All natural-born hams who could pull a scene from Robert De Niro, they were charging around, popping up behind every bush, chundering over the side of boats, firing guns and getting closeups galore and I was fighting for a place. (Feb 4, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

chunder a custard¶

phr. to vomit (esp. after too much liquor) [ca1960 (Auckland V. O'Sullivan)]

chunder bunny¶

n. someone with a weak capacity for beer

A game called Anchorman played by the students at one of the University of Otago's Halls of Residence, requires participants to consume six jugs of ale in four hours without being sick. The reward is an Anchorman's badge. ... Although it has been banned by college authorities ... [it is] regarded as a way of sorting out Men' from thechunder bunnies' or `coma kids'. To become an Anchorman is to be like an anchor which stands firm even when completely submerged. (Mar 13, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,16)

chunder out¶

v. (figurative)

Anyone can master the trick of chundering out soundbites for the all-important TV news. (Aug 26, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

chundering¶

n. vomiting [1981 citation belongs with verb]

There was much mess, some chundering, and a great deal of laughter. (Mar 23, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

My daughter's chundering on the Axminster because some prick called Kim who drives a red Porsche has sold her ecstasy. (Jun 1999,Metro,50)

Chundering, whales and a faint aurora punctuated the five nights sailing to the Chathams. (Oct 30, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),52)

KIDMAN The plane rocked dangerously ... There was much talk of chundering. Most of them were hungover. (1982,Mrs Dixon and Friend,143)

McGEE Been out chundering, can't hold your piss, eh? (1981,Foreskin's Lament,81)

chunderously¶

adv.

The underlying philosophy of social democracy - whoever is trying to define it - can sound chunderously mother-and-apple-pie, which is why it probably never will become a household brand. (Apr 1, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

chundiferous¶

adj.

A mile south of us is the Akatarawa Road, famous for its narrow chundiferous corners, and infamous as a dropping-off spot for unwanted pets. (Jul 18, 2001,Capital Times,2)

chunk honey¶

1 n. (Rural) comb honey cut in pieces.

Chunk Honey Production: A proftable sideline in bee-keeping.[hdg] A form of honey which has a great appeal to many people is that called 'chunk honey' in which large frames of comb honey are cut into strips and fitted into glass jars, the space around the strips being filled with light-coloured liquid honey. (Aug 26, 1936,Weekly News,74)

chupa-chup-sucking¶

adj.

A journo friend has convinced me this television "phenomenon" is luring more than just chupa-chup-sucking 10-year-olds. (Mar 12, 2000,Dominion Sunday Times,F7)

chur bro¶

exclam.

A project on slang saw the Lytton third formers explain that "chur bro" was a greeting and "going off man" meant really neat, and the Welsh students said "munting" meant ugly, "Mosher" was someone who liked grunge music, and "skank" meant not fair. (Jul 3, 1997,NZ Infotech Weekly,21)

church mouse¶

n. a threepenny bit, ?the smallest silver coin that could be respectably put in the plate. -->

SANSOM A row of oyster bottles - like glass pickle-bottles - in the fish-shed, was the first bank', but depositors put their coins into these bottles not for themselves ... The bottles were labelledPennies', Church Mice' (that was the threepence),Bobs' (the shillings) and `Scotsman's Half-Crown (the florin). (1970,Stewart Islanders,125)

churchie¶

n. church-goer

They're a bunch of hard-core churchies, aren't they? (Oct 15, 1997,Dominion,8)

Churchill¶

n. monkfish (from a fancied resemblance to a bulldog in appearance of head)

SORENSON MONKFISH (a) Scientific name: (i) Geniagnus monopterygius (ii) Kathetostoma giganteum. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (both) Whitefish. (c) Other common names: (both) Monkfish, Monks, Stargazer, Flathead (also applied at times to export gurnard); Churchills, Toebiters, Bulldogs, Spotted Stargazer, Maori Chief (Dunedin); Muddies. (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Cook Strait, Nelson, Banks Peninsula, Bluff-Stewart Island. ... Monkfish is a general term for species of the Families Uranoscopidae and Leptoscopidiae. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,37)

[species name] stargazer .. [scientific name] Kathetostoma giganteum .. [other name(s)] monkfish, boofs, bulldogs, churchills, flathead monk, giant stargazer, monks, muddies, spotted stargazer, toebiters, whitefish, sandcod (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

churn¶

n. short for churn rate (see ODE)

Churn - the measure of subscriber losses - was 21 per cent at the half-year on December. (Jun 22, 2002,Dominion,15)

The "churn" was still high for New Zealand... "By the middle of summer, if we've got numbers down at 10,000 or 12,000 churn per month, then I think we've got a problem with the market really," he said. (Oct 31, 2001,Dominion,20)

...evidence of how consumers value the product is that we have had very little churn. (Aug 4, 2002,Sunday Star Times,E1)

churn fee¶

n. charge for changing services

Telecom has made significant changes to its proposed broadband wholesale plan, but has retained its controversial "churn fee". (Jul 27, 2004,Dominion Post,C2)

churning¶

n. a batch of butter or cheese

In the early days of the 'Co-op' all except two churnings were sent to Wellington for shipment to the 'homeland' on the ship Tongariro. (Aug 2001,NZ Memories,No. 31/52)

chut¶

n. vagina [1945 Wellington]

chute¶

n. the passage or ramp from which shorn sheep leave the shearing board and shed.

SCRYMGEOUR ... rousies, and even young Jim, who was assisting to pen up, followed out from the side door to where the shoots from the stands gave the nearest exit, to the level space of the outside turf, that made eventually the [boxing] ring. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,50)

Chute: Ramp from the porthole in a shearing shed taking sheep to a lower level. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53)

chute ... NZ & Austral. ramp by which sheep leave shearing shed. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,128) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

chute: Also called the `porthole', this is a low opening and ramp through which the shorn sheep are passed down to the counting out pen. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/23) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

1 n. (Rural) [high country mustering] a steep narrow access between rocks. (See chimney,staircase,snowchute)

LOUGHNAN shoot or shute: the pedantic would call it chute. A narrow, newly eroded and steep-sided gut cutting down through the tussock-clad hillside. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,725)

HALL I then rushed down a little rock chute, taking a gamble that it was the shortest way down. (1987,Shepherd's Year, A,70)

HOLDEN But he slipped trying to get across an icy chute and went down the thing. (1991,Fall Muster,24)

HOLDEN In the head of a chute-like gully a bull thar was looking up at him. (1996,Great Hunting Yarns,195)

STACEY The shingle basin I was in came to a chute which shot over a lip of rock to land on the shingle far below. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,71)

2 n. a shearing shed designed on a different plan from the conventional board type.

BOWEN Competition was held in true shed conditions, the five-stand chute-shed being conducted in the same way as for its usual shearing activities. Ibid. 110 These two plans illustrate the two main types of shed - the board shed and the chute shed. [check to define] (1955,Wool Away!,109)

(Feb 23, 1956,NZ Farmer,10)

chute cowshed¶

n. a shed which cows are held in a straight line for milking at the side so that they all enter and leave the shed together.

Chute cowshed. Where cows are held in a straight line for milking at the side. They all enter and leave the shed together (now obs). (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,39)

chute shed¶

n. (Rural) an early design of cowshed [see citation].

MAF Chute: Where cows are held in a straight line for milking at the side. They all enter and leave the shed together. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,39)

1 n. (Rural) a design of woolshed.

BOWEN In many chute sheds a raised board is used. (1955,Wool Away!,117)

"A South Island farmer once said this to me : 'I don't like a chute shed.'" (Feb 23, 1956,NZ Farmer,10)

BOWEN Competition was held in true shed conditions, the five-stand chute-shed being conducted in the same way as for its usual shearing activities. (1955,Wool Away!,109)

BOWEN These two plans illustrate the two main types of shed - the board shed and the chute shed. (1955,Wool Away!,110)

BOWEN In a chute shed a shearer does not have to cross the board or go so far for his sheep, for it is caught right behind the machine. (1955,Wool Away!,111)

MILLS At Wyndham an idea was discovered which is commended to all owners of chute sheds. ..the hinged trapdoor over the porthole. 1964 NZ Farmer Dec 31. 6 It is an internal chute shed with tally pens under the floor. 2. 1982 MAF Agric. Glossary 39 Chute: Where cows are held in a straight line for milking at the side. They all enter and leave the shed together. (1960,Sheep-O,66)

chutney¶

n. in New Zealand, a preserve made with fruit

In New Zealand, chutney, is most often made with fruit, including dried fruit such as raisins. It is usually sweeter than a pickle, and is cooked long enough to develop a thick, jammy consistency. There is a fresh chutney which is made of chopped fresh fruit, herbs or coconut and is served as soon as it is ready. Fresh chutney is closer in style to the original chatni, the Indian word from which chutney is derived, than to the savoury jam that we call chutney, which had its origins in Britain. (May 15, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

CIB¶

abbr. Criminal Investigation Branch [ORIGIN: acronym]

C.I.B. abbrev. for Criminal Investigation Branch (of the New Zealand and Australian police). (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,199) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 128; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 85]]

cicada¶

n. Amphipsalta cingulata (See also scorpion fly)

[Caption] The red grub at right is a nymph of the common clapping cicada (Amphipsalta cingulata), cause of the happy commotion that is the soundtrack of a New Zealand summer. (Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/71)

cigarette trousers¶

n. stovepipe trousers (or merely descriptive?)

ANTHONY They were accompanied by a dudish looking young man in about the weirdest-looking suit I ever saw. ... It went in at the waist until it was a wonder the poor devil wearing it didn't snap in half with the strain, and the trousers were of the cigarette variety. [ibid 134] The cheap stuff his suit was made of kept on shrinking and shrinking, and his cigarette trousers had climbed nearly up to his knees. (1927,Gus Tomlins,128) [NOTES: (1977 ed Sturm)]

cill¶

n.

Downstream from the opening, one or more large timber balks known as cills were laid across the stream. Timber planks were laid over these cills and also fixed vertically on the downstream sides of the opening in the dam, or gateway, to form the flume of the dam. (Sep 1991,Historic Places,28)

Cinderella-ise¶

v.

"The thought they could marginalise us and Cinderella-ise us", he says, adding a new verb to the language. (Aug 21, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

cinema of unease¶

phr. phrase coined by Sam Neill for the darkness of some New Zealand films

The phrase "cinema of unease" was a too-neat title to sum up an increasingly diverse film practice - it locked the New Zealand tradition into a permanent early-80s of Bruno Lawrence road movies and male self-loathing, with the forces of law and order always closing in (okay, the ultimate "unease" film is therefore Smash Palace). (Oct 18, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

cineraria¶

n.

ADAMS On coarse shingle or sandy shores a bright-magenta, yellow-centered daisy with divided, rather succulent leaves is a conspicuous coastal plant sometimes called wild cineraria. Botanical name: Senecio elegans, South Africa. Family: Compositae. (1980,Wild Flowers,36)

circle¶

n. a one-year sentence [ca1930 P and D] (See cf. moon)

circling disease¶

n. (Rural) listeriosis, a brain disease of sheep, of which a symptom is walking in circles.

Circling disease of sheep is a condition in which there is an infectious inflammation of the animal's brain and its covering membranes. It is called 'circling' because one of the symptoms shown is a tendency to turn in a circle ... (May 20, 1933,NZ Journal of Agriculture,251)

Since 'circling disease' occurs, with few exceptions in the late summer and early winter, it is not likely to be the more mature larvae that are causing it ... (May 20, 1933,NZ Journal of Agriculture,253)

EDGAR Circling disease (Listeriosis) symptoms: walking in circles or aimless wandering. (1959,NZ Farmers' Veterinary Guide,116)

circular¶

n. ellipt. for circular saw.

BAINES A circular to work effectively requires - speed, to be perfectly well sharpened, a strong spindle, a wide and not over-tight belt, water on the saw, fully ten-horse power to drive her, and two men with life in them to work her. (1874,Edward Crewe,181)

MANDER They watched the progress of the log from the booms up the skids to the side of the breakdown platform... Halved and quartered, it was then levered ... on to greased rollers and rushed towards the big circulars, which turned it into flitches. Then the small circulars, the drag, and the goose completed its metamorphosis into the regulation strips ... (1920,Story of a NZ River, The,198,1960 ed.)

circular file¶

n. wastepaper basket

...throw it in the circular file. (Nov 7, 2003,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Nine to Noon]

circular saw¶

n. a marine mollusc, Astraea spp.

On the deck, circular saw shells crawl across the sand and shell rubble, and trumpet shells sit in the darker areas near the sides. (Nov 1, 2003,Dominion Post,E9)

POWELL CIRCULAR SAW (Astraea heliotropium). This requires no description. It occurs throughout New Zealand. (1947,Animals of NZ, The,25)

McLINTOCK CIRCULAR SAW (Astraea heliotropium). This aptly named shellfish requires no description. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/352)

NATUSCH 11. Circular saw, Astraea. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,73)

circulating-medium¶

n. a dogcart

CRESSWELL Here Fitzgerald, the Provincial Superintendent was waiting, and after treating the party to strawberries and cream, took the Bishop and Mrs Harper into Christchurch in his `circulating-medium'. This curiously named dogcart the Superintendent had made himself. It had a pair of wheels 8 or 9 feet high, and though generally driven tandem, Fitzgerald sometimes used in it 3 or even 4 horses. (1951,Canterbury Tales,29)

Upper Hutt Mayor Rex Kirton greeted news of the CIT closure last week by saying he was "gutted: and angry with CIT management and governance over the past few years. (Apr 18, 2001,Evening Post,5)

[Hdg] 120 CIT staff lose jobs. One hundred and twenty staff have been made redundant with the closure of Upper Hutt's Central Institute of Technology. (Jul 5, 2001,Evening Post,5)

The Citizens' All Black Tour Association (no Maoris, no tour) was formed. (Jul 14, 2001,Evening Post,31)

Cits and Rats¶

n. Auckland Citizens and Ratepayers organisation

He was a stalwart of the Natonal Party's back rooms and active in Citzens & Ratepayers (often called "Cits & Rats"), the "National Party-in-drag" organisation which has controlled Auckland City politics since the 1930s. (Apr 1998,North & South,53)

City of Blazes¶

n. Gore

The Gore Historical Society tells us that Gore was once known as the 'City of Blazes'. In the 21 years between 1897 and 1918, 62 shops and businesses in the town were destroyed by fire. (Feb 2001,NZ Memories,21)

City of Gales¶

n. Wellington - a misplaced forerunner of City of Sails?

No citation taken. (Apr 26, 1919,NZ Observer,19)

City of Sails¶

n.

Clearly, no one's told her a fear and loathing of the City of Sails is one of the quiet joys of being a New Zealander. (Feb 14, 1999,Sunday Star Times,D2)

Auckland wants to do away with its slogan "City of Sails", and Hamilton is no longer happy with its frankly mad brag, "Hamilton Where It's Happening." (Aug 28, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

McGILL City of Sails Auckland, which has more yachts to the nautical mile than anywhere else in either hemisphere, okay? (1989,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,20)

MORRISON Auckland is often called, by simplemistake, the 'City of Sails,' though whenthis objectionable cliche was beingcoined it was likely that it reallyreferred to a 'city of sales.' (1989,Auckland City & Sea,[5])

We are the City of Sails, after all. (Sep 10, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

Kirton was visiting family in King Country prior to the game, but his air ticket had expired meaning he was unable to travel to the City of Sails. (Sep 9, 2010,Rugby News,19)

SIERS Regatta Day.. usually provides the most spectacular turnout of Auckland's fleet of pleasure boats, but even this major fixture in the City of Sails was eclipsed by the 1986 start of the Whitbread Round the World Race. (1986,Above Auckland,115)

TEMPLE & APSE Known as the 'City of Sails'. Auckland has been one of the regular staging points for the Whitbread Round the World Yacht Race... The 'City of Sails has the biggest one-day regatta in the world. (1986,New Zealand From the Air,20)

We're the City of Sails, the harbour's our playground. (1991,NZ Books,17)

City of Snails¶

n. Auckland (a play on City of Sails)

The prospect of being named City of Snails had goaded them into action. (Nov 11, 2001,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: http://www.act.org.nz/news-article.aspx/21650]

And we even remembered to bring a bottle or two back when we returned to the City of Snails. (2001,Internet - see Notes,2) [NOTES: http://www.thefix.co.nz/drinksmanship/307.drinksmanship.1.phtml]

Auckland is a popular home for slugs and snails - in fact it is sometimes jokingly referred to as "City of Snails"! (Dec 2005,NZ Gardener,115)

It's an act of sacrifice to try and speed up the city of snails... (Jun 9, 2003,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: http://www.darkness.net.nz/archives/000134.html]

Better even than Auckland, which Hobson made the capital - the first mayor, Archibald Clark, is buried in this small city of snails along with merchants (Robert the "rope manufacturer") and military veterans (George, a veteran of the Burma War and who served in the Madras horse Artillery). (Nov 13, 2005,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),58)

Auckland's commuters have had three wet winters and are halfway through a damp spring. This is how things are done in the City of Snails. (Oct 3, 2004,Sunday Star Times,A13)

City of the Plains¶

n. Christchurch

Some call her the Cathedral City, the most English City, the City of the Plains. (Aug 1, 1928,NZ Free Lance,18)

PUBLIC MEETING AT CHRISTCHURCH. ... this `City of the Plains' has become the scene of the first political demonstration in the Canterbury settlement ... (Aug 23, 1851,Lyttelton Times,7)

It [the bittern] was once very common about Christchurch, `the City of the Plains,' it still haunts the banks of the Avon, and breeds in the neighbouring swamps. (1870,TrNZI,2/69) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

HOPEFUL Well, to begin with, it is generally called the `City of the Plains', and is named after Christ Church, Oxford - and well indeed it deserves its former title; ... (1887,Taken In,75)

WILSON Christchurch, the city of the plains, on three sides is bounded by wide roads ... (1894,In the Land of the Tui,35) [NOTES: 1889 Sep in 1894 Wilson Land of the Tui 35]

PICARD Got loose in the garden city of Maoriland ... Here's Cathedral Square, the centre of the City of the Plains ... (1906,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,34)

THOMPSON From the Bluff I shipped to Christchurch or the City of the Plains,/ As the cultured people call it .../ (1909,Ballads about Business,92)

GUTHRIE St. Christopher [Christchurch] is called the city of the plains. (1935,Little Country, The,105,1937 ed.)

SLATTER Christchurch, The City of The Plains, a city of long straight streets and the gently curving Avon, a fine city. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,76)

SCRYMGEOUR Wallie was rather lethargic socially, but did enjoy the jaunts around the agricultural areas, situated near the environs of the city of `The Plains'. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,152)

civil defence emergency¶

phr. a civil defence emergency, national, regional or local, may be declared in a situation (apart from war) which police and fire services cannot otherwise deal with. [Jim Cameron writes: This term originated in the Civil Defence Act 1983. The earlier equivalent 1962-83 was "major disaster". The Britiish concept of civil defence is a response to enemy action; neither civil defence emergency nor its less formal variant civil emergency (as to which see Dominion 2/12/1999 p1), nor state of emergency is in NSOD or Collins.]

Civil Service Entrance Exam¶

n. a public examination sat in junior secondary school which if passed could lead to an offer of employment in the Public Service; later Public Service Entrance.
