The incentive to obtain licensed interpreters' certificates and Maori being made a subject for the Civil Service Entrance Exams formed the first outside step. Then followed the Matric. (Mar 6, 1929,Na To Hoa Aroha,1/182) [NOTES: (Buck)]

civil union partner¶

n. [cf CUP]

His electorate chairman, Peter Kaiser, who is also his civil union partner, said: "I've got no comment to make," before hanging up the telephone last night. (Sep 22, 2010,Your Weekend,A2)

civil unionise¶

v. join in a civil union

We can now choose to be civilunionised www.civilunions.org.nz. (Dec 29, 2004,Capital Times,p4)

They're goin' to the chapel and they're gonna get married. Well, "civil unionised" anyway. And there won't be any chapel. (Dec 11, 2004,Dominion Post,E15)

Why are you civil unionising? (Apr 20, 2005,Express (Gay & Lesbian Express),10,20 Apr-03 May ed.)

civil-ise¶

v. join in a civil union (See unionise,civil unionise)

My favourite [feel-good phrase] is Brash's support for civil unions which he always champions for "couples in sincere committed relationships". This would, presumably, be as opposed to frivolous, trollopy types which might to get civil-ised just to show off? (Jul 9, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

civilisation¶

n.

He was so far lost to all religious feelings when I was in New Zealand that he would contend that the civilization of the young women was promoted by their living as prostitutes on board the whalers. (Mar 17, 1825,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,415,1932 ed.)

CHAPMAN . - the protection and civilization of the aborigines; (1843,NZ Portfolio,[final page advt] ..)

[=civilising sc. of Maoris] Truth to tell however, the New Zealanders are acute, intelligent Savages, susceptible no doubt of a considerable degree of civilization - (1940,Founding of New Zealand, The,220) [NOTES: 1845 F.Mathew Present State ... of NZ in 1940 Founding of NZ 220]

SELWYN There is some truth in the saying, that the whalefishers impart a considerable amount of civilization to the natives. ... There is much, of course, in the habits of whalers which all must deeply lament; but I have rarely found a station in which advice was not patiently and even thankfully received. (Aug 30, 1848,New Zealand (Selwyn),Part V (Church in the Colonies XX) 99)

4 In these and many other ways the efforts of the Government have been successfully directed to the improvement and civilization of the Maori race. -->1862 Aug 23 Otago Witness 2 [of the natives] He [Mr. Fitzgerald, MP for Ellesmere] then reviewed the present condition of the Maori; it was a state of decay. The civilization that had been going on had been checked, owing in a great degree to the late war. ... The Natives were, however, in a state of retreat from civilization before the wa[r]s, from various causes, such as the loss of power by the old chiefs - a loss that allowed the Natives to fall into a state of political anarchy, because no institutions had been given them in its place. Another cause of decay was, that they had lost the arts of their old life before they had acquired the arts of civilization. (Oct 13, 1858,Memorandum by Native Secretary,105) [NOTES: 1858 Oct 13 Memorandum by Native Secretary in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 105.]

[Maori art] is a vigorous, earnest expression of the minds of the people before their `civilization' commenced. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,177)

2 n. the town when perceived from the country.

PFAFF A party of adventuresome white people in 1860 ... arrived at the Buller ... expressed their desire to return to civilisation, and Mackay, after fixing up some Native Reserves at the Buller, agreed to shepherd them to Massacre bay. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,1)

civilise¶

v. spec. to bring maoris to European ways

SHEPHERD He said Arms is the only sure method of sivilising them that Missionaries were of little or no use. (Mar 25, 1826,Journal) [NOTES: 1826 Mar 25 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 364]

The Missionaries have done much to civilize the New Zealanders both by themselves, and indirectly by educating and sending among them native teachers. (1841,Establishment of New Plymouth Settlement) [NOTES: 1841 Establishment of New Plymouth Colony in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 71]

Marsden had thought that the best approach to mission work would be to `civilise' the Maoris first and then to introduce them to Christianity. (1971,New Zealand's Heritage,1/253)

civiliser¶

n. a Pakeha as a hypocritical example to Maori

MUNDY [Then off went everybody to the races where] many a reeling wretch among the white civilizers of the savage, fell victim to the rum-booters. (1852,Our Antipodes,2/393) [NOTES: 1852 Mundy Our Antipodes 2/393 in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 167]

civilising¶

n. [1851 use is verb]

MORTON Markham thought it was 'a curious Thing that the Chiefs have married of late years often the girls who have been living on Board of Whalers, and I do believe the sailors have done as much towards the Civilizing of the Natives as the Missionaries have, or more.' (1982,Whale's Wake,219) [NOTES: Morton undated. From Transcript of NZ or Recollections of it by E. Markham in the Hocken Library]

SHORTLAND He {Tuhawaiki of Otago) was appealed to as evidence of what they [sc. whalers] had done towards civilizing the New Zealanders. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,81)

civilly unionise¶

v. [-] (See civil unionise)

..kneel down, hold your breathe, gaze into your lovers eyes and propose: "Will you civilly unionise me?" (Jun 2005,Tearaway,27)

cladder¶

n. [Jim writes: Cladder is not recorded in NSOD, Collins or other dictionaries I have consulted but is an obvious derivative of cladding - material used for the outside of a building (Collins) - and unlikely to be distinctive MNZE?]

Where were the cladders with their load of Temuka stone that was not genuine stone but layers of imitation wood painted the colour of stone? (1988,Carpathians, The,147)

claddie¶

n. (See korari)

claddy-stick¶

n. (See korari)

HOOPER `I'll show you how I used to make claddy-stick canoes.' ... Soon he had cut and hollowed a ten-inch length of claddy-stick, pointed a bow ... (1981,Goat Paddock,111)

clag¶

n. thick low cloud or mist [Jim writes: An informant confirms that the term is well-known to Tararua trampers, especially in the form clagged in, meaning that cloud or mist blocks out the surroundings and inhibits or prevents travelling. Clag in is also known and used in Otago, to refer for instance to fog coming over the tops.]

Rising early next morning is still not early enough to beat the clag. (Mar 13, 2004,Dominion Post,E17)

ALLEN Frequently walking on the tops [in the Auckland Islands] is dangerous, if not impossible due to weather, i.e. very strong winds and rain, and worst of all thick clag (low cloud) which makes finding your way nearly impossible, even with a compass. (1997,Wake of the Invercauld,46)

MACLEAN It was not until they reached McGregor in the late afternoon that the cloud finally cloaked the ridge and, even then, occasional glimpses through the clag enabled them to reach Holdsworth. (1994,Tararua : the Story of a Mountain Range,144)

clag in¶

v. (Rural) to cover in cloud and mist.

SUTHERLAND If the valley was clagged in by the weather, then the air-drop would take place on the next fine day. (1998,Sea of Gold, A,48)

SUTHERLAND He worked at a furious pace until the valley became completely clagged in. (1998,Sea of Gold, A,104)

clag-up¶

1 n. (Rural) an obstruction in movement of stock.

GORDON The clag-up was created by Colin Black, the short head marshal, who was trying to muster and count off a cut for an early start on his course. (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,171)

clagged in¶

v.

CHAPPLE It's clagged in around here and we've got a sou'wester. (2002,Te Araroa: the New Zealand Trail,103)

clagged up¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of land and farm activities] obstructed by weather or other factors.

GORDON The hot and humid climate of the hinterland also means early morning mists that completely choke the valleys, and they can stay clagged up till 9 o'clock or later. (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,211)

clagger¶

n.

ANDERSON The mill-hands usually feasted on mutton and clagger (a heavy plum-pudding). (1976,Water Joey,10) [NOTES: 1977 edition]

claggy¶

adj.

The claggy font, newsprint-grey photos, and dismissive "as taken from.." all imply a cheap reprint from the 1909 edition. (Jun 24, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),47)

BORNHOLDT, O'BRIEN, WILLIAMS the rich claggy rind / of the world where / dinosaurs once / were kings (1997,Anthology of NZ Poetry in English, An,179)

claim¶

n. a piece of land marked off or taken for (esp. gold) mining (US Aust.).

SWAINSON Every person desirous of establishing a claim to a particular portion of unoccupied ground, by working in the ordinary method, for alluvial Gold, may have his claim marked out on the following scale, viz., (1) 15 feet frontage to either side of a River. ... (1853,Auckland,161) [NOTES: 1852 Coromandel Gold Field. Provisional Regulations in 1853 Swainson Auckland 161]

... an errant cradle' or a disabledlong tom' or two has been no uncommon sight in the swollen river course of the Aorere, far from the claims of their disconsolate owners. (Aug 5, 1857,Lyttelton Times,5)

HODDER We marked out our `claim' through the bed of the stream, according to the published regulations which allowed twenty square feet of land to each man for surface digging or 30 square feet for deep sinking. (1862,Memories of NZ Life,74)

J.G.WALKER On Saturday we went over into the other gully and watched a man ground-sluicing. Saw him wash out 2 dishes of dirt. He showed us his morning's work, about 1-1/2 oz. and grumbled at that [sic] I wish he had given us the claim. (Jan 12, 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker)) [NOTES: (Central Otago)]

Otago Alluvial claims, River claims, Beach claims, Quartz claims. (1864,AJHR,C-4-7) [NOTES: Regulations under Goldfields Act (1862)]

THATCHER The Golden Crown leader runs right through the claim; ... (1869,Wit and Humour: Local Songs...,25) [NOTES: (Gold)]

NESFIELD We spent many jolly evenings in the claims, and met men in rough flannels and dirty soil-stained moles ... (1881,Chequered Career,75)

Claim (kl&amacr.m), n. [Add.] Prospecting claim. See under PROSPECTING. - Reward claim. See under REWARD. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2020)

claim n. piece of land appropriated for mining purposes; then the mine itself. [also U.S.A.]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

McARA Claim: A title to mine issued by the Warden's Court under the Mining Act. A claim might be granted for any period up to 42 years. An annual rental was payable. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),316)

claim ... NZ & Austral. piece of land allotted for mining. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,131) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 203, sense 8; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 87]]

n. [see beach claim, dredging claim, wet claim, et al. 2 citations here, wide variety of claims listed]

WEKEY Claims shall be classified thus;- 1. Ordinary Claims, i.e., alluvial claims worked without the aid of sluices or machines. 2. Sluice and machine claims, i.e., alluvial claims worked with the aid of sluices or puddling machines. 3. Wet Claims, i.e., alluvial claims in flooded ground ... 4. Creek or river claims, i.e., alluvial claims in the bed of creeks or rivers. 5. Quartz claims. (1862,Otago As It Is,61) [NOTES: (quoting Otago Gfds Regs)]

Dunstan, 13th June, - ... At the Kawarau ... all the river claims are submerged, the paddocks and tunnels in the banks are mostly fallen in ... Arrow Township, 10th July. - ... Huts, tents, wheels, sluice-boxes - everything on the beach and river claims have been swept off by the torrent, ... (Jul 18, 1863,Otago Witness,7)

2 n. [re moa bones]

BUICK A few of the bones were taken into Waimate, and [137] an account of the find ... attracted the attention of Professor Hutton, who at once entered into negotiations for the purchase of the claim'; and ... the saidclaim' passed into his hands. (1937,Moa-Hunters of NZ,136)

claim-holder¶

n.

COOPER ... if the charges ... are persisted in, than very few, except the first-class claim-holders, can by any possibility avail themselves of [the crushing machine]. (Nov 22, 1867,Digger's Diary,15,1978 ed.)

PYKE For instance, when auriferous quartz reefs were first discovered in Victoria, a claim for four men was only 24 feet square, and it therefore happened that in some of the richest claims on the Sailor's Gully Reef at Forest Creek the surface claim-holders knocked the bottoms out of their shafts at a depth of about 20 feet - a result which will readily be understood by all who are acquainted with the ordinary angular direction of the `dip' in quartz reefs. (1887,History of the Early Gold Discoveries in Otago,61,1962 ed.)

claim-jumper¶

n.

claim-jumping¶

n. the illegal occupation often by force of another's claim [goldmining] (See also jump v)

HISLOP His claim produced a real good patch of gold, ... but although ... he had to do no claim-jumping to get it, I cannot say it was quite above board. (1943,Pure Gold,100)

clam¶

n. an early name for various native bivalves, esp. pipi or pipi-like shellfish; recently (198?8) re-introduced as a commercial export name for mussels

McDONNELL There are abundance of lobsters, crawfish, oysters, prawns, and shrimps; besides clams, peppies, muscles, limpets, and cockles. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,15,1979 ed.)

POLACK [There are] a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202 fn)

WAKEFIELD Mussels, cockles, and clams also resemble our English sorts. (1849,Handbook for New Zealand, The,161)

CLAMS (OR PIPIS) ... Fry bacon and ... onion, add chopped potato and ... tomato ... Simmer ... add clams, and cook ... Thicken the gravy ... (1910,Colonial Everyday Cookery,114)

2 n. the NZ cockle

It makes sense for paella in New Zealand to include.. greenshell mussels and littleneck clams (the correct name for what we used to call cockles). (Sep 6, 2003,Dominion Post,E7)

2 n.

Surf clams are species similar to the common tuatua. (Oct 1991,Cuisine,29 / 11)

clamp¶

n. [(silage)]

Self-fed clamps without a base are quite satisfactory on sand, shingle and pumice soils. (Feb 1960,NZ Dairy Exporter,21)

These young stock are.. often top-fed on wedge clamps in the winter. (Jul 1959,NZ Dairy Exporter,47)

1 n. (Rural) a style of making and conserving silage.

RIDDOLLS The bun clamp is simply a heap of grass shaped like an inverted saucer. With the ordinary wedge clamp consolidation right out to the edges is impossible without endangering the tractor and driver. (1958,Farm Engineering,368)

RIDDOLLS Silage has been constructed here [in NZ] in stacks, 'clamps' and 'buns' which require no constructional work. (1958,Farm Engineering,400)

CONNELL & HADFIELD There are four main ensiling methods:- (1) the overground silo, (2) the pit and the trench, (3) the clamp, (4) the stack. ibid 367 Introduction of the buckrake led to the invention of new types of silage stacks, collectively referred to as clamps. (1961,Agriculture,366)

The choice back then for farmers for their hay was either pit silage if they had one or the up and over silage clamp, said Ken. (Nov 4, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,23)

clamp on the pace¶

phr. to put on speed; to increase strain, effort, esp. as clamp on the pace. [ca1950s at least: Wellington e.g. He clamped on the pace to win by ten yards; The pace gets clamped on in the third term just before exams.]

clan lab¶

n. (informal) a clandestine laboratory [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

Police believe the burglars broke into the school hazardous goods store and science laboratory to steal materials for a 'clan lab' for the manufacture of the methamphetamine 'P'. (Mar 16, 2004,Hutt News,7)

Clandestine laboratories, called "clan labs", are highly dangerous and the "cooks" who make the drugs often become affected by the chemical vapours generated. (Dec 17, 2003,Dominion Post,A12)

One raid netted an alleged mobile "clan lab" (clandestine laboratory) and several grams of crystal methamphetamine, a victory in the battle against the drug... (Jun 5, 2003,Dominion Post,A5)

In clan labs highly volatile chemicals are used. (Dec 16, 2003,TV1)

In the bust, police found a mobile 'clan (clandestine) lab', several grams of crystal methamphetamine, a hydroponics set-up with cannabis plants.. numerous meth pipes and pills that have yet to be analysed. (Jun 18, 2003,Norwester,1)

Clandestine methamphetamine laboratories - known as clan labs - are extremely dangerous with volatile chemicals involved in the manufacturing process. (Jan 29, 2001,Evening Post,1)

clap¶

v.

Clap.-To c. a dog is to make him sit down. I am told the expression is in frequent use at dog-trials. I have never heard it on a station except from one very Scotch shepherd who used `c. down' as a word of command. (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

NEWTON He was plain-eyed and barked when pulling, but was an outstanding hill dog. ... He used to `clap' and would lie there barking. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,26)

v. (Rural) [of a sheepdog] to lie flat while eyeing its sheep.

LOUGHNAN clap: a dog is made to clap - or may do so naturally - when during a run he stops but does not just stand still on his feet or sit on his haunches, but crouches down on his belly. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,18)

Clap - a dog that whenever it's stationary - when working up to sheep - lies flat on the ground, but is still firmly giving them the eye. [clapping (verbal noun)] (Sep 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,9)

1 v. (Rural) to make a sheepdog lie down while controlling sheep.

ACLAND to clap a dog is to make him sit down. I am told the expression is in frequent use at dog trials. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,369)

clap-clap¶

exclam. said on seeing a mess made [1984 14 F E138Wgton Girls C. 19 CLAP CLAP [F2]]

clapmatch¶

n. a Pacific whalers' name for a female (?fur) seal (See cf. wig)

McNAB ... the Clap Match, or female seal, furnish great proportion [of kills]. Ibid. 271 I do assert of late the southern and western coasts of New Zealand have been infested with Europeans and New Zealanders, who, without consideration, have killed the pups before they are prime, and the clap matches before pupping, for the sake of eating their carcasses; ... (1907,Murihiku,172) [NOTES: 1815 Sydney Gazette in 1907 McNab Murihiku 172]

McNAB ... the Clap Match, or female seal, furnish great proportion [of kills]. Ibid. 271 I do assert of late the southern and western coasts of New Zealand have been infested with Europeans and New Zealanders, who, without consideration, have killed the pups before they are prime, and the clap matches before pupping, for the sake of eating their carcasses; ... (1907,Murihiku,172) [NOTES: 1815 Sydney Gazette in 1907 McNab Murihiku 172]

HOWARD Incoming skins are sorted to arbitrary standards -wigs (old males), clap-matches (females), bulls, yearlings, grey or silver pups (under one year), black pups. (1940,Rakiura,40)

BEATTIE Beattie comments `the explanation of our own usage of wigs and clapmatches is not meant for refined ears.' (1950,Far-Famed Fiordland,2)

clapping¶

n. (of a sheep dog) see cit. (See cf. clap v)

RENNIE Clapping is considered a fault in heading dogs [38] by most trainers in New Zealand. The term describes the habit of some heading dogs particularly those with a strong eye, of lying down every time they stop moving. ... If you decide clapping is a fault you wish to correct, the time to do it is when the dog ... `claps' for the first time. (1985,Working Dogs,37)

1 n. (Rural) an action of a heading dog, lying down to eye sheep.

Royal Scott gave a particularly smooth performance, but he was a little too prone to clapping, whereas Sweep did all his work on his feet. (Dec 2, 1954,NZ Farmer,44)

Clarkism¶

n.

"The Clarkism. It's something you can't remember that you never said. (May 5, 2005,Dominion Post,A2)

class¶

v. to grade (wool) for sale according to type, quality, etc.

MEREDITH Fortunately, pater showed me how to class wool. This is about the least strenuous job on a shearing-board, and suits me down to the ground. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,41) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 41]

WILLIAMS & REEVES Is there any advantage in classing each fleece ? / Does it pay to wash wool, or send Home in the grease ? (1889,Colonial Couplets,10) [NOTES: [`A New Chum's Letter Home']]

WILSON At the main entrance of the shearing-shed, which is a long building with pens down the centre, and an outlet at each end, stands a wool-press, and behind this are the bins into which the fleeces, after having been classed, are placed preparatory to being pressed. (1894,In the Land of the Tui,242)

... the latter is always skirted and classed, whereas the black fleece was rolled up just as taken from the sheep's back, the belly-pieces being also left in. ... For example, white wool divides, when skirted by the roller at the wool-table, thus: Belly pieces, say, 6d. per pound; first pieces, 8d. per pound; ... fragments or locks, 4d. per pound. (1901,TrNZI,33/196)

ACTON-ADAMS I do not think my classer, who has classed for me for 4 or 5 years, understands scouring, and I want to know if you could get a competent scourer from Blenheim. (May 22, 1900,Letter) [NOTES: 1900 May 22 Acton-Adams Letter in 1969 McCaskill Molesworth 83]

Class. The woolclasser decides under what description each fleece shall be sold, or classes the clip. In Australia they speak of classing sheep (for mating, etc). I have never heard it used in that sense here. (G. P. W., p.(2)) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15)

Most of the large sheep station owners have their wool classed at shearing time by an experienced wool classer. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,709)

BLAKISTON The parents of Harry Smith, who classed the Gorge wool for forty years, came to Mt. Peel by bullock dray in 1856. (1952,My Yesteryears,30) [NOTES: [f. c1869]]

RICHARDS A steam whistle ... blew for the commencement and finish of each run. The wool tables for rolling and skirting were in the centre of the woolboard. Close by stood the classer's table, where he sat and classed each fleece before it was carried by a shed hand to its respective bin. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,113)

Why is the wool classed or sorted in the colonies? (Oct 25, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,13)

WOODHOUSE It is difficult to imagine how these two men could skirt, roll, class and carry away the 1600 or so fleeces shorn in a day. (1982,Blue Cliffs,89)

n. the category of each fleece

OGONOWSKA-COATES Class. The category of each fleece. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,95)

n. the classification block of a (?or Paremoremo) prison

NEWBOLD Class (n) Classification block. (1982,Big Huey, The,246)

[Paremoremo prison] Classification Block slowly evolved into a de-classification block. True, all new Parry' residents were initially sent there for observation and assessment. ButClass' was also the home of prisoners who did not quite fit elsewhere - inmates who needed protection from others, those who could not cope with the stresses of prison life or men deserving punishment that stopped short of incarceration in D Block. (May 12, 1985,NZ Times,4)

class settlement¶

n.

FITTON But it [a labourer's letter] will ... prove to persons who have hitherto objected to Canterbury, as a `class settlement', in which the interest of the wealthier emigrants has been better cared for, than that of their more humble companions; that ... labourers ... enjoy ... an equal chance (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),207)

classer¶

n. one who classes or grades wool; a wool classer (See wool classer)

... when shearing commences, a sorter or classer's table, be it ever so simple should be erected. (1878,Country Journal,2/400,1877 ed.)

WILSON Meanwhile the shorn fleeces are carried to a large table in the wool-shed by a man appropriately named `Fleecy', and are spread out by four wool-pickers, who tear away the bad parts and fold the fleeces square, passing them to the classer, who, in turn, after a rapid examination hands them on to his attendant, and he places them in their respective bins according to their quality. (1894,In the Land of the Tui,244)

ACTON-ADAMS I do not think my classer, who has classed for me for 4 or 5 years, understands scouring, and I want to know if you could get a competent scourer from Blenheim. (May 22, 1900,Letter) [NOTES: 1900 May Letter in 1969 McCaskill Molesworth 83]

LANCASTER The classers were silent at the table. (1904,Sons o' Men,78,1905 ed.)

CARR Wool Rolling. - When the fleece is thrown on the table by the fleece-picker, the wool rollers (generally there are two) skirt - i.e., take off the dirty wool - the neck (in some sheds) and legs, ... turn in the sides and roll up, from each end. The Classer, by feel, sight, and general knowledge, decides what class it belongs to. (1913,Country Work,15)

PERRY Classing. - Where the clip is over 30 bales it will pay to engage an expert classer; (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,120)

DEVANNY ... the classers' benches. (1926,Butcher Shop, The,11)

See Woolc[lasser] (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

STUDHOLME At shearing time [at Benmore, 1892] about 55 men were employed in the shed: 28 to 30 shearers, 2 penners-up, 4 pickers-up, 2 broomies, 6 rollers, 1 classer, 1 fleece carrier, 4 piece sorters, 3 pressers, 1 bale brander, 1 butcher and brander. (1940,Te Waimate,208,1954 ed.)

McLEOD The classer has the key position in the shed and I always feel that in New Zealand his importance has often been underrated. He has full authority over the shed hands and is in complete control of the wool. In addition he can, if he has the right personality, have a very big influence over the shearers, and contribute very much towards the peaceful efficiency of the whole shearing. Besides these qualities of leadership and authority he is expected to be highly skilled in the classing and preparation of wool for sale. Ibid. 28 The classer stands beside the gong ... and when the clang of the old isc blade rings through the shed, the catching pen doors are flung open ... (1951,High Country,27)

STRONACH The wool rollers at the table whereon the fleecies had thrown the wool took what was necessary off each fleece and then rolled it, ready for the classer's inspection. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,30)

SCRYMGEOUR The only European [in the shearing gang] was the classer, but, of course, some of the team were half-castes, and what a mighty job this team did, ... and Joe Gillies walked the board as boss. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,110)

FERNANDEZ Erina had gathered up Mutu's last fleece and thrown it expertly on te table before the classer. A few random wrist movements removed the necks and edging pieces. (1973,Tussock Fever,3)

BREMNER Classer hand who groups together fleeces of similar style - length, fineness, quality - usually in shearing shed. (1985,Woolscours of NZ,9)

RICHARDS A steam whistle ... blew for the commencement and finish of each run. The wool tables for rolling and skirting were in the centre of the woolboard. Close by stood the classer's table, where he sat and classed each fleece before it was carried by a shed hand to its respective bin. Ibid. 136 The classer urged me to pull out and not be such a fool. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,113)

classer; wool classer: The key employee of the shed who classes the wool into grades according to quality before it is placed in the wool bins, and who is responsible for all processing after the fleece leaves the sheep's back. He is colloquially known as the guesser' orconman'. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/23) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

n. (Rural) a drafter or picker of stock.

A person who selects stock for sale: a classer. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

1 n. (Rural) a person who classes wool in the shearing shed and is in charge of the wool once it is shorn.

MCLEOD One classer, two rollers, two fleece-pickers, two pressers, one penner up, make up the shed contingent and the cook and offsider complete the total. (1951,NZ High Country,27)

LOUGHNAN In just the same way as the classer enjoys the top of the woolshed's social scale, so the dagger is the most lowly. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,25)

STRONACH The wool rollers at the table whereon the fleecies had thrown the wool took what was necessary off each fleece and then rolled it, ready for the classer's inspection. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,30)

LOUGHNAN classer: a woolclasser, the expert who sorts the fleeces according to condition, and length, and strength of staple. In the well-defined pecking order of the shearing gang he is the senior in status. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,18)

Classical Maori¶

n. usu. attrib. applied by students to the period in Maori culture after the moa-hunter but before the main European discovery and settlement [check PR

FULLER Some time after the Moa-hunters came the Classical Maori. (1978,Maori Food and Cookery,10)

David Simmons follows with an essay that describes the tribal styles, beginning with those known in literature as Classic Maori, which belong to the Puawaitanga period (1500-1800), and extending to the varied styles of more recent times. (1984,Te Maori,35)

classing¶

n. (Rural)

MACDONALD The big stations may make classing a very simple business, ... and may even divide up the skirtings or pieces from the fleece into different classes, besides keeping the bellies, locks, and stained wool separate. (1920,Australian & NZ Sheep Farming,144)

PERRY Classing. - Where the clip is over 30 bales it will pay to engage an expert classer; (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,120)

PINNEY The Benmore classing was a big job, as some 3,000 fleeces came over four tables each day. There were four to six skirters to be supervised ... (1981,Early Northern Otago Runs,23)

Other lots were discounted through careless classing and not being skirted. (Dec 7, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,21)

1 n. (Rural) sorting or classifying of fleece-wool.

One man will find himself kept fairly busy keeping the sheep up to two good crutchers, and dag-classing at the same time. (Jul 1911,NZ Farmer,705)

MCLEOD [The classer] is expected to be highly skilled in the classing and preparation of wool for sale. (1951,NZ High Country,27)

MACDONALD The big stations may make classing a very simple business. (1920,Australian & NZ Sheep Farming,144)

HENDERSON .. provision might have to be made in the classing plan for accommodation of heavy-conditioned fleeces. (1965,Wool & Woolclassing,115)

classing table¶

n. (Rural) a table in a woolshed on which fleeces are spread, and skirted.

PERRY There should be good large windows in the roof over the classing or wool tables. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,17)

MOMATIUK & EASTCOTT The footstep of fleecees carrying snowy bundles to the classing table. (1980,High Country,73)

claw¶

n. the manifold that spaces the teatcups in forming a cluster and connects them to the long milk tubes and long pulse tubes in a milking machine

The claw was connected to the main milk and air pipes above by rubber tubes and metal pipes. (Dec 2003,NZ Memories,No. 45/11)

Claw. The manifold that spaces the teatcups in forming a cluster and connects them to the long milk and long pulse tubes. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,39)

claw tube¶

1 n. (Rural) a part of an inflation cup used in milking machines.

.. the outer surface of the claw tubes is often wet. (Jun 1, 1946,NZ Dairy Exporter,20)

.. it is usually not economical to use a rubber for these tubes which is different from that used for claw tubes..The best rubber for claw tubes..is therefore a carbon black reinforced natural rubber designed for high tensile strength and reasonable flexibility. (Mar 15, 1956,NZ Journal of Agriculture,281)

clay¶

n.

SHADBOLT see Shit-stirring list and Put (1974,Touch of Clay, A,178)

clayie¶

n. a clay marble

KEITH & MAIN Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them ... World War II brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. (1984,NZ Yesterdays,288)

McGILL clayie clay marble. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,28)

Clayton's¶

n. (from the proprietary name of a hard-liquor substitute) Usu. attrib., indicating a pretence to or a largely unsuccessful imitation of the real thing

He says a cut in MPs would save money, while also getting rid of the 55 "Clayton's" MPs. (Aug 29, 1999,Sunday Star Times,C3)

...as a fitness test it was a Clayton's one. (Dec 15, 2003,Dominion Post,D10)

MUIR We were what you could call a 'Clayton's'team. (1986,Long Time Passing,74)

That would give credence to National's claim that the legal restrictions being imposed amount to a Clayton's moratorium. (Oct 9, 2003,Dominion Post,C2)

The sham of a loveless marriage is to be replaced by the sham of a Claytons one in which the couple are not quite married but not quite divorced. (Dec 10, 1992,Evening Post,6)

What do you call a minister you have when you're not having a minister? The Opposition quickly identified John Tamihere as the quintessential Claytons Cabinet man, after failing to get the Government to explain how it was possible to leave his supposedly important portfolios unfilled for the foreseeable future. (Nov 10, 2004,Dominion Post,A2)

I suggest we have a St. Clayton's Day Service when those who don't go to church could go to church knowing it was a special day designed to bring them home in a non-threatening way. (Aug 23, 1998,NZ Catholic,9)

...the Hurricanes have been dreadfully unkind with some making Clayton's appearances - playing when they're not really playing. (Oct 19, 2002,Dominion Post,C24)

My concern is we have at present a Clayton's law where the police could, if they chose, come down on the industry, but because in general they have an understanding of the issue, they don't. (Sep 18, 1999,Dominion,17)

We thought of it as a Clayton's Plan - the Plan you have when you don't have a Plan - but we called it "The First Steps" which conveys the same idea. (Jun 1986,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,72/50)

This particular example of loss of choice is another small symptom of changes that the New Zealand public continues to endure as the Mother of all Clayton's choices rushes towards voters. (Oct 23, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

Clear Communications launched a free Internet service yesterday.. amid accusations from Telecom that it was a "Clayton's" free service. (Apr 19, 2000,Dominion,10)

Community work has become a Clayton's sentence. (Mar 29, 2004,Dominion Post,A3)

It is rapidly becoming more evident that this new wave of "Claytons" politicians have got it onto their Bellamy's befuddled heads that we are their servants, not they ours. (Jun 7, 2000,Evening Post,4)

[He] dismissed one of the three proposals as a "Clayton's" offer. (Apr 2, 1993,Evening Post,9)

[Ian Fraser used the term `Clayton's principle' about visits of nuclear ships.] (Aug 7, 1983,TV1) [NOTES: Newsmakers]

To those criticising Muldoon for producing a Claytons Budget I say: `Be thankful you're still living. He could have done worse.' Maybe, just maybe, this do-nothing Budget is evidence that God is running out of thunderbolts. (Aug 15, 1983,National Business Review,7)

`Claytons is the word that springs to mind ... Clayton's increase - the [wage] increase you get when you are not really getting an increase.' (Sep 4, 1983,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: ca1983 Sep 4 2YA Wellington Sunday Supplement Roy Walker, Dunedin]

Feel like a streak, ladies? Now you can do it in comfort. This is known as the Claytons streak. It's the streak you have when you're not having a streak!. (Sep 7, 1983,NZ Truth,2)

A clayton's compulsion ... a compulsion when you're not having compulsion. (Sep 16, 1983,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 1983 Sept 16 2YA Wellington Parliamentary Debate 10.30pm]

..., the Government has regulated mortgage interest rates, centralised meat marketing and adopted a Clayton's policy on removing external protection. (Sep 21, 1983,National Business Review,7)

Counsel ... asked the jury of five men and seven women to see the trial for what it was - a `Clayton's' conspiracy, the conspiracy that really isn't a conspiracy. (Jul 6, 1984,Evening Post,8)

"We don't feel we have been listened to at all. It's a Clayton's report really." (Aug 14, 2007,Dominion Post,A2) [NOTES: response to a report on the continuing use of 1080 poison]

Remember Clayton's, the drink you have when you are not having a drink? Believe it or not, Clayton is Barry's middle name. True to the label, his retirement is to be a Clayton's retirement, since he is to work on contract to finish the Raglan and Kawhia mapping. (Nov 1990,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,90/38)

While winning the Shell Cup is no meanfeat, there's no doubt that in most eyesit's the Clayton's trophy. (Feb 1992,North & South,74)

Councillor, Mr Ted Armstron asked the council to give its animal control unit more resources so the bylaw could be enforced. "Otherwise it will be a Clayton's bylaw." (May 14, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9) [NOTES: Original in Waikato This Week 11/3/94]

I am the most ardent fighter forreserves, but let's have a cuppa, slowdown, and look at introducing reservesthat are working and not have any'Clayton's reserves'. (Mar 19, 1995,Sunday Star Times,A6)

SM (supplementary member): Clayton's MMP. Would give minor parties a foot in the door without allowing other parts of the anatomy to follow. (Aug 29, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

SM (supplementary member): Clayton's MMP. (Aug 29, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

Claytonian¶

adj. make-believe

The upshot of all these reforms is that we have a market, we have competition (of a curious Claytonian sort), we have all the benefits that these wonderful mechanisms undoubtedly bring, but we don't have anyone running the show. (Apr 19, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

clean¶

adj. free of disease, esp. scab or pleuro-pneumonia

FOX I hear awful accounts of scab in the Wairau. Only three flocks are said to be clean - Cooper's, Duppa's and Morse's - ... They say it will cost Monro [pounds]800 to clean his own (and I presume yours) and some other flocks which he admits caught it of his. (Feb 8, 1850,Letter) [NOTES: 1850 Feb 8 Fox to Dillon in 1954 The Dillon Letters 106]

Arthur had to go to Lyttelton to get a clean certificate from the scab inspector. (Nov 3, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,108,1950 ed.)

CRESSWELL Mr Pasley inspected 16,000 sheep and finding all clean he left this afternoon on his way to Nelson. (1951,Canterbury Tales,137) [NOTES: 1872 May 18 in Cresswell Canterbury Tales (1951) 137]

MEREDITH As the sheep are slightly infected with scab we have to dip them periodically to eradicate ... the parasite; but it is a hard job because, on these fern-clad [Wairarapa] runs, it is almost impossible to get an absolutely clean muster of the sheep. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,87) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 87]

CARR A means of keeping [ragwort] under by grazing clean sheep (i.e., sheep off clean pasture) has been found. (1913,Country Work,28)

McCASKILL The only point I would mention is the scab question. ... And after the country has been cleaned at my expense, ... you propose ... to place the whole of the Amuri in danger ... At last after enormous effort the Amuri is clean ... (1969,Molesworth,56) [NOTES: [sc. country cf CLEAR: sc of scab] 1885 July Acton-Adams in 1969 McCaskill Molesworth 56]

BURDON It is notorious that, whereas the whole of the province of Nelson is scabbed, Canterbury is clean. (1938,High Country,79)

TOMLINSON It was mostly clean country, and McCallum had built up a well known Merino flock, ... (1968,Remembered Trails,56)

TOMLINSON It was mostly clean country, and McCallum had built up a well known Merino flock, ... (1968,Remembered Trails,56) [NOTES: [?= not bushed]]

AYSON Just as they were beginning work on the third day a messenger arrived to say that he had to drive over for some of his cattle at Galt's where the beasts were being inspected by the stock inspector for cases of pleuro-pneumonia to allow them to pass over the Wyndham River which was the boundary at that time for what was called the clean hundreds. (1937,Thomas,99)

adj. complete, without stragglers

Abner and I took the top of the range ... There were eight fellows spread about the face of the range below us but we did not make a very clean muster notwithstanding. (Oct 24, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,202,1950 ed.)

MEREDITH On these fern-clad [Wairarapa] runs, it is almost impossible to get an absolutely clean muster of the sheep. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,87) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 87]

adj. (Rural) [of sheep] without dags.

The fly now troubling us was not the ordinary fly and he had known perfectly clean sheep attacked. (Aug 1900,NZ Farmer,Supplement A & P Conference iv)

v. to free (sheep country) of scab (cf. clear).

ACTON-ADAMS The only point I would mention is the scab question. ... I have kept mustering [the Severn Block] to get in the wild sheep and my station diary will show that I have spent about [pounds]300 cleaning it. ... And after the country has been cleaned at my expense, ... you propose ... to place the whole of the Amuri in danger ... At last after enormous effort the Amuri is clean ... (Jul 1885,Letter) [NOTES: 1885 July Acton-Adams in 1969 McCaskill Molesworth 56]

adj. innocent (See see also cleanskin)

NEWBOLD Clean (adj) Innocent, free from incriminating evidence. (1982,Big Huey, The,246)

BEATON DI: ... Someone told her [the new inmate] I could score, so I helped her out. ... MA: Bit risky, weren't it? DI: Nah, she's clean. You know o how I feel about dogshit. (1984,Outside In,42)

adj. (Rural) [of farmland] clear of noxious weeds or scrub.

.. most of the clean tussock country falls into the Wehenga class, and that which is invaded by manuka scrub is mainly of the Taioma class. (Mar 1955,NZ Journal of Agriculture,277)

No one should attempt sowing lucerne in land otherwise than clean. (Jan 5, 1881,Napier Daily Telegraph,1)

The main question with regard to noxious weeds was the danger of their spreading over clean country. (Sep 1913,NZ Farmer,1232)

November is a favourable month in most districts for sowing lucerne if the land is clean. (Oct 20, 1926,NZ Journal of Agriculture,266)

The flats are clean, but still with great scope for more intensive farming. (Apr 25, 1968,NZ Farmer,3)

NEWTON .. it takes in a strip of beautiful clean cabbage tree country ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,16)

Te Mahaki has about 72 ha of fertile terrace river flats suitable for orchards and 161 ha of clean, steep grazable hills. (Mar 12, 2001,NZ Farmer,40)

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheep or station] free from scab. (See clean certificate)

Stock inspector passed the sheep clean. (May 13, 1867,Castle Station Diary,258) [NOTES: in Vance (1965)]

RICKARD Scab was not finally eliminated from New Zealand until 1892 when D'Urville Island. where it had lingered longest, was pronounced clean. (1967,Strangers in the Wilderness,102)

Sheep inspected and declared clean. (Dec 19, 1863,Haldon Station Diary,249) [NOTES: in Vance (1965) High Endeavour]

KENNAWAY .. it was necessary to go one hundred and eighty miles for clean sheep. (1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,130)

The fact of this portion of the colony being clean may be considered thoroughly established. The whole of the Picton subdivision is also on the clean list ... (Jul 4, 1886,NZ Farmer)

ACLAND Glenmark was one of the last runs in Canterbury to be clean of scab. (1946,Early Canterbury Runs,274)

KERR The owners, too, of those properties through which sheep travelled - Orari, Arowhenua and The Levels - had great difficulty in keeping their flocks clean. (1976,From the Beginning: chronicles of a county,132)

KAY To have a flock declared 'clean' as Anthony's was shown to be in all the Sheep Returns, was a matter for both relief and praise. (1996,Anthony Wall, Settler of Porirua,82)

2 adj. scoured

2 adj. free from wool contaminants; hence, of the act of shearing, without difficulties or hold-ups

LANCASTER A big Maori was making the [shearing] pace; opening up in a scientific fashion with a clean-run cut over the ear-root. (1905,Sons o' Men,81)

BOWEN One comb should do a run if properly ground on average clean shearing. (1955,Wool Away!,78)

3 adj. freed from scrub, fern, etc

LEVY Also the grazing management including full utilisation and spelling of oversown and consistently topdressed country has definitely overcome any efforts of manuka, bracken fern, hard fern, and piripiri to re-assert themselves. There are great areas of relatively clean country in the Wellington district, ... (1951,Grasslands of NZ,265,1970 ed.)

clean (and) green¶

phr. with minimal pollution [adjectival, often collocated with image]

I can vaguely remember reacting cynically to the release of Banrock Station's "clean and green" cask when it first graced my tasting bench back in the late 1980s. (Aug 17, 2002,Dominion Post,F7)

In its report on the impact of GE release, the Berl forecasting group traced the origins of global and local consciousness of New Zealand's "clean, green" image right back to the Rainbow Warrior bombing and to the nuclear-free legislation. (Jul 9, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

Everyone says our advantage lies in our 'clean green' image, but before we developed the Green Tick there was no measurable way for producers of conventional goods and services to show they were genuinely clean and green. (Aug 5, 2002,Dominion Post Farming,6)

The Japanese also like New Zealand's clean, green brand, growers who care for their soil and use chemicals sparingly, and the reliability and quality of the biotech industry. (Dec 5, 2005,Dominion Post,C1)

21 "It's all very well for Tourism New Zealand to waltz around the world promoting us as clean and green, but we don't realise the impact it's having on a nation as small as ours," he warns. (May 25, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

clean burn¶

1 n. (Rural) a white burn or complete tussock or forest burn.

MAY In due time we fired it and had the satisfaction of having a clean burn-off. (1869,May's Guide to Farming in NZ,18)

BARKER .. it must not be too violent, or the flames will fly over the grass, just scorching it instead of making a 'clean burn.' (1867,Station Life in NZ,194)

Solid fern would give a clean burn .. but manuka of any size or thickness had to be cut up by hand for a clean burn, or else killed by a scrub fire and allowed to rot. (Jul 15, 1947,NZ Journal of Agriculture,25)

WATERS .. the trees were chopped according to the density of the bush and the amount of timber required on the ground to carry a good fierce fire and so give a good clean burn. [clean burn-off] (1976,Man of Straw,90)

clean certificate¶

1 n. (Rural) a certificate issued to a property by sheep inspectors [mid-late 1800s] if sheep on the property were found to be free of scab.

MURISON Blackstone Hill has clean certificate. (Jun 11, 1864,Puketoi Station Diary)

A clean certificate was issued in April 1890. (Apr 1, 1920,NZ Farmer,451)

It appears that a week or ten days ago a mob of about 600 sheep, for which a clean certificate had been obtained in Marlborough, was driven through to Nelson via Ria [sic] Valley .. they were driven to stockyards at Richmond, where Mr. E. Price, scab inspector saw them ... (Mar 31, 1884,Hawera & Normanby Star,3)

MEREDITH The Government is going to have a lot of bother with this [East Coast Maori] flock, in getting rid of the scab. ... Otherwise the sheep will constitute a bar to the issue of a `clean certificate' for the colony. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,146) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 146]

The Sheep Inspector at Castle Point had given Mr Harding a certificate of the said sheep being clean. (May 1, 1858,Hawke's Bay Herald and Aruhihi Advocate,4)

They came from a scabby flock, the owner of which held a clean certificate, but which flock has since been declared scabby. (Feb 3, 1882,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

HASTIE Messrs Monro & Blundel came and examined my sheep which I was going to dip and they gave me a clean certificate. (Jan 24, 1885,Andrew Hastie Diary.)

Two years ago every flock in New Zealand had a clean certificate. (Aug 11, 1888,Egmont Star,9)

JONES .. the Inspector had to give me a clean certificate before I could stock up the run again with sheep. (1933,Autobiography of an Early Settler,84)

clean district¶

1 n. (Rural) a local area free from sheep disease.

'Clean district' means any district in which there are no infected sheep ... (1878,NZ Statutes,148)

clean farm¶

1 n. (Rural) a farm property free of native vegetation and scrub.

HARGREAVES Dad thought you could fall the bush, burn it off, after two years let the grass grow long and then burn off again and have a clean farm, like they did in the Gisborne area. (2000,To the Back and Beyond,31)

clean feed¶

1 n. (Rural) land that has not been grazed for at least a month.

STEVENS Wean early and wean on to clean feed, which means ground which has been free from sheep for at least a month. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,70)

clean muster¶

n. (Rural) a complete muster, leaving no 'stragglers'.

ACLAND Loburn was very scrubby and a bad place to get a clean muster. (1946,Early Canterbury Runs,71)

NEWTON .. although it was impossible for the musterers to see for more than a chain or two they were able to get reasonably clean musters. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,230)

ACLAND The great difficulty in cleaning the sheep consists .. clean muster. (1858,Notes on Sheepfarming in NZ,12)

NEWTON .. the only way to ensure a clean muster - one has no option but to walk for miles ... (1964,Straggle Muster,2)

MILLS ET AL Eventually, if a clean muster is your aim, you will finish up with a lamb or two in front of your saddle. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,84)

SINCLAIR The dog has to work the sheep well to achieve a good clean muster. (1973,Boot in the Stirrup,31)

clean mustering¶

1 n. (Rural) complete gathering-in of stock.

NEWTON .. sheep don't run as they used to - and this also militates against clean mustering. (1966,Boss's Story, The,121)

clean off¶

v. (Rural) [stock-grazing] to eat out or clean-graze.

BELL Ernest Gilbertson .. was kind to me and lent some 200 steers to clean off the long rank grasses. (1953,Roundaway: Story of a Sheep Farm,32)

clean paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a paddock that has been spelled and should harbour no disease.

Ewes should lamb in paddocks that have been spelled, lambs should be weaned into clean paddocks, and both ewes and lambs before and after weaning should be moved regularly to fresh pasture. (May 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,492)

clean potato¶

n. a person of unblemished reputation

A rag like yours can only circulate among a certain set, who like yourself are by no means very clean potatoes. If you were put upon the market I don't think 160 sacks of your kidney would even fetch 10/-. (Jul 20, 1907,NZ Truth,6)

BEARDSLEY clean potato (wasn't the c- p-) wasn't the honest person (1984,Blackball 08,243) [NOTES: (Glossary)]

clean run¶

1 n. (Rural) a grazing area free from disease.

STUDHOLME The hill lambs were weaned on to a block of country which had been spelled since shearing time, and did remarkably well on this clean run. (1940,Te Waimate,113)

clean shearing¶

1 n. (Rural) the shearing of sheep without second cuts or nicks of sheep.

OGONOWSKA-COATES Clean shearing was the order of the day, and if a man cut a sheep, the cut sheep was marked and excluded from the day's tally ... (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,17)

clean shed¶

1 n. (Rural) a woolshed with no history of disease.

Numbers have been dying off the shears in many cases; [of blood poisoning] in one case 200 lambs had died after being treated in a clean shed. (Aug 1900,NZ Farmer,Supplement A & P Conference iv)

clean skinned¶

adj. of cattle, without brand or earmark

MASTERS All were clean skinned wild cattle bar one, a 15-year-old steer with the old Willow Flat ear mark. (1960,Back-Country Tales,221)

clean up¶

v. (Rural) [stock-grazing] to eat out or clean-graze lank feed or weeds from a paddock or block.

Ewes can be used to clean up any dirty paddocks. (Apr 20, 1922,NZ Journal of Agriculture,219)

What happens is that after drying off, cows steadily lose condition while cleaning up farms or run-offs. (Oct 1970,NZ Dairy Exporter,13)

clean wool¶

n. scoured wool

Clean wool: Scoured wool. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53)

clean-faced¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheep] with faces clear of wool; snipe-nosed.

Snipe-nosed sheep were culled. By snipe-nosed he meant what we now call clean-faced. (1930,BLANK ENTRY,247) [NOTES: in ACLAND (1951) Early Canterbury Runs]

NEWTON They were a beautiful line of clean-faced sheep. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,34)

NEWTON Clean-faced romneys, they were attractive sheep. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,233)

clean-grazed¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of land] evenly grazed and carrying no rogue weeds or scrub.

GASCOIGNE His farms, in rough country-side, too often in that day showing scrub and fern, were clean-grazed and swept up green to the hill-tops. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,57)

clean-grazer¶

1 n. (Rural) an animal that grazes thoroughly and systematically, not picking randomly at herbage.

HAYES Another advantage is that Corriedales are clean-grazers, moving across a paddock eating instead of picking here and there. (1978,From the Toss of a Coin,75)

clean-legged¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheep] having legs clear of wool and hairy fibre.

TAIT The founder of Blackford was after a reasonably open-faced and clean-legged type. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,36)

clean-run¶

n. mullet

This variety of mullet [which feeds in the ocean and shoals along the coast] is known to the fishermen and the [Northland] settlers as the clean-gut',clean-run', or sea-mullet'. ... The other variety [which stays in the harbour] is known to the fishermen as thesettler' or muddy fish'. When opened they are not clean and bright ... but full of slimy mud ... (1897,AJHR,H-17/2) [NOTES: Hector Protection of Mullet]

Clean-Shirt Ministry¶

n. (historical)

T. Forsaith was asked by surprise (when at work at his business) to form a Ministry. [He said] I put on a clean shirt and waited on His Excellency.' [The unfortunate short Ministry was hounded by the name] <i>(1898,Gentleman's Magellan,284 No.2010</i>) [NOTES: Article by J.F. HoganThe Clean-Shirt Ministry' 1st September 1854.]

HYDE The Governor called on an Auckland baker to form a new Ministry. The said gentleman popped upstairs to don a clean shirt before calling on His Excellency, thereby providing his cabinet with the splendid title, `The Clean-Shirt Ministry.' (1935,Journalese,222)

BUSH & SCOTT When cabinets were formed the southern gentry used to wonder which Aucklander was presentable enough to make minister. When Thomas Forsaith, a draper, was asked to call on the administrator about forming a ministry in 1854 he first went home from his store to change his clothes. His government was called the clean shirt ministry'. It only lasted two days. <i>(1977,Auckland at Full Stretch,31</i>) [NOTES: 1977 Keith SinclairExperiences of Auckland ...' in Bush and Scott (ed) Auckland at Full Stretch 31]

clean-skinned¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of a sheep or cattle beast] without earmark, brand or tattoo.

MASTERS All the cattle were got away to the freezing works. All were clean-skinned cattle but one, a 15 yearold steer with the old Willow Flat earmark. (1960,Back-Country Tales,221)

clean-up¶

n. the action or process of extracting gold from a ripple-board.

Mr. William Beetham ... in Nelson, mentioned the trouble ... occasioned at the periodical `clean-up' by the presence of ... lead which collected in the ripples with the gold. (1903,TrNZI,35/403)

cleaned up¶

v. killed or wounded

PARTRIDGE 1935 A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287 (1935,Slang Today,287)

cleanerfish¶

n.

AYLING CRIMSON CLEANERFISH Suezichthys sp. Halichoeres sp. (Pseudolabrus albolineatus) ... The crimson cleanerfish is a brightly coloured elongate wrasse ... As their name suggests, these fishes act as cleaners, removing parasites and damaged scales and skin from other fishes. (1982,Collins Guide,259,1984 ed.)

cleanfill¶

n. type of landfill

Stung by Rodney District councillors' acceptance of a new cleanfill in their midst, the residents are calling for a boundary change on the border of the two councils. (Nov 22, 2005,NZ Herald,a2)

cleaning crop¶

1 n. (Rural) a crop such as potatoes or maize that receives considerable cultivation, cleaning soil of weeds before planting with other crops.

CONNELL & HADFIELD A modification of this method is the practice of growing 'cleaning crops' such as potatoes, maize and mangels which receive a large amount of cultivation and leave the land in a fairly clean condition. (1961,Agriculture,242)

cleaning down¶

n.

McARA Cleaning down: The removal of loose and dangerous ground after firing, to eliminate the danger of men being struck by falling rocks; this was done by using a pick or, in stopes, by a long, light pinch-bar. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),316)

cleaning-up¶

n. [goldmining] (See cit,see also clean up v)

MAY WASHING-UP: the whole operation of saving gold from the wash-dirt. `Cleaning up' had the same meaning. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,528,1962 ed.)

cleanpointed¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheep] with little wool on legs.

NEWTON .. they were big bold sheep, densely woolled yet cleanpointed ... (1973,Big Country of the South Island,79)

cleanskin¶

n. an unbranded bottled wine

One of the by-products ot the Australian wine industry's recent bout of economic heaving has been the swelling presence of "cleanskins". Cleanskins are bottled wines that bear no branded information.... Cleanskins typically become cleanskins because there is no other market for the wine... On a recent visit to Melbourne, I kept running into recently opened specialist cleanskin retail outlets. (Jan 26, 2004,Capital Times,18)

n. an un-earmarked and unbranded cattle-beast; a clear-skin

NEWTON Cleanskins : Cattle which have not been ear-marked. Really wild cattle are referred to as cleanskins (1947,Wayleggo,153) [NOTES: 1948 edition]

Clean.skins. (kl&emacr.n.sk&ibreve.nz.), } Clear.skins. (kl&emacr.r.sk&ibreve.nz.), } n. pl. Unbranded cattle. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2020)

Cleanskin n. an animal without a brand. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3)

NEWTON Clearskins: Cattle which have not been ear-marked. Really wild cattle are referred to as clearskins. Ibid. 98 The cattle were of course real wild stuff - cleanskins born and bred in the bush. (1947,Wayleggo) [NOTES: Glossary]

TURNER Clearskin or cleanskin are names for unbranded animals. In the underworld, cleanskin has been used for a man who has not crossed with the police before. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,148)

NEWTON ... I had a go at the wild cattle at Lake Coleridge. These cattle, all cleanskins, were mainly in the bush-bound Harper country, ... (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,74)

NEWTON ... there were always the odd little bunches of `cleanskins' that had either been missed or had beaten the dogs in previous musters. (1975,Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,220)

1 n. (Rural) an unmarked animal, often one that has run wild.

NEWTON Every autumn the Rocklands men had to scratch-muster the back of both Beaumont and Gladbrook for straying cattle and it was not uncommon to run across odd bunches of 'cleanskins' - unmarked cattle. (1975,Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,161)

HINDMARSH He leaves a few calves unmarked and then hocks them off as cleanskins out of the bush ... [clean-skin] (1997,Come Be a Pioneer,169)

NEWTON The cattle were of course real wild stuff - cleanskins born and bred in the bush. (1947,Wayleggo,98)

Through this gate too, the marked calves could be turned loose with ease instead of having to be backed down the crush to mingle with the cleanskins again ... (Mar 23, 1967,NZ Farmer,33)

SINCLAIR People had tried to get some out, with little success. Most of them were cleanskins, but some were marked and these were as wild as those born there. (1973,Boot in the Stirrup,70)

LOUGHNAN cleanskin(s): wild cattle. So termed because, never having been mustered in, they have never been branded or earmarked. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,18)

STACEY Once we found a cleanskin heifer which had to be branded. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,78)

2 n. a person without a criminal record.

clean skin, clear skin n. in Australia, unbranded cattle or horses; in N.Z., prison slang for person without prison record. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

NEWBOLD CLEANSKIN (n) Person without a criminal record. From Australian pastoral slang for unbranded cattle, a word in use there in the 1880s. (1982,Big Huey, The,246)

Williams ran checks on Coveny, tossing his name round experienced drug squad detectives and checking police files. Nothing came back. He was what police call a `cleanskin' - a person with no police record. (Mar 11, 1981,Dominion,7)

clear¶

v. in NZ as a v.t. (or occas. v.i.) it is often used in ref. to the bush or scrub, etc. cleared, in a sense near `clearfell', rather than as OED2 10 b. (b) of clearing land from trees; or OED2 11. of clearing (land, etc.) of (inhabitants, etc.).

Sawyers clearing the Bush for their Work (Oct 27, 1837,Piraki Log,58,1911 ed.)

CATHERINE CHAPMAN We have some Maories clearing for us [in Karori, Wellington]. They are burning off all logs on three acres for [pounds]7. Europeans ask [pounds]3.10.0 per acre. (Dec 16, 1846,Letter) [NOTES: 1846 Dec 16 Catherine Chapman Letter in 1960 Drummond Married and Gone to NZ 72]

1 v. (Rural) [sp.use] to muster hill country.

NEWTON .. lying well into the sun it is great country to clear, although being as clean as a whistle and very steep there is the danger of avalanching in heavy snow. (1975,Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,51)

WESTMACOTT His dogs had cleared the country on the far side and between us well; not a sheep was to be seen below him ... (1977,After-Breakfast Cigar, The,141)

NEWTON He was a good dog below sheep and although he was too wide and fast for trial hunting, he would clear country with any huntaway. (1949,High Country,16)

WESTMACOTT I was to leave him, cross the gully .. and clear the hundred acres Flint had fallen .. driving the sheep in front of us. (1977,After-Breakfast Cigar, The,140)

clear off¶

v. to rid land of felled debris, logs, etc. usu. by burning

BELL The season promised to be a good one for bush-burning; and those who had bush-felled were congratulating themselves on the prospect of getting excellent burns,' while many, who, ... had been unfortunate in getting badburns,' were now hopeful of clearing off much of the timber by means of a second fire. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,198)

clear out¶

adv. clear (of money); net [?omit].

HAY He may find he has made 10/- a day clear out [in contract work]. (1882,Brighter Britain,188)

clear the board¶

exclam. a woolshed cry or order to stop shearing

Clear the board! Clear the board! is the shout./ Big Mick is smiling grimly as he takes the cobbler out./ (1950,Farm & Station Verse,33) [NOTES: c1890s Wright `Shearing' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 33]

CRADOCK The wool-classer, or shed manager, as the case may be, roars out for the final time `Clear the Board!' (1904,Sport in NZ,172)

Clear the board: Order given (now usually by a gong or bell) to the shearers to stop shearing. ([c1890-1900]) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

clear the knuckles¶

exclam. a freezing works cry (See knuckles)

clear-felling¶

n. forestry procedure, removing all trees

At Phil Moore's instigation, the Society has approached Carter Holt Holdings Ltd expressing concern at the effects of forest clear-felling on the Mangahounga Stream and the Te Hoe Valley, Wairoa County, and the possibility of silting and/or clogging up of the stream beds and burying of the vertebrate fossil-bearing materials being studied by Mrs Joan Wiffen (see Newsletter No. 63, p.29 - 32). (Oct 1984,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,66/8)

clearfell¶

v. [OED goes back to 1922]

No natural forest in Southland is being clearfelled under the conditions of a Treaty of Waitangi settlement. (May 2000,North & South,15)

clearing¶

1 n. (Rural) a bush section or bush farm, from which bush has been cleared.

WESTMACOTT He returned to his clearing next day. (1977,After-Breakfast Cigar, The,146)

My old clearing is pretty clear but in parts of the new one they [thistles] absolutely cover the ground. (1862,BLANK ENTRY,797) [NOTES: in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers I]

BELL A large clearing opened out on the right, and a little way back from the road-linestood a slab hut. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,8)

WESTMACOTT My clearing was not fenced, but experienced men said I need not worry about that. (1977,After-Breakfast Cigar, The,161)

1 n. (Rural) an area cleared of bush; a cleared part of a bush-farm (See also bush clearing)

ARNOLD She is one of a lot of cattle that have just been landed ... but she is now out on the clearing with Mr. Barrow's cows, and feeding away heartily, ... (Jul 24, 1848,NZ Letters,60,1960 ed.)

[?2.] Arthur is going to make a clearing on our land this year, and ...[sic] after the burn would put up a slab house of two rooms which might serve afterwards for cowshed or kitchen or workshop ... `Bird's heart is in the bushland, his heart is not here.' (Aug 8, 1855,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/172) [NOTES: (Jane M. Atkinson)]

Started with my hook ... to cut thistles. ... My old clearing is pretty clear but in parts of the new one they absolutely cover the ground to the exclusion of all grass. (Oct 15, 1862,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/797) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

The so called road between French's & Barriball's clearing ...[sic] is really the worst part of the line as it is so thickly overgrown [96] with makos &c. The tracks were destroyed by the pigs but there were still traces [of Maori] - one a mako stick cut, & others some hairs of a mat caught in a stick. (Mar 15, 1864,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/95) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

HAY The Tauhau (Zosterops lateralis) is a beautiful little green bird, much like a wren. ... It is much seen about gardens and clearings, and settlers know it as the `blight-bird'. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/226)

BELL In one of the lately settled bush districts of the Wellington Province, where the clearings were as yet comparatively few and of no very great extent - ... this story opens. Ibid. 8 A large clearing opened out on the right, and a little way back from the road-line stood a slab hut - or whare [e-acute], as it is generally called in New Zealand - of a rather better appearance than ordinary, from the iron chimney of which issued the smoke which the travellers had seen. Farther back from the road were yards and a larger building evidently used as a wool-shed. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,1)

I would include among New Zealand English words: clearing: glen (May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class)

2 n. (Rural) the clearing of land from bush, scrub, and other hindrances to cultivation.

HEAPHY Evidently the best way of clearing land is that pursued by the Canadians ... The settler is thus always employed either in the cultivation of the ground, or on fresh clearings; ... (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),74)

WAKEFIELD .. the expense of clearing was as follows: felling and lopping, logging and burning, at 5l. an acre; ... (1949,Handbook for New Zealand, The,177) [NOTES: 1844 F.A.Molesworth to the House of Commons Committee on NZ Matters in 1848 Wakefield Handbook for NZ 177 .]

BELL This was Maurice McKeown, employed ... to assist ... in the work of the farm, in attending to the stock, in logging up and clearing, in fencing, and also ... in doing a little bushfalling, though the latter work was usually let by contract, one of which was ... being carried out by ... Flash Harry, and his mates. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,9)

3 n. (Rural) land cleared and left for burning; occas. as clearing off.

The houses in this neighbourhood have been in some danger from bush firings ... then just as several people had lighted their clearings a strong gale from the south-east, what is called here `the mountain wind', sprang up. In a few hours all the dead trees and stumps in the neighbourhood were on fire. (Feb 24, 1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/141,1960 ed.)

They wanted to burn the large clearing that day. (Feb 26, 1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/143) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

As there was a nice breeze we lighted our clearings. Bill and the Ronalds also burnt - in all about 46 acres. I had not time to see how mine had burnt. (Mar 10, 1856,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/201,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

The burn must be pronounced on the whole bad ... 30/- per acre spent on clearing up will probably make a pretty fair clearing of it ... (May 4, 1857,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/262,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (H.R. Richmond)]

When burning the rest of the clearing-off in March ... (1892,TrNZI,24/704) [NOTES: (Millar)]

4 n. (Rural) (Clearing) as an early placename

FEATON Shortly after the Miltary posts had been established ..., contracts were let for clearing away the bush for some distance on each side of the road. ... [S]ome bushmen ... were busy at work felling and clearing away the bush alongside the road, a short distance past Williamson's Clearing. (1879,Waikato War,43) [NOTES: Auckland here]

clearing sale¶

1 n. (Rural) a sale of stock and equipment at the end of a farming season or when a farm property is sold.

The season of farm clearing sales began auspiciously in Taranaki last week ... (Jun 13, 1946,NZ Farmer,20)

Clearing sale: Insul timber posts and tie-downs ... (Nov 10, 1993,Napier Daily Telegraph,21)

Geary He'd bought the scythe at Cravens' clearing sale two years back. Not touched it since. (2003,Man of the People, A,117)

[Hdg] Unreserved Clearing Sale (May 15, 1915,Rangitikei Advocate,8)

ANTHONY On Sunday morning I ran my gig out of the shed..I had bought it at a clearing sale ... (1924,Follow the Call,23)

High rates have been ruling for dairy cattle at clearing sales and at saleyards. (May 31, 1945,NZ Farmer,40)

SHARPE When a farmer attends his own farewell party, either before or after his clearing sale, the idea that he is already dead is hard to avoid. (1962,Country Occasions,150)

Last year his old girls lambed 160 per cent and I bought the equivalent at his clearing sale. (Sep 10, 1970,NZ Farmer,60)

My father had a bad habit of going to clearing sales when he should have been doing his stockwork. (2001,Lifestyle Farmer,Feb/March 24)

The clearing sale season has arrived again. (May 2, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,17)

clearing-off¶

n.

Fires, originating generally from settlers' clearing-off operations, or the operations of kauri gum diggers and mineral prospectors, have in the past done considerable destruction, ... (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,581)

clearing-off sale¶

n.

CARR This station has been recently cut up for closer settlement, and settlers allowed the goats to be sold at the clearing-off sale. (1913,Country Work,28)

clears¶

n. the clears, the mainly fern-covered peaty land on Chatham Island, open or barren peat country; usu. collective pl. the clears.

[Sheep] feed on the open ground (`clears' as they are called here) in fine weather, and in rainy ... they all make for shelter in the bush. (1875,McLean Papers,42/) [NOTES: (S. Deighton, Waitangi, Chatham Island)]

Urged on ... he decided that the moors or clears between the big lagoon and the north coast ... would make ideal sheep land. (1883,Chudleigh Diary,210,1950 ed.)

[Chathams] Commenced ploughing the clears proper. (Mar 30, 1883,Chudleigh Diary,321,1950 ed.)

Having by observation found its sleeping place on the `clears', the Morioris made long tracks leading up to it ... (1897,TrNZI,29/166)

When the sea-birds came to lay their eggs in the `clears' in the south of the island the Morioris would live in that part. (1901,TrNZI,34/253) [NOTES: (Cockayne)]

SHAND They [sc. Chathams duck] were driven from the lagoons into the rushes and coarse growth of the `clears', or open land, where large [6] numbers were caught. (1911,Moriori People of the Chatham Islands, The,5)

*Clears, the.-Great areas of barren, peaty land growing nothing but stunted fern and a few weakly plants of fog. A term confined to the Chatham Islands. (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Gloss. additions]

ACLAND The clears: Great areas of barren, peaty land growing nothing but stunted fern and a few weakly plants of fog. A term confined to the Chatham Islands. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,361)

Peat country, which is usually wet, is locally referred to as clears', apparently because it was clear or free from trees and forest when the Chathams were discovered <i>(Apr 15, 1955,NZ Journal of Agriculture,90(4): 338-354</i>) [NOTES: (MaddenFarming and Rural Life on the Chatham Islands.')]

GRUNDY Well,' she explained,the men get up early morning and ride into the clears. [[fn] Peaty areas covered with tussock, flax and bracken.] They round up all the cattle they can find and bring them in.' (1968,Who'd Marry a Doctor?,66)

LANGDALE-HUNT There were three paddocks named after Morioris that had lived there: Meinui Field, near Fred Hunt's house, Kapata on the Paynter block, and Coachies Clear at Ranceby [?Rauceby]. (1985,Last Entail Male,142)

n.

SCOTT Clears Timber without (clear of) specified faults. (1987,Imported Timbers,70)

n. marbles

SUTTON-SMITH Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. (1972,Folkgames of Children,175)

clearskin¶

n. unbranded, wild cattle-beast; (See also cleanskin)

Clean.skins. (kl&emacr.n.sk&ibreve.nz.), } Clear.skins. emacr.r.sk&ibreve.nz.), } n. pl. Unbranded cattle. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2020)

CRADOCK ... the station offered ... [one pound] a head for all `clear skins' - that is belonging to unbranded genuine wild cattle. (1904,Sport in NZ,173)

LYON In this large area [of Rangitikei flax swamp] of perhaps forty thousand acres, cattle bred unmolested, and it was the custom of early settlers to shoot a clearskin, or unbranded young animal for meat. (1952,Faring South,85)

TURNER Clearskin or cleanskin are names for unbranded animals. In the underworld, cleanskin has been used for a man who has not crossed with the police before. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,148)

2 n. a man who has not crossed with the police before. (See also cleanskin)

TURNER Clearskin or cleanskin are names for unbranded animals. In the underworld, cleanskin has been used for a man who has not crossed with the police before. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,148)

clematis¶

n. one of the various indigenous species of climbing plants of the genus Clematis, which includes those by the names of pikiarero and puawananga.

A grey-green tapestry of manuka and kanuka trees in the gully beside us already has a few shawls of clematis. (Sep 21, 2007,Daily News,A6)

When introducing new pests to get rid of Old Man's Beard (Clematis vitalba), there is a lot of silliness and lack of knowledge, and sometimes where money comes in the brain goes out. (Dec 10, 2009,Daily News,A21)

We landed on Motu tapu in a lovely sheltered spot, where the clematis and convolvulus and other creeping plants hung beautifully around. (Nov 27, 1833,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,351)

POLACK The clematis, campanula trachelium, or bell flower, whose hues, white, red, and yellow, with the convolvulus, or bind-weed, and immumerable liands, [106] hung around in pleasing disorder. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/105)

COLENSO I detected a rambling Clematis with ternate, coriaceous, and glabrous leaves. (1844,Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ) [NOTES: 1844 Colenso Excursions North Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 12]

ANGAS The large and star-like flowers of the clematis, or piki-arero of the New Zealanders (1850,Savage Life,1/289)

HURSTHOUSE GET FROM MASTER (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/365)

ANGAS In the New Zealand forest the blossoms of the clematis and the passionflower enliven the sombre foliage of the larger trees, and the sweet-scented hoya fills the air with its fragrance. ... The natives call this plant `horopito'. (1866,Polynesia,51)

BARKER ... their stumps were already hidden by clematis and wild creepers of other kinds .. (1867,Station Life in NZ,180,1870 ed.)

DOMETT No clematis, so lovely in decline,/ Whose star-flowers when they cease to shine/ Fade into feathery wreaths silk-bright/ Ibid. 2/48 The King-pine that grandly towers: -/ The fuchsia-tree with its flowers,/ ... The clematis-garlands that cure/ Ibid. 2/337 Clematis ..... O. Ranunculaceae; G. Clematis; S. C. indivisa. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/132)

LADY MARTIN It was spring-time, and the great white clematis and the yellow kowai blossoms hung over the brim of the river in masses of gold and silver, which were reflected in the clear blue water. (1884,Our Maoris,94)

FEATON Pikiarero [Maori name] .. Clematis [Settlers' name] .. Clematis hexasepala .. Climber (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,178)

MANSFIELD We got great sprays of clematis - and konini, and drove first [I.A.Gordon edn: just] through a bush path - (Nov 20, 1907,Letters,1984,1/31 ed.)

The kohia (Passiflora tetrandra) is very abundant, ... while karioi [supplejack], mangemange, clematis, and tataramoa twine and intertwine as they unite tree to tree. (1889,TrNZI,21/37)

TURNER (And) Clematis indivisa (1909,AJHR,C-11) [NOTES: Botanical Examination Higher Waimarino]

The sweet-scented clematis (C. foetida) flourished on the Cattlemarket Reserve, now Montpelier, and parsonia (P. heterophylla) was more abundant on the Belt than it is now. (1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,IV/281) [NOTES: (Bathgate, Otago)]

SCANLAN Taller ferns, bracken, supplejack vines, clematis, bush lawyer, manuka, thousand-jacket twined and wreathed both trunk and branch . (1933,Tides of Youth,59)

LAING & BLACKWELL Taller ferns, bracken, supplejack vines, clematis, bush lawyer, manuka, thousand-jacket twined and wreathed both trunk and branch . (1940,Plants of NZ,173)

clematis : creeping plant with large (usually white) flowers. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,173)

MARTIN see also BUSH CLEMATIS (1929,Flora NZ,146,1961 ed.)

McLINTOCK New Zealand Clematis - pikiarero, pua-wananga, Clematis paniculata, Clematis species, and other climbing plants (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

HENDERSON Surely, the possibility of sneaking in just one more flower, The Lady of October as Golden Bay housewives call our native clematis, from the earth to the stars. (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,86)
