WILSON [=C. indivisa] Clematis paniculata CLEMATIS ... Puawaananga (1982,Stewart Island Plants,38)

F EATON CLEMATIS INDIVISA (Willd.) The Entire-leaved Clematis. ...The `PUAWANANGA'. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,2)

FEATON Puawananga [Maori name] .. Large Clematis [Settlers' name] .. Clematis indivisa ..Climber (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,178)

WHITE I would, of course, encourage our beautiful white native Clematis, but ugly things I would replace with the beautiful. (1905,My NZ Garden,53)

COCKAYNE (And) Clematis indivisa (1907,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island]

COCKAYNE (And) Clematis indivisa (1915,AJHR,C-6) [NOTES: Notes on the Plant Covering of Kennedy's Bush ... Canterbury]

FEATON Pokonuiahuru [Maori name] .. Small Clematis [Settlers' name] .. Clematis parviflora .. Climber (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,178)

COCKAYNE (And) Clematis hexasepala Clematis hexasepala, small white clematis (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Waipoua Kauri Forest]

On the whole the beech forest is dark and gloomy, but here and there it may be lighted up by a tuft of scarlet or yellow native mistletoe [fn Species of Loranthus.], or in spring by the gay garlands of white clematis; while in the more open places grows the beautiful ribbon-wood [fn Gaya ribifolia, slightly different from the more western Gaya lyallii.], with a profusion of white flowers resembling pear-blossom. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,186)

COCKAYNE (And) Clematis indivisa (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

clematis, oriental [s] Clematis orientalis L. Ibid. 55 oriental clematis [s] Clematis orientalis L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

The New Zealand clematis is now in full flower. (Aug 31, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,58)

Fewer reports are received of the leafless clematis, with yellow flowers. (Sep 14, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17)

On the tops of the tallest trees could be seen the clinging, twining vines of the clematis with its myriads of starry, snowy white blooms. (Dec 14, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,14)

To the pre-European Maori the clematis was a sacred flower as it indicated the coming of the warmth of spring. (Sep 1999,NZ Wilderness,54)

There are 11 species of clematis in New Zealand and they all have white or yellowish-green flowers. (Sep 1999,NZ Wilderness,54)

clemmed¶

adj. overcome by hunger, thirst, cold, etc, be (fair) clemmed

LADY BARKER `I'm fair clemmed wi' cold and wet', the swagger said. (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,168)

clench one's fist¶

phr. to die, to go west

Mafish.- Sam Slang remarks; It is well known how the Turkish word mafish' is commonly used now in place of old slang, such asgone a million,' blown out,'snuffed it,' clenched his fist,'crashed in,' handed in his checks,'took the count,' `skied the towel,' etc. (Nov 1, 1918,Quick March,15)

Cleopatra¶

n. New York pippin apple [No longer grown commercially.]

ROYAL NZ INSTITUTE HORTICULTURE In the case of yellow and green apples, the appearance of such apples is enhanced if a blush is present, such as may be found in Cleopatra. (1951,Official Judging Rules,21)

Mr. J.G. Sharpe.. has given to the Herald some particulars regarding a box of sample apples, in duplicate sent to England... Cleopatra - Both sound. (Jul 24, 1890,Otago Witness,5)

Cleopatra: VARIETIES ... Apples Ballarat Seedling ... Cleopatra ... Rome Beauty ... -- (Jan 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,60)

The New York Pippins (Cleopatras) were a nice line. Although apparently an early shipment of this variety, it is one that will stand shipping on the green side. (Jan 15, 1913,NZ Journal of Agriculture,388)

CLEOPATRA Causes of deterioration. (1933,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,14/288)

Five included lists of apples for export, the following varieties have been recommended:- Blenheim Orange.. Wellington Pippin.. Northern Spy.. Cleopatra. (Jul 30, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,34)

BENSEMANN A photo is taken of the six varieties as follows.. Cox Orange Pippin.. Cleopatra.. Delicious. Sturmer.. Jonathan.. Dunn's Favourite. Ibid. 89 [Caption] Fig. 40 showing Sturmer and Cleopatra apples. (1939,Apple Culture,68)

Apple to name is Grannie Smith, which somewhat resembles Cleopatra. (Jun 22, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,54)

clew up¶

v. to finish

The season was clewed up on Saturday when Poneke (challengers) and Petone (holders, by virtue of its winning of the Senior Championship) met to decide possession of the Charity Cup for the ensuing twelve months. (Oct 6, 1906,NZ Truth,3)

clianthus¶

n. Commonly known as kaka beak or kaka's beak, the Clianthus puniceus is a shrub with vibrant red flowers shaped like the beak of a kaka or parrot.

With so few spectacular native bloomers here it's no surprise that our Kaka's beak, Clianthus puniceus, was a hit with Captain Cook's plant hunters and those who followed them, which may or may not have resulted in its having become rare in the wild. (Aug 26, 2006,Dominion Post,B19)

MACKIE The only native plant grown in the gardens for the beauty of its flowers is the Clianthus. (Jun 23, 1853,Traveller under Concern,119,1973 ed.)

Hooker says the genus clianthus consists of the Australian and New Zealand species only, the latter is there- fore clearly indigenous. `One of the most beautiful plants known' (Hooker). Sir Joseph Banks and Dr. Solander found it during Cook's first voyage.' (Nov 24, 1892,Otago Witness) [NOTES: (Native Trees) [Morris]]

Cli-ań.thus (kl.-&abreve.ń.th&ubreve.s), n. [N.L., fr. Gr. {klei}-, akin to {kleos} glory + {anthos} flower.] (Bot.) A genus of Australian leguminous plants (the glory pea), with only two species : C. Dampierii, called also Sturt's desert pea; and C. puniceus, confined to New Zealand, - called also parrot's bill, kaka-bill, and parrot's bill kowhai. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2020)

MORRIS Clianthus ... scientic name for an Australasian genus of plants, N.O. Leguminosa, containing only two species-in Australia, Sturt's Desert Pea (q.v.), C. damperi; and in New Zealand, the Kaka-bill (q.v.), C. puniceus. Both species are called glory-pea, from Grk. (1898,Austral English,89)

TANNOCK The clianthus is a most showy plant, ... (1921,Manual of Gardening,140)

clianthus n. a leguminous plant of Australia and New Zealand with ornamental clusters of slender flowers. [C19: NL, prob. < GK klei-, kleos glory + anthos flower] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,207)

clianthus /klai|aen[th][es/ n. ornamental Australian or NZ shrub with red flowers (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,133)

2 n. Clianthus puniceus

(1837,Botanist, The) [NOTES: 1837 The Botanist (1837-46) ed. B. Maund (And)]

2 n.

LAING & BLACKWELL Clianthus puniceus (The Scarlet Clianthus)... This tree [shrub] is known as the Red Kowhai, Parrot's Bill, or Kaka's Beak Native name Kowhai-ngutu-kaka, signifying the Parrot-beaked kowhai. It is also called in the Urewera Country Ngutu-Kakariki, the Parroquet's Beak. (1907,Plants of NZ,210,1940, p. 221 ed.)

2 n. Sophora microphylla kowhai

TANCRED Sophora microphylla (Edinburgh New Philos. Journal (NS) Jan 1856) (And) (1856,Natural History of Canterbury) [NOTES: 1856 Tancred Notes on the Natural History of ... Canterbury]

clickie¶

n. train guard [mistake for clippie?]

I have the dubious distinction of being carted from the Hutt into Wellington and back every day by the indifferent Tranz Metro crowd, who it can be said doesn't include the long-suffering 'clickies' or drivers. (Jan 14, 2003,Dominion Post,A2)

clicks¶

n. a technical term in the game of knucklebones

MARSHALL Creamy was even better with the aluminium ones [sc. knuckle bones]. Cutting cabbages, camels, swatting flies, clicks, little jingles, through the arch, goliath, horses in the stable; Creamy mastered them all. (1982,Master of Big Jingles,55)

clicksies¶

exclam. [ca1964 Auckland ... said when one wants, or has, another go or turn]

clicky hip¶

n.

Clicky hip is a condition, which although affecting few children, can have a dramatic effect on them and their parents... Clicky hip is a condition in which the hip joint falls out of its socket, with a clicking sound, which gives the condition its common name. (May 1, 2001,Independent Herald (Wellington),4)

climb over¶

n.

We had travelled about half a mile over and under boulders, with several annoying `climb overs'. (Aug 1934,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,14)

climbing aniseed¶

n. [one entry, climbing aniseed - A geniculata] (See aniseed)

COCKAYNE Angelica geniculata Climbing-aniseed (1915,AJHR,C-6) [NOTES: Plant Covering Kennedy's Bush in AJHR (Canterbury) (And).]

climbing broom¶

n. (Environment) an endangered indigenous broom, Carmichaelia kirkii

The Kaikoura ranges also represent the northern and southern limits for some plant species, including the northern most population of the nationally threatened climbing broom ( Carmichaelia kirkii ) which has a threat category of Nationally Endangered. (Jun 2008,Internet - see Notes,3) [NOTES: Kaikoura District Council newsletter, June 2008]

climbing fern¶

n.

LAING & BLACKWELL ... the climbing fern (Lygodium articulatum) [is], however, often found growing under the stately pines. (1907,Plants of NZ,62,1940 p. 61 ed.)

(And) Lygodium articulatum (1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue)

COCKAYNE The Climbing Fern (Blechnum filiforme), showing the small early leaf-form (1910,NZ Plants,31)

COCKAYNE The Climbing Fern (Blechnum filiforme), showing the small early leaf-form (1910,NZ Plants,31)

n. Muehlenbeckia adpressa.

(And) Muehlenbeckia adpressa . climbing lignum (Jul 1920,Victorian Naturalist)

climbing lily¶

n. Rhipogonum scandens ; =supplejack. [-->1900 Dendy In Canterbury Old and New (And)]

climbing rata¶

n. [eg Metrosideros carminea and M. fulgens]

There are six climbing ratas, four of them with showy flowers and the others with small, white flowers. (Mar 13, 2004,Dominion Post,E10)

Extensive curtains of the climbing rata Metrosideros colensoi cloak many limestone rock walls. (Mar 2003,Open Space,No. 60/28)

LAING & BLACKWELL (And) (1906,Plants of NZ)

clinah/cliner¶

n. a girl or girlfriend [a1930 up to but not after c1930: W.H.B. Orsman]

For he tells you, not being prudy,/ That your love's a Tom' orTart',/ Or a clinah' or aJudy',/ Likwise Bit of Skirt' orTart'. (Mar 31, 1906,NZ Truth,41/6/4) [NOTES: [Bloke's Patter]]

PICARD ... no thanks to this party [26] who had been smoodging to a clina up the line instead of slinging the roaring lion his hash. (1906,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,25)

clinah, cliner n. (slang) girl [orig. German or Yiddish]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),613)

clinah, cliner n. (Sl.) girl [Orig. German or Yiddish]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

cling-on¶

n.

Up on the heights, in the scree, where plants can be sheered off moving surfaces or baked in the sun, alpine cling-ons form tight cushions and shelter from winds by forming a low continuous surface and making masses of twiggy growth which is tightly covered in small hard leaves to prevent moisture loss. (Feb 9, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,8)

clingfish¶

n. piripiri-pohutu, suckerfish

PAUL Clingfishes Family Gobiesocidae. ... There are about ten New Zealand species ... (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,135)

PHILLIPPS Trachelochismus littoreus (Forster). CLINGFISH. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,55,1971 ed.)

Trachelochismus littoreus (Forster). Cling-fish. (1938,TrRSNZ,68/418) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

[species name] clingfish .. [scientific name] Diplocrepis puniceus .. or Trachelochismus littoreus .. [other name(s)] lionhead (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

GRAHAM Clingfish Trachelochismus melobesia Phillipps (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,413) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 413]

2 n. piripiri-pohutu, suckerfish.

POWELL CLING FISH (Diplocrepis puniceus). This is found by turning over stones at low tide, for it frequently makes no attempt to escape, but clings tightly to the stone by means of a specially designed suction disc on the under side of the body ... common in Auckland waters. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,65)

NATUSCH Family GOBIESOCIDAE. Small clingfish are found inshore, under stones in intertidal pools. About the most appropriate word for the various species is the Maori piripiri-pohutu. Pohutu means head, and piripiri is better known in the corrupted form bidibid. In this case the sucker is an adaptation of the ventral fins and the lower rays of the pectorals. Diplocrepis ... is found under stones on open rocky coasts that take a fair pounding; ... (1967,Animals of NZ, The,233)

GRAHAM Clingfish Diplocrepis puniceus(Richardson) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,413) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 413]

WILSON CLINGFISH Of the eight Clingfish found in New Zealand only one, Diplocrepis puniceus, is commonly sighted. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,36)

DOOGUE & MORELAND Other names: Diplocrepis puniceus; suckerfish, a name more appropriate to the remora or shark sucker. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,292)

MORELAND CLINGFISH [Diplocrepis puniceus] ... Suckerfish is an alternative name. (1967,Marine Fishes,20)

3 n.

GRAHAM Clingfish Gastrocymba quadriradiata (Rendahl) (1955,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,413) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 413]

4 n.

GRAHAM Clingfish Dellichthys morelandi Briggs (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,413) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 413]

5 n.

GRAHAM Clingfish Haplocylix littoreus (Bloch and Schn.) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,413) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 413]

6 n. [[check scient. name].]

GRAHAM Clingfish Gastroscyphus hectoris (Gunther) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,413) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 413]

7 n. [[check scient. name].]

GRAHAM Clingfish Gastrocyathus gracilis Briggs (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,413) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 413]

8 n.

AYLING ORANGE CLINGFISH Diplocrepis puniceus ... Orange clingfish are common on rocky coasts throughout New Zealand but are restricted to a narrow band reaching from immediately above low water level down to about 5m depth. (1982,Collins Guide,134,1984 ed.)

clinging rata¶

n. .

clinging rata [s] Metrosideros perforata (Forst.) A. Rich. Ibid. 63 rata, clinging [s] Metrosideros perforata (Forst.) A. Rich. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

Myrtaceae M[etrosideros] perforataclinging rata (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: (Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri)]

clinic¶

n. an MP's regular meeting-place for interviewing constituents in his electorate. -

People do lobby politicians directly: even MP's local clinics, as they are called, are part of this. (Jul 16, 1987,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: National Party's Vice-President on National Radio]

clinker beech¶

n. Nothofagus truncata, HARD BEECH [[a1927] = Vernacular names supplied by L. Cockayne (And) Nothofagus truncata clinker beech .ho;[a1927 Ver. (A). =Vernacular names supplied by B.C. Aston (And) ?Nothofagus Menziesii clinker birch]

LAING & BLACKWELL N. fusca (The Red Beech) ... North Island: mountainous districts; South Island: abundant. The Red Birch. A somewhat similar species is N. truncata, the Clinker Beech, often called the Hard-Beech. (1940,Plants of NZ,139)

clinkered¶

adj. hob-nailed [check EDD; ?get NZ uses of the noun]

`Well, out of the boo-ai comes three trampers. ... One had ... clinkered boots and an old kidney-rotter. ...' (Apr 19, 1971,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

clip¶

n.

n. all the wool shorn from sheep from one area, farm, or group, or the wool shorn in a season

I have a clip would fill a ship. (Dec 6, 1913,NZ Observer,16)

ECCLES & REED Mr. Jones's clip (and he began with but a handful) amounted last year to 4,500; this year it will be 6,000, and which is quite within the regular progressive increase. (1949,John Jones of Otago,49) [NOTES: 1848 Sep 23 Cargill in Eccles and Reed John Jones of Otago (1949) 49]

WELD I think that this sum, the proceeds of two clips of wool, should carry your station over the first two years ... (1851,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,5)

... the old clip; of the new clip ... including the May Sales, about 122,000 bales have been sold (Feb 8, 1851,Lyttelton Times,3)

SAM STEPHENS It is feared that many [Flock-owners] will not be able to save their clip of wool (1851,Journal,534)

ADAMS ... the clip being completed, the wool-sacks are conveyed to the port. (1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,74)

[advt] The Undersigned is a buyer of WOOL of the ensuing clip. Wellington, Jan., 1855. W.S. LOXLEY (1855,Wellington and Canterbury Almanack)

ACLAND One gentleman, with a flock of nearly five thousand sheep, told me, in 1856, his preceding clip had averaged four pounds ... all round, though many lambs had been shorn. (1858,Notes on Sheepfarming in NZ,6)

It is possible your clips may arrive [in London] to the early sales. (1863,McLean Papers,XX2/202,1839 ed.)

My shearing has been a long one and my clip a light one and ... sheep are missing. (Dec 5, 1879,Chudleigh Diary,282,1950 ed.)

CAMPBELL Under his hospitable roof I took my first lesson in dumping wool,' for he was busybaling his clip' to send down to Sydney for shipment home. (1881,Poenamo,Bk1/3/41)

The average clips for the various breeds of sheep are approximately as follow: Merino, from 4lb. to 7lb.; quarter-breds, about 6 1/2lb.; half-breds, 7 1/2lb.; three-quarter breds, 8 1/2lb (1892,NZ Official Handbook,122)

The average clips for the various breeds of sheep are approximately as follow : Merino, from 4lb. to 7lb.; quarter-breds, about 6-1/2lb.; half-breds, 7-1/2lb.; three-quarter-breds, 8-1/2lb.; .. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,92)

OWEN They're not half a bad flock ... It ought to be a good clip (1909,Philip Loveluck,172)

R EES It's going to be a good clip (1925,Lake of Enchantment,114)

Regarding the respective values of the clips, it is hardly necessary to state that fleeces from March-shorn sheep were not able to be rolled. (1929,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,10/326)

Clip. The whole body of wool for the year (off a station, or belonging to a man). C. My <i>clip</i> is not so good this year as last', or,My ewes clipped seven pounds all round'; but more usually, `My ewes cut seven lbs'. ([c1890-1900]) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15)

HUNT The phenomenal growth of my company aroused certain of our competitors from whom we were taking scores of clips of wool that they had handled for many years. (1951,Confessions,71)

In large clips of 100 bales or more each of these lines would usually be subdivided into two lots, as: ... (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,710)

DICK There is a small creek, not far from the woolshed, called Woolwash Creek, wherein Pringle scoured his clip. Ibid. 25 In the 1915-16 shearing season the whole clip was sold privately for 10d per pound, with the exception of the locks which were 4d per pound. (1964,High Country Family,21)

MEEK CLIP: The total bulk of wool shorn. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

Clip. Quantity of shorn wool from a defined area (farm or locality) or group of sheep. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53)

OGONOWSKA-COATES Clip. The wool shorn on a station each season. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,53)

The wool is being cleared very slowly,space for less than 2,000 bales of thenew clip having been allotted. (Jan 8, 1918,Evening Post,6)

The quality of the clip was above the average offered at the Auckland sales. (Dec 7, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,21)

As you ship your wool direct to London, you can't depend on any cash coming in for this season's clip. (Nov 4, 1924,Otago Witness,54)

The third Christchurch wool sale is traditionally regarded as the sale at which the big back country clips make their appearance. (Mar 10, 1934,Feilding Star,7)

v.

Shearing at Langdale was concluded on Wednesday last, three hundred bales having been clipped in a fortnight... A luncheon was provided in the woolshed. (Nov 23, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

... he [E.J.Wakefield] alone will clip 7000 sheep (1850,Stafford Papers,1/71)

CRAWFORD .. make a thorough muster for stragglers ... and after dipping and clipping them ... (1949,Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury,48,1949 ed.) [NOTES: 1861 Duppa in Crawford Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury (1949) 48]

v.

NEWTON [Wild sheep] clip very little wool. (1947,Wayleggo,52)

WHEELER We shear 21,000 sheep ... and clip 500 bales. (1973,Historic Sheep Stations NI,18)

n. (Rural) fleeceweight of wool from an individual sheep.

HAYES It [a Corriedale sheep] also produces a heavy clip of wool. (1978,From the Toss of a Coin,75)

BARKER Water, and sheltered feed, and undisturbed camping grounds, - all these good things were provided for them, and in return they were expected to yield a large percentage of lambs and a good 'clip.' (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,223)

n. (Rural) the process of shearing.

With most of the plains shearing completed, the back-country is proceeding spasmodically with its clip, interrupted by frequent north-west rains. (Jan 16, 1941,NZ Farmer,5)

1 v. (Rural) [sheep] to produce wool for clipping.

.. our sheep are larger than the Australian, and clip a much heavier fleece. (1860,BLANK ENTRY,41) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

1 n. (Rural) the total annual amount of wool from a specific property, province, a type of sheep or from the nation.

TAIT The wool clip has been kept up. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,93)

BREMNER During World War II the entire national clip was commandeered by the Government and all private exporting ceased. (1985,Woolscours of NZ,118)

WELD I think that this sum, the proceeds of two clips of wool, should carry your station over the first two years. (1851,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,5)

BALFOUR Usually the grazier too one-half of the annual wool clip of the 'terms' sheep ... (1885,Balfour Diaries,75)

ALLEN The Te Maire stock was driven along a track through the bush to the saleyards there but the wool clip was sledged down to the river landing and went to Wanganui by boat. (1980,Farm on the Wanganui River, A,9)

LOUGHNAN clip: (i) (n): sum total of wool taken in a year from a flock. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,18)

EASY The third season the price of wool improved and we had three clips to sell. (1991,Looking Backwards,40)

Ideally it [Growerco] would secure 50,000 tonnes or a third of the nation's strong-wool clip. (Nov 15, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,21)

2 v.

BOWEN The [Cheviot] breed clips well, and the wool is reasonably fine, ... Ibid. 144 The Lincoln clips a big weight of wool per sheep, and the heavy long staple is inclined to pull the skin out. (1955,Wool Away!,139)

NEWTON They were shearing lambs ... and for all the drought conditions they [? the lambs] were clipping about 3 [and half] pounds. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,16)

clipon¶

n. Nippon clipon q.v., or other add-on

A new constitution would reflect the true spirit of the Treaty partnership, not the tokenism enshrined in current legislation or the clip-on commitments to the Treaty favoured by the professions. (Mar 27, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34)

We've closed the northbound clipon.. until January 6 so we can replace the damaged seal with a new polyurethane surface material. (Dec 29, 1996,Sunday Star Times,A3)

It was about three years ago that Jim Anderton began to channel this small-town anguish into a demand for a People's Bank. The best that NZ Post.. could come up with appeared to be a rather limited banking clip-on to its regular Post Shopservices. (Feb 8, 2001,Independent Business Weekly,13)

clipon lane¶

n. one of the traffic lanes added to the Auckland Harbour Bridge (See also Nippon clipon)

All four lanes will have to close each night, as will the on-ramp from Curran St in St Mary's Bay, confining traffic to the two clip-on lanes in each direction. ... He acknowledged that the work would have to be finished before a separate project to reseal the two northbound clip-on lanes could begin but said he was not about to start panicking. (Oct 11, 2005,NZ Herald,A2)

clipper¶

n.

BELL It was Mary who came to the door ... `She's a regular clipper, and no mistake; and enough to make any sober-minded chap like George begin to think seriously about matrimony.' (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,86)

n. machine or mechanical shears as distinct from hand-shears or blades

DEVANNY During the wool-clipping [he] invariably became uneasy ... and the hand holding the clippers would shake. (1926,Butcher Shop, The,10)

1 n. (Rural) a fleece-bearing sheep.

The Parorangi Romneys are noted for their good frames, fineness and density of fleece, being heavy clippers of hardy constitution. (May 1909,NZ Farmer,349)

The Hui Hui Corriedales are big clippers of superior Corriedale wool - well crimped from skin to tip. (Jan 1, 1929,NZ Farmer,59)

These flocks are bred principally from Wairongomai strain. They carry dense crimpy wool and are very good clippers. (Oct 15, 1937,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

Kainui sheep have a reputation for good frames and are heavy clippers of good quality wool. (Jan 9, 1941,NZ Farmer,34)

clippie¶

n. a train, bus or tram conductor

Things are bad in New Zealand now for such women, What with clippies on the trams, land girls and meat factory girls. (Mar 13, 1944,NZEF Times,III/142 : 7)

Tomorrow morning, when your tram ticket is punched by the same Maori clippie you meet every day, and you don't turn up your European nose at her, then you have the authority of the film for feeling enlightened, ... (Sep 1952,Here & Now,29)

Where's the guard, where's the guard?,' she said. We had this clippie with us and she said `What's the matter?' (Jul 25, 1980,Dominion,1/3)

clipping¶

n.

TAIT Jigs and clippings and other mysteries [of coalmining] were explained to me. (1948,Short Sketches of Life in NZ,16)

adj. (Rural) [of sheep] growing wool.

.. a wave seems to have come in favour of the Lincoln again, which must always be the foundation of a good clipping sheep. (Feb 10, 1906,Farmers' Union Advocate,12)

clobbering machine¶

n. the local or bureaucratic conservatism allegedly responsible for quashing individual creativity. [often preceded by (great) Kiwi/New Zealand]

This exercise in destruction and negativity is yet another example of the Kiwi Clobbering Machine in full cry. (May 11, 2006,Dominion Post,B6)

Couldn't the Great New Zealand Clobbering Machine lay off Sharon? (Sep 27, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

"There's a bit of a clobbering machine when you come in because you have got to conform, and learn to listen and learn the tricks of this trade. There lies the real challenge, which is how do you keep that talent and fresh ideas and not clobber it," says the diplomat. (Mar 17, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C1)

You can talk for hours about the clobbering machine or the tall poppy syndrome, but I think it's time we put all that to bed. (Jul 25, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48)

He is in a better position than many to analyse the Great Kiwi Clobbering Machine. "Some of us are lucky to survive it," he says, without a trace of self-pity. (May 17, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

I think I've been quite lucky so far in that the great Kiwi clobbering machine has left me alone. (Jun 11, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

It was hardly surprising to see the great New Zealand clobbering machine grinding into action. (Nov 18, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10)

The Great New Zealand Clobbering Machine which keeps our heroes down to a manageable number goaded him on to triumph. (Mar 27, 1992,Evening Post,4)

"This is the nature of the New Zealand sporting fan, we saw it with the All Blacks, it is called the great Kiwi clobbering machine. (Jun 7, 2000,Dominion,48)

Sadly, the great Kiwi clobbering machine is alive and well in New Zealand, if the antics of those organising the campaign to stop overnight trips to Kapiti Islands are anything to go by. (Feb 23, 2002,Dominion,19)

clobbering machine n. N.Z. inf. pressure to conform with accepted standards. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,208) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 89]]

(The musical clobbering-machine in New Zealand is not short on frenzied moral outrage.) (Oct 3, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

The `Kiwi clobbering machine' comes down hard on those who stick their heads above the dingy crowd ... Sportsmen like Sir Edmund Hillary and Colin Meads become archetypes of sainted Kiwihood, their virtues deemed to be all-embracing ... (Dec 27, 1987,Dominion Sunday Times,6)

Thanks to the machinations of the Great Kiwi Clobbering machine we all know the fallacy of such a naive assumption. (Jun 25, 1988,Evening Post,6)

`The great Kiwi clobbering machine does not exist in the bookworld, as people do take a pride in their country and their heritage,' Mr King said ... (Jul 14, 1988,Evening Post,37)

McGILL clobbering machine, the the way in which the system is alleged to command conformity by squashing people who stand out, cutting tall poppies down to everybody's size, the tyranny of the mediocre, the dark side of egalitarianism - or sour grapes from those frustrated by conformity or slowed down by rules and regulations. Somewhat dated by Rogernomics. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,29)

The great brown clobbering machine is a major obstacle to Maori achievement at school, say two researchers ... Achievers are labelledmallowpuff Maoris' and, in some cases, deliberately break from their Maori friends to escape negative peer pressure. (Feb 14, 1989,Press, The,19)

This exercise in destruction and negativity is yet another example of the Kiwi Clobbering Machine in full cry. (May 11, 2006,Dominion Post,B6)

It's been a very odd week and a little bruising for Walden. He's been caught in the headlights of the Kiwi clobbering machine. (Sep 22, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C1)

Clobbery, the¶

n. (name of a) menswear shop.

HOWE On our way up-town [Auckland] we passed a store labelled the Clobbery. The stock seemed to consist of gent's furnishing goods. Perhaps an English friend can tell you where the word clobbery comes from; I never heard it before. (1913,Travel Letters,44)

clock¶

n. the freezing-works butcher equivalent of the "ringer" in a shearing gang

The "clock" in the days of solo butchering in the freezing works was the equivalent of the "ringer" in the shearing gang. The "clock" who was, however, not necessarily the fastest butcher, gave the signal for the butchers to dash into the pen and stick three animals. He waited then until the slowest of the butchers in the team had dressed their animals before he gave the word for a further foray to be made. (Feb 11, 1977,Press, The,19)

clocken¶

adj. Dial. cf clocking--> at clucky

MOSER ... like a `clocken hen' he ha been perpetually sitting. (1863,Mahoe Leaves,50)

clodocracy¶

n. formed by analogy as a political nonce-word for the agricultural leaseholders in the Otago land debates; hence clodocrat, clodocratic

1871 May 31 Otago Daily Times in McLintock `The History of Otago' 541 (Griffiths Collection) (May 31, 1871,Otago Daily Times)

clonette¶

n.

To his horror, adolescent clonettes Teaspoon were squeaking, "I wanna have sex on the beach, sex on the beach." (Jul 23, 2000,Sunday Star Times,F4)

clop¶

v. to hit

BAILEY & ROTH Hey! Watch that sling. (3) If it should clop me and knock me in! (1967,Shanties,141)

close-grazed¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of land] grazed completely, in order to encourage new growth.

NEWTON The Finlaysons' policy is to mob-stock with heavy concentrations of both sheep and cattle, and close-grazed, it [kikuyu] is a good grass. (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,190)

With the help of the sheep, the sward is kept close grazed ... (Aug 19, 1936,Weekly News,78)

NEWTON Next in importance in his opinion is that the country be close-grazed; rank growth must not be permitted. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,74)

close-hauled¶

adj. short of cash

EADDY ... there would be no use in landing in London for the first time close-hauled. (1933,Hull Down,17)

close-hilled country¶

1 n. (Rural) land that is broken by very narrow, steep valleys.

MACDONALD The lay of the land to the sun is a considerable matter in close-hilled country. (1920,Australian & NZ Sheep Farming,2)

close-paddocking¶

n.

PATTERSON Now, on account of the smallness of the gum, the use of the spear has now been all but abandoned, and `close-paddocking' is the rule, from the absolute necessity of collecting all the gum that exists, however small it may be. (1904,Kauri-Gum,6)

close-to-profit¶

1 adj. (Rural) [stock sales] [see at profit; near profit] (of a a ewe or cow) about to produce offspring.

The market for in-milk and close-to-profit dairy cattle was stable at Inglewood on Monday. [close-to-profit; ] (Nov 1, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,19)

2 adj. (Rural, humorous) (of a woman) in late pregnancy.

SHARPE As the [film] show progressed there appeared on the screen the figure of a woman who was, as we put it, close to profit. In other words, she was soon to have a child. (1962,Country Occasions,15)

close-up¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of cows or other farm stock] close to reproducing.

The majority of town milk suppliers do not breed their own replacements, but rely on buying close-up cows at dispersal sales. (Oct 9, 1952,NZ Farmer,22)

The graziers will hold them [the backward cattle] for a couple of months until they are close up. (Aug 16, 1951,NZ Farmer,43)

Prices for best cows went to aGBP18 but the general run of close-up cows fetched around aGBP16. (Dec 6, 1951,NZ Farmer,47)

As calving approaches sort throught the herd each week and bring the close-up cows into the safe paddock near the shed. [close up] (Mar 1967,NZ Journal of Agriculture,37)

closed flock¶

1 n. (Rural) a flock of sheep that has been maintained without new strains being introduced.

It has been a closed flock for 40 years. (Dec 31, 1964,NZ Farmer,5)

Expert Livestock If we take this example of a closed ewe flock with a lambing percentage of 100% ... (Feb 10, 2002,Fencepost.com)

closed herd¶

1 n. (Rural) a herd that is bred on a property, having no stock added to it from other breeders, and consequently thought to have no contamination or disease.

STEVENS The Longbeach herd remained closed; only Longbeach bulls or bulls of Longbeach breeding from satellite herds were ever used during the lifetime of JCN Grigg. (1970,Pyne Gould Guinness: the jubilee history,80)

He's got a closed herd so either the dips don't do all they say, or else the lice live on the matagouri during dipping. (Sep 10, 1970,NZ Farmer,35)

This is a closed herd ... (May 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,106)

MAF said to me 'You of all people have the perfect closed herd.' (Jul 6, 1995,NZ Farmer,18)

closed shed¶

1 n. (Rural) a woolshed where a gang is hired before the shearing season or where an individual shearer can book a stand, usually involving a deposit.

LOUGHNAN Add I 1 closed shed: a system no longer in vogue, by which a shearer could book a stand (usually on a aGBP1 deposit.) (1981,Loughnan Glossary)

VANCE Eventually there evolved a more satisfactory system of engaging labour, known as the 'closed shed' which permitted a shearer to book a pen for the next season. (1965,High Endeavour,51)

Closer Economic Partnership¶

phr. economic pact with Singapore etc. (See also CEP)

It fits neatly alongside the superbly Orwellian terminology "Closer Economic Partnership", coined for Singapore, and now Hong Kong. (Jun 9, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

Closer Economic Relationship¶

phr. sc. with Australia; now usu. CER, Closer Economic Relations (trade agreement between the two countries signed in 1983)

It is important to remember that when the Closer Economic Relationship between Australia and New Zealand began to be aired about 10 years ago, the long-term goal was not only to come to terms with the cumbersome provisions of Nafta, but also to provide a basis of strength for an assault on world markets, including Asia. (Dec 12, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

Closing the Gaps¶

phr. Government initiatives to remove disparities between Maori and pakeha and between rich and poor.

[Hdg] Vicious attack on Gaps debunker... His crime? Publishing a paper exposiung the flawed assumptions underpinning Labour's Closing the Gaps policy of preferential treatment for New Zealanders of Maori descent. (Dec 11, 2000,Dominion,6)

The previous government, with Tau Henare as Minister of Maori Affairs, produced the first "Closing the Gaps" report in 1998. (Oct 28, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

[Hdg] Clark turns 'gaps' gun on Nats... Miss Clark said "Closing the Gaps" had been coined by the previous government but in opposition National had used it to play the race card. (Dec 13, 2000,Dominion,2)

[These themes] were embodied by the policy hot potato formerly known as "closing the gaps" and by the new Employment Relations Act. (Aug 28, 2003,Dominion Post)

But the long term problem remains this closing the gaps beast. (Dec 24, 2000,Sunday Star Times,A6)

The anniversary of the launch of the no-longer-so-named Closing the Gaps policy sparked renewed anger among Maori and calls of a "duplicitous approach" from National. (Jan 27, 2001,Evening Post,52)

Closing the Gaps has become the [sic] Closing the Subject, and just last week the Government dumped controversial terms from resource management legislation that would have included the woolly words "spiritual" and "ancestral landscapes". (May 20, 2003,Dominion Post,B4)

The prime minister has put great store in the Closing the Gaps social programme launched in last month's budget. (Jul 2, 2000,Sunday Star Times,A11)

The Government's commitment to closing the gaps came under fire at a Maori development conference yesterday... "How can we close the gaps at the tertiary level {when this happens]? All of us know we need skilled people. (Jul 5, 2000,Evening Post,9)

The Government...says it's allocating one of four 3G frequency slots to Maori as part of its "closing the gaps" strategy. (Jul 8, 2000,Evening Post,12)

The Closing the Gaps programme will endeavour to transfer resources directly to communities and the establishment of a self-management capacity is the central feature of the policy. (Jul 20, 2000,Dominion,8)

If anyone still questions the Government's plan to close the gaps they just need to look at the statistics. (Jul 29, 2000,Evening Post,9)

Those gaps are discussed in a May 2000 report to the Minister of Maori Affairs, Progress Towards Closing Social and Economic Gaps Between Maori and Non-Maori... A leading member of the Auckland Maori Catholic community has reservations about the Government's Closing the Gaps programming... In the Closing the Gaps programme, education receives almost $158 million. (Jul 30, 2000,NZ Catholic,7)

Labour will be forced to justify ahead of the next election its Closing the Gaps policy... Labour insiders concede there is an awful lot of antagonism and prejudice about the Gaps policy among white New Zealanders... Critics feel that Mrs Turia should be concentrating on selling the Gaps policy, rather than raising issues which detract from it. (Sep 2, 2000,Evening Post,9)

She has been ruthless about ditching. Note Dover Samuels. And Closing the Gaps. (Jul 19, 2004,Dominion Post,B5)

Closing the gaps is now a banned phrase in government circles - the name was changed to Reducing Inequalities after a political furore - but the actual policy remains. The government still wants to close the gaps.Ibid.C8 Closing the gaps is hard to do, as a new government report makes clear. (Jan 18, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C1)

I rang the prime minister's office in search of the closing the gaps policy statement, I was told there was none, only a sentence that made reference to closing the gaps between Maori and Pacific people and other New Zealanders. There are two Te Puni Kokiri reports on closing the gaps. One of these (1998) predates this government and the second was issued in May this year. (Nov 5, 2000,Sunday Star Times,C8)

clostrometer¶

1 n. (Rural) an instrument that measures the specific gravity of colostrum.

WESTWOOD Quality can be tested with a 'clostrometer' which tests the specific gravity of the colostrum. (2000,Rearing Healthy Calves,1)

cloth plant¶

n.

The third sort of Ahou [cloak] seemed to be made of the Cloth Plant coarse- ly beat out or of a kind of narrow Sedge or course [sic] grass- ... the ends of the stuff of about a foot long were left out so as to form a thick covering layer over layer, and very much resembled what Seamen call thrum-Matts. (1955,Cook's Journals,1/572) [NOTES: 1769 Oct 11 W.B. Monkhouse in 1955 Cook Journal I-572]

clothes hoist¶

n.

clothing/clothing class¶

1 n. (Rural) one of two classes of fleece wool; the shorter and more tender type.

Clothing wool is either unsound or too short to comb and so is made into clothing. (Jul 1892,NZ Farmer,291)

CHANDLER On the open end of the main floor were the slatted inclined tables for throwing out the fleeces upon, so that the wool classer could class the fleece, sort it and then roll it up and pitch it into a convenient hole according to its class - combing or clothing in those days. (1996,Land of the Mountain and the Flood,37)

BISLEY ... we recommend that the separation of the fleece portion of the clip, should be restricted to two main divisions - combing and clothing. (1897,Practical Treatise on Wool and Sheep Breeding,41)

MACDONALD Clothing wool: wool that is short in the staple. (1920,Australian & NZ Sheep Farming,142)

Cloud Piercer¶

n. Mount Cook [translation of Maori 'Aorangi' and 'Aoraki']

.. we drove in towards the backbone of the Southern Alps along the access road to Mt Cook, catching ever-enlarging glimpses of the mighty Cloud Piercer, Aoraki (Aorangi to North Islanders). (Apr 11, 2006,NZ Herald,D6)

Cloudy Bay cod¶

n. = ling, blacodes

HECTOR 77. LING. ...(Genypterus blacodes). This fish, also known as the Cloudy Bay Cod, is exceedingly common in Cook Strait, ... (1872,Edible Fishes,116)

SHERRIN LING (Genypterus blacodes). ... This fish is also known as the Cloudy Bay cod, and is exceedingly common in Cook Strait and on other parts of the coast to the southward. (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,59)

MORRIS Cloudy-bay cod, ... a New Zealand name for the Ling (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,89)

PARROTT The Ling was known to the Maoris as Hokarari. Some years ago ago large catches were made in Cloudy Bay, and were placed on the Wellington market as Cloudy Bay Cod'. The scientific name <i>Genypterus blacodes</i>, freely translated, meansa flabby fish, with a fin on the chin.' (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,159)

WIL.SON [Ling is] ... Known around Wellington as Cloudy Bay Cod. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,143)

2 n. Lotella rhacinus , aka kelp cod

PARROTT [The rock cod] occurs not uncommonly in Cloudy Bay, and Mr. W. J. Phillipps records that, in 1924, small numbers were sold in Wellington as Cloudy Bay Cod.' It may be noted that Ling ... which were caught in Cloudy Bay were also sold in Wellington asCloudy Bay Cod'. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,43)

McLINTOCK The Cloudy Bay cod (Lotella rhacinus), also known as rock cod and southern hake, is rather more brown and lacks the dark blotch by the pectoral fin. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/373)

SORENSON (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,18) [NOTES: see cit. rock cod d.]

WILSON [ROCK COD] ... Known also as Cloudy Bay Cod in some areas ... (1981,Fisherman's Bible,38)

Cloudy Bay fashion¶

phr. [Editor's footnote: "A reference to the rough and ready methods used at Cloudy Bay, at the northeast corner of the South Island of New Zealand, where whaleships of many nationalities anchored and whaled in competition with shore stations."]

WILSON 1840/1/16 The 2nd Mate when he came aboard, absolutely foamed at the mouth, & was more like a madman than any thing reasonable: he accused the Mate of cutting his line wantonly, - "coming Cloudy Bay fashion over him, & so on!! (1991,Cruise of the Gipsy,24) [NOTES: [Note: This was a British whaler which fished mainly on the Japan grounds and in Micronesia, and did not call anywhere near NZ. The actual citation occurs on the outward voyage, somewhere in the south Atlantic.]]

cloudy gecko¶

n. a rare gecko found only on Stewart Island and outliers, distinguished by muted patterning in mossy colours. [Hoplodactylus nebulosus]

Following 10 years of rat eradication on Codfish Island / Whenua Hou, Rod Hitchmough, a scientific officer with the threatened species science unit, at the Department of Conservation, and a small band of researchers spent two weeks looking for green and cloudy gecko populations. They found just three individuals. (Sep 2010,NZ Geographic,46)

Southland is also home to the long tailed bat and short-tailed bat as well as a number of lizards- cloudy gecko, harlequin gecko, jewelled gecko, Fiordland skink, green skink, southern skink, and the small-eared skink. (Department of Conservation 2008) (2008,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.es.govt.nz/documents/planning/regional-policy/rps-and-sdc-plan-reviews/review/papers/biodiversity-issues-and-options-paper.pdf]

Cloudy gecko: .. Description: Olive-grey to dark pinkish-brown (rarely dark olive-green), individuals usually only undergo minor colour changes. (2009,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.conservation.org.nz/conservation/native-animals/reptiles-and-frogs/species-information/atlas-of-the-amphibians-and-reptiles-of-nz/electronic-atlas/atlas-details/?SpeciesID=13182]

This programme has also created opportunities for introducingto Codfish Island threatened flora and fauna fromother islands in the Titi Islands group, many of which holdremnant populations of threatened and endangered species(e.g. cloudy gecko (Hoplodactylus nebulosus)). (2002,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.issg.org/database/species/reference_files/TURTID/McClelland.pdf Published in 2002 in Turning the tide : eradication of Invasive species ; proceedings of the international conference on the eradication of island invasives ed CR Veitch and MN Clout.]

clout¶

v. to steal; seize

PAR TRIDGE ... 3. To seize; to steal; New Zealanders': C.20. ... (1937,Dictionary of Slang,161)

[In local criminal slang] ... to clout,'to pole,' `to fend off' are to steal; ... (Apr 4, 1938,Press, The) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

PARTRIDGE clout, v. To steal (pocket handkerchiefs): 1734, implied in clouting q.v; 1823 (see the same); 1889 B and L (id.); obsolete by 1900, except in New Zealand (Partridge, 1937) - and in Australia (Baker, 1942) - and in U.S.A., where it is recorded in 1914 by Jackson and Hellyer. (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,132,1961 ed.)

clout on¶

v.

That brother-in-law of mine had clouted on the lot [of beer] and tells me that he did not think I would want it. (1963,Home Life,2) [NOTES: (McCallum)]

McCALLUM [The mussels] have all gone. The wife's brother has clouted on them while we are[sic] away ... (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,16)

clover¶

n. [Main entry to go at clover check that only x-refs remain at: bokhara, burr, calvary, mangere, spotted burr, stone, suckling, sweet, yellow suckling clover]

clover [=] medick: melilot [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, yellow sweet [s] Melilotus officinalis (L.) Pall. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,15)

2 n.

clover, Bokhara [=] King Island melilot: sweet clover: yellow sweet clover [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n. spotted bur(r) clover [AND 1878 Trifolium spp], calvary clover, spotted medick.

HIL;GENDORF BURR CLOVER (Medicago [polymorpha syn. M.] hispida formerly M. denticulata) is a similar but more luxuriant plant, [to black medick] its trailing stems sometimes reaching a length of 3 or 4 feet. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,105,1967 ed.)

Burr clovers (Medicago maculata and M. denticulata), are often volunteer dominants on friable open-textured soils, ... (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,363)

bur clover [=] bur medick [s]... bur clover, spotted [=] spotted bur medick [s] Ibid. 14 clover, bur [=] bur medick [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,9)

2 n.

clover, Calvary [=] spotted bur medick [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

clover, Calvary [=] spotted bur medick [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, clustered [s] Trifolium glomeratum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

TAYLOR CLUSTERED CLOVER (Trifolium glomeratum) ... Introduced from Eurasia, clustered clover is common throughout New Zealand, volunteering in pasture, especially after it has been thinned by drought. (1981,Weeds of Lawns,32)

2 n.

clover, crimson [s] Trifolium incarnatum L. Ibid.18 crimson clover [s] Trifolium incarnatum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, drooping-flowered [s] Trifolium cernuum Brot. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, four-leaved water [s] Marsilea quadrifolia L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, lesser suckling [s] Trifolium micranthum Viv (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, Persian [=] reversed clover [s] Ibid. 57 Persian clover [=] reversed clover [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, red [s] Trifolium pratense L. Ibid. 63 red clover [s] Trifolium pratense L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n. little trefoil

HILGENDORF SUCKLING CLOVER (Trifolium dubium) was formerly named T. minus. Alternative common names are yellow suckling clover and little trefoil. it is common in pastures throughout all the sown grass lands and even where no sowing has taken place. Its seeds pass unharmed through sheep, and are therefore scattered wherever sheep can travel. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,105,1967 ed.)

suckling clover [s] Trifolium dubium Sibth. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,76)

TAYLOR SUCKLING CLOVER (Trifolium dubium) ... Introduced from Eurasia, suckling clover is common throughout New Zealand, volunteering in most pasture and abundant in some,. . . (1981,Weeds of Lawns,110)

2 n.

clover, reserved [s] Trifolium resupinatum L. Ibid. 64 reversed clover [s] Trifolium resupinatum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, rose [s] Trifolium hirtum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, spotted bur [=] spotted bur medick [s] Ibid.74 spotted bur clover [=] spotted bur medick [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

HILGENDORF & CALDER SPOTTED BURR CLOVER (Medicago arabica formerly M. maculata), called also calvary clover and spotted medick, is very similar to the former species [small burr over], but there is almost always a large central spot on each leaflet. This species is commoner in the Auckland district than elsewhere. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,105,1967 ed.)

2 n.

clover, strawberry [s] Trifolium fragiferum L. Ibid. 75 strawberry clover [s] Trifolium fragiferum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, striated [s] Trifolium striatum L. Ibid. 76 striated clover [s] Trifolium striatum L (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, subterranean [s] Trifolium subterraneum L. Ibid. 76 subterranean clover [s] Trifolium subterraneum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

HILGENDORF SUBTERRANEAN CLOVER (Trifolium subterranean).-This is a small clover growing on rather rich land in scattered localities in both islands. ... it has become the dominant weed in many pastures near Auckland so that it is sometimes called `Mangere clover,' and has spread to most or all districts where ploughing is practised. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,107)

TAYLOR SUBTERRANEAN CLOVER (Trifolium subtterraneum) ... This introduced Mediterranean clover ... is a weed in some autumn-sown crops and many lawns and playing fields. (1981,Weeds of Lawns,110)

2 n.

clover, suckling [s] Trifolium dubium Sibth. Ibid. 76 suckling clover, lesser [s] Trifolium micranthum Viv.. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, suffocated [s] Trifolium suffocatum L. Ibid. 76 suffocated clover [s] Trifolium suffocatum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n. melilot

clover, sweet [s] Melilotus alba Med. Ibid. 76 sweet clover [s] Melilotus alba Med. ... 76 sweet clover, yellow [s] Melilotus officinalis (L.) Pall. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

HILGENDORF MELILOT (Melilotus spp.) is called also sweet clover, Bokhara clover, and yellow lucerne. ... It is annual or biennial, grows 2 or 3 feet high, with stiff erect branching stems. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,109,1967 ed.)

2 n.

water clover, four-leaved [s] Marsilea quadrifolia L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n. (See grass,knotted clover)

clover, knotted [=] striated clover [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

clover, woolly [s] Trifolium tomentosum L. Ibid. 88 woolly clover [s] Trifolium tomentosum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,15)

2 n.

clover, yellow [s] Trifolium aureum Poll. Ibid. 89 yellow clover [s] Trifolium aureum Poll. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,15)

2 n.

A herd of inquisitive cows has breathed new life into attempts to grow the much-vaunted Caucasian clover on lower North Island hill country farms... Caucasian clover has been in New Zealand about 20 years but early strains had difficulty producing seeds and forming root structure. (Oct 30, 2003,Dominion Post,C6)

2 n.

White clover's natural nitrogen is estimated to be worth $2 billion to the farming economy and Caucasian clover could add $20 million.. to the lower North Island alone. (Oct 30, 2003,Dominion Post,C6)

clover, white [s] Trifolium repens L. Ibid. 85 white clover [s] Trifolium repens L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

2 n.

BROWN The plant to be found on dry knolls, resembling at flowering an elongated trefoil head, is known as `Hop Clover'. (1939,Farmer's Wife, The)

2 n. black medick

HILGENDORF BLACK MEDICK (Medicago lupulina), also called English trefoil and nonsuch clover, is found as a weed of pastures, especially on limestone soil. It is a small clover-like plant with trailing stems up to a foot in length. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,103,1967 ed.)

2 n.

Where sheep once grazed, nibbling sun-parched hare's-foot clover, you won't see a farmer on a quad bike but a real-estate agent nailing up a "For Sale" sign. (Sep 2003,NZ Geographic,No., 65/42)

2 n. subterranean clover particularly abundant in New Zealand. (See subterranean clover)

HILGENDORF SUBTERRANEAN CLOVER (Trifolium subterranean).-This is a small clover growing on rather rich land in scattered localities in both islands. ... It has become the dominant weed in many pastures near Auckland so that it is sometimes called `Mangere clover,' and has spread to most or all districts where ploughing is practised. Trifolium subterraneum, subterranean clover. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,107,nf. 1967 ed.)

Subterranean clover was first recorded in New Zealand in this district [Mangere] & was known for many years as Mangere clover. (Jun 15, 1956,NZ Journal of Agriculture,92(6)/518) [NOTES: (S.H. Saxby)]

2 n. haresfoot trefoil

COCKAYNE But ... the stonecrop, ... and the foxglove, to mention only a few British plants, are now wild in various places. (1910,NZ Plants,135)

HILGENDORF HARESFOOT TREFOIL (Trifolium arvense), also occasionally called stone clover and pussy tail, is a weed of light dry gravelly soils and roadsides over both islands. It is an annual with greyish, downy, very inconspicuous leaves, ... and the hairy flower heads, feeling something like a hare's foot, are very characteristic. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,108,1967 ed.)

2 n.

clover, Alsike [s] Trifolium hybridum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

clover casebearer¶

n.

clover casebearer n : a casebearer moth (Coleophora spissicomis) the larvae of which feed on the developing seeds of clover esp. in New Zealand. (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,429)

clover dodder¶

n. dodder (See hellbind)

HOOKER Dodder. Cuscuta dentiflora. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),764)

HILGENDORF DODDER (Cuscuta epithymum), or clover dodder, is one of the best known parasites among the following plants, and soon sends up a thin thread-like twining stem. Unless this stem finds a suitable host plant, e.g.; red clover, it dies, but if such a plant is present the stem twines round it, and sends little suckers through its skin, and commences to draw nutriment from it. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,137,1967 ed.)

dodder, clover [s] Cuscuta epithymum Murr. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,22)

clover rose¶

n.

rose, clover [s] Trifolium hirtum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,65)

clover-sheller¶

n.

The [clover] seed ripens in March, and is then cut and dried, and threshed out by machines known as clover-shellers. (1892,NZ Official Yearbook,119)

clownfish¶

n.

GRAHAM Clown Fish Canthigaster callisternus (Ogilby) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,414) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 414]

[index to common names 283-293] clownfish 2356 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

club¶

n.

FORSTER ... we heard a loud hallooing on ... an island, which on this occasion obtained the name of Indian Island; and standing on the shore we perceived one of the natives ... He stood with a club or battle-axe in his hand, ... and behind him ... two women, each of them having a long spear. ... held a long speech ... swing round his club, on which he leaned at other times. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/317)

[sc. a Moriori club] But both their Spears and Clubs were subject to great variety. Some of the Spears were very long and pointed only at one end, without much neatness. Their Clubs were rough pieces of Wood, ... and a very few had two stones lashed on at one end, which gave them the appearance of a double-headed maul. (Nov 29, 1791,Journal of the 'Chatham',2/506) [NOTES: 1791 Nov 29 Journal of the Chatham in 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/506]

n. a seal club

... [seal-]club (1907,Murihiku,340) [NOTES: 1895 Lay of the Endeavour [Capt Bampton] 1907 Murihiku 340]

2 n.

As affording some guide ... two clubs of black-maire (Olea cunninghamii) - the kind used by the natives in crushing fern-root - were found ... (1904,TrNZI,36/460)

club charter¶

n. a document authorising a club to sell liquor to its members, granted by the Minister of Internal Affairs (to 1948) and by the Licensing Control Commission (1948-89). [Jim writes: Largely historical (1881-1989). Such clubs were known as chartered clubs. A special NZ application of charter, in that the charter did not constitute the club or give it a higher status but was no more and no less than a liquor licence. Now replaced by the club licence except for some old chartered clubs. Collins notes chartered club in this sense as NZ.]

club in¶

v. to contribute jointly towards a purchase, gift, etc.; to chip in. [ODE has club together]

NEWTON The musterers had ... `clubbed' in and purchased a new ball. (1949,High Country Days,59)

clubbed tunicate¶

n. sea squirt

The sea squirt, also known as clubbed tunicate and Styela clava, has been found in Lyttelton and Auckland harbours. (Oct 13, 2005,NZ Herald,A8)

clubbie¶

n. club member

Mountain Biking Otago, for example, regularly runs "no-Lycra days", when flashy gear is banned and the clubbies go out for a pleasant ride in company, just like a social tramp. (Feb 1997,North & South,97)

What struck me is that those who patrol our beaches are always 'clubbies' and we have had a great service out of all our local lifesaving clubs. (Nov 7, 2005,Horowhenua-Kapiti Chronicle,2)

clubmoss¶

n.

Looking most unfernlike, Phylloglossum drummondii is a 22 cm-high clubmoss - a fern ally. Its habitat is unusual, too: exposed gumland clays and sands of low fertility, such as occur in Northland. (Jan 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/80)

Only the alpine shield fern (Polystichum cystostegia), bladder fern (Cystopteris tasmanica), mountain kiokio (Blechnum montanum), thousand-leaved fern (Hypolepis millefolium), finger ferns (Grammitis poeppigiana and G. givenii), one filmy fern (Hymenophyllum villosum) and two clubmosses (Huperzia australiana and Lycopodium fastigiatum) are found primarily in this habitat (Jan 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/78)

The hanging clubmoss (Huperzia varia) forms long tassles from the bases of Collospermum or Astelia clumps growing high in the crowns of forest trees. (2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/72)

n. Lycopodium spp.

THOMSON (1882,Ferns & Fern Allies of NZ) [NOTES: (And)]

COCKAYNE (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story)

WILLIAMS Matukutuku, ... Club moss, Lycopodium sp. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,227)

COCKAYNE (And) (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

COCKAYNE (And) Lycopodium laterale (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Waipoua Kauri Forest]

COCKAYNE (And) (1908,AJHR) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Tongariro National Park]

climbing clubmoss [s] Lycopodium volubile Forst. f. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

TURNER (And) HANGING CLUBMOSS (1909,AJHR,C-11) [NOTES: Botanical Examination Higher Waimarino]

WILSON Lycopodium varium HANGING CLUBMOSS ... Tassel fern ... Dark green tufts of variable form: (A) growing upright on the ground, with drooping tips[? HWO =`tassels']; ... (C) long, pendent from tree trunks and branches ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,474)

COCKAYNE (1909,AJHR,C-12) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Stewart Island]

clucker¶

1 n. (Rural) an egg-producing hen.

Down in the poultry pen we noticed that our old cluckers weren't giving us as many eggs as usual. (Apr 2001,Growing Today,64)

clucky¶

adj. wanting a child; of a woman: pregnant; broody. [1941 Baker.] Acting as if one yearned for babies, grandchildren, also cluckiness. [known to DEH from 40s]

FERGUSON [?Sc. dial. spg] And those who cannot shake theirs, fegs!/ Are deemed no more than `Chinkies',/ Or left like clocking hens, on eggs,/ (1883,Castle Gay,213)

McGILL clucky showing signs of wanting children, being pregnant, or being fussy about children, akin to the clucking of a brooding hen; eg `Win's been quite clucky of late. You haven't duffed her, have you, Brian?' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,29)

We all get clucky. And, by the sound of all the oohing and aahing, the sight of Romanian orphans on television has set off a small epidemic of cluckiness. (Jan 13, 1990,NZ Herald,Sect. 1 page ?5 ?8 (leader page))

"... the women in these groups were saying it was the men these days who 'get clucky' and put the pressure on for children ..." (Oct 1, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

cluster¶

n. a group of (small) industries cooperating to tender for or carry out a contract larger than they could execute individually

Clusters are the latest fashion in business development... With Industry New Zealand funding waiting to be claimed, a cluster could also provide a job for an organiser. Or part-time work for more than one person. In that sense, the fad for clusters is a little like the old public service with people paid by the government - which is better than simply getting the dole because the government funding may in turn help to create a self-paying job. (Nov 20, 2002,Capital Times,4)

n. a pair or several parishes cooperating to meet a shortage of ministers

"Should at any time there be insufficient priests available for appointment as pastors of all parishes, groups of two or more neighbouring parishes are to be formed into clusters, with one or more priests appointed to serve the cluster, and with pastoral leadership in those parishes without a resident priest being entrusted to a lay man or woman."... Cardinal Williams presented some ideas as to how we might cluster parishes... From all the discussions that day it seemed those present were in favour of clustering soon and of clustering the Archdiocese as a whole. (May 2002,Wel-com (Wellington),7) [NOTES: Section in quotes from decision made by 1998 Catholic Synod of NZ]

1 n. (Rural) a milking shed assembly comprising teatcups, claw, long milk tubes, and long pulse tubes.

ensure both milkers work together when changing clusters. (Oct 1999,NZ Dairy Exporter,26)

Cluster. An assembly comprising teatcups, claw, long milk tubes, and long pulse tubes. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,39)

One farmer told me that two things suggested to him that his Bodmin clusters were gentler in action than conventional types. (Nov 13, 1975,NZ Farmer,25)

Clydie¶

n. (informal) a Clydesdale horse

There are clydies, thoroughbreds, and station-breds hacks. [sic] (Sep 16, 2005,Internet - see Notes,1/2) [NOTES: http://www.horsetalk.co.nz]

It is good to see there were quite a few new riders who came along and there was also a variety of horses on the day in all shapes, sizes and breeds - from clydies to standard breds and appaloosas to arabs and stationbreds - and a few mixtures in between. (Sep 13, 2005,Wairarapa Midweek,8)

CMS¶

abbr. Church Missionary Society

TAYLOR Mr Matthews also came to learn the result of his application to the C.M.S. (Mar 18, 1847,Journal,V/5)

LUSH This used to be Mr Morgan's C.M.S. station: now Mr Phillips ... is the resident Clergyman. (Jan 21, 1881,Waikato Journals,168,1982 ed.)

MATTHEWS Firstly, the C.M.S. were short of funds, there were not sufficient trade goods available at the time with which to purchase the necessary land, ... (1940,Matthews of Kaitaia,40)

CMT¶

abbr. compulsory military training [ORIGIN: acronym]

SLATTER Because he's a soldier, if only a Compulsory Military Trainee.) (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,47)

abbr. cut, make and trim

She uses two cut-make trim (CMT) factories in Wellington, and two people who sew... "In Auckland I found a CMT that fit [sic] with what I'm doing, then a few weeks later they closed down." (Feb 11, 2002,Evening Post,11)

In [the clothing] industry there are two types of organisation operating; (1) the factory which purchases materials, manufactures clothing and sells the finished products; and (2) the `cut, make and trim' factory which manufactures apparel from materials owned and supplied by others. (1962,Report on the Industrial Production Statistics,9) [NOTES: 1962 Report on the Industrial Production Statistics of NZ for the Year 1961-62 9]

co-curricular¶

adj. non-curricular activities during school time as opposed to extra-curricular (e.g. rugby, netball) [Radio NZ discussion 12/06/2002 referring to co-curricular activities and bans.]

co-op¶

n. a farmers' co-operative dairy factory; also attrib. applied often to the general store atttached to the factory

Have sent your letter to R. Ross, storekeeper, Glen Oroua, who has been manager of a large co-op. store and is in full sympathy with the movement, ... (Mar 20, 1911,Maoriland Worker,7/8/2)

SINCLAIR The farmers were not as individualistic as they imagined. For instance they combined to form their own butter and cheese factories, over half of which, by 1903, were `co-ops'. (1959,History of New Zealand,201)

HILL The calendars on the walls of all sets are always from the Moaville Co-op Dairy Factory. (1985,More from Moaville,57)

co-operative¶

adj. (Rural) [used elsewhere but sign. to NZ rural economy] of or relating to a farmer co-owned dairy company.

The above incident was brought under theattention of a calm, cool and canny Scot,who is the chairman of a co-operativedairy factory in Southern Taranaki. (Sep 25, 1912,Otago Witness,16)

The preference for the Jersey is largely due to the fact that the co-operative companies have adopted the system of paying for milk on the butter-fat content ... (Jul 5, 1923,Hawera Star,3)

The recently-celebrated golden jubilee of the Tamaki-Kiritaki Co-op Dairy Co. in Southern Hawkes Bay, automatically calls to mind some of the earlier proprietary co-operative struggles in the district before the co-operative system had become universal in our dairy industry. (Sep 1959,NZ Dairy Exporter,20)

One hundred years ago this month, New Zealand's co-operative dairy industry was brought into being by the enterprise and courage of seven forward-looking settlers on the Otago Peninsula. (Sep 1971,NZ Dairy Exporter,43)

In this district, there has grown up the largest co-operative dairying company in the world. (Oct 26, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,31)

MCALLISTER The second decade of this century, particularly during the war years, saw a renewed spate of conversions to co-operative dairy factories, whereby the local communities of farmers broke away from the larger organisations, pooled their capital in their own small limited liability company, and built their own factory to make butter or cheese. (1976,Old Taranaki,108)

In 1881 the first co-operative butter and cheese factory was established in the neighbourhood of Greytown. (Jul 25, 1925,NZ Dairy Exporter,27)

The expansion of co-operative dairying in New Zealand has been remarkable. (1925,NZ Dairy Exporter,28)

co-opertition¶

n.

A colleague assembling a feature article on people using the Internet to sell houses online, reports that one of her sources referred to relationships between real estate agents as co-opertition. She bridled at this peculiar word, but the agent stoutly defended it as common currency among his brethren. It means, he insisted, a praiseworthy mixture of competition and cooperation. (Jun 30, 2001,Dominion,12)

co-payment¶

n. top-up fee (a joint payment for health and/or dental services by government and the patient) [dentist on Radio NZ Nine to Noon 14/8/2003- "dentists will charge co-payments"]

The proposed changes.. would mean that private specialists taking referrals from public hospitals will not be allowed to charge the patient a co-payment (top-up fee) in addition to the state subsidy. (Nov 3, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

co-provincials¶

n.

Your brother has no enviable task at Dunedin. Quousque tandem? will your old co-provincials go? (May 14, 1867,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/244) [NOTES: (A.J. Johnston)]

coach it¶

v.

THOMPSON He'd scaled the heights of Nevis, `padded hoof' to Albertown,/ Tramped and coached it through Kawarau Gorge and spelled at Arrowtown./ (1909,Ballads about Business,63)

coacher¶

n. a tame bullock used as a decoy to catch wild ones

CRADOCK A storekeeper ... turned out on the ground twenty mikers which were intended to act as `coachers' - tame cattle to entice wild cattle down to the yard. (1904,Sport in NZ,174)

coaches¶

n. an obs. children's game

SUTTON-SMITH And then there was Coaches, which also faded into obscurity: On a cold and frosty morning we would have a dozen in a row as a coach, hands joined behind backs. (1900; Waikouaiti) (1981,History of Children's Play,65)

coal fish¶

n. Parapercis colias, blue cod [also cole fish]

PARKINSON All the coves of this bay teem with fish of various kinds, such as cuttle-fish, large breams, ... small grey breams, small and large barracootas, flying gurnards, horse-mackarel, dog-fish, soles, dabs, mullets, drums, scorpenas or rock-fish, cole-fish, the beautiful fish called chimera, and shags. [In the Stout Collection copy, Victoria University Library, an early 19th C. or late 18th C. hand has added: `*Baracootas, a fish remarkably smooth about 7 or 8 foot long [dagger] Flying Gurnards, a flying fish, of a remarkable fine Gold Colour. [double dagger] Chimeras, a fish of Silver Colour - [triple dagger] Drum fish, so call'd from the noise they make, - ' (Jan 15, 1770,Journal,14)

Besides these there were many species which tho they did not at all resemble any fish that I at least have before [7] seen, our seamen contrivd to give names to, so that hakes [1], breams [2], Cole fish [3] &c. were appellations familiar with us, and I must say that those who bear these names in England need not be ashamed of their nam[e]sakes in this countrey. [ed. fn] 1. Probably Rock Cod Lotellus rachinus (Forster). 2. Snapper and Tarakihi. 3. These were Blue Cod, Parapercis colias. (Mar 1770,Banks Journal,2/6,1962 ed.)

the Coal fish (as we call it) is here [in Dusky Bay] in vast plenty, is larger and better flavoured than I have any where tasted. [fn1 Parapercis colias (Bloch and Schon.), the New Zealand Blue Cod, Rawaru of the Maoris.] (May 11, 1773,Cook's Journals,2/135,1961 ed.) [NOTES: Also in Murihuku p. 21]

FORSTER The kinds of fish were in my opinion not all new: one kind which our people called the Colefish is a new one, & belongs to the Jugular fish, but has spinous rays in its only back fin, ... & is therefore in that particular different from the Genus of Gadi & is either one of the Gadi, or next to it. [ed. fn] Gadus colias of Descr. Anim., p. 122 ... (Mar 27, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/240)

ANDERSON (Queen Charlotte Sound) With hook and line we caught chiefly a blackish fish of the size of a hadock, call'd Cole fish by the seamen [ed. fn Blue Cod, Parapercis colias.] but differing much from that known by the same name in Europe, ... (Feb 1777,Journal) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/807]

FORSTER The best and most savoury fish was a species of cod, which, from its external colour, our sailors called a coal-fish : besides this we caught several species of excellent flat cavalhas (sciaenae), some scorpens, mullets, horse-mackrel, and many other sorts ... which were entirely unknown in Europe (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/126)

The best are the Cole Fish and Skip Jack. (1791,Journal of Voyage in HMS 'Chatham') [NOTES: 1791 Journal of `Chatham' in 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/500]

Fresh provisions are readily procured [at Dusky Sound]. Coal-fish are innumerable, and may be caught with hooks and lines in almost any quantity, and have this peculiar excellence - my people ate them without bread for many months twice a day, and [179] were fond of them to the last. (Nov 19, 1793,Letter) [NOTES: 1793 Nov 19 Capt. Raven to Lieut-Governor King in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/178-179]

Fish ... was in very great plenty ... the best are the Cole Fish & Skip-Jack - many of the former weigh'd from 10 to 15lbs and were equal in firmness, & flavor to Codd. (Nov 1791,Journal of Voyage in HMS 'Chatham') [NOTES: 1791 Nov E.Bell Journal of Voyage in H.M.S. `Chatham' (Vancouver expedition) (MS ATB) 51]

POLACK Many other fish are equally numerous, answering to our hakes, tench, bream, snapper, haddock, elephant-fish, pollock, salmon, gurnards, pipe-fish, parrot-fish, leather-jackets, cole-fish, John Dorys, sword-fish, cod; various kinds of skate and cat-fish, sting-ray and dog-fish. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/322)

DIEFFENBACH Polack mentions cod-fish', bearing the native name ofWapuka,' but we do not know the fish he alludes to. The polach' he speaks of are, perhaps, the young of the <i>Percis colias,</i> the adult of which are known to the settlers as thecole-fish'. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/222) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna (Richardson's Fish) in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/222]

WAKEFIELD There are also several other kinds of fish, which are called by the sailors, from some slight resemblance to the English sorts, Herrings, Horse-mackarel, Cole-fish, and Ling. The latter is often taken of the weight of forty pounds. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,161)

HECTOR 38. ROCK COD. ... This (Percis colias) is the Coal Fish of Captain Cook and Blue Cod of the settlers in the South, and the Pakirikiri of the Maoris ... (1872,Edible Fishes,113)

SHERRIN ROCK COD (Percis colias). ... This is the coal-fish of Captain Cook, and blue-cod of the settlers in the South, and the pakirikiri of the Maoris, and is the most commonly-caught fish among rocks on the coast. (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,15)

PARROTT Blue Cod Parapercichthys colias Coal-fish Ibid. 141 This [Blue Cod], is the fish known to Captain Cook as the Coal-fish', and it has frequently been referred to by older authors as theRock Cod'. It was known to the Maoris as Rawaru' orPakirikiri'. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,169)

MORELAND [Blue cod] BLUE COD [Parapercis colias] ... A very old name from Cook's time, coalfish, is still in use. A variety of Maori names are now little used. (1967,Marine Fishes,28)

DOOGUE & MORELAND BLUE COD ... Other names: Parapercis colias; coal fish; rawaru, pakirikiri, patutuki (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,264)

SORENSON COD, BLUE (a) Scientific name: Parapercis colias. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Blue cod; New Zealand cod. (c) Other common names: Coal fish (first applied by Captain Cook). (d) Principal localities where taken: ... abundant only about south of Cook Strait and at Chatham Islands. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,15)

[species name] blue cod .. [scientific name] Parapercis colias.. [other name(s)] N.Z. cod, taapini fillets, coalfish (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Blue cod Parapercis colias ... Found only in New Zealand. Known almost exclusively by this common name, the occasionally listed coal-fish being a name used only by Captain Cook and some early writers, and derived from an unrelated European fish. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,114)

coal hulk¶

n. a ship used for storing coal

"It was a sad end to a great ship, but better this than to be converted into a filthy coal hulk" (Lee Force Brace). (Dec 2001,NZ Memories,No. 27/6)

I sat enthralled as we sailed past the old coal hulks moored near the Hutt Road... (Jun 2001,NZ Memories,No. 30/26)

coal range¶

n.

My brother kept the coal range well stoked. (Dec 2001,NZ Memories,No. 27/44)

We start with early years around Stanley Bay on Auckland's North Shore, porridge bubbling on the coal range while author and author's brother do perilous things on cliffs. (Jul 10, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

coal-boat¶

n. a ship engaged in the coastal carriage of West Coast coal

HYDE In a week's time he was taken down and put aboard the Kittawa, which was ... the bloodiest little coal-boat on the West Coast run. Bloody or not by nature, the Kittawa in her person was black, but not comely. (1936,Passport to Hell,31)

coal-box¶

n. a (? Turkish) shell

When the Squadrons had beaten into the `long grass' of adjacent gullies and the Headquarters Sergt. was busy getting his neddies off the lines, he suddenly got an earful of an oncoming shell and immediately camouflaged by trying to look like the of[sic] side of a pack saddle - the only cover handy. The coal-box lobbed about 20 yards away and gently rolled against the other side of the saddle - a dud. P.S. Have often wondered if the Sergeant tip-toed away in case it woke up. (Aug 15, 1918,Kia-ora Coo-ee,Second Series 2/5,1981 ed.)

Coalcorp¶

n. successor to State Coal

In mid-October an important step was taken when the Appeal Court ruled that the Government was wrong in ignoring the Tainui land claim when it put Coalcorp up for sale. (Nov 20, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),126)

coaler¶

n. coal-boat.

HYDE This feeling was not without reason, having arisen, as so many things do on a coaler, in a pan of hash. (1936,Passport to Hell,32)

coaly percis¶

n. coal fish, blue cod

DIEFFENBACH 7. Percis colias. - Coaly Percis, ... (1843,Travels in NZ,2/207) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna (Richardson's Fish) in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/207]

coarse¶

adj. of gold, granulated in comparatively large particles. Contrast fine. [goldmining]

PFAFF We made a good haul of very coarse gold. Ibid. 94 ... some few of them had done a little desultory gold getting with shovel and tin dish ... one of whom ... had in his possession in 1862 a fine sample of coarse gold obtained ... up the Kapiti Creek ... (1914,Diggers' Story, The,64)
