The gold occurring in the quartz was very fine, and it was considered that the coarse alluvial gold found in the creek-beds could not have been shed from the lodes discovered. (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/12)

BROWN He was shown fine gold from from the Matakitaki and coarse gold from the Mangles. (1976,Difficult Country,38)

DENNIS .. the gold soon gained a reputation for being coarse and nuggety. (1981,Paparoas Guide,68)

coarse rugby¶

n. rugby union played for fun [1980 Goldie Brown Letter (Check)]

coarse-britched¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheep] with coarse, rough wool in the britch area.

BELL These were strong-woolled ewes with coarse britches which had been crossed with the Corriedale by Jack Nairn to eradicate this defect. In the years to come, these coarse-britched ewes and the progeny of the Corriedale cross were to create considerable problems. (1953,Roundaway: Story of a Sheep Farm,32)

coast¶

v. ?to work on coastal traders

PFAFF For a considerable time [in 1860s] I was coasting and beach combing until Wakamarina rush took place. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,45)

Coast¶

adj. West Coast

That distinct Coast flavour (a mixture of rain, pub talk, coal dust, ancient religious tribalisms and suspicion of outsiders) is one of its main attractions. (Oct 8, 2000,Sunday Star Times,F2)

FINDLAY Who talks as fast as a Coast cockatoo? (1908,Humbugs and Homilies,258)

COWAN Only one Chinaman, says Coast gossip, ever ran the gauntlet, ... (1926,Travel in NZ,(Vol II South Island) 90)

DEVANNY ... the Coast land. (1930,Bushman Burke,165)

I was newly arrived from Christchurch, and unaware of Coast ways... There you have a Coast feed, two right-sized whitebait patties,... (1977,Listener Short Stories,120) [NOTES: 1974 Hulme `King Bait' in 1977 Listener Short Stories 120]

n. (the Coast) the West Coast of the SI, esp. Westland province (See West Coast)

MUELLER The greatest drawback with beach diggins is, they are so quickly washed out. Unless they find gold in the Ranges, and have deep sinking, there is very little prospect of the diggers now at the Coast remaining long. (Jan 2, 1866,My Dear Bannie,100,1958 ed.)

(A. McKay) (1878,TrNZI,10/481)

HAAST The sleek ... appearance of the horses, when compared with their usual miserable conditions on the Coast, testified that the grass growing here ... was ... nutritious. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,100)

NESFIELD My wages were to be two pounds per week, and my tucker;' but that was nothing out of the way at that timeon the coast'... [A Nelson man speaks] There was nothing out of the way at that time `on the Coast.' (1881,Chequered Career,72)

REID J. McKay's last exploring expedition to the Coast was in 1862. (1884,Rambles on the Golden Coast,18 (et pass))

PRESHAW If the Coast goes ahead I'll get some congregated [sic, check] iron from Nelson. Ibid. 155 A few of us landed in one of the ship's boats; not a safe thing to do as a rule on the Coast, what are known as `blind rollers' often rising and swamping a boat. (1888,Banking Under Difficulties,146)

WOODHOUSE The same with Harry, the bloke I worked with, the time I was over upon the Coast,/ He went for a fly-round over to Sydney, to stay for a forthnight - a month at most!/ (1950,Farm & Station Verse,38) [NOTES: c1890s McKee Wright Station Ballads `While The Billy Boils' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 38]

MANSFIIELD The husband was a pal of mine once, down the West Coast - a fine, big chap, with a voice on him like a trombone. She'd been a barmaid down the Coast - as pretty as a wax doll. Ibid. 114 If you was back at the Coast, I'd 'ave you lynched for child murder. (1912,Stories,113,1984 Alpers ed.)

PFAFF [=West Coast] The miners of the Coast did not wear coats, and there were no white shirts about. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,13)

DAVIN Nearly as scared as I was. No snakes on the Coast. (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,13)

ACLAND The Coast: Short for West Coast, but since world war II have heard people who live between Kaikoura and Blenheim speak of that country as `the coast'. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,362)

SLATTER To him the Coast was home and there was no place like it. ... To him the Coast was the rattling bridge at Hokitika, ... and the friendly ways of the real Coasters. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,76)

McLINTOCK The west coast of the South Island is The Coast and residents there are Coasters. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/680) [NOTES: Wall NZ Speech]

[One thing everybody does know about the Coast is bait. White bait.] ... Tons ... are railed and flown over the hill, weekly. The Coast becomes a joyous place, ... Ibid. 120 I was newly arrived from Christchurch, and unaware of Coast ways. (1977,Listener Short Stories,118) [NOTES: 1974 Hulme in 1977 NZ Listener Short Stories 118 King Bait Also 1986 Hulme Te Kaihau (King Bait) 37]

To the Coasters, the Coast is God's best creation. (Mar 4, 1924,Otago Witness,69)

2 adj. East Coast

Already the Coast and Bay of Plenty tribes were moving to Waitangi ... (Mar 17, 1934,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/132) [NOTES: 1934 Mar 17 in 1988 Na To Hoa Aroha (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 3/132 (Ngata)]

BALLANTYNE ... these Coast Maoris. Ibid. 25 I got nothing against Maoris, Fred. ... Especially these coast Maoris. (1948,Cunninghams, The,21,1976 ed.)

2 n. (the Coast) the East Coast of the North Island roughly from Tikirau (Cape Runaway) to Te Toka-a-Taiau (the northern bank of the Turanganui River at Gisborne) [August Tangaere p.c. 26 February 1987] (See East Coast)

C. BAKER By all means leave the Coast & if possible N.Z. too. (Nov 25, 1852,Letter) [NOTES: 1852 Nov 25 C. Baker to Colenso in 1986 Baker Never the Faint Hearted 131]

T.S. GRACE [=East Coast] A week ago I received a letter from the Revd. R. Barker telling me that he is leaving the Coast. (Apr 29, 1853,Letter) [NOTES: 1853 Apr 29 T.S.Grace letter in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 24]

BAKER Several other sections of the New Zealand coastline are known as the Coast, notably the East Coast of the North Island, but the general application is to the South Island. (1941,NZ Slang,44)

WHEELER [=East Coast] The ram type press ... is not uncommon on the Coast ... (1973,Historic Sheep Stations NI,71)

MITCALFE The word Nati' may need explaining. It is used for men and horses on the East Coast - but not by outsiders! It is an abbreviation of the tribal name Ngati Porou. As a name for the numerous wild and half-wild horses of the region it has replaced another Maori colloquialism,taika'. That name came from `Tiger', the first horse to be seen on the Coast, a piebald stallion given by Tamati Waka Nene to Waka Perohuka of Poverty Bay in exchange for the canoe, Te Toki-a-Tapiri. (1974,Maori Poetry,138)

IHIMAERA There's something about Maori women from Gisborne or up the Coast. (1986,Matriarch, The,25)

[the East Coast] One of the choicest culinary features the Coast can provide is fresh seafood. (Aug 16, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),82)

3 n. (the Coast) the north-east coast of the SI

Coast, the.-Short for West Coast, but since the war I have heard people who live between Kaikoura and Blenheim speak of that country as the C. (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Gloss. additions]

4 n. (the Coast) the west coast of the NI from roughly Paremata to Paekakariki (or further north) (also the Gold(en) Coast)

I heard up the Coast [from Wanganui] that our new member is not panning out to expectations. (Aug 25, 1906,NZ Truth,62/4/8)

[The Coast, Wellington Golden Coast] Golden Coasters are not, by and large, keen gardeners. Perhaps the heavy clay deters them. More likely the Coast attracts a different type: the open air fraternity which prefers boating and fishing ... The fishing off Mana and Kapiti Islands is good. (Oct 1971,Comment,17/11) [NOTES: year needs checking]

Coast to Coast¶

n. an annual multisport competition across the South Island from Kumara Beach to Sumner

There's just no one close to Kristina and absent three time Coast-to-Coast champion Jill Westenra in the country... (May 19, 2003,Dominion Post,D1)

A lot of competitors in the Speight's Coast to Coast don't do enough specific training... More than 100 athletes are registered for the Coast to Coast, with a waiting list of 100. (Feb 3, 2002,Sunday Star Times,B8)

More recent recreationalists have turned to the challenges of endurance and speed, and the last chapter in Hunter's book [Coast to Coast:who was first?] outlines the birth of endurance racing and the origins of the Coast to Coast. (Nov 2007,FMC - (Federated Mountain Clubs of NZ) Bulletin,39)

[Hdg] The Coast to Coast - still crazy after 20 years... Coast to Coast racers cycle to the Alps, run over the mountains, then alternately kayak and cycle the rest of the way. (Feb 23, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

coast/coastal¶

adj. in names of plants, see coprosma, cutty-grass, daisy-tree, gentian; fern, hard fern; jointed rush, sow-thistle, veronica, forget-me-not, groundsel, milk-tree

coastal¶

n. a coastal vessel.

SRAGESON coastal: coastal vessel. (1964,Collected Stories,298) [NOTES: 1964 Pearson Glossary to 1964 Sargeson Collected Stories 1935-1963 298]

coastal cutty grass¶

n.

coastal cutty grass [=] cyperus ustulatus [s] Ibid.31 grass, cutty, coastal [=] cyperus ustulatus [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,15)

Coastal Express¶

n. the Christchurch-Picton passenger rail service

89 What InterCity did to the Tranz Alpine has been repeated on the Picton-Christchurch express, now the snazzy Coastal Express. (Nov 12, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

coastal flax¶

n.

It is also found perched on steep cliffs wih companion plants such as Pimelea prostrata, native daphne, Phormium cookianum, coastal flax, Coprosma propinquua, mingimingi and Poa cita, silver tussock. (Oct 2, 2004,Dominion Post,E13)

coastal milk tree¶

n. Paratrophis Banksii

(1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/) [NOTES: (And)]

coastal run¶

1 n. (Rural) a large grazing property bordered by sea.

GUTHRIE-SMITH It [evening primrose] appeared about a plough camp, a plant here and a plant there, on the site of tents of contractors whose last work had been done on a coastal run. (1921,Tutira,251)

coastal sowthistle¶

n. Sonchus littoralis

COCKAYNE Sonchus littoralis coastal sowthistle (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: (And) Botanical Survey Stewart Island]

COCKAYNE Sonchus littoralis coastal sowthistle (1911,AJHR,C-13) [NOTES: Report on Dune-areas]

coastal speargrass¶

n. (Environment)

.. numbers of the coastal speargrass (Aciphylla dieffenbachii) had doubled to 1065 plants since a survey in 1999. (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26/7)

coastal station¶

1 n. (Rural) a sheep and/or cattle property bordered by sea.

Shepherd required for coastal station. (Mar 3, 2001,Dominion,54)

GASCOIGNE So the work went on all day with minor interruptions, Saul chatting away about his life on a Gisborne coastal station. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,69)

BARDSLEY King, Gwen .. Worked on coastal Hawke's Bay and coastal Wairarapa stations. (2000,Land Girls, The,155)

Shepherd required for large coastal station. (Feb 17, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,25)

coasteering¶

n. [Google search mar 2006: www 416 000, NZ 1460 hits.]

The novelty of this race is coasteering. It's traversing the shoreline and it's very popular. (Oct 20, 2005,Wellingtonian,20)

There is coasteering during the run, so contestants have to be ready to get their feet wet. (Mar 8, 2006,Porirua City News,3)

Coaster¶

n. a person born or living on the West Coast of the South Island (See West Coaster)

Well, the thing is, when it comes down to it, us Coasters, along with the peasant farmers in Mexico and such, might have something to say about how the world's run. (Jun 4, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

This is a bitter joke about Prime Minister Helen Clark and her crack at the "feral" Coasters protesting about the ban on native logging. ... Fred clearly has a feeling for the beauty of the river, though he dislikes the green "bleaters" who come over the hill and criticise the Coasters for ruining their region. (Oct 9, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C3)

Coasters have more helicopters per capita than anywhere else in the country, and they are comparatively cheap to hire. (Jan 31, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27) [NOTES: West Coast]

I'm in my 18th year as mayor of Buller and I'm a coaster, I was born and bred in Westport and I've lived all my life on the coast. (Jun 3, 2001,Sunday Star Times,A9)

"But Coasters are Coasters," he says. "They are different to other New Zealanders." (Feb 1993,North & South,106)

DRUMMOND [Seddon's] good wife (who shared the love of all Coasters with her husband) ... (1907,Life & Work of Seddon,349)

"Coasters" are so friendly that it is a pleasure to be bar-bound in their company. (Mar 1937,NZ Railways Magazine,55)

BARR On the strength of having beaten Canterbury last season, the enthusiastic Coasters congratulated themselves on having more than a reasonable chance of lowering the British colours ... (1908,British Rugby Team in Maoriland,74)

FINDLAY ... a mixed lot of Coasters like you. (1908,Humbugs and Homilies,259)

HALL Another of his stories was of an old coaster ... (1914,Woman in the Antipodes, A,102)

PFAFF Among the old Coasters ... the question is always asked: `Did you ever hear about the fight at the Big Dam?' (1914,Diggers' Story, The,36)

ODELL This way was difficult and dangerous, and when the problem of travelling stock was solved by the Coasters raising their own meat, the efforts to construct a track over Browning Pass were discontinued. (1935,Handbook Arthur Pass National Park,13)

BAKER Coaster for a resident [of the West Coast of the South Island] is also well known. (1941,NZ Slang,44)

SLATTER To him the Coast was home and there was no place like it. ... To him the Coast was the rattling bridge at Hokitika, ... and the friendly ways of the real Coasters. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,76)

McLINTOCK The west coast of the South Island is The Coast and residents there are Coasters (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/680) [NOTES: (Wall NZ Speech)]

Coasters in their hundreds flock to the rivers and streams to swoop and scoop ... as many [whitebait] as possible ... The Coast becomes a joyous place, the Coaster a contented boy? Ibid. 119 Well, I mean, Coasters have their channels for spreading news, mainly ex-Coasters. (1977,Listener Short Stories,118) [NOTES: 1974 Hulme in 1977 NZ Listener Short Stories 118]

Coaster n. N.Z. a person from the West Coast of the South Island, New Zealand. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,212) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 90]]

HULME I think this season'll be the last, you know. Well, I mean, Coasters have their channels for spreading news, mainly ex-Coasters. (1986,Te Kaihau,37)

McGILL Coaster person from the West Coast of the South Island. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,29)

To the Coasters, the Coast is God's best creation. (Mar 4, 1924,Otago Witness,69)

HENDERSON "The sea went round to the north" as the curious expression of the Coasters has it. (1967,Return to Open Country,17)

2 n. a person who lives at, or near, the East coast of the North Island

Mr Haenga, a coaster born and bred in the area, has no doubts Ruatoria will soon return to the lifestyle of the good old days. (Jan 2, 1987,Dominion,3) [NOTES: [Article: Ruatoria Wants Peace]]

Lupe Gibson, Ruatoria schoolteacher, East Coast representative lock between 1955 and 1958 and a spectator at Saturday's game, sums up what rugby means to Coasters : "It is the only conversation on the Coast." (Sep 24, 1998,Dominion,9)

3 n. a person who lives at, or near, the coast as distinct from one who lives ? in town; one who lives in a beach town or suburb

BALLANTYNE 11 I'm always on the lookout for stories. And coasters like reading what outsiders think of them. (1980,Penfriend,11)

Coastie¶

n. an East Coaster

Like most Coasties, I went to Wellington when I finished school. (Dec 1996,Mana,No. 11 : 17)

Wellington was a culture shock for Te Coasties, Rapai Te Hau and Dale Ferris when they moved down here from Gisborne... Te Coasties are hard to categorise and as a result they accept comparisons to The Topp Twins as inevitable... Te Coasties play to stereotypes and the main target is themselves. Running gags include references to East Coast staples, Steinlager and marijuana. (Feb 25, 2004,Capital Times,10)

So I went for the audition and they, "Are you Ngati Porou." They're the coasties - staunch. Syd Jackson, Hone Kaa, those kind of people. (Feb 1993,North & South,90)

McGILL Coastie North Island East Coaster, mainly Ngati Porou and Whanau Apanui between Opotiki, the Cape and Gisborne. [G. Johnston] (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,21)

2 n. (informal) a West Coast [South Island] resident or a person who comes from that area. [ORIGIN: abbreviation, distinguished from a person from the East Coast of the North Island.]

.. Greymouth claims me as their own. I was born and bred there - grew up there. It's cool. The Coasties yell out, "Hey, Brendon's from Greymouth. He's one of us." It's nice to be able to claim it. I'm in love with the West Coast and it's an identity thing. (Jun 28, 2009,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),33)

coastie¶

n. a coastal skipper (or sailor)

GLOVER In the Navy you'd say Portfive ... These coasties seem to get along with about three wheel orders (1963,Bedside Book,160)

coastliner¶

n. a Maori supporting distribution of fishery assets on a coastline basis

He said it would result in "tribal infighting at its worst" as the populationists and coastliners kept squaring off. (Sep 17, 2002,Dominion Post,A2)

coastwatcher¶

n. [In OED 1916, 1928 (UK); then 1955 (US referring to Australian coastwatchers)]

Peter Wilson, whose father spent a year on Campbell Island as a wartime coastwatcher, had been there several times before. (Aug 13, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),51)

After a little field work in Hawkes bay, he [Charles Fleming] was dispatched for a year to the Auckland Islands as a coastwatcher... (2006,National Geographic Magazine,#77, Jan - Feb 2006, p34)

On the outbreak of war, Australia and New Zealand, realising that Germany would again use commerce raiders to disrupt trade, set up an extensive network of coastwatchers covering most of the Pacific from Antarctica to the Equator... Ibid. 162 New Zealand Coastwatchers were a mixture of Army personnel and Post and Telegraph employees, seconded to the Coastwatchers. (Oct 2000,Pacifica,38 (153) : 161)

coat flapper¶

1 n. (Rural) a musterer [from occ. having to wave his oilskin coat to move sheep.]

musterer - coat flapper. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

coathanger¶

n. (Rural) [farm forestry] a horizontal branch that needs to be removed.

FOREST FOREMAN I had continually to send him over his work to clean trees higher and remove coathangers. (Apr 28, 1938,Letter) [NOTES: 1938 Apr 28 Letter from a FOREST FOREMAN (NZFS MS)]

"Make sure not to leave any coat-hangers ..." (1988,NZ Journal of Agriculture,Feb/Mar 18)

n. (in rugby) an illegal high tackle

Ironically the Taniwha did not play that badly and will be relieved that squad halfback Luke Hamilton still has his head attached to his body after Fritz Lee's coat-hanger. (Sep 30, 2010,Rugby News,22)

DUFF A 'coat-hanger' tackle is one where the tackler crooks his arm and aims for the runner's head. (2000,Maori Heroes,56)

(Jul 22, 1984,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Rugby League Commentator, NZ-Great Britain match]

McGILL coat-hanger stiff one-armed neck tackle in rugby, dangerous and illegal. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,29)

.. centre Ryan Nicholas caught Bay halfback Ruki Tipuna in a "coat hanger" tackle. Paddy O'Brien, New Zealand's top referee, sent Nicholas to the bin. (Nov 15, 2004,Dominion Post,C12)

n. a town spiv, Cuba Street Yank.

v. (from the noun's rugby sense)

Did Lawrence Dallaglio's mum get sick of him bitching every time she told him off? Or did he coathanger her too? (Jun 16, 2004,Capital Times,13)

2 n. close-pruned pinetree

McGILL coathanger close-pruned pinetree, the way it is supposed to be done. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,21)

Coathanger, the¶

n. the Auckland Harbour Bridge

the Coathanger: the Auckland Harbour Bridge (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

POPE & POPE Inevitably its [sc. Auckland Harbour Bridge's] design earns the nickname, 'the coat hanger', while the Japanese-built extensions adding additional lanes on either side are known as the 'Nippon clip-ons'. (1982,Mobil Illust. Guide NZ,45)

cob¶

n. a building material of clay and straw

Other cob buildings which remain are the Molesworth cottage at the Blenheim end of the station, dating back to 1865, and the Tarndale accommodation house, built in 1874, also by Ned James. (Dec 22, 2003,Dominion Post,B6)

SALMOND cob a mixture of clay, water, chopped straw or grass (in New Zealand tussock or wiwi), and often animal manure, all thoroughly mixed and trodden in layers to form walls COD entry has been edited, and reduced from the older version in 8cocol35: this reduced version is the COD5 (.ho;) version. A postscript version of 16/3/90 (codbold5) sent to Oxford. (1986,Old New Zealand Houses,231) [NOTES: Glossary of Building Terminology]

47/29 Built of cob in the late 1870s by James Keeffe for his wife Bridget and family, Alma Cottage, a solidly constructed home with thick insulating walls, remains remarkably intact. (May 1994,NZ Historic Places)

cob house¶

n.

BIDWILL & WOODHOUSE There were very few houses built with the sawn timber, nearly all being made with wattle and dab or "cob". (1927,Bidwill of Pihautea,61) [NOTES: Quote from Orbell, 1909]

The difference between a sod house and a cob house is that the former is made of sods cut square and laid like bricks to form a wall, while a cob house is built of clay cemented with tussock. (Jun 29, 1944,Feilding Express,4)

The original small cob house, built by George Matson the first runholder in about 1860, was now concealed behind a larger wooden structure. (May 1994,NZ Historic Places,47/24)

cobalt deficiency¶

n.

It is now realised that the cobalt deficiency on much of the North Island pumice country is associated with some of the pumice ash showers. (Jul 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,67)

Cobb¶

n. short for Cobb's coach q.v.

MEREWETHER Into ruts plunged the vacillating & fluctuating Cobb.' <i>Ibid.</i> 169 I got into theCobb' again with my fellow passengers. (1874,By Sea and Land,170)

MORRIS ~ sometimes used as equivalent to a coach. `I am going by cobb.' The word is still used, though no Mr. Cobb has been connected with Australian coaches for many years. See quotation. (1898,Austral English,91)

McCOMBIE (1861,Australian Sketches,184)

Everywhere else the name of coach is `Cobb,' and throughout both Islands there are numerous roads and bridle-tracks. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,35)

PFAFF Cobb and Co. (Mr.Beamish) had to remain until we were ready to start. Cobb, in trying to pass me to get the road, smashed several splinters off my hind wheels. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,73) [NOTES: [= a Cobb and Co coach]...]

Cobb & Co¶

n. [figurative use]

Even [Roger] Hall ("the Cobb & Co of New Zealand theatre") is not immune. (Jul 24, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),63)

n. (Cobb and Co. never operated in NZ, but it was usual for coach-line proprietors to use the name Cobb and Co in the proprietary titles of their lines. J. Halket Millar, High Noon for Coaches (1954 (1965)) pp 40-41 discusses the coach and company name; a generic name in early NZ for a coach or coach-line, the latter mostly having no connection with the original proprietary Cobb and Co. )

REDMOND Driving across the Klondike bridge, where the Cobb & Co coach drivers experienced many hair-raising crossings of the Waimakariri, John recalled the previous year's major flood. (2000,Truckers: NZ Truckers on the Road,100)

The tender of Cobb and Co. has been accepted for the conveyance of mails inland. (Jul 1, 1865,Southland Daily News) [NOTES: 1865 July 1 Southland News in 1931 Lovell-Smith Old Coaching Days 99]

Started for Mt. Peel by Cobb & Co. (Dec 4, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,207,1950 ed.)

From Mercer to Hamilton is some 50 miles ... I took Cobb & Co. coach for 16 miles. (Aug 26, 1875,Chudleigh Diary,237,1950 ed.)

SEDDON Cobb and Company's coaches stopped at our place and the horses were stabled right alongside our home. (1968,Seddons, The,12)

Cobb and Co., as a company or business, never operated here, although curiously, the name was used. Cobb and Co. was an Australian company, formed in 1854 by some Americans (including one Freeman Cobb) which operated express waggons out of Melbourne... When the Otago gold discoveries became known in 1860, a Melbourne coach driver, Charles Cole, chartered a ship and brought his coach and horses to Dunedin in October 1861 and set up the first coach line, Cobb and Co., C.C. Cole and Co., proprietors. The name Cobb was used as a traditional one in respect of the "first" coach line, and also as a means of advertising, for which a licence fee was paid in some instances. (Apr 2000,NZ Geographic,No. 46/6)

Cobb Igneous Complex¶

n. (Geology)

Also of Cambrian age is a belt of ultramafic rock..called the Cobb Igneous Complex, present in the Cobb area. (1990,Tramping in South Island Forest Parks,59)

Cobb's coach/Cobb coach¶

n. generic term for specific type of coach, thorough-braced, rather than sprung, popular in NZ and Aust. in the 19th and early 20th centuries. (See Cobb & Co)

Then there were the Cobb coaches, drawn by five lovely horses and driven by men of character and skill, the lifeline to the West Coast. (Apr 2004,NZ Memories,No. 47/35)

WALKER (Dunstan Diggings) Sent our swags by Cobb's coach. They took them for [pound]1 each ... (Jan 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker))

On Monday last, at 6 o'clock, Cobb's coach ... left Dunedin for Dunstan all right, but after running twenty miles, one of the fore wheels collapsed. ... Upon [the driver's] arrival at the Union Hotel with his polers, he was rushed with enquiries. ...Seating himself on the axle in a comical position, he was Joe'd' by a chorus of lookers-on. Replying that those who had nothing better to do thanJoe' him were a set of `tarnation fools', he drove off at top speed. (Jul 25, 1863,Otago Colonist) [NOTES: 1863 July 25 Otago Colonist in 1931 Lovell-Smith Old Coaching Days 35]

MUELLER I go to Christchurch ..., and shall probably leave for Hokitika per Cobbs coach next Tuesday. (Sep 14, 1865,My Dear Bannie,37,1958 ed.)

HARPER The coach [at Hokitika], - dismiss all visions of the Vivid' or theRocket', surviving still in Scotland and Wales, and imagine an American notion', invented by one Cobb, immortalized throughout Australia and New Zealand byCobb's Coach'; - clumsy in appearance ... [description follows] (Oct 15, 1866,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,93,1914 ed.)

BARKER These conveyances have a world-wide celebrity as `Cobb's coaches,' both in America and in Australia, where they are invariably the pioneers of all wheeled vehicles ... They are both strong and light, with leathern springs and a powerful break .. (1867,Station Life in NZ,139,1870 ed.)

LORD LYTTELTON Cobb's coaches mean in fact the style of American - built coaches which he introduced, and which is universal in these colonies. (1868,Two Lectures,26)

SEWELL The first public conveyances are monopolised by Americans and go under the generic name of `Cobb's Coaches'. Cobb's Coaches were first established in Australia from thence they have been transplanted to New Zealand, and have taken root; strange vehicles they are with springs of leather. (1870,Lecture on NZ,16)

ST JOHN I started off in Cobb's coach from Wellington. (1873,Rambles in NZ) [NOTES: 1873 St John Pakeha Rambles in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 576]

WHITWORTH [Front advt] OCCIDENTAL HOTEL / DUNEDIN / ... Visitors to Dunedin are respectfully informed that ... they can have accommodation unsurpassed in the Southern Hemisphere, and at a moderate charge. ... Cobb's Coaches Call Every Morning. (1875,Cobb's Box)

D'AVIGDOR The Cobb' coaches - as these vehicles are termed from their original proprietor - are very strongly built; the body is borne by a combination of leather and iron, called athorough brace', which certainly seems to stand any amount of hard usage, but is as rough as can be conceived. (1888,Antipodean Notes,190)

BULLER On the 5th October, standing on the Paikakariki road-cutting, waiting for Cobb's coach to come up ... (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/255)

HOCKEN At length the gold days and Cobb's coaches ended this uncertain travel, and now that ... journey is accomplished in an hour-and-a-half. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,108)

LOVELL-SMITH The Jopp Brothers, of Riversdale, held the contracts in 1904, and the last two or three years of coaching saw a well-equipped `Cobb' coach, painted red, and drawn by four good horses, meet the train at Riversdale ... (1931,Old Coaching Days,117)

NEAVE The coaches [c1900] were very like the Cobb Coach, and were set on springs above the axles of the four wheels. (1980,Land of Munros, The,48)

Cobb's mail¶

n.

We ride as far as the Rakaia and then on by Cobs Mail. (Jun 9, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,189,1950 ed.)

cobber¶

v. to become mates with, make friends with.

PEARSON You wait and see, they'll cobber up in no time. It's natural for a young chap to cobber up with chaps his own age. (1963,Coal Flat,104)

ARMFELT Yes, Graham, I knew from your first game that we'd cobber up beaut. (1971,Catching Up,125)

(Feb 1949,Geographic Magazine,368)

McGILL cobber up with make friends with; eg `I cobbered up with Barry over the duck-shooting season, but I haven't seen him since.' take a liking to] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,29)

n. a close friend, a mate

My cobbers don't like it either. (Jul 19, 1943,NZEF Times,III/108 : 5)

The Kiwis taught us the real meaning of "cobbers". (Aug 16, 1943,NZEF Times,III/112 : 6)

WRIGHT The man who is cobbers' with Christ comes off best if he's ever so poor. <i>(1897,Station Ballads,59</i>) [NOTES: (So Long')]

The big Hawkes Bay squattah, Sir William Russell, who has just returned to Maoriland after congenial association with his Conservative cobblers [sic] in Hingland. (Aug 19, 1905,NZ Truth,9/1/8)

.. he cannot get tick, / He is thirsty and sick/ And he can't see a cobber about. (Dec 16, 1905,NZ Truth,26/1/8)

Young Graham and some cobbers were out for the usual spree. (Dec 23, 1905,NZ Truth,27/5/1)

... temperance skiters ... attempting to show their superiority over red-nosed `cobbers.' (Apr 7, 1906,NZ Truth,42/1/5)

This he does with great danger to himself from the onslaught of the tough's cobbers', who are not particular whether it isthe boot' (it is seldom the hands) or a stone, or even a bottle that is brought into action. (Mar 23, 1907,NZ Truth,92/4/5)

Then go to Farndon, where yer find yer cobber has done ya in an' beat yer for yer tart. (Feb 8, 1913,NZ Bulletin,16)

What you've got to do is to keep up agin the tote and when I signal, bung in and get the div. quick,' a youth was explaining to hiscobber'. -->?dateline as above I'll admit I was stiff when I lost that fifty francs, but my cobber produced another ten; and when the ring-keeper said `Up and do 'em', I collected 200 francs. (Jan 10, 1916,Triad, The,43)

INGRAM [NB quotes] My companion is Stan Allen ... a real hard doer', good pal and champion scrounger. In Ruahine Company we found several of our oldcobbers' who had joined up whilst we were still in the segregation camp at Etaples. (Aug 29, 1917,Anzac Diary,39,1987 ed.)

COBBER. - A friend; a pal. Ibid. 32 He's just a friendly little bloke - / Good cobbers with the boys./ Ibid. 56 Real good pal, most staunch and true of cobbers,/ Dear old cobber, ever lucky Jim./ Ibid. 180 Digger and cobber, mate and chum - / Who says there is nothing in a name? (1917,New Zealand At the Front,xiii)

: Listened the other day to a Tommy's description of an Anzac : He's a brown, lanky bloke 'oo calls 'is cobber 'er cow. <i>(Mar 15, 1918,Kia-ora Coo-ee,1/487',1981 ed.)

THE N.Z. CAMEL CUP.' ... While back at the base, resting after chasing Abdul across the Jordan, we organised a Sports Meeting. ... My socialistic cobber, whose beast was particularly speedy, enlisted my help to christen his steed. I immediately suggestedPaddy Webb', but was met with the scornful rejoinder : `I want the prad to go to the front, not stay behind.' (Aug 1, 1918,Quick March,11)

Cobber.- Revival' gives a reminder that the much-usedcobber' is a revival of an old word that had a run in the colonies long years ago. The writer gives an opinion that the term came originally from the cockney quarter of London. `Dinkum' was current at least twenty years ago; the war has given it another lease of life. (Nov 1, 1918,Quick March,15)

It is not to be denied, for every soldier knows how - maybe in some remote French village or English town - the sight of a New Zealand uniform in the street was an instant announcement that here was a friend, a `cobber', a fellow-Digger. (Dec 1, 1919,Quick March,67)

FRASER & GIBBONS COBBER, A: Comrade. A friend or chum. (An Australian word). (1925,Soldier and Sailor Words,59)

DEVANNY ... his mate, his `cobber' for 20 odd years. (1926,Butcher Shop, The,104)

DEVANNY ... with his cobbers. (1927,Old Savage,170)

DEVANNY Flaherty and his cobbers. (1928,Dawn Beloved,237)

ALLEN Had Andy and Ponto belonged to a later decade, they would have been described in the jargon of the Cally' ascobbers.' The word so exactly hits off their relationship, that I must use it. The bond between cobber and cobber has about it no taint of sentiment. (1936,Poor Scholar,67)

HYDE Leave it to your uncle, boy ... Get in there and keep your cobber cheerful. (1936,Passport to Hell,77)

COMBS ... a group of `cobbers' who were chyacking him. (1939,Harrowed Toad,30)

BAKER [suggests English dial] (1941,NZ Slang,66)

BENNETT [Yiddish chaber and refers Notes and Queries 28 Sept, 1929; suggests from Aboriginal cubba.] (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,88)

Cobber - friend. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,38)

Other unusual words are explained in text, except perhaps one or two which are in almost universal use in New Zealand. ... Cobber', originally English dialect, is now firmly established in both Australia and New Zealand, and meansgood friend'. (1945,NZ Geographer,39) [NOTES: (Cumberland's note to Pascoe's `Canterbury High Country')]

And others ... came back winking at their cobbers,... (1977,Listener Short Stories,21) [NOTES: 1945 Sargeson `Showers' in 1977 Listener Short Stories 21]

BAXTER The Cairo women, cobbers under sand (1979,Collected Poems,42) [NOTES: (1946) Baxter Collected Poems (1979) 42 [Returned Soldier]]

SOLJAK Following are examples of colloquialisms common to New Zealand and Australian English, with their English or American equivalent ... cobber: friend (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),115)

DAVIN A man was able to get back to his tent and attend to a bit of booze his cobbers had kept for him. (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,76)

SARGESON They came out from the shelter of fern and scrub, perhaps finding themselves on their own and nervously running about and baaing for their cobbers; ... (1949,I Saw in My Dream,122,(1974 ed Rhodes) ed.)

When I came back from England none of my old cobbers had changed a bit. ... `How's things?' they said. The homely greeting sounded so good I almost forgot you don't answer that one straight. (Sep 1952,Here & Now,15) [NOTES: [phr: my old cobbers]]

I would include among New Zealand English words: cobber (May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class)

BOWEN ... shearers (all you good cobbers' that have shorn sheep) know the romance, glory,shi-ack' and fascination of this grand job. (1955,Wool Away!,2)

SHADBOLT `Don't you want to see your old cobber?' (1959,New Zealanders, The,135,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (Play the Fife Lowly)]

CROWTHER I asked the tall gum-chewing youth [Christchurch] if he had been to the Dean's meeting on Friday. He said that a lot of his cobbers had been turned away. `They wouldn't let them in. ... There was only one Army joker in there ...' (1956,Street Society in Christchurch,15)

There is a world of difference between "friend" and "cobber". (Mar 25, 1953,NZ Observer,4)

FRAME ... meeting his cobbers and talking their private language of the biscuit, .. (1957,Owls Do Cry,76,1958 ed.)

SHADBOLT Well anyway this boy said they never had anything to do with the girl, he and his cobbers. (1959,New Zealanders, The,101)

SLATTER Basil said he would leave no cobber of his in the country to walk home. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,15)

MASTERS As sometimes happened when camped at the Herrick Hut, two of Alex's town cobbers, Tony and Ron, turned up with pig dogs for a spot of hunting. (1960,Back-Country Tales,49)

Crump: I'd like to introduce you to a cobber of mine, a joker (Apr 19, 1962,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

BACON The foreman winked at Les. ` ... Just tell her you're a cobber of Fred's, and she'll be right.' Ibid.180 cobbers - Good friends, mates. (1963,In the Sticks,89)

BAXTER I hate to see a cobber go hungry for/ Tobacco or drink, (1979,Collected Poems,294) [NOTES: (1963-64) Baxter Collected Poems (1979) 294]

SARGESON cobbers: mates. (1964,Collected Stories,298)

SHADBOLT As far as I can see you're still alive. Which is more than you can say for your cobber, the Maori fellow. (1965,Among the Cinders,80)

McLINTOCK Australian importations include ... cobber for a friend or mate, ... called Bruce Murphy. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/680) [NOTES: (Wall NZ Speech)]

n. (slang) bosom friend, pal [orig. doubtful.] (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),613)

I thought I would surely find a cobber in the pub. (1976,NZ Short Stories,86) [NOTES: 1966 NZ Short Stories (1976) 86 (Wilson `It was Easter')]

cobber ... n. (Sl.) friend, mate, companion, intimate [Yiddish chaber, companion, associate]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

SLATTER I've just about had this cobber thingo, said Erik Johansen. Cobbers are cobbers when it suits them. (1968,Pagan Game, The,150)

MASON WERIHE. ... I say I come; they tell their cobbers in Australia; they meet me, take me round. (1969,Awatea,85,1978 ed.)

HUNT Yes, we were all cobbers those days. (1981,Speaking a Silence,26)

cobber n. Austral. arch. & N.Z. a friend; mate: used as a term of address to males. [C19: < E dialect cob to take a liking to someone] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,212) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 137; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 91]]

McCAULEY `If I run into your cobber,' she said, half-Australian already, ... (1982,Other Halves,32)

My old Cobber hung round that fencerather longer than I thought necessary. (Sep 15, 1916,Christchurch Girls' High School,I/2 : 39)

They were cobbers - that's N.Z. for"chum". (Jan 31, 1917,Chronicles NZEF,I/11 : 244)

The knowledge that he has beenrecommended by his C.O. for recognitionhas met with the warm approval of all his"digger" cobbers. (Aug 2, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/49 : 8)

My "cobber," A Little French Maid, cuts my letters out of their paper. (Apr 22, 1924,Otago Witness,64)

n. (as form of address) mate, sport

Feel like a drink, cobber? (1917,Digger Transport Magazine, The,4)

And many went exceeding crook, and cried amongst themselves, Never come at that game, cobber.' <i>Ibid.</i>107 As the onlookers at the fence moved away, one voiced the question:Who is it, cobber?' `Sergeant Billy Fordyce, killed at the guns last night.' (1917,New Zealand At the Front,78)

Murder on the old sergeant-major.'Ten frog half-way, cobber. Right, she's set.' Come on, me lucky lads, you come 'ere in a pill-box and go away in a Rolls-Royce.'The last spin, digs, so plank it down thick and heavy now; you pick 'em and I'll pay 'em.' (Aug 10, 1921,Quick March,27)

GRAEME-HOLDER Sorry, cobber, ... I betcha they was on the beach ... Awright, cobber. (1933,Restless Earth,75)

cobber: pal or friend; e.g., `Hello there cobber.' (1981,NZ Police National Headquarters) [NOTES: Goldie Brown Collection)]

n. (used by or of a woman) a friend

HARVEY [a girl-friend] I heard a girl say to another girl, `Look! There's a Yank in the ladies' compartment.' Her cobber licked all her fingers and tried to smooth the fuzz down on her sticky-out eyebrows. Ibid. 89 Anyhow, she didn't seem to mind and after that we were real cobbers for a while. (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,17)

MIHAKA But Hinekatorangi was in fact a Queen of the Hawkes Bay Maoris. She came over to mourn for her lifetime cobber, Te Aputa O Ngati Raukawa [a kind of Queen of the Ngati Raukawa]. (1984,Whakapohane,105)

n. red scorpionfish [[is this in error for cobbler?].]

MORELAND RED SCORPIONFISH [Scorpaena cardinalis] ... A variety of names is in use including cobber and grandfather hapuku. (1967,Marine Fishes,26)

cobber up¶

v. (informal)

We took train again, about six, andcobbering up with an "Ossie" at SalisburyI was safely escorted to Waterloo. (Sep 29, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/3 : 66)

cobbery¶

adj. friendly

SLATTER He's pretty cobbery with some of the owners and trainers and he wouldn't miss a meeting for quids. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,51)

SLATTER he had been cobbery with them for years (1968,Pagan Game, The,161)

cobble-up¶

1 n. (Rural) a poor fencing job.

a poor fencing job - a cobble-up, or Taranaki fence. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

cobbler¶

n. the hardest (usu. the last) sheep left in the shearing pen

M EREDITH When the word is given to start, the shearers go into the catching-pen' and feel over the sheep, select one, carry it out on to the shearing-floor, and commence shearing. Naturally, the easiest-shorn sheep --bare-bellies' and `bare points' -- are selected first. It is amusing to watch the tactics of some of the shearers to dodge the Kapara (Cobbler) the last sheep in the pen, which, presumably, is the worst shearing sheep of the lot. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,143) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 143]

WOODHOUSE Clear the board! Clear the board! is the shout./ Big Mick is smiling grimly as he takes the cobbler out. (1950,Farm & Station Verse,33)

WILSON The last sheep to be shorn is often the most difficult to catch, and is called the `cobbler.' (1894,In the Land of the Tui,243)

CRADOCK The wool-shed' where all shearing is done has a row of pens (catching-pens' they are called) in it reaching from one end to the other, each pen holding some 25-30 sheep. Opposite each of these are two shearers, who draw their sheep one by one out of their pen until the pen is exhausted. Naturally each man tries to pick a sheep that looks easy to shear, so the last one is generally a great ugly brute with matted wool and his fleece full of sand. This fellow is invariably nicknamed the `cobbler.' (1904,Sport in NZ,172)

The cobbler' used to be the last sheep in a shearing pen probably because hesticks to the last.' - being usually rough-fleeced or burry or dirty, or otherwise objectionable.... But now we are told that cobbler is an obs term for a learner'- who would also naturally belast' to finish his task; [instead of the last sheep in the pen]. (Jul 7, 1911,Maoriland Worker,18/14/2)

CARR Another job suitable for a new hand is Sheep O!' The work consists of filling up thecatching pens' when empty. The shearer who takes the last sheep (called the cobbler') calls outSheep O!' when the boy ... immediately fills up the back pen. (1913,Country Work,17)

SMITH ... they always leave the `cobblers', or hard sheep, until the last ... (1927,Sheep & Wool Industry,76)

Bill beat him for the "cobbler". (1913,NZ Observer,Xmas Annual : 4)

cobbler n. the last sheep of a mob to be shorn. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3)

Cobbler. Shearers' slang. Worst sheep to shear in a pen. Two shearers usually catch out of one pen and each takes the easiest sheep he can find, and so downwards until only the hardest and roughest sheep is left. (See [1898 Morris Austral-English] for derivation.) (Sep 15, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

Cobbler.-The last sheep of a pen full. A correspondent points out that this word is also applied to the last load of hay, etc., in the harvest field. (For derivation see OE.) (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Gloss. additions]

STUDHOLME ... cobbler', a hard-shearing sheep ... <i>Ibid.</i> 129 When an old hand and a young one were sharing a catching pen, the former [130] would let the learner in for thecobbler', or hard shearing sheep, at the end of every pen, and when the pen had been re-filled, quickly catch and shear all the `rosellas,' or easily shorn sheep, before the unfortunate novice had finished his cobbler. (1940,Te Waimate,112)

NEWTON Cobbler: The last sheep in a shearer's pen is called the cobbler. It is usually a tough one - hard shearing - and consequently any very hard shearing sheep are called cobblers. (1949,High Country Days,193,1950 ed.)

MEEK COBBLER: The last and usually the roughest sheep in the catching-pen. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

BOWEN The Cobbler This is the odd tough sheep in a mob, the one that makes the `sheepo' unpopular when a shearer finds it in his pen. Ibid. 155 COBBLER. A hard, difficult-shearing sheep. (1955,Wool Away!,48)

Cobbler: A sheep which proves hard to shear because of its matted fleece. (Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing)]

TURNER There are names for types of sheep, the cot with matted wool; the cobbler, a difficult sheep; the flyer, a fast one; the kicker; the sandyback and the gasper, which gasps apparently because grass comes into its throat. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,147)

COBBLER: A sheep which proves hard to shear because of a matted fleece. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20)

cobbler n. dirty sheep, often left last to be shorn; last load of hay in harvest. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

A sheep which provides hard to shear because of a matted fleece. (Feb 24, 1977,Dominion,11)

Cobbler: Sheep which is difficult shearing. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53)

cobbler ... NZ & Austral. colloq. awkward sheep to shear or last sheep to be shorn. [pun on cobbler's last] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,137) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

RICHARDS I found I could hold him on the good ones, but he had the edge on me when it came to the cobblers'. <i>Ibid.</i> 122 Agun' will often be foxy' ... andspring' when he has his chief adversary at a disadvantage - caught with a pen full of `cobblers'. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,95)

OGONOWSKA-COATES Cobbler. The worst sheep in the pen. When two shearers share a catching pen they usually start with the easiest sheep and work until only the roughest sheep are left. The last and usually the roughest sheep of all is the cobbler. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,95)

cobbler: The last sheep left in the catching pen (because it was difficult to shear) is called the cobbler', a play onthe cobbler's last'. Naturally shearers like to make this their bell sheep'. It was a simple transfer to use the termcobbler' or `sandy cobbler' to describe a rough hard sheep at any time. . (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/23) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

n. the last load of hay etc in the harvest field.

Cobbler.-The last sheep of a pen full. A correspondent points out that this word is also applied to the last load of hay, etc., in the harvest field. (For derivation see OE.) (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Gloss. additions]

ACLAND A correspondent also points out that this word is also applied to the last load of hay etc in tthe harvest field. (1933,Sheep-station Glossary)

cobbler n. dirty sheep, often left last to be shorn; last load of hay in harvest (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

n. red scorpionfish

Cob.bler (k&obreve.b.bl&etilde.r), n. [Add.] 4. (Zoo.l.) A kind of fish. See FORTESCUE. [Local, Melbourne and Sydney] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2020)

Scorpion-fish or cobbler. Scorpaena cruenta Rich. [233] This fish [scorpion-fish Scorpaena cruenta] is the common scarpee of Cook Strait and the cobbler of Napier. Wellington Maoris call it ngutoro or puraruraru ... The cobbler differs from the sea-perch in having more pronounced ridges on the head ... (1932,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,13/232) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

PARROTT [The Red Rock Cod], is also known as the Common Scarpee' and in Napier it is known as theCobbler'. Perhaps `Cobbler' would be the best to use for this fish, but it is unfortunately not known under this name outside Napier. The name Red Rock Cod is generally used that it would be very confusing if the name was changed, and under these circumstances the name Red Rock Cod will have to remain. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,164)

WILSON COBBLER: see Scorpionfish (1981,Fisherman's Bible,44)

DOOGUE & MORELAND RED SCORPIONFISH ... Other names: Scorpaena cardinalis; red rock cod, scarpee, grandfather hapuku, cobber; red rock cod (Australia); matua-whapuku (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,288)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] cobbler 1175-8 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

n. (Rural) a last load of hay in a harvesting [derived from the pun on the cobbler's last].

cobbler, n. last load of hay in harvest. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

cobbler. A correspondent points out that this word is also applied to the last load of hay etc in the harvest field. (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The (Acland Glossary),13)

BAKER cobbler, the last load of hay in a harvest. (1941,NZ Slang,54)

1 n. (Rural) a sheep with coarse, grimy wool that is difficult to shear and can blunt cutters and combs.

STUDHOLME When an old hand and a young one were sharing a catching pen, the former would let the learner in for the 'cobbler' or hard shearing sheep, at the end of every pen, and when the pen had been refilled, quickly catch the 'rosellas' or easily shorn sheep, before the unfortunate novice had finished his cobbler. (1940,Te Waimate,129)

MEREDITH It is amusing to watch the tactics of some of the shearers to dodge the Kapara (cobbler) the last sheep in the pen, which, presumably, is the worst shearing sheep of the lot. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies) [NOTES: Adventuring in Maoriland (1935)]

CARR The shearer who takes the last sheep (called the 'cobbler') calls out 'Sheep-O!' (1913,Country Work,17)

NEWTON Cobbler: the last sheep in a shearer's pen is called the cobbler. It is usually a tough one - hard shearing - and consequently any very hard shearing sheep are called cobblers. (1949,High Country Days,193)

cobbler's pegs¶

n.

cobbler's pegs n. tall, erect, annual weed, with clinging seeds. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

cobblers' pegs [s] Bidens pilosa L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,15)

2 n. fleabane.

HILGENDORF FLEABANE (Erigeron canadensis), also called Canadian fleabane, woolly cobbler's peg and, mistakenly, fire weed, is abundant throughout the North Island, and is found in waste ground and dry pastures. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,171,1967 ed.)

cobler¶

n. variant of cobbler (seabird)

RICHARDS As we got closer to the reef [of Jackson's Keys] we could hear the wailing cry of the penguins - like babies crying; then the coblers' from the rocks would come wheeling round us. Suddenly the headsman makes a sign foroars' and they are laid in noiselessly. (1982,Whaling and Sealing,5) [NOTES: 1843 May 2 in 1863 C.Heaphy `A Chapter on Sealing' Southern Monthly Magazine Vol I No.4 June pp 173, 176 in 1982 Richards Whaling and Sealing 5]

cocco¶

n. taro (See also sweet potato)

In them were planted sweet potatoes, cocos and some one of the cucumber kind. (Oct 21, 1769,Banks Journal,1/41,1962 ed.)

Their food ... consists of ... sweet potatoes, Yams, Cocco[fn5], some few wild plants as sow thistles, Palun Cabbage[fn7] &c. 5. Taro Colocasia antiquorim 7. Kouka, the inner leaf-shoots of the C. Australis (Mar 1770,Banks Journal,2/19,1962 ed.)

Firn [sic] roots, Dogs, Fish and wild foul [sic] is their chief diet, for Cocos, Yamms and sweet Potatoes is[sic] not cultivated every w[h]ere. (Mar 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/282,1955 ed.)

CRAIK In these spots were sweet potatoes, coccos, or eddas, which are well known and much esteemed both in the East and West Indies ... (1830,New Zealanders, The,169)

cock a deaf'un¶

phr.

MEEK COCK A DEAF'UN: To pretend one is not listening. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

cock a deaf 'un: To pretend one is not listening. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/23) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

cockabull¶

n. cockabully

BEATTIE At Otamita I got a big spotted `cockabull' about 1/2lb weight and we cooked and ate it, but it was not appetising as it was hard tasteless meat. (1956,Pioneer Recollections,44,1956 ed.) [NOTES: 1947-1948 Beattie Pioneer Recollections (1956) 44]

cockabully¶

n. a small fish, kokopu or kokopara.

GEE She had me put my hand on the baby to feel it move.. a flick like a cockabully's tail. (1992,Going West,147)

-No you can't take it home, she said. It'd miss the other cockabullies. Mumma bully, Poppa bully, all the little bullies. (Aug 25, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),97)

MALCOLM One day he went fishing for cocker bullies, or papane. (1982,Where it all Began,81)

HULME & MORRISON Not to mention the whitebait called kokopara, that somehow transmogrified to be the cockabully... (1989,Homeplaces,10)

Strictly speaking, the word cockabully should be used only for marine fish in the family Trypterygiidae. However, cockabully was probably used by early settlers in New Zealand to also include similar looking freshwater fish which we now call bullies (short for cockabully). (Aug 20, 2007,Manawatu Evening Standard,A8)

He was a digger, living by himself.. seven or eight miles from the township (school, store, and ever present "pub") of Cockabullyburn. (Dec 23, 1890,Otago Witness,17)

Like many Wellington families we looked forward to and loved holidays in the Sounds where we went to bed in candlelight, fished in the stream for cockabullies (the hook a bent pin) and hovered round the end of the jetty to inspect the latest wave of holiday makers arriving. (Aug 3, 2000,Evening Post,9)

I would spend many summer days swimming, catching cockabullies, or just lying on a big warm volcanic rock staring at the beautiful expansive sky or enjoying picnics under the shady trees. (Dec 2003,NZ Memories,No. 45/27)

A flicker of transparent tail as a cockabully betrayed itself above the matching bottom of sand. (Mar 1990,Landfall,173/58) [NOTES: a saltwater species?]

COMBS He cast an eagle eye over the swimming-hole, whence emerged, weeping, his sailor-suit dripping and starchless, a small boy who had fallen in off a log while angling for cocker bullies. (1939,Harrowed Toad,31)

v. fish for cockabullies

He was brought up in the family home at 18 Riverside, in the days before television and organised sport and spent many happy hours with his friends, eeling, cockabullying and catching and cooking freshwater crayfish in the nearby Matai River. (Aug 2002,NZ Memories,37/5)

cockapoo¶

n. a poodle-spaniel cross

The cockapoo (spoodle) has been bred in the United States and Australia as a family dog for decades (Sep 13, 2000,Evening Post,23)

cockatoo¶

n. a parrot of the Nestor genus; a kaka..

SAVAGE Cockatoos and parrots, in great variety, are said to inhabit the woods ... (1807,New Zealand (various authors/titles),10) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

BIDWILL I bought for two blue beads a cockatoo - or rather parrot (nestor), the most common bird in New Zealand, and good to eat - ... (1841,Rambles in NZ,95,1952 ed.)

n. a fish

GRAHAM Cockatoo Duymaeria flagellifera (Cuv. and Val.) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,408) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 408]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] cockatoo 1673 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

n. a small farmer (more often cocky from c1920s) (See cf. forty-acre farmer)

Bidding adieu for a while to my friends, the village, and special settler and other, the cockatoo-ral-loos of the bush settlements, I entrain at Woodville and emerge upon the plains of Squatterdom. (Aug 13, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

MUTER [The squatter's enemy] the land-purchaser, of whom there were two classes - the one generally from Australia who swallowed up the ground where the squatter stood; and cockatoos', as the station-owners call the other, whospotted' his run all over with fifty and 100 acre sections, and worried him for trespass. (1864,Travels and Adventures,2/260)

RICHARD TAYLOR Mr Wilson [a Canterbury cattle-station owner] is annoyed by someone having bought a portion of his run. He styles those who thus obtain land in the midst of other's runs cockatoos. (1865,TrNZI,12/175) [NOTES: HWO suggests TNZI but dates don't fitFIT]

(May 21, 1866,Lyttelton Times,2)

LADY BARKER In one of our rides ... we suddenly dropped down on what would be called in England a hamlet, but here it is designated by the extraordinary name of a nest of cockatoos' ... [110] These small farmers [who have started from next to nothing] are called Cockatoos in Australia by the squatters or sheepfarmers who dislike them for buying up the best bits of land on their runs; and say that, like a cockatoo, the small freeholder alights on good ground, extracts all he can get from it, and then flies away tofresh fields and pastures new.' ... [111] However, whether the name is just or not, it is a recognized one here; and I have heard a man say in answer to a question about his usual occupation I'm a Cockatoo.' ... The Cockatoos arenobody's business' [that is, their interests are looked after by no one in particular]. (1867,Station Life in NZ,109,1874 ed.)

MITCHELL It was early in the year 1870 ... that I composed the following pieces, some of which appeared in the Oamaru Times' ... [21] THE LEVANTING COCKATOOS./ In summer time, when work was slack/ .../ ... says C. to Jack,/Let's go a cockatooing'./ They leased some land upon the plain/ On very easy terms,/ And wrote Home to anxious friends/ About their stock and farms./ (1889,Rhymes and Rambles,20) [NOTES: [c1870] in 1889 Mitchell Rhymes and Rambles 20-21]

CLYDE Great joyfulness the welcome news/ Occasioned to the Cockatoos. (1872,Te Kooti,1)

G.M. WILSON [v. squatter] Much of the land in Canterbury is all freehold, but the land held by lease is generally protected by the owners buying up the river frontages. So that the Cockatoos cannot get water, I believe there is a sort of fight going on here just the same as there was in Victoria during the `65 Land Act' between squatters and cockatoos. (Feb 2, 1873,Diary) [NOTES: 1873 Feb 2 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 164]

BATHGATE Many words in daily use in Otago bear traces of importation from the neighbouring Australian colonies, and none betrays its Australian origin more than that used to denote the agricultural class who are usually styled `cockatoos.' Important as they are, the cockatoos are not so interesting from a literary point of view, as the miners. (1874,Colonial Experiences,194)

CAIRD He [new-chum] can be a squatter - that is, a sheepfarmer or a cockatoo, as the ordinary arable farmer is called, or a storekeeper. (1874,NZ Sheepfarming,40)

BROOMHALL A man who farms less than 100 acres is a ground parrot; more than 100 acres but less than 1000 acres, he is a cockatoo; over 1000 acres, he is a gentleman. The Digger himself can die out ... The Cockatoo, whether the Beef or Potatoe variety of the breed, can follow suit. (1877,Journey in NZ,41)

PEACHE The first season ... was good and large crops were grown by `cockatoos'. (May 30, 1879,Journal) [NOTES: 1879 May 30 Peache Jnl in 1970 Gray Quiet with the Hills 57]

FERGUSON What can a commmon ploughman do?/ For Lizzie could get .../ A storekeeper or a cockatoo. [fn] Colonial term for farmer. (1883,Castle Gay,248)

BRADSHAW ... Cockatoos - colonial for small farmers. (1888,New Zealand Of Today,148)

DOUGLAS (1890,Letter) [NOTES: 1890 Douglas Letter in Roberts in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 112]

WOODHOUSE The Squatter and the Cockatoo were walking hand in hand/ ... /The Squatter went destroying in a different way to Cocky,/ (1950,Farm & Station Verse,27) [NOTES: 1891 G.B. Starky `The Weasel' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 27]

SWANTON There is very little to be said about [mixed farming'] except to remark that the men who go in for it in New Zealand are calledcockatoos', so I will now proceed to what is called a `sheep farm'. (1892,Notes on NZ,89)

DOWNING He's got a bit of land now, and calls himself a cockatoo (fifty acre farmer). (1894,He,39)

MOFFATT Arriving in Canvastown ... we met an old digger acquaintance who said the whole thing was a fraud and that the `cockatoos' had got it up as they wanted their bush felled cheap. (1896,Adventures by Sea and Land,72,1979 ed.)

MORRIS ~ (1) Bird-name. The word is Malay, Kakatua. (O.E.D.') -->(2) A small farmer, called earlier in Tasmania a Cockatooer (q.v.). The name was originally given in contempt (see quotations), but it is now used by farmers themselves. cocky is a common abbreviation. Some people distinguish between a cockatoo and a ground-parrot, the latter being the farmer on a very small scale. Trollope's etymology (see quotation, 1873) will not hold, for it is not true that the cockatoo scratches the ground. After the gold fever circa 1860, the selectors swarmed over the country and ate up the substance of the squatters; hence they were called Cockatoos. The word is also used adjectivally. (1898,Austral English,92)

BELL [a swagger speaks] But de'il tak' the hour I agreed to gang amang the cockatoos wi' ye, Bill; an' I could wish mysel' back amang the squatters again. Your wee bit farmers are a measly lot ... To be sure, ane is aye made at hame in a bush fa'ers' or roadmen's camp to a share o' what's goin'; ... Ibid. 34 The speaker was Mr. Dennis O'Byrne, a `small cacytoo,' as he called himself. He was the occupier of a rough section, ... He had a small portion ... in grass, on which he kept a few sheep; ... Ibid 84 ... here we have the mere sight of her virgin charms transforming my mate ... a bit of a rambler - into a prospective, douce, staid, stay-at-home-of-an-evening-and-nurse-the-baby cockatoo of the future (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,7)

BEVERIDGE Oi'm going to be married To what is termed a Cockatoo- which manes a farmer.' (1863,Gatherings among the Gum-Trees,154)

BOLDREWOOD (2) A special sense-to sit on a fence as the bird sits. (1890,Squatter's Dream,20/245)

BOLDREWOOD The correct thing, on first arriving at a drafting-yard, is tocockatoo,' or sit on the rails high above the tossing horn-billows.' (1890,Colonial Reformer, A,18/224)

ALEXANDER & CURRIE New fences climb the warm brown spurs to guard the scrubber ewes, Because the run is broken up for hungry cockatoos; Ibid. 289 Cockatoos: small runholders. (1906,Treasury of NZ Verse,70)

THOMPSON Thus spake der Deutscher `cockatoo', and vot he dells is true,/ Ibid. 92 Well, I did a bit of croppin' for a Southland cockatoo,/ (1909,Ballads about Business,28)

Cockatoos' in the Wairarapa are going in strongly for the aristocraticmotah'. Probably cocky drives the separator with it, and probably not. Cocky generally uses his half-starved, sleepy offspring for everything. (Jan 1, 1910,NZ Truth,236/1/3)

One burly cockatoo shareholder who is endowed with more beef than brains (Dec 21, 1912,Hutt Valley Independent,2)

CARR .. the bulk of this class of agriculture is carried on by comparatively small holders, commonly called Cockatoos', or for endearmentCocky'. (1913,Country Work,35)

RODGER I'll slip the jade [sc. his muse] and sling the trade,/ And turn a cockatoo, man. (1914,Blue Mountain Rhymes,1)

~ n. a person farming a small area;-a.-cosk'ie, cock'y n. a cockatoo farmer.- boss-cock'ie n. sl. a cockatoo farmer who employs labour. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3) [NOTES: c1929-1936 Whitcombe's Etym. Dict.Aust.-NZ Supplement 3]

see COCKATOO v. (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

NEWTON Cocky : Cockatoo. A flat country man with a small farm. (1947,Wayleggo,gloss.)

cockatoo: small farmer. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,173)

~ 1. A large kind of parrot. 2. In Australia and New Zealand a small farmer is called a cockatoo or `cocky'. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),81,8th edn ed.)

SINCLAIR In the southern Provinces there was fierce competition between the pastoral tenants and the cockatoos', a name for small farmers which originated in Australia by analogy with the swarms of birds which descended on the land of the luckless farmer at harvest time. It has persisted in New Zealand to the present day in the termcow cockies' for dairy farmers. (1959,History of New Zealand,155)

cockatoo small farmer now usually abbreviated to cocky or cow cocky, one who keeps watch while an illegal game is in progress; dairy farmer; cocky's joy, treacle or golden syrup; boss cocky, farmer who employs men. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),613)

WILSON ... his spectacular role of gallant guy among the sheepfarmers' wives ... who made up our golf-playing crowd. ... But among the crowd of fast young marrieds and all the rest of the country club cockatoos, ... he apparently became a gallant hero. (1973,NZ Jack,84)

cockatoo n. pl. -toos. ... 2. Austral. & N.Z. a small farmer or settler. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,213) [NOTES: [See NZPOD COCKY, 138, also 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. COCKY, 91]]

BREMNER Cockatoo small farmer who freeholded areas in large leasehold runs. (1985,Woolscours of NZ,9)

ELDRED-GRIGG Farther south, too, the lower classes prospered... From Golden Bay to Foveaux Strait this new rank of people, known as 'cockatoos', were beginning to grow more comfortable. Ibid. 53 The second rural class with whom the gentry were in direct economic contact were the independent farmers - the cockatoos. Ibid. 146. Differences in fortune between large land-owner and cockatoo were much less obvious than they had been in the nineteenth century. (1980,Southern Gentry,146)

n. a lookout

A cockatoo is someone who keeps peg (keeps watch) for someone else, for example, in a fight when doing drugs or tattooing. (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

After both parents died when he was in his early teens, he put food on the table by professional boxing and acting as "cockatoo" for a roving two-up game. (Feb 28, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

He started as a dogsbody and cockatoo for.. his dad... [He] spent his childhood in hotels doing jobs a youngster could handle - including keeping watch for the constabulary in case they chose to enforce 6 o'clock closing. The seven-year-old's piping alarm - not always as tuneful as the cockatoo - alerted his father and patrons to the gendarme's approach. (Apr 13, 2000,Evening Post,5)

After both parents died when he was in his early teens, [Scrimgeour] earned a living by professional boxing and acting as a "cockatoo" for a roving two-up game. (Apr 27, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),86)

I had cockatoos (lookouts) posted, radios turned to drown the noise arranged. (Nov 4, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

n. [attrib. uses]

[Signed] `A Cockatoo Settler' (Sep 25, 1859,Letter) [NOTES: 1859 Sep 25 Letter in 1860 Ridgway Voices from Auckland 51]

BULLER When riding betweeen Woodville and the Manawatu Gorge, I saw at a `Cockatoo homestead', a flock of domestic ducks. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,255) [NOTES: CHECK 1873]

But lately, when riding between Woodville and the Manawatu Gorge, I saw, at a `cockatoo homestead,' a flock of domestic ducks on the roadside ... (1879,TrNZI,11/372)

BARR Farming, on a `cockatoo' scale, the industrious pioneers, who inhabited these houses, vigorously prosecuted. (1879,Old Identities, The,193)

SCOTT We'll get a job on a `Cockatoo' farm somewhere. (1897,How I Stole 10,000 Sheep,7)

adj. with derog. connotations, implying land poorly or badly farmed or stock poorly raised.

HAWDON The stock is miserable, especially sheep, beside which the scrubbiest `cockatoo' sheep would look prizewinners. (1907,New Zealanders & the Boer War,188) [NOTES: 1901 Letter in 1907 Hawdon New Zealanders and the Boer War 188]

v.

DONNE Some are dairying, others `cockatooing' with a few acres of land, three or four cows, half a dozen pigs ... (1927,Maori Past and Present,11)

v. to work or live as a small farmer

MITCHELL It was early in the year 1870 ... that I composed the following pieces, some of which appeared in the Oamaru Times' ... [21] THE LEVANTING COCKATOOS./ In summer time, when work was slack/ .../ ... says C. to Jack,/Let's go a cockatooing'./ They leased some land upon the plain/ On very easy terms,/ And wrote Home to anxious friends/ About their stock and farms./ (1889,Rhymes and Rambles,20)

O'REGAN They tell me you're now `cockatooing',/ And worried to death, I suppose,/ With striving and riving and sueing/ ... (1896,Poems (various authors),30)

Cockatoo. Now usually abbreviated to cocky. An agricultural farmer, a small farmer, as opposed to a squatter or sheep farmer. /Derivation in [1898 Morris Austral-English] C[ockatoo] is also used as a verb. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]; S.L., p.110). (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

n. (Rural) an arable farmer or agriculturist.

CAIRD He can either be a squatter, i.e. a sheep farmer, or a cockatoo, as the ordinary arable farmer is called. (1874,Notes on Sheepfarming in NZ,40)

1 n. (Rural) [mainly 19th century and usually derisive] a small farmer.

.. the cockatoo is awaking from his dream of a rapid fortune to find that he has mortgaged his fencing material without liquidating his tucker bill. (Mar 1895,NZ Farmer,98)

Twenty years ago ewes of the Down Crosses were to be seen in almost every cockatoo's flock on the Canterbury plains and as a consequence a race of mongrels sprung up which it took a long time to eradicate. (Aug 15, 1903,Farmers' Union Advocate,5)

BARKER If a 'cockatoo' (ie a small farmer) or a speculator in mines, fancied any part of your country, he had only to go to the land office, and challenge your pre-emptive rights. (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,90)

To see this fern at home, let us away across the wide Canterbury Plains, whence the wicked squatter has been driven by the virtuous cockatoo. (Jan 1, 1878,NZ Country Journal,24)

COURAGE B- assured him that he could at any time get more land by simply buying out the two or three "cockatoos' (small settlers) who would always be glad to sell if it were made worth their while to do so. (1896,Lights and Shadows of Colonial Life,30)

MCKEE WRIGHT New fences climb the warm brown spurs to guard the scrubber ewes, Because the run is broken up for hungry cockatoos. (1898,Station Ballads,46)

One continually notices some poor unfortunate blighter of an unsophisticated Cockatoo attempting to do something with his land which is absolutely bound to end in failure. (Oct 20, 1926,NZ Dairyman,85)

STUDHOLME .. where there might be 90,000 sheep to put through [the dip] including a few thousands for the cockatoo (small farmer) neighbours. (1940,Te Waimate,117)

cockatoo curl¶

n. (It appears as the title of the story and is used there (`Old Cockatoo Curl') as a sort of nickname, poss. from a crest of hair.)

MANSFIELD `Not at all, they were cheap as cheap. I bought them from a fat man with a Cockatoo curl. (1912,Stories,125,(1984 Alpers) ed.)

cockatoo farmer¶

n. (See cockatoo)

TROLLOPE ... the cockatoo farmer ... (1874,New Zealand (various authors/titles),61)

ELRED-GRIGG Shepherds and cockatoo farmers came from miles away.. and amusements.. included a 'lolly scramble' and a few boxing matches. (1980,Southern Gentry,80)

cockatoo's nest¶

1 n. (Rural) a home of a small farmer or agriculturist.

BARKER .. no pleasures stand out more vividly than my evening rides up winding gullies or across low hill-ranges in search of a shepherd's hut or a cockatoo's nest. (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,120)

cockatoo's weather¶

n. (Rural) weather that makes farming easy, i.e. rain by night and fine conditions by day.

LOUGHNAN cocky's weather: fine by day and rain by night [cocky's weather] (1981,Loughnan Glossary,18)

ACLAND Cockatoo's weather: Fine by day and rain at night; or, sometimes, fine all the week and wet on Sunday. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,362)

We are still having lots of rain: in fact, regular cockatoo's weather - rain all night and fine all day. (Jan 1893,NZ Farmer,18)

Cockatoo's weather.- Fine by day and rain at night; or sometimes, fine all the week and wet on Sunday. (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The (Acland Glossary),13)

BAKER cockatoo's weather, sun all day and rain at night. (1941,NZ Slang,55)

cockatoocracy¶

n.

There are some half-score of these sets, ranging from the milky way of the creme de la creme of the cockatoocracy to the long-beer constellations that gyrate round the "luminous" Hebe. (Mar 12, 1887,200 Years of NZ Food & Cookery)

cockey¶

v. (Rural, informal) work or live as a small farmer

I rode up from the sticks at Waitotara where I was cockeying. (1997,Volunteers, The,5(2) : 25) [NOTES: From a soldier's letter from South Africa @ 1900].]

cockey/cockie¶

n. (Rural) variants of cocky [-] (See cocky)

Running tourists alongside merinos has saved many a cockie's bottom line. (Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

cockfight¶

n. [A complex of various esp. Sc dial. uses of cock (cock's-headlin .us;to ride cockie-breekie, cock-a-legs) for a boys' game in which one mounts on another's shoulders with the form cock-fight; cf cockie n (Sc) in various combinations.] [ca1932 (Turner Dannevirke) Cockfight: Game where boys take one another pick-a-back and try and push each other over. ca1940 Havelock children; c1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream. 1953 14 M A17 Thames DHS 20 COCK-FIGHTS [unorganised games]]

CONDON Other games played by the whole school from time to time included rounders, bedlam, tick-tack,tiggy tiggy touchwood, hide and seek, hares and hounds and cock fights - a form of piggy back (1992,Hurleyville,25)

SUTTON-SMITH They had races with them, competed to see who could walk on the highest stilts, played a crude soccer with a tin or soft ball between two sticks or two caps for a goal, and had `cockfights' in which great groups of boys jostled each other in a struggle on sticks. (1981,History of Children's Play,27)

cockfighting¶

n. a children's game

HEINZ Some of the simple games played by the [West Coast] children were rounders, shinty, duckstone, tiggy touchwood, kiss in the ring, ... cockfighting, marbles, fly the garter and leapfrog. (1974,Pure Gold,38) [NOTES: [c1870s] 1953 Patrick Magee (aged 86) Growing Up at the Diggings in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 38]

SUTTON-SMITH Wrestling, Sacks on the Mill, Heave Ho, No Man Standing, Cock-fighting and boys' behaviour in Forts and Dens are characteristic activities which reflect this aggressive and physical solidarity. (1953,Unorganized Games,2/619)

HILLIARD He liked nearly all the boys [at primary school in early 1930s] ... They played cock-fighting and keeny-seeny, and stuffed grass down the necks of girls who gave cheek or got in the road. (1965,Power of Joy,133)

SUTTON-SMITH Perhaps the most recurrent and universal of rough games in the early period was Cockfighting (K-78). This was a free-for-all contest in which a smaller boy mounted on the back of a bigger boy and the two endeavored [sic] to dislodge all other riders by pushing or [202] pulling them over. ... Sometimes the game was known as a Piggy-back Contest or as Pulling Off. One trick of the game was tobuck-jump' your rider, which consisted in jerking your elbows so that the rider was lifted over your head' (Naseby, Otago, 1905). (1972,Folkgames of Children,201)

BENNETT We had our games [c1907]. A favourite was `Monkey', where the contestant climbed one of the fir trees along one side of the ground (still there at the present day) and did a grand traverse of as many trees as possible. It was characterized by noise, boasting, cheating and an occasional sprained wrist. There was cockfighting in which each of two players, mounted pick-a-back, tried to resist dislodgement. (1980,Canterbury Tale, A,34)

SUTTON-SMITH This led to an extended season of play in which the drapery stilts, one foot off the ground, competed cockfighting fashion with one another and with other homemade stilts often stilted at a higher level above the ground. (1981,History of Children's Play,28)

cockie joint¶

1 n. (Rural) a small farm.

STACEY cockie joint: a small farm. i.e. the farmer is a cockie and the joint is his farm or house. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,164)

cocking up¶

n.

CARR Haymaking. ... The jobs to look for are cocking up' (with a two or three pronged fork), driving the horse rake (no handrakes are used nowadays) ... loading the drays or sledges when ready ... Acrow' is also employed, whose work consists of passing the fork-fulls thrown up by the carter to the stacker. (1913,Country Work,11)

cockit-hat¶

n.

[WICKHAM] Fox himself, with his "cockit"-hat and spurs, was to be there. (1897,Casual Ramblings,49)

cockle¶

n. a cake, kiss.

COCKLES OR KISSES ... butter ... flour ... cornflour ... sugar ... powder ... Drop one teaspoon of mixture on ... trays. Bake ... when cool fasten two together with jam or whipped cream, and dip in powdered sugar. (1906,Tetaka Kai: A Book of Well Tried Recipes,71)

n. any of a group of edible, bivalve molluscs with ribbed shells; in NZ applied chiefly to two shellfish of different genera: A. Chione stutchburyi tuangi; and less often B. Amphidesma australe pipi; in NZ often called pipi; littleneck clam

Roger Belton, founder of Southern Clams... busily dispensed samples of his wares - grilled queen scallops, tuatua, pipis and the cheerful little round shellfish, the littleneck clams that most New Zealanders still inaccurately call "cockles". (Jul 6, 2003,Dominion Post,F7)

The Natives brought to the ship and sold to our people, small Cockles, Clams and Mussels enough for all hands. (Nov 6, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/194,1955 ed.)

WALES ... there are not wanting Several Sorts [of fish] that are well known; such as Mullet, Cavallas, Guard-Fish, Horse-Mackeral. Amongst the crustaceous Tribes we found Craw-fish, Muscles. [sic] Cockles, Scollops, Whelks, Periwinkles, ... (1773,Journal) [NOTES: 1773 Wales Journal in Cook Journal (1961) 2/787 [?]]

ANDERSON There is also Cockles buried in the sand of the small beaches, ... ed. fn Probably Chione stutchburyi, the Maori Tuangi (and a variety of other names). (Feb 1777,Journal) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/808 (Queen Charlotte Sound)]

SAVAGE To such as are fond of cockles, muscles, and all the varieties of small shell-fish, the bay of islands [sic] must prove a most desirable place to visit; . (1807,New Zealand (various authors/titles),11)

KENDALL They then generally leave the school, and repair to the rivers or bush in pursuit of fish, fern-root, cockles, etc., and return in the evening, and after repeating their lessons retire to rest. (Oct 16, 1816,Journal) [NOTES: 1816 Oct 16 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 129]

McNABB Q. What sort of fish did you obtain at New Zealand? A.A great variety and many of the fish are very good. There are snappers (schnapper), mullet, bream, soles, eels, and a great quantity of cockles, and some rock oysters. There is likewise abundance of lobsters, or a fish between a lobster and a craw-fish.
