(1908,Historical Records,1/550) [NOTES: 1821 May Ensign McCrae's Evidence before Commissioner Bigge in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/550]

SHEPHERD He shot several ducks Red bills a wood hen and killed a hare seal. ... cockles Mussels & oisters are plentiful and excellent. (1826,Journal) [NOTES: 1826 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 357]

BEGG (|= macron precedes) cockles, to|o|akki [tuangi] (1979,Boultbee Journal,282,1979 ed.) [NOTES: 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 282 >c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986)110 cockles -too'akki [tuangi]]

McDONNELL The rivers are well stocked with fine fish ... - the very creeks swarm with them. There are abundance of lobsters, crawfish, oysters, prawns, and shrimps; besides clams, peppies, muscles, limpets, and cockles. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,15,1979 ed.)

During the few days we remained at the Kaika Totoe (Totoe's Settlement) we lived on fernroot, cockles, and small dried eels, - ... [in Boultbee's vocab = TUAKI, the white cockle] (1835,Boultbee Journal,62,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 62]

YATE Those saltwater fish] most plentiful, and of greatest note, are, soles, mackarel, cod-fish, a species of salmon, whiting, snapper, mullet, bream, skate, gurnards, and a few smaller kinds, some not near so large as a sprat; with an abundance of crayfish, oysters, shrimps, prawns, muscles, and cockles. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),71)

WAKEFIELD Mussels, cockles, and clams also resemble our English sorts. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,161)

BULLER On those shoals the women gather cockles (pipi), and at night the men, with torches in their hands, spear the patiti [sic] (a flat fish like the plaice). (1878,Forty Years in NZ,27)

HAAST Then follows a series of shell beds, consisting of the remains of the following species, now still inhabiting the estuary;- Chione stutchburyi (Cockle); Huai or Pipi, Mesodesma chemnitzii, Pipi; Amphibola avellana (Periwinkle) Hetikutiku, and Mytilus smaragdinus (Mussel) Kuku; (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,416)

WILLIAMS Tuangi, n. 1 cockles. (1892,Dictionary of the NZ Language,209)

MORRIS Cockle ... In England the name is given to a species of the familiar marine bivalve mollusc, Cardium. The commonest Australian species is cardium tenuicostum, Lamarck, present in all extra-tropical Australia. The name is also commonly applied to members of the genus chione. (1898,Austral English,94)

BUICK The deposit consisted of a layer of cockle and pipi shells about 2 feet in depth .... (1937,Moa-Hunters of NZ,121) [NOTES: [contrast pipi]]

FULLER COCKLES (TUANGI) The cockle (Chione stichburyi or Amphidesma australe) is a small bivalve that lives in the sand. (1978,Maori Food and Cookery,50)

[species name] cockle .. [scientific name] Chione stutchburyi .. [other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Cockle Austrovenus stutchburyi The so-called cockle of New Zealand, from its superficial similarity to the European cockle. However, the species is really a venus clam (faily Veneridae) being closely related to species of hardshell clam popular in North America. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,158)

MARKHAM Now Why(?) heckie was the name of a bed of Pippies or Cockles, in the River. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),45,1963 ed.)

BIDWILL Other shell-fish are also abundant, particularly Cockles - of these I have seen more than a man could carry collected by one woman during the space of a tide; Scallops are also tolerably abundant, and are most delicious eating. (1841,Rambles in NZ,115,1952 ed.)

FULLER COCKLES (TUANGI) The cockle (Chione stichburyi or Amphidesma australe) is a small bivalve that lives in the sand. (1978,Maori Food and Cookery,50)

n.

POLACK [There are] great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202fn)

n.

DOMETT There he leaps ashore - seeks - .../ A cockle-shell - .../ (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,2/104)

1 n. (Rural) a diseased nodule on a sheep skin.

MAF Cockle: lamb/sheep pelt defect. A preventable disease resulting in the development of nodules over the pelt surface. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,62)

2 n.

McLINTOCK Large Dog Cockle: kuhakuha, Glycymeris laticostata (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

The cockle tribe also includes the glycymeridae family to which the local large and small dog cockles belong. The small one is known as glycymeris modesta and is plentiful. The large dog cockle is glycymeris laticosta, is also common, and can grow to 10cm. (Jun 22, 1984,Marlborough Express,23)

[species name] glycymeris laticostata .. [scientific name] Glycymeris laticostata .. [other name(s)] dog cockle (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

2 n.

McLINTOCK TUANGI (Chione stutchburyi). Well known as the New Zealand `cockle', it is not a true cockle; venus shell, or the Maori name, tuangi, is preferable. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/456)

BURTON ... the New Zealand species belongs to a completely different family from that of the English cockle: Venus' shell or the Maori tuangi are better names. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,58)

23 So does the New Zealand cockle. Its common name is simply `cockle' but it is not a true cockle. It is chione stutchburyi and is distantly related to the quahaugs. (Jun 22, 1984,Marlborough Express)

2 n.

CAMPBELL ... pippies, or native cockles. (1840,Present State of NZ,9)

2 n. Nemocardium pulchellum.

Locally the only true cockle is the strawberry cockle. It belongs, like all true cockles, to the cardiiae family, not the veneridae. Its proper name is nemocardium pulchellum and it is small and not common. (Jun 22, 1984,Marlborough Express,23)

cockle-cruncher¶

n. a large snapper

You'd get cut hands with those old linen lines, and if you fished for half an hour, you wouldn't be able to carry home your load of snapper. And all cockle-crunchers, too. They were Big. (May 2002,NZ Geographic,57/86)

cockroach¶

n. in NZ usu. popularly called black beetle, Maori bug, or occas. kekerengu.

McLINTOCK Cockroach: Maori Bug, Black Beetle, kekerengu, Platyzosteria novae-seelandiae (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

cocksfoot¶

n. (See grass,cocksfoot)

Cocksfoot Age¶

1 n. (Rural) pastoralism in New Zealand, following the clearing of bush.

TAIT The Timber Age was succeeded by the Cocksfoot Age. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,28)

cocksfoot fever¶

1 n. (Rural) the flood of enthusiastic growers and harvesters of cocksfoot into Banks Peninsula and other parts of Canterbury in the 1870s to 1930s.

COULSON Some idea of 'cocksfoot fever' may be gleaned from the following extract from the Akaroa Mail of Friday, January 19, 1897 - 'The Monarch Cocksfoot absorbs all interest in the Peninsula this week, and nothing else is thought of, talked of, or worked at.' (1979,Golden Harvest,25)

cocksfoot paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a fenced area where cocksfoot seed is grown and harvested for sale.

COULSON Once they were there, they would pitch their tents near the cocksfoot paddock and set up a rough camp. (1979,Golden Harvest,35)

cocksfooter¶

n. one who gathers for sale the seed of wild cocksfoot grass.

All parts of New Zealand send their quota of cocksfooters to 'make a cheque'. (1903,NZ Illustrated Magazine,VIII/439)

cocksfooting¶

n. the gathering of wild cocksfoot seed for sale (See also grass-seeding)

Cocksfooting on Banks Peninsula [title] In many ways cocksfooting resembles shearing. (1903,NZ Illustrated Magazine,8/349)

CARR Cocksfoot cutting on Banks' Peninsula ... follows. Before `cocksfooting' (as it is termed) is finished, i.e., about the middle of January, Canterbury ... will be crying out for men ... Ibid. 12 To get back to cocksfooting. The grass is cut with a sickle ... (1913,Country Work,8)

1 n. (Rural) harvesting of cocksfoot seed.

COULSON Golden Harvest 66 Parties of men with little or no responsibility come 'cocksfooting' to the peninsula; they take a contract and as a rule select the most weakly, incompetent and brainless member as cook.' (1979,Golden Harvest,66)

COULSON Early in the industry, it soon became known where good accommodation and 'tucker' was available, and all who took part in 'cocksfooting' knew it was a rigorous job demanding physical fitness and a willingness to work for seven days a week if the weather held. (1979,Golden Harvest,70)

cockspur¶

n. a device to stop the blades of hand-shears opening so wide as to overlap wrongly when closed for the cutting stroke

McLEOD The shearers buy their shears from the station and then proceed to cut them and bend them, and embellish them with drivers,'knockers,' jockeys' andcockspurs' until their makers would hardly recognise them. (1951,High Country,26)

cockspur: A metal guard fitted to shears to stop the blades from overlapping when opened wide. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/23) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

1 n. (Rural) an attachment placed on hand shears to prevent blades sticking together when closed in cutting.

JARDINE They .. had spent many hours at the grindstones 'taking them down', attaching drivers, jockeys, cockspurs and knockers. (1978,Shadows on the Hill,130)

MCLEOD The shearers buy their shears from the station and then proceed to cut them and bend them and embellish them with 'drivers', 'knockers', 'jockeys' and 'cockspurs' until their makers would hardly recognise them. (1951,NZ High Country,26)

cockspur: A metal guard fitted to shears to stop the blades from overlapping when opened wide. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,23)

cocky¶

n. (Rural) a general term for farmer. (See bush cocky; cow cocky)

.. another cocky can drag a man's gates, fences, wife or farming methods through any verbal mire ... (Aug 16, 1951,NZ Farmer,63)

Fancy having our freezers so bung full that cockies cannot get their lambs killed now in June. (Jul 14, 1983,NZ Farmer,82)

Some cockies can get pretty possessive about their rights to the Crown's long acre ... (Nov 1987,NZ Journal of Agriculture,35)

Wairarapa east coast hill country farmer John Jury puts more work into his farm than the average cocky. (May 4, 1993,NZ Farmer,15)

STACEY I heard Con bellowing occasionally as the crow, a cocky's son, placed the sheaves the wrong way round. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,41)

We had a meeting of 44 cockies in Taranaki 10 days ago and they told me they wanted to retain the Wool Board. (Oct 14, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,15)

I had a little bit of spray left in the tanks and the cocky asked me to put it on a small patch near the house. (Jan 24, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,14)

n. farmer

If only the cockies would drive 5 km/h faster there's be no queues. (Jul 21, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

"The only people that go along it are a couple of cockies who have picked a paddock on top and people going four-wheel-driving or mountain biking. (Jun 9, 2006,Dominion Post,C4)

There's usually a sale on Monday, and the cockies will be standing around the bar. (Nov 13, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

Come off it, I hear cockies howl - national pride was at stake. (Mar 25, 2000,Dominion,13)

[heading] Greenies land on the wrong side of cockies (Jun 28, 2005,NZ Herald,A9)

It's too important to the country top be left to cow cockies who play at being company directors. (Apr 5, 2000,Evening Post,4)

Before the flooods, BNZ chief economist Tony Alexander put cockies on notice that Fonterra's payout might drop to levels that made dairying unsustainable, at least for some. (Feb 23, 2003,Dominion Post,B4)

You probably don't get much change from a cocky at a saleyard at the best of times. (Jul 13, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

In working for an extra sixpence the cocky is robbing himself of several pounds. (Feb 1, 1913,NZ Observer,4)

"...half the time the cocky just pokes his head out the back door and says it's okay." (Jun 13, 2003,Dominion Post,C7)

Little two-seater Robinsons, which some of the cockies have, were ferrying snow rakers up to the tops. (Oct 1992,North & South,17)

Even if oats don't pay, it is to be hoped that the "poor cockie" will have some other means of paying his way. (Oct 16, 1890,Otago Witness,17)

"I'd say we're townies," says Philip Journeaux.. who has studied the way townies want to be cockies in smallholder heaven from the Bay of Plenty through to the north. (May 12, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

Uaccustomed to such tropical sensuality, the cockies from Gore are wandering round in shorts and jandals. (Jun 16, 2006,NZ Herald,A11)

SCOTT believe it or not, the cockies simply lapped it up. (1953,Breakfast at Six,25)

OWEN& PERKINS Maybe an extra can [sc. of illegal whisky] would be delivered to a certain cocky's place, and probably the cocky got a regular bottle of free whisky supplied to him for being a go-between. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,67)

n. short for cockabully [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

I forgot we did catch a great number of "cockies". (Feb 12, 1924,Otago Witness,71)

1 n. (Rural) [sp. use by high-country dwellers] a small farm owner or down-country farmer.

NEWTON .. that class of country tended to make the runholder a 'cocky' rather than a hillman. (1949,High Country Days,182)

NEWTON cocky: an upcountry man's name for a small or downcountry farmer. (1949,High Country Days,193)

The down-country cockies like nothing better than a nice line of blacks and will pay accordingly. (Sep 10, 1970,NZ Farmer,35)

cocky's dog¶

n. an indifferently bred or trained working dog of doubtful intelligence

NEWTON ... although he was just an ordinary cocky's dog, to me he was about the best ever. ... [19] ... That dog was never broken in, really, and as a consequence was never more than a ordinary cocky's dog. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,18)

n. (Rural, derogatory) a 'soft' dog that has had little experience in stock handling or in mustering.

NEWTON It wasn't difficult going really but it wasn't country for cocky's dogs .. No place for cocky's dogs, anyway. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,26)

NEWTON For a property of that size, it is a wild, broken block. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,21)

NEWTON .. that experience on the dip didn't do much to improve my opinion of cockies' dogs. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,146)

cocky's holiday¶

1 n. (Rural) a farmer's wife's sojourn in a maternity home.

Rosalie's letter reminded me, as the mention of the rissoles always does, of my very first trip - 'cocky's holiday' - to the nursing home. (Sep 1, 1949,NZ Farmer,56)

cocky's holiday - farmer's wife's visit to the maternity home. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

cocky's joy¶

n. golden syrup or treacle [c1940 at least Mrs N.Ngatai: fide p.c. Helen Small 1986 Mar 3 [golden syrup] [cf Simpson Sugarbag Years 64 informant speaks of cocky's joy as G. Syrup and fried scones : Mrs Ngatai mentions fried scones as well] Also as cocky's delight (no cit.)] (See bullocky's joy)

Served in enamel cups or pannikins and accompanied by fresh bread and cockie's joy (golden syrup), it was delicious. (Feb 4, 1999,Dominion,11)

My father, a World War I veteran, liked his "Cockies' Joy" bread, butter and golden syrup. (Sep 7, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

DAVIN Go easy on that Cocky's Joy.' (1947,Gorse Blooms Pale, The,194)

joy, cocky's n. treacle, golden syrup. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),11)

HILLIARD Martha Nelson put out a freshly cooked plate of hot hinu-bread and a tin of golden syrup. ... Homai te cocky's joy!' [homaigive me'] (1969,Green River,45)

HILLIARD Martha Nelson put out a freshly cooked plate of hot hinu-bread and a tin of golden syrup. ... Homai te cocky's joy!' [homaigive me'] (1969,Green River,45)

Oh you [bush-felling] contractors in black singlets and bowyangs, fuelled on spuds and mutton and pumpkin and rice and spotted dog or deadman's arm and black billy tea: perfect toast sopping with butter and Cocky's Joy (treacle): come into our art galleries, onto our stamps, wrap within songs, ... (Feb 3, 1985,NZ Times,5) [NOTES: (Jim Henderson)]

I suppose you had to cook for yourself,' ...That's right,' he answered. `Though some days I didn't bother. Always a tin of cocky's joy handy, and bread once a week.' (Aug 1986,Islands,37/39)

cocky's joy sl. golden syrup, treacle. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,138) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

McGILL cocky's joy treacle or golden syrup, a favoured spread on bread in less affluent days in poorer and usually rural parts. ANZ. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,29)

SIMPSON Silver beet, mashed spuds and a poached egg was a feast [during the Depression], or sometimes we'd have `cocky's joy' - fried scones with golden syrup. (1974,Sugarbag Years,64)

OWEN & PERKINS The billy was ninety-nine times out of a hundred an old 'cocky's joy' tin - the old golden syrup or treacle tin was the ideal brewing billy. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,71)

My father, a World War I veteran, liked his 'Cockies' Joy' bread butter and golden syrup. (Sep 7, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

PARK Most ate their breakfast, bread and cocky's joy - golden syrup - on the horse's back. (1992,Fence Around the Cuckoo,29)

cocky's string¶

n. (Rural) fencing wire

McGILL cocky's string fencing wire, called `cocky's friend' in Australia. [Turner] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,29)

cocky-farmer¶

n. cocky

LUSK They were `cocky-farmers' in well-pressed navy blue suits. (1934,Waimana,215)

cockydom¶

n.

Cockydom, finding that it must make a return of its income for taxation purposes, is sitting around upon its tail, and pointing its long nose at the political stars, and howling that it is oppressed. (Dec 4, 1915,NZ Observer,16)

This highly intellectual sample of cockeydom admits that the fires are destructive. (Mar 1, 1913,NZ Observer,9)

1 n. (Rural) the world of downcountry or agriculturist farmers.

This highly intellectual sample of cockeydom admits that the fires are destructive. [cockeydom] (Mar 1, 1913,NZ Observer,9)

cocoa matting¶

n. ?short or error for coconut matting

KITTO The cocoa matting and expanded metal [in the quicksilver box] should also be covered with the quicksilver. (1900,Practical Dredgeman's Manual,10)

coconut¶

n. (offensive) a Pacific Islander (orig. prob. applied by Maori to other Polynesians, esp. in Auckland). [ca1955 heard used by an Auckland Maori. 1984 17 M E105Pakuranga Coll. 24E COCONUTS] (See cf. Raro)

Fiu He grunted about the war, the sacrifices he and his forefathers had made, only for coconuts to take perfectly good jobs away from him and his friends. (2006,Purple Heart)

Kapisi.. is a self-proclaimed "Newtown-born coconut. (Oct 28, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

We all roared at Billy T. James' Irish joke. Could we have more please - about coconuts, dallies, poms and horis? Chows too, if possible. (Jun 15, 1986,Sunday Star (Auckland),A8)

HULME Fa' had fitted in by then.The boys protected him from the sneers - `Hey coconut!' (1986,Te Kaihau,111)

McGILL coconut insulting nickname for a Pacific Islander. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,29)

CAMPBELL Are you a Maori?'No - a Cook Islander.' `Ah - a Coconut.' (1989,Frigate Bird,71)

The self-proclaimed "Newtown born coconut" is proud of his Samoan heritage. (Nov 8, 2000,Capital Times,9)

It was the first time someone had called me a coconut. (Oct 26, 1991,Evening Post,25)

Suddenly the national character seemed to go from happy go lucky farmer with a piece of number 8 wire to a racist paranoid redneck looking to use that wire to hang "coconuts". (Nov 1999,North & South,71)

The comedy Elvis was a Coconut, which opens tomorrow, traces the career of a Rarotonga-based Elvis Presley who has never heard of his Memphis double. (Jul 12, 1999,Evening Post,3)

Elvis was a Coconut has to be one of the funniest names for a play ever. (Jul 28, 1999,Capital Times,7)

Mario Gaoa's Indian dairy owner who rails against Coconuts who don't pay their bills, is one of the best moments in the show.. (Jan 23, 2002,Capital Times,9)

Coconuts. When applied to Samoans, the term has PC Thought-Police wringing their hands but Etuati Ete is out to reclaim the word. "It was a label put on us - but it's a word we love." (Oct 28, 1999,City Voice,5)

"Only I can call a show Coconuts. We don't take ourselves very seriously and that gives us license to laugh at other folk." (Oct 27, 1999,Capital Times,6)

There's.. a politician trying to warm up an audience for the televised launch of the Coconuts United Party. (Nov 4, 1999,Dominion,31)

Clearly, Chinks, Coconuts and Currymunchers was out to shock, in a goodnatured way. (Nov 23, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),78)

too much rugby league brawn / on the arms of coconuts (Oct 25, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

She's not like all those other Coconuts. (Dec 1996,Mana,No. 11 : 34)

Williams had repeatedly called baby Kathleen a coconut, she said. "He said he hated Kathleen because she was a coconut and he hated coconuts." (Dec 2, 2005,Dominion Post,A5)

"I'm definitely not ganster. I'm a coconut!" (Nov 16, 2005,Western News,13)

Gadd, Bernard Someone had some beer in a car. "Give the coconut a drink,' said one of them in a friendly voice.I know some papalagi think that us Islanders drink a lot. (1981,Where to Go?,40)

New Zealand-born Michel Tuffery, of Ngaio, says his Samoan descent causes him uncertainty. "At the moment I'm a little confused...because I was born here but at the same time there's this thing going on between the Maori and the pakeha... and I'm trying to figure out 'okay where does the coconut fit?'." (Jun 1, 2004,Independent Herald (Wellington),6) [NOTES: Punctuation as original]

I am a Samoan, but not a Samoan. To New Zealanders I am a bloody coconut or a Pacific Islander at best. To my own, I'm not a Samoan, I'm a Palagi, and to my parents I am a child. (Mar 6, 2003,Dominion Post,A6)

The Taotahi kids have all known, as Atia does, the "teasing" of schoolmates - "Coconuts don't have flush loos, what do ya wipe yourself with?" (Jun 12, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

FRANCES This is the elite part of town. Islanders, Chinamen and Maoris. Coconuts, horis and chinks. (1964,Johnny Rapana,121)

BERRY The Islanders were Coconuts or Raros to the biased Maori; the Maoris were Black Bastards to the bigoted Pakeha; the militant Maori spat `Paak-ia' as an obscenity ... (1980,First Offender,42)

LELAND In addition to referring to the usual hairy milk filled nut, this appellation is used as a derisive name for Pacific Islanders living in New Zealand. The term is most often used by Maoris who resent the Islanders' attempts to move in to the jobs and neighborhoods that are their customary reserve. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,27)

LELAND In addition to referring to the usual hairy milk filled nut, this appellation is used as a derisive name for Pacific Islanders living in New Zealand. The term is most often used by Maoris who resent the Islanders' attempts to move in to the jobs and neighborhoods that are their customary reserve. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,27)

coconut: immigrant from the Pacific islands (1980,Lynfield College, Auckland) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

coconut: Islander (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

Miss Angela Hedley, ... said in written evidence she heard Britt making comments about `blacks and coconuts should not be allowed in the country', referring to Polynesians generally (Mar 28, 1984,Dominion,7)

MITCALFE `Samoa, eh? Another coconut, eh? We got to crack these coconuts, eh Gary, else there be no room for us kumaras, what you reckon?' So they were Maoris ... (1985,Hey Hey Hey,16)

coconut bomber¶

n. someone who served in the Pacific; used in the Middle East theatre for members of Third NZ Div who had earlier served in the Pacific (See cf. glamour boys)

[Caption] And to think I once moaned about being a "Coconut Bomber". (Jan 29, 1945,NZEF Times,IV/188 : 4)

She was to get a lot closer to enemy submarines in November, 1943, when she sailed with the troop ship Maui to entertain "coconut bombers" (New Zealand troops) in New Caledonia. (Apr 22, 2001,Wanganui Chronicle,4)

HENDERSON This pleasing brief chant in Papakura Camp 1940 even spread by way of B Force, the original coconut Bombers, to Fiji and the mosquito-haunted mangroves of Momi Bay. (1998,From Top to Bottom : Reinga to Bluff,52)

The intellectual is as snobbish in his attitude to books and writers as other New Zealanders are to many things, notably to returned soldiers - whether they had been cocoanut bombers' in the Pacific or had beenreally overseas' to Africa, ... (Sep 1952,Landfall,23/223) [NOTES: (Pearson `Fretful Sleepers')]

HENDERSON We Coconut Bombers, the defenders (sic!) of the Pacific, closest to home if the Japanese come south with their firecrackers, and our glamour is nil, we rate nothing. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,252)

BARBER Few New Zealanders, except the kith and kin of those who fought in the Pacific knew much about the Third Division's activities at the time. ... The `Coconut bombers' received little media coverage ... (1984,Red Coat to Jungle Green,122)

Dave rose to great heights - heights that would make the tales of "glamour boys" or "cocoanut [sic] bombers" pale into comparative insignificance. (Dec 22, 1941,NZEF Times,I/26 : 22)

coconut bread¶

n.

Emma and her family will have been cleaned out of coconut bread, of pisu (tapioca with coconut cream) and pineapple pies. (Sep 12, 1998,Dominion,17)

coconut illusion/coconut delusion¶

n. a small meringue cake: present-day coconut pyramid.

BRANDON COCOANUT ILLUSIONS ... White Sugar ... Cocanut ... Whites of Two Eggs ... Beat ... to a stiff froth, then add cocoanut. Bake. (1905,'Ukneadit'. Home for Incurables Bazaar,62)

COCOANUT ILLUSIONS Whites of 2 eggs beaten ... white sugar ... dessicated cocoanut ... cornflour ... (1915,Our Boys Cookery Book,96)

COCOANUT DELUSIONS ... whites of 2 eggs to a stiff froth ... castor sugar ... cocoanut; ... bake in moderate oven ... (1932,St Andrew's Cookery Book,182)

coconut tackle¶

n. a heavy Samoan tackle

There's been all the usual talk of big hits and even the Samoan rugby website this week referred to "coconut tackles" and captain Inoke Afeaki kept to the theme whan he said: "You will see some big hitting and sore bodies afterwards". (Jul 10, 2004,Dominion Post,D8)

Cocos zeylandica¶

n. (Geology)

Two samples of Cocos zeylandica were found on the surface (V20/214148). (Nov 1996,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,111/36)

cod¶

n. [The name of the Atlantic Gadus, transferred to various cod-like fishes of NZ waters, the simplex usu. preceded by a distinguishing (usu. colour) epithet: AND 1821.] (See also codfish; tommy cod)

POLACK Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod ... (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202fn)

PAUL The name cod' is applied to many fishes, often quite unrelated. True cods (family Gadidae), typified by the common Northern Hemisphere cod, are represented in New Zealand by only two species. The so-calledcods' of our waters belong to other families. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,56)

FORSTER The best and most savoury fish was a species of cod, which, from its external colour, our sailors called a coal-fish: besides this we caught several species of excellent flat cavalhas (sciaenae), some scorpens, ... and many other sorts ... which were entirely unknown in Europe (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/126)

Of course, the cod and groper are plentiful, also butter-fish and barracouta. (1896,TrNZI,28/53) [NOTES: (Henry)]

2 n. (obsolete) hapuku (See codfish,rock cod sense 2)

TAYLOR Hapuku or whapuku commonly called the cod, but a much richer fish in flavor ... (1855,Te Ika a Maui,411)

CHAPMAN A hundred Hapukus (New Zealand Cod) ... (1856,Letters & Journals,3/621)

SENIOR Another native fish, the hapuku, is commonly called the the New Zealand cod, although properly it is a sea-perch. (1880,Travel & Trout,294)

TREGEAR The cod (hapuku) is a fine sea-fish, sometimes attaining a weight of 50 pounds. (1904,Maori Race, The,106)

cod fat¶

n. (Rural) fat stored in the scrotum of a castrated animal.

LOUGHNAN cod fat: fat stored in the scrotum of a castrated animal. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,20)

cod-mouth¶

n. (offensive) a wordy person, a big-mouth

... do you think I'm a yob'/ For to work in the rain like you/ Just to hold the bloomin' job?'/All right, `cod-mouth', don't split yer face,/ You're only a one-man show' ... (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,28)

codding¶

n. fishing for cod

HARGREAVES Luckily, I can mix the crays up with codding and the groper to get me through. (1998,On the Next Tide,25)

codfish¶

n. i.e red cod q.v.

FORSTER The day before, the greater Dog fish, (Squalus cogris), well described by Mr Pennant in his Br. Zool. Vol. III. was caught, & likewise a new kind of Codfish, [[ed. fn] Gadus bachus of Descr. Anim., p.120.] it has 2 dorsal-fins, & one beard under the Chin, a dark back, but is allover reddish, & even under the belly & on the fins. I had got such another red Codfish some days before ... (May 2, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/269)

2 n. (obsolete) hapuku (cod sense 2)

LEE & KENDALL Wap|uku, s. The cod-fish. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,225)

YATE Those [saltwater fish] most plentiful, and of greatest note, are, soles, mackarel, cod-fish, a species of salmon, whiting, snapper, mullet, bream, skate, gurnards, and a few smaller kinds, some not near so large as a sprat; with an abundance of crayfish, oysters, shrimps, prawns, muscles, and cockles. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),71) [NOTES: [Griffiths Collection]]

POLACK Some deep banks lie off the east coast, on which the kanai, or mullet, wapuka, or cod-fish, and the ka[acute]ha[acute]wai, or colourless salmon, abound. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/322)

SELWYN In a moment the little population [of Stewarts Island] was alive - children dragging up cod-fish [30] (hapuka) nearly as large as themselves; ... all sharing the joy. (Feb 7, 1844,Journal,Part III (Church in the Colonies VIII) 29) [NOTES: 1844 Feb 7 Selwyn Journal in 1851 NZ Part III (Church in the Colonies VIII) 29-30]

CHAPMAN A hundred Hapukus (New Zealand Cod) ... (1856,Letters & Journals,3/621)

HECTOR The first on the list of edible fishes is the Hapuku or Whapuku of the Maoris (Oligorus gigas), or Habuka, as the name is generally pronounced by Europeans, who in the South apply the name Groper to the same fish. It is also occasionally called the Cod fish, which is altogether erroneous ... (1872,Edible Fishes,102)

SHERRIN HAPUKU (Oligorus gigas). The first on the list of marketable fishes is the hapuku, or whapuku of the Maoris (Hectoria gigas of Count Castelnau), or habuka, as the name is generally pronounced by Europeans, who in the south, apply the name groper to the same fish. It is also occasionally called the cod-fish, which is altogether erroneous, as it is more properly the representative of the sea-perch of European seas. (1886,Fishes NZ,40)

3 n. (obsolete) i.e. blue cod

BEGG (|= macron precedes) cod-fish, ra|ooroo [rawara] c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 113 cod fish - rao'oroo [rawaru] (1979,Boultbee Journal,286,1826 ed.) [NOTES: >1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 286]

codge¶

n. a toilet

HENDERSON Dragons, yellow scaly ones, from an old black-covered Whitcombe and Tombs book, lurked to devour small boys at the lavatory or "codge". Why codge instead of dunny I have never known. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,11)

coff¶

n. a floating cage used to store live lobsters & other seafoods [[this word may be of Australian origin, as it is more widely used there]]

JOHNSON Depending on the proximity of the fishing grounds to markets, floating 'coffs' (large cages) were used as temporary storage. (2004,Hooked,145)

coffee bun¶

n. a bun, the size of a sponge-cake, with a top coating of mock cream and dessicated coconut [Jim writes: The standard name in Wellington in the 1940s for what I had known as sally lunn (in British dictionaries)- a small round bun whose top was covered with icing and (often) desiccated coconut. Coffee bun is not recorded in the OED or any other dictionary I have seen. Its use as a NZ term may be worth investigation. DEH adds : I agree but I think of it as a large round cake-sized bun.]

Their coffee buns (threepence each) were another treat, coated with pink icing and coconut and filled with sultanas. (Feb 12, 2005,Dominion Post,E3)

coffee bush¶

n. spp. of the genus Coprosma which is allied to the coffee plant.

I have seen it stated that coffee of fine flavour had been produced from the karamu, coprosma lucida. (1877,TrNZI) [NOTES: (J.C. Crawford)]

Let but a grass-green parrakeet alight/ To pluck from some wild coffee-bush in sight,/ And nibble .../ The scarlet berries; let some kingfisher/ Slip darting from the post .../ Ibid. 1/154 Coffee-bush (Karamu) ..... O. Rubiaceae(?) G Coprosma(?) Several species. Fruit and seeds like small coffee berries, in scarlet colour, arrangement, and taste. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/154) [NOTES: also 1895 NZ Reader 102 quoting Ranolf and Amohia ... some wild coffee-bush]

Coffee-bush ... a settlers' name for the New Zealand tree the Karamu (q.v.). Sometimes called also coffee-plant. (1898,Austral English,94)

coffee bush: karamu (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,173)

coffee bush n. rarely used name for N.Z. bushy plant, member of the coprosma family. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

coffee lounge¶

n. [Jim writes: Coffee lounges as well as coffee bars and coffee houses were common in NZ in and after the mid-1950s. They still exist under this names especially in more out of the way places. I recently saw one in Dunedin and in Wanganui. Not recorded in OED or other dictionaries, nor have I noticed it in extra-NZ reading. It may be distinctive NZE.]

Outside of good, honest tearooms and coffee lounges, they are probably the indoors where I feel most at home in the world. (Nov 11, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

It's true that coffee lounges are disappearing all over the shop. Linzi of Wellington recently sent me a column from Contact newspaper.. in which Emily Symons also lamented the passing of the Pioneer and the great Matterhorn in Cuba St, although I was relieved to read that the Crystal Lake Coffee Lounge in Manners Mall is still alive and brewing. (Jan 13, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

Readers had supplied the names of 36 tearooms and coffee lounges around the country. (Jun 17, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

This is the seventh instalment of the "Milk, no sugar" chronicles - set up to celebrate the nation's good, honest tearooms and coffee lounges, and to condemn that disease known as the espresso slophouse. (Jun 17, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

coffee tree¶

n. Coprosma lucida.

NAIRN & SON (1912,Catalogue (Nairn & Son)) [NOTES: (And)]

coffeeberry¶

n. =coffee bush

coffeeberry n 3 a : a New Zealand shrub (C. lucida) (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,439)

coffin¶

n. a quiet cell

Mr Williams said the concept of a man being confined indefinitely in the detention block, known at Paremoremo as the coffin' or thequiet cell', was bad enough. (Oct 6, 1973,Dominion,1/3)

n. a mining term

[Tin-ore] has been followed down from the open `coffins' [fn Miners' term for the surface streaming-pits.] of our remote Cornish ancestors to a depth of 300 fathoms ... Notes (Colenso Cornish Tin Mines) (1900,TrNZI,32/323)

coffin foundry¶

n. a funeral parlour.

Some of the lads decided to inspect the `coffin foundry' ... examples of the undertaker's art. (1936,Hills and Valleys,2/43)

coffin-slot¶

n. a slit trench

AIKEN [Dec. 1915, Gallipoli] We rationed with a section of Aucklanders in roomy dug-outs ... but we bivouacked out in the open in coffin-slots among the rhododendrons or oleanders. (1963,Gallipoli to the Somme)

coffin-tack¶

n. a var. of coffin-nail, a cigarette.

... each time I offered him a coffin-tack ... (Sep 13, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,82)

cohou-cohou¶

n. (See kohukohu)

coiling¶

n. shirking work

D'AVIGDOR (Colonialisms) Coiling is to shirk work. (1888,Antipodean Notes,169)

coin¶

v. to damage paintwork with a coin

[He] also confirmed Wendy's new boyfriend's car was coined by someone when it was parked outside her house on Wednesday night. (May 23, 2004,Sunday Star Times,A3)

"When your car is coined on school property, rather than the shopping centre, you take it personally." (Dec 22, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C6)

Chris Jack took the reversals of fortune as personally as if a Springbok forward had coined the 1973 Ford Fairlane that's his pride and joy. (Jul 25, 2004,Sunday Star Times,B2)

coining¶

n. the Cambodian health remedy (goh kyol) of rubbing body with a coin and oil

The Cambodian practice of "coining" - a health remedy that leaves frightening red marks on the skin - has drawn concern from health officials and teachers... The grandmother takes a coin and dips it into a jar of oil. Swiftly and repetitively she rubs the edge of the coin along the girl's back...Coining (goh kyol in Cambodian) is said to release excess wind from the body. By correcting the imbalance, good health is restored. (May 12, 2001,Evening Post,35)

In fact, coining - 0r goh kyol (rubbing the wind) - is relatively painless and afterward even pleasurable... Mrs Young also addresses student teacher and student nurse classes so they can recognise coining. In one class, a student nurse asked if it could help her headache and Mrs Young said she did coining on the young woman's neck. (Mar 19, 2002,Dominion,7)

coinleaf¶

n. Epilobium spp., a willowherb, from the shape of the leaf.

RICHARDS The coinleaf or threepenny bit [Epilobimun sp.: a willowherb] has dull green fleshy round leaves and forms a valuable food for sheep on account of the creeping root system and its rapid growth. (1952,Chatham Islands,35)

cold bite¶

n. a person who is an easy touch for money, cf bite v; cold-botting

BRUNO .. he was renowned as the best `cold bite' in the entire Brigade ... made a bee-line for his tent with hard-luck tales when the feloose ran out. (1944,Desert Daze,19)

cold biting/cold botting¶

n. requesting money [[cold `cool', clever and impudent.]] (See cf. bite v,bot v,cold pigging)

BAKER Here we find that cold biting is rendered as a straight-out request by a tramp or dead-beat for money. On the other hand cold botting is a straight-out request for food at house-doors. (1941,NZ Slang,52)

PARTRIDGE cold-biting; cold-botting. A beggar's frank request for a loan (-biting) or, at a house-door for a meal (-botting): New Zealand and Australian: C.20. Baker, 1941 and 1942. Cf. s. bite, to ask (someone) for a loan', <i>bot</i> is low Australian s. forto sponge'. Ex the persistent bot-fly. (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,138,1961 ed.)

cold calling¶

n. see cit. [adaptation of general English meaning]

The phenomenon is the result of 'cold calling' where teens text unknown friends of friends to gauge the possibility of romance or friendship, then leave their phones on overnight just in case they get a call. (Mar 10, 2004,Otago Daily Times,A11)

cold chain integrity¶

phr. ensuring a cold temperature regime is kept unbroken

This is all about protecting what is known in the trade as "the cold-chain integrity" of products such as chilled meat... Evans mulls over the changes he has seen in 32 years... The method for testing cold-chain integrity back then came down to seizing a frozen carcass and attempting to pull the legs apart. (Sep 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 65/67)

cold country¶

n. high (or shady) country, cf winter country

LADY BARKER New Zealand sheep-farmers are not sentimental. Beyond a rapid thought of self-congratulation that such `cold country' was not on their run, they did not feel affected by its eternal silence and gloom. (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,69)

2 n. (a play on Old Country) Britain

Mr Hoban remarked that the wife viewed with alarm a promise made by Holbrook's father of [pounds]50 to enable Walter to visit friends in the Cold Country. (Jan 9, 1909,NZ Truth,186/?/3)

Cold Duck¶

n.

I know it's traditional and all that to drink bubbly but I just find that Cold Duck too dry. (Dec 20, 2001,Evening Post,6)

Sherry would be served, for the ladies, and anything sparkling (Cold Duck, perhaps) came not in flutes but in those glasses supposedly modelled on some famous courtesan's breasts. (Feb 1, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),7)

Those were the days of Cold Duck and sweet sauternes; we were pretty ignorant then when it came to wine. (Dec 1996,North & South,13)

Montana would, in the 1960s, expand its operations to a 120-hectare vineyard at Mangatangi in the northern Waikato and would soon launch onto the market a concoction which even today lives on in the national memory of a generation - Cold Duck, along with Montana Pearl, was made from siebel bybrid grapes with a touch of sherry material thrown in. Drunk like cordial at student balls, these two - and another Montana line, an orange-flavoured concoction called Poulet Poulet - possibly led to more acts of sexual intercourse than any other contributing factor in the New Zealand of the late 1960s and early 1970s. (Oct 1999,North & South,75)

The biggest single thing that changed the perception about wine was two sparkling Montana wines - Cold Duck and Pearl. (Oct 14, 2001,Sunday Star Times,E5)

"And we've got the last few bottles of Cold Duck [wine] - you can't get it now," Mrs Bardsley said. (May 9, 2003,Dominion Post,A4)

Many young or new to the industry.. may have wondered what it was all about - the Beatles songs, the bright-eyed dancers, the re-introduction of a sparkling red wine called Cold Duck. (Jun 22, 1995,Sunday Star Times,E10)

It was Cold Duck (a cheap and cheerful wine popular in the 60s), and it was served to a crowd of cronies who cut their teeth on it, and remember attending Beatles concerts. (Jun 18, 1997,Capital Times,15)

[Montana's] recent release of the most notorious proto-alcopop, Cold Duck, refreshed memories of an old marketing wheeze. Ibid. 51 The only thing more intriguing than Montana's recent exposure of its dirty duck linen was the media orgy that it provoked, with a raft of bizarre 70s nostalgia riding on the Cold Duck wave... Cold Duck was certainly the most popular of the booze labels that served those grim days when getting legless was the sole purpose of a night out. (Jul 19, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

Wolfe, co-author of New Zealand! New Zealand, in Praise of Kiwiana suggests [Lindauer] can be equated to Cold Duck, the sparkling red wine that celebrated its 25th anniversary in 1997 with a re-release from Montana, selling at $8.95 a bottle. (Apr 29, 2001,Sunday Star Times,D6)

Remember the short-flighted revival of Cold Duck a few years back (which was actually pretty good stuff)? (Dec 7, 2002,Dominion Post,F7)

The world went from black and white television, Cold Duck,and saveloys, to CD-Roms, vodka and the panini. (Jul 6, 2000,Evening Post,6)

Ten ways to reduce the amount of alcohol we're drinking. One. Bring back Cold Duck. (Jun 2, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

"Years go we used to drink Cold Duck and Blackberry Nip and think that was what wine was all about." (Sep 14, 2000,Dominion,17)

Cold Duck rally¶

n.

[He] will be one of about 1200 motorcyclists to brave the weather at the Cold Duck rally in Waipawa, south of Hastings, this weekend. (May 9, 2003,Dominion Post)

cold lake¶

n. (usu. pl.) one of the SI non-thermal lakes (See contrast hot lake)

LYSNAR [South Island] lakes are sometimes called the Cold Lakes , in order to distinguish them from the Hot Lakes in the North Island. (1924,New Zealand (various authors/titles),15)

LEE For in New Zealand we designate lakes hot or cold. Our thermal regions give us the hot lakes in the north as a set-off to the cold lakes of Alpine temperatures. (1934,Children of the Poor,28,1949 ed.)

cold meat ticket¶

n. variant of meat ticket q.v.

FRASER & McGIBBON COLD MEAT TICKET: The soldier's Identity Disc (q.v). It bore his name, regimental number and creed, and was worn under the uniform to serve as the means of identification in case of the wearer being killed. (1925,Soldier and Sailor Words,60)

cold pigging¶

n. practice of selling goods from door to door.

PARTRIDGE A New Zealand variation of cold-biting. Baker, 1941. (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,138)

PARTRIDGE Cold pigging. `The practice of hawking goods from door to door' (B., 1942): New Zealand and Australian: C. 20. In this phrase and in cold biting, cold =cool =cheeky. (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1018)

pigging, cold (Phr.) practice of selling goods from door to door. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),15)

cold shoe¶

1 v. (Rural) to provide a horse with a replacement shoe between blacksmith visits [using clippers and rasps to fashion shoe and fit it to hoof without using heat.]

NELSON cold shoe: v. If a horse throws a shoe between blacksmith visits, the shepherd cold shoes it. (1999,Eugene Nelson Glossary,4)

Cold Tea¶

n. prohibitionism

Mr. Seddon's opponents will most certainly have the cold tea party against him. (Apr 16, 1904,NZ Observer,3)

The wash of Cold Tea is undermining the basis of Seddon's fortress at last. (Aug 27, 1904,NZ Observer,3)

The Maoriland Cold Tea people are aghast at the idea of a dissolution just now for.. if this Parliament is killed.. no Prohibition referendum can be taken at the general elections. (Sep 20, 1913,NZ Observer,3)

Before the worker decides to support a candidate he should consider the candidate's platform and record. As to Mack's platform, it is a nauseous mixture of Lib.-Labism and Cold Tea. (Oct 30, 1911,Maoriland Worker,33/17/2)

cold teaite¶

n. a prohibitionist [[frequent about this time]] (See also coldwaterite)

He is a bigot of the worst type, a rabid cold tea-ite, and was secretary of the N.S.W. Alliance, which, like its Maoriland prototype, is down on all the good liquid things of the world. (Jul 28, 1906,NZ Truth,58/1/7)

cold-mutton-and-damper¶

n.

When two young men in the Canterbury settlement in 1852 were about to depart for the cold-mutton-and-damper life of a new sheep run, they were in danger of becoming `semi-barbarous'. (1961,Distance Looks Our Way,41) [NOTES: (Sinclair)]

coldie¶

n. a cold drink

The traditional New Zealand summer 'coldie' is usually a lager. (Nov 9, 2001,City Voice,6)

The security man at the gate inspected the bin and took away their grog. I can understand their stopping young men toting a couple of dozen coldies on their back, but two respectable women? What could they possibly do? As they were able to buy two cans inside the Park at inflated prices, I wonder where avarice comes in and commonsense goes out the window? (Mar 23, 1983,NZ Truth,2)

coldshelf¶

n. [Google search: WWW Jan 2006, 7/10 are NZ.]

COLDSHELF Position 3 We have a vacancy for a person to work full time restocking the milk fridge etc (Jan 28, 2006,Hawke's Bay Today,16,Weekend Market ed.)

[heading] WANTED - Great Staff Grocery Coldshelf Produce (Sep 25, 2004,Hawke's Bay Today,H17)

coldstart¶

adj.

Proudfoot .. says it was common at the time for students to find potential partners by holding what are still known as "coldstart" dinner parties. While the term isn't widely known outside Otago and Canterbury universities, the practice is common around New Zealand, she says. (Feb 11, 2005,Dominion Post,B10)

coldwaterite¶

n. a prohibitionist

They are going back on tea and Laurenson, the coldwaterite in the House of Representatives, recently gave it as his opinion that tea-drinking is one of the greatest evils of our modern life. (Sep 28, 1907,NZ Truth,119/1/4)

(Aug 26, 1905,NZ Truth,10/4/5)

cole fish¶

n. (See coal fish)

Colenso's¶

n. as a distinguishing epithet translating spec. colensoi, see coprosma, daisy-tree; fern, bristle, filmy; fuchsia; grass, poa; mistletoe, nothopanax, ourisia, phyllachne, spaniard, spleenwort, wineberry.

Colenso's mistletoe¶

n. Loranthus Colensoi = Elytranthe = Peraxilla colensoi

LAING & BLACKWELL Loranthus Colensoi Colenso's mistletoe (1906,Plants of NZ) [NOTES: (And)]

Colenso's Spaniard¶

n.

A FINE HEAD OF SPEARGRASS (COLENSO'S SPANIARD) FIDLER'S GULLY. (May 8, 1907,Otago Witness,46) [NOTES: Photo Caption]

Colenso's wineberry¶

n. Aristotelia Colensoi

COCKAYNE (And) Aristotelia Colensoi Colenso's wineberry (1909,AJHR,C-12) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Stewart Island]

collar¶

n. (the collar) the (indeterminate) sentence for being a habitual criminal; in full dog collar

GLOSSARY OF TECHNICAL TERMS: A boobhead is a prisoner; a screw is a warder; a topper is a toady or an informer. The Act or the Collar - The Habitual Criminals Act, under which persons declared habitual criminals can have their sentences increased by the Prisons Board for offences against prison discipline during their incarceration.... That's Joe, they said, doing six years and the Act for shooting a copper. He was the last man in New Zealand to stop a flogging. ... [15] Joe was doing six years and the Collar, which meant he didn't know when he'd get out. (Nov 1950,Here & Now,14) [NOTES: (Ian Hamilton `NZd's Last Flogging')]

MACKENZIE In 1953 I made a study ... of New Zealand's habitual criminals. These 520 people ... had received the accolade of New Zealand criminality ... In prison language they had been given the collar', thekey', the Kathleen Mavourneen sentence - `It may be for years and it may be for ever'. (1980,While We Have Prisons,9)

n.

McARA Collar: The narrow steel clamp on the drifter-drill column placed below the horizontal arm to provide temporary support while the arm was being loosened off to shift the drill to a new position or when `lining up' on a hole. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),316) [NOTES: Glossary of Waihi Mining Terms]

v. to roll (a swag) and carry it like a horse-collar

SIDEBOTTOM ... Seventeen and I collared our swags and tracked on. (Mar 6, 1855,Letter) [NOTES: 1855 Mar 6's letter in 1958 Gillespie South Canterbury (1971) 459]

3 n. a (too-)wide rim of froth on a glass of beer.

PEARSON One without a collar, Paul?' old Dan said with just a little more pep in his voice than usual: he had evidently had one or two with Jimmy too. <.i>Ibid.</i> 55 She heard the barman say,One without a collar, Jimmy?' (1963,Coal Flat,18)

collar and elbow¶

phr. a form of wrestling

SEDDON The boys learnt a form of wrestling called Collar and elbow' brought by miners from Lancashire. A Cumberland form of that sport was not so popular. InCollar and elbow' the opponents clutched one another in strange `holts' - a right hand grasped an opponent's left shoulder, the other hand grabbed his adversary's right elbow. (1968,Seddons, The,22)

collar rot¶

1 n. (Rural) a disease of seed crops carried by seeds such as peas, and of fruit trees.

Judging from the description given, I should say there is no doubt the trees have been attacked by a disease known by several names: in Italy it is called "Mal-di-goma,"; in Florida "foot-rot"; in New Zealand the name "collar-rot" is generally applied. (Feb 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,157)

Two major groups of field-pea and garden-pea disease have proved serious problems to growers. These are collar-rot (embracing several related organisms) and virus diseases. Collar-rot is a seed-borne disease ... (Jan 21, 1929,NZ Journal of Agriculture,7)

Collar rot (Sclerotinia sclerotiorum) causes considerable losses in plantations where the water-table is high or drainage poor. (Aug 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,133)

collar work¶

1 n. (Rural) uphill work for draught-horses or saddle-horses.

NELSON Collar work: harness or uphill work with saddle or draught horses. (1999,Eugene Nelson Glossary,3)

collar-proud¶

adj.

Denis Wederell.. has dug up an unusual term to describe the feeling a lot of people have.. when driven by lack of money to return to paid employment... Denis, confronted with collar-proud to describe this uncomfortable feeling, says he can't find it in his reference books... A fellow with a farming background... said it's a term for the chafing on a draughthorse's neck when it is put in a collar after a long spell off work. (Jan 25, 1997,Dominion,18)

collar/collar man¶

n. a clergyman [1984 14 F E134Wgton Girls C. 24D COLLAR MAN [clergyman] -->1984 16 F E38 Pakuranga Coll. 24D COLLARS]

collect¶

v. to (a) collide with, or (b) receive as a result of a collision of mishap.

n. a winning bet at a race meeting

..we took three small bets for three collects, a first, second and a third in three different races. (2001,Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success,43)

SLATTER ... we're knocking on the window for the big collect for the big win but I never have big wins and Amy won't open the window because you're too sexo she says ... (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,230)

SLATTER What score have you got in the sweep? ... I've got the right score. This is my lucky week. I'm due for a collect. (1968,Pagan Game, The,115)

college¶

n. a secondary school [Education: a) a tertiary vocational institution such as a Teachers College. b) a name for a secondary school. c) a residential building for students at a university, etc]

[all small even caps] NUMBER OF PUBLIC (PRIMARY) SCHOOLS, COLLEGES, GRAMMAR AND HIGH SCHOOLS, PRIVATE SCHOOLS, INDUSTRIAL SCHOOLS, ORPHANAGES, AND NATIVE SCHOOLS, IN THE COLONY OF NEW ZEALAND, ON 31ST DECEMBER, 1890 ... (1892,NZ Official Handbook,107)

McCANDLISH `One thing I notice is that there are very few working men going out to fight. A greater part of the chaps here have been to College and every other one [55] comes from the Wanganui School. (Oct 6, 1914,Letter) [NOTES: 1914 Oct 6 McCandlish letter in 1984 Pugsley Gallipoli 54-55]

BLAKISTON On a later date, while I was on my way back to college, we found that the flooded Ashburton river had washed away the ford. (1952,My Yesteryears,15) [NOTES: 1952 Blakiston My Yesteryears [f. c1869] 15]

WINKS New Zealanders are just as sloppy about their use of the term college'. Here, a high school may find itself honored with the title ofcollege'. In America, college' means only one thing - an institute of higher learning above the high school - the New Zealanduniversity college'. For this reason confusion often crops up - when someone from Arizona reports the very true fact that [50] `five years of college education are necessary before one can become a high school teacher', he means five years of university work - through the M.A. degree. The New Zealander usually thinks he means one year beyond high school, and therefore thinks of American educational standards as being lower than they are. (1954,These New Zealanders,49)

I say, wait for me, he would call in that strange sort of English English we all somehow picked up when we went to college. (1977,Listener Short Stories,124) [NOTES: I say, wait for me, he would call in that strange sort of English English we all somehow picked up when we went to college.]

LELAND College: This is not a term that (with one and a half exceptions) refers to University level institutions, nor does it (as in some British and North American institutions) refer to the component parts of a University. These parts are called Faculties, e.g. the Faculties of Medicine and Law. Most colleges are HIGH SCHOOLS and this is the general term for a high school. The institutions that train teachers are also called Teachers' College. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,27)

CHISHOLME Streamed into the B class in his first year at college, and all boys' school, Brian finished secon for the year. (1987,From the Heart,10)

College of Education¶

n.

This appears to us to be superfluous in centres provided with university colleges. (1901,NZ Journal of Education,3/134)

To take a degree you had to pass matriculation and keep terms, but the college also welcomed anybody who cared to come to lectures. (1934,Spur of Morning,56)

collins¶

n.

STEVENS [General Freyberg] liked three pieces particularly: first Mr Collins' announcement of his forthcoming letter of thanks for hospitality. The General always spoke of such a letter as "a collins". (1965,Major General Freyberg,60)

colonel¶

n. (usu. pl. the colonels) a member of a 1980 failed coup to replace Robert Muldoon as Prime Minister

[Differences] boiled up again in 1980 when Gair joined the "colonels" in the atttempt to oust Muldoon... (Jun 11, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

Colonel Peerless's Light Infantry¶

phr.

PARTRIDGE In London, for preference; there I can have a mag to a tabby, or if any of you fellows put the boot into me in any way, I'll parade sick and join Colonel Peerless's Light Infantry at the base. (1935,Slang Today,287) [NOTES: 1935 A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287]

`Colonel Peerless's Light Infantry' served at the base at Etaples under a medical officer, Colonel Peerless. There were many titles of that kind. (Apr 4, 1938,Press, The) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang Press [Slang of the NZEF]]

PARTRIDGE Colonel Peerless's Light Infantry. NZ soldiers working at the base at Etaples: NZ military: latter half of WW2. Ex Colonel Peerless, the medical officer in charge. (1984,Dictionary of Slang,240,8th ed.)

colonial¶

n. English used in the colony of NZ

D'AVIGDOR The chap would hang about till some digger would shout to all comers. [fn] Shout: Colonial for offering drinks. (1888,Antipodean Notes,48)

n.

TINNE The korero might have been indefinitely prolonged, for, like all colonials, they [Maoris] are much given to `yarning' ... (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,31)

n. (a beer)

Foaming jugs of "colonial" decked the board. (Dec 1912,NZ Free Lance,Xmas Annual : 25)

n. a European resident of NZ; a non-Maori native-born New Zealander; a person who lives in a colony; one born, or resident, outside the home country

KOEBEL "You shouldn't squeal for the sake of a drop of water like that. It isn't colonial. (1905,Return of Joe,137)

He was glad to say that he was a colonial, anyhow. (Apr 23, 1904,NZ Observer,4)

When he was first returned by an Auckland constituency, he made it a boast that he was a "colonial" born and bred, and while all colonials were duly proud of him, colonists generally were on the tip-toe of expectation. (May 26, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

Food is good... The quantity is notperhaps what we Colonials are used to. (Aug 30, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/1 : 9)

All colonials, "big islanders" included.,agree with the speaker that in the pastythere has been too much Anzac; it's abouttime we heard of the brave and gloriousaccomplished by the British Tommies inFrance. (Aug 30, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/1 : 10)

cole "Not too much of the bloody colonials,chum!" he said. (1949,It Was So Late,60)

HOPEFUL I am sure I don't know if the young Colonial forms his or her idea of `My Lord Archbishop', .. (1887,Taken In,76)

PAULIN M. was almost a colonial, having come out to New Zealand when very young, and being now about 27. (1889,Wild West Coast,2)

On the other hand, it was charitably concluded by the Pilgrims' that a long deprivation of the refinements of good society had warped the judgement of thecolonials', causing them to take too cynical a view of the new aids to colonization. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,85)

BAUCKE [=New Zealander] I am a colonial, and sweet to me are the scents of the land of my birth. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,148)

THORNTON Another restaurant [in Cairo] had for its sign these cryptic words: SQUAR DINKUM FEED', ... A liquor bar held out the following inducement to Colonials:AUSTRALIANS DONE HERE,' ... (1917,With the Anzacs in Cairo,43)

COAD All the town had been invited [to celebrate the 2nd anniversary of the founding of NZ], and they were arriving like true colonials in drays, carts, and waggons of every description. ... It was a gay, light-hearted crowd of pioneers, out for a well-deserved spree. (1931,Such Is Life,41)

ACLAND Until about 1900 most NZ born people spoke of themselves as Colonials, where now they would call themselves New Zealanders. (1933,Sheep-station Glossary)

MULGAN It'll be a positive kindness to the poor chap to turn him into a good colonial. (1934,Spur of Morning,162)

BEATTIE My mate on this trip was a regular new-chum just fresh out from Home ... The two of us, new-chum and colonial, got on well together ... (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,138)

DAVIN But the first-class passengers were all a much more refined set, even the New Zealanders among them - colonials, as we [English] used to say. (1959,No Remittance,23)

HASCOMBE After nine years in New Zealand we know there are still people who will never be convinced that we do not refer to them or think of them as colonials' ... that the only occasions when we have heard the wordcolonials' used to describe the people of New Zealand have been when New Zealanders themselves have used the expression. (1969,Down and Almost Under,50)

2 adj.

The Privy Council was a "colonial relic" and should be replaced by a New Zealand Supreme Court... (May 29, 2003,Dominion,AQ4)

[Advt] Also on hand a large assortment of COLONIAL FURNITURE comprising chiffoniers, chest of drawers, washstands.. couches and other goods to numerous to mention. (Jan 28, 1873,Nelson Colonist,00) [NOTES: check page number]

NORTHCOTE-BADE When applied to furniture, the term colonial will simply denote the furniture used by colonists, it will not imply any special style, as their furniture embraced a number of styles.Ibid.15 Colonial houses are the setting for colonial furniture. Ibid. 131 Perhaps in the chairs shown.. all made here shortly after the treaty of Waitangi, it may be possible to discern a style which with certain justification might be termed "early colonial". (1971,Colonial Furniture in NZ,12)

McGILL And [56] then on to the partridge hatchery, another colonial museum and a Devonshire tea without the double Devonshire clotted cream. (1985,G'day Country,55)

WILLIAMS Upon the question of the children's education I was somewhat surprised to observe the general opinion in favour of a colonial education; my brother and myself were opposed to all the rest; ... [Apr 7 50] The question again was entered upon, relative to the education of the children, when I stood alone for the education of the children in N.Z. (Apr 6, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,50,1961 ed.)

CAPTAIN GREENE [?official term for whalers] After having recourse to the same manners as our Colonial and other English whalers thereat, ... we [sc. Americans] departed thence, having secured but two whales. (1836,Report) [NOTES: 1836 Capt. Greene Report in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 155]

BAUCKE Its [the outback house] style is the undecorated early colonial : two front rooms and a lean-to ... (1905,Where the White Man Treads,23)

HOPEFUL ... a free public reading-room; where a number of London, as well as Colonial papers are to be seen; ... (1873,Taken In,73)

2 adj. As an adj, usu. pejorative or derog. or joc. when used of European life or conditions in NZ; often with a sense of `rough, makeshift' (compare bush, Maori aj), of the person or thing described being inferior in some respect.

"The last thing we wanted was to present a colonial attitude," says Cole. (Sep 27, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

McRAE The meal that night would be a typical colonial one - boiled mutton and potatoes, Maori cabbage and sago pudding, washed down with strong tea and brown sugar. (1963,By the Braes of Balquether,40)

Colonial (1) Made in the colonies. A colonial saddle has large knee pads, a very dipped seat, and numerous dees. (2) Noun use. Until about 1900 most New Zealand-born people spoke of themselves as Colonials. where now I think they would call themselves New Zealanders. (C.) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

MULGAN He had superimposed on a Rugby education a dozen years of colonial shepherding and sawmilling; ... (1934,Spur of Morning,27)

BRUNO It became commonplace for enraged warriors to scream, when challenged in a correct and soldierly manner: Argh!! Go and - ' etc., and even more, etc. In receipt of which undoubted colonial answer wouold come the satified reply:Pass, Kiwi.' (1944,Sa-eeda Wog!,16)

SHADBOLT She was a member of the third generation of a famous pioneer family, and lived ... in a large and prosperous white homestead near the town. The homestead ... was often visited by those who wished to find an authentic colonial atmosphere. (1959,New Zealanders, The,18,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (The Woman's Story)]

MITCHELL About this time, Thatcher, of colonial notoriety, who styled himself `The Inimitable' ... visited Oamaru. (1889,Rhymes and Rambles,23)

And so I smoke Silk Cut and fill my wild colonial face with baked beans and eggs laid by pale English chickens and drink steaming cups of tea poured straight from the pot at St Giles, and read the Timesand the Guardian, because I like a balanced meal. (Oct 27, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

HOPEFUL ... beer is 6d. a pint, ... and this alludes only to Colonial brew, much of which is inferior. English beer is 6d. a small glass. (1887,Taken In,147)

KENDALL Perhaps some captains of colonial vessels may be induced to put into this river occasionally (Aug 1, 1822,Letter) [NOTES: 1822 Aug 1 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 191]

FITZROY The very few persons who are not (to use the current expression) `colonial' in their ideas and conduct, are neither understood nor estimated as they deserve to be, and as they would be in old countries. (1846,Remarks on NZ,28)

SELWYN And, as a natural consequence of the publication [of Selwyn's `Protest'] in England, the Colonial police force, composed of English and New Zealanders, was the medium of communication to this large body of natives. (1851,New Zealand (Selwyn),Part V (Church in the Colonies XX) 81) [NOTES: 1848 Selwyn in 1851 NZ Part V (Church in the Colonies XX) 81]

H.S. CHAPMAN On the other hand, very young men who have been thrown early into this new Colonial life live very rudely indeed. (Nov 24, 1847,Letters to His Father, 1843-1851) [NOTES: 1847 Nov 24 H.S. Chapman Letters to His Father [TS, ATB] in [sc. of life in the backblocks] 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 140]

McKILLOP We all reached the ships unmolested, after an [132] absence of five weeks, during which time we had become quite colonial - an expression very common both in New South Wales and New Zealand, and means that we had learned how to sleep in the bush with a blanket round us, ... build a ware [e-acute] or hut, ... and say Cawpie the maori, `very good the native!' - (1849,Reminiscences,131)

The cut of the people here [in Wellington] is very peculiar, and is only explained by the term colonial. (1850,Emigrants' Letters from British Colonies,94)

FITTON ... I expect you would be surprised to see how very little the reality agrees with the notion formed at home of an early colonial life. ... Believe me, there is nothing wild or savage (hardly colonial), in our mode of life. (Aug 1851,New Zealand (various authors/titles),272)

Co-ló.ni-al (kA.-l&omacr.́.n&ibreve.-al), a. [Add.] Colonial goose, a baked leg of mutton stuffed with savory herbs, to imitate roast goose. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2020)

SWAINSON A little more attention to dress, and somewhat more formality of manner, are observable in Auckland than in the other settlements. The colonial practice of standing idly smoking at the shop doors in broad daylight, and of wearing bush costume is more honoured in the breach than the observance. (1853,Auckland,67)

RICHMOND There is nothing not branded unmistakably `Colonial.' (1854,Letters,1/317)

Everything was most beautifully managed, they all have so much neatness, cleanness and taste that I have been at parties ... which might be called clumsy and vulgar in comparison with this colonial and servantless entertainment. (Feb 11, 1855,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/156,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (Jane M. Atkinson)]

FITTON [in advts] BOOTS AND SHOES.- ... Napoleons, 35s. ... per pair; Wellingtons, English, 30s. ...; colonial, 35s. ... per pair; Bluchers and Oxford, ... 12s; ... (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),83)

BUTLER I hardly know why I introduced this into an account of a trip with a bullock dray; it is, however, a colonial incident, such as might happen any day. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,viii/128)

BARKER We lunched at the principal hotel, where F-- was much amused at the colonial prices. (1865,Station Life in NZ,18,1870 ed.)

[in advts] Colonial Tweed Suits ... Colonial and English Made Boots. (Jan 7, 1869,Grey River Argus,4)

CAIRD There is another thing that will strike a new arrival forcibly. He finds that he belongs to a despised class, he is a new chum', and, as such, he is supposed to be totally incapable of doing anything, though he probably imagined himself to be a rather clever fellow on the whole before. He very soon discovers that he really is anew chum' in the true sense of the word; he cannot crack a stock whip, his first attempt probably causing the lash to come in severe contact with his own face ... in these and many other things he will find himself far from being up to the colonial standard of efficiency, so he must bear the name of new chum with equanimity, till the happy time arrives when he is capable of performing his various duties in true colonial fashion. (1874,NZ Sheepfarming,12)

LADY MARTIN Our captain, whose experiences of colonial life had been confined to the West Indies, ... (1884,Our Maoris,11)

COLENSO ... he [the author] applied to the Government of the colony to publish his MSS., deeming them, though brief, to be not merely interesting, but also of a colonial, if not of a national, importance, especially in days to come; ... (1890,Treaty of Waitangi,6)

... almost (to use a well-known colonial phrase) `by leaps and bounds' ... (1897,TrNZI,29/144)

.. we were all bursting with new-chum energy as we took our first steps in colonial life. (Dec 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,177)

LANCASTER Colonial is nearly as loose a term as European. Don't you tell a Sydney chap (fellow is technically correct over there) that you took him for a New Zealander, or ask a man from the Gulf how they pack Tasmanian apples. (1904,Sons o' Men,152,1905 ed.)

There have been frequent mentions in `Truth' of the inconceivable dislike manifested for Australians by Maorilanders. [Australians are] the scum of colonial life ... (Sep 15, 1906,NZ Truth,65/5/6)

colonial ale¶

n. a poor local ale (as distinct from the imported varieties)

KAIAPOI HOTEL ... English and Colonial ale and porter, on draught or in bottle, always at hand. (Apr 15, 1865,Punch in Canterbury,3)

JKM A glass of thick, saltish, mess called Colonial ale. (1867,Mary Ira,9)

colonial allowance¶

n. ?an allowance paid for non-Home duty

JFK ... he exchanged to [a regiment] in New Zealand, where what are called colonial allowances, though paid by the home government, would enable him to support himself. (1872,Henry Ancrum,55)

colonial beer¶

n. locally brewed beer (? or a brand name); cf. colonial ale.

Fetch in some fresh colonial beer! (1866,Canterbury Rhymes,64) [NOTES: 1859 June in 1866 Canterbury Rhymes 64]

... there was some stale Colonial beer in the sale room. (Dec 29, 1870,Evening Post,2)

Beer, colonial .. per hhd. .. [pounds]4 to [pounds]4 10/ Beer, english, bottled .. per doz. qrts. ... (1892,NZ Official Handbook,166)

colonial blanket¶

n. (? merely descriptive)

SPECIAL PROCESS/ ... All-wool Colonial Blankets./ ... SPECIAL PRICES in MANCHESTER GOOD (Jul 3, 1922,Evening Post,6) [NOTES: check year]

colonial cabbage¶

n.

The children were sent out to gather sow- thistle, and what they called Colonial Cabbage. [Note] "Colonial" or "Maori Cabbage" resembled rape and was plentiful in the early days. (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,104) [NOTES: Writing of 1940]

colonial carriage¶

n. [(?ca1870) R. Mason notes: A four-wheeled vehicle, with a hood - definitely not abuggy', I am assured. In Christchurch I have heard references to one having been used in the centenary celebrations.']

Colonial Carrying Company¶

n.

BATES The three NZASC units, Supply Column and Petrol and Ammunition Companies... [were] generally known as "The Colonial Carrying Company". (1955,Supply Company,17)

Colonial Church¶

n. as distinct from the Church in England

LADY BARKER Some years later, a great man, preaching in London on the wants of the Colonial Church, talked of the coral reefs in New Zealand! (1884,Our Maoris,1)

colonial couch¶

n.

[Advt] Furniture, Groceries, &c... W.Dowden Will Sell by Auction... Bedsteads,Cots, Colonial Couches. (Sep 4, 1874,NZ Herald,4)

[Advt] 100 Colonial Sofas and Couches. (Jul 16, 1874,Otago Daily Times,4)

NORTHCOTE-BADE The term "colonial couch" is a survival of the term: the style differs from place to place. From the advertisement quoted it obviously meant "colonial made." (1971,Colonial Furniture in NZ,144)

WEBB She invited me to be seated, and settling herself upon the end of the colonial couch, prepared for a comfortable chat. (1925,Miss Peters' Special,37)

[Diary, Wairarapa farm, 1948] Our second-hand ... bedroom suite, ... looked well in the main bedroom, as did the re-upholstered colonial couch under the kitchen window. (Jan 3, 1984,Dominion,10)

DAVIES The house had a huge kitchen with ... a colonial couch where the Dad read the Auckland Weekly and farming magazines. (1984,Bread and Roses,21)

colonial cringe¶

n.

It is often assumed that the publication overseas is somehow more meritorious than local publication. This is no more colonial cringe! (Nov 1998,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,117/2)

Far from being some sort of colonial cringe, I believe that having a greater knowledge of where we come from makes us more certain of who we are as New Zealanders. (May 23, 2006,NZ Herald,D2)

If that gun is a memorial it reminds us of "colonial cringe" and the bungling of the British High Command that left hundreds of New Zealanders dead in Gallipoli and France. (May 23, 2000,Evening Post,4)

colonial crossbred¶

n. (Rural) a breed of sheep crossed with the merino and a stronger woolled breed.

STEVENS They [Merinos] had been replaced by a variety of 'Colonial crossbreds.' This term covered a wide range of wool types from the fine woolled Halfbred and Corriedale, the stronger woolled Three-quarter bred to the Romney and Lincoln-Romney ... (1970,Pyne Gould Guinness: the jubilee history,105)

colonial debt¶

n. the money a colony owes to its mother country.

DALZIEL Colonial debt: The money a colony owes to its mother country. (1968,Sir Julius Vogel,32)

Colonial Defence Force¶

n.

NESFIELD The Colonel was at that time chief officer of the Colonial Defence Force ... (1881,Chequered Career,117)

colonial dialect¶

1 n. (Rural) a vocabulary used by some early settlers.

.. I was anxious to become an old chum, as the colonial dialect calls a settler ... (Mar 1860,BLANK ENTRY,52) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

colonial experience¶

n. the practical experience of life in colonial New Zealand to be gained by new immigrants; the conventional wisdom of an old hand.

REVANS Partridge will do well - Our Colonial experience is useful, and we know how to buy and sell quickly. (May 15, 1840,Letter) [NOTES: 1840 May 15 Revans to Chapman 40 (Port Nicholson)]

(The Overseer's Lament) Sowing at once, with a double stitch,/ Colonial experience and groans./ (1866,Canterbury Rhymes,18) [NOTES: 1853 Jan in 1866 Canterbury Rhymes 18]

Colonial experience have, indeed, led him to appreciate more thoroughly the difficulties in the way of the application of any theory. (1853,Guardian, The (London),2) [NOTES: 1853 Canterbury (Extracts from `Guardian' 29 June) 2]

FITTON [Persons] who are desirous of knowing what the prospects are of people now reaching New Zealand, as emigrants from England, without any previous colonial experience; ... (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2)

... their successors will require to employ capital, where the pioneers used colonial experience. (1859,Handbook of Province of Nelson,9)

... unless he has colonial experience. (1864,Digger's Notes,47)

BATHGATE New Chums', on their first arrival in the colonies, hear a great deal said on all sides aboutColonial Experience', and are apt to imagine, as many of the colonists themselves appear firmly to believe, that this phrase means a great deal, and that a man possessed of this quality has acquired a degree of infallibility to be gained nowhere out of the colonies. (1874,Colonial Experiences,1)

KENNAWAY Ah! how does a day's travel amidst wild country differ, in bitter colonial experience, from the ideal ... pic-nic tour of the uninitiated English imagination! (1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,183)

WILLIAMS & REEVES My colonial experience also extends/ To the purchase of horses ... (1889,Colonial Couplets,11) [NOTES: [`A New Chum's Letter Home']]

R EEVES Such men [sc know-all newchums] have not a faint conception of that subtle, untranslatable quality called colonial experience' ... When the new chum says,This is a horrid place; I can't possibly live here a year', we reply Hold on a bit; you will be all right when you getcolonial experience' ... As far as I can see Colonial Experience means the rapid power of adaptability to circumstances and the faculty of unlearning. (1892,Homeward Bound,25)

One man and I had a go at [cleaning the filthy] storeroom. ... I have never gone through anything as bad as this in all my colonial experience. (Mar 5, 1896,Chudleigh Diary,393,1950 ed.)

MORRIS ~ and used as adj. same as cadet (q.v.). in New Zealand; a young man learning squatting business, gaining his colonial experience. Called also Jackaroo (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,94)

BOLDREWOOD (1890,Colonial Reformer, A,95)

BELL That colonial experience which is thought so much of at home, and which you were sent out here to acquire, can hardly be said to have been perfected yet. Ibid. The fact is my dear Mrs. Ashwin, I am supposed to be here for the purpose of gaining `colonial experience,' as it is called. I am supposed to be ... receiving daily lessons in the rougher and more laborious branches of colonisation - here, where men are hourly engaged in breaking-in the wilderness, and all that sort of thing. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,28)

[Clarence] had come straight out from England with a letter of introduction to the boss, `to learn colonial experience'. (1930,NZ Short Stories,12) [NOTES: 1930 Arthur H. Adams in NZ Short Stories 12]

BEATTIE I knew Mieville who was on a sheep station near us gaining colonial experience, and who, near the end of 1853, took up the Glenham run in South Otago. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,53)

He had arrived in Victoria as early as 1838, and when he judged in Market Square had had 14 years colonial experience. (1951,Canterbury Tales,115)

NESFIELD It is the fashion now for people to take the colonies in the grand tour. They fly round the seven colonies ... They write a book. The public read it as colonial experiences and accept it as the truth. (1881,Chequered Career,63)
