1 n. (Rural) the training and experience in rural New Zealand life in the 1800s.

BATHGATE 'New chums' on their first arrival in the colonies, hear a great deal said on all sides about 'Colonial Experience' ... (1874,Colonial Experiences,1)

ROBERTS I had served my apprenticeship on a sheep and cattle run in the Wairau, and had gained a 'colonial experience', which in my case was very general. (1895,Southland in 1856,3)

STODDART Oh! Squatters with beautiful runs! .. Sowing at once with a double stitch, Colonial experience and groans. (1853,BLANK ENTRY,11) [NOTES: in Reeves (1883) Canterbury Rhymes]

WILLIAMS My Colonial Experience also extends To the purchase of horses; for some of my friends ... (1889,Colonial Couplets,11)

They [shennan Bros.] got their first colonial experience at Meadowbank, near Milton, then the property of the late John Cargill. (1910,Tapanui Station,84)

colonial fever¶

n. (obsolete) typhoid fever

Typhoid, sometimes recognised and very often not, goes by many names, e.g. colonial fever, low fever, gastric or bilious fever, blood poisoning, swamp fever etc. (1883,TrNZI,15/498) [NOTES: (Newman)]

NORRIS ... an epidemic of typhoid and `colonial fever' in Hamilton in 1876 was blamed on the immigrants. (1964,Settlers in Depression,12)

colonial goose¶

n. a stuffed leg of mutton, orig. a leg of mutton boned and stuffed; now often mutton flap etc., rolled and stuffed.

Colonial Goose (so-named, I am reliably informed, because it sounded as if the family weren't having mutton again when, in fact, they were) is a delicious underrated dish which keeps the meat moist and the children happy. (May 2000,North & South,112)

Colonial Goose... Leg of mutton... Forcemeat... Sew up openings ..roast or braise (1908,Colonial Everyday Cookery,47)

BURTON Anzac hare. This simple meat loaf bears about as much resemblance to hare as colonial goose does to poultry, but Anzac hare it has always been, and Anzac hare it will remain. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,111)

[Caption] What do you mean I didn't haveto prove I can cook haggis? This iscolonial goose! (Apr 8, 1953,NZ Truth,11)

A TRAMP The goose was mutton. (1891,Casual Ramblings,61)

COURAGE ... and also `Colonial Goose.' (1897,Lights and Shadows of Colonial Life,37)

McADAM Colonial goose, a savoury variant on the usual mutton, ... .. (1905,Pagan's Love, A,38)

[forcemeat : stuffing] COLONIAL GOOSE shoulder of mutton ... remove ... bones ... Spread some forcemeat over the inside of the shoulder, and roll it into the shape of a goose. (1913,Australasian Cookery Book, The,80)

MILLER COLONIAL GOOSE Boned Leg or Shoulder of Mutton,or Colonial Goose (1917,Economic Technical Cookery Book,115)

colonial goose n.-colo'nial goose' n. a boned and stuffed leg of mutton (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,5) [NOTES: c1929-1936 Whitcombe's Etym. Dict.Aust.-NZ Supplement 5]

Colonial goose: Leg of mutton, boned and stuffed. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

COLONIAL GOOSE ... press the mixture into the cavity ... and secure the opening ... serve with good gravy. (1936,Home of Compassion Book of Recipes,33)

COLONIAL GOOSE ... shoulder of mutton ... pepper ... breadcrumbs ... egg ... suet ... minced onion ... sage ... flour ... salt ... dripping ... Fill the cavity with stuffing ... ... Serve with good gravy ... and apple sauce. (1939,Bread - The Basic Food. Facts and Recipes,37)

BAKER One of our standard dishes of mutton is known as colonial goose [as it is in Australia] (1941,NZ Slang,62)

colonial goose: boned leg of mutton, stuffed with sage and onions. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,173)

... Colonial Goose, which is strong mutton sliced wafer thin and served with onion stuffing and an almost black gravy; ... (Apr 4, 1952,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

COLONIAL GOOSE/ One leg or shoulder of mutton, 2 cups breadcrumbs, ... sage, ... onion ... remove [joint] ... Fill the cavity with stuffing ... Serve with good gravy made from the bones, and apple sauce. (1955,New Home Cookery,33)

~ Boned leg of mutton stuffed with sage and onions (New Zealand and Australia). (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),82)

colonial goose n, Austral : a boned leg of mutton stuffed with savory herbs (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,447)

colonial goose n. boned leg of mutton stuffed with sage and onions and baked. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

LELAND Colonial goose. If fowl is New Zealand's most expensive meat, mutton (which you might think is lamb overseas) is the cheapest. Hence a ROLL OF MUTTON filled WITH A BREAD CRUMB STUFFING is substituted. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,27)

BURTON [Title] Colonial goose This is a true national dish. ... 1 leg mutton 115g fresh breadcrumbs 60g suet 1 large onion, finely diced 1 Tbs chopped parsley 1/2 tsp sage 1/2 tsp thyme salt and pepper 1 egg beaten milk ... (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,99)

colonial goose n. N.Z. an old-fashioned name for stuffed roast mutton. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,219) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 141; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 93]]

OGONOWSKA-COATES Colonial goose. Leg of mutton, boned out, stuffed and roasted. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,95)

2 n. (humorous) a New Zealander

HORTON [title] (1984,Memoirs of a Colonial Goose)

3 n. a gannet

CAMPBELL `Captain Cook and his crew called gannets "colonial goose"' I added. (1955,By Reef and Range,91) [NOTES: [?No other evidence of this: ?mistaken: check whether Cook or other diarists referred to them as geese.]]

Colonial Government¶

n.

FOX Now this has ... been practically reserved in the hands of the Governor as the representative of the Imperial Government, and the Colonial Government in fact has had little or nothing to do with it. fever, bilious fever ...) (Oct 8, 1861,Memorandum of Ministers) [NOTES: 1861 Oct 8 W. Fox Memorandum of Ministers in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 111a-b]

colonial hair grass¶

n. (See grass)

colonial halfbred¶

n.

The Merino was crossed with two of these breeds, the Lincoln and the English Leicester, to produce the `Colonial Halfbred'. (1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,57)

colonial language¶

n. coarse language (See also great colonial adjective)

VON HAAST For the first day we were fairly free from sandflies ... but ... with the rain, the sandflies, and the mosquitoes we passed our existence, now and then indulging in a little Colonial language in our impatience. (1948,Julius Von Haast,282) [NOTES: 1862 Von Haast in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 282]

colonial lantern¶

n. (See bush lantern,digger's lantern)

BATHGATE Every guest [at a private dance in Dunedin in 1860s] carried a parcel containing dancing footwear, ... and colonial lanterns, which consisted of a clear bottle with the bottom removed, and a candle dropped into the neck, which acted as a handle, were in common use, and were hidden in the garden ... to be picked up again ... (1925,Random Recollections,18)

DRUMMOND [ref a1860s] ... a weekly dance ..., followed by a walk home of two or three miles through the bush by the light of a `colonial lantern', a bottle with the bottom knocked out and carried upside-down with a candle in its neck. (1982,Waikato Journals,191) [NOTES: 1982 Drummand (ed) Lust Waikato Journals 191]

colonial meal¶

n. usu. mutton, tea and damper [also colonial menu (1939 cit. DNZE)]

BATHGATE We were invited to lunch [at the early Greenfield run c1860s], which we had in a hut, and there I partook of my first old-style colonial meal, consisting of mutton chops, colonial oven bread, and tea without milk ... (1925,Random Recollections,19)

colonial oven¶

n. a long narrow iron box in the form of an oven with a door, bricked into a hearth with room for the fire on top (for boiling and stewing with pots) and under the bottom (for baking).

[Advt] Elegant Drawing-Room Suite,Pianoforte, Household Furniture... NewSafes, Large Colonial Oven.. &c., &c. (Oct 2, 1874,NZ Herald,4)

It was a great day when Grandfather brought home a camp over, and when later still a colonial oven was installed, Grandmother felt that life had little more to offer. (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,211) [NOTES: Writing of 1940]

OVERTON In the cookhouse was a colonial oven and a camp oven, with a small table on which the meals were dished up; with a few forms for seating accommodation. (1949,Fifty Years Sheep Farming,47)

EASTWOOD Our kitchen had a colonial oven embedded in stones cracked flat and plastered with clay. A tunnel was placed at the back on the right and left corner also in clay. The stones and clay were filled in about 6 ft up and the hobs each side on the top of the oven were raised about four inches. At the left side, a crane or arm was erected, and swung in and out. On it were chains and hooks and from it hung our pots, kettles and boilers. (1982,Brief History of Gold Mining, A,107)

Some years ago Mr. H.H. Smith began the manufacture of what was called "colonial ovens". (Jan 11, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,14)

This [sc. a men's hut] consisted of a kitchen with colonial oven and beside it a baker's long brick oven where bread was baked for the station. (1982,Blue Cliffs,20)

FEATON [frontispiece advt] Try the /CHEAP HARDWARE HOUSE/ FOR/ ... /COLONIAL OVENS, &C. ... Hand, Rip. Tennon, Cross-cut, Pit, and Buck Saws. (1879,Waikato War)

Batch after batch he ... gloated over as they came out of the long-suffering Colonial oven, nicely risen and browned. (Apr 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,48)

Colonial oven: A plain oven without divisions, trays or dampers, like a box with the door at one side. It is set a little above the floor of the fireplace so that a fire can be put under it for baking, but most of the cooking is done on an open fire lighted on top if it. (C.) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary (ca1890-1910)]

STEWART We ... had friends to early dinner of roast sirloin, admirably cooked ... in a `Colonial oven,' a sort of iron box with a wood-fire under and over it. (1908,My Simple Life in NZ,13,1878 ed.)

colonial oven: box-like oven with door, used in early days of settlement. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,173)

EVANS Board houses replaced slab whares. ... the colonial oven entered in all its glory. The colonial oven was an elongated iron box afair, bricked into place, with provision for a fire underneath it. On top was the main cooking fire, and kettles and pots rested on iron bars above the flames or were suspended on chains. (1962,Waikaka Saga,221)

PEARSON There was an old-fashioned open fireplace with a hot coal fire ... with colonial oven alongside it. (1963,Coal Flat,61)

DRUMMOND [a picture of a colonial oven] `a long narrow iron box with firepiles on top of it set solidly in the brick or clay surround of the fireplace' .... often an iron griddle above the top fire for pots, kettle etc. (1967,At Home In NZ,87)

JOHNSON At Redheugh we graduated in bread baking from the camp oven to the Colonial ... (1970,Life's Vagaries,47)

BURTON The Colonial oven was also very popular in the very early days. This was simply a cast iron box, with a door at the front, which sat in the fireplace. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,23)

LANGDALE-HUNT It was only a punga house with a corrugated iron roof, but beautifully kept inside and the cooking was done with a colonial oven. (1985,Last Entail Male,130)

colonial pudding¶

n. [two different recipes below]

McCREDIE COLONIAL PUDDING ... eggs ... butter ... sugar ... flour ... jam ... baking powder ... Steam ... (1915,Bungalow Recipe Book, The,57)

COLONIAL PUDDING ... Minced Suet ... Eggs ... Breadcrumbs ... Milk ... Sugar ... Flour ... Baking Powder ... Raisins ... Nutmeg ... `Cathedral Brand' Essence of Lemon ... Grated Carrots ... steam for 2 1/2 hours. (1920,Stevens' Cathedral Brand Essences Cookery Book,34)

colonial Robert¶

n. (historical) a shilling (bob)

the writer gets accommodation at Otautau for "one'colonial Robert' representing the charge for meals and beds" (Nov 14, 1895,Otago Witness,50)

people join the Waikoikoi Arbor Association by "paying to thetreasurer a 'colonial Robert', or, in the vulgar tongue, by 'bobbing it'.It is expected that the treasurer will be handsomely 'bobbed'." (Aug 1, 1895,Otago Witness) [NOTES: This suggests a use of "bob" (for shilling) in a verbal sense which has notbeen noted in the dictionary.Otautau is near Riverton; Waikoikoi is near Gore]

colonial saddle¶

n.

BARKER We were well mounted, and all our luggage consisted of my little travelling-bag ... and what is termed a swag' in front of F--'s saddle; that is, a long narrow bundle, in this instance enclosed in a neat waterproof case, and fastened with two straps to theD's,' which are the steel loops let in in four places to all colonial saddles, for the purpose of carrying blankets, &c. (1866,Station Life in NZ,82,1870 ed.)

Colonial saddle: (1) Made in the colonies. A colonial saddle has large knee pads, a very dipped seat, and numerous dees. (2) Noun use. Until about 1900 most New Zealand-born people spoke of themselves as Colonials where now I think they would call themselves New Zealanders. (C.) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

Colonial Secretary¶

n.

Amongst the Officers thus to be created, the most evidently indispensable are those of a Judge, a Public Prosecutor, a Protector of Aborigines, a Colonial Secretary, a Treasurer, a Surveyor General of Lands, and a Superintendent of Police. (1971,Speeches & Documents,16) [NOTES: 1839 Aug 14 Instructions from the Secretary of State to Captain Hobson, C.O. 209/4 pp.251-81 in 1971 Speeches and Documents 16]

I have been subject ... to great inconvenience ... from being deprived of the assistance ... of a Colonial Secretary, or legal adviser; ... (1841,GBPP,(No.311) : 13) [NOTES: 1840 Feb 20 Hobson to Normanby in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 13]

Mr.Shortland, I find, is appointed Colonial Secretary. (1841,GBPP,(No.311) 109) [NOTES: 1840 June 28 Thomas Bunbury's Report in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 109]

And I do hereby further proclaim ... that Her Majesty has been further pleased to appoint a Legislative Council for the said colony of New Zealand ... and to ... direct that such Legislative Council shall ... consist of ... His Excellency the Governor for the time being, the Colonial Secretary ..., the Attorney-General ..., the Colonial Treasurer ... (May 3, 1841,Governor Hobson's Proclamation) [NOTES: 1841 May 3 Governor Hobson's Proclamation in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 11(a)]

CHAPMAN At the present moment New Zealand is governed by the governor and council, the lattter comprising the attorney-general, the colonial secretary and treasurer, ... (1843,NZ Portfolio,122)

With this you will probably receive an official letter from me with a copy of my communication on the subject of the native Hiriwanu to the Col. Secretary. (Jul 28, 1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/151,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C.W.Richmond)]

HOCKEN A month later the money was returned with a polite letter from the Colonial Secretary, who explained that it had been removed to Wellington solely for `greater security', ... (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,115)

colonial sheep¶

1 n. (Rural) a high country sheep.

An average colonial sheep will weigh, I think, about 56lb. when fully fleeced. (1888,Textile Educator I,263)

colonial skin wool¶

1 n. (Rural) wool for export that has been loosed from the skin with chemicals [1800s & early 1900s]

Colonial skin wool is wool which has been loosened from the pelt by the use of sulphide of sodium. (1919,Wool in NZ,33)

colonial sofa¶

n.

[Advt] Otago Couches and Colonial Sofas,with or without cushions. (Jan 4, 1865,Otago Daily Times,3)

colonial stove¶

n. an iron box with a door which can be placed in a fire; a kind of camp oven. (See cf. colonial oven)

... to sell by auction ... a new Colonial Stove ... (Mar 15, 1851,Lyttelton Times,1)

A LADY ... small cottages of four rooms with Colonial Stoves ... Ibid. 19 I ought to explain that a Colonial stove is simply an iron box with a door, and in it everything is baked - on it the fire is set. (1883,Facts Relating to NZ,8)

colonial tablecloth¶

n. ? a spread newspaper [ca1930 R. Mason (cf 1950 Cherrill Story NZ Sheep Farm 85 He now liked to see the dinner table laid with a damask (where previously an old newspaper had served the purpose [when he was baching]))]

colonial tongue¶

1 n. (Rural) the swearing of bullockies and shepherds in their work context.

ANGUS Swearing was elevated to an art form by the most fluent bullockies and shepherds, and it became so common that it was called the 'colonial tongue.' (1981,Aspiring Settlers,70)

Colonial Treasurer¶

n. the official responsible to the Governor for internal affairs in the NZ colony

Amongst the Officers thus to be created, the most evidently indispensable are those of a Judge, a Public Prosecutor, a Protector of Aborigines, a Colonial Secretary, a Treasurer, a Surveyor General of Lands, and a Superintendent of Police. (1971,Speeches & Documents,16) [NOTES: 1839 Aug 14 Instructions from the Secretary of State to Captain Hobson, C.O. 209/4 pp.251-81 in 1971 Speeches and Documents 16]

And I do hereby further proclaim ... that Her Majesty has been further pleased to appoint a Legislative Council for the said colony of New Zealand ... and to ... direct that such Legislative Council shall ... consist of ... His Excellency the Governor for the time being, the Colonial Secretary ..., the Attorney-General ..., the Colonial Treasurer .. (May 3, 1841,Governor Hobson's Proclamation) [NOTES: 1841 May 3 Governor Hobson's Proclamation in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 11(a)]

CHAPMAN At the present moment New Zealand is governed by the governor and council, the lattter comprising the attorney-general, the colonial secretary and treasurer, . (1843,NZ Portfolio,122)

MANING The whole upshot of this treaty on political economy ... (which I humbly lay at the feet of the Colonial Treasurer) is this:- I would not give one of your locks, my dear, for all the gold, silver, pearls, diamonds, mere pounamus - stop, let me think, - a good mere pounamu would be a temptation (1863,Old New Zealand,(II) 26)

DALZIEL Colonial Treasurer: The cabinet member responsible for finance, similar to the Minister of Finance of today. (1968,Sir Julius Vogel,32)

colonial twang¶

n. [incl fig. ref to taste]

"Let me have another taste," said the somewhat confused connoisseur, and then with a deprecating gesture, "H'm, there is a colonial twang about it after all." (May 30, 1881,Wanganui Chronicle,2)

BARNICOAT Everyone, of course, is prepared for the `colonial twang' - an evil worse in some parts of New Zealand than in others, but increasing everywhere; (Nov 1903,Life in NZ,394) [NOTES: 1903 Nov Constance A. Barnicoat Life in New Zealand As It Is in Empire Review 394]

Above the babel of colonial twang, the noise and din in the estaminet near, rose the raucous shout of the proprietor of the royal and ancient game of chance. (1917,New Zealand At the Front,105)

Above the babel of Colonial twang, the din and clatter, in the little estaminet, rose the raucous shout of the proprietor of that Royal and Ancient Game of Chance -- Crown and Anchor. (Aug 10, 1921,Quick March,27)

colonial varnish¶

n.

SOUTHAN These shelves [in the hut] are also papered with a light-brown wrapping paper, which has been varnished with what is termed `colonial varnish' - made from a little of any kind of spirit, and mixed with some of the gum which is very plentiful in Victoria and Tasmania. (1881,Two Lawyers,231)

colonial villa¶

n. (See villa)

They shifted ... to a large old colonial villa ... overlooking Glenfield ... (1988,Through the Looking Glass,154) [NOTES: Kirk]

Colonial Volunteers¶

n. a local militia raised to control Maori 'hostiles'

MOSER Colonial volunteers are not as a body the most indisposed for a joke ... (1863,Mahoe Leaves,48)

colonial war¶

n. ref. the New Zealand Wars

REISCHEK Perhaps, also, he will help to remind them how good, how strenuous life was `in the good old days,' when their Dominion was still half-savage, still unsettled after the toughest of colonial wars, and before the fire and axe of succeeding generations of peaceful settlers had robbed her of so much of her incomparable possession, the native bush. (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,7) [NOTES: 1930 Andreas Reischek Yesterdays in Maoriland (1933) H.E.L. Priday Preface 7]

colonial wardrobe¶

n. ? a curtain run across the angle of a wall; or phs a suitcase [ca1930 R. Mason]

colonial-grown¶

adj.

In the past there has been in the minds of the New Zealand farmer and merchant a prejudice against colonial-grown Brassica seed. (1939,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,20/100A)

colonial-made¶

adj.

Diggers, Station-holders, and Farmers supplied with the best colonial made boots and shoes cheap for cash. (Apr 15, 1865,Punch in Canterbury,3)

colonialise¶

v.

SINCLAIR In fact the central Government was eventually to take both revenues [land and customs], the land fund being `colonialized' by Grey himself when he became Premier in 1877. (1959,History of New Zealand,152)

colonialism¶

n.

THORNTON He was - to use a colonialism - `a white man'. (1916,Wowser, The,45)

colonially¶

adv. (obsolete)

HALL-JONES A new plant ... colonially termed a `Spaniard' ... (1971,Mr Surveyor Thomson) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection) c1850s in 1971 Hall-Jones Mr Surveyor Thomson]

colonially-manufactured¶

adj. NZ-manufactured

A considerable trade is also done in colonially-manufactured jams. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,132)

colonially-reared¶

adj.

His wife is a pretty little person with the limited experience and ideas ... of a colonially-reared girl. (Oct 21, 1857,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/318,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

colonies, the¶

n. the eastern Aust. colonies (esp. New South Wales and Tasmania), alone or including NZ.

MARKHAM ... the Sawn Plank is very cheap in the Colonies and lately there is some prejudice against the New Zealand Pine. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),48,1963 ed.)

colonisation¶

n. the European settlement, or Europeanisation of NZ and New Zealanders.

WILY & MAUNSELL At the three principal posts of colonization, the Bay of Islands, Auckland (the metropolis near [76] us), and at Wellington, the Company's town at the western part of Cook's Straits. (Mar 31, 1842,Robert Maunsell,75)

INGESTRE It is impossible to reconcile the missionary system with that of the Company. ... The avowed object of the missionaries has been to prevent colonization, to preserve the nationality of the New Zealanders, ... and to maintain their exclusive property in the whole soil of the islands.Our system ... was ... to encourage the settlement of European colonists, and to turn to account the peculiar facilities which the aboriginal race of New Zealand seem to possess for intermixture and amalgamation with the European population. (May 5, 1845,Letter) [NOTES: 1845 May 5 Lord Ingestre to Lord Stanley in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 12]

If the Government desired to undertake the work of real colonization ... (Jul 1, 1851,Lyttelton Times,5)

Not so [jovial] Mr Govett, the vicar, who is innocent & naive enough to fear the corruption that these worthies may introduce into his cure. This fear of spoiling their `happy valleys' has been epidemic on the ministry here, and has made the missionaries oppose colonization and led them to vamp up all the nauseous maudlin maori fancying stuff that has caused disaster ... here... (Aug 13, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/103,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond)]

Not so [jovial] Mr Govett, the vicar, who is innocent & naive enough to fear the corruption that these worthies may introduce into his cure. This fear of spoiling their `happy valleys' has been epidemic on the ministry here, and has made the missionaries oppose colonization and led them to vamp up all the nauseous maudlin maori fancying stuff that has caused disaster ... here... (Aug 13, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/103,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond)]

SWAINSON But when it was seen ... that an irregular species of colonization was already going on, ... `fatal to the natives;' that the New Zealanders were improvidently divesting themselves of their [2] territorial possessions; ... (1853,Auckland,1)

BUDDLE It does not fall within the objects of this pamphlet to enter into a defence of the Missionaries ... against those whose pens are now so ready to slander them, ... to stigmatise them as opponents of colonization and enemies of the country's progress. (1860,Maori King Movement,22)

LINDSAY Like the Leptosperma, in the early days of colonisation, the plant [Acaena] was much used, in bush journeys, to yield by infusion a substitute for tea. (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,59)

HAWTHORNE It has been shewn that, by his conquest of the East Coast, Mr. M`Lean had paved the way for its speedy and peaceful colonization. ... By 1867, manifold conflicting interests had grown up in Poverty Bay and East Coast districts, in the shape of land purchases ... (1869,Dark Chapter from NZ History,10)

T.S.GRACE In early years they [Natives] received Christianity - and I may say Colonization- at our hands without doubting, and, to a great extent, on credit. Colonization, war, confiscation and English vices have followed each other in quick succession, while the expectations anticipated from representations made when they signed the `Treaty of Waitangi' have not been realized. (Nov 18, 1877,Letter,286,1928 ed.) [NOTES: 1877 Nov 18 T.S.Grace letter in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 286]

BELL I saw the old gentleman. He seems to be rather too far gone in the sere and yellow leaf to give promise of much success in the glorious work of colonisation, as you would call [25] it, Wilmot. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,24)

MARSHALL It is strange that this part of New Zealand [Northland], where colonisation began, and which contained the original seat of government, should have slipped back into an isolated backwater. (1983,Memoirs,24)

colonise¶

v. to settle (NZ) with Europeans; to establish a British settlement (in NZ).

With sixty persons Taranaki may be considered as colonised. In two or three months there will be from three to five hundred persons there. (1940,Establishment of New Plymouth Settlement,xv) [NOTES: 1841 Feb 13 in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth xv]

RUTHERFORD The Crown devolved on [the NZ Company] the function of colonizing New Zealand; that is, of filling it with inhabitants. (1949,Selected Documents,12) [NOTES: 1845 May 5 Lord Ingestre to Lord Stanley in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 12]

WAKEFIELD But it is not the intention of the [Canterbury] Association to divide ... the territory to be colonized ... into sections of regular size and figure, ... (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,14)

The Spectator is dreadfully scandalized that New Zealand should be colonized by Companies in whose management the settlers have no voice, ... (Apr 19, 1851,Lyttelton Times,5)

COURAGE In the early days, settlers felt they were `colonizing', now the new arrivals immigrate in the same way. (1897,Lights and Shadows of Colonial Life,354)

v. of the Maori settlement of NZ

CHEESEMAN [Pomaderris apetala, Lab.] Tainui. A common Australian plant. The Maoris assert that it sprang from the rollers or skids that were brought in the canoe `Tainui' when they first colonised New Zealand. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,99)

v.

HILLIARD `It looks different to me. You've always got to be the boss. Is that just pakeha, or is it being a man? Let me just be myself. Don't try to make me be like you. Then we'll get along fine. But don't try to colonize me. You do it all the time.' Colonize. A strange word for her; must have learnt it in school. Why the English came out here: to colonize New Zealand. That would be pretty hard for them to take : Maori kids, being told how they were colonized. (1978,Glory and the Dream, The,126)

2 v. ?to make a home in; thence, to make oneself at home in; hence (3.?To adjust to `colonial' ways).

This is all very homely [i.e. domestic servants quickly marrying and setting up homes of their own]; but the romance of the colonies is of a very domestic nature - to make homes' is another mode of expressingto colonize.' (1875,Official Handbook of NZ) [NOTES: 1875 Julius Vogel's Introduction to the Official Handbook of NZ quoted in 1935 Harrop (ed) Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland xvii]

3 v. usu. as a pa. ppl. or verbal complement be, come, get colonised (occas. colonialised), to become adjusted to NZ ways and life; to become a colonial.

BATHGATE If an unfortunate new chum ventures mildly to protest against some trifling hardships he is at once silenced by being told that it is evident he is not `colonised' yet, and that he must get used to such things. If any particular philologist should read this, he will probably object to the word colonised in place of the more correct but uglier colonialised, but he would find it a vain task to attempt to argue the colonists into the use of any other. (1874,Colonial Experiences,9)

BATHGATE I shall not care to venture on that rapid river in a tub like that [Maori canoe]', said Gilbert [a new chum] ... [75]Oh! She will be getting more colonised py and py [sic], and not caring so much', was Dougal's [the Highland shepherd's] patronising remark (1881,Waitaruna,74)

HAY There's an Auckland proverb, that a new chum never does any good until his nose has grown. ... After inhaling this magnificent air of ours for a year or two, your nose will grow bigger to receive it; and about the same time you will have spent the money you bought with you, gone in for hard work, learnt common sense, and become `colonised.' (1882,Brighter Britain,1/21)

CHAMIER `You ain't colonised yet', remarked Jack [to the new chum]. (1891,Philosopher Dick,149)

coloniser¶

n.

Among her colonizers brave/ Shall many a soul be found/ To make the Southern wild and wave/ Henceforth poetic ground. (1866,Canterbury Rhymes,22) [NOTES: 1853 Nov in 1866 Canterbury Rhymes 22]

colonist¶

n. an early settler

HOCHSTETTER On account of their slender blades terminating in sharp spines the colonists have named them spear grass',wild Irishman', and `wild Spaniard'. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),133)

colony¶

n. any one of the original local New Zealand settlements (See cf. settlement)

Within the country, New Zealand was after 1840 known as the Colony, and subsequently as the Dominion, the title it carried from 1907 until the 1940s or somewhat later. Now it is simply the country, or more formally the nation, and of course home (as opposed to Home) for those Kiwis who are temporarily absent from it. (Oct 2000,NZWords,4 : 2)

WEEKES On landing in the Colony the Storekeeper ... is authorised to allow you these amounts ... Ibid. 54 This is the effect of the labourers having no amusements, there being a great sameness and want of excitement in this infant colony. (Nov 9, 1840,Letter) [NOTES: 1840 Nov 9 Weekes Letter in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 4]

CHAPMAN [Ships] which conveyed the first colony to Port Nicholson - an emigration unprecedented in the annals of colonization. (1843,NZ Portfolio,104)

WAKEFIELD [cf Settlement] Such persons ... who are about to take part in founding the proposed Settlement of Canterbury ... a separate description of each of the existing Settlements, and of several districts of country ... which appear to offer eligible sites for the Canterbury Colony; (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,2)

[=settlement] Another drawback at present is, that we are dependent upon other colonies for supplying us with provisions until we can raise our own. (Sep 13, 1849,Letters from Otago,37,1978 ed.)

GOVERNOR GREY The group of colonies comprised in the New Zealand islands are composed at present of what might be termed nine principal European settlements besides smaller dependencies of these. (Aug 30, 1851,Letter) [NOTES: 1851 Aug 30 Governor Grey to Earl Grey in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 44.11 [contrast settlement] 11]

GOVERNOR GREY 25. In the two islands there exist six principal towns, five of which are situated on good harbours, and each of these form emporiums for considerable colonies in their neighbourhood. 26. These five colonies were settled at different times, each upon a totally distinct plan of colonization, and by persons who proceeded direct to their respective colony, either from Great Britain or from the neighbouring Australian colonies, and who rarely passed through any other New Zealand settlement previously to reaching the colony which they now inhabit; and who ... rarely travel from their own colony to any neighbouring settlement. (Aug 30, 1851,Letter) [NOTES: 1851 Aug 30 Governor Grey to Earl Grey in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 44.25-26]

FOX [title] (1852,Six Colonies of NZ, The)

PUBLIC NOTICE/ The largely increasing immigration to this province from adjacent colonies, notwithstanding the appearance, both in Australia and Dunedin, of such accounts of the goldfield ... (Oct 1, 1861,NZ Goldfields,31,1976 ed.) [NOTES: 1861 Oct 1 Dunedin in NZ Goldfields 1861 (1976) 31]

SINCLAIR The first `colony' of New Zealand Company settlers reached Port Nicholson late in January 1840. Ibid. 105 Until late in the nineteenth century, however, most of the settlers thought of themselves as belonging to the colony of Otago or Wellington, not the colony of New Zealand. (1959,History of New Zealand,68)

2 n. New Zealand regarded as a country or as a political or administrative whole; later called Dominion.

THOMAS BUNBURY I obtained ... the signature of a very intelligent well-dressed native, who spoke English better than any that I have yet met with in this colony. (Jun 28, 1840,Report) [NOTES: 1840 June 28 Thomas Bunbury's Report in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 106]

RUTHERFORD And we do hereby declare, that from henceforth the said islands shall be known and designated as the colony of New Zealand, and the principal islands, heretofore known as or commonly called the Northern Island', theMiddle Island', and Stewart's Island', shall henceforth be designated and known respectively asNew Ulster', New Munster', andNew Leinster'. ...Provided always, that nothing in these our letters patent contained shall affect ... the rights of any aboriginal natives of the said colony of New Zealand to the actual occupation or enjoyment in their own persons, or in the persons of their descendants, of any lands in the said colony now actually occupied or enjoyed by such natives. (1949,Selected Documents,8) [NOTES: 1840 Nov 16 Charter for Erecting the Colony of NZ in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 8]

The colony of New Zealand will ... be indebted to the colony of New South Wales for any advances made from the one treasury to the other ... (1841,GBPP,(No.311) 27) [NOTES: 1840 Dec 9 Lord John Russell to Governor Hobson in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 27]

In order ... to do away with the temptation ... which this colony affords for smuggling, by its bays and rivers ... (1842,GBPP,(No.569) 117) [NOTES: 1841 July 27 Governor Hobson Despatch in GBPP 1842 (No.569) 117]

MILLER In fact there is little or no money in the Colony except the Company's. On you Sir the (visa : versa) success of the Colony depends. (1958,Early Victorian NZ,122) [NOTES: 1843 Jan 14 The Working Men of Nelson to Captain Wakefield. NZ Company Papers 208/2 in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 122]

RUTHERFORD All questions of a vexatious nature between the Government and the settlers in that part of the colony [sc. Cook's Strait] have now been finally set at rest; ... (1949,Selected Documents,21) [NOTES: 1846 Oct 7 Grey to Gladstone in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 21]

The Imperial Parliament having conferred upon the Colony of New Zealand a constitution of unparalleled liberty ... I am wishful to see that constitution properly read and carried out ... (Jul 1, 1857,Lyttelton Times,2)

.. but anything more treacherous than the Home Govt. [sic] in luring on the Colony to such ... expenditure for the final settlement of this Maori question, ... I never heard of. (Aug 5, 1864,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,23/117,1860 ed.) [NOTES: (Jane M. Atkinson) .]

MEREDITH The New Zealand Government did not seize the lands of the colony. All lands were paid for to the different hapus (tribes) and resold to settlers. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,83,1935 ed.)

D'AVIGDOR A hungry man will do anything, so [he] began his labours next morning at sunrise, for this was one of the few places in the Colony where the eight hours rule was ignored, where men worked ten hours daily ... (1888,Antipodean Notes,160)

MEREDITH The New Zealand Government did not seize the lands of the colony. All lands were paid for to the different hapus (tribes) and resold to settlers. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,83,1935 ed.)

D'AVIGDOR A hungry man will do anything, so [he] began his labours next morning at sunrise, for this was one of the few places in the Colony where the eight hours rule was ignored, where men worked ten hours daily ... (1888,Antipodean Notes,160)

The Colony of New Zealand consists of three main islands ... These three islands ... namely, North island ... South Island ... and Stewart Island. ... New Zealand ... has ... large plains in both the North and Middle Islands. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,1)

HARPER A few, possibly, who prefer a free and unfettered existence in a part of the colony where they can easily make a small living, may consent to dwell in such an out-of-the-way locality. (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,31)

HOCKEN For the government of the Colony as a whole there were constituted the two Houses which at present exist (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,140)

BELL [He had] emigrated to the Colony some years previously, and, at first in the South Island and afterwards in the Bush districts of the North, had ... found employment ... (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,10)

Old identities are dying all over the Colony. (Mar 31, 1906,NZ Truth,1)

... I have lately collected a great deal of information dealing with the position that has arisen in New Zealand since acclimatisation was commenced in this colony, over forty years ago. (1907,NZ Truth,39/227)

POWER (Introd) A very large ... audience assembled in the Town Hall, Dungarvan, [Ireland], on Thursday evening, October 8, 1908, to hear the ... ideas on the rising Colony in the Southern Seas. [The later edition has Colony deleted and replaced by Dominion. (1988,New Zealand: The Islands of the Blest)

BURDON The first two stages of the Colony's growth, pastoral and agricultural, had clashed. The time when the pastoral industry had been of supreme importance was passing by; but pastoralism still lay ... across the path of progress in agriculture. (1938,High Country,150)

SEDDON In 1908 he [Sir Joseph Ward] attended an Imperial Conference. When he returned home he announced that we were no longer a Colony but a Dominion. Parliament debated the change for days. The opposition naturally were against the elevation. A few Government members were luke-warm about saying good-bye to the term `Colony' ... (1968,Seddons, The,199)

3 n. (historical) New South Wales

ELDER Mr. John O'Neal, mate of the vessel and a native of the Colony, for some time defended Mr. Burnett against the attacks of several adversaries, with an empty musket. (1934,Marsden's Lieutenants,90,1934 ed.) [NOTES: 1815 Aug 31 Burnett quoted in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 90]

[=?NSW ?B ofI] The whole of his misconduct would soon spread through the Colony after our arrival, which would under his situation be painful. (Nov 1823,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,401,1932 ed.)

WILLIAMS In the afternoon assembled the committee; when it was determined the Herald should return to the Colony for stores, as none had come down exceptg. flour ... (Mar 16, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,45,1961 ed.)

WILLIAMS Ship arr'd from the Colony for Liverpool to sail in the morning; ... (Jun 4, 1833,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,317,1961 ed.)

BULLER Rafts of long spars, ... were floated down to the ships - ... to be taken ... to New South Wales, or to `the colony,' as it was then [1836] called. (1878,Forty Years in NZ,28)

Colorsteel¶

n. a proprietary brand of roofing iron

It has a textured Insulclad exterior and a curved Colorsteel roof... (Jul 21, 2004,Dominion Post,C15)

colour¶

n. gold

BOWMAN It was not long before numbers of Port Chalmers men began to return crestfallen to the town, for many of them had failed to find the "colour". (1948,Port Chalmers,19)

BARKER They talk of having "found the colour" (of gold) in some places. (1980,St Patrick's College, Silverstream 1931-1956,66) [NOTES: Check page]

HOCHSTETTER Nor was there a single dish full of dirt' that did not show thecolour'. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),97)

colour line¶

n. a colour bar

BEATTIE That [sc. inviting a Maori couple to stay] was over 80 years ago [c1856, Otago] and there was no colour line then - the Maori was as good as the white man. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,48)

coloured¶

adj. `non-white' in NZ applied to sheep (coloured flock, coloured sheep) rather than to people.

My own coloured flock was commenced about ten years ago from a mixed lot of merino and Lincoln-merino ewes ... the lambs of the first season - the produce of the black or coloured ewes, sired by the reddish-coloured ram - were all so-called black lambs. (1901,TrNZI,33/197)

coloured sheep NZ one of some small flocks mostly black or grey, yielding wool suitable for home-spinning and weaving (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,142)

adj. Maori

CARR In Poverty Bay the bulk of the [shearing] work is still done by the `Day and Martins', as the white shearers frequently term their coloured brethren. (1913,Country Work,14)

colours¶

n. gang identification

The colours come off and we go as a family and no one even knows who were are. (Feb 16, 2002,Manawatu Evening Standard Saturday Magazine,9)

colt¶

n. member of a junior sports team [? not only NZ]

MOURIE & PALENSKI The following year marked my first class debut - for Wellington Colts against Horowhenua. (1982,Graham Mourie Captain,54)

The New Zealand Colts team to tour New South Wales country districts has been chosen. (Dec 28, 1955,Auckland Weekly News,39)

The tour of northern New South Wales by the New Zealand colts [cricket] team was successful from a playing point of view. (Feb 8, 1956,Auckland Weekly News,42)

colt ... (chiefly in pl) Rugby player below certain age, usu. 21 and under (NZ colts, Auckland colts) (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,142)

Plural A rugby football team comprising players under a certain age. b) a member of such a team. (1988,Heinemann NZ Dictionary,22)

coma kid¶

n.

A game called Anchorman played by the students at one of the University of Otago's Halls of Residence, requires participants to consume six jugs of ale in four hours without being sick. The reward is an Anchorman's badge. ... Although it has been banned by college authorities ... [it is] regarded as a way of sorting out Men' from thechunder bunnies' or `coma kids'. To become an Anchorman is to be like an anchor which stands firm even when completely submerged (Mar 13, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,16)

comb¶

n. in shearing, the lower, stationary unit of shearing handpiece which enters and holds the wool as it is cut (See wide comb,narrow comb)

In sheds where machines are used.. theshearers to pay for combs and cutters atcost price. (1906,Awards etc.,VII/625)

If I mistake not, a man is also required to sharpen knives and keep combs in order. (Dec 11, 1890,North & South,7)

On the morning of shearing the shearers grind and set cutters and combs ready to start work. (1945,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),3(6) : 24)

She had gouged her hand on a rusty shearing comb. (Nov 26, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),57)

That Rule 99 in regard to widecut combs and cutters be strictly adhered to. (Aug 11, 1911,Maoriland Worker,11)

WALLACE The cutter ... moves from side to side 4,000 times per minute over the comb, which rests upon the skin of the sheep, and threads its way among the wool close to the surface of the body. (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,370) [NOTES: [OED2]]

Assets Shearers' Combs, Cutters, etc. ... 7000 (1912,NZ Shearers (Report Third Annual Conference),23)

  1. In sheds where machines are used ... the shearers shall pay for combs and cutters at cost-price. (1912,Sheepowner's Handbook, The,27)

MACDONALD [Advt] Cooper's Little Wonder Shearing Machine ... The Shearing Attachments comprise ... two Latest Model Cooper Handpieces. ... COOPER COMBS AND CUTTERS will fit any make of handpiece ... (1915,NZ Sheepfarming,xv)

SMITH Each shed employs an expert, who sharpens the shearers' combs and cutters and looks after the machinery. (1927,Sheep & Wool Industry,70)

Dust can lower the value of a clip, ... besides being hard on combs and cutters. (Oct 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,310) [NOTES: [OED2]]

BOWEN ... when the comb digs in it makes the sheep kick and the dropper moves around and loses its true swing. (1955,Wool Away!,4)

MIDDLETON When ... I had spread the fleece on Charlie's skirting table, the shearers began to sharpen their combs and cutters for the next shed. (1959,Stone, The,49) [NOTES: (The Stone)]

FERNANDEZ He pushed his completed, naked sheep through his legs and out the porthole then paused to change his cutter. The pumice in the wool played up with the gear, blunted the cutter and combs, ruined a man's tally; ... (1973,Tussock Fever,3)

Comb: Stationary unit of shearing handpiece which enters and holds the wool as it is cut. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53)

comb ... 3. Austral. & N.Z. the fixed cutter on a sheep-shearing machine. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,220) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 142; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 94]]

RICHARDS None of them had ever shorn a sheep before, nor had they ever seen a handpiece correctly set up with comb and cutter. Ibid. 67 We were anxious to grind our combs and cutters and get our gear set up for the morning, ... (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,55)

Shearing hand pieces worth nearly $7400 were stolen from a Palmerston North stock agency firm. Wrightson-NMA's ... shop lost seven hand shearing pieces, and many combs ... (May 26, 1986,Manawatu Evening Standard,1)

v. (Rural) [sheep while shorn] to shear easily.

As I started to shear it, it wouldn't comb and when I came down the last side it flopped on the floor like it was dead. After that the sheep combed like butter ... (Apr 6, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,15)

n.

ELDER (1819,Marsden's Lieutenants,165) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

v. back-formation from beachcomber na2., to sift black sand for gold.

HALL They work on the [West Coast] beach `combing' up the black sand ... with which the flour-like gold dust is associated. (1914,Woman in the Antipodes, A,99)

HYDE There's plenty of men back in the hills [of Central Otago] yet, combing for gold. They reckon one day they might strike the Empress Reef. That reef never petered out, you know. Ibid. 129 He thought of Macnamara, combing for gold up in the mountains of Otago central, and wondered if he had found any; ... (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,54)

phr. to comb country in search of gold. (See also gold-combing)

1 v. (Rural) to muster or scratch hills for sheep.

MCMILLAN The gangs are out on Castle Peak and combing Snowy's crown. (2000,Country Bloke and Other Verse, The,193)

MILLER The country had to be combed and re-combed for stragglers. (1958,Sturdy Sons,128)

SHARPE 'George, you take young Alf and comb that big basin on the western side and the rest of us will do the head of Snowy Creek.' (1962,Country Occasions,120)

SHARPE On subsequent days, after most of the summer country has been 'combed' the mustering gang becomes more like a team. (1962,Country Occasions,123)

1 n. (Rural) a lower blade on a shearing handpiece. (See cover comb,snowcomb)

RICHARDS I now have a collection of antiques .. old handpieces, combs, cutters, droppers. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,41)

WALLACE The cutter .. moves from side to side 4,000 times per minute over the comb, which rests upon the skin of the sheep. (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,379)

MACINTOSH How I welcomed an unexpected stop for a change of cutter or comb on the handpiece. (1974,Never a Dull Moment,113)

2 n.

comb fern¶

n.

Comb ferns are equally distinctive in being the only ferns in New Zealand in which the stalk of the frond (the stipe) is much longer than the leafy blade (the lamina) and often forks several times. (2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/72)

POTTS (And) Schizaea dichotoma [etc.,etc.] (1882,Out in the Open)

COCKAYNE (And) Schizaea fistulosa slender comb-fern (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island]

WILSON Schizea fistulosa var. australis COMB FERN ... Small tufts or clumps of stiffly erect, wiry, often wavy stalks, about 10-15 cm tall, ... each terminated by a comb-like cluster of brown fertile segments. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,472)

BROWNSEY &SMITH-DODSWORTH [get cit] (1989,Personal Communication)

comb wheat grass¶

n. (See grass)

comb-tooth shark¶

n. [not a NZ specific term; aka seven gilled shark; one ref]

WILSON COMB-TOOTH SHARK: see Seven-Gilled Shark (1981,Fisherman's Bible,226)

comb-weed¶

n.

MARTIN The comb-weeds (Pterocladia) are mainly North Island seaweeds which grow in immense quantities, ... (1961,Flora NZ,26,1929 ed.)

2 n.

WILSON Marginariella boryana SAWTOOTHED COMBWEED ... Native to: Southern New Zealand. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,307)

comber¶

n. a prospector who searches (`combs') a place (esp. old workings) for gold.

HYDE The hills was [sic] stiff with combers ... but none of them had any luck [finding the lost reef] Ibid. 56 There's not much [gold] to be picked up in the hills now.'Oh, the combers make a living, if they can stand the cold.' Ibid. 56-57 It's all bare, you know. Why don't you go up with the combers, young fellow? ...' `Me with one fin in plaster. I'd look nice, sitting over a mountain stream rocking a cradle.' (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,54) [NOTES: [Is this a RH idiosyncracy or mishearing??]]

2 n. a beachcomber na2.

SMITH Biddy had the `comber's' art of panning off a dish. (1946,Poetical Works,200)

combfish¶

n.

DOAK Combfish Coris picta A very beautiful new discovery in 1969 was the combfish, a cleaner labrid of the same genus as Sandager's parrotfish. (1972,Fishes,90)

AYLING COMBFISH Coris picta [also act as cleaners] (1982,Collins Guide,262,1984 ed.)

PAUL Combfish Coris picta (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,109)

combination¶

n.

I. Adamson Type of stock truck crate which has 2 floors and divisions for sheep, but which fold up for cattle. (Sep 8, 1971,Personal Communication) [NOTES: I. Adamson, of Adamson's Transport Oamaru, Dunedin Mater Hospital (Griffiths Collection)]

combination crate¶

1 n. (Rural) a fenced enclosure on a truck or trailer tray to transport both sheep and cattle. (See double-decker; sheep crate; triple-decker; unit)

SALISBURY Combination crates appeared and gone were the days when drivers had to crawl on hands and knees to either load or unload their vehicles. Later still we saw the implementation of triple decker crates which meant between seven hundred and eight hundred lambs could be carted on one unit, or forty-odd cattle beasts. (1994,I Was So Lucky,212)

combing/combing wool¶

1 n. (Rural) a strong class of fleece wool [used in yarn-making].

MACDONALD Combing wool: the longer Merino sort, and the long-wools or cross-breds. (1920,Australian & NZ Sheep Farming,142)

Combing wool must be sound and of fair length. It is primarily used in the manufacture of woollen yarns. (Jul 1892,NZ Farmer,291)

BISLEY .. we recommend that the separation of the fleece portion of the clip, should be restricted to two main divisions - combing and clothing. (1897,Practical Treatise on Wool and Sheep Breeding,41)

CHANDLER On the open end of the main floor were the slatted inclined tables for throwing out the fleeces upon, so that the wool classer could class the fleece, sort it and then roll it up and pitch it into a convenient hole according to its class - combing or clothing in those days. (1996,Land of the Mountain and the Flood,37)

come a greaser¶

phr. take a fall (lit. or fig.) cf. come a gutser

LELAND come a greaser: (A) HAVE BAD LUCK (of any kind) (B) To FALL OFF as from a bike, skis, etc. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,27)

come a gutser¶

phr. have a heavy fall; come a cropper, make a mistake; fail. (Air Force slang to crash) [[1918 Chron NZEF 1919 War Slang 1925 F and G. to 1957 Godboy, 1960 Crump GKM.; AC 191; so P `both low'.] cf. greaser. Also spelt gutzer.]

"People told me to my face I was a bloody idiot, that I would come a gutser." (Jan 31, 2003,Dominion Post,C4)

SYDER & HODGETTS To crash heavily either physically, or, in one's expectations. .in 4;As he ran tripped over a root, and come a gutser on the stones - he was half-stunned when he got up.'The shop, stock andbooks were all in order, but there was no business, no customers; he said he came a gutser on that deal.' (1962,Australian & NZ English [TS],198,1974 ed.)

FRASER & GIBBONS GUTZER, TO COME A: To crash' or fall badly. (Originally an Air Force term with reference to an aeroplane.) Also used generally. To get into serious trouble, e.g.,He's before a court martial and looks like coming a gutzer'. `Gutzer' is pre-war slang, and an old term among Scottish boys for falling flat on the water in diving, instead of making a clean header. (1925,Soldier and Sailor Words,113)

PARTRIDGE He was a quean to look at, yet he produced; but when I tried to put the nips in for a franc he said he had been stung before, so you see I came a gutser. (1935,Slang Today,287) [NOTES: 1935 A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287]

You'll come gutzer' every time / While you're on thefodder' wage. (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,28)

WILSON `... She's only practising on Mundy. It makes me laugh to see them together. He's heading for a gutzer and maybe she is too.' (1956,Sweet White Wine,74)

SLATTER Tried to cut me out with me sheila. ... Put the kybosh on that smartly. You'll come a gutzer soon I sez. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,91)

Not for the first time, everyone associated with a taboo object came a gutser, including the film crew, who had the quickness of mind to film their own misfortune on a sinking boat. (Dec 9, 1973,Sunday Times (NZ),49/3)

VIRTUE She ran so fast Parnell was certain that her leg would come off and that Sister would have a gutzer. (1991,NZ Alpine Plants,30)

Of course, a politician can call an early election and come a gutser - national's Robert Muldoon did so in 1984 - but he still shouldn't have the power to even try. (Feb 6, 2011,Sunday Star Times,1)

He also points to the place of optimism in economic development. Optimistic entrepreneurs who come a gutser pick themselves up and try again, as do cheerful scientists whose experiments have failed. (Feb 20, 2011,Sunday Star Times: Escape,3)

There was the Meads family home divided between Colin and his brother.. Stan. Colin added to his Came a gutser. (Feb 17, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

"I reckon you've come a gutser, Digger,"remarked one. (Apr 10, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/41 : 108)

Believe ye.. That the tenderfoot andZambuck, Working madly in the trenches,Comes a "gutzer" in those trenches, Andis taught to take a rumble. (Jun 21, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/46 : 221)

In the colloquial parlance of the"Digger," they came a gentle "gutzer". (Jul 19, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/48 : 274)

come a thud¶

phr. to make a bad mistake [1960 16C F B5 Wellington Girls C. 16 THUD, COME A THUD]

SARGESON thud: come a thud, fallen in, made a mistake. (1964,Collected Poems,304)

SARGESON I'd nearly come a thud over Maggie. (1946,That Summer,94)

Punters came a thud over Royal Mac in the Stewards' Stakes, in which he was backed down to well under evens. (Oct 8, 1921,NZ Truth,7)

Supporters of Jamieson's stable came a thud over the hot Springs Handicap last Saturday. (Mar 6, 1930,NZ Truth,13)

come at¶

v. in NZ use recorded usu. in neg. connot to attempt to `try (something) on'; to refuse to consider (a suggestion, etc). str., esp. don't come at that, not to accept,

FULLARTON ... don't come at that [sc. cheating] you Wog... bastard. (1944,Troop Target,95) [NOTES: [check cit]]

DAVIN We ordered you a chaser ... Barry won't come at it. Says he's not going to start the Mission with a skinful of piss. (1949,Roads from Home,44)

CRUMP Who'd get up to that sort of thing?' Jim looked sideways at me.Don't come at it too often,' he said. (1960,Good Keen Man, A,26)

Mr Hanan: [Minister of Justice] You could do that but not many members would. Mr May [M.P.]: Don't come at that. I don't want to get down to the level of the Minister. I would have to get under the carpet. (Sep 19, 1963,Dominion,1)

SYDER & HODGETTS Always used negatively. (To refuse) to consider a proposition. .in 4;`I like that bay horse of his. I made him a pretty good offer for it once, but he wouldn't come at it. He won't part with that one.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],199)

v.

MASTERS We got lots of pigs, but try as I did I couldn't get Jim to go in with the holding dogs and stick one, not even a sucker. He reckoned a man needed experience before coming at that sort of thing, though how he reckoned to get it by standing away back and just watching, had me acked. (1960,Back-Country Tales,85)

come at ... NZ & Austral. sl. take on or try (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,143) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 221]]

come away¶

1 v. (Rural) [crops or stock] to grow well or flourish in response to top-dressing, food or warmth.

TAIT When the turnips were finished and the sheep taken off, the grass came away well.' (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,82)

The grass is early to come away in the spring, and this, again, coupled with the high palatability of the leafy foliage, makes it a highly desirable constituent of any pasture ... (Oct 20, 1926,NZ Journal of Agriculture,248)

STAPLES Cooks and Shepherds, Come Away. [title] (1964,Cooks and Shepherds Come Away)

come down¶

v. (Rural) [South Island rivers] to flood.

ACLAND .. was grazing a mob of sheep there when the Bowyer came down in flood and drowned most of them. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,327)

BUTLER The river had come down the evening on which we had crossed it, and so he had been unable to get the beef or himself home again. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,83)

LOUGHNAN come down: a river is said to come down when it floods. Though locals rarely even notice the apparent phenomenon, visitors to Canterbury and Otago are often surprised to see that the rivers fed by the Southern Alps have come down in pleasantly warm weather; this is due to thawing rains on the Main Divide. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,20)

v. of a river, to fresh, to flood.

The river had come down on the evening we had crossed it, so he had been unable to get the beef and [?or] himself home again. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,ch vii 77) [NOTES: [vii 83 check 1st edn cit. ch page]]

The flood came down with a rush ... but it backed up terrific. (1903,NZ Illustrated Magazine,8/367)

Come down: To flood (of a river). (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

... his brother was grazing a mob of sheep there when the Bowyer Stream came down in flood and drowned most of them. (1975,Early Canterbury Runs) [NOTES: (4th ed.)]

ACLAND ... his brother was grazing a mob of sheep there when the Bowyer Stream came down in flood and drowned most of them. (1975,Early Canterbury Runs,ch xi 325,(4th ed.) ed.)

come good¶

v. to recover from an illness

SYDER & HODGETTS To recover from an illness. .in 4;`I'm a lot better than I was. Oh, I'll come good, it's just a matter of time.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],202) [NOTES: (1962-63)1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust and NZ English [TS] 202]

2 v.

SYDER & HODGETTS To produce the amount of money due, rather against expectations. .in 4;`Oh' yes. He paid me what he owed. He came good.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],204) [NOTES: (1962-63)1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust and NZ English [TS] 204]

3 v.

SYDER & HODGETTS To establish good character for oneself after a poor standard of conduct previously. .in 4;`When he was a young fellow, Alfred was a regular no-hoper, one of the worst larrikings about the place. Now he's settled down, got a nice wife and a good job - he's come good.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],205) [NOTES: (1962-63)1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust and NZ English [TS] 205]

come ... 21. come good. Austral. & N.Z. inf. to recover after a setback, to succeed. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,221) [NOTES: [1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 94 for sense 21]]

come honing¶

phr. to come speeding, on the form (or as a nonce var.) of come haring, hooling, hooping, huring.

[X] came honing around the scrum (May 27, 1950,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Winston McCarthy (1st Rugby Test 2YA)]

come in¶

v. to come or be brought in to production, (cf be brought in).

It does not do to make a road over a drained peat bog ... This country will not come in for 10 years yet. It has been draining ten years now ... (Aug 5, 1885,Chudleigh Diary,334,1950 ed.)

v. (Rural) [dairy cows] to produce calf and milk.

The breed winters exceptionally well on lucerne hay alone, and when given a fair ration of this feed the cows invariably "come in" in the spring in first-class condition. [to be in] (Oct 20, 1926,NZ Journal of Agriculture,237)

2 v. an occas. var. of till the cows come home, expressing a length of time which will never be fulfilled [?come in = come in to bail].

2 v. to come in to milk; to calve

This depends very much on the season of the year the cows "come in." (May 7, 1892,Auckland Weekly News,34)

[OED2] But sows farrowing in May, and their litters too, must be fed until the cows come in. (May 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,485/1)

3 v. to have one's monthly period (female)

She's come in the books, stupid,' says the queen.He doesn't understand' (Sep 19, 1973,Salient,11)

come in on the grouter¶

phr.

SYDER & HODGETTS To reap an advantage in the project, through circumstances beyond one's control. .in 4;`When McLeod came into all the inheritance, he sold out his share of this land here to Brian, seeing they was partners and good mates, for half what they gave for it. Brain came in on the grouter. All the improvements they done he got for nothing.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],206)

come in the lift¶

phr. to come quickly, immediately [1928 Auckland (R. Mason) ca1943 Wellington (R. Mason) e.g.How long will you be?'I'm coming in the lift'.]

come K.O. over¶

phr.

(Letter from Westrupp (Gisborne)) I assure you I have studiously tried to avoid any unpleasant feeling springing up in his mind that I was trying to come K.O. over him. (1870,McLean Papers,X/140)

come off¶

v. stop, cease; `cut it out'.

DEVANNY Come off! Come off! Come off the high brow. (1926,Lenore Divine,107)

SMYTH Oh, come off, Thomson. (1929,Girl from Mason Creek, The,64)

v.

Come off At the end of the day musterers come off (the hill). They do not say they descend' or evencome down'. ([c1890-1910].) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

v. (Rural) to finish and retire from one day's mustering in a muster of two or more days' duration.

LOUGHNAN come off: at the end of the first day of a double header, the musterers come off. At any other time they muster off. [come off the hill] (1981,Loughnan Glossary,20)

2 v. a var. of come off (it), expressing disbelief or mild exasperation with an exaggerated claim, etc.

speaker being interviewed Come off the grass! [expressing disbelief] (Jul 11, 1987,Radio NZ / National Radio)

come out¶

v. emigrate to New Zealand [Jim writes: DNZE tags this as obs., but it remains current in this sense and with reference to an extended visit esp. from Britain or the US, e.g. "When did you come out?". "She's coming out this November". "Come over" is used in the same sense, but this is in NSOD. I have heard both expressions several times within the last year.]

ANDERSON Suspicious before she came out? (1995,House Guest, The,229)

BUTLER I had two cadets with me, and must explain that a cadet means a young fellow who has lately come out, and who wants to see a little of up-country life. He is neither paid, nor pays. He receives his food and lodging gratis, but works (or is supposed to work) in order to learn. (Jun 1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,vi/74)

(Acland Gloss.) [sc. from Britain, emigrate] (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,vi/74)

come over¶

v. to admit an offence:

PARTRIDGE Come over. 3. In C. 20 New Zealand c., to admit an offence: cf come clean, q.v. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,17)

PARTRIDGE come over ... To admit an offence, to plead guilty to a charge: New Zealand: 1932, Nelson Baylis (private letter); extant. (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,142,1961 ed.)

come the raw prawn (with)¶

phr. try to deceive (someone), esp. by `acting innocent' (at p. 244 Wilkes 1944 Services) [ca1970 W. Martin (Seamen's Union) [ed'd first hearing] Don't come the raw prawn with me.]

SHADBOLT Break it down, Pop,' said the farmer.Don't you come the raw prawn with me.' (1965,Among the Cinders,202)

LELAND raw prawn with, don't come the DON'T TRY TO FEED ME THAT LINE. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,34)

NEWBOLD The lads . . .started discussing plans . . . if the / [prison] administration tried to come the raw prawn over Christmas parcels. (1982,Big Huey, The,81)

come to light¶

v. to produce (money, racing form, etc.) (absolute use, cf. come to light with).

We in New Zealand always hoped against hope, that he would come to light if only for a decent race, and show them what he could do. Now, this horse's failure alone has undoubtedly done much harm to the sale of our best horses in England, (Mar 11, 1911,NZ Truth,298/2/4)

... we hit him up for a loan for weeks afterwards and he always came to light too. (Sep 5, 1917,NZEF Chronicles,28)

come to light with¶

v. to produce, come up with

Now, to become a member of the League the sum of 2s 6d has to be planked down, and as quite a number of ardent Chow-haters have come to light' with theirhalf-dollars,' it would be interesting to know from Mr. Cameron himself where the money goes. (Aug 15, 1908,NZ Truth,165/4/6)

Bonser little nurse goes past; comes to light with lollies an' tips a cove a smile. (1917,Tiki Talk,35)

ANTHONY I had to borrow [pounds]20 ... before I could come to light with the engagement ring. (1936,Follow the Call,(?ed. ch vii) 83)

MARSH You come to light with them two books. (1949,Died in the Wool,156)

MASTERS ... I came to light with a Spanish kid skin wine bag which I had filled with sherry before leaving home and secretly planted in my swag. (1960,Back-Country Tales,42)

come ... 21. come good. Austral. & N.Z. inf. to recover after a setback, to succeed. ... 23. come to light with. Austral. & N.Z. inf. to find or produce. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,221) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 144 for sense 23 below; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 94 for sense 21]]

come to light with NZ & Austral. colloq. produce, come up with (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,144)

McGILL come to light with to supply (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,30)

come up¶

v. used in greeting How are you coming up? (phs imitation Ma. Eng.).

OWEN Hullo Wiremu. How are you coming up, as usual, eh? (1909,Philip Loveluck,119)

come up the straight¶

v. be within sight of an end or goal

SYDER & HODGETTS To reach a position near the goal of the project. .in 4;`There isn't much to do before they'll be finished - they put the roof on yesterday. There's still the spouting to go on, and one or two odd jobs, but they're coming up the straight.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],212)

come-to-Jesus¶

adj. very best

SARGESON He'd put on a stiff collar and a come-to-Jesus tie (1936,Conversations with My Uncle,24)

comeback¶

adj. [attrib; relating to comeback (sheep), eg comeback wool]

Prices for comeback wools are rather higher. (Jul 31, 1920,Grey River Argus,6)

The highest price paid at this season's wool sales in New Zealand for strong combing Merino or 'comeback' wool was secured by an Otago grower. [comeback] (May 1932,NZ Farmer,329)

n. spec. a soldier returned from service overseas during WW1.

The Returned Heroes' [title] We are a crowd of come-backs!/ We've fought and swung the lead!/But now we're in New Zealand,/ We might as well be dead!/ And one night in the Town Hall/ I heard the Stokers say:/Hoch! Hoch! mein Gott,/ What a very wild lot/ Are the Anzacs of today!' [fn] It might be mentioned that the Stokers' are the ones whoKeep the Home Fires Burning'. (May 25, 1918,Quick March,9)

1 n. (Rural) a quarterback sheep [bred when a pure Merino is put to a cross ewe.]

The highest price paid at this season's wool sales in New Zealand for strong combing Merino or 'comeback' wool was secured by an Otago grower. [comeback] (May 1932,NZ Farmer,329)

WALLACE When a pure Merino ram is put to a cross ewe, the product is termed a 'come-back' or 'quarter-back.' (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,360)

It has been found a much superior cross to that of the Merino ram on the long-woolled ewe (the 'come-back' as it is called) .. both for wool and mutton, and coming so earlier to maturity. (Feb 1906,Farmers' Union Advocate,24)

Comebacks and half-breds brought excellent prices ... (1919,Wool in NZ,39)

WALLACE When a pure Merino ram is put to a cross ewe the produce is termed a come -back' orquarter-back'.] A sheep three-quarters merino and one-quarter crossbred; its wool. (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,360)

Comeback: A sheep three quarters merino and one quarter longwool. The word is often used; but in New Zealand I think these sheep are oftener called quarterbreds or quarter-backs. ([c1890-1910].) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

comfort stop¶

n. originally a halt by a tour bus or car for toilet purposes; by extension any pause or break for that purpose.

.. and still have time for a comfort stop before the press conference. (Jan 1, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),00) [NOTES: check page]

[Hdg] Comfort stop proves costly. An Australian holidaymaker who urinated in front of passengers on a Qantas flight from Melbourne to Auckland, was fined $1000 and ordered to pay $130 in costs in Otahuhu Court after he admitted offensive behaviour. (Dec 26, 1999,Sunday Star Times,A4)

comic¶

n. the Public Service Official Circular [1984 Nov 13 G.S. Orr, Gregory Campbell (Labour) I cannot recall the term 1954-1960 HWO.]

coming-in¶

1 n. (Rural) the germination of pasture seeds.

LEVY The natural coming-in of white clover is in itself an indicator that fertility and soil requirements are correct for the species. (1970,Grasslands of NZ,152)

comish¶

n. commission

Glorious Auckland! Happy Queen Street! Land of Baksheesh and comish,/ (Jun 15, 1892,Auckland Star) [NOTES: 1892 June 15 Auckland Star in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 82]

Commercial Broadcasting¶

n.

EDWARDS After listening to another sermon last night by the controller of commercial broadcasting, I desire.. to lodge a protest. (1971,Scrim,125) [NOTES: Quote from 1941]

EDWARDS "I have never been enamoured of Commercial Broadcasting". (1971,Scrim,168) [NOTES: Quote from Fraser 1943]

I suppose commercial broadcasting cannot, at this late stage, be curtailed. (Jan 26, 1966,Weekly News,62)

Commercial Broadcasting Service¶

n.

EDWARDS There are many thousands of people who believe Mr Scrimgeour to be essential to the Commercial Broadcasting Service. (1971,Scrim,153) [NOTES: Quoted from Truth editorial 3 Mar. 1943]

EDWARDS Scrim's title was easily settled; he was Controller of the National Commercial broadcasting Service. (1971,Scrim,92)

With the Commercial Broadcasting Service approaching its third anniversary there is perhaps a tendency to remember only the good programmes. (Jun 28, 1940,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

[Advt] Another achievement by the Commercial Broadcasting Service. (Apr 1937,NZ Railways Magazine,33)

commercial network¶

n.

EDWARDS Three months later, 1ZB was operating as the first station of the state commercial network. (1971,Scrim,92)

DOWNES & HARCOURT On the commercial network radio was unashamedly designed to attract the masses. (1976,Voices in the Air,146)

Michael Joseph Savage's 1935 Labour government announced their commitment to a government-controlled commercial network as the way of the future for New Zealand radio. (2008,NZ Memories,73/42)

commercial radio¶

n.

No one.. considered seriously what an effect commercial radio has had on our thinking in the past 10 years. (May 14, 1947,NZ Observer,13)

Commercial Radio... One of the most obvious defects of the Commercial Programmes at the present time is the scarcity of music between the hours of 7 and 10 p.m. (Feb 17, 1938,NZ Observer,21)

DOWNES & HARCOURT An interesting entry.. shows a further run of 'Fred and Maggie Everybody', probably the most popular of all the serials in the first five years or so of New Zealand's commercial radio. (1976,Voices in the Air,146)

DOWNES & HARCOURT In 1940 commercial radio stations had a great success with a nation-wide campaign to sell within the country over a million cases of apples. (1976,Voices in the Air,129)

The commercial radio service showsaGBP10,597 profit for the first time. (Aug 25, 1939,Taranaki Herald,8)

commercial rates¶

n. town tax applied to commercial properties

Income from commercial rates will decline slightly over the same period. (May 31, 2001,City Voice,2)

commercial station¶

n.

DOWNES & HARCOURT Commercial stations opened after 1ZB in sequence - 2ZB in Wellington in April 1937. (1976,Voices in the Air,107)

SMITH The object of the commercial stations is to provide entertainment. (1947,From N to Z,144)

The interest of the Commercial station in War efforts has led to a rather unusual position in Christchurch. (Jul 26, 1940,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48)

One step.. would be to extend the broadcasting hours of commercial stations to eleven o'clock. (1953,NZ Parliamentary Debates,300/1647)

The BBC.. edition of Doctor in the House (now going the rounds of National and Commercial Stations) should bring back an outside case of stitches in the humerus. (May 13, 1955,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

Bulletins are now being transmitted by the commercial stations and by televison. (1962,Landfall,61/384)

McLINTOCK Within 18 months of the 1936 Act, 12 non-commercial stations and four commercial stations were being operated by the Government. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,I/250)

Seeking the 2..30 news, I pressed the button of a commercial station. (Jun 21, 1966,Weekly News,62)

[Advt] Wellington's new commercial station, 2ZB, offers entertainment never before equalled in New Zealand's radio history. (May 1937,NZ Railways Magazine,20)

commercial traveller¶

n. as a travelling man (cf the connected word-play drummer for a swagger (he carries a drum swag) and for a commercial traveller (he drums up business).

Commercial or c. traveller.- Slang for swagger. Probably so called because they travelled. Cf. drummer, another nickname they were given. ([c1890-1910].) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

2 n. a ram

commercial traveller: Rams are sometimes called this in humorous allusion to the notion that they satisfy a large number of females. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/23) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

commercial/commercial traveller¶

n. (Rural) a wayward ram that wanders.

LOUGHNAN a ram. Implies one which constantly breaks in with the ewes (as often as not, the neighbour's!) (1981,Loughnan Glossary,20 (ii))

commercial traveller: Rams are sometimes called this in humorous allusion to the notion that they satisfy a large number of females. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,III 23)

commercial traveller: a trespassing ram. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

Dry humour runs thick through this collection; for example, commercial traveller - a ram that jumps the fence into a neighbouring paddock ... (Nov 22, 2002,Dominion,C6)

1 n. (Rural) a swagger.

LOUGHNAN commercial traveller: (i) a swagger, a vagrant (sometimes seeking work) (1981,Loughnan Glossary,20)

Commercial or c traveller. - Slang for swagger. Probably so called because they travelled. (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

ACLAND One one occasion Mr Reed was taking a mob of sheep out to one of the paddocks when he met two 'commercials.' (1946,Early Canterbury Runs,122)

commission of inquiry¶

n. a body appointed by the Governor-General to inquire into specific matters of public importance. (See Commissions of Inquiry Act 1908) [Jim Cameron writes: The British equivalent is Tribunal of Inquiry. In both countries a Royal Commission may also be appointed for the same purposes. It sounds more august but at least in NZ its powers are the same.]

Commissioner¶

n. a goldfields magistrate

PYKE Commissioner was the title then given to the Gold-field's magistrates. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,1/v/20,(1889,1974) ed.)

PYKE Here it seems desirable to place on record the names of the chief officers who were first appointed to the charge of the Otago Goldfields. In doing so I must premise that for some unexplained reason the title of commissioner' was at first assigned to these gentlemen in place of that ofwarden' as directed by the Goldfields Act. The proper and correct designation was however afterwards bestowed. (1887,History of the Early Gold Discoveries in Otago,62,1962 ed.)

MAY JOE OR JOE'D: to be called a Joe' was to be ridiculed, laughed at, or cried down.Joe! Joe!' was the old Australian warning-cry signalling the approach of `the traps' (the police) or of commissioners checking for gold-digging licences. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,527,1962 ed.)

VEITCH It was thought best to appoint Jackson Keddell, who was already in charge of the Gold Escort, as Commissioner, ... (1976,Clyde on the Dunstan,13)

Commissioner for Children¶

n.

Children's agencies in this country, such as the Commissioner for Children, Barnados and the Plunket Society, have stepped up their calls for bans on spanking and the repeal of s59. Children's Commissioner Roger McClay says that he was smacked with a belt, or a switch from a nectarine tree, as a child. (May 5, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

Commissioner for Extinguishing Native Titles¶

n.

[Mantell] became deputy postmaster in Wellington, learnt Maori and in 1848 became Commissioner for Extinguishing Native (land) Titles in the South Island, according to the Dictionary of New Zealand Biography. (Jul 19, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

commo¶

n. a member, or imagined member of the Communist Party, or one thought to support Communist principles; a redfed, in NZ preferred to commie (US) or prob. com.

I know all about it now. Going behind my back, you and that Commo you live with. (1960,Maori Girl,245)

PEARSON If they would just look at the ringleaders of this boycott they would soon find out they were commos. (1963,Coal Flat,355)

McGILL Commo a Communist. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,30)

n. common sense

common¶
