adj. as a distinguishing epithet occas. used with the names of the following plants (mainly Andersen's list): alpine ligusticum, adder's tongue, alpine donatia, anistome, astelia, avens, bladder-wort; fern, boss fern; bracken, burr, carpha, celmisia, climbing polypody; rata, climbing; club-rush, convolvulus, coprosma, cotton-plant, crantzia, cudweed, davallia, dendrobe, dichondra, donatia, drapetes; broom, dwarf; bracken, English; fern, poa; fireweed, forstera; fern, hard; orchid, hooded; ivy-tree, karamu, koromiko, kowhai, libertia; fern, maidenhair; mistletoe; gentian, mountain; groundsel, mountain; tree-daisy, mountain; heath; buttercup, NZ; epacris, NZ; gentian, NZ; groundsel, NZ; lobelia, NZ; mistletoe, NZ; plantain, NZ; pondweed, NZ; violet, NZ; grass, oat-grass; oreobolus, phyllachne, pimelea, polypody, pondweed, pratia, raoulia, rush, scleranth, spider-orchid, solanum, spleenwort, thelymitra, tussock-grass, tutu, twig-rush, vegetable sheep, veronica, water-milfoil; koromiko, whipcord.

2 adj. as a distinguishing epithet in names of fish, see: bully; crab, swimming; crayfish; dogfish, spiny; gurnard, mackerel, mullet, river galaxias, roughy, scarpee, sole, stargazer, toado, warehou.

common crayfish¶

n. the marine species Jasus edwardsii

DOOGUE & MORELAND COMMON CRAYFISH ...Other names: Jasus lalandei; spiny crayfish; koura, koura-papatea (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,298)

common diving petrel¶

n.

Common Diving Petrel Pelecanoides urinatrix (GMELIN, 1789) ... New Zealand Diving Petrel P.u. urinatrix ... OTHER NAMES: Kuaka Chatham Island diving petrel, Kerguelen diving petrel. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,106)

common dolphin¶

n.

The most frequently seen dolphin is the cream and grey common dolphin... (Dec 27, 2003,Dominion Post,E13)

The common dolphin (Delphinus delphis) has a well-marked beak and a high falcate dorsal fin. (1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,5/141) [NOTES: (Oliver)]

DOOGUE & MORELAND COMMON DOLPHIN ... Other names: Delphinus delphis. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,303)

common fern¶

n. Pteridium esculentum

(And) Pteridium esculentum common fern (1846,Calendar of St John's College)

(And) Pteridium esculentum common fern (1848,NZ Journal)

HURSTHOUSE (And) Pteridium esculentum common fern (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles)) [NOTES: 1857 Hursthouse NZ, or Zealandia]

CHEESEMAN (And) Pteridium esculentum common fern (1906,NZ Flora)

POTTS Pteris aquilina, var. esculenta, for thus the botanist labels the New Zealand variety of the common fern or bracken. (1882,Out in the Open,80)

common flounder¶

n. Rhombosolea plebeia

Rhombosolea plebeia Richardson. The common flounder, or sand-flounder, described and figured by Waite ... (1913,TrNZI,45/232) [NOTES: (Thomson, Otago)]

common gecko¶

n. (Environment) an attractively marked gecko commonly found in the north of the South Island and in the east of the North Island from Wellington to Coromandel. [Hoplodactylus maculatus, aka Matua gecko] (See brown gecko)

'So for the extensive survey, we're using a basic method of counting how many lizards are captured in a 24-hour period. It's a quick index of population size for species such as common skinks and McCann's skinks and common (brown) geckos. Unfortunately we're unlikely to detect less abundant species such as green skinks, cryptic skinks or jewelled geckos.' (Mar 2009,Open Space,75/11)

Two variants of the common gecko found in the same valley in central Otago may be separate species. These are popularly known as the 'Southern mini' and the 'Otago' and look quite different from each other. (May 2002,Forest & Bird,No. 304/17)

[Caption] More variants of the common gecko which may prove to be among 10 new species. Some have quite restricted distributions as indicated by their given names: Hoplodactylus species, 'Mt Arthur'.. and 'Marlborough'. (May 2002,Forest & Bird,No. 304/18)

Ornate skink (Gradual Decline), North Cape Pacific gecko (Gradual Decline), Matapia gecko (Gradual Decline), North Cape green gecko (Sparse), Cyclodina levidensa (regionally significant), shore skink, and common gecko. (1997,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.conservation.govt.nz/upload/documents/conservation/land-and-freshwater/land/te-paki-ecological-district/te-paki-shrublands-n02-003.pdf]

common green gecko¶

n. the Auckland, or Elegant, gecko; bright green sometimes with creamy patches, common in the central and northern North Island. [Auckland green gecko Naultinus elegans elegens aka Elegant gecko Naultinus elegans cf green gecko] (See Auckland green gecko)

These newborn common green geckos (Naultinus elegans) hatched and were incubated inside their mother, an adaptation to living in a relatively cool climate - most geckos in other parts of the world lay eggs. (2007,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.teara.govt.nz/TheBush/FishFrogsAndReptiles/Lizards/1/ENZ-Resources/Standard/4/en#breadcrumbtop]

The Auckland Green Gecko is found in the northern half of the North Island, north of Taranaki. The tail is very versatile, being used as a "fifth limb" to climb and for balance. It hunts by night for insects but also likes to sunbathe. The Auckland Green Gecko lives in scrub and forest areas, especially Kanuka and Manuka, also known as tea tree. (2009,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.nhc.net.nz/index/lizards-new-zealand/auckland-green-gecko/auckland-green-gecko.htm No date given, 2009 is estimate]

common mackerel¶

n.

SORENSON MACKEREL (two species) (a) Scientific name: (i) Scomber australasicus (ii) Trachurus declivis. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Blue Mackerel (ii) Jack mackerel. (c) Other common names: (i) Common Mackerel, Frigate mackerel, English mackerel (ii) Horse Mackerel. (d) Principal localities where taken: (both) Gisborne, Nelson, Picton ... (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,34)

[species name] blue mackerel .. [scientific name] Scomber australasicus .. [other name(s)] English mackerel, common mackerel, frigate mackerel, pacific mackerel, southern mackerel (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

MORELAND COMMON MACKEREL [Scomber australasicus] ... The names southern mackerel, English mackerel, and sometimes frigate mackerel are in use. (The latter properly belongs to another species.) (1967,Marine Fishes,48)

DOOGUE & MORELAND COMMON MACKEREL ... Other names: Scomber japonicus; southern mackerel, English mackerel, frigate mackerel; tawatawa (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,267)

WILSON MACKEREL ... The common Mackerel is also known as the English Mackerel, Frigate Mackerel or Southern Mackerel. The Horse Mackerel is also known as the Yellowtail. The Koheru is also sometimes known as Yellowtail and is often misnamed Horse Mackerel and Scad. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,162)

[species name] blue mackerel .. [scientific name] Scomber australasicus .. [other name(s)] English mackerel, common mackerel, frigate mackerel, pacific mackerel, southern mackerel (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

common mollymawk¶

n.

The common mollymawk should not be confused with its cousins, the white- capped mollymawk, the grey-headed mollymawk, the yellow-nosed mollymawk, and the grey-backed mollymawk. (Aug 3, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17)

common pipit¶

n.

The smaller [hawk] nests invariably in the immediate neighbourhood of the bush, or close to the Plains, ... and during this period it may be seen almost daily pursuing the common Pipit (Anthus novae-zealandiae) on the wing ... (Jan 1884,NZ Journal of Science,84)

common tern¶

n. (Environment)

STERNA ANTARCTICA, Forst. Common Tern. (1870,TrNZI,2/77) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

HUTTON 114. STERNA ANTARCTICA. Forst. Common Tern. Hydrochelidon albostriata. GRAY. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,42)

STERNA - Sea swallows (Tara). Five species in New Zealand ...; but Sterna antarctica (Common Tern) I found as far as forty miles inland ... (1869,TrNZI,18/99) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

STERNA ANTARCTICA, Forst. - Common Tern. (1886,TrNZI,18/218) [NOTES: (Hamilton)]

No.1 is the common tern, or sea swallow, often called the plough bird, from its habit of following the plough in spring time, for grubs, worms, &c. (Nov 3, 1892,Otago Witness,24)

common warehou¶

n. (as blue warehou)

AYLING COMMON WAREHOU Seriolella brama (1982,Collins Guide,300,1984 ed.)

[species name] common warehou .. [scientific name] Seriolella brama .. [other name(s)] warehou, blue warehou, [occas. BREAM] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Blue warehou Seriolella brama ... Often just warehou or common warehou. Also occurs off southern Australia. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,136)

commonage¶

n. land held in common; public land of a township?

EVANS The Waikaka [heading] When the dredging commenced in 1897 more and more people began to settle round Waikaka village and the land on the hill on the east side of the township became a common land where anyone grazed cows and hacks. Finally a large area ... was declared a commonage ... Between 1900 and 1914 this Commonage was cut up into farmlets varying from thirty to fifty acres. (1962,Waikaka Saga,175)

comms centre¶

n. a police communications centre [Police Commissioner speaking]

People who work in comms centres do their best to give the public the best possible service, sometimes under extreme pressure. (Nov 10, 2004,Dominion Post,B4)

community board¶

n.

Not only was there duplication between the community board and the council, but also between the community board and the Mainstreet committee. (Aug 19, 2003,Bush Telegraph,13)

community card¶

n. = community services card

If you're poor, you've got a community card and you get it cheap, but if you're middle class that's a cost increase for you. (Aug 7, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

community care¶

n.

Other non-custodial sentences include periodic detention (PD), which is in NZPOD but not DNZE, and community care (recently renamed community programmes) which is in neither. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2)

community constable¶

n.

[Hdg] J'ville odd one out for community cop... Johnsonville is not getting a community constable to replace Ray Buist, who retired this month. (Oct 27, 1999,Norwester,1)

There aren't many hills in Levin, but community constable Roy Sanson reckons they can hold a trolley derby anyway. (Oct 25, 2000,Capital Times,12)

Community Corrective Service¶

n.

Big increases in the numbers of men being referred to these programmes as part of supervisory sentences are stretching Community Corrective Service resources to the limit. (May 20, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

community house¶

n.

Ammundsen, who is also head of Community Services, says community houses were first established in New Zealand about 15 years ago (initially in Auckland). Ibid. 17 Community houses, Ammundsen says, are important focal points, places where people can meet each other or social workers, public health nurses and others with access to useful resources. (May 31, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

community magistrate¶

n. a person (non-lawyer) appointed to hear minor criminal cases in a district court (District Courts Amendment Act 1998).

Originally district courts were intermediate courts created in 1858; they were squeezed out between the Supreme Court (now the High Court) and the magistrates courts and were formally abolished in 1925.) The latest episode of this serial is the creation in 1998 of community magistrates to sit in district courts and exercise minor criminal jurisdiction. They are not defined with any reference to JPs. (Jan 1999,NZWords,1)

Community Probation Service¶

n.

The law has for many years provided four sentences aimed at restorative justice, overseen by the Community Probation Service. (Jul 22, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10)

community services card¶

n. card entitling low-income NZers to medical and social benefits

But wait! as Neil Martin would say - there's more! The biggest post-facto fairy-tale is the one being told about the community services card. (May 12, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

In the meantime, they keep on charging $4 entry $2 with a community services card. They don't hire out togs. (Jun 30, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

community sing¶

n. [Jim writes: Hist? NSOD and Collins have entries for community singing - Collins "esp of hymns" and OED has 2 citations (1922 and 1923); at least one is US. No entry in DNZE or any other dictionary for commmunity sing. A feature of the Depression times was the community sing (eg at lunchtime once a week in the Wellington Town Hall) to raise money for relief of the unemployed. DEH adds that this tradition carried on in Dunedin Town Hall until at least 1954.]

IHIMAERA And on very wet days, after we'd finished our sandwiches, we'd sit round the old stove in the corner and have a community sing. (1982,Into the World of Light,82)

FRAME Each week the manager appeared on the stage to announce competitions and to remind the adults of the community sing that was held at the Majestic each week. (1982,To the Is-Land,109)

Some of you might be reminded of the old community sing days. (Oct 17, 2000,Radio NZ / National Radio,Wayne Mowat)

DOWNES & HARCOURT In fact, regular community sing broadcasts had already begun, on June 5th that year [sc. 1929]. They were to continue, reaching a peak of popularity during the hardest years of the Depression. (1976,Voices in the Air,77)

HALL Supposing voluntary surrender of permitted hours were made, which, with the three-quarters of an hour in hand, would aggregate sufficient time for a broadcast of the community sing, could that be undertaken? the department was asked... These transgressions also had to be expiated by surrenders of equivalent future time before permission to broadcast the community sing was confirmed. (1980,History of Broadcasting in NZ, The,73)

community supervision¶

n.

Community supervision for a youth who attacked a taxi driver and a student was rejected by Judge Patrick Keane in Wellington District Court yesterday. (Nov 20, 1999,Dominion,7)

community wage¶

n.

The largest benefit category is New Zealand Superannuation, the state pension paid to 459,595 people, followed by the 164,902 registered unemployed who are paid what is now called the "community wage". (Oct 1999,North & South,50)

community work¶

n. enforced (by law) service or labour in one's community

..when he sentenced them to complete 150 hours and 100 hours respectively on two charges of assault with intent to injure. (Jan 19, 2005,Dominion Post,A11)

community worker¶

n. formerly a Periodic Detention worker

Most of us know them as PD (periodic detention) workers. Their title, however, is now "Community Workers" and they have been an essential tool in restoring the inlet to its former beauty and natural habitat... (Oct 27, 2004,Northern Courier,1)

Company¶

n. prob. an earlier NZ Land Company rather than the (Wakefeldian) New Zealand Company

SHEPHERD Having now seen all the land ... I do not think it necessary to make any remarks in addition to those I have already made as the advantages to be derived from this Island to the Company is of so very little importance ... (Mar 26, 1826,Journal) [NOTES: 1826 Mar 22 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 362 [Shepherd was `a member of the first NZ Company Company's Expedition under Captain Herd in 1826.' (Howard 355)]]

n. (the Company) in early NZ, the New Zealand Company (See cf. John Company)

BEST [the NZ Company] The 27th had been the day appointed for the holders of land [in Wellington] under the Company to choose their Town Acres and during the previous week the Plan had been exhibited, ... Ibid. 235 The Company are so disgusted at the Perfidy of the British Crown and Government that many members of that disinterested body intend removing ... (Jun 27, 1840,Journal,231,1966 ed.)

New Zealand House,/ Broad-street Buildings, 22 October 1840. ... The gentlemen who have been associated under the name of the New Zealand Company, for the purpose of promoting the settlement of New Zealand, ... It is, therefore, with great satisfaction that the Company perceives in the recent proclamations ... an opening for a satisfactory adjustment ... (1841,GBPP,(No.311) 21) [NOTES: 1840 Oct 22 Joseph Somes to Lord John Russell in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 21]

POLACK The price I paid to the chiefs in some instances per acre, seven years since, was twenty-six times the value now asked by the New Zealand Land Company, in London; superiority in the locality causes the difference. [fn] The Company charge twenty shillings per acre, engaging to return 75 per cent. for passage-money. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/xxxiii and fn)

JAMESON NZ, South Aust and NSW (1841,New Zealand, S. Aust. and NSW,339)

JAMESON The Company should take charge, during his minority, of the landed property, intended for a cadet. (1841,New Zealand, S. Aust. and NSW,339)

WEEKES The Vanguard has brought fifty barrels of flour for the Company. None to be sold excepting as rations to those who work for the Company. Col. Wakefield is rather hard with us. (Jan 1842,Journal) [NOTES: 1842 Jan Weekes Journal in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 59]

... am now employed with John Lye, by the Company, cutting lines for surveyors. (1968,Letters from New Plymouth,27) [NOTES: (1842 Mar 8) 1843 (1968) Letters from New Plymouth 27]

HEAPHY From the circumstance of my having been in the service of the Company by whom the colony was founded, it may be imagined that I am interested in upholding its principles, and am now writing by its dictation. (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),vii)

MILLER [= NZC] It is a well known fact that many of the pretended Capitalists are reduced already to all but starving point. Shiners with them are something like Angels Visits, few and far between. In fact there is little or no money in the Colony except the Company's. On you Sir the (visa : versa) success of the Colony depends. (1958,Early Victorian NZ,122) [NOTES: 1843 Jan 14 The Working Men of Nelson to Captain Wakefield, NZ Company Papers 208/2 in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 122]

CHAPMAN No body of colonists ever had larger claims upon the sympathies of their fellow countrymen at home than the first settlers under the Company ... (1843,NZ Portfolio,iv)

[the NZ Company] It is impossible to reconcile the missionary system with that of the Company. ... The avowed object of the missionaries has been to prevent colonization, to preserve the nationality of the New Zealanders, ... and to maintain their exclusive property in the whole soil of the islands. Our system ... was ... to encourage the settlement of European colonists, and to turn to acount the peculiar facilities which the aboriginal race of New Zealand seem to possess for intermixture and amalgamation with the European population. (1949,Selected Documents,12) [NOTES: 1845 May 5 Lord Ingestre to Lord Stanley in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 12]

WAKEFIELD [=NZC] A bridle-road has been marked out by the Company ... round the eastern spurs of Mount Egmont. ... (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The)

FITTON [NZC] The Company was finally broken up in 1851, ... (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),17)

company¶

n. in phr. keep (in) or join company, of whaling ships, to sail together in each other's sight

HEBERLEY We asked him [a whaler] where he was going to cruise .... We kept company together till we arrived at Japan. (1828,Autobiography,18)

1836 Journ. Austr W B Rhodes 19 (1836,Journal,19)

J. BISCOE At 8 the Cutter joined Company. (Nov 25, 1831,Journal) [NOTES: 1831 Nov 25 J.Biscoe Journal in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 419]

company lease¶

n. a device facilitating the separate ownership of 2 or more flats or offices on the same piece of land; legal ownership is vested in a company whose members are the occupiers of the individual units, the company giving a licence to occupy over each unit. [Jim Cameron writes: This device originated about 1960 when the first OYO flats were built; it fell out of favour with the advent of cross-leases and unit tiles - see DNZE - but a number still exist.]

Compensation Act¶

n.

People had absolutely to cringe to a Government to get some additional relief under the Compensation Act. (1922,NZ Parliamentary Debates,198/661)

competency¶

n. (R. Mason) A pass in thePROFICIENCY' examination, taken in Standard 6, sufficient to give a free place at a Technical School, but not good enough to gain `proficiency' and a free place at a secondary school. Obsolete since the proficiency examination was abolished in 193?.

competitions¶

n.

[Hdg] Dunedin Competitions Society (Nov 3, 1903,Otago Daily Times,3)

[Hdg] Dunedin Competitions Society.The Competitions brought to a Close. (Nov 4, 1903,Otago Witness,16)

If you have never attended Competitions, you can have no fair beginning or suspicion of an idea of what you are in for. (Feb 10, 1910,Triad, The,XVII(2) : 41)

At the piping and dancing competitions held in Dunedin last week, Oamaru competitors were very successful.Ibid.29 June 4 At a meeting of the Oamaru Competitions Society it was decided to hold a two-days competition on August 19 and 20. (Jun 11, 1932,Oamaru Mail,6)

Competition week in Oamaru was at one time a very important event, bringing large numbers of visitors to the town. Ibid. 7 In 1923 a group of people gathered together and discussed the possibility of forming a Competitions Society in Oamaru... The splendid array of Cups and Trophies presented by well-wishers reflected most creditably on the competition mindness [sic] of the people of North Otago. (May 8, 1987,Oamaru Mail,Extra/ 6)

The stormy weather last night had itseffect on the attendance at theCompetitions in the Town Hall. (Sep 3, 1929,Evening Post,5)

While in England and America competitionswere growing in popularity, in NewZealand they appeared to have reached thebeginning of their decay. (Sep 9, 1929,Evening Post,11)

Six excellent singers sang arias fromopera in the golden jubilee Festival ofthe Hutt Valley Performing ArtsCompetitions Society last night. (May 12, 1993,Evening Post,28)

The Competitions were resumed at the TownHall yesterday in wretched weather. Itrained steadily, remorselessly throughoutthe entire day, much to the disgust ofthe competitors and executive. (Nov 27, 1912,Dominion,8)

An interesting feature this year is thatthe Hawera Competitions are the venue forthe elimination of candidates entered forthe Dame Nellie Melba Scholarship tenableat the Melbourne Conservatorium of Music. (Aug 22, 1939,Taranaki Herald,12)

HARCOURT Other entertainments [sc. in Auckland in1920] included a concert by theWaterside Workers Band, a concert "in aidof Mount Eden School Old Boys' 'MemorialFund'".. and - Competitions.Advertisements informed prospectiveentrants that these had as their'PRINCIPAL OBJECT - to unearth dormanttalent for the various theatricalenterprises throughout Australasia.' (1978,Dramatic Appearance, A,17)

SIMPSON During one week in 1960, twenty-six year-old Donald McIntyre auditioned for thetwo major opera companies in London - theRoyal Opera and Sadlers' Wells. For bothhe sang the aria that had served him wellduring the Auckland Competitions backhome in New Zealand; "Schweig! Schweig!"from Weber's Der Freischutz. (1990,Opera in NZ,121)

Some operatic dancing is good, some isbad, and some is indifferent, as visitorsto the Wellington competitions festivalhave discovered. (Aug 27, 1940,Taranaki Herald,4)

At the concluding session of the Haweracompetitions festival last night thejudges praised the work of thecompetitors generally. (Aug 23, 1940,Taranaki Herald,3)

The [North Shore] competitions cover thewhole range of performing arts frominstrumental to choral and solo singing,ballet, jazz and tap dancing. (Aug 1988,Metro,221)

She can remember seeing Michael Houstonplaying the piano at the Ashburtoncompetitions years ago, and hearing theyoung Kiri Te Kanawa singing in the vocalsection at North Shore. (Aug 1988,Metro,222)

complete¶

v. (Rural) [dog trials] to finish a particular course within an allotted time.

I feel sorry for Don as in both run-offs he was unable to complete.. (Aug 15, 1984,NZ Journal of Agriculture,21)

1 n. (Rural) a finished course in dog trialling [in which a dog performs his sheep work within an allotted time.]

HALL We achieved a complete in the long pull. I put two dogs in that event and got a complete with one and about halfway down with the other, which gave me some points .. I didn't get a complete, but both my heading dogs' runs got points, and I felt rather good doing it, hobbling away on my crutches .. I got five completes in all, and found out a couple of days later that I'd won the local mustering cup for aggregated points. (1987,Shepherd's Year, A,79)

compo¶

n. a compensation payment or allowance under the Workers Compensation Act (now Accident Compensation Commission) for an injury received in the course of employment; the compensation system in general; a compensation payment. [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

[Hdg] Telecom silent on cellphone fault compo. (Dec 9, 2000,Dominion,3)

BAKER (1941,NZ Slang,52) [NOTES: See cit. compo king.]

DAVIN They're afraid they might have to pay out a bit of compo. (1949,Roads from Home,69)

The wharfies ... must also of necessity carry their own insurance against damage and loss - as well as workers' compo. (Oct 1949,Here & Now,34)

CROWTHER Yeah. That's how I lost ma finger - va top of one finger.' ...Did you get any compo?' No.'Why not?' Not the first joint.'Oh, a pity.' (1956,Street Society in Christchurch,17)

CASEY For years he'd been trying to work out how he could go off sick - you could collect a fair wad in the way of compo if you lost a finger or two, you know, ... (1963,As Short a Spring,276)

McCALLUM ... this [injury] will put me out of action at the factory and I can't get compo for playing golf. (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,75)

BOOTH He might be off work for a couple of weeks, but if he's clever he could fiddle compo. out of it (1964,Footsteps in the Sea,61)

TURNER Words in -o are more specifically Australian, though compo, (compensation), metho (a drinker of methylated spirits) and smoko (with the sense morning or afternoon tea' rather thana rest for a smoke' now) are current in New Zealand. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,118)

MASON ... mortgages on houses, tax forms, social security, compo. Ibid. 111 A week ago, a carcase fell on Tane; he was give three week's compo. (1969,Awatea,105,1978 ed.)

ANDERSON Compo is the universal term for payments made to workers injured on the job, and denotes a payment under the Worker's Compensation Act. (1975,Milford Road,92)

Compo rises to keep pace with wages. Substantial increases are to be made in accident compensation payments; ... (Dec 11, 1981,Evening Post,4)

compo ... 2. Austral. & N.Z. inf. compensation, esp. for injury or loss of work. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,228) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 149; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 97]]

Non-unionists have been recipients of much unwelcome publicity, due.. also to the operations of "compo" artists. (Nov 24, 1938,NZ Observer,7)

CRUMP Non-unionists have been recipients of much unwelcome publicity, due.. also to the operations of "compo" artists. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,39) [NOTES: 1970 edition]

Grace ...he'd have to go easy on the spending. The stay in Wellington had eaten into his compo. (2001,Dogside Story,198)

LACEY I haven't seen.. Ma-in-law lookin' so happy since the compo cheque came through. (1976,Loosehead Len's Bumper Thump Book,60)

"Uh - I've got a pinched nerve in me back mate. Compo! Smoko!" (Nov 12, 2000,Sunday Star Times,C3)

[Heading] Injury Cases Increasingly'Rampant' since Compo. (Nov 8, 1975,NZ Herald,1)

Own up: who took the compo for the bad back and played touch on Thursday? (Jun 14, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

2 n. a children's game

SUTTON-SMITH The spontaneous variations of the organized sports include, for Rugby, Compo (Nelson), a game in which several players kick in turns at a goal post receiving points for the type of kicks they succeed with. (1953,Unorganized Games,2/745)

compo king¶

n. one who, through clumsiness or malingering, spends much of his time `on compo'.

PARTRIDGE A social parasite who makes a practice of injuring himself or malingering in order to secure workers' compensation,' Sidney J. Baker, New Zealand Slang, 1941; perhaps, orig., c.; by 1940, at latest, workers' and labour-exchange s. Excomposition'? (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,143,1961 ed.)

ANDERSON In the PWD there was a sprinkling of what were known as `compo kings'. These were men who always seemed to be on compo [either by bad luck, accident prone-ness, or malingering]. (1975,Milford Road,95)

An Auckland dentist who led a campaign against the accident compensation scheme six years ago has surfaced again to take on who he describes as the criminal `Compo Kings'. Dr Lloyd Grenlie left his job at Auckland Hospital in 1979 disturbed by the large amounts of money going to injured criminals. (Jul 20, 1986,NZ Times,5)

BAKER Compo king, a social parasite who makes a practice of injuring himself or malingering in order to secure workers' compensation. (1941,NZ Slang,52)

n.

BAKER We have also ... some underworld slang ... : compo king, a social parasite who makes a practice of injuring himself or malingering in order to secure workers' compensation. (1941,NZ Slang,52)

compo-itis¶

n.

OWEN & PERKINS I think compo-itis was the most striking disease. I imagine that's disappeared with the advent of Accident Compensation. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,197)

composite¶

n. cross-bred from two or more breeds

The introduction of Texel genes to the composite ewes has given the new lambs the vigour to begin suckling as soon as possible. (Oct 16, 2003,BLANK ENTRY,C5)

In recent years composite sheep have started to challenge the lamb market. These cross up to four breeds to increase fertility and production.... "I'm confident that if everything is done properly, composites should beat any purebreds and most crossbreds we can produce from our indigenous sheep." (Oct 9, 2003,Dominion Post,C87)

1 n. (Rural) [sp. use] [stock breeding] a combination of different breeds.

There is a place for crossbreds, he says, but believes farmers will be happier using composite rams because of the difficulties of running multiple breeds on one property. (2002,Wairarapa Times-Age,Farming Supp. 5)

John Booker with a composite Friesian/Poll Dorset/Corriedale lamb. (2001,Wool Grower,Autumn 10)

On the hill country at Mokai, they have 9800 breeding ewes, which they run in three mobs, including 1800 two-tooth four-way composites. At Sandon Block are 3000 ewe hoggets, all composites, which will be put to their composite rams .. The Parkeses aim to build up to where all their sheep are four-way composites [Finn, Texel, Poll Dorset and Romney.] (May 31, 2002,Dominion,15)

compree¶

v.

The word the most employed is "compree";in French "compris" means understood.This word in the new abbreviated lingo isused in every phrase. If a peasant doesnot understand, he says "No compree";then they have trying explanationswithout end of patience. Very often theyadd the word "that," which is not Frenchor Flemish, and becomes "Compree dat." (Jan 30, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,III/36 : 286)

They say our Premier's coming to reviewthe boys today, I wonder if he"comprees" what's in store. (Jul 5, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/47 : 243)

Compulsory Military Training¶

n.

Compulsory Military Training [reference to the NZ Defence Act] (1912,NZ Shearers (Report Third Annual Conference),12)

concentration camp¶

n. a (secure) place where particular kinds or sections of people could be held together

TREADWELL ... at the end of some six weeks [of training in 1914] we marched out of those Showgrounds and entrained for a large concentration camp in the Wairarapa. Ibid.48-49 The women [sc. Cairo prostitutes, WW1] of the old area were examined, and those infected were immediately placed in a concentration camp, known as the barbed wire', behind which she remained until she received a clean [49] bill of health. <i>Ibid.</i> 104 When the civilians who still stayed in Armentieres saw the desecration of their church ... Many then began to leave for Paris, or the less fortunate for the concentration camps. (1936,Recollections of an Amateur Soldier,15)

concerning¶

adj. causing distress

Health authorities said it was a concerning statistic. (Mar 22, 2000,Radio NZ / National Radio,Morning Report : Unknown Journalist) [NOTES: Mr Reid comments : The New Shorter Oxford" regards this use as archaic]

Concert network¶

n.

Williams is hopeful that a Maori network will exist by next year, and using the Concert network is as much a foot in the door to that goal as it is an important broadcasting event in its own right. (May 31, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

Concert Programme¶

n. subsequently Radio New Zealand Concert

"The Concert Programme is used for dog trials, for horse races, and for parliamentarians. Why shouldn't it be used for Maori culture?" ((31/0/1986),Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

concertina loaf¶

n. a cylindrical loaf baked in an enclosed tin with horizontally oriented corrugations in it [ca1938 (Havelock), ca1949 (Wellington), but ca1986 at Karori Hot Bread Shop now called a tank loaf]

conciliation board¶

n. (historical)

The conciliation boards established under the New Zealand Arbitration Act of 1894. (1902,Encyclopedia Britannica,25/550)

SINCLAIR The country was divided into districts in which Conciliation Boards, elected by masters and workers, were set up. Reeves believed that the majority of [industrial] disputes would be settled by the Boards, ... (1959,History of New Zealand,180)

Since 1894 the wages and conditions of employment of most workers in New Zealand ... have been settled by agreements or awards made under the industrial Arbitration and Conciliation Act. (1965,Oxford NZ Encyclopedia,108)

Conciliation Court¶

n.

Canterbury wool kings, ..., motored to the Conciliation Court, Christchurch, last week, or arrived there behind a 200-guinea pair of bays, for the purposes of demanding a reduction of the shearing rates to 17s 6d per hundred. (1910,NZ Truth,4)

concrete mixer¶

n. a rugby front-row forward

I got tired of people calling us front rowers concrete mixers. (Jun 16, 2005,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Kees Mieuws, Nine to Noon]

condition¶

n. (Rural) the amount of natural grease and dirt in fleecewool.

Condition - refers to the state of a fleece, having regard to the amount of natural grease or yolk, moisture or earthy matter it contains. A full, bright, light Lincoln may be termed 'light' in condition. Heavy conditioned wool contains more than the required amount of grease for the preservation of the fleece. (1919,Wool Grower,19)

STEVENS That the fleece weight was not due to 'condition' - that is, grease and earthy matter - is shown by the high yield ... (1958,Sheep Husbandry,182)

1 n. (Rural) [general qualitative rural term applied to stock, soil, feed, vehicles, buildings etc.] health, production, scope or situation.

The priority for 1997-98 was to get condition on to cows before calving started on July 19. (Oct 1999,NZ Dairy Exporter,110)

"Condition" is a much-abused term when indiscriminately applied to animals. "In good condition" should mean in good condition for the purposes for which the animal is required. (Dec 20, 1916,NZ Journal of Agriculture,467)

Brushing is a common complaint in young horses, especially when in a low condition. (Jan 20, 1917,NZ Journal of Agriculture,71)

If it gets wet it will be hard to keep condition on them ... (May 4, 1993,NZ Farmer,39)

condition score¶

v. (Rural) to assess stock by providing them with a score of 1 to 5, according to the covering of flesh.

Ewes and two-tooths in participating flocks were regularly weighed and condition-scored. (Sep 18, 1997,NZ Farmer,28)

Condition score your cows .. it's more practical than weighing. (Dec 9, 1976,NZ Farmer,27)

In June, for instance, cows are condition-scored and supplementary magnesium starts. (Oct 1999,NZ Dairy Exporter,28)

Graham says the first time he and Susan condition scored the ewes with Chris Mulvaney they knew the sheep were in good order. [condition-score] (Jun 2001,Country-Wide,19)

1 n. (Rural) a quantitative measurement (1-5) of stock condition, particularly dairy cows.

Our cows probably never get below a condition score of four, and at calving, are always above five. If you can maintain a good condition score right through, cows perform better. (Sep 2000,Taranaki Daily News,Farming 2000 Supp 22)

Bang, half a condition score had gone just like that. (1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,13)

.. dairy cows should have a minimum condition score four or five before being loaded on trucks to cross the Cook Strait by inter-island ferry. (Jul 13, 1995,NZ Farmer,14)

His cows are at condition score 5 or better for most of the year. (Oct 1999,NZ Dairy Exporter,6)

Dry matter and cow condition scores are two yardsticks that are used as part of New Zealand dairy farming management structures. (Oct 14, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,14)

Condition score at calving is the most important aspect of feeding - get this right and it will cover up a lot of problems of feeding after calving. [CS] (Apr 2, 2001,Fencepost.com,Expert Farmer)

condition scoring¶

1 n. (Rural) an assessment of flesh or fat cover on an animal.

Condition scoring in Dairy Cows: Condition scoring is done by assessing the fat cover over the backbone, ribs, hip bones and pin bones, and around the base of the tail ... (Jul 6, 2001,Fencepost.com,Expert Farming)

Condition scoring or assessment is much more realistic and meaningful to farmers and can be easily applied in practice. (Dec 9, 1976,NZ Farmer,27)

Condition scoring is a means of comparing sheep regardless of differences in breed, body frame sixe or category of ewes. eg hill country vs intensive farming. (1994,Guide to Feed Planning for Sheep Farmers,11)

Condition scoring cows. Condition scoring (CS) cows was developed many years ago to help farmers specify how skinny or fat their cows were ... (Nov 2001,Lifestyleblock.co.nz) [NOTES: ?Lifestyleblock.co.nz 397 Nov.]

Condition scoring assesses the amount of body fat or condition ... (Feb 2002,In the Paddock,1)

conditioned¶

1 adj. (Rural) [sp. use] [of stock] presented in a certain state of health.

The improved cow - the heavy milker, the good doer - is the most likely to suffer, and high-conditioned animals are all disposed to milk fever. (Dec 20, 1916,NZ Journal of Agriculture,467)

LESLIE Rough and ready methods adopted by some sheepmen are (1) to kill old poor-conditioned ewes ... (1938,Diseases of Breeding Ewes,123)

.. fresh-conditioned cows and those suitable for the fattening paddocks finding a ready outlet with graziers. Low-conditioned aged ewes and lambs 8s all counted. (Nov 25, 1939,Hawera Star,12)

condomania¶

n.

Condomania is upon us! Deborah Morris wants free condoms to be available for all school children. (Aug 19, 1997,Dominion,6)

conductor¶

The buses can be easily identified as 'the [walking school] conductors', or parent helpers, will be wearing sashes... (Oct 27, 2004,Northern Courier,6)

cone¶

Jonno suggested.. everyone come round his place and have a couple of cones and get the whole thing sorted. (Nov 2, 2000,City Voice,15)

n. bookau

CONE: A raised mound at the base of a mature kauri tree. PUKAU (1952,NZ Forest Glossary)

...he's telling me that in Tauranga he and his mates all get a crate of beer, a couple of cones, and watch the show... (Mar 13, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

WESTAWAY It rams so hard at the dollop of ice-cream that the cone crumples in my hand. (1996,Reliable Friendly Girls,62)

Confederation¶

n. (historical) an alliance of Maori chiefs, signatories to the Declaration of Independence in 1835

The treaty which forms the base of all my proceedings was signed at Waitangi on the 6th February 1840, by 52 chiefs, 26 of whom were of the confederation, and formed a majority of those who signed the Declaration of Independence. This [sc copy of treaty] instrument I consider to be de facto the treaty, and all signatures that are subsequently obtained are merely testimonials of adherence to the original document. (1841,GBPP,17) [NOTES: 1840 Apr 25 Hobson to Bunbury in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 17]

confiscated lands¶

n.

There is another class of land.. known as "Confiscated Lands". These lands are situated in the provincial districts of Auckland and Taranaki, and were principally the property of natives who rebelled against the Queen's Authority, and took part in the Waikato and Taranaki Wars. (Jun 18, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

confiscation line¶

n. (See aukati)

NORRIS Although the chiefs disapproved of the murder, they would neither allow Winiata to be arrested in the King Country, nor return him over the Confiscation Line to be taken in charge by the Europeans. (1964,Settlers in Depression,151)

congestication¶

n. city

The aura and pace of the place is quite the opposite to that familiar to most of the urban metrosexies and yucks that ponce and preen in the congestications known as cities. (Sep 26, 2004,Sunday Star Times,B13)

connection¶

n. (usu. pl.) a person who shares a financial interest in a horse

McLINTOCK As a three-year-old [Carbine] was taken to Australia, but to the chagrin of his connections his record was spoiled when he was beaten by Ensigne in the V.R.C. Derby. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/24)

SMITH The excitement and yelling were as tremendous as ever; and, although the friends, and connections of my horse gave me credit for a good race, yet I could see they were sadly disappointed. (Nov 1909,Lone Hand, The,6/110) [NOTES: ALSO in Phillips (ed) 2000 First Past the Post, p. 193]

A host of horses who wanted a wet track will now have unsuitable conditions and the connections of the horses who were withdrawn on Wednesday morning because of track conditions are understandably furious. (Sep 12, 2003,Dominion Post RaceForm,20)

The immediate connections of St Hippo are, however, I am assured, not responsible for the colt's position in the quotations, which is rather difficult to understand, considering the great opportunities presented to them of getting on at a fair price. (Feb 25, 1893,Auckland Weekly News,11)

The plan gathered momentum on Friday night when Baltic Eagle's connections started interdominion celebrations at Addington with officials of the NZ Metropolitan Trotting Club. (Apr 13, 2003,Sunday Star Times,B14)

He was occasionally known in turf circles as a connection, the quaint term used to denote a person who shares a financial interest in a horse. Among them was Red Pepper, which won once, and Karayarkin, which never did... (Jun 20, 2002,Evening Post,7)

7/4 250 (1953,Landfall)

connie¶

n. a type of playing marble [[AND n2. [f. corn(elian + -Y]]

SUTTON-SMITH Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, ... (1972,Folkgames of Children,174)

consentability¶

n. [traffic or local body jargon]

However, this cannot be approved if it fails to meet the requirements for "consentability". (Oct 18, 2005,Dominion Post,B7)

Conservancy¶

n. a section of the Department of Conservation

The Wellington Conservancy covers the lower portion of the North Island and the Chatham Islands, some 800 kilometres southeast of Wellington... The conservancy is divided into three areas on the mainland and one on the Chatham Islands. (Jun 2001,Footnotes,No. 15 : 12)

conservation estate¶

n. (Environment) a land conservation area administered by the Department of Conservation.

The Labour government is turning the South Island's spine into a conservation estate running from top to bottom. [19] No one I spoke to believes that the Department of Conservatioon (DOC) will be able to manage its huge conservation estate, which they predict will quickly be overrun by weeds and pests. (Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

As a Central Otago famer, I have seen the local conservation estate continue to grow. (Jun 1999,North & South,14)

Whether these airborne thrill-seekers "use" the conservation estate at all is arguable...The conservation estate, anyway, should be free of the noise pollution deafening the rest of the world. (Aug 20, 2000,Sunday Star Times,A8)

This huge conservation estate was disputed for decades by pro-development and conservation factions, before the 1986 West Coast Blakely Accord (named after the environment secretary who presided over the negotiations) divided the spoils between the two. (Jan 16, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

This is not an earth-shattering Bill, butthere are some important provisions withregard to the administration ofconservation estate. (1994,NZ Parliamentary Debates,544/4785)

He indicated he had some sympathy forclaims against the conservation estate. (May 4, 1995,Dominion,2)

The Department of Conservation isconsidering the question of charging aconcession fee for special or sportingevents that utilise the conservationestate. (1991,NZ Parliamentary Debates,520/5226)

The Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheriesis responsible for that part of thepossum control that is used for animalhealth - tuberculosis control on theconservation estate (1992,NZ Parliamentary Debates,527/10201)

The Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheriesis responsible for that part of thepossum control that is used for animalhealth - tuberculosis control on theconservation estate (1992,NZ Parliamentary Debates,527/10201)

Relph When all of these areas [in the high country] are included, the conservation estate covers about 40 per cent of all of the high country in central Canterbury, and this proportion will increase further as the tenure review process continues. (2007,From Tussocks to Tourists,147)

conservation land¶

1 n. (Rural) land that has been officially retired from farming.

.. lessees have been given continued grazing rights over some 18% of this new conservation land including mountain tops and fragile alpine herbfields. One proposal would allow the lessee to continue to graze sheep on the mountain tops of new conservation land for 21 years! Write to Lands Minister .. for grazing licences to not be issued over large areas of new conservation land. (May 2000,Conservation News,1)

conservation park¶

n. a land area managed by the Department of Conservation, which includes areas formerly known as forest parks.

A new conservation park encompassing snow-capped peaks in the Kaikoura Ranges and rugged high country was officially opened on 7 June. (Aug 2008,FMC - (Federated Mountain Clubs of NZ) Bulletin,30)

Newly created conservation parks, such as Te Papanui, west of Dunedin, which opened in March, will link national parks, estates and reserves. (Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

New conservation parks are planned to protect the natural values of the high-country. Conservation land is being set aside during a process called Land Tenure Review. High country run holders who usually hold their land on a perpetual lease now have the opportunity to freehold the better pastures. In return, sensitive and valued conservation areas are set aside as Crown reserves. Valley floors tend to remain farmed while higher country is protected. (Nov 2002,Forest & Bird,306/4)

MACLEAN In 1987, control passed to the newly created Department of Conservation (DoC) whose management objective was defined by the Conservation Act : "Every conservation park shall be so managed that its natural and historic resources are protected, and to facilitate public recreation and enjoyment.' (1994,Tararua : the Story of a Mountain Range,235)

In the list of high priority reas for new conservation parks, a 200,000-hectare Ohau Conservation Park was recommended. (Jun 2010,FMC - (Federated Mountain Clubs of NZ) Bulletin,24)

More conservation parks in the high country highlighted the issue of public access. (Aug 7, 2006,Otago Daily Times,6)

Conservator¶

n. spec., in full Conservator of Forests, formerly an administrave official of the NZ Forest Service, esp. one in charge of a conservancy, a territorial administrative district.

In 1876 a Forest Department was created, forest legislation passed, and many timber reserves were made. Within these the department was supreme. It was under a Chief Conservator of Forests (Mr.T.Kirk) and a staff of conservators and rangers. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,115)

Conservator of Forests¶

n.

The Governor may, for the purposes of this Act, from time to time appoint and remove all the officers and servants required for the purposes of this Act. including one or more conservator or conservators of State forests... Ibid. 76 The Conservator, with the approval of the Commissioner, shall regulate the mode of falling and utilizing timber to be cut on such part of any State forest as shall be classed as a level reserve. (1885,NZ Statutes,49 Vict. 30/72)

Report of the Conservator of State Forests with Proposals for the Organization and Working of the State Forest Department... I have avoided going into detail of the duties to be performed by the officers it is proposed to employ, and which will form part of the organization or interior economy of the department, for which the Conservator is now responsible. (1877,AJHR,C-3/1) [NOTES: NB - This term doesn't seem to have been used again for the big boss who seems to have been appointed (not verified) as the Commissioner.]

It is shown in the reports of the Conservators that the output of timber for the year is considerably less than last year. (1921,AJHR,C-3/4)

It is shown in the reports of the Conservators that the output of timber for the year is considerably less than last year. (1921,AJHR,C-3/4)

conservatory¶

n. a glass-roofed room, usually a later addition to a house, used more for living in than in the traditional sense of a place for plants

Newstalk ZB's midnight-to-dawn talkback host, Martin Crump, leads me into the conservatory of his Auckland home. (Jan 13, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),64)

Much loved family home suitable for any age or stage, 3 bedrooms, family bathroom, spacious living with open fire and a sun drenched conservatory. (Nov 22, 2000,Property Press,7)

Coming off the kitchen are the separate laundry.. a separate shower and the conservatory, where the owners often have breakfast. (Nov 22, 2000,Dominion,29)

Constantinople¶

exclam. Christ, Christ Almighty

McGILL Constantinople! euphemism for `Christ almighty!' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,30)

consultation¶

n. usu. overseas consultation, a euphemism for Tattersall's sweepstake, illegal in NZ. (See Tatts)

A young man was much surprised because I did not know the price of horse-racing "consultation" tickets. (Mar 15, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

The totalisator and "consultations" have a lot to answer for. (Dec 11, 1890,Otago Witness,23)

[Advt] Venture, in returning thanks to the subscribers of his No. 1 Consultation, begs to inform them that it is closed FULL. (Jan 13, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,3)

Referring to the supposed death of sweeps and consultations, the Feilding Star understands that companies will be forced to work on the totalisator, which is a legal institution. (Nov 4, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

It is to be hoped that everyone feels better, purer, and generally higher toned, through the coming in force today of the Act prohibiting consultations. (Nov 6, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

The only way I can see for a customer tobe hoodwinked is for an agent to..purchase another ticket in the same namein a later consultation. (Jan 21, 1953,NZ Truth,5)

The success of certain New Zealand investors in the "sweeps" or "consultations" promoted in Tasmania, will have the effect of increasing the sum sent from this colony by people who are desirous of putting their luck to the test. (Oct 25, 1897,NZ Times,2)

The syndicate of five which last week won a aGBP12,000 first prize in Tattersalls consultation is a case in point. (Mar 16, 1934,Feilding Star,6)

consultation industry¶

phr.

There is also the Brash-amplified suspicion that its extensive consultation mandate has given rise to consultation industry among iwi, whose net contribution is hard to discern. (Apr 10, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

contagious abortion¶

n.

[Advt] Practical farmers can now be satisfied that contagious abortion in dairy herds can be prevented and cured. (Jan 31, 1926,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,18)

Strain 19 for contagious abortion hadn't emerged from the biochemists' test-tubes. (Jan 1972,NZ Dairy Exporter,41)

contemporary claim¶

n. a Maori claim on present-day resources, e.g. a share of the radio spectrum [contrastive with historic(al) claim; also as contemporary grievance below]

He says also that the Prime Minister has told him that Government needs to figure out how to deal with contemporary claims. (May 22, 2000,NZ Infotech Weekly,442 : 4)

It cites the issue of Maori access to the new mobile phone spectrum as an example of "contemporary grievances" which the Crown is struggling to handle. (May 28, 2000,Sunday Star Times,A2)

The settlement process had become drawn out because claimants had attempted to address contemporary Treaty claims and constitutional issues within a framework established to deal with historical claims only. (Jul 7, 2000,Evening Post,17)

Claims to oil and gas and other Crown minerals owned in the "national interest" are ruled out of historic settlements - but claims to natural resources will be explored under contemporary claims. (Jul 20, 2000,Evening Post,1)

Mrs Shipley said the Government's consideration of a proposal allowing the trust exclusive right to buy the block of frequency was taking New Zealand down a dangerous path. If it heads down this path it could find itself open to a range of contemporary claims and demands relating to things such as minerals and hydro-electricity that have no legitimacy under the Treaty [of Waitangi]. (May 8, 2000,Dominion,2)

The Government was still exploring how to "appropriately provide for Maori interests within the petroleum regulatory regime". He later declined to say if that left the door open to a conemporary claim to petroleum resources. (Oct 20, 2000,Dominion,1)

Contemporary claims are claims arising after 1992 and cover alleged breaches of existing obligations to Maori. (Oct 25, 2000,Evening Post,5)

contestability¶

n. allowing other unions' right to contest any union's membership coverage. [1986 Wage Round Aug-Sep 1986]

Mr Cullen said Mr Rodger was trying to disguise the fact that union contestability would be introduced, and to mount an attack on the national award system. (Sep 30, 1986,Dominion,1)

Putting aside the two most difficult points for the unions, contestability under the guise of a provision for union coverage and demarcation ... the FOL has fared relatively well. (Oct 3, 1986,National Business Review,14)

ROBERTS [The active principles followed in the process of decoupling the Government from the public sector include:] (h) Contestability: The recognition of a range of possible means to achieve objectives and the adoption of the position that policy should not inhibit bids by competing agencies unless clear benefit can be demonstrated. (1987,Politicians, Public Servants & Public Enterprise,15)

contingent¶

n. a spec. use during the Boer War and WW1 of OED2 B. 5 b. `a force contributed to form part of an or navy' as a name for the various batches of NZ troops sent overseas. Compare WW2 echelon.

They saw more fighting than any othercorps [in the Maori Wars], except thefriendly Maori contingents. (Nov 26, 1910,NZ Free Lance,13)

We'd best muster up the lot,/ And send a sixth contingent to the war. (1907,College Songs,31)

Had it not been for the pressure of other work, notably examination of horses for South African contingents, certain doubtful points might have been elucidated ... (1900,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,8/200)

Mr A.E.G.Rhodes entertained the 8th Contingent and I was an invited guest. (Feb 5, 1902,Chudleigh Diary,410,1950 ed.)

n.

M & N ROSS The men from the Antipodes have brought with them a ... slang of their own. Their definition of the various batches of volunteers that have come out to fight is worth quoting. The first contingent became known as `The Tourists'. (1916,Light and Shade)

HYDE Well, there's a contingent leaving in about twenty days' time - you can join up with that. (1936,Passport to Hell,75)

Both the first and second contingents were landed in South Africa at the expense of the New Zealand Government. (Feb 2005,NZ Memories,No. 52, p. 62)

n. group

1892 saw the first contingent of men leave Timaru for the North Island to erect huts for their families. (Dec 2001,NZ Memories,No. 27/38)

contingenter¶

n.

Jack Moeller (who is a New Zealandcontingenter, lost his life in the SouthAfrican War). (Aug 20, 1910,NZ Free Lance,17)

The hall is constantly full of waitingcontingenters and volunteers saying"Goodbye." (Aug 12, 1914,Wanganui Herald,6)

Several stowaways were found among theAuckland contingenters when the specialtrain reached Palmerston on Monday. (Aug 13, 1914,Wanganui Herald,4)

[Hdg] Contingenters and their Money (Aug 23, 1914,Wanganui Herald,3)

[Hdg] Contingenters in Disgrace (Feb 12, 1915,Wanganui Herald,8)

If a separate building for theconvalescent contingenters were erectedon the Hospital grounds, it would be usedafterwards for the purposes he hadindicated. (Jun 22, 1915,Wanganui Herald,4)

... some blasted [Australian] contingenters (though Maoriland's Boer swaddies were worse) ... (Sep 15, 1906,NZ Truth,5)

Continuance¶

n.

In the first [voting-paper], the voter is asked whether he votes for continuance or no-license. (1910,NZ Parliamentary Debates,153/603)

I VOTE for ContinuanceI VOTE for No-License (1910,NZ Statutes,1 Geo.V, No. 46/210)

TURNER ... in New Zealand a triennial poll is held to decide whether drink should be prohibited. ... The voting is for one of three alternatives, National Continuance',State Purchase and Control' or National Prohibition'. ... to make matters worse, bothcontinuance' and `State purchase and control' are very ill defined. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,156)

Continuous Government¶

n. = Continuous Ministry q.v.

Did any honorable member ever imagine or infer that the Government of which Sir Julius Vogel became Premier was a different Government from that over which the Hon. Fox had been Premier? It was to all intents a continuous Government. (1877,NZ Parliamentary Debates,26/106)

Continuous Ministry¶

n. (historical)

The honourable gentleman opposite has dwelt very strongly upon the ContinuousMinistry. Now "the Continuous Ministry" is one of those political catch-wordswhich have become very common, and it has become as familiar as a household word...The honourable gentleman [sc. the MP for Christchurch North] began this ContinuousMinistry. (1884,NZ Parliamentary Debates,48/74)

I say the combination is simply the change of a few offices among the Premier's own party, and I say this is the Continuous Ministry. (1884,NZ Parliamentary Debates,48/70)

An attempt has been made by the Attorney-General to show that the present Ministry are not responsible at least for some part of the matter of which they are accused. inasmuch as they were not in office at the time when the libel was printed. But that is a prevarication, for this is a continuous Ministry.Ibid. 108 Again, the Attorney-General in the speech which he delivered asserted that the Ministry of which he forms part was not a continuous Ministry... Everyone knows it is a continuous Ministry. (1877,NZ Parliamentary Debates,26/31)

The Continuous Ministry is played out. (Aug 2, 1890,North & South,7)

No interference with the dear Civil Servants, and the Continuous Ministry for ever and ever, amen! (Nov 15, 1890,NZ Observer,14)

The Continuous Ministry is as dead as Queen Anne. (Dec 13, 1890,NZ Observer,4)

At one time Premier Seddon was amongst the most persistent railers against the "Continuous Ministry" as the various Whitaker-Atkinson combinations that so long ruled the country came to be called. (Mar 5, 1904,NZ Observer,5)

In the bad old Tory days, when Sir John Hall ran for many years what eventually became known as the Continuous Ministry, it never occurred to him to step down from the Treasury benches. (Apr 16, 1904,NZ Observer,2)

The continuous Ministry, which for years held office, robbed the people of the country of their lands. (Feb 15, 1913,NZ Observer,17)

REEVES The Continuous Ministry was a name given to a shifting combination, or rather series of combinations, amongst public men, by which the cabinet was from time to time modified without being completely changed at any one moment. (1898,Long White Cloud, The,335)

With a weak Labour Party and a divided opposition, National might under present voting conditions establish a near continuous ministry as it did from 1949-84. (Aug 2, 1992,Dominion Sunday Times,11)

In the event of their resuming their places in the new Administration, the cry of the "Continuous Ministry" would again have been raised. (Oct 1, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,17)

It will be as unreasonable to put downthis exodus as the fault of the presentGovernment as it was to accuse the tail-end of the Continuous Ministry of thatwhich took place in the colony four yearsago (1895,NZ Parliamentary Debates,85/206)

SINCLAIR the frequent reshuffling of the cabinet, it was so obvious that the changes of personnel involved no change that the Government came to be called `the continuous ministry' [1869-1891]. (1959,History of New Zealand,160)

The Continuous Ministry' wasa name given to a shifting combination, or rather series of cmbinations, amongst public men, by which the cabinet was from time to time modified without being completely changed at any one moment.' [quoting 1898 Reeves Long White Cloud 335-336] ... [48] John Sheehan, one of the ablest ... debaters in the opposition, claimed that the most inoffensive epithet' he could apply to the government [c1875] was that of thecontinuous Government'. [NZPD 1875, 19, p. 60] The Continuous Ministry' label was established by frequent reiteration. Samuel Hodgkinson ... flatly asserted:this is a continuous Ministry. There may have been a new material put into it, but it is much the same Ministry as an old garment is the same garment though it has been patched from time to time.' [quoting NZPD, 1877, 26, p. 31] (Apr 1987,NZ Journal of History,47) [NOTES: (Dalziel)]

contour fencing¶

1 n. (Rural) a line of fencing that follows the contour of land along the crests of hills.

On Ernest Nielsen's advice, in redesigning their subdivisional plans, they used contour fencing on this steeper country .. As their name implies, contour fences follow the contour along the crest of the hills and thus fence the tops from off the sidelings. (Apr 11, 1960,NZ Dairy Exporter,5)

contour/contour-ditch irrigation¶

1 n. (Rural) a type of surface irrigation where head ditches supply contour ditches to enable lower rolling land to be flooded.

RIDDOLLS .. the water is made to overflow the contour ditch, diverting the water into it in both directions ... (1958,Farm Engineering,192)

There are a number of methods [sic] of irrigating land, of which the following are the principal: .. 3. Contour. (Jul 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,25)

RIDDOLLS Contour-ditch Irrigation. When the fall of the land is 3 ft or more per chain, the only practicable surface-irrigation method is by contour ditches. (1958,Farm Engineering,190)

RIDDOLLS In rolling country with a fall of 3 ft per chain or more, the only possible method of surface irrigation is the contour-ditch system. (1958,Farm Engineering,195)

contract boarder¶

n. one who gives his paycheck to his landlord and helps himself to what he wants.

SATCHELL While securing his baggage Clifford looked about for the contract boarder [at the inn], but he was nowhere to be seen. ... His time is nearly up,' said the innkeeper.Most men would have turned him out before this, but I like to give full value.' (1902,Land of the Lost,30)

contract fencer¶

n.

We criss-crossed the countryside roundWarkworth looking for kiwifruit farmersin the early stages of development,sharemilkers, contract fencers andshearers. (Jul 12, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

contract fencing¶

n.

They pooled their money from contract fencing, drove to Wellington. (May 12, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),64)

1 n. (Rural) the short-term employment of farm fencers according to a particular contract.

They pooled their money from contract fencing, drove to Wellington in their Falcon - the "Dickmobile" - and recorded a single. (May 21, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),64)

COWAN He used to do contract fencing at Awakino and my mother would end up cooking for the fencing gang in the camps, with old camp ovens. (1997,Pigs and Me: Tales of the Bygone Bush.,16)

contract milker¶

1 n. (Rural) a dairy worker who is hired on contract to milk a certain number of cows for a season.

He employs a contract milker who in turn employs a married man. (Jan 1977,NZ Dairy Exporter,9)

Experienced contract milker required on 210 hectare 600 cow property near Winton. (Nov 18, 2000,Christchurch Star,43)

contract shearing¶

n.

Mr Macdonald was one of the first North Islanders to undertake contract shearing as a large-scale business, operating gangs as far afield as the western bays of Lake Taupo and Taihape from his Hamilton base in the 1960s and 1970s. (Jun 3, 2004,Dominion Post,B9)

Contract shearing is becoming general throughout the country. (1982,Blue Cliffs,248)

FITTON The shearing of the sheep is generally done by contract; ... at so much per 100 sheep shorn - their [sc. hands'] rations, in addition to their pay, being provided for the shearers.] (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),220)

I do not think that many of the boys across the water [in Australia] approve of contract shearing, but the system has taken root and will be hard to abolish. (Oct 6, 1911,Maoriland Worker,31/17/1)

Contract shearing gangs (consisting of shearers; shed hands; and, usually, a cook) travel from farm to farm. (1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,66)

RICHARDS I was very fortunate in having had a couple of days to settle in and get the `feel' of contract shearing (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,95)

contract shed¶

n.

RICHARDS Otoro was George's first contract shed. ... But all his shed hands, shearers and his wool classer had been with him before. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,94)

1 n. (Rural) a farm or station where shearing is done on contract, i.e. for a price per number of sheep shorn.

RICHARDS George Stuart had added another large station Mangaohone to his contract sheds, and as it adjoined Otupae he now had three sheds in the high rugged tussock country. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,51)

RICHARDS Otoro was George's first contract shed. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,94)

WATERSON Wart had several big contract sheds at the back of Taumaranui ... (1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,77)

contractor¶

n. in NZ a spec. freq. extension of OED2 2. (1724 gen. and building contractor) to agricultural (esp. shearing) contractor; one who undertakes various farm services on contract, or who contracts to grow spec. crops for canning companies, seed-merchants. etc [??OMIT].

PASK [cf notes] (1883,Report on NZ,5)

MITCHELL I then went to plough on the Awamoa Estate for one Andrew Winter, a contractor. (1889,Rhymes and Rambles,20)

It's sitting in the same place in the contractor's car every day - rousies in the back of course - arguing over who's going to open the gate today. (Mar 1988,More Magazine,31)

conventional fence¶

1 n. (Rural) a post and batten fence with five to seven wires [that is not electric.]

RIDDOLLS The advantages of chain dropper fences compared with conventional fences are cheapness, lightness, tightness ... (1958,Farm Engineering,427)

Generally easy and medium hill well subdivided with conventional and electric fences into 29 paddocks. (Nov 10, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,22)

Subdivided in 30 main and 4 holding paddocks by a very high standard of conventional fence aided by a central race. (Nov 13, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,32)

The area for lease is fenced into 18 main and 4 holding paddocks by a very good standard of conventional fences aided by electric ... (Apr 6, 2002,Hawke's Bay Today,26)

conventional fencing¶

1 n. (Rural) post and batten fencing with five to seven wires [that is not electric.]

Subdivided into some 30 paddocks by conventional fencing. (Feb 2, 2002,Dominion,48)

WASWO Power fencing, as it is now known, costs less to establish and if correctly constructed, costs less to maintain than conventional fencing. Hawke's Bay Today Nov 10. 22 Ten paddocks fenced with conventional batten wire and electric. (1996,Farming Progress in NZ 1814-1995,145)

100.9691 ha - flat contour, subdivided into 16 paddocks, good conventional fencing. (Jun 22, 2002,Dominion,48)

conversation lolly¶

n. a flat sweet with a usu. sentimental message or motto stamped on it

TUNNICLIFFE 'Mrs 'obhouse are you fond ofconversation lollies?' was a questionwith which she mystified me one day. (1992,Selected Letters of Mary Hobhouse,95) [NOTES: Quoted from Hobhouse, 1862.]

... the party were amusing themselves with `converstion lollies.' (May 11, 1880,Evening Post,2)

LANGTON ... conversation lollies ... (1889,Mark Anderson,95)

SCANLAN Kitty remembered she always asked for Conversation Lollies' with those touching little phrases to aid a laggard in love:Meet me to-night,' or `Are you my true love?' (1934,Winds of Heaven,42)

PARK And Mrs Bedding, the lolly-shop lady, poured out all the wonders she had stored ... in the back of the shop. Black gelatinous bears ..., the blackballs, aniseed balls, ... Hundreds and thousands, musk lollies hard as bullets ... green, white, yellow conversation lollies with inscriptions of Oh, you kid!' andIs that so?' and sometimes, blushingly, `You're the cat's pyjamas.' (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,78)

BOSWELL ... and most wondrous of all [lollies] the variously-coloured conversations' with their entrancing mottoes -I love you', Meet me by moonlight,'Love me alone,' and a dozen others. (1955,Dim Horizons,74,1956 ed.)

OWEN I don't suppose many people today would remember what 'conversation lollies" were like. They were little flat pink and yellow and white lollies with things printed on them, like "Will you be my sweetheart? Or "I love you" or "Will you marry me?" or something of the sort. (1998,Snapshots of the Century,18)

He sat Tommy on the counter and bought him two brandysnaps and a packet of conversational lollies. (Jun 13, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

conversion¶

n.

Some [NZ] words and senses get left out [of the Collins Concise Dictionary]. One might ? instance pikelet, car conversion and Taranaki gate ; boatie is in but not postie, yachtie (used recently in a 1YA newscast), garryowen but not willieaway. (Aug 20, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),101)

Little linguistic innovation has occurred in criminal law or procedure, three exceptions being conversion (of cars etc.), which is defined in DNZE, Crown solicitor, and infringement notice. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2)

The theft and unlawful conversion of 10 motor cars.. were referred to in 28 charges preferred against seven youths. (Nov 30, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,17)

n. (Rural) the process of changing from one type of farming to another on the same land.

Mr Gibbard said the farm was ideal for conversion to dairy. (Sep 12, 2002,Wanganui Chronicle,21)

The dairy company has approved 73 farm conversions for 1993-94. (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,37)

The original Dacre property was one of the first to come on the market during the initial wave of conversions and was considered small. (Nov 16, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,15)

Mrs Wylie said other issues attached to conversions included the availability of stock and farm staff. (2000,Taranaki Daily News,16)

Our agricultural industry as we know it has only got on its feet because it had support from the Government in the early days. We don't want to be seen as having favourites, but I think it's also important that people have a degree of certainty about conversion. (Dec 7, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,13)

With all the huge conversions happening down here, a massive shortage of trained staff is predicted. (Mar 15, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,18)

There are about 70 farms expected to start up in the South Island next year, as the conversion of traditional sheep and beef farms continues. (Aug 8, 2001,Dominion,22)

Conversion to dairying is now easily the biggest change in rural land use. (Aug 24, 2001,Dominion,16)

n. (Rural) a farm property that has changed its land use.

In a conversion of this size it is interesting to see how much you can save if you shop around. (Feb 28, 1990,NZ Farmer,15)

This is an opportunity to discuss problems associated with a new conversion and the merits of moving to Southland. (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,37)

Over the past six seasons the number of conversions from sheep and beef to new dairy farms has been ... (Nov 4, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,24)

A position is available on a 320 ha. first year conversion in Northern Southland. (Nov 18, 2000,Press, The,43)

Thirty-four conversions will see the Mid-South Canterbury dairy farm area increase by nearly 9400 hectares in the next season ... (Mar 2001,Timaru Herald,27)

Wing Point Farm is a new conversion milking 800 dairy cows through a 70 bale rotary. (Apr 3, 2002,Dominion,18)

1 n. (Rural) the development of land into pasture production from forest and bush.

TAIT The conversion of this area of virgin bush to good pasture in little over 50 years is the result of hard work. (1958,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol II,494)

LEVY I have viewed with absorbing interest the conversion of some 11 million acres of forest to grassland and have worked among the blackened stumps and logs of the indifferent forest burn. (1970,Grasslands of NZ,330)

CONNELL & HADFIELD A major modification of ecological development by man in New Zealand has been the conversion of forest and scrub lands to pasture. (1961,Agriculture,293)

2 n.

But increasing numbers of conversion during a period of rising milk payouts have shown bigger cash surpluses for farm owners who employed a manager of contract milker rather than a 450-50 sharemilker. (May 31, 2002,Dominion,32)

convert¶

v. sense or use nf OED2 convert v; conversion 11 c Forestry. defines as a change of sylvicultural system, theough the second cit. might suggest the usu. NZ forestry sense: to convert (growing wood) into an end product, formerly usu. sawn timber. Hence conversion, conversion factor.

All the men engaged at the sawmills [of West Oxford] had heard of `tooth-leaved beech,' but only one or two of them had seen it growing, and no one had seen it converted. (1884,TrNZI,17/302) [NOTES: (Kirk, NZ Beeches)]

v. convert v. take possession of an article, especially a motor vehicle, without authority in N.Z. This is seldom called theft.

convert v. take possession of an article, especially a motor vehicle, without authority in N.Z. This is seldom called theft. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

(1979,Heinemann NZ Dictionary,233)

LELAND In this genteel society, `down under' one does not do anything so crass as to STEAL A CAR, one merely converts it to one's own use. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A)

[cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 245, sense 5; cf. 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 104] convert ... NZ & Austral. take (another's property, esp. a motor vehicle) illegally or without permission. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,161)

[Hdg] Motor Cars "Converted". (Nov 30, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,17)

1 v. (Rural) to change the use of farm property from one type of farming to another [particularly from sheep and beef to dairying in the 1990s, when sheep profits were depressed and dairy profits were high.]

I've got clients who are sheep farmers wanting to convert who are saying they don't want to see a sharemilking budget. Mrs Wylie said farmers were converting property more aggressively than they had done during the first wave in the 1990s. (Nov 16, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,16)

The drought through much of the east coast of the South Island has become a worry for many farmers who converted. (Aug 24, 2001,Dominion,16)

It costs between $2500 and $3000 per hectare to convert and John had to leave Karen in charge up north ... (Sep 2001,North & South,43)

A property all set to convert, currently 142 hectares being milked on and balance used for intensive dairy grazing and wintering. (Feb 2, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,38)

converter¶

1 n. (Rural) a farm animal that converts feed to condition.

.. the Charolais are big converters and have to climb a bit on the property. (2000,Lifestyle Farmer,Autumn 8)

conveyor¶

1 n. (Rural) [sp. use] a raised conveyor platform upon which sheep are placed for drenching, vaccination etc.

Wanganui Veterinary Services has recently purchased a sheep conveyor .. The use of these conveyors is a relatively recent innovation for handling sheep and they have already become a routine sheep handling aid on many properties, particularly in the South Island. (Sep 12, 2002,Wanganui Chronicle,20)

conveyor gang¶

1 n. (Rural) a team of workers on a sheep conveyor.

It [the conveyor] is far kinder to both the animals and the people working with them and means that the farmer simply chases the sheep through the yard while the 'conveyor gang' administers the animal remedies etc. (Sep 12, 2002,Wanganui Chronicle,20)

convictism¶

n. the use of NZ as a penal colony

FITTON In New Zealand, too, has not spread its moral blight as in Van Diemen's Land or New South Wales, for convicts have never been sent to New Zealand. (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),342) [NOTES: [quoting Frederick Young's NZ circular]]

THOMSON ... and the antipodeal colonies, separated by half the globe from England, are tainted with convictism and cannibalism ... (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,2/309)

CAMPBELL Well. The arrival at Waiomu was not the arrival of Pakehas tainted with convictism or ship-run-awayism, waiperou-ism, or any other tourekareka-ism, [sic] this last word meaning a slave or low born ... (1881,Poenamo,3/2/141)

convolvulus¶

n. a large family of vines to which bindweed and morning glory belong; powhiwhi; pohuehue [convolvulere to roll together]; spp. of wild flower, the introduced variety being often troublesome noxious weeds; bindweed, black bindweed, cornbind, morning glory (See also sand c,shore c)

2 n.

H. WILLIAMS We landed on Motu tapu in a lovely sheltered spot, where the clematis and convolvulus and other creeping plants hung beautifully around. (Nov 27, 1833,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,351,1961 ed.)

POLACK The clematis, campanula trachelium, or bell flower, whose hues, white, red, and yellow, with the convolvulus, or bind-weed, and immumerable liands, [106] hung around in pleasing disorder. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/105)

F. MATHEW I found, however, that what has the appearance of Downs is in reality covered with Fern, so thick and strong as to be almost impenetrable, ... added to which it is entangled ... with the vines of the wild Convolvulus, which grows everywhere in the greatest luxuriance, so that to traverse it is all but impossible.
