(Feb 27, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Feb 27 F.Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 64]

WILLIAMS Poohue, and pohuehue, n. a name given to several climbing or trailing plants, as convolvulus; clematis &c. (1871,Dictionary of the Maori Language,118)

DOMETT Convolvulus .....O. Convolvulaceae; G. Convolvulus Five species - mostly white or rose-hued. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/302)

TREGEAR The roots of the common convolvulus (pohue: Convolvulus sepium) were carefully dug up and cooked ... (1904,Maori Race, The,99)

BAUGHAN Kauri and Totara, Rimu, and Mataiand Maire,/ -as-blood Rata, and bright-as-blood Pohutukawa,/ Manuka dark-ey'd, Convolvulus star-ey'd - / The glittering of you that morning! (1908,Shingle-Short,54)

3 n.

Among the sho-plants ... are the wild celery (Apium prostratum) and convolvulus (Calystegia Soldanella), with ... sand-grass (Spinifex hirsutus) ... (1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/200)

HILGENDORF & CALDER ? =CORNBIND Ibid. 135 [1926 headword convolvulus; 1967 headword bindweed] CONVOLVULUS [BINDWEED] (Convolvulus arvensis), is also called bindweed and black bindweed, cornbind, and morning glory. It is an introduced weed found in fields, gardens and waste places in many localities. It has a perennial creeping underground stem, trailing or twining [aerial] stems with leaves 1 to 3 inches long, shaped like a spear head, and handsome bell-shaped flowers an -inch or more in diameter- ... (1967,Weeds of New Zealand,64) [NOTES: [nf 1926]]

convolvulus, [=] field bindweed: greater bindweed [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,15)

Convolvulus and the three-cornered garlic - allium triquetrum are examples of weeds which are difficult to eradicate once they become established in the garden. (Dec 10, 1973,Dominion,18/6-7-8)

4 n.

ADAMS Various bindweeds collectively known as `convolvulus' are vigorous twiners with white or pink flowers. The most beautiful is the royal-blue morning glory that covers shrubs ... Botanical name: Ipomaea learii, tropical America. Family: Convolvulaceae. (1980,Wild Flowers,28)

5 n.

(And) Calystegia sepium (1886,NZ Country Journal,Vol I 1877-XXII 1898)

WILSON Calystegia tuguriorum NATIVE BINDWEED ... Convolvulus ... High climbing, twining stems with thin leaves. Flowers white, conspicuous. ... Introduced] CONVOLVULUS or GREAT BINDWEED (*Calystegia silvatica) has much larger, longer leaves, and larger white flowers ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,42)

6 n. Calystegia tuguriorum.

COCKAYNE (1907,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island (And)]

6 n. Calystegia tuguriorum.

COCKAYNE Calystegia tuguriorum (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

COCKAYNE Calystegia tuguriorum (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

6 n.

BULLER The nest is a rather loose structure, ... sometimes interlaced with the wiry stems of the bush convolvulus, ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,95,[1888 2nd edn 1/90] ed.)

6 n.

Convolvulaceae Calystegia tuguriorum NZ convolvulus (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: (Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri)]

McLINTOCK New Zealand Convolvulus : pohue, pouwhiwhi, powhiwhi Calystegia tuguriorum (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

COCKAYNE (And) Calystegia tuguriorum (1915,AJHR,C-6) [NOTES: Notes on the Plant Covering of Kennedy's Bush ... Canterbury]

6 n.

WILLIAMS Panahi, n. 1. Calystegia sepium and C. soldanella; bindweed. Panake, n. Calystegia sepium; wild convolvulus. =poohue. (1971,Dictionary of the Maori Language,256)

6 n. Convolvulus erubescens.

LAING & BLACKWELL (1906,Plants of NZ) [NOTES: (And)]

6 n.

blue convolvulus [=] blue morning glory [s] Ibid. 15 convolvulus, blue [=] blue morning glory [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,6)

6 n.

RICHARDS Calystegia ... Soldanella ... Found only on the beach at the Chathams ... Beach Convolvulus. NIHI. (1952,Chatham Islands,40)

6 n.

convolvulus, greater [=] greater bindweed [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,15)

6 n. Convolvulus erubescens.

COCKAYNE (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

convoy cock¶

n.

SLATTER (1968,Pagan Game, The,70) [NOTES: see n.y.d.]

cooee¶

n.

CUNNINGHAM (1827,New South Wales,vol. ii. p. 23)

MORRIS ~ and interj. spelt in various ways. See quotations. A call borrowed from the aborigines and used in the bush by one wishing to find or to be found by another. In the vocabulary of native words in `Hunter's Journal,' published in 1790, we find ' Cow-ee to come.' (1898,Austral English,95)

R EEVES [In Canterbury c1850] The Australian coo-ee, the Australian buck-jumping horse, the Australian stockwhip and wideawake hat came into New Zealand pastoral life. (1898,Long White Cloud, The,242)

COO-EE - strange, strong, resonant sounding syllables. Oft has the heart of a weary traveller in the lonely bush beat with joy at its cheerful stabbing of the air. Across the wide wastes of desert, the remarkable sound carries. The hillsides of Gallipoli have resounded with it ... (Mar 15, 1918,Kia-ora Coo-ee,1/1,1981 ed.)

ANTHONY I sat up there for an hour before I thought of cooeeing for Gus. I heard Gus cooee back and then he came blundering through the darkness towards me. He had been rambling about since dusk looking for me under the impression that I was bushed. His last `Cooee' brought him within a chain of me, and when he heard me answer he started to go crook. (1927,Me and Gus) [NOTES: a1927 Anthony Me and Gus in 1977 Gus Tomlins 80]

Cooee: A call (described in [1898 Morris Austral-English]) The use of the cry seems to be dying out rather; but the word will probably survive in the expression not within cooee, meaning `nowhere near'. I have heard musterers who could not whistle use a cooee to stop their dogs. ([1874 Kennaway Crusts], p.68; [1857 Paul Letters from Canterbury], p.18; [1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

SCANLAN Just when they were giving up hope a faint `Cooee' caught their ear. (1933,Tides of Youth,76)

HYDE George gave a long cooee of warning from the higher hills. (1936,Passport to Hell,50)

cooee: cry or call adopted from Australia (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,173)

CHERRILL She was standing at the gate and gave me a coo-ee. (1950,Story of a NZ Sheepfarm,108)

~ A long-distance call adopted by Australian settlers from the natives; also used in New Zealand. `Within cooee' means within calling distance. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),96)

MASTERS I cupped my hands and cooeed. A few minutes later Margaret's responding cooee,[sic] was borne back to me on the still night air. (1960,Back-Country Tales,94)

~ n. call borrowed from aborigines, used in the bush by one wishing to find or be found by another: whence r.tr. to coose, and figuratively within cooee of, and not within coo-ee of within or not within possibity of success. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),613)

cooee ... n. bush hailing call [Abo.]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

cooee or cooey ... 2. Austral. & N.Z. inf. calling distance (esp. in within (a) cooee (of)). (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,246) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 162; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 104]]

n.

LAING & BLACKWELL With sunset the north-wester always lulls for a short time, and then its roar gives place to the coo-ee of the weka and the melancholy cry of the owl. (1907,Plants of NZ,132,1940, p. 136 ed.)

n. an outdoor call formerly often used as a signal to attract attention [ORIGIN: Aboriginal]

CHAMIER From his hidden retreat he sounded a loud "Coo-e!" (1891,Philosopher Dick,113)

SCOTT Returning to my camp, I gave several cooees. (1900,Tales of the Colonial Turf,203)

HOCHSTETTER In the dark bush, over hill and dale and in ravines which were once hushed in deathlike silence, the ringing of the axe, the creaking of the saw, and the far-sounding `cooey' of the wood-cutters are to be heard. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),148)

POLACK Tamaroa [a1,a2-acute] ... requested to carry me over. He would admit of no refusal, but ... we heard a native kuhi, or halloo, which came from two of our comrades who had halted here, to relieve Tamaroa [a1,a2-acute] carrying me. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/404) [NOTES: [spg kuhi, and attrib to Maori]]

TAYLOR [He] did not succeed in finding his way through the wood that when the natives heard his co-e they came straight to the spot where he was. (Nov 29, 1845,Journal,3/185)

RICHARDSON We gave the usual coo-oo-e, which was responded to without delay. (1854,Summer's Excursion,127)

KENNAWAY On Sunday, 22nd, I find [in my diary] - ... Just starting back to camp next morning, when faintcooee' [fn] heard, and human being seen slowly fording the river below us. [1874 fn] The well-known Australian and New Zealand native call. (1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,68) [NOTES: 1855 June 22 in 1874 Kennaway Crusts 68]

THOMSON [Auckland 1842] Two Australian customs had already taken root in the colony; one a beverage composed of brandy and ginger-beer, which was denominated a stone fence; the other a halloo used by settlers in shouting to people at a distance; the cry was coooe, the halloo or shriek of the Australian aborigines under similar circumstances. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,2/61)

BUTLER Two or three vigorous `Coo-eys' brought him down to the side of the creek which bounds my run upon one side. (Jun 1860,Forest Creek MS,40,1960 ed.)

BUTLER Now then for the Coo-ey'. This corresponds to our English Hoy! Halloa! but is infinitely more puzzling - for the Hoy and the Halloa are generally but preludes to an explicit expression in plain English of the wishes of the Hoyer or the Halloer to the Hoyee or Hallowee respectively. Coo-ey however is far more extended in its signification and is often expected to convey that signification in itself. Coo-ey can be heard for a very very long way - theCoo-' is dwelt on for some time and the `ey' is brought out sharp and quick in high relief as it were from the Coo - and at an unnaturally high pitch. It requires some courage to give vent to a Coo-ey at first; the first attempts are generally abortive, not to say rather doleful and at the same time ludicrous; by and by however as one gains confidence one's Coo-eys are more successful; my own at present is quite unimpeachable though in [46] England nothing would have induced me to give utterance to such a noise on any consideration. The butcher boy is coming up with the meat. He Coo-eys a long way off and by the time he has got up to the house the door is opened to receive the meat and he goes on his way rejoicing ... There I cooeyed and then the Irishman came down the terrace and met us. (Jun 1860,Forest Creek MS,45,1960 ed.)

HODDER Peter, who had kept some little distance, raised the native [?Maori] cry of `coo-ee!' (1862,Memories of NZ Life,15)

Just after this we heard a cooey close by & then saw a man put his head up out of the fern about 80 yards off - ... (Apr 6, 1864,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/102) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

In half an hour I heard a lusty co-hee up the river. Tim the head boatman had headed them [sc. runaway sheep]. The answering co-hees drew nearer on all sides .. (Nov 12, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,153,1950 ed.) [NOTES: [spg co-hee-->]]

LADY BARKER All too soon came a loud `coo---ee' from the house ... 1867Ibid 189 [The back-country bushman] called by a loud coo-ee to his man Sandy. (1866,Station Life in NZ,101,1874 ed.)

We gave a loud `coo-ee!' (colonial for yodel). (1869,NZ Alpine Journal,2/9/161) [NOTES: (M. Ross)]

MONEY ... we gave vent to coo'ee after coo'ee, which went pealing over the water and let the inhabitants understand that we were anxious to cross over as soon as possible. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,66)

TINNE A loud `cooee' brought the natives down to the ferry ... (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,22)

BAINES [I] 'cooed' [e umlaut] once - twice, when a prolonged coo-e! came back in reply from the mill. (1874,Edward Crewe,210)

Coo.ey } (k&omacr.&omacr.&ibreve.), v. i. [imp. & p. p. COOEYED or COO- Coo.ee } EED (k&omacr.&omacr.&ibreve.d); p. pr. & vb. n. COOEEYING, or COOEEING (k&omacr.&omacr.&ibreve.-&ibreve.ng)]. To call out cooee. See Cooey, n. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2020)

KOEBEL The latter gave vent to a sonorous "Coo-ee". (1905,Return of Joe,212)

ELKINGTON Suddenly we were startled by hearing a faint coo-ee. (1906,Adrift in NZ,259)

OTAGONIAN He then gave a long and shrill cooee. (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher,47)

A distressed cooey rang out. (Apr 5, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,19)

"Coo-ee, coo-ee", a call finding its origins perhaps in the hardy Australian whalers of a century ago, comes faintly down the wind. (Mar 1938,NZ Railways Magazine,12)

"Cooee! responded Hartly. (Dec 9, 1897,Otago Witness,46)

v. to cry out, to attract attention

We sat down and cooi-ed ... but without effect. ... still cooi-ing at intervals. (1843,Geographical Journal,186) [NOTES: 1843 NZ [Journal of Excursion to find a Route to ... Wairoo Valley]]

Turned out at daylight ... coo-ed and were heard by Mr Boswell and party ... (Sep 29, 1850,Torlesse Papers,169,1958 ed.)

TAYLOR ... at last we came to a fence, and cooing loudly were at last answered. 1864 Ibid. 12/127 ... someone cooed to me. (1850,Journal,7/124)

SIDEBOTTOM Mackenzie sprang up and began whistling and cooeing. (Mar 6, 1855,Letter) [NOTES: 1855 Mar 6 Sidebottom's letter in 1958 Gillespie South Canterbury (1971) 459]

After talking with him ... the dogs began to ko-hi. Upon being questioned what he was kohi-'ng for, he stated that `they were his mates,' but witness was not to be afraid, they would not hurt him. (Apr 18, 1855,Lyttelton Times,6)

LUSH I ... saw the Archdeacon near the beach, who seeing me `coo-ed': so I hastened on to him. (Jul 9, 1855,Auckland Journals,160,1971 ed.)

BUTLER Now then for the Coo-ey'. This corresponds to our English Hoy! Halloa! but is infinitely more puzzling - for the Hoy and the Halloa are generally but preludes to an explicit expression in plain English of the wishes of the Hoyer or the Halloer to the Hoyee or Hallowee respectively. Coo-ey however is far more extended in its signification and is often expected to convey that signification in itself. Coo-ey can be heard for a very very long way - theCoo-' is dwelt on for some time and the `ey' is brought out sharp and quick in high relief as it were from the Coo - and at an unnaturally high pitch. It requires some courage to give vent to a Coo-ey at first; the first attempts are generally abortive, not to say rather doleful and at the same time lucicrous; by and by however as one gains confidence one's Coo-eys are more successful; my own at present is quite unimpeachable though in [46] England nothing would have induced me to give utterance to such a noise on any consideration. The butcher boy is coming up with the meat. He Coo-eys a long way off and by the time he has got up to the house the door is opened to receive the meat and he goes on his way rejoicing ... There I cooeyed and then the Irishman came down the terrace and met us. (Jun 1860,Forest Creek MS,45)

BUTLER [They] decamped, assuring [the prisoners] that if they kept cooeying, some one would surely pass by in a few hours and let them go. (Sep 19, 1861,Letter) [NOTES: 1861 Sep 19 Butler letter in 1962 Family Letters of Samuel Butler 103]

People were cooheeing all over the plains last night, they lost their ways. (Aug 7, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,52,1950 ed.)

HAL;L-JONES We arrived at the brink of a sluggish river, and called, or rather coo'ee'd ... (1971,Mr Surveyor Thomson,30) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

SMALL Cooey here, cooey there, /Revelations, strange sensations: ... (1866,NZ & Australian Songster,12,1970 ed.)

... he `cooeyed' and the prisoner came down ... (Sep 7, 1867,Otago Witness,4) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

BARRINGTON Cooeyed all the way as I went, but got no answer. (May 4, 1864,Diary) [NOTES: 1864 May 4 Barrington Diary in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 410]

LUSH ... we ... had not gone far before the lad's sister came cooeing after us, ... (Jul 8, 1866,Waikato Journals,88,1982 ed.)

MONEY We `coo'ed' instantly, and after a few minutes were joined by one of Howitt's party, with sixty pounds of flour. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,29)

BUTLER I cooeyed to him, but he would not hear. (1872,Erewhon,[chapter IV])

[I] 'cooed' [e umlaut] once - twice, when a prolonged coo-e! came back in reply from the mill. (1874,Edward Crewe,210)

PRESHAW coo-ey (1888,Banking Under Difficulties) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

ANTHONY I sat up there for an hour before I thought of cooeeing for Gus. I heard Gus cooee back ... He had been rambling about since dusk looking for me under the impression that I was bushed. His last `Cooee' brought him within a chain of me, and when he heard me answer he started to go crook. (1927,Me and Gus) [NOTES: a1927 Anthony Me and Gus in 1977 Gus Tomlins 80]

MASTERS I cupped my hands and cooeed. A few minutes later Margaret's responding cooee,[sic] was borne back to me on the still night air. (1960,Back-Country Tales,94)

`Well, out of the boo-ai comes three trampers. ... They cooed out, ...' (Apr 19, 1971,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56) [NOTES: [trampers' use]]

BARKER The servants ... were setting out to look for us, `coo-eeing' as they came along. (1868,Station Life in NZ,235,1870 ed.)

HUNT I cooeed for the puntman but got no response. (1981,Speaking a Silence,66)

"H" I cooeed for the puntman but got no response. (1898,Grain of Gold, The,66)

People coo-eeing into your kitchen without so much as a knock; borrowing the patio chairs when you are absent at Christmas. (Apr 17, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45)

The pupils could be turned adrift in a piece of forest where they could get lost, and so learn to go round in a circle and "coo-e-e". (Mar 19, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

I coo-oo-ed... A distant voice comes cooo-ing over the hills. (Jan 27, 1852,ANZ Gazette,ns 170/87)

She went a little further and began to "cooee" and "holloa". (Apr 19, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,17)

Let them pause, and hear when nights arestill The other girl who coo-ees from"down under". (Dec 27, 1916,College Rhymes,I/9 : 199)

Wally Stretton.. coo-ee-d for the punt to be brought across. (Nov 18, 1924,Otago Witness,54)

v.

Extinct birds ... Laughing Owl Sceloglaux albifacies ... Apparently it was easily kept in captivity, and reports say that it cooeyed in the evening, yelped like a young dog and mewed and chuckled. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,308)

cooeeing¶

n. calling cooee

Mackenzie started up and began whistling and cooeeing. (Apr 14, 1855,Otago Witness) [NOTES: 1855 Apr 14 Otago Witness in 1937 Ayson Pioneering in Otago 49]

PAUL Cooeings - a sort of shriek, distinctly audible at a great distance. It is uttered by bush-travellers in Australia and New Zealand to indicate their whereabouts. (1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,18)

HAAST ... Dick ... could only maintain the direction in which he proceeded by our continual cooie-ing to him. (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,8)

MONEY While we were waiting we heard a `cooing' to our left, ... and presently a number of men appeared coming towards us ... (1871,Knocking About in NZ,71)

The art of cooeeing is probably not familiar to many New Zealanders, although the country will no doubt have backblocks exponents with considerable expertise ? (Aug 11, 1982,Evening Post,18)

heard shrill whistling and loud and prolonged coo-eeing proceeding from the river. (Jan 22, 1924,Otago Witness,7)

cook¶

n. a look (See also Captain Cook)

When I draw'd me wind, and wus walkin' aht/ In me slommicky 'orspital blue,/ I sights a tart, who gets me cart'/ Wiv aglad' wot bites me through./ ... We wus photograrfed, jest me an' 'er,/ 'Ere 'ave a cook at the proof.'/ Bill cooked' and saw RED. <i>(Jul 10, 1919,Quick March,17</i>) [NOTES: When I draw'd me wind, and wus walkin' aht/ In me slommicky 'orspital blue,/ I sights a tart, whogets me cart'/ Wiv a glad' wot bites me through./ ... We wus photograrfed, jest me an' 'er,/ 'Ere 'ave a cook at the proof.'/ Billcooked' and saw RED.]

n. the making of illicit drugs

"The most important variable is the knowledge of whoever is doing the cook," says Beal. (Apr 6, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

n. an illicit drug manufacturer (See also chef)

An essential guide for the most sophisticated cooks, named 'Sectrets of Methamphetamine Manufacture (3rd ed.) by Uncle Fester, is readily available on the net ... (Oct 2003,Investigate,p40)

"It would be fair to say that guy was the best cook we've ever seen," says Beal... According to Dave, prison is still the best cooking school. "For every cook they put in there, two or three come out with the knowledge of how to make [meth]. (Apr 6, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

The pharmaceutical industry also seems keen to stack the shelves with substances that can be easily converted by the many good "cooks" getting around the place. Some of these guys now have superstar status. (Apr 20, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

Mr Knowles said speed labs were relatively simple to set up, with drug "cooks" requiring rudimentary chemical knowledge and equipment, plus a quantity of over-the-counter medicines containing pseudoephredrine [sic]. (Sep 11, 2002,Dominion Post,A5)

Drug "cooks" are in high demand, and gangs have been known to recruit overseas cooks to set up the labs. But an experienced cook can find themselves chained to the job; a South Auckland cook was last year kidnapped three times by gang members. (Mar 23, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,2)

Police said that, in the hands of the right "cook", [pseudoephridine]could be turned into more than $1 million worth of the popular illegal drug. (Apr 24, 2003,Dominion Post,A3)

Cook Island¶

adj.

The Government has been urged to redefine the term Pacific Islander so more people can qualify for scholarships. Melanesian and Micronesian students are excluded from some grants. ... [The Pacific Island Education Foundation] says grants can only go to pupils of Samoan, Cook Island, Niuean, Tongan or Tokelauan descent. (Sep 16, 1988,Dominion,8)

Cook Island Maori¶

adj.

Geary Made a pilgrimage to the Spirit Rock, where she chatted with some old local Cook Island Maori guy about it being like our Cape Reinga. (2003,Man of the People, A,82)

Cook Island orange¶

n.

It should go a long way to re-establishing the Rarotonga and Cook Island orange ... (Jan 23, 1933,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/58) [NOTES: 1933 Jan 23 in 1988 Na To Hoa Aroha (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 3/58 (Ngata)]

Cook Islander¶

n.

Cook Islander native or inhabitant of the Cook Islands in the Pacific, (since 1965) a self-governing State in free association with New Zealand. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,162) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 105]]

CAMPBELL Are you a Maori?'No - a Cook Islander.' `Ah - a Coconut.' Ibid.128 Lofty was a thirty-year-old Australian, who has married a Cook Islander. (1989,Frigate Bird,71)

This will inaugurate a deliberate attempt to bring the Cook Islander closer to his New Zealand relative. (Jul 11, 1933,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/88,1988 ed.) [NOTES: Ngata]

Cook Medal/Cook's Medal¶

n.

FORSTER Capt Cook gave the old man a Medal & I gave one glass bead, the only thing we had about us.] (Apr 7, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/249)

FORSTER To conciliate their [sc. New Zealanders'] good will, we left some medals, looking-glasses, beads ... (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/132)

We found one of Cook's Medals amongst a heap of rubbish on Iron Island; it was a composite piece, of the size of a penny, on one side, was the head of George the Third, and the other was a representation of 2 ships & `Resolution and Adventure; sailed from England March 1772'. This I foolishly gave away for a trifle, (which I am sorry for as several of my friends would have liked to have had it). [fn] The idea for these brass medals to commemorate the voyage of the Resolution and Adventure came from Joseph Banks. Measuring 42mm in diameter they were struck by Matthew Boulton for the Admiralty (39, vol 2, p. xxix) and distributed to native people during the voyage (Plates 109 and 110). Cook left some of these medals in a Maori canoe on the beach at Cascade Cove in Dusky Bay in March 1773 (39, vol 2, p.113). The medal found by Boultbee fifty-three years later is the only one known to have been found in Dusky Bay (Plate 113). (1826,Boultbee Journal) [NOTES: 1826 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 164 Also 1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 54]

SUTHERLAND Cook Medals. ... The first medallic link between Great Britain and New Zealand was ... forged by Captain James Cook who arranged (in 1772), with [210] the approval of the Lords of the Admiralty, to strike silver, copper and brass medals bearing, on the obverse, a portrait of King George III, and on the reverse a representation of two sailing ships - Resolution and the Adventure - with which Cook was to undertake his second voyage of discovery. (1941,Numismatic History of NZ,209)

cook one's mutton¶

phr. (Rural, informal) to leave, scram [cf. hook one's mutton]

LOUGHNAN go and cook your mutton: tells someone to leave (mainly S.I.) (1981,Loughnan Glossary,7)

Cook Strait giant weta¶

n. (Environment) a large weta that is found on offshore islands of the Wellington and Marlborough areas bordering Cook Strait. [Deinacrida rugosa]

RARE INSECT: Six-year-old Rion Anderson of Ngaio showed no fear when he let a Cook Strait giant weta crawl all over his hands and face at wildlife sanctuary Zealandia. (21 January 2010) (Jan 21, 2010,Dominion Post,3)

Apart from feeding their new chicks with insects, such as darkling beetles or wire worms, they [takahe] tend to be herbivores, though they absolutely love Cook Strait giant weta. (Jan 13, 2007,Dominion Post,E9)

I once saw a takahe pluck a Cook Strait giant weta off a clump of long dry grass, whereupon a second takahe gave chase. (Jan 7, 2006,Dominion Post,E10)

Wellington giant weta and the Cook Strait giant weta have been introduced to the island [sc. Matiu/Somes] by the department and appear to be thriving. (Nov 24, 2004,Dominion Post,A12)

Mana Island is now a haven for several rare species, including the Cook Strait giant weta, the McGregor's skink and the goldstripe gecko. (Jan 28, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

Cook Strait blue penguin¶

n. (Environment)

10.b. Eudyptula minor variabilis Kinsky and Falla, 1976 Cook Strait Blue Penguin Central New Zealand ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,16,1980 ed.)

Blue Penguin Eudyptula minor (FORSTER, 1781) ENDEMIC Northern Blue Penguin E.m. iredalei MATHEWS, 1911. Cook Strait Blue Penguin E.m. variabilis KINSKY & FALLA, 1976. White-flippered Penguin E.m. albosignata FINSCH, 1874. Southern Blue Penguin E.m. minor (FORSTER, 1781). Chatham Island Blue Penguin E.m. chathamensis KINSKY & FALLA, 1976. OTHER NAMES: Little blue penguin, little penguin, fairy penguin, korara. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,46)

Cook Strait click beetle¶

n. a rare insect found on islands of the Cook Strait and Marlborough Sounds which can click a joint under its body to flick itself into the air to elude predators.

A rare insect to be found near the track, out to the World War II fortifications, is the Cook Strait click beetle. The Cook Strait click beetles have long lost their ability to click, so have to rely on their bark colouring to merge into the tree trunks from which they eat lichen and oozing sap. (Jan 13, 2007,Dominion Post,E9)

Cook Strait ferry¶

n. a New Zealand interisland ferry

"JOIDES Resolution" is slightly larger than a Cook Straight ferry. (Nov 1998,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,117/7)

Then there are the infamous Cook Strait ferries - there's a a good reason why the seagulls in the advertisment are facing into the wind at the bow. (Dec 10, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

Cook Strait striped gecko¶

n. A rare gecko found on Stephens and Maud Islands in Marlborough. [Hoplodactylus stephensi Cook Strait populations aka striped gecko]

Cook Strait Striped GeckoDescription: Looks very similar to the Goldstripe Gecko, brown with paler stripes. Distribution: Stephens and Maud Islands in the Marlborough Sounds. (Aug 2008,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.reptiles.org.nz/index.php?page=Stephensi]

Cook Strait Striped Gecko: .. Description: Light beige to dark tan, with broad, pale smooth-edged stripes that may be dull or bright but are always obvious. (2009,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.conservation.org.nz/conservation/native-animals/reptiles-and-frogs/species-information/atlas-of-the-amphibians-and-reptiles-of-nz/electronic-atlas/atlas-details/?SpeciesID=13185]

The Cook Strait striped gecko Hoplodactylus stephensi "Cook Strait" is listed in the 2005 New Zealand Threat Classification System as 'Range Restricted', found only on Stephen's Island and Maud Island. (2007,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.terranature.org/geckoCoroStriped.htm]

Cook's giant weta¶

n. (Environment) a type of weta.

The Cook's Giant weta doesn't bite, the smaller Wellington tree weta does. (Sep 20, 2005,NZ Herald,D8)

cook's offsider¶

n. almost a catchphrase for a kitchen hand; often used joc.; cf offsider, slushy.

MILLER I missed, being cook's offsider, whose principal job is to collect wood. (1939,Camps, Tramps and Trenches,144) [NOTES: 1917 Sep 27 in 1939 Miller Camps, Tracks and Trenches 144]

SLATTER ... a man, chatting amiably with a joker who could have been a cook's offsider ... (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,147)

HARPER The [station] cook's offsider ... was a gullible chap and the boys often played practical jok (1975,Eight Daughters,56)

Cooks (offsiders) aGBP2 per week ... cooks aGBP3 per week for 30 boarders, and 1s per week extra for each boarder up to 40, over 40 an "offsider" to be employed. (Jul 18, 1914,Evening Post,14)

Cook's petrel¶

n.

.. as well as illustrations of Cook's petrel, the native merganser, and the peculiar little rail Cabalus would have added to the value of the book ... (Jul 4, 1889,Otago Witness,23)

He appends the following list of birds to be found on the Little Barrier in support of his statement .. Cook's petrel ... (Nov 16, 1892,Colonist (Nelson),3)

I became personally acquainted with the black petrel (Majaqueus parkinsoni) and Cook's petrel (Oestrelata cooki) ... (1908,TrNZI,40/503)

BULLER PROCELLARIA {OESTRELATA} COOKII. (COOK'S PETREL.) ... {Native name.- Titi.} (1873,Birds of New Zealand,307,1888 2nd edn 2/217 ed.)

44. Pterodroma [cookii cookii] (Gray, 1843) Cook's petrel (Titi) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,24,1980 ed.)

FALLA et al. COOK'S PETREL Pterodroma cooki Maori name: Titi (1966,Birds of New Zealand,52)

Cook's Petrel Pterodroma cookii GRAY, 1843) ... OTHER NAME: Titi. ... [81] Many yearsago, adult and young Cook's petrels were taken for food by Maoris. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,80)

Cook's petrel is grey and white. (Feb 26, 1924,Otago Witness,6)

At night.. these birds chase each other all over the sky in courting display, the Cook's petrel uttering a rapid "ti-ti-ti" while the larger black petrel voices a "purring" note. (Apr 27, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,38)

Cook's petrel and the rare black petrel arrive in spring to breed. (Nov 8, 1993,Evening Post,21)

About 8.:15 the petrel (Cook's) commenced to come in from the sea in their thousands filling the air with their cries of ti-ti-ti, the swish of their wings sounding like the surge of a distant waterfall rising and falling irregularly as the birds drop from a higher altitude to the level of the gorge. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/24) [NOTES: W M Hamilton's 1932 journal in NZ Geographic]

Conservator Rob McCallum said the extermination of rats would lead to a dramatic return of some wildlife, including tuatara. lizards, insects, giant weta and Duvaucel's gecko, and a threatened burrowing seabird, the Cook's petrel... "The most dramatic comeback will be from Cook's petrel," Mr McCallum said. (Jun 11, 2004,Dominion Post,A7)

The initiative follows DoC's successful eradication of kiore - the indigenous rat - from Little Barrier Island, which has allowed tuatara, giant weta, skinks and Cook's petrel to thrive again. (Jun 12, 2006,NZ Herald,A3)

They generally went in a north-west direction in small flocks, especially Cook's petrel. (Nov 8, 1905,Otago Witness,84)

Cook's scurvy grass¶

n. (Environment) Lepidium oleraceum (var) acutidentatum a plant said to be used by Captain Cook as antiscorbutic greens [Captain Cook's crest, scurvy grass. A rare plant, Lepidium oleraceum, with celery-like leaves, used by James Cook as a fresh green to combat scurvy. Loosely used, the term scurvy grass covers a range of brassicaceous herbs in New Zealand, but the specific Lepidium oleraceum, now endangered, was in plentiful supply in the time of Cook's visits.] (See scurvy grass)

CROWE Cook's Scurvy Grass Lepidium oleraceum nau... It was once common, but is now fairly rare partly due to grazing by stock, and perhaps partly to the appetite of the cabbage white butterfly. Ibid. As its common name suggests, the plant was however used by Captain Cook as a remedy for scurvy, a disease caused by lack of vitamin C in the diet. (1997,Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,75)

In the 1770s it was a lifesaver, hence the name, Cook's scurvy grass/nau. (Jun 2007,Conservation Action,14)

KIRK (1899,Students' Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

CHEESEMAN [Lepidium oleraceum] Best known as `Cook's scurvy-grass'. The whole plant has a heavy disagreeable smell and hot biting taste. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,39)

(1909,AJHR,C-12) [NOTES: (And)Cockayne Botanical Survey Stewart Island]

COCKAYNE (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story)

Another significant plant recovery projectis the strong-smelling native herb, nau,or Cook's scurvy grass (Lepidiumoleraceum). (Feb 9, 1996,Dominion,11)

A new population of a rare species of Cook's scurvy grass has been found at Cape Young on the northern coast of Chatham Island. (May 2004,Footnotes,No. 21/8)

Cook also made his men eat New Zealand native celery and a green-leafed plant that came to be known as Cook's Scurvy Grass. (Jun 2004,North & South,32)

Cook's scurvy grass is described as a bushy, leafy, aromatic herb that grows up to a metre tall. It releases a strong smell of cabbage when crushed. (Dec 3, 2005,Dominion Post,B16)

Here and there patches of Captain Cook's scurvy-grass (Lepidium oleraceum) were growing vigorously on the highly-manured ground. (1891,TrNZI,23 : 412)

Cook's scurvy-grass Lepidium oleraceum var. acutidentatum. (1925,TrNZI,57 : 919)

[Caption] Rare Cook's scurvy grass discovered A CROP of endangered plant nau, or Cook's scurvy grass, has been found on remote Waikato islet. (Oct 17, 2006,Dominion Post,A7)

(1912,TrNZI,44/)

LOCKE Some time during that botany year Kath Mays and I searched the Lion Rock at Piha for Cook's scurvy grass, which our lecturer Mr Lancaster said could be found there. (Since Captain Cook's time, cattle and sheep had made a clear sweep of that cress, Lepidium, in accessible places.) (1981,Student At The Gates,72)

(Oct 31, 1952,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 1952 Oct 31 2ZB Nature Session (Reference to Marlborough Sounds)]

RICHARDS LEPIDIUM ... oleraceum ... The famous Cook's scurvy grass is 10-24 in. high ... Found on rocky shores here and in New Zealand ... [30] Cook's Scurvy Grass. NAU, EKETERA. (1952,Chatham Islands,29)

MOORE & IRWIN LEPIDIUM OLERACEUM, Cook's scurvy grass. The most famous and now perhaps the least common of New Zealand crucifers. [see Cook 27 Oct 1769] (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,40)

BROOKER et al. Lepidium oleraceum Forst.f. Common name: Cook's scurvygrass ri name: (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,48)

WILSON Lepidium oleraceum COOK'S SCURVY GRASS ... Nau ... Erect or bushy hairless herb up to a half a metre tall ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,140)

Letidium oleraceum] A rare herb known as Cook's scurvy grass, thought to have vanished from the South Island, has been found in the Moeraki area near Oamaru. (Dec 11, 1984,Press, The,25)

Today DOC will head out to Somes Island with a new batch of plants grown from Wellington captive breeding populations, including the critically endangered cook scurvy grass. (Aug 13, 2001,Evening Post,25)

An example of a medicinal plant, which had been thought nearly extinct, has been found on one of the Sugar Loaf Islands off New Plymouth. The plant, Cook's scurvy grass, was found on Saddle-back Island by a group ... doing a survey of life on the offshore island. ... the specimen found was in flower. ... The plant was used by Captain James Cook to feed his scurvy-suffering crew ... (Oct 2, 1973,Dominion,4/9-10)

BURTON [=NAU] A voyager on Cook's third voyage in Discovery in 1772, Dr Sparrman, notes that `the green stuffs which were cooked with pease and broth or used as salads, consisted of wild celery (Apium prostratum), wild spinach (Tetragonia expansa) and Cook's scurvy grass (Lepidum oleraceum).' The last mentioned, known as nau by the Maori, has nowadays been virtually eaten out of existence by sheep and cattle. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,16)

SANSOM Herekopare and Woman's Island are the only two beneficiary muttonbird islands. All the rest are Crown lands. ... I know ... that the fierce nettle also grows on Herekopare. Other lovely ... plants are there too - the Stewart Island yellow senecio, teteaweka of course, ... Cook's health-giving scurvy grass, soft native tatahi grass and punui, the giant-leafed umbrella-like araliad. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,69)

LOCKE Some time during that botany year Kath Mays and I searched the Lion Rock at Piha for Cook's scurvy grass, which our lecturer Mr Lancaster said could be found there. (Since Captain Cook's time, cattle and sheep had made a clear sweep of that cress, Lepidium, in accessible places.) (1981,Student At The Gates,72)

[Letidium oleraceum] A rare herb known as Cook's scurvy grass, thought to have vanished from the South Island, has been found in the Moeraki area near Oamaru. (Dec 11, 1984,Press, The,25)

(1774,Voyage to the Pacific Ocean, A)

(1891,TrNZI)

(1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/) [NOTES: (Andersen 7 entries)]

Cook's tea-tree¶

n.

MYRTLE FAMILY. Cook's Tea tree, Scrub Manuka, or Kahikatoa (Leptospermum scoparium). (1869,TrNZI,1/III/32) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Cook's Tourists¶

n. members of the Second Echelon, NZEF, WWII

HAYDON These are the experiences of a soldier of the Second Echelon, 2NZEF, the `Cook's Tourists.' The name was bestowed on them by envious members of the First and Third Echelons, who languished among the Wogs and smells of Egypt. (1941,NZ Soldiers in England,4)

HENDERSON Bronzed, fit, wide open spaces, boy scout hats, wristlet watches,' quote Second Echelon chaps, sniggering about some English journalist's impression of these New Zealanders during their brief stay in England. The Second Echelon areCook's Tourists'. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,261)

McGILL Cook's Tourists Second Echelon. 2NZEF, WWII, because they went to Britain. [Jim Henderson] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,30)

I went away with the "wife-beaters" and "debt-dodgers". The people who went in the Second Echelon were known as "Cook's Tourists." (1961,NZ Parliamentary Debates,326:122)

Cook's turban shell¶

n. a univalve mollusc shaped like a turban.

cookaroo/cookeroo¶

1 n. (Rural) a (novice) station cook.

NEWTON As for [station] cooks _ well there were cooks, cookees, and cookeroo bastards. That was what one of them told us anyway _ and, needless to add, he was a cook. (1973,Big Country,196,1977 ed.)

NEWTON I'm the cook. there are cooks, cuckoos and cookaroos. (1964,Straggle Muster,86)

ANDERSON I couldn't help thinking to myself that if Charlie was such a cookaroo perhaps it was just as well, as it would have been a waste of good turkeys. (1976,Water Joey,27)

ANDERSON There's cooks and cookaroos and wilful bloody murderers who choke good blokes to death with their rotten food. (1976,Water Joey,81)

BRITTAIN Station cooks are important, and are said to have been classified variously as cooks, cookoos, cookeroos, and cookeroo bastards. [cookeroo; cuckoo] (2000,Lake Coleridge,85)

cookee¶

n.

GRACE A great chief like you ought not to be afraid of a mere Queen's servant (cookie) like Donald McLean. (1899,Sketch of the NZ War,67)

n. a slave in Maori society.

NICHOLAS He held no rank among his countrymen, but was one of the [115] common men, or what they themselves call cookee, ... with a pleasing countenance. (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),114)

CRUISE ... saying, `that if it were the child of a rungateeda, or gentleman, it should be laid in tabbooed ground, and every funeral rite paid to it; but that a cookee could not be allowed even the decency of burial, ... Ibid.1823 p. 181 There is a striking difference between the rungateedas, that is, the chiefs ... and those who are by birth cookees, or slaves. (1823,Journal,87,1957 ed.) [NOTES: 1820 Apr 26 in 1823 Cruise Journal (1957) 87]

BUTLER It may be seen that Shunghee has become so intolerably insolent since his return from England, that he not only comes into our place without leave himself, but on his account the verycookeys' are saucy to the last degree! (Sep 5, 1821,Letter) [NOTES: 1821 Sep 5 John Butler in 1927 (?1977) Earliest New Zealand (ed Barton) 172]

Tarboka had taken a woman as his cookie or slave Ibid. 196 .... Price, who spoke but little of the language, told the natives Capt K was a tourikka or cookie and that he was of no note etc. (1827,Boultbee Journal) [NOTES: 1827 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 189]

POLACK Slaves are also termed kuki; from the English word cook. (1828,New Zealand (Polack),2/110)

McNAB They are divided into two classes, viz., ranghateeroos (or chiefs) and their relations of different degrees of consanguinity, and cookees (slaves), who are nearly black, and much shorter, and appear a different race of people. (1908,Historical Records,1/696) [NOTES: 1829 Mar 2 Atkins's Narrative in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/696]

CRAIK Cookee ... is the term generally used for a slave, in recent accounts of New Zealand; but it does not appear whether it is a native word or a formation from the English `cook' - a profession which the New Zealanders hold in greatest comtempt and look upon as only for slaves. Ibid. 236 ... when cookees die they perish for ever . (1830,New Zealanders, The,52fn)

MARKHAM You may see the Cookee [kuki] or Slave [38] doing that, and throwing it to the Chief or Rangitara [rangatira] or his Wife. [fn] Merely a Maori form of the English cook'. Polack gives this explanation ... [NZ 2/110-111]. <i>Ibid.</i> 81 A Mourie Slave or Cookee named(More Prower)' [Mauparaoa] or Carrier of the Whale bone, had stolen a Boat ... (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),37)

Tarboka had taken a woman as his cookie or slave, ... when he asked her to sing, which she declined, on this in the wantonness of his anger, he dispatched her with a tomahawk. (1835,Boultbee Journal,71,1986 ed.)

(Duppa) ... cooke or slave. (1840,NZ Journal,1/17/221)

... a British subject, named McGregor ... had suddenly disappeared ... taking with him some of this chief's women and kookis (slaves); ... (1841,GBPP,(No.311) 107) [NOTES: 1840 June 28 Thomas Bunbury's Report in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 107]

POLACK The term of Cookee is incorrect for that of a slave; this word is derived from the word cook, an office on board British ships, accounted as only fit for a slave by the New Zealanders - hence the term. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/25fn)

HODGSKIN The native inhabitants are divided into three classes - 1st, the chiefs; 2ndly, freemen; 3rdly, cookees [orig. has ???coohees] or slaves. (1841,Narrative of Eight Months Sojourn in NZ, A,18)

WAKEFIELD The fourth [word for slave] kuki is probably only a corruption from the `cook' on board ship. (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/382)

ANGAS Black Charley' the Australian [aborigine] ... always exhibited the most violent signs of fear whenever any of the natives came on board the schooner, fully expecting they would purchase him for acooky,' or slave, to be killed and eaten. (1847,Savage Life,I/280)

EARP ... according to New Zealand notions of rank he being the highest in the scale, and his tormentor being regarded as a cookee, or slave, the lowest. (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),50)

HENDERSON ... the tohunga made it ...tapu, so that the kukis, taurekarekas, tutuas, and other varieties of slaves ... would be afraid to meddle. (1948,Taina,26)

CRUISE George ran upon the deck in a most furious passion, with a musket in his hand to shoot one of his cookees, who he said had stolen some bread from him. (1823,Journal of Ten Months' Residence in NZ,182)

The natives shrewdly observed that he was the only Rangatira, or gentleman, among them and that the rest were only cookees or slaves. (1839,New Zealand in 1839,30)

cooker¶

n. a hot day, a scorcher

DAVIS `Bit of a cooker up on deck now. Better strip off a bit like. ...' (1964,Watersiders,33)

Cooker¶

n. ellipt. for Captain Cooker [ca1940 Havelock =Captain Cooker]

STUDHOLME After being ripped by a pig, and subsequently recovering, most dogs soon dropped to the fact that some of these old `Cookers' should be approached with caution and treated with due respect, ... (1940,Te Waimate,258,1954 ed.)

cookered¶

adj. Euphemism for buggered?

The paper won't be tackling the NZ Herald. "We'd be absolutely cookered in competition with a metropolitan daily." (Sep 7, 1997,Sunday Star Times,D3)

Cookham boots¶

n. strong outdoor (?working) boots (See cf. O'Briens; Harry Pannells)

Softgoods, and hard, and holloware,/ With Stringers buns and toffees;/ And Cookham's famous boots are there,/ So is the Union Office. (1866,Canterbury Rhymes,76) [NOTES: 1860 Apr in 1866 Canterbury Rhymes 76]

LADY BARKER I took off my Cookhams and worsted socks at each ford. (1872,Christmas Cake in Four Quarters,Ch iii)

LADY BARKER [The bushmen's] working dress of red flannel shirt, and moleskin trousers, Cookham' boots, and diggers' plush hats ... [209] ...Cookham' boots, (great heavy things with nails in the soles). (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,15)

HINGSTON Here and there, over [Christchurch] shops, one sees this mysterious inscription, `Cookham Boots' - only that, and nothing more. ... We found that a peculiar boot supplied by a particular place in England was best appreciated in this southern city of the saints. (1879,Australian Abroad, The,320)

McNEISH It was necessary for Mackenzie to remain in Christchurch until the celebrations ended, for he needed a new pair of Cookham boots, size ten. (1970,Mackenzie,58)

cookhouse¶

n. the kitchen on a ship

No passenger shall go to the ship's cook-house without special permission from the master, nor remain in the forecastle among the sailors on any account. (Jun 13, 1853,NZ Government Gazette,1/9/56) [NOTES: 1853 June 13 NZGG 1/9/56 (Order-in-Council of 16 October 1852 at the Court of Windsor) 22.]

n. the cooking shed of a pa or kainga; the kitchen building on a marae

ANGAS The cook-house [of a kainga] is merely a shed, built of posts or slabs of wood placed several inches apart, so as to admit the air and wind, ... (1847,Savage Life,1/332)

ANGAS In each court [yard of a pa] stands the house and cook-house, as well as the elevated `pakuta,' or store for food, of one of the families. (1866,Polynesia,153)

In many places, the tribal meeting-house stands alone or flanked by a solitary cook-house, patiently awaiting until a death or some object of great moment shall for a brief period draw its people together under its sheltering roof. (1924,TrNZI,55/367) [NOTES: (Buck `Passing of the Maori')]

n. the kitchen of a station or men's camp

The cookhouse is steamed up - Jane has been preparing dinner for hours. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/92)

IHIMAERA & LONG (ed.) She had made herself a cook-house with some corrugated iron and a fireplace of stones from the beach. (1982,Into the World of Light,83)

Ancillary buildings including a manager's house, a carpenter's shop, a cookhouse and a bunkhouse were built. (Feb 2000,NZ Historic Places,76/23)

A dozen of the men were on the roof of the cookhouse. (Feb 23, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,8)

One day he wuz carried into the cook-house all of a heap. (1900,Auckland Weekly News,19)

1 n. (Rural) a cookshop on a station, at an outstation or camp where meals are cooked for single hands.

LEE I caught up with the station cookhouse myself. (1977,Roughnecks, Rolling stones & Rouseabouts,28)

cookhouse boy¶

1 n. (Rural) a single worker or whare boy on a station, fed by the station cook.

ECCLESTON The cookhouse boys seemed to thrive on the things that he supplied. (1977,Irish Kiwi,96)

cookie/cooky¶

n. (See cookee)

cooking fly¶

n.

McCASKILL and the cooking fly had to be inspected. (1969,Molesworth,100)

Cooks, the¶

n. abbrev or ellipt. for the Cook Islands. [?Omit, as a usual construction.]

cookshop¶

n. a station or camp cookhouse

OVERTON In the cookhouse was a colonial oven and a camp oven, with a small table on which the meals were dished up; with a few forms for seating accommodation. (1949,Fifty Years Sheep Farming,47)

ST LEONARD'S STATION Rum and plum duff at the cook shop. (Jan 1, 1857,Diary) [NOTES: 1857 Jan 1 Diary of St Leonard's Station in 1946 Macfarlane Amuri 123]

WOODHOUSE To jump out o' bed in darkness, and go trampin' through the snow,/ To the cook-shop for yer breakfast as the cocks begin to crow;/ (1950,Farm & Station Verse,45) [NOTES: c1890-1900 Thompson `Another Station Ballad' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 45]

THOMPSON ... go trampin' through the snow,/ To the [station] cook-shop for your breakfast .../ (1909,Ballads about Business,44)

Cookshop: Kitchen and dining room where station hands' food is cooked and eaten. It is sometimes a separate building, sometimes part of the men's hut. ([c1890-1910].) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

STUDHOLME They [swaggers] generally arrived at the homestead in the evening, and were given some food at the cook shop, ... (1940,Te Waimate,216,1954 ed.)

NEWTON ... they were also to collect tucker-box and billy from the cook-shop. (1940,High Country Days,19)

MEEK COOKSHOP: Where the meals are cooked and served out for the men. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

NEWTON ... he took us across to the cookshop to meet the boys and have a meal. (1952,High Country Journey,85)

STRONACH The cookshop was an old army hut, and this morning there was a pile of snow that had come in through the ridge of the roof down the middle of the table. We cooled our tea by placing the pannikins in it. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,8)

McLAGLAN The schoolmaster's house had been co-opted as a cookshop and hostel for the volunteer nurses (1965,Stethoscope & Saddlebags,147)

BARRY The single mens' tents, and the cookshop, must have formed quite a little settlement near the stream. (1966,In the Lee of the Hokonuis,280)

NEAVE Later, traction engines [for threshing] ... had their own galley and cook, and it was a great sight to see engine, mill, water-cart and dog box - a two wheeled hut. The boss and Water Joey slept near the machinery to be handy to get up steam in the morning, and then get the cookshop going. (1980,Land of Munros, The,90)

HUNT ... at the Cobb [hydro] they went and put in a flash new cookshop ... (1981,Speaking a Silence,85)

WHEELER [caption] Remains of the cookshop and bunkhouse in `Cookshop Gully'. (1982,Historic Sheep Stations of NZ,59)

cook-shop n. NZ cookhouse or kitchen on sheep station. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,162) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

OGONOWSKA-COATES Cookshop. Kitchen/dining room. Often these two rooms were combined and the shearers ate at tables at one end of the kitchen. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,95)

George and Mrs. Walker run the "cook shop." (Jul 25, 1928,NZ Free Lance,7)

The "bush express", which consists of one carriage known as the "pie-cart" and a light locomotive, leaves the cookshop daily at 7.15 a.m. (Jul 25, 1928,NZ Free Lance,7)

NEWTON Old Alf and young Ron were the only two at the cookshop. Ibid. 130 They tuckered at the cookshop and while they were there the boys lived like kings. (1966,Boss's Story, The,123)

Building at Kuriheka of the stables, the cookshop and the drawing room (now the oldest part of the homestead) began after the marriage. (May 1996,NZ Historic Places,58/18)

THOMPSON Ain't it lovely in the mornin', ere thesun begins to shine,..To jump out o' bed in darkness, and gotrampin' through the snow,To the cook-shop for yer breakfast as thecocks begin to crow. (1909,Ballads about Business,44)

THOMPSON Once I heard a fellow tellAbout a sheep that sometime fellInto a creek where it soon diedThen to the cook-shop was supplied. (1909,Ballads about Business,53)

1 n. (Rural) a cookhouse on a station, at a dog-trial course, at an outstation or camp [often on runners or wheels so as to be mobile.]

Rum and plum duff at the cookshop. (Jan 1, 1857,St Leonard's Station Diary,123) [NOTES: in Macfarlane (1946) Amuri]

NEWTON .. the cowboy was tuckering at the cookshop on his own. (1964,Straggle Muster,87)

STAPLES The large woolshed with its many port-holes was passed before we pulled up at the door of the cookshop. (1964,Cooks and Shepherds Come Away,10)

Every trial has a cookshop, run by local women, who'll always provide something very edible. (Nov 1987,NZ Journal of Agriculture,48)

STACEY We went to live in the quarters attached to the cook shop. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,29)

HOLDEN Best of all, Midget liked to visit the shearers' cookshop. (2001,Riding Country,57)

cool chamber¶

n.

The question of cool chambers on board ship.. is also all-important to the success of the industry in New Zealand. (Oct 30, 1890,Otago Witness,7)

I omitted the mention of a cool-chamber, with refrigerating plant. (1898,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,VI : 59)

Suppl. 6 [The carcases] were sent gliding smoothly to the cooling chamber. (Feb 2, 1900,Auckland Weekly News)

cool one's elbow¶

phr. to have a drink (in a bar)

FULLARTON I'm cooling my elbows on the bar. (1944,Troop Target,26)

cool store¶

n.

MEETING OF CHEESE AND BUTTER MAKERS The following telegram from Mr J. D. Ritchie, secretary of the Agricultural department, Wellington, to Mr J. Sawers, was read :-" Shipping companies, through Agent-general, recommend all produce being placed in cool store for say fortnight previous to shipment. Consult conference, and find out what would be considered reasonable charge for private owners of cool stores to make." (Aug 18, 1892,Otago Daily Times,4)

Unlike mutton which goes into a cool store, thence to the consumer, butter is placed upon the market at once and enters immediately into consumption. It is therefore imperative, if our butter is to secure and maintain a high standard of price, that this detail in connection with the shipping arrangements should receive attention. (Oct 16, 1901,Ohinemuri Gazette,2)

LONDON, 24th November. By the Rotorua last Monday there arrived the second shipment of 1626 cases of New Zealand eggs. .. The temperature in the cool store on board was kept at the same level as in the case of the Corinthic shipment (34 degrees), and this was maintained with practically no variation throughout the voyage. (Jan 3, 1924,Evening Post,3)

If you have a cool store, rubbing with salt will be unnecessary, provided the bacon has been properly cured. (Sep 24, 1886,Otago Witness,18)

cool to korero¶

phr. a schools programme promoting the speaking of Maori

David Geary And, yeah, Gary wasn't that confident in his Maoritanga way back then, when it wasn't so cool to korero. (2008,Six Pack 3, The,109)

Cool to korero cruises to the different kura around the motu .. (2005,Te Mana Taiohi,1,Spring ed.)

CoolCap¶

n. a head-cooling device for babies

A head-cooling device designed in New Zealand has become the first treatment to successfully prevent brain damage in oxygen-deprived newborn babies. An International trial of the CoolCap, developed by Auckland University's Liggins Institute, has shown the device significantly reduced the rate of death and disability in babies asphyxiated in the birth process. (May 7, 2004,Dominion Post,A7)

cooley¶

n. a Maori

WALKER ... we took advantage of a lift into C.C. [Christchurch] The cart was driven by a cooley, [20] we could not understand him and he could not understand us. (Oct 19, 1862,Journal and Letters (Walker))

coolstore¶

v. to keep in a coolstore

...this is a good time to buy up gold or green kiwifruit as it becomes coolstored now. (Jun 24, 2004,Dominion Post,D5)

cooma-cooma¶

n. (See kamokamo)

coon¶

n. a Pacific Islander. Rarely applied to a Maori: occas. used c1890-1920 in the name of nigger minstrel' type groups: e.g. Wellington ?dateKaraka Koons'.

coon: Maori or Islander (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

`The head doorman explained the rules to me as no jeans, no people who were drunk and no coons, which I knew meant no Pacific Islanders. I discussed the rule with another bouncer who asked me if I had been told the same thing,' he said. (Jun 15, 1987,Evening Post,3)

Newly graduated police officers talking about "darkies" and "coons". (Mar 14, 1999,Sunday Star Times,A6)

n. (Rural) a possum hunters' term for the possum Trichosurus vulpecula.

MARSHALL Possum hunters have many more euphemistic terms for Trichosurus vulpecula. eg coon, jacko or monkey. (1984,Possum Hunting in New Zealand,1)

Coopdale¶

1 n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred sheep [result of a cross between Coopworth and Perendale breeds.]

A new breed of sheep 'Coopdale' is making its presence felt in Mid-South Canterbury and North Otago. There was a lot of country there suitable for the Coopdales - "they combine the hardiness of the Perendale with the production of the Coopworth." (Sep 28, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,21)

Across these, Coopworth x Perendale or 'Coopdale' rams are being used. Contained within total ewe numbers are 600-700 recorded stud ewes - Coopworth, Coopdales and some Texels. (2002,Wool Grower,Spring 18)

cooper's flag¶

n. raupo

BAYLY After breakfast the Surgeon & myself with three Midshipmen & the Ships Cooper went in a small cutter to some Bays near the ship to get flags for the Coopers use & what greens we could. (Dec 17, 1773,Journal) [NOTES: 1773 Dec 17 Bayly's Journal in 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/217]

McNAB [Cargo from NZ] 10 logs of timber, 890 rickers, 165 handspikes, 13 casks of black whale oil, ... 3 tons flax, 86 bundles coopers' flags, ... [consigned to George Weller]. (1913,Old Whaling Days,102) [NOTES: 1834 Apr 26 Log Lucy Ann: Cargo in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 102]

JOLLIE Raupo, a sort of Cooper's flags. (1879,Reminiscences,57)

MORRIS Coopers'-flag ... another name in New Zealand for Raupo. (1898,Austral English,97)

Coopworth¶

n. a breed of sheep bred for wool and meat emulating Border Romney developed by Professor Ian Coop (b. 1914)

Coopworth n. NZ breed of sheep farmed for meat and wool. [I. E. Coop zoologist] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,163) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 105]]

This year.. has produced 18 splotchy dark chocolate-coloured crossbred offspring, a mixture of Romnney, coopworth and Border Leicester stock, which they are selling for between $200 and $350 each. (Oct 30, 2002,Dominion Post,C3)

Crucial to his success are his Coopworth sheep, which he has farmed since the early 70s, shortly after the breed was first released by its creator, Professor Ian Coop. (Sep 26, 2003,Dominion Post,C10)

"In 1968, farmers using border cross rams formed a society, and chose the name Coopworth." It was a radical move. Coopworth stud breeders had to record everything, and select strictly on performance. (Oct 9, 2003,Dominion Post,C8)

Coopworths are bred for easy-care characteristics. (Sep 30, 2004,Dominion Post,C10)

1 n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred sheep [developed during the 1950s and 1960s from the Border Leicester and Romney breeds, named after Professor Ian Coop.]

KERR In honour of Professor Coop of Lincoln College, they named it 'Coopworth.' (1976,From the Beginning: chronicles of a county,143)

Coopworths cut 4lb of wool off (the fleece weights of progeny of) any Romney they're put over and endanger meat production by encouraging Omega grade lambs. (Sep 13, 1973,NZ Farmer,9)

WARMAN The Coopworth, like the Perendale, belongs to the new generation of New Zealand bred sheep. (1991,What Sheep is that?,24)

MEADOWS The Coopworth has been remarkably successful in New Zealand where it has become the second most popular breed. (1997,Sheep Breeds of New Zealand,35)

coot¶

n.

PARKINSON We found here [Poverty Bay] a sort of long-pepper, which tasted very much like mace; a Fulica, or bald Coot, of a dark blue colour; and a Black-bird, the flesh of which was of an orange colour, and tasted like stewed shell-fish. (Oct 11, 1769,Journal,89)

PASCOE Some people call [the pukeko] the coote, from some fanciful resemblance to the water hen of the Old Country. Swamp hen it is generally called in Westland, ... (1957,Mr Explorer Douglas,234) [NOTES: c1899 Douglas Birds of South Westland in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 234]

n. in NZ in fig. or proverbial use for a foolish, clumsy, or bald person as silly as, clumsy as, bald as a coot, or with other depreciatory or contemptuous application to a person of no account

BOLITHO ... a bit of a coot, isn't he. (1927,Solemn Boy,46)

SMYTH You're a clumsy coot. (1929,Girl from Mason Creek, The,17)

CRUMP He must be chronic', said Bob.... I wouldn't put up with a shiftless coot like that for five minutes. (1962,One of Us,49)

DUFF `Sport! These coots never heard of sport! I wouldn't mind if they were shooting ducks.' (May 20, 1951,Shepherd's Calendar,32,1961 ed.)

MEEK COOT: A blockhead; mug; a silly coot. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

McCALLUM If its not the pakeha coot from up the road, its the wife's brother ... or the missus. [very frequent in these stories, as is joker] (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,1)

MASON We saw you talkin' to that Firpo coot. (1970,End of the Golden Weather, The,78) [NOTES: 2nd edition]

ANDERSON "Crazy as a coot," said the shearer. (1976,Water Joey,43) [NOTES: 1977 edition]

coota¶

n. as abbrev. of barracouta (fish and loaf) (See couta)

cooter¶

n. as abbrev. of barracouta (fish and loaf) (See couta)

cootie¶

n. (See kutu)

PERHAM As soon as the new outfit was received the old one got a quick passage ... into the sea, ... Tough luck for the `cooties' [body lice] to be marooned like that, ... (1958,Kimberley Flying Column,81)

BACON `Uncle Stevie says I've got cooties!' He whipped a sheet of paper from out of his desk, ... and shook his head vigorously over it. Ibid. 180 cooties-A familiar term for headlice. (1963,In the Sticks,53)

cootie n. N.Z. & U.S. a slang name for the body louse. [C20: < Maori & ? (for U.S.) Malay kutu louse] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,247) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 105]]

McGILL cootie head louse, from Maori and Polynesian kutu', louse, and not unlike the Hindi wordkhuthi', a scab, used in army slang as cootie' to refer to body louse, and the Malayancootie', a dog tick, (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,30)

coots-grass¶

n. (See couch grass)

cop¶

n. a catch; a `good thing' (esp. a good cop; a dead cop).

BRUNO Any other bottles [other than the three that paid for his seat at the pictures] that fell into his maw were distinct 'cop'. (1944,Desert Daze,11)

PUGH-WILLIAMS I have often heard seamen and watersiders use on a cop when they are paid overtime till, for example, 9am and complete the job at 6.30. (1951,Letter)

COP¶

abbr. Certificate of Proficiency [ORIGIN: acronym]

C.O.P. Certificate of Proficiency (1985,Collins Compact Dictionary,105)

cop it like a toff¶

phr. to accept something without complaint

NEWBOLD Cop it like a toff (v) Accept without complaint. (1982,Big Huey, The,246)

cop it sweet¶

phr. to accept without complaint

NEWBOLD Cop it sweet (v) 1. Accept without complaint. 2. Enjoy, relish, be without problems. (1982,Big Huey, The,248)

NEWBOLD The whole thing seemed the wrong way around, but I had no option but to cop it sweet. (1982,Big Huey, The,114)

cop Kitty¶

phr. to ??

They were to `cop Kitty' all the time and every time, due precautions being taken to keep the paws of pious, penny-pinching local preachers out of the mission plate. ... Where all this boodle went to only to only Chapman and Co. know and they'll take damned good care not to tell. (Jul 24, 1909,NZ Truth,213/1/2)

cop the damper¶

phr. (informal, obsolete) variant of to take the cake [1917 Brown Lay of Bantry Bay 29 Those woolly bounders fairly cop the damper. 7/23/2007]

copper¶

n.

Yesterday I had the copper fixed up on the rata roots above the bank and did the washing. (1987,Alfredton,308) [NOTES: Quote from 1900]

In the outhouse stood a copper - not even set in, as is generally the case. (Jun 30, 1944,Te Awamutu Courier,4)

She went to the copper, which collected surplus rain water from the roof of her home, to bathe her face, when she tripped over a box nearby, and fell head first into the copper. (Dec 26, 1944,Wyndham Farmer,3)

GEORGE A copper boiler would be rigged up outside, and someone put in charge of it to stoke it up and get the brew of tea on for supper. (1990,Ohakune,192)

You had to handpump the water there, and carry it to a copper in the wash-house where you heated it. (Dec 24, 1947,NZ Observer,21)

KEITH The 'copper', as it was widely called, doubled as a boiler for the Christmas ham and puddings and for making jam. (1991,Lovely Day Tomorrow, A,36)

The "copper". As it was widely known, doubled as a boiler for the Christmas ham. (Jul 26, 2000,Evening Post,23)

The copper was cleaned ready for boiling the pudding... (Dec 2002,NZ Memories,No.39/51)

[In 1959] The copper and the hand-wringer were being phased out and in their place were washing machines and clothes driers. (Nov 26, 2001,NZ Infotech Weekly,No. 517 : 21)

TRASK In winter, it was a tricky business. Dashing from the back door, across the yard to where a fierce fire under the copper was boiling the water furiously around the "whites" and filling the place with clouds of hot steam. (1976,Elizabeth of Lavington,37)

BATISTICH Emi stirred the copper as if it were a cauldron. (1987,Sing Vila in the Mountain,64)

copper Maori¶

n. Copper Maori seems to have been used by Europeans in the North Island (esp. Northland) for the more usual hangi, umu. with copper. The Maori suffix (variously spelt in early texts) is curious. (1) It is used both with its flexionless Maori pl and its anglicised pl in -s. (2) If it is an aj, the placement after the noun follows Maori grammatical usage: a fuller anglicisation would be Maori copper, occas. used. (3) Williams (p?) states that Maori aj and n native, belonging to New Zealand' is a comparatively recent use not recorded before 1850, and probably first used by Maoris themselves. Is this an early Maori use of the modern sense of Maori? Or an early Pakeha use? (4) Or is it a use of the sensenormal, usual, ordinary' - kopa Maori being the usual earth-oven, perhaps distinct from the iron tripot etc., (then called in English `copper'), the *kopa Pakeha; (See hangi,umu)

We cooked some meat in a copper mauri or hangi, being the native term which is an excellent method of cooking. (1843,NZ Journal,4(95) : 216)

WALES It having been discovered on board that most of [the bread] which we had in Butts was damp and Mouldy; to day a Copper Oven was brought on Shore and fixed up by the Tent to rebake it.' (5) Whatever is the case, the term seems to be influenced by English copper, which could transliterate as something like kopara, kapara in the early 19th century. cf. also Markham's trasliteration of kapura (1834 NZ 38): the Natives told him to his Teeth ... they would put (Corpora) Fire to it. [Note irrelevantly that the English word boiler was transliterated into Maori as paera, its early or dial. variant pron. /bail*/.] 1. (Arranged under predominant spg forms.) (Nov 5, 1773,Journal) [NOTES: 1773 November 5 Wales Journal in Cook Journals (1961) 2/816]

HOLMAN in MALCOLM They made a great fuss and cooked a grand breakfast for us in a copper Maori (hangi). (1982,Where it all Began,124) [NOTES: Quote from 1853]

The feast was prepared in the traditional "Kopa Maori". (Mar 7, 1938,NZ Observer,20)

HAY The pig was first allowed to dry, and then the hair was singed off, and he was ready for the "koppah". Ibid. 32 he was then placed in the koppah, which was made as follows :- A hole was firstly dug in the ground and then partially filled with stones. (1915,Reminiscences of Earliest Canterbury,13)

BAUCKE "Coppa Maori", "Maori oven, etc. - these are the slang names given by those know no better. By the natives it is called an "umu" and universally a "Haangi". (1905,Where the White Man Treads,101)

MOON This peculiar mode of cooking is called by the natives a hangi, but more commonly by Europeans, a copper Maori. (1858,Wreck of the 'Osprey', The,83)

MARKHAM I have many times made a grand Meal in a Kanga Mouri or Native Village on Pippies [pipi], sitting round the Coppre Mouries, each helping themselves till it was done.Ibid. 71 She was civil... and seen many a Man killed and eaten, but first put into a Coppre Mourie. (1834,New Zealand (Heaphy),45) [NOTES: 1963 edition]

"The food is cooked and the kapa Maori open." (Nov 30, 1939,NZ Centennial News,23)

They made a huge "Kapa Maori" (native oven) and spread 60 magnificent flounder. (Feb 22, 1913,NZ Observer,22)

The "copper Maori," as it is termed - steaming the food on red hot stones, when covered with earth - is far preferable. (Oct 8, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7)

Immediately above the beach the trampers saw the burnt stones of many old-time hangis or kapas Maori. (Mar 2, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,42)

n.

HEBERLEY They sucked [the slave girl's] blood till [she] was dead, then they cut her up and cooked her in a copper Maori. spg also Copper Coppre Mourie, pl Coppre Mouries (1828,Autobiography) [NOTES: c1826 1828 J. Heberley Autobiography 1809-1843 [TS] 13 (Wellington)]

MARKHAM [The sawyer] had a beautiful sucking pig done in the Copper Coppre Mouri; ... sitting round Coppre Mouries, each helping themselves till all was done, ... Ibid. 62 My Traps went inside, and in an hour some Pork and Potatoes from a `Coppre Mourie' came in Smoking with the Koraddie Baskets, and at it we went. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),45,1963 ed.)

MARKHAM Coppre [kopa] Mourie, or the Native Ovens are described I rather think in Captain Cookes Voyages. They are done this way. They scratch a hole 8 or 10 inches deep and two Feet in Diameter and then light the Fire in the hole; when the fire is at its best. They cover it all over with Stones The size of Potatoes or what you would put on the roads in England. They are well heated and [when] the fire dies down a wet cloth of Mat is put round the edge. The Potatoes having been scraped with Shells, are laid on the hot stones. A small Calebash of Water is thrown over the stones & Potatoes and fire first taken out, a tremendous steam arises, and a wet mat is laid over all and then covered up with six or seven inches of Earth, left for three quarters of an hour, and then they are beautifully done so you see these Potaotes Pies. The Natives now begin to use Iron pots, known to them by the name of, `Go on Shores,'* from the circumstance of Boats going up and down the Rivers, coming to an Anchor and going on Shore to Cook, but the Natives prefer the Old plan and I think they are right. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),44)

NIDWILL ... and when I visited it, I saw all the native ovens (copper mowries, according to English pronounciation) in which the cooking had been performed, and a portion of the entrails, etc., were strewed about. (1841,Rambles in NZ,30,1952 ed.)

J B WILLIAMS ... and roasted in a copper maurie, ... that is baked in the ground, layed between red hot stones, covered with leaves. (Dec 25, 1842,NZ Journal,32,1956 ed.)

We cooked some meat in a copper mauri, or hangi being the native name. (1843,NZ Journal,96/216) [NOTES: (C.H. Kettle, Surveyor)]

WHISKER [The natives] were taking up there [sic]Breakfast out of the copper Maories. (Jan 1, 1846,Memorandum Book,18) [NOTES: [The natives] were taking up there [sic]Breakfast out of the copper Maories.]

MOON This peculiar mode of cooking is called by the natives a Hangi, but more commonly by Europeans, a Copper [check spg] Maori. (1858,Wreck of the 'Osprey', The,83)

[Maori copper [one of the first times Chudleigh spells Maori correctly : usually Mouray]] We roasted half a sheep in a Maori copper, that is first dig a hole in the ground in proportion to the thing you want to cook. Line the bottom and sides with stones as big as a breakfast cup then light a fire over them till they are quite red hot throwing in more loose stones to put on the top. Then take out all the ashes, wrap your meat in green grass put it in the pit, throw the loose stones on top and cover the whole with sods of grass, clay or anything that will keep the steam in, three or four hours will cook your meat to perfection. (Oct 7, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,147,1950 ed.)

VON TEMPSKY They could not fail to see now that this smoke was such as issues, of a sudden, from a Copa-Maori. [fn](NOTE)- A cooking hole dug in the ground and filled afterwards with heated stones and articles of food. (1864,Memoranda,78)

TINNE ... we watched ... the preparation of our food in a genuine copu-maori, or native oven. (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,16)

GREY I had told Mrs Tautari that I had never partaken of food cooked in a copper-Maori. (1879,His Island Home,21) [NOTES: (Northland)]

PRICE The native women busied themselves with their `copper-maoris.' (1891,Through the Uriwera [sic] Country,17)

PHILIPS The `copper Maori', as it is termed, - steaming the food on red-hot stones, when covered with earth - is far preferable [to an iron pot]. (1891,Memories of the Past,26)

MORRIS ~ This spelling has been influence by the English word Copper, but it is really a corruption of a Maori word. There is a difference of opinion amongst Maori scholars what this word is. Some say Kapura, a common fire used for cooking, in contradistinction to a `chief's fire,' at which he sat sat, and which would not be allowed to be defiled with food. Others say Kopa. The Maori word Kopa was (1) adj meaning bent, (2) angle or corner, and (3) the native oven, or more strictly the hole scooped out for the oven. (1898,Austral English,97)

So they set to work and dug holes on the flat, each hole about 2 ft. across and about 1 [and a half] ft. deep, and shaped something like a <i>Kopa Maori</i>.' <i>(1888,TrNZI,21/417</i>) [NOTES: T Pine,A local tradition of Raukawa,']

In the black soil of this terrrace are again the burnt stones of the `copper Maoris' [fn ?Kapura Maori. - Ed. [= Sir James Hector]] ... (1898,TrNZI,30/535) [NOTES: (Hutchinson Maori Middens)]

Kopa = a steam-oven (syn. hangi, hapi, etc). Probably the European term `copper Maori' comes from this name. (1903,TrNZI,35/89 fn)

BAUCKE Coppa Maori,'Maori oven,' etc. - these are the slang names given by those who know no better. By the natives it is called an Umu' and universally aHaangi'. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,102)

THE HANGI, OR KOPPA MAORI ... An hour is long enough for a moderate sized hangi ... An uncooked hangi is considered by the Maori as a disgrace, a ... sign of ... disaster ... It is not too much to hope that some day Hangi parties will become fashionable. (1908,Souvenir of All Nations Fair,11)

One name for these food-steaming pits is kopa, a much ill-used term, for it has been corrupted into copper' by the intrusive <i>pakeha</i>, who discourses ofcopper mouree' with glib assurance. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/54) [NOTES: (Best)]

copper maori: native oven. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,173)

~ n. type of Maori oven, the food being placed on heated stones in a hole, then covered with earth, ashes and ferns [Origin doubtful but probably Maori Kapura, a communal fire used for cooking]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),613)

copper Maori n. Maori earth oven which cooks food on heated stones, more often called a hangi [Per. Maori kopa, oven, kapura, fire, or Eng. copper]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

BURTON And can you cook wild pork, man,/ Well - a la kopa Maori? (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,22) [NOTES: [Quoting The Candidate - anon., early poem]]

Copper Maori NZ hist. hangi or Maori earth-oven, in which food is cooked on heated stones and covered with flax and earth. [M kapura fire] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,163) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

GREY It was intimated to us that the copper-maori was ready for consumption. ... [It] consisted of kumeras ... Indian corn, mullet etc. (1879,His Island Home,21) [NOTES: (Northland)]

copper moki¶

n.

Latris aerosa Hutton. ... It is called by Hutton `the copper moki'. (1913,TrNZI,45/228) [NOTES: (Thomson, Otago)]

WILSON One of four types of Moki that occurs in our waters, mainly about the East Coast of the South Island. Rare. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,37)

[species name] copper moki 6 Latridopsis aerosa .. [other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Copper moki Latridopsis forsteri ... More common around southern New Zealand. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,106)

AYLING Five species [of trumpeter] are recorded from New Zealand but there appears to be some confusion regarding ... the bastard trumpeter Latridopsis forsteri and the copper moki Latridopsis aerosa. Though officially recognised, the bastard trumpeter appears to be identical to the young blue moki ... On the other hand the copper moki sems to be a valid species - although referred to here as Latridopsis forsteri. Ibid. 247 COPPER MOKI (Bastard trumpeter) Latridopsis forsteri (Latridopsis aerosa) ... The body is silvery with four fine zig-zag horizontal bands of pink or olive tinged pink along the back ... They are most abundant around Stewart Island and become progressively less common further north ... (1982,Collins Guide,246,1984 ed.)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] moki, copper 1611 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

copper skink¶

n. (Environment) a relatively common but secretive, mostly grey/brown, North Island skink. [ Oligosoma aenea aka pre 2009 Cyclodina aenea]

Leaving behind the topside boulders, sheltering moko, shore and copper skinks, one swims over submerged boulders literally crawling with crabs, sea stars, chitons, shrimps, limpets, paua , whelks and large trumpet shells. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/19)

New Zealand's smallest native lizard, the copper skink (up to 62 mm,, excluding the tail), is widespread in the North Island. It is found in forests, open areas with ground cover, and on the seashore near the high-tide mark. It has taken to life in the suburbs, making itself particularly at home in rock gardens and compost heaps. (Jul 2000,NZ Geographic,No. 47/80)

The copper skink is one of the more common and widespread of the NewZealand lizards. (Aug 1999,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/tsrp27.pdfAugust 1999, Department of Conservation]

The Cyclodina group of lizards contains more rare species than any other group of New Zealand lizard.
