The group is also notable for containing the smallest indigenous skink - the copper skink (120mm) - and the largest - the 'presumed extinct' Northland skink (350mm). (2009,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.doc.govt.nz/conservation/native-animals/reptiles-and-frogs/lizards/cyclodina-skink/facts/]

The Copper Skink is very common over much of the North Island. Sleek, glossy and coppery in colour, it grows to about 10 cms, with a very long tail. Being nocturnal they are active mainly by night and eat small insects, spiders and similar invertebrates.The Copper Skink does not lay eggs but is a live-bearer. Usually 3 - 7 in number, the young are born in February - March and are often large at birth, sometimes up to half the adult length. (2004,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.tiritirimatangi.org.nz/NonAvianFauna/CopperSkink.htm2004 Supporters of Tiritiri Matangi Inc.]

The copper skink is one of the more common and widespread of the NewZealand lizards. (Aug 1999,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/tsrp27.pdfAugust 1999, Department of Conservation]

copper stick¶

n. a stick for moving clothes when washing them in the boiling water of a copper [Ian Douglas (51 Liverpool St, Wanganui; dougie@xtra.co.nz) says the term used in England 60 years ago was "poss stick" a long wooden stick. "There was also a 'posser' which was a pole with a sort of vacuum creating hood on the end which was used to dump or dunk the clothes up and down and help shift the dirt." John Mihaljevic (jmjm@ihug.co.nz) writes that a BBC World Service My Century documentary (The Invention that Feed Women) broadcast by Radio NZ has a woman born in the East End of London in 1927 describing washdays (presumably the 1930s) and referring to her mother's use of copper sticks. "This was not just any piece of wood, but a specific tool; she described it as a 'one-handled rolling pin'" Alan Burnett (aged 75) writes (2/10/1999) that when he was a child in Scotland "we always spoke of the copper-stick or SPURKLE which was made by cutting a broom-handle in half! and used for poking the boiling clothes.]

It was [a] copper stick. I used to get that on the bum (Aug 25, 2000,TV1,Holmes : Merepeka Raukawa-Tait)

copper tussock¶

n.

Normally stoneflies are found in streams, but this species has adapted to life in the damp centre of the copper tussock (C. rubra cuprea) on Dunedin's Swampy Summit. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/43)

copperdom¶

n. the police force

Coppedom crushed. (Oct 10, 1905,NZ Truth,5)

It is a piece of damnable effrontery for copperdom to charge a man with being a low down vagrant, having no visible means of support, when he doesn't belong to that class of no-class person at all. (Oct 20, 1905,NZ Truth,8)

coprosma¶

n. a genus of shrubs or small trees, found in NZ, Aust. and Hawaii.

[Hdg] Compost and coprosma... "Compost and Coprosma" was the story of the Onslow College arboretum in Wellington... (Aug 24, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),67)

It's no surprise that coprosmas - those supertough natives with waxy leaves - are doing well. (Mar 22, 2001,Evening Post,22)

There may be.. other coprosmas fruiting pale red berries. (Jul 26, 1992,Dominion Sunday Times,21)

Another reason might be that the plants have coloured foliage such as cultivars of flax, Pittosporum, Coprosma and Hebe. (Mar 25, 1993,Evening Post,17)

n. a shrub, karamu

WILLIAMS Karamuu, n. coprosma, a shrub, of various species. (1871,Dictionary of the NZ Language,45)

MORRIS ~ scientific and vernacular name for a large genus of trees and shrubs of the order Rubiaceae. From the Greek dung, on account of the bad smell of some of the species. See quotation. The Maori name is Karamu (q.v.). Various species receive special vernacular names, which appear in their places in the Dictionary. (1898,Austral English,98)

KIRK (1889,Forest Flora,110)

MARTIN A majority of small bushy shrubs with twiggy branches and small opposite leaves are Coprosmas, colloquially known as wiggy bushes'miki-miks', this name being a corruption of the Southern Maori miki-miki. (1961,Flora NZ,215,1929 ed.)

~ A large class of New Zealand shrubs; Australia has a few and others grow in the Pacific Islands. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),96)

coprosma n [NL. fr. copr + -osma] 1 cap : a genus of shrubs or small trees of the family Rubiaceae found in New Zealand, Australia, and Hawaii and having shining often variegated leaves and small flowers with revolute corolla lobes 2 -s: a plant of the genus Coprosma (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,503)

McLINTOCK Coprosma - karamu, karangu, Coprosma lucida, Coprosma robusta.Coprosma - mamangi, Coprosma arborea. Coprosma - taupata, C. repens. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

McLEOD Coprosma: A large genus of dense shrubs described as dung-smelling. From the Greek word copros. (1972,Mountain World,310)

MANTELL The garden had been allowed to revert to wild-garden, ... green on green, splashed by an occasional yellow-leafed coprosma. (1980,Murder and Chips,35)

MANTELL They went towards the courts until they disappeared behind a tangle of creeper-draped coprosma, a mass of impenetrable green ... (1984,Murder in Vain,69)

coprosma n. any of a group of small evergreen trees and shrubs found in Australasia. [GK kopros dung, osme smell] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,163) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

DAWSON The coprosma is sometimes known as `stinkwood' because the crushed leaves smell like rotten cabbage. (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,104)

On the flanks of Mt Taranaki Dieffenbach collected the first specimens of creeping coprosoma (C. perpusilla), snow buttercups (Ranunculus nivicola) and Egmont mountain foxglove (Ourisia m. macrophylla). (Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/49)

coprosma, sand [s] Coprosma acerosa A. Cunn. Ibid. 67 sand coprosma [s] Coprosma acerosa A. Cunn. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,15)

WILSON Coprosma acerosa SAND COPROSMA ... Low-growing shrub ... Common in sand and shrubland of coastal dunes (1982,Stewart Island Plants,57)

...many vistors aren't familiar with the look of some of the plants - such as the "bird's nest" type, of which the sprawling Coprosma acerosa (sand coprosma) is an example... (Jan 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 67/11)

A report on the current status and future management of coastal dune vegetation in the Wellington Conservancy recommends a higher level of protection be secured for 10 sites supporting at least one of the five key indigenous coastal plant species - sand tussock (Austrofestuca littoralis), pingao (Desmoschoenus spiralis, spinifex or silvery sand grass (Spinifex sericeus), sand coprosma (Coprosma acerosa) and sand daphne ({Pimelea aff. arenaria). (May 2003,Footnotes,No. 19/6)

2 n. Coprosma tenuicaulis.

COCKAYNE (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

LEVY ... such species as lancewood, karamu, toro, ramarama, koromiko, kanono, kohuhu, kawakawa, hangehange, rangiora, five finger, patete, toru, tree daisies, broadleaf, kamahi, mahoe, tarata, karo, lacebark, wineberry, fuchsia, kowhai, with tree ferns, weki, and mamuku. Toetoe, phormium, cabbage tree, with swamp coprosma and hupiro may figure as a developmental phase on wet soils. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,87,1970 ed.)

coprosma hedge¶

n. -

HYDE ... over a coprosma hedge he fell in love ... with Fanny's little sister, May. (1936,Passport to Hell,42)

HYDE He flung his bicycle against the coprosma hedge, and Carly and Eliza came running out to meet him. (1938,Godwits Fly, The,12,1970 ed.)

HYDE Starkie moved on behind the coprosma hedge. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,63)

copse-wood¶

n.

YATE The copse-wood and flax . (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),10, also 13) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)..]

... where stands a small copse-wood, called Lee's Bush (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher,2) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

coral¶

2 n. Hippomenella vellicata

A second, more brittle variety, called cornflakes coral, Hippomenella vellicata, forms similar but less robust growths... Both types of coral - Tasman Bay and cornflake - have since been found in fossil deposits near Kahurangi Point, in north-west Nelson, dating back some 20-22 million years. (Jan 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 61/86)

Off Abel Tasman National Park there are huge beds of a 15-30 cm-high clump-forming bryozoan known as Tasman Bay coral, Celleporaria agglutinans... Both types of coral - Tasman Bay and cornflake - have since been found in fossil deposits near Kahurangi Point, in north-west Nelson, dating back some 20-22 million years. (Jan 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 61/86)

coral broom¶

n. Corallospartium crassicaule

KIRK Corallospartium crassicaule coral broom (1899,Students' Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

As we ascend the grassy slopes we may note the curious leafless coral-broom [fn Corallospartium crassicaule.], with its stiffribbed stems; ... (1900,Canterbury Old & New,190)

CHEESEMAN C[orollospartium] crassicaule, Armstr. ... Carmichaelia crassicaulis, Hook.f. ... Coral-broom ... It appears to be confined to ... eastern slopes of the Southern Alps. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,108)

Corallospartium crassicaule coral broom (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

COCKAYNE C. crassicaule var. racemosa coral broom (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The) [NOTES: (And)]

ALLAN 1. C. crassicaule (Hook.f.) ... Montane and subalpine grassland ... east of divide ... Coral broom, sticks. (1961,Flora NZ,1/371)

MARK & ADAMS Genus CORALLOSPARTIUM `Coral Broom' - referring to the stems. Consists of a single species, confined to the South Island. Corallospartium crassicaule (Hook. f.) J.B. Armst CORAL BROOM (1973,NZ Alpine Plants,76,1979 ed.)

MOORE & IRWIN CORALLOSPARTIUM CRASSICAULE, coral broom. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,164)

I came across a fine clump of the coral broom (Corallospartium crassicaule). (Mar 18, 1924,Otago Witness,10)

coral lichen¶

n.

WILSON Cladia retipora CORAL LICHEN ... Lace lichen ... Clumps or extensive patches of white, branching growths, sometimes tinged with grey; neatly perforated to give a lacy or coral-like appearance; soft when wet, brittle when dry. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,485)

n.

WILSON Cladia retipora CORAL LICHEN ... Lace lichen ... Clumps or extensive patches of white, branching growths, sometimes tinged with grey; neatly perforated to give a lacy or coral-like appearance; soft when wet, brittle when dry. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,485)

coral shrub¶

n. Helichrysum coralloides.

COCKAYNE (And) (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

COCKAYNE (And) (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The)

MARTIN Several shrubby daisies belonging to the genus Helichrysum ..., chief of which in interest ... is the CORAL SHRUB (H. coralloides), a subalpine lithophyte from Marlborough. (1929,Flora NZ,207,1961 ed.)

coral stomper¶

n. Pacific Islander

McGILL coral stomper Pacific Islander; mildly offensive. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,30)

coralfish¶

n. (See Lord Howe Island coralfish)

Coral Fish Chelmonops howensis (Waite) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,407) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 407]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] coralfish 1525 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

GRAHAM Coral Fish Chelmonops trunctatus (Kner) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,407) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 407]

cordella¶

n.

GEORGE In 1955 the 100 per cent sisal carpet, cordella, was introduced. (1987,Foxton 1888-1988,136)

corduroy¶

n. a roadway formed (esp. over boggy ground) by laying logs transversely across the pathway; the logs etc. so used

MALFROY SNIGGING-TRACKS. ... Good straight tracks make hauling easy. A few pieces of corduroy placed across the track are a great help ... A good snigger will see that a log is not jammed before signalling `Right ahead' to the hauler, and will use his snigging-shoe ... to lift the log out of bad places. Ibid. 38 Corduroy .. Small saplings placed side by side across a soft wet track to avoid the sinking of the load. (1923,Small Sawmills,13)

DEVANNY [The horses] nailed shoes slipped on the corduroy. (1930,Bushman Burke,95)

LOVELL-SMITH [quoting James Coutts Crawford who made the trip in April 1864 : probably from Recollections of Travel in NZ 1880 [check]] `Part of this road was corduroy.' (1931,Old Coaching Days,109)

There were no roads; we followed narrow, boggy tracks, where there was ... corduroy where the bottom was undiscoverable. [fn] Logs laid across the track. (1940,Tales of Pioneer Women,157,1988 ed.)

HENDERSON The worst parts of mud and ooze were covered with `corduroy', short small logs from saplings pegged tight one against the other. (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The)

BEARDSLEY corduroy logs of wood laid across a path (1984,Blackball 08,243)

MASTERS In place the corduroys of the track had broken or slipped away, with the result that the [149] horses would have to plunge through mud up to their girths to get by. [1903] (1959,Tales of the Mails,148)

v.

DILKE The highway is `corduroyed' with trunks of the tree fern (1868,Greater Britain,1/340)

COWAN A rough and narrow bush road, `corduroyed' with fern-tree trunks in the marshy portions, wound through the forest from the bridge at the fort; ... (1922,NZ Wars, The,1/104)

Corduroying bush tracks was not the only lesson the American backwoods could teach. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,359,1962 ed.)

TOMLINSON A great deal of it [sc. a bush track] was corduroyed, that is saplings or split timber, perhaps up to ten feet wide, laid close together and covered with dirt or gravel. (1968,Remembered Trails,52)

corduroy pathway¶

n.

REED The corduroy pathway to these mighty trees has been constructed of the trunks of tree - fern. (1961,North Cape to Bluff,46)

corduroy road¶

n.

CARTER The roads over the swampy flats were ... made possible by means of bush poles, which were laid close together across the middle of the roads. These were - as in America - called `corderoy roads.' (1866,NZ Colonist,2/107)

CORDUROY ROAD A road built generally in lower swampy places and consisting of logs, poles, and trunks of tree-ferns laid side by side. (1952,NZ Forest Glossary)

LOVELL-SMITH The formation of the road surface, at this place, consisted of tree trunks fastened together and laid across the road going over the swamp. It was known as a plank' orcorduroy' road. ... The other passengers were shaken off while going over the `corduroy' section of the road (1931,Old Coaching Days,19)

CRESSWELL Here was a muddy creek where drays often stuck fast and when this happened bundles of sticks were laid down to form a corduroy road. Hence the name `Sticks' - changed in the course of time to Styx. (1951,Canterbury Tales,122)

OWEN & PERKINS It was astonishing the tremendous loads they could pull out of the bush along the ground - snigging', that was called. In many places the logs were brought out on what was called acat', which was short for catamaran. A catamaran was a big heavy sledge made of bush timber ... The bushmen would build a special road for them - a corduroy road, or `skidded' road, as we used to call it. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,160) [NOTES: (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country)]

OWEN & PERKINS The bushmen would build a special road for them [sc. log sledges] - a corduroy road, or 'skidded road' as we used to call it. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,160)

PARK At the worst places [the road] was corduroy - rows of small tree trunks hammered down into the mud. (1992,Fence Around the Cuckoo,132)

1 n. (Rural) a primitive road made of logs placed side by side at right angles to traffic [often made of manuka].

BARRER The corduroy road, along what is now Morison's Bush, was the worst part of it, for it consisted of logs laid side by side on which the horses' feet constantly slipped. (1939,Brave Days: Pioneer Women of New Zealand,174)

CRESSWELL Here was a muddy creek where drays often stuck fast and when this happened bundles of sticks were laid down to form a corduroy road. (1951,Canterbury Tales,122)

Until corduroy roads were formed to take wheeled traffic. (1961,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol III,93)

corduroy track¶

n.

ACLAND Corduroy track. More used in the North Island than in the South. (1933,Sheep-station Glossary)

Corduroy track.-Roadway made by laying poles across it to stop the wheels sinking in the mud. (More used in the North Island than the South.) (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Gloss. additions]

FINLAYSON Might be caught after dark on a mountain road or one of them long narrow corduroy tracks across a swamp. (1948,Tidal Creek,119,1979 ed.)

ACLAND Corduroy track: Roadway made by laying poles across it to stop wheels sinking in the mud. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,363)

The corduroy track was still sound in many places a big help in the swampy areas. (1978,Manawatu Tramping Club Jubilee,86)

cordwood¶

n. firewood (by the cord)

HARPER The chaps who was cutting cordwood for Thatcher. (1934,Windy Island,190)

cordyline¶

n.

Shiny stainless steel cordylines - the ultimate in no-maintenance planting - were tucked into the undergrowth in Boardman, Gelly and Co's 'Forever Green'. (Jul 20, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),15)

Dracaenas and their other relationscordylines (cabbage trees) can be used togreat effect. (Oct 1992,Marist Messenger,28)

WHITE Parallel with the happy family on the trellis I planted a row of twenty Cordylines, or Palm Lilies, commonly [50] called New Zealand Cabbage Trees, for the uninteresting reason that someone once boiled some and ate them as a vegetable. (1905,My NZ Garden,49)

CORE¶

abbr. Centre of Research Excellence

Consideration of a category B fund follows the creation last year of what is essentially a 'category A' fund, the Centres of Research Excellence (CORE) fund, which focuses on research excellence and collaboration between institutions... But Thompson said a sufficient number of research programmes were already in place and included the COREs, the Foundation for Research, Science and Technology's consortia, the Venture Investment Fund, Industry New Zealand and a range of incubators linking industry to science. (Mar 20, 2002,NZ Education Review,2)

core¶

v. to turn a skipping rope.

FRAME Nora Bone, whom I despised because she, like myself, was seldom asked to join the skipping, but whose need was so strong that she always offered to `core for ever,' that is, turn and turn the skipping rope and never herself join in the skipping. (1982,To the Is-Land,72,1984 ed.) [NOTES: [ref 1930s]]

Corinth of the Southern Hemisphere¶

phr. Auckland [(or of the South Pacific, or of the North??)]

Auckland, as the centre of this singularly beautiful and well-watered province, from its own local position and natural advantages, has been termed by the Bishop of New Zealand, and men of classic recollections, `the Corinth of the Southern Hemisphere.' (1860,Handbook for Emigrants,13)

KNOX I see,' said Fred, ...that the island is very narrow here.' ... It reminds me of Corinth, in Greece,' said Fred, as he continued the contemplation of the map.No doubt it does,' said the officer ... `Auckland is called the Corinth of the South Pacific; . (1888,Boy Travellers,196)

BULLOCK Beautiful for situation, [Auckland] has therefore been styled the `Corinth of the North.' (1899,Wonderland of the Antipodes,2)

cork¶

n. fighting [1953 14 M A16 Thames DHS 30 CORK]

cork elm¶

n. (See corkwood)

Cork Lou¶

n. a game played for drinks

SMYTH `Cork Lou's' a game you play for drinks. (1929,Girl from Mason Creek, The,200)

cork tree¶

n. also New Zealand cork tree, Entelea arborescens , whau.

CRAIK Among those which the natives principally make use of, are the henow, from which they extract a black dye, and the vow, a species of cork tree. (1830,New Zealanders, The,175)

POLACK The Pongo, and Wou, (achroma petandria Zelandica) are varieties of the corktree, when cut down an adhesive juice exudes in some quantity, and are of much service to the natives in their fishing nets. The fronds are five feet long, virent, circumference of trunk one and a half foot, covered with chaffy scales. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/399) [NOTES: [seems some confusion here]]

... the paper mulberry tree and the New Zealand cork tree. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/47) [NOTES: (Colenso Maori races)]

FEATON ENTELEA ARBORESCENS (Brown.) ... The WHAU', orHAUAMA'.- This very beautiful small tree is peculiar to the Northern Island of New Zealand, but is not common. ... Owing to the extreme lightness [61] and bouyancy of the wood, the tree is known to the Colonists as the `Cork Tree'. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,60)

The whau (so-called cork tree) may not be rare among native horticulturists, but it is sufficiently rare and pleasing to attract notice. (Nov 14, 1938,Evening Post,5)

corker¶

n. something very good; OED2 b. sense is recorded in NZ from 1865 and has been in common use since; the a. sense may be present in the drinking pun (with the similarly sensed bottler) in 1865 cit.

[Charlie Corker and his friend Tom Bottler.]. (Oct 28, 1856,Dunedin Punch,154)

MOSLEY I'm down at last; I own [the walk] has been a corker,/ To go back now would be a bitter pill; (1885,Illustrated Guide to Christchurch,11) [NOTES: c1862-63 Thatcher `Over the Hill' in 1885 Mosley Illustrative Guide to Christchurch 11]

BALLANTYNE Isn't Marjorie a corker, Fred? Think she'd write and let her mother know ...' (1948,Cunninghams, The,20)

A corker, a belter, a nice day for it. (Jan 31, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

2 adj. very good, fine, excellent, `beaut'.

The gadgets are just like Dad's though -a bell that makes a 'corker' loud ring. (Sep 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,90)

You little beaut! What a corker! (Dec 4, 1944,NZEF Times,IV/180 : 5)

MARSH We tried her out till we was sick and tired of her and she worked corker every time. She worked good-oh, didn't she? Ibid. 72 He talks with a corker sort of voice. Not queeny, but just corker. ... he's got a corking sort of laugh. Ibid 174 The idiom is a bit puzzling but `corker' seems to be the general adjective of approbation. (1937,Vintage Murder,49)

HARVEY He had beaut savs, that butcher - they were smoked and went corker with lots of tomato sauce. (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,14)

BAKER In constant use by youngsters [are]: stunner ... corker. (1941,NZ Slang,51)

BENNETT A whole group of [words in -er] express admiration: corker, stunner (both used as adjectives as well as nouns). (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,89)

GASKELL It's such a corker name for a small country pub.' <i>(1944,All Part of the Game,24</i>) [NOTES:Pig and Whistle']

But to say a thing is corker' orbosker' means that it's swell, while `fair dinkum' means honest-to-god. Ibid. 39 Corker - very good. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,38)

Other unusual words are explained in the text except perhaps one or two which are in almost universal use in Australia and NZ. Such, for example, is corker', a common adjective signifyinggood', fine',swell.' (1945,NZ Geographer,39) [NOTES: (Cumberland's note to Pascoe's `High Country)]

TEXIDOR They must have been interested in the Islands, or why did ... Miss Massey say so many times, How corker. (1945,In Fifteen Minutes,179,1987 ed.)

SOLJAK Following are examples of colloquialisms common to New Zealand and Australian English, with their English or American equivalent ... corker: excellent (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),115)

GASKELL `It's a corker wee place,' I said. (1947,Big Game,30)

BALLANTYNE Gosh, it would be corker if he could go outside with Carole Plowman (1948,Cunninghams, The,62,1976 ed.)

FINLAYSON `You have a corker garden,' Jake says. (1948,Tidal Creek,81,1979 ed.)

It was corker and clean and shining. (1950,Landfall,13/16) [NOTES: (Gaskell)]

FRAME Minnie agreed. Yes it's a corker kite. (1951,Lagoon, The,64,1961 ed.)

I would include among New Zealand English words: corker (May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class)

SLATTER It's a corker dress. Would look nice with a dash of red to show it off. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,124)

KINROSS He's always going on about what a corker cook you are , Lizzie. (1963,Please to Remember,71)

McCALLUM ... it is such a corker day and I am enjoying the sunshine. (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,37)

SARGESON corker: admirable, attractive. (1964,Collected Stories,298)

GILDERDALE corker Good, splendid. B. Sutton-Smith's Our Street (1950) page 24. (1982,Sea Change,240)

Clarrie saying By Christ boy/ it's a corker day knew what he was saying. (May 3, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11) [NOTES: (O'Sullivan `Then')]

corker ... 2 a. NZ fine, enjoyable, splendid. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,164) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 249; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 106]]

Our Deirdre looked so corker and all at her wedding to Ken. (Jul 21, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),95)

PHILLIPS I didn't know what to say about getting dumped off Scallywag the other morning because Cliff knew some corker tortures. (2000,First Past the Post,68) [NOTES: Gaskell "All Part of the Game" in Some Other Country 1996]

ANDERSON Charlie tells meat about 6 a.m. that there were stars and it was corker. (1999,Long Hot Summer,139)

[Hdg] A corker of a vintage. (Aug 12, 2001,Sunday Star Times,B6)

I noted that Lieutenants Jimmy Rochford and Mick Maher 'looked corker', for their swords were unsheathed and held erect. (1935,St Patrick's College 1883-1935)

PARK A stove, a corker little stove with bandy legs. (1992,Fence Around the Cuckoo,255)

corkscrew¶

n. a mollusc

POWELL CORKSCREW (Pyxipoma weldii). This shell, which is from 2 to 2 1/2 inches long, is loosely coiled and has an open slit running up one side (1947,Native Animals of NZ,26)

corkwood¶

n. Entelea arborescens , whau.

The few clumps of trees consist of pohutukawa, mapou, manuka, rewarewa, akeake, whau or corkwood, pukapuka, and a few puriri, which, however, is of little value, being very scattered and ruined by fire. (1884,TrNZI,17/419) [NOTES: (Gold-Smith)]

... at the head also of these glens are some very fine corkwood' trees about one foot through, the largest I have seen; this wood is calledcorkwood' by bushmen from its being, like cork, very buoyant in water. (1884,TrNZI,17/426) [NOTES: (Stewart)]

FEATON Hauama [Maori name] .. Cork-wood [Settlers' name] .. Entelea arborescens .. Small tree Ibid. 178 Cork-wood [Settlers' name] .. Entelea arborescens .. Small tree (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,177)

KIRK The whau ... is termed cork-wood by the settlers on account of its light specific gravity. (1889,Forest Flora,45)

Whau (corkwood) .. Entelea arborescens .. The lightest timber in New Zealand, weight 8lb. to 11lb. per cubic foot, being about half that of cork; ... Ibid. 21 296 Lithograph of whau foliage (corkwood).Ibid. 30 710 Specimen of New Zealand corkwood, grown in Auckland by the late Judge Gillies. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,14)

MORRIS Corkwood ... a New Zealand tree, Entelea arborescens, R. Br., N.O. Tiliaceae. Maori name, Whau. (1898,Austral English,98)

LAING & BLACKWELL [The wood] is about half the weight of cork, and the whau is sometimes, therefore, termed `the cork-wood tree.' Mr T. Kirk suggested that it might be utilized for life-belts. (1907,Plants of NZ,243,1940, p. 257 ed.)

MOORE & IRWIN ENTELEA ARBORESCENS, whau, corkwood. A round-headed tree up to 10m tall, remarkable for its light wood - ... (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,70)

Once dry, [whau] is about half the weight of an equivalent-sized piece of cork and was called corkwood by early Europeans settlers. (Oct 15, 2005,Dominion Post,E13)

2 n. cork elm

  1. Occas. applied to the cork-elm Ulmus X hollandica Mill. Ulmus procera Salisb. introduced from Europe. (1875,Durability NZ Timbers)

Cormo¶

1 n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred sheep [a Corriedale/Merino cross. ]

NEWTON ... it was decided to introduce the 'Cormo' - the Merino-Corriedale cross. I'd hazard a guess that those Cormo will boost these weights still further. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,79)

cormorant¶

n. [According to Dr Brian Bell, Aust. ornithologists prefer cormorant, New Zealand, shag.] (See shag)

FORSTER He brought in all 41 Ducks ... and Shags on board, one of them was the common Cormorant (Pelecanus Carbo), [[ed. fn] Black Shag.] the other the small shag ... (May 9, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/273)

FORSTER A very fine species of crayfish (cancer homarus Lin.) longer than the lobster, some shell-fish, and ... a cormorant, duck, pigeon, or parrot gave us an agreeable variety at our table (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/144)

YATE (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),69) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection) lists it among NZ seabirds; no Maori name [not recorded f. Yate]]

DIEFFENBACH After leaving the village we crossed to another bay, E-Taua. This bay also is spacious and pleasant. Kingfishers, oystercatchers, tuis [fn Anthochoera concinnata, Vig. and Horsfield.], and cormorants [fn Pelecanus pica, Forst.], enlivened the trees on its shores, and many birds were singing in the forest. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/59)

The whole beach [at Waikouaite] was strewed with gigantic fragments of the bones of whales, and flocks of gulls, cormorants, and other sea-birds, ... prowled about to pick up the refuse. (Jul 20, 1844,Nelson Examiner) [NOTES: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 241]

SELWYN May 10 and 11. - The southerly gale continuing, ... we remained at anchor, and looked around [79] the Cove for traces of Captain Cook. My crew followed the Tory's example, by feasting on cormorants. (Aug 30, 1848,New Zealand (Selwyn),Part V (Church in the Colonies XX) 78)

DRURY BIRDS MET WITH IN PELORUS ... Cormorants - several kinds ... The Phalacrocorax Punctatus, or Cristatus (Spotted Shag) is said to be common in Pelorus ... all kinds are called Kauwau by the natives. (1855,Sailing Directions,66)

HAAST Another day a cormorant (Graucalus varius) [was] passing in the same neighbourhood ... In speaking of cormorants, I may add that there are several species which exist all along the rivers and sea coast. (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,137)

THOMSON Several kinds of birds are indigenous to the woods and waters; among them the oyster-catcher, bittern, kingfisher, cormorant, quail, wild-duck, mocking or [16] parson bird, parrots, parroquets, woodhen, pigeon, etc. (the [sic] gigantic Moa bird is believed to be now quite extinct). (1867,Twelve Years in Canterbury,15)

The following is a list of the birds shot ... Querquedula gibberifrons, little teal; Anas superciliosa, grey duck; ... Graculus carbo, cormorant or black shag; Graculus varius, pied shag; Graculus brevirostris, white throated shag; also another species of shag, locally called the `blue shag' ... pretty highly esteemed by the sailors as an article of food; (1872,Appendix Proc. Otago Prov. Council,39) [NOTES: (Black Stewart Island)]

BAINE Sailing along we passed several colonies of cormorants (shags), perched on these [pohutukawa] trees; ... (1874,Edward Crewe,144)

DOMETT Cormorant ..... Pelicanidae; Grauculus punctatus, etc. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,2/338)

HOCKEN As the boat speeds round the various points, flocks of seagulls and cormorants rise, startled at the unwonted intrusion. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,79)

2 n.

HUTTON 147. GRACULUS CARBO. L. Cormorant. Black Shag. Kawau. G. carboides. GRAY. Phalacrocorax Novae Hollandiae. BULLER. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,50)

RICHARDS Phalacrocorax ... carbo ... Black Shag or Cormorant. KAWAU (1952,Chatham Islands,89)

3 n.

Pied Cormorant Phalacrocorax varius (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAMES: Karuhiruhi, pied shag, yellow-faced cormorant. ... Common around mainland Australia ... (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,116)

3 n.

DIEFFENBACH That beautiful bird the large-crested cormorant [[fn] Phalacrocorax punctatus] is found here [Hutt] in great numbers among the higher branches of the trees. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/76)

3 n. black shag

Great Cormorant P[halacrocorax] c[arbo] steadi (MATHEWS & IREDALE, 1913) OTHER NAMES: Kawau-tua-whenua, black cormorant, black shag. ... In New Zealand, ranges round inland and coastal waters ... Also found on the shores of the North Atlantic ocean; mainly on inland waters in Eurasia, Africa, Australia. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,114)

McLINTOCK Cormorant - kawau, Phalacrocorax carbo (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

3 n.

King Shag Leucocarbo carunculatus (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAMES: Carunculated shag, Marlborough Sounds shag, rough-faced shag, Cook Strait cormorant. ... The only shag with pink feet in the Cook Strait and Marlborough Sounds area. Prominent caruncles at base of bill. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,118)

3 n.

Great Cormorant P[halacrocorax] c[arbo] steadi (MATHEWS & IREDALE, 1913) OTHER NAMES: Kawau-tua-whenua, black cormorant, black shag. ... In New Zealand, ranges round inland and coastal waters ... Also found on the shores of the North Atlantic ocean; mainly on inland waters in Eurasia, Africa, Australia. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,114)

Great Cormorant P[halacrocorax] c[arbo] steadi (MATHEWS & IREDALE, 1913) OTHER NAMES: Kawau-tua-whenua, black cormorant, black shag. ... In New Zealand, ranges round inland and coastal waters ... Also found on the shores of the North Atlantic ocean; mainly on inland waters in Eurasia, Africa, Australia. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,114)

3 n.

3 n.

Little Pied Cormorant Phalacrocorax melanoleucos (VIEILLOT, 1817) ... OTHER NAMES: Kawaupaka, white-throated shag, frilled shag, little river shag, little cormorant, little shag. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,117)

3 n.

Little Black Cormorant Phalacrocorax sulcirostris (BRANDT, 1837) ... OTHER NAME: Little black shag. ... Although the little black cormorant often forages in large flocks, it is not a common New Zealand bird. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,115)

3 n.

Pied Cormorant Phalacrocorax varius (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAMES: Karuhiruhi, pied shag, yellow-faced cormorant. ... Common around mainland Australia (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,116)

3 n.

Little Pied Cormorant Phalacrocorax melanoleucos (VIEILLOT, 1817) ... OTHER NAMES: Kawaupaka, white-throated shag, frilled shag, little river shag, little cormorant, little shag. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,117)

corn¶

n. In 20th c. NZ usage corn usu. applied as in US usage to maize, now usu. sweet corn, rather than to grain as in British usage, though the latter was common in earlier 19th c. NZ.

ROCHFORT Another great evil is the immense number of rats, which destroy corn and everything eatable. ... add to this [expense], the supply of corn, &c., required is small, and the natives grow all kinds of grain and vegetables cheaper than the white man can ... (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,26)

corn chamomile¶

n.

HILGENDORF CORN CHAMOMILE (Anthemis arvensis). A weed similar to stinking mayweed, no strong smell; coarser, shorter and broader leaf segments. ... Occasional in waste places in both islands. (1967,Weeds of New Zealand,186)

corn chamomile [s] Anthemis arvensis L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,15)

corn cockle¶

n.

corn cockle [s] Agrostemma githago L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,15)

corn gromwell¶

n.

corn gromwell [s] Lithospermum arvense L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,15)

corn marigold¶

n.

corn marigold [s] Chrysanthemum segetum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,15)

corn salad¶

n.

corn salad [s] Valerianella carinata Loisl. Valerianella locusta (L.) Betche (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,16)

corn thistle¶

n. Californian thistle

GUTHRIE-SMITH Corn thistle (Cnicus arvensis), in New Zealand rechristened Californian or Canadian thistle, was first detected by me on Putorino, ... (1926,Tutira,254)

cornbind¶

n. convolvulus, bindweed, black bindweed.

HILGENDORF CORNBIND (Polygonum convolvulus) is also called [convolvulus,] bindweed and black bindweed. It occurs in gardens and cultivated fields, especially in cereal crops. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,59) [NOTES: (1926 headword convulus; 1967 headword bindweed)]

cornbind [s] Polygonum convolvulus L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,16)

TAYLOR CORNBIND (Polygonum convolulus) ... introduced from Europe, is a common weed of cultivated ground throughout the South Island perhaps most plentiful in South Canterbury; less common in the North Island, ... (1980,Weeds of Crops,32)

HILGENDORF & CALDER CONVOLVULUS [BINDWEED] (Convolvulus arvensis), is also called bindweed and black bindweed, cornbind, and morning glory. It is an introduced weed found in fields, gardens and waste places in many localities. It has a perennial creeping underground stem, trailing or twining [aerial] stems with leaves 1 to 3 inches long, shaped like a spear head, and handsome bell-shaped flowers an inch or more in diameter- ... (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,1967 ed.)

corner¶

n.

SALMOND corner corners of weatherboarded walls and against which the weatherboards finish - cf boxed corner (1986,Old New Zealand Houses,231)

corner dairy¶

n.

HALEY I went into a corner dairy and bought an icecream. (1989,Transfer Station,56)

corner peg¶

n. (See section peg)

New find 145 feet from N.E corner peg, 155 feet from S.E corner peg, and 60 feet from centre peg adjoining Manukau boundary, clipping right into centre of claim under old main run of gold in No.1 reef, depth 135 feet from top of shaft. (Nov 29, 1872,Daily Southern Cross,3)

".. They put in another drive near the corner peg of the Marquis of Waterford and struck another leader ..." (Oct 8, 1868,Daily Southern Cross,5)

The practice hitherto has been when dealing with bush land, which is difficult and expensive in survey, to run merely the frontage lines, and by corner pegs and ranging pegs to indicate the course of the remaining lines. (Jul 24, 1880,Southland Times,2)

cornflower¶

n. Centaurea cyanus L.

cornflower [s] Centaurea cyanus L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,16)

2 n. viper's bugloss

cornflower [=] viper's bugloss [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,16)

Corngate¶

n. political kerfuffle over the alleged planting of GE-modified corn

I'm pleased that Helen Clark and Labour are campaigning on trust. So let's see - paintergate, corngate, speedgate, Winstongate, foreshore-and-seabedgate ... (Sep 27, 2008,Dominion Post,B4)

[Hdg] MPs point to Corngate 'cover-up'. A paper trail of Corngate correspondence amounts to a cover-up, Opposition MPs say. (Aug 28, 2003,Dominion Post,A3)

The mystery of Corngate continues to deepen, and the government's credibility suffers. (Aug 31, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C8)

Home Truths is Campbell at his most geothermal (in a nice rather than a Corngate way), threatening to engulf his guest in a lahar of delighted affection. (May 24, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),78)

The government became distracted by "Corngate" while the Nats simply imploded. (Feb 2005,North & South,104)

'Corngate' and 'lying in unison' have occupied the media recently, and both stories have common themes, writes State Services Commissioner Michael Wintringham. (Sep 10, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

Her fury was warranted over several aspects of Corngate, but it was less justifiable in the case of Paintergate. (Jul 15, 2002,Dominion Post,A2)

Even though there was an odour coming from this "corngate" issue, they couldn't quite work out what it was. (Jul 21, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A12)

Corngate was memorable, because it was sort of controversial and much talked about. (Jun 2005,Tearaway,24)

Ah, Corngate. Hand me another pinhead to dance on. (Sep 13, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

cornies¶

n. (See cf. weeties)

`CORNIES' ... butter ... sugar ... flour ... dates ... egg ... cornflakes ... baking powder ... vanilla ... milk ... Spread flakes on board, and roll teaspoon lots ... Bake ... (1938,Souvenir Book of Cookery Recipes,41)

cornstalk¶

n. the Aust. nickname for orig. a NSW man, later applied occas. as a gen. term for an Australian, esp. in WW1.

THOMSON Two generations in Australia change the children of the broad-shouldered emigrants into a lithe race more nervous than muscular. `Sydney corn-stalks,' as the youth of that city are denominated, are no match in intellect against men brought up in colder countries. For this reason Australia settlers ... (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,2/230)

The epithet `cornstalk' graphically depicts one change. In New South Wales and Victoria the colonial born grow tall and thin ... (1877,TrNZI,9/43)

[Intercolonial Cricket match] ... Yates showed fine form, and appeared to master the Cornstalks' bowling, ... In the New South Wales second innings . (1890,First Fifty Years,87)

Footballers in almost every part of the Colony will be given the opportunity of seeing the Cornstalks and the Bananalanders [sc. the NSW and Queensland football teams] rushing the leather. (Jul 1, 1905,NZ Truth,2)

McCANDLISH For instance in the route march through Cairo the Australians were there. The papers ... did not mention the Cornstalks at all. (Jan 5, 1915,Letter) [NOTES: 1915 Jan 5 McCandlish letter in 1984 Pugsley Gallipoli 81]

SCANLAN Geoffrey ... was an Australian, a typical Cornstalk in appearance. (1933,Tides of Youth,52)

FULLARTON On his own the Aussie's a regular guy ... Three cornstalks for every Kiwi in the Middle East. (1944,Troop Target,104)

corokia¶

n. Corokia buddleoides

LAING & BLACKWELL (1906,Plants of NZ) [NOTES: (And)]

n. Corokia cotoneaster

LAING AND BLACKWELL (1906,Plants of NZ) [NOTES: (And).]

n. (See korokio)

The corokia berries are very popular in autumn. (Nov 5, 1999,Dominion,12)

Coromandel Granite¶

n. rock classification

Mr D.N.B. Skinner - a petrographic and stratigraphic study of the Moehau-Colville area, Coromandel Peninsula, with special attention to xenoliths in [sic] and the contact aureole of quartz diorite intrusives ("Coromandel Granite") and the relationship of Tertiary sediments and volcanics. (Dec 1961,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,11/3)

Coromandel Green¶

n. a strain of cannabis

Thames plods along reliant on light industry, farming, forestry, tourism and, if local lore is to be believed, "Coromandel Green": cannabis. (Aug 23, 1999,Dominion,8)

Coromandel striped gecko¶

n. extremely rare and elusive gecko found on Coromandel Pennisula. [Hoplodactylus stephensi Coromandel poulations. aka Striped gecko Genus B: stephensi]

A lone male Coromandel striped gecko Hoplodactylus stephensi "Coromandel" has appeared in a home garden in the Coromandel township. No other is known to be alive so it is possible the species may effectively be extinct.It is New Zealand's rarest and most elusive reptile, and the world's rarest gecko.It is the third live Coromandel striped gecko to be found, since a male was first discouvered in 1997 just 300 metres away. (Jan 17, 2007,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.terranature.org/geckoCoroStriped.htm]

Environment Waikato has granted $20,000 from its Environmental Initiatives Fund to sponsor the construction of a pest-proof fence around the Driving Creek Wildlife Sanctuary. .. The sanctuary could also be important for species that don't need a large habitat area, such as the rare Coromandel striped gecko. (Dec 2007,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.ew.govt.nz/News-and-events/Media-releases-archived/Council-grant-to-fund-pest-proof-fence-in-the-Coromandel/]

Mist Preservation Society Inc. - for rat control on the Mist Scenic Reserve on the northern Coromandel Peninsula. The 240ha Mist Scenic Reserve hosts the Moehau Beetle and the Coromandel striped gecko. Kiwis are also present. Up to $84,439. (2004,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.beehive.govt.nz/Documents/Files/Biodiversity%20Grants%202004%20-%20regional%20details.pdf Hon Marian Hobbs Minister of Environment Hon Chris Carter Minister of Conservation Biodiversity Condition and Advice Fund Grants 2004]

Coromandel weed¶

n.

(Sep 12, 1999,Sunday Star Times,C6)

coronation cake¶

n. a pink/red cake (from the addition of cochineal)

CORONATION CAKE ... butter, sugar, flour and almonds, 2 eggs ... baking powder ... cochineal ... bake. (1932,St Andrew's Cookery Book,150)

coronation pudding¶

n.

CORONATION PUDDING ... flour ... raisins ... peel ... sugar ... butter in ... boiling water ... soda ... cold water ... Mix over night ... Steam. (1938,Souvenir Book of Cookery Recipes,28)

corporate farm¶

1 n. (Rural) a large farm property owned by many shareholders.

Ben Nevis can truly be described as a corporate farm, far removed from the nuclear-family ownership ... (1987,NZ Journal of Agriculture,6)

corpse reviver¶

n. an alchoholic pick-me-up drink; a first drink to dispel a hangover; the `hair of the dog'; G.J.Griffiths notes: liquor name; not quoted, but McHutcheson has added pencil quotes in his copy to show colloquialism; US context

McHUTCHESON (1888,New Zealander Abroad, The,128) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

DAVIDSON (1889,Stories of NZ Life,38)

When he awoke, thirsty and thick-headed, he grabbed his coat, looked for his quondam friend, and made a beeline for the bar and a corpse reviver, but lo! he had not the wherewithal. Meville(?) had copped the oof and mizzle (Mar 12, 1910,NZ Truth,246/7/(5)-6)

Corrections¶

n. short for the Corrections Department [Jim Cameron writes: Used in recent legislation and admimnistration to denote the penal system.There is a Department of Corrections and community corrections (non-custodial punishments - see Criminal Justice Amendment Act 1993, S.48). DNZE notes under probie that the term community corrections replaces probation service. This was my belief but probation service is commonly used in the press e.g. NZ Herald 29/3/2000. A specific use of the general term correction for punishment. Recorded in NZ Oxford Paperback.]

Corrections (meaning legal penalties and punishments) is a recent import from North America. It is not in NSOD; NZPOD) categorises it as archaic. But we now have a Department of Corrections and community corrections, that is, non-custodial penalties. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2)

This raises questions about disciplinary procedures within Corrections on mistakes of this magnitude. (Oct 11, 2000,Dominion,10)

The department, through Corrections Minister Matt Robson, said it did everything by the book and it cannot be faulted over its handling of Hotene. (Oct 11, 2000,Dominion,10)

Corrections Department¶

n.

The Corrections Department blundered appallingly by not objecting to multiple sex-offender Taffy Hotene being paroled last April after serving eight years of a 12-year sentence for rape and other serious assaults... The Parole Board should be less willing to free dangerous criminals early and the Corrections Department should be quicker to pursue section 105 objections to early release. (Oct 11, 2000,Dominion,10)

corrections officer¶

n. a prison warder

Rimutaka Prison corrections officer Jack Boynton - once he'd have been known as a prison warden - has more daily exposure to criminals than ordinary people ever do. (Nov 17, 1999,Evening Post,23)

corrective training¶

n. a custodial sentence of 3 months duration for young offenders. [Jim Cameron writes: In its present form it was introduced in 1985 by the Criminal Justice Act. Formerly (1954-63) an indeterminate sentence for adult offenders of up to 3 years' imprisonment, based on British legislation of 1948 and replacing in part (see preventative detention) the sentence of reformative detention (1910-1954).]

Correspondence¶

n. short for Correspondence School (esp. in the phrase on correspondence i.e. receiving education from the Correspondence School)

Geary And I said to Dad I wanted to go on correspondence and just ride around with him in his truck. (2003,Man of the People, A,108)

Correspondence School¶

n. a state-funded institution providing education by mail and other media to children living in remote parts of the country or otherwise unable to attend ordinary schools. [also as Correspondence elliptical q.v.] (See also TCS abbreviation)

According to the Correspondence School principal, the broadcasts back up written lessons, are useful for language and music courses.. and serve to pass on useful housekeeping information. (Apr 8, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

According to the Correspondence School principal, the broadcasts back up written lessons, are useful for language and music courses.. and serve to pass on useful housekeeping information. (Apr 8, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

MACNICOL The children were educated by correspondence school. (1965,Skippers Road,118)

Initially it played in the morning and then moved to the afternoon along with the Correspondence School and the Schools Current Affairs Programmes. (Feb 15, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

Will there be any use of Dept of Ed, university, correspondence school videos and resources? (Jan 7, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

Home schoolers also face signifcant financial barriers if they wish to make use of the Correspondence School..."Why should we have to pay so much for Correspondence School tuition when those who have been kicked out of school for smoking dope get it for free?" (Dec 1999,North & South,124)

My copy had also arrived the day before, and had just been jettisoned down the long drop dunny, as did all things which looked like official mail from the Correspondence school Clifton Terrace Wellington. (2001,Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success,17)

HENDERSON I fear I would have defied to the death Correspondence School lessons, even had I been leg-roped. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,153)

Every one of the pupils of the correspondence school is isolated from the railroad and other recognised means of transport. (May 6, 1939,Taranaki Herald,6)

Correspondence School is a Department of Education production emanating from Wellington... (1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

The Minister of Education.. spoke particularly of the excellent work accomplished by the correspondence school which had been started four years ago with only 40 pupils. (Mar 18, 1924,Otago Witness,59)

OWEN & PERKINS Nowadays, if you have too few children for a school, you have this magnificent service, the Correspondence School. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,176)

corrie¶

n. (informal) corrugated iron [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

The sky is blue, the pub is lemon and it's got a red corrie roof with a little lion in [sic]it. (Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),60)

Corriedale¶

n. a breed of NZ sheep evolved from Rommey, Lincoln, Merino and Leicester breeds to yield both wool and meat f. the name of the estate in North Otago, NZ, where the breed was evolved.

In The Corriedale, New Zealand's Contribution to the Sheep World,' 1924, G.H. Holford ...designates these animals, arising from merino and long-wool sheep, aspossibly the finest combination wool and mutton breed in the world.' The first Corriedales were bred by Mr. James Little from Romneys ... and merinos already present in the country. (1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/342)

SMITH THE CORRIEDALE. The breed originated through ... Mr.J.Little of Corriedale, New Zealand ... These sheep were known for some time as in-bred half-breeds, and as the breeds became more fixed were named after Mr.Little's property `Corriedale'. (1927,Sheep & Wool Industry,43)

The wool industry, however, has been markedly affected by the scientific breeding work carried out by James Little, the founder of the Corriedale. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,296)

STUDHOLME The Corriedale is New Zealand's contribution to the sheep breeds of the world. (1940,Te Waimate,96)

CRESSWELL Before long he had begun experiments on fixing a breed of sheep we call to-day `Corriedale'. Hitherto merinos were pastured on the runs and a few cross-breds on the farms. How to dispose of the merino ewe lambs? Crossed by the Leicester or Lincoln, the half-bred progeny was disappointing in size and fattening quality. ... Little gave it the name of the estate he managed - Corriedale. (1951,Canterbury Tales,57)

SINCLAIR By crossing the Merino with the Lincoln and other strains, New Zealand sheep-breeders produced a new type of sheep, the Corriedale, which came to be prized both in America and Australia because it yielded both good wool and good quality lambs. (1959,History of New Zealand,154)

corriedale n -s usu cap [Corriedale, ranch in New Zealand where the breed was developed] : a member of a dual-purpose breed of rather large usu. hornless sheep developed in New Zealand from the Lincoln, Leicester, and Merino breeds (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,512)

Corriedale n. sheep breed of Victoria. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

Corriedale n. NZ breed of sheep farmed for meat and wool. [estate in N. Otago] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,166) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

On the drier, lighter land of the plains the most predominant breed is the Corriedale. (1945,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),3(6) : 22)

Using merino ewes, which were the principal breed of sheep in the South Island at that time, he [sc. James Little] successfully established a flock of in-bred half-bred sheep which he named Corriedales. (Sep 14, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,83)

The Corriedale should at once give the impression of a hardy sheep, of great constitution. (Jun 10, 1924,Otago Witness,5)

(OEDS) The amendment in favour of naming the breed `Corriedale' was ... put and carried. (1902,Report of Conf. Delegates Agric. Soc.,64)

Some breeders claim that the new breed, Corriedale, is a class of sheep which embraces these desired qualities and possesses a fixity of type. The generally accepted meaning of the Corriedale is a sheep resulting from the fourth cross of half-bred Lincoln-merino, and the rams Lincoln. The progeny of these is half-bred. These in turn are bred, half-breds to half-breds, for four generations, and a Corriedale is the result. It was Mr. James Little, of Allandale, Waikari, Canterbury, who gave sheep bred on these lines the distinctive name of `Corriedale.' (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,93)

HAWKESWORTH (1911,Australian Sheep and Wool) [NOTES: (OEDS)]

(Sep 20, 1915,NZ Journal of Agriculture,271)

MACDONALD The Corriedale is a well woolled sheep ... (1915,NZ Sheepfarming,27)

MACDONALD The Corriedale has been negatively yet appropriately described as a `purebred-crossbred'. (1920,Australian & NZ Sheep Farming,43)

1 n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred sheep [a cross of Merino with long-wolled English Leicester or Lincoln developed in the 1860s by James Little of Corriedale Station in North Otago.]

KERR The Conference of Agricultural and Pastoral Associations in 1902 agreed that this 'in-bred half-bred' should be called Corriedale in deference to Webster whose property was its birth-place. (1976,From the Beginning: chronicles of a county,135)

The generally accepted meaning of the Corriedale is a sheep resulting from the fourth-cross of half-bred Lincoln-Merino and the rams Lincoln. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,93)

The Corriedale is an attempt to fix the half-breed type by inbreeding and has been more or less successful ... (Feb 24, 1906,Farmers' Union Advocate,10)

MEADOWS The Corriedale is now the fourth most popular breed in New Zealand. (1997,Sheep Breeds of New Zealand,38)

Corriedale country¶

1 n. (Rural) Canterbury [particularly the northern downlands where stud Corriedales are bred and flourish.]

NEWTON Surely this [Canterbury] can be called the Corriedale country. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,152)

In the heart of North Canterbury's Corriedale country, John Allan dares to be different. (Sep 18, 1997,NZ Forest Glossary,31)

corro¶

n. abbrev. corrugated iron. [1985 Feb 25 Robin Rait ... put up another sheet of corro.]

corroboree¶

n. applied to a Maori korero; or gen. to a discussion [ca1920s Mr Justice B. O'Regan West Coast Corroboree used for general discussion-meeting; a party]

ROCHFORT After a smoke a corrobery* ensued, then we began to think of taking some rest. The whare was built of toi-toi, about 12 feet by 8, and 6 feet to the ridge-pole; ... [fn] Conversation. (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,35)

PYKE We had a `corroboree' over our digging experiences on Ballarat, Fryer's Creek, Mount Alexander, Bendigo, Mount Korong; (1887,History of the Early Gold Discoveries in Otago,39,1962 ed.)

GAMBIER After a day or two of Corroborries (called in Maori Koren [sic]), more war-dancing and races ... between the huge war canoes. (1906,Links in My Life,161,1907 ed.)

corrugated iron¶

n. used elsewhere but of special significance in NZ

Past the new corrugated iron and oiled wood school and Willowby's other feature, its garage. (Sep 2, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34)

WAKEFIELD [What to Buy for Exportation] ... some corrugated iron or zinc will be found very handy for roofing houses or verandahs quickly. `congregated iron' (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,446) [NOTES: [?First use.]]

A corrugated iron house will speedily, I am told, be erected here ... (May 7, 1864,Nelson Examiner,8)

PRESHAW The first building erected by the Bank of NSW at Hokitika was a corrugated iron one. (1888,Banking Under Difficulties,142) [NOTES: -]

Though the musicians sit on the green grass of the set for Circa's current production, Playing a Round, somewhat incongruous with its corrugated iron sheds, they were here to amuse us as much through the words as through the music. (Feb 5, 2002,Evening Post,16)

When he bathes, a sheet of corrugated iron acts as a windbreak. (Jan 6, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

their first steps are from the carpark.. up past For most, the corrugated-iron camphouse that originally served as a redcoat barracks in New Plymouth and is reputed to be the oldest surviving corrugated iron-structire in the world. (Sep 27, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),44)

Past the old Waihohonu Hut, with double-skin corrugated iron walls packed with pumice insulation. (Aug 28, 2004,Dominion Post,E16)

On the goldfields, timber is preceded by calico and corrugated iron. (1876,TrNZI,8/166) [NOTES: Blair Building Materials Otago]

In 1957 Bruce Mason, thinking of New Zealand, disdainfully enquired, "What sort of society can develop under corrugated iron?" (Aug 18, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),39)

Hard rain on a corrugated iron roof has always held a special place in my memories, more so when it is West Coast rain, and you're sitting in front of a cosy fire. (Aug 2004,Photographer's Mail, The,13 (8)/8)

HILL The rows of two-tiered spectator benches within the corrugated-iron enclosures are composed of radiata from Ballantyne's Sawmills - undressed rather than dressed radiata, one should mention. (1985,More from Moaville,22)

HENDERSON A short cut down a side street finds us blocked behind a lorry unloading enough corrugated iron to build a second Jerusalem. (1962,One Foot at the Pole,22)

Hemi would put a small sheet of corrugated iron on the embers. (Oct 5, 1992,Sunday Times (NZ),24)

STEWART It was a big house, of white painted timber, with a red corrugated iron roof. (1983,Springtime in Taranaki,29) [NOTES: 1991 edition]

ROBERTS In September a large store, 100 feet by 60 feet, was built with galvanised corrugated iron. (1890,History of Oamaru & North Otago,43) [NOTES: quote from 1886]

From rows of suburban houses in Porirua East, a long driveway sweeps up to a farmhouse, farm dogs barking in kennels and a typical corrugated iron wool shed sits against rolling hills. (Dec 2001,Elements,13 : 1)

HILL Lofty's garage .. was built of corrugated iron - a not uncommon building medium in Moaville, where corrugated iron is used for garden sheds, water troughs, haybarns, lean-tos, personal apartments for goats., and the Ladies' and Gent's at the Moaville United Rugby Football Club. (1985,More from Moaville,60)

CORSO¶

abbr. Council of Organisations for Relief Services Overseas [ORIGIN: acronym]

This quality implies a religious attitude to life, which indeed underlies ... the application of these abroad, as in Corso's work, ... (1962,Landfall Country,44) [NOTES: 1953 Mar Brasch in 1962 Landfall Country 44]

McLINTOCK The New Zealand Council for Organisations for Relief Services Overseas, familiarly called CORSO, coordinates the work of many religious, national, youth, labour, medical, relief, and charitable organisations which are interested in relief of distressed areas throughout the world. It was formed on 16 August 1944 ... (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/403)

SLATTER He was sick of school ... the collecting of money for CORSO and UNICEF, ... the double periods of history ... (1968,Pagan Game, The,63)

Corso - the initials stand for Council of Relief Services Overseas - was set up in August 1944 when the National Council of Churches, the New Zealand Red Cross Society and the Society of Friends met to form an organisation for post-war relief work. (Feb 7, 1974,Dominion,4/5)

... the correct full name of Corso since 1972 has been simply CORSO (Incorporated). Before then its name was the New Zealand Council of Organisations for Relief Services Oversea (Incorporated), from which the acronym Corso was formed. In 1972 the acronym became the legal name. Since 1972 the legal name CORSO (Incorporated) has been followed in the rules by a descriptive phrase, which is not part of the legal name. (Aug 29, 1979,Dominion,6)

M,ARSHALL He gave startlingly large donations to CORSO and the Leper appeal. (1982,Master of Big Jingles,22)

BOYD ..., Mrs S.M. Ballantyne, wife of a local doctor, who had come from England 6 years earlier, was a member of the CORSO committee and a Girl Guides commissioner and promised to promote women's interests. (1984,City of the Plains,388)

cossack¶

n. a nickname for a Boer commando

[Memories of a Veldt Christmas] They've found us! We'd betterfootsack' a bit further down. The `cossack' on the flat rock was possibly thinking that his watch in the history of the world ... (Dec 1, 1919,Quick March,43)

cossie¶

n. a swimming costume.

The cossies are gorgeous as well as adaptable, impossible without a lot of imagination and a tonne of velcro. (Sep 26, 2001,Capital Times,11)

They not only have to cope with the rapid fire farcical elements of hurtling in and out of doors, up and down ladders and making quick cossie changes, they must also rapidly waltz around the stage changing sets. (Nov 14, 2001,Capital Times,9)

McGILL cossie a swimming costume. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,30)

I've more important things to think about, like swimwear and celebrities and will next summer's cossies spell an end to pubic hair once and for all? (Jun 5, 2001,Evening Post Flair,4)

BEARDSLEY They went brown as berries in the hand-me-down cossies, drooping from shouldersto skinny knees, at the swimming hole... The boys didn't wear cossies, that's why, and they'd skite after about how red their bums had got. Ibid. 243 cossies bathing costumes (1984,Blackball 08,152)

Speedos celebrate their 75th anniversary this year. We've always thought of them as the great Kiwi togs although, like the pavlova, Australians claim ownership of the "great Aussie cossie". (Nov 22, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

cossie club¶

n. (informal) Cosmopolitan Club [Google search mar 2006: 300 hits all NZ on WWW.]

He and Bartlett do sit-down acoustic shows around the RSAs, cossie clubs and so on, and he likes them. (Apr 30, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

They're more liekly to go to a restaurant or cozzy club. (Feb 23, 2005,Radio NZ / National Radio)

COST¶

abbr. Citizens Opposed to the Springbok Tour

Passions ran high and the country was divided, but Citizens Opposed to the Springbok Tour (COST) was not intent on revolution, or even challenging social structures. (Jul 17, 2001,Evening Post,7)

cot¶

n. (Rural) a sheep with a cotted (matted) fleece.

TURNER There are [shearers'] names for types of sheep, the cot with matted wool; the cobbler, a difficult one; ... (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,147)

BOWEN cot: a sheep with matted wool. (1955,Wool Away!,155)

cot-case¶

n. very sick or injured person, confined to bed

[Caption] Cot cases paying their tribute to departed comrades. (May 2, 1928,25 Years of Care,27)

A COT CASE. [title] ... sketch ... of his first day in a military hospital. (Dec 2, 1918,Quick March,18)

J.G. WILSON He said those who were not cot cases were not allowed to smoke in the Ward but cot cases could and they were striking matches all night long to light their cigs. (Mar 23, 1929,Letter) [NOTES: 1929 Mar 23 J.G.Wilson Letter in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 218 [cf also transf. and fig.]]

ALISON The doctor considered him a `cot-case', giving him only two years to live. (1939,New Zealander Looks On, A,56)

CHERRILL He almost looks like a cot-case. (1950,Story of a NZ Sheepfarm,173)

CRUMP You take it easy for a few days, lad. We don't want to make a cot-case out of you. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,42)

SARGESON cot cases: patients confined to bed. (1964,Collected Stories,298) [NOTES: Pearson Glossary]

KNIGHT The unfortunate result ... was that his nervous system and glands were undermined and soon he was a cot case. (1986,Geriatrics, The,104)

There were many cot cases, especiallyfrom Walton... The Medical Service choseto call them cot cases, and cot casesthey were to be. (Nov 15, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/6 :124)

2 n. someone incapacitated esp. by drink; someone hopelessly drunk

SLATTER There we were arse up with care over the bank--- ...On the dog-dosing strip at Kuripuni I fell in love with you---His one desire was to sing soprano in the village choir- A real cot case---The far queue. (1968,Pagan Game, The,162)

SARGESON We don't want any more cot-cases. (1946,That Summer,133)

HASCOMBE One man asked, Are they both crook, then?' ...One is very tired and the other not too well.' `Two cot-cases - that's what I meant,' he said. (1969,Down and Almost Under,123)

McGILL cot case lunatic or very drunk, fit only for a cot or baby's enclosed bed. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,30)

cott¶

1 n. (Rural) a sheep's fleece that has become matted.

In eight years of classifying fleeces at the hill country station, the percentage of cotts varied from 63 per cent in 1953 to 24 per cent in 1958. The chief effect of age appeared to be increasing the number of cotts rather than the severity of cotting. (Sep 14, 1961,NZ Farmer,8)

Crossbred cotts (2-8 per cent of national sale) were 3 per cent cheaper, as were bulky skirtings and second-shear bellies and pieces. (Dec 14, 2001,Dominion,19)

Cotts - fleeces in which the fibres have felted together. (1919,Wool in NZ,20)

COOP In several Romney clips which normally had several bales of cotts, there are now one whatever. (1950,Shearing Ewes before Lambing,22)

BARTON Grading - good: remove cotts .. average: remove hard cotts. (1972,Sheepfarming Annual 1972,110)

MAF Cott: fleece that has become matted during growth. A very badly matted fleece is termed a hard cott and a lightly matted fleece a soft cott. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,54)

Cotts, 4.2% of the sale, were up 2.5 per cent cheaper than last year. (May 24, 2002,Dominion,15)

1 v. (Rural) [sheep fleece-wool] to mat or tangle.

The ewes cotted as two-tooths showed approximately twice the tendency to cott than sheep free as two-tooths. It was of interest to note that the tendency to cott as a two-tooth indicated a tendency to cott throughout its lifetime. (Sep 14, 1961,NZ Farmer,9)

cottage¶

1 n. (Rural) a secondary house on a farm or station, often small, and occupied by a married shepherd or ''married man''.

PULLEN .. we decided to put the furniture in an old empty farm cottage on Archie Bayley's place at Kanakanaia. (1996,On the Road Again,8)

The other dwelling on the station is a two-bedroom cottage. (May 4, 1993,NZ Farmer,27)

NEWTON With the homestead itself the star attraction, the setup of staff cottages and buildings is perhaps Richmond Brook's most striking feature. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,80)

cotted¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheep or fleecewool] matted.

This agreed with other evidence showing that cotted sheep produced less wool but more lambs. (Sep 14, 1961,NZ Farmer,9)

HENDERSON Most cotted fleeces have a hairy tip. (1968,Growing Better Wool,100)

BARTON Heavily cotted fleeces may have to be subject to more vigorous opening procedures. This can lead to extra expense ands results in greater fibre breakage so that ideally cotted fleeces should be kept separate. (1971,Sheepfarming Annual 1971,5)

BARTON Inferior grade - heavily discoloured, unskirted but with locks separate, may be cotted and carrying vegetable matter. (1972,Sheepfarming Annual 1972,108)

LOUGHNAN cotted: trhis usually occurs in a high rainfall area. Not only is the fibre matted but also the yolk sets hard and the shears will not drive through the fleece easily. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,20)

OGONOWSKA-COATES It was the cotted sheep that got the better of the ringer. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,68)

cottiness¶

1 n. (Rural) the matting of fleecewool [usually due to wet weather and poor nutrition.]

Up here we have trouble with water stain and cottiness if fleeces get too long. (Aug 9, 1984,NZ Farmer,18)

cotting¶

1 n. (Rural) matting of fleece wool on sheep.

.. the question of the matting or cotting of wool is rather a difficult one, as it arises from so many causes. (Dec 1893,NZ Farmer,451)

.. markedly faulty fleeces showing break, cotting and weak, open backs. (Nov 11, 1951,NZ Farmer,8)

The chief effect of age appeared to be increasing the number of cotts rather than the severity of cotting. (Sep 14, 1961,NZ Farmer,8)

HENDERSON Usually when wool is affected by break it is also deficient in some other respects chiefly through associated cotting and yellow staining. (1968,Growing Better Wool,37)

It is a widely held view that frequent wetting leads to severe cotting. (1968,Growing Better Wool,64)

BARTON Thus it seems that the factors contributing to fibre length (staple length, soundness and freedom from cotting) could be of greater future importance. (1971,Sheepfarming Annual 1971,5)

cotton ball¶

n. niniao [cf. cotton shrub]

cotton ball [=] niniao [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,16)

cotton bush¶

n. a name given to both Pomaderris phylicaefolia, and Cassinia leptophylla, both also called tauhinu. [aka cottonwood]

It [Chewings fescue] develops a thick mat of roots or sole that successfully resists the intrusion of the manuka, fern, and cotton bush, the foes of the northern settler upon arid country. (May 10, 1892,Timaru Herald,2)

cotton fireweed¶

n. Erechtites quadridentata

cotton fireweed [s] Erechtites quadridentata (Lab.) DC. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,16)

TAYLOR COTTON FIREWEED (Erechtites quadridentata). ... Many fine hairs give the whole plant a silvery appearance. Cotton fireweed is native to New Zealand and also to Australia. (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,53)

cotton plant¶

n.

n. (Rural) Celmisia spp..[used by early rural travellers to make leggings for protection from the spikes of matagouri and Spaniard].

HOCHSTETTER Snowgrass and the leaves of the Celmesia coriacea, called cotton plant by the settlers, are often the only feed procurable. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),491)

What should have been grassy flats in themain valley.. were covered to theexclusion of everything else for acres ata time with dense cushions of the commoncotton-plant, Celmisia spectabilis, theleaves dark glossy green above and verywoolly beneath. (1933,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,II/43)

NEWTON The bulk of the country lies in the south and is cold, unattractive cotton-plant country. (1952,High Country Journey,73)

KERR All these travellers found the going hard, the rough tussock and fern and matagouri and spaniard tearing their clothing and spiking their legs in spite of leggings made of the stripped leaves of tikumi, the cotton plant. (1976,From the Beginning: chronicles of a county,44)

LOUGHNAN cotton plant: mountain daisy of the genus Celmisia. There must be fifty or sixty species, many of which have leaves which vary from a silvery to green upper side and are like cotton wool on the underside .. As they flourish after a fire they also answer to the name fireweed. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,20)

cotton shrub¶

n. = niniao (See cf. cotton ball)

cotton shrub [=] niniao [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,16)

cotton-grass¶

n. Celmisia longifolia.

The various species of Celmisia, chiefly known by the settlers as cotton-grass or leather-plant, appear well adapted for our purpose. (1874,TrNZI,6/56)

cottonwood¶

n. Cassinia leptophylla tauhinu

Cassinia leptophylla, cotton-wood. - Common on sand-hills all round the coast; seeds abundantly. (1873,TrNZI,6/51) [NOTES: (Kirk)]

CHEESEMAN (1906,Manual NZ Flora) [NOTES: (Andersen)]

COCKAYNE Cassinia leptophylla (1907,AJHR,C-8) [NOTES: Report on Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island (And)]

LAING & BLACKWELL Cassinia leptophylla (The Narrow-leaved Cassinia) ... Colonists' [Local] name Cottonwood, Maori name Tauhinu. [In Marlborough particularly a troublesome weed.] (1906,Plants of NZ,433,1940, p. 467 ed.)

COCKAYNE Taranaki, Hawke's Bay, and the shores of Cook Strait have the tauhinu or cottonwood (C[assinia] leptophylla); ... (1910,NZ Plants,72)

LEVY [caption] In the drier (25-in.-rainfall belt) the fern and tutu, scrub and forests came readily to rye-white pastures on the lowlands with a tardy development to danthonia, meadow rice grass, sweet vernal and annual clovers on the hills, often after repeated clearing of manuka, cottonwood, etc. Ibid. 293 Gorse, blackberry, bracken fern, hard fern, manuka, cottonwood, tauhinu, and other scrub growths are neglected on the hills, ... (1951,Grasslands of NZ,253,1970 ed.)

EVANS The whole [Waikaka] valley and the ... ridges were covered [in 1876] with luxurious white tussocks (Poa caespitosa) diversified with a few snow grass tussocks (Danthonia raoulii), trees and shrubs comprising Maukoko, or native broom (Carmichaelia australia[?lis]), Koromiko (Veronica salicifo), daisy tree (Aleria rirgata [?virgata]), cottonwood (Cassinia fulvida), ... native thorns or matagouri and mingimingi (Coprosma propinqua). [check] (1962,Waikaka Saga,239)

MOORE & IRWIN CASSINIA LEPTOPHYLLA. Cassinia is a genus of Australasian and South African shrubs. The five New Zealand species, known as cottonwoods'ortauhinu', ... The grey-leaved C. leptophylla so invaded neglected hill pastures (as about Wellington) that it, along with the golden tauhinu C. fulvida, was designated a`scheduled noxious weed'. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,138)

cottonwood n. NZ = TAUHINU. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,168) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 253]]

n.

HUDSON (1898,NZ Moths & Butterflies) [NOTES: (And)]

2 n. (See tauhinu)

cotton-wood, New Zealand [=] golden tauhinu: mountain tauhinu: niniao: tauhinu [s] Ibid. 52 New Zealand cotton-wood [=] golden tauhinu: mountain tauhinu: niniao: tauhinu [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,16) [NOTES: [???check -weed]]

tauhinu noun, a small shrub; the New Zealand cottonwood. (1979,Heinemann NZ Dictionary,1133)

2 n.

COCKAYNE (And) Cassinia fulvida (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

LEVY ... shrubs common in the tussock zone: matagouri, native brooms, dwarf koromikos, monoao, sarmentose tutu, the grasslike spiky-leaved Spaniard, the harsh patotara, golden cottonwood, cushion-like pimeleas, and the low, matted, carpet-like growth of the scabweeds are characteristic of the low tussock country, ... Ibid. 89 [Table 2] Golden cottonwood (1951,Grasslands of NZ,35,1970 ed.)

2 n. Cassinia Vauvilliersii.

COCKAYNE (And) Cassinia Vauvilliersii YELLOW-LEAVED MOUNTAIN-COTTONWOOD (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

MARK & ADAMS Cassinia vauvilliersii (Homb. &. Jacq.) Hook. f. MOUNTAIN COTTONWOOD (1973,NZ Alpine Plants,166)

DENNIS Mountain cottonwood (Cassinia vauvilliersii) and Senecio bennettii are also common plants in plants in the region immediately above the bushline. (1981,Paparoas Guide,164)

2 n.

LEVY [Table 2] Silver cottonwood (1951,Grasslands of NZ,89,1970 ed.)

cotty¶

adj. of wool, matted; of a sheep, with cotted wool

BOWEN [One blow is made] ... with the comb on the side to cut the morty neck wool (the first few inches up the neck) that is always a bit cotty and is the hardest to break. (1955,Wool Away!,32)

RICHARDS Unfortunately in the afternoon we got ahead of the musterers, so the manager had to run in a mob of undagged cotty sheep that were being held until the cut out. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,130)

n. (Rural) a sheep with matted fleece wool.

LOUGHNAN cotty (n): a sheep with cotted fleece which the shearer invariably leaves as his cobbler. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,20)

ADDENBROOKE It became okay as long as I had good cutting wool but when I came to a cotty ... (1992,Home from the Hill,145)

.. Canterbury duster, Waiouru blonde, cotty, decoy, glue pot and scrubdasher. (Nov 22, 2002,Dominion,C6)

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheep's fleecewool] matted and sticky.

RICHARDS Unfortunately in the afternoon we got ahead of the musterers, so the manager had to run in a mob of undagged cotty sheep that were being held until the cut out. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,130)

WATERSON The sheep were sticky and cotty. (1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,63)

cotula¶

n.

TAYLOR COTULA AUSTRALIS (Cotula australis) ... This plant, probably introduced from Australia, is one of the most widespread in New Zealand. (1980,Weeds of Crops,33)

cotula australis [s] Cotula australis (Sieb.) Hook. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,16)
