couch¶

n. [nf Weeds 1984; see also grass]

HILGENDORF TWITCH (Agropyron repens) is sometimes called couch, and [also] blue, English, white, or old man, twitches or couch. It is one of the worst twitch [?es] of arable land and gardens. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,49,1967 ed.)

Cooch was an enemy to be guarded against. (Aug 31, 2000,Evening Post,16)

couch burning¶

n. [student ritual, esp Otago but also Massey; see also couch fire]

Couch burning has been rife in Palmerston North in recent days as students celebrated the end of their exams. .. For the students, couch burning is normal, along with stealing road signs and drunkeness. (Jun 23, 2008,Manawatu Standard,8,1 ed.)

couch fire¶

n. burning of a couch or sofa; a traditional act of vandalism by Otago tertiary students [note also couch burning]

A firefighter was cut by a beer bottle thrown at him while extinguishing a couch fire earlier in the year ... (May 23, 2005,NZ Herald,3)

Police were unable to contain those who gathered on Castle St to watch a couch fire set about 11.50 pm, just as more young people poured from the Gardens Tavern. (Aug 25, 2008,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/19320/undie-visitors-not-blame]

To point out the fact that a couch fire is more than a simple prank but a criminal matter punishable by a serious term of imprisonment.[sic] Couch fires damage the surface of the road ... (Jul 25, 2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.campuscop.co.nz/fires]

At around 7 pm at least two couch fires were lit .. Meanwhile a large contingent of students left behind by police, lit more couch fires and set alight an Undie 500 van. One couch fire came dangerously close to engulfing a flat. (Aug 26, 2007,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.critic.co.nz/about/home23?page=4]

No smoke without a couch fire: Stereotyping Students (Apr 10, 2007,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.critic.co.nz/about/features/10?page=13]

couchy¶

adj. (See couch)

MACDONALD Owing to its [sc. poa pratensis] `couchy' root habits, it should not be quartered in land intended for cultivation. (1920,Australian & NZ Sheep Farming,112)

coudie¶

n. (See kauri)

coudy¶

n. (See kauri)

cough one's cud¶

phr. (Rural) to vomit.

RICHARDS The poor townie turned green, rushed for the rail, and as we say in the country, coughed his cud. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,91)

couldn't sell a statue to a pigeon¶

phr. a catchphrase said of a completely ineffectual person [1957 July (Christchurch) (R. Mason)]

McGILL couldn't sell a statue to a pigeon derisive remark about an ineffectual person. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

coumala¶

n. (See kumara)

Council¶

n. short for Executive Council

MULGAN If they can't block us in the House, they'll do it in the Council. (1934,Spur of Morning,212)

2 n. (historical) short for Provincial Council

Wm. is `in town' ...[sic] he is made clerk of the Council (our Parliament that is) and is proposed Attorney for the province by the Superintendent and Council. (Oct 30, 1853,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/136,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (Jane M. Richmond)]

Council house¶

n. whare runanga

BULLER I had been addressing a large meeting of natives in the Whare-runanga, or Council-house [at Rangitikei], on a matter of considerable political importance, and had been urging my views with all the earnestness that the subject demanded. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,89,1888 2nd edn 1/96 ed.)

Council of Trade Unions¶

n.

If [the Federation of Labour] doesn't do it by subsuming itself into the proposed Council of Trade Unions, it'll go of collective lung cancer: walk into an FOL conference and you're in the original smoke-filled room. (May 31, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

count¶

n. (Rural) [sp. to stock drafting and sales] a tally or total.

LOUGHNAN count: the number of sheep in a flock. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,21)

1 n. (Rural) the degree of fineness or coarseness of the fleece wool of a sheep.

LOUGHNAN Count: Term classifying the diameter of a wool fibre. It now frequently describes a quality, eg 54s quality. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,21)

TAIT Glen Lea Romney wool is dense, of medium count and is noted for ... (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,105)

STEVENS Count is sufficiently strongly inherited to breed a particular count with some degree of certainty - or at least the range of count in the ewe flock can be kept within limits which ensure that the most profitable fleeces are being produced. As the rams have been well fed and are males, it is wise to select for a count coarser than the wool required for the ewe flock. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,112)

count out¶

v.

count out ... NZ & Austral. count (sheep) as they leave shearing shed. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,168) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

count-out¶

1 n. (Rural) the tallying of stock.

RICHARDS After count-out' he flew at Les ... and condemned the quality of his work. ... Les got hischip' all right, but Roy's [the foreman's] comments were unfair compared to the quality of shearing turned out ... (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,122)

WESTMACOTT The count-out through the gate proved the number correct. (1977,After-Breakfast Cigar, The,115)

count-out pen¶

n. counting-out pen

Count-out pen: Pen adjacent to a shearing stand into which sheep are released after shearing to be counted. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,54)

1 n. (Rural) a tally pen where sheep are held once shorn, crutched, dipped or drafted but before tallies are made.

Count-out pens can help with quality control. Count-out pens are exactly that, pens to collect and count sheep in after shearing. (2002,Wool Grower,Winter 18)

MILLS In those days .. a shearer had to shear cleanly, or have his sheep heavily marked in the count-out pens and excluded from his tally. (1960,Sheep-O,122)

counter¶

n. a varied use of shoemakers' counter (OED2 sb&sup6.) `The piece stiff leather forming the back part of a shoe or boot round the heel'.

STRONACH Some of us had added to our boots what is known as a counter'. It is a stiff piece of leather, which, commencing at the instep, runs round the back of the boot, above the heel proper, acts as an ankle support, and prevents its wearer fromgoing over'. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,14)

counter lunch¶

n. lunchtime meal served at the bar of a pubOR: savoury (often reputedly salty) snacks provided free to drinkers; cf. counter snack

A counter lunch was put on consisting ofbaked potatoes, rissoles, sausage rollsor lambs' fry. (Jun 13, 1924,Grey River Argus,4)

There'll be some battles won over the counter-lunch. (Aug 9, 1943,NZEF Times,III/111 : 6)

HYDE ... the counterlunches you could once get in any New Zealand pub. Ibid. 202 When they came in late there were always huge door-step sandwiches ..., with slices of ham and sweet pickles in them, just like the old counter-lunches you could once get in any New Zealand pub by putting down sixpence for a handle of beer. (1936,Passport to Hell,193)

HYDE He broke off [drinking] to say: `Johnnie, are you off counter lunches? It's a bit late, but I'm half starved. Couldn't you turn on a counter supper for once?' Ibid. 257 All the hotels had dropped their counter lunches [at the start of the Depression], but tha hit custom so heavily that they had to resurrect a ghost of the old hearty piles; that was only between noon and two o'clock, and you had to nip in quickly, or the sere sandwiches and stale pickles had been whisked out of sight. Cheese was a thing of the past. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,158)

Cheese is bung. By long tradition this has been our tradition. Bung comes in two varieties - mild or tasty. Or soap and putty. Something to fill up on ... or to toss on the bar as counter-lunch. Come to think of it, counter-lunch is le mot juste, stifling as it does all desire for other food. (Dec 1952,Here & Now,5)

SLATTER And who's got the pub now? they ask. As if it matters. ... as if he really were shouting one now and then like they used to. And counter-lunch too. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,225)

MACKAY The old-time counter-lunch has gone, of course, and times don't seem the same without it. [77] The menu consisted mostly of squares of bread and cheese, hot saveloys (halved ...) and sardines and toast. (1961,Puborama,76)

BAXTER When the counter lunch came in he ate five saveloys, ... (1985,Horse,24) [NOTES: c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Name and the Game ?d) 24]

SARGESON counter-lunch: plates of sandwiches or savouries put on the bar of a hotel. (1964,Collected Stories,298) [NOTES: Pearson Glossary]

LEE He seemed to spend the rest of his money on beer; not much on food when there was counter lunch on the bar. (1965,Rhetoric at the Red Dawn,122)

SARGESON ... I had one forenoon invested in a half-handle of beer as an excuse for establishing myself in a public bar handily close to the service door through which trays of counterlunch would shortly be borne ... (1965,Memoirs of a Peon,250)

BAXTER Nobody gets a look in/ When Caelius cleans up the counter-lunch/ ... Cheese, chicken, saveloys, black pudding,/ (Sep 4, 1966,Collected Poems,359)

Bill SAara instructed us in mine and face sampling - a major Coal Survey task - and in the attributes of Albion (now Kings) "counter lunches" on Fridays. (Mar 1987,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,74/40)

SIMPSON They told us about one hotel that put on a counter-lunch at midday. It was apparently a pretty good one with cheese on toast, roast rabbit, rissoles and the like. (1974,Sugarbag Years,29)

HUNT In the city pubs they'd put on a counter lunch at ten in the morning. (1981,Speaking a Silence,146)

Counter lunch was on at a neighbouring hostelry. (Nov 8, 1913,NZ Observer,20)

Counter "lunches" look like feasts. (1945,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),3(3) : 28)

When food was cheap, and counter-lunchwas always on... I lent a bloke a quid. (Feb 4, 1953,NZ Times,17)

The N.Z.Y.M.C.A. provide backshee cocoa,biscuits and coffee for the wounded, anda "counter lunch" for the staff. (Apr 24, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/42 : 130)

counter snack¶

n.

BURTON The old custom of counter snacks was well dead by the 1960s. At one time the hotels in New Zealand would regale their customers with all sorts of savouries ... and, what is more, it was all on the house. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,33)

counter-spank¶

n. a shop assistant

HILLIARD And she would hover, ... while the salesman looked impatiently from her to him. ... Afterwards he [sc. her boyfriend] would lecture her: `... Don't let these counter-spanks rush you. They'll kid you into taking something you don't want ...' (1960,Maori Girl,210)

counting-out¶

n. the tallying of the number of sheep shorn

MEREDITH As I was finishing the counting-out, the boss came towards the shed with a couple of towels in his hand and invited me to come for a swim. I said I would join him as soon as I had all the tallies. The two ringer contestants then called to him, `We're going.'. (1975,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,144,1935 ed.)

1 n. (Rural) a tallying of stock, particularly as they are passing through a gate.

MEREDITH As I was finishing the counting-out the boss came towards the sheep. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,144) [NOTES: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies (1935)]

counting-out pen¶

n. a pen in a shearing shed where shorn sheep are held for counting to a shearer's tally (See also count out)

CARR Fleece-picking. - As soon as a shearer has taken the fleece off and let the sheep go through the port-hole to the counting-out pen, the picker gathers the fleece up in such a manner that she or he can on getting to the rolling table, throw it out with the breech part at the right end. (1913,Country Work,14)

PERRY COUNTING-OUT PENS [on diagram of woolshed, behind the shearing board, and entered by] port `Holes'. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,18)

Counting-out pens Narrow pens outside the woolshed. Each shearer has his own and passes his shorn sheep through a port hole into it, so that his tally may be counted. (C.) (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

Counting-out pen: The pen where sheep are held for tallying after going `out the port-hole'. On the Masterton board, the catching pens are to the shearer's left as seen by the announcer. (Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing)]

MACNICOL Finally he built counting-out pens and yards. (1965,Skippers Road,31)

COUNTING-OUT PEN: The pen where sheep are held for tallying after going out the port-hole. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20)

RICHARDS There were holding and drafting yards at the back of the shed, but the `counting out' pens opened out directly into a 100 acre paddock. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,65)

OGONOWSKA-COATES Counting-out pens. Each shearer passes the shorn sheep through a porthole and into an individual counting-out pen that adjoins the woolshed on the outside. The sheep are held in these pens until counted by the boss, who confirms each shearer's tally. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,95)

counting out pen: A narrow pen outside the shed and connected to it by the chute. The shorn sheep are passed from the board down the chute, and into this pen for tallying at the end of the run. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/23) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

1 n. (Rural) a pen where sheep are held after shearing, crutching, dipping or drafting, where they can be tallied for payment purposes.

RICHARDS There were holding and drafting yards at the back of the shed but the 'counting out' pens opened out directly into a 100 acre paddock. Once the sheep were let out of the counting pens, they were soon lost to view as they disappeared into the scrub and tea tree. [counting pen] (1991,Off the Sheep's Back,65)

MCLEOD All along the board are doors into the sheep pens - catching pens, they call them - and opposite them are other doors called portholes, leading out of the shed into counting-out pens. (1954,On the Hill,11)

TAIT The shed is equipped with automatic counters, thus avoiding the necessity for counting out pens - a big help on a 'one-man' farm. (1961,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol III,155)

country¶

n. rural land. [used in a a range of sp. combinations. See: back c-, big c-, broken c-, brown-top c-, bush c-, bushbound c-, bush burn c-, bush-sick c-, close-hilled c-, Corriedale c-, danthonia c-, dopy c-, down c-, downy c-, early c-, easy c-, eco c-, ewe c-, fan c-, fat lamb c-, fattening c-, fern c-, foothill c-, front c-, gorge c-, grass c-, gum c-, half-bred c-, hard c-, hard-walking c-, hay c-, headwater c-, high c-, hill c-, hilly c-, hogget c-, hundred-inch c-, huntaway c-, karaka c-, lambing c-, late c-, light c-, log c-, low c-, MacKenzie c-, manuka c-, marrowbone c-, merino c-, moving c-, mustering c-, open c-, oversown c-, pakihi c-, Pannell c-, papa c-, pigskin c-, ploughable c-, pumice c-, rabbit c-, rough c-, run c-, safe c-, sandy c-, scrub c-, secondary growth c-, shady c-, sheep c-, shingle c-, snow c-, snowgrass c-, soft c-, stalking c-, starvation c-, store hill c-, stump c-, summer c-, summer-wet c-, summer-dry c-, surface-sown c-, swamp c-, tall c-, tea-tree c-, tiger c-, tractor c-, trial c-, tupping c-, tussocky c-, two ewe c-, under-runner c-, unploughable c-, up c-, walking c-, wether c-, white-clover c-, winter c-, wintering c-, wool c-, young c-, young man's c-.]
and in the following: birch- that has been in native beech, black birch- that has been in native black beech, cabbage tree- that has a natural covering of cabbage-trees, cattle- that is more suited to grazing of cattle then sheep, cleared- that is cleared of bush, cold- that lies to the south, cotton-plant- that has a natural covering of cotton-plant, cow- that used for dairying, cow-cocky- that used for dairying, cut-over- that where native bush has been cut and not cleared, fattening- that used to fatten stock, fine-wool- that used for grazing or breeding Merino and other fine-wools, finishing- that used to fatten or prime stock, gorse- that harbouring gorse, grazing- that used for pastoral occupation, healthy- that with a good sole of cover and with warmth, kauri- that where kauri naturally grew and were harvested, kind- that is warm and where stock flourish, limestone- that containing high natural concentrations of lime, log- cut-over land, manoao-that with a natural cover of manoao, Maori- that owned by Maori, mud- that is wet, heavy and pugged if stocked, nassella- that where nassella tussock flourishes, native- that growing native cover, new- that is recently brought into pasture, plateau- that of the Central plateau area of the North Island, ploughable- that is cultivable, pot-holy- that with frequent pot-holes or tomos, range- that of the central ranges, risky- that of unpredictable snow or summer drought, river-flat- that of alluvial river terraces, rock- that of shingly high country, scrubby- that growing manuka, matagouri or other scrub, sheep and beef- that able to fatten or prime both sheep and beef, shingly- that of the South Island high country tops, store stock - that suitable only for grazing not fattening, strong-wool- that carrying coarse-woolled sheep, tawa bush- that with a natural covering of tawa, top- that of high country or is high-producing, unforgiving- land that will not respond to development, fertilizers etc, unkind- land that will not respond to development, fertilizers etc, warm - that faces north, wine- that is used for viticulture.

The river-flat country of Grey Valley, Kotatahi, and South Westland, for example, is particularly fertile ... (Jul 2, 1923,NZ Farmer,924)

SMITH .. it is almost impossible to grow successfully a fine-woolled sheep on strong-wool country. (1929,Sheep & Wool Industry,13)

LAWLOR The first trip had been to the cow country of Taranaki. (1938,House of Commons: Parliamentary Debates (UK),144)

I never burn any high country or any broken single country. On scrubby country it improves the carrying-capacity. (May 3, 1945,NZ Farmer,10)

TURNER The real cow-cocky country is in the North Island of New Zeland, especially in Taranaki and the Waikato. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,148)

NEWTON Rising to just on 2,000 feet at its highest point it takes in a strip of beautiful clean cabbage tree country along the coast. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,16)

NEWTON But that country is too big; it is range country and the odds are that Ngamatea will remain that way. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,155)

NEWTON .. and at the time of the subdivision in 1920 it was mainly harsh, unattractive snowgrass country. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,157)

NEWTON From the homestead a landrover track heads out over the plateau county ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,158)

NEWTON .. leaving the open manoao county winds its way through a jungle of towering manuka. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,183)

NEWTON Block by block new country was giant-disced and sown down until finally 2,000 acres had been broken in. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,184)

NEWTON I only saw it from a distance, but it looked like nice, warm, healthy country. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,215)

NEWTON I had always imagined Waipaoa as being wild broken country. .. it is comparitaively easy high-quality counrty. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,240)

The ridges sprawled out to black birch country, which is poor in its virgin state. (Jul 22, 1971,NZ Farmer,13)

NEWTON Mainly cut-over country that has been burnt, it is about the wildest and most unlikely farming country that I saw. (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,158)

NEWTON This [Omaina] also is mud country, the strongest grassland, and the 2,200 acres is carrying over 8,000 sheep and 800 bullocks (country around Rotorua/Taupo). (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,163)

NEWTON This is 'kind' country, which is that something about it that takes a stockman's eye. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,3)

NEWTON .. as the area of cleared country increased they gradually changed to sheep. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,10)

NEWTON Here again the story is one of Merino sheep and wool, for this is essentially fine-wool country. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,54)

NEWTON It involved a full twenty miles, with much of it at high altitude and through difficult rock country ... (1973,Big Country of the South Island,97)

We aim .. stock on the native hill country .. Stock was on risky country and Mike says there was not enough weather warning. (May 19, 1993,NZ Farmer,15)

PLUMMER Dartmoor was much kinder country than Wakarara and much easier country to work. (1994,From Drover to Director,53)

HENDERSON Knowing the sort of 'pot-holy' country on which we were living ... (2000,Mountain Farm, Bush Farm,42)

Acquire 18 acres of land in the heart of Hawke's Bay Wine country ... (Dec 7, 2001,Hawke's Bay Property Guide,36)

419 acres overlooking Hawkes Bay Wine country ... (Dec 8, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,24)

Good strong beef and sheep country. (Dec 7, 2001,Manawatu Evening Standard & Property Guide,65)

Kawatiri [farm] is regarded as being very kind and warm country. (Sep 27, 2002,Dominion,C13)

BARKER Beyond a rapid thought of self-congratualtion that such 'cold country' was not on their run, they did not feel affected by its eternal silence and gloom. (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,69)

Carries a limited number of sheep on the hilly portions, with some swampy cattle country between. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,233)

.. a very good example of North Island hill country, elevated at around 1400 ft fairly broken in contour, predominantly store stock counrty ... (Jul 22, 1971,NZ Farmer,19)

WATERS This was good grazing country with numerous lime outcrops showing up. The Ure River gives an idea of the limestone country in the area. (1976,Mostly a Farmer,54)

Country that is not productive and does not carry much stock: unforgiving country. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

Country that is not productive and does not carry much stock: unkindly country. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

NEWTON the higher country which was in heavy bush was mainly tawa .. this birch counrty was infested with wild cattle ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,242)

NEWTON The Department [of Lands and Survey] had already had some experience with nassella country ... (1973,Big Country of the South Island,143)

NEWTON Local agricultural contractors put in long hours breaking in the manuka and gorse country. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,144)

1 n. (Rural) [sp. use] of pioneering, land to be obtained for grazing or cropping.

ROBERTS If a run was wanted, it was 'looking for country' - the word land was evidently not expressive enough. (1895,BLANK ENTRY,11) [NOTES: in Beattie Pioneers Explore Otago (1947)]

MCDONALD In these years, [1853-1856] then, we may picture eager seekers of 'country', singly or in groups, generally on horseback, probing the land beyond the bounds of existing runs. (1962,White Stone Country,41)

BARKER 'You must take up more country directly' was the invariable formula of the advice we, comparatively 'new chums' received on all sides.' (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,91)

I am now going to put up a V hut on the country that I took up on the Rangitata ... (1860,BLANK ENTRY,65) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

BARKER If a cockatoo (small farmer) or a speculator in mines, fancied any part of your country, he had only to go to the land office, and challenge your pre-emptive rights. (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,90)

GRANT & FOSTER There is a good deal of country in the vicinity that will grow wheat well ... (1880,New Zealand: Report on its Agric. Conditions,37)

BEATTIE Early in the winter of 1855 he and Robert Develing left Dunedin afoot looking for country. (1947,Pioneers Explore Otago,41)

MCKENZIE In company with Freeman Jackson he made his way south in search of 'country' meeting the usual difficulties in those days of finding fords and landmarks. (1951,Wakatipu Pioneers,39)

country acre¶

n. an allotment of land in early settlement outside a planned town boundary (See cf. town acre)

These doubly-selected lands will be divided into 1100 sections, each section comprising one town-acre, and 100 country-acres. 110 sections will be reserved by the Company, ... (1971,Speeches & Documents,19) [NOTES: 1839 June 1 Terms of Sale of the New Zealand Land Company; Great Britian, Parliamentary Papers, 1852, xxxv. 570, p.18 in 1971 Speeches and Documents 19]

... we have bought a section of land in the town. ... The country section we have got together (1843,Letters from New Plymouth,1,1968 ed.) [NOTES: (1842 Feb 7) 1843 (1968) Letters from New Plymouth 1]

Country Calendar¶

n. long-running television documentary of NZ farm life and industry

[Hdg]21 years of gentle fossicking... Country Calendar is New Zealand's longest-running TV programme. In over 730 episodes it has gently fossicked through every area of country life... (Apr 4, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

In doing so, Country Calendar has nabbed itself the affection of generations of New Zealanders, includeing a large chunck of anti septic urbanities who woldn't dream of mowing their own lawns. (Feb 27, 2005,Sunday Star Times,Escape p1)

"It's a bit like espresso Country Calendar really," he laughs. (Sep 28, 2004,Dominion Post TV Week,5)

Country Calendar, in its 37th year, topped last week's television ratings for Auckland viewers over five - ahead of Fight for Life, Friends and Coronation Street. ..."[Country Calendar] is an icon. It's the new Teletubbies." (Jun 16, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A4)

1 n. (Rural) a rural New Zealand TV programme [shown first in 1966 and the longest-running NZ TV programme.]

HINDMARSH A group from the television show Country Calendar was also billeted on the station in the week preceding the sale. (1997,Come Be a Pioneer,52)

WATERS We have seen only a few of them on television's "Country Calendar." (1976,Mostly a Farmer,53)

Country Caledar is New Zealand's longest-running TV programme. (Apr 4, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

PEAT .. I wonder what it would do for the ratings of television's 'Country Calendar' programme if the medium ever managed to transmit odour as well as the picture and sound. (1992,Falcon and the Lark, The,49)

Country Library Service¶

n.

In 1938 former MA student and first Car librarian Geoff Alley was invited to go to Wellington to establish the Country Library Service, which was in many respects the Car scheme writ large. The shool library system followed, and Alley became a central figure in the move to establish the National Library. (Sep 27, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49)

COLE I had seen him with books from the Country Library Service. (1949,It Was So Late,75,1978 ed.)

JACKSON To this end we borrowed books from the Country Library Service van which stopped at Hikuwai every Saturday morning ... (1988,Rainshadow,102)

Country Party¶

n. (historical)

SINCLAIR Some of the farmers, dissatisfied with the attempt of Reform to satisfy its urban as well as its rural wing, at last, in 1922, formed a Country Party, which advocated free trade, agricultural banks, cheap credit, and a farmers' co-operative shipping line. It contested four elections, with negigible success, ... (1959,History of New Zealand,246)

country quota¶

n.

Contrary to general belief the abolition of the country quota would not necessarily benefit the Labour Party. (Oct 23, 1944,NZEF Times,IV/174 : 8)

COUNTRY QUOTA/ HOW IT WORKS (Oct 20, 1945,Evening Post,8)

SINCLAIR Since the eighteen-eighties the electoral system had included a `country quota' which, by adding a fictitious twenty-eight per cent to the rural population when electoral boundaries were determined, gave the countryside that much extra political representation. (1959,History of New Zealand,204)

So, to bolster up, and tinker at, and provide artificial cures or inadequate palliatives, there are those who would maintain the country quota. (1945,NZ Parliamentary Debates,268/228)

"What is this Country Quota, anyhow?" (Jan 30, 1946,People's Voice,3)

[Hdg] Direct Action Against Country Quota will Fail (Aug 31, 1945,People's Voice,8)

Country quota has often been described as votes for cows. (Dec 29, 1938,Tomorrow,102)

BATEMAN COUNTRY QUOTA was a percentage once added to the population of rural electorates to give them what was seen as a fairer balance with urban electorates in general elections. The country quota was first granted in 1881 and was equivalent to one-third of the population added to the actual population of rural constituencies. This was reduced to 18 per cent in 1887 and then increased to 28 per cent in 1889, the figure at which it remained until the country quota was abolished by the Labour Government in 1945. (1986,Illustrated Encycl. of NZ,255)

Here was a Bill.. which removed the country quota entirely. (1950,NZ Parliamentary Debates,289/600)

Mr. Holland has been weeping crocodile tears over the likely abolition of the country quota, which is long overdue. (Jun 29, 1944,Northern Tribune,3)

McLINTOCK The electoral device known as the 'country quota' was first used in New Zealand in 1881 when a 'quota' equivalent to 33 1/3 per cent of the population was added to rural constituencies. In 1887 this was reduced to 18 per cent, but was increased in 1889 to 28 per cent. It remained at this figure until 1945 when it was abolished by the Labour Government. Between 1881 and 1945 the `country quota' was added to the population of rural electorates which, for the purposes of the Electoral Act, meant population other than that contained in a city or borough of over 2,000 inhabitants, or in any area within 5 miles of the chief post offices in Auckland, Wellington, Christchurch, or Dunedin. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,I/861)

An attempt to remove the country quotawhich operates in the voting power ofbranches affiliated to the N.Z.R.S.A. wasdefeated at the conference yesterday. (Jun 20, 1947,Dominion,8)

country rock¶

n.

His work on the silicified rocks plainly pointed the way to a theory of metasomatic replacement of country by vein-material. [fn] The term country rock', now so commonly employed by writers on economic geology, is, strictly speaking, tautological. The miners of the Hauraki Goldfield, as a rule, employ the more correct expression,country'. (1911,TrNZI,43/261)

country school¶

1 n. (Rural) a primary school in a rural area.

ECCLESTON Whakataki School was a typical New Zealand country school. (1977,Irish Kiwi,59)

DONEY Essays on Bushfarming 13 Even in country schools little that children learn has any direct connection with what should be the business of their lives. That is the culture of the soil. (1891,Essays on Bush-Farming,13)

DRUMMOND .. the Jordan school, a small country school closed for the past nine years, came into view. (1947,Holiday on Horseback, A,15)

NEWPORT Small country schools were usually staffed by young folk who were gaining experience in the teaching profession. (1989,Footprints Farewell,189)

country section¶

n.

Right of choice number 287, town acre and country section, for aGBP300. (Apr 25, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2)

TO BE SOLD or LET on Building Leases a Town and Country Section, being the second in the order of choice in the first British settlement in New Zealand. (Aug 21, 1839,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,1)

HURSTHOUSE & SMITH, LAND AGENTS, HAVE Houses, Town and Country Sections, &c, &c, for Sale or to Lease; and will be happy to furnish Gratuitous Information to any New Arrivals. (Apr 20, 1853,Taranaki Herald,1)

For every district in which you have property you must make a separate claim, being particular to rightly describe the nature of the property and the No. of the town acre or country section, as the case may be. (Mar 26, 1870,Wellington Independent,5)

SALE BY ORDER OF THE MORTGAGEE. .. All that piece or parcel of land containing 6 acres 1 rood and 4 perches, being allotment No. 57 on the plan of sub-division of country sections 2G, 27, and known as Aramoho Township[.] (Jun 18, 1880,Evening Post,4)

EDWARD N. LIFFITON will sell by public auction, at the Rutland Chambers, on the above date, under instructions from the D.0. A., Palmerston North: - 4 Acres 0 roods 36 perches, part Country Section 16, fronting St. John's Hill and Town Belt roads. (Jun 10, 1891,Wanganui Chronicle,3)

.. The Freehold Property, in the Hutt District, containing by admeasurement 9a 10r, or thereabouts, and being portion of Country section known as No. 32, and described as allotment 23 on the plan of the said section. (Apr 8, 1901,Evening Post,8)

..The Freehold Property situated in the Wairio District in the Provincial District of Otago, containing seven hundred and ninety-seven (797/ acres three (3) roods and two (2) poles (more or less) being Country Section marked eighty-four(84) on the Public Map of the said Wairio District. (Dec 10, 1912,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,6)

Wellington city, as it was formed in 1840, was a limited liability company, with shareholders in England, purely a speculation. Half of the shareholders never came to look at it, but all were entitled to hold one city section of an acre, and a country section of 100 acres. (Apr 5, 1927,Evening Post,10)

It is proposed to survey two other townships, each one a mile square, at intervals of ten miles on the railway line; and around these suburban and country sections, according to requirements and the nature of the soil. (Mar 4, 1874,Wellington Independent,3)

PUBLIC SALE OF VALUABLE TOWN AND COUNTRY LAND. .. COUNTRY SECTION No.33, in the Makara District, containing 116 Acres of Land, with Frontage to the Hutt Road, divided into 25 acre Allotments. (Jan 10, 1860,Wellington Independent,2)

country service¶

n. a term of rural teaching enforced on probationary teachers, the period during which a teacher in the State service is required to teach in schools in rural districts.

(Oct 1, 1938,NZ Education Gazette,184/1)

(Jul 18, 1963,Evening Post)

TURNER [the teacher] may have a permanent position, perhaps in the country doing his compulsory country service. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,158)

SLATTER His three years at Ruamahanga College had not had such an impact on him ... for it was mainly a matter of getting his country service over. (1968,Pagan Game, The,92)

LELAND Country service. In order to be eligible for promotion beyond basic levels of pay, public school teachers under 30 years of age must spend three years teaching at schools considered rural. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,29)

All male, [the teachers] tended to do country service and leave. (1988,Through the Looking Glass,141) [NOTES: Dodd]

Gee, Maurice He trained as a teacher, and went off to do his country service. I went to work for the DSIR. (2005,Blindsight,52)

country time¶

n.

REES As all the clocks were kept at country time' - that is one hour ahead oftown time' - breakfast was served in Whangamata when the Post Office clock in Beverly was striking six. (1924,April's Sowing,100)

Country Women's Institute¶

n.

And a proud community spirit, marked by acts of kindness: $1200 raised for a stroke appeal, cakes and puddings presented to Meals on Wheels last Christmas by the local Country Women's Institute, a woman gifted a car after her house burnt down. (Oct 25, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

While the children were growing up she used to perform with a local Country Women's Institute group. (Jun 3, 2001,Sunday Star Times,D9)

countryman¶

n.

Countryman: One who comes from the same part of England. This was the educated man's equivalent for townie (q.v.). I know of no New Zealand expression for a dweller in the country. (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

County¶

2 n. short for County Council

TAYLOR Gray says he'll go to the County about it after Christmas (1971,Plekhov Place, The,12)

county¶

n. a former unit of rural administration controlled by an elected council as a territorial or administrative unit of local government.

When the nine provinces were abolished in 1876 the colony was divided for local government purposes into counties, regard being had to boundaries of existing road districts, and the counties were subdivided into ridings, each riding being empowered to elect a certain number of members of the Council of the county. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,142)

BARLOW The main road through the county is supposed to be constructed by the County Council, which is composed of representatives from the several ridings or districts forming the county, each riding electing a councillor every three years. (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,95)

BARLOW The main county road here is not yet formed in places ... (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,96)

County Council¶

n. (historical)

Reports from County Councils have shown a marked improvement in rate payments fromMaori land. (Aug 26, 1943,NZ Farmers' Weekly,7)

HENDERSON By "they" you mean the local body - the county council. (1969,Open Country Calling,273)

BARLOW The main road through the county is supposed to be constructed by the County Council, which is composed of representatives from the several ridings or districts forming the county, each riding electing a councillor every three years. (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,95)

At present some of our County Councils give rewards for the eggs and heads of small birds ... (1898,TrNZI,30/270)

GUTHRIE The Government, county councils, harbour boards ... had gone in for a race of borrowing from overseas. (1935,Little Country, The,15,1937 ed.)

[WICKHAM] Another remedy that might be tried with advantage is the abolition of the County Councils and Road Boards. (1897,Casual Ramblings,11)

Who is there to prevent the local bodies - County Councils, Borough Councils, Road Boards - from being empowered to elect members of Land Boards, just as School Committees now have power to elect members of the Provincial Education Boards? (Mar 5, 1904,NZ Observer,3)

An instance.. was related by the Chairman of the Wairarapa East County Council yesterday. (Oct 14, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

LAMBERT The actual transition from provincial to County and Borough Councils was a very peaceful one in Taranaki. (1983,Illustrated History of Taranaki,73)

Now for the County Council. (Oct 22, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,14)

County Councilman¶

n.

From the Prime Minister to the meanest West Coast member, from the Speaker of the Upper House to the buffoon and "chawbacon" of the Lower, Waste Lands Board, County Councilmen, prigs and policemen, all are travelling on us. (May 21, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,21)

County paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a district holding paddock, usually on a stock-route to a saleyard or near district saleyards.

RICHARDS I lifted the sheep from the County paddock shortly after daylight. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,85)

County Ranger¶

n.

From the same, relating to the appointment of rangers, and stating that the roads had been put under the charge of the County's ranger. (Feb 15, 1878,North Otago Times,2)

The action of the County Ranger in suing the sheep owners for the trespass of their sheep on the commonage has had the effect, in the case of Mr Cotton, of causing that gentleman to come down pretty severely on the settlers at Waipori for the trespass of their cattle on his run. (May 31, 1879,Tuapeka Times,2)

n. ?a special type of bit.

BEATTIE In connection with stock the following terms were used: - Let the sheep draw down to the Taieri';stags,' crawlers,'stragglers,' a horse with couples in his mouth,'the bull baked on the road,' cut and tailed,'lagoon washing,' spaying cattle,'killed a pleuro,' herding lambs,'buisting weaners,' `a camp for the cattle,' ... n. someone involved in organising a coup

...Mr English's own "ship slip" over United States nuclear ship visits last week triggered a second wave of coupsters into action which precipitated the final blow... Within hours a raft of MPs were calling for a change at the top - something which became overheated and almost spooked the inner circle of coupsters who were beginning to wonder if they were managing one coup or two. (Oct 30, 2003,Dominion Post,B7)

Court of Appeal¶

n.

"The loss of votes was an incentive to take it over or sell out. If they go dog, we will ask the Court of Appeal to address it." (Dec 21, 2002,Dominion Post,C2)

The move has opened the door to a younger Court of Appeal bench, which has also been named. Its most experienced judges will move up to the Supreme Court... (Nov 11, 2003,Dominion Post,A2)

cous¶

n. (See cuz)

MITCALFE Howdy, cous',' said he [21] extending a hand.What you mean, cous'?' said Sefulu ... `I mean cousin, what else? Vaine, she my Auntie, small world, eh, man.' (1985,Hey Hey Hey,20)

McGILL coz greeting of friend, short for cousin; a Kiwi revival of archaic greeting used by likes of Romeo and Benvolio in Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

Go out and wring your best friend'sneck. What do you reckon, Cous? (Sep 7, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

Cousin Jack¶

n. a Cornishman

Scotchmen, Welshmen, Geordies', andCousin Jacks' were they - (Sep 20, 1861,NZ Goldfields,6,1976 ed.)

ANZAC ... they were as saving as a Cousin Jack - (1916,On the Anzac Trail,52)

Cousin Jack: A Cornishman. ([1890-1910].) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

HYDE There were a couple of Cousin Jacks in there [sc gaol] - English fellows - and were they disgusted? (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,196)

STUDHOLME We might have English, Irish, Scotch, Cornish (Cousin Jack) or German gangs working. (1940,Te Waimate,161)

couta¶

n. (informal) barracouta [ORIGIN: abbreviation, c1949 Havelock] (See also king couta)

MEREDITH ... I amused myself catching barracouta ... When travelling fast through the water, it [sc. the board with a nail in it] resembles a fish, and the 'coota goes for it open-mouthed. ... Directly the line is slackened on deck the 'coota lets go the bait, which is dropped over for the next victim. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,9) [NOTES: 1872 Oct 1 in c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 9]

Sumner is a small place, and the atmospheric disturbance was finally traced to a hawker named John Brown, who carried a basket containing twelve barracouta, ... Hampton said that the 'couta were rotten and and stinking and fell to pieces when gingerly handled by the bobby. (Apr 1, 1911,NZ Truth,6)

PARROT Barracouta Thyrsites atun Couta (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,169)

BALLANTYNE Dad's got plently of lines. He doesn't care when we use them. Specially if we catch a 'couta or kingie. (1968,Sydney Bridge,148)

SORENSON BARRACOUTA (a) Scientific name: Thyrsites atun. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Sea Pike; Couta; Snoek; Barra Fillets. (c) Other common names: B/couta; Bait. (d) Principal localities where taken: Gisborne, Motueka, Nelson, Timaru, Port Chalmers. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,11)

WILSON Although they are basically surface pelagics, the coutas are met in shoals at all depths down to forty fathoms. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,26)

[species name] barracouta .. [scientific name] Thyrsites atun .. [other name(s)] couta, snoek (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

[index to common names 283-293] couta 2028 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

HULME & MORRISON the jaws of couta with tiny peg teeth time-blunted, no longer vicious (1989,Homeplaces,117)

It is unusual for me to write a piece about how NOT to catch fish, but here are some ways for winter coastal fishermen to, if not avoid then at least reduce the 'couta menace. (Jun 2, 2002,Sunday Star Times,B7)

couta lure¶

n. a barracouta lure

WILSON `COUTA' LURES In selecting lures it should be borne in mind that this fish's teeth are particularly sharp and strong. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,26)

CAIRD (1874,NZ Sheepfarming,23) [NOTES: [sic: see notes: OEDS]]

couta stick¶

n. pa na2..

GRAHAM BARRACOUTA (MANGA) Leionura atun dentatus (Bloch and Schneider) INCREDIBLE as it may seem these fish, with their well-armed jaws of sharp fang-like teeth, were usually caught on a slightly curved stick about four feet in length. Fastened to this stick was a piece of stout fishing line about three to four feet in length, carrying a piece of red-coloured wood - usually cedar - about five to six inches in length. A bent nail was secured to this piece of wood in the form of a hook but no bait was used. When a school of Barracouta was found the Couta stick, or paw, was brought out ready for fishing. From the cockpit of the launch the piece of wood with the nail was violently swirled with a circular motion in and out of the water, causing a disturbance of the water in a good imitation of a number of Sprats, Pilchards or other small fish jumping in and out of the sea. The Barracouta would swim for such a place. Seeing the piece of red wood moving rapidly through the water they would take it for a fish, snap at it or even jump out of the water for the lure and were caught by the crude iron hook. As the fish was hooked during the time the paw was being drawn through the water the fisherman would swing the fish over his head above the boat or launch and when the caught fish was midway in the air, more or less above the cockpit, would expertly give the stick a dexterous smart twist. As there was no barb on the hook the fish was released and fell into the cockpit. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,310)

GRAHAM [Ibid 311] Should there be any Barracouta about the... Couta sticks were then set to work to paw the water and attract Barracouta to the spot. [I bid.314] The Maori also knew he could catch Barracouta without bait and he, too, used a short piece of stick and line with a baitless hook and leaned over his canoe and threshed the water to and fro, which is known as Kaihau manga!' When the European fisherman called his fishing outfit [315]paw', the Maori uses the term `pa'. This fish was a great favourite with them and was caught in large numbers. On returning to the shore, the women cleaned the fish and then hung them up on racks to dry in the sun. Old Maoris of Opotiki told me they used a chip of Tawhai (Nothofagus fusca), which is dark red, in the making of a pa (paw). (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,311)

Coutts clause¶

n. an America's Cup exclusion clause

Protocol Clause 13.12: "Forbids a sailor to swap teams if he had been "contracted, engaged, paid or otherwise engaged" by a team for 180 days since the last cup... The old rule stated that after January 2000, a competitor ahall not engage any person in any capacity who has sailed on another competitor's yacht. It now reads "from March 2 this year a person contracted, employed, paid or otherwise engaged by a competitor, may not be engaged by another competitor." The change was quickly dubbed the "Coutts Clause" and means Coutts, one of the most effective America's Cup skippers in history, is probably out of the preparation for the 2007 challenge in Valencia. (Jul 28, 2004,Dominion Post,D8)

It's quite obvious they've done it as the Coutts clause. (Jul 27, 2004,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Pete Montgomery, late night news.]

Coutts process¶

n.

The new Standard Brewery at Palmerston North is justly claimed to be the world's first brewery to produce its total output by continuous fermentation. ... The process has been patented and is known as the `Coutts' Process after Mr Morton W. Coutts, Technical Director of Dominion Breweries Ltd, under whose guidance the process was initiated and first put into commercial use in 1956. (1960,Proceedings RSNZ,41) [NOTES: 1960 Proceedings of Royal Soc of NZ, Report of the Ninth Science Congress, Wellington May 12-17 1960 41]

cove¶

n. a fellow, bloke, chap (See also Auckland cove)

THOMSON (1859,Story of New Zealand, The) [NOTES: [see AUCKLAND COVE transfer here.]]

THATCHER A cove there with a camera/ The sports was photographing,/ (1865,Otago Songster,6)

FARJEON I arsked the cove to stop in [prison] another week, so that I might be reformed, as the beak said ... I tells him, I've bin to quod. (1866,Grif: a Story of Colonial Life,4)

THOMSON [Old Yarmouth sailor speaks] I know you are the cove' to ride in a bullock, and I want you to be with me tomorrow for thatere job. ... and then there's the killing of it. (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher,147)

INGLIS If I wasn't workin', some blasted cove, wot wants my billet 'ud be making remarks. (1887,Our NZ Cousins,40)

McKEE WRIGHT `The Bloke That Ran across a Snag' (also in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 31) So they started in, or Dick did, Brice had work to dodge his blows;/ But he dodged them - how he done it, not a bloke as seen it knows!/ And the other joker maddened when he couldn't touch his man,/ While we coves all laughed and shouted, and the barracking began./ (1897,Station Ballads,34)

McKEE WRIGHT A rabbiter or digger cove will stand a chap a feed. (1897,Station Ballads,30)

WOODHOUSE There is coves and coves! Some I liked partic'lar, and some I would sooner I never knowed,/ But a bloke can't choose the chaps that he's thrown with in the harvest paddock or here in the road./ There was chaps from the other side that I shore with that I'd like to have taken along for mates,/ But we said, So long!' and we laughed and parted for good and all at the station gates./ <i>(1950,Farm & Station Verse,38</i>) [NOTES: c1890s McKee WrightWhile The Billy Boils' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 38]

McKEE WRIGHT He'll talk of a bloke', and acove', and a joker', / And the luckless days when he was abroker'. (1900,Wisps of Tussock,24)

.. cowardly coves like Percy are much too tony to attack the well-dressed bounders. (Jun 24, 1905,NZ Truth,1/4)

... a good natured cove. (Sep 30, 1905,NZ Truth,15/4/6)

A confounded boy spilt his big can full all over me' he explained, disgustedly.What did you do to him?' inquired a sport. I called him a blanky cow,' replied the indignant cove.I suppose on account of him giving you so much milk?' chipped in the skittish barmaid. The the laugh went up. (Jul 18, 1908,NZ Truth,161/1/3)

Said Martin, of the Dinks, Why, he was the greatestswi-up king' in the Inverteds', and he used to give thevin rouge' a boscar lash to leg. ... some of you coves will know him ... (Sep 5, 1917,NZEF Chronicles,28)

SMYTH Got to have some cove massage me ... (1929,Girl from Mason Creek, The,149)

MASON Let the fruit be plucked/ and the cake be iced;/ ... / and the wine be spiced/ in the old cove's night-cap :/ (1962,Collected Poems,56,1963 ed.) [NOTES: (1934) 1962 Mason Collected Poems (1963) 56 (`On the Swag')]

Cove - man. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,39)

I would include among New Zealand English words:cove (May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class)

WEBBER `You coves from Scott Base beat me,' said the Bloke. (1962,Look No Hands!,93)

FERNANDEZ The visitor was a Government rabbiter, Pat, a cheerful cove, talkative and delighted to have company. (1973,Tussock Fever,40)

LELAND `He's a right rum cove, that bartender', translates as he's a very perculiar PERSON, that bartender. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,29(A))

2 n. the owner of a sheep-station or the boss overseer.

KENNAWAY [The squatter] fancies the sheep upon his run are only being half-shepherded while `the cove' (as he is called) isn't on the ground, - ... (1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,175)

FERGUSON Then in the fence we'll mak [sic] a breach,/ And to the cove [fn Bush term for boss.] a yarn we'll pitch,/ (1883,Castle Gay,175)

covenant¶

n. a legal mechanism to secure animal or plant protection on private land

An open space covenant is a legally binding agreement between a landholder (Covenantor) and the Trust to maintain an area of land or water as open space in perpetuity. (Mar 2003,Old Whaling Days,No. 60/2)

n. an agreement between two parties, used in NZ to cover agreements between private and public parties

The first covenant in 1987 was a 1.67 hectare fenced block, which includes a historic Maori drawing on limestone of the ancient wedge-tailed eagle now extinct. Another covenant is an 85 hectare block, including an area of valley, stream, bush and limestone cliffs which have been referrred to in European times as the Valley of the Moa. (Mar 2003,Open Space,No. 60/4)

1 v. (Rural) to place a protective order on land of ecological importance [such as wetland or native bush.]

DOMINY As the back country that 'number eight Men' populated gets retired and covenanted for conservation purposes ... (2001,Calling the Station Home,91)

According to.. Rosemary Davison, who, with her husband, Graham, has convented a stand of kahikatea on their Otorohanga dairy farm, trees do more than provide a scenic backdrop. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/85)

The land has been covenanted under the Resource Management Act agreement ... (Oct 15, 2002,Dominion,C10)

covenant block¶

1 n. (Rural) an area of legally protected land of ecological significance.

.. the trust is taking him and Mr Carter for a chopper flight around some of the Wellington region's covenant blocks, where private landowners have signed their remnant bush, wetlands and scrub over to the trust for rehabilitation and permanent protection from development. (Nov 20, 2002,Dominion,B7)

covenanted¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of land] controlled by a protective covenant.

Covenanted land varies in size and content. (Oct 2002,Wairarapa Times-Age,Supp. 16)

...Brian is proud of what he and his family have achieved on their covenanted block with a limited budget, no poison and no secondary kill. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/96)

Looking down on the small blocks of covenanted land, I question how such meagre remnants can serve any useful ecological function ... (Nov 20, 2002,Dominion,B7)

If Dave Hansford thinks that small blocks of covenanted land can serve no useful ecological purpose (Nov 20), he needs to visit our 7.5 hectare of QEII National Trust covenanted bush and wetlands in the Wairarapa. (Nov 30, 2002,Dominion,A14)

covenanting¶

n.

If you get hooked on a grant system for the act of covenanting, it kills the whole process stone dead. Ibid. 94 "Convenanting was a trailblazing idea back when we started," notes Lady Fiona. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/85)

covenantor¶

n. a party to a covenant agreement

[Hdg] Dannevirke covenantors win award. (Mar 2003,Open Space,9)

cover comb¶

n. (Rural) a machine shearing comb that leaves a certain length of wool (cover) on the sheep in high country areas. (See winter comb)

BROSNAHAN Machine shearing with the cover comb did not leave as much cover as the shears did. (1998,Glenaray 1898-1998,76)

Winter shearing with a comb-cover is used to encourage survival, with colder ewes eating more to keep warm. (Feb 14, 2006,Dominion Post,C6)

They have for years used a snow comb like the 'cover' comb demonstrated to the Wool Board last year. (Dec 9, 1976,NZ Farmer,19)

Lynn and Les Webb, Mt Cass, Waipara, plan to keep up cover-comb shearing of the ewes which last year reduced vulnerability to the cold. (May 19, 1993,NZ Farmer,14)

The B flock is machine-shorn with covercomb in July, then is breakfed handy to home on greenfeed (concord and turnips) until being setstocked for lambing. (Dec 7, 2000,NZ Farmer,21)

They [winter combs] are also referred to as 'cover comb' - a popular brand of winter comb. [covercomb; snowcomb; cover-comb. ] (Jun 2002,In the Paddock,02)

covers gang¶

n. a watersider gang in charge of the framework coverings for hatches on ships. [considered a soft or easy job]

DAVIN They would be putting him in the covers gang with the boys and the old men next. (Sep 1935,Review (Otago University),48/26)

covey¶

n. a swag-strap

HODDER Our knapsacks, or swags, as they are more generally called, ... were fastened to our back with a pair of slings called `coveys' which are made by the natives of dressed flax. (1862,Memories of NZ Life,137)

n. a person, cove

PICARD They are not fit to breathe the same breeze as us covey's [sic], are they? (1906,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,36)

WOODHOUSE There's covies humping baskets. (1950,Farm & Station Verse,152) [NOTES: 1940 Meek `Wool Commander' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 152]

cow¶

n. milk, `cow-juice', cf tinned cow

She boils! Mugs up, here's the cow; who's got some grit. (Apr 19, 1971,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

n. (informal) disliked person

I'll get even with the cows for that. (Jun 7, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/45 : 204)

Moskovitz (Oct 31, 1999,North & South)

n. [1984 16 F E21 Pakuranga Coll. 3 COW [someone/something disliked] [F8] 1984 14 F E125Wgton Girls C. 3 COW [F7]]

A confounded boy spilt his big can full all over me' he explained, disgustedly.What did you do to him?' inquired a sport. I called him a blanky cow,' replied the indignant cove.I suppose on account of him giving you so much milk?' chipped in the skittish barmaid. Then the laugh went up. (Jul 18, 1908,NZ Truth,161/1/3)

... to see a blanky bobby's eyebrows risin'. Suspicious cow! 'e wants a flamin' biff. (Feb 8, 1913,NZ Bulletin,16)

[a person] ... a heavy cow. (Dec 11, 1915,Hutt Valley Independent,2)

I shall look [179] forward to your Dad's cigars as that is the one thing the `cows' can't stand. (Aug 13, 1917,Great Adventure,178) [NOTES: (Howden)]

Listened the other day to a Tommy's description of an Anzac : `He's a brown, lanky bloke 'oo calls 'is cobber 'er cow. (Mar 15, 1918,Kia-ora Coo-ee,1/4:87,1981 ed.)

I'll get even with the cows for that. (Jun 7, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,204)

Sorter smash the cow before he gets his wind, see? (Oct 10, 1919,Quick March,33)

Cow - may just mean cow, but may also mean an unpleasant man, woman, or situation. These things may also be called progressively, a fair cow, and a fair adjectival cow. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,39)

BALLANTYNE The cow was mad, Gil thought. Only a madman would want to go to a war unless he had to. These redfeds were always thinking about killing someone; ... (1948,Cunninghams, The,128,1976 ed.)

DUFF What, is someone else using your possie?'Two or three of the cows. When I got there last night there were three guns about five yards from me.' (May 20, 1951,Shepherd's Calendar,31,1961 ed.)

PARK That Georgie Wi must be a crook cow,' whispered his fellow penitents.Look at the time he's in there [sc. confessional box]!' (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,52)

HOGAN We were making for the irrigation drain/ Both our billy cans were empty/ So we hardly spoke a word/ Except to say, `The cow will never rain.' (1962,Billy-Can Ballads,21)

ADSETT There's that truant joker, too. Rotten cow ... Cruel swine that. (1963,Magpie Sings, A,10)

HARVEY `You stupid little cows,' he said right in our ears. (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,24)

McLAGLAN Finally he called them the most insulting name he could think of. `You two rotten old cows,' he shouted, then plunged into the icy water above his knees and tugged them out by the reins. (1965,Stethoscope & Saddlebags,172)

cow ... NZ & Austral. sl. troublesome or unpleasant person or thing (a fair cow) (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,171) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 258]]

McGILL cow unpleasant, mean, ill-tempered person or uncooperative thing, such as `a cow of a lawnmower'. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

n. an unpleasant or wretched person, animal, thing, or situation, often preceded by an intensifying, often depreciatory epithet fair; dirty, rotten, silly etc., and often used good-humouredly

We had breakfast and I changed the yellow cow, a fine horse in the water, for the old mare Sprightly and went away home ... (Jul 26, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,50,1950 ed.)

COTTLE The less spirited [horses] become regular cows (as we called them) and only go because they are obliged to. (1891,Frank Melton's Luck,78)

KOEBEL That old cow [sc. an old stallion] is the Gunner's particular property. (1907,Return of Joe,285)

SINCLAIR Jordan sat on the other side. He asked why the menu was in French, as Hugh Dalton wrote in his diary, and went on,When I asked them this in a West End restaurant a few weeks ago, they said, The chef's a Frenchman'. I said,It would be a cow, wouldn't it, if he were a Maori?' (1976,Nash,147) [NOTES: 1937 Hugh Dalton Diaries quoted in 1976 Sinclair Nash 147]

SYDER & HODGETTS An expression describing a situation which may be unhappy, annoying, distressing, exasperating, unfortunate, perplexing, disappointing, a cause for pity or commiseration, anger or consternation. Common. .in 4;It's still raining, the paddock's 're all under water - it's cow.' .in 4;It's a cow - I've left my hammer at home.' .in 4;`This is a cow of a teapot. My wife likes the shape, but I can never see the shape matters if it won't pour properly.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],570)

cow beef¶

1 n. (Rural) dairy beef, calves or milking cows bred for fattening and slaughter.

Mr Ambury said that owing to the extension of the dairying industry in the Auckland district, a large proportion of the meat now produced in the province was cow beef. The dairy herds were annually culled, and cows unsuitable for milking were fattened off for killing. (May 28, 1921,Hawera Star,3)

cow class¶

n. economy class air travel; variant of cattle class

"I'm always back there in the cow class." (May 28, 2002,TV1)

cow clipper¶

1 n. (Rural) an instrument used to dock cow tails.

Clearing sale: cow covers, cow clippers large and small size. (Apr 13, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,24)

cow cockle¶

n.

cow cockle [s] Vaccaria pyramidata Med. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,16)

cow country¶

n. dairy farming country (See also country)

LAWLOR The first trip had been to the cow country of Taranaki. (1938,House of Templemore, The,144)

HILLIARD The cow country is owned by pakehas. (1960,Maori Girl,9)

VIRTUE Morrinsville was almost right in the middle of the Waikato cow country, a rich farming area in New Zealand. (1987,Redemption of Elsdon Bird, The,46,1988 ed.)

cow dollop¶

n. a polite form of `cow muck'; usu. cowpat.

Basil in the willows scraping cow dollop from his shoe. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,14)

cow grass¶

n. (See grass)

DUFF ... it takes a harder pull to move her [a cow] on from a locust tree, with its thorny stems, than from a fresh patch of cow grass. (Apr 17, 1951,Shepherd's Calendar,27,1961 ed.)

cow gravy¶

n. a polite form of `cow muck'.

PICARD I got over to Taranaki, the place where the cow gravy and buttermilk hails from. (1906,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,3)

cow itch¶

n.

Despite the fact that by 1820 the Bay of Islands was already "over-run by cow itch", a potent herbal vermifuge, the spiny seeds of which transfix and kill intestinal worms (which plant Maori gave "Marion du Fresne the credit of having left among them" in 1772), early pakeha planting lists barely mention medicinal herbs. (Feb 2000,NZ Historic Places,76/35)

cow jerker¶

n. a dairy hand; a milker

PICARD Aggie [from the dairy] is a champion cow jerker, can do seven an hour. ... She has a goo-goo eye and a blameless past. (1906,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,12)

cow jockey¶

1 n. (Rural) a person employed on a station to milk cows.

NEWTON Among the many who came to Algidus in William Urquhart's time was a new 'cow jockey', a fourteen-year old lad, Ron Anderson. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,205)

a person who milks cows - a cow jockey. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

cow kingdom¶

1 n. (Rural) a dairying district.

One of the most remarkable things of which we have heard in the 'cow kingdom' occurred last month, says the Inglewood Record. (Aug 26, 1912,Hawera Star,04)

cow mat¶

1 n. (Rural) a dry surfaced mat that allows cow hooves to dry out.

Mr Sweetman also developed the "cow mat" and the "hoof mat" that are used on farms throughout New Zealand to prevent foot rot in cattle. (Mar 10, 2001,Dominion,7)

cow of a¶

phr. indicating an extremely unpleasant variety or occurrence of that denoted by a following noun (See cf. hang of a)

... of all the cows of places. (Jul 5, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,252)

SMYTH You cow of a thing [to a dog]. (1928,Jean of the Tussock Country,197)

SMYTH These tricky cows of horses. Ibid. 63 A cow of a job' he muttereda bit crook for yer.' (1929,Girl from Mason Creek, The,15)

HYDE `It's been blooming wet lately. A cow of a climate, and no error.' (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,12)

Cow' is a common word of abuse, not so surprising when so many of the people have to struggle with the beasts. If something is godawful, they'll say it's afair cow,' or they'll call a bad day a `cow of a day.' (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,38)

Dr. G.E. BELL [NZ usage includes] `a cow of a job'. (Nov 25, 1957,Letter)

MISHEARD, NOT MISS HERD: That was a cowardly thing to do,' said Mr W.A. Harlow, S.M., sternly rebuking a man accused of assaulting his wife, in the Napier Magistrate's Court. A young reporter did not quite hear the remark, and in an evening newspaper, Mr Harlow was reported as saying:That was a cow of a thing to do.' The following evening there was a correction under the heading, `What Mr. Harlow Really Did Say', and the dignity of the court was restored. (Jun 2, 1959,NZ Truth,16)

DAVIS Blue and me and the dogs ... snuggling up to that cow of a dead pig all freezing night. (1964,Watersiders,133)

cow n. (Sl.) anything objectionable, as e.g. a cow of a day... (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

ROCHE When they [New Zealanders c1939] meant think' they saidreckon'. When the weather depressed them they grunted, `Cow of a day!' (1979,Foreigner,187)

`You can go to hell, you miserable cow!' (1984,Some Other Country,33) [NOTES: >1936? Lee in 1984 Some Other Country 33]

cow paddock¶

n.

STUDHOLME He levelled an area near our cottage in the cow paddock and kept the grass cut and rolled. (Dec 26, 1912,Coldstream,129)

MANDER He went through the house, the gardens, the cow paddock, the horse paddock, searching carefully in the little clumps of trees he had left for shelter. (1925,Allen Adair,118,1971 ed.)

HYDE When a German `plane broke its back in a cow-paddock overnight, the pilot and his mechanic ... looked like toy figures ... (1936,Passport to Hell,201)

FINLAYSON `Now for the old girls,' he says, and Taipo yaps with joy. Uncle Ted heads for the cow paddock ... (1948,Tidal Creek,28,1979 ed.)

DARE To make matters worse, the manager .... put three more heifers and two bulls into my cow paddock. (1956,Rouseabout Jane,155)

SLATTER Hunka who made bows from the prickly hedge in the cow paddock to stalk the pukekos in the swamp. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,10)

Who left the gate of the cow-paddock open?' <i>(1962,Landfall Country,163</i>) [NOTES: (CourageAn Evening for a Fish')]

The back country runs have quite a vocabulary of their own ... terms like cow paddock and horse paddock and tea-oh and township which, like most of these terms, took on their special use in Australia. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/679) [NOTES: (Wall NZ Speech)]

McGEE A melange of O'Reilly's creamy thighs, ... and a sheepdog retrieving the ball in a cow-paddock in Morrinsville. (1981,Foreskin's Lament,93)

jones Raymond left town for ... a rock festival held on a cow paddock somewhere outside Hamilton. (1985,Gilmore's Dairy,110)

1 n. (Rural) a paddock close to the homestead where a ''house-cow'' is grazed.

A common practice in pig management is to turn the sow out at weaning to forage for herself in the cow paddocks .. the area over which the sow grazed was a fenced-off portion of a cow paddock ... (Aug 15, 1939,NZ Journal of Agriculture,117)

DAVIS Take a long sweep round the cow paddock. (1962,Mutton on the Menu,133)

EVANS I can remember that for certain Sundays after, I had to spend an amount of time out in the cow paddock keeping the cows away from the cow trough. (1975,Silver Tussock, The,122)

BRITTAIN Long hot summers, the cow paddock full of yellow-eyed white daisies ... (2000,Lake Coleridge,52)

cow parsnip¶

n.

parsnip, cow [s] Heracleum [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,56)

cow shark¶

n. [Not NZ specific term]

AYLING SIXGILL SHARK Hexanthus griseus (Cow shark, mud shark, grey shark) (1982,Collins Guide,45,1984 ed.)

PAUL Sixgill shark Hexanchus griseus Alternatively cow shark (family Hexanchidae). Probably world wide in distribution ... (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,24)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] shark, cow 23-4 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

cow sling¶

1 n. (Rural) a piece of equipment for lifting sick cows.

Auction: calfetaria, cow sling ... (Apr 14, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,28)

Clearing sale: waratah driver, cow sling ... (Apr 13, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,46)

For sale: backblade, back end scoop, cow sling, feedout wagon ... (May 22, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,18)

cow stop¶

n. cattle-stop (See also cow-grid)

MARSHALL They pull over when the car has rattled past the cow stop. Alun and Meredith look across their father's land to the sea. Dry pasture, ... (1982,Master of Big Jingles,127)

cow time¶

n. milking time

TURNER [In winter] a farmer does not have to be mindful of cow-time milking time on town day (or sale day, equivalent to English `market day'). In winter, one or two house cows might be milked by hand. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,150)

1 n. (Rural) [dairying] the hour to collect and milk cows.

ANTHONY As soon as Peter had gone I set to work on the knife again, and kept at it until cow time. (1936,Follow the Call,134)

After dinner Mrs Hall insisted that Walter and I should rest until 'cow time.' (Sep 26, 1925,Hawera Star,16)

So now he relies on .. a white cloth hung on the clothesline which he can see from the hills, to tell him when it is cow-time. (Apr 6, 1944,NZ Farmer,42)

He takes a long lunch until cow time, which gives him ample opportunity to do some chores for his wife. (Jun 1, 1957,NZ Dairy Exporter,68)

CARR At this time I was sharemilking at the end of Windust Road and going bush between cow times on suitable days. [cow-time] (1997,Wild Boars of Oruaiti, The,43)

cow up¶

v. to spoil; make a `cow' of. [ca1957 Christchurch (R. Mason) The rain cowed them [raspberries] all up.]

cow's kipper¶

n.

McGILL cow's kipper cow dung. Look out there,' her mother would warn young Joy Shepard,you'll go for a skate on a cow's kipper.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

cow-bang¶

v. to milk cows; to be a dairy farmer

These new chums should not get into the employ of a Taranaki farmer, whose aim in life is to get such men into his tender clutches, and make them cow-bang. (Sep 9, 1905,NZ Truth,12/8/3-4)

McGILL cowbang to run a dairy farm. NZA. Also cowspank. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

BAUGHAM It's a poor job, cowbangin' all alone. (1912,Brown Bread,118)

cow-banger¶

n. a dairy farmer; occas. - cowboy, one who milks the house cow and tends to other domestic chores on a large farm or station; (See cowspanker,cattle-banger)

. a certain money-grubbing Mangaroa cow-banger ... (Jul 3, 1915,Hutt Valley Independent,3)

BAKER Cow spank, to be a dairy farmer or a farmhand, whence cowspanker (we also use cattle-banger and cow-banger) (1941,NZ Slang,42)

cow-[b]anger, cowspanker n. dairy farmer, farm hand. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

McGILL cowbanger dairy farmer. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

If the "rumored" surprises.. really happens [sic] in Taranaki, the cow-bangers must have taught them an exceedingly bad habit. (Oct 20, 1917,NZ Truth,1)

cow-byre¶

n. a cowshed (See also byre)

If there is no desire on the part of the operator to learn the art thoroughly it is not likely that proficiency will ever be reached; and a milker of this sort should never be allowed inside a cow-byre except to clean it out. (Jan 15, 1913,NZ Journal of Agriculture,584)

HYDE156 Nevertheless, you could never forget [the] ... red-cheeked women who came into the estaminets, still smelling of soil and cow-byre, ... (1936,Passport to Hell)

MILLER There was an old galvanised iron bath in his cowbyre (1946,There Was Gold,88)

SCRYMGEOUR Many stables, cow byres, men's quarters and other buildings graced [18] `Teviot' [Station] .. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,17)

KINROSS My father looked a bit nettled as he led Bluebell down to the cowbyre, bailed her up, and proceeded to milk her. (1963,Please to Remember,159)

BARRY The outbuildings caught fire and were quickly consumed, wash-house, car shed, and cow byre being levelled, while the house itself had begun to burn. (1966,In the Lee of the Hokonuis,28)

FRAME The ground was like a Southland cowbyre in winter, churned with mud and hoofmarks. (1985,Envoy from Mirror City,129)

RUTHERFORD Cow-byre manure is packed in on mules ... This cowshed manure is a priceless treasure on the Continent. (1912,Impressions of a NZ Pastoralist on Tour,148)

cow-cocky¶

n. a dairy-farmer, (often in small way)

SARGESON My father was a cow-cocky, but he couldn't make cow-cockying pay.Ibid. 298 cocky: small farmer; cow-cocky, a dairy farmer (1964,Collected Stories,64) [NOTES: original 1937]

SCANLAN There was another hard frost and he sat in the bar and drank beer with a couple of the cow-cockies, while the last day of September went to join history. (1933,Tides of Youth,17)

SCANLAN The cow cockies were still in bondage. (1934,Winds of Heaven,314)

SARGESON My father was a cow-cocky, but he couldn't make cow-cockying pay. (Jan 1937,Tomorrow,6) [NOTES: 1937 Jan 6 Tomorrow (Sargeson Cow Pats') in 1978 Islands 21/239: also 1940 Sargeson A Man and His Wife 29 (Cow Pats')]

BENNETT A cocky or cowcocky (from Australian cockatoo farmer) is a small farmer. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,88)

Cocky - farmer, generally on a small farm. Cow-cocky - dairy farmer. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,38)

A cow-cocky who was reckoned to be pretty well in said he'd killed and eaten a lot of meat in his time, and he knew for a fact that no man ... could eat a whole calf ... (1977,Listener Short Stories,21) [NOTES: 1945 Sargeson `Showers' in 1977 Listener Short Stories 21]

... just before midday the cow-cocky took the butcher by the sleeve and led him round to the kitchen ... (1945,Listener (New Zealand Listener)) [NOTES: SARGESON]

MILLER There is the ... runholder and more important station owner; there is the cow cocky, the gold miner ... the Public Works raceman ... (1946,There Was Gold,13)

SOLJAK Following are examples of colloquialisms common to New Zealand and Australian English, with their English or American equivalent ... cocky: small farmer; cow cocky: dairy farmer. (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),115)

SCANLAN You cow-cockies are never satisfied,' Whitton said. ...Cow-cockie did you say?' and Roger threatened him with a shovel. (1948,Dusty Road,68,1949 ed.)

PARTRIDGE Cow cocky. since ca. 1910, also New Zealand (Niall Alexander, letter of Oct. 22, 1939). (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1022)

DAVIN ... I began to dream what I'd have done if I'd had a couple of thousand acres of sheep country instead of a miserable little cow cocky's place in land that would go back to bush ... (1959,No Remittance,136)

SINCLAIR In the southern Provinces there was fierce competition between the pastoral tenants and the cockatoos', a name for small farmers which originated in Australia by analogy with the swarms of birds which descended on the land of the luckless farmer at harvest time. It has persisted in New Zealand to the present day in the termcow cockies' for dairy farmers. Ibid. 303 [Colonial-NZ glossary] cow cockie - Dairy farmer (1959,History of New Zealand,155)

SLATTER He was one of the big family of Donovans, cow cockies over on the Coast. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,27)

I would include among New Zealand English words: cow-cockie, cow-cocky (cow-) cocky (May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class)

~ n. small dairy farmer. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),614)

cow cocky n. small dairy farmer. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

cow-cocky (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

cockie/cow cockie: farmer who has a dairy herd; e.g., `Henry's a cow cockie in Taranaki.' (1981,NZ Police National Headquarters) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

CHARLES There is a good cheque you can earn, seeding a burn,/ Or cutting some cow-cocky's scrub./ (1981,Black Billy Tea,74)

cow-cocky n. Austral. & N.Z. a one-man dairy farmer. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,258) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 171; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 110]]

BENTLEY & FRASER A cow cocky up Tokoroa/ Rang his agent to order a moa./ Told They're dead as a dodo!'/ He said, <i>Quocumque modo?/ Then you'd best send a hoiho, e hoa!' (1985,Grand Limerick Tour, A,8)

SHERWOOD The words flew, and enriched Celia's [an English visitor's] vocabulary. Duck shoving' was the local name for buck-passing between government departments. AQueen Street farmer' was a city slicker who owned land or stock for tax-fiddle reasons. Skite' anddrongo' were terms of abuse. A cow-cockie' was a dairy farmer and inferior for some reason to arunholder' concerned only with sheep. A `piker' was a faint-hearted person who gave up the fight too soon, ... (1985,Botanist at Bay,26)

McGILL cow cocky dairy farmer. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

SLATTER he's in there somewhere, still alive, while Mick from cow cocky [stock] lies in his honoured grave overseas. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,77)

TURNER The real cow-cocky country is in the North island of New Zealand, especially in Taranaki and the Waikato ... (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,148)

He is referred to by public speakers.. as a dairy farmer, by his neighbours (and in particular sheep farmers) as a "cow-cockie", and the latter is the name that will appear most when in future years the history of New Zealand is written. (Feb 5, 1924,Otago Witness,15)

adj.

VIRTUE Going to the Waikato seemed like going to the other side of the world. `They'll be a bit cow-cocky up there, I reckon,' he told himself ... (1987,Redemption of Elsdon Bird, The,44,1988 ed.)

1 n. (Rural) a dairy farmer.

He is referred to by public speakers .. as a dairy farmer, by his neighbours (and in particular sheep farmers) as a 'cow-cockie.' (Feb 5, 1924,Otago Witness,15)

When the dairy industry became established and the cropping farms were cut up such men became the first generation of 'cow cockies.' (Jul 1947,NZ Journal of Agriculture,21)

North Island cow cockies are queuing up to buy irrigated Canterbury farms. (Jun 11, 1981,NZ Farmer,37)

YEREX A city girl who married a sheep farmer was going up in the world; one who married a 'cow cocky' was to be pitied. (1989,Empire of the Dairy Farmers,59)

WATERSON That's a real cow cocky's way of doing it. (1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,78)

And he has no regrets that he missed his chance to be a Taranaki cow cockie. (Mar 3, 2001,Dominion,34)

.. it's enough to make grown cow-cockies cry ... (Nov 8, 2001,Dominion,17)

A pair of Taranaki cow cockies made aristocracy weep at the National Yearling Sales at Karaka last year ... [cow-cocky] (Mar 22, 2002,Hawke's Bay Today,11)

cow-cockying¶

n.

(The Plot that Failed) Southill, the cow-cockying district ... (May 1942,National Education,146)

n. dairy farming

SARGESON My father was a cow-cocky, but he couldn't make cow-cockying pay. (Jan 1937,Tomorrow,6) [NOTES: Original 1937; also 1940 Sargeson A Man and His Wife 29; 1978 Islands 21/239, etc.]

cow-dog¶

n. a dog trained to bring home milking-cows. (See contrast cattle dog)

`He's a good enough cow-dog,' he said, soon calm again. (Aug 1986,Islands,37/40)

cow-farm¶

n.

cow-farmer¶

n.

cow-feed¶

1 n. (Rural) pasture crop or clover for feeding to cows.
