I have a paddock of 15 acres that I want to put into cow-feed for the coming autumn. It was new ground broken up last spring, and put into swede turnips, which were fed off by cows. (Sep 15, 1913,NZ Journal of Agriculture,346)

cow-grid¶

n. a cattle-stop (See also cow stop)

VIRTUE By the time they'd reached the farm, rattled over the cow-grid at the gate and along the track to the house, Elsdon had forgotten feeling bothered. (1987,Redemption of Elsdon Bird, The,84,1988 ed.)

cow-hand¶

n. rarely used in NZ for a dairy-farm worker

I would include among New Zealand English words: cow-hand: dairy farm labourer (May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class)

cow-hocked¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of animals] with hind legs very close together.

PETER cow hocked - animal with back legs very close together. (2000,Peter Glossary,6)

cow-house¶

n. cowshed

HOCKEN 25. Dr.Stewart's cowhouse on Sec.20, Blk.VI. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,130) [NOTES: 1851 Key to `View of Dunedin ...' in [facing] 1898 Hocken Contributions 130]

BAINES The former bovine female was a brute to manage, and whom it would have been impossible to milk without a `bail.' To what man or country the honour of this invention belongs, who can tell? It is in very general use in the Australian colonies; and my advice to any one troubled with a naughty cow, who kicks like fury during the process of milking, is to have a bail constructed in their cow-house. (1874,Edward Crewe,225) [NOTES: [checked against orig.]]

cow-kick¶

v. to kick out violently to one side.

MEREDITH Some of the sailors ... amused themselves by trying to ride some horses brought in from a wild mob running in the back-blocks. These horses would buck a town down,' as the saying is. I saw one sailor get a cropper; he regained his feet quickly, ... and caught hold of the stirrup; whereupon the neddycow-kicked,' and caught him in the stomach. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,70) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 70]

cow-pie¶

n. a polite form of `cow-muck'.

ROBINSON ... for the trouble of closing a gate or two and getting cow-pie on your Nikes you can run almost anywhere without trespassing. (1986,Heroes and Sparrows,125)

cow-puncher hat¶

n.

They do the Dominion every credit, theseboys with the cow-puncher hats. (Jul 10, 1917,Stratford Evening Post,4)

cow-punching¶

n. dairy-farming; occas. milking [second citation belongs with verb]

Taranaki can't get a sufficient supply of schoolteachers ... Cow-punching affords more possibilities. (Sep 9, 1905,NZ Truth,1)

Youngsters are kept cow-punching [in Taranaki] until they are ... exhausted. (Oct 5, 1905,NZ Truth,5)

cow-spang¶

v. = cow-spank [?error or misprint in citation for cow-spanking; or cow-spanking + cow-banging]

FOSTON He had got a job cow-spanging on a good farm. (1921,At The Front,154)

cow-testing¶

n. = herd-testing

Some cows tested in connection with the cow-testing associations gave as much as 300 lb. fat in the season. Ibid.. 381 Cow-testing Work. Conducted by Marlborough High School. [heading] (Jan 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,258)

The extension of the cow-testing movement this season has been gratifying, and bears splendid evidence to the fact that dairy-farmers are improving their herds ... (Jan 15, 1913,NZ Journal of Agriculture,308)

TURNER But the point to note is that another set of references could be got from the same journal [NZJAg] for a word cow-testing with the same meaning [as herd-testing]; this word is never used now. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,45)

1 n. (Rural) herd-testing.

One herd, say, is equal to the average of all the cows tested by the cow-testing associations last year ... (1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,100)

I started testing my herd when the Dairy Division of the Agricultural Department opened the Cow-testing Association at Kaupokonui at the beginning of the season a year ago. (Feb 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,98)

Some people have an idea that a cow-testing association is not altogether what it ought to be ... (1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,101)

Some dairymen who are not yet satisfied as to the necessity of cow-testing, and who feel that the work entails trouble not compensated for by the results ... (Mar 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,176)

cow-town¶

n.

While the largest agricultural expo in the southern hemisphere was on down the road, Hamilton, striving to shake off its cow-town image, kicked off Fuel, a month-long thespian-fest of new or newish work by Kiwi writers, directors and performers. (Jun 29, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),63)

cow-track¶

n. a rough track (as though made by cows).

Your section is behind that. You have two razor-backs and a gully and no way in except a cow-track. (1902,NZ Illustrated Magazine,5/379)

cow-tucker¶

n. feed for cows

n. feed for cows

CASEY Terrible pity to see good cow-tucker going to waste like that, you know. Ibid. 156 Won't you have them [sc. cows] running short of feed?'Well ... Nobody's got cow-tucker to burn. I started feeding out before the end of April.' How are you off for hay, then?'Just about cut out, what the hell do you think?' (1963,As Short a Spring,108)

cowage¶

n. Bidens pilosa.

HOOKER Cowage. Bidens pilosa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),764)

cowbail¶

n.

HARTLEY As I opened the cowbail door I saw Tony with his wife in his arms ... (1987,Swagger on Our Doorstep,182)

n. [?collect COW- bail, pat etc under one COW combin as in AND; collect up all the euphemisms for cowmuck together (HWO)]

MALCOLM During the depression he built a cow-bail and bought a herd of 70 cows. (1982,Where it all Began,171)

Drafting yard and cow bails. (1849,Notes on NZ,2/26)

The cowbails and stockyard are fastened up. (May 12, 1851,Journal of Edward Ward,180,1951 ed.)

EARP The yard is generally divided into three ... a large yard for the whole herd, a drafting yard, and a milking yard, at one end of which is placed the milking shed, cow bails, and calf house ... (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),123) [NOTES: 1853 Allom letter in 1853 Earp NZ 123 (Wairarapa)]

Dray returned from Moa cottage with cow bale, hurdles paint oil &c. (Jul 11, 1860,Puketoi Station Diary) [NOTES: [=head stall]]

Cleaned out stockyard and flagged cowbale. (Jul 19, 1861,Puketoi Station Diary)

Made a cow bale in the morning, worked at the punga fence in the afternoon, damp and nasty. (Nov 4, 1882,Chudleigh Diary,314,1950 ed.)

... slept all night in a cowbail. (Aug 12, 1905,NZ Truth,8/7/8)

BAUGHAN Yet, see! past the cow-bails,/ Down, deep in the gully,/ What glimmers ? (1908,Shingle-Short,81)

... in the cold grey light of dawn she would rise and share with her husband the work of the cowbails. (1940,Tales of Pioneer Women,213,1988 ed.)

FINLAYSON Thursday morning Uncle Ted and Jake are cleaning up round the cowshed ... And he stands by the cowbails with his hands stuck inside the band of his pants to listen. (1948,Tidal Creek,140,1979 ed.)

SCANLAN For an hour Ambrose smoked his pipe as he leant over the slip-rail behind the cow-bails; ... Ibid. 90 `Just wait till he gets home,' she thought as she took down the cow-bails. (1948,Dusty Road,81)

DARE This consisted of a very small cowyard and a corrugated iron cow-bail holding two cows at a time. Ibid. 118 He always came to the cow-bail to collect his milk. Ibid.147 My cow-bail, situated in the middle of a wood, was in excellent order, with a nice concrete yard, easy to clean, and with a tap and hose handy. ...The cows were driven into a small yard and then into the bail, which held two at a time. They walked into position and were not tied up, but a chain hooked around their hindquarters kept them from backing out, and when I had finished milking there was a door in front of their heads which I opened with the aid of a long rope, and the cow walked out into the field again. (1956,Rouseabout Jane,7)

HILLIARD She ... could fetch things when told ... from the cowbail, the garden, the smoking-shed with its bacon sides ... (1960,Maori Girl,13)

KEENE Two cowbails were made against a huge rata log over six feet through. (1967,Tang of The Bush,58)

SUTHERLAND He'd either be in the front paddock, or in the cowbail ... (1978,Elver, The,45)

BOYD Milk sellers should be licensed and all dairies, cowbails and animals should be inspected, preferably by a vet. (1984,City of the Plains,74)

1 n. (Rural) a cowshed or area where cows are bailed.

ALLOM The yard is generally divided into .. a milking yard, at one end of which is placed the milking shed, cow bails and calf house. (1849,Letter,123) [NOTES: in Earp Handbook (1852)]

CHUDLEIGH Made a cow bale this morning ... (Nov 4, 1882,Chudleigh Diary,314) [NOTES: (1950)]

The nature of the cow-bail surroundings has a big effect on the quality of cream produced on the farm. (Dec 20, 1928,NZ Dairy Exporter,14)

At one time the Trials were confined to sheep men only, but close settlement, also low profits of sheepfarming, have driven a large number of our doggy men into the cow bail. (Apr 1932,NZ Farmer,255)

.. little cowbails like this started to appear. (Apr 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture,40)

KERR Arthur's cowbail was a bugger of a thing down on the freezing flats and his cows had warty tits, so I sold the cows and built a new high dry bail. Derek Wooten was gathering opinions about the gold bracelet he had bought for his wife on their twenty-fifth wedding anniversary and asked what I'd got Ima for ours. I told him: a new cowbail with a nice concrete slab floor ... [cow bail; cow-bail; cowbale] (2000,High Times in the High Country,123)

cowbar¶

n. a stout frame of metal bars mouted on the front of vehicles to reduce damage in the event of a collision with stray animals or vehicles.

Cowbars originally designed to protect farm vehicles from stock are being increasingly used on the roads ... Commonly called cow-catchers, these cowbars are not catching cows but are catching motorcyclists; ... (Jan 2, 1982,Evening Post,3/3)

cowboy¶

n. (Rural) a young worker employed to milk house cows and assist in maintaining the homestead supplies of wood, fruit, vegetables etc.

WILSON & FRASER They had a Maori youth who acted as cowboy and general rouseabout. (1936,Book of the Pioneers, The,31)

LOUGHNAN Cowboy: Lad who milks the station cows. He may possibly play a guitar in the whare but he rarely needs to ride a horse. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,21)

Did you rattle the cowboy along this morning? If so, it's quite probable that by tomorrow the whole district will have heard how you murdered him and hung him up the dog-tucker tree. (Sep 27, 1962,NZ Farmer,53)

DICK 1932 saw Alan as a lad of seventeen and out to his first job: cow boy to a farmer near Oamaru. (1964,High Country Family,28)

The manpower at present [on Erewhon Station] consists of the manager (who is also the head shepherd) a married general hand, a married shepherd, four single shepherds, a married fencer and a cowboy. (Jan 28, 1965,NZ Farmer,7)

NEWTON He started as a cowboy at Tablelands, rose to head shepherd at Lagoon Hill and in 1949 went to Glenburn as manager. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,24)

SALISBURY At one stage the cowboy, Henry Horsfeld broke his leg and I had to take over the job of milking the cows for some six weeks. (1994,I Was So Lucky,10)

n. (Rural) a farmer who is not thorough and dedicated to animal management; a rough-and-ready farmer; a farmer whose main aim is to make money quickly.

Consumers wanted the standards to be extremely high, but some producers, "especially cowboys" wanted them as low as possible so they "get on board really quickly and make a quick buck." Support for producers converting to organics was requested by many submitters, Mr Ewen-Street said. A simple answer would be a subsidy, but apart from being "a dirty word in New Zealand" there would be no comeback if a "cowboy" did not deliver on his promises. (Feb 22, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,17)

n. a (junior) stationhand who milks the house cow, and tends to domestic chores; now cowman(-gardener). (See contrast cattle man)

WOOD It did not take Frank long ... to ... drive the cow down. In the township he met Edwards, who ... said ... `Hallo! have you turned cow-boy?' (1875,Waiting for the Mail,83)

WILLIAMS & REEVES Michael Miggs the station cowboy was invariably there. (1891,Double Harness,8)

The cow-boy was waitin' with a dog-cart to take her up to the station. (1903,NZ Illustrated Magazine,8/365)

The wife got a kit of potatoes and called all the pigs. The cowboys let the pigs out of a yard and they all ran after the wife who ran towards the beach where there were strong yards and into these yards ran the pigs. (Feb 18, 1906,Chudleigh Diary,431,1950 ed.)

ROBIN [a herd] ... surrounded by a number of `cattle men' ... The term cowboy is not known here. [quoted by ? OED: a US author] (1907,Trip to Maoriland, A,26)

CARR Cow-boy. I nearly forgot the cow-boy. Where the gardener does not milk, a boy of 14 or 16 years old is generally employed. His duties are to milk ... chop wood, carry in and out washing, etc. (1913,Country Work,34)

BEATTIE I was cook, housemaid, cowboy - for I had a cow and `lashings of milk' - rouseabout, ploughman. (1913,Trade Hunting,[10])

Cowboy: The boy who milks, etc. Not the romantic American horseman. (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

ACLAND ... once when a cowboy of his brought a disastrous career to an end by raiding the pantry ... Tripp asked him what he could do. (1946,Early Canterbury Runs,153)

BEATTIE Even if no other cattle were on the run, it behoved the station to keep a cow or two for milking purposes, and generally a lad was kept whose duties were to tend and milk the animals, and perhaps to assist in the garden. This lad was called the cowboy, and this was no abuse of the meaning of the term, whereas the American cowboy might have long grey whiskers and have never milked a cow in his life. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,40)

BEATTIE When I was a cowboy I made up my mind I was going to be a farmer and I stuck to it, never working at gold mining or on a run, ... (1956,Pioneer Recollections,16,1956 ed.)

McLEOD Very often a lad starts as a cowboy on a station, ... (1951,High Country,17)

BLAKISTON On Moreroa we kept several cows, and usually managed to get a cowboy from the neighbourhood. Ibid.. 51 In the eighties [1880s], the station had no difficulty in getting good boys. As far as I can remember, nearly every Woodbury man who worked at the Gorge started as a cowboy, and almost all of them become good workers. (1952,My Yesteryears,38) [NOTES: [f. c1869]]

NEWTON ... he got the cowboy to fix me up with a feed for my horse ... (1952,High Country Journey,21)

DARE ... I used to try ... and get the cowboy to teach me the rudiments of milking. Ibid. 146 My official capacity was cowboy or `rouseabout', meaning odd jobber ... (1956,Rouseabout Jane,63)

MASTERS Lou Cheer, who now resides in Hastings, was cowboy on Blackhead at the time [1903]. Ibid. 169 It was a slack time of the year on the station, and when he arrived back, the only ones down at the men's quarters were the cook and Bill the cowboy. (1959,Tales of the Mails,124)

DICK 1932 saw Allan as a lad of seventeen, and out to his first job: cow boy to a farmer near Oamaru, his wages the princely sum of five shillings a week. (1964,High Country Family,28)

[nf.8th edn] [See def.] cowboy A man or boy whose duty it is to look after cows. (1967,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),108)

McCASKILL In 1881, a boy of fourteen, he went to Tarndale as a fleece picker for the shearing, stayed on as cowboy and in succesion became packer, musterer, stockman, head stockman, head shepherd and manager. (1969,Molesworth,81)

NEWTON He started there [at Molesworth Station] as cowboy in 1879. (1973,Big Country,26,1977 ed.)

WATSON [On the Queensland sheep station there were] the head shepherd and the shepherds, the cowboy (which is the Australian term for cowman-gardener) .. (1980,Flowers from Happyever,11)

LANGDALE-HUNT On the way back to the [Chatham Island] hotel the cowboy, quite a young lad, said in a quavering voice, `Do you think she will die, Mr Hunt?' (1985,Last Entail Male,136)

1 n. (Rural) a worker employed on a dairy farm to milk cows.

Labour Unionism has now invaded the dairying industry, a cowboys' union having been formed at Tokarahi, North Otago. Following are the main rules - That cowboys over 16 be paid aGBP1 a week ... (Aug 22, 1903,Farmers' Union Advocate,6)

3 n.

The groups of motor-bike cowboys who congregated in Queen Street with their gleaming motor bikes parked at the kerb enlivened the Friday night scene. With their leather jackets and slicked back hair the motor- bike cowboys provided a sharp contrast to the more conventionally dressed shoppers. (Jun 2004,NZ Memories,No. 48/6)

cowdie/cowdy¶

n. (See kauri)

cowfish¶

n.

McDOWALL A Mr A. E. Gibson tried three times to raise whitebait to the adult stage, concluding that they "are what we call cowfish or inanga." Ibid. 61 In March 1932, when coming along at high tide or just after it had receded, I noticed Inanga everywhere amongst the rushes and in one pool which the tride had left, it seemed as if, say two buckets of milk had been thrown in. This was full of fish, evidently just spawning. This is the origin of the name "cowfish" sometimes used for this species. (1984,NZ Whitebait Book, The,8)

They are what we call cowfish' orinanga.' (1903,TrNZI,35/311) [NOTES: (Hector)]

The adult minnow [Galaxias attenuatus], which migrates down-stream during February and march, is at this season known to Hokitika fishermen by the seemingly misapplied appellation of `cowfish'. It is, however, on account of the fact that, when captured, milk-like ova or semen comes away from the body of the fish that this name has been so readily adopted. (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,7/117) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

WILSON COWFISH: see Whitebait; also Eagle-ray (1981,Fisherman's Bible,43)

2 n. bottlenosed dolphin

WILLIAMS Terehu n. Tursiops tursio, cow-fish. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,483)

The Marlborough Sounds ... are the haunts of the cowfish - a mammal whose scientific name is Tursiops. ... the popular name of `porpoise' applied to it by steamer passenger is ... wrong. (Apr 10, 1920,Quick March,37)

The cowfish (Tursiops truncatus) is a large dolphin occasionally seen off the coast of the South Island, and entering the sounds in the south-west. It has a distinct but short beak, a high falcate dorsal fin, and 22 or 23 pairs of teeth. (1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,5/139) [NOTES: (Oliver)]

REISCHEK Next morning I found a stranded cow-fish, whose carcass it took me four days to get clean, ... (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,70,1933 ed.)

DOOGUE & MORELAND BOTTLENOSED DOLPHIN ... Other names: Tursiops truncatus; cowfish. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,302)

Once, too, we passed a school of cowfish - smaller cetaceans allied to the porpoises, but fifteen feet long, salty in colour and having a falcate dorsal fin in place of the more usual rounded one. (1966,NZ Short Stories,33) [NOTES: (Ruben `My First Whale')]

SANSOM Wonderful days those were, when we might be amongst the dolphins (cow-fish we called them) or a school of pilot whales (black fish to us), or to see a single thresher shark whacking the water with a tail as long as its body. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,78)

3 n. eagleray.

DOOGUE & MORELAND EAGLERAY ... Other names: Myliobatus tenuicaudatus; whipray, cowfish (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,190)

MORELAND EAGLERAY [Myliobatis tenuicaudatus] ... Whiptail, stingray and cowfish are among other names in use. (1967,Marine Fishes,14)

WILSON COWFISH see Eagle-ray (1981,Fisherman's Bible,37)

[species name] eagle ray.br;[species name] Myliobatis tenuicaudatus .. [other name(s)] cowfish (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

cowgrass¶

1 n. (Rural) red clover.

TAIT The first red clover (cowgrass) seed was produced and pioneered at Caythorpe and in conjunction with this, the first clover huller ... (1958,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol II,7)

CONNELL & HADFIELD Broad red clover, which is also called early-flowering red clover and cowgrass. (1961,Agriculture,267)

cowleaf¶

n. (obsolete) mahoe (See cf. cowtree)

In many parts of Banks Peninsula, ... [Melicytus ramiflorus] is known as `Cowleaf', from the avidity with which its leaves are devoured by cattle. (1870,TrNZI,3/184) [NOTES: (Potts and Gray)]

POTTS (And) (1882,Out in the Open)

LAING & BLACKWELL On Banks Peninsula [Melicytus ramiflorus, mahoe] is sometimes called the cow-leaf, as cows are very fond of its foliage. (1907,Plants of NZ,266,1940, p. 280 ed.)

COCKAYNE (And) (1911,AJHR,C-13) [NOTES: Report on Dune-areas]

cowlick¶

n. cattle-lick, esp. rock salt. [ca1940 Havelock]

cowman¶

n. a general farmhand responsible for milking and for other domestic chores, esp. attending to the homestead vegetable garden

HAYES ... F. Denham (cowman). (1978,From the Toss of a Coin,156) [NOTES: 1914 Normanvale, Canterbury, Wages Book in 1978 Hayes Toss Of a Coin 156]

CURNOW Wasn't this the site, asked the historian,/ Of the original homestead?/ Couldn't tell you, said the cowman;/ I just live here, he said,/ ... She's all of eighty said the cowman/ Down at the milking-shed. (1941,Island and Time,20)

MARSH ... a wool-classer, three boys, two gardeners, a cowman and a station cook. (1945,Died in the Wool,28)

McLEOD In winter time the number of men [on a station] is small, perhaps only a single shepherd and a cowman.... (1951,High Country,16)

DARE The vegetable garden ... was looked after by a cowman-gardener. (1956,Rouseabout Jane,28)

CURNOW She's all of eighty said the cowman,/ Down at the milking-shed. (1971,Nowhere Far from the Sea,124) [NOTES: 1971 Nowhere Far from the Sea (Curnow `House and Land') 124]

LETHBRIDGE The only permanent hands were D'Arcy and the cowman. ... The latter's job, apart from looking after some half-dozen cows, was to help with the garden and vegetables, the firewood, and butcher the meat. (1971,Sunrise on the Hills,26)

FERNANDEZ Any old station hand - even the cowman - gets more than me. (1973,Tussock Fever,26)

n.

WATSON The only suitable job was a cowman-gardener on a [140] station; ... (1965,Stand in the Rain,139)

WATSON [On the Queensland sheep station there were] the head shepherd and the shepherds, the cowboy (which is the Australian term for cowman-gardener) ... (1980,Flowers from Happyever,11)

cowman-gardener¶

1 n. (Rural) an older male person who milks cows, does handyman homestead chores and looks after the vegetable garden of a station.

PLUMMER The only other man on the property was a cowman-gardener named Simmons. [cowman] (1994,From Drover to Director,28)

NEWTON I was seeking information from the cowman to the owner. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,10)

LOUGHNAN cowman: Though of much more mature years he does the same job as the cowboy. Very often his job is combined with another and he is termed the cowman-gardener. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,21)

cowmanship¶

1 n. (Rural) a qualitative assessment of a dairy farmer.

I shall try to correct this by contacting local farmers who have earned a high reputation for good cowmanship ... (Jun 10, 1958,NZ Dairy Exporter,41)

In the time that we spent on the farm with Peter Fisher we reached the conclusion that he is applying in his approach to his job that mixture of qualities which can best be summed up in two words, 'good cowmanship.' And as we have said on many occasions before - good cowmanship - the natural capacity to get the best from each individual member of the herd - is the highest common factor in successful dairy farming. (Apr 11, 1960,NZ Dairy Exporter,13)

cowpat¶

n.

Land Rovers inside shops, meals being cooked on shovels over a fire, rustic barbecues on the street and among some of the finest delicacies to tempt your tastebuds during this "bit of a dag day" will be cowpat burgers, hot dag dishes, and real rustic-sized meals. (Apr 5, 1999,Dominion,10)

SARGESON One of my brothers found out a good way of warming his feet up. He stuck them in a cow-pat that had just been dropped. Ibid. 298 cow-pats : rounds of cow-dung (1964,Collected Stories,64) [NOTES: From 1944 A Man and His Wife and 1937 Tomorrow 6 Jan]

These green paddocks dotted with thistles and cow-pats. (1954,Landfall,8/273)

KINROSS ... the ball struck a tuft of cocksfoot or the edge of a dry cowpat ... (1963,Please to Remember,36)

SARGESON cow-pats: rounds of cow-dung. (1964,Collected Stories,298)

SUTHERLAND He picked up an old dry cowpat from the paddock ... (1978,Elver, The,64)

I just havew time to sit on a cow-pat before Rhys arrives with the car. (Dec 20, 2003,Dominion Post,E8)

cowrie¶

n. spelling variant of kauri [also cowry, courie; note also cowdy, caudie, coudie, coudy et al. (Anglicisation)]

BIDWILL The Cowrie or pine of the country (Dammara australis) is abundant here, although it is almost the by the Canterbury Association, sailed together from England ... (1841,Rambles in NZ,28,1952 ed.)

Nicholas Of those trees which were generally to be met with, the pine was by far the most beautiful, and in height exceeded all the others beyond any degree of comparison. We observed two species of it, but the mountain-pine, called by the natives cowrie, which we found growing upon the sides and summits of the hills, and rising to an enormous size, was the most remarkable. (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/233)

There is little or no couru (pine) on the immediate banks of the Hokianga itself, ... [possibly a misprint or misinterpretation in original for the courie of p34] ... there are some splendid courie forests up the river, ... (Aug 9, 1834,NZ Independent,32,1979 ed.)

cowry¶

n. (See kauri)

cowsh¶

n. nonsense [ca1914]

[Captain] Ken Nolan ... a song on the rain and a shovel in a bucket of cowsh [TEXT] It's not bull ... it's cow. (Nov 27, 1977,Sunday Times (NZ),17)

McGILL cowsh nonsense, short for `cowshit'. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

cowshed¶

n. a farm building in which cows are milked (See also byre,milking shed)

Cowsheds have been described as "New Zealand's own white-slave trade". Woimen and children were in virtual bondage to the land and the demands of the farm. (Dec 17, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

Probably, the only other building [as well as the bach] that we can claim to have developed to be our own is, rather comically, the cowshed. (Oct 19, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

Once in the past MAF determined that the good old kiwi "cowshed" should be called a "milking parlour". (Jan 16, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

MARSDEN What they have at present are as bad as cowsheds. (1830,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,490,1932 ed.)

MATTHEW ... cow-shed ... (1840,Journal,3/30)

POWER We had but a moment to look at this dreadful sight when the cries of a young child were heard from a neighbouring cowshed. ... On entering the cowshed I was horror-struck by the most dreadful sight my eyes ever beheld. (1849,Sketches in NZ,89)

EARP Improvements by putting up cow-shed, pig-sty, fowl-house, and tool-house, 6l. (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),158)

Arthur is going to make a clearing on our land this year, and ...[sic] after the burn would put up a slab house of two rooms which might serve afterwards for cowshed or kitchen or workshop. (Aug 8, 1855,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/172,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (Jane M. Atkinson)]

Harry has lent his large cowshed to the military authorities for a guardhouse at Fort Herbert ...[sic] (Jul 17, 1860,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/617,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (J. Maria Atkinson)]

... three ricks blown down do [?ditto] an old cow-shed, ... (Aug 5, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,141,1950 ed.)

CHARLEY TURNER I'm glad you have a cowshed, you ought to get fat now. (Jul 30, 1867,Letter) [NOTES: 1867 July 30 Charley Turner in 1969 Neal From London to Lonely Rai 47]

JOHN HURNDALL Arthur commencd [sic] taking down old cowshed, built 17 years ago. (Aug 3, 1881,Diary) [NOTES: 1881 Aug 3 John Hurndall's Diary in 1988 Warr From Bush-burn to Butter 52]

EVISON ... cowshed ... (1889,Murder Will Out,26)

BELL A neat dairy was to be seen at the back of the house; and ... a comfortable cowshed and yards, where milking operations were in progress. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,36)

The dearest cowsheds are in the Taranaki country. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,281)

BAUCKE But there can be no finality to a system of inspector, valuer, and rangerships; where coercion is juxtaposed to base compliance; ... where `good enough' is labelled on loop-hanging wire fences, [303] despondent cowsheds, dogleg stockyards, wire-hinged field-gates, ... (1905,Where the White Man Treads,302)

RUTHERFORD Cow-byre manure is packed in on mules ... This cowshed manure is a priceless treasure on the Continent. (1912,Impressions of a NZ Pastoralist on Tour,148)

POWDRELL There are many types of cow-shed, for example the Race, the Double bail, the Single back-out, and the Walk-through type of shed. (1920,Dairy Farming in NZ,22)

ANTHONY Two-roomed house and four-bailed cowshed on property. Will milk twenty cows. (1924,Follow the Call,3,1975 ed.)

GUTHRIE On it came, this avalanche of mud, tearing up ... the cow-sheds 80 feet in length. (1930,NZ Memories,164) [NOTES: [a milking-shed, not a shelter shed]]

BEATTIE ... the stables, cowsheds and barns were better than the men's dwellings [c1840] (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,5)

FINLAYSON It was on the way home ... that his father came upon him in the cowshed, ... (Jan 22, 1947,Brown Man's Burden,9,1973 ed.) [NOTES: `Rui's Ship']

DUGGAN ... he waited for the metal-banging signal to call him into the cowshed ... (1981,Collected Stories (Duggan),52)

FINLAYSON Thursday morning Uncle Ted and Jake are cleaning up round the cowshed ... a strange man come upon them round the corner of the cowshed ... And he stands by the cowbails with his hands stuck inside the band of his pants to listen. (1948,Tidal Creek,140,1979 ed.)

For these units the Department supplied stock, fencing-materials, fertilizers, seeds, cow-sheds ... [51]. Now two large dams built in the hills [above Ruatoki] supply every house, marae, and cow-shed. (1948,Our Own Country,50)

Power lines to the cow-shed don't necessarily mean electric stoves ... plenty [of women] still help in the milking sheds. (Oct 1949,Here & Now,17) [NOTES: [cf milking shed]]

DEWAR Nearby would be the cowshed, rough and small, having before it a sea of mud where four or five lean cows showed daily what they could do ... (1953,Chaslands,22) [NOTES: [Southland]]

BOSWELL ... but one by one the off-shoots of the farmhouse appeared - [47] cowshed, dairy, calf house for calves in winter, and pig sty. (1955,Dim Horizons,46,1956 ed.)

DAVIN He went back towards the cowshed and I took the path to the house. (1959,No Remittance,69) [NOTES: [Southland]]

MIDDLETON As she came past the cowshed, her father came out ... (1964,Walk on the Beach,17)

TURNER All the familiar details of the cowshed are named .. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,149)

MIDDLETON `There are plenty of fine new cowsheds though,' joked the man. (1975,NZ Short Stories III,67,1975 ed.)

McNAUGHTON ... he noticed a red-headed girl releasing a cow from a bail in a small cowshed. (1970,Tat,103) [NOTES: [Otago]]

WILSON On sultry summer evenings, when it was still daylight after we'd finished cleaning down the cowshed, we used to sit by the tank stand, under our windmill. (1984,South Pacific Street,6)

I never saw his cowshed, or his cows. (Aug 1986,Islands,37/39)

HEWNDERSON The two-bail cowshed's open side looked out to the most beautiful view in all dairying. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,120)

n. (Rural) a shed or dairy where cows are milked. [Used more in the North Island whereas in the South Island, cowbail or byre is used. ] (See byre,milking shed)

MARSDEN What they have at present is as bad as cowsheds. (1830,Letters & Journals,490) [NOTES: (1932)]

This 92 ha property has a near new 24 aside H/B cowshed ... [cow shed] (Oct 27, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,38)

There is a good House upon the land, with dairy, cowsheds, piggeries, &c. (Feb 10, 1868,Daily Southern Cross,4) [NOTES: Advert]

368 acres, 154 in grass; a 2 roomed house, dairy, cowshed, &c, E.R. (May 26, 1896,Taranaki Herald,4) [NOTES: Advert]

The regulations referred to by the Hon. R. McNab are 32 in number, and provide that every dairyman shall apply to the inspector under the Act for registration of his dairy, accompanying it with a ground-plan of the cowshed, race, stockyard, and milk-stand, with dimensions shown. (Sep 15, 1908,Hawera & Normanby Star,6)

SMALL DAIRY FARM, 90 acres, situate New River, with Cottage, Cowshed, Dairy, etc. (May 7, 1913,Grey River Argus,7) [NOTES: Advert]

The buildings (now occupied by Mr. Wicksteed) consist of one of Manning's houses, weather-boarded and well painted, twenty-seven feet by eighteen, a kitchen with brick chimney and oven, out-houses, pigsties, cow-shed, fowl-house, &c. (Apr 20, 1842,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,1) [NOTES: Advert]

Harry has lent his large cowshed to the military authorities for a guardhouse. (1860,BLANK ENTRY,617) [NOTES: in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers I]

LOUGHNAN Bail: Though the word is not of New Zealand origin our cows in the south are milked in a bail or cow-bail (or even a byre) as distinct from the Taranaki/Waikato terms milking shed or cowshed. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,2)

Next season will be her first for breaking in heifers, but the cow shed is familiar territory to the rising two-year-olds. (Apr 19, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,18)

cowshed paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a field where the milking shed is located on a farm.

Poppy waddled into the cowshed paddock ... (Oct 3, 2001,Lifestyleblock.co.nz)

cowshit¶

n. an occas. var. of bullshit. [ca1952 Wellington] (See also cowsh)

cowsick¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of land] changed or restricted by the habits and disease of grazing cattle.

It is good practice too to have a few sheep on a dairy farm; they help to keep the land from getting cowsick and will pay for their keep. (Aug 30, 1924,Hawera Star,9)

cowspank¶

v. to run a dairy farm

Cowspanker.-Station slang for cowboy; but a correspondent points out that to people in the town it connotes a dairy farmer, and that to cowspank is to run a dairy farm. (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Gloss]

SCANLAN If it hadn't been for Michael, Kelly would still be cow-spanking somewhere up-country; ... (1934,Winds of Heaven,189)

v.

He cow-spanks at a place called Kaimiro. (Oct 26, 1912,NZ Ferns,4)

cowspanker¶

n. a dairy farmer (See also cow-banger)

A burly young cow-spanker from the backblocks had come to town. (May 18, 1912,NZ Free Lance,14)

"What's your name, Honey-bunch?"..."Cowspanker" she said simply. (Dec 29, 1944,Taranaki Herald,2)

"The Cow Spankers" is the name of thelatest political party in the House. (Sep 22, 1900,NZ Free Lance,12)

It was rather unfortunate that he included in his sentry group some cowspankers, as the enemy collared the said group milking "Strawberry" one mile in advance of our line. (Dec 1916,Roll Call,30)

McGILL They climbed trees and had fights with cow spankers, plates of dried dung. (1980,In Praise of Older Buildings,18)

The king of Okoia cow-spankers rules his small boggy kingdom with a rod of iron (Aug 11, 1906,NZ Truth,60/3/38)

MILLER ... scummy Colonial [chk cap.] cow-spankers and bush-whackers. (1939,Camps, Tramps and Trenches,49) [NOTES: ... scummy Colonial [chk cap.] cow-spankers and bush-whackers.]

Cowspanker.-Station slang for cowboy; but a correspondent points out that to people in the town it connotes a dairy farmer, and that to cowspank is to run a dairy farm (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Gloss. additions]

SOLJAK New Zealanders have coined or adapted many expressions to meet local requirements, as illustrated by the following: ... cowspank: to milk cows; cowspanker: dairy farmer (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),117)

FINLAYSON And it's true what his mother always said - Uncle Ted's cruel to his animals, a real cowspanker he reckons. (1948,Tidal Creek,67,1979 ed.)

SOLJAK New Zealanders have coined or adapted many expressions to meet local requirements, as illustrated by the following: ... cowspank: to milk cows; cowspanker; dairy farmer (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),117)

McLINTOCK Dairy farmers are (or were) cowspankers. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/680) [NOTES: Wall NZ Speech]

McGILL cowspanker dairy farmer. NZA (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

From the worried gentlemen in Tooley Street to the humblest cow-spanker, we all look to the cow. (Dec 18, 1926,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,35)

This [sc. a circus] just makes Mr Cowspanker real hilarious. (Nov 1, 1890,NZ Observer,4)

Catching on to a competition with the local cow-spankers.. [he] soon showed himself able to beat them at their own game. (Mar 5, 1904,NZ Observer,4)

The fact that the majority of C Coy. boys come from Taranaki, the land of the cow spankers, will possibly account for the similarity of character displayed by so many of the men, though variety is made up by the n.c.o.'s, most of whom are of a much more cosmopolitan nature. (1918,Link, The,31)

I was forced to put on the uniform of the cowspanker. (Sep 10, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,20) [NOTES: May be US rather than Taranaki in origin]

He entered on the profession of a "cow spanker," as they call it here. (Oct 9, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

THE SARGE "Cow spanker," said Herbert proudly. (1950,Excuse my Feet!,7)

1 n. (Rural) a milker of cows.

I see that 'Visitor' in his letter about dirty cow-spankers and muddy yards comes to the conclusion that 50 per cent of the milk is ruined before it comes to the factory. Then "W.G." takes up the cudgels for the cow-spankers and tells us all about the dirty factories. (Jun 22, 1898,Hawera Star,2)

LOUGHNAN cow-cocky or cow-spanker: Here there occurs an interesting variance between urban and rural diction. In the towns both terms denote a dairy farmer, but in the country a cow-cocky is a dairyfarmer and a cowspanker is the cowboy or cowman. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,22)

He entered on the profession of a 'cow spanker' as they call it here. (Oct 8, 1887,Weekly News,8)

.. in dairying here cows and cowspankers take a rest, and come in all the better for it in the spring. (Jul 1899,NZ Farmer,233)

He [the creamery manager] is wasteful and careless often and yet wants a rise and the poor 'cow-spanker' has to suffer. (Nov 21, 1903,Farmers' Union Advocate,5)

Higher wages in the country would solve most farming problems, says cow-spanker. (Jan 1, 1941,NZ Dairy Exporter,13)

GORDON This is a true story of a young lad who worked on Dot's farm as a cowspanker and general hand. (1990,Matawhero, Elsewhere and Other Things,40)

2 n. a cowboy; one who milks the house-cow

SCANLAN ... ploughmen, and drovers and cowspankers. (1932,Pencarrow,87)

Cowspanker: Station slang for cowboy. ([1890-1910].) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

cowspanking¶

n. the work or process of (?hand-)milking cows

... there would in time be an end to the eternal round of cow-spanking, school, and getting up (1900,NZ Illustrated Magazine,2/592)

WOOLLASTON ... milking ... with milking machines, now prevalent ... the ghastliness of cow-spanking was a thing of the past. (1980,Sage Tea,187)

n. dairy farming

Taranaki has a future before it in oil. Oil and cow-spanking combined are better than many gold-mines. (Jan 27, 1912,NZ Free Lance,26)

... beats cow-spanking at Taranaki. (Aug 18, 1906,NZ Truth,5) [NOTES: [Johnny the Milker]]

FOSTON Cow-spanking [sc. in Taranaki] is an interesting life. (1911,Bell Bird's Lair,36)

All.. are residents of the town, and know too much to embark in cow-spanking. (Jun 11, 1904,NZ Observer,5)

Before that I was "cow-spanking" in the Waikato. (Nov 30, 1920,Otago Witness,56)

Cow-spanking evidently agrees with manypeople. (Jan 9, 1899,Taranaki Herald,3)

NEWTON Normally these musterers are inclined to jib at milking cows but there was no objection this time - cow-spanking would be a lot easier than that fencing job.Ibid. 98 When I come to look back on my own cow-spanking days I can't say I broke any records myself as a gardener. (1966,Boss's Story, The,85)

McMEEKAN "Cow-spanking," or a job in town! (1960,Grass to Milk,2)

I tried my hand at dairyin', but soonbegan to see / Cow spankin' wasn't quite the game they cracked it up to be. (1909,Ballads about Business,94)

1 n. (Rural) the milking of cows.

Cow-spanking evidently agrees with many people. (Jan 9, 1899,Taranaki Herald,3)

Any person of either sex, young or old, who can extract cowjuice need not be long unemployed in this district. Cowspanking is not the cleanest of work in our moist climate. (Jan 19, 1893,NZ Farmer)

Dairying is now being taken up by people who, half a dozen years ago, would have turned up their noses at cowspanking. (Jul 1899,NZ Farmer,234)

MCMEEKAN 'Cowspanking' or a job in town! These were the only alternatives. (1960,Grass to Milk,2)

cowtree¶

n. karaka or mahoe [so called from the palatability of their leaves to cows] [cf. cowleaf]

The partiality which stock exhibit for ... mahoe or hinahina, the so-called `cow-tree' of the settler (Melicytus ramiflorus) ... led to the practice among stockmen of cutting the shrubs down for fodder. (1912,TrNZI) [NOTES: 1911 Proceedings 22 in 1912 TrNZI]

BENNETT The karaka-tree of New Zealand (Corynocarpus laevigata), also called Kopi by the natives, and Cow-tree by Europeans (from that animal being partial to its leaves), grows luxuriantly in Sydney.' (1860,Gatherings of a Naturalist,346) [NOTES: 1860 Bennett Gatherings of a Naturalist 346 [Morris]]

MORRIS Cow-tree, n. a native tree of New Zealand. Maori name Karaka. [cites Bennett.] (1898,Austral English,103)

DEVANNY Cowtree and five-finger ... (1930,Bushman Burke,9) [NOTES: [West Coast: could be mahoe.]]

... the cow-tree of the settler. (1912,TrNZI,44) [NOTES: (Proceedings 22) [chk to see whether mahoe or karaka]]

cowyard¶

n.

FINLAYSON Uncle Ted has the cows rounded up and in the cowyard by now, he guesses. (1948,Tidal Creek,28,1979 ed.)

DARE This consisted of a very small cowyard and a corrugated iron cow-bail holding two cows at a time. (1956,Rouseabout Jane,7)

coxcomb oyster/crested oyster¶

n. =?rock oyster

ANGAS The rocks along the sea-shore, in the bays surrounding Waitemata harbour, and indeed on almost [295] every portion of the coast, are covered with a small species of oyster called the crested or coxcomb oyster (ostrea cristata), which is very palatable. (1847,Savage Life,1/294)

coz¶

n. (See cuz)

CPAC¶

abbr. (See see-packed seeker)

CPAG¶

abbr. Child Poverty Action Group

"Medicine and politics cannot and should not be kept apart," says Professor Innes Asher, a member of the Child Poverty Action Group (CPAG), a political pressure group... One of the thrusts of CPAG is to see that the government meets its duty," she says. (Mar 29, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),31)

The row flared when the Child Poverty Action Group (CPAG) came out and called "time's up" on how the government was tackling poverty. (Dec 5, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C1)

CPI¶

abbr. Consumer Price Index

This enabled them to set the political scene for the cpi announcement well in advance, conditioning the public to an increase if this was forecast or alternatively making the most out of a buildup to a good announcement. (Jul 16, 1987,Dominion,1)

National secretary Andrew Little says that the current official annual consumer price index (CPI) figure of 1.6 percent doesn't reflect the real increase in the cost of living for workers. "The CPI includes costs which don't really affect our members, like international travel." (Mar 6, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

CPO¶

abbr. Chief Post Office

CPO NZ Chief Post Office. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,172) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

crab¶

v. to steal, pinch.

... some of these Jokers are going to crab all on copy rights. (1946,Johnny Enzed in the Middle East,44)

n. a Crustacean

[species name] crab .. [scientific name] -- .. [other name(s)] unspecified - see PADDLE CRAB, GIANT SPIDER (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

2 n.

[species name] giant spider crab .. [scientific name] Jacquinotia edwardsii .. [other name(s)] Auckland Islands crab (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Giant spider crab Jacquinotia edwardsii ... A spider crab (family Majidae) restricted to southern New Zealand. Also known as the southern spider crab and Auckland Islands crab. ... The name southern spider crab is more usually and properly given to a smaller species in the same area, Leptomithrax australis. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,154)

2 n.

[species name] lithodes murrayi .. [scientific name] Lithodes murrayi .. [other name(s)] stone crab (not [Neolithodes brodiei] ...Neolithodes brodiei .. [other name(s)] stone crab ... Paralomis zelandica .. [other name(s)] stone crab (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

2 n.

PAUL Swimming crab Ovalipes catharus ... Also commonly known as paddle crab, sometimes surf crab. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,155)

2 n.

[species name] paddle crab .. [scientific name] Ovalipes catharus .. [other name(s)] common swimming crab, red swimming crab (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Swimming crab Ovalipes catharus ... Also commonly known as paddle crab, sometimes surf crab. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,155)

2 n.

This is a northern continental shelf andupper slope species not found south ofCook Strait, commonly referred to as"tojo crab" on Bay of Plenty trawlers inthe 1950s, and harp crab or smooth frogcrab in Australia. (1994,Occas. Papers Hutton Foundation,2) [NOTES: [This series is a privately producedscientific series from the HuttonFoundation (alias Elliot W Dawson) at theWallypug Press, Eastbourne. I rememberthe name Tojo crab being used at thistime but it may be difficult to pin downcontemporary popular citations; fishermendon't normally make PR releases on returnto port]]

2 n. The large heavy deep-water spider crab(up to 215 mm carapace length and 3.5 kgweight) edwardsii(fam.Majiidae) with large edible claws andbluntly-spined or knobbly carapace

PAUL Giant spider crab Jacquinotia edwardsii ... A spider crab (family Majidae) restricted to southern New Zealand. Also known as the southern spider crab and Auckland Islands crab. ... The name southern spider crab is more usually and properly given to a smaller species in the same area, Leptomithrax australis. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,154)

[species name] southern spider crab .. [scientific name] Leptomithrax australis[other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

It is proposed that the full common nameof Jacquinotia edwardsii be:"Jacquinot's southern spider crab"normally abbreviated to southern spidercrab. (1970,Fisheries Technical Report,52/2)

This expedition.. demonstrated that fairquantities of the southern spider crabscould be caught and processed using acomparatively small vessel. (1971,Fisheries Technical Report,101/79)

2 n. The large, heavy, deepwater stone crabmurrayi (fam. Lithodiidae) withleg spread up to 1m, with sharply-spinedcarapace and long chelae; closely relatedto the Alaskan king crab

The large, heavy, deepwater stone crabLithodes murrayi (fam. Lithodiidae) withleg spread up to 1m, with sharply-spinedcarapace and long chelae; closely relatedto the Alaskan king crab (1970,Fisheries Technical Report,97/1)

2 n.

PAUL Giant spider crab Jacquinotia edwardsii ... A spider crab (family Majidae) restricted to southern New Zealand. Also known as the southern spider crab and Auckland Islands crab. ... The name southern spider crab is more usually and properly given to a smaller species in the same area, Leptomithrax australis. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,154)

[species name] giant spider crab .. [scientific name] Jacquinotia edwardsii .. [other name(s)] Auckland Islands crab (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

2 n.

Ebalia tumefacta, Bryer's Nut Crab. Cancer tumefacta, Mont. ...Ebalia bryerii, Leach. (1879,TrNZI,11/395)

2 n.

PAUL In some localities (mainly harbours) the cancer crab, Cancer novaezelandiae, is sufficiently common and large to be worth collecting for food. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,155)

2 n.

WILLIAMS Kaunga, n. hermit crab. (1892,Dictionary of the NZ Language,56)

2 n.

McLINTOCK Large Shore Crab - papaka, Leptograpsus variegatus. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-12)

2 n.

[=SWIMMING CRAB, =SURF CRAB, =SAND CRAB] The paddle crab (Ovalipes catharus) is also known as the swimming, surf or sand crab and lives mainly within 200 metres of the shore. It is particularly aggressive, emerging from the sand to nip the soles and toes of bathers, and the fingers of pipi diggers. (Jun 29, 1983,Evening Post,23)

PAUL Swimming crab Ovalipes catharus ... Also commonly known as paddle crab, sometimes surf crab. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,155)

[species name] paddle crab .. [scientific name] Ovalipes catharus .. [other name(s)] common swimming crab, red swimming crab (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

Late in the summer there was an invasion of paddle crabs in the bay. (Oct 25, 1992,Sunday Star Times,24)

In the turbid water off the Petone foreshore, where crushed shell and coarse sand form underwater waves, and the glutinous muds washed from Hutt River bind the harbour bed into a home for paddle crabs, whelks and tubular worms, a journey has begun. (Jun 2000,Evening Post)

2 n.

[species name] spider crab .. [scientific name] Latreillopsis petterdi .. [other name(s)] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

2 n.

Elamena producta, sp. nov. New Zealand Spider crab. (1879,TrNZI,11/395)

crab hole¶

n. a hole washed out of a track or road and filled with water so hiding their depth, and danger to horses (in which horses can trip).

HALL-JONES .. the bearers stumbled in the crab-holes on either side, or over the tussocks. (1971,Mr Surveyor Thomson,45) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection) c1850s in 1971 Hall-Jones Mr Surveyor Thomson 45]

W.H.S. ROBERTS We went down a spur for two miles that was very soft from the late rain, and full of waterholes, called crab-holes. These holes were formed by the large snowgrass tussocks being burnt out roots and all, leaving a hole, or by the uprooting of trees, where the hole was very large ... In some places these holes made by(?) cattle mustering a most hazardous undertaking. In Mr Alex Garvie's report in 1858 he refers to podge holes,' presumably a variety ofcrab-holes.' (1856,Diary) [NOTES: 1856 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 323]

THOMPSON We had to hold by the lower spurs of the ranges, now ascending one to head the small streamlets or creeks, and then descending another; now floundering in a swamp, then stumbling into crab-holes. (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher,22)

PYKE Ages ago its waters cleft their way through the mountains which then intercepted its course; and by their resistless unceasing action was thus drained the great network of lakes, whereof the existing representatives - large as still their area - are mere `crab-holes' by comparison. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,1/iii/16,(1889,1974) ed.)

Crab.hole. (kr&abreve.b.h&omacr.l.), n. The hole burrowed by the Australian land crab or crayfish; also, name applied to the undulating hollows formed by the action of water and the subsidence of earth over these burrows, common throughout Australia and dangerous to horsemen. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2020)

Mabel and I walked the swamp and lit fires. We both fell into crab-holes a name given to swampy country when full of holes and full of water in wet weather but dry now. These holes are hip deep to me and the poor little wife nearly went out of sight but she stuck to it. (Apr 13, 1910,Chudleigh Diary,450,1950 ed.)

WILSON Carefully straddling high ruts [in the badly constructed road] here and there, and crossing gently over soft and swampy places, he would dodge all the `crab-holes and glue-pots' with a dexterity born of long experience. (1912,Reminiscences of Early Settlement Dunedin,240)

AYSON Thomas found that he had to ride along a ridge at the edge of the bush over very rough country consisting of rocks, scrub, flax, crab holes, and deep little gullies running into the bush between each ridge. (1937,Thomas,84) [NOTES: [Otago]]

Once Bob disappeared altogether in a treacherous crab-hole. (Jan 2, 1890,Otago Witness,4)

Eastward of Te Anau and Manapouri lakes there are large areas of crabholes or "Maori graves" caused by falling trees. (Oct 9, 1890,Otago Witness,20)

McKAY (1897) While the rim-rock.. was.. smooth andregular, that of the Lawrence side wasrendered remarkably by "crab-holes," asthey were called by the miners. (1894,Report on the Older Auriferous Drifts of C.Otago,6)

1 n. (Rural) hole left in the ground when tussocks are burned.

The large tussocks would burn out, roots and all, leaving large holes in the ground which were called crab holes. (1856,BLANK ENTRY) [NOTES: in Southland Daily News and Southlander Jubilee Issue 13 (1911)]

crabgrass¶

n. (See grass)

[The inhabitants] also make use of the crab-grass (Agrostis virginica), a grass which has been found equally useful for stopping encroachments as for pasture. (Oct 4, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,19)

crack¶

n. a (rifle) bullet

man dumps his bloomin' pack - / (Quit it,Dig'. You'll stop a crack!') (1917,New Zealand At the Front,19)

crack a fat¶

phr. to get an erection [ca1968 Wellington (W. Maughan)]

O'SULLIVAN Like the stuff they put in your tea in the last one [sc. War]. Stop you cracking a fat at the front. (1985,Shuriken,21)

McGILL crack to hit, as in Frank S. Anthony's Me and Gus; crack a fat, a male erection and/or ejaculation; crack a greenie, riding a wave or opening a bottle of beer. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

crack along¶

v. to get a move on

SLATTER I got work to do. Come on, honey, let's crack along.' (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,199)

crack hardy/crack hearty¶

phr. (informal) to put on a tough or bold front (in the face of difficulties, pain); to endure patiently.

FULLARTON Hark at the four-figure man cracking hardy. (1944,Troop Target,67)

SARGESON Daley's got a big family to keep. ... So he cracks hearty. (1949,I Saw in My Dream,177)

DAVIES You were always a battler, Dad ... But don't crack too hardy. (1975,Outback,104)

MANTELL Gave me the willies just looking at it. So I thought maybe Angela was cracking hardy - y'know. (1980,Murder or Three, A,34)

crack hardy or hearty NZ & Austral. colloq. accept difficulty etc. cheerfully. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,172) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 259; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 111]]

MIchael King What followed was pure farce. Ward cracked hearty and optimistic as of old, but very little of the aGBP70 million was, or could be, borrowed. (2003,Penguin History of New Zealand,280) [NOTES: cited from BASSETT Sir Joseph Ward (1993)]

PARK What a lot we were, down at heel, shabby, perished with cold most of the time, and yet ostentatiously cheerful. This was called cracking hardy. (1992,Fence Around the Cuckoo,118)

crack it¶

v. of a woman, to have, offer, or provide sexual intercourse (?usu. for money).

Wilson, when asked how he got money ..., said: `You know Shirley's been cracking it.' Wilson alleged to have told police a deposit of $300 ... was the proceeds of prostitution. (Jul 25, 1972,NZ Truth,7/3) [NOTES: -->1972 July 25 Truth 7/3 []

[Supreme Court report of proceedings] He further said: You know Shirley's been cracking it.' ...I understand `cracking it' means a person selling their body for money.' (Oct 17, 1972,NZ Truth,26/3)

Two of my shippie mates who were both butch actually `cracked it' ... (Sep 19, 1973,Salient,10)

`I've been on the game 11 years and first cracked it for a chemist in return for dope.' (Apr 1984,Metro,42)

We were encouraged to seek other forms of remuneration, cracking it, as it was known then, or prostitution, to earn the extra money to survive. (Nov 9, 2000,Dominion,1)

v. to bring something off, to make it

NEWBOLD And your always got the feeling ... that by not smiling and waving, and by not cracking it for a chat with the screws ... you were blowing your chances of work-release or parole. (1982,Big Huey, The,120)

BEATON KATE: ... Ginny might pull one. SANDY: No way, she's fucken in for it, boy ... Ginny's cracked it before now. iBID. 109 Crack it - to succeed in an enterprise; bring something off. (1984,Outside In,20)

crack of the whip¶

phr. a drink to cure or ease a hangover, the `hair of the dog'.

CRUMPTON He awoke about midday and called loudly for a crack o' the whip, but when told he had made short work of it the night before, demanded a quart of black billy tea, ... (1979,Spencer: the Gold Seeker,43)

crack one's whip¶

phr. to shout or stand drinks.

TURNER I have heard Can he crack his whip?' used ... to meanDoes he join us for a drink in the pub?' or `Is he a good drinking man?' (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,148)

SUTHERLAND That being so we'll have one [sc. bottle of beer],' I told him.You've carried it all the way up here and now you can crack your whip. ... (1953,Golden Bush, The,166,1963 ed.)

NEWTON ... and when one did get a win he had to crack the whip. Ibid. 168 (Glossary) Crack your whip: To shout or stand drinks. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,85)

NEWTON Glossary: Crack your whip: To shout or stand drinks. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,168)

2 phr. (of a male) to urinate

GOLDIE BROWN crack one's whip to go for a pee (1980,Letter)

(1989,Heinemann NZ Dictionary)

crack whip¶

n. occas. early var. of stockwhip

HODDER ... the tchluck of the crack whip. (1862,Memories of NZ Life,44)

cracker¶

n. (See karaka)

n. a short piece of twisted flax etc at end of stockwhip to make it sting and crack (=? US popper) (See stockwhip)

HENDERSON The boss had cut a blade of flax, and, having stripped it into whiitau, was making a cracker for his stockwhip. (1974,Open Country Muster,178)

W.H.S. ROBERTS The [bullock] whip was rawhide plaited sinnet, about six feet long, thick at the upper end, where it was fastened to a handle as long as itself, but tapering nearly to a point, to which was attached a narrow strip of rawhide, called the fall,' finishing off with a twistedcracker' made of weetau' or dressed flax in [43] place of whipcord, and was a powerful flagellator in the hands of an experiencedbullock puncher.' (Sep 19, 1856,Diary) [NOTES: 1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42-43]

Did a little to a great many things. One was to milk some cows, make some crackers, cross-cut and chop some fire-wood, etc. (Dec 9, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,69,1950 ed.)

KOEBEL Fresh and efficient crackers swing continually at the ends of the stockwhips. (1907,Return of Joe,164)

BATHGATE Flax proved useful ... providing a temporary boot lace or a cracker for a whip. (1925,Random Recollections,24)

Cracker: Short piece of twisted flax (or silk) at the end of a stock or bullock whip. To make it sting more, some bullockies used to twist in a piece of very fine wire. (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

BEATTIE The [bullock-driver's] whip was rawhide plaited sinnet, about six feet long, thick at the upper end ... but tapering nearly to a point, to which was attached a narrow strip of rawhide, called the fall', finishing off with a twistedcracker' made of `weetan' or dressed flax in place of whipcord ... . (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,42) [NOTES: 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42 [? quoting W.H.S. Roberts Diary 1856]]

HARPER The older children made her ask the musterers for flax `crackers' for the stockwhips. (1975,Eight Daughters,108)

cracker ... NZ & Austral. attachment to whip to make it crack. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,172) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

Lucy became noted for the manufacture of whip lashes or crackers. These were skilfully plaited from dressed flax and sold in bundles of 50, for one shilling (10 cents) to teamsters and drovers for fitting to the ends of their whips. (Dec 2003,NZ Memories,No. 45/25)

n. a cartridge

PARTRIDGE Cracker. 10. (Gen. pl.) A cartridge: New Zealanders': from ca. 1910. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,188)

[Slang of the NZEF] ... a `cracker' was a cartridge, ... (Apr 4, 1938,Press, The) [NOTES: McNABB NZ Slang]

BAKER Probably ... originally from the country are ...crackers, cartridges. (1941,NZ Slang,55)

McGILL cracker cartridge; c.1900. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

exclam. [1985 Jane Godfrey p.c. remarks: Popular in schools as `Cracker, my son.' which I think is from Fred Dagg of the early 1970s]

cracker: an expletive of something very pleasing (1981,NZ Police National Headquarters) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

advert for Cheese with Bruce Forsythe. Rugby player, presented with thick cheese sandwich, says: `Cracker, Bruce.' (1981,TV1)

n. firework

B. Sutton-Smith At the time of year they would spend their Friday nights running past shop doors and throwing in lighted crackers, then going for their lives. (1950,Our Street,p73)

n. the smallest amount; in negative constructions, esp. not to have a cracker, to have no money, not to have a cent.

HILLIARD I'm just worried whether my girl's getting a decent bargain. I've got nothing, Harry: not a cracker. (1960,Maori Girl,240)

CRUMP Ten o'clock at night, and we never had a cracker. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,18)

OWEN & PERKINS ... months of bushwork, with hardly a cracker coming from it, made me carry a swag. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,76) [NOTES: (Bob Edwards, bushman)]

HENDERSON Yes. Buckshee. No Payment. Not a cracker. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,144)

n. apparatus used in illicit drug-making

The gas is generally dispensed through a "cracker", a brass-coloured tool resembling a tap fixture, into a balloon. (Feb 1, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

adj. very good; excellent or admirable of its kind

HARVEY The huge Maori put the Yank down ... By Kori,' he said with a kind smile.That was a cracker yarn, mate. Why not tell that beauty about yer girl-friend in New York again?' (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,41)

BALLANTYNE On a cracker day like this?' she asked.I'm hot enough as it is.' (1978,Talkback Man,112)

(Advt) Keep up with ... CRICKET. Cracker Day at the Cricket. Will New Zealand sink at the Basin? Full coverage of the ... One Day Cricket Series. ... (Feb 20, 1982,Dominion,9)

HOLDEN `They're cracker tusks all right, too,' Stan said. (1982,Wild Pig,45)

[cartoon: after-match function] No doubt about it - she's a cracker game, Bruce - you've got to be a man to really appreciate it, eh ... (Sep 27, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

McGILL cracker excellent, highly approved (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

...when you get a cracker day with a very light southerly the west coast off Wellington, from south of Makara up to Kapiti is a great playground for fishos and boaties. (Apr 19, 2005,Independent (Auckland),17)

cradle¶

n. a box on rockers used for washing sand or gravel to remove any gold

The gold is in dust and nuggets. ... The implement most effectual in economising labour is the `Long Tom', or trough strainer, cradles are but of little comparative service. (Dec 10, 1852,NZ Government Gazette,V/30/183) [NOTES: (Heaphy's Report)]

HODKINSON men ... had with two toms and a cradle, got ... 9lbs of gold. (1858,Description of Canterbury,218) [NOTES: 1857 May 9 in 1858 Hodgkinson Description Canterbury 218]

... an errant cradle' or a disabledlong tom' or two has been no uncommon sight in the swollen river course of the Aorere, far from the claims of their disconsolate owners. (Aug 5, 1857,Lyttelton Times,5)

The other party consisted of two men, who wrought with a `cradle'. (Jun 29, 1861,Otago Witness,5)

HODDER We worked a `cradle' ... a machine into which the earth is thrown and rocked about until merely a small residue remains under a sheet of perforated iron amongst which the gold is found. (1862,Memories of NZ Life,74)

The gullies ... require [?requiring] only the cradle for washing operations. (1862,Otago: Its Goldfields and Resources,19)

J.G. WALKER On Thursday we came upon what we believe to be payable gold, but as we have no cradle we are not certain, we borrowed one for a little time yesterday and washed out ten buckets, I think we have got about 2 or 3 dwt. (Jan 4, 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker)) [NOTES: (Central Otago)]

HEINZ Went out to Dome Gully and had only washed three pans of dirt ... Tried to borrow a cradle. (1974,Bright Fine Gold,95) [NOTES: 1863 May 22 Diary of an Unsuccessful Digger in 1931 Aug 27 Star (Christchurch) in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 95]

(1863,Otago: Its Goldfields and Resources,19) [NOTES: [sic]]

Their plant consists of long-handled shovels, tubs of water, a cradle for washing gold. (Oct 1866,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,100,1940 ed.)

SMALL Bustle here, bustle there,/Cradles rocking, strangers flocking:/ (1866,NZ & Australian Songster,13,1970 ed.)

EVANS ... during the winter or when the harvesting is over, the means employed to wash the gold by the miners are cradles. (1962,Waikaka Saga,19)

MONEY Our cradle was set, ... and we began to take up the ground in the bed of the creek to get down to the bottom, where the heaviest gold always lies in `pockets' or rock holes, and crevices. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,16)

PYKE He was what is termed in mining phraseology, a hatter', - meaning one who works by himself. ... Alone and unaided he scooped the wash-dirt into his cradle, which he vigorously rocked with his left hand, whilst with the right he ladled water from the river into thehopper' or seive [sic]. ... He cast aside the `dipper', and hastened towards the eddy. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,3/vii/95,(1889,1974) ed.)

BULLER All along the coast, ... diggers were washing gold, from the sand, in their `cradles'. (1878,Forty Years in NZ,120)

cradle n. a trough on rockers by means of which gold can be separated from the powdered rock. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3)

LOVELL-SMITH ... they despatched the late Mr. William Crawley ... with a load of timber prepared for miners' cradles for gold-washing. (1931,Old Coaching Days,30)

The first miners used only the pick, the shove, the dish, and the cradle. But the wash that would yield a profit with these was soon exhausted. (1931,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,12/159)

BLYTH Cradle: The apparatus, made of wood used for washing gold-bearing wash or dirt. (1935,Gold Mining Year Book,11)

AYSON He made a cradle and `long tom' from a pattern given him by an old digger from Australia. (1937,Thomas,23)

HYDE It's all bare, you know. Why don't you go up with the combers, young fellow? ...' `Me with one fin in plaster. I'd look nice, sitting over a mountain stream rocking a cradle.' (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,56)

The original prospectors washed the gold-bearing soil in cradles' andgold-pans'... (1940,Tales of Pioneer Women,291,1988 ed.)

MILLER Like a child's cradle, [a miner's cradle] had two rockers fastened to its base, and it was rocked rather more violently. But internally the resemblance ended. It was, broadly speaking, an open box with the sides sloping inwards towards the base, and the bottom board extended about a foot beyond the end; while the end board, which formed one of the sides, did not reach to the bottom, but left an aperture. The box was fitted on top with an iron hopper punched full of quarter-inch holes and with sides about three inches high. It was into this hopper that the gold-bearing gravel was thrown, a shovelful at a time. (1946,There Was Gold,41)

MILLER It took two men to work the cradle satisfactorily - one to shovel and one to rock it violently by means of a handle that was fastened up the back end of the contraption, and at the same time to dash water on to it by means of a dipper fastened to a stick. The cradle was always placed, of course, at the water's edge, and the stones that did not fall through the hopper were tipped out the front end, which was left without any retaining side. The material which was washed through the holes, and which contained the gold, fell straight down on to a sloping wooden table covered with a coarse piece of matting on which the gold was saved. The table was fitted firmly against the back and sides of the box, but stopped short about an inch from the front end to allow the tailings and what gold was not saved to fall on to another table - this one fitting firmly to the front end and the sides, and sloping dowm towards the back end. From there the tailings fell on to the back end of the bottom board, which was generally covered with coconut matting to catch any gold that might have gone all the distance, and followed along the bottom and out over the lip. By this means the wash had to travel a surprisingly long distance, and was also shaken from side to side of the cradle, so that there little chance if it was worked properly of losing any gold. (1946,There Was Gold,41 (cont.))

EVANS If a claim was very rich and localised the cradle could be used, but where large amounts of shingle had to be shifted the sluice box was ... the best method to recover the gold. (1962,Waikaka Saga,11)

MAY Collet's quicksilver plates rapidly became common on the beach-claims although they did not completely supplant the simpler cradle and sluice-box. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,170,1962 ed.)

cradle n. box on rockers with sloping shelves used by alluvial miners in final gold wash. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

WOOD In the cradle the gravel was separated from the sand and gold through a perforated metal hopper and the gold remained in the short segments of riffle box and matting below. (1970,Gold Trails of Otago,7)

McARA Cradle: The mounting of a drifter-drill equipped with manual screw-feed. In setting up the machine the cradle was usually placed on an arm attached to a vertical column wedged between the roof and the floor of the working. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),317) [NOTES: (Glossary of Waihi Mining Terms)]

We found, about thirty men engaged in the digging and washing operations, the latter being carried on by means of a small stream of water, carried by means of leads or small channels into the "claim" of each party, and carried by each through their "long tom," or into tubs or buckets for use in the cradle. (Feb 28, 1855,Nelson Examiner,2)

DAVIES We waited the subsiding of the waters;amusing ourselves with a self-actingcradle, washing the surface at our door. (1884,Poems & Other Literary Remains,266)

Mr. Hardy calls for the owner of the cradle; no answer; the cradle contains a load, which Mr. H. proceeds very diligently to wash, and, with his trooper, he manages to get enough gold to pay three or four licenses. (Jan 2, 1852,Daily Southern Cross,3)

n.

HISLOP So there [in a grave] the good old chap lies bedsides the remains of his unknown miner of the 1865 tin dish and cradle days. (1943,Pure Gold,115)

n. sc. of a scythe

LYON If oats or other grain was to be mown, the grass nail was removed and a strong flexible withe of wood was substituted. This was called a cradle and had the effect of leaving behind a skilled mower small sheaves which reduced the gathering and binding of the crop, though this latter job was usually performed by the men. (1952,Faring South,122) [NOTES: [Wellington c1880s]]

v. to wash (goldbearing washdirt) in a cradle

MONEY I started them [the diggers] to cradle some headings', or dirt thrown out of deserted holes, which had not been considered worth washing by the lucky boys who had originally sunk them and made their littlepiles'. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,18)

PFAFF We passed some men cradling on the river bank near Kanieri. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,42)

MILLER When we were not cradling for gold we made furniture for our camp. (1946,There Was Gold,31)

n. (Rural) [slaughtering] the bed on which cattle are skinned.

LOUGHNAN cradle: i. a cradle-shaped frame which guides the carcasses on a mutton chain under an automatic washing spray. ii. the bed on which cattle are skinned is sometimes called a cradle. iii. Four sturdy spokes all set on right angles which will revolve over a base, around an axis pin (usually a crowbar or dibbler driven into the ground) and used to unwind a coil of fencing wire. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,22)

n. (Rural) [fencing] the revolving mount from which wire is fed.

LOUGHNAN cradle: i. a cradle-shaped frame which guides the carcasses on a mutton chain under an automatic washing spray. ii. the bed on which cattle are skinned is sometimes called a cradle. iii. Four sturdy spokes all set on right angles which will revolve over a base, around an axis pin (usually a crowbar or dibbler driven into the ground) and used to unwind a coil of fencing wire. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,22)

n. (Rural) [castration or docking operations of lambs or marking of calves, a bed in which the animal reclines.

We were dosing them as we were putting them through the cradle. (Jun 15, 1994,NZ Farmer,21)

n. (Rural) The form taken when cocksfoot seedheads are bent over to enhance drying.

COULSON The stubble was bent over to form a 'cradle' ensuring that the heads were higher than the butts of the sheaves and allowing any rain to drain off the heads. (1979,Golden Harvest,39)

1 n. (Rural) [slaughtering] a frame that guides carcasses on a mutton chain under an automatic washing spray.

LOUGHNAN cradle: i. a cradle-shaped frame which guides the carcasses on a mutton chain under an automatic washing spray. ii. the bed on which cattle are skinned is sometimes called a cradle. iii. Four sturdy spokes all set on right angles which will revolve over a base, around an axis pin (usually a crowbar or dibbler driven into the ground) and used to unwind a coil of fencing wire. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,22)

cradle saddle¶

n.

Cradle saddle: A pack saddle made with an iron frame outside convenient for packing solid stuff that would not strap easily. Such saddles were used at Orari Gorge and elsewhere but were far too heavy and have gone out of use now, I think. (C.) (Oct 17, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

cradle-trailer¶

n.

NEWBOLD Every few days we'd drive around in the tractor, load the logs on to a cradle-trailer, and haul them out to the skid. (1982,Big Huey, The,209)

cradler¶

n.

MURRAY Cradles were not the only things that were swept away. Many of the cradlers found it expedient to live close to their claims ... (1977,Costly Gold,21)

cradling¶

n. working a miner's cradle; washing paydirt in a miner's cradle.

HODGKINSON ... a claim for the purposes of sinking, surface digging, tomming or cradling ...' (1858,Description of Canterbury,19)

The men are satisfied with the amount of gold found [in Otago] though it is not of a very good [40] quality, too fine, not nuggety enough to use a sluice well so they adopt the slower and surer way of cradling. (May 23, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,39)

Miners engaged in cradling ... (1863,AJHR,D-6-19) [NOTES: (Pyke Goldfields Reports)]

PYKE The miners, knowing the importance of making hay while the sun shines['], strained every effort to obtain the auriferousdirt,' and stacking it on their claims, leaving the washing up and `cradling' to be done when the getting more dirt was impossible. (1887,History of the Early Gold Discoveries in Otago,79,1962 ed.)

MIILLER I decided, as long as I had the water for cradling to work the gold in this way ... (1946,There Was Gold,69)

EVANS In order to have a daily supply of water for cradling and panning many miners combined to build this dam. (1962,Waikaka Saga,228)

cradling fern¶

n. Asplenium bulbiferum =mauku. [check we have this prob omit]

ANDERSON Mauku is also the name of the cradling fern (Asplenium bulbiferum). There are other forms of the name - mouku and mouki; and as this well-developed fern is one of the common ferns of the bush, and being large-fronded and graceful is well-known, it would be useful as well to use one of the variant names, say mouki, to save confusion with mauku (a species of ti). (1942,Maori Place Names,283)

crag hole¶

1 n. (Rural) a ground hole or pot hole in pasture.

SINCLAIR & TROTTER It was fairly flat country out on the Garvie range but it was full of crag holes, sour kind of country with not much feed there. (1994,From Caithness to Southland,24)

CRAIG¶

1 abbr. (Rural) Classer Registration Advisory Industry Group, a wool quality assessment organisation.

CRAIG includes representatives from WoolPro, Merino New Zealand, the shearing contractors association, wool brokers, exporters and merchants. CRAIG registrar, Struan Hulme, said the group was concerned about some lots that had been classed into categories as narrow as 0.1 microns, with little regard for other factors. CRAIG said with some bales weighing just 100 kg greasy (70 kg clean) or less, exporters find them difficult to sell. (Jul 8, 2001,Fencepost.com,Newspage)

Crammer, the¶

n. the Crammer, a former nickname for the Nelson Examiner newspaper

BURNS `I see, my son, when I look through/ The pages of the Crammer,/ [fn] Crammer, a by-name for the Nelson Examiner newspaper. (1869,Scottish Echoes,94,1883 ed.)

crammy¶

adj. with a maimed hand (cf. gammy, having a maimed leg)

BEATTIE His widow married John Washburn Hunter, better known to the old hands' asCrammy Hunter' because he had a maimed hand. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,6)

cramp¶

v.

NEWTON CRAMPED: When shearing the last side of the sheep, the animal is held in a sitting position. To `cramp' the sheep, it is squeezed downwards - like closing a concertina - there is consequently a smaller area to be covered with the blades. Some shearers are experts at this. (1949,High Country Days,194,1950 ed.)

crampfish¶

n. the blind torpedo ray or numbfish Typhlonarke aysoni(Hamilton)

GRAHAM BLIND TORPEDO RAY OR NUMBFISH Typhlonarke aysoni (Hamilton) [ibid]. 92]. This uncommon fish has several names, all of which relate to its manner of producing electric shocks, some of which are Numb-fish, Crampfish and Electric Skate. These vernacular names are given by fishermen on account of the fish benumbing or paralysing the person who unwittingly grasps one with his hands. The last name is from the somewhat similar shape to that of a skate or ray, ray being another common term for skates and also the scientific family name. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,90)

NATUSCH [The ray] T[orpedo] aysoni, the numbfish or cramp fish, is round, with short tail and pelvic fins, and grows up to 3 ft. [sic] (1967,Animals of NZ, The,202)

WILSON CRAMPFISH: see Blind Torpedo Ray Ibid. 198 BLIND TORPEDO RAY A rare ray, Typhlonarke aysoni, as he is called in Latin, has the ability to emit sparks and make a needle magnetic - yet not to see. Variously named Numbfish, Crampfish and Electric Skate. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,43)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] crampfish 325 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

Cran's bully¶

n.

Among these were Cran's bullies, freshwater mussels, crabs and crayfish (koura) and an eel which had taken up residence in a bottle. (Nov 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 60/52)

Koru Aquaculture went to the High Court at Auckland last week seeking an injunction to stop the drainage, on the grounds that it was also killing a native fish, the Cran's bully. (Jan 20, 1993,Evening Post,22)
