When KAL drains the first pond, alongwith "many thousands" of the somewhatrare native freshwater fish "Cran'sBully", a number of good-sized nativekoura will also be destroyed. (May 1992,North & South,71)

crane¶

n. white heron, kotuku (See white crane)

HAY The Kotuku, or crane (Ardea syrmatophora), must just be mentioned, though none of us ever saw one. But the Maori have a proverb - `as rare as the kotuku.' (1882,Brighter Britain,2/225)

cranefly¶

n.

FORSTER ... a sort of little crane-flies (tipula alis incumbentibus), which had plagued us ever since our entrance into Dusky Bay, became remarkably troublesome during the bad weather. They were numerous in the [136] skirts of the woods, not half so large as gnats or musketoes, and our sailors called them sand-flies. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/135)

n.

McLINTOCK Crane fly - matua waeroa, Macromastix (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

2 n. Macromastix viridis

The green cranefly, Macromastix viridis.., is one of at least 500 species of daddy-longlegs" known from New Zealand, and they are probably our largest family of flies. (Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/62)

cranery¶

n. a "rookery" for cranes

HON. W .FOX Do you know of the existence of a Cranery' of the White Crane at Okarita, on the West Coast? ... The OkaritaCranery' is, I suspect, nearly the last ... (Apr 17, 1872,Letter) [NOTES: 1872 Apr 17 Hon. W. Fox in 1873 Buller Birds of NZ 227]

cranesbill¶

n. [also crane's bill] (See dove's foot)

(Queen Charlotte Sound) Amongst the known kinds of plants are common and rough Bindweed, Nightshade and Nettles, ... and Cranes bill: [fnc Geranium. [ed. [Probably Geranium sessiflorum.]]] also Cudweed, [ed. fn 3 Possibly Gnaphalium sp. or Helichrysum sp.], rushes, ... (Feb 1777,Cook's Journals,3/804) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/804-805]

POLACK Speedwell, sow, and melon thistles (coetus), virgin's bower, vanilloe, or willow, euphorbia, cudweed, crane's-bill, junchous rushes in all the swamps ... (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/295)

(And) Geranium Crane's-bill Geranium cranesbill (Jan 1856,Edinburgh New Philosophical Journal) [NOTES: 1856 Jan Tancred Notes on Natural History Canterbury in Edinburgh New Philos. Journ.(NS)]

HOOKER Cranesbill. Geranium. Geranium crane's bill (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),764)

FEATON (1889,Art Album NZ Flora)

cranesbill, small-flowered [=] small-flowered geranium [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,17)

2 n.

COCKAYNE ... the Chatham Island cranesbill (Geranium Traversii), of which there are white and pink varieties; ... (1910,NZ Plants,124)

Geranium Traversii Chatham cranesbill (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

2 n.

HILGENDORF CUT-LEAVED GERANIUM (Geranium dissectum) is also called cut leaved cranes bill, jagged-leaved-cranes bill and wild geranium. It is found in waste places from Auckland to the Bluff, but is commonest in the north. It is a perennial, [A hairy annual] with branching, trailing, or semi-erect stems 1 to 2 ft. long. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,113,1967, p. 113 ed.)

2 n. jagged-leaved-cranes bill

HILGENDORF CUT-LEAVED GERANIUM (Geranium dissectum) is also called cut leaved cranes bill, jagged-leaved-cranes bill and wild geranium. It is found in waste places from Auckland to the Bluff, but is commonest in the north. It is a perennial, [A hairy annual] with branching, trailing, or semi-erect stems 1 to 2 ft. long. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,113)

2 n.

[On Molesworth there are] the small rosettes of mountain cranesbill dotted here and there, a remnant of the primitive plant-covering not eaten even by rabbits; ... (1919,NZ Journal of Agriculture) [NOTES: c1919 Cockayne Journal of Agriculture in 1969 McCaskill Molesworth 154]

2 n.

COCKAYNE (And) Geranium sessiliflorum var.glabrum short-flowered crane's-bill (1907,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island]

COCKAYNE (And) Geranium sessiliflorum var.glabrum short-flowered cranesbill (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island]

COCKAYNE (And) (1911,AJHR,C-13)

COCKAYNE (And) (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

2 n. Geranium microphyllum.

COCKAYNE (And) (1915,AJHR,C-6) [NOTES: Notes on the Plant Covering of Kennedy's Bush ... Canterbury]

2 n.

small-flowered cranesbill [=] small-flowered geranium [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,70)

2 n.

COCKAYNE (And) Geranium microphyllum small-leaved crane's bill Geranium microphyllum (1907,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island]

COCKAYNE (And) Geranium microphyllum small-leaved cranesbill (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island]

TURNER Botanical Examination of the Higher Waimarino District (1909,AJHR,C-11)

COCKAYNE (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

2 n. dovesfoot

HILGENDORF DOVESFOOT (Geranium molle), or soft geranium or wild geranium or soft cranes bill, is common in all soils and situations, and has been considered a native. It is a diffuse much-branched annual or perennial, softly hairy in all it parts. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,113)

crank¶

n.

BATHGATE The rocks ... relieved by the vegetation which filled every crank and cranny (1881,Waitaruna,92)

n. methamphetamine

Methamphetamine is a stimulant that affects the central nervous system. It's known on the street as Speed, Snort and Crank. (Sep 11, 2000,Evening Post,1)

crank handle¶

n. (See cf. starting handle)

L. BAUER He, as Britisher, would use Starting-handle'; his wife usesCrank-handle'; as does HWO : ?NZ (Feb 2, 1987,Personal Communication)

crank up¶

v. to smoke [1984 17 M E107Pakuranga Coll. 33 CRANK UP -->1984 16 F E9 Pakuranga Coll. 34 CRANKING UP -->1984 17 M E112Pakuranga Coll. 33 CRANKING UP (SMOKING)]

cranky¶

n. the man who cranks the engine of an engine-driven plant

BOWEN CRANKY. The man who cranks the engine of an engine-driven plant. (1956,Wool Away!,156)

adj. sickly

... whenever the mobs were mustered for ...shearing (1891,NZ Journal of Science,1/173)

crap-scared¶

adj. very scared, shit-scared

As a 17-year-old, I was crap-scared of the police. (May 5, 2001,Dominion Weekend Magazine,2)

crape fern¶

n. Occas. (esp. by Cockayne) called double or single crape fern. Leptopteris (synonym Todea) superba, [check this: is it so??] =Prince of Wales feathers. [OED2 NZ] [OED2 crape 3 b. a New Zealand fern Leptopteris superba. 1882 Thomson Ferns of NZ 94]

THOMPSON Todea superba, Colenso. (Crape-fern). (1882,Ferns & Fern Allies of NZ,94)

FIELD (And) (1890,Ferns of NZ)

CHEESEMAN T[odea] superba, Col. ... Crape-fern; Prince of Wales's Feather. [1026] Probably the most beautiful fern in New Zealand. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,1025)

COCKAYNE (And) Leptopteris superba crape fern. (1908,AJHR) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Tongariro National Park]

(And) Leptopteris hymenophylloides single crape-fern (1908,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of the Tongariro National Park]

COCKAYNE (And)Leptopteris hymenophylloides single crape-fern (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Waipoua Kauri Forest]

COCKAYNE (And) Leptopteris hymenophylloides single crape-fern (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island]

TURNER Leptopteris hymenophylloides single crape-fern Ibid. (And) Leptopteris superba double crape-fern (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: Botanical Examination of the Higher Waimarino District in AJHR C-11]

In ... dark places Todea superba (double crape-fern), were plentiful. (1910,TrNZI,42/17)

COCKAYNE Such, amongst others, are the filmy ferns ... [and] the beautiful crape-fern Todaea superba. (1910,NZ Plants,37)

COCKAYNE (And) Leptopteris Superba crape-fern (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The)

CROOKES L[eptopteris superba (superb). Heru-heru.' The most beautifuk fern in New Zealand; sometimes calledPrince of Wales Feathers', or `Crape Fern'. (1951,Dobbie's NZ Ferns,20)

Crape fern, a popular name for a beautiful fern which grows only in New Zealand; also called `Prince of Wales's feathers'. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),101,8th ed.)

WILSON Leptopteris hymenophylloides CRAPE FERN ... Heruheru ...(=Todea hymenophylloides ... Leptopteris superba PRINCE OF WALES FEATHERS ... Heruheru ... Double crape fern ... (=Todea superba). (1982,Stewart Island Plants,436)

SANSOM There's no better walk for seeing one of the Wonders of the World, the double crepe ferns or Prince of Wales Feathers, carpeted with umbrella mosses. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,31)

DAWSON The famous crepe fern (L[eptopteris] superba) favours moist, shady, cool situations... Ibid.. 127 Larger ferns on the forest floor include the well-known crepe fern or Prince of Wales Feathers (Leptopteris superba) and Blechnum discolor. (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,104)

By the streams I found some noble specimens of the crape fern, Todea Superba, of most delicate plumes. (Dec 17, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

In shady gullies, where moisture is abundant, the loveliest of all the feathery ferns, the crape fern - or Prince of Wales feather, as it is often called - is found. (Apr 17, 1890,Otago Witness,18)

Crapeau¶

n. mistaken spg of French crapaud `toad' as a derisive name among sailors for a Frenchman.

E.J. WAKEFIELD Captain Lucas, of the Justine, [a French merchantman] is a civil Crapeau. (Apr 23, 1840,Diary) [NOTES: 1840 Apr 23 (1839) E.J. Wakefield's MS Diary]

craptogram¶

n. a (latrine) rumour

X the Unknown to where we're on the way/ A craptogram solves it fresh every day. (1940,HM Transports 23 and 23A,12) [NOTES: 1940-41 HM Transports 23 and 23A 12]

crash¶

n. a game of tackle football, usually played indoors

NEWBOLD The main game of the summer season at Paremoremo is called Crash... Crash is organised along similar lines to touch. There is a referee on each side and a play-back after each tackle. Because the teams are large and there is no limit on subs, each block only fields one team. (1982,Big Huey, The,97)

n.

The symptoms of depression experienced during the "crash" or coming down" phase, post-amphetamine use, are thought to be due to depleted levels of dopamine and noradrenaline. (Apr 6, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

crash hot¶

adj.

McGILL crash hot! excellent. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

crash rugby¶

n. (See crash n)

NEWBOLD Crash rugby is a bit like rugby league except that in Paremoremo the men are still not permitted to go outside on to the grass, so the game is played in the gymnasium, on a wooden floor. (1982,Big Huey, The,97)

crash up¶

v. to inject oneself with drugs

NEWBOLD Crash up (v) inject oneself with drugs. Origin unknown. (1982,Big Huey, The,248)

crashed¶

adj.

crashed: drunk, stoned party crasher (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

crate¶

n. breasts

LELAND Crate: Teenage slang for the most prominent feature(s) of a buxom wench (also: old car, wooden box etc.) [breasts'] (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,29)

n. a beer crate holding two dozen beer (DNZE) (usu. one dozen??) (See cf. swappa crate)

CHARLES And the driver comes in and breasts up to the bar./ He says, Give me a jar and a couple of crates,/ For I am running the cutter tonight for me mates!'/...We are fresh out of beer,/So that's why I'm here,/ Running the cutter tonight./ (1981,Black Billy Tea)

Then he handed her the knife and the stone, and went back inside to finish off the remaining crate. He was a noisy drunk ... (Mar 8, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26) [NOTES: Hulme (The Knife)]

But beneath that there is an entire substratum of what we might call part-time hoons',weekend hoons' or `holiday hoons'. The sons (and daughters) of the middle classes, they are less professional in their hooning. Tell-tale signs: car obviously belonging to mum ..., two in the front (no bench seat), four in the back with crates on their knees, zinc on their noses, ... (Dec 20, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

v. (Rural) to confine stock, especially pigs, in small fenced enclosures.

It's hard to vote with your fork when there is no way of knowing whether or not your Christmas ham was produced by one of the 60-odd percent of farmers who don't crate their pigs. ALSO: .. that's forcing MPs to think about issues such as cow-docking and sow-crating. (Dec 22, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

1 n. (Rural) a hurdled pen in which to transport stock.

Farm clearing sale: chain saws .. transport tray .. ute crate ... (Jun 22, 2002,Hawke's Bay Today,22)

Craterland¶

n.

Up the line he had been with many of usin Craterland. (Jun 7, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/45 : 196)

crawfish¶

v. to withdraw unreservedly from an untenable position

n.

... there are not wanting Several Sorts [of fish] that are well known; such as Mullet, Cavallas, Guard-Fish, Horse-Mackeral. Amongst the crustaceous Tribes we found Craw-fish, Muscles. [sic] Cockles, Scollops, Whelks, Periwinkles, ... (1773,Cook's Journals,2/787,1961 ed.) [NOTES: 1773 Wales Journal in Cook Journal (1961) 2/787]

Amongst the crustaceous Tribes we found Craw-fish, Muscles, [sic] Cockles, Scollops, Whelks, Periwinkles, ... (1773,Cook's Journals,2/787) [NOTES: 1773 Wales Journal in Cook Journal (1961) 2/787]

(Queen Charlotte Sound) The indians [sic] likewise sometimes brought us Craw fish equal to our largest lobsters [ed. fn Jasus lalandii.] ...and cuttle fish which they eat themselves. [ed. fn Notodarus sloanei.] (Feb 1777,Cook's Journals,3/808,1967 ed.) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/808]

FORSTER Here [at Anchor Island] they sat down by the side of a pleasant brook, and made a slight repast on some boiled craw-fish ... (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/150)

McNABB Q. What sort of fish did you obtain at New Zealand? A.A great variety ... There is likewise abundance of lobsters, or a fish between a lobster and a craw-fish. (1908,Historical Records,1/550) [NOTES: 1821 May Ensign McCrae's Evidence before Commissioner Bigge in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/550]

We staid 24 days on the island, amusing ourselves by catching crawfish from off the cliffs, .... (1826,Boultbee Journal) [NOTES: 1826 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 152]

McDONNELL The rivers are well stocked with fine fish ... - the very creeks swarm with them. There are abundance of lobsters, crawfish, oysters, prawns, and shrimps; besides clams, peppies, muscles, limpets, and cockles. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,15,1979 ed.)

We had ... a quantity of cakes baked in the pan, a keg of sugar, and some boiled crawfish. (1835,Boultbee Journal,48,1986 ed.)

We are extremely well off for provisions, and fish in abundance, among which are crawfish, oysters and freshwater eels. (Aug 1840,NZ Journal,1(16) : 205)

POLACK [The cavern] is mostly in request by parties fishing for the kohuda, (craw fish), and other fish, (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/136)

DIEFFENBACH Kai Koura `a feast of crawfish'. (1839,New Zealand (various authors/titles))

BIDWILL I have often seen the natives eat raw potatoes, and once living craw-fish; two things I never was so hard-pushed as to try. (1841,Rambles in NZ,34,1952 ed.)

COLENSO ... crawfish ... (1841,Journal,1/57)

DIEFFENBACH ... I often had occasion to admire ... the women in diving for crawfish in the surf near the Sugarloaf Islands. (1843,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/163)

WAKEFIELD A large Craw-fish, obtained by diving among the rocks, supplies the place of the lobster. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,161)

27th Dec. - Visitors went down to Taieri; came back with pig, ducks and crawfish. (Dec 27, 1858,Puketoi Station Diary) [NOTES: 1858 Dec 27 Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 76]

n.

We were 6 in party, ourselves, young Stark & 3 Maoris with `pikau' burdens. ... After tiring of [singing] they set off with burning brand & tomahawk [check spg ?tomehawk] to catch crawfish & tuna, the eels of the country, in a little brook near our encampment. (Mar 25, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/79) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond)]

crawing¶

n.

REED Special care had to be taken should a leaning tree be required to fall to one side or the other. Additional wedging had to be done on the lower side - known as `crawing'. (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,157)

crawker¶

v. to catch crawlers, freshwater crayfish [[Is this an error for crawlering.]]

ELLIOTT & ADSHEAD I spent my time [as a schoolboy in Fielding in the 1920s] birdnesting and mushrooming as well as eeling and crawkering (catching freshwater crayfish a few inches long) in the Makino Stream. [18] While crawkering I also learnt to swim in the Makino Stream ... (1967,Cowshed to Dog Collar,17)

crawl¶

v. to crawl (under a house) to inspect (it). [ca1940 State Advances Corporation field-workers: p.c. H.S. Gajadhar. 1951 State Advances Corporation, Valuer's Report I could not `crawl' the house as the piles were too low.]

crawler¶

n. a sycophant; a toady (esp. of a workman to the boss).

Although he could not be called a "crawler".. he knew that orders were orders. (Dec 21, 1942,NZEF Times,II/78 : 20)

LANCASTER You crawler! Can`t you stand up to me like a man. (1904,Sons o' Men,122)

BOOTH A rough lot of characters were ... seen there ... the wretched debauched crawler, the villainous-looking `lag'. (1912,Five Years in NZ,39)

Mac is a crawler. (Sep 25, 1913,Hutt Valley Independent,2)

Who is dinkum, who's a crawler? (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,82)

Crawler.-Man subservient to the boss. (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Gloss]

ACLAND Crawler: man subservient to the boss. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,363)

crawler, crawlie n. man subservient to his employer; freshwater lobster [Corr. of Maori koura]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

LETHBRIDGE His pet aversion were `crawlers' - people who tried to appear good in the eyes of the Boss ... (1971,Sunrise on the Hills,58)

HILLIARD .. Oh yes, it had all been reported back to him [the boss] by the crawlers who wanted to ingratiate themselves ... (1974,Maori Woman,10) [NOTES: [workmen's] .]

DEVANNY [The manager's wife] ... was condescendingly nice to what the miners termed the crawler' section, but never recognised thered' element. (1928,Dawn Beloved,175)

n. a freshwater crayfish, koura (although this is mainly a children's word, it is the main popular name for these crayfish).

GIBBONS In the creek were freshwater crayfish... Willie Hanna went off to catch the crawlers as we called them. (1989,Recollections (various authors/titles),40)

We caught crawlers and roasted them, and boiled watercress. (1976,Moments of Life,6)

BAUME (1933,Half Caste,221) [NOTES: [see biddy-burs]]

FINLAYSON `They was only crawlers, mighty small fry,' he says cheerlessly. (1948,Tidal Creek,40)

SARGESON And in the creek they saw the crayfish and Mr Jones said he called them crawlers, but the Maoris called them koura. [ital sic] Ibid. 102 And there are little crayfish in the creek. Koura? Crawlers? - you wouldn't get very fat on them, Dave said. (1949,I Saw in My Dream,82,1974 ed.)

MIDDLETON Geoff ... showed me how to catch crawlers and inanga. (1959,Stone, The,32) [NOTES: (The Stone)]

SLATTER Hunka Harris who went in the creek after crawlers in his bare feet. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,10)

crawler, crawlie n. man subservient to his employer; freshwater lobster [Corr. of Maori koura]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

crawler ... NZ & Austral.shwater crayfish, koura. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,173) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

n. a slow-moving sheep

In connection with stock the following terms were used: - Let the sheep draw down to the Taieri';stags,' crawlers,'stragglers,' a horse with couples in his mouth,'the bull baked on the road,' cut and tailed,'lagoon washing,' spaying cattle,'killed a pleuro,' herding lambs,'buisting weaners,' `a camp for the cattle,' ... (1858,Puketoi Station Diary) [NOTES: [1858-1869] Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 85]

CRAWFORD In the springtime of 1869 there were held on these paddocks 1,000 sheep which were described as `crawlers', a term used to describe sheep that were too weak or lame to keep up with the mob. (1981,Station Years,33) [NOTES: [1869] 1981 Crawford Station Years 33]

CRAWFORD His sheep are crawlers [a term used to describe weak sheep, unable to follow a mob] of merinos which have shorn only 4lb of greasy wool ... (1981,Station Years,113 ed.) [NOTES: 1877 March Ritchie in 1981 Crawford Station Years 113]

WILLIAMS & REEVES Be they freezers or crawlers or wethers or ewes. (1889,Colonial Couplets,21)

Had splendid muster. Sheep very large and fat with heavy fleeces. No crawlers. (Nov 24, 1891,Chudleigh Diary,378,1950 ed.)

He pretended to give me every opportunity of `mothering' (as it is called) my missing lambs, but for fifteen ewes I could find but four. Again, next year, he played me a similar trick, and ... curtly told me to keep my crawlers on my own grass ... (1889,Zealandia,1/30) [NOTES: Reeves]

1 n. (Rural) 1. a slow sheep that has missed a first muster 2. an aged ewe or wether with footrot. (See straggler)

BALFOUR And the sheep. The less said about them, the better, for I never did see such a lot of crawlers. (Dec 1872,Balfour Diaries,31)

WILLIAMS Be they freezers or crawlers or wethers or ewes. (1889,Colonial Couplets,21)

MURISON Count of Lauchlan's flock 1272 - four or five crawlers not in. Dec 16 Shearing crawlers. (May 1861,Puketoi Station Diary,8)

[they must] decide if they would be likely to go to that expense to get in a few hundreds of straggling sheep to dip, notwithstanding that they would probably be the crawlers of the mob and the very ones most likely to want dipping. 2. (Jun 1898,NZ Farmer,201)

HUTCHINSON Jack, Brown and I killing crawlers. May 21. Finished killing crawlers. Total 167. (May 20, 1886,Diary,125) [NOTES: in Hutchinson (1982) Hutchinsons of NZ]

CRAWFORD In the springtime of 1969 there were held on these paddocks 1,000 sheep which were described as 'crawlers', a term used to describe sheep that were too weak or lame to keep up with the mob. (1981,Station Years,33)

4 n. a ladder with a hook end to fasten on the ridge of a roof; a roof-ladder.

CHECK your other needs carefully - ladder, crawler, rope, brushes (cleaning and applying), scrapper (crawler - a kind of ladder with a hook end to catch on the ridge of a steep roof. You can make one easily enough out of light material). (Jan 8, 1967,Sunday Times (NZ),31)

crawlie/crawley/crawly¶

n. crawler, freshwater crayfish [-] (See crawler)

IHIMAERA & LONG We'd go for walks. Watch crawlies in the stream behind the cow bail. (1982,Into the World of Light,155)

McGILL We caught crawlies by putting a branch of manuka in the creek and hauling it out next day. (1989,Kiwi Baby Boomers,64)

Everyone enjoyed it except the crawlies. (Mar 16, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),75)

R J SEDDON Dear old Stuart. That crawly catching should be stopped. (Feb 3, 1893,Letter) [NOTES: 1893 Feb 3 R.J.Seddon letter in Seddon The Seddons (1968) 42]

ANDERSEN A stream with fresh-water crayfish (crawlies) [was] in the vicinity. (1942,Maori Place Names,351)

SUTTON-SMITH Perhaps the most intriguing game of this nature [sc. tormenting insects or animals] is Spang Weazling'. This game was played at Denniston in 1930-35. A crawley was placed on the end of a stick the middle section of which lay balanced over a stone. Before the crawley could crawl off the stick a stone had to be thrown onto the other end of the stick so as to catapult the crawley off the stick and over the cliff. A variation of the same game was being played at Denniston when I visited there in 1949. It was called alternativelyHit the Crawley' or `Strike the Crayfish'. In this version the other end of the stick was hit with a batting stick (as in Tip Cat) and when the crawley was catapultedinto the air it was hit again with the bat. (1953,Unorganized Games,1/406)

WILSON Catching crawlies in the little spring ..., one of the children found a mere (a Maori axe). (1955,Land of My Children,195)

NATUSCH A disturbed crawlie, as the children call [the freshwater crayfish, Paranephrops sp(p)] ... (1967,Animals of NZ, The,109)

SEDDON What would school be like in Wellington? Were there creeks where I could go catching `crawlies?' (1968,Seddons, The,44)

crawler, crawlie n. man subservient to his employer; freshwater lobster [Corr. of Maori koura]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

THOMPSON While other boys pulled freshwater crawlies from the creek above the town with bare hands, holding them amidships so as to avoid their nippers. (1980,All My Lives,31)

WILSON Sometimes on Sunday afternoons, before milking began around half past three, we'd go down to the creek at the back of the farm to catch koura, those small freshwater crayfish we called crawlies. (1984,South Pacific Street,5)

You got quite good at it after a bit, the way you learnt where was the best place for catching eels in the creeks or crawlies in the flooded gravel pits ... round the Mataura. (Aug 1986,Islands,37/45)

RICHARDS They taught me how to catch eels, kupai, and koura (crawlies) out of nearby streams ... Ibid. 27 The creeks [up-country from Raglan c1914-1018] were full of eels, butterfish and crawlies (freshwater crayfish), so we never lacked in a variety of foods. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,22)

He taught me crawly fishing up the hospital hill,..he even taught me to ride a two wheeler. (2001,Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success,199)

In the bush the hollows between roots bogged, furrows were creeks, depressions great pools full of water-newts and crawlies. (Jan 1947,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

cray¶

n. (informal) crayfish (usu. marine) [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

Tens of thousands of dollars worth of crayfish on the deck and a fresh-hauled pot chokka with crays. (Sep 13, 1996,Independent (Auckland),20)

BAYLY There is plenty of Cray & other fish in this Bay and great quantities of herbs for salading, boiling in broth or soups, &c. (Nov 9, 1773,Journal) [NOTES: 1773 Nov 9 Bayly's Journal in 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/212]

POLACK Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, ... besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202fn)

LAWLOR To him a crayfish became a cray only when it poked its nippers through the clumsy parcel under a drunk's arm. (1935,Confessions of a Journalist,216)

HYDE I caught a cray, Mummy. (1937,Wednesday's Children,60)

ANDREWS It hadn't been a fresh cray for ever so long. (1944,Something To Tell,21)

[A crayfisherman] said a ton of fish was refused because the crays were dead when they reached the market. (Mar 4, 1953,NZ Truth,3)

PASCOE Later they used a penguin as bait for fish and cray. (1957,Mr Explorer Douglas,46)

BAXTER `There's twenty good men, Campbell,/ Have sold their crays and terakihi, ...' (1979,Collected Poems,219) [NOTES: (1960) Baxter Collected Poems (1979) 219]

MIDDLETON He said it was ... great money once ... the crays really started coming in. (1964,Walk on the Beach,175) [NOTES: (Not for a Seagull)]

McGILL He lived at Kaikoura and kept a few pots and took the kids out fishing. Not that he ate crays anymore. (1985,G'day Country,120)

cray n. NZ & Austral. crayfish. [abbr.] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,173) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

My light ... dinghy ... was one of the several small boats kept on ... the foreshore ... during the cray season. (Aug 31, 1963,Evening Post,31)

NATUSCH We have no way of telling how fast crayfish grow ... And certain areas are established as `small cray' places. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,109)

This is big cray country; squadrons of jet-boating crayfishers make their way from Kicks Bay to the fast refrigerator trucks which will take the delicacy out of town - probably to Wellington and Auckland restaurant tables. (Aug 16, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),82)

Ihimaera 'Eh? What?' 'His father, Laurence's son-in-law is GAY.' 'He was the one who brought the crays? Oh, well done.' (2007,Ask the Posts,132)

"We want the Cray twins, and we want them... alive!" But it's too late. They've been dropped into a water tank along with other crays. (Feb 1992,Metro,29)

FARRELL A cousin of his had a boat and they wereoff to the Chathams after crays. (1992,Skinny Louie Book,96)

[Caption]Cray diver tells of stingray attack (Sep 29, 2006,Dominion Post,A3)

SUTHERLAND The cray allowed itself to be sniffed [by the dog] all along the back without protest, ... (1953,Golden Bush, The,44,1963 ed.)

A Southern Cross reporter was suspiciousthat some 'crays' in a Wellington fishshop were not up to requirement. (Aug 18, 1949,Southern Cross (Wgton),2)

Only later, over a dinner of crays, bread and beer, did Mitch confess uneasiness. The crays were much smaller these days than when he's started selling them. (May 2007,NZ Geographic,97)

2 n. a hundred-dollar note

McGILL cray 100 dollar bill; from its colour red, same as a crayfish; eg Bold poker player to the table: `His cray and up two.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

cray boat¶

n. (Marine) a fishing boat used specifically for catching crayfish

Country Calendar finishes this year's series with a trip on a cray boat in the treacherous waters just south of Cook Strait. (Aug 22, 2006,Dominion Post TV Week,15)

[caption] Monique Hedges 39, cray boat deckhand, Ngawi. (Aug 17, 2006,Dominion Post,D3)

The final involves a trip on a cray boat on the treacherous waters south of Cook Strait with John Reader, who has been fishing the same patch for 25 years. (Aug 24, 2006,Time Out,34)

be back aboard the cray-boat in a few minutes. (Sep 11, 1987,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 1987 Sep 11 National Radio Rural Programme]

craybird flight¶

n. ??

Fred, who instigated the lucrative 'craybird' flights to Auckland for local fishermen, went to extra lengths to break the islanders' sense of isolation. (Jan 1991,NZ Geographic,118)

crayfish¶

n. a 50-pound note

I plonk 10 rogue and villains on it I suppose, home it rolls and I'm winning a crayfish. crayfish ... $50.00 (May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19)

n. a crawler; one who backs down or away from trouble (? pun on two senses of crawler).

PARTRIDGE He is a crayfish, isn't he, Joe Joe. Now don't say that about my tin plate [mate] or I'll go crook: ... There is nothing lousy about him, and I always believe in giving a man a fair go and that's why I object to the word crayfish and I think you fellows are making it too hot when you say that. (1935,Slang Today,287) [NOTES: 1935 A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287]

PARTRIDGE Crayfish. A `crawler'; a contemptible schemer: New Zealanders': in G.W. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,190)

McGILL crayfish a crawler or contemptible schemer; from army WWI; eg `That ruddy Miller's the crayfish round here. Next time one of us is done, he cops a bunch of fives.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,31)

n. (a transf. use of crayfish for any of various edible aquatic decapod crustaceans) any of several small freshwater varieties or large marine varieties of NZ crustacean. (See cf. (rock) lobster

Grimshaw Miranda broke the leg of her crayfish with a tiny crack and sucked out the flesh. (2007,Opportunity,254)

PARKINSON This bay [?Tolaga] abounds in a variety of fish, particularly shell and cray-fish; (Oct 22, 1769,Journal,99)

FORSTER Since two or three days some crayfish (Cancer Homarus) but better than the Lobster, were caught in great Numbers in the various coves around the Ship. (Apr 10, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/251)

FORSTER A very fine species of crayfish cancer homarus Lin.) longer than the lobster, some shell-fish, and ... a cormorant, duck, pigeon, or parrot gave us an agreeable variety at our table... (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/144)

BELL We never caught any Flat Fish - and the only Shellfish besides small Musells and Limpets were Cray-fish - (Nov 1791,Journal of Voyage in HMS 'Chatham',51)

...he will eat the crayfish green-garnished in its blush of dying, / burned, like love, in and beyond the salt element. (Aug 28, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),40) [NOTES: Eater of Crayfish (Janet Frame)]

SAVAGE the cray fish and crabs are excellent (1807,New Zealand (various authors/titles),11)

J BISCOE At 11 A.M. some New Zealanders came alongside in a Canoe, but had nothing with them except a few Cray Fish ... (Oct 30, 1831,Journal) [NOTES: 1831 Oct 30 J.Biscoe Journal in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 415]

YATE Those saltwater fish] most plentiful, and of greatest note, are, soles, mackarel, cod-fish, a species of salmon, whiting, snapper, mullet, bream, skate, gurnards, and a few smaller kinds, some not near so large as a sprat; with an abundance of crayfish, oysters, shrimps, prawns, muscles, and cockles. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),71)

POLACK ... this net is found to be extremely serviceable in fishing for the kohuda or [198] cray-fish, that congregate among the rocks in certain places very numerously; ... (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/197)

HODGSKIN Fine large crayfish, as good as any lobsters. (1841,Narrative of Eight Months Sojourn in NZ, A,34)

DIEFFENBACH 11. Palinurus ?sp. Lobster, or Sea Cray-fish.' <i>Cook</i> ...Kohuda or cray-fish', Kohura. Dieffenbach. Polack, i. p.326. (1843,Travels in NZ) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna (Anulose Animals) in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/266]

LUSH At Hall tasted for the first time some New Zealand crayfish; like immense lobsters but without claws. (Nov 19, 1850,Auckland Journals,38,1971 ed.)

BAINES Truly ... presently in the bottom of the boat lay Hapuku, Tamuri, Tarakiki [sic], Rock-cod, Yellow tail, young shark, crayfish ... (1874,Edward Crewe,163)

The fishing off the island is very good, there being abundance of hapuku, kokiri, kohikohi, maumau [sic], schnapper, kahawai, tarakihi, in addition to plenty of shell-fish such as koura or crayfish, crabs, paua, etc. The mako shark, so well known for its beautiful teeth, which are highly prized by the Maoris as ornaments, is found off this island and nowhere else in the world I believe, ... (1884,TrNZI,17/419) [NOTES: (Gold-Smith)]

SKEY On pipis he lives - on cockles and eels,/ And lobsters so fine and so red;/ ... / And kakapos stewed for desert; [p.ix ERRATA] Page 17 - 6 for lobsters read crayfish. Page 17 - 10 for kakapos read katipos (1889,Pirate Chief and the Mummy's Complaint..., The,17) [NOTES: (`The Hermit') [cp lobster]]

WILLIAMS Koura, n. crayfish. (1892,Dictionary of the Maori Language,76)

Crayfish are very plentiful all along the East Coast and Bay of Plenty area. (1926,TrNZI,58/626) [NOTES: (Buck)]

McLINTOCK Crayfish - koura, Jasus (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

[species name] rock lobster .. [scientific name] Jasus edwardsii .. [other name(s)] crayfish, crayfish spiny, crays red, lobster red, red crayfish, spiny rock lobster (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Red rock lobster Jasus edwardsii ... Closely related to J. novaehollandiae of southern Australia and J. lalandii of South Africa ... Crayfish' has been regularly used as a common name, although it is more properly applied to freshwater species. Some combination ofred', spiny', androck lobster' is more appropriate. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,150)

SMITH ... a Maori who was with us caught some crey [sic] fish, and ... cooked and presented them to us ... (Jan 27, 1858,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1858 Jan 27 Smith Notes of a Journey in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 378]

TAYLOR Amongst the Crustacea is the koura, which is the general name for both the sea cray fish and the fresh water; the former is nearly two feet long, and abundant on all the rocky shores; the latter is from four to eight inches long. The Rotorua lakes abound with the largest, but near Paparoa, on the Wanganui, I met with one nearly a foot long. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,415)

MCKAY CRAYFISH PATTIES Cook crayfish ... put white meat through the mincer, make a nice batter ... drop mixture in tablespoons; fry ... (1929,Practical Home Cookery,140)

FARRELL That would set them all talking: VeraBattersby with a crayfish on a leadstrolling down Keats Street to the shops. (1992,Skinny Louie Book,78)

SHORTLAND There was the "mango" or shark, the "koura" or crayfish.. and a variety of dainties. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,70)

I woke up this morning with the blackened stub of a cigar in one hand and the dismembered body of a Queen Street crayfish in the other. (Oct 8, 1937,King Country Chronicle,5)

For the main course there may be crayfish,.. pan-fried hapuku or fillet steak. (Aug 1991,Cuisine,87)

Crayfish Holes¶

n.

Amongst the hills around Waimate [Canterbury] are many deep pools, known as the `Crayfish Holes', from which the crayfish can be taken in any quantity. (1915,TrNZI,19/309) [NOTES: (?Spec. local Waimate.)]

crayfish pot¶

n. (figurative use)

"At the moment we have got quite a few crayfish pots that have been hung around ratepayers' necks." (May 12, 2005,Wellingtonian,p3)

n.

The crayfish pot.. sometimes contains as many as twenty, squirming blind eels. (Mar 9, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

crayfish potting¶

n.

Crayfish potting is the only form of commercial fishing in Doubtful Sound, and the position of each pot is marked by a bright buoy. (Mar 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 50/39)

crayfish supper¶

n.

The night after the match.. a big crayfish supper was held. (Jun 15, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,49)

crayfish-eyes¶

n.

ANDERSON titoki, a tree (Alectryon excelsum), scarlet fruit with shiny black seed at tip, whence the tree (or fruit) is called crayfish-eyes: ... (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

crayfisher¶

n.

WHITE The men in my drawing are crayfishers awaiting the tide before they cruise round their pots. (1982,Historic Sheep Stations of NZ,69)

This is big cray country; squadrons of jet-boating crayfishers make their way from Hicks Bay to the fast refrigerator trucks which will take the delicacy out of town - probably to Wellington and Auckland restaurant tables. (Aug 16, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),82)

The marine reserve's crayfish stocks and their habit of wandering outside the boundaries are known to local crayfishers, and the boundaries of the marine reserve are dotted with commercial crayfish pots. (May 9, 2007,NZ Herald,A18)

crayfisherman¶

n.

SANSOM ... I tried to forget the lone crayfisherman ... (1982,In the Grip of an Island,84)

Des did what he reckons almost every crayfisherman does; he bought home a feed of shorties' (illegal-sized crayfish) for his mates. It was to be a treat, Southland hospitality. It was a generous feed Des planned on giving them. A fisheries inspector was on the wharf at Riverton when Des returned. The inspector seized the sacks ofshorties'. (Sep 2, 1984,NZ Times,9)

crayfishing¶

n. the catching of crayfish

GRUNDY In recent years ... the terrific potential of the crayfishing at the Chathams has been realised ... (1968,Who'd Marry a Doctor?,51)

SLATTER He had been overseas and he had been up and down the island picking up jobs ... Crayfishing and scrubcutting. Contract fencing. Poisoning rabbits. Even collecting agar. On the chain at Whakatu [166] when they put through 13,000 lambs a day. Share-milking for a while. (1968,Pagan Game, The,165)

[Caption] Cray-fishing at the Bay of Islands. (Jan 5, 1949,Auckland Weekly News,37)

The introduction of air travel by flying boat in the 1950s made the commercial exploitation of packhorses possible, and led to a crayfishing boom on the island. (Jan 1991,NZ Geographic,106)

craying¶

n. crayfishing

[Fishermen's Col] It was ideal weather for craying ... (Aug 31, 1963,Evening Post,31)

craypot¶

n.

Cray pots for sale. (Oct 26, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,10)

The morning streets of Bluff seem as still as the vases on every windowsill, as the craypots heaped at the back of vast barns, as the seagull lying dead and spotlessly white on its back in an empty section. (Nov 20, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

HYDE An absent face ... as far/ As fisher's boats that bob across the bay/ Setting their cray-pots in the island's shadow;/ (1984,Selected Poems,59) [NOTES: c1937 Hyde Selected Poems (1984) 59]

HYDE As fishers ... boats that bob across the bay/ Setting their cray-pots in the island's shadow. (1939,Houses by the Sea,116)

DEMPSEY It was the first time I had seen the cray-pots hauled aboard ... (1964,Little World of Stewart island,121)

BRAMBLEY Coming home from servicing the craypot one day, I carried an octopus in a bag on my back ... (1966,Sea-cockies of the Manukau,71)

MARSHALL As George turned back to the fence he noticed a [31] fishing-boat setting cray-pots off the point. (1979,Supper Waltz Wilson,30)

JOHNSTON She would meet him one morning when he returned ... from lifting his cray-pots ... (1981,Fish Factory,53)

Johnston ... instead of going down to the wharf to throw himself off the end of it with a few cray-pot weights tied around his neck, ... (1981,Fish Factory,86)

This is Marlborough: we heard of a fisherman who set a craypot in his back yard to catch a cat. (Mar 1963,Sea Spray,72)

crazy ant¶

n. the introduced ant Paratrechina longicornis

[Hdg] Timber yards searched for crazy ants... The crazy ant (Paratrechina longicornis) and yellow crazy ant (Anoplolepis gracilipes) cause severe irritation on humans and animals. When disturbed, they run erratically in large numbers... it was possible that crazy ant colonies recently found on Auckland and Mt Maunganui wharves had arrived in New Zealand on sawn timber imported from the Solomon Islands, Fiji and Papua New Guinea. (May 1, 2003,Dominion Post,A4)

crazy/screwy as a two-bob watch¶

phr. (See also silly as a two-bob watch)

COWLEY "You're mad!" he said. "You know that? You're as crazy as a two-bob watch." (1979,Growing Season, The,74)

MASON FOOTBALLER 1: Ah, what can you do? He's as screwy as a two-bob watch ....[sic] (1974,Hand on the Rail, The,30,(1981 TS) ed.)

Crazyman¶

n. a multisport event - hill-climbing, mountain biking and kayaking.

Athlete Al Cross is defending his Kathmandu-sponsored Crazyman title on May 18... And as for that name, Crazyman, organiser Michael Jacques says it has far less to do with ones state of mind for taking on the challenge and more to do with the fact that you would be crazy not to experience everything that is the Crazyman. (May 14, 2003,Capital Times,18)

The 28-year-old smashed nearly 20 minutes off the Women's race record as she produced the mnost dominant performance in the history of the Wellington Crazyman multisport classic. (May 19, 2003,Dominion Post,D1)

cream boat¶

n. (Rural) a boat that collects cream and other farm produce and delivers supplies to outlying areas.

BENNETT Both worked on Mangatoi Station, 27 miles up the Mokau River, in "the middle of nowhere." The only means of access to the 62,000 acre station was by the coal barge or cream boat which also transported the mail, stores and other necessities. (1990,Bryans, The: At Home on the Farm,57)

cream can¶

n. a can in which cream was collected from farms for delivery or transport to a butter factory

Dairy and cheese factories are dotted over the plains, cream-cans stand at farm gates. (1948,Our Own Country,25)

SHADBOLT ... Father mounted me ... on the konaki beside the cream-cans and took me, with the cans, down to our jetty, there to await the cream-launch ... (1959,New Zealanders, The,16,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (The Woman's Story)]

TURNER ... the milk goes through the separator and the cream, in smaller cream cans, goes on to the creamstand to be picked up by the cream lorry. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,149)

HARTLEY After breakfast Dad left the house with mugs and a cream can of oatmeal water - a refreshing drink of rain water, lemon juice and a large handful of oatmeal. (1987,Swagger on Our Doorstep,188)

BATISTICH As well as the cream cans that had to be dropped off at the farm gates, Charlie had his shopping lists to deliver. (1987,Sing Vila in the Mountain,73)

1 n. (Rural) a metal container in which cream is transported from farm to dairy factory.

BARDSLEY Romance flourished, with letters sent in the lids of cream-cans. (2000,Land Girls, The,161)

Farmers should think of the cream cans by the roadside. (Dec 20, 1928,NZ Dairy Exporter,16)

Once a week, each woman leaves a cake or parcel of jams, preserves etc for the man on the cream lorry to collect along with the cream cans. (Mar 28, 1931,NZ Dairy Exporter,39)

Janet was in the act of lifting a cream-can on to the stand. (Jan 1, 1941,NZ Dairy Exporter,48)

How we envied the big high school boys who were allowed off at each stop to load the cream cans. (May 1982,NZ Journal of Agriculture,40)

For sale: .. cattle crush, 5 Holstein Friesian rising 1 yr bulls, cream cans. (Apr 6, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,28)

cream cart¶

1 n. (Rural) a cart or dray in which cream is transported to a creamery or factory.

HARGREAVES A little billy of cream was produced .. took it forward to catch the cream cart to the factory. (2000,To the Back and Beyond,33)

cream cheque¶

n. the money a dairy farmer receives for selling cream to his local dairy factory.

... the best that could be done was to keep the food bill paid out of the cream cheque. (1931,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,13/59) [NOTES: (Wright)]

The work in this will [88] be representative of all Maoridom. The first collections from cream cheques came to a little under [pounds]140 ... (Jun 11, 1933,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/87-88) [NOTES: 1933 June 11 in 1988 Na To Hoa Aroha (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) (Ngata)]

FINLAYSON What's money to me? The cream cheque goes to the store and pays the month's bills and everything, ... (1948,Tidal Creek,30,1979 ed.)

These advances were charged against the land and a proportion of the cream cheque taken for repayment. (1948,Our Own Country,50)

When secondary school assistants wed/ A cocksfoot man from the cream-cheque land. / There's no time for books and less for bed,/ But tits and cups in your early hand. (Apr 1953,Here & Now,3/6/3) [NOTES: (Keith Sinclair)]

SHADBOLT He chopped and burnt through the second-growth of scrub and fern ... and flayed his way into new acres of bushland. But the results were slow: the cream-cheques were never large; money was always short. (1959,New Zealanders, The,12,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (The Woman's Story)]

cream cheque: the monthly payment to a farmer from the local dairy factory for milk and cream supplied. (1973,Brown Man's Burden) [NOTES: (Pearson's Glossary)]

HARTLEY I am mystified as to know how my parents achieved such stylish comfort in the early 1930s on their share of the cream cheque. (1987,Swagger on Our Doorstep,148)

1 n. (Rural) a monthly cheque received by a dairy farmer for his supply of cream or milk.

Apparently the cream cheque was being splashed with a vengeance! (Jan 1, 1929,NZ Farmer,120)

After a cream cheque or two, many tried to lift production to attain that magical goal: a monthly cheque that was the same as the monthly bill from the grocer. (Apr 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture,40)

MACINTOSH Certainly, I could hang on to a few cream cheques. (1974,Never a Dull Moment,132)

DUGGAN Collected Stories 161 The lady couldn't stand it perhaps, this fiery doom of scrub and small cream cheques? (1981,Collected Stories (Duggan),161)

cream factory¶

n.

MANDER Already he saw the cream factories which men down south were dreaming as part of every township. (1925,Allen Adair,48,1971 ed.)

cream launch¶

1 n. (Rural) a boat that collects cream and other farm produce [mostly around Northland harbours and islands and Taranaki rivers.]

When the men came home from World War I, they were given the rehabilitation blocks. For an instant cash crop, all they had to do was burn the scrub, clear the land and introduce the dairy cow. Hence the cream launch .. though this boat was the cream-launch, she officially began running the river in 1913, taking the mail up. [cream-launch] (Dec 22, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,13)

SHADBOLT ... Father mounted me ... on the konaki beside the cream-cans and took me, with the cans, down to our jetty, there to await the cream-launch ... (1959,New Zealanders, The,16,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (The Woman's Story)]

Motor lorries have replaced the cream launches of former days. (Jan 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,9)

SHADBOLT .. each morning she continued her journey on the cream-launch all the way down-creek to the high school in the town ... (1959,New Zealanders, The,22)

cream lorry¶

n. a truck which collected cream cans from farmers' cream stands

As driver of the cream lorry which servespart of the district, [he] has won theesteem and regard of all by his obligingmanner, efficient service anddependability. (Jan 5, 1929,Northern Advocate,8)

SCOTT Send us bread by the cream-lorry. (1936,Barbara of the Backblocks,14)

SLATTER A frontier land ... the flooded flats of the dairy land, the Otira gorge road washed [77] out again, ... the bulldozers nudging a slippery track for the cream lorries waiting in the rain. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,76)

CRUMP I missed the cream lorry this morning and yesterday they brought one of the cans back. (1960,Good Keen Man, A,103)

MIDDLETON ... as I rattled along our road in the cream lorry I began to look forward to seeing my parents .. (1964,Walk on the Beach,169) [NOTES: (Not for a Seagull)]

TUWHARE On the cream-lorry/ or the morning paper van no one comes,/ (1964,No Ordinary Sun,21,1977 ed.) [NOTES: (The Old Place)]

TURNER ... the milk goes thorugh the separator and the cream, in smaller cream cans, goes on to the creamstand to be picked up by the cream lorry. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,149)

TOMLINSON I ... soon had 600 sheep as well as milking sixteen cows for the factory. The cream lorry called three times a week. (1968,Remembered Trails,99)

SUTHERLAND ... a Goosman cream lorry, Wills' Reo Speedwagon Big Tree petrol tanker, the T model Ford fire engine. (1978,Elver, The,20)

RICHARDS We returned to Te Akau on the mail and cream lorry. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,89)

She took over a cream lorry and a school bus when her husband George went off to World War II. (1995,Mana,10:: 5)

Once a week, each woman leaves a cake orparcel of jams, preserves, etc., for theman on the cream lorry to collect alongwith the cream cans. (Mar 28, 1931,Exporter & Home Journal,39)

Supplies came to the farm in large quantities: 100lb bag of flour, 70lb bag of sugar, 5lb chest of tea, together with other items delivered by cream lorry twice weekly as the need arose. (Oct 2003,NZ Memories,No. 44/32)

1 n. (Rural) a truck used to collect cream cans from dairy farms for the butter factory.

MARRIOTT As we always took the cream over to meet the cream lorry on Monday mornings, and Cyrus came back on it, we would have a yarn on the way back to his camp. (1981,Life in the Gorge,118)

HARGREAVES Squib had an old Rugby light truck and carted his cream down to meet the cream lorry. (2000,To the Back and Beyond,81)

The covered cream stand is almost unknown in Hawke's Bay. In far too many cases farmers rely on the fact that the cream lorry will call within an hour or two. (Oct 29, 1927,NZ Dairy Exporter,22)

Once a week, each woman leaves a cake or parcel of jams, preserves etc for the man on the cream lorry to collect along with the cream cans. (Mar 28, 1931,NZ Dairy Exporter,39)

MULGAN Like his service-car brother he [the cream-lorry driver] does occasional commissions for the farmer and the farmer's wife. "Send it out by the cream lorry." "It" may be anything from a joint or a tin of tobacco to a spare part for the milking machine. (1946,Pastoral NZ,53)

MARRIOTT As there was only one cream stand, our cream and Rant's were picked up together, and as the cream-lorry brought stores, bread and papers, we had to meet there ... (1981,Life in the Gorge,121)

cream run¶

1 n. (Rural) a circuit taken for collection of cream cans from farms to factories.

The cream run involved collecting cans from 42 Hikurangi Dairy Company suupliers around Motatau - and also dropping off, to the farmers, orders that might include 44-gallon drums of petrol (or benzine as it was known then), bags of flour and boxes of butter. (1995,Mana,10 : 5)

At 7.30 I'd take the truck out on the cream run, as my father didn't drive. (Apr 9, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

HINDMARSH The milking had to be done by hand and the cream taken to Hick's Bay - the nearest point of the cream run. (1997,Come Be a Pioneer,201)

HARGREAVES I went on the cream run with Old Nut one morning. (2000,To the Back and Beyond,139)

cream stand¶

n. a stand (usu. outside a farm gate) holding a farmer's cream cans for convenient collection by a cream truck.

GRIEVE MOENGAWAHINE - a bridge and a creamstand, and Moengawahine, too, was behind us.Ibid. 104 On another occasion a ... bump-bump-bump in the vicinity of the cream-stand drew me as a glittering object draws the curious weka. (1939,Sketches from Maoriland,17,1961 ed.)

CRUMP Uncle Wally lifted the can ... on to the old konaki, and took me down to the cream stand. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,109)

TURNER ... the milk goes through the separator and the cream, in smaller cream cans, goes on to the creamstand to be picked up by the cream lorry. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,149)

WATSON It's Erin Carter, disgruntled farmer, crossing the Otago river. Erin Carter born in March 1932, brought up on his father's farm in Northland, near a tin pot village where there's only the store with the red benzine bowsers in front of it, and across the metal road, the cream stand under the wattle trees. (1986,Address to a King,59)

HARTLEY Mr Davis put a large box of groceries in our cream stand once a week. Ibid. 127 I swear, Mrs Bird, I didn't take the orange. It was Don. He took it from the cream stand.' (1987,Swagger on Our Doorstep,97)

Early in the thirties settlers who supplied cream to the Raetihi Dairy Company had to transport their cans of cream on horseback to the junction of the Makakahi Road with the Orautoha Valley Road where there was a covered cream stand. (Oct 2003,NZ Memories,No.4/32)

1 n. (Rural) a platform on which metal cream cans are placed for collection [usually at a farm gate.]

Another thing that's necessary in this district is a cream stand by the roadside. (Oct 30, 1926,NZ Dairy Exporter,30)

The covered creamstand is almost unknown in Hawke's Bay. In far too many cases farmers rely on the fact that the cream lorry will call within an hour or two. (Oct 29, 1927,NZ Dairy Exporter,22)

Farmers should think of the cream cans by the roadside. A fair number of covered cream stands were erected last season. (Dec 20, 1928,NZ Dairy Exporter,16)

MARRIOTT As there was only one cream-stand, our cream and Rant's were picked up together, and as the cream-lorry brought stores, bread and papers, we had to meet there ... (1981,Life in the Gorge,121)

STIRLING 'Well, 'said my new client, 'it's a bit hard to explain, but tell you what, if you come up the road through Ivydale, I'll come down to the gate and meet you by the cream stand ...' (1990,From the Hills Above Taiamai,87)

STIRLING He was leaning on a creamstand smoking a pipe, stoked with tobacco of a less expensive sort .. On this discouraging note the farmer led not one, but two horses out of the shadow of the creamstand. [creamstand; cream-stand] (1990,From the Hills Above Taiamai,88)

cream truck¶

n. (Rural) a truck which collected farmers' cream-cans for delivery to a butter-factory [ca1920 see cream lorry; cream boat etc]

Being no end of a joker with the sheilas,and really punishing the keg on the creamtruck. (1955,Peter Cape Sings (record sleeve),00)

At times they nearly missed the 8.50 a.m. cream truck. (Jul 1959,NZ Dairy Exporter,39)

HILLIARD Here, half a century ago, the county council built a wooden bridge which somehow still stands, ... its stringers creaking beneath every cream-truck and tractor. (1960,Maori Girl,9)

stopped worrying that minute and sat by the cream stand out on the main road. ... If I'd waited for the cream truck I'd have had to face old brownstone Hohepa .. (1981,Collected Stories,209) [NOTES: 1963 `Along Rideout Road ...' in 1981 Collected Stories 209]

I had a schottische with the tart from the Butcher's,/ Got stuck for a waltz with the constable's wife;/ I had a beer from the keg on the cream-truck,/ And the cop had one, too, you can bet your life. (1964,Book of New Zealand, A (J.C. Reid),259) [NOTES: (Cape `Down the Hall on Saturday Night)]

The cream truck in the 50s, with few private cars around, was one of the favoured ... means of transport into town. (Dec 21, 1986,Sunday Times (NZ),2)

...she went to the shop on the cream truck to get some soap and she hasn'tcome back yet. (2005,Huia 6: Contemp. Maori Fiction,1)

CAPE Had a beer from the keg on the cream truck. (1967,Quick March,148)

They milked a couple of cows and left their small cream can in the same covered shelter as our family did ready for the daily collection by the Mauriceville cream truck. (May 2007,Carterton Crier,6)

BATISTICH This time I really minded having to go with Mrs Berich, not even the thought of riding on the Cream Truck made it better. (1987,Sing Vila in the Mountain,75)

creamery¶

n. in NZ used early, as a distinct entity from factories; ?? but replaced with butter factory ??date; (See cf. factory)

Classification of Dairies. - Dairies are registered as - Factories' orcreameries,' i.e., milking at least fifty cows; ... (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,149) [NOTES: 1898 Dairy Industry Act in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 149]

When a settlement has progressed a little further, a creamery will probably be started ... . Butter factories at Ross and in the Waitaha are already spoken of. (1908,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.6 (NS) 29) [NOTES: (Morgan, Mikonui)]

CARR Creameries are run where there are not sufficient cows to warrant a factory. They are usually run by one man who forwards the cream by rail ... to the factory. (1913,Country Work,39)

NEAVE However, before separators came in, there was a creamery in Ferguson Street [Kurow] just opposite the end of Gordon Street and now occupied by Mr Dudley Craighead. The farmers brought their milk to this factory, waited for the cream to be separated, and received the skim milk back to take home for various uses. (1980,Land of Munros, The,45)

WOOLLASTON [c WW1, Taranaki] ... the men at the Creamery. (1980,Sage Tea,46)

Hitherto, that policy has been to discourage creameries, or as they are more correctly called - skimming stations, and to deal with all the milk at the large central factory. (May 25, 1899,Taranaki Herald,2)

Mr Spriggs met intending suppliers at the new creamery. (1965,They Came by Ship,53) [NOTES: Quoted from 1892]

...Bolger looked a few minutes ago like the cat who'd got the creamery. (Apr 19, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

These creameries represent an important epoch in the dairying industry in Waikato for they purpose to do for butter what the freezing meat company should do for beef and mutton - produced an export market for the produce. (Nov 26, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,29)

Years ago the creameries did not handleenough milk to become factories, but nowthere are creameries receiving the milkof perhaps twelve hundred to fifteenhundred cows. (Sep 11, 1917,Stratford Evening Post,3)

LANCASTER The district [sc. Taranaki] reeks with creameries. (1904,Sons o' Men,206)

All that remains.. is.. a neglected ruin of what was an important creamery. (Feb 16, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,60)

CONDON After the milk is separated the factorywagon starts from the furtherestcreamery (ours Gentle Annie by name)about 10am and travels very fast callingat two other creameries for their creamand arrive at the central factory notlater than 12 o'clock, then all the creamis churned into butter. (1992,Hurleyville,72) [NOTES: See also "skimming station"]

"Factory" or "creamery" shall mean aplace established for receiving the milkor cream of cows from the public for thepurpose of manufacturing the same or anyportion of the same into butter orcheese, or both, as the case may be. (1892,NZ Statutes,56 Vict. 30/178)

"Dairy factory" means butter-factory orcheese-factory, and includes creameriesand skimming stations. (1898,NZ Statutes,62 Vict. 22/73)

[Advt.] 181 acres, partly improved dairy farm.. 2 miles from creamery. (Jan 2, 1914,Hawera & Normanby Star,3)

It is said that at a later date there were as many creameries as there were sawmills. (1957,Mangamaire School,29)

SINCLAIR & HARREX Creameries or skimming stations were established in dairying districts to that farmers didn't have to maintain their own dairies, and so that they could produce a more uniform butter by pooling their milk. (1978,Looking Back,97)

Numerous small creamery factories were then being built, but miles apart, so farmers would have somewhere to deliver the milk that was being produced. (1957,Mangamaire School,29)

2 n.

It's buttermilk that makes the creamery boys spooney. (Nov 22, 1890,NZ Observer,11)

creamery butter¶

n. factory butter; or at least contrasted with dairy butter

They [sc. English brokers and merchants] comment very favourable concerning the quality of our "factory" or "creamery" butter. (1894,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,II/202)

Standard for grading Creamery Butter. IBid. 151 Stamps. - The following stamps are prescribed by the regulations:- ... In the case of a creamery or factory - ... NEW ZEALAND/ Produce. Pure/ CREAMERY BUTTER./ No. 0 Regd./ ... (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,107)

creamfish¶

n. leatherjacket, triggerfish, kokiri

CANTHERINES CONVEXIROSTRIS (Gunther[u-dieresis]). Leather-jacket; Kokiri[o-macron]. Large numbers are skinned and sold in Auckland as `cream-fish.' ... Distribution: New Zealand coasts (less common, South Island). (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/123) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

POWELL LEATHER-JACKET (Cantherines convexirostris), Kokiri of the Maoris, is a curious rough-skinned fish with a small mouth and a trigger-like spine on the back which can be locked into a vertical position at will. This fish resembles brown suede leather except for the fins, which are bright yellow. It is a good food fish and is sold in the Auckland markets in the form of skinned fillets under the name of `cream-fish.' (1947,Native Animals of NZ,72)

LEATHERJACKET (Novodon convexirostris), or kokiri of the Maoris, is a small rough-skinned fish with a tiny mouth ... It is a good food fish and is sold in the Auckland market in the form of skinned fillets under the name of `cream fish'. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/294)

SORENSON LEATHERJACKET (a) Scientific name: Navodon scaber. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Creamfish (fillets); Leatherjacket. (c) Other common names: Triggerfish; Filefish. (d) Principal localities where taken: Auckland, Tauranga, Tasman Bay. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,33)

AYLING LEATHERJACKET Parika scaber (Navodon scaber) (Triggerfish, cream fish, kokiri) ... [314] They make excellent eating and are usually sold under the name of cream fish. (1982,Collins Guide,313)

BURTON Leatherjacket [title] This cheeky little thick-skinned fish, also known as creamfish, triggerfish or kokiri in Maori, is widespread around the rocky coast of New Zealand. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,76)

The range [in a Wellington sea-food delicatessen includes] Blue grenadier, a deep water species which retails for about $7.49 a kilo. Stargazer which sells at about $8 a kilo. Cream fish, small fish which are sold whole for 59 cents each. Gem fish, popular in New South Wales, which retails for about $8 a kilo. (May 18, 1985,Evening Post,56)

PAUL Leatherjacket Parika scaber ... Also occurs off southern Australia. ... Leatherjackets have some commercial value, ... being caught ... and sold as creamfish. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,146)

creaming soda¶

n. a one-time popular aerated mineral drink (cream soda)

Creaming Soda with my tea distant summer dream. (Feb 24, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),60)

Creamoata¶

n. proprietary brand of porridge oats

Flemings' mill in Gore... opened in 1878 and Creamoata - yes, Cream o' the oat! - rolled off the production line for the first time in 1918. (Jun 9, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

For many years Creamoata was known as the national breakfast. (Aug 9, 2001,Dominion,27)

But even now in patches of country surrounding the national park there remains a lost world where all is not spring lambs and Cremoata [sic] (Jun 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 52/38)

creases¶

n. a truce word; ? var. of crosses

I have also had a report of creases' and what to me were two novelties,flicks' and `skinch'. (Feb 5, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),72) [NOTES: I.A. Gordon]

Creative New Zealand¶

n. NZ's arts funding organisation

Then out of the fax maxhine popped a Creative New Zealand media release with the news that contemporary dance was to get a funding boost of half a million dollars. (Aug 12, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34)

Then out of the fax machine popped a Creative New Zealand media release with the news that contemporary dance was to get a funding boost of half a million dollars. (Aug 12, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34)

crechenik¶

n. child

But does the radio dial offer any more relief for bored ankle-biters, crecheniks and fractious parents today? (May 4, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),87)

credentialling¶

n. checking qualifications and credentials of medical staff

"Credentialling"? A new word, seemingly acceptable in healthspeak, related to policies for the qualifications and credentials of medical staff. (Feb 21, 2002,Dominion,3)

credit card walker¶

phr. a luxury hiker, one wanting leisure without labour.

"Credit card walkers they call us - baby boomers with teenage or adult children, who now have more time for leisure but don't want to lug bottles of sauvignon blanc and the entire gourmet section of the supermarket on our backs to maintain the sort of lifestyle we've come to expect." (Mar 6, 2005,Sunday Star Times,11)

creditite¶

n. a supporter of Social Credit theory in the first Labour Government.

SINCLAIR The men behind the abortive coup were the remnants of the credit reformers, or Leeites, in the caucus of the 1930s: Mason (who detested Nash), Bill Anderton, and Nordmeyer who, while probably never a creditite, had been numbered in the ranks of the dissidents as an ambitious young `stirrer'. (1976,Nash,292)

creek¶

n.

n.

COWAN Three of us once cruised about [Stewart Island's] secret coves and in and out of its tidal creeks in a whaleboat carrying mainsail and jib ... (1926,Travel in NZ,2/169) [NOTES: [sc. tidal creek]]

MULGAN Little steamers sailed every week from Eden to mainland harbours, tidal creeks, and islands. (1934,Spur of Morning,44)

SHADBOLT I grew to awareness rejecting as alien our scrubby backblocks farm, the thick bush of tall kauri, rimu and kahikatea ..., the mangroved tidal creek, ... the cabbage trees in the playground ... Ibid. 32 The barbecue was held on a sandy spit about a mile, by water, from the place where the town met the tidal creeks; there the creeks became sea, and the sea swelled out to the harbour heads. (1959,New Zealanders, The,10,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (The Woman's Story)]

Fore part, people employ'd getting a spar out of the Creek for a windlass, and one for the sheer legs. At 11 A.M. took the Sheers down, and brought two legs ashore to put the cross-piece on... (Oct 2, 1839,Piraki Log,99,1911 ed.) [NOTES: 1839 Oct [?check Aug] [?saltwater ?freshwater]]

SARAH MATHEW We had ... an impassable creek and ravine still between us and the height we were so anxious to gain. (1840,Journal,58) [NOTES: [She also uses creek for `saltwater creek']]

n. (now mainly Northland: ?hist); a tidal or saltwater creek; an inlet from the sea, a harbour.

... after securing the Boat in a little creek, I proceeded to the the place. (Apr 12, 1773,Cook's Journals,2/120,1961 ed.)

FORSTER At length they [natives in a canoe] went ashore, in a little creek [?an arm of Dusky Bay] hard by ours, and afterwards came and sat down on the shore abreast of the vessel ... [150] Here [at Anchor Island] they sat down by the side of a pleasant brook, and made a slight repast on some boiled craw-fish ... (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/149)

MARSDEN A creek of salt water, about one hundred yards wide, runs from the main river round to the rear of the hippah till it meets a fresh-water stream. The creek was navigable for small craft where I crossed it. (Jul 18, 1820,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,260,1932 ed.)

McCRAE [He uses stream elsewhere] Next morning we left Mooto Kraka and went up a Creek to see some timber ... which yielded a quantity of excellent rosin - we remained thee until evening waiting [24] for the tide ... (1820,Journal,23)

CRUISE There were many wild ducks and curlews in the creeks and rivers about the harbour ... we discovered a creek to the west of our anchorage, which terminated in rather a large river. (Jul 3, 1820,Journal,122,1957 ed.)

SHEPHERD The name of this part of the harbour is called Seal Cove we saw a great number of Creeks and little bays on each side as we went along in the boat. Ibid. 361 Mar. 20 I went to a flat piece of ground in a creek which branched off from Seal Creek with Typro a chief ... (Mar 10, 1826,Journal) [NOTES: 1826 Mar 10 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 359]

McDONNELL The rivers are well stocked with fine fish ... - the very creeks swarm with them. There are abundance of lobsters, crawfish, oysters, prawns, and shrimps; besides clams, peppies, muscles, limpets, and cockles. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,15,1979 ed.)

SARAH MATHEW We had ... an impassable creek and ravine still between us and the height we were so anxious to gain. (1840,Journal,58) [NOTES: [She also uses creek for `saltwater creek']]

Another small portion lying along the banks of fresh water creeks, covered with evergreens and tree ferns, affords a rich, pliable clay, ... Ibid 38 ... this [Papakura] district is bounded on the west by the waters of the Manukau, which deeply indent it in various directions, with its numerous creeks. (1843,Report of Auckland Agricultural Society,21) [NOTES: 1843 First Report of the Committee of the Auckland Agricultural Society in 1853 Swainson Auckland 21]

BAINES It was a place [16 miles by boat from Auckland] we never could have found without a guide, there were so many creeks, as big as the main one apparently, branching off on both sides. (1874,Edward Crewe,38)

DOMETT As, when you turn upon a sea-creek's shore,/ Some limpet-crusted boulder o'er,/ (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/138)

[? a sea-arm] This great inlet [Pelorus Sound] ... extends in a southerly direction about 25 miles, branching of to the eastward and westward into numerous arms and creeks ... (1892,NZ Official Handbook,242)

LAING & BLACKWELL Here [kauri logs] lie until a fresh' drives them down to the creek or harbour where theboom' lies waiting. (1940,Plants of NZ,62)

FINLAYSON But this morning he thinks he'd like to find a way to the banks of the creek up which the Seahawk comes. (1948,Tidal Creek,42,1979 ed.)

CHERRILL At home a creek means an inlet from the sea; out here it seems to mean any old stream. (1950,Story of a NZ Sheepfarm,112)

creek. 1. A narrow arm of the sea running into the land. 2. A small stream. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),101)

THOMAS He carted sacked ... gum from the fields to the wharf or to the landing places on the harbour front and creeks. (1970,Way Up North,39)

n.

ANDERSON Wisterias were planted, gardens made, a tennis court achieved and a nearby creek dammed for a swimming hole beneath a waterfall. (1999,Long Hot Summer,119)

We found a small creek to wade through. (Oct 22, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,10)

The Kingz, after a good solid season last year, are back up that smelly creek, in a barbed wire canoe, paddling frantically against the swell. (Sep 19, 2001,Capital Times,4)

Two people drowned in Northland while trying to cross a flooded creek... (2008,NZ Geographic,94/34)

FRAME Even I use words that are out of date. And where have all the creeks gone, and the paddocks? (1988,Carpathians, The,30)

1 n. (Rural) a small river.

The putting of the land in order was a big undertaking, as swampy creeks zig-zagged through the property. (1910,Tapanui Station,60)

PAUL In the Australian Colonies, as in America, brooks are called creeks. (1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,65)

A little river, brook, or stream, is always called a creek; nothing but the great rivers are called rivers. (1860,BLANK ENTRY,46) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year Feb 13 (1863) 46]

16 paddocks, watered by stony-bottom creeks. (Nov 1, 1920,Hawera Star,1)

SINCLAIR As Boy headed, the hermit shot straight down the slide to the creek. (1973,Boot in the Stirrup,57)

2 n. a stream, a brook; a stream, usu. smaller than a river

NICHOLAS ... all that piece and parcel of land situate in the district of Hoshee, in theIsland of New Zealand, bounded on the south side by the bay of Tippoona andthe town of Ranghee Hoo, on the north side by a creek of fresh water, and on thewest by a public road into the interior; (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/194) [NOTES: 1815 Feb 24 Deeds ceding land to Missionaries in 1817 Nicholas NZ 2/194 [the first occurrence in Nicholas]]

124 bounded ... on the north side by a creek of fresh water ... (Feb 24, 1815,Marsden's Lieutenants) [NOTES: 1815 Feb 24 Missionary Society Deed in Elder Marsden 124 (Griffiths Collection) [Tuckett, 1844, used stream, not creek]Check title]

MARSDEN These villages stand at the head of a most beautiful valley into which a small creek, navigable for canoes, runs from the river. (1819,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,195,1032 ed.)

MARSDEN [The warm spring] is situated in a wood on the bank of a small fresh-water stream. There are two warm springs opposite each other, one on each bank of the creek, about ten feet above the level of the fresh water, which runs between them. (May 8, 1820,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,1932)

HAY ... the rivers are also numerous, and mostly navigable, ... and branching off into others, from which run numerous streams and creeks. (1832,Notices of NZ,7,1979 ed.)

YATE The harbour has several small creeks or rivers emptying themselves into it; and fresh water may be procured almost anywhere on its sides. Ibid. 71 .. several tribes go together to the little creeks where these fish [mackerel] frequent ... (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),25)

POLACK We arrived near sunset on the borders of a creek that gently wound its way through the surrounding woods and fertile valleys. This rivulet, which flowed into the Kaihu river, meandered ... having the appearance of mixing its pellucid waters with another stream. Ibid. 1/129 The young females are generally very cleanly in their habits; in summer, often bathing during the day, in the sea or fresh-water creeks. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/112)

SARAH MATHEW We had ... an impassable creek and ravine still between us and the height we were so anxious to gain. (1840,Journal,58) [NOTES: [She also uses creek for `saltwater creek']]

F. MATHEW Small creeks are flowing between them [sc. sand ridges], and on their banks the land is a light, good soil. (1840,Report,1/14)

POLACK A river in New Zealand, from twenty to forty miles in length in a direct course, often flows in serpentine directions nearly three times that length; the salt-water rivers are joined at their entrances by fresh-water creeks, many of which pursue routes inland, through perhaps eighty miles of country. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/169fn)

From the extreme value of allotments with water frontages for commercial people, the [Auckland] waterside was subdivided into very small allotments ... but two of the best of these [allotments], bordering on a fresh-water creek, which runs down through the valley, have been selected by Government officers. (1842,GBPP,(No.569) 134) [NOTES: 1841 July 19 D.Sinclair to Lord John Russell in GBPP 1842 (No.569) 134]

[Rivers] originate in little creeks (1841,NZ Journal,2/29/51) [NOTES: (Dieffenbach)]

DIEFFENBACH After scrambling for two hours through dense underwood and a soft alluvial soil, we reached the creek, which we crossed, and on the banks of which we encamped. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/85)

DIEFFENBACH .. a fresh-water creek. (1843,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/219)

Another small portion lying along the banks of fresh water creeks, covered with evergreens and tree ferns, affords a rich, pliable clay, ... Ibid. 38 ... this [Papakura] district is bounded on the west by the waters of the Manukau, which deeply indent it in various directions, with its numerous creeks. (1843,Report of Auckland Agricultural Society,21) [NOTES: [freshwater and salt water creek]]

I was obliged ... to clear a piece of ground on this side of the creek. (1847,McLean Papers,4/27) [NOTES: (Rev. Turton)]

Walked over low swampy land with creeks, ... fine good soil - flax, toi-toi, grass &c. (Dec 17, 1848,Torlesse Papers,42,1958 ed.)

Two other lakes connected by deep creeks ... the Clutha, ... into which fall other minor but useful creeks and streams. (1850,Otago Journal,6/93) [NOTES: (William Fox)]

HARPER The plains here are swampy, traversed by rivulets locally known as `creeks', deep, narrow, and bordered by treacherous ground, ... (Sep 1, 1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,18,1914 ed.)

PAUL In the Australian Colonies, as in America, brooks are called creeks. (1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,65)

BUTLER A little river, brook, or stream, is always called a creek; nothing but the great rivers are called rivers. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,4/46) [NOTES: 1860 Feb 13 in 1863 Butler First Year iv/46]

CARBERRY There is a creek here where we bathe every morning and there is a settlement of Friendly natives at the other side of it ... (Feb 24, 1865,Journal)

BARKER The next thing was to find a deep hole in the creek . (1865,Station Life in NZ,29,1870 ed.)

BARKER ... a wide, shallow creek. Ibid. 63 ... first it was necessary to build on a flat (as the valleys here are called), not too far off the main track, on account of having to make the road to it ourselves; ... and a good creek, or brook, which would not go dry in the summer, close at hand. . Ibid. 95 Three bright creeks come rushing ... down to join and flow on in quite a good sized river. Ibid. 185 A pretty creek; exactly like a Scotch burn, wide and noisy, tumbling down from rock to rock, but not very deep. (1865,Station Life in NZ,27,1874 ed.)

WILLIAMS & REEVES What they call a brook or brooklet or a streamlet or a rill,/ I do only, I confess it, call a creek and always will. (1889,Colonial Couplets,2)

THOMPSON Past fern-girt gully and gurgling creek, with a wealth of bush beside;/ (1909,Ballads about Business,103)

MANSFIELD We had hardly spoken since dawn. At noon we lunched off fly biscuits and apricots by the side of a swampy creek. (1912,Stories,109,(1984 Alpers) ed.)

~ n. a brook; a small river; a branch or tributary of a river. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3)
