Creek: Any stream, from a mountain torrent to a tidal stream, which is too small to call river. A much misused term. [1951, p.364 Many creeks are full-sized rivers, especially in flood.] (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p.46; [1898 Morris Austral-English]) [This usage belongs originally to the U.[1873 Lady Barker Station Amusements]--A.W.] (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

Creek.-A much misused term. Many are full sized rivers; for instance, Pyke's Creek, N.W. Otago, which is generally unfordable on foot. (Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Gloss. additions]

LEE There was a gently flowing creek that ran under the dusty road through a wooden culvert, ... (1934,Children of the Poor,46,1949 ed.)

BEATTIE Next day a cattle track led him to Tolmie's Crossing over a small creek ... (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,114)

CHERRILL At home a creek means an inlet from the sea; out here it seems to mean any old stream. (1950,Story of a NZ Sheepfarm,112)

SINCLAIR They used many Australian or North American terms. A stream was known as a creek', forests or woods were merelybush', while the largest field could be a paddock'. [Samuel Butler on N.Z. settlers' speech]. (1959,History of New Zealand,101)

SLATTER Hunka Harris who went in the creek after crawlers in his bare feet. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,10)

SCRYMGEOUR She fished, waded in the creeks, chased the wild Plymouth rocks, grays, leghorns, or orpingtons long domiciled in the plantations or with the larrikin elder brother Jim, following him round the rabbit traps in the evenings ... (1960,Memories of Maoriland,30)

BACON creek-Any small stream. (1963,In the Sticks,180)

McLINTOCK The vocabulary of New Zealand English has been influenced by changes in the usage of traditional English words, which have acquired new meanings ... Familiar examples of the first group are mob, creek, paddock, and bush, all of which acquired their new meaning first in Australia. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/679) [NOTES: (Wall NZ Speech)]

MAY CREEK: properly, the tributary of a river. A gully is the feeder of a creek. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,526,1962 ed.)

creek n. small river, brook, branch of a river. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

creek ... 2. U.S., Canad., Austral. & N.Z. a small stream or tributary. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,263) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 174; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 112]]

Creek: A small stream or waterway. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,4)

WILSON In my spare time I went continually down to our muddy creek among thick blackberry bushes, dark soft raupo and high teatree. (1984,South Pacific Street,7)

creek bed¶

n.

MONEY On my return to the lower world in the creek-bed, I found the party broken up, one having joined in a drive or tunnel, and the other two ... moved down to a little piece of ground which they intended to work quietly by themselves. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,78)

In July, 1867, gold was discovered in a creek-bed at the Thames ... (1892,NZ Official Handbook,172)

The gold occurring in the quartz was very fine, and it was considered that the coarse alluvial gold found in the creek-beds could not have been shed from the lodes discovered. (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/12)

In the creek-bed ... the conglomerate ... is hard and solid. (Jan 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,3/299) [NOTES: (Morgan)]

MULGAN The once open creek-bed, where we used to bathe and bask in the sun, ... (1958,Making of a New Zealander, The,34)

DEMPSEY At high water the creek bed is filled from bank to bank ... (1964,Little World of Stewart island,133)

TUWHARE (`Haiku') Stop/ your snivelling/ creek-bed: (1970,Come Rain Hail,5)

(1973,Islands,4/117) [NOTES: Henderson (The Dead Bush)]

We made use wherever possible of creek beds. (Sep 30, 1924,Otago Witness,67)

1 n. (Rural) a bottom or base of a stream.

MONEY On my return to the lower world in the creek-bed, I found the party broken up. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,78)

MCCONOCHIE The head was disappointing so we cut off some back steaks and set a fast pace to the dry creek-bed to start a fire for grilling our meat. [creek-bed] (1966,You'll Learn No Harm from the Hills,115)

HILL 'That part of Moaville County previously and generally referred to as Murphy Road shall be redesignated Blue Heron Rise.'.. It was a name that provoked a certain resentment.. especially since there had been blue herons in the creekbeds up Murphy Road - until the executives moved in and the creekbeds and blue herons moved out. (1986,Moaville Magic,63)

CHAMIER The shingly creek bed that serpentines at the base of the hillocks ... (1891,Philosopher Dick,270)

On the farm today there is not a blackberry-vine nor a gorse-bush to be seen, all having been cleared out of even the steepest and most inaccessible creek-beds. (Nov 21, 1927,NZ Journal of Agriculture,296)

creek fern¶

n. Blechnum fluviatile

PYKE (And) Blechnum fluviatile (1882,Province of Otago in NZ, The)

POTTS (And) Blechnum fluviatile (1882,Out in the Open)

COCKAYNE (And) Blechnum fluviatile (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Waipoua Kauri Forest]

COCKAYNE (And) Blechnum fluviatile creek-fern (1908,AJHR) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Tongariro National Park]

COCKAYNE (And).Blechnum fluviatile creek-fern (1915,AJHR,C-6) [NOTES: Plant Covering Kennedy's Bush (Canterbury)]

COCKAYNE (And) Blechnum fluviatile creek-fern (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

creek fern n [1 creek] : a stout New Zealand fern (Lomaria fluviatilis) with a large crown of numerous pinnate fronds (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,533)

creek-bank¶

n.

In damp places on creek-banks ... Elatostemma rugosum ... is a characteristic covering. (1911,TrNZI,43/198)

creek-flat¶

1 n. (Rural) a small river terrace or flat.

DUFF You live cows, think cows, talk cows, breather cows everywhere but on the rocky hump of Coromandel Peninsula; and even there you come on cows as often as you drop to the creek-flats and swamps. (1940,New Zealand Now,54)

Most of the creek flats were poorly drained and swampy. [creek flat] (May 31, 2002,Dominion,16)

creek-head¶

n.

CRUMP ... told and retold a bored Stan ... how I shot that old hind in the creek-head. (1960,Good Keen Man, A,131)

creek-water¶

n. [OED only c1450]

FRAME The fowls say quark quark quark,.. dipping their beaks into the rusty pan of clear creek-water.. then pointing their beak to the sky for the creek-water to trickle down in a clear thread. (1960,Owls Do Cry,117)

creekie¶

n.

SUTTON-SMITH We shook these in the water and chased the fish downstream. In this way we caught hosts of creekies' (minnows) and bullies and sometimes enough whitebait for a fritter each for tea. As well, we went fishing forguffy' from the rocks. Often we caught a crayfish and at low tide sometimes several. ... (1890; Akaroa) (1981,History of Children's Play,133) [NOTES: 1890 Akaroa in Sutton-Smith History of Children's Play (1981) 133]

creeklet¶

n. a poetic diminutive of creek

BRACKEN [Title] PAX VOBISCUM. In a forest, far away,/ One small creeklet, day by day,/ Murmurs only this sad lay:/ `Peace be with thee, Lilian.'/ (1884,Lays of the Maori,91) [NOTES: 1884 Bracken Lays of the Land of the Maori and Moa 91]

creekside¶

n.

FRAME There on the creekside the bird refugees were free to waddle and preen, ... (1957,Owls Do Cry,74,1958 ed.)

MAY The narrow side-gullies, where the washdirt was skimpy, were quickly exhausted, but for many miles along the creek-sides lay likely looking terraces, all of them auriferous. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,148,1962 ed.)

ADCOCK We went along the creekside, pushing our way through the wild mint, ... (1979,Butter in a Lordly Dish,49)

SANSOM Mint, watercress and pennyroyal by the creek-side scent the air. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,32)

creep grazing¶

1 n. (Rural) a habit of adult animals to graze under and through fences [as if they were juveniles being managed by creep feeding.]

HARRISON Sid thought he had her cured, there'd be no more creep grazing from Maud. (1986,She's a Fair Cow,32)

creep out¶

v. to give one the creeps

This not only creeps people out but it makes you look like an idiot. (2004,Salient,9/25)

creeper¶

n. (Environment) a bird. titipounamu, ?rifleman.

FORSTER ... the birds seemed to retire from it to a little distance, where the shrill notes of thrushes, the graver pipe of wattle-birds, and the enchanting melody of various creepers resounded on all sides ... (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/148)

FORSTER ... the birds seemed to retire from it to a little distance, where the shrill notes of thrushes, the graver pipe of wattle-birds, and the enchanting melody of various creepers resounded on all sides ... (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/148)

BULLER Although this Creeper may be seen in almost every bush from the coast to the distant alpine ranges, we have only once found its nest. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,106) [NOTES: 1869 TrNZI 2/59 T.H. Potts in 1873 Buller Birds of NZ 106]

HUTTON 18. ACANTHISITTA CHLORIS. Sparrm. Creeper. Titipounamu (1871,Birds of New Zealand,8)

MORRIS Creeper, ... The name (sc. Tree-creeper) is given to several New Zealand birds of the genus certhiparus, N.O. Passers. The Maori names are pipipi, Toitoi, and Mohona. (1898,Austral English,108)

BULLER Certhiparus Nova Zelandia, Finsch. New Zealand Creeper.' [A full description.] (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/51)

n. (Environment) black creeper, the Dobson fly larva, Archichauliodes spp., toe-biter

Order 4 (alder-flies) is represented in New Zealand by only a single species Archicauliodes dubitatus, an insect of large size, whose fat, succulent larva is found under rocks in streams, and forms excellent food for trout. This larva is called the black creeper,' or sometimes thetoe-biter'. (Jan 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,3/273) [NOTES: (Tillyard)]

NATUSCH The Dobson fly ... is a speckled orange-winged insect which flits weakly over streams at dusk. The larva (known as the black creeper or toe-biter) ... hides under stones in the creek bed by day, coming out for a night's career with its powerful jaws ready to seize and devour whatever comes its way; ... (1967,Animals of NZ, The,151)

n. a ground hugging platform on castors on which car mechanics propel themselves supine, under vehicles to inspect their undercarriage

AUCTION..HP Water Pumps, Mech. Seats & Creepers... (Feb 12, 2005,Hawke's Bay Today,11)

Workshop:..Mechanical Seats and Creepers x 50... (May 28, 2005,Hawke's Bay Today,11)

2 n. (Environment) brown linnet, toitoi, tree creeper

All around the bush is alive with the chatter of young birds, riflemen, tomtits, brown creepers, bellbirds and tui. (Mar 13, 2004,Dominion Post,E17)

CERTHIPARUS NOVAE ZELANDIAE, Gml. Brown creeper; Brown Canary. Although this Creeper may be seen in almost every bush, from the coast to the distant Alpine Ranges, we have only once found its nest. (1870,TrNZI,2/59) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

HUTTON 27. CERTHIPARUS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. Gml. Brown Creeper. Brown Linnet. Toitoi. C. Maculicaudus. Gray. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,11)

Certhiparus Novae-Zaelandiae[sic], Gml. Brown Creeper. (Nov 1884,NZ Journal of Science,26) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

Brown Creeper (Certhiparus novae-zealandiae, Gml.). (1895,TrNZI,28/361)

So with the New Zealand birds: the Mocker, the Tui, the warbler, the Tomtit, the Robin, the Brown Creeper, the Canary, the White-eye ...are all known to feed the Cuckoo bantlings ... (1904,TrNZI,36/116)

WILLIAMS Toitoi ... 6. Finschia novae-zealandiae, brown creeper; a bird. = pipipi. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,506)

Finschia novaeseelandiae Gm. Brown Creeper. Of this species no startling diminution has been recorded. Fulton (1908) mentioned three localities in which it was fairly plentiful. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/93) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

GUTHRIE-SMITH A few Brown Creepers (Finschia novae seelandiae) were also seen, a few Robin (Miro australis), no Crow, no Thrush. (1936,NZ Naturalist,55)

STUDHOLME The discordant notes of the Brown Creepers, as they flitted from tree to tree, ... (1940,Te Waimate,230,1954 ed.)

FALLA et al. BROWN CREEPER Finschia novaeseelandiae Maori name: Pipipi. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,207)

NATUSCH The brown creeper ... is an inconspicuous bush-warbler of the South Island and Stewart Island back country. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,277)

251. Finschia novaeseelandiae (Gmelin, 1789) Brown Creeper (Pipipi) ... South Island forested areas ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,66,1980 ed.)

Bird call on national programme ... the ... or Brown Creeper. (Nov 22, 1985,Radio NZ / National Radio)

Brown Creeper Finschia novaeseelandiae (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAME: Pipipi. ... DISTRIBUTION South Island, Stewart Island and their nearer outlying islands. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,275)

2 n. (Environment) ?brown creeper

GUTHRIE-SMITH From one or other of a Bush Creeper pair came the note that told us ... of their two babies ... Bush [63] Creepers are not frequent in these [Nelson] woods ... . (1936,NZ Naturalist,62)

2 n. (Environment) a bird

[Brown creepers] are seen at Wyndham in little flocks, and are often called the grey creeper' andthe other canary' ... (1908,TrNZI,40/491)

creeper gear¶

1 n. (Rural) a low gear and slow and careful manoeuvring of a loaded or towing vehicle [usually on a hill slope. ]

SALISBURY On really steep ridges we would tie a snig chain from the back of the truck and use a bulldozer to ease us down. All this was done in a creeper gear and I often had lots of time to think and wonder what would happen if the snig chain broke. (1994,I Was So Lucky,251)

creeping¶

adj. as a distinguishing epithet in names of plants, see bellflower, bent; burr-reed, NZ; buttercup, campanula, cinquefoil; claceolaria, NZ; club-moss, coprosma, crowfoot, cudweed, dichondra, everlasting, eyebright, fern; fern, maidenhair; fern, tree-fern; foxglove, fuchsia; grass, fog; grass, velvet; gunnera, lawyer, lucerne, mallow, marsh willowherb, matipo, muehlenbeckia, myrtle, ourisia, pimelea, pohuehue, pratia, sage, sedge, selliera, shamrock, sowthistle, thistle, thyme, totara, willow-herb, woodsorrel.

n. a children's game

SUTTON-SMITH There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. <West Coast: Dunk and Davey, Spang Weazling; ... Golden Bay: Who's That Walking Round My House Tonight, I've Come to See Poor Mary Jane, Steps and Stairs, Creeping, Branding, O'Leary; (1981,History of Children's Play,231)

creeping dichondra¶

n. (See also dichondra)

cockayne creeping dichondra Dichondra repens. (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

LAING & BLACKWELL (And) (1906,Plants of NZ)

creeping fog¶

1 n. (Rural) a twitch that is a widespread weed.

HILGENDORF Creeping Fog is one of the worst twitches we have. (1918,Pasture Plants & Pastures of NZ,40)

creeping Jesus¶

n. a general term of contempt for a whinger or sneak, or one who goes behind the back; a gutless person (esp. if ostensibly religious); occas. intensified to creeping Judas. [ca1914 W.H.B. Orsman for a contemptible person who puts one's pot on.]

WALLIS I wish to Christ Creeping Jesus had been able to put more of this across. (1963,Point of Origin,41)

creeping lawyer¶

n. a plant

COCKAYNE Rubus parvus creeping-lawyer (1919,NZ Plants) [NOTES: AND]

creeping lawyer n: a small half-buried prickly New Zealand blackberry ( Rubus parvus ) with large juicy fruit (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,534)

creeping lucerne¶

n.

creeping lucerne [s] Medicago glutinosa M. Bieb. Ibid. 45 lucerne, creeping [s] Medicago glutinosa M.Bieb... (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,17)

creeping matipo¶

n. Suttonia nummularia

Suttonia nummularia creeping matipo (1908,AJHR) [NOTES: Cockayne Botanical Survey Tongariro National Park (And)]

Suttonia nummularia creeping matipo (1909,AJHR,C-12) [NOTES: Cockayne Botanical Survey Stewart Island (And)]

creeping muehlenbeckia¶

n.

muehlenbeckia, creeping [s] Muehlenbeckia axillaris (Hook.f.) Walp. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,51)

creeping totara¶

n. = alpine totara, podocarpus nivalis

TURNER (1909,AJHR,C-11) [NOTES: Botanical Examination Higher Waimarino (And)]

crema¶

n.

All shots of espresso will have a "crema" of creamy golden-brown foam, with a hint of hokey-pokey in its flavour, on top. (Jan 22, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

My home coffee has crema like the best of them. (Apr 13, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,6)

crescent¶

n. [ca1960 at least (Wgton) a [crescent, thence any brand of] adjustable spanner, occasionally, wrench. ? PROPRIETARY NAME]

cress¶

n.

cress, New Zealand bitter [s] Cardamine debilis Banks ex DC. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,18)

n. PEPPER CRESS Lepidium campestre

HILGENDORF PEPPER CRESS (Lepidium campestre), also called wild cress and pepper wort, is found in fields and waste places in scattered localities, chiefly in Auckland. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,88,1967 ed.)

cress, wart [s] Coronopus squamatus (Forsk.) Asch. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,18)

TAYLOR WINTER CRESS (Barbarea spp.) Consists of several species, all native to Europe ... (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,175)

2 n. swine cress, hog cress, wart cress.

HILGENDORF HOARY CRESS ([Cardaria] draba), called also swine cress, hog cress and wart cress, is found as a very serious weed in some gardens and fields in Canterbury. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,95)

cress, hoary [s] Cardaria draba (L.) Desf. Ibid. 38 hoary cress [s] Cardaria draba (L.) Desf. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,18)

TAYLOR HOARY CRESS (Carodaria draba) . . ., native to Eurasia, is a serious crop weed in many countries but of limited occurrence in New Zealand. It is abundant in a few places in Canterbury, Marlborough and Hawke's Bay. (1980,Weeds of Crops,58)

cress, marsh [s] Rorippa islandica (Oeder) Borbas. Nasturtium palustra Ibid. 47 marsh cress [s] Rorippa islandica (Oeder) Borbas (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,18)

2 n. swine cress, wart cress, way-side cress, wild cress, pepper cress, pepper weed, scurvy grass.

cress, narrow-leaved [s] Lepidium ruderale L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,18)

HILGENDORF NARROW-LEAVED CRESS (Lepidium ruderale) is also called swine cress, wart cress, wild cress, pepper cress, pepper weed, and scurvy grass. It is common on waste lands, especially near the sea. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,18) [NOTES: [nf. 1967]]

cress, penny [s] Thlaspi arvense L. Ibid. 57 penny cress [s] Thlaspi arvense L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,18)

TAYLOR PENNY CRESS (Thlaspi arvense) ... is often called `stinkweed' from its strong smell when crushed. Small plants can be identified this way or from their appearance. Penny cress introduced from Eurasia, is abundant in many crops just south of Oamaru. . . (1980,Weeds of Crops,76)

2 n. Lepidium spp.

HILGENDORF NARROW-LEAVED CRESS (Lepidium ruderale) is also called swine cress, wart cress, way-side cress, wild cress, pepper cress, pepper weed, and scurvy grass. It is common on waste lands, especially near the sea. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,95) [NOTES: [nf. 1967]]

2 n.

HILGENDORF TWIN CRESS (Coronopus didymus, formerly Senebiera didyma) is often called wart cress, but, as this name is given to at least two other species, I suggest dropping the name entirely and substituting twin cress as a good descriptive term;. . . This weed is also called swine cress, hog cress, and scurvy grass [and land cress]. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,93,1967 ed.)

CROWE Bitter cress Cardamine debilis Panapana; New Zealand bitter cress...Panapana, though apparently not eaten by the Maori, was recommnended to New Zealanders by the Rev. Taylor.. as an edible cress, 'boiled and eaten as cabbage'. (1997,Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,71)

cresset¶

n.

We wonder if.. Grandmother said something under her breath when the "cresset," made by amateurish hands and often slightly larger at the bottom than at the top, defied all her efforts to get the cheese out. (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,212) [NOTES: Writing of 1940]

Cresta Dore¶

n. a popular 1960s NZ wine, now frequently derided (See Bakano)

crested¶

adj. as a distinguishing epithet in names of plants and animals, see bandfish, flounder, grass, crested dogstail; grass, crested wheat; grebe, penguin, shag, weedfish.

crested flounder¶

n. Lophonectes gallus

GRAHAM Crested Flounder Lophonectes mongonuiensis (Regan) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,404) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 404]

[species name] crested flounder .. [scientific name] Lophonectes gallus .. [other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Witch Arnoglossus scapha Also called megrim, both names derived from similar European flatfishes. Found only in New Zealand. ... A related but smaller species, the crested flounder Lophonectes gallus, of northern coastal waters, can be distinguished by a `crest' of long white dorsal fin rays. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,145)

AYLING CRESTED FLOUNDER Lophonected gallus ... It is easily distinguished from the witch by the greatly elongated rays on the front of the dorsal fin that form a crest above the eyes. (1982,Collins Guide,308,1984 ed.)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] flounder, crested 2223-4 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

crested grebe¶

n. (See grebe)

Crested grebes.. are fairly plentiful on Lake Ianthe, South Westland. (May 18, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

A pair of crested grebes may be seen swimming on the lake. (Nov 23, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17)

Lake Pearson supports populations of the rare southern crested grebe and scaup (diving duck). (Jul 16, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

MORELAND Late that evening we came to Lake Whahapo - a silver mirror, where a crested grebe made its slow way across in an ever-widening V of ripples. (1911,Through South Westland,30)

crested penguin¶

n. [includes four species: Fiordland crested penguin, Snares crested penguin, erect crested penguin, and rockhopper penguin.]

The Otago Museum. The following are the principal additions to the collection .. crested penguin, kingfisher, and bones of seal, by Mr. David Ross. (Aug 12, 1882,Otago Witness,23)

The Birds of New Zealand .. (35) Crested Penguin (Dunedin Harbour) .. (38) Crested Penguin (Dusky Sound) ... (Dec 18, 1907,Otago Witness,28)

Next to the Blue Penguin, the one most frequently seen is the Yellow-crested Penguin, which still breeds in small numbers in some of the West Coast Sounds. (Apr 14, 1920,Grey River Argus,6)

The plumages represented in the collection are those of the .. yellow-crested penguin ... (Mar 5, 1889,Evening Post,2)

This is the list of eggs Dr Fulton wants to order to make a complete collection for the museum .. Big Crested Penguin ... (Sep 20, 1905,Otago Witness,88)

crested shag¶

n. (Environment) spotted shag (See also flip-flap)

The crested shag, or cormorant, was another beautiful bird found there! (Mar 30, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,96)

Spotted Shag Stictocarbo punctatus (SPARRMAN, 1786) ... Spotted Shag S. p. punctatus (SPARRMAN, 1786). Blue Shag S.p. steadi (OLIVER, 1930). ... OTHER NAMES: Parekareka, ocean shag, crested shag, flip-flap, blue shag. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,125)

ANDERSON About the rocks are seen black sea pies [ed. note [Black Oyster Catcher, Haematopus unicolor.]] with red bills, and crested shags of a leaden colour with small black spots on the wings and shoulders and the rest of the upper part of a velvet black ting'd with green. (Feb 1777,Journal) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/807 (Queen Charlotte Sound)]

Spotted shags, inhabiting the shores of D'Urville Island, are locally known as crested shags. (May 16, 1951,Auckland Weekly News,24)

crevicing¶

n. fossicking in crevices of rocks in esp. stream beds for gold that has been washed there. --

HEINZ Crevicing: Collecting gold from the crevices or cracks in rock. (1947,Bright Fine Gold,200)

Talk W.S. Hynds Gold Prospecting Some days when the creeks are too low for sluicing, we go crevicing. (Aug 1952,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 2YA Wellington]

WOOD Crevicing can be a fascinating occupation, for one never knows when one might find a virgin crevice with its quota of shotty gold and even a small nugget. (1970,Gold Trails of Otago,81)

NOLAN Crevicing: This simple method consisted of scraping out cracks in rock bars or in rock masses once covered by the river. Good gold can be got this way but you must persist until you have scraped out every last particle of dirt and gravel. In fact, in any kind of fossicking always remember that the gold will have worked its way down as far as it can. (1976,Historic Gold Trails of Nelson & Marlborough,88)

cria¶

n. baby alpaca

After 11a months of pregnancy, they choose a fine day and deliver their baby, known as a cria, between 10am and 2pm. In their high-altitude homeland, that is the time when it is warmest... [Alpacas] can live for 25 years and are capable of having crias till quite late... (Apr 12, 2002,Dominion,7)

A female gives birth to one offspring, known as a cria, after 11a months of pregnancy (Oct 3, 2003,Dominion Post,C4)

crib¶

n. lunch, esp. a cut lunch eaten at work; meal-time at the workplace.

Those events include a 13-week strike.. by Blackball miners who demanded half an hour instead of the 15 minutes the company allowed for their "crib" or lunch-break. (Jul 28, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

WILLIAMS We ate our crib hurriedly and went to see the results of the holes. (1987,Racing for Gold,49)

LANCASTER Sereld growled because someone had spilt tobacco-ash into his crib - which is bushman for dinner. Ibid. 159 ... his crib flying at the tail of his neck-strap. (1904,Sons o' Men,159)

LANCASTER In the cook-hut [of mill-camp] someone was bawling for a stolen crib. (1907,Tracks We Tread,89)

MAY The time allowed by the Blackball Coal Company for miners' `crib' (lunch time) had long been a miners' grievance (Jan 1908,Miners and Militants,119) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

The other day we received the sad intelligence that William Young was killed in one of the Westport mines while sitting at crib! [West Coast coalminers'] (Apr 20, 1911,Maoriland Worker,8/2/3)

... any Royal Commission sitting upon mine accidents would be forced to make the following recommendations:- ... That a six hours' day be enforced with one hour for crib. (Apr 20, 1911,Maoriland Worker,8/2/3)

HICKEY One of the standing grievances was the time allowed for `crib' (meal-time) underground. In other collieries the time was thirty minutes; in Blackball, fifteen. (1925,Red Fed. Memoirs,11) [NOTES: [Blackball, 1908]]

DEVANNY My crib is along with Crighton's. (1930,Bushman Burke,290) [NOTES: (West Coast)]

LAKER crib: noun: meaning a cut lunch i.e. `I am not going home at dinner time today as I have my crib with me.' Also crib-tin - a container for carrying such a lunch. (Dec 10, 1957,Letter) [NOTES: (Westport)]

PEARSON [Gloss] crib: A miner's lunch. (1963,Coal Flat,420)

HOWE And what of Thames itself? ... dusty roads, always thronged with ... miners carrying ... their cribs in tin boxes ... (1964,Stamper Battery,3)

... a worker shall not be required to work more than five hours continuously without being granted a break for a meal or supper or crib.... (e) When a worker is working overtime, supper and crib-time (Apr 12, 1967,Manapouri Power Project) [NOTES: 1967 Apr 12 Manapouri Power Project Employees' Industrial Agreement (Schedule) [TS] 3(c)]

Nevertheless the carpenters ... together with some labourers, riggers, rebar[??] men and concrete workers ceased work when they knocked off for their crib at 12 noon, March 4th. ibid p4 ... the main outstanding complaint regarding the clean-up ... of the area concerning the crib tables was ... completed in time for the 8 o'clock crib. (Mar 6, 1968,Manapouri Power Project) [NOTES: 1968 Mar 9 TS Report of Industrial Relations Manager on a Work Stoppage at Manapouri Power Project (MOW 92/12/70/5)]

McARA Crib: The miner's lunch which he carried to work in a specially-designed tin box together with his enamelled or aluminium tea-billy. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),317)

West Cost crib', defined as acut lunch', is a definite plus for the editor, though he might also have noted the extension of its meaning to cover `lunch hour', for it was a running argument over the time taken for the miners' crib which led to trouble in the Blackball mine. (Mar 28, 1979,Otago Daily Times,21) [NOTES: (G. Griffiths)]

I like a little kip after my crib, but there's no time for that, not even forty winks, and I tell you there's times my tucker burns in my bingy all afternoon. Ibid. 243 crib lunch (1984,Blackball 08,33)

RANSOM Crib: Meal taken at the workplace in the middle of his workday by a shift-worker, based on fact that the worker gats paid for eight hours and thus is paid for his meal-time as well. In return the worker is expected to eat near the job and be ready to cope with an emergency. (Nov 21, 1985,Letter) [NOTES: ca1985 Nov 21 Tiwai Aluminium Smelter, Invercargill (Nicholas Ransom)]

HUNT We'd take our crib into the [gold]mine with us [c1916]: a cut lunch wrapped up in newspaper, cold meat, stew or bacon sandwiches and tea. (1985,I'm Ninety-five,28) [NOTES: (Bill Henderson)]

crib ... Austral. & local NZ a light meal or cut lunch to be eaten at work. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,1`75) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 113]]

RICHARDS The miners always carried their food (crib) to work in a specially designed tin box called a crib tin, together with an enamelled tea billy equipped with a drinking mug. The crib tin was necessary in the damp conditionsm because the mine was overrun with rats as big as bulldogs. The miners looked for a dry spot in a worked-out section of tunnel in which to leave their gear. This was known as the crib cuddy'. <i>Ibid.</i> 30 When Dad was chopping in the bush ..., Pud and I would often take hiscrib' out to him. This would usually consist of hot scones, hot pie, and bread. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,5)

Ruby Roycroft says her father, Andrew Austin, began on Martha Hill in 1900 as a labourer sinking a shaft. ... She says women were not allowed on the hill and when her husband was on the surface working on the crusher, she would take him his crib (lunch), and hurry back. (Feb 13, 1988,Auckland Herald,Sect. 2/2)

My girlfriend lived next door to the local cemetery, my flatmate packed sandwiches for his crib and went to the mines each morning at 5.00; the river burst its banks, on still evenings the smell of coal rose like musk. (Mar 20, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

RICHARDS When Dad was chopping in the bush.. Pudand I would often take his "crib" out tohim. This would usually consist of hotscones, hot pie and bread. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,30)

HENDERSON Crib over, swags adjusted, we'd marched across the river to Kurow. (1967,Return to Open Country,195)

n. billet; permanent job (perhaps an extension of n1.)

CHAMIER `He's looking for a crib to settle down.' (1891,Philosopher Dick,114)

n. A room to have a baby in [is this n&sup4. or an extension of n1.: cf crib n1. 1969 Truth cit. referring to this incident??].

The murder charge, however, had been narrowed down by the Crown prosecution to a baby born to Miss Mary McLeod, who for a fee, had arranged to rent a crib in the Coopers' house during her pregnancy, then, for the Coopers to arrange adoption for the child after its birth. ... But the circumstantial evidence was overwhelming, for it had also been established that a Miss Lester (some reports referred to her as Lister) who shared the crib with Miss McLeod, had also given birth to a baby on the Cooper property, and like her, had given the baby to the Coopers for adoption, never seeing it again. This was confirmed in court by witnesses. Likewise, Miss Lester had witnessed the McLeod baby being taken away by the Coopers. ... Lily Lester (the woman confined in the crib with Mary McLeod) had testified under cross-examination that Mrs Cooper ... (Oct 13, 1984,Dominion,10)

n. a shed for storing maize cobs

Ten years they were kids who crawled into the maize cribs to sleep. (May 15, 1931,Na To Hoa Aroha,2/146,1987 ed.)

FINLAYSON maize crib: an airy shed for storing maize cobs. (1973,Brown Man's Burden,141)

HORI NGATA. A corn crib; Maori what-kaa (1987,Personal Communication)

n.

PHILLIPS ... they packed up and started for Oakden - ... found Mr. O. just preparing to ... take them some provisions it now began to rain and the party were not at all sorry to find themselves comfortably housed in Mr. O's snug little crib where after spending a very pleasant evening ... they turned in and slept soundly ... (Dec 30, 1856,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,62)

THATCHER For the weather and time had so peppered/ That tumble-down crib, I declare/ That it didn't require a Jack Sheppard/ To find his way quick out of there [sc. the Dunedin gaol]. (1862,Dunedin Songster,No.1/5) [NOTES: The Old Dunedin Jail]

THATCHER The [Post-] office is an ancient crib,/ Built several years ago,/ When Auckland was tiny place,/ (1862,Auckland Vocalist,16)

THATCHER The offenders who once were confined there,/ Were mostly townsfolk, I've heard say,/ And the Governor treated them kind there,/ And held out inducements to stay;/ For the weather and time had so peppered/ This tumble-down crib, I declare/ That it didn't require a Jack Sheppard/ To find his way quick out of there. (1869,Wit and Humour: Local Songs...,35) [NOTES: (The Old Dunedin Jail)]

CHAMIER [crib, house/hut, station usage] (1891,Philosopher Dick,177)

It appears [the constable] got wind of a crib in Utiku [Taihape] where the illict whiskey bottle was wont to go the rounds. (Aug 25, 1906,NZ Truth,1)

The bach,' said the doctor was absolutely unfit for human habitation. ... The owner of the place, who used to draw three shillings a week in rent for the rotten crib, was feverishly engaged in pulling it down on the following day. <i>(Feb 24, 1912,NZ Truth,6</i>) [NOTES: [Christchurch reference: is this an intermediate use, between<i>crib</i>, a sub-standard or makeshift dwelling-place, and <i>bach</i>, in the older sense of alean-to' or a `whare']]

SMYTH `Here's my crib', he announced. (1929,Bonzer Jones,213)

BEATTIE He [the pioneer pastoralist] has built a domicile of some sort, be it of canvas, calico, bagging, sticks, ferntrees, grass, slabs, mud, clay, stone, or wattle and daub. He may call it various names according to its materials, but three names would not enter his head - i.e., crib, bach, or shack. He may call it a cabin, a shanty, a cottage, a warrie [whare], but probably he would use the commonest term of all - hut. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,33)

FINLAYSON [sc. for holding maize] There on the river flats were our crops of corn and kumara and riwai that we kids had to hoe. And here and there you see the nikau thatch roofs of our maize cribs. (1966,Brown Man's Burden,120,1973 ed.)

NEAVE [caption] `Westmere' ... was built by Christian Hille in the 1860's. The original crib was burnt [sc. the original homestead-hut on the station]. (1980,Land of Munros, The,75)

n.

[The prisoners] are then at liberty to arrange their cribs and go to sleep. (1864,Saturday Review,4/15)

n. a small holiday home, a bach (See bach)

[Advt] A Crib at Puketerahi:-Beautifully-built week-end Crib...Everything that four fellows couldpossibly require... A party of four ataGBP11 5s a head and everything complete (Dec 30, 1909,Otago Daily Times,10)

aGBP150 - Macandrew's Bay; 4-roomed Crib;aGBP65 another Crib. (Nov 1, 1919,Otago Daily Times,16)

[Advt] Wanted to let, 2-roomed FurnishedCrib, Brighton. (Nov 5, 1921,Otago Daily Times,11)

[Advt] Wanted, crib, at seaside for twomonths or longer; rent must bereasonable. (Jan 11, 1927,Otago Daily Times,14)

When the mater returned to Dunedin afterher holidays in this city, I determinedto try "baching," and after having beensix months in my crib at the top of thehill, I am more than ever resolved not todescend again to town level... My "bach"is perched.. about 7000ft above sea-level. (Oct 9, 1912,Otago Witness,79)

It became the focal point of crib life: our life-support system, camouflaged as a large white concrete water tank. (Feb 24, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),41)

Boock recently bought herself a littlehouse at Warrington where the familyowned a crib during her childhood. (Nov 11, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

In a way, Aramoana is closed tooutsiders. Its cribs, as these cottagesare known south of the Waitaki, circulateamongst insiders. (Mar 18, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

Then on to Oban for two nights at Ngahere, a genuine southern family crib, eccentric but comfortable. (Mar 24, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C13)

SMITH Cribs vary greatly in size and cost...You might have a modest crib built out of a couple of motor car cases... The ideas of a crib is to give you some place to go at the week-ends. (1947,From N to Z,132)

That meant that as children it became our place as well, first when in rented cribs - we lived well south of the Waitaki River, where cribs mysteriously became baches - and later in our own place, a small cinnamon-coloured cottage. (Jan 1, 1904,Dominion Post,C1)

HISLOP As for the old horse trams, which used to run about a mile past the present Normanby [Dunedin] terminus, several of them made their last run to many of our bonnie coastal camping grounds converted into real good cribs. (1943,Pure Gold,80)

GASKELL If it's fine George will be taking them up to his crib (1947,Big Game,88) [NOTES: [The reference is to Taupo-Taumaranui: but Gaskell comes from Invercargill] Also in 1947 Gaskell `School Picnic' in 1978 All Part of the Game 85]

BAXTER Or mowing lawns by the summer cribs of townsfolk. (1979,Collected Poems,80,1949 ed.)

F.M. O'BRIEN INVERCARGILL Crib: a batch at a beach; a whare. (Dec 28, 1950,Personal Communication)

While he had two young girls ... staying ... under his care at a crib beside Waituna Lagoon, Southland. (Nov 15, 1950,NZ Truth,11) [NOTES: [Dunedin Reporter]]

SINCLAIR [Colonial glossary] crib ... seaside cottage (1959,History of New Zealand,320)

DUCKWORTH Is Timothy in with Mrs Flint?'No, she's gone to her brother's crib for the weekend - up Central. ...' (1963,Barbarous Tongue, A,181)

[Cooper was a Newlands, Wellington, baby-farmer c1902] He told her she could occupy a `crib' on his place at Newlands, at a rent of 15/- a week. (Sep 29, 1964,NZ Truth,27)

DEMPSEY And we are apt to say, when speaking of a person who is away, that he is `off the Island'. If we are told that someone has gone over to the Other Side ... we understand he has gone to Invercargill or to Bluff. Where the North Islander talks of his beach cottage, or bach, we call these little places cribs, a much more euphonious name. (1964,Little World of Stewart island,6)

FRAME He ... had ... a crib round one of the newly fashionable [Dunedin] bays: half native bush, half sea-view. (1968,Rainbirds, The,112)

FRAME He ... had ... a crib round one of the newly fashionable [Dunedin] bays: half native bush, half sea-view. (1968,Rainbirds, The,112)

DAVIN Then back to the crib again, set off from the road in the bush. (1970,Not Here, Not Now,115)

DOWLING Far off, ... the majesty of Aspiring;/ At hand, campers and cribs, bathers, and boats for hiring. (1973,Unreturning Native,25) [NOTES: (`By Lake Wanaka')]

LELAND Crib. House of ... No, sorry. This term refers to a weekend cottage in South Island parlance. (see: bach, cot) (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,30)

crib ... 5. N.Z. a weekend cottage: term is South Island usage only. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,264) [NOTES: [cf. 1986 NZPOD 175; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 113]]

FRAME I looked with envy toward the place where the group sat, eagerly talking, shaking with laughter as they recounted what Mummy and Daddy had said and done during the weekend at the crib by the sea. (1982,To the Is-Land,168,1984 ed.)

GILDERDALE crib Holiday house. Used in the South Island as `bach' is in the North. (1982,Sea Change,240) [NOTES: P. Wardell's Hazard Island (1976) page 17.]

HULME At the cribs they light the lamps. (1982,Moeraki Conversations,38) [NOTES: The Silences Between]

Crib ... a weekend cottage' is annotated [in the Collins <i>Concise Dictionary</i>]term is South Island usage only'. This was strikingly demonstrated in the New Zealand Herald for July 4 this year, which ... quoted a report that used the word cribs' and translated it for the benefit of its Auckland readers as(cottages)'. (Aug 20, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),101)

McGILL ... Alan didn't have a bad life in Dunedin, probably because a good deal of it was out the point, at Puratanu. `I've got a wee crib there. Get over as often as I can. ... I've always liked the old shellfish, the gulls and herons. (1985,G'day Country,171)

Quest.2. 2. Is this dwelling 01 separate house ... 05 Bach, crib or hut (not in a work camp) 06 Caravan, cabin or tent in a motor camp. (1986,NZ Census of Population and Dwellings)

McGILL crib weekend or beach cottage in South Island; c.1862. - cut lunch on the West Coast of South Island, appearing as such in coalminer awards, moving with dam workers into Central Otago. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,32)

GLEN Jock closed the gears and began to edge slowly out of our Te Anau crib driveway. (1980,Bush in Our Yard,63)

Wanaka's first million-dollar crib sold last week ... (Aug 1, 2006,Dominion Post,A10)

Its coves are dotted with ramshackle cribs ("baches" for those north of the Waitaki)... (Jun 19, 2005,Sunday Star Times,Escape/9)

[Hdg] Cooper's Crib Crushed... Dreadful Dunedin Den (Feb 12, 1910,NZ Truth,5)

South of the Waitaki River, baches become cribs. (Jan 19, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

As a result of complains from the owners of the cribs at Tomahawk.. the police have been watching the locality. (Nov 23, 1920,Otago Witness,1)

FARRELL A crib tacked together from car casesand an old tram. (1992,Skinny Louie Book,171)

Blenheim. Where summers of the late-70's were spent digging garlic or picking apples and the highlight was the annual, week-long holiday at a friend's crib in the Marlborough Sounds where glorious hot days were spent fishing from the jetty and sweaty nights were spent raiding the host's secret stash of Playboy magazines. (Sep 19, 2010,Sunday Star Times: Escape,4)

Crib owning caught the public imagination early in the century. Ibid. Cribs are always warm and friendly places. Ibid. The term crib meaning a week-end cottage, originated in Otago, and the colloquialism is confined mainly to the South Island. (Jan 3, 1953,Evening Star,4)

CHAMIER He's looking for a crib to settle down; ain't you, Jim? Ibid. 177 I was welcomed like the prodigal son, hugged all round, installed in my old crib, and made drunk every night. (1891,Philosopher Dick,114)

HULME & MORRISON It's the crib I'm kaitiaki for, guardian of & caretaker to: Bill and his mate.Ibid. 67 Other cribs fared worse: two were wrecked entirely, and have never been rebuilt. (1989,Homeplaces,66)

1 n. (Rural) a packed or paddock lunch, eaten at work-site.

Richards When Dad was chopping in the bush and not too far away, Pud and I would often take his crib out to him. This would usually consist of hot scones, hot pie and bread. The food would be placed on a tin plate, then carried in a tea towel tied together at the four corners to form a convenient grip or handle. (1991,Off the Sheep's Back,30)

Richards Each time we stopped for crib, the bush which we had just felled would be alive with sound. (1991,Off the Sheep's Back,62)

3 n. (?A villa' ordetached' accommodation at a southern mental hospital or an isolated seaside bach.)

... a mental expert ... ordered her removal to a quiet seaside resort, under the care of a mental nurse. As the crib which was taken for our habitation was built facing a river with the ocean to one side, and the bush behind, one can realise the opportunities afforded to one who was admittedly `tired of life' ... (1912,Kai Tiaki,59)

6 v. of a trial sheep dog

NEWTON This dog had many successes, but he had one habit that Charlie couldn't abide. He was inclined to crib - a habit which was often his undoing. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,67)

crib bag¶

n. a tucker bag

RICHARDS [To our British teacher] a paddock was now a field, our tucker or crib bags (made out of sugar bags) became satchels or lunch bags and our oilskin coats became macs. We preferred to retain our bush language. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,38)

crib box¶

n. a lunch box, cf. crib tin

HUTCHINSON Men, coming off and going on shift [at Thames mines, carrying their crib-boxes, met them. (1971,Forbidden Marriage,49)

crib cuddy¶

n. (See cuddy)

McARA Crib cuddy: A warm dry disused underground working used as a place where miners could have their meals. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),317)

RICHARDS The miners always carried their food (crib) to work in a specially designed tin box called a crib tin, together with an enamelled tea billy equipped with a drinking mug. The crib tin was necessary in the damp conditions because the mine was overrun with rats as big as bulldogs. The miners looked for a dry spot in a worked-out section of tunnel in which to leave their gear. This was known as the `crib cuddy'. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,5)

Two of the tunnellers were interested enough to chalk up on the walls of the "crib-cuddy," where the mid-shift lunches were eaten, account of progress made. (Feb 10, 1940,Otago Daily Times,12)

crib hut¶

n. as crib shed

KEINZLY `Didn't I tell you blokes a man needs drink to live?' The crib hut laughed and Janiss went back out to the truck. (1960,Tangahano,124)

The Union terms were set out as follows:- 1) The crib tables ... to be cleaned up ... 3) The crib huts walled-in or crib huts provided in place of tables. (Mar 9, 1968,Manapouri Power Project) [NOTES: 1968 Mar 9 TS Report of Industrial Relations Manager on a Work Stoppage at Manapouri Power Project (p2) (MOW 92/12/70/5)]

crib log hut¶

n. a crib or hut

LYON It was after the foregoing incident that [the two diggers] occupied a on the hillside leading to the mine they worked [120 miles from Nelson]. (1952,Faring South,173) [NOTES: occupied a crib log hut? check citation]

crib room¶

n. a lunch room at a worksite

I grip my thick, whitebait pattie sandwich and try not to think about the rats that are now the most regular visitors to the 'crib room' I'm sitting in. (May 9, 2006,NZ Herald,D6)

NICHOLAS RANSOM At the Tiwai Aluminium Smelter, Invercargill, a place provided for a crib [n2] to be eaten. (Nov 21, 1985,Personal Communication)

crib shed¶

n. for eating cribs in

... the Union Secretary, on behalf of carpenters and associated workers in the Machine Hall, that unless the Company provided properly closed-in crib sheds, washing facilities, and additional toilets ... the men ... would refuse to work there (Mar 9, 1968,Manapouri Power Project) [NOTES: 1968 Mar 9 TS Report of Industrial Relations Manager on a Work Stoppage at Manapouri Power Project (MOW 92/12/70/5)]

crib table¶

n.

The Union was advised that the Company did not propose to provide an alternative to the crib tables currently being used as these had been approved by the Mines Inspector.... the clean up and disinfecting of the crib tables ... would be put in hand as soon as work resumed. (Mar 9, 1968,Manapouri Power Project) [NOTES: 1968 Mar 9 TS Report of Industrial Relations Manager on a Work Stoppage at Manapouri Power Project (MOW 92/12/70/5)]

crib time¶

n. a meal-time; lunch-time; smoko.

[Auckland (Waihi) Gold-Miners] That theweek's work consist of forty-six hoursfor men working day-shifts and afternoon-shift, and forty-seven hours for menworking night-shift, including crib-time. (1901,Awards etc.,II.74) [NOTES: 1901 award]

LOCKE The miners complained that the company allowed only fifteen minutes "crib-time" in which to eat their lunch. (1984,Kauri & The Willow, The,137)

I had arrived at crib time - smoko - so the mining machines were silent. (Jul 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 68/40)

Along with 120 other miners, they [sc. Bob Semple and Paddy Webb] went on strike for three months to get their "crib time" (lunch break) extended from 15 minutes to half an hour. (Sep 21, 1999,Dominion,9)

Michael King After three months the employers [at Blackball in 1908] relented. They increased 'crib-time' to half an hour and reinstated miners who had been dismissed for organising the strike. (2003,Penguin History of New Zealand,270)

HENDERSON CRIB TIME: Meal time at quartz and coal mines. (1961,Friends in Chains,185) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 185]

Half an hour's `crib' time [at Blackball, NZ] is also granted. (May 13, 1908,Western Gazette,6/1) [NOTES: [OED2]]

A gentleman invented a musical syren [sic] in Coromandel fourteen years ago, and induced the management of a local gold mine to give it a trial. Afterwards the three shifts started and knocked off [sic] the tunes of Annie Rooney,'Ben Bolt,' and What-o! She Bumps!' and crib time was signalised withTa-ra-ra-boom-de-ay.' (Aug 27, 1910,NZ Truth,270/1/4)

The shot firer charges the hole. He does it during crib time; even he would have to hurry if there were a number of holes to be fired. (Nov 3, 1911,Maoriland Worker,35/5/3)

HICKEY .. the fine ... arising out of the `crib' - time incident. (1925,Red Fed. Memoirs,15)

HOGAN Miners [at Waihi] are a knowledgeable clan and down below at crib time discussions took place that would have done credit to the back-room boys ... (1962,Billy-Can Ballads,2) [NOTES: [at Waihi mines]]

PEARSON Just before crib-time the manager came by. (1963,Coal Flat,207)

3(c) ... a worker shall not be required to work more than five hours continuously without being granted a break for a meal or supper or crib.... (e) When a worker is working overtime, supper and crib-time shall be paid for at the rate appropriate to the time.... 4(b) ... eight hours inclusive of half an hour for crib, shall constitute a day's work in tunnels ... (Apr 12, 1967,Manapouri Power Project) [NOTES: 1967 Apr 12 Manapouri Power Project Employees' Industrial Agreement (Schedule) [TS] [miners' and tunnellers']]

THOMPSON And there was an inseparable Maori duo ... who, emerging unhurt from a fall of coal ..., added yet another story to the folklore which the miners loved to bring out at crib-time and embroider like Irish wives. (1980,All My Lives,41)

BUCKLEY It was the [Cornish] working-man's lunch ... slipped into his pocket to keep warm until `crib-time' at noon. [sc. by miners] (1983,Of Toffs and Toilers,38) [NOTES: [? a Cornish word. Check]]

BEARDSLEY Crib time, it's a real grievance inBlackball. (1984,Blackball 08,30)

HENDERSON With the exception of crib time, I saw little of my mates until we knocked off. (1961,Friends in Chains,30)

crib tin¶

n. a (cut-)lunch tin

DEVANNY We stopped ... to hang up his towel and crib tin. (1929,Dawn Beloved,273) [NOTES: (West Coast)]

PEARSON There were a dozen familiar faces of miners on their way home, in rough clothes, their sugar-bags and crib-tins laid on a bench. (1963,Coal Flat,17)

TURNER Crib has a special meaning on the West Coast to mean a miner's lunch. A crib tin is a lunch tin. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,178)

THOMPSON Opening my father's crib-tin and eating the treasured sandwich he always left there when he came home after work. Playing with his miner's helmet ... (1980,All My Lives,33) [NOTES: [West Coast, Runanga]]

RICHARDS The miners always carried their food (crib) to work in a specially designed tin box called a crib tin, together with an enamelled tea billy equipped with a drinking mug. The crib tin was necessary in the damp conditionsm because the mine was overrun with rats as big as bulldogs. The miners looked for a dry spot in a worked-out section of tunnel in which to leave their gear. This was known as the `crib cuddy'. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,5)

crib wall¶

n. a supporting wall constructed of crossed pieces of timber (cribs); by extension to concrete crib walls; NZ a type of retaining wall used to hold up earth banks [a trademark]. [Collins tags this compound as NZ]

?a trademark (1979,Heinemann NZ Dictionary,251)

cribbie¶

n. shortened form of "crib-owner"; a person who owns or uses a crib [definition from Orsman data.]

"Are you a local?" Uncertainty clouded his brow. "I'm a cribbie," he explained. "My family have had a crib down near the heads for 60 years."... there was a case recently where a lease was not renewed and the cribbie lost everything. (Jan 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/28)

Karitane, Otago, New Zealand, nestles between rolling foothills and the sea, some 40 kilometres north of Dunedin. ... During the summer months `cribbies', as the holiday vacationers who spend time in their little cottages are termed, swells the small population of permanent residents. (1985,Postcard) [NOTES: Karitane postcard]

Although cribbies have been here along time, this palls in comparison with their Ngai Tahu landlords... (Jun 19, 2005,Sunday Star Times,Escape/9)

cricket¶

n. cicada

McLINTOCK Cricket or Cicada - kihikihi kai, etc., Melampsalta sp(p) (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

Cricket Max¶

n. a short-lived version of one-day cricket developed in NZ (superseded by Twenty20)

[Hdg] Twose key man in max international... New Zealand coach David Trist will rely on the ideas and knowledge of captain Roger Twose for today's max cricket international against the West Indies... For the West Indies it will be their first experience of max. They had a session with its originator Martin Crowe yesterday to familiarise themselves with the rules. (Dec 3, 1999,Dominion,22)

One pleasing aspect of this summer's sport has been the apparent demise of Cricket Max. (Jan 24, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),37)

A series of international matches in the short, designed-for-television game of Cricket Max featured New Zealand's Max Blacks, and in men's test cricket the Black Caps (named for that traditional item of their on-field attire) took over to most supporters' relief from the recently less than explosive Young Guns. (Jan 1999,NZWords,5)

For my money, it's too like that dreadful cricket max that thankfully has disappeared without trace. (Jul 6, 2004,Independent Herald (Wellington),15)

crikey dick¶

exclam. [(1838) nf OED2, P8.]-->1951 14 M 14 St Bede's, Chch 5 CRIKEY DICK -->1953 15 M A27 Thames DHS 5 CRIKEY DICK -->1953 16 M A31 Thames DHS 5 CRIKEY HOLY COW -->1960 16C F B4 Wanganui Girls C. 5 CRICKEY DICK -->1960 17C F B9 Wanganui Girls C.G 5 CRIKEY DICK ! -->]

HENDERSON Crikey-dick, what a road this is. (1967,Return to Open Country,118)

But crikey dick mate, how d'ya learn to speak real if you can't shout a jug and talk to genuine Kiwis in the first place? (Nov 26, 2002,Dominion Post,B4)

HUNT I've always liked the bush. Crikey Dick, it was my job. (1981,Speaking a Silence,100)

(Jun 29, 1976,Evening Post,14/4-5-6 (4))

HALL Crikey dick if the load of four be twosand pinex didn't arrive. (1980,Prisoner of Mother England,21)

McGEE A man can take a joke as good as the rest, but crikey dick, that's a bit - (on the nose). (1981,Foreskin's Lament,33)

crim¶

n. a (convicted) criminal

LELAND A crim is a CRIMINAL, this term is used by police, social workers, prison officers, criminals, etc. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,30)

BEATON DI: ... They make good crims most of them. They've got guts! (1984,Outside In,102)

There were 70 people [in Oakley mental hospital]; the majority of those were crims, most were stir-crazy. ... The Whare Paia got the M3 dregs, not much improved from Savage's day. (Jun 18, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

McGill Maybe she was misjudging him. Maybe not. He had to be some kind of a crim, owning all that. (1995,Gold in the Creek,179)

crime¶

n. an offence for which the offender may be proceeded against by indictment [Jim Cameron writes: Many dictionary definitions of crime/offence are loose, overlapping and sometimes circular, reflecting general usage. But in NZ they also have a precise legal meaning... The definition of a crime is thus procedural, although approximately a crime = a serious offence. See Crimes Act 1961 s2 - the definitions date from the Criminal Code Act 1893.] (See summary offence)

Crimean shirt¶

n. a long, usu. blue, flannel shirt, a kind of early bush shirt, as part of the early colonial outdoors costume (See cf. Garibaldi shirt,bluey)

A Crimean shirt, very much discoloured,reaching nearly to his knees,supplemented by a rough flax mat abouthis shoulders, is all the old patricianwill deign to wear. (Jan 23, 1896,Otago Witness,42)

[Advt] Thirty-one Packages of Soft Goods,viz:- Crimean Shirts, Pilot Jackets,Blankets, Kersey Drawers. (Jan 4, 1865,Otago Daily Times,3)

HODDER [sic p1 notes] (1862,Memories of NZ Life,?137)

) [sic p1 notes] (Nov 11, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,152,1950 ed.)

When I was at Canvastown my clothes [included] ... 2 Crimean shirts (one on, and the other in the swag). (1866,Maungatapu Murders,45)

The men's dress of the 70's and 80's was usually composed of rough working clothes ... A heavy grey twill Crimean shirt with a red bandana handkerchief was tied around the neck ... (1914,History of North Otago,130,1978 ed.) [NOTES: [c1870s] 1914 History of North Otago (1978) 130]

SATCHELL He wore a blue Crimea shirt, open at the throat. (1902,Land of the Lost,14)

He came down for breakfast that morning dressed in.. a soft wideawake hat, a Crimean shirt... If you take my advice you will change your Crimean for a white shirt. (Jan 1, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,23)

crimino¶

n. criminal [ca1941-5 Prison (Riverside Community) Crim or crimino used for those on criminal charges]

crimmo¶

n. criminal

McKAY `Everybody knows that the Jerusalem community is a bank of weirdos, no-hopers, drop-outs, mad people, crimmos, thieves and junkies ...' (1990,James K. Baxter,264) [NOTES: 1972 Jerusalem Daybook 42 in 1990 McKay James K. Baxter 264]

crimp¶

v. to entice seamen off ships to become farm labourers.

... I cannot ... consent to allow another of Her Majesty's ships to be stationed at Wellington, so long as the crimping which prevails there both for the Sheep Farms and the Coasting Trade is allowed to remain on its present footing. (Feb 19, 1861,AJHR,D-9) [NOTES: 1861 Feb 19 Commodore F.Beauchamp Seymour, HMS Pelorus, Auckland to Colonel Gore Browne Appendices to the Journals 1861 D-9 [????] (Griffiths Collection)]

... the disgraceful system of crimping which the inefficient Police of Auckland seem powerless to check. (Apr 18, 1862,AJHR,D-5) [NOTES: 1862 Apr 18 Seymour to Sir George Grey Appendices to the Journals 1861 D-5 (Griffiths Collection)]

(Griffiths Collection) ... I believe `crimping', in its proper light, is not known in the Province. Many of the bush settlers have, it is true, been deluded by these runaways, who describe themselves as newly-arrived immigrants. It is a certainty, too, that the sailors require no enticing .. (May 23, 1862,AJHR,D-5) [NOTES: 1862 May 23 James Naughton, Commissioner of Police, Auckland Appendices to the Journals D-5]

... system of crimping on the part of the employers of labour - owners of sheep runs in particular. ... They must first escape the control of their own Officers before they can fall under that of the crimps ... (1862,AJHR,D-5) [NOTES: 1862 William Fox Memorandum Appendices to the Journals D-5 (Griffiths Collection)]

v. to crimp [a fuse] [a detonator] to put a crimp in it, cf crimper 2f. crimper, crimping tool; nf OED; W3 check.]

v.

BOWEN There are several known styles of shearing. They range from the old blade method of stretching the sheep and shearing more round and round, to the modern method of dumping or crimping the sheep and following the blows right through more along the body of the sheep; ... (1955,Wool Away!,5)

n. of wool

Shelley sorts the fleeces according to the length and feel of the fibres, the frequency of the crimps and the amount of foreign matter in the wool. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/84)

n. ?swindling go-between; dishonest broker.

As was to have been expected, that crimp of corrupt capitalism, Clemenceau the French Premier, has, after the manner of his kind, climbed down in the most cowardly fashion. (Jul 20, 1907,NZ Truth,109/4/5)

He admitted taking Krause and another German to Zimmer's German hashhouse at 2 a.m. and letting them in by the back door and providing accommodation for them. ... Counsel alleged that Buhler was a crimp, but the `Square-head' was discreetly unintelligent and nothing could be got from him. (Jan 29, 1910,NZ Truth,240/7/4)

1 v. (Rural) [shearing] to squeeze or dump sheep.

BOWEN They [styles of shearing] range from the old blade method of stretching the sheep and shearing more round and round, to the modern method of dumping, or crimping the sheep and following the blows right through more along the body of the sheep. (1955,Wool Away!,5)

crimped¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of fleecewool] undulating and ribbed.

Well-covered sheep with dense, soft-handling, good crimped wool. (Jan 1, 1929,NZ Farmer,52)

The Hui Hui Corriedales are big clippers of superior Corriedale wool - well crimped from skin to tip. (1929,NZ Farmer,59)

The ideal to be aimed at is a long, well-grown 'meaty' staple, even and clearly crimped over the whole fleece. (Oct 11, 1951,NZ Farmer,8)

crimson¶

adj. as a distinguishing epithet in names of plants, see clianthus, rata, manuka.

crimson cleaner¶

n. a fish

PAUL Crimson cleaner Suezichthys sp. ... Most obtain their food by cleaning other fishes. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,109)

crimson kowhai¶

n. = red kowhai

FEATON Kowhai-ngutu-kaka [Maori name] .. Crimson Kowhai [Settlers' name] .. Clianthus puniceus .. Shrub (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,177)
