Leptospermum Nichollsii crimson-flowered manuka (1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue) [NOTES: (And)]

Leptospermum Nichollsii crimson manuka (1916,NZ Association of Nurserymen, Trade Register) [NOTES: (And)]

crimson mistletoe¶

n. = scarlet mistletoe

Our first excursion was through ... beech forest in which we noted ... the gorgeous crimson mistletoe, and up ... to a height of 4,100 feet to the first of the Edelweiss. (1891,NZ Journal of Science,1/202)

cringie¶

adj. showing (cultural) cringe

How cringie is that? We give prominence to an overseas journalist above the response of the 2 million people who have visited the museum. (Feb 13, 1999,Evening Post,10)

crinkle cuts¶

n. short for crinkle-cut chips

Rumours circulate constantly about who gives the most chips, who pees in the fat and who has "crinkle cuts". (Dec 1996,North & South,43)

crispies¶

n. a biscuit

BASHAM CRISPIES ... Mix together flour, cocoanut, rolled oats, and sugar. Melt butter and syrup, and mix with the soda ... bake ... (1939,Aunt Daisy's Cookery Book,111)

criss-cross¶

n. a crossbred produced after a period of using each of the two parent breeds alternately (check Ag gloss).

croak it¶

v. to die

He had also earlier shouted "Ring the brother, tell him she' croaked it, she's toes up." (Mar 9, 2001,Dominion,3)

CROC¶

abbr. Crown-Owned Company [ORIGIN: acronym, Heard on TV1 news, 26/06/2001]

Last week TVNZ became that much harder for any future share-holding minister to sell, with the decision to remove it from the act and set it up as a crown-owned company under its own legislation. (Jul 1, 2001,Sunday Star Times,C2)

The service is expected to be run as a Crown-Owned Company (Croc) with a board of a minority of Government appointees. (Jul 23, 2001,Evening Post,3)

The TVNZ Bill would turn it from a profit-oriented SOE into the unfortunately acronymed Crown Owned Company (Croc), run commercially, but with cultural and social obligations. (Feb 1, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

Technically, SOEs can't die. They either get sold, or they reincarnate into CrOCs - Crown-Owned Companies. (That acronym should really be COCs, but gentility mandated an extra "r".)... Potentially, a CrOC could require government funding every year, just like a government department. TVNZ is the first to be reborn as a CrOC. And in NZ Post's current state, both financially and administratively, the only way to excuse its condition will be to at least pretend that it's more of a CrOC than an SOE. (Jul 14, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

TVNZ is a CROC - a crown-owned company (Dec 15, 2004,TV1)

croc¶

n. a chain (crocodile) of walking schoolchildren, esp. girls.

HENDERSON The reverend mother opened the street door and there were the girls drawn up in a long procession, two and two. A crocodile' was a new thing to us.This is Susan,' said the reverend mother to the `crock', which replied simultaneously ... (1948,Taina,158)

WILSON We [school-girls] were taken for walks in `croc' as was usual. (1950,My First 80 Years,88) [NOTES: [c1880]]

CrOCing¶

n. turning (a company) into a CROC q.v.

The government can do without any further revving on this front, as its CrOCing of TVNZ is already financially delicate. (Jul 14, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

crock¶

n.

N.C.C. SMALL At Wanganui Collegiate School when a boy was officially excused from organised games or exercise he was said to be on crock', and acrock-form' (an official specification of the exercise permitted) had to be filled in and signed by the school-doctor. (1930,Personal Communication) [NOTES: ca1930 p.c.(Wellington 1951)]

crocked¶

adj. drunk

He's obviously crocked to the eyebrows on vino. (Jan 31, 1944,NZEF Times,III/136 : 7)

crocodiles' tears¶

n. raw, fiery liquor [cf. camels' bile, purple death, rooster's blood]

He should be able to hold his liquor ... even Purple Death [Crocodiles' Tears and Camels' Bile] (1946,Johnny Enzed in Italy,53)

croisssantisation¶

n.

The original destination for Pacific migrants, Ponsonby, is now latte heaven as croissantisation (the arrival of the French bakery in the neighbourhood) reflects the growing affluence of the locals. (Nov 2003,Massey,No. 15/15)

Cromwell chafer beetle¶

n. (Environment) an endangered flightless beetle, Prodontria lewisi , endemic to Central Otago.

Adult Cromwell chafer beetles ( Prodontria lewisi ) from the Cromwell area were investigated for sex-specific morphological variation. (1999,Conservation Advisory Science Notes,227/1)

The flightless Cromwell chafer beetle (Prodontria lewisii ) is restricted to a small area near Cromwell in Central Otago. The adults live in shallow, loamy sands, emerging at night during spring and summer to eat plants and lichens. (Nov 5, 2007,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.teara.govt.nz/The Bush/InsectsAnd OtherInvertebrates/Beetles/en]

The approved management plan for the reserve has as its primary objective the conservation of the Cromwell chafer beetle (Department of Lands and Survey 1985). (2000,NZ Journal of Botany,38/242)

In what was probably a world first, a reserve was set up in 1979 to protect the rare Cromwell chafer beetle ( Prodontria lewisi ). (Nov 2007,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.teara.govt.nz/The Bush/InsectsAndOtherInvertebrates/Beetles/5/en]

The Cromwell chafer beetle is adapted to a special inland dune habitat, which is also home to a number of other unusual plants and animals. (2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/about-doc/concessions-and-permits/conservation-revealed/central-otago-plants-animals-lowres.pdf]

The most well-known of these is the Cromwell chafer beetle, which was first discovered in 1903 in the sand dunes around Cromwell. (2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/about-doc/concessions-and-permits/conservation-revealed/central-otago-plants-animals-lowres.pdf]

Cromwell gecko¶

n. a common species of gecko found in the schist country of Otago. [Hoplodactylus "Cromwell" aka Kawarau gecko]

Further away from Lake Wanaka, beyond the knownrange of the Southern Alps gecko, the Cromwell geckobecomes more variable, and may have a greenishcolouring in the eye. (Jan 2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/otagogeckosa.pdf]

The southern limit of distribution for the Cromwell gecko isin the Shotover River catchment and Kawerau Gorge. (Jul 2002,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.conservation.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/OCLizards.pdf]

Cromwell gecko Hoplodactylus aff. maculatusCromwellWidespread and abundant on theCarrick Range and Bannockburnbelow 1000 m altitude. (Jun 2004,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.linz.govt.nz/docs/crownproperty/high-country-leases/leaselist/carrick-crr-pt-1.pdf]

Cronje¶

n. (See Cunning Joe)

cronk¶

adj. Ill, unwell, infirm (of men and animals, esp. horses).

P.S. ARDERN I don't remember hearing cronk after my schooldays (which ended in 1899), nor with any other sense than `ill'. I suggest a derivation from a Yiddish pronunciation of Ger krank [as does Morris]. (1899,Personal Communication) [NOTES: (Auckland)]

Eventually he took ill and died ... and before his death he was in a very cronk state, being practically [comatose]. (Mar 17, 1906,NZ Truth,39/3/4) [NOTES: [Christchurch corresp.]]

Cronk: Ill, not at all well. (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

cronk a. cranky; unsteady; of race-horses, unfit to run;-sl. dishonestly obtained. [Ger. krank, sick, ill] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3)

BAKER Cronk, sick, worthless, or illegal. (1941,NZ Slang,62) [NOTES: [Australian borrowings]]

cronk adj. (Sl.) ill, unwell, worthless, out of order, originally applied to dishonest horse-racing or prize-fighting v.t. cronk up, fail in health. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

McGILL cronk ill; originally among shearers; since 1880s of a horse made to appear ill to cheat its backers; from German `krank', ill. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,32)

2 adj. crooked, counterfeit, spurious

... whoever takes these cronk coins. (Sep 2, 1905,NZ Truth,11/5/6)

Yet this stuff [a patent medicine] is sold throughout the Commonwealth as the genuine article, and every week you will see it advertised in big type, and backed up with a lot of cronk testimonials. (Aug 4, 1906,NZ Truth,59/8/4)

... getting a good fiver for a cronk tenner. (Sep 8, 1906,NZ Truth,64/3/3)

3 adj. bad, inferior, worthless, etc.

And the financing of the Bank of New Zealand has been the cronkest thing in financial history (Jun 24, 1905,NZ Truth,1/1/1)

... so many sly grog shops about ladling out kronk stuff warranted to kill at a thousand yards. (Sep 9, 1905,NZ Truth,12/8/4)

.. the swindling wool-kings of the Canterbury Plains who make up cronk bales of wool and palm them off ... as the best ... they fill up the centre with dags. (Sep 23, 1905,NZ Truth,14/5/1)

The Public Works Committee ought to drive this cronk notion out of their brain-boxes for good. (Oct 7, 1905,NZ Truth,16/5/6)

... writing to the local paper, some cronk-craniumed cove ... (Nov 4, 1905,NZ Truth,20/4/4)

Cronk catering a matter for the Minister of Railways. (Jan 26, 1906,NZ Truth,4)

crook¶

n. a dipping crutch for holding sheep under the surface of the dip

SHARPE When a sheep [in the dip] has swum past a man who pushes its head under with an instrument called a crook, it can walk ... out of the far end. (1962,Country Occasions,70)

n. a naturally in-curved piece of timbe

SANSOM It was an established custom to go out looking for crooks in the bush. `Crook' is a word that needs some defining. It can be a rogue, or in this case, a natural bend from either a suitable broadleaf or totara tree. ... A planned new dinghy or fishing boat would begin with the procuring of a natural bend or crook from the bush. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,36)

MASSEY Crook A tree trunk with a natural curve.(Noun) To warp longitudinally in board form.(Verb) (1987,Woodturning in New Zealand,93)

adj. ill, sick

If the New Zealand health sector were a hospital patient, it would probably be in the ward for the chronically crook. (Aug 10, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

I've just been vaccinated, and am feeling pretty crook. (Dec 1916,Oil Sheet Transport Magazine,7)

MARSH ... he kidded he felt crook. Ibid. 116 He was looking horribly crook.'Ill?' asked Alleyn cautiously. `Too right, sir.' (1937,Vintage Murder,94)

HISLOP I am feeling pretty crook today, Jimmy, and I am going to get a tooth out. Can you lay me on to a good dentist. (1943,Pure Gold,32)

DAVIN Poor old Frank. He's not what he was.' `Yes, he looks bloody crook.' (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,199)

Crook - ill, bad. To feel crook, to feel ill. A crook boss, a bad employer. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,39)

SOLJAK Following are examples of colloquialisms common to New Zealand and Australian English, with their English or American equivalent ... crook: ill, angry or bad; to feel crook: to feel ill (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),115)

BALLANTYNE He felt crook again, remembered the old tart hitting him with a broom, the kids watching. (1948,Cunninghams, The,28,1976 ed.)

PARK `Come on, Dig, feeling crook, eh? Come on round to my dump,' said Mr Solivich. (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,140)

HAMILTON I didn't realise how fond I'd become of Phil ... and it made me feel really crook. (1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,80)

BACON crook-To feel crook is to feel unwell; to be pretty crook is to be extremely ill. (1963,In the Sticks,180)

McCALLUM All these say they rather stay in bed 'cause they all feel so crook. (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,9)

SHADBOLT ... What the hell's the matter with you.[sic] Your leg still crook?' ...I still feel crook,' I said. (1965,Among the Cinders,80)

crook adj. (Sl.) sick, bad, inferior; (Phr.) to feel crook, to feel ill; go crook on, become annoyed with, upbraid. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6) [NOTES: Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 266; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 113]

MARSH `Take the dog. ... The boss give it to her. Well, it goes crook and they get a vet and he reckons it's hopeless and it ought to be put out of its misery. So she goes crook. Screechin' and moanin', ...' (1980,Photo-Finish,31)

WILSON It made me feel pretty crook when she told me ... (1976,Pacific Star,136)

crook ... 3 a. NZ & Austral. ill, out of sorts (John felt pretty crook); (of thing) unsatisfactory, out of order (things went crook from the beginning, the engine sounds crook to me). 4. go crook (at) NZ & Austral. be angry (with), speak angrily (to). (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,176)

VIRTUE He thought she might be a bit shook about Aunt Melva, who was crook. (1987,Redemption of Elsdon Bird, The,4,1988 ed.)

He gave me some extra money, so I went to the milkbar and bought a gobstopper and some other lollies. I stuffed my face, and felt crook all the way home. (1988,University Entrance Board Bursaries Exam,6)

McCALLUM The boss who owns the big flash Jaguar looks plurry crook because the production manager has just bought the Cadillac. (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,53)

adj. sick, useless

A man up here a week before me told methat his wife got only aGBP1 a week from theP.W.D. when she went up, so if they offeryou that you go crook. (Oct 23, 1935,Christchurch Star-Sun,8)

When you're crook, what you want around you is a feeling of positiveness. (Nov 28, 2000,Evening Post,2)

IHIMAERA & LONG (ed.) 'Please Miss, he's got a crook guts'... 'You mean sore stomach, don't you?' (1982,Into the World of Light,109)

"Can you assure me," I can hear some Taiwanese tycoon asking Simon Upton, "that in order to safeguard my profit margin, enough Kiwis will continue to get, as you say, crook?" (May 4, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

They were ignominiously herded in, protesting the while in lurid language against what they termed "a crook trick". Ibid. 150 We had a crook spin. (1916,On the Anzac Trail,44)

I was on sick parade with a toe that looked as if it was going to go crook. (Jul 19, 1943,NZEF Times,III/108 : 5)

Under managed care, caring for crook patients becomes a cost (rather than an income) to the doctor. (Oct 21, 1998,Evening Post,13)

A crook back made him quit in 1996. (Feb 1998,Mana,No. 20: 34)

They had to "go crook" - to appease wounded pride. (Nov 24, 1938,NZ Observer,8)

'You've got to come home with me.. Dip's crook.' (1975,Islands,4(2) : 143)

MACDONALD That awful word "crook" - how they loved it. It was "Sister, me arm's crook"; or "Gee, I've come over all crook." (1945,Away from Home,15)

"Look out, Bill [Massey], Jerry's over and we're in a crook possie here!" (May 15, 1923,Aussie (NZ Section),I)

I was feeling a bit crook; effects of the vaccination, whirling brain, etc. (Feb 4, 1916,Patea & Waverly Press,2)

"Your cam sensor's a bit crook." (Mar 3, 2001,Dominion,22)

Kupu Vanisi is returning home, his crook knee ruling him out of Sunday's game. (Mar 16, 2001,Evening Post,28)

"He was quite crook when he arrived here but he's recovered nicely." (Sep 16, 2000,Dominion,2)

"I went out for dinner with some people and I had the symptoms of a cold, but I didn't even get to the entree I felt so crook." (Jun 16, 2003,Dominion Post,A10)

All the rooks on the course declared that a crook one had come to light and were laughing in consequence, but their joy was short lived, for when they returned to the Empire City, they found an S.P. commissioner had been at work and depleted their coffers of several hundred pounds. (Apr 18, 1908,NZ Truth,148/2/6)

I thought the phone line was a bit crook. (May 16, 1993,Sunday Star (Auckland),B-3)

Can you assure me.. that in order to safeguard my profit margin, enough Kiwis will continue to get, as you say, crook? (May 4, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

"It's what we did for 15 years when I was a little kid until I was a teenager, then Bill got real crook." (Jan 19, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

The poor plucked pigeon of a punter.. imagines he is capable of holding his own against the "smarties" who take up "crook" pony racing as a livelihood. (Jan 15, 1910,NZ Truth,5)

McCarthy is a dyed-in-the-wool member of the National Party.. but he believes the Nats are going to be very crook indeed if they don't see their rural vote is evaporating. (Mar 6, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

Some "crook" totalisator tickets got intocirculation at the Hastings racesyesterday. (Oct 9, 1919,Hawke's Bay Herald,5)

[Hdg] Minister taken down. Did aGBP200 in crook tourist business. (Feb 14, 1934,NZ Truth,9)

"Soldier, didn't you notice my uniform?" Recruit: "Yes, it's crook all right, but look at what they gave me." (Dec 22, 1941,NZEF Times,I/26 : 24)

n. a broken-down horse

MITCHELL I then did horsey dealings,/ On my own particular hook,/ And sore against my feelings/ Put a blind one into cruck. (1889,Rhymes and Rambles,30 ed.)

adj. bad, inferior; out of order, unsatisfactory; unpleasant, dreadful

Krook or Kronk is bad. (Dec 17, 1898,Sydney Bulletin,Red p. 2)

WILLIS (1933,Anzac Memory,4/62) [NOTES: 1933]

WILLIS (1933,Anzac Memory,4/62) [NOTES: 1915]

HENDERSON A cigarette first thing in the morning, before a cup of tea, tastes crook. (1945,Gunner Inglorious,24)

adj. in various senses of bad, in performance, appearance, honesty, or health; cf cronk but not `angry', cp crook av.

MARSH Crook' meansill', angry', orunscrupulous' according to the context. (1937,Vintage Murder,174)

Crook' might present difficulty, since its use here has no reference to criminal.Crook' as an adjective signifies bad',ill'. Thus we have crook weather',feel crook' and `to go crook', which latter means to be rude or lose one's temper. (1945,NZ Geographer,19) [NOTES: (Cumberland)]

SYDER & HODGETTS Wrong, unsatisfactory, ailing. .in 4;Look at this, mortar's crumbling, this brickwork's a crook job.'We struck some crook weather, even the Norwegians complained about the cold.' `He's got a crook back - it's no use asking him to lift any heavy weight while his back's bad.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],231)

adj. ill, sick (esp. to be a bit crook; feel, get crook).

MILLER Crook with dysentery all day - (1939,Camps, Tramps and Trenches,42) [NOTES: 1917 Mar 20 in 1939 Miller Camps Tracks and Trenches 42]

SMYTH You're a bit crook about the eyes. (1929,Girl from Mason Creek, The,52)

Crook: Same as cronk, [`ill, not at all well'] but less so, perhaps. Often a bit crook. Both these words are slang. Here, they are applied to men, dogs and horses. (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

BENNETT A man who is crook is ill. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,90)

Crook - ill, bad. To feel crook, to feel ill. A crook boss, a bad employer. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,39)

SOLJAK Following are examples of colloquialisms common to New Zealand and Australian English, with their English or American equivalent ... crook: ill, angry or bad; to feel crook: to feel ill (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),115)

BALLANTYNE [He] wasn't feeble-minded because he was crook. ... Maybe he'd feel better by Christmas. (1948,Cunninghams, The,60,1976 ed.)

SARGESON ... I suppose you blokes get told a lot of yarns about a crook missus and a swag of kids. All right mate, I'll tell you the trouble fair dinkum, only it's just between you and me - see? (1949,I Saw in My Dream,67,(1974 ed Rhodes) ed.)

SLATTER I wasn't there. I was out crook at the time (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,34)

HILLIARD Boy, you were sure out to it. I thought at the time, `By crikey, I bet she's crook tomorrow.' (1960,Maori Girl,124)

BACON crook-To feel crook is to feel unwell; to be pretty crook is to be extremely ill. (1963,In the Sticks,180)

crook adj. (Sl.) sick, bad, inferior; (Phr.) to feel crook, to feel ill; go crook on, become annoyed with, upbraid. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6) [NOTES: [Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 266; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 113]]

HASCOMBE One man asked, Are they both crook, then?' ...One is very tired and the other not too well.' `Two cot-cases - that's what I meant,' he said. (1969,Down and Almost Under,123)

MITCHELL crook: State of health after eating local food. (1972,Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The,182)

Crook: ill (1981,Auckland Savings Bank) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

BEARDSLEY crook (get c-) get sick (1984,Blackball 08,243)

VIRTUE Mrs Nation must be real crook the way she carried on,' Elsdon said. ...She's a bit crook in the head.' (1987,Redemption of Elsdon Bird, The,28,1988 ed.)

adv. badly

SCANLAN Surely they don't expect to win all that on her in one race, unless Pencarrow is running crook. (1934,Winds of Heaven,78)

2 adj. wrongful (of a trick, business, etc.), immoral

... one or two of the head officials in this State Coal concern seem to be also agents for private companies. If this is so we wouldn't be surprised if things are crook. (Aug 29, 1905,NZ Truth,10/4/6)

He has interviewed Dwyer ... in connection with this crook conviction but has been ordered out of the office every time. (Nov 4, 1905,NZ Truth,20/5/7)

ANZAC .. protesting in lurid language against what they styled `a crook trick.' (1916,On the Anzac Trail,44)

SMYTH `I reckon, though he don't let on, that he knows all about station work. If that don't make him queer and crook I'd like to know what does!' (1928,Jean of the Tussock Country,78)

SARGESON ... they said it [pulling a race-horse] was a crook business right through. (1936,Conversations with My Uncle,15)

MARSH You [sc. a detective] seemed to guess there was something crook about this Liversidge from the kick-off. (1937,Vintage Murder,145)

PARK `I done something crook, Dad, I hit her.' (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,93)

SLATTER There was nothing wrong with that. I was only doing it for a bet ...'It looked pretty crook to me.' (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,209)

PARK That Georgie Wi must be a crook cow,' whispered his fellow penitents.Look at the time he's in there [sc. confessional box]!' (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,52)

CRUMP The warder swore black and blue that Tonker done it on purpose and he got another four months ... for crook conduct. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,68)

WEBBER Point is, how does a joker register a protest about buying crook articles at a crook price? (1962,Look No Hands!,25)

McCALLUM I have never done a crook turn in my life ... (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,86)

SARGESON crook: a crook business right through, a thoroughly dishonest racket; go crook, (to) object or protest strongly; looked pretty crook on it, looked ill. (1964,Collected Stories,298) [NOTES: Pearson Glossary to 1964 Sargeson Collected Stories 1935-1963 298]

Crook - ill, bad. To feel crook, to feel ill. A crook boss, a bad employer. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,39)

McGILL crook sick, dishonest, unhealthy, unpleasant people, and things out of order. Endless antipodean permutations, of which some are: crook deal fate not being nice to you. - crook do rotten job. - crook job rotten job. - crook run unlucky period. - crook steer misleading information. - crook trot unlucky period. Overheard in North Auckland pub: Gee, this beer's crook.'Yeah, I'll be glad when I've had enough.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,32)

If not that he is occasionally found navvying, and there he is boss, and when he is not in that line he is found eking out an existence on the goldfields, and it is strange, passing strange, that a Chow on a deserted goldfield can always show color[sic], and if it is not on a deserted field, the Chow, too, can always be found on the `cross' (viz.) buying crook stuff. (Sep 21, 1907,NZ Truth,118/5/6)

SARGESON crook: a crook business right through, a thoroughly dishonest racket; go crook, (to) object or protest strongly; looked pretty crook on itlooked ill. (1964,Collected Stories,298)

3 adj. Of events, situations, work, objects, bad, unpleasant, unsatisfactory

PILLING Had a very crook night, sickness, cramp, dysentery .. (1933,Anzac Memory) [NOTES: 1915 Oct 4 in 1933 Pilling Anzac Memory 62]

SMYTH What have you against Englishmen?'They're mostly crook.' (1928,Jean of the Tussock Country,26)

SMYTH We've got a kinda crook job. Ibid. 163 Cow of a job', he muttered.A bit crook for yer.' Ibid. 76 His temper's that crook. (1929,Girl from Mason Creek, The,12)

LAWLOR `Crook health and crook times,' he explained in a small asthmatic voice. (1930,NZ Short Stories,176)

GASKELL It's a nice we spot,' I said.Very quiet, ... Isn't it crook about Keith and Gordon? ...' (1978,All Part of the Game,43) [NOTES: 1945 Gaskell `Tidings of Joy' in 1978 All Part of the Game 43 Also in 1947 Gaskell Big Game 32]

SYDER & HODGETTS An unsatisfactory situation which irritates the speaker. .in 4;`Well, this is a crook sort of a turnout - the doctor was supposed to be here this morning, and now it seems the message never even reached him!' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],233)

crook adj. (Sl.) sick, bad, inferior; (Phr.) to feel crook, to feel ill; go crook on, become annoyed with, upbraid. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6) [NOTES: Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 266; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 113]]

PICARD That's dead crook. Look here, I'll write to the War cry about it. (1906,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,33)

crook ... 3 a. NZ & Austral. ill, out of sorts (John felt pretty crook); (of thing) unsatisfactory, out of order (things went crook from the beginning, the engine sounds crook to me). 4. go crook (at) NZ & Austral. be angry (with), speak angrily (to). (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,176)

4 adj. dud, disabled, damaged, out of order, broken.

MILLER The rifle issued to me was a crook one that fired high and left. (1939,Camps, Tramps and Trenches,52) [NOTES: 1917 Apr 4 in 1939 Miller Camps Tracks and Trenches 52]

HYDE You at the war?'That's where I got my crook arm. ... Too many of my mates went west, and besides that's where I buggered up this arm.' Ibid. 208 All the decorations I brought back [from the War] were a crook knee and arm. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,106)

FULLARTON [He's] got a crook shoulder. (1944,Troop Target,39)

MASTERS They started scrambling and leaping out like corks out of bottles of a crook brew or of home made beer. (1960,Back-Country Tales,154)

SHADBOLT ` ... What the hell's the matter with you.[sic] Your leg still crook?' ... (1965,Among the Cinders,80)

SLATTER Erik, the scandalous Scandy from the Skagerrak - This is crook beer. I'll be glad when I've had enough - (1968,Pagan Game, The,161)

crook as a dog¶

phr. (Rural) [common in rural conversation] very ill.

She was an unwilling mule - broke, crook as a dog, stranded, she met a stranger who said he'd give her a thousand pounds if she carried his drugs. (Aug 17, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),55)

"I'm as crook as a dog, actually," a coughing, spluttering, but still engaging, Ulmer professes. (Jun 6, 2004,Sunday Times (NZ),B7)

Farm-based exports are in booming good health, but forest products look as crook as a dog. (Jul 14, 2001,Dominion,16)

crook Cook¶

n. the Captain Cook statue in Gisborne

He has a sharp eye for picturesque detail - the statue of Captain Cook, for example, known to locals as "Crook Cook", because, due to a low budget and sloppy research, the statue's commissioners were supplied the image of a man in some kind of Italian military uniform. (May 29, 2004,Dominion Post,E15)

crookbill¶

n. a wrybill (See also crookbill plover)

NO. B.65. - ANARHYNCHUS FRONTALIS, Quoy. ... In the `Ibis,' January, 1873, also in Dr. Buller's book, page 219, appear statements that the pectoral band is less conspicuous on the left than on the right side of the Crook-bill. (1873,TrNZI,6/150) [NOTES: (Potts)]

crookbill plover¶

n. [also crookbilled plover below] (See wrybill)

HUTTON 66. ANARHYNCHUS FRONTALIS. Quoy. et Gaim. Crook-bill Plover. Thinomis Rossii [Of the Otago Museum.] (1871,Birds of New Zealand,25)

  1. Anarhynchus frontalis Quoy et Gaim. Crookbill Plover, Sand-lark. - The Crookbill at breeding season is less wary than perhaps any other species of the family ... (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,509) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

FALLA et al. WRYBILL Anarhynchus frontalis Other Names: Wry-billed Plover, Crook-bill Plover, Ngutu-parore (1966,Birds of New Zealand,130)

... the Crook-billed Plover scuttled slowly off with outstretched wing. Ibid. 68 ANARHYNCHUS FRONTALIS, Quoy. and Gaim. Scissor-bill, Crook-billed Plover. (1870,TrNZI,2/48) [NOTES: -]

.. "Ornithologist" mentions any or all of the following as a first draft he wants information upon:- The dotterel, red-bill, parakeet .. crook-bill plover ... (Sep 5, 1906,Otago Witness,88)

crooked¶

adj. wrong

WHITWORTH I was down there with Old Ashmore's lot, doing the trampoline, and so on; but things was very quizby. Everything went crooked somehow, and the gorger had a hawful cramp in his kick. (1879,Spangles and Sawdust,5)

crooked as a dog's hind leg¶

phr. very crooked

PFAFF Revell Street [Hokitika] ... was as crooked as a dog's hind leg, as the saying is, ... (1914,Diggers' Story, The,4)

BALLANTYNE ... it would have been all right if he'd made a good job of it, but the lawn edge ended up as crooked as a dog's hind leg. (1948,Cunninghams, The,14,1976 ed.)

LELAND Crooked as a dog's hind leg. Some of the back metal roads in the mountains of central Otago (e.g. Crown Range Road) could be safely described this way. It is seldom used as a reflection on someone's honesty. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,30)

crookie¶

n. something defective; someone or something crook (q.v.).

He states a soldier was "rotting" a rifle, saying that it would not fire true, and was a "crookie". (Nov 11, 1915,Feilding Star,2)

So we let them through, gently pushed the crookie into the sheep pens and managed to grab him in the drafting race. (Oct 2000,Growing Today,74)

And a gammey leg and one glass eye./ ... The good eye always looked at the cash,/ But the crookie looked you full in the gob/ (Mar 1953,Here & Now,14) [NOTES: (A.Vogt)]

CRUMP These West Coast publicans are usually a pretty good team but there's a crookie in every bunch of blokes. (1962,One of Us,104)

1 n. (Rural) a sick animal.

a sick cow - a crookie. a sick sheep - a crookie. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

crookness¶

n. illness; sickness.

This crookness this MP's got. (1946,Johnny Enzed in Italy,35)

cropper¶

n. a sharecropper, a small farmer

PASH In New Zealand there are two classes of men that are rarely found connected with Agriculture in England, viz:- Contractors and croppers. ... The contractors undertake to do the ploughing, harrowing, sowing and other farm operations at a given price per acre ... The croppers are a class of men who pay a price per acre for the privilege of taking off a crop of corn after the land had been fed a couple of years in clover or grass. ... [6] [Origin of contractors and croppers is: the great want of the Colony is and has been <i>men</i> not money'; andthe large holdings and the inability of the landowner to work all his land himself'] (1883,Report on NZ,5)

VINCENT We passed a few huts and tumble-down shanties [in Canterbury] belonging to croppers', or men who break up andcrop' the land for a couple of years, at a rent of 10 shillings per acre, after which it is sown in grass for the owner, the cropper moving elsewhere. (1885,Forty Thousand Miles Over Land and Water,217)

WALLACE The land [near Oamaru] is let for one crop of wheat ... to a class of contractors called `croppers'. These men plough up the lea (?ley) about Christmas ..., and sow turnip-seed for the owners. ... It is afterwards ploughed and sown with wheat ... (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,285)

n. a fall

ANTHONY I've still got some rags of pride left, you know, in spite of my cropper. (1936,Follow the Call,173)

cross¶

v. v.t. to put (stock) across (a river)

It being too late to get down the river tonight I only crossed the drafted cattle over one stream and took them on one mile. (May 5, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,181,1950 ed.)

n. a lode or vein which intersects a main lode at right angles.

CROSS-COURSE.- A lode running nearly at right angles to a lode in order to cut it. (1868,Thames Miner's Guide, The,53)

Cross 7¶

n. a cultivar of wheat (for others see citation) [??admit wheat varietal names cf the following ca1960]

J. WINCHESTER We have been breeding wheat for over 35 years and during that time six new varieties have been produced: Cross 7, Fife, Tuscan, Yielder, Hilgendorf, Arawa, and Aotea; a well as two other varieties, tainui and Tairoa, by re-selection. (1960,Personal Communication)

cross chute¶

n.

BOWEN In a cross chute, a shearer does not have to cross the board or go so far for his sheep. (1955,Wool Away!,111)

cross cutting¶

n.

... the rest goes for cross cutting and heaping [logs]. (1960,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/476,1960 ed.) [NOTES: 1859 July 17 Richmond-Atkinson Papers (1960) I/476 (J.C. Richmond)]

cross head¶

n.

1 n. (Rural) a fault made by a heading dog when he begins his cast out to one side and then switches to the other.

MILLS ET AL You must guard against what is known as 'crossing his head' which is going out on one side and then at some stage crossing over, to finish up by heading his sheep from the opposite side from which he started. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,33)

LOUGHNAN crosshead (n or v): a fault made by a heading dog when he begins his cast out to one side and then switches to the other. [crosshead, cross one's head] (1981,Loughnan Glossary,23)

NEWTON (Glossary) Cross-head: A dog usually heads on one predetermined side. If after having started on that side he changes direction and heads on the other this is `cross-heading'. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,168)

MILLS ET AL 'Crossing his head' and 'crossing his line' both come within the worst possible category. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,34)

cross heading¶

1 n. (Rural) a change in direction of a heading dog when moving towards sheep.

GORDON The worst and most penalty prone method is known as cross heading. (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,122)

cross the river¶

phr. to die (See cf. New Zealand death)

STUDHOLME ... many pioneers have crossed the river many years ago. (1940,Te Waimate,xi)

Cross, the¶

n. ellipt. for the Southern Cross (constellation).

The old cross up there. (1903,Reuben & Other Poems,00) [NOTES: Needs page number]

Midnight is past, the Cross begins to bend. (1897,TrNZI,29/147)

BAUGHAN The old Cross up there. (1903,Reuben & Other Poems)

It was Ack Ack Emma,/ A Moon or two swayed in the welkin,/ And the Cross resembled many `milky' ways./ (Jul 10, 1920,Quick March,41)

FINLAYSON Where the surrounding trees were lowest he could just catch a glimpse of the Southern Cross ... The stars that formed the Cross weren't so very much bigger and brighter than the bright ones about it, were they? (1952,Schooner Came to Atia, The,29)

cross-bencher¶

n. member of parliament who sits physically and philosophically on the cross benches, taking sides as it suits. [cf. ODE sense (House of Lords only)]

It's just the rest of us who must come to terms with the fact that a "man for a change" is actually a cross-bencher. (Sep 9, 2005,NZ Herald,A13)

cross-kid¶

v.

The graft was as follows: The owners of the horse thought their boy could mag pretty well, so they cross-kidded to him, by explaining that it would be folly to back the horse here but better wait for the _____ meeting. (Apr 18, 1908,NZ Truth,148/2/6)

cross-lease¶

n.

MARSHALL His mother.. had a cross-lease town house of concrete block [sic] in Herne Bay {Auckland]. (1999,Harlequin Rex,137) [NOTES: Probably local, legal and semi-legal]

The shrinking size of residential sections, and the move towards apartment living, has produced several distinctive terms. Stratum (or strata) title and unit title are fully defined in DNZE; the common overseas term condominium is not NZE. Cross-lease may be another distinctive term. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2)

"It does cause quite a lot of problems, particularly with cross-lease titles"... With a cross-lease, you share in the loan and lease a unit. (May 14, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),55)

cross-leased¶

adj. [used by lawyers, real estate agents]

BUTLER [Josephine] was to build a small house on a cross-leased section in what was once the back garden of the oldest house.. in the same street. (1999,There Was a Time,23)

cross-reef¶

n.

The Bendigo mining-area is traversed by two distinct vein-systems - namely one running N.E.-S.W., and the other approximately E.-W. ... The veins of the former system are locally termed `cross-lodes'. d. cross-reef, a reef which intersects another. (1908,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.5 (NS) 49) [NOTES: (Park) [Cromwell]]

... the intersection of cross-reefs carrying sulphides ... (1906,Mining Handbook,54)

cross-towner¶

n.

What the photo doesn't show (to cross-towners) is that on the beach side there is an upstairs open-air deck area which must be glorious on a balmy summer/spring day. (Sep 21, 2005,Capital Times,3)

crossbred¶

n. a hybrid sheep of other then Merino breeds, the result of crossing two or more breeds, lines or strains, a two-way cross' being made up from crossing two basic breeds, athree-way cross', from three; the wool from such a sheep; (See also criss-cross,rotational cross)

WELD ... the Merino has the more valuable wool, being finer, and particularly superior in the `skirts', which are remarkably deficient in crossed sheep.] (1851,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,8) [NOTES: [cf crossed sheep]]

MEREDITH I go out on the run, ... and select one that is not too fat, generally a merino if I can find one. Most of the crossbreds would have [42] about an inch thick of fat on the ribs. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,41,1935 ed.) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 41-42]

T.C. KIERNAN Put X-breds in Newton block, and T.S. took the Merion [sic] wethers over Papa creek. (Feb 1, 1879,Diary) [NOTES: 1879 Feb 1 Diary in 1921 Guthrie-Smith Tutira 125]

GRANT & FOSTER The weight of these [fleeces] in the grease seemed to average about 5[half] or 6lbs., while that of the cross-breds were [sic] very little heavier. (1880,New Zealand (various authors/titles),42)

PASH 11,700 crossbreds, bred from Merino ewes by Lincoln rams. (1883,Report on NZ,8)

MACDONALD The half-bred is produced by the above crosses, and by placing the same kind of ram again to the half-bred [51] ewes the cross-bred, so much prized for mutton-cum-wool, is obtained. (1915,NZ Sheepfarming,50)

PERRY The half-bred ewe [sc. obtained by crossing a long-woolled ram ... on the Merino ewe] is then crossed with a ram of a mutton breed to obtain the cross-bred ewe, which is the chief type of sheep found on the majority of farms in Canterbury. The class of cross-bred chiefly in evidence varies considerably in different parts of the Dominion ... (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,65)

The term cross-bred' is used to define any long-woolled sheep which has been produced by (1) crossing any of the long-woolled breeds with each other; (2) crossing any long-woolled breed with the progeny from the first cross; (3) crossing any long-woolled ram with Down or Ryeland ewes; (4) crossing any long-woolled ram with the progeny from (3) above; (5) mating cross-breds with each other. The wool produced by any of the above crosses is termedcross-bred,' and ranges in quality from 34's to 50's. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,415)

Crossbred: Crossbred produced after a period of using each of the two parent breeds alternately. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,15)

BREMNER Crossbred cross of coarse-woolled breeds. (1985,Woolscours of NZ,9)

n. (fig. and transf.)

I hate your milk-and-water crossbreds between a Sunday School pic-nic and a Methody prayer meeting. (1889,Zealandia,1/15) [NOTES: (Graham)]

n.

The same could not be said of crossbreds, however, the majority of which met with disappointed bidding. (Feb 6, 1934,Feilding Star,7)

adj. of or pertaining to cross-bred sheep or their wool; see esp. cit. 1982.

GUTHRIE-SMITH 600 ewes, 100 wethers, and 800 cross-bred wethers. (1921,Tutira,129) [NOTES: 1879 Mar 23 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie-Smith Tutira 129]

MASTERS `This part of the country passes through country of home-like rolling downs, all in English grasses, carrying, I am informed, 20,000 crossbred sheep, all in excellent condition, and notwithstanding this large number of mouths, it appeared to me that the country was understocked.' (1959,Tales of the Mails,58) [NOTES: c1880s an anonymous tourist in 1959 L. Masters Tales of the Mails 58]

... large herds of dairy stock, with flocks of long-wool and cross-bred sheep. The west coast of the island is essentially a cattle-country. Ibid. 121 Crossbred Sheep: Those bred from Merino ewes and long-wool rams are the most suitable for the frozen-meat trade, and are known as `freezers'. The dapper little Southdowns flourish wherever crossbreds thrive... The Merino ewe furnishes the foundation of all the cross-bred varieties. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,115)

The staple of New Zealand wool, especially the long-wool and cross-bred, is remarkable for its freedom from breaks and other imperfections ... (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,92)

PERRY The half-bred ewe [sc. obtained by crossing a long-woolled ram ... on the Merino ewe] is then crossed with a ram of a mutton breed to obtain the cross-bred ewe, which is the chief type of sheep found on the majority of farms in Canterbury. The class of cross-bred chiefly in evidence varies considerably in different parts of the Dominion ... (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,65)

Fine-wool sheep, expecially Merinos, are much slower than crossbred sheep. Wrinkles, dense wool, trimmings, all have a bearing on shearing. (1955,Wool Away!,3)

Crossbred wool: Type of wool grown by Romney, Perendale, Coopworth, Leicester, and Lincoln sheep and their crosses with other than Merino or part-Merino breeds. A lustre wool varying in fineness from 36's to 56's in quality number. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,54)

adj.

There's a tweed spun from crossbred wool... It's out of fashion now, and we cannot sell any of it. (Aug 25, 1900,Egmont Star,17)

crosscut¶

n. a crosscut saw

Whit saws and cross-cuts. (1848,Otago Journal,3/46) [NOTES: (E. Atkinson)]

JONES Woolbales Sewing twine Grave stone ... Files, for crosscut and handsaw (1919,Samuel Butler,1/82) [NOTES: 1860 Oct Butler's list `Things for the Dray to bring up' in 1919 Jones Samuel Butler I/82]

WAITE The musterer and station owner ... forsook their flocks; the bushman put away his crosscut and axe; the flaxmill hand left swamp and mill and hurried to the nearest railway station. (1919,New Zealanders at Gallipoli,2)

ROGERS Those blokes walking out to the gig with a fence-puller in one hand and a cross-cut in the other; ... (1960,Long White Cloud, The,91)

v. to cut transversely through a log or tree-stem with a crosscut saw.

S.D. PARNELL Notebook and Farm Diary -->Cross-cutting Mairi. (1844,Notebook & Farm Diary) [NOTES: [MS ATB]]

S.D. PARNELL Notebook and Farm Diary -->Cross-cutting Mairi. (1844,Notebook & Farm Diary) [NOTES: [MS ATB]]

PHARAZYN ... after breakfast cross-cut Manuka tree. (1846,Journal,36)

We used to fell trees, cross-cut them into lengths, and sell them for firewood. (1849,Notes on NZ,(?1850) No6/7) [NOTES: (a carpenter at Wellington)]

Did a little to a great many things. One was to milk some cows, make some crackers, cross-cut and chop some fire-wood, etc. (Dec 9, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,69,1950 ed.)

BAINES A bushman ... entered into a contract with me to fall, cross-cut, and roll handy to the creek's side 200,000 feet of timber. Ibid. 174 [While he was] falling and cross-cutting logs, from ten to twenty-five feet in length, I was busy with another gang of men building a flood-dam, ... (1874,Edward Crewe,170)

PRATT The cross-cut saw ... had a great deal of what is technically called `set' upon [its teeth], being especially adapted for cross-cutting green ... white-pine logs. (1877,Colonial Experiences,16)

BATHGATE Often I have cross-cutted with a handsaw fallen logs a foot or more through. (1881,Battle of Life,74)

The trees are felled and cross-cut into suitable lengths for conversion, the logs being conveyed to the mill by flotation, by tramline, or ... by oxen or horses. (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,331) [NOTES: (T. Kirk)]

HENDERSON It was cross-cut into three lengths and then sawn up into boards and scantlings. With the outside slabs Tod built a workshop ... (1948,Taina,26)

REED ... two good men might crosscut a four-feet log in less than a couple of hours. (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,162)

CRUMP Jack and I were cross-cutting in the last stand of kauri. (1963,Hang on a Minute, Mate,32)

n. see citations

Crosscut : A tunnel driven to reach a reef or cutting across the reef system. (Sep 1999,Ohinemuri Regional History Journal,43 : 14)

McARA The term driving generally referred to tunnelling in any direction but in some circumstances, where reefs were present, it meant tunnelling along the line of the reef or parallel to it. The term drifting was used more specifically for driving on a reef, while the term crosscutting referred to tunnelling across the reef up to an angle of say forty-five degrees; however it was common to talk of `driving a crosscut'. Ibid. 317 Crosscut: A tunnel cutting across the reef system. As the shafts were sunk to new levels a main crosscut was put out from the shaft chamber on each level to cut the reefs approximately at right-angles, after which driving in both directions usually started on the first reef, while crosscutting continued until the farthest reef was opened up. It was usually necessary to make a [318] connection with the level above, near the end of the crosscut, for ventilation. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi,184)

1 v. (Rural) [spec. use] to saw a log or tree transversely with a crosscut saw.

KEENE Cross-cutting a kauri log for shingles for St Saviour's, Kaitaia [cap] (1977,To the Northward,96)

WATERSON .. he wouldn't mind a hand to crosscut a few totara logs laying about on the back of his farm. [cross-cut] (1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,51)

CHUDLEIGH Did a little to a great many things. One was to milk some cows, make some crackers, cross-cut and chop some firewood. (Dec 9, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,69) [NOTES: (1950)]

BATES Jack was crosscutting a log for firewood. (1988,Okoroa,62)

BATES Another time Jack and Mr Menefy were crosscutting a big log while Harry and Tui were playing around in the bracken fern. (1988,Okoroa,91)

crosscut saw¶

n.

...his father gave them an axe, an 'M' tooth crosscut saw, a shotgun, a sack of flour and some spuds and sent them to work felling bush. (2001,NZ Memories,No. 27/39)

...his father gave them an axe, an 'M' tooth crosscut saw, a shotgun, a sack of flour and some spuds and sent them to work felling bush. (Dec 2001,NZ Memories,No. 27/39)

MAY ... a cross-cut saw... (1869,May's Guide to Farming in NZ,31) [NOTES: needs expanding; not held Turnbull]

MARSDEN A List of Articles Wanted for the Use of the Active and the Settlement in New Zealand, 1815 [heading] ... [138] ... twenty dozen tommy hawkes, twenty dozen of sickles, eight pit and four crosscut saws (two pit saws as long as can be procured), ... (1815,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,137,1932 ed.)

SHEPHERD After breakfast all hands ... proceeded immediately to cut down the timber and with the use of cross cut saws and axes cut down 15 trees before dinner. (Mar 8, 1826,Journal) [NOTES: 1826 Mar 8 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 359]

POLACK A stage is generally erected about three feet from the ground, when, with a cross-cut saw, the party (chiefs included,) work in turn until the tree is levelled; ... (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/168)

... cross-cut saw. (1842,Deans' Letters,45,1937 ed.)

WAKEFIELD The Colonist's attention should be directed to the following articles, with which he must provide himself according to his means and his intentions. For clearing and cultivating timbered land... cross cut saws, ... (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,45,1937 ed.)

The implements necessary ... will be ... good axes, spades, ... a cross-cut saw, two or three good iron wedges, ... reaping hooks, ... (Apr 16, 1849,Letters from Otago,32,1978 ed.)

(Annual Contracts, Col.Secretary's Office) [heading] TOOLS FOR ROAD PARTIES ... Blasting Tools/ Crowbars ......per lb./ Jumpers ......per lb./ Rammers .....per lb./ Spoons and Needles ......per lb. ...Saws/ Hand .....per foot./ Cross Cut .....per foot./ Pit ......per foot. (Dec 21, 1852,NZ Government Gazette,V/31/193)

HURSTHOUSE ... the trees are thrown with the x [sic] cut saw and American axe. (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/331)

MAY ... a cross-cut saw ... (1869,Guide to Farming in NZ,31)

BAINES The principal tools required [by the kauri bushman] were Yankee axes, cross-cut saws, and timber (not screw) jacks. Ibid. 173 Cross-cut saws have what is called a peg-tooth and cut both ways. It is a great improvement to sharpen every fifth tooth, counting from the centre to the ends, as a drag tooth, that is, a tooth filed square across and with a considerable hook, this arrangement tends to keep the cut clear of sawdust. (1874,Edward Crewe,171)

[Advt} Try the /CHEAP HARDWARE HOUSE/ FOR/ ... /COLONIAL OVENS, &C. ... Hand, Rip. Tennon, Cross-cut, Pit, and Buck Saws. (1879,Waikato War,frontispiece)

A trial of the thin back racer cross-cut saw, held recently by the Loan and Mercantile, was a success. (Jun 2, 1900,Egmont Star,17)

crosscutter¶

n. one who uses a crosscut saw.

The axemen and crosscutters at work. (1902,NZ Illustrated Magazine,5/373)

RUST (`A') Timber was being got ... along its immense stretch of foreshore. Hundreds of bushmen, loggers, jackers, bullock-drivers, cross-cutters and rafters were employed ... in the different sawmills [at Maungakaramea]. (1936,Whangarei & District Early Reminiscences,163)

CROSS CUTTER. A workman who saws trees into log-lengths. In New Zealand cross cutters generally fall trees also. (1952,NZ Forest Glossary)

R EED Good crosscutters can tell to an inch where the tree will land. (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,156) [NOTES: (Dan Lewis)]

n.

GEORGE Among the other employees there was .. the 'ropey' whose job it was to fasten a heavy steel rope to the log. (1990,Ohakune,95)

A skilled faller, or cross-cutter - the crewman whose job it is to drop each tree to begin with - must read the terrain through the hauler's eyes and direct each toppling trunk so that it lands where it can be most easily and efficiently dragged away for processing. (Jul 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 64/104)

CROSS CUTTER KFL has vacancies in BOP forest harvesting operations felling for cable hauler. (Aug 30, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,9)

OWEN & PERKINS The work of felling was in the hands of the cross-cutters, and usually they were specialists at this type of work, and did it under subcontract. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,155)

crosshand-saw¶

Its big and stately trunk is cross-hand-sawn into two or three lengths. (1890,TrNZI,488) [NOTES: (Colenso)]
