crouch¶

n. excrement [ca1938]

crow¶

v. in building a (hay)stack, to fork across the sheaves to the stacker

Instead [of stacking] you may "crow". (1944,Kohimarama,2(7) : 8)

Instead [of stacking] you may "crow". (1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),2(7) : 8)

ANTHONY He usually ends up by putting Gus crowing for him on the stack - says he can keep an eye on him there. Gus says he wouldn't mind being crow, if he got any credit for it, ... [224] note gives a contextual meaning] (1927,Me and Gus,72,(1977 Gus Tomlins ed Sturm) ed.)

BARRY My first job was crowing, for a neighbour. We started when it was dry in the morning and went on till it was too dark to see. The stacks were 40 ft. long, and I stood in the middle and had to throw the sheaves to both ends. (1966,In the Lee of the Hokonuis,370)

n. a person who pitches sheaves to the stacker

OVERTON For general harvesting and the above class of work, speaking as one who started as a crow and finished up as a stacker, we received from ninepence to one shilling per hour. (1949,Fifty Years Sheep Farming,15)

With it go stacker and crow until they are well above the dray. (1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),2(7) : 8)

DARE One on a (hay) stack who pitches sheaves to the builder of the stack, a man on a haystack (or grainstack) who pitches sheaves to the stacker or builder. (1956,Rouseabout Jane,XXIV/785) [NOTES: nf EDD]

BRADSHAW When harvest came ... he ought to have taken his place as crow' upon the stack. [fn] Acrow' is the man who pitches the sheaves to the stacker. (1888,New Zealand Of Today,171)

CARR Haymaking. ... The jobs to look for are cocking up' (with a two or three pronged fork), driving the horse rake (no handrakes are used nowadays) ... loading the drays or sledges when ready ... Acrow' is also employed, whose work consists of passing the fork-fulls thrown up by the carter to the stacker. (1913,Country Work,11)

ANTHONY He usually ends up by putting Gus crowing for him on the stack - says he can keep an eye on him there. Gus says he wouldn't mind being crow, if he got any credit for it, ... [224 note gives a contextual meaning] Ibid. 84 Gus says he wouldn't mind being crow [building a stack]. (1927,Me and Gus,72,(1977 Gus Tomlins ed Sturm) ed.)

MILLER ... I found keen enjoyment in forking [the new-mown hay] to the stack and keeping the crow busy spreading the hay along the top. Generally the boss was the crow ... (1946,There Was Gold,134)

DARE When it came to stacking the corn, my job was to be `crow', which meant that I had to catch every sheaf on the end of pitchfork as it was thrown out of the wagon, and deposit in the right place for the stacker who put the sheaves in the correct position. (1956,Rouseabout Jane,185)

While the stack [of oats] was building the sheaves were passed to the builder by the `crow' a man who stood opposite where the wagons pulled in to unload. (Jan 22, 1964,Auckland Weekly News,37?)

FERNANDEZ Back at the stack these [sheaves] were then forked off [the truck] to the crow who fed them to the stacker. David elected to be the crow. (1973,Tussock Fever,145)

HAYES The crop was then stooked, and the grain left until hard and dry, then stacked. This took five men in the paddock - the stacker, the crow (the one who forked to the stacker), two on the drays, and one forking to the men on the drays. (1978,From the Toss of a Coin,112)

KERSE At the stack the [dray] load was forked to the `crow' who in turn moved the sheaves to the builder. Some of the old hands were expert stackers: their stacks were good to look at and shed every drop of rain, ... (1984,Knapdale Run, The,146)

There is.. the "crow" who passed the sheaves on to the stacker in the days of wheat and oat stacks before header harvesters eliminated stooking and stacking. (Feb 11, 1977,Press, The,19)

n. a girl(-friend), young woman; girls in general, often used derog

In the sad New Zealand summer/ when the rainclouds clog the sky/ and in the quiet boozer/ roost my loving crow and I/ drinking gin and lemon squashes (1953,Here & Now,3/11/27) [NOTES: (J.K.Baxter `The Man I Might Have Been')]

SUTTON-SMITH Some of the [slang] expressions listed by children in two schools are: Up the shoot, going eyes out, bullswool, go jump in the lake, ... shivery dick, shiver me timbers, ... you're telling I, got it on the brain, like smoke in a wheelbarrow' (Kaitaia),Sheila, crow, bud, frig it, grub, holy moses, blast it, mole, balls to you, shut your face, ... nerts to you, go bite your back, have a roll, fluff off, scram, ants in your pants, rag bag, ... you're bats, dronk, drongo, dill, dip, dippy, ya big lug, greetings gruesome, who dented your beak. (South Wellington). (1953,Unorganized Games,2/677)

BHILLIARD Girls too, real girls, not like the crows you saw up country. (1974,Maori Woman,53)

MORRIESON You might get yourself a crow out there, Merv. Some of the crows out there might want to come back with you ... (1974,Predicament,203,1981 ed.)

HILLIARD Why bother with a crow like that?' ...She's not a crow.' `No? She's the type you might have a go at after you've dipped out on the one you're really after.' (1976,Send Somebody Nice,100)

n. constr. with the, the bar-counter of a hotel.

He used to keep the Eastern Hotel, but has been three years without a hostelry, and when sixpences cease to come across the `crow' for three years, a financial gap is created. (Sep 25, 1909,NZ Truth,222/6/2)

[Letter] ... the Government of 1911 said that `the crow' is no place for barmaids.' (Oct 17, 1957,Press, The,3)

MEEK And this shearer's roll and six quid as well - from the sale of his old bay nag,/ Went over the `crow' at the bush hotel for a riotous non-stop jag. Ibid./110 CROW: The counter in the bar of an hotel. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,75)

n. kokako (cf. river crow = shag) (See kokako)

... the flute-like tones of the Crow or Wattle bird, the wailing call of the Weka ... (1870,TrNZI,2/45) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

MONEY (... thanks to Howitt's lessons, we could get ducks, crows, and wood-hens in abundance). Ibid. 33 The crow being very similar to our black bird, and seldom flying further than a few yards at a time, is generally found in low bushes, hopping from bough to bough. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,30)

BULLER Blue and Orange Wattled crow. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,LIX)

  1. Glaucopis cinerea, Gml. Wattlebird or Crow, Kokako. - I first became acquainted with this bird on the flats of the Wilberforce river, west of the Rakaia gorge, on 20th April, 1856; it was abundant amongst the isolated beech trees ... (Mar 1885,NZ Journal of Science,376) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

GLAUCOPIS. - Crow, two species (Kokako). (1886,TrNZI,18/102) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

The high slopes would be a ... resort for ... crow (Glaucopis), saddle-back (Creadion), New Zealand titmouse (Orthonyx ochrocephala), creeper ... (1887,TrNZI,19/183) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

HARPER ... and if one is hard pushed for food, the smaller birds, such as the crow, tui, paraquet, and saddle-backs, are all acceptable. (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,41)

HILL I do not know to what to attribute the scarcity of small birds, ...such as crows, saddlebacks, thrushes, tuis, canaries, wrens, riflebeaks, fantails and many others. (1987,Richard Henry of Resolution Island,88) [NOTES: 1897 Apr 5 E.H. Wilmot Exploration and Topographical Survey in Fiord Country in 1987 Hill Richard Henry of Resolution Island 88]

MORRIS Crow, ... common English bird-name. The Australian species is - white-eyed, Corvus coronoides V. and H. In New Zealand (Maori name, Kokako) the name is used for the Blue-wattled crow, Glaucopis wilsoni and for the (N. island) orange- wattled, G. cinerea, Gmel. (S. island). (1898,Austral English,108)

BEATTIE The most noticeable absentee from the birds recorded [in the Maori food lists c1880] is the koreke or quail, once extremely plentiful. ... The matuku, or bittern, once common enough is not mentioned, nor is the kokako or crow, nor any of the smaller birds. (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,64)

1 n. (Rural) a person who passes sheaves to a stacker when stackmaking.

LOUGHNAN Crow: the man who stands in the centre of the stack and feeds the hay or the sheaves to the stacker. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,23)

.. and the crow who passed the sheaves on to the stacker in the days of the wheat and oat stacks. (Feb 11, 1977,Press, The,19)

STACEY I heard Con, bellowing occasionally as the crow, a cocky's son, placed the sheaves the wrong way round. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,41)

crow bait¶

1 n. (Rural) a sick animal.

a sick sheep - crow bait. a feeble newborn lamb - crow bait. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

crow garlic¶

n. wild onion

HILGENDORF WILD ONION (Allium vineal), is also called wild garlic and crow garlic ... [It is a bulbous perennial with tall cylindrical stem, bearing at its apex a cluster of white to reddish flowers ...] (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,55,1967 ed.)

crow garlic [=] wild onion [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,19)

crow's nest¶

n. (Rural) a platform in a cabbage tree or on poles, used as a lookout for boundary keeping purposes [prior to fencing].

Platform built on poles or in a cabbage tree from which a shepherd could see his sheep. C[row's] n[est]s were used on the old plains stations until the runs were fenced about 1860. ([ca1890-1910].) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

CRAWFORD In order to disturb the sheep as little as possible ... `crows nests', platforms on poles or in cabbage trees, were frequently built on the plains as look-out stations [for boundary keepers]. (1949,Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury,39)

ACLAND On some of the plains stations 'crow's nests' were built - platforms on poles or up cabbage trees ... (1946,Early Canterbury Runs,19)

LOUGHNAN crowsnest: a platform, used before the days when the plains lands were fenced, built in the top of a cabbage tree from which a shepherd could survey his sheep. [crowsnest] (1981,Loughnan Glossary,23)

crowdie¶

n.

[omitted from 1955 edn] Cottage Cheese or Crowdie. Use either old milk which has soured or add 1 teaspoon of rennet to 1 quart of fresh milk. Leave to thicken, cut into 1/2 inch pieces with a knife and put into a scalded linen cloth to drain. Scrape the inside of cloth occasionally to facilitate drainage and when all whey is removed mix in 1/2 teaspoon of salt to curd from 1 quart milk. Balls of this often are useful in salads or it makes a good base for sandwiches, or savoury biscuits, using any of the following: Lettuce, chives, cress, tomato, cucumber, pimento, chopped apple, pineapple, walnuts, peanuts, dates, raisins, figs, caraway seeds, etc. (1936,Cookery Book of NZ Women's Institutes,83)

crowfoot¶

n. Ranunculus.

FEATON (And) (1889,Art Album NZ Flora)

2 n. creeping buttercup

HILGENDORF CREEPING BUTTERCUP (Ranunculus repens), called also creeping crowfoot, is found in pastures and waste places throughout the islands. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,84,1967 ed.)

creeping crowfoot [=] creeping buttercup [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,17)

2 n.

hairy crowfoot [=] hairy buttercup [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,35)

2 n.

small-flowered crowfoot [=] small-flowered buttercup [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,70)

2 n.

water crowfoot [=] water buttercup [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,84)

crowing¶

n. performing the work of a crow (haymaking sense)

CARR Stacking. - The stacker is boss of the paddock. ... The only way to learn is to take on jobs at `crowing'. (1913,Country Work,1913)

Crown Agent¶

n.

Crown agents; that is to say, organisations that give direct effect to government policy (e.g. the Tourism Board or Health Funding Authority... We've decided to give the name "crown agent" to those organisations that are required to be immediately responsive to the policy directions of the government. (Jul 28, 1999,Dominion,12)

Crown Agents will have a high level of strategic and fiscal risk, and as such will be subject to a high level of ministerial control. (Aug 22, 2000,Evening Post,13)

Crown agents have functions with a high level of strategic, policy and fiscal risk and will be subject to greater ministerial control. They must follow government policy, board members are appointed for three years by the responsible minister. (Nov 21, 2000,Evening Post,2)

Crown company¶

n. shorter form of Crown-owned company q.v.

Crown Companies will operate under the Companies Act and Crown entities legislation, with board members appointed by shareholding Ministers. (Aug 22, 2000,Evening Post,13)

Crown entity¶

n.

Crown entities are not departments or ministries, like the Department of Internal Affairs or the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Neither are they state-owned enterprises, like New Zealand Post. The term crown entity has been applied like a mop to most of the other bodies which the crown has set up over the years to carry out little bits of its business. There are about 160 of them... We've divided them into five categories... Crown agents... Independent, quasi-judicial bodies (e.g. the Police Complaints Authority or the Environmental Risk Management Authority)..Trusts (e.g. Road Safety Trust).. Companies (e.g. Radio New Zealand).. Other organisations (e.g. schools). (Jul 28, 1999,Dominion,12)

[Crown entities] included the Fire Service Commission, Lotteries Commission and the Toursim Board... Crown entities will be classified as Crown Agents, Autonomous Crown Entities, Independent Crown Entities and Crown Companies. (Aug 22, 2000,Evening Post,13)

Blakely politely refutes the possibility, saying that the Fire Service is an "operational agency and you'd always want it to be in some form a Crown entity." (May 23, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

You can't have one rule for all Crown entities, because there are hundreds of the blighters, and all have different functions, and therefore need different lines of accountability, including the business of hirage and fireage. (Jul 3, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

Efforts to stop golden handshakes and make Crown entities more accountable are taking longer than expected. (Nov 21, 2000,Evening Post,18)

crown fern¶

n. Blechnum discolor

Heralding spring, a cluster of young fronds unfurls in the centre of a piupiu or crown fern, Blechnum discolor. (Jan 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/82)

DOBBIE (And) Blechnum discolor crown-fern (Nov 21, 1921,Letters)

MARTIN At higher altitudes the larger, erect-growing Crown Fern .us(B. discolor) replaces them. (1946,Flora NZ,77)

CRUMP There was a brief interval of silence, while Mr Hartshorne struggled up through the crown-fern. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,46)

HELMER [Urewera] In some places the crown fern completely obscured the path ... and my legs were soon scratched and bleeding from the saw-toothed edges of the fronds. (1964,Stag Party,42)

MARTIN Of forest-frequenting species [of Blechnum] none is more common than the CROWN FERN or SWORD FERN (B. discolor), colonies of which often cover the forest floor as far as the eye can see. (1961,Flora NZ,106)

crown fern [s] Blechnum discolor (Forst.f.) Keys (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,19)

CRUMP Mr Hartshorne struggled up through the crown-fern. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,46)

... a jungle of pepperwood (Pseudowintera colorata), rohutu (Neomyrtus pedunculatus), or the crown fern (Blechnum discolor) does not represent regeneration ... but marks areas of extreme modification. (1971,VUC First Year English Class,55)

Blechnaceae B[lechnum] discolor crown fern (1975,Tane) [NOTES: (Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri)]

WILSON Blechnum discolor CROWN FERN ...Piupiu ... Crowns of numerous, stiffly upright fronds up to a metre long, ... Crown fern dominates wide stretches of forest floor ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,460)

The crown fern (Blechnum discolor) produced short stolons from its rhizomes, just like a strawberry plant, and each one can give rise to a new plant so that the fern often dominates a large area of ground. (Jan 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/69)

Crown grant¶

n. (pertaining to land tenure)

SHORTLAND And as the Commissioners may recommend the issue of Crown grants to lands, the title to which rests on such evidence, cases will probably occur where the lands may be resold ... (Jun 10, 1844,Letter) [NOTES: 1844 June 10 Shortland letter in Shortland Traditions and Superstitions (1856) 309]

WAKEFIELD The New Zealand Company has received a Crown grant, under the seal of the territory, dated 13th of April, 1846, of the portion of this District [of Otago] (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,297)

(15) On the expiration of three years ..., each settler ... will be entitled to a Crown Grant of the town allotment, and farm section allotted to him, ... (1863,NZ Gazette) [NOTES: c1863-64 NZ Gazette in 1879 Featon Waikato War 52]

TAYLOR He indignantly threw down the Crown grant and left, to become a leader of the king party. (1868,Past and Present of NZ,116)

BATHGATE ... the lessee is entitled to a `Crown grant' or transfer of the freehold without further payment. (1874,Colonial Experiences,202)

HOCKEN [sc. of land] When the selection [of the N.Z. Company share of the Otago Block] had been made the Crown grant was to be issued, and there was an understanding that if Colonel Wakefield desired still more land he was to have it. This was the origin of what was afterwards known as the depasturage licences, under which settlers were authorised to run cattle and sheep in the adjoining districts. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,59)

Crown land¶

n. unalienated land

GRIFFITHS The Chief Commissioner: `... Where the pre-emptive rights of a runholder interfere with the sale of Crown Lands, the Government has the power to disallow those rights ...' (1971,King Wakatip,99) [NOTES: 1863 Feb Hearing before Waste land Board in 1971 Griffiths King Wakatip 99]

... such a proceeding is not less opposed to the instructions ... for the disposal of Crown lands, than unprecedented in the history of the neighbouring colonies. (1842,GBPP,(No.569) 131) [NOTES: 1841 Feb 10 D.Sinclair and Others to Sir George Gipps in GBPP 1842 (No.569) 131]

Of Crown lands there are available, roughly speaking, some 11,000,000 acres. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,1)

THOMAS With the exception of a few individuals engaged in raising cattle on unfenced Crown land, ... the whole population of the far north of New Zealand at the turn of the century depended on ... kauri gum. (1970,Way Up North,29)

Huts are frequently built on crown land or road reserve ... (Oct 15, 1989,Dominion Sunday Times,13)

The question of unpaid rates on Crown lands was brought to the notice of the Minister of Lands. (Jan 21, 1937,King Country Chronicle,4)

1 n. (Rural) land that is owned by the government.

THOMSON The first sale of crown lands took place in Auckland in April 1841. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,II 27)

Platform: 2 That when rural Crown lands are thrown open for settlement the provisions of the Land Act should be carried out so that selectors may have a choice of tenure ... (Mar 9, 1907,Farmers' Union Advocate,16)

.. they not only make it difficult for a farmer to acquire Crown lands, but deliberately shut up from occupation the millions of acres of maori lands ... (Jun 3, 1909,Weekly News,44)

The major portion of the pakihi country is Crown land. (Jun 15, 1910,NZ Journal of Agriculture,22)

It is illegal to drive stock on roads or Crown lands between 6pm and 6 am during the months of April to August. (1919,Livestock in New Zealand,48)

There are twelve million acres of publicly owned forests in New Zealand, including State forests, National parks and Crown lands, and some four million acres of privately owned forest, much of it on Maori land. (Dec 1, 1952,NZ Dairy Exporter,89)

Crown Lands Ranger¶

n. [aka Crown Ranger]

SITE OF THE NEW TOWNSHIP ON THE HOGBURN. A deputation from the storekeepers and miners on the Hogburn rush waited on his Honor the Superintendent yesterday, to present a memorial, praying the Government to take steps to rescind the order issued by the Crown Lands Ranger, to remove the stores from their present site to the new township lately marked out by the Warden, Mr Hardcastle. (Aug 28, 1863,Otago Witness,4)

The Wellington Land Board passed a resolution to-day expressing their appreciation of Mr. Robinson as Crown Lands Ranger, and expressing regret at his severance in connection with this district. (May 28, 1885,Taranaki Herald,2)

Is it legal for a Crown Lands Ranger to seize stock and other property mortaged to His Majesty the King and to sell the same privately? (Jan 17, 1925,NZ Truth,16)

It would require some consideration before we in Otago went as far as this, but in the meantime I cannot see what possible reason there can be for the Government and Crown Ranger being so uncommon sharp with small squatters. (Aug 10, 1870,Bruce Herald,3)

You are the Crown Lands Ranger for Otago? Yes. (1913,AJHR,C-12/10)

The reports received from Crown Lands Rangers during the year show that.. genuine and bona fide settlement is progressing very favourably in this district (sc. Westland]... The work done by the Crown Lands: Rangers, whose manifold duties comprise inspecting settlement holdings, reporting on transfers, applications for leases of Crown lands, reserves, riverbeds, &c., resuming possession of forfeited holdings, inspecting pastoral runs, and watching over the preservation of bush lands, &c., can only be very imperfectly indicated in any tabular statements. (1899,AJHR,C-1/22)

Crown Lynn¶

n. the iconic NZ pottery of WWII and post-war period

An emigre from Holland, Carpay arrived in Auckland in 1955 and took up a position at Crown Lynn, then at the high point of its most innovative period... Crown Lynn didn't really know what to do with him, but Carpay quickly turned out a series of elegant, linear hand-painted ceramic designs - 175 in six months. (May 15, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),57)

crown pen¶

1 n. (Rural) a diamond-shaped pen used in stockyards, served by a race at each end and with four pens opening from it. (See diamond)

GASCOIGNE The pattern of present-day construction has come down to us directly from these emergencies of our early settlement - the great receiving yards, the 'diamond' or 'crown' pen leading into the crush pens with the drafting race and gates opening into yards for the finally separated sheep. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,12)

GASCOIGNE Manu would drive about one hundred in to the crown pen which supplied the narrow sorting pens where we worked under a roof. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,68)

GASCOIGNE Manu worked at the rear with his dogs and faithfully kept the crown pen filled ... (1965,From the Top of a Hill,155)

crown shy¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of plant spp] averse to being planted closely to others.

The species [Eucalyptus] is 'crown shy' or averse to brushing foliage with competing trees. (2001,Lifestyle Farmer,Oct/Nov 51)

Crown solicitor¶

n. a lawyer, normally in private practice, appointed to prosecute crimes and otherwise act for the Crown in their district [Jim Cameron writes: The office (and the term) has existed since the 1840s and has no close counterpart in England, where the prosecution system is organised in a different way. It corresponds to the Canadian term Crown Attorney (recorded in Collins). In relation to criminal cases Crown solicitors are also referred to as Crown prosecutors (as in Canada) but their function is wider. A brief reference to the history and functions of the office is in the Law Commission's paper on Criminal Prosecution (NZLC PP. 28, 1997)]

Little linguistic innovation has occurred in criminal law or procedure, three exceptions being conversion (of cars etc.), which is defined in DNZE, Crown solicitor, and infringement notice. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2)

crown-grant¶

v.

WILLIAMS [The land] is wretched stuff, not worth crown-granting. (1899,Page from History, A,9)

Since the Ngapuhi had been getting their lands Crown-granted these persons had been left wandering about without any place of abode. (1880,NZ Parliamentary Debates,37 : 707-a)

Crown-owned company¶

n. (See CROC)

New Zealanders will see far more about themselves on television in the wake of yesterday's decision to change Television New Zealand from a State-owned company to a Crown-owned company, Prime Minister Helen Clark said today. (Mar 26, 2001,Evening Post,3)

Crown-Owned Companies (CrOCs) are commercial and operate within the Companies Act. (Nov 21, 2000,Evening Post,18)

crowning dog¶

n. ?a rabbiting dog which sniffs out burrows

SUTHERLAND Pup's a good crowning dog, too,' said Ewan.What's a crowning dog?' He shows you where the rabbits are in their burrows,' said Ewan.You dig where he scratches and there you'll find the rabbits.' (1978,Elver, The,56)

crud¶

n. cloud

PICKERING So to cope with the rituals of tramping, its pains and camaraderie, a slang language has developed to suit. Lots of quick short words to fit in the breathless pauses as you pant uphill. Crud' (cloud),bush-bash', a gunn' tramper (which must have originated from Davy Gunn's famous trek up the Hollyford Valley to help victims of a plane crash in 1936; he travelled 40 km by rowing boat, horse and foot in 21 hours),windfall' (a collapsed pile of trees), pit' (the tramper's true friend, a sleeping bag),pog' (porridge), bastard grass' andlawyer' (two unpleasant plants), piker' (one who stayed home),Huey' (all-powerful god of weather), and many, many more. (1988,Hills, The,8)

cruise¶

n.

JEWELL Cruise. Survey of forest land to locate timber and estimate quantities. (1948,Accounting in the Timber Industry,128)

v. to assess and measure standing timber

JEWELL To assess and measure standing timber (1948,Accounting in the Timber Industry,130)

cruiser¶

n. one who assesses the quantities of standing timber

MACKAY In the rip-roaring times of the King Country, Matai beer was a favourite with those who were strong enough and tough enough to drink it. It went out of favour when `cruisers' for the various timber mills complained that much good yellow pine was being ruined through the number of deep axe cuts and even auger holes in the standing trees ... (1961,Puborama,95)

crummach¶

n.

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR Long dipping poles each topped with a horizontal S-hook were used [to duck sheep in the dip ca1931]. Mr Knox called these poles crummachs. (1981,Sunrise,66)

crummer¶

n. (Rural) a drainer's implement, consisting of a scythe mounted on a long straight handle.

STUDHOLME He had a spade, a long handled shovel, a scythe (mounted on a long straight handle) for cutting weeds, an implement known as a 'crummer' and several others. (1940,Te Waimate,101)

STUDHOLME [c1880s Canterbury] ... the drainer had [among others] ... an implement known as a `crummer.' (1940,Te Waimate,85) [NOTES: a tool for removing loose earth or rubble from dug drains.]

Crumpdom¶

n.

[Hdg] Good keen 200 in Crumpdom. (Nov 15, 1986,NZ Herald,1)

Crumpian¶

adj. like Barry Crump or a character from his stories

The Crumpian truth was confined to the novels. (Feb 28, 1999,Sunday Star Times,F7)

Crumpish¶

adj.

Using the washing line as a wardrobe and a place to dress from may seem rather Crumpish but it brings a certain freedom and simplicity that values function above wondering what others will think. (Jan 20, 2001,Dominion,29)

[Hdg] Crump-like, but much less macho (Aug 17, 2001,Evening Post,7)

Crumpism¶

n.

The people who knew him keep using these Crumpisms. (Feb 20, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

Crumpy¶

adj.

A genuine crumpy conversation if ever I had one, darkly reflective of the Socratic method, rich with echoes of the Kantian imperative, its universal mate, summoning sharply to the minds of each the history of the first trystings of all immortal lovers, the tragic and tangled tale, indeed, of all star-crossed moonings, mum and dad, mister and missus unotoo and all. (1963,Landfall,17(1): 11)

'A genuine crumpy conversation' Buster observes; and in that gibe at a fellow-author (Barry Crump) Duggan dissociates himself from the line of New Zealand fiction which has gone in for the realism of inarticulacy. (1981,Collected Stories (Duggan),13)

A genuine crumpy conversation if ever I heard one, darkly reflective of the Socratic method, rich with echoes of the Kantian imperative, ... (1981,Collected Stories) [NOTES: 1963 Duggan `Along Rideout Road ...' in 1981 Collected Stories 198 (Griffiths Collection)]

The father is a Crumpy-esque 'man of the land', a charmer who demands his wife and daughter follow his rules. (Oct 25, 2000,Capital Times,8)

Rod McKenzie, rural ward councillor, is the quintessential Crumpesque Kiwi joker, always keen to put his neck out for the rural folk. (Aug 11, 2001,Wairarapa Times-Age,1)

crunch gun¶

n.

WILSON We call the Hun 210mm a crunch gun', happy terminology. The giant shell thrown by this gun, slow in flight, is fired very accurately, and it is the supreme cruncher of casas. <i>Ibid.</i>124The crunch gun on a road crossing,' says Hadfield to me. He is correct. We call the Hun 210 mm. a `crunch gun,' happy terminology. The giant shell thrown by this gun, slow in flight, is fired very accurately, and it is the supreme cruncher of casas. Turned upon the infantry, it crunches to shreds flesh and bones, mortar and stone, steel and rock without discrimination. It is the ultimate destroyer, the arch weapon. (1950,Brave Company,106)

Crunchie Bar¶

n. a proprietary chocolate-covered hokey-pokey bar

He did ask what perks there were, so I told him about the odd Crunchie bar I put in the tank along with the diesel, but he seemed to expect more. (Jul 1998,NZ Geographic,No. 39/124)

BAKER They sat with their tea, ate the rest of the Gingernuts and some stale Crunchie bars from the cafe. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,77)

crunchy¶

adj.

The next few years will be a rather crunchy time for Wellington in that respect. (Dec 17, 1992,Evening Post,8)

n.

HUGHES Finally an infantryman and a cavalryman took their turns. The tanky had no hesitation about insulting the grunt and was quite certain that he was in line for a famous victory. Sadly, the crunchy knew a trick or two. (1999,Shooting from the Lip,166)

Crusaders¶

n. a Super rugby franchise based in Christchurch (also in sing. a member of the Crusaders team)

Hansen was Smith's assistant when the Crusaders won their second Super 12 title in 1999... (May 7, 2004,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,3)

crush¶

n. a narrowing part at the end of a race to restrain animals; crush pen.

SWANTON The [unbroken] horses are put in a stockyard and there roped and driven into a crush, the head stalls and breaking rollers are put on, and the bits placed in their mouths. (1892,Notes on NZ,124)

Crush (kr&ubreve.sh), n. [Add.] 3. A fenced or boarded passageway, esp. for cattle or sheep, growing narrower as it extends in length. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2020)

Crush: Part of a stockyard where a single beast may be jammed and held for branding, etc. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

NEWTON ... the `crush' - a race perhaps ten yards in length and just wide enough for a grown beast to pass through. ... beyond the [drafting] gate the race terminated in the crush itself, the end being blocked by a rudely constructed bail. This was so designed that a horned beast could just get its head through the open bail ... the hinged arm pulled across and the ... animal locked behind the ears ... a further hinged rail ... swung over forcing and pinning its head down into a forked stump.' [cf illustr p94] (1949,High Country Days,93)

The function of the crush, which may consist of one, two, or even more separate pens, is to make it easier to force sheep through into the race. (Aug 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,133)

crush n. funnel-shaped part of a stockyard, used for controlling cattle. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),6)

WHEELER [caption] Rebuilding the cattleyards, showing the vet race and cattle crush. (1973,Historic Sheep Stations of NZ,14)

Crush. A small pen in which animals can be held tightly or a portion at the end of a race to restrain animals. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,4)

YEREX The area set aside for drenching, vaccinating, etc [sic] (the `crush') is invariably best situated adjacent to the drafting-yard and loading-out facility. (1982,Farming of Deer,101)

crush ... NZ (also crush-pen) fenced passage narrow at one end for handling stock. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,179) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

n. ?men; ?merely transf. or metaphorical

WOODHOUSE Big Mick the Speewah ringer, must make skin and trimmings fly/ This season if he means to keep ahead;/ For Barcoo Ben will run him and half a dozen more/ Of the lank Australian crush upon the board,/ And it ain't no use to tell us of the tallies that he shore,/ There'll be records broke this year, you take my word. (1950,Farm & Station Verse,33) [NOTES: 1897 McKee Wright Station Ballads `Shearing' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 33]

v. to confine a beast in a crush pen

SHARPE He [sc. the farmer] has no yard into which he can crush a beast so that it has to stand still. (1962,Country Occasions,63)

crush out¶

v. (Rural) (of cattle or sheep) to smash and tread young fern and second-growth.

.. while feeding on it [cattle] crushed out the second-growth fern which invariably came up ... (Jul 15, 1947,NZ Journal of Agriculture,25)

crush pen¶

n. a small pen, or a drafting pen with a narrowing race, for confining and controlling animals for drenching, branding, etc; also called crush.

W.H.S. ROBERTS At Macfarlane's the men saddled fresh horses and rode in some cattle which we had a great bother to yard, as everything was new ... The yard was divided into three - one large and two small - but as there was no crush pen, or drafting race, we had to head rope those requiring branding ... [check brands] (Dec 18, 1856,Diary) [NOTES: 1856 Dec 18 W.H.S. Roberts diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 43]

Crush pen: Name sometimes given to the forcing pens in sheep[yards], (especially dip[ping]) yards. (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

Can you please let me know the dimensions, structure, &c.,of a crush-pen for cattle. (Jan 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,534)

HARPER The lean-to in its turn was divided into crush-pens and a large receiving pen. (1934,Windy Island,240) [NOTES: [?1931 OEDS]]

The forwarding yards or pens, which are considerably smaller and consequently are useful for dealing with small mobs of sheep, as well as their function of leading up to The crush or forcing pen(s): These are usually one or two long, small pens, frequently tapering at one end, and holding about 50 sheep. (Jul 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,7)

BOWEN Receiving yards. These must have the capacity to take incoming mobs. They communicate with the forwarding yards, or diamond pens, which are much smaller, and lead up to the crush pens or forcing pens. ... These last [crush pens or forcing pens] are usually one or two long pens that communicate by a two-way gate with the mouth of the drafting race. (1955,Wool Away!,120)

SHARPE A crush pen used for the slaughter of cattle on farm or station ... is never torn down and rebuilt. (1962,Country Occasions,64)

SHARPE Dave's [stock-] yards consisted of two main pens and one small one, known as the `Crush', into which calves could be driven for earmarking and castration. (1966,Fiordland Muster,76)

crush ... NZ (also crush-pen) fenced passage narrow at one end for handling stock. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,179) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

1 n. (Rural) a long, narrow race or pen usually within a stockyard, used for examining or for restraining animals.

Can you please let me know the dimensions, structure &c., of a crush-pen for cattle. (Jun 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,534)

ROBERTS There was no crush pen or drafting race. (1856,Diary,43) [NOTES: in Beattie (1947) Early Runholding in Otago]

BOWEN The shape of crush pens should be long and narrow, so that it will be easy for one man to pack sheep up. (1955,Wool Away!,120)

MILLS ET AL When such a mob is being worked out of a yard, say into the crush-pen it is always wise to walk back into the yard corners through the sheep to loosen them up. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,71)

crush yard¶

1 n. (Rural) a stockyard that leads into a crush race or crush pen.

... would have done more but for the number of previously shorn sheep being mixed up with the woolly, making it necessary to fill the crush-yard more often, consequence being loss of time. (Feb 26, 1879,Tutira Station Diary) [NOTES: 1879 Feb 26 Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie-Smith Tutira 127]

For handling large herds a crush yard is recommended. (Apr 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,2)

crusher¶

n. a machine in which ore is crushed prior to the extraction of metal

An Otis crusher was erected to crush ore from the latter claim, but the yield of gold was insufficient ... (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/12)

BLYTH Crusher: Ores are broken down in crushing machines for reducing the size of the ore. (1935,Gold Mining Year Book,11)

Ruby Roycroft says her father, Andrew Austin, began on Martha Hill in 1900 as a labourer sinking a shaft. ... She says women were not allowed on the hill and when her husband was on the surface working on the crusher, she would take him his crib (lunch), and hurry back. (Feb 13, 1988,Auckland Herald,Sect. 2/2)

McARA Gates crusher: A type of gyratory crusher used at Waikino; some of them had corrugated mantles. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),323)

STEWART The shingle bank where the gaunt old crusher stood. (1983,Springtime in Taranaki,197) [NOTES: 1991 edition]

crushing¶

n. the agricultural practice of crushing fern, often prior to clearing, by overstocking esp. with cattle; fern-crushing.

LEVY ... the exponents of crushing have many millions of acres to their credit, using cattle merely as an implement. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,247,1970 ed.)

The historic `crushing' of bracken, to use a local term, was accompanied by a combination of fire and temporary overstocking with sheep, as is vividly described in Guthrie-Smith's Tutira. (Apr 1952,NZ Geographer,12) [NOTES: (Murphy)]

crushing room¶

n.

'H' They saunter into the roaring `crushing room', and watch the hard quartz rock slowly passing under the relentless stampers. (1898,Grain of Gold, The,5)

crushings¶

n. crushed metalliferous ore

SHORTLAND ... proprietors ... are contributing to the working of some claims, ... or are drawing dividends from good `crushings'. (Mar 12, 1868,Town by Night,31,1978 ed.)

BAINES At length we who had been spoilt by such marvellous rich stone as that we had had at first to deal with, were now tired ... with the poor return our crushings at this time yielded, and determined to abandon the mine. (1874,Edward Crewe,266)

crust¶

n. a charge under the Vagrancey Act

As a consequence Albert, the mendicant, was charged with vag,' otherwise known asthe crust,' and Magistrate Bartholomew let him off when he took a prohibition order out against himself, but told him to be careful. (Dec 13, 1912,NZ Truth,7)

n. a job, living, livelihood

Billy Murphy [a boxer] now knocking out a crust in the butter country ... (Jun 24, 1905,NZ Truth,1/7)

PICARD He's a man for pushing ahead for a crust and not hanging round chewing hops ... (1906,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,7)

NEWTON ... deer shooting for my crust. (1947,Wayleggo,36)

WILLIAMS Vic's in his office ... prior to accommodating any of the local work force determined to squander their credits of lethargy carefully accumulated during the average man's `just making a crust' day. (1979,Skin Deep,71)

JOHNSTON As long as ...the sun rose ... and gave them light [148] to do something about earning a crust, they were happy. (1981,Fish Factory,147)

crust ... NZ & Austral. sl. livelihood, living (what do you do for a crust?). (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,179) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 269; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 115]]

crusthead¶

n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] crusthead 986 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

crusty¶

adj. unclean

HARGREAVES At times the frustration of days searching with little return hurts the best of them. I remember lying on a crusty bunk down below and fully empathizing with whoever had painted, 'F*%$@ this shit!' (1998,On the Next Tide,10)

n. [confusion with crumbly or wrinkly in cits below? or are the cits illustrating crusty as in ODE?]

...that way you won't end up like us crusties at Capital Times - turning 30 with hardly a chapter to show for it. (Jan 23, 2002,Capital Times,14)

"Out of the way, crusties!" yelled one of the teens. The "crusties" turned around, revealing themselves as the ageing Tim Finn and his kid brother Neil. (Oct 11, 1997,Dominion,60)

Or maybe Womad New Zealand is the most compelling reason for all those Grey Lynn Festival crusties to leave their dank villas and join the world. (Apr 5, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

crusty back¶

n. huhu bug

NATUSCH The huhu, Prionoplus reticularis, also known as horny bug',crusty back' and `hum-bug' in adult life, is said to be a toothsome morsel in the grub stage - (1967,Animals of NZ, The,150)

crutch¶

v. to remove wool from the hindquarter of a sheep

When we were crutching, [the guys] always made sure they beat me, but that didn't worry me. (Jul 8, 2000,Dominion,32)

BOWEN No wether should be crutched without being pizzle-ringed (1955,Wool Away!,62)

McDONALD (1915,NZ Sheepfarming,68) [NOTES: See cit crutching vbl n2]

(Jul 20, 1920,NZ Journal of Agriculture,8)

15 Crutch. (1) to cut away the wool round a sheep's tail and hind legs so that he will not foul himself. (2) When sheep are dipped they are shoved under with a thing like an inverted crutch. This is called crutching. (3) The implement used for (2). (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

MARSH We're crutching now. (1945,Died in the Wool,28)

(1953,NZ Short Stories,189) [NOTES: 1953 Middleton in Stead NZ Short Stories (1966) 189]

BOWEN Sheep that are crutched heavily are usually fat-lamb ewes, the sheepowner being not as wool-conscious as the man who farms for wool and breeding. (1955,Wool Away!,53)

HARPER The sheep were drafted, then crutched and dipped. (1975,Eight Daughters,43)

crutch ... 5. Austral. & N.Z. to clip (wool) from the hindquarters of a sheep. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,269) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 179; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 115]]

RICHARDS It was in 1925 while at Waimai crutching for the Wilson brothers that I first heard the wireless (the name radio came later). (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,80)

crutch: To cut away the wool from the tail and hind legs so that the sheep will not foul itself. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/23) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

STUDHOLME Jan. 12th. Finished crutching wethers. Started on ewe lambs. (Jan 12, 1925,Coldstream,157,1985 ed.)

We're crutching sheep at the moment sothe kitchen's full of people havingmorning tea - but that's normal. (Jun 1992,North & South,7)

v. (Rural) to push sheep under dipping fluid with the use of a crutch, a long pole with an S-shaped rod at the end, with which to pull and push sheep's heads.

crutch: a pole having at one end a slightly curved crosspiece and used to push sheep under as they swim through the dip. Hence the verb to crutch, to push sheep under. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,23)

STUDHOLME One day whilst trying to 'crutch' (push under) some slippery-backed old ewe, my brother Geoffrey fell in amongst the sheep and got wet right over the top of his head. (1940,Tale of NZ,117)

STUDHOLME Another day, when working at John Douglas's dip at Waihao Downs, a cadet named TK Evans, who was crutching, went right out of sight - top boots, chokebore pants and all. (1940,Te Waimate,118)

n.

The `crutch' (or point of insertion of the main lateral branches) [of the kauri] is cross-grained ... (1874,TrNZI,185) [NOTES: (Firth)]

n. a crutch-shaped wooden implement designed to push sheep under during dipping.

It is necessary to hold each lot of sheep in the bath for the time necessary to secure thorough immersion. This may be done ... by the use of the crutch. (Sep 20, 1916,NZ Journal of Agriculture,228) [NOTES: [OED2]]

Crutch. (1) to cut away the wool round a sheep's tail and hind legs so that he will not foul himself. (2) When sheep are dipped they are shoved under with a thing like an inverted crutch. This is called crutching. (3) The implement used for (2). (C.) Implement used for crutching sheep [in the dip]. (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

NEWTON ... armed with a crutch [for pushing sheep under the dip]. (1949,High Country Days,102)

SCOTT And then Paul handed me a long stick that he called a crutch. `Think you could help push them under [the dip]?' (1953,Breakfast at Six,34)

STRONACH But dipping a big flock is a slow job. ... We had two men on the `crutch' pushing the sheep's heads under, and seven men at the race. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,55)

TOMLINSON We children [c1890s] used to plunge empty dip packets attached to a sheep crutch into a long swim sheep dip made of wood. (1968,Remembered Trails,11)

crutch ... NZ & Austral. instrument used to immerse sheep for dipping. 2 v.t. NZ & Austral. immerse (sheep) with a crutch. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,179) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

RICHARDS</b> Dad wascrutch' man and also responsible for timing each dip full of sheep before opening the gate and letting them out into the draining pens. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,48)

v. to push (sheep) under a swim-dip with a crutch

Crutch. (1) to cut away the wool round a sheep's tail and hind legs so that he will not foul himself. (2) When sheep are dipped they are shoved under with a thing like an inverted crutch. This is called crutching. (3) The implement used for (2). (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

STUDHOLME One day whilst trying to `crutch' (push under) some slippery-backed old ewe, my brother Geoffrey fell in amongst the sheep ... and in spite of jumping into the creek ... lost a good deal of skin from dip burns. (1940,Te Waimate,117,1954 ed.)

crutch ... NZ & Austral. instrument used to immerse sheep for dipping. 2 v.t. NZ & Austral. immerse (sheep) with a crutch. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,179) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

1 v. (Rural) to remove wool from the head, belly and rear end of a sheep in order to keep fleece-wool clean, to prevent wool-blindness and to clear udders for lambing.

The keeping-lambs are crutched, branded, dipped and placed out. (Jul 20, 1920,NZ Journal of Agriculture,8)

On some stations the whole flock are crutched in the autumn. (Oct 1891,NZ Farmer,418)

1 n. (Rural) a long pole with an S-shaped iron attached for forcing sheep's heads under the wash in a plunge, pot, or swim dip. (See dipping crutch)

MCLEOD Alongside the dip stood George, holding the crutch, a long stick with a curved iron on the end, shaped with one side bent down and the other up. Sometimes a weak sheep could not swim all the way and had to have its head lifted with the crutch to help it through. (1954,On the Hill,24)

.. he rubbed the soapy water well into them, particularly round their necks, with a weapon designated a 'crutch.' (1888,Textile Educator I,262)

LOUGHNAN crutch: a pole having at one end a slightly curved crosspiece and used to push sheep under as they swim through the dip. Hence the verb to crutch, to push sheep under. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,23)

crutch gum¶

n.

Gum seekers soon discovered that crutch gum could be recovered from the high forks [in kauri trees] by climbing for it. (Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,29)

crutch man¶

1 n. (Rural) a worker at a swim, pot, or plunge dip who uses a crutch to plunge sheep's heads under the dipping fluid.

NELSON The man on the crutch was known as the 'crutch man.' (1999,Eugene Nelson Glossary,4)

RICHARDS Dad was crutch man and also responsible for timing each dip full of sheep before opening the gate and letting them into the draining pens. (1991,Off the Sheep's Back,48)

crutch strike¶

1 n. (Rural) fly-blowing of sheep in the folds of the crutch.

In districts where crutch-strike causes trouble in ewes, crutching or early shearing is advised. (Sep 1961,NZ Journal of Agriculture,230)

crutcher¶

n. (Rural) a worker who crutches [i.e. removes wool from belly and hindquarters of sheep prior to winter and lambing ,often itinerant, working in pairs or small gangs.] (See crutch)

STAPLES Morning and afternoon teas must be prepared for the crutchers and haycarters and permanent men. ibid 48 Four crutchers were back, and drafting off and shedding up were going on every day. (1964,Cooks and Shepherds Come Away,25)

ASPINALL When the weather permits three crutchers come and trim the wool from around the sheep's [sic] eyes and tails. (1993,Farming Under Aspiring,161)

There should be someone penning up for the crutchers and also picking over the wool. One man will find himself kept fairly busy keeping the sheep up to two good crutchers, and 'dag-classing' at the same time. (Jul 1911,NZ Farmer,705)

MILLS ET AL The crutchers were a fine bunch of chaps ... (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,122)

RICHARDS He spent the entire day .. at the end of the shearing board watching the crutchers at work. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,52)

RICHARDS The best and fastest crutcher I ever met was Jimmy Rota from Okirae Pa. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A)

n. one who crutches the hindquarters of sheep; occas. crutcher-and-dagger

He has sailed to Fiji, been a crutcher on a shearing gang, and a gilly on a Scottish deer farm. (Oct 23, 2002,Capital Times,5)

FAIRBURN a drunken swagger, a crutcher-and-dagger,/ (1958,Poetry Harbinger,21) [NOTES: (`Deep South')]

DICK A room full of crutchers, rough diamonds all of them. (1964,High Country Family,70)

FISH Ralph's attitude towards the `drifters' - gangs of scrubcutters, shearers, crutchers, footrotters, dippers, fencers and dockers was quite different. (1978,Dolphins and Killer Whales,45)

ANDERSON Besides, the crutchers will be here any day now. (1981,Both Sides of the River,102)

1 n. (Rural) a worker who operates the crutch during the process of sheep dipping. (See crutch man)

.. the dry chuckers-in will vie with another in feats of strength, selecting heavy sheep and pitching them over instead of through the door. There is an additional charm in this, because thereby the first crutcher below is made very angry. (1888,Textile Educator I,279)

BREMNER A description of an unidentified sheepstation in 1881 recorded that a twenty-two man gang ... put through [the sheep-wash] 1250 sheep in a ... day. ... The trough was divided into four partitions with a `crutcher' at each. Four times each sheep was soaped, its back scrubbed with a crutch. (1985,Woolscours of NZ,15)

crutching¶

n.

Mr Cregoe works alone on the farm for much of the time, getting in a casual worker for docking and weaning and contractors for crutching and shearing. (May 13, 2004,Dominion Post,C7)

Proper dipping, crutching, dagging, &c., are necessary; and if scouring be present care should especially be taken to keep the posterior parts clear of dung-clogged wool ... (Jan 15, 1913,NZ Journal of Agriculture,577)

MacDONALD Three or four weeks before lambing time the ewes should be dagged, and if crutching is followed, any wool ... may be clipped in a careful manner. (1915,NZ Sheepfarming,68)

MacDONALD BLOWFLY. - Cleanliness by way of proper dipping, crutching, etc., assists towards suppression of the fly. (1920,Australian & NZ Sheep Farming,156)

Crutch. (1) to cut away the wool round a sheep's tail and hind legs so that he will not foul himself. (2) When sheep are dipped they are shoved under with a thing like an inverted crutch. This is called crutching. (3) The implement used for (2). (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

The wool removed by crutching is of low value and the amount per clip is usually small. For these reasons `crutchings' are seldom if ever classed except by the wool brokers when the wool is sent to them for binning. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,710)

In the rural districts [of New Zealand] a formidable body of idiomatic uses is developing and a new language is being coined. This is no more true than it is of the remote' back-country of Canterbury, where changing vocabulary is already a noticable geographical characteristic. The local idiom is naturally often linked with sheep, wool, and station practice.Dag', for example, is a word used first to describe a tuft of wool fouled by excrement. The removal of dags from the hind-quarters of sheep is a seasonal operation usually called crutching.' Used personally,dag' was earlier a term of some (1945,NZ Geographer,19) [NOTES: (Cumberland's note to Pascoe's `High Country')]

STRONACH The huge woolshed was equipped with machines, used for crutching only. Ibid. 36 Next came the Rainbow, on which were wethers, and finally the Saxon again, to get the ewes in for crutching ... (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,8)

BOWEN I am of the opinion that crutching can be overdone, as well as underdone. No more wool should be taken off than is necessary to keep the sheep clean, and to allow the lamb to feed and find the teats easily, for heavy crutching can spoil the fleece when it comes to shearing time, causing a large quantity of half-wool pieces. (1955,Wool Away!,53)

NEWTON After crutching, the ewes were simply turned up each side of the Poulter. Ibid. 185 Crutching: Trimming the wool off from around the sheep's tail so that they do not get `daggy' or dirty. (1966,Boss's Story, The,58)

A social visit really, but there was some work as a number of farmers called in shearers and rousies to do their crutching. (1988,More Magazine,32)

But aside from shearing and crutching times, life was good at the station ... (1966,NZ Short Stories,128,1976 ed.) [NOTES: (Middleton `Saving the Breed')]

NEWTON After crutching, the ewes were simply turned up each side of the Poulter. (1996,Boss's Story, The,58)

n. (Rural) the removal of wool from the head, belly and rear end of sheep, in order to keep fleece-wool clean, sheep from becoming wool-blind and allow udders to be clear for lambing. (See crutch)

MACDONALD If crutching is followed, any wool that might hinder the lambs from sucking may be clipped. (1915,NZ Sheepfarming,68)

BOWEN .. for any shearer this sticky crutching involves a larger number of blows. (1955,Wool Away!,64)

In crutching the sheep are taken into the shearing shed, and the wool taken off close to the skin, starting a third of the way up the belly, clearing out the crutch and continuing up over the tail. (Oct 1891,NZ Farmer,418)

Proper dipping, crutching, dagging &c. are necessary. (Jan 1919,NZ Journal of Agriculture,577)

NEWTON The boys were mustering the hoggets for crutching the day I was there ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,214)

1 n. (Rural) the action of pushing sheep under dipping fluid in a swim, plunge or pot dip with a crutch. (See crutch man; on the crutch)

.. the trough is always full from end to end with the sheep passing through it in a continuous string; the man at each partition repeating the process of 'crutching' already described. (1888,Textile Educator I,262)

When sheep are dipped, they are shoved under with a thing like an inverted crutch. This is called crutching. (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

Crutch. ... (2) When sheep are dipped they are shoved under with a thing like an inverted crutch. This is called crutching. (3) The implement used for (2). (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

crutching cramp¶

1 n. (Rural) white muscle or stiff lamb disease, occurring where sheep are wintered on turnips.

EDGAR White muscle disease (Crutching Cramp, Stiff Lamb disease) .. Many outbreaks have occurred when hoggets were taken to the shearing shed for crutching and in districts where this has occurred the condition is known as 'crutching cramp.' (1959,NZ Farmers' Veterinary Guide,163)

crutching gang¶

1 n. (Rural) a team of crutchers and a shed hand or two.

WATERSON It was winter time late in the '50s and the crutching gang was in full swing. (1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,115)

crutching muster¶

1 n. (Rural) a gathering of sheep to a woolshed to be crutched [usually prior to tupping or lambing.]

NEWTON After weaning, they [the hoggets] were taken out to Lochinvar until the autumn muster in May when they were out back on their blocks until the crutching muster in early July. (1952,High Country Journey,137)

DU FAUR .. this can be done at the crutching muster ... (1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,37)

SALISBURY It was during this crutching muster that I had quite a tumble from my horse. (1994,I Was So Lucky,96)

crutching sale¶

n. a sale of crutchings

Regarding the respective values of the clips, it is hardly necessary to state that fleeces from March-shorn sheep were not able to be rolled. From them only stained wool and bellies were sorted out ... A star bale sold at a crutching sale made 101/4d., while a fadge of the same wool pooled later made 121/4 pence ... (1929,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,10/326)

crutching shed¶

1 n. (Rural) a small, basic woolshed with only one or two stands [with insufficient room for wool table etc.]

Improvements include sheepyards and crutching shed. (Nov 17, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,32)

crutchings¶

n. wool removed during crutching

Crutchings: Wool removed from the posterior of sheep at crutching. Normally coarser, and in the case of crossbred wool, more medullated than the remainder of the fleece. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,54)

The wool removed by crutching is of low value and the amount per clip is usually small. For these reasons `crutchings' are seldom if ever classed except by the wool brokers when the wool is sent to them for binning. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,710)

ABRRY He recalls a bale of crutchings from Friedlander, weighing 950 lbs. the biggest ever carted by Dixon brothers. (1966,In the Lee of the Hokonuis,373)

crutchings pl. n. Austral. & N.Z. wool clipped from a sheep's hindquarters. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,269) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 179; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 115]]

SLIGO A bale of crutchings that would fetch a fair price ... was open. -->=daggy wool removed from sheep (1987,Final Things,136)

HUTCHINGS We used to roam the district ... picking up wool bales, crutchings and dags ... (1987,Tall Half-Backs,79)

McKAY Baxter's duties, as recorded in the station journal kept by the manager Mr Charlie Harris, were with the sheep, drafting, and picking over crutchings and dead wool in the paddocks. (1990,James K. Baxter,86)

1 n. (Rural) wool taken from head, tail and belly of lambs and sheep.

SQUIRE Crutchings - Wool from around the britch and hind quarter area of a sheep. Identified as either first crutchings, second crutchings, fly or ring crutchings. (1991,A to Z Glossary of Wool Terms,14)

BRABAZON Carted 1 bale crutchings, Railway. (Jun 9, 1893,Brabazon Diaries)

We hear farmers bragging of the good money they have received for crutchings. (May 1909,NZ Farmer,364)

In addition, crutchings bring in aGBP60, these returns being based on war control prices. (May 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,502)

Crutchings made up 5.5 per cent of the catalogues. [first crutchings, second crutchings, fly crutchings, ring crutchings.] (Aug 24, 2001,Dominion,16)

cry babies¶

n. (recipe)

BASHAM CRY BABIES ... hot coffee ... nutmeg ... eggs ... soda ... treacle ... salt ... sugar ... vinegar ... butter ... flour ... ground ginger ... Mix and drop with teaspoon on buttered tray ... Ice with a splash of icing to look soft and teary ... (1939,Aunt Daisy's Cookery Book,130)

cry off¶

v. give up (an activity)

SARGESON cry off the booze: give up drinking (1964,Collected Stories,299)

cry ruth¶

phr. to vomit

McGILL ruth vomit, phr. cry ruth; derived from the sound involved. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,95)

Crying Jenny¶

n. a common goldfields (and then ?general) name for a creek, cf Roaring Meg, Gentle Annie.

PYKE There are three creeks in succession on this line of road - tributaries of the Kawarau River. The first is very small and in a dry season merely drips from the rocks, and is called Crying Jenny.' The second, which tumbles down from the mountains impetuously and with great noise, isRoaring Meg.' The third, being a sluggish stream, has received, by popular assent, the designation of `Gentle Annie.' (1874,George Washington Pratt,3)

cryptic skink¶

n. a skink commonly seen in Southland and the damper areas of Otago, characterised by reddish brown colouring on upper surfaces. [Oligosoma inconspicuum]

'So for the extensive survey, we're using a basic method of counting how many lizards are captured in a 24-hour period. It's a quick index of population size for species such as common skinks and McCann's skinks and common (brown) geckos. Unfortunately we're unlikely to detect less abundant species such as green skinks, cryptic skinks or jewelled geckos.' (Mar 2009,Internet - see Notes,75/11)

Other endemic Central Otago skinks include the scree skink, the green skink and the cryptic skink. (2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/about-doc/concessions-and-permits/conservation-revealed/central-otago-plants-animals-lowres.pdf]

.. the intricately patterned cryptic skink, favours herb and shrub areas and can tolerate damp conditions ... (2002,NZ Geographic,57/6)

Common skinks, McCann's skinks and cryptic skinks are diurnal heliotherms that obtain heat from direct sunlight. (Dec 3, 2007,NZ Journal of Ecology,171) [NOTES: Published online 3.12.07]

crypto¶

n. short for cryptosporidium

Cryptosporidium is an animal present on Earth in uncountable numbers... The only good news is that they can't handle rejection, making little effort to combat the body's immune system.That's a good thing for the crypto, too, as they reproduced so fast that if not rapidly, and usually explosively, excreted, they would kill every host species and themselves. (Dec 6, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

crypto-wowser¶

adj. secretly or not-obviously puritanical.

FAIRBURN The extension of Trust control might be beneficial in New Zealand, provided it did not conceal a crypto-wowser motive. (1967,Woman Problem,53) [NOTES: 1955 Fairburn The Wowser in the Woodpile in 1967 Woman Problem 53]

cryptosporidium bug¶

n.

The contamination of the water supply in Masterton with the cryptosporidium bug is a reminder that public health can never be taken for granted. (Sep 27, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

A recent outbreak of the cryptosporidium stomach bug among Hutt Valley school children has prompted a renewed call to ensure that the infectious bug doesn't get into local swimming pools again. (Nov 9, 2000,Dominion,12)

CSU¶

abbr. Combined State Unions

Tangihanga leave [headline] The CSU is to lodge a claim for the recognition of tangihanga leave. The claim is based on the belief that tangihanga is a grieving process, and that as a consequence, extended bereavement leave should be granted those attending a tangi. (Jun 18, 1986,PSA Journal,6)

CTU¶

abbr. Council of Trade Unions replacing FOL from 10 May 1988; first official use at the final meeting of FOL.

Mr Knox paid tribute to the new leadership of the CTU and ... to CTU president Ken Douglas. (May 10, 1988,Evening Post,12)

Cuba Street Yank¶

n. one who parades a main street with the dressy confidence of an American serviceman; c1946-7 to c1952 a Wellington name for a `wide-boy' often in distinctive dress, who spends the evening promenading [Compare bodgie, bunny, greaso, milkbar cowboy, zoot-suit boy.] (See also Queen Street Yank)

1 [Candid Comment' on narrow-legged trousers]Cuba Street Yank': I don't mind them narrow, but I sure wouldn't want them that narrow. (Feb 6, 1952,Evening Post,14)

cube¶

n. short for cubic metre

Native Timber For Sale ... 32 Cube Kahikatea .. 2 Cube Yellow Kahikatea .. 8 Cube Matai .. 12 Cube Rata .. 9 Cube of Shorts (Apr 19, 2003,Hawke's Bay Today,C3)

cubehead¶

n.

GRAHAM Cubehead Cubiceps caeruleus Regan ... Cubehead Cubiceps baxteri McCulloch (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,405) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 405]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] cubehead 2204-5 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

cuckoo¶

n. any of various migrating birds which lay their eggs in nests of other birds. In New Zealand applied to the migratory Pacific spp. shining cuckoo Chrysococcyx lucius (1889), and the longtailed cuckoo Eudynamis taitensis (1889) (M)

(Queen Charlotte Sound) Two sorts of Cuckoos, one as large as our common sort, of a brown colour variegated with black, [ed. note [Long-tailed Cuckoo, Eudynamis taitensis.]] the other not larger than a sparrow, [ed. note [Shining Cuckoo, Chalcites lucidus.]] of a splendid green cast above & elegantly varied with waves of a gold, green, brown, & white colour below. (Feb 1777,Cook's Journals,3/806) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/806]

POLACK Cuckoos ... are also found, with various plumage; (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/297)

DIEFFENBACH Two migra-[123]tory cuckoos (the Cuculus fasciatus, Forst.), called kohaperoa, or koekoia, and a very small and beautiful kind (the Cuculus nitems of the same author), called by the natives pipiwawaroa - which appear on the coast at Christmas - mark the period of the first potato-harvest. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/122)

ANGAS The summer birds of passage are already arriving, and a most brilliant little cuckoo (chrysococcyx lucidus), with green and golden plumage, was brought in ... killed by a cat. (1847,Savage Life,2/66)

THOMSON Two migratory Cuckoos visit New Zealand in summer from Australia and the southern islands, and depart in autumn. During the warm summer nights they sing sweetly. The Kohoperoa, one of these cuckoos, is about the size and colour of the sparrow-hawk; the Pipiwarauroa cuckoo is a much smaller and a more variegated-feathered bird. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/26)

DOMETT Cuckoo ..... F. Cuculidae; Chrysococcus lucidus (Gray). Cuculus nitens (Forster) (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/307)

PARKER ` There are two species of the Long-tailed Cuckoo ( Eudynamis taitensis), and the beautiful Bronze or Shining cuckoo (chrysococcyx lucidus). They ar both migratory birds. The Long-tailed Cuckoo spends its winter in some of the Pacific islands, the Shining Cuckoo in Australia.' (1889,Catalogue NZ Exhibition,118) [NOTES: [Morris]]

MORRIS Cuckoo ... Common English bird-name. In New Zealand, the name if applied to Eudynamis taitensis (sc. of Tahiti) Sparm., the long-tailed Cockoo; and to chrysococcyx lucidus, Gmel., the Shining Cuckoo. (1898,Austral English,109)

PFAFF All night the More-pokes, Wekas (Maori hens), Kiwis, and, in summer, the Cuckoos, kept up their cries ... (1914,Diggers' Story, The,11)

BEATTIE I never saw the native quail, the cuckoo nor the morepork in the Central [Otago, c1860s], but I saw the sparrow-hawk, the rock wren, and plenty of hawks and pihoihoi (ground larks). (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,121)

SARGESON (1965,Memoirs of a Peon,155) [NOTES: check genus]

3 n. one who does not pay Union fees but receives Union benefits

Get rid of the Union cuckoo'/ And thestool pigeon' as well./ The arrear fiends' and thering-necks' ... (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,28)

cuckoo cress¶

n.

cuckoo cress [s] Cardamine pratensis L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,19)

cuckoo scab¶

n.

Cuckoo scab.-A skin disease sheep get at the back of their heads and on their ears. I have only noticed it among merino and in the back country. (Jan 20, 1934,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

cuckoo/cookoo¶

n. (Rural) a novice or poor station cook. (See also cookaroo/cookeroo)

Newton The next job was the babbling brook'. I once had a chap (a cook himself) inform me that there werecooks, cuckoos, cuckeroos, and cuckeroo b - s'. Needless to add my informant was a cook. (1966,Boss's Story, The,65)

NEWTON I'm the cook. There are cooks, cuckoos and cookaroos. (1964,Straggle Muster,86)

BRITTAIN Station cooks are important, and are said to be classified variously as cooks, cookoos, cookeroos and cookeroo bastards. [cuckoo] (2000,Lake Coleridge,85)

cucumber¶

n. cucumber fish

HULME & MORRISON Whitebait in pristine condition are beautiful... There are local names for them, too - elephant ears and Don Doolin 'bait (which isn't true whitebait at all), and cucumbers (which are actually smelt, Retropinna retropinna, or paraki). (1989,Homeplaces,104)

PAUL Common smelt Retropinna retropinna Also called silvery, estuarine smelt, or cucumber (from the smell of freshly caught fish). Silvery, particularly along the sides. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,49)

n. a sea cucumber

[species name] sea cucumber .. [scientific name] -- [other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Sea cucumber Stichopus mollis A holthurian, quite cucumber-like in general appearance ... (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,172)

SANSOM From ... Thule he collected the sea cucumbers, ... and sent a shipment to the Chinese market. These cucumbers or sea slugs are members of the tropical beche-de-mer ... (1982,In the Grip of an Island,144)

2 n.

Indeed, rare species such as Pycroft's petrel, Duvaucel's gecko and the New Zealand native cucumber are all showing signs of regaining their foothold on these islands. (May 2002,Forest & Bird,304/10)

cucumber fish¶

n. various small fish, or fry, with a cucumbery taste

1/164 Chlorophthalmus Nigripinnis ... Cucumber Fish. (1911,Records of the Canterbury Museum) [NOTES: Waite]

GR AHAM Cucumber Fish Chlorophthalmus nigripinnis Gunther (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,400) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 400]

NATUSCH Family SUDIDAE (cucumber fishes). Similar to the lantern fishes, ... Chlorophthalmus nigripinnis ... green above and silvery below, averages seven inches in length. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,29)

WILSON CUCUMBER FISH A small marine fish which is related to the lizard-fish and the lantern-fish and gets its name because it smells like sliced, fresh cucumber. ... Often confused with the [smelt] (they both smell of cucumber) but no relation. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,43)

[species name] cucumber fish .. [scientific name] Chlorophthalmus nigripinnis . [other name(s)] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Cucumber fish Chlorophthalmus nigripinnis (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,54)

The surrounding water [off Point Chevalier] was alive with crabs and small fishes, cucumber fishes, and eels. (Aug 8, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62) [NOTES: (Sinclair `At the Point')]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] cucumberfish 600-2 124 [?Phillipps ?] CUCUMBER FISH Chlorophthalmus nigripinnis ... The cucumber fish is an elongate cigar-shaped species that reaches a maximum length of about 20cm. ... The fish derives its name from the strange cucumber-like smell it emits. (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n. (cucumber) smelt

McDOWALL The cucumber fish, trout, and blenny are too few in number to represent all that are left of the whitebait swarms... It is strange that Douglas makes no mention of inanga. (1984,NZ Whitebait Book, The,99)

PHILLIPPS NEW ZEALAND SMELT Retropinna retropinna Richardson. ... The smelt is the cucumber fish of some localities and the silvery of others. (1940,Fishes NZ,53)

GRAHAM SMELT (PARAKI) Retropinna retropinna (Richardson) ... They are often referred to as Silvery, while in other parts they are called Cucumber Fish. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,113)

DOOGUE & MORELAND SMELT ... Other names: Retropinna sp.; silvery, cucumber-fish; inanga-papa (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,196)

WILSON SMELT A common little fish often confused with - and caught with - whitebait. He is the bitter, silver fellow the sharp-eyed whitebaiter discards from his nets. Smells like cucumber, hence one of his other names Cucumber-fish. Also called Silvery. ... Several types of smelt occur around New Zealand - Canterbury, Chatham Islands, Rotorua, Sea Foam, Southland and Stokell's - but it takes a real expert to tell them apart. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,208)

cucumber rumble¶

phr. sexual act

If this was so then why did he come on strong with her best friend on the very day Andrew and Anne had done the cucumber rumble? (Mar 13, 2001,Evening Post,6)

cucumber smelt¶

n.

BUICK Then there came [up the Waitaki] what from its bright appearance was known as the silvery' (<i>Argentina retropinna</i>), and, from its odour when young, as thecucumber' smelt. (1937,Moa-Hunters of NZ,174)

STUDHOLME Enunga[sic] Smelts (mature whitebait) and silveries (Cucumber smelts). (1940,Te Waimate,236)

In Lake Huro, we saw a shoal of small fish, and on capturing some of them found them to be the cucumber smelt, identical with the New Zealand fish. (Feb 12, 1924,Otago Witness,7)

cuda¶

n. (informal) a barracuda [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

LELAND Cuda - a cute cuddly name for a BARRACUDA! (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,30)

cuddly¶

n. a blanket, a rug

... We remembered that babies don't sleep much whether they're wrapped in a cuddly or spread on a sheepskin ... (Oct 18, 1989,Evening Post,33)

cuddy¶

n. the saloon or cabin in large ship where officers and cabin passengers have meals, etc., familiar to early immigrants

MONEY Half of the entire cuddy berths were occupied by a wealthy Canterbury squatter.] (1871,Knocking About in NZ,2)

n. a donkey

BEATTIE A man I knew, Tom Cuddie by name, drove a load up to Gabriel's in 1861. He had a bullock in the shafts and a horse in the lead, and when the diggers saw this mixed team, and knew the name of the driver, they jokingly said the load had been brought by a horse, a bullock, and a cuddy. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,172)

2 n. an early small cottage

SHAW [Caption] The Cuddy (1854), Te Waimate Station. This tiny cottage with its steeply-pitched, hipped roof, symmetrically placed windows and entry porch, was built from vertically laid totara slabs. (1997,History of New Zealand Architecture,16)

STUDHOLME ... he was taken to the `cuddy' to sleep, as we had no other accommodation. (1954,Te Waimate,50)

STRONGMAN Michael Studholme's first home, The Cuddy, was constructed in 1854 from a single totara tree and the roof was thatched with snowgrass. In the winter of 1860 the small vegetable garden belonging to the cuddy was empty ... (1984,Gardens of Canterbury,59)

ADAMS ... every few minutes a shower of hail ...would compel us to make a precipitate retreat into the cuddy. (1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,21)

KENNAWAY ... our delicate ... stomachs received the most racy and highly esteemed dainties peculiar to the cuddy table, and which when you all come out you will soon discover, such as `Duff & Treacle', Boiled Pudding, Plum Duff, ... and bread in particular. (1851,Biscuit and Butter,78,1973 ed.)

3 n. the parlour or saloon of an accommodation-house

HALL-JONES ... our host asked us into the `cuddy', as he called the parlour [of his accommodation-house]. (1971,Mr Surveyor Thomson,48) [NOTES: c1850s in 1971 Hall-Jones Mr Surveyor Thomson 48 -house].]

4 n. a stall for animals

MACNICOL Warm `cuddies' were built along a shed wall to house his pets [goats]. (1965,Skippers Road,84)

cudweed¶

n. the common name for Gnaphalium, silver weed.

(Queen Charlotte Sound) Amongst the known kinds of plants are common and rough Bindweed, Nightshade and Nettles, ... and Cranes bill: [fnc Geranium. [ed. [Probably Geranium sessiflorum.]]] also Cudweed, [ed. fn 3 Possibly Gnaphalium sp. or Helichrysum sp.], rushes, ... (Feb 1777,Cook's Journals,3/804,1967 ed.) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/804-805]

POLACK Speedwell, sow, and melon thistles (coetus), virgin's bower, vanilloe, or willow, euphorbia, cudweed, crane's-bill, junchous rushes in all the swamps ... (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/295)

Compositae Gnaphalium luteo-album Agg. cudweed (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: (Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri)]

HILGENDORF CUDWEED (Gnaphalium luteo-album). This or an allied species is sometimes called silver weed. It is found all over the world including New Zealand, in all soils and climates. It is an annual or rarely biennial with a weak stem reaching a height of 15 or 18 inches. Clothed in all its parts ... with soft white woolly down. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,171,1967 ed.)

2 n.

cudweed, Jersey [s] Gnaphalium luteo-album L. Ibid. 41 Jersey cudweed [s] Gnaphalium luteo-album L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,19)

2 n. Guaphalium paludosum.

cuffs-an'-collar farmer¶

n. (Rural) a farmer who has not had a practical training in farming.

Sandy scoffed. "Teachin' him to be a cuffs-an'-collar farmer, think," he said. "Ugh, the only college I know on to teach a boy is his father's farm where he's born and brought up." (Jul 25, 1925,NZ Dairy Exporter,60)

culch/colch¶

v.

The mess [from the oyster dredge] is dumped on the deck and picked over - culched' - while the nextdrift' goes on. (Aug 10, 1921,Quick March,31)

BOB CATER heard from a Bluff oysterman Removing saleable oysters from the mass of weed, grit, shell, etc. which comes up in the trawl, and is dumped onto a shipboard table for colching. One also `colches' this lot. (Sep 28, 1988,Personal Communication)

culching¶

n. returning material to the sea

JOHNSON Takeable oysters were sorted and bagged, and all else returned to the sea - a process called 'culching' which helped rejuvenate the beds. (2004,Hooked,207)

cull¶

n.

The sheep were culls and he valued them at about 5s 6d per head. (Sep 23, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

HENDERSON Hadn't we seen our officers, when we cameinto camp, weeding 'em out - through therace - the culls into the infantry. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,238)

The first point is the disposal ofculls. (May 11, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,55)

A fat ewe is worth 18s, if good. There are always some culls. (Mar 25, 1937,King Country Chronicle,3)

v. to select stock according to quality

WILLIAMS & REEVES I'd far sooner choose/ To be writing to you, than be culling the ewes. (1889,Colonial Couplets,9)

Cull: (1) A broken-down old sheep. A sheep to be sold out of the flock for age, bad wool, or poor condition. As adj[ective], cull describes a ewe, wether, cow, etc., that has been marked for disposal. (2) To select, as above. (C.) 2. [In NZ the word developed into a euphemism for exterminate, esp. since the passing of the Noxious Animals Act 1954. Contrast OED2 4 b. spec. To select and kill (wild animals or birds), usu. in order to improve the stock ...] To exterminate noxious wild animals, esp. deer. (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

With the object of determining the best method of culling deer in the Tararuas ... the sum of [pouinds]10 was granted by the Acclimatisation Society last night. (Apr 12, 1934,Evening Post,10) [NOTES: [OED2]]

DUGGAN These stags stand on the skyline of the mind,/ .../ If you must cull, oh make of death an art,/ Shoot at short range and only through the heart./ (1951,More Poems,22)
