NEWTON In an attempt to check this decline the Acclimatisation Society started a systematic shooting campaign. The Muir brothers and McLennan were sent in there and although they were only culling (shooting the poorer types) they recorded some enormous tallies. (1952,High Country Journey,96)

MARSHALL Raf thought we should cull the rabbits before we had too much beer, and we went off ... towards the pines. (1982,Master of Big Jingles,78)

[Hdg] Cull the Cows Now... The dairy farmer should not miss the opportunity of culling out of his herd.. any heifers which are obviously duds. (Nov 30, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,86)

adj.

A powder that preserves the characteristic flavour of the onion and which can be made from cull onions.. is reported. (Feb 15, 1934,Feilding Star,4)

Cull lambs were easier at 8s to 9s. (Mar 6, 1937,King Country Chronicle,5)

NEWTON I.. also took out a hundred or so old ewes and a handful of cull two-tooths. (1966,Boss's Story, The,88)

v. (Rural) to draft unwanted animals or those of poor quality from a main mob or herd.

Snipe-nosed sheep were culled. (1930,BLANK ENTRY,247) [NOTES: in ACLAND (1950) Early Canterbury Runs]

WILLIAMS & REEVES I'd far sooner choose To be writing to you, than be culling the ewes. (1889,Colonial Couplets,9)

Mr Turner culls for dagginess. (Jul 6, 1995,NZ Farmer,15)

.. he removes about 30 cows a year when he culls on high cell counts. (Jul 2002,Dominion,36.C7)

1 n. (Rural) a cow or sheep that is no longer required for grazing or breeding and is usually sent to freezing-works for slaughter.

Culls could then often be bought at from 6d to 2s ... (1910,Tapanui Station,36)

RICHARDS The culls grew and thrived on the young grass. (1991,Off the Sheep's Back,25)

The ewes as a rule were inferior both in quality and condition, many of them being aged, and apparently 'culls' from the standing flocks of the settlers ... (Mar 1895,NZ Farmer,94)

Diseases, mainly mammitis and sterility, are responsible for more than half the culls from the herd.. (May 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,14)

As might be expected, there's a very ready demand in the Christchurch town milk herds for the Macartney culls. (Mar 1, 1955,NZ Dairy Exporter,6)

NEWTON Immediately after that, we straggled the ewe blocks .. I kept in about 200 culls ... (1966,Boss's Story, The,32)

cull cow¶

1 n. (Rural) a dairy cow that is no longer a worthwhile asset in a herd.

I don't like the idea of quitting them at cull-cow prices. (Apr 1, 1957,NZ Dairy Exporter,33)

Wanted! Cull cows & works bulls. [cull-cow] (Apr 4, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,19)

cull out¶

v. (Rural) to cleanse a herd or flock by sending poor producers or unthifty stock for sale or slaughter.

It is quite right to cull out the cow giving a small amount of milk with a low test - every time - they are certainly the robbers. (Dec 20, 1928,NZ Dairy Exporter,30)

By culling out the lowest producers every year ... (Aug 1, 1936,NZ Dairy Exporter,50)

STUDHOLME .. my father had a great down on light coloured beasts, which he culled out and slaughtered. (1940,Te Waimate,135)

Such data will objectively detect 'poor doers' and 'shy feeders.' Shy feeders should be culled out as detected and treated. (Mar 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture,5)

culled¶

adj.

The sheep in question was not a culledewe. (Oct 24, 1914,Stratford Evening Post,2)

Cullen fund¶

n. (Politics) the Labour government's superannuation scheme, initiated by Minister of Finance Michael Cullen

He also notes the Clark Government's signature economic achievements: KiwiSaver and the Cullen fund. (Aug 15, 2009,Listener (New Zealand Listener),40)

The Opposition's great gift here is that the government's superannuation solution, the Cullen fund, is something of an undersold political scandal. (Mar 13, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

Cullenisation¶

n.

National's Bill English asked if the frail dollar, the slowed gdp growth and possibility of a budget deficit might not be evidence, "to coin a phrase", of the Cullenisation of New Zealand. (Sep 7, 2000,Dominion,2)

[Hdg] Speaker says no to 'cullenisation'. Speaker Jonathan Hunt yesterday banned the use of the (Sep 7, 2000,Evening Post,2)

culler¶

n. a professional hunter employed, usu. by the State, to kill noxious animals, esp. deer

NEWTON Deer cullers, men who shoot deer professionally for the Government or an acclimatization society. (1947,Wayleggo,53)

DUFF It is true that this is primarily a trampers' hut, but trampers don't usually carry periodicals in their swags. ... But here the two journals are now, and I wish I knew how often they are read by the other users of this shelter - rabbiters, deer-cullers, roadmen, storm-bound swaggers, and so on. (Mar 19, 1951,Shepherd's Calendar,25,1961 ed.)

SLATTER I could get right back into the bush and live in deer cullers' huts. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,169)

HOLLIS An elderly deer-culler arrived from Dunedin, ... and valiantly offered to track Graham down all by himself. (1959,Killer on the Coast,25)

CRUMP [Title] I Become a Deer Culler. (1960,Good Keen Man, A,9)

HINTZ In spite of the efforts of the deer cullers, whose mission it is to exterminate a forest pest, the deer stalking out side the State forest areas can still be exciting. (1964,Trout at Taupo,88)

TURNER Against the depredations of imported animals, deerstalkers and deercullers are employed. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,154)

TOMLINSON There must have been thousands of deer through that back country before the deer culler and skin hunter took over. (1968,Remembered Trails,104)

DRYLAND I was a deer-culler for a couple of years before I took up teaching ... (1973,Multiple Texture, A,157)

HOLDEN They are hunted by Forest Service professionals called deercullers who still operate in many parts, as Government hunters have for nearly fifty years. (1980,Stag,7)

deer-culler NZ professional shooter of deer. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,194) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 125]]

HALL It's been on the market for eight months. Every ex deer culler in the country's got a machine he's trying to flogoff. (1983,Hot Water,17)

If a Swanndri survives two months on a deerculler, it's a winner. (Feb 12, 1989,Dominion Sunday Times,17)

PICKERING When deer were first released in the early days of the colony it was little anticipated what the result would be. When their numbers grew out of hand the government committed itself to doing something about it and so inaugurated the day of the government deer-culler. When the cullers had come and gone they left behind a classic emblem of the hills: the orange-painted, four- or six-bunk Forest Service hut. ... They became home for a generation of cullers and, when these moved out, a later influx of trampers. (1988,Hills, The,7)

To keep their jobs in the depression, the deer cullers were required to turn in 20 skins a week - for each skin they received one shilling and sixpence bonus and three bullets. (Mar 2, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),65)

Sir John emigrated to New Zealand in 1956 and worked as a deer culler, truck driver and cray-fisherman before retiring, and has written books on botany. (Apr 4, 2001,Dominion,13)

Lasenby has worked on the wharves, in the freezing works, as a deer culler.. and in all his work he had told and listened to stories. (Mar 27, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

With the cullers broke camp at 8.30a.m. (Nov 3, 1933,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,72,1934 ed.)

THOMSON [job description] Though we are still graced with the name of cullers, culling out is no longer our job. Now we are killers, with orders to clean out every deer. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,18)

We rather feared that some over-zealous culler had skittled the old boy's reindeer for Father Christmas failed to call [at our camp] that night. (Sep 1958,Tararua,40)

MASTERS When I worked on Ngamatea in 1917 small herds of deer were to be met up with, and by the late 20's they had become very thick. Government cullers were put on and some big kills made, all the same they were still numerous in 1934. (1960,Back-Country Tales,17)

REID [caption] DEER-HUNTERS/ Some 100,000 deer are shot every year in New Zealand, about half by amateurs, the rest by professional deer-cullers employed by the government. Here four cullers display wapiti and red deer antlers destined for the Dominion Museum, Wellington. (1964,Book of New Zealand, A (J.C. Reid),225)

MACNICOL The cullers worked in pairs or alone. ... The goats would be mustered like sheep to some point where escape was cut off ... Ibid 131 (`We've decided to give the goat-cullers a trial.') (1965,Skippers Road,133)

SHARPE The area in which we had been working was far too remote for penetration by Government cullers. (1966,Fiordland Muster,120)

YEREX Although the work of reducing deer numbers was assigned to government-employed shooters (termed `cullers', but quite wrongly) there had always been private individuals who shot deer for sport or in order to sell skins. (1982,Farming of Deer,73)

culler ... 2. sheep marked for culling (1985,Collins Compact Dictionary,116) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 272; cf. 1986 NZPOD 180]]

culler n. NZ professional killer of noxious animals, esp. deer or opossums. (from cull v as used in NZ for originally selective shooting of esp. deer, the [????] When deer were first released in the early days of the colony it was little anticipated what the result would be. When their numbers grew out of hand the government committed itself to doing something about it and so inaugurated the day of the government deer-culler. When the cullers had come and gone they left behind a classic emblem of the hills: the orange-painted, four- or six-bunk Forest Service hut. ... They became home for a generation of cullers and, when these moved out, a later influx of trampers. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,180) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 272; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 116]]

It might be good tactics for a culler who encountered a large herd to leave it alone for a period until he could assemble aid so that fewer would eventually escape... One experienced culler said yesterday that the culling season had been very successful. (Jun 4, 1948,Dominion,8)

MACLEAN [Caption] Originally private deer hunters were regarded as a nuisance by 'Skipper' Yerex and his professional deer cullers... In winter the 'deer cullers' did other work such as track cutting or returned to the community. (1994,Tararua : the Story of a Mountain Range,182)

n.

It might be good tactics for a culler whoencountered a large herd to leave italone for a period until he couldassemble aid so that fewer wouldeventually escape. (Jun 4, 1948,Dominion,8)

One experienced culler said yesterdaythat the culling season had been verysuccessful. (Jun 4, 1948,Dominion,8)

n. (Rural) a stock buyer or picker.

A person who selects stock for sale or slaughter: a culler. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

1 n. (Rural) [used elsewhere, but sp. use in NZ] a goat or deer-shooter employed by the Forest Service to eliminate wild goats and deer [prior to live-capture and farming of these animals.]

THOMSON Though we are still graced with the name of cullers, culling out is no longer our job. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,18)

FORRESTER Cullers of the day were paid a bonus on tails produced as proof of kills ... (1983,Chopper Boys, The,17)

FORRESTER Cullers explored and opened up the back country, pioneering tracks across alpine passes later to be followed by thousands of trampers, sports hunters, mountaineers and nature-lovers. (1983,Chopper Boys, The,18)

HOLDEN I first met him when I turned to meat hunting for a living and Chris was on the Forestry's payroll as a culler. (1996,Great Hunting Yarns,67)

2 n.

ANDERSON Not long after the ranger's visit it became legal to kill the birds [wild geese]. In fact, by the following spring the Government had cullers smashing eggs and shooting the old geese. (1981,Both Sides of the River,110)

PICKERING (1988,Hills, The,7)

culling¶

n. the sorting of unwanted sheep from wanted animals

As the time between the shearing and picking and culling - picking out the fat sheep to send to the freezing works and culling the old ewes from the young ones - was not a particularly busy one..Heather was free to do more in the house (Oct 14, 1924,Otago Witness,54)

2 n. the professional killing of wild deer.

SUTHERLAND Some of the high tallies taken in the early days of the so-called `culling' operations in the great snow-grass basins of the Southern Alps and elsewhere show that the shooters learned the wisdom of concentrating their fire on the leader hinds . (1953,Golden Bush, The,69,1963 ed.)

One experienced culler said yesterdaythat the culling season had been verysuccessful. (Jun 4, 1948,Dominion,8)

culling mate¶

1 n. (Rural) one of a pair of Forestry Service deer-cullers.

'Who are you?' asked one old culling mate as he peered into the back of the Falcon. (Mar 2006,FMC - (Federated Mountain Clubs of NZ) Bulletin,39)

HOLDEN He teamed up with an old culling mate of his ... (1996,Great Hunting Yarns,49)

culling stick¶

1 n. (Rural) a stick used in the drafting yards to indicate an animal to be separated from others. (See drafting stick)

If she had been like it from birth, she would probably have had the culling stick as a four-tooth. (Feb 2, 1942,NZ Dairy Exporter,24)

cully¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of stock] suitable for slaughter.

Medium male hoggets made up to $41 with a good demand for smaller and cully sorts. (Oct 8, 1998,NZ Farmer,35)

The market for the very small and cully hoggets was particularly strong with little selling under $55. (Aug 16, 2000,Wanganui Chronicle,11)

Useful mixed sex sheep brought between $69 and $72 while very small and cully hoggets sold up to $60. (Sep 12, 2002,Wanganui Chronicle,18)

culp¶

n. [ca1950's Greenmeadows Seminary `A public confession of external faults, or such a fault confessed.' (F.M. McKay SM)]

cultivation paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a fenced area close to the homestead for growing vegetables, fruit and supplementary stock feed.

DEANS In one of the others the horses are kept, and in the third milk cows and bulls and pigs; the fourth is a cultivation paddock ... (Aug 3, 1848,Letter,51) [NOTES: in Deans (1964) Pioneers on Port Cooper Plains]

cultural cringe¶

n.

Those who like to speculate on the sociolgy of science may detect something of the "Cultural Cringe" factor at work here! (Jul 1994,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,104/8)

A Tourism New Zealand survey shows a depressingly large number of us are still stuck lock-kneed in the cultural cringe. (Aug 31, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C8)

A government-funded survey commissioned by Tourism NZ shows we suffer so badly from cultural cringe from a "sense of inferiority", that we are warning off tourists. (Aug 31, 2003,Sunday Star Times,A3)

[heading] Kiwi movies beating the cultural cringe. ..the sucessful New Zeland films overseas has removed, hopefully once and for all, the cultural cringe factor. (Jan 25, 2006,Dominion Post,B4)

These editors don't have much use for Ian Wedde's rusted-on irony about "the cultural cringe" either. (Feb 22, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49)

Phillips must be one of the few US nationals to know what it feels to be on the receiving end of the cultural cringe. (Jan 18, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

Instead of that information, we are treated to a delightful display of colonial cultural cringe (if you'll excuse my alliteration). (Jul 8, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

cultural cringer¶

n.

His sense of "going back to the 1950's of my childhood" in a world bereft of ideas and debate is personal, and anecdotal, but I dispute his conclusion that we are still those cultural cringers who are afraid to ask ourselves who we are. (Oct 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

cultural detective¶

n.

Taranui Falconer is a cultural detective, but her tools don't include anything like a bushy moustache, a houndstooth hat or an oversized magnifying glass. (Feb 4, 2006,NZ Herald,Canvas p 10)

[heading] Cultural Detective New Zealand. "Kiwis" live with an extraordinary opportunity to create their future. Cultural Detective New Zealand will give you invaluable clues to making the most of your relationships with New Zealanders. (Feb 2006,Internet - see Notes,0) [NOTES: http://www.culturaldetective.com/cultures.html#NZ]

cultural fishing rights¶

n.

The deal had been signed and sealed in 1922 with the Fenton Agreement, which granted the tribe cultural fishing rights and an annuity of aGBP6000 a year, he said. (Aug 5, 2005,NZ Herald,A11)

culverting¶

adj.

Kokopu species and koaro were widespread in the [Wellington] region, but the annual whitebait catch, silting up of waterways, and culverting streams interrupted their life cycles. (May 7, 2001,Evening Post,18)

cume¶

adj. (informal) cumulative [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

Clark has not yet matched Hill's cume audience figures - the number of unique listeners in a week - or the length of time spent listening. (Oct 3, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),21)

cummy-cum¶

n. kamokamo [This is the Taranaki pakeha pronunciation I remember (DEH)]

cunning as a backhouse rat¶

phr.

R. MASON Cunning as a backhouse rat: My mother says the expression goes back as far as she can remember, -1890 say. She would have heard it in the Wanganui-Bulls area. She agrees with me in not having heard it in Auckland. I have heard it occasionally in Wellington recently. (Jun 7, 1952,Letter)

HELMER `And cunning, eh? Like a backhouse rat.' (1964,Stag Party)

cunning as a kuri¶

phr.

KEENE Now, Platypus was, as Bert would say, was as cunning as a kuri, and while she was in sight of the house, she ambled along innocently, ... (1982,Myrtle and Sophia,49)

cunning as a Maori dog¶

phr. (of a person or animal) extremely perceptive and/or manipulative. [ca1890 at least R. Mason's mother remembered it from c1890 in the Wanganui-Bulls district.]

NEWTON As cunning as a Maori dog, it [a boar] would unconcernedly and quietly snuffle about among the ewes and lambs. (1966,Boss's Story, The,60)

SCOTT `Cunning as a Maori dog,' supplemented Sam vulgarly. matter, as the country was unsuitable for sheep, ... (1953,Breakfast at Six,30)

NEWTON Cunning as a Maori dog, I would ... (1947,Wayleggo,148)

DAVIN Innocent as a child and cunning as a Maori dog, Bert had once called him. (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,239)

NEWTON Cunning as Maori dogs, the musterers ... (1949,High Country Days,59)

SLATTER Cunning as a Maori dog. Too right he is. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,91)

IRVINE `As cunning as Maori dog' is a common simile in New Zealand, although there is not the same local flavour in the slang there. (1962,Australian Universal Dictionary,(Contents) 1)

DAVIS [non-derogatory] But you've got to hand it to the Yanks. They're cunning as Maori dogs on this sort of caper [sulphur-drilling]. They put up a rig and drill down a dirty great pipe until they're in the gypsum below the sulphur-bearing strata. (1964,Watersiders,161)

NEWTON I once watched an old boar trying to catch a lamb. As cunning as a Maori dog, it would unconcernedly and quietly snuffle about among the ewes and lambs . (1966,Boss's Story, The,60)

HAYWARD 30 Tuesday, 18 April. Mr K spent the weekend on the East Coast, addressing a Jaycees' conference in Hastings, and a Maori Labour Party conference in Gisborne. ... He's told us about being at a Maori gathering when a pakeha said unthinkingly, He's as cunning as a Maori dog'. It appeared to have gone unnoticed until a Maori remarked,He's as cunning as a pakeha dog.' Mr K enjoyed that. (1981,Diary of the Kirk Years) [NOTES: 1972 Apr 18 Hayward Diary of the Kirk Years (1981)]

McGILL cunning as a Maori dog very cunning or sly; Gordon Slatter, A Gun in My Hand (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,32)

I watched an old boar trying to catch a lamb. As cunning as a Maori dog, it would unconcernedly and quietly snuffle about among the ewes and lambs as though its only intent was roots and grubs in the tussock. (1966,Boss's Story, The,60)

NEWTON Cunning as a Maori dog, I would make a present of the choicest of my catches to the star cook at Cass ... (1947,Wayleggo,148)

cunning as a Maori hen¶

phr. [[??is this a euphemism, or SI term for cunning as a Maori dog].]

COWAN The weka is a wingless bird, grey brown in colour, about the size of an ordinary fowl, and is often called the wood-hen, or Maori-hen'.As cunning as a Maori hen' is a familiar New Zealand bush simile. (1926,Travel in NZ,(Vol II South Island) 63)

cunning as a rat¶

phr.

BAILEY & ROTH Old Abdul under cover was as cunning as a rat;/ As yet we'd done no shootin' - saw nothin' to shoot at,/ Till a Turkey popped his head up; that head he ne'er withdrew,/ For a rifle pinged... (1967,Shanties,115) [NOTES: [ca1915-1918] in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 115]

cunning as a shithouse rat¶

phr.

Former [union] president Wally Clement is described by a union member as "cunning as a shit-house rat"... (Feb 23, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

cunning as an outhouse rat¶

phr.

He's as cunning as an outhouse rat. (Dec 15, 1993,TV3,Ralston Group)

Cunning Joe¶

n. a children's team game

159 But the most interesting of all the team games was a small group game variously known as Cunning Joe (K-6), Cunny, Conjure, Conjo, Cunny Joe, and Cronje. In this game the cat [a thin 6-inch stick with pointed ends] was sometimes called the Cunning Joe stick (Waikouaiti, Otago, 1900) or the kip (Dunedin, 1895). It was a game for four players. Two rings were marked on the ground a short distance from each other with a square drawn in the middle of each. A boy armed with a short stick stood at each ring, a bowler behind him. One of the bowlers tossed a short piece of wood at the ring opposite. The striker hit it as hard as he could, then both boys ran as in cricket. (1972,Folkgames of Children,SUTTON-SMITH,159 ed.)

Cunningham's snowgrass¶

n. Danthonia Cunninghamii.

(And) (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/)

Cunningham's tree fern¶

n. Cyathea Cunninghamii.

POTTS (1882,Out in the Open) [NOTES: (And)]

Cunningham's violet¶

n. Viola Cunninghamii.

LAING & BLACKWELL (And) (1906,Plants of NZ)

Cunny¶

n. (See Cunning Joe)

cup¶

n. of a milking machine, the receptacle for the cow's teat ca?1940, also @v to cup cows.

COWLEY The cups fell onto the concrete with a clatter and the loss of suction caused the other sets of cups to do the same. (1979,Growing Season, The,70)

[Caption] Adjusting the milking cups. (Oct 26, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,46)

Minutes later three city-slicker actors are up to their ankles in cows' nerves, pretending to be expert milkers, trying to attach 1940 suction cups to very apprehensive cattle. (Feb 4, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

Gently place the chain over your client's back, kneel down to the the six cups on, click the suction clamp, and you're in business. (Sep 18, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

It's milking time back home now, but hands itchy for cups and udders clap politely instead, as the Prime Minister makes his way to the stage to address them. (Aug 16, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

The milk cups consisted of a metal case housing a rubber inflation which fitted over the top of the cup and down into the claw. (Dec 2003,NZ Memories,No. 45/11)

Most farmers wait after washing and stimulating, before putting their cups on. (Jul 1959,NZ Dairy Exporter,37)

Those were times of six sets of cups in a walk-through shed; back chains, legropes - those filthy things. (Jan 1972,NZ Dairy Exporter,39)

[Advt.] FREE trial of these Real Money-making Teat Cups. Your Milking Machine is no better than the Teat Cups you use on it. (Jul 31, 1926,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,21)

"stainless steel machines and cups dance in the cowsheds / sound of water-pumps and radios sing... (May 24, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

ANTHONY It simply meant that I took a little longer because I had to hang up a set of cups every now and then... (1936,Follow the Call,117)

When secondary school assistants wed/ A cocksfoot man from the cream-cheque land/ There's no time for books and less for bed,/ But tits and cups in your early hand. (Apr 1953,Here & Now,31) [NOTES: (K.Sinclair)]

DUGGAN ... I was bent double stripping old Daisy ... after the cups came off. (1981,Collected Stories (Duggan),199) [NOTES: 1963 Duggan `Along Rideout Road ...' in 1981 Collected Stories 199 (also in 1966 NZ Short Stories (1976))]

TURNER The parts of the [milking] machines are named, the cups which attach to the cow's teats, the rubber inflations inside the cups, the pulsators which regulate the vacuum and the releaser. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,149)

STEWART We were genuinely able to be of some usein the cowshed - helping Dick to bring upthe herd.. from the night paddock,hustling them into the shed, leg-ropingthem.. attaching the machine's strangecups to their fleshy teats. (1983,Springtime in Taranaki,116)

This shed could alternatively be used with one milker placing cups on and one removing cups. (May 1972,NZ Dairy Exporter,00) [NOTES: Check page number]

Minutes later three city-slicker actors are up to their ankles in cows' nerves, pretending to be expert milkers, trying to attach 1940 suction cups to very apprehensive cattle. (Feb 4, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

n. of a separator

...wash down the concrete with buckets of water and wash the separator cups... (Dec 2002,NZ Memories,No. 39/14)

n. spec. a china or pottery insulator on telephone or power, etc., poles

SLATTER Juvenile delinquency. What about us? Breaking cups on the power posts along the [10] country roads. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,9)

CUP¶

abbr. Civil Union Partner; a partner in an officially recognised gay relationship [see also civil union partner]

I've learned that we will now have to accommodate a new title, civil union partner. Imagine how ridiculous this will sound - "I'd like you to meet my CUP." (Dec 2, 2004,Dominion Post,B4)

cup crawl¶

1 n. (Rural) the cutting off of milk flow from a cow when a milking cup crawls up the teat.

MCMEEKAN For cows known to need machine-stripping because of teat-cup crawl, the cups should be pulled down when the indicator shows a flow rate of about 1lb per minute. (1960,Grass to Milk,148)

MAF Teatcup crawl: the action of the teatcup crawling up the teat during milking to a point where it could cut off the milk flow. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,43)

By February the auto cups were literally falling off the cow - what is called 'cup crawl.' [teatcup crawl] (Jul 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,25)

cup of tea¶

phr. [also as cuppa tea below] (See also cuppa,tea break)

Quipped Sir Roger: "Since 1991 they'vehad a gigantic cup of tea that DavidLange would be proud of." (Sep 17, 1993,Dominion,17)

JONES [Hdg] Time for that Cup of TeaBreather (1993,Wowser Whacking,67)

He thinks it is now "time for a cup of tea". (Jan 31, 2003,Dominion Post,C4)

They were stopped midstream by the cuppatea fellow and prevented from institutingthe Rogercare side to Rogernomics. (Apr 14, 1996,Sunday Star Times,A10)

We had a good first half, we had a cup of tea and a bun, and the rest of the world passed us by. (Sep 11, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

In the words of former Labour prime minister David Lange, they wanted a cup of tea and a breather. (Jul 23, 2002,Dominion Post,B6)

The Government is taking a cup of tea and the Employers put the kettle on. (Jun 2, 2000,Radio NZ / National Radio,Sean Plunkett, Morning Report)

In short, for five extraordinary years David Lange was us - torn between the old and the new, headily excited by economic change, nervously aware of social damage, glass of chardonnay in one hand, a cup of tea in the other. (Aug 27, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

Ruth also fears the New Zealand economyhas reverted to the Langeistic "cuppa teaand a lie down" stage. (Oct 6, 1995,Independent (Auckland),15)

The problem was that from the time Daviddeclared the cup of tea, Labour wastrying to row against the tide it hadcreated. (Dec 3, 1995,Sunday Star Times,D3)

cup remover¶

1 n. (Rural) an automatic device to remove teat cups from a cow when milking is completed.

.. a farmer, who was considering installing cup removers so that he could milk 160 to 180 cows without employing labour. (Jan 1977,NZ Dairy Exporter,38)

Automatic cup-removers were accompanied by spring-mounted bail restraints that keep a cow from backing out of a bail too soon. (Dec 8, 2005,Dominion Post,C9)

MAF cup remover: a device to automatically remove the teat cups from the cow when milking is completed. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,40)

Excellent on-farm facilities include a 50-AS Herringbone shed with cup removers, a 350 cow feed pad and large calf sheds. (Feb 2, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,23)

Herd manager required for 150 ha milking platform 24 cup HB shed with cup removers. (Apr 20, 2002,Hawke's Bay Today,22)

cup slip¶

1 n. (Rural) [dairying] the dislodging of a cup fitting from a cow's udder.

You cannot afford to tolerate problems like incomplete milkout, cup slip or teat damage. (1999,Taranaki Daily News,Farming Today Supplement 30)

No cup slip, no teat damage, maximum speed and maximum milk yields are advantages .. No cup slip eliminates the frustration of milkers rushing to and fro in the long herringbone where Pauline and Ray take just one hour to milk 245 cows, including the colostrum mob. (Sep 20, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,20)

Cupid's Whispers¶

n. ?conversation-type sweets

Other sweets current at the time were Cupid's Whispers', ... sen sens, cable-twist, ... butter balls, acid drops ... aniseed balls ... mint rock. There were ponfret cakes (licorice stuff ...) and of courselucky bags' ... in addition to the sweets they contained they had the gambling element. Some of them contained a three-penny bit ... soon clamped down on by the `wowser' of the day. (Sep 17, 1977,Dominion,7/1/5) [NOTES: 1903 January 15 Lawlor Diary in 1977 Sep 17 Dominion 7/1/5]

Cupola gecko¶

n. species known from just one example, a charcoal and black patterned gecko, yet to be fully classified. [Hoplodactylus "Cupola"]

The taxonomic status of the Cupola geckoHoplodactylus'Cupola' (Genus B: sp. 1, p. 34) isstill undecided. The Cupola gecko has distinctivemarkings on the snout, but is otherwise not greatlydifferent from the forest gecko H. granulatus. (2009,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.biolsci.monash.edu/staff/chapple/docs/29.pdf New Zealand Journal of Zoology, 2009, Vol. 36: 59-710301-4223/09/3601-0059 a(C) The Royal Society of New Zealand 2009]

cuppa¶

n. (political allusion) (See also cup of tea,tea break)

But what say we have a little breatherhere and then we set off on the roadagain after we have picked up thecasualties and had a cuppa. (Aug 20, 1988,Dominion,1) [NOTES: metaphor.]

When Mr Lange said in Canberra that itwas time to pause for a cuppa and abreather, his critics took the view thatwhat he needed was a cuppa and a lie-down. (Aug 29, 1988,Dominion,12)

"So," he says ** , feeling for folksyimages. "let's have a little breatherhere, after we've picked up thecasualties and had a cuppa." (May 14, 1990,Dominion,8) [NOTES: Also in JONES Punch Lines 96]

Cuppa's over, and the Act must go on..."Roger's back! Tea break's over!" (Sep 3, 1993,National Business Review,11)

[Hdg] It's time for a cuppa, PM told. (Apr 10, 2000,Dominion,1)

Mr Lange's infamous pause "for a cuppa" was too little, too late. (Jul 19, 2004,Dominion Post,B5)

On both fronts, Bolger can now claim victory - in essence, he has won the battle for a "cuppa" that eluded Lange. (Dec 11, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),37)

[Hdg] Roger's Way. No More Cuppas. (Sep 24, 1993,Dominion,1)

I am the most ardent fighter forreserves, but let's have a cuppa, slowdown, and look at introducing reservesthat are working and not have any'Clayton's reserves'. (Mar 19, 1995,Sunday Star Times,A6)

[Hdg] Time for a cuppa after 50 years.... Tomorrow, the 66-year-old from Petone will end half a century of moulding dough, mixing chocolate and whipping up sugary and creamy fillings for countless biscuits, and swap it for a life of gold, home renovation and fast cars. (Nov 2, 2004,Dominion Post,A3)

curing-shed¶

1 n. (Rural) a building used for the drying of tobacco.

Curing-sheds will require cleaning up and refitting. (Nov 21, 1927,NZ Journal of Agriculture,340)

A curing-shed charged from floor to ceiling with plants hung in this manner soon has a warm humid atmosphere at this season of the year. (Jan 21, 1929,NZ Journal of Agriculture,59)

curing-stick¶

1 n. (Rural) a horizontal stick or bar upon which tobacco leaves are placed to cure.

..the curing practice here is to cut the mature plant down a little above the ground and split the butt to within 2in. or 3 in. of the end; it is then threaded on to a curing-stick. These sticks are an inch or two over 4 ft long and 1 in. in diameter. If the distance between curing-sticks on the tier-poles is reckoned at 8in, it is now possible to work out the accommodation required for curing the crop. (Nov 21, 1927,NZ Journal of Agriculture,340)

A curing-stick is about 4ft 3in in length. The stick is placed on tier poles, which run like parallel bars in the curing-shed. (Jan 21, 1929,NZ Journal of Agriculture,59)

curl grub¶

n. the larval stage of Odontria spp.

There are twenty-eight native species belonging to the genus Odontria, but all observers agree that the principal grass grub is Odontria zealandica. In the larval stage this is known as grass grub,'white grub,' or curl grub,' and the adult stage is known asgrass grub beetle,' brown beetle.' orturnip fly.' (1943,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,23/306A)

curlew¶

n. a black bird (Dusky Sound); lists it among NZ sea birds; no Maori name [not in main dict.

I also met with good sport among the Curlews or Black Birds. [fn5] The black phase of the N.Z. Oyster-catcher, the Maori Torepango, Haematopus ostralegus. unicolor Forst. [Met first at Mercury Bay] (Apr 4, 1773,Cook's Journals,2/115,1961 ed.)

FORSTER ... saw on the beach [at Dusky Bay] some black birds, with red bills & feet; the people who had been here before, called them Curlews, but they had rather the appearance of Sea Pies. [ed. fn] Haemotopus unicolor of Descr. Anim., p. 112; the Variable Oystercatcher haemotopus unicolor Forster, 1844; ... Ibid. 2/276 ... abounding with New Zeeland black Shags, Oystercatchers (commonly called Curlews) ... (Mar 27, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/240)

  • and in the space of two hours shot eleven Brace of Parrots, Wood Hens, & Curlews; Ibid.. 50 The Best kinds were Ducks, Curlews, a bird very much resembling a Wood Cock & Sea Pies; - Shags, Wood Hens, & Parrots were in great abundance ... the Wood Hen very much resembles the Common Barn door Fowl in England (Nov 1791,Journal of Voyage in HMS 'Chatham',48) [NOTES: 1791 Nov E.Bell Journal of Voyage in H.M.S. `Chatham' (Vancouver expedition) (MS ATB)]

YATE (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),69) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

POLACK Masses of sandstone ... gave this part of the coast [near Waipo[u]a] a barren ... appearance; large detached masses of black rocks lined the shore, on which the gannet, curlew, pelican, and gulls ... sat perched ... (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/72)

POWER A few curlews, whale-birds, sand-pipers, and wild ducks frequent the coast and river swamps, but are generally fishy, and unfit for the table. (1849,Sketches in NZ,72)

2 n. godwit, kuaka, southern godwit, Limosa Novae Zealandiae (not the rare straggler, the Australian Curlew' Numenius cyanopus, 1888 Buller 2/45).

HUTTON 76. LIMOSA UROPYGIALIS. Gould. Goodwit.[sic] Curlew. Kuaka. L. Novae Zealandiae. GRAY. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,28)

CAMPBELL No sign of human life that morning; the shrill cry of the curlew on the beach and the full rich carol of the tui or parson-bird from the brushwood skirting the shore fell faintly upon the ear. (1881,Poenamo,2/5/99)

HAY The Kuaka (Limosa Baueri) is the bird spoken of as curlew' andgrey snipe' by the colonists. Large flocks are to be seen on our rivers, feeding on the mud-banks. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/222)

BULLER Curlew-shooting' (as it [sc Godwit-shooting] is termed in the colony) sometimes, however, becomes more legitimate sport ... [quoting a New Zealand correspondent of <i>The Field</i>:]Curlew-shooting has just begun; I had a day last week (early in March). The best locality for this kind of shooting is the upper part of Auckland harbour ... [44] The Curlew feed on the mud-flats after the ebbing tide, and the best plan is to choose the time when the flight commences from one coast to the other. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/43)

BARLOW ... what are called curlew here are really godwit ... (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,31)

About the end of November flocks of a ... wading bird appear on the swamp - the godwit, or curlew as it is more commonly called. (1901,TrNZI,33/217)

HUNT Out ... at the end of the [Farewell] spit we made acquaintance with the myriads of sea birds that abound there - godwits, or curlews, as they are sometimes called. (1951,Confessions,146)

FALLA et al. Godwits are sometimes referred to as snipe' orcurlew'. Both these names are quite incorrect. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,116)

3 n.

Far-eastern Curlew Numenius madagascarensis (LINNAEUS, 1766) MIGRANT OTHER NAMES: Eastern curlew, long-billed curlew, Australian curlew. ... Sightings of the far-eastern curlew have increased steadily over the past 30 years. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,190)

3 n.

157. Numenius madagascariensis (Linnaeus, 1758) [Far-eastern Curlew] Breeding eastern Siberia ... regularly reaching New Zealand (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,46,1980 ed.)

Far-eastern Curlew Numenius madagascarensis (LINNAEUS, 1766) MIGRANT OTHER NAMES: Eastern curlew, long-billed curlew, Australian curlew. ... Sightings of the far-eastern curlew have increased steadily over the past 30 years. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,190)

3 n.

curlew-shooting¶

n. godwit-shooting

BULLER Curlew-shooting' (as it [sc Godwit-shooting] is termed in the colony) sometimes, however, becomes more legitimate sport ... [quoting a New Zealand correspondent of <i>The Field:</i>]Curlew-shooting has just begun; I had a day last week (early in March). The best locality for this kind of shooting is the upper part of Auckland harbour ... [44] The Curlew feed on the mud-flats after the ebbing tide, and the best plan is to choose the time when the flight commences from one coast to the other. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/43)

curly¶

n. a wentletrap

POWELL CURLY or WENTLE-TRAP (Cirsotrema zelebori). A charming little white shell up to an inch in length with a long tapered spire sculptured with regular vertical ridges crossed by finer spirals. They wash ashore on sandy beaches of the east coast, particularly in the Bay of Plenty. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,28)

McLINTOCK CURLY or WENTLE-TRAP (Cirsotrema zelebori). A pure white shell up to 1 inch in height, beautifully ornamented in ladderlike patterns. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/425)

adj. difficult, tricky (See curly one,extra curly)

The meeting was very rewarding and the questions curlier than anywhere else. (Nov 1996,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,111/2)

.. the lads should have a programme that deals with their "issues" - if that's what chaps call them - probably "curly ones" would be the preferred terminology. (Apr 30, 2005,Dominion Post,B7)

very curly: difficult, pleasant (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

PARTRIDGE curly ... Difficult, as in That's a curly one' ...(?mostly) Aus.: since ca. 11950. ...2. But in NZ as , e.g.,That was extra curly' (Slatter), it seems to mean excellent' orattractive' and to date since ca. 1935. (1984,Dictionary of Slang,280)

McGILL curly a difficult situation, derived possibly from googly ball in cricket; eg `That second question on the exam paper's a curly one.' Mostly ANZ since 1950. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,33)

adj. pleasant, better than average

very curly: difficult, pleasant (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

Partridge curly ... Difficult, as in That's a curly one' ...(?mostly) Aus.: since ca. 11950. ...2. But in NZ as , e.g.,That was extra curly' (Slatter), it seems to mean excellent' orattractive' and to date since ca. 1935. (1984,Dictionary of Slang,280)

curly cockatoo¶

phr. the cat's pyjamas

WILSON Gee, 'struth,' Gil said.Anyone would think you were on probation or something. You're a curly cockatoo, aren't you? (1973,NZ Jack,95)

curly grass¶

n. (See grass)

curly mo¶

adj. all right, fine

NEWBOLD Curly Mo: (adj or adv) All right, fine, go ahead. Rhyming slang for `A great go.' (1982,Big Huey, The,248)

curly one¶

n. difficulty, quandary

It's a curly one and as the population ages, the issue of euthanasia will be one we all have to come to terms with. (Aug 1, 2010,NZ Herald,A026)

OK, it's a curly one, so here's the answer - it's Christchuch-based investment banker Kenji Steven. (Jun 5, 2011,Sunday Star Times,11)

.. the lads should have a programme that deals with their "issues" - if that's what chaps call them - probably "curly ones" would be the preferred terminology. (Apr 30, 2005,Dominion Post,B7)

.. Todd wasn't fed any lines. "That's a curly one" was all his own. (Mar 9, 2003,Sunday Star Times,1)

Fuel prices had increased in New Zealandand the exchange rate was "a curly one". (Apr 21, 2011,Southland Times,3)

Many advisers had moved to operate on a fee-only basis to remove all doubt. "But it is a curly one." (Apr 14, 2011,NZ Herald,B001)

curly-dwarf¶

1 n. (Rural) a viral disease of commercial potato crops.

Mild-mosaic, rugose-mosaic, aucuba-mosaic, leaf-drop, stipple-streak, spindle-tuber, curly-dwarf, leaf-roll, streak and wildings are all present in New-Zealand-grown commercial lines. (Jan 21, 1929,NZ Journal of Agriculture,6)

Curnow's curse¶

n. Calandrinia spp., a local noxious weed.

HILGENDORF & CALDER CURNOW'S CURSE (Calandrinia ciliata var. caulescens) is also called portulaca, horgan's weed, and purple calandrinia. It has spreading fleshly stems and somewhat fleshy leaves. (1967,Weeds of New Zealand,78) [NOTES: [nf 1926]]

Curnow's curse [=] calandrinia [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,19)

currant¶

n. wineberry, from the resemblance of its berries to red or black currants

(And) Aristotelia racemosa (1908,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of the Tongariro National Park]

MARRINER (And) Aristotelia racemosa (1908,Kea, The: a NZ Problem)

THOMSON (And) Aristotelia racemosa (1909,NZ Naturalist's Calendar)

COCKAYNE (And) Aristotelia racemosa (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story)

2 n.

currant, flowering [s] Ribes glutinosum Benth. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,19)

2 n. Aristotelia fruticosa, a mountain shrub; mountain wineberry

COCKAYNE (And) (1909,AJHR,C-12) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Stewart Island]

COCKAYNE The weeping-matipo (Suttonia divaricata), Pittosporum rigidum, the mountain-currant (Aristotelia fruticosa), the wauwaupaku (Nothopanax anomalum), .... (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story,60)

MARTIN Aristotelia fruticosa Mountain Currant. (1929,Flora NZ,235,1961 ed.)

2 n.

BARRINGTON Simonin gathered a handful of tutu berries, ... and got a pint of wine ... The native currant also makes first-rate wine, and grows very profusely. (Mar 16, 1864,Diary) [NOTES: 1864 Mar 16 Barrington Diary in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 402]

Aristotelia racemosa native currant (1898,TrNZI,30)

[The kea] feeds on ... the black berries of Aristotelia fruticosa (the `native currant'), as well as the fruit of the pitch-pine and the totara (1907,TrNZI,39/80)

2 n. [NZ Currant 1898 HMB 1906 TIC (Andersen, 3 entries)]

TAYLOR The native currant also makes first-rate wine. [fn] Aristotelia racemosa or A. serrata. In Otago it is called New Zealand currant or `Moko-mok', and is otherwise known as Mako-mako or wineberry. (1959,Early Travellers,402)

HUDSON The plant most usually selected by the caterpillar is Aristotelia racemosa, called by the settlers `New Zealand currant', from its large clusters of rich-looking black berries, which appear in autumn. (1892,Elementary Manual of NZ Entomology,70)

THOMSON (And) (1906,Introductory Classbook of Botany)

LAING & BLACKWELL [Aristotelia serrata (The Wineberry)] ... In bush clearings, it is one of the first plants to come up, and would, on this account, be termed by the Americans a fireweed.' [...] It goes by different names in different districts. In Otago, it is the New Zealand Currant, orMoko-mok'. In Canterbury, it is called the Wine-berry. In the North Island, it is the Mako-mako. (1907,Plants of NZ,246,1940 p. 258 ed.)

currant bun¶

n. a son

2 n. the sun

Next morning the old currant bun popped into the sky, looking not at all ashamed of itself. (Sep 1958,Tararua,44)

DAVIS `Here comes the old currant bun.' The heavy rainclouds ... were drifting apart. (1964,Watersiders,83)

NEWBOLD Currant bun (n) Sun. (1982,Big Huey, The,248)

currant cake¶

adj. awake [rhyming slang]

There are many examples of rhyming slang in use at Paparua:..currant cake for awake (aware, informed). (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

NEWBOLD There was a screw ... who'd just arrived ... and who wasn't too currant cake about the way the things worked. ibid. 248 Currant (cake) (adv) Awake, aware, informed. (1982,Big Huey, The,89)

currant tree¶

n. wineberry, Aristotelia racemosa (See also currant)

Makomako (currant-tree) .. Aristotelia racemosa .. Timber light and straight grained; ... (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,11)

HUDSON This curious species is found abundantly in the stems of dead currant trees (Aristotelia racemosa), in which it excavates numerous cylindrical burrows like the last species, which it closely resembles when in the larval state. (1892,Elementary Manual of NZ Entomology,31)

188 Makomako (wine berry or currant tree) slab. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,19)

currency¶

n. privately issued local notes of exchange discounted against sterling, also colonial currency

SUTHERLAND In a rat-chewed diary ... kept by James Busby during the years 1828-38 ... are to be seen references to trade transactions in Sydney Currency' ... Owing to a shortage of coins at Sydney and Hobart, traders resorted to the issue of promissory notes ... for amounts down to 3d., and these were termedcurrency' as distinguished from sterling', specie or Government money. This originated the termCurrency Lad' [82] (Colonial-born). Ibid. 148 Colonial Currency.'-</i> In addition to Government notes, known assterling currency,' traders and whalers issued currency notes, known as `colonial currency' which circulated throughout Australasia long after the Government notes had been called in [past 1826]. (1941,Numismatic History of NZ,81)

currency n. name given to early paper money issued by private traders, and to foreign coins then in circulation; (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

currency lad¶

n. the term for a native-born non-Aboriginal Australian is recorded from NZ from c1840. -- [also currency lass]

SARAH MATHEW [- lass] [Mrs. Williams] is a plain sort of motherly person, has been in the country 17 years, and has a large family of raw, uncouth boys and girls, nowise superior to the currency lads and lasses of Australia. (Mar 28, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Mar 28 Sarah Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 99]

WAKEFIELD Some few, born in those colonies [VDL and NSW] were probably descended from members of one or other of these two classes [runaway convicts and sailors]. These `currency lads', as they are called [among whalers etc.] ... (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/311)

LADY CAMPBELL Their children [sc. of runaway sailors and convicts from New South Wales and Van Diemen's Land], the descendants of native mothers, were as fine specimens of strength and natural manly [184] beauty as could be met with, and, as all there [at Cloudy Bay] was slang, went by the name of `Currency Lads'. (1864,Martin Tobin,1/183)

current retrenchment¶

phr.

JOHNSON If what the [Fishing Industry] Board called 'current retrenchment' continued, 1979 and 1980 catches might be as low as 88,000 and 100,000 tonnes, respectively. Current retrenchment referred to problems being experienced by a number of major South Island companies. Catching less-familiar species was all very well, but they had to be solved. (2004,Hooked,300)

Currie boy¶

n.

McGILL Currie boy bikie frequenting Currie's milkbar, Queen Street, Auckland, in the 1950s. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,33)

curry¶

n. (offensive) an Indian (See also curry-muncher)

THE CURRIES are just like the Jews,' a youth said about the fire-bombing of the shop of a Petone Indian ...This reference I [Mr Johnson] took to mean the Indians, ...' (Sep 26, 1979,Evening Post,48/1-3)

n. violence; fighting; heat; esp. give someone curry

HUTCHINS If a forward whispered compliments in his [sc the rugby union selector's] ear at after match functions and indulged in the occasional curry on the paddock he would invariably get the nod. (1983,Rugby Rabbits,37)

McGILL give someone curry to abuse or razz vigorously, aften in sport; from the heat associated with curry; eg `That useless Aussie bowler, did we give him some curry!' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,49)

And it's anybody's guess what Japanese tourists make of such Kiwisms [sic] as She's applesput the nips in' feeling crook' orgive him some curry'. (Jan 7, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

Curry Te Kanawa¶

n. (humorous) a dish punning on the name of Kiri Te Kanawa

In a country where we have such dishes as Curry Te Kanawa, Kiri Te Kumara and the delicious kiwifruit mousse, Kiwi Te Kanawa, the only indignity that she really insists on is no coughing in the audience. (May 27, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

curry-muncher¶

n. (offensive) an Indian (See also curry)

curry muncher: Indian (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

McGILL curry-muncher Indian; offensive. Mostly ANZ. (1981,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,33)

curtain raiser¶

n. a (football) game played immediately before a major fixture [ca1960 NZ]

curved board¶

1 n. (Rural) a design of woolshed.

Because few builders specialise in woolshed design they can be fazed by the state-of-the-art curved board which optimises wool flow and minimises work for shedhands. (Jun 1, 1994,NZ Farmer,25)

cushion flower¶

n. a variety of hakea

cushion flower n. variety of the N.Z. shrub, the hakea. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

cushion plant¶

2 n.

Scleranthus biflorus cushion plant (1915,TrNZI,47/)

COCKAYNE (And) [Andersen's note] Distinction between cushion plants and mat-plants described by C.E. Foweraker: TrNZI vol 49, pp. 2, 3, 1917. (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story)

No tall shrub can grow here; nothing but low-growing cushion plants. (Jan 29, 1924,Otago Witness,70)

cushy-doe¶

n.

... if you do not object to ignoble game, I can take you to where you may knock down some cushy-does. Ah! you know what that means. (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher,42) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

custard square¶

n.

There's also a custard square or something that resembled a custard square: the family at the bakery hadn't quite perfected the colour - this one was a shimmering sulphuric yellow stuck to a plank of Vietnamese equivalent of shortcrust pastry. (Oct 28, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

I spent more time standing out on the pavement than inside, ogling through the thin lace window-curtain at the strapping doughnuts, and custard squares with egg all over their face, and slice of sponge cake bleeding with so much red, red jam that they looked as though they had been in a road accident. (Mar 25, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

...the Corner House cafe still does a mean date scone and a big line in custard squares. (Apr 5, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34)

Such knowledge is invaluable; eight weeks of sausage rolls and custard squares isn't good for the band's health, either. (Jul 17, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

We chose salmon sandwiches and gingerbread men and ordered coffee and a custard square for our father... (Dec 18, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),126)

custie¶

n. (informal) customer [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

...the Bistro was fresh and airy from its open doors and windows and, sadly for the management, but not for me, no great crush of custies at 6.30pm. (Feb 15, 2003,Dominion Post,F6)

customary fishing rights¶

n.

Commercial and Maori customary fishing rights are already guaranteed by law. (Mar 5, 2001,Dominion,3)

customary interest(s)¶

n.

Of all the opaque and shifting rhetoric surrounding the foreshore and seabed debate, my personal favourite has got to be customary interest. This was the catch-all term for various Maori claims employed in the government's recently released report... (Aug 30, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

Thus the term "Maori customary rights" that has been bandied around in the past few weeks has overnight become "customary interests", and it is access, rather than ownership, that is one of the fundamental principles the Government has sought to address. (Aug 19, 2003,Dominion Post,B4)

customary land¶

n.

In the late 1860s and later. millions of hectares of Maori customary land was wrongly and unfairly confiscated. (May 21, 2003,Dominion Post,B7)

He prepared evidence for the Maori Land Court hearings over customary land on the southern slopes of Mt Ruapehu. (May 29, 2003,Dominion,B7)

Maori customary land is land held by Maori in accordance with tikanga Maori. Very little if any of such land has survived the depredations of successive parliaments and land courts. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2)

customary rights¶

n.

We have a general environment, an ambience, an atmosphere, in which Maori people feel they are justified in making all sorts of ridiculous claims simply because they have customary rights guaranteed under the Treaty of Waitangi. (Jan 25, 1998,Sunday Star Times,Focus 4)

Comedian Raybon Kan used to have a wry line on customary rights; he complained that although his tribal ancestors had been running restaurants and takeaways in Courtenay Place for generations, he could not now get a carpark. (Jul 5, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

Having danced on a thousand pinheads about how its "customary rights" proposal would not enable Maori to edge out other seaside users, despite a ton of evidence to the contrary, the government suddenly reintroduced the dreaded words "Crown ownership". (Mar 6, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

[Hdg] Customary rights... These rights, to the extent that they still exist, are iwi- and hapu-based... Only one of the many hapu of Ngai Tahu has a customary right to take mutton birds. (May 21, 2003,Dominion Post,B7)

The Crown will argue that "the tide of history has washed away" the customary rights, as an Australian judge put it. (Aug 9, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

In ancestral terms, a customary right is the right to stand on the foreshore with an axe and defend it against all comers. The modern equivalent of that is the right of iwi authorities to be the representative voice taking submissions to the regional authorities or the Crown to protect the interests, which would include usage rights. (May 1, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

[The courts] have established that customary rights can extend over resources of species unknown in 1840 - the Becroft decision allowing Maori rights over trout species introduced around 1900 is a classic, and not inconsistent with previous judgments. (Mar 29, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

..."where the collection of customary rights ... have amounted to something like freehold title ... a freehold title is a logical consequence..." (Sep 13, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

Thus the term "Maori customary rights" that has been bandied around in the past few weeks has overnight become "customary interests", and it is access, rather than ownership, that is one of the fundamental principles the Government has sought to address. (Aug 19, 2003,Dominion Post,B4)

customary title¶

n.

We still don't know how firm the legal difference is between "customary title" and "customary use", and the government daren't let a court ever rule on this. (Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

The most pervasive customary right was customary title, which, though unique, almost equated to ownership. It was territorial and the hapu could not have existed without the full use of the land in question. To prove a customary title, a hapu had to show it was in exclusive occupation of the land prior to sovereignty passing and that it had continued to follow customary activities on it ever since. (May 21, 2003,Dominion Post,B7)

The means by which customary use / customary title may become freehold title is [sic] cloudy. (Sep 13, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

What is customary title? Much like an ordinary title to land, customary title confers rights to the holder. These could include the right to use the land for farming or living on. However, customary title arises where the Maori holds land in accordance with tikanga Maori or Maori custom. It is held communally (as opposed to owned) and cannot be alienated (sold or mortgaged) to anyone but the crown. (Sep 12, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),50)

customary use¶

n.

Ministers know that Maori aspirations extend beyond isolated shellfish beds and reefs, and they doubt that the Maori Land Court has the power to award "customary use" rather than "customary" title. (Jun 30, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

Waitangi Fisheries Commissioner Maui Solomon insisted that you could not legally distinguish customary use from legal title so easily. (Jul 5, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

The distinction is important because, one imagines, it doesn't take a tribunal or court to declare that Maori can continue to visit and use their local beaches s they have always done, as in "customary use". They can do that now. (Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

customwood¶

n. a type of fibreboard, in common use by builders, tradesmen, and handymen [Jim writes: Proprietary (Carter Holt Harvey) but used in the same way as gibraltar board, pink batts. An informant tells me the word is not known in England.]

cut¶

n. esp. take a cut (of a mob, etc.), a mob of sheep or cattle `cut out' or detached from the main mob for usu. some purpose, (See also cut out)

(Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.) [see cut @v]]

JONES [They] took a small cut of 20 or 30 sheep up to the river. (1933,Autobiography,93)

NEWTON Cut: A cut is a portion of the mob. The term is probably derived from the fact that to get the portion a man cuts through the mob to separate them. (1949,High Country Days,194)

BEATTIE The snowgrass was so long [c1855-1856] that it was necessary to take a small cut of the main flock of sheep and drive them ahead a half-mile or so, ... (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,50) [NOTES: 1947 Thos MacGibbon in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 50]

STRONACH [sc cattle] At last we got a small cut of out mob over and the rest was easy. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,68)

MASTERS [sc. sheep] Jackaroo and Bluey held the main mob while I took a small cut quietly forward and tried to ease them down to water. The cut I had, on scenting the water, started bleating and tearing forward. (1960,Back-Country Tales,239)

NEWTON Cut: A cut is a portion of the mob. The term is probably derived from the fact that to get the portion a man `cuts' through the mob to separate them. (1966,Boss's Story, The,185)

McCASKILL Cows and calves have already been mustered ... Small cuts of only 300 to 400 are taken, to avoid mis-mothering as much as possible. 1969 ... Cuts of a total of 800 cows and their calves, are driven over the Robinson Saddle. (1969,Molesworth,198)

LETHBRIDGE Do we bring them right into the station?' I asked.Just a cut,' he replied. `Enough to keep the shearers going. We'll pick up the rest next day ...' (1971,Sunrise on the Hills,113)

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR After tea Bill had to help pack the [shearing] shed with another cut of dry-fleeced sheep for the morning run. (1981,Sunrise on the Hills,49)

v. to clear (a line)

T.S. GRACE The war at Taranaki commenced by a land agent inducing a Chief to cut a boundary line (for the purpose of sale) through land of which he was, at most, a part owner only! (Mar 24, 1858,Letter,77) [NOTES: 1858 Mar 24 T.S.Grace letter in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 77]

DOBSON When working in the bush, cutting lines, as survey hands, or when working on the claims as miners, trousers and a flannel shirt were all that were required. (1930,Reminiscences,156)

n. a style of shearing

Cut (4).-Style of shearing; e.g., They have a very rough <i>c. </i>at So-and-so's' means thatSo-and-so' does not care whether his sheep are neatly shorn or not. (Jan 20, 1934,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

SCRYMGEOUR Proceeding just fair, but with their regularity that follows a shearer getting his back used to the arduous job, the advancement went on but with a different and a rougher cut than was usual. More frequently application of the loppies galloping down the board, to the ever increasing cry of `Tar'. The cut was becoming rougher and numbers spoilt good work, and slowly the gore of the classer, the shepherds, and certainly that of William Steuart, rose. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,49)

n. a share (general English?)

PARTRIDGE [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... cut, a share, where Tommy preferred whack; (1935,Slang Today,285) [NOTES: 1935 Mitchell and Strong in Partridge Slang Today 285]

PARTRIDGE Cut. 7. A share: Australian and New Zealand coll.: late C. 19-20. (1938,Dictionary of Slang,200)

McGILL cut share; late C19; in for one's cut expecting one's share of profit; eg `Hey I contributed to that winning ticket. Where's my cut?' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,33)

n. strip (of grass)

HILL Moving electric fence to give stock another cut of grass. (1988,More from Moaville,38)

v. (of a sheep) to produce wool (from a shearing)

Until the commencement of the frozen-meat industry, in 1882, sheep-farmers in New Zealand confined their attention exclusively to producing the class of sheep that would cut the heaviest fleece; ... (1892,NZ Official Handbook,123)

A sheep is said to cut, that is produce, so many pounds of wool... If a mob of sheep is too large for any purpose, you cut them or take c[ut]s of the required size. Taking a cut of ewes and lambs from a paddock for shearing is one of the most delicate and responsible jobs a shepherd has to do. (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

v. (of a farmer) to produce (wool) by shearing

TOMLINSON These [Merino wethers] did very well the first year and he cut about sixty-five bales of wool. (1968,Remembered Trails,58)

n. a character, a dag.

KOEBEL I've seen some cuts of men about, but anything like this - (1908,Anchorage,57)

SARGESON cut: would look a cut, would look an oddity. (1964,Collected Stories,299)

n. a go, a try (in phrase have a cut at) (? from card games).

SCOTT I'm going to have a cut for the National. (1908,Colonial Turf,110)

adj. often of liquor, finished, cut out (See cut v)

She's [the keg's] cut, is she? ... (1946,Johnny Enzed in Italy,5)

DAVIN No need to worry about [giving me a rise]. The gratuity's not cut ... (1956,Sullen Bell,214)

CASEY Anyway the plonk's cut. Mmm[????????], I'm tired. (1963,As Short a Spring,168)

SLATTER Bert's beer was cut anyway. (1968,Pagan Game, The,171)

adj. drunk

There was real beer in those glasses. I often ended up three parts cut. (Feb 17, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A5)

v. (Rural) [sheep] to produce wool for shearing.

EVAN Started shearing - sheep cutting very light. (Jan 6, 1868,Letter,242) [NOTES: in Vance (1965) High Endeavour]

v. to cease doing

J.Rogan (Auckland) I think I should get married in real earnest and cut the bush work (1859,McLean Papers,16/113)

v. to finish (off), empty, use up (See also cut out)

HENDERSON [chk ?131 Let's cut the lot. (1945,Gunner Inglorious,134)

WILSON Here, drink it down. We must cut this bottle tonight. (1952,Julian Ware,241)

McCLENAGHAN Dropsy tapped the keg ... `Our form is good today. We'll soon have this cut.' (1976,Travelling Man,45)

McGILL cut to finish or finished; eg Let's cut all the beer.'Too late. It's all cut.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,33)

HENDERSON Plenty of garrulous half-shot but willing hands, generous with advice and counter-advice, had all the wool stacked safely in the store by 1 am, when they turned to even more willingly and cut the keg. (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,14)

n. (mining term) see cit.

McARA Holes [for blasting-charges] were drilled about two feet apart and four or five feet deep in the bottom of the shaft, in accordance with the pattern or cut' being used. <i>Ibid.</i> 318 <i>Cut</i>: The pattern of drill-holes used to make the initial penetration of a face, for the purpose of creating a secondfree face', to facilitate the breaking of the rock. A cut usually entailed drilling several angled holes, usually in the centre of the face, to open up the face and make an opening, to which holes drilled parallel would break. in the cool store ... . (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi,179)

n. early European alteration of Ma. kati (W.103, 4n. Barrier, boundary, pale) used in the expression put a cut on (sthg). (See cf. aukati)

The Hau Haus have put a cut [fn kati] on this port, and have laid down a law that no vessels are to be allowed to come here under pain of being taken, and all on board put to death. (1865,AJHR,E-4) [NOTES: J. White Spread of Hau Hau Superstition (Letter of Miss Wallace, Whakatane)]

1 n. (Rural) a part of a mob, usually of sheep.

LOUGHNAN cut: a portion of a herd or flock. It needs a good man on a good horse to cut cows from their calves at foot, and, an even more delicate operation to take a cut of ewes without mismothering them from their lambs. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,23)

MCLEOD The next few days were spent drafting sheep which had been mustered, taking out mobs which had been shorn, and getting in 'cuts' for next day's shearing. (1960,Tall Tussock,47)

MOWAT Aubrey and I mustered a cut of the ewes ... (Oct 21, 1915,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

MILLS ET AL He will then, after opening the gates, move into the pen behind, smartly cover a cut and push them forward. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,75)

The second cut will go to the finishing blocks and whether they are sold to the works or in the yards depends on the market at the time ... (Sep 25, 1997,NZ Farmer,13)

2 v. to shear more than (another shearer); to outshear.

RICHARDS [to shear more sheep than (another shearer)] On the next run I cut Mack by three, so I knew he was working at top speed. ... On the last run I cut him by five. He ended the day with 324 and I shore 326. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,137)

3 v. to cut (a sheep's skin) by rough shearing

MEREDITH Two of them [sc shearers] were running one another for the title of `ringer' (the one who shore the most sheep in one day) and were cutting the sheep rather badly, necessitating the constant application of the Stockholm-tar brush to the cuts. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,143) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 143]

SCRYMGEOUR Passing down the board towards the end, he saw Jack Gwydir cutting badly, and quietly touched him on his Jackey Howe' and bare arm, and said,Try not to cut too much, I don't like it.' (1960,Memories of Maoriland,49)

7 n. a job as a shearer

Organiser John Mee, ..., went to Christchurch with the intention of perhaps getting a cut in at a late shed or taking part in the straw rush; but he found that most of the sheds were cut out, ... (Feb 16, 1912,Maoriland Worker,49/12/2)

cut (out) the rough stuff¶

phr. usu. as an exclam. or command, perhaps an alteration of 'cut it out', to stop doing or saying something rough or offensive (See also cut the rough)

That's why I kicked it.'Well, cut out the rough stuff. This isn't a test match.' (1933,Auckland Capping Book,27)

SYDER & HODGETTS A rebuke. Your language or your topic, or both, offend. .in 4;Hey cut out the rough stuff! That old bag you're talking about happens to be my mother-in-law.' No more of this! or, cease this disorderly conduct! .in 4;Cut out the rough stuff! These boxes are marked `Fragile', they're full of glassware. You can't throw them on any old how.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],241) [NOTES: (1962-63)1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust and NZ English [TS] 241]

PARTRIDGE Cut the rough (stuff). To cease doing or saying something obnoxious to another: Australian and New Zealand (lower classes', then military coll.: C. 20. i.e. cut out, desist from. Supp: also in imp. Stop it!, Austr: 20C.: Baker. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,202)

cut and tail¶

v. usu. collocated as two farming jobs undertaken at the same time; see also cutting and tailing.

TRIPP We all helped at cutting, tailing etc. the lambs. 470 were cut. (Oct 29, 1857,Diary) [NOTES: 1857 Oct 29 Tripp Diary in 1967 Harper Kettle on Fuchsia 32]

BEATTIE In connection with stock the following terms were used: - Let the sheep draw down to the Taieri';stags,' crawlers,'stragglers,' a horse with couples in his mouth,'the bull baked on the road,' cut and tailed,'lagoon washing,' spaying cattle,'killed a pleuro,' herding lambs,'buisting weaners,' `a camp for the cattle,' ... Ibid. 107 Fine day. ... Chapman's flock in cut and tailed - tally 2,510. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,85) [NOTES: [1858-1869] Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 85]

PHILLIPS All hands hard at it in spite of rain & mud - cut and tailed 2740 lambs and brought ewes up to hills in evening. (Dec 5, 1867,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,134)

PEACHE We cut and tailed the lambs from ... half-breds. (Oct 7, 1876,Journal) [NOTES: 1876 Oct 7 Peache Jnl in 1970 Gray Quiet with the Hills 52]

cut dags¶

phr. (Rural) to remove encrusted faeces from sheep rear ends.

BIBBY We had plenty to do as there were no broom hands or set sheepo, and cutting dags was done in spare time. (1990,Lunesdale: A Bush Farm Community from 1871,36)

cut in¶

v. (Rural) to begin shearing.

Most shearers are particular about this .. and they had so many sheds to go to, that they got desperate and cut in when the sheep were not fit. (Mar 1918,NZ Farmer,259)

v. to make cuts in blubber of a whale; to strip blubber from a whale.

McNAB [Whalers] were under the impression that ... they would have no further labour ... than to fasten to whales alongside, cut in, try out, stow away without intermission, until their cargoes would be completed. (1913,Old Whaling Days,154) [NOTES: 1836 Capt. Greene Report in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 154]

... got the whale along side and commenced cutting in. (1836,Journal Barque 'Australian',6)

RHODES The whales when caught were towed back to the ships to be `cut in' (i.e. to be stripped of their blubber) ... (1954,Whaling Journal,xvi) [NOTES: 1954 ed Straubel Rhodes Whaling Journal xvi]

noon brought the whale alongside, and in the afternoon cut her in. (May 22, 1836,Piraki Log,36,ed. Anson 1911 ed.)

TUCKETT They were busy cutting in a captured whale of large size. (May 3, 1844,Diary) [NOTES: 1844 May 3 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 215]

cut lunch¶

n. sandwiches and other snacks to be eaten elsewhere than at home or at a formal eating-place.

(1979,Heinemann NZ Dictionary)

FRANCIS The [station] midday meal was more often a cut lunch eaten on the job. The main meal, `tea', was basically mutton, potatoes, onions, ... and, for afters, stewed dried fruit, plum duff or rice and prunes. (1983,Wildlife Ranger,2)

HUNT We'd take our crib into the [gold]mine with us [c1916]: a cut lunch wrapped up in newspaper, cold meat, stew or bacon sandwiches and tea. (1985,I'm Ninety-five,28) [NOTES: (Bill Henderson)]

A cut lunch (packed lunch) is handy to have with you, so if you feel peckish (hungry), you can pull over for a wee (small) picnic. (Jan 14, 1987,NZ Woman's Weekly) [NOTES: 1986 B.G. Ostmann U.S. food-writer's written remarks: p.c.Tui Flower NZ Woman's Weekly (14 Jan 1987)]

cut lunch NZ & Austral. sandwiches etc. to be eaten away from home (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,183) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 118]]

PFAHLERT & WATSON I stated my requirements. `A single room, full board with a cut lunch Monday to Friday.' (1987,Some Must Die,28)

cut off my penis and call me Venus¶

exclam. an expression of surprise [(? 1930)-]

MORRIESON The [snooker] ball hovered on the edge of a pocket but defied gravity. Snip Hughes said, Well, cut off my penis and call me Venus.'Hard luck,' said Snip's opponent. (1981,Predicament,153)

cut off the horn¶

phr. said of tough beef

WILSON The men [sc. contract bushmen c1880s] often complained about the quality sent: they declared ... that the butcher's joint of beef was undoubtedly a cut off the horn. (1955,Land of My Children,5)

cut one's strings¶

phr.

OWEN & PERKINS But after I'd had a couple of those scones, I knew why Dick had cut his strings, because, stone the crows, they were bloody frightful! (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,70) [NOTES: (Bob Edwards, bushman)]

cut out¶

v. (forestry)

LAING & BLACKWELL A forest that has been "cut out" will, in time, replace itself. (1940,Plants of NZ,10)

1 n. (Rural) completion time, particularly in shearing, sheep yard and bush work. (See cut-out)

RICHARDS Unfortunately in the afternoon we got ahead of the musterers, so the manager had to run in a mob of undagged cotty sheep that were being held until the cut out. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,130)

MCKENNY Very often he must take the opportunity of getting shearers between the 'cut-out' of one shed and the starting of another. (1927,Sheep-Farming, Fencing etc.,15)

RICHARDS When the day of the cut-out finally arrived and we were 'squared up',' the lorry arrived, loaded a few bales of wool, and we threw up our swags and scrambled on top of the bales for the 50-mile journey to Taihape. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,46)

DAVIDSON The boss always shouted a dozen beer at 'Cut Out.' (2001,Road from Retrow, The,96)

1 v. (Rural) to complete work, particularly of shearing, sheep yard and bush work.

WATERSON All the Coromandel sheds were finally cut out and it was off to Taihape! (1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,60)

MEREDITH The Brancepath flock was cut out last week. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,96) [NOTES: in the Seventies (1935)]

MOWAT Cut out the hoggets about 3 pm. (1915,Alexander Mowat Diaries,8)

The beginning of March will see the shearing in the back country, but I am afraid that some of the sheds will not get cut out before that time. (Mar 1918,NZ Farmer,259)

STUDHOLME After 'cutting out' the Waimate shed, they would go on to the back country stations, such as Morven Hills.. (1940,Te Waimate,128)

MACNICOL Owners, with their permanent men, joined the mustering team, dropping out when their own sheds were reached, but joining up again as soon as the shearers had cut out their sheds. (1965,Beyond the Skippers Road,22)

RICHARDS When Otupae was cut out, we travelled by lorry to Ngamatea Station, a shed seven miles off the road. 'We should cut out by noon.' (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,46)

COWAN This [drinking] would go on for weeks and weeks, especially when they all cut out a big bush job. (1997,Pigs and Me: Tales of the Bygone Bush.,76)

WATERSON Harrigam had organised a relief crew on a Sunday to help cut the shed out. (1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,62)

KERR The shed cut out without incident and I suggested to Mick he stay with us over Christmas. [cut-out] (2000,High Times in the High Country,115)

2 v. (Rural) to separate an animal or animals from others, usually while in a paddock.

THOMSON ... the operation of cutting-out the fattest bullock. (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher,149)

BEATTIE One who was present has told me of a cattle drafting on the Beaumont Run, above Wrey's Bush. ... what with cutting-out the beasts wanted, rounding-up the remainder, dodging wild charging brutes, ... there was some ... exciting work done that day. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,44)

MCKENNY Generally there are a few newly-born lambs at this time which are unfit to travel. They should be 'cut out' and left behind until the second docking. (1927,Sheep-Farming, Fencing etc.,27)

If it is possible to cut out the lambed ewes quietly ... (Aug 5, 1936,Weekly News,82)

These ewes should be cut out of the main mob, given a change of feed, and kept under careful observation. (Sep 1, 1937,NZ Farmer,36)

LOUGHNAN cut out: to sort cattle without using drafting gates, ie in the open on horseback. I once saw a shepherd on foot and in the corner of a paddock, using three good dogs, who cut the rams out from the ewes at the end of tupping. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,24)

3 v. (Rural) to spend all one's pay, a habit of rural workers on only occasional visits to town.

MASTERS When he had cut his cheque out ... (1959,Tales of the Mails,52)

RICHARDS Many a bushman .. came into town with his cheque .. told the publican to tell him when it was 'cut out.' (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,96)

cut out the bows¶

phr.

cut out the bows: This means to cut a nick in the bows of a shear to weaken the spring. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/23) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

cut the cactus¶

exclam. cut out the (your) nonsense (perhaps influenced by cut the cackle! shut up!).

Mmm,' I murmur (but I think,Cut the cactus, Colonel, the ole dragon wouldn't have me before!'). (Jun 1952,Here & Now,13)

cut the cheese¶

phr. to fart [1951 14 M 14 St Bede's, Chch 5 GO AND DUST THE CHEESE (expressing annoyance, dismissal) 4. cut the cheese [nf P8] to fart.]

McGILL cheese phr. cut the cheese to fart; eg `Okay, who cut the cheese?' A cheeser was C18 English for a strong-smelling fart. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,26)

cut the dust¶

phr. (Rural) [farm stock] to move fast in dry conditions.

GASCOIGNE Into the yards they poured, small hooves cutting the dust ... (1965,From the Top of a Hill,12)

cut the rough¶

phr. stop annoying one; (as excl.) cut it out [CUT THE ROUGH, to stop doing something annoying (to the speaker); often as an exclamation `stop it!' -->ca1920 W.H.B.Orsman cut the rough used about WW1 P: cut the rough: cease doing or saying something obnoxious to another: Aust and NZ lower classes then military coll.: 20c.]

cut up¶

v. (Rural) to subdivide land into separate blocks or to convert land into shared ownership within a family.

SIMPSON Farms ought to be cut up on all the runs so as to give to each settler a portion of river flats, of terrace and of hill land. (Jan 2, 1880,Diary of Tours of Southland Estates)

BLAKISTON The first block to be mustered was the Four Peaks Range, which is now cut up into several small sheep runs and farms. (1952,My Yesteryears,19)

NEWTON After the last war the bulk of this property was cut up for soldier settlement. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,54)

Several wealthy syndicates are making enquiries in various parts of Southland (says the Mataura Ensign) for blocks suitable for cutting up into conveniently sized farms ... (Jan 19, 1905,Hawera Star,2)
