Owner is prepared to cut up into 500 acres, or more, but would rather sell the whole block. (Feb 3, 1906,Farmers' Union Advocate,7)

Taranaki heifers have established a reputation for their milking qualities. Already three hundred have been sent from Stratford to a Canterbury run-holder who is cutting up his sheep run into milking farms and putting on sharemilkers. (Jun 4, 1910,Hawera Star,4)

TAIT The farm is part of the old Te Arai Station, cut up in 1908. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,12)

MILLS ET AL .. gradually more accessible country is being cut up into smaller holdings. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,89)

2 v.

I am ... much improved with the stockwhip. I can crack it well enough but the thing is to be able to cut up your beast. An old Australian will cut a rut in two at full gallop and take the sight from a bullock. (Apr 2, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,30,1950 ed.)

3 v. cut out' [?pun on whalingcut'].

HUNT The busy [whaling] seasons lasted about five years; the ground then became pretty well cut up. (1866,Chatham Islands,59)

4 v.

NEWBOLD Cut up (v) Mutilate oneself. (1983,Big Huey, The,248)

cut-out¶

n.

RICHARDS Stan enjoyed a full-time accountant tokeep in touch with the gangs and pay themen at "cut-outs." (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,138)

n. the saleable product obtained from a carcass excluding fat and other trim, and bone where this is normally removed (as for beef).

Cut-out: The term often applied to the proportion of saleable product obtained from a carcass excluding fat and other trim, and bone where this is normally removed as for beef. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,33)

cut-out pass¶

n. a pass in rugby missing out the person(s) next in line to receive it

He got halfback Stacey Jones stationed at first receiver, throwing cutout-passes and bringing in secondary runners, and he had his three props... adding some footwork... ... The Kiwis used that momentum, and a smart passing movement, with a typical Jones cutout-pass in the middle, creating room for teenage winger Manu Vatuvei to score his first try in the corner. ... Amid a flurry of penalties from English official Steve Ganson, fullback Brent Webb shot across from another Jones cutout-pass and when Jones concluded the scoring with another penalty just before the hour, it was all over for the Australians. (Nov 28, 2005,Dominion Post,D2)

cut-up¶

n. the process and the product of sectionalising a national map.

Discussions over the past year amongst D.S.I.R. Divisions demonstrated a need for a 1:250,000 metric map cut-up which suited scientific research purposes, particularly a cut-up which covered systematically both onshore New Zealand and a substantial offshore area. (Nov 1978,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,46/25)

cutlassfish¶

n.

[species name] frost fish .. [scientific name] Lepidopus caudatus .. [other name(s)] cutlassfish, scabbardfish (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] CUTLASSFISHES 2035-46 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

cutover¶

n. an area of former forest

DENNIS In the early stages the track passes through old cutover, now overgrown with tall gorse and manuka scrub. (1981,Paparoas Guide,23)

1 n. (Rural) an area of forest that has been cleared and is awaiting replanting.

NGAWHIKA I was driving the roads purposely looking for cutovers and young, open pine blocks. (1996,Tell Them I've Gone Pighunting,124)

NGAWHIKA ibid. 171 Elton was struggling across a cutover with a fat black and white boar of about 60 lb under his arm. (1996,Tell Them I've Gone Pighunting,171)

cutover bush¶

1 n. (Rural) native bushland with the largest trees removed.

TAIT .. they literally hacked out their farms from cut-over bushland. (1958,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol II,464)

WATERSON Morry stood beside me at the cowshed, pointed at a steep hillside of cut-over bush country and said ... [cutover bush country; cut-over bush] (1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,8)

Although this from a distance looks like heavy bush, it is, in fact, all cut-over bush - bush that has had the big trees taken out many years ago for timber. The conventional way of bringing this cut-over bush country into grass is, of course, to fell it. (Mar 9, 1967,NZ Farmer,08)

NEWTON Between the two blocks over 7,000 acres have now been grassed, including 2,000 acres of cut-over bush. (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,133)

cuts¶

n. (the cuts) strokes of the strap or cane, as corporal punishment, esp. of primary school children. [-->1953 14-15 M A6 Thames DHS 23 CUTS [M4] -->1951 15-18 M 3 Marlborough C. 23 CUTS [F10M3] -->1951 14-18 M 9 St Bede's, Chch 23 CUTS [M8] -->1951 16-17 F 10 St Mary's, Wgton 23 CUTS [F3] -->1951 15 F 8 Wellington H.S. 23 CUTS [F5] -->1951 14-15 M 33 Wellington H.S. 23 CUTS [M10]]

Stapleton Remember the names of your teachers? .. WJ (Bill) Jeffries and Noel Young as headmasters, both of whom were perfectly capable of administering the "cuts" or strap! (2007,Wanderings in Westland: Trips down Memory Lane,38)

A country journal records that fact that one poor little boy who made a [April] fool' of his master received no fewer thanten cuts,' as the boy put it. (Apr 12, 1913,NZ Truth,407/1/6)

R. MASON R. Mason quotes a Pukekohe skipping rhyme: Andy pandy sugary candy,/ French Almond nuts,/ If you don't behave yourself/ You're sure to get the cuts': or, alternatively,If you stay away from school/ You will not get the cuts.' (1920,Personal Communication) [NOTES: ca1920 (Pukekohe, Auckland)]

LAWLOR Yer'l git the cuts. (1938,House of Templemore, The,123)

SARGESON [You] would get the cuts for sure. (1945,When the Wind Blows,14)

ADSETT If anyone was careless enough to use the wrong peg, their coat ... could be thrown on the floor without fear of getting the cuts. This was a form of discipline at which Miss Lyons excelled. Some ... even fought over who had been honoured by most cuts. (1963,Magpie Sings, A,57)

see Adam's Ale corporal punishment, usually with strap on hands; occas., cane (Jun 29, 1976,Evening Post,14/4-5-6 (4))

cut ... (in pl.) NZ & Austral. sl. corporal punishment. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,183) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

McGILL cuts corporal punishment in antipodean schools; eg `It wasn't fair the whole class getting the cuts, old Jolly knew which ones were the culprits.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,33)

FARRELL On the final day he took the strap fromits hook behind the door and gave Jackthe cuts: only two, one on each hand. (1992,Skinny Louie Book,37)

I once got the cuts for leaving out an apostrophe. (Apr 1992,North & South,39)

cutter¶

n. the reciprocating unit of shearing handpiece which cuts the wool against against the stationary comb.

In sheds where machines are used.. theshearers to pay for combs and cutters atcost price. (1906,Awards etc.,VII/625)

On the morning of shearing the shearers grind and set cutters and combs ready to start work. (1945,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),3(6) : 24)

PEACHE When in town last week I saw a new shearing machine for shearing the wool off sheep. ... I think the stroke of the cutter might be lengthened ... (Apr 20, 1890,Letter) [NOTES: 1890 Apr 20 letter Peache Jnl in 1970 Gray Quiet with the Hills 82]

Assets Shearers' Combs, Cutters, etc. ... 7000 (1912,NZ Shearers (Report Third Annual Conference),23)

MACDONALD [Advt.] Cooper's Little Wonder Shearing Machine ... The Shearing Attachments comprise ... two Latest Model Cooper Handpieces. ... COOPER COMBS AND CUTTERS will fit any make of handpiece ... (1915,NZ Sheepfarming,xv)

SMITH Each shed employs an expert, who sharpens the shearers' combs and cutters and looks after the machinery. (1927,Sheep & Wool Industry,70)

Dust can lower the value of a clip, ... besides being hard on combs and cutters. (Oct 16, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,310)

MIDDLETON When ... I had spread the fleece on Charlie's skirting table, the shearers began to sharpen their combs and cutters for the next shed. (1959,Stone, The,49) [NOTES: (The Stone)]

FERNANDEZ He pushed his completed, naked sheep through his legs and out the porthole then paused to change his cutter. The pumice in the wool played up with the gear, blunted the cutter and combs, ruined a man's tally; ... (1973,Tussock Fever,3)

Cutter. Reciprocating unit of shearing handpiece which cuts the wool against the stationary comb. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,54)

cutter ... NZ & Austral. moving blade in handpiece of shearing machine (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,184) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

RICHARDS None of them had ever shorn a sheep before, nor had they ever seen a handpiece correctly set up with comb and cutter. Ibid. 67 We were anxious to grind our combs and cutters and get our gear set up for the morning, ... (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,55)

n. a flaxcutter

CARR The cutter, armed with a sickle, stoops down and cuts the plant as near the base as he can get without taking in too much of the white growth, commonly called `rhubarb'. (1913,Country Work,43)

n. a digger (poss. a bound collocation gun cutter).

A gun cutter, swamp lingo for a good man (Mar 11, 1916,NZ Truth,6)

1 n. (Rural) a blade on a shearing handpiece.

MACINTOSH How I welcomed an unexpected stop for a change of cutter or comb on the handpiece. (1974,Never a Dull Moment,113)

WALLACE The cutter .. moves from side to side 4,000 times per minute over the comb, which rests upon the skin of the sheep. (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,379)

BOWEN Machine men only stop a few times a run to change cutters, compared with blade men giving their shears several wipes in a run. (1955,Wool Away!,9)

RICHARDS I now have a collection of antiques .. old handpieces, combs, cutters, droppers. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,41)

cutter-in¶

n. one who makes the first cuts in the blubber of a whale to enable its removal. [[First recorded in NZ.]]

DIEFFENBACH [The tongue of the whale] is the monopoly of the tonguer' orcutter-in'. (1843,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/51)

cutter-out¶

1 n. (Rural) a stockman who separates stock within a mob.

STUDHOLME Most of the drafting was done in the open by a process known as cutting out. Several men would hold the cattle together in a bend of a boggy creek or a corner of a paddock while the [136] `cutter-out' rode through them, and after spotting the beast that he wanted, would follow it out to the edge of the mob, when the holder would open out and allow both beast and cutter-out to pass through... A second's false timing, and the cutter-out's manoeuvre was ruined. I have had some nice things said about my ancestors by the cutter-out when things do not eventuate as they should have done. (1940,Te Waimate,135)

cutting¶

n. of sheep or fleecewool, usu. with a modifying av, indicative of the ease of shearing

SCRYMGEOUR Perhaps a week had passed, 26 men on the board, mostly Australians, who came over in the off-season making a good cheque on the soft cutting New Zealand flocks, then hired their professional ability back to the land of the kangaroo, .. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,48)

CHAR;ES Good cutting sheep they were - shore a thousand head./ (1981,Black Billy Tea,53)

RICHARDS ... my two mates selected a [sic] easy cutting ewe hogget each and got `stuck into it'. Ibid.75 We will be on hoggets all day. They are big and well wooled, but will be good cutting. Ibid.82 The farm itself was very poor and covered with hutiwai (biddy bids), so the sheep were fairly slow cutting. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,68)

n. a natural `cutting' (in a hill, ridge, etc.)

LADY BARKER We found our way to the station, across the flat, down a steep cutting. (1867,Station Life in NZ,192,1874 ed.)

n.

MAY CUTTING: working out a layer in a shaft or tunnel. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,527,1962 ed.)

n. [applied in NZ to other than the artificial excavations (the cuttings of OED2 8.) to (occas. a surveyor's line, and to natural river etc. cuttings, steep gullies, and the like.]

WOOD A wilderness barely accessible on hands and buses through a surveyor's `cutting.' (1843,Twelve Months in Wellington,11)

1 adj. (Rural) [of livestock] for sale for slaughter as lamb, mutton, pork or beef.

A mixed yarding ranging from very light to overfats saw fewer good cutting sheep than usual in the yarding of 4700. Good cutting ewes found a stronger market than last week by $1 a head. Hoggets had a very strong sale for good cutting ones, regardless of weight. (Dec 7, 1988,NZ Farmer,36)

A yarding of 7000, a return of dry weather and shortage of killing space saw good cutting shorn ewes selling at about $8. Choppers were in good supply and included a line of 55 from a Hawke's Bay vendor which averaged $160. Best cutting choppers made up to $200. (Dec 14, 1988,NZ Farmer,42)

Good cutting shorn ewes sold from $8.50 to $9.50. (Dec 21, 1988,NZ Farmer,32)

Some very good cutting ewes were entered in the fat sheep pens. (Mar 27, 1991,NZ Farmer,33)

Good cutting ewes fetched $32 to $35.50 ... (May 4, 1993,NZ Farmer,37)

Overfats $28-$30; better cutting, heavy $31-$33. (Aug 1, 1996,NZ Farmer,42)

Prime cattle: good cutting ox 505 kg $2.43/kg. Good cutting heifers 425 kg.. (Sep 5, 2001,Southland Times,7)

The first carcasses have been cut in Richmond's new $9.8 million lamb-cutting shop at its Oringi plant, in Dannevirke. (Dec 14, 2001,Dominion,19)

cutting and tailing¶

phr. the farming process of castrating and docking male lambs, gen. done in the same operation.

ACLAND About a fortnight after lambing is over the operation of `cutting and tailing' is performed, ... (1858,Notes on Sheepfarming in NZ,10)

DUPPA Cutting and tailing. (1949,Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury,47) [NOTES: 1860 Sep Duppa in 1949 Crawford Sheep and Sheepmen Canterbury 47]

[Hocken TS] Cleared out pens and prepared yard for cutting & tailing (Nov 6, 1862,Puketoi Station Diary)

ELWELL The sheep had to be mustered ... in the latter part of the spring for cutting and tailing; ... in autumn to catch any stragglers that might want shearing, branding or tailing; (tailing here meaning cutting off the tails). (1878,Boy Colonists,172)

WILLIAMS & REEVES `New Chum's Letter' ... cutting and tailing the poor little lambs. (1889,Colonial Couplets,9)

VOGEL When the docking, and dagging and cutting came he is worked as hard as any man. (1898,Maori Maid,147)

(1) Castrate. Cutting and tailing was the old term for earmarking, castrating and taking the tails off lambs, all of which operations are performed together. Cutting and tailing is still the general name mostly used by shepherds, but owing to more ladies living up country, I suppose [(probably because more women now live up country], is being replaced by tailing or marking. (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

cutting cabbages¶

phr. a term used in the game of knucklebones

MARSHALL Creamy was even better with the aluminium ones [sc. knuckle bones]. Cutting cabbages, camels, swatting flies, clicks, little jingles, through the arch, goliath, horses in the stable; Creamy mastered them all. (1982,Master of Big Jingles,55)

cutting grass¶

n. any of several grasses, sedges or grass-like plants having sharp-edged leaves or stems (here Gahnia spp.)

TAYLOR Gahnia Gaudichaudii (1855,Te Ika a Maui)

VON TEMPSKY The bush was open on account of the absence of supplejack and cutting grass; ... (1864,Memoranda,19)

HOOKER Cutting grass. Gahnia, various sp. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),764)

The slopes of the hills are usually covered with a dense forest ... and immense tussocks of an undescribed Astelia, and cutting grasses (Gahnia lacera, Stend., G. arenaria, Hook. f.) ... render all progress tedious ... (1870,TrNZI,2/90) [NOTES: (Kirk)]

Gahnia xanthocarpa Cutting grass (1870,TrNZI,2/127) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

Cutting grasses, Gahnia setifolia and Gahnia ebenocarpa, appear well adapted for the manufacture of coarse papers. (1873,TrNZI,6/56) [NOTES: (Kirk)]

TURNER Gahnia xanthocarpa . Hierochloe redolens. (1909,AJHR,C-11) [NOTES: Botanical Examination Higher Waimarino in AJHR C(And)]

The tufts of the toe-kiwi - the `cutting-grass' of the bushmen - which are a feature of the kauri bush, are set in a blaze; and as the flames flare up ... the masses of the puwharawhara (Asteliads) which encumber the branches are ignited ... (1897,TrNZI,29/493) [NOTES: (Walsh)]

n.

MEREDITH The original homesteads on the coast were very primitive. The roofs were always made of toi-toi, very much like our [sc Tasmanian] cutting grass. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,51) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 51]

TREGEAR ... sometimes a plaster of the leaves of cutting-grass (toetoe) was applied and sometimes the wounds were held in the smoke of a fire. (1904,Maori Race, The,18)

2 n. (See also cutting toetoe)

TURNER Mariscus ustulatus (1909,AJHR,C-11) [NOTES: Botanical Examination Higher Waimarino(And)]

Mariscus ustulatus (1888,TrNZI,20/) [NOTES: (And.)]

Various grass-like sedges occupy the moist ground ... and these include the niggerhead (Carex secta), cutting-grass (Mariscus ustulatus ) ... (1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/203)

cutting out¶

1 n. (Rural) a separation of stock from a mob, usually carried out by an operator on horseback.

Breakfast before daylight, cutting out till 4 o'clock when we drove five miles along the sea shore, jamed [sic] the cattle in a bite and pitched our tent, boiled some of my cocoa (Apr 16, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,32,1950 ed.)

STUDHOLME Most of the drafting was done in the open by a process known as cutting out. Several men would hold the cattle together in a bend of a boggy creek or a corner of a paddock while the [136] `cutter-out' rode through them, and after spotting the beast that he wanted, would follow it out to the edge of the mob, when the holder would open out and allow both beast and cutter-out to pass through. (1940,Te Waimate,135,1954 ed.)

Being more manoeuvrable than either a truck or tractor, it is handy for cutting out or shedding off ewes, which may be necessary two or three times a day during lambing, depending on the number of lambs dropped. (Sep 28, 1961,NZ Farmer,18)

STACEY Cutting out is not a difficult job providing it is done in as quiet a manner as possible with a heading dog in front of each mob to stop them drifting too far apart. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,90)

NOLAN 'Cutting out' as it was called, took many hours for 300 or so head and entailed a lot of penning up. The cutting out was done on horseback and was a pretty hard session for the horses. (1998,Droving Days, The,10)

cutting room¶

n.

Meat is processed in a boning or cutting room, after it comes (whole or in quarters) from the cooling floor or from the chiller. (1974,NZ Agriculture,189)

cutting spade¶

n. an implement for cutting into and removing a whale's blubber. Compare boat spade.

38 Irons - .. 8/- ea. ... 14 Lances - .. 8/- ea. ... 1 Cutting Spade - .. 8/- ... 2 Boat Spades - .. .16. 4 Boat axes - .. 4/- ea. ... 5 Boat Knives - .. 2/- ea. ... 3 Pughs - .. .9. ... 2 Blubber Knives - .. . 8. ... 1 [Boat] Traveller - .. .4. (1837,Piraki Log,49) [NOTES: 1837 List of Gear Lost Piraki Log (ed. Anson 1911) 49]

cutting toetoe¶

n. Mariscus ustulatus (See cutting grass)

Mariscus ustulatus cutting toetoe (1872,TrNZI,4/) [NOTES: (And)]

cutting up¶

1 n. (Rural) a division of large blocks of land into smaller units.

WHYTE But even with this cutting up of the country, we still have the irregular contours, the rugged hills and the bush-clad slopes to contend with ... (1927,Sheep-Dog, The,114)

The changeover was hastened by the cutting up of enormous blocks of grassland in the eastern portion of the Waikato Basin. (Jul 1947,NZ Journal of Agriculture,22)

cutting-block¶

n. ?where blubber is cut into pieces for try-pot.

(ed. Anson 1911) (Apr 23, 1840,Piraki Log,107)

cutting-in¶

n. the process of incising and stripping the blubber of a whale; see also cutting-up.

Second Mate got one whale 3 got it alongside and 6 finished cutting in. (Jan 11, 1836,Piraki Log,23,(ed. Anson 1911) ed.)

RHODES At 3.30pm got the whale alongside and commenced cutting in. Ibid. At daylight began to cut in the remainder of the whale. (1836,Whaling Journal,8,1954 ed.)

BAUCKE Then the cutting in' is begun; the huge slabs of fat are sliced and allowed toripen' in casks, with one head removed. When the last cask is full, the first is emptied into the try-pot, ... (1905,Where the White Man Treads,76)

GRADY Cutting-in - Making the guideline cuts or directions on a dead whale for taking the blubber off. It is the start of the flensing of a whale. (1982,Perano Whalers,226) [NOTES: (Cook Strait Whalers' glossary)]

JOHNSTON ... while the cutting-in was progressing and the blubber was lying on the staging ready for the vats, oil was running from it in streams. (1968,Turn of the Tide, The,33)

2 n. [first two citations belong with verb to cut in]

17 people employed fitting Boats, Cutting in gear, &c. &c. (Dec 5, 1835,Piraki Log,(ed. Anson 1911) ed.)

JOHNSON A Mr Wilkins from Wellington had arrived at Te Awaiti to take ... films of a chase and of the cutting-in and drying-out process. (1968,Turn of the Tide, The,29)

people employed refitting Cutting in Penants &c. &c. (Feb 4, 1836,Piraki Log,25,(ed. Anson 1911) ed.)

cutting-out horse¶

1 n. (Rural) a saddle-horse used to separate cattle in a mob.

MILLS ET AL These men educate cattle as they work them, and they will also train a raw hack to become a good cutting-out horse. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,105)

cutting-up¶

n. = cutting-in

DIEFFENBACH The `cutting-up' of a whale, secundum artem, is a process which requires great proficiency, like that of the skilful dissector, who separates the cutis, and with it at once all fat and cellular tissue, from the subjacent muscles. In the whale the blubber is to be regarded as the cutis, in the cellular structure of which the oily matter has been deposited. Shortly after the death of the fish the epidermis comes off in large pieces, looking like oiled and dried satin. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/51)

cutty¶

adj.

HYDE ... the wharf-steps are thick with old, cutty barnacles. (1938,Godwits Fly, The,118,1970 ed.)

cutty grass¶

n. Cortaderia splendens, a common nickname for cutting-grass

PRINCE The Falls were soon arrived at, and standing ... upon a little terrace of cutty grass, a full ... view was obtained. (1889,Diary of a Trip,11)

... spidery tafia [check ? rafia; or M. ? tawhia n.f.] and cutty grass ... (1900,NZ Illustrated Magazine,3/203)

COCKAYNE Her is also the home of the sedge family, to which the so-called `cutty-grasses' belong. (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story,109)

STRACHAN The [Otematata homestead] building [in 1858] consisted of the usual cob and clay, ... and thatched with cutty grass tied on with native flax which had been boiled to make it tough. (1917,Experiences) [NOTES: 1917 James Strachan Experiences (Hocken L.) in 1980 Neave The Land of Munros 65]

MANDER Among the rushes and cuttigrass. (1920,Story of a NZ River, The,2/29)

GUTHRIE-SMITH [The lake-edge flats'] growth of carex, `cutty-grass' and raupo provide excellent harbourage for the smaller rails and other interesting species. Ibid. 162 The nest is planted deep ... in the heart of a bunch of cutty grass. (1927,Birds of New Zealand,3)

FINLAYSON Cutty grass scars his arms and cheeks, bush-lawyer vines hook into clothes and flesh ... (1948,Tidal Creek,80,1979 ed.)

HEINZ Some huts [on the early diggings] were built with logs, criblogged, and the roof thatched with rushes or cutty grass. (1974,Bright Fine Gold,37) [NOTES: 1953 Magee in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 37]

cutty grass. A name used in Australia and New Zealand for various kinds of sedge, grass-like plants whose leaves have sharp and often saw-like edges. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),107)

ROGERS A voice said: `About time. I could eat cutty grass.' (1960,Long White Cloud, The,12)

EVANS The numerous wet places [at Waikaka] were crowded with interesting plants ... sedge, or cuttygrass, niggerheads, wiwi or rush, and epilobium or willow herb with its beautiful white flowers. (1962,Waikaka Saga,239)

TURNER Probably Australians influenced the naming of the New Zealand cabbage tree and cutty grass may owe something to Australian cutting grass. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,166)

cutting grass n. grass with long, narrow sharp blades, often called sword grass, in N.Z. cutty grass. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

grass, cutty [=] carex virgata: cyperus ustulatus: gahnia: hooked sedge: karetu: niggerhead: pampas grass: purple pampas grass: purua grass: rautahi: tall fescue: toetoe [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,31)

BROOKER et al. Cyperus ustulatus A. Rich. Common name: Cutty grass Maori names: Toetoe, upokotangata ... The name `toetoe' was applied to various grasses and sedges. ... Cheeseman's name for it was Mariscus ustulatus (A. Rich.) Cheesem. (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,49)

MARSHALL In the afternoon a fine rain began on the river. It billowed in from the east like a dust, and built up on the lupins and cutty grass. (1982,Master of Big Jingles,65)

WILSON Carex SEDGES ... Cutty grasses ... The larger species have very rough leaf margins (appearing saw-edged through a lens) which can easily cut the skin, hence the common generic name `cutty grass'. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,354)

SLIGO Natalia ...looked at her son's legs, scratched by the cutty-grass down at the river paddock where he'd been sent to round up a bunch of ewes ... (1987,Final Things,44)

BEATTIE This greenness is not caused by grass or verdant pasture but by a `water cutty grass' and similar vegetation growing in a swamp there. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,127)

Maori were once kite-fliers, forming kites from tapa, having brought the aute tree, or paper mulberry, from their ancestral home to Aotearoa. Just a couple of small, early-twentieth century examples made of indigenous materials - raupo leaves, flax fibre, toetoe, harrier feathers, cutty grass - are on view, along with a contemporary birdman kite, or manu aute. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/19)

FRAME The cutty grass and the tinkertailor were brushing against her black stockings (1963,Reservoir, The,139)

New Zealand has about 162 native grass species, including the familiar toetoe, or cutty grass (Cortederia spp), and the tussocks (Chionchloa spp), which help create the dramatic tussock plains of the New Zealand high country. (Jun 23, 2007,Dominion Post Indulgence,17)

I.. was in great difficulties among tall cutting grass (gahnia). (Dec 17, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

HYDE She proved it by decoying him through huge, evil patches of cutty-grass, whence he emerged with legs and arms gory in a dozen places. (1937,Wednesday's Children,138) [NOTES: 1989 edition]

CROWE Toetoe is resistant to salt wind... Often called cutty grass (particularly by children) because of the many fine, sharp teeth along the edges of the leaves. This is New Zealand's largest native grass. (1995,Which Coastal Plant?,18)

n. (Rural) Carex ternaria, a grass with sharp blades, capable of cutting one's skin open [occas. used for other sharp-bladed grass spp.].

NGAWHIKA Realising the vehicle could move ten metres at a time, we drove straight up a bank and into a clump of capeweed and cutty grass. (1996,Tell Them I've Gone Pighunting,109)

.. handling a swing plough was no easy job, with horses knee-deep in swamp, or hard in the collar working 'cutty grass.' (1910,Tapanui Station,51)

LOUGHNAN cutty grass: several grasses having the capacity to cut one's skin have earned this name, but at least one of them has an appreciable usefulness. This is Carex ternaria, which grows in swampy ground. Where it can be sighted, there the ground can be trusted to bear a horse or a cattle beast. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,24)

cutty-cut¶

n. (See cutter)

SCRYMGEOUR Any complaints Joe attended to, and the `cutty-cut' as the shearing machines were designated [by the Maori shearers], did a beautiful job, smooth, even, with no second cuts, with an eversmiling keen sense of rivalry prevailing. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,110)

cuz¶

n. a cousin; among Polynesians often in address, a member of the family at large. (See cf. bro,cous,cuzzie)

"She was screaming because she noticed she was bleeding and she was saying, 'Cuz, get her cuz'." (Sep 26, 2006,NZ Herald,A6)

There was clearly one point of perfect accuracy in the picture: when they looked at Pauanui they licked their chops and declared, let's go for it, cuz. (Feb 13, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

cuzzie¶

n. as cuz q.v.

This you understand, is an intensely Maori group. It would seem that Billy's not entirely joking when he talks about his countless cuzzies. (Sep 1986,Metro,33)

There's a jug of beer for you because you put my cuzzie in jail and he deserved it. (Apr 30, 1999,Dominion,8)

He squirms slightly in his chair, lets fly with a couple of cuzzie chuckles, steadies himself for the blow. (Jun 11, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

It may be that half of all staff are of Ngai Tahu descent but this is no gravy boat for the cuzzies; the employment policy is strictly the best person for the job. (Feb 10, 2001,Dominion,28)

I could have taken the easy path, followed Billy and been a warm, fuzzy cuzzie. (May 18, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),77)

"We were buzzing, we got high from seeing the kids enjoying themselves, being with the cuzzies and kicking back." (Sep 29, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,6)

Kaimana came...and we had the hangi ready and all - the cuzzies were all here - but it was such bad news that we never shared kai together. (2007,Huia 7: Contemp. Maori Fiction,141)

cuzzy-bro¶

n. [cousi-bro, cuzzie bro, etc]

There's a lot of cuzzie bros in our dressing-room. (Sep 24, 1998,Dominion,9)

Under closer economic relations IBM PCsmade by our Digger cuzzy-bros areapparently as good as home-made. (Sep 21, 1992,Dominion Infotech Weekly,4)

Kai Time is a great show because the two hosts are classic cousi-bros who love their kai and are into weird and wonderful ways of preparing and cooking it. (Dec 12, 2005,NZ Herald,B4)

adj. Maori or Polynesian

[Hdg] Cuzzybro Comedy (Jun 11, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

53 "I hear there's heaps of Maoris up in Whangarei, eh?" she jibes, in a flawless cuzzy-bro accent to a pale North Shore crowd. (Dec 1, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

cyanide¶

v. to poison opossums with cyanide baits (illegally till ca1951; legally after then). [(Also vbl n cyaniding.) ca1945]

cyanide shyness¶

1 n. (Rural) [pest control] the suspicion of some species towards bait.

Field trials are underway in areas where there is cyanide shyness. (Aug 22, 1996,NZ Farmer,19)

cyberhui¶

n. a hui to discuss communication developments

[Hdg] Cyber-hui may be repeated. Technology came face to face with "flaxroots" at an inaugural rural cyber-hui... About 100 representatives of Maori, social service, youth and cultural groups in Northland attended the one-day conference in Kaitaia. The cyber-hui is part of the Government's efforts to enable community access to information and communications technologies. (Sep 29, 2003,Dominion Post,C9)

Cyclone Bola¶

n.

These weather conditions occurred in 1968, creating the storm that led to the Wahine disaster, and 20 years later in March, 1988, when Cyclone Bola slammed into the North Island's east coast... (Nov 26, 2005,Dominion Post,E1)

In Gisborne two weeks ago the talk was all of Cyclone Bola in 1988, of 1000mm of rain in 36 hours, three people drowned, stock, bridges, roads, houses wiped out. (Dec 12, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

CYFS¶

(/sifs/) abbr. Child, Youth & Family Service [ORIGIN: acronym, Jim Cameron writes: The acronym CYPFS recorded in NZ slang may be obsolete with the creation in 1999 of the new Department of Child, Youth and Family Service. By analogy the pronunciation "SIPS" may become "SIFS" in popular usage.]

"She's been in CYFS care since she was 10. She's been expelled from two schools in their care. She's run away six times. Now she's run away again." (Jul 14, 2005,NZ Herald,A10)

For the child "living in pain, confusion, fear, terror, extreme danger" in the privacy of a family, CYFS is a "potential lifeline", says Brown. (Mar 17, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

cylinder¶

n. a maimai

CRADDOCK The principal [type of mai-mai for duck-shooting] is a circular galvanised iron tube 3ft high by 3ft diameter, open at both ends, and called locally [at Selwyn River] a `cylinder'. (1904,Sport in NZ,158)

CYPFA¶

abbr. Children, Young Persons & Their Families Service. As a replacement for Sips (Children & Young Persons Service)

cypress¶

n. (rare, obsolete) kahikatea

MARSDEN ... the quality of the timber is not considered good enough for masts, especially a species of the Cyprus (cypress) which composes the principal forests here and is called by the natives kikatea. (Jun 21, 1820,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,256,1932 ed.)

2 n. kawaka

HOOKER Cypress. Libocedrus Doniana. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),764)

HECTOR Libocedrus doniana, Endl. Kawaka, Cypress, Cedar. - This handsome tree attains a height of 60-100 feet, and a diameter of 3-5 feet. Wood reddish, fine-grained and heavy. Libocedrus Bidwillii, CEDAR (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,122)

Libocedrus Bidwillii native cypress (1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue) [NOTES: 1917 Duncan and Davies Descriptive Catalogue (And)]

(And) Libocedrus Bidwillii New Zealand cypress- (1916,Official Trade Register of Nurserymen)

COWAN Here the trees are totara, manuka, and a kind of cypress, or arbor vitae, no kareao; ... The akepiri ... is here abundant. (1916,Bush Explorers) [NOTES: 1916 Cowan Bush Explorers `More Reminiscences' (TS:VUW)]

cypress snail¶

n. a variety of NZ giant snail

Solid energy environmental manager Mark Pizey said the Cypress snails and juvenile kiwi would be in a 20ha area surrounded by an excluder fence... (Jul 13, 2005,NZ Herald,A13 ed.)

cypress-koromiko¶

n. Veronica cupressoides.

COCKAYNE (And) Veronica cupressoides cypress-koromiko (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

cypress koromiko n -es : a New Zealand shrub (Veronica cupressoides) with very slender much-forked branches, minute leaves, and tiny flowers (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,566)
